column2: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Administrative Office of the United States Courts estimated today that bankruptcy cases increased by more than 29 per cent in the last fiscal year and predicted the increase would be even greater in the year which began July 1.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Indians, trying for second place in the American League, ran into superb five-hit pitching by Jack Kramer today and dropped a 4-to-3 decision to the Browns in the teams' final clash of the season.

LUEBECK, Germany, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Jewish refugees from the Exodus 1947 ignored today a renewed offer of sanctuary in France and a simultaneous British warning that if they remain here they would have to live on reduced rations.

The last of the defendants in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle, Isidore Rapoport, 56 years old, pleaded guilty yesterday in Kings County Court to an indictment charging grand larceny and forgery on fifty counts.

The suggestion of financial relief for some of the city's ailing bus companies in the form of reduced franchise taxes received indirect lid yesterday from former Supreme Court Justice George Frankenthaler in an arbitration award covering two Queens bus lines.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- President Truman today named a special citizens committee to lead a campaign for conservation of food and to advise him on steps to aid in feeding Europe's hungry nations.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Began consideration of Balkan question and received United States draft resolution finding Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria guilty of supporting guerrillas in Greece, and setting up special committee to observe Balkan nations compliance.

WILLOW RUN, Mich., Sept. 25 -- A new Kaiser custom four-door sedan was introduced today by the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation as the 100,000th production unit was run off the assembly line. The mechanical features of the car are identical with other models in the Kaiser line, but a wide range of choice is presented not only in interior and exterior color combinations but also in built-in accessories, chrome trim, upholstery fabric, comfort and convenience requirements.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- John L. Lewis will win the overwhelming support of the American Federation of Labor convention in his opposition to signing the non-Communist affidavit required by the office of the general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, Robert N. Denham.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 20, 1947, totaled 931,072 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 8,712 cars, or 0.9 per cent more than for the preceding week, 32,020 cars, or 3.6 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 93,779 cars, or 11.2 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Young People's Astronomy and Parents' Refresher Course, a series of eight talks for both young and old, will be given Saturdays at 9:45 A.M. beginning Oct. 4 at the Hayden Planetarium. These talks will be especially adapted for boys and girls 8 to 14 years.

NAUGATUCK, Conn., Sept. 25 -- Retail and wholesale food distributors' representatives told a subcommittee of the Joint Congressional Commiteee on the economic report today that their experiences in the last five months shows that consumers are ready to cooperate with Government in any plan of distribution or consumption that will produce adequate supplies of food at prices which they can afford to pay.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- The Soviet Union offered today, at a meeting of the Security Council, to vote in favor of the admission of Italy to the United Nations, but only on condition that Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria and Finland be admitted simultaneously.

Ten thousand application forms for eviction certificates have been obtained from the City Rent Commission by landlords since the city rent laws caused a suspension of eviction proceedings in the Municipal Courts eight days ago, it was learned yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- Following conferences between West Coast representatives of the Maritime Commission and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Association, the commission in Washington has been requested to ask James Sinclair, president of the Luckenbach Steamship Company, what further steps might be taken to obtain release of ships tied up by the walking boss strike on this coast.

THOMPSONVILLE, Conn., Sept. 25 -- Bigelow Sanford Carpet Company will double its pre-war output of twelve-foot Wilton carpeting by Jan. 1, 1948, James DeCamp Wise, president, disclosed in an interview at the organization's plant here today.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 25 -- The hard-pressed chiefs of the Slovak Democratic party, whose destruction could give the Communists undisputed control of Czechoslovakia, today defied the demand of the so-called partisan organizations for a general investigation of the political past of all Slovak citizens.

There have been disquieting reports from India recently of government dissatisfaction with the stories of communal rioting that have been sent from there by foreign correspondents. Pandit Nehru has stated publicly his concern. What our Robert Trumbull calls "gentle pressure" is being exerted by the Information Ministry on foreign correspondents to present India in a "proper perspective."

A Congressional price-investigating subcommittee failed to find any evidence of profiteering in the New York metropolitan area, Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, the chairman, said last night at the close of four days of hearings.

Confirming officially reports that have been current for some time, Burlington Mills Corporation announced yesterday acquisition of certain assets of Duplex Fabrics Corporation, distributor of finished rayon fabrics to the dress trade.

VIENNA, Sept. 25 -- The United States accused the Soviet Union today of attempting to abandon the principle of the voluntary repatriation of displaced persons and refugees, which Moscow had "purported" to accept. The charge was made at a session of the Austrian Treaty Commission by United States Delegate David Ginsburg, who said:
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Independent Communications Workers of America today virtually declared war on the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 (US) -- Art Houtteman's seven-hit hurling and timely hitting by his mates today enabled the Tigers to down the Indians, 5 to 2, and assure themselves of at least a third-place finish in the American League standings.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Syracuse University football team made an unimpressive debut tonight, sqeezing out a 14-7 victory over an underdog University of Niagara eleven before 25,000 fans.

The Soviet proposal for the withdrawal early next year of both the Red Army and the United States Army from Korea comes two years too late. Had it been made in the fall of 1945 and based then on the completion of the military task that had been assigned the two forces -- disarmament and repatriation of the Japanese armed forces in Korea -- it would have been welcome.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 26 -- Arab and Jewish spokesmen professed nominal satisfaction with the declaration of Britain's desire to surrender the Palestine mandate, evacuate the country and give it independence. But both sides doubt Britain's sincerity.

Among Displaced Persons Incited by the Secretary General's plaint that the United Nations is in the situation of a repeatedly displaced person, our scout has been exploring the site on our East River which was hopefully provided by John D. Rockefeller Jr. to put an end to those displacements and give the new Parliament of Man and its Secretariat a permanent home where Mr. Lie can say, "J'y suis, j'y reste."
Belmont Park's Double Attraction -- Armed vs. Assault -- will be in sixth on a nine-event card today with no betting in the mutuels the mile-and-a-quarter duel for $100,000 purse and a gold cup.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The hapless Pirates were without a manager today -- and the only line of applicants for the job vacated by Billy Herman's resignation was formed from guesswork.

There are several games around the country that carry more double -edged significance, but the contest that has college football followers in this section all agog on the 1947 season's first day of general activity is Army's debut against Villanova at West Point.

FRANKLIN, Mich., Sept. 26 -- For the first time in the history of the women's national amateur golf championship, two clubmates reached the final round as Miss Louise Suggs and Miss Dorothy Kirby of the Capital City Club of Atlanta, Ga., won comparatively easy matches in the semi-final round of the forty-seventh championship at the Franklin Hills Country Club today.

Churches of the nation will emphasize religious education in programs to be conducted for a week starting tomorrow. The week has been proclaimed by President Truman, many Governors and Mayors as "Religious Education Week." This will be the seventeenth annual such observance.
The Yankees closed their season's book with the Red Sox at the Stadium yesterday, when Boston's 1946 American League champions beat the current pennant winners, 3 -- 2.

Out in California, Dr. Max Radin, Professor of Law at the University of California, has been, giving some thought to how the voters of his state reacted to referenda placed on the ballots in the period between 1936 and 1946. Writing in The California Law Review, he says that sixty-eight proposals were rejected by the people and forty-eight were approved.

An indictment returned Dec. 19, 1944, which charged that Carl L. Norden, Inc., its officers and others with having conspired to restrict the production of Norden bombsights, was dismissed yesterday by Federal Judge Stephen W. Brennan at the request of G. Osmond Hyde, Assistant United States Attorney General.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange failed yesterday to develop a trend and closed 10 points lower to 5 points higher than the day before. They opened 1 to 4 points down and established an equilibrium just under the previous closing levels.

If there is still time to ponder -- as the pace of Washington, Senator Taft's retrospective speech on foreign policy and the long wrangles on procedure at Lake Success suggest that there is -- four aspects of the crisis in Italy are worth pondering for the light they throw on what is happening in the world.

The will signed by Fiorello H. La Guardia, "also known as F. H. La Guardia," as he phrased it, on Feb. 2,. 1935, a year after he assumed the office of Mayor, was filed for probate in Bronx County Surrogate's Court yesterday.

If Andrei Y. Vishinsky were not an official representative of the Soviet Government it would not be necessary to reply to his second outburst of whirling words at Lake Success yesterday. But he made one statement that cannot be passed over as the familiar rhetoric of a Vishinsky polemic.
PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Seventy-six Vichy regime collaborationists escaped from the Carrere prison camp near Toulouse early today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 26 -- The following is the text of the policy speech delivered to the United Nations Assembly's Extraordinary Committee on Palestine today by Colonial Secretary Arthur CreechJones of Britain: It will be for the convenience of this committee if I, on behalf of His Majesty's Government in the United Kingdom, make a statement at the beginning of our deliberations.

SHEFFIELD, England, Sept. 26 -- Sheffield's famous cutlery trade is doing well, but its great traditions of craftsmanship are gradually dying out. The machine age is leaving less and less work for the man whose skill even today puts the highest grade of British cutlery in a distinctive class.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Citizens Food Committee, just appointed by President Truman to help see Europe through its new famine crisis, will set up headquarters in the office of John R. Steelman, Economic Adviser to the President, in the East Wing of the White House, it was learned on good authority today.

A.S. Barnes will bring out on Oct. 4 a story of the Washington Redskins football team by Corinne Griffith Marshall, the former silent screen star and wife of the owner of the team. Entitled "My Life With the Redskins," the book covers ten years of football games by that team.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- Results achieved from large wartime expenditures on research show that the pre-war research level was too low not only in radio but in other fields as well, a West Coast convention of the Institute of Radio Engineers was told tonight by Dr. Frederick E. Terman, dean of the Stanford School of Engineering.

Interstate Power Securities distributors are astonisned at the action of the Securities and Exchange Commission in disapproving on Thursday the sale of Interstate Power Company's common stock at a competitive sale price which, under an SEC-and-court-approved recapitalization plan, would have yielded to certain holders of old securities a return deemed by the commission to be inequitably low.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today industrial production turned up during August after four successive months of decline.
Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Oct. 14 on $3,000,000 of water and sewer bonds dated Oct. 1, 1947, and due Oct. 1 from 1948 to 1987.

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 26 -- Chester Bowles, former econemic stabilizer and OPA chief, blamed the country's price problems on "irresponsibility, ignorance and outright greed" when he appeared before a Congressional subcommittee here today.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- With an explosive second-half drive that netted three touchdowns, Boston College surged back from the brink of disaster to defeat Clemson, 32 to 22, before a chilled crowd of 30,000 at Braves Field in its football opener tonight.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 26 -- Champion Tilwall Tiger Lad, owned by Joseph F. Delany of Malverne, L. I., won in the smooth variety and Mr. and Mrs. Howard McGuire's Aman Tradition of McWire among the wires in the eighty-second specialty of the American Fox Terrier Club on the Garden City Hotel grounds today.

GAMBIER, Ohio, Sept. 26 -- The duty of the United States is to become so powerful a nation in a spirit of liberty as to compel the Soviet Union to abandon its contumacious attitude in favor of a democratic form of government. This was stated today by Prof. Herman Finer of the University of Chicago at the opening session of the conference at Kenyon College on the heritage of the Englishspeaking peoples and their responsibility.

NOT content with investigating the Army in the Mediterranean Theatre of Operations, Robert C. Ruark has been looking into the gaudier variety of historical novels. His attitude seems to have been, "How long has this been going on ?" Facing even vaster forces than the Army, Mr. Ruark has proceeded to write "Grenadine Etching, Her Life and Loves,"* the latest historical novel to end all historical novels.
A mystery developed yesterday in connection with the Freedom Train, which ended its two-day stay in Manhattan. Officials were puzzled at the slow pace at which New Yorkers inoved through the train.

LONDON, Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- British fashion designers unveiled today their secret weapon in the battle of the hemline -- the "spiral silhouette," which shows its wearer's legs yet gives the impression of length.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 3,500 head: total. 5.500. General market slow and steady to strong; strength on weights, 170 to 210 pounds: top on hogs, however, 25 cents lower at $28.25; sows steady to strong:

A play dealing with the Reconstruction period in the South after the Civil War will be presented tonight at the Royale Theatre by Eddie Dowling and Louis J. Singer, the team responsible for the production of "The Glass Menagerie." Entitled "Our Lan' " and written by Theodore Ward, the work was tried out last April by the Associated Playwrights at the Henry Street Playhouse.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 -- In a surprise departure from policy, the Baltimore Typographical Union, offered today to make a written contract with employing printers if an agreement could be reached.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Sept. 26 -- Although the United States and the Soviet Union are manifestly engaged in a "cold war," a more open conflict is not inevitable if both nations can overcome their inability to understand each other, Professor Joseph E. Johnson, former chief of the State Department International Security Division, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Administration officials gave up today their search for means of financing stop-gap aid to Europe without calling a special session of Congress, it' was learned. The risk of violating Congressional intent has stymied official efforts to arrange for relief shipments through the Export-Import Bank and the Commodity Credit Corporation, it was understood.

aWASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Under a new policy the United States is admitting correspondents for foreign Communist journals to this country for the sole purpose of reporting activities of the United Nations. Immigration laws and Justice Department rulings bar Communists -- aside from officials and diplomats -- from unrestricted entry.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- The United Nations was vigorously prodded today by several members of the headquarters committee of its General Assembly, and by Robert Moses, New York City's construction coordinator, to raise $65,000,000 at once to prevent any long delay in constructing the future world capital.

Addition of fluorine to the water supply of Newburgh, N.Y., in an experiment conducted by the State Department of Health, has resulted in a marked decrease in the susceptibility of that city's children to tooth decay.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 -- Prices of grains were on the upgrade today on the Board of Trade, and at one time wheat was 6 3/4 cents a bushel higher than yesterday and corn up 4 1/2 cents. However, profit-taking developed following a report by the Department of Agriculture indicating that 70 per cent of the corn crop was safe from frost damage and closing prices were below the best.

WASHINGTON, Sept, 26 -- The prosecution for perjury and illegally contriving an entry into this country of Johannes (Hanns) Eisler, an admitted former German Communist and an accused holder of high place in world communism, was recommended today by the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities.

Store Sales Jump 40% Department store sales for Manhattan and Brooklyn this week were estimated yesterday at 40 per cent over the corresponding week a year ago. The high percentage gain was attributed to stimulated business this week while a year ago volume fell off heavily because of truck and delivery stoppages, hot weather and the holiday period.

Serge M. Rubinstein, Russianborn international financier, who is in the Lewisburg (Pa.) Federal penitentiary under a draft-dodging conviction, will not have to accept the service of legal papers in his wife's suit for separation and temporary alimony.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 26 -- Under the cover of Soviet participation in the Joint United States-Soviet Commission discussions the Russians have been operating a tightly knit espionage and spy ring here, highly reliable sources said today.

The American Television Society announces that its annual awards have been won by the following: John R. Poppele, president of the Television Broadcasters Association, for his work in solving many problems confronting the video industry during the last year, including the matter of apartment house aerials for television sets.

NANKING, Sept. 26 --The State Council adopted today a resolution calling for a thirty-day postponement in China's first national elections. The vote for delegates to the National Assembly, which is scheduled to meet Dec. 25 to implement the new Constitution, has been put off from Oct. 21 to Nov. 21.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said today it had licensed the TransArabian Pipe Line Company to ship 20,000 tons of steel to Saudi Arabia between October and December for oil pipeline construction.

GAZA, Palestine, Sept. 26 -- Exploratory drilling for oil has started near Gaza in the northwestern tip of the Negeb, disputed southern part of Palestine, which the majority of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine proposed to include in a Jewish state.

A fine of $2,500 was imposed on the Twentieth Century Sporting Club by the New York State Athletic Commission in session yesterday. The board's action was announced by Chairman Eddie Eagan, who sat with his fellow commissioners Leon Swears and Dr. C.B. Powell.

A small army of electricians and carpenters invaded City Hall yesterday and began the job of making "glamorous" the ancient structure, inside and out, for the big fashion show to be held there Monday night, when 100 professional models will display the latest in women's styles.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 26 -- City Commissioner Meyer C. Ellenstein, who is opposed to the Port of New York Authority's plan to lease the local airport, toaay challenged the accuracy of claims by Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port Authority, that "nearly all the Authority's major installations are exceeding revenue forecasts."

The New York University School of Law held a special celebration dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night in connection with the publication of plans for the projected N.Y.U. Law Center on Washington Square, Officials of the university, however, still refused to name the exact location of the center despite the protests of residents living in the Washington Square area.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- The United States made public today its formal resolution for a committee of the United Nations General Assembly to meet the year round and give the "international congress" greater voice in cases involving world peace and security.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Sept. 26 -- Registration statements covering $1,200,000 of debentures, 374,989 shares of preferred stock and 1,230,000 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by four companies.
The Navy sounded the death knell for two famous old warships yesterday with the announcement that it was prepared to accept offers for the scrapping of the battleships Idaho and Wyoming.

Svend O. Sandgren, 51-year-old public school custodian, whose six white bull terriers chewed and mangled to death 11-year-old Stanley Balaban of the Bronx on July 1, was indicted on a charge of manslaughter in the second degree yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Lutheran World Relief, Inc., agency of the churches of that communion in distributing aid to war lands, has shipped five and a third million pounds of supplies to a dozen European and Asiatic countries since its founding twenty-one months ago.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- Mohandas K. Gandhi, foremost proponent of non-violence, said today that Hindu India might "have to go to war" against Pakistan if the Moslem, dominion failed to see its "proved error" in the treatment of Hindus and Sikhs.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 -- Department store executives disclaimed responsibility today for high prices and testified that their profits on a dollar of sales after Federal taxes were noticeably lower the first six months of this year than they were in the corresponding period of 1946.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26 -- Pending a last minute intervention by President Juan D. Peron, a full-scale strike of the Buenos Aires port workers is scheduled to being at seven tomorrow morning. Wages are the primary issue, but the union issued a statement reminding the present Federal Intervenor, Admiral Walter Von Rentzell, that port problems could be solved better by "prudence and intelligence than by the machete."
DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 26 -- The threat of a general strike of Danbury's 130 public school teachers loomed tonight in a pay dispute between the teachers and the Board of Education.

St. Louis, Sept. 26 -- A group of Catholics opposing the admission of Negroes to Catholic schools here made several unsuccessful efforts to confer with Archbishop .Joseph E. Ritter or ids qualified representative prior to the Archbishop's pastoral letter warning of excommunication if they proceeded with their opposition.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: My attention has recently been called to Maj. Gen. Lunsford E. Oliver's address to war veterans in Chicago, as reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 29. His speech contained a most shocking statement regarding the massacre of Armenians by the Turks after the First World War.
A loyalty check of 31,000 postoffice employes in Manhattan and the Bronx was begun yesterday.
Harry M. Gross Jr. has been named executive secretary to E. Allan Williford, vice president of General Aniline and Film Corporation in charge of the Ansco division.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Swayne P. Goodfenough of Rochester, N.Y., president of the Financial Advertisers Association, said today banks by their advertising encourage the public to go into debt.

BOSTON, Mass., Sept. 26 -- The convention of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers, CIO, charged today that the foreign policies of the Truman administration were controlled by "Wall Street" and were designed to "suppress and exploit the people of the world."

Under our immigration law the State Department has made a valid and workable distinction between United Nations and United States in laying down restrictions on the movements and activities of Pierre Courtade, chief writer on foreign affairs for the Paris Communist newspaper L'Humanite.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- A call to business men to end a growing rift between Government and business was made here today by Simon Loeb, president, at the fourteenth annual convention of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants.

MADRID, Sept. 26 -- Spanish Anarchist elements launched a new and violent manifesto today demanding that disorder be created so that the United Nations would be forced to consider Spain as an urgent problem.

ROME, Sept. 26 -- The Left-Wing Socialist leader, Pietro Nenni, and the Italian Communist leader, Palmiro Togliatti, opened fire today in the Leftists' battle in the Constituent Assembly to overthrow the government of Premier Alcide de Gasperi.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Britain could probably have flown an "automatic flight" airplane across the Atlantic ten years ago "if there had been the need," R.F. Wagstaff, aeronautical expert, told a press conference today.

MUNICH, Germany, Sept. 25 (Delayed) -- Under a proposed law unanimously approved this afternoon by a committee representing all four political parties chartered in Bavaria, no German citizen can be forced into military service or into the acceptance of "war duties" in the event of another international conflict.

GEARHART, Ore., Sept. 26 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio reversed himself tonight when he declared the Republican-controlled Congress would and should act at the next session on a broad program of social legislation that eventually might cost $1,000,000,000 a year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Following is the text of a United States draft resolution on the establishment of an interim committee of the General Assembly, as presented to the Assembly's Political and Security Committee liere today:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Pressing the Soviet attack against "warmongers" in the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly here today, Valerian. A. Zorin of the Russian delegation called for world-wide punishment of owners of newspapers that print libelous material about other countries.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- At one stage, New York University held a 7-6 lead over Temple as both teams launched the football season under the lights before 18,000 spectators at Temple Stadium tonight. The Violets rallied early in the second period to gain their 1-point edge, but the Owls rebounded five minutes later and romped to a 32-7 victory.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 26 -- Virtually every major handbook operator in Fairfield County was out of business today as the result of a series of raids by State Troopers and local policemen.

CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Cleveland Browns remained the only team in the undefeated column in the All-America Footbal Conference tonight by trouncing the Chicago Rockets, 41 to 21, before a crowd of 23,067.

Asked for a comment last night, Walter Winchell replied that the war that Andrei Y. Vishinsky thought was coming on might be avoided if newspaper men were permitted to get all the facts in the situation and tell them to the Russians as well as the rest of the world.

Supporters of Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, won a clear-cut victory yesterday afternoon at the union's sixth biennial convention in Manhattan Center by electing eleven candidates to the important fifteen-man resolutions committee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, today resigned from the President's Air Policy Commission because of the pressure of private affairs. His resignation and its acceptance were announced by the White House.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Philadelphia and Washington split a twilight-night double-header tonight, the Athletics capturing the opener, 11 -- 8, and the Senators taking the second game, 4 -- 3.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Accusing the Labor Government of "failure to prepare for or to meet the economic crisis," the British Conservative party will call next week for a new Parliament as the Only means of national recovery. Anthony Eden will lead the debate on economic crisis at the opening of the party's annual conference to be held in Brighton, and Winston Churchill will adress a mass meeting afterward, it was announced today.

WHITES PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- More ammunition for Westchester County in its fight against "discrimination" in the state's distribution of funds for education was filed today with the Board of Supervisors here by State Senator Pliny W. Williamson of Scarsdale.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 26 (U.P.) -- The Palestine Arab Higher Committee called on the 1,200,000 Arabs in Palestine to join in mass demonstrations Oct. 3 in protest against recommendations of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine for the partition of Palestine into Arab and Jewish states.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Tourelay, owned by Helen Hickman, closed fast on the outside to win the Ogontz Purse, a six-furlong dash for claimers of the $15,000-$12,000 variety, at Garden State Park today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Gael Sullivan, executive director of the Democratic National Committee, today challenged Senator Robert A. Taft "to answer my question as to whether or not he has stopped blackmailing the American voter on social legislation."
Stages of children's growth at ages 6, 7 and 8 years are newly analyzed as clues to learning by the New York State Council for Early Childhood Education.

The stock market operated yesterday within the trading range of the week, with an irregular price drift which left quotations slightly on the lower side at the close. The list again scraped the low levels of the prevailing movement, with major alterations confined mainly to the oils and the combined averages off 0.05 point on the day.

VIENNA, Sept. 26 -- A proposal that Austria should not be allowed to import arms or munitions to equip the 58,000 soldiers provided in the Austrian draft treaty but should be required to manufacture them herself was made by the Soviet delegation at today's meeting of the Austrian Treaty Commission.

American housewives never think of making soups with ingredients like lotus seeds, lily roots and chestnuts. But would they and their families enjoy the flavor if somebody else prepared them ? The Mandarin Food Products thought so, and since last October has been canning six such soups according to authentic Oriental recipes in one-and-three-quarter pound tins for home consumption.

Federal Judge Clarence G. Galston in the United States District Court, Brooklyn, voided yesterday a Navy general court-martial verdict finding Harold E. Hirshberg guilty of mistreating fellow prisoners of war during their imprisonment by the Japanese.

Six major United States industrial concerns, including the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, are negotiating with Egyptian business interests for the establishment of branches or factories in Egypt, Mustafa Maher Bey, director general of the Egyptian Department of Industry and Commerce, disclosed yesterday.

To meet the increased demand for better quality fabrics in face of a shortage of fine combing wools, manufacturers of woolens and worsteds will introduce many new types of cloths in 1948, it was learned in the trade yesterday.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 26 --The conspiracy case against thirty-nine high-ranking army officers headed by Gen. Kiril Stanchev, commander in chief of the Bulgarian Second Army that fought against the Germans, was deposited in district court by the Sofia General Prosecutor today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The New York State Public Service Commission opposed before the Federal Power Commission today the application of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation for a permanent certificate to pipe natural gas into the Philadelphia area.

Reporting on operations of the Timken-Detroit Axle Company and its subsidiaries for the fiscal year ended with June, Willard F. Rockwell, chairman, informed shareholders yesterday that sales of $89,466,972 were the highest for any peacetime year in its history.

Harry Martin, amusements editor of The Memphis Commercial Appeal, was elected president of the American 'Newspaper Guild, CIO, on the basis of unofficial but nearly complete results announced here yesterday

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Long conferences here today between Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, and officials of the Midwest grain trade resulted in a report by Mr. Anderson that the trade had no intention of raising margins.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Six newly appointed officials in the unified National Military Establishment took their oaths of office today. Coincidentally, the now independent Air Force announced the setting-up of an Atomic Energy Division, with Maj. Gen. William E. Kepner in charge of atomic propulsion of aircraft as its principal objective.
Division, whose battle memories reach from the Mexican border to the Hindenburg Line and to Island-taking in the Central Pacific, are meeting here in their first post-war reunion.
A memorial program for Fiorello H. La Guardia was held yesterday morning in the auditorium of the High School of Music and Art, Convent Avenue and 135th Street.

The New York Board of Trade said yesterday it would start an investigation Monday to determine the effects of the week-old Railway Express Agency strike and "why people are not complying with the law."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 -- George Munger says "thanks" to one and all for kind words that have been written about the Pennsylvania team, but the kindness is killing him. If it's just the same to them, he'd appreciate it if Penn's friends would desist from being so nice and become a little more realistic.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Britain's withdrawal from Palestine would not imply her withdrawal from the Middle East, a Foreign Office spokesman said tonight.

BILOXI, Miss., Sept. 26 -- The National Association of Secretaries of State adopted a resolution today commending the Governors of the states on their recent decision to unite in sponsoring Congressional legislation acknowledging state ownership of tidelands and all soil, minerals and oil under their navigable inland waters.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, today renewed his attack on American "warmongers" and declared that anyone who attempted to break up the principle of unanimity among the great powers -- the veto -- would make cooperation among them "impossible."

Puccini's "La Boheme" was presented by the New York City Opera Company, last night at City Center, as the second offering of its new season. There were two changes necessitated in the cast. Luigi Infantino appeared as Rudolfo, replacing Eugene Conley, who was indisposed, and Norman Young assumed the role of Marcello, because Enzo Mascherini had not arrived as yet from South America.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- The British Government announced today that it must lay own its mandate over Palestine. In the absence of a settlement of the Palestine question, Britain plans an early withdrawal of British forces and of the British administration.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- Plans to suspend completely all water transportation activities in the Los Angeles and Long Beach harbors, beginning at midnight next Tuesday, were announced tonight by the Waterfront Employers Association of California, Southern California District.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., Sept. 26 -- Mr. and Mrs. W. Plunket Stewart of Unionville, Pa., won permanent possession today of the second Foxhunters Trophy for the best bona fide hunter at the forty-sixth annual Bryn Mawr horse show. They retired the first trophy in 1939.

A test of the constitutionality of the city's new rent control laws was initiated yesterday by Harry Klein and Simon Rappaport, realty firm officials who on Thursday were sentenced to serve five-day workhouse terms and to pay fines totaling $500 on convictions of violating the laws in two eviction cases.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- Yugoslavia's delegation to the United Nations warned today that there was a "smell of the dynamite of the new world war" in the United States draft resolution charging the Belgrade Government, Bulgaria and Albania with aggression in the Balkans.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- The Soviet Union today agreed with the British suggestion of yesterday that the United Nations 1948 budget should be reduced by $9,000,000 to $30,000,000. Russia stipulated, however, that the working capital fund of the peace organization should be halved to $10,000,000 next year.

Mayor O'Dwyer appealed yesterday to all New Yorkers to contribute to the united fund-raising campaign of the Y.W.C.A.'s of Manhattan, Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. At a City Hall ceremony in which he received the first official campaign poster, the Mayor urged generous support of the campaign to raise $445,000 which will open on Oct. 7.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 26 -- Paced by Arthur F. Lynch, Jarvis S. Hicks Jr. and Perry E. Hall, who accounted for clean sweeps of three points, New York's ten-man team easily carried off top honors in the 43-year-old Lesley Cup competition today.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 26 -- The Soviet delegation to the Joint United States-Soviet Commission dropped a bombshell into the tangled negotiations today by proposing simultaneous withdrawal of United States and Soviet troops from Korea by the beginning of 1948.

ALBANY, Sept. 26 -- Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the State Public Service Commission, announced today that the commission had denied a petition by the Pullman Company to increase rates for Pullman accommodations in New York State by the same amount as ordered on interstate traffic by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 26 (AP) -- The daughter of a pioneer automobile manufacturer, her husband, a retired naval commander who served in two wars, and a private detective have been indicted here on charges, respectively, of buying and selling narcotic drugs.

Furniture factories are tightening wholesale credit terms for small dealers because they look for unsound financial developments after Regulation W expires on Nov. 1, several representatives of leading producers reported yesterday.

The refusal by union officials to comply with the affidavit requirements of the Taft-Hartley Act has worked to the disadvantage of employers seeking to clarify the representation status of their employes and has deprived them of rights they had under the old Wagner Act.
ALBANY, Sept. 26 -- A drive to replace the controversial 1947 permissive local-tax law with a statecollected 2 per cent sales tax ran into strong opposition today from the state administration.

Veterans are going to share in another "bonus," in the form of National Service Life Insurance surplus, Harold W. Breining, assistant administrator for insurance of the Veterans Administration, announced last week. The surplus to be distributed is estimated at $1,000,000,000 to $2,000,000,000.

TOKYO, Sept. 26 -- If the Japanese Government, under the terms of the controversial bill now before the Diet takes over control of the nation's coal mines it will be expected to guarantee a production of 50,000,000 tons a year -- 20,000,000 more than the production planned for this year -- the Supreme Allied Command has informed Premier Tetsu Katayama.

For the first time in more than twenty years, a major industrywide program of management and engineering advancement is being undertaken by organized groups in the cast iron foundry industry, spokesmen revealed here yesterday. Plans based upon final results of national gray iron production surveys recently completed are being brought into action immediately, they disclosed, with the aim of stabilizing upward production and profit trends and meeting recession problems before they occur.

Fake trade-in allowances which blighted the radio receiver industry before the war are appearing again in radio merchandising, according to the National Better Business Bureau, Inc., yesterday. Seeking to forestall the development of false trade-ins into an accepted trade practice, the bureau has sought the cooperation of all radio manufacturers in eliminating trade-in allowances.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 26 -- More than $500,000 of Palestinian currency was snatched from a police armored car in Tel Aviv today by a band of Zionist terrorists, who also killed four British constables in the hold-up. The band later abandoned two-thirds of its booty, which was recovered.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- It will be fourth place for the Giants in that final standing of the National League. That was certified today when Lefty Warren Spahn shut out New York, 2 to 0, for his seventh whitewashing job and his twentyfirst triumph in the Giants' final appearance of the season at Braves Field.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 26 -- The United States is confronting the Russian question "hysterically" and if historical precedents are repeated the American policy means war, Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of New York told delegates from all over the world attending the Ecumenical Methodist Conference here tonight.

Henry Morgenthau Jr. planned to resign as Secretary of the Treasury when President Roosevelt decided to revive his "pump priming" program after the 1937 stock market crash, because he felt the program ended the chance for a balanced budget and committed the nation to an "unsound policy."

Coimng at the close of a campaign spiced with innumerable upsets, the forthcoming world series clash between the Yankees and Dodgers should provide a fitting climax. It does promise to be a series in which anything can happen and probably will.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, in considering reasons for the delay in fulfilment of the modernization program, for the city's school system, placed emphasis yesterday on the lack of available finances and called for the help of community forces in solving the problem.
CHICAGO, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Encouraged by the hitting and pitching of Al Brazle, the Cardinals stopped the Cubs, 5 to 3, today in the first of a three-game series.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- Fifty-six fighting ships, with 22,000 officers and men aboard, steamed through the Golden Gate today. The gleaming vessels gave to the Bay Cities their greatest concentration of naval power since the war.

Mrs. Johanna Lindlof, president of the Kindergarten-6B Association, yesterday brought that organization into the current fight by teachers' organizations against superior merit rating sections of the Feinberg teachers salary law. She said that the Board of Education is permitted under the act to retain its present manner of rating teachers for automatic increases.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- The prospect of prolonged disfranchisement today faced some 1,100 GI college students who live here with their wives and children in converted Army barracks. They have organized to stave it off and seek the help of Gen. Dwight D. Elsenhower, their wartime commander

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am just back from a visit to six European countries. I am returning greatly depressed and alarmed. I am as much alarmed by the situation here at home as by the situation in Europe.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 26 -- Tyrone Power, film star, now on a vacation in South Africa, visited Pretoria today and was received by Premier Jan Christiaan Smuts in his office. Crowds of women assembled at many points to cheer him.

An expanded building program designed to provide new community centers for National Jewish Welfare Board activities was outlined yesterday at the opening of a three-day conference of its Jewish center division committee at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A two-day conference between representatives of the American Newspaper Publishers Association and the International Typographical Union (AFL to "resolve existing differences" between them ended tonight in a stalemate.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Lifting a total of 661 pounds in three international lifts, Joe de Pietro of Paterson, N.J., tonight won the world's bantamweight weight-lifting championship before a crowd of 4,000 in Convention Hall.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 26 -- Dorothy Lamour has been signed by Columbia to star in an untitled musical film after completion of "Lulu Belle," another musical comedy, in which she is appearing for Benedict Bogeaus, Who is producing the film independently for Columbia release.

Grain prices started a new advance yesterday in the nation's primary markets. In their wake, wholesale prices gained a little, abruptly halting the recent decline, and retail food prices, except for butter, held steady close to the levels that had evoked widespread consumer dissatisfaction and resistance.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Classing himself as one of the volunteers for the National Community Chest Drive of next month, President Truman called on the American people tonight to keep alive the tradition of neighborliness implicit in it.
Robert Irwin, for seventeen years with Matthew G. Ely and later renting manager of 55 Liberty Street, has opened his own realty office at 52 William Street to handle sales, leases and mortgages.

The idol-worshipers of Flatbush had their day yesterday -- nearly a half million of them -- when they gave a blazing welcome to those flaming heroes, the Beloved Bums, who are known in calmer sections of the country as the Brooklyn Dodgers.

Attacking Congress for enacting the Taft-Hartley Labor Law, for removing price controls, for pigeonholing the bill for construction of low-rent housing and for adopting an economy program which crippled vital services of the Federal Government, Newbold Morris, former Republican President of the City Council, called last night for a political realignment in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26. -- An air-conditioning system akin to Thomas Jefferson's plan for the ventilation of Monticello, but adding and utilizing modern devices, was patented this week by Malcolm E. Haines of Xenia, Ohio.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 26 -- The American Bar Association ended its seventieth annual convention today with the election of Tappan Gregory of Chicago as president.

Edward R. Stettinius Jr., former Secretary of State of the United States, and Gabriel L. Dennis, Secretary of State of Liberia, announced plans yesterday for a "pioneer experiment" to develop the natural resources of the Negro republic with private American capital and business know-how.

Complaints alleging violation of the provisions against, secondary boycotts in the Taft-Hartley Act have been filed against two American Federation of Labor unions as the result of a five-day strike at the port of Albany, it was disclosed here yesterday.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- In debate on Balkan question, heard Dr. Ales Bebler of Yugoslavia charge report of Balkan investigating commission was not "trustworthy."

As a measure of protection for motorists, a resolution, urging a sixty-five-foot clearance by airplanes over roadways bordering or leading into airports was adopted yesterday at the closing session of the American Association of State Highway Officials at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

Sharp reduction in leather tanning activities throughout Latin America is attracting considerable attention in the leather and shoe industries here. Reports reaching the local trade have indicated a substantial reduction under the wartime peaks in tanning in these countries.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, urged Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan today to release Floyd Bennett Field to the City of New York.

Sharp reduction in leather tanning activities throughout Latin America is attracting considerable attention in the leather and shoe industries here. Reports reaching the local trade have indicated a substantial reduction under the wartime peaks in tanning in these countries.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat, of New York, urged Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan today to release Floyd Bennett Field to the City of New York.
LONDON, Sept. 26. -- Under the lead of good dividends, together with large buying orders, the stock markets here today continued cheerful.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 26 -- For its failure to submit a trusteeship agreement on SouthWest Africa in accordance with last year's United Nations General Assembly resolution, the Union of South Africa was again condemned today as nine more nations, including the Soviet Union, took the floor in the Assembly's Trusteeship Committee.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26 -- President Juan Peron began this week an unusual series of conferences with bankers, businessmen and industrialists. He hinted that a new phase of the economics of his revolution was at hand, in which a gradual withdrawal of government controls would usher in a new era of increased freedom for private enterprise.

Blond October comes striding over the hills wearing a crimson shirt and faded green trousers. His morning breath is the mist in the valleys, and at evening there are stars in his eyes, a waxing moon over his shoulder, and the cool whisper of valley breeze in his voice.

WITH his "End of a Berlin Diary" visiting the front pages of book reviews and in residence at the bookstores. William C. Shirer is catching his breath by writing a play -- a play, he told a visitor from this bureau the other day.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Two days before he is to meet with those leaders of Congress who accepted his invitation to discuss "world problems," the President's mind is still open with respect to an extra session of Congress.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 -- If the Marshall Plan means anything to the so-called average citizen in this area it is that the Secretary of State has a plan for feeding Europe. Beyond this, few realize the full import of the idea.

THERE'S a note from the Coast this morning with both a contemporary twist and one that should stir the memories of Broadway's old-timers. Tecumseh, himself, overcome with nostalgia, calls it a voice from the past.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Vern Stephens' tenth-inning single with the bases loaded gave the St. Louis Browns a 3-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox in the second game of a double-header today after the Browns had lost the opener, 2 -- 1.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The newly-won freedoms of employers to obtain employe representation polls have been impeded by the non-compliance of most unions with the non-Communist affidavit requirement, officials of the National Labor Relations Board said today.

TO THE EDITOR: Miss Caldwell has returned from her "sentimental journey to England" with some remarkably brutal information which surprises me as a Britisher and would, I imagine, equally surprise the majority of my fellow-countrymen.

Gunvor Mjelva, Norwegian soprano, gave her first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Widely known abroad by appearances in Scandanavia, Central Europe and England, Miss Mjelva has not only sung extensively in Lieder programs, but also been heard in oratorio, opera and as orchestral soloist since her debut in 1932.

AS the literary revival of the Nineteen Twenties moved east, it came to represent almost every section of the country. But Chicago was the center of the earlier movement, the literary capital of the United States, as Mencken had called it, the Cliff City of Dreiser, Sandburg, Masters, Sherwood Anderson and Henry Fuller.

DIGGING this year's peanut crop is under way down South. It promises to be one of the richest Harvests in the history of the Arachis hypogaea. Quadrupled in value during the war, the peanut last year yielded a harvest amounting to more than two billion pounds valued at $300,000,000 and today ranks tenth among all crops of the nation.

The public's attention during the past few days may have been more keenly attracted by the hot words uttered at Lake Success than by the remarkable document from Paris which this newspaper was privileged to publish on Wednesday. Everyone is fascinated by a fight, and Mr. Vishinsky, in his addresses to the United Nations Assembly and in his press conference on Friday, fought with no blows ruled out and no holds barred.

THE advent of color film for processing by the user has brought a number of concerns into the growing field of manufacturing stainless steel darkroom equipment, especially suitable for color. The equipment is also in demand for black-and-white photography where its more general use, however, is at present rather limited, particularly among amateurs, because of the comparatively high cost.

ONE measure of Shakespeare's durability is the way his works somehow withstand the things his theatrical heirs do with them. His plays have been trimmed, cut and otherwise rendered without tears; they have been adapted to modern dress and psychological dogma, and, in one case only a few months ago at Stratford itself, spiced with sex.

ONE of two methers heard comparing notes said that she had had a perfectly lovely time that morning. She went to the dentist, while a neighbor looked after her child, and, "It was such a relief to get away from home."

The convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, now being held at the Manhattan Center, voted 360 to 336 on a roll call yesterday afternoon to reject a minority report by the credentials committee that barred the seating of two delegates from Cleveland.

Housing progress and building trends will be among the chief topics of industrial leaders and Government officials at the annual meeting of the Producers Council, national organization of building products manufacturers, on Thursday and Friday in the Commodore Hotel.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 27 (AP) -- An Indiana team that overcame the big weigh advantage of Nebraska's line by speed and agility whipped the Cornhuskers today, 17 to 0, before a crowd of 32,000 watching the last of the current twelve-game series between the Big Nine and Big Six rivals.
ATLANTA, Sept. 7 (AP) Bob Neyland, the "old Gray Fox" from Tennessee, got a football lesson today from a former pupil as Georgia Tech swept to a surprisingly easy 27-0 victory over the Vols.

HOLLYWOOD. PERSONS who are intrigued by Hollywood methods may find additional entertainment in the logic which has been exercised on a competent newcomer named Howard da Silva. Mr. da Silva is a big man with a deep, pent-up affection for the stage and acting, or anything connected with it.

LITCHFIELD, Conn. -- This small New England village, which has somehow managed to preserve the unique combination of natural and architectural beauty for which it was famous in Colonial days, will be host on Oct. 11 to about 1,000 members of the Antiquarian and Landmarks Society of Connecticut.

NOTHING is more distasteful to the "modern" mind than the idea of miracles. The universe is supposed to be like a well-made clock, and should behave accordingly. A steady process of "explaining away" the unexplainable has been going on for over a century: we are offered as the "core" of Christianity the moral teachings of Jesus -- and the miracles are tossed aside as legendary accretions to the simple story of His life.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 27 -- The length of the hemline and the home runs of baseball's major leaguers have been taking precedence over all other thoughts, national or international, in this steel capital.
TROY, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- The favored Coast Guard Academy managed to earn a hard-pressed 19-to-19 deadlock with the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute football team today.

WHAT is the essential ingredient of a modern house? Not a flat roof, nor a window wall, nor an open plan -- as any modern architect will tell you. Not an outdoor living room nor an indoor builtin garden, as any landscape designer will likewise admit.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 27 -- Dairen, once the principal commercial port on the Yellow Sea handling 15,000,000 tons of cargo a year is today an isolated, deteriorating city, according to United States Consul General M.H. Benninghoff, who arrived here two days ago from that city.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- The Headquarters Committee of the United Nations General Assembly bogged down today for the second successive day in a vexatious debate over financing of the $65,000,000 world capital in midtown Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- It is a long time until November, 1948, but that fact does not prevent the professional politicians from trying even now to estimate the circumstances which will influence the voters of the United States when they step into their polling booths on the Tuesday following the first Monday of that month.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Army's invincibility on the football field carried into a fourth successive year today as the West Pointers opened their fifty-seventh season with a 13-0 victory over Villanova.

THE difficulties encountered by young Harold Wick, a rich Englishman's grandson, in his attempt to pass through the needle's eye into the secular kingdom of marital and social self-adjustment provide Timothy Pember, a 37-year-old British writer whose work is new to this country, with the substance for a novel of considerable depth and importance.
WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 27 -- The three duos that tied for medal honors yesterday were eliminated today as match play in the annual Meadow Brook invitation best-ball golf tournament got under way.

OMAHA, Sept. 27 -- Nebraska's farm income should pass the billion-dollar mark this year for the first time. Wheat-wealthy Kansas expects to book a dollar value of $1.8 billion in land production -- crops, livestock and minerals. Kansas' happy condition has been described as "a Klondyke, a Cripple Creek strike and a California gold rush."

James Madison upset Boys High, co-holder of the Brooklyn title in 1946 with Brooklyn Tech. 13 -- 0, in the inaugural football game of the season at Boys High Field yesterday before 5,000 spectators. The Golden Tornado did all of its scoring in the first half.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The President's Committee on Foreign Aid declared in a special interim report given out by the White House today that the United States during the crop year 1947-48 "clearly" could export 500,000,000 bushels of wheat without imposing "grave hardship on the American people as a whole, if its effects be measured in physical terms."

CLEVELAND, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Tigers tallied the winning run on Joe Gordon's boot of a grounder in the eighth inning today and added an insurance tally in the ninth to eliminate the Indians from third-place contention, 4 -- 2. Hal Newhouser gained his seventeenth, victory by scattering seven hits and fanning eight, while Bob Lemon suffered his fifth loss.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 27 -- If support of the Marshall Plan depended upon thorough public understanding of its involvements, that support would be woefully weak in this area except among specialized groups, according to the best evidence at hand.

DALLAS, Tex., Sept. 27 -- Sentiment for or against the Marshall Plan is just about as confused in Texas as the average man's knowledge of what it encompasses and why. The average Texan knows it has something to do with spending a lot of money in Europe, but he knows little more.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Ken Johnson, 24-year-old Cardinal southpaw, marked his debut in the majors today with a one-hit, 3-1 victory over the Cubs before 10,369 astonished fans. Eddie Waitkus singled to left with two out in the eighth to spoil Johnson's no-hitter.

Unless the Western powers provide a Marshall plan for education in Europe they will help lay the groundwork not only for communism but for a long-term collapse of Western civilization on the continent, Sir Kenneth Lindsay, Independent Member of Parliament for English Universities and former British Minister of Education, said yesterday.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A joint conference of thirty United States Congress members and Governors proposed today "an immediate readjustment of the Federal-state tax relationship" and urged adoption of a five-point taxing program by which states and local governments could "assume those functions * * * which they can administer best."

The domestic airlines, worried over continuing operating deficits and low load factors, are again looking to the Government to help extricate them from a financial situation that is fast becoming desperate.

WITH five conductors of different nationalities each devising programs of his own, the offerings of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will be of a decidedly varied nature during its 106th season, which operated on Oct. 9 at Carnegie Hall.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- One of the effects of the high-level tax rates on upper bracket incomes is the increasing number of stockholder-managers, it was said here today by J.K. Lasser, tax authority and author of "Your Income Tax," speaking at the fourteenth annual conference of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants.
Palestine and the U.N. For twenty-five years Great Britain has ruled Palestine, which she wrested from the tottering Ottoman Empire in World War I, under a mandate of the League of Nations.

DURING the last sixteen months an organization vulgarly known as ANTA has been appearing in the theatrical news with increasing frequency. Last autumn ANTA brought all the warring elements into the same room and succeeded in founding the Experimental Theatre, furnished a playhouse and finally paid $9,337.74 of the Experimental Theatre's $16,345.78 deficit.

IN this volume of James Barrie's letters -- edited by Viola Meynell -- there is little to divert the general reader and even less to attract the drama student. The morbid shyness of the Scottish playwright, with his hatred of notoriety, publicity and public appearances, seems to have invaded his correspondence as well, and even in writing to his friends he disclosed nothing of his inner self.

SCOTCH PLAINS, N.J., Sept. 27 -- Alexander Muir of 1845 Front Street, a member of the Scotch Plains Township Committee for eight years, and long active in civic and religious affairs here, died today in Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield, at the age of 70.

THE idea of killing weeds with chemicals has caught the imagination of experienced and amateur gardeners alike. Such sprays did not become really practical, however, until 2, 4-D (2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid) was found to have weed-killing properties.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The remaining tax claim of $50,446,284,58 against the estate of Edsel B. Ford, son of Henry Ford and former head of the Ford Motor Company, has been settled for $8,810,724,27, it was learned today.

Under any plan of fulfilling the 4 1/2 billion dollar plant and equipment requirements of the Marshall Plan, as estimated by the general report of the European conference last week, American manufacturers will probably have to initiate some kind of voluntary allocation of output to insure deliveries during 1948-51, industry leaders revealed here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The physical capacity of the steel industry in relation to the country's requirements for a prosperous economy, not now but two years hence and thereafter, is the subject of a spirited controversy.
With almost as much enthusiasm as they showed for the pennantwinning Dodgers, Brooklyn residents turned out yesterday to welcome the Freedom Train on its one-day stay in that borough.

ALL lilies profit by fall planting. Those of European and North American origin must be planted then if they are to Become established and make successful growth the first season. Bulbs should be set out as early as they can be obtained from the nursery, but dates of shipment will vary considerably, as the different varieties mature at various times.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla. -- The traditional rivalry for winter tourist traffic between Florida's West and East Coasts extended even to the big hurricane of Sept. 17-18. West Coast resort operators consider they got off lightly, since the storm caused more damage on the Atlantic side of the state.

TROT, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- The Twenty-seventh Infantry Division, after three years of "silent suffering" while evidence was held back for national security or policy reasons, loosed a strong counter-attack today on public criticism of its battle conduct during the capture of Saipan from the Japanese.
The supply of dwelling units continues to expand in most sections of the country, according to a survey just completed by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 27 -- South Korea's reaction to the Russian proposal of withdrawal of United States and Soviet troops from Korea by the first of the year was confined today to statements made to the United States press by one extreme Rightist and one moderate.

NO aspect of the record scene is healthier than the small independents who bring fresh ideas and energy to the repertory and the technical problems of recording. One of the liveliest of the independents should be Keynote, whose management was taken over recently by John Hammond, intelligent and discriminating friend of music of all kinds.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Cornell's Big Red football team began its sixtieth anniversary season today with a 27-0 victory over a Lehigh eleven which failed to penetrate the Ithacans' defenses to any extent and was ineffective against the off-tackle and aerial thrusts of the home forces.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Eastern Europe's opposition to the report of the Paris Economic Conference on the Marshall plan was placed squarely before the United Nations General Assembly today by Dr. Oscar Lange, vice chairman of the Polish delegation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- The United Nations Trusteeship Committee decided today to postpone until at least Thursday further discussion of the Union of South Africa's mandate over South-West Africa. It called for specific resolutions by midnight Wednesday on whether the Union was legally obliged to propose a trusteeship for the area in dispute.
OTTAWA, Sept. 27 -- Canada's reputation as that happy country in which roast beef and steaks are plentiful and cheap seems in some jeopardy.
Plans for a constituent assembly to be held in Geneva in 1950 to draft charter for a world government were described here yesterday by Henry C. Usborne, Labor Member of the British Parliament.

With the passing of the bull market in bonds, new influences and market practices are becoming discernible in the primary market for capital, particularly in the field of corporate securities affected by the requirement for competitive bidding, set up by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- A dominant note to be heard in discussions of the Marshall Plan is a warning that Congress, which will have to sanction this country's suggested $16,000,000,000 share of the expenditure, should hold complete debate on the proposal.

To the Screen Editor: THE TIMES of Sept. 14 contained a letter from an Arthur Neal, in which he condemned praising English films, and not American ones. There is obviously only one reason why this is done: English films are of a more consistently high quality than those made in this country.

EUROPEAN regulations which frequently require passengers to turn out for customs inspections at inconvenient hours will occupy an important place in discussions at the International Conference of National Official Travel Organizations meeting's in Paris on Oct. 13.

ONCE more the crime shows on the radio are receiving national attention, this time as the result of the steps taken by the National broadcasting Company to minimize the likelihood of such shows being heard by children.

ATHENS. AMERICA'S new role as the leading power of the world is reflected in the remarkable interest on the part of Greek intellectuals in American publications. The United States as a kind of fairyland is, of course, not new to Greece, but as a world power it certainly is.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 27 -- After a fight at sea, in which one Jew was shot dead, Jewish illegal immigrants on a former tank landing craft were brought to Haifa tonight under a British naval escort.

ROME, Sept. 27 -- Right Wing Socialist leader Giuseppe Saragat delivered a speech in the Constituent Assembly this morning in which he left the door wide open for any understanding between himself and Premier Dr. Alcide de Gasperi and at the same time widened the breach between his party and the extreme Left.

The perennial problem of military man power, one of the annual "headaches" of Congress, is again becoming a major issue as an election year approaches and recruiting drives lag somewhat behind their goals.

BILOXI, Miss., Sept. 27 -- The Marshall Plan for rehabilitation of European countries appears to have generated little interest in the South at this time, although there are many indications that Southerners largely would be hospitable to a coordination of facts and apt illustrations to convince them that they should support the proposals reached at the recent Paris conference.

FEW Americans have had David Bernstein's opportunity to see Philippine politics from the inside. During the war he was an adviser to President Manuel L. Quezon in Washington. Later he was on President Sergio Osmena's staff.

TRIESTE, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Three United States soldiers, who had been in Yugoslav captivity since Monday, returned to the Free Territory unscathed tonight, riding their own horses and followed by their big black mongrel mascot, Tiny.

NOTWITHSTANDING all the commercial and financial difficulties under which the theatre suffers, I believe they can be surmounted if the more fundamental problems are solved: first, how are we to obtain more good plays; second, how are these plays to reach the stage; and third, how are they to be kept on the stage until they have had a chance to succeed?

ST. LAWRENCE -- Institutes A five-point program of field work and extension services has been mapped by the Departments of Business Administration and Economics, Sociology, Psychology, History and Education at St. Lawrence University. The program will go into effect during the current academic year and will include institutes in family guidance, business administration and business management problems, as well as undergraduate and graduate work for social workers.

ONE likes cats because they set standards of beauty, dignity and deportment unequaled in the animal kingdom, and yet tolerate the company of men. They would have every right to sneer at our awkward manners, our groundless self-importance, our cowardly interdependence.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Washington's sixty-fifth and youngest foreign diplomatic establishment, the Embassy of Pakistan, is already functioning efficiently. Only the formality of having the new Ambassador, M.A.H. Ispahani, present his credentials to President Truman is lacking.

Completely Changed His Mind A friend of this department, who is practically never ill -- the last time he spent twenty-four hours in bed was, according to him, in the early Thirties -- suddenly found himself some days ago running a temperature.

ON the map the Caribbean has a delusive entity, and the interested eye spins between the islands a web of trade and travel routes which, if they existed, should surely make of the area the paradise that travel posters paint.

What is the difference between a psychopathic and a neurotic? According to the authorities, the psychopathic has a family history that points to a defective heredity. He has intense feelings of unrest which he satisfies by some action that violates social conventions. The world is against him, he thinks.

More than 12,000 invitations have been extended to members of the real estate industry in the New York area to attend the Building Maintenance Supplies Exposition to be held in Grand Central Palace, Oct. 27 to Nov. 1, inclusive.

THE agreement announced last week, drawing into a league of close, constructive cooperation the Metropolitan Museum, the Whitney and the Museum of Modern Art, is bound to be widely discussed. There are controversial elements involved, but the plan itself is of potential significance and should, when put actively into effect, serve to establish better conditions than have maintained in the local museum ealm up to now.

THE planned use of photographic technique to realize or strengthen a picture idea, rather than technique for its own sake, is an outstanding feature of the work of the Photo League currently on exhibition at the League's quarters, 30 East Twenty-ninth Street.
WORCESTER, Mass., Sept. 27 -- Dartmouth, by virtue of three heroic goal-line stands, held favored Holy Cross to a scoreless tie today as 25,000 spectators looked on at Fitton Field.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Two members of Congress directly concerned with food and food prices indicated today that the grain markets themselves should be allowed self-regulation and self-examination before the power of the Federal Government was invoked against speculation.

THERE are few signs as yet of blissful wedlock between Hollywood's writers and producers; but even while extremists try to build the barricades, more and more Hollywood authors are finding themselves on both sides of the fence.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 27 -- George M. Clark, president of the Pioneer Bank, Chattanooga, Tenn., was elected president today of the Consumer Bankers Association, succeeding Joseph E. Birnie, president of the Bank of Georgia, Atlanta.

One of the nation's larger utility holding company systems is now in the final phase of compliance with the integration provisions of the Holding Company Act with divestment by the American Gas and Electric Company of most of its ownership of the Atlantic City Electric Company.

In the current issue of Science Dr. David M. Greenberg and Martin Shulman (University of California Medical School) point out that sulfa drugs and antibiotics in general check the synthesis of compounds essential to the growth and multiplication of bacteria. This process is known as metabolite antagonism.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 27 -- When and if a showdown comes on the Palestine issue between the Arab states on the one hand and Great Britain and the United States on the other, oil will be the ultimate test of the Arabs ability to impose effective economic, political and cultural sanctions against the Western powers.
Nominal picket lines stationed in the garment center by Local 808 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, had a negligible effect yesterday on business in the area.

LONDON. WHEN I was abroad last spring, I was surprised to find with what hope and admiration many continental intellectuals are looking toward contemporary English literature. The bookshops of Oslo are full of English books, while the more highbrow Norwegians order the latest poetry direct from London publishers.

NEW ORLEANS -- With beach homes flattened, great live oaks uprooted and not a pier left standing, the Mississippi Gulf Coast, one of the South's most popular vacation spots, presents a sad picture today. There is scarcely a spot along the fifty-mile stretch of beach road -- extending from Lakeshore to Ocean Springs -- which does not show effects of the hurricane.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 27 -- Two indications of Britain's earnestness in announcing her intention to evacuate Palestine were given today in the face of Jewish and Arab skepticism.

The demand for one and two-family homes in Bergen County that prevailed during the summer months is continuing in the fall market. Reports of sales activity by brokers and builders yesterday indicate a record volume of business in residential realty in the last few weeks.
CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Todays report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

For the past few weeks, like a small bell tolling a warning, an appeal has sounded for the American people to cut their food consumption and share part of their bounty with the hungry world. Chester Davis, member of the President's Committee on Foreign Aid, warns that we must choose between voluntary meat rationing or legislative controls on wheat to fight hunger in Europe.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 27 -- The Indian Government gave official assurance to foreign correspondents today that press censorship was not "contemplated."

LAMERI'S newly formed Exotic Ballet will make its formal debut on Wednesday evening at 9 in the remodeled Ethnologic Dance Center, 110 East Fifty-ninth Street. The company consists of sixteen young dancers in support of the star, and the repertoire will deal, as the title would indicate, with the dances of peoples from other parts of the world.

Unseasonably cool weather pushed the mercury here down to 41 degrees at 5:50 A.M. yesterday, undercutting by almost two degrees the previous low record for Sept. 27. The cold spell brought "several hundred" complaints of chilly apartments to the Health Department.

DOZENS of books have been written on semantics and hundreds have been written on contract bridge, and it is unfortunate that none has touched on a case in which the former has some application to the latter.

THERE is a kind of fiction, extremely popular just now, which might, in the literary parlor game of classification, be called the "mono-neurosis school." Its apex, I suppose, was "The Lost Weekend," and it has been adopted by the most august members of the book club boards.

ADMISSION prices, seemingly always a topic of great public interest, came in for considerable debate at the recent convention of theatre owners in Washington, which resulted in the formation of the Theatre Owners of America.
