THE essay with which these handsome full-tone reproductions are prefaced is a concise, informative outline of the several social forces which have conditioned America's artistic growth. It is written with the eye of the philosophical historian, or historical philosopher -- whichever name best describes an author who has judiciously avoided confining his remarks to a panegyric of the illustrations.

TO THE EDITOR: As an American who lived, worked, ate only British rations, and stood in queues in England both during and after the war, I am impelled to protest the grotesque misrepresentations found in Taylor Caldwell's letter published on Sept. 14 as a retort to J. B. Priestley's article, "A Briton's Faith in Britain."

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 27 -- The likelihood that the situation of the Argentine universities would come up at the forthcoming conference of the United Nations Educational Social and Cultural Commission it Mexico City in November was suggested yesterday as the Chamber of Deputies completed its legislative approval of President Juan Peron's program for higher education.
THE NUMBER of genuine Stradivarius instruments in existence today has been estimated by various researchers at 600 to 3,000.

It was no contest. The Calumet Farm's Armed merely breezed to victory by half a dozen lengths over the King Ranch's Assault in their winner-take-all special for a $100,000 jackpot and a gold cup at Belmont Park yesterday.

JUDGING by appearances, the way to win pennants is to get away from baseball. A manager should avoid the season-after-season grind, for in hanging on year after year he loses his perspective and can no longer see the forest for the trees. There is a school of thought which holds that upon occasion men should retire from the tumult and the shouting, retreat into solitude and so find peace of mind and new objectives.

HAMBURG, Germany, Sept. 27 -- One of the surest aids in combating the spread of communism in Germany would be to import enough food to guarantee a daily ration of 2,000 calories, Joseph Cardinal Frings, Archbishop of Cologne declared today.

ATHENS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Representative John Taber, Republican, of New York, chairman of the United States House of Representatives Appropriations Committee, declared here today that the Greeks had "plenty of troops" to combat guerrillas and that the army "must get a move on."

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mr. Bevin's brief suggestion last week that the gold reserve of the United States be used to finance the Marshall Plan deserved fuller examination than it has so far received. Our supply of gold could be utilized as a cheap and constructive source of funds for carrying out emergency reconstruction aid.

FOR one of the top spots on the list of unsung heroines of World War II, Mrs. Roberts of Great Falls, Mont., gets my nomination. She fought one of the toughest campaigns never to be recorded in the pages of history -- the battle of the boarders -- and lived to tell the tale.

FIRST likely to impress visitors to the Mies van der Rohe show at the Museum of Modern Art is the installation, supervised by the architect himself. Here spaciousness reflects the element that more perhaps than any other single attribute characterizes the work of this distinguished modernist in the field of building.

DURING the revolution which resulted in the overthrow of Ecuador's President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra last August, the 50-centavos, 1-sucre and 2-sucre stamps in Ecuador's 1938 air-mail series commemorating the United States Constitution were overprinted in black with the words: "Primero la Patria" (First the Country).

MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Soviet periodical, Literary Gazette, declared today that under the leadership of Secretary of State Marshall, the United States State Department "quickly filled with persons in uniform."

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., missed a difficult $1,000 putt by inches but fired a seven-under-par 65 which equaled the course record and gave him a three-stroke halfway lead in the $5,000 international golf tourney today.
GENEVA, Sept. 27 -- The trade agreement between the United States and Prance has been virtually completed, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- The Justice Department tonight claimed another victory in its continuing legal fight to get American assets of I.G. Farbenindustrie away from the German dye trust's one-time cartel associate, Standard Oil Company of New Jersey.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Wisconsin Badgers, getting the jump on their Big Nine football opposition, scored in every period today to defeat an outmanned Purdue team, 32 -- 14, before 41,000 fans at Camp Randall Stadium.

NUMEROUS Americans, through the medium of Thomas Costain's best-seller, "The Moneyman," have just been initiated into the mysteries of the court of Charles VII of France. Now Muriel Roy Bolton follows with another king-size novel of fifteenth-century France -- a blueblood-and-thunder story which, chronologically at least, can serve as a sequel to "The Moneyman."

The advent of cooler weather and fresh autumnal breezes serves as a reminder again that this is the time of year when the State Fair flourishes anew. Ever since 1819, when Elkanah Watson, a prosperous merchant of Albany, N.Y., conceived the idea, millions of neighborly Americans have gathered annually to test their competitive spirit and skills.

LOUIS BROMFIELD has been a very uneven writer, as most prolific writers are, the best included. As such, they suffer a good many critical scoldings; many more than those whose creative stream is thinner. The somewhat constipated perfectionists, like A.E. Housman, fare better at the hands of the literary commentators.

To the Drama Editor: IF you study the so-called "Weimar" period you will find that the bona fide democrats and the liberals were not equipped to handle so complicated a machinery as modern democracy and that the reactionaries had a field day in ridiculing a system whose work-ability even its followers could not demonstrate.
City College and Susquehanna University battled to a 9 -- 9 tie before a near-capacity turnout of 6,500 at the Lewisohn Stadium last night. It was the season's opening game for both football teams.

HERE are two examples of the historically set romance, the period piece in every sense of the phrase. One, "Whirlwind in Petticoats," is a serious attempt at the genre. The second, "Grenadine Etching: Her Life and Loves," is manifestly a parody.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 27 -- The Danbury Fair, rich in New England tradition and set in the heart of the Fairfield Hills, presented today its seventy-fourth annual show, abounding in livestock and agricultural exhibits and bedecked in color.

THAT Europe must federalize in order to survive is the conclusion of William Henry Chamberlin in a reasoned but pessimistic volume, "The European Cockpit." Furthermore, Mr. Chamberlin argues, it is up to the United States to exercise all its influence to encourage such a movement in the world's interest and in its own.

WITH Palestine so urgently in the news, the showing of Palestinian art must be of considerable interest at this time if on that score alone. Much of the work placed on view last week as supplementing the large general Palestine Exhibition long current at the Museum of Science and Industry can, however, stand quite on its own merit.

The Common Aim NO man can draw a free breath who does not share with other men a common and disinterested ideal. Life has taught us that love does not consist in gazing at each other but in looking outward together in the same direction.

Premier Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia has extended, through his Ambassador to the United States, an invitation to six Americans, including two former Roosevelt Cabinet members, to visit his country and "see for themselves" whether Yugoslavia is an aggressor in the Balkans.

TEHERAN, Sept. 27 -- Iran, perennial buffer state, is again in the international spotlight. This time she is suffering from too many diplomatic embraces, and the effects are beginning to become evident.

WITH the casual cookery of the summer behind us, most of us feel the urge to spruce up the kitchen and get domestic affairs in general on a good, running basis once again. Checking over culinary equipment and replacing the wornout with the new pleases two opposite types of housewife -- the kind who cooks for fun and the kind who does it out of necessity.

U.N. Committee Stage The United Nations General Assembly last Wednesday shifted from the colonnaded building at Flushing Meadow eight miles away to the U.N.'s "business offices" at Lake Success. Phase I of the meeting -- the phase of words in the opening debate -- was over.

BOSTON, Sept. 27 -- Financial aid to Europe is widely regarded as both inevitable and sensible in New England. Interest in this section centers chiefly on making sure that such assistance really helps in re-establishing Europe's buying power and that the American taxpayer is not hit more than necessary.

ON a Monday in early September of 1937 a cryptic sign "Acre for sale" on a Long Island wood lot caught the imagination of Roy Chapman Andrews and his wife, Billie. By the following Saturday they were the slightly breathless owners of a dilapidated farmhouse and 150 acres of land near Colebrook in the hills of northwestern Connecticut.

Georgian and early American furniture and decorations belonging to several owners, among them Mrs. Hope Aspell of New York will go under the hammer on Thursday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

CHICAGO Sept. 27 -- While the experiment has been conducted under trying conditions, due to lack of equipment and congested tracks and yards, Chicago railroad spokesmen agree that the operation of passenger cars in through sleeper-car service between the Atlantic and Pacific Coasts has been a success since it was inaugurated in the spring of 1946.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Displaying a smooth ground attack after getting off to a slow start, Brown University's football team overpowered the University of Connecticut eleven, 33-13, today in the opening game of the season for both colleges at Brown Stadium.

NEW ENGLAND'S autumn foliage, an annual attraction for the color photographer, has begun to turn sufficiently to offer picture-making opportunities starting this week. The coloring is expected to continue in full splendor through the middle of October, reaching the peak of perfection somewhere around the 10th.

THE Garden Club of New Jersey's fourth annual Garden State Flower Show, to be held at the Woman's Club of Upper Montclair on Thursday and Friday, will have Governor and Mrs. Alfred E. Driscoll as guests on the first day.

BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 27 -- Here in the heart of a million acres of arid wasteland, top executives of the $13,000,000,000 power and light industry are accompanying a representative group of newsmen on a tour of five Western, Pacific, Southeastern and Central States, where some of the country's largest utility systems have embarked on an unprecedented $5,000,000,000 five-year expansion program to meet the growing demand for electric energy.

OUT of the war have come airmen's reports of a mountain of fabulous height, located somewhere in the obscure borderlands between Tibet and Western China. This peak is tentatively called Amne Machen, and there are stories told of flyers who have looked up at it from an elevation of 29,000 feet.

Heavier hedge selling than witnessed at any previous time this season was the feature of the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, and final prices were 9 to 22 points net lower than on Friday.

Sixty-three musical events have been announced by the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences to take place in the Brooklyn Academy of Music this season. It will be the institute's 124th consecutive year of operation.

NANKING, Sept. 27 -- Public scandals keep popping up frequently in China. The latest concerns the housing boom that has dotted Nanking with yellow, red and pink stucco and brick buildings, which are being offered to foreigners at rents up to $12,000 (United States) a year, payable in advance.
LIVES of great men all remind Irving Stone that he can make their lives sublime by turning them into fiction -- and departing, thus, leave no footnotes in the sands of time.

FOR his first novel Robert Bloch has chosen a tested melodramatic theme, used a tricky but reliable form to project it, sauced it copiously with psychiatry. "The Scarf" is the case-history of a pathological murderer, told in the strangler's own words.

MONTICELLO, N.Y.-- An enchanting Japanese palace nestled among pines and brilliant Japanese maples, six miles from here, is now open to the public for the first time in more than forty years. Only seventy-five miles from New York, on Route 42 between Port Jervis and Monticello, Shofu-den ("Pine and Maple Palace") is a replica of the 1,200-year-old Kyoto Imperial Coronation Palace of Japan.
LONDON, Sept. 27 -- In a slashing indictment tonight Winston Churchill accused the Soviet Union of "aggressions and intrigues" in all countries on its borders.

MIAMI, Fla. -- The winter visitor to Florida's East Coast will be reminded throughout his stay here of the big hurricane of Sept. 17. Most of the damage reparable by man will be cleaned up before the early autumn crowds arrive, but nature will require several seasons to heal the palm trees and tropical vegetation of their hurricane injuries.
NANKING, Sept. 27 -- Chinese officials here say that some Government leaders are considering a shift in China's foreign policy toward Soviet Russia.

AT the outset (if only as a frame for this little book), it should be noted that many skeptics dislike the Texan style. From a safe distance they mock the lack of culture, of science -- indeed, of rudimentary civilization -- among the sons of the Alamo.

Vice Admiral W.W. Smith, chairman of the Maritime Commission, will preside over the annual meeting of the American Merchant Marine Conference on Oct. 16 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The meeting, sponsored by the Propeller Club of the United States, is held in conjunction with the club's twenty-first annual convention Oct. 15, 16 and 17.

TOKYO, Sept. 27 -- The first steps toward reconstruction of their businesses in Japan have been taken by Standard Vacuum Oil Company and Rising Sun Petroleum Company, which in pre-war times supplied about half the Empires market for petroleum products. Informal inquiries also have been made by Brunner Mond Co., a subsidiary of Imperial Chemical Industries.

IT will be welcome news to many dance lovers over the country that Harald Kreutzberg will shortly be back. Now in South America on a tour, he will arrive in this neighborhood late next month to play a fourweek engagement in the East under the management of S. Hurok.

JACK LAURICE (Dodger fans call him "Shorty") is the Toscanini of Ebbets Field. For ten years, in the baseball season, Shorty has been the leader of a cluster of peace-destroyers, volunteers all, utilising more or less musical instruments, occupying seats back of the players' bench of the Brooklyn National League baseball club.

ENID, OKLA., Sept. 27 -- An interesting and nationally important experiment in vocational rehabilitation has passed the half-way point here in a "guinea pig" county selected as typical for the one-year test.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27 -- Yale had a better than brisk workout in its game against the Kings Point eleven in the Bowl today. The Elis won handily and clearly enough, 34 to 13, but the fight put up by the Merchant Marine Eleven provided a number of thrills for the 18,000 fans.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 27 -- Seasonal buying, particularly in men's and women's clothing, was a factor in pushing department store sales back above the level of a year ago. For the four weeks ended Sept. 20, the twenty-two reporting stores in Minneapolis, St. Paul, Duluth and Superior, Wis., reported dollar volume as 104 per cent of the same period in 1946.

THE Metropolitan Opera starts rehearsals tomorrow, dispelling any doubts that the fall season is really under way. The chorus, under Kurt Adler, will be the first to convene, its complement rounded out by new members who passed the auditions.

LOS ANGELES -- One of the most amazing natural wonders the tourist to California will encounter is California driving. It is a matter bearing close attention, along with the palm trees and sunsets, if the visitor is interested in surviving.

THIS is one of those novels which begins with an idea for which the writer must find time, place and characters. In it the author of "The Townsman" turns to a story of the racial problem in the South after the Civil War.

The Government, labor and producers of materials, as "the ones who control the production of houses," should be the object of the first attack in any assault against high prices of homes, Morgan L. Fitch of Chicago, president of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, declared yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 27 -- As President Miguel Aleman's first year in office was drawing to a close, he was obliged at the end of the week to take notice of the growing discontent throughout the country over the ever-increasing cost of living.

INASMUCH as the flappers ("bobby-soxers," I think they now call them) who used to wait outside the stage door for Hope Williams' autograph during my last Broadway production are now grandmothers (if their daughters married at the age of 14) and inasmuch as I have spent at least half of the intervening time amid the happy flesh-pots of Southern California, I suppose I am prpperly to be tagged as a "Hollywood writer."

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Early autumn is one of the most delightful seasons in the Asheville area of western North Carolina, and hotel and resort operators are looking forward to a busy October, hopeful that it will more than make up for a summer season that was off from previous peak years.

On the plea of members from up-State cities that have municipal elections on Nov. 4, the State Committee of the Liberal party adopted yesterday a resolution urging restoration of the state income and business taxes to their former levels with the increases going to the localities.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Sept. 27 -- Champion Rock Ridge Night Rocket, the young Bedlington terrier that became one of America's big dogs by taking top prize at the Morris and Essex show last spring, reaffirmed his class today by getting best-in-show at the ninth annual event of the Suffolk County Kennel Club.

DURHAM, N.C., Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- Tackle Louis Alien, capitalizing on a rare opportunity for a lineman, forgot is chores as a "mule" just long enough to snatch a blocked pass and run like a scared colt today for the touchdown that gave Duke a 7, to 0 fourth period triumph over North Carolina State.

The American Christian Palestine Committee announced yesterday that twenty-three Christian religious leaders had sent to Secretary of State Marshall a telegram urging him to give the "full support of our Government" to the majority report of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine.

SEPTEMBER brings some of the most brilliant flowers into bloom, and the arranger has an opportunity to make compositions that are dramatic and eye-catching. Dahlias predominate in many a design, but other fall blooms, usually in the yellow color range, provide equally vivid material.

AMERICANS in forty-eight States all have their opinions of New York City and express them promptly if given a chance. During a recent trip around the country I made a point of finding out just what outsiders think of the city, its people and its way of life.

TOKYO, Sept. 27 -- William H. Draper Jr., Under-Secretary of the Army, today told a press conference that he "assumed" that a "proper provision" would be written into the peace treaty for the defense of a Japan that under the new Constitution had renounced forever the maintenance of an Army, Navy or Air Force?

American exports are continuing their down trend, with indications that the drop for the remainder of this year may range around 30 per cent under the spring peak. On this basis, total 1947 exports would approximate $13,500,000,000, a figure considerably under expectations when export volume hit its peak of $1,421,800,000 last May.

Five teen-age robbery suspects were rounded up yesterday by the police. Four of the youths, they charged, had terrified five women, and a man at pistol-point in a two-hour sortie through Queens that brought them $1,000 in cash and jewelry.

SKILL in vegetable growing has increased so much in recent years that it is hard to find a plot that is bare and useless by September. For at least another month, crops are yielded in quantity, and even after that the space is not entirely vacant.

MANILA, Sept. 27 -- President Manuel A. Roxas today let it become known that he was endorsing United States-educated Princess Tarhata Kiram of Jolo for the highest elective post among the some 300,000 Mohammedan Moro people in the coming national elections for provincial and municipal offices on Nov. 11.

A new sales training course to be completed in a ninety-minute session will be given to 1,500 local Launderall automatic electric washer dealers and retail salesmen by Colen-Gruhn, Inc., beginning Oct. 2, M. Mitchell Gruhn, president of the organization, metropolitan area distributor for the appliance, disclosed in an interview last week.

GOSSIP, malice, calculation, infidelity, adultery, attempted murder, sudden death, and a set of surprise bequests that more or less straighten things out -- these are some of the dominant matters treated in "Country Place."

The main objective of the current Congressional investigation of high prices was emphasized again last week by the unusual action of the Eastern subcommittee in telegraphing President Truman to do something about speculation on the country's big grain and commodity exchanges.

HOLLYWOOD. AFTER six weeks of payroll slashing and fearful forebodings precipitated by the British 75 per cent tax on imported films, Hollywood has begun to adjust itself to a new situation -- rising production costs and a restricted selling market.

AFTER a series of technical mishaps had plagued the original production of his "Ring" cycle at Bayreuth in 1876, Richard Wagner is reported to have observed that the whole thing would have to be done differently the next year.

Convinced that the mortgage financing industry is entering its greatest period of activity, the Mortgage Bankers Association will this year dispense with guest speakers from fields related to real estate financing at its three-day convention beginning Oct. 2, at the Hotel Statler in Cleveland, Ohio.

To the Radio Editor: APROPOS your article last Sunday on the Atlantic City meeting of the National Association of Broadcasters, WNEW stated at the convention, and states again here, that any effective code for the radio industry cannot reasonably overlook the large segment of the industry which is independent and has no affiliation with the networks.

PORTLAND, Me. -- The State Fish and Game Department, sportsmen and sporting-camp operators in Maine are disturbed by the aerial invasion of the State's wilderness lakes by flying fishermen. Warden William H. Turgeon, who does his patrolling by airplane, says that airborne fishermen are visiting remote lakes and carrying away so many game fish that trout, salmon and togue stocks are being depleted.

The pro-Peron Buenos Aires newspaper, Democracia, takes it upon itself to lecture the press of the United States for what it sees as an anti-Peron attitude. "What is this sector of United States journalism getting at, or what would it like to get at?" Democracia asks.

The newly intensified attack of Communists and left-wing Socialists against the American way of life seems to be bringing about at least a partial restoration of the national unity with which the war against Fascism was fought. Liberal intellectuals and conservative business men are beginning to find common ground in the defense of freedom of thought, free enterprise and free labor against the totalitarian threat from the Left as well as from the Right.

Next to food the cry of every war-stricken nation in the world is for coal. Coal guarantees the industrial production which will buy food and shelter. Europe, where there is sufficient coal in the ground to supply all needs, is suffering from an acute coal shortage. Now a letter from General MacArthur published in Tokyo reveals the same situation in Japan.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Coast Guard stationed a second weather ship in the North Atlantic today to help guide planes of a dozen nations through winter skies.

IN the tradition of practically all screen villains, Richard Widmark is really a gentle and rather bashful guy himself. The new Twentieth Century-Fox star, whose first movie appearance as the vicious, psychopathic killer in "Kiss of Death" was generally conceded to have walked off with the film's acting honors, looks and talks more like the average American college boy than almost anyone you can name in Hollywood.

CONTEMPORARY books on Asia, even when they differ on the technique of reform, are almost all alike in their projection of a broad and happy future for Far Eastern nations, new and old -- provided the outworn colonial forms finally wither away and the rising tide of agrarian revolt and fresh industrial development flows freely.

IN 1936 a successful British play starring a successful British actress opened on Broadway. The play was "Love on the Dole." The star was Wendy Hiller. To the considerable surprise of a good many people, it closed in short order.

MONTREAL. A SIGNIFICANT, if disturbing, phase in the life of Canada's National Film Board was passed during late August when Maunee Duplessis, Premier of the Province of Quebec, announced that henceforth all narrow-gauge 16-millimeter films in Quebec -- shown commercially or non-commercially -- would be subject to examination by the Board of Film Censors.

Back to Ohio Senator Robert A. Taft heads homeward to Ohio this week after a three-week tour of seven Far Western states. The trip had two purposes. One was to carry out his own advice that "the issues before the country" be "freely discussed * * * particularly by Republicans."

THERE'S an all-day singin' here in Georgia at some church every Sunday the year round -- save when midwinter makes the clay roads impossible. But followers of this old-time practice of melodious and religious sociability detect a seasonal peak -- any time from mid-August through September, as the cotton-picking season draws to its close throughout the state and people have time and reason for relaxation.

PORTLAND, Ore. AT the grocery store a five-dollar bill dissolves like sugar in a kettle of mother's strawberry preserves. We used to borrow a cart from the boy next door to haul home five dollars' worth of groceries. Now you can tuck the whole business in an overcoat pocket, and still have room for your gloves and keycase.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- President Truman's Scientific Research Board revealed tonight a "revolutionary" naval weapon which might be perfected into a defense against rocket-borne weapons of atomic or poison warfare.

"THE HUNTER'S HORN" deals with a few months of growing pains in a boy's life. The locale is a South that is also suffering from change, as the "good old days" steadily depart along with the Civil War generation and the old timber, while the scrubby new growth pushes through.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 27 -- A national advertising campaign, employing the radio, magazines and newspapers and interpreting "the central truths and activities" of the Christian church, was urged upon Methodism here today by the Rev. Dr. Paul W. Quillian of Houston, Tex.

OFFHAND, it would be hard to dream up a more unpromising hero for the novelist than the American Communist -- even for as nimble a prestidigitator as Howard Fast. Yet it is precisely this species that Mr. Fast has chosen to illumine -- and of course, to vindicate -- in his present contribution to the polemics of 1947.
CORVALLIS, Ore., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft charged tonight that "half" of the CIO unions in the country were "Communist dominated."

FRANKLIN, Mich., Sept. 27 -- By triumphing in the most hotly contested final round in the history of the women's national amateur golf championship, Miss Louise Suggs of the Capital City Country Club, Atlanta, Ga., captured the title today in the forty-seventh tournament.

NUREMBERG. A YEAR ago this week the first Nuremberg war crimes trials culminated in the conviction of twelve top Nazis. Since then Nuremberg has figured only rarely in the news. But despite the lack of publicity the ancient city has been the scene of an unbroken succession of trials involving field marshals and generals, industrial magnates and others.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 27 -- The Giants' reconstruction campaign for 1948 continued today at accelerated tempo. Experimenting with a Jersey City battery, the New Yorkers dropped a ball game to the Phillies, 10 -- 7, but since the teams are only playing out the schedule, no significance was attached to the setback.

NEWARK is engaged in an interesting experiment in the elimination of airport noise. New traffic patterns for take-offs and landings at the airport have been developed, designed to keep planes away from the residential and business areas whence have come the chief objections to the further development and enlargement of the airport by the Port of New York Authority.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Brookfield Farms Itsabet, only filly in the $25,000 added Garden State Stakes, easily turned back six male rivals in the sixth running of that fixture at Garden State Park today.

NORTH ATTLEBORO, Mass. AROUND this time of year Congressmen go out to mend their political fences, mix with the voters and find out what people want them to do at the next session. This year it seems especially urgent for a Congressman to know what his people are thinking and saying -- about such crucial problems, for example, as aid to Europe, tax reduction and communism.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 27 -- The machinery that makes the United Nations work -- or sputter and stall -- is being put through a careful examination by the delegations that constructed it with a prayer a couple of years ago at San Francisco. Some of the diplomats have announced that already they can hear doleful creaks; others are worried because the parts of the machine aren't meshing.

Webb Knapp, Inc., offered yesterday to post a $500,000 bond to allay any doubts over the concern's intentions to proceed with the construction of "Dream City," proposed shopping and business center in Flushing, Queens.

DULUTH, Minn., Sept. 27 -- A $77,000,000 project for producing high-grade iron concentrate from taconite, a rock formation with low iron content abounding almost limitlessly here, is the latest development in a movement held likely to influence the future of the steel industry.

The National Student Association, which recently adjourned its constitutional convention, has embarked upon an extensive program designed to promote better relations and understanding everywhere as well as to raise the level of student welfare in this country.

Deposits in the mutual savings banks of the nation continued to gain during August, although at a lesser rate than for any month during the first half of the year, according to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

GAMBIER, Ohio, Sept. 27 -- The constitutional system of checks and balances in this country was recommended today as a pattern for the solution of labor-management problems by a spokesman for the United Automobile Workers at the second conference at Kenyon College on the heritage of the English-speaking peoples and their responsibility.

TO THE EDITOR: In your issue of Sept. 14 Mrs. Mina Hoffmann asks why Americans should be expected to give their dollars for a Jordan Valley scheme when "the British forbid the Jews to emigrate into Palestine, yet import thousands of Arabs from other parts of the Near East, creating riots by having their agents roam through Arab settlements inciting them against the Jews."

After a six-year turn of the wheel, world series baseball comes back to Greater New York this week with a setting similar to that of 1941, the game's last pre-war classic. In the one corner will be the Yankees who will be carrying the American League banner for the fifteenth time.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 27 -- Mrs. Vera Micheles Dean, research, director of the Foreign Policy Association, said here tonight that the situation in Europe was not a temporary crisis but "a painful, long-run readjustment of an entire continent to new conditions."

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Heard Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet delegate, accuse Greek leaders of "hatching" war between Russia and the United States, and demand that Assembly order withdrawal of foreign troops from Greece.

VIENNA. ON April 13, 1945 -- precisely seven years and four weeks after the forced Anschluss -- when the red-white-red flag of the Austrian Republic waved from Vienna's neo-Gothic town hall again, together with the red flag of the victorious Russians, the capital had been badly damaged in the last stages of the war.

THE coming of autumn does not mean that sprayers and dusters can be left on the shelf, no matter how regularly they were used during spring and summer. Insect pests are troublesome during fall also. In fact, control is more effective for some during this season.
VISHNICA, Yugoslavia. ACCORDING to recent plans of the Yugoslav Government, a special emissary of good-will is being readied for visits to foreign countries, including the United States.

A far-reaching educational program, resigned to improve the standards of The New York City school system and correct existing shortcomings, is proosed in a report issued last week by the Citizens Committee on Children.

To transfer from the gridiron at Baker Field to the cold, black print on a sports page all the thrills of the local season's inaugural college football game, in which Columbia defeated Rutgers, 40 -- 28, yesterday, should be a routine task.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Although the Labor-Management Relations Act of 1947 got off to a slow start, the speed of its operations picked up somewhat this week when the law was invoked in a few important test cases. However, millions of employes are still barred from access to the law's machinery and comparatively few employers have as yet availed themselves of it.

Bank operating costs, earnings and the current inflationary trend with its implications, through the boom-and-bust cycle, for the continued operation of the banking industry under the private enterprise system, are scheduled to be prime topics for consideration by the American Bankers Association this week at the group's seventy-third annual convention in Atlantic City.
While their "permanent" and transient guests go about their business as usual and demand all the customary services many big New York hotels are undergoing major repairs.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Grains moved upward again today on the Board of Trade. Wheat received support from sales of cash grain and flour to the Government, while feed grains were aided by reports of light to heavy frosts overnight in Illinois.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Sept. 27 -- Two perfect passes by big Walt Pupa brought North Carolina a 14-to-7 football triumph over Georgia today after the Bulldogs had takern an early lead and had kept the Tarheels' famed running back, Charlie Justice, fairly well shackled.

FOR THIS WEEK: Continue to spray roses, especially for black spot, and spray or dust other plants on which green leafhoppers have been noticed with DDT, pyrethrum or nicotine sulfate.... Add milky disease spore dust to lawns as a control for Japanese beetles next year.... Cut down the canes that bore fruit on raspberry plants this year.

Activity in all sections of department stores was good last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Departments where brisk activity was reported were coat, suit, dress, sportswear, linens, domestics and yardage.

THE builders who were called in under the Marshall Plan submitted their estimate last week for the job of reconstructing western Europe. After some sharp pruning by our own experts, the report of the 16-nation Committee of Cooperation calls for about $22 1/2 billions in U.S. aid for the period 1948-51.

LAKE SUCCESS, Sept. 27 -- The tumult and the shouting of the General Assembly's first days have died away, and the United Nations is now left with the job of deciding what the threatened showdown between the United States and the Soviet Union indicates for the future.

The present waterfowl picture continues to be something of a jigsaw pattern, with many of the pieces still to be fitted into their places, and with the duck hunter standing on the sidelines wondering what is going to happen.

Prokofieff: Romeo and Juliet, Ballet Suite No. 2. Boston Symphony Orchestra conducted by Serge Koussevitzky. (Victor, two twelve-inch records). These excerpts from Prokofieff's score for a "Romeo and Juliet" ballet show that the composer did his usual efficient, journeyman job of composing.

Two parent-and-son combinations who, the police charge, specialized in stealing automobiles were rounded up yesterday. One pair, a mother and her stepson, were arrested in Providence. The arrest of the other pair, father and son, was announced by the Federal Bureau of Investigation here.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 27 -- An archaeological exploration in an industrial community just north of Paris produced during the summer two of the "missing links" in the development of Gothic architecture and sculpture. The exploration, one of a series begun in 1938, but suspended during the war years, was conducted by Prof. Sumner McK. Crosby, chairman of the Department of the History of Art at Yale University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Cyrus S. Ching, director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, put employers and labor organizations on notice today that the service will not be available generally in disputes which are primarily local in consequence and concern.

Approached from a Federal income tax point of view, community property State laws have a strong appeal to individual taxpayers. This is demonstrated by the fact that thirteen States have adopted such laws and that the Legislature of the State of New York may soon consider the advisibility of such adoption.

SOME of the best of the war's front-line photographs were made by Robert Capa. Time and again, from Africa to Aachen, Capa risked his life for the sake of a good shot. He jumped with parachute troops over Italy and Germany, and he landed on the Normandy beachhead on D-Day.

THERE are some movie stars in Hollywood who complain that they are "type cast." They mean that after scoring a success in one particular role they are forced, like it or not, to play that kind of part again and again.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Dr. C. Valentine Kirby, retired director of art education in the Department of Public Instruction, died at his home in near-by Camp Hill today after a week's illness. His age was 71.

On Aid For Europe Winter comes early for most of the Continent of Europe. In late September chill winds sweep in from the north, the temperature drops into the forties. Europeans know that within a matter of weeks there will be a freeze and the cold months will be upon them.

EVANSTON, Ill., Sept. 27 -- Vanderbilt's scrappy Commodores ruined the debut of 31-year-old Bob Voigts as Northwestern's football coach today by scoring an upset 3-to-0 victory in the final four minutes before a crowd of 42,000.

Increased activity in the wholesale markets last week reflected the pick-up in retail business occasioned by the advent of cooler weather, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.

LONDON. A ROYAL AIR FORCE pilot, after a reconnaissance flight over German-held France, put his plane down in England one evening and turned in a report which ended with the laconic statement: "Shot up one Emett on the beach in France."

NARGANA, San Blas -- Travelers pausing in Panama on their way through the Canal to South America or points west can take a rewarding side trip to the little-known San Blas Islands, east of the Canal, just off the Atlantic Coast of Panama.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Negro troops from Manhattan and Brooklyn bid farewell to Camp Smith tomorrow morning, ending a twelve-day encampment made somewhat disagreeable by the unseasonable cold weather.

THIS week marks the return to standard time by the nation. And this week, too, will find a full complement of the fall season's radio entertainers -- with the exception of a very few latecomers -- back at the microphone.
Grain prices continued their new advance on the Chicago Board of Trade for the third day yesterday, all cereals scoring substantial gains.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The resignation of Robert E. Hannegan as Chairman of the Democratic National Committee was made public today. It was announced also that Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island had been designated as his successor.

Whole Town's Talking In last Tuesday's twilight two boys sat on a stoop on Gansevoort Street, hard by a Manhattan wholesale food market on the edge of Greenwich Village. One asked: "Gonna see the Freedom Train?" His companion queried: "What train?"

HOLLYWOOD. ONE of the most tragic and at the same time most historic moments of World War II was reborn here last week when the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer studios re-enacted the conquest of Anzio by units of the U.S. Fifth Army.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- The Soviet Union called on the General Assembly today to order all foreign troops out of Greece and warned sharply that United States policy on the Balkans might lead to a collapse of the United Nations.

Although New York, with its nearly 1,500,000 students enrolled in public schools, private schools and colleges, is the greatest center of education in the world, there is one field in which the city, instead of being first, is last. That is in job training for disabled veterans.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Ohio State's Buckeyes came from behind in the last three minutes today to snatch at 13-to-7 victory over Missouri for their new coach, Wesley E. Fesler, and maintain their record of never losing an opener to a collegiate foe.

To The Drama Editor: IN answering the reasoned considerations of S.M. Levitas of The New Leader against the wisdom of producing "All My Sons" before audiences in the occupied territory of Europe, where we are engaged in instructing as to the virtues of our kind of democracy, your critic does seem to strain considerably away from the simplicities of the question.

A new process for manufacturing specialized alloy steels has been perfected after twelve years of research, it was announced yesterday by H.R. Austin, president of the M.W. Kellog Company, chemical engineers, of Jersey City and New York.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- The United States and Britain have decided to support Argentina for a place in the United Nations Security Council, it was learned today.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- Defeating Burnley by 1-0 on Burnley's ground before a crowd of 45,000, Arsenal made it eight out of nine games this season and stayed at the head of the English Football League's first division.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 27 -- Autumn yacht racing, or what has become known as an annual post-season series following the close of the Long Island Sound championship class competition, began today off the Larchmont Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The Baltimore Typographical Union's offer to enter into a written contract with employing printers was reported here today to be limited to demands which the employers may legally meet within the framework of the Taft-Hartley Act.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 27 (AP) -- By the margin of a run which was forced in on a base on balls in the eighth inning, the Syracuse Chiefs took the opening game of the Little World Series from the Milwaukee Brewers Here tonight, 7 to 6.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- Extensive use of diesel-electric locomotives and larger freight cars is the most important change planned for rebuilding war-damaged railway systems of western Europe, railroad union leaders of six European countries said at a press conference here.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Sept. 27 (AP) A high-spirited, stubborn Pittsburgh team stalled Illinois' football machine for three quarters today before a second - string halfback, Dwight Eddleman, punched over two touchdowns in the final period to give the Illini a 14-0 victory.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Sept. 27 (U.P.) -- Minnesota's hard-pressed Gophers were forced into a savage last-minute battle today to pull out a 7 to 6 victory over a stubborn University of Washington football team.

Many new office machines based on electronic operation are among the automatic types of equipment included by more than 100 exhibitors in the National Business Show which opens at 1 P.M. tomorrow at Grand Central Palace, Frank E. Tupper, managing director, disclosed here yesterday.

HIGHWAYS that hum rebukes when motorists cross traffic separation lines are in the making in New Jersey, to the keen interest of delegates to the American Association of State Highway Officials, who met at the Waldorf-Astoria last week.

THE special race between Armed and Assault at beautiful Belmont followed the script with painful exactitude yesterday. The golden gelding won another $100,000 and both Ben and Jimmy Jones wish they could corral all their money as easily as they captured what the railbirds describe as "the hunnert grand."

CORBIERE was born a hundred years ago and died seventy years ago; I heard of no celebration of his centenary, I know almost no one who reads him; but there are not many men who have written poems as good as his, and he can wait in mocking confidence for the world to make its way to his grave.

BRISK winds and low temperatures have served to turn the year-round gardener's thoughts toward house plants which will bridge the gap to spring. Many pot plants now in bloom give immediate results in the window garden.

Work has just been completed on the transformation of the Edison Junior High School in Summit, N.J., into an industrial research laboratory for the Celanese Corporation. Details of the unusual alteration were described yesterday by C. Benson Wigton, president of the Wigton-Abbott Corporation, engineers and contractors.

Events abroad and their possible repercussions on our domestic economy held security markets within a narrow trading range last week. Interest was divided between the report on the Marshall Plan, to put Europe back on its economic feet by 1951, and Government attempts to check the rising cost of living.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 27 -- Harvard, after scoring four touchdowns in the first period, coasted to a 52-0 opening-game victory over Western Maryland before 17,000 spectators at the Stadium today.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Tulane's light, sophomore - rich Green Wave negotiated three long scoring plays today to upset Alabama's big Crimson Tide, 21 to 20, before 60,000 spectators. It was Alabama's first one-point defeat since the Tide lost, 5 to 4, to the Birmingham Athletic Club in the first football game it ever played, back in 1892.

FOLLOWING a now wellestablished trend in radio, Jacques Fray is joining the growing brotherhood of disk jockeys, with the distinction that, instead of falling into the tired pattern of popular tunes, guest interviews and brittle chit-chat, his selections will be largely classical and his talk will be about the music he plays.

The ways and means of encouraging college students to take a more active interest in governmental, affairs and politics will be the subject of a two-day conference opening tomorrow morning at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The conference will be sponsored by the New York University School of Law in cooperation with the American Bar Association and the American Political Science Association.
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 27 -- California's hard-hitting Bears achieved a smashing early-season football upset today by defeating Navy, 14-7, before a sell-out crowd of nearly 80,000.

BOSTON, Sept. 27 -- It caused no great pain to anybody this afternoon when Tommy Holmes, the Brooklyn boy who plays for Boston, slapped a single inside third base in the ninth inning to score Connie Ryan and end the threat of another one of those marathons for which the Dodgers and Braves are famous.

OUT of an experience of nearly half a century in Fleet Street, Lord Camrose, owner of The Daily Telegraph of London, has prepared a report on the ownership and control of every morning, evening and Sunday newspaper in the United Kingdom.

DETROIT, Sept. 27 -- Either the officers of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, must comply with the Communist affidavit provision of the Taft-Hartley Law or the union's effectiveness as a collective bargaining agency will be so impaired as to risk destruction of the union, Emil Mazey, member of the international executive board and co-director of Region No. 1, warned members today.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 27 -- Hugh John. Lofting, author of the "Dr. Dolittle" series of children's books and other fiction for Juveniles, died last night in his home here. He was 61 years old.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 27 (UP) -- Michigan's versatile Wolverines, favorites to represent the Big Nine in the 1948 Rose Bowl game, did just what they were expected to do with Michigan State College today, crushing the Spartans, 55 to 0, and treating 73,115 fans to an all-out exhibition of brilliant running, passing and kicking.

Vying for attention this evening are two openings -- "The Heiress" and "Shylock and His Daughter." The eyes of Broadway, however, are riveted on the Biltmore, where the curtain of "The Heiress" is announced to rise at 8:15 sharp. Fifteen minutes later the first performance of "Shylock and His Daughter" will commence at the owntown Yiddish Art Theatre.
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- The projected constitution to establish the Saar as an autonomous country attached economically to France is being studied by foreign affairs officials here, it was learned today.

Mayor O'Dwyer and other public officials ware among 800 guests who attended the annual clambake of the Jefferson Democratic Club of Flushing, Queens, held yesterday afternoon and evening in Lost Battalion Hall, 93-29 Queens Boulevard, Elmhurst, Queens. James A. Roe, Democratic leader of Queens, is president of the club.

HOLLYWOOD. Calif., Sept. 28 -- e conclusion of a deal for Walter anger Pictures, which recently mpleted "Tap Roots" for Univer-International, to become associated with Eagle Lion Films, is pected this week, according to gle Lion.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 28 -- The nation's banks are in a sounder condition than ever before in their history and by continuing their conservative policies, will be able to withstand satisfactorily any adjustments which may be required by the national economy, C.W. Bailey, president of the American Bankers Association, declared here today.

Doris Trotman, soprano, who won a gold medal of the New York Music Week Association in 1925, appeared in Town Hall late yesterday afternoon in a program of songs, classical arias and spirituals. She displayed a small, naturallypleasant voice which she knew how to color, but which was edgy and uncertain in the high register.

Museums and galleries have arranged a busy week of art events, including the fourth annual nationwide Pepsi-Cola competition showing, "Paintings of the Tear," opening on Wednesday at the National Academy. A memorial exhibition of work by the late Horace Pippin will start today at the Knoedler Galleries, and on Wednesday the Museum, of Modern Art will open a retrospective exhibition of paintings by Ben Shahn.

MACKINAC ISLAND, Mich., Sept. 28 -- Terming themselves "indulgent, demanding and competitive" 250 American and Canadian women attending the North American Assembly for Moral Rearmament accepted "responsibility for the present chaos" of the world.

NEW MARTINSVILLE, W. Va., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Four world records were shattered here today during the running of the eighth annual Ohio River regatta before a crowd estimated at 30,000 persons who lined both the West Virginia and Ohio banks of the stream.

Democracy is hard to define, though many gifted persons have tried to find the words. Longitude in these days also makes a difference. But possibly in a democracy something like this might happen: The head of the State, facing a series of painfully difficult and unspeakably important decisions, might wish to go to church.

ROBERT PAYNE, who can write more books in Jess time than any other serious and talented modern writer, will have six of his books published in this country this year. "David and Anna," a strange and beautiful novel about love and Malaya, and a collection of poems, "The Rose Tree," appeared some months ago. "The Bear Coughs at the North Pole"" and "The Revolt of Asia" comprise his contribution to the freshet of September publications.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -- If waterfront employers carry through their announced intention of shutting down the Los AngelesLong Beach harbor at midnight on Tuesday they will cancel automatically the West Coast longshore contract covering all ports between Canada and Mexico, according to Harry Bridges, president of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union.

Dropping atomic bombs on Russia would not be the solution to the problems of the world, the Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell declared yesterday morning in his sermon in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- As opposition from a large crowd at a meeting of the pro-Fascist British League of ex-Servicemen was about to boil over into street fighting tonight, the police closed the meeting.

Mrs. Celina Barska, the chief Jewish child care worker in Poland, will start studying social work at Western Reserve University in Cleveland today on the Adele Rosenwald Levy Scholarship granted by the National Council of Jewish Women, it was announced.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- National banks in the United States and possessions reported net earnings of $319,182,000 for the first six months of the year ended on June 30, it was reported today by Preston Delano, Comptroller of the Currency.

They rolled back the years at the Stadium yesterday as a crowd of 25,084, gathered for the Yankees' final home game of the regular championship season, cheered to the echo one of the most remarkable pageants even seen in a baseball arena.

Tchaikovsky's "Eugen Onegin" which had been given in English by the New York City Opera Company last season, was presented in Russian for the first time by that organization last night at City Center. The attempt to perform the opera with its original text deserved commendation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Edward R. Stettinius Jr., former Secretary of State, was today named chairman of a Citizens' Advisory Council to study possible expansion of the Government's socialsecurity program under which 42,000,000 Americans are at present entitled to benefit.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have read with great interest the extracts from the forthcoming book by Ambassador Winant which have been appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
The $5,000,000 Grace Line Pier 57 at Fifteenth Street and the North River was destroyed early today by a fire that was brought under control at 2 A.M. after spreading to Pier 58 to the north.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A small group of men who met here a few days ago made some strategic moves on the chessboard of international labor relations which may in their way, have as important repercussions in that sphere as any moves on the political chessboard by the United Nations.
PEIPING, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Chinese newspapers reported today that plane - supported Government troops had routed Communists who for a week vainly assaulted Chinhsi in southwest Manchuria.

Unless 2,000,000 deadweight tons of merchant shipping can be obtained within four years by the sixteen member nations of the Marshall plan for European rehabilitation, one of the goals of the plan, cannot be attained, statistics showed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- The Government is about to break into the black on its budget for this fiscal year.

An advertising and promotion campaign for Austin Motor Company of Birmingham, England, is being prepared to break in November when the first shipments of cars begin to arrive for dealers, it was announced over the weekend by J.M. Mathes, Inc., which has been appointed to handle the company's advertising and public relations in the United States.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Sept. 28 -- "Immediately the way is clear, Switzerland will faithfully fulfill all her obligations under the Washington Agreement of May 25, 1946, regarding the liquidation of German assets," a high Swiss official in Berne said this week-end.

THERE isn't a more moth-eaten phrase in sports than the old horse-chestnut, "Anything can happen in a short series." It's so trite that it makes one ashamed to use it. But it's so true that there's just no escape. In fact, it is so true that the experts are eternally confounded and embarrassed. They weigh one set of statistics against the other.

ATHENS, Sept. 28 -- A significant but precarious improvement in public morale has been achieved in northern Greece, where the guerrilla problem is most acute, by the three-week-old Liberal-Populist Coalition Government of Premier Themistocles Sophoulis.

PRAGUE, Sept. 28 -- Czechoslovakia hopes soon to complete agreements concerning foreign claims for nationalized property with all interested countries except the United States. Czechoslovak sources say Washington will not enter into a general agreement because Prague wants to differentiate on United States citizens according to the date of their naturalization.

BOSTON, Sept. 28 -- Eddie Stevens lost a simple ground ball in the ninth inning, the Dodgers lost another ball game, Umpire Bill Stewart lost his temper and the Braves lost two players who lost their sense of direction and collided under a fly ball in the eighth inning.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 28 -- With fensive efficiency that was a y to behold, the New York nkees piled up a 21-7 lead over e Baltimore Colts in the first lf of their football game today took an equally sparkling defence performance by Ray Flaherty's uad to make this count stand as the final score.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 28 -- While a trio played "By the Sea" and 1,000 spectators cheered here today, Mrs. Edna lamb of Maurice River, N.J., ate 186 cherrystone clams and became the new national clam eating champion.

It stood, until a few days ago, as it had stood for more than threescore years -- brown and solid and foursquare, on the northwest corner of Fifty-first Street and Fifth Avenue -- the last of the great Vanderbilt mansions on the lordly thoroughfare that epitomized their New York of multiplying millions of dollars and scintillating turns of fashion.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Acharya Kripalani, Congress party president, assailed today a reported appeal by Pakistan for outside aid in ending Hindu-Moslem warfare.
Ushering in the eight-day Succoth holiday, Jews throughout the world began at sundown yesterday the traditional observance of the harvest season with prayers and hymns.

MIAMI, Fla., Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Coast Guard here reported today that winds of gale force and heavy seas along the southern Atlantic Coast brought messages of distress from three vessels, while a fourth reported a man lost overboard during the night off the eastern tip of Cuba.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- Dr. Catherine Personius, head of the Department of Food and Nutrition in the College of Home Economics, Cornell University, has been named assistant director of the Cornell University Agricultural Experiment Station. She is one of only two women in the United States to hold such a position in an agricultural experiment station.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Admiral William F. (Bull) Halsey was the target of a broadside today from the Methodist Board of Temperance.

BERLIN, Sept. 28 -- Most of the influential members of the Congressional inspection teams now in Europe are convinced that the United States must "finish the job" of restoring peace in Europe regardless of the cost in time and money.

400th Birthday of a Supreme genius Just as there is uncertainty about where he was buried, so also is there doubt about when he was born. That the year was 1547 is a known fact -- that the month was September is generally considered to be fact -- but here certainty ends and surmise begins.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 28 -- Premier Marshal Tito appeared yesterday in the role of spokesman and leader for the formation of a new world bloc of Left Wing elements, which he called "People's Fronts."

Housewives' hopes of a general lowering of meat prices were dampened yesterday by Jack Kranis, president of the National Meat Industry Council, who predicted the return of $1-a-pound beef in many New York retail shops by the end of this week.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months, amount to $52,241,833,847. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, declared tonight that advantages to be gained from the Feinberg salary law enacted this year were so important that every effort should be made to see that it worked.

PARIS, Sept. 28 -- As a prelude to the official opening of the Women's World Fellowship congress here, delegates from fifty nations were greeted and introduced today by the French Acting Committee. The meeting will discuss what women can do to maintain peace.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- Perfection of a serum which, has cut the whooping-cough death toll among children under six months from more than 25 per cent to 8.2 per cent was revealed here yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 28 -- The fifth day of the Ecumenical Methodist Conference was devoted largely to worship. Eighty-nine ministers attending the conference were guest preachers in pulpits of several Protestant denominations in Sprinfield, throughout Massachusetts, and in Connecticut, Rhode Island and New Hampshire.
Four hundred volunteer lawyers will be trained to staff an all-year bureau that will guard against election "frauds in this city, State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein announced yesterday.

With only two days left for garages and parking lot operators to obtain licenses, 80 per cent of the 4,500 affected by the new law have filed their applications, it was reported yesterday by Benjamin Fielding, License Commissioner.

SECOND ELEPHANT CAMP, Tana River, Kenya Colony, Sept. 17 (By Airmail) -- There are mixed emotions of joy and anxiety in the McMillan East African Expedition second elephant camp tonight. Out in the bush three miles from camp lies the hulk of a giant tusker.

The President will meet today with Congressional leaders representing the two major parties to take up the vital and pressing problem of food relief to Europe. Some might say that this was not one problem, but two. However that may be, the subject is of profound importance to two continents and involves two far-reaching decisions in the field of national policy.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- With debates over Greece, Palestine and the admission of Italy and four Soviet satellite countries to the United Nations already scheduled for tomorrow, a move to expedite the General Assembly's business was added today to the already heavy calendar.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 28 -- An Afghan hound already loaded down with honors tacked on another today when Mrs. Lean P. McConaha's champion Ali Khyber got best in show in the silver anniversary event of the Westbury Kennel Association.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 28 -- Commenting on Great Britain's declared intention to evacuate Palestine; David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, asserted today that the Jews themselves were prepared to implement the settlement of the problem by providing for the immediate establishment of a Jewish state.

Last week's cooler weather spurred both retail and wholesale activity to a considerable degree, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. Emphasis in coat requests, the reports stated, was on hooded types both trimmed and untrimmed.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Ernie Bonham, a one-time New York Yankee, was in championship form today, allowing just two hits as he pitched the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 7-0 shut-out victory over the Cincinnati Reds in the final game of the National League season.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Women may soon be called upon to serve as referees in a fashion battle of "the new look" versus "the young look." The contest will take place when shops and department stores receive in their stocks the styles now on display at the National Wash Apparel Industry Show, which opened here today.

Despite the severity of the world crisis, Christians should take hope in the fact that "this is not the first time that the world has entered the valley of decision," the Rev. Bernard M. Martin of the staff of the New York Catholic Charities declared yesterday in his sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

The first direct air service between New York and Santiago, Chile, was started yesterday when Gen. Harold L. George's Peruvian International Airways brought its first DC-4 into La Guardia Field with Gen. Armando Revoredo. Air Minister of Peru, as guest.

Jose Fugueroa, Puerto Rican violinist, gave a recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. His elaborate program consisted of the Vivaldi Sonata in A major; Bach's "Chaccone"; Turina's Sonata, Op. 82; Chausson's "Poeme," and the Concerto in B minor by SaintSaens.

Marshal Tito's invitation to six prominent Americans of his own choosing to visit Yugoslavia and "see for themselves" whether or not his country is a Balkan aggressor aiding the Greek guerrillas throws considerable light on at least one phase of the present controversy.

STAMFORD, conn., sept. 28 -- A thirty-six-bell carillon, one of the largest in the world, was presented formally today to the First Presbyterian Church here. It was the gift of the international Nestle Company in appreciation of the hospitality shown by the people of Stamford to employes of the company's headquarters staff moved here from Vevey, Switzerland, in 1939 to facilitate operations of the company during the war.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial comment on shore erosion and its prevention has probably convinced many of your regular readers of your particular concern with this problem, but it is not very evident from your comment that there may be more than one way of looking at it.

Last year 10,424 patients receive 108,066 days of care, the majority of them without fee or below cost in Beth Israel Hospital. Stuyvesan Park East and Sixteenth Street according to the hospital's fifty seventh annual report made public yesterday.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Sept. 28 -- President Vassil Kolarov and Minister of Foreign Affairs Kimon Georgiev of Bulgaria have told THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent they saw no hope that the new Government of Premier Themistocles Sophoulis, veteran liberal leader, in Greece would result in improved relations between Greece and Bulgaria.

The Navy and New England residents in the triangle between Boston, Worcester, Mass., and Portland, Me., hunted yesterday for balloons carrying scientific apparatus and possibly information of importance in the study of cosmic rays and mesons, fundamental particles of matter.

When the eleventh New York Antiques Exposition opened its doors at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday afternoon 300 persons were waiting to be admitted. Sixty dealers' booths filled the Basildon Room, the Jade Room and the Astor gallery on the third floor.

ROME, Sept. 28 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi's Government has been greatly strengthened, according to political observers, by the opposition speech delivered in the Constituent Assembly yesterday by the right-wing socialist leader, Giuseppe Saragat.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Retail stores sales in the United States totaled $8,820,000,000 in August, the office of business economics of the Department of Commerce reported today. This was 3 per cent over a year ago as compared with the year-to-year gain of 16 per cent in the first half of this year.

A recent announcement from the Census Bureau shows significant trends in population movements in the United States. The total population passed the 143,000,000 mark in April of this year. The Bureau's report stated that in the seven-year period ending April 7, 1947, the rural farm population shrank by 2,911,000 to 27,305,000.

A long-range development plan for the Hebrew University in Palestine, to cost $15,000,000, was outlined yesterday by Leo W. Schwarz, former director of the Joint Distribution Committee in Germany. Mr. Schwarz, who recently returned from a month's stay in Jerusalem, reported to the directors of the American Friends of the Hebrew University in the Hotel Commodore.

MOSCOW, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- A survey of the Russian press today showed that virtually every printed word about America, even in such publications as poetry magazines, hammers into the average Russian reader the idea that the policies of United States leaders are similar to those of the Nazis.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, has suggested to the Export-Import Bank that it extend ample credit to foreign producers of newsprint.

With parade and song, the borough of Queens welcomed the Freedom Train yesterday on its one-day stay. Members of veterans and civic organizations, accompanied by band and fife and drum corps, hailed the seven-car exhibit of 130 American historical documents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- A proportional decrease in enrollment of Jewish students in United States professional schools was attributed today to increased discrimination against Jews in such schools and departments in a report by Leon J. Obermayer of Philadelphia, chairman of the B'nai B'rith Vocational Service Commission.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Steps to speed up air travel between the United States and Argentina and to facilitate air freight service were made public today by two of the country's leading airlines.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Jerome Herman (Dizzy) Dean pitched the St. Louis Browns to a good start but his relief, Glenn Moulder, weakened in the ninth and the Chicago White Sox crowded five runs across the plate for a 5-to-2 victory before 15,916 fans today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 28 -- National steel operations advanced last week 4 points to 85 per cent of rated capacity from the revised rate of 91 per cent in the week before. Practically all of this change was due to the full resumption of steelmaking plants in this district, where operations had been curtailed by a strike.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Ben Hogan of Hershey, Pa., who earlier this year scorned to play for Promoter George S. May, today won May's second international golf tourney with a nine-under-par 135 to annex the $5,000 prize.

Cardinal Spellman condemned "atheistic communism as an enemy of all men who believe in God and America" in speaking last night to 45,000 persons at the Polo Grounds for the world unity religious service of the Holy Name Society.

A rise in new building construction contrary to the seasonal trend occurred in the thirty-seven states east of the Rocky Mountains last month, when contract awards amounted to $823,216,000, an increase of 25 per cent over July and 21 per cent over August, 1946.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 28 -- At the height of a bitter attack against him and his regime over the proposed Soviet-Iranian oil pact, Premier Ahmad Ghavam walked out of the Majlis (Parliament) today and with a gesture of his hand summoned his Ministers and a majority of the Deputies to follow him.
Completion of the League of Nations cataloguing project by the Woodrow Wilson Foundation has been assured by a continuing grant from the Rockefeller Foundation, it was announced yesterday.
Manager Bucky Harris usually considered to be something on the conservative side, yesterday shattered a number of world series precedents.

BATAVIA, Java, Sept. 28 (U.P.) -- Dutch and Indonesian communiques reported heavy fighting in Western and Eastern Java today and continued skirmishing along most of the Java front despite a nine-week-old cease-fire order by the United Nations Security Council.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Although outpassed by Chicago's Sid Luckman, Indian Jack Jacobs of the Packers climaxed the quarterback duel by slashing around end with six seconds to play to pace Green Bay to a 29-20 victory over the Bears in the National Football League opener here today.
ROME, Sept. 28 (AP) -- General strikes tied up two Italian cities today. Peasants continued occupying untilled land in the Rome area

TO THE EDITOR OF NEW YORK TIMES: There can be no doubt but that 90 per cent of the American people are heartily in sympathy with both the Truman and the Marshall Plan and an all-out effort to block the spread of communism. Inasmuch as there is widespread feeling that war with Russia may result within the foreseeable future, it seems essential to analyze the strength of Russia or any other potential enemy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP) -- A plea for Christian unity was made today by the Rev. Dr. Anson Phelps Stokes in services commemorating the laying of the foundation stone of Washington Cathedral forty years ago.

Loans to foreign countries should be approached with a realistic sense of what they can accomplish, according to a report soon to be issued by the Twentieth Century Fund. The survey of problems of foreign trade and investment was prepared for the fund by Norman S. Buchanan, Professor of Economics at the University of California, and Friedrich A. Lutz, Professor of Economics at Princeton University.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Eagles and Redskins smashed all National Football League scoring records today with the Eagles finishing on the long end of a 4542 count before a crowd of 35,400 at Municipal Stadium.

WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 28 -- An underdog Western side, headed by George Oliver, took command in the third period and went on to hand the thirty-goal Eastern poloists a 9-to-7 setback before 4,500 on the International Field of the Meadow Brook Club today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- High farm wages, high prices for farm products, rapid reduction of farmers' debts and the likelihood of large exports of food have figured prominently in shaping farm machinery manufacturers' intentions to expand production through the final quarter of this year and well into the first half of next year.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 28 (Reuters) -- The Dominion of India's pro-Congress party press was generally critical today of the Pakistan Government's official appeal to Britain and the other dominions for help in solving the communal problem.
The Regional Hospital Plan of the New York University College of Medicine will open today with twenty-four doctors from seven hospitals within a 100-mile radius of New York participating.

Aid to Europe must be implemented by a plan to supply textile manufacturing equipment which will enable industry there to step up production of consumer goods, Royal Little, president of Textron, Inc., declared over the week-end. If the equipment is provided, he said, it will not only mean that Europe will be able to help herself but the reduced demand on American textile manufacturers will bring domestic textile prices into line.
George C. Cichy has teen appointed vice president in charge of purchasing for Brown Industries Company, operators of a chain of Chicago retail hardware stores.

By coming uptown from Grand Street, where it was originally produced last April, Theodore Ward's "Our Lan'" has acquired theatrical dimensions and lost simplicity. On the large stage of the Royale, where it was acted Saturday evening, the theatrical weakness of the script assumes an importance it did not have in the tiny downtown playhouse last spring.

LONDON, Sept. 28 -- The stock markets here were more subdued in the last week, and business dwindled to small dimensions. Investors appear to be groping through various economic developments, endeavoring to size up the value of different measures and policies and their possible results in the next few months.

The fight to repeal the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council is led by "the political bosses against the people of the City of New York," it was charged yesterday by former Assemblyman John J. Lamula, campaign manager of the Keep PR Committee, and Gabriel L. Kaplan, its counsel.
PARIS, Sept. 28 -- Speaking at Mulhouse in Alsace today, Premier Paul Ramadier said it was me for Europe to unite. He even appealed for cooperation with Germany.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 28 -- As a parting shot to the Giants in the 1947 campaign, at Shibe Park today, Manager Ben Chapman unveiled his pitching prodigy, the 18-year-old schoolboy southpaw, Curt Simmons, and earned a split in a twin bill that saved the Phillies the ignominy of finishing in the cellar.

Final arrangements for televising the world series baseball games have been worked out. Under a system agreed upon by all interested parties the three television stations operating in the New York area will take turns in bringing the contests between the Yankees and the Dodgers to owners of television sets.

It is important for the Christian to know his real need, the Rev. Dr. George A. Buttrick, minister of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Seventy-third Street, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

TOKYO, Sept. 28 -- Henceforth the Emperor's familiar chrysanthemum crest will not appear on Japanese postage stamps, Gen. Douglas MacArthur revealed in the official report of his occupation for July made public today. "The Japanese Government," the document declared, "regarded the change in the Emperor's status as making the use of the crest inappropriate."

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 28 -- The probability that Czechoslovakia will have her version of "the Hungarian conspiracy" affair was reported today as increased. The Slovak Ministry of the Interior, it was announced, had requested the lifting of the parliamentary immunity of two Catholic secretaries general of the Slovak Democratic party.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Uncertainty as to Government action in regard to the high cost of living in the face of a possible increase in exports of food to Europe resulted last week in holding lard futures prices within comparatively narrow limits on the Board of Trade.
