FRANKFURT, Germany, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Max Sehmeling won his first fight in a comeback campaign today by knocking out Werner Vollmer in the seventh round of a scheduled ten-rounder. But even in victory he looked a lot different from the battler who once held the world's heavyweight championship.

The natural emphasis that has been given to the recent diatribes of Mr. Vishinsky and the replies to them may cause us at least temporarily to overlook some of the less spectacular but more constructive utterances that were made in the opening debate.

BUFFALO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Striking back savagrely after trailing 24 -- 7 in the third period, the San Francisco 49ers today defeated the Buffalo Bills, 41 -- 24, in an AllAmerican Football Conference game before 36,099 spectators -- Buffalo's record gridiron crowd.

Leo Nadelmann, Swiss pianist new to New York listeners, presented a serious program to an intent Town Hall audience last night. His training in the European school was apparent both in his selection of music and in his performance.

GENEVA, Sept. 28 -- Progress in cleaning up the problem of German assets in neutral countries has been so slow that responsible United States and British authorities are considering the advisability of dumping the entire matter into the lap of the Interallied Reparations Agency in Brussels, it was learned today.
A reduction in air freight rates was announced yesterday by two airlines coincidentally with changes in their operating schedules to conform with the return to standard time and to autumn traffic.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 28 -- Application of "trade-union common sense," without "brilliant oratory" and "flamboyant statements," to the solution of problems arising under the Taft-Hartley Act was recommended today by John P. Frey, president of the Metal Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor.

The net registered tonnage of vessels in the foreign trade of this country increased by 3 per cent during July to 9,250,000 net tons entering United States ports and 8,953,000 net tons clearing, it was shown yesterday in a report by the Bureau of the Census, Department of Commerce.

Eighteen hundred persons have signed petitions urging New York University not to build its new law center on the block at the southwest corner of Washington Square between Sullivan and Macdougal Streets, the Save Washington Square Committee announced last night.

One of the most assiduously cultivated of current fictions is that the nation, in 1946, was enticed into the abandonment of price control through misrepresentation and false promises. It was told, so this popular theme runs, that if price ceilings were dropped, goods would immediately (or very soon thereafter) be made available to the consumer in abundance and at declining prices.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 -- Grain markets staged a strong rally last week. They advanced rapidly from the low prices of the previous week after resumption of buying of cash wheat by Government agencies, killing frost in the more northern sections of the Corn Belt and President Truman's statement on the critical food shortage in Europe.

Prices of cotton for future delivery in the domestic market urned easier last week, with delines especially pronounced in the horter contracts. At the close of rading on Saturday active futures ontracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the week net osses of 17 to 77 points.
Examining the relative offensive merits of the Yankees and Dodgers, there again seems to be a curious jumble of angles to confuse the world series dopesters.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 28 (AP) -- Lashing out with six runs in the first inning, the Syracuse Chiefs of the International League trounced the Milwaukee Brewers of the American Association, 7-1, today to take a 2-0 lead in the best-ofseven games little world series.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 (AP)) -- One step away from the cellar, the Washington Senators wound up their dismal season today with a 5-1 victory over the Boston Red Sox, before 5,238 fans in Griffith Stadium.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- The Arab Higher Committee of Palestine, which boycotted the United Nations' investigation on the Holy Land, tomorrow will present its "three noes" to the General Assembly's special committee -- no partition, no further Jewish immigration, no Jewish state.

The Maritime Commission offered for sale yesterday under competitive bidding, five damaged T-2 type tankers, five former German merchant vessels and sixty LST's (landing ship, tank). The tankers and former Nazi vessels were offered for operation, but the landing craft must be scrapped, the commission said.
CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs closed the season today by defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 3 to 0, behind the fivehit pitching of Johnny Schmitz.

A campaign by the State Labor Department to reduce industrial homework from the high wartime levels has succeeded in decreasing such labor to nearly one-third the 1945 volume, a report by State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi showed yesterday.

Dr. Jorge Garcia Granados, Guatemalan member who signed the majority report of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine, yesterday denounced British rule in the Holy Land and stressed the humanitarian and legal rights of the Jewish people for statehood in that country.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 28 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, expanding on the implications of the foreign-policy speech he made on Thursday at Tacoma, Wash., conceded today that American foreign policy, soft-pedaled as an issue in 1940 and 1944 would be a legitimate topic for debate in the 1948 campaign.
TEHERAN, Sept. 28 (AP) -- An Azerbaijan Deputy, Emani Ahari,

WASHINGTON, Sept. 28 -- Key Congressional leaders were assembling in Washington tonight to hear President Truman and Secretary of State Marshall analyze Europe's economic crisis, and to exchange views on whether a special session of Congress should be called to meet the situation.

Business in the foreign exchange market last week settled in the pattern of its predecessors -- chief interest centering in the pound sterling, Canadian and Swiss free currencies. All other descriptions were lightly traded at no important price change.
NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 28 -- Pakistan may ask neutral observers to aid in solving communal problems, Dr. Zahid Hussain, High Commissioner for Pakistan in India, said today.

In the first rush of its post-war school building program, the Board of Education has let contracts totaling $16,124,109, and early next month it will have twelve building projects under way in four boroughs, it was learned yesterday.

This column on butter cakes is the first in a series of three on cake preparation. The second, on fatless cakes (sponge and angel food), win appear tomorrow. The third, on frostings, is scheduled for Wednesday.

TRIESTE, Sept. 28 -- First Lieut. William T. Van Atten of East Orange, N.J., safe in Trieste after five days as a Yugoslav prisoner, said today that Marshal Tito's troops blamed President Truman for the loss of Yugoslav territory and bitterly opposed the creation of the Free Territory.

The Port of New York Authority has made substantial progress toward physical and financial rehabilitation of La Guardia Field and the completion of Idlewild Airport since June 1, when it took them over, Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the bi-state agency, reported yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 28 -- The United Nations was asked today to end Soviet control over five eastern Europe countries -- Yugoslavia, Poland, Bulgaria, Hungary and Rumania -- before the "brutalities of Communist subjugation" touched off another war.

CHICAGO, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Paul Christman, former All-America from Missouri, tossed two scoring passes and set up three other touchdowns with his aerial work to lead the Chicago Cardinals to a 45-to-21 victory over the Detroit Lions in an opening National Football League game today before 22,739 fans in Comiskey Park.

About $1,000,000 worth of reduction gears, fans and blowers, miscellaneous electrical supplies valued at $505,000, welding machines costing $702,000 and more than 4,000 unused truck and bus tires are among the leading lines of government surplus offerings this week in the New York-New Jersey area announced over the week-end by Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director of the War Asset Administration.

A "decline in sexual morality" is striking at the foundations of society, the Rev. Dr. William E. Purcell, vicar of St. Peter's Church, Maidstone, England, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 28 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark, addressing 1,000 guests at the National Exchange Club's convention dinner here tonight, pledged a continuing war on Communists, Fascists and other subversive groups.

MANILA, Sept. 28 -- Undertaking to forestall criticism of the Philippine Government for signing a treaty of, friendship with Spain yesterday, Vice President Elpidio Quirino, as Secretary of Foreign Affairs, today summoned press representatives to explain the Philippine motives.

CAIRO, Egypt, Sept. 28 (AP) -- Neighboring countries imposed severe restrictions today on travel to and from cholera stricken Egypt as British and United States planes sped vaccine and other medical supplies to help combat the epidemic.

BELGRADE, Sept. 28 (AP) -- The trial of the twenty-four persons at Tirana accused of planning to overthrow the Communist Government of Premier Enver Hoxha with -- the Albanian Government charged -- British and American aid, began Sept. 5.

The following dinner for a family of five totals $2.78, according to a menu suggested by the City Department of Markets and based on the department's survey of citywide retail food prices. The recipe for the soup is appended.

A "decline in sexual morality" is striking at the foundations of society, the Rev. Dr. William E. Purcell, vicar of St. Peter's Church, Maidstone, England, declared yesterday morning in a sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 28 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark, addressing 1,000 guests at the National Exchange Club's convention dinner here tonight, pledged a continuing war on Communists, Fascists and other subversive groups.

MANILA, Sept. 28 -- Undertaking to forestall criticism of the Philippine Government for signing a treaty of, friendship with Spain yesterday, Vice President Elpidio Quirino, as Secretary of Foreign Affairs, today summoned press representatives to explain the Philippine motives.

Raymond Massey, the Abe Lincoln of years ago, will be seen, tonight as a professor of astronomy in a new comedy by Donald Ogden Stewart called "How I Wonder," opening at the Hudson Theatre. The play, the first in seventeen years from the pen of Mr. Stewart, represents the managerial debut of Ruth Gordon, actress-playwright, author of "Over 21" and "Years Ago," and of Garson Kanin, her playwright-director husband, who wrote and staged "Born Yesterday."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- The United Nations Secretariat cannot properly pare down the United Nations budget for 1948 any further, Byron Price, Assistant Secretary General for Administrative and Financial Services, said here today.

Prentice-Hall reports that Lajos Zilahy, Hungarian novelist, playwright and poet, who recently arrived here, has completed a new novel, entitled "Ararat." The book is being translated from the Hungarian by John Pauker and publication is scheduled for next fall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today made public a letter to Olin, Murphy Redmond of New York City to rectify a misunderstanding of its recent action authorizing an increase in commutation fates in the New York City area.

Fourteen tenants of an apartment building at 200 West Fiftyfourth Street appeared yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Court to press a charge against John Markle, manager of the Broadway Theatre, that flickering lights from an advertising sign prevented them from sleeping.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Officials of the Department of Agriculture defended today the 470,000,000bushel export figure presented by the Cabinet Committee on World Food Programs. The officials said the total was "more realistic" than the 570,000,000-bushel figure of the Harriman report, "in view of the domestic economy."
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned upward yesterday and closed near the best levels of the day, with net gains of 52 to 62 points.

New York's historic City Hall witnessed an unusual spectacle last night as a fashion pageant passed through, its halls. The occasion was the presenting of the Fifth Annual American Fashion Critics Award to the four winners for 1946.

Scientists of the American Museum of Natural History, for whom the distant past holds few mysteries, got their first glimpse yesterday of a treasure trove of ancient dinosaur and mammal fossils unearthed last summer. They visibly brightened at the significance of the find.

Joseph Stack's announced plans for seeking reinstatement as vice president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, received a setback yesterday when results of an election of members of the important fifteen-man appeals committee were announced at the union's biennial convention at Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirtyfourth Street.

Police Captain Nicholas J. Gaffney, two sergeants and four of six patrolmen accused of laxity toward midtown gamblers, pleaded not guilty yesterday when they appeared for trial at Police Headquarters.
CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade, in a special meeting today prior to the start of trading, adopted a variable system of margin requirements.

TOPEKA, Kan., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Speaker of the House Joseph W. Martin Jr. said today he believed meetings of key Congressional committees called by President Truman foreshadowed a special session of Congress late in November to consider stop-gap aid to Europe.
William Meyer has been appointed assistant sales manager of DeJur Amsco Corporation, Long Island City, but will continue as advertising manager of the company, which makes photographic equipment.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Cornell moves into the Yale Bowl this week for one of the big Ivy showdowns of the season, and George K. (Lefty) James knows the torture of a coach awaiting the most important test of his career.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Following is the text of the statement made to the United Nations General Assembly's Committee on the Palestine question here today by Jamal el-Husseini, chairman of the Palestine Arab delegation:

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Eddie Dyer, whose St. Louis Cardinals made a spirited but unsuccessful bid to repeat as National League champions after a miserable start this season, signed a one-year contract today to continue as manager of the club.
The war dead from European battlefields will begin arriving in the United States on Oct. 26, it was announced yesterday at the Army's New York Port of Embarkation in Brooklyn.

Yankee Stadium was a bee-hive of activity yesterday. In the vast, empty stands, cleaners brushed, swept and dusted in preparation of the great crowd expected for the world series opener. Workmen were arranging new bunting and flags in the traditional decorations for baseball's annual post-season classic.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Important price changes were few and far between today, with gilt edge issues furnishing the day's most spectacular activity by gaining appreciably on investment demand. Home rails ateo improved slightly.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The recovery by Congress of the "power of the purse," which it virtually surrendered to the executive during the Roosevelt administrations, and President Truman's approval of that return to the Constitutional system are implicit in his statement today on stopgap relief to Western Europe.

The National Electrical Wholesalers Association has begun an all-out promotional drive to secure increased time sales of appliances by special instructions to 9,000 salesmen employed by its 900 member organizations, Charles G. Pyle, managing director, disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Former President Herbert Hoover, now 73 years old, accepted as his "last public service" today the post of chairman of a twelvemember commission which will study how to simplify and promote economy in the Federal Government.
The fashion world took over City Hall last night after one of the strangest days in the history of the venerable structure.

Merging of the National Guard and the Organized Reserves of the Army into one Federally controlled force is urged in an authoritative article by Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, military aide to the President, published in the current issue of The Reserve Officer.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 -- Shortage of housing was declared today, at the opening session of the twelfth annual conference of the National Institute of Municipal Law Officers, to have confronted City Attorneys with their major problem, and responsibility for the situation was laid to Congressional inaction.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 29 -- In the "dangerous triangle" between Nablus, Jenin and Tulkarm in the harsh, stony hills north of Jerusalem, Arab villagers emphatically say these days that they are ready to fight and die for the independence and unity of Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The United States Court of Appeals ruled today that employers cannot be forced to bargain with foremen's organizations. Under this decision, based on the Taft-Hartley Act, unions of supervisors would lose the bargaining rights the courts had ruled were due them under the Wagner Act.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As the parent of two boys, aged 8 and 11, who were deeply disappointed and bewildered at reading that they would not be admitted to the Freedom Train, I wish to protest the action of the American Heritage Foundation in denying to children under 12 the privilege of viewing these historic documents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Eric Johnston, the principal spokesman for the motion picture makers, welcomed today the Congressional investigation of alleged Communist infiltration into that industry. He categorically denied that subversive or un-American propaganda had been put upon the screen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A sharp, formal protest has been lodged with the Soviet Government over a "personal insult gratuitously offered to President Truman" in an article published in a Moscow magazine, the State Department disclosed today.

The possibility of a split in the international labor movement is raised by the reluctance of the International Transport Workers Federation to affiliate with the two-year-old World Federation of Trade Unions, reported yesterday in Louis Stark's dispatch to this newspaper from Washington.
This article on fatless cakes (angel food and sponge) is the second in a series of three on cake preparation. The third column, on frostings, will appear tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (U.P.) -- Following is the text of a translation of the Literary Gazette article by Boris Gorbatov, entitled "Harry Truman," which evoked the United States protest. The translation was given out by the State Department.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The question whether Yugoslav-Greek relations are a threat to world peace should not be determined by a group of private citizens, James F. Byrnes, former Secretary of State, declared today to Sava Kosanovitch in a telegram declining an invitation to visit Yugoslavia.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 29 -- Raymond Hakim, independent producer at RKO, has borrowed Joan Fontaine from her own company, Rampart Productions, to play the leading feminine role in the projected remake of "Mayerling," which is scheduled for the cameras in December.

Productivity of office workers can be increased from 25 to as much, as 300 or more per cent using new machines for standard office jobs, according to leading companies among more than 100 exhibitors at the thirty-ninth National Business Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday.

Plans for a new building at 1 East 100th Street for Mount Sinai Hospital, Fifth Avenue and 100th Street, at an estimated cost of $4,600,000, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. Kahn Jacobs are the architects and Fred N. Severud is the engineer.

The responsibility of building up the supply of the world's fine wools lies with Australia and the United States, it was asserted yesterday by members of the International Wool Secretariat meeting in New York. They estimated that it would take a minimum of three years to build up sneep population to a point where production will fall into line with current consumption of better grades of wool.

The difference between villainy and martyrdom can be just a matter of perspective. From the standpoint of "Shylock and His Daughter," which Maurice Schwartz offered last evening at his Yiddish Art Theatre on lower Second Avenue, Shakespeare's harsh portrait of the villian in "The Mercahnt of Venice" takes on dimensions of humanity and sympathy.

The broadcast of the initial game of the world series will go on the air at 1:15 P.M. today, fifteen minutes before the first batter steps to the plate. Here are the details of the coverage planned by radio and television: Station WOR and the Mutual Broadcasting System will carry the play-by-play account of Walter Lanier (Red) Barber and Mel Allen.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Declaring that Palestinian Arabs would accept neither partition nor a federal Palestine, Jamal el-Husseini, spokesman for the Arab Higher Committee, served notice today that they would drench the soil of the Holy Land "with the last drop of our blood in the lawful defense of all and every inch of it."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration announced today the establishment of a special program of medical rehabilitation for veterans with service-connected hearing impairments.

A large memorial exhibition of paintings by the American Negro artist, Horace Pippin, who died last year at the age of 59, opened yesterday at Knoedler's, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, to remain through Oct. 11. The assembled work occupies three galleries on the ground floor.
ALBANY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today designated Oct. 1--8 a week of "tribute to our newspapers," which he declared were "an indispensable part of free society."

The rayon converting section of Concordia-Gallia Corporation has been sold to Burlington Mills, it, was announced yesterday by William G. Ewald, president of Concordia. The company, which also has been engaged in throwing synthetic yarn and weaving narrow fabrics, is in the process of liquidating its business, he said.

PARIS, France, Sept. 29 -- A second Battle of Verdun, raging for over a week around two sugar barges bound for occupied Germany, was tonight becoming a front rank internal political issue between the Communists and the Government.

With the assistance of Wendy Hiller and Basil Rathbone, a bit of Henry James came into the theatre last evening. Using "Washington Square" as their sourcebook, Ruth and Augustus Goetz call their drama ''The Heiress," which is now on the stage of the Biltmore.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The aviation manufacturing industry, which expanded to produce 100,000 planes a year in the last war, has shrunk to a point inadequate to meet even normal operational requirements of the military forces in an emergency, according to testimony by leading spokesmen for the industry given here today before the President's Air Policy Commission.

Steel and New Freight Cars Just what has become of a large part of the steel that the steel manufacturing companies have been shipping to the car builders under the program to produce 7,000 new freight cars a month for domestic use is becoming more of a puzzle daily.

Store Sales Show 41% Gain Brooklyn and Manhattan department store sales for the week ended Sept. 27 showed a gain of 41 per cent over the corresponding week of 1946, according to the "flash" report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- John L. Lewis was sharply attacked today by John P. Frey, president of the Metal Trades Department of the American Federation of Labor, for his refusal to join with other members of the AFL executive council in signing non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley Act.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- The Women's World Fellowship Congress, opening at UNESCO House here today, heard Senora Moreau de Justo of Argentina urge women to aid the peace struggle by using their vote. They can no longer afford to shun politics, she insisted.
All through yesterday's lazy autumn afternoon the General Motors Train of Tomorrow whisked down the Harlem Valley countryside bound for its first showing here.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29 -- Stating that the time to prepare to fight a depression is before it starts, Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation, called tonight for a program to yield dynamic stability which would include recasting of the tax structure and stabilization of credit.

BIRKDALE, England, Sept. 29 (AP) -- British open champion Fred Daly of Ireland was ousted from The London Daily Telegraph's amateur - professional foursomes match play tournament today in the first round. This thwarted his bid to pick up Britain's two fattest golf purses in ten days.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Fourteen leading United Nations delegates took up for consideration today a program to streamline debates in the General Assembly, but found themselves so badly snarled in their own procedural arguments that they decided --in some chagrin--to pass on the speed-up suggestions to two other committees.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 9 -- With both factions maintaining their positions, the United Nations Security Council came to o decision this afternoon on the admission of Italy, Hungary, Rumania, Bulgaria and Finland to membership in the United Nations.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 28 (Delayed) -- Ibrahim Khajeh Noori, chief of propaganda, told the Iranian people in no uncertain terms tonight that Iranian oil should be exploited by Iranians and by no one else.

Although war during the next two or three years "is not only improbable but impossible," after that time "anything" can happen if we are not prepared," Col. William H. Neblett, national president of the Reserve Officers Association of the United States, told members of the Manhattan chapter of the Reserve Officers Association at their annual meeting last night in Essex House.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- The possibility of a close race between Argentina and Uruguay for election to the United Nations Security Council developed tonight. Although the Latin - American countries, together with the United States and Great Britain, are committed to Argentina, it was understood that Sweden, Norway, Denmark, the Soviet Union and countries in the Soviet bloc might vote for Uruguay.

Sermons for Succoth, the traditional Jewish, observance of the harvest season, were delivered yesterday in temples and synagogues throughout the city, stressing the necessity for solving the world food problem on a just and democratic basis.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 -- Henry Ford 2d, president of the Ford Motor Company, asserted tonight that other nations should recognize the time-tested link between our systems of government and free enterprise before setting out to overtake us in production "by taking unworkable political short cuts and using phony economic systems."

ATHENS, Sept. 29 -- A project to arm villagers and townspeople of endangered areas and incorporate them into national guard units so as to release the Greek Army for offensive action is evolving in the minds of American officials here as the most effective and immediate step that could be taken to combat the guerrillas.

The Queens County Grand Jury yesteday handed up a presentment to Judge Thomas Downs declaring that in its opinion Capt. William A. Davidson, the pilot, "was in a state of intoxication" when the American Airlines experimental plane Alpha crashed in Bowery Bay last Aug. 8, killing him and two other members of the crew."

HUMPHREY SLATER'S "The Heretics" is one of the most arresting and chilling novels to come out of England in a long time. . It really is two separate novels related only in their concern with the same theme. One of them is a moving and quite terrible excursion into the early thirteenth century. The other is an equally grim story about the Spanish Civil War.

Shipments of steel for freight cars for domestic railroads have exceeded the tonnage specified by the Office of Defense Transportation for building 7,000 cars monthly, Walter S. Tower, president of the American Iron and Steel Institute, said yesterday.

Half a dozen Government witnesses testified yesterday that John Santo, international organizer of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, was an active Communist and had attended anywhere from 100 to 200 party gatherings.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- Dr. Clark Kerr head of the Institute of Industrial Relations of the University of California, has resigned as longshore arbitrator under the contract between the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Association, Congress of Industrial Organizations, it was learned today.

The teacher shortage in the city schools, which had bordered on the verge of crisis in the last few years, has evaporated to the point where it no longer exists, the office of the Superintendent of Schools announced yesterday. Instead of an under supply, it was said, there are now 380 persons on teacher waiting lists.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Heavy steers went to a new high price for the year today at 535.90 for strictly choice kinds. Livestock ranged steady to 75 cents higher throughout with hogs up 50 to 75 cents, cattle steady to 50 cents higher, and sheep steady.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 -- The Pittsburgh Building Trades and Construction Council, AFL, representing some 80,000 craftsmen in this area, announced today that it would sign non-Communist affidavits in compliance with the Taft-Hartley Act.

Attack-minded Columbia began drilling for its next opponent, Navy, yesterday at Baker Field by polishing: the high-scoring offense, operated by a backfield which Coach Lou Little has prophesied might be "the best I've ever coached."

The Textile Distributors Institute begins its campaign today to explain the position of the fabric converter in the textile industry. The opening gun is 1100-line advertisement which explains the fuction of the converter in relation to (1) the consumer and (2) the apparel manufacturer to whom the converter renders a customer service that is closely fitted to his seasonal and style requirements.
Judge Clarence G. Galston, in the United States District Court, Brooklyn, signed an order yesterday calling for the discharge from custody of Chief Signalman Harold E. Hirshberg.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- Early reorganization of the Air Force staff was forecast today by reliable sources who said Maj. Gen. Lauris Norstad, Army director of plans and operations, was leading candidate for a new key position.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Christopher P. Mayhew, British Foreign Under-Secretary, today upheld the work of the Paris conference on the Marshall plan as a great advance for the United Nations. Point by point, he replied to Poland's charges that the success of the plan would impede the peace organization.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) --Heard Constantin Tsaldaris of Greece plead for speedy action on Balkan question.

To many English ears Winston Churchill's voice has become that of Cassandra. They listen to his forebodings as impatiently as the Trojans did to hers. But to us he still speaks as a steadfast and trusted friend. It is pleasant, therefore, to find the cloud of his latest and darkest predictions, made before the membership of his own party, pierced by a little ray of light falling on an unexpected quarter.
TRIESTE, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Three men died today when the 2,200-ton United States destroyer Douglas H. Fox struck a mine in the upper Adriatic Sea, eighteen miles off Trieste.

Facing millions of dollars in losses as a result of the eleven-day Railway Express Agency strike, employers in the New York millinery industry instructed their attorney yesterday to invoke the provisions of the Taft-Hartley law to halt picketing of hat factories by striking Railway Express drivers.

Lucy Brown, New York pianist, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. It was her first appearance there in nearly eight years, though in the intervening seasons she has built up a following by many appearances in smaller halls in association with other artists.

PARIS, Sept. 29 -- France, the principal country involved in the stop-gap aid discussed today by President Truman and Congressional leaders, has asked for $150,000,000 immediately and $120,000,000 monthly thereafter until the "Marshall funds" become available, it was stated here tonight.

Reflecting a gain in 1946 sales to $48,525,942 from the $41,831,481 volume the year before, earnings of the Fairchild Engine and Airplane Corporation increased to $962,048 from $688,034 earned in 1945, according to the annual report of J. Carlton Ward Jr., president, issued to stockholders yesterday.
It will be flaming youth on display today as the curtain lifts on the forty-fourth annual renewal of baseball's blue ribbon event -- the World Series.

GENEVA, Sept. 29 -- Brazil has decided to become one of the original signatories of the protocol giving provisional application to the multilateral tariff agreement negotiated at Geneva, it was learned today.

The Port of New York Authority has now been in charge of the city's airports for four months. It is not claiming that any miracles have been performed, but Chairman Cullman in a radio report to the people of New York was able to report significant progress. New concessions are being brought in at La Guardia Airport to increase nonaviation revenues.

The New York City Symphony's concert at City Center last night was enchanting. The composer all evening was Mozart, which was a good start toward felicity. The guest artist was Jennie Tourel, a cultivated, sensitive singer. And Leonard Bernstein, as conductor and piano soloist, directed everything and every one, including himself, with an ear for the fresh, varied and subtle feeling that makes Mozart's music ageless and new.

House in the City That friend of ours who insists that the freedom of the city is the thing for him has dropped in upon us again. It seems he has had what is, for him, a rare adventure in this town, to which he likes to believe himself so well adjusted -- if we may be permitted to use a word nowadays considerably overworked.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Undeterred by a legal move that might conceivably render a great deal of work useless, the Chicago Transit Authority today was preparing to take over by purchase tomorrow Chicago surface lines and the Chicago Rapid Transit Company.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your recent editorial commenting on the critical shortage of nurses will, I am sure, help focus the attention of the public on one of the most vital and crucial problems in connection with the care of the sick.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The question of an early recall of Congress into special session for stopgap economic aid to Europe remained far from being settled tonight.
Random notes: The past week provided fish as well as fishing for those who tried the Jamestown and Narragansett areas, but many who came late found the wind had shifted, as well as the bass.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Sir Stafford Cripps becomes Minister for Economic Affairs, with sweeping powers to coordinate Britain's whole economic policy both at home and abroad, in Cabinet changes announced tonight.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Sept. 29 -- Ernst Greene of Sound View, and Al Brosch of Cherry Valley, the Long Island open champion, put together a 29, 35 -- 64 score to win the amature-pro event of the Metropolitan P.G.A. at the Fresh Meadow Club today.

LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Books criticizing aspects of Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery's participation in the Normandy campaign were answered today by Lord Montgomery himself when he recommended his own book "From Normandy to the Baltic."

Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein confirmed last night reports that he had ordered Health Department doctors who had been on the paid faculties of medical schools to discontinue private work on city time.
The world series visitor who had a room in a hotel last night was a lucky individual.

Frederick Hudson Ecker, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, will receive this year the annual gold medal award of the Hundred Year Association of New York, on the basis of his achievements, particularly in the field of better housing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I agree with you entirely that if censorship is imposed on news out of Pakistan or of Hindu India, every story out of India will be suspect and that imagination will, in that case, replace information.

The ruined Grace Line Pier 57, at Fifteenth Street and the North River, its girders grotesquely twisted, collapsed in four sections yesterday as firemen continued to fight the stubborn fire that started at 8 P.M. Sunday.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 29 (AP) -- An official Indian military spokesman said today that the peak of communal killings had passed in both East and West Punjab and that India and Pakistan now faced the problem of organizing orderly evacuation and rehabilitation of refugees.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- The Navy Department received early today two dispatches from Vice Admiral Bernhard H. Bieri, commander of United States naval forces in the Mediterranean, reporting heavy damage to the destroyer Douglas H. Fox.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 29 -- The real cause for divorce may be traced to unadulterated selfishness, according to the secretary's report of a group which has been discussing Christian ideals of home and marriage at the seventh ecumenical Methodist conference here.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Thomas Allegretti, Chicago lawyer who offered to defend one of the I.G. Farbenindustrie directors before a war crimes court, dropped from sight tonight after publicly defying a United States Army order directing him to leave Germany by noon.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Navy's football team, conquered by California at Berkeley Saturday, flew in from the West Coast early today ready to give eight future opponents "a run for their money."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- President Truman told Congressional leaders today that $580,000,000 was needed in addition to $332,000,000 now on hand to help France and Italy survive the winter months "as free and independent nations," but left it for his conferees to decide whether a special session should be called to provide the money.

A leveling off is indicated in the trend toward stabilization of building material prices and labor wage rates in New York City, where building costs have about reached a peak, according to a survey just completed by the New York Building Congress.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 29 -- Arriving here today from Tahiti, after the 4,300-mile Kon-Tiki expedition trip across the South Pacific on a balsa wood raft, Dr. Thor Heyerdahl, 32-year-old Norwegian ethnologist and zoologist, said his party of six men now had "indubitable proof" of the tenability of the theory it had set out to test.

As a contrast to last week when no mentors were present, coaches of Gotham's top collegiate football squads were very much in evidence yesterday as the Football Writers held their weekly luncheon at Toots Shor's.

Butter and cheese, cattle and hogs, hides, soap, shortening and cottonseed oil whirled to higher wholesale price levels yesterday as all grains pushed upward the full limit permitted for any one day on the nation's exchanges.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The full general committee of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, meeting here today, voted unanimously to ask the membership to authorize a strike of train, yard and road employes of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

The stock market yesterday broke a two-month record or weak Monday sessions and, spurred by a better tone in the pivotal groups, prices rose fractions to a point. The advance was scored, however, on comparatively light volume and the dearth of offerings in the oil division.

Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday appointed four members of the New York City Youth Bureau and directed them to start by making an analytical survey of the work of private and public agencies already active in child welfare. He said the bureau would not supplant any other agency but would coordinate and supplement the work of other groups, and asked the members to draw up a plan for action by the administration.

The Tuesday dinner recommended by the City Department of Markets will be demonstrated at 11 A.M. today at the American Red Cross, 315 Lexington Avenue, by the organization's nutrition service. Consumers are invited to attend.
Contending teams -- New York Yankees, champions of the American League, vs. Brooklyn Dodgers, champions of the National League.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Senator Tom Connally of Texas, senior Democrat on the Foreign Relations Committee, predicted today that a stopgap appropriation could be passed. He said that "under the President's plan, I think the committees could meet by the middle of October, certainly not later than Nov. 1."

Blocks of common and preferred stock of industrial companies will be placed on the market today by underwriting managers as follows: Sommers Drug Stores Company -- 100,000 shares of $5 par value 50 cents cumulative convertible preferred stock at $9 a share and 67,500 shares of common stock at $6.50 a share, by Alex. Brown Sons.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 29 -- What is far and away the largest budget in Argentine history was pushed through the Chamber of Deputies by President Juan D. Peron's majority forces.

Reporting on operations of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., and its subsidiaries in the six months ended on July 31, Bernard F. Gimbel, president, informed shareholders in an interim unaudited statement yesterday that sales of $134,429,719 increased $1,421,003 or 1.1 per cent over the $133,008,716 volume for the corresponding six months a year ago.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 29 (AP) -- William D. Pawley's Travancore, the second choice, came from behind today at Narragansett Park to score by a neck over A. and R. Craig's My Tet Rambler in the featured Quincy Purse.

HAVANA, Sept. 29 -- Army authorities announced today the breaking up of an expedition by groups plotting a revolution against the Dominican Republic. Most of the participants were captured, the statement said. Eleven bombers were seized on various airfields, a Cuban officer said.

11 Housing Authorities The Federal Public Housing Authority announced yesterday that temporary loan note issues aggregating $16,478,000 will be offered by eleven local agencies on Oct. 7. The notes will be dated Oct. 28, 1947, and will come due on Nov.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 29 -- Objections and dismissal motions by seventy individual defendants and Kuhn, Loeb Co. were filed today in Federal Court in the Government's anti-trust suit against the Association of American Railroads, Western Association of Railway Executives, forty-seven railroads, the individuals, and two banking firms.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 29 -- The blast that killed ten British and Arab policemen and civilians at the Haifa district police headquarters and injured fifty-three others early today was set off by a onebarrel ton of explosives placed ingeniously by terrorists.

Cosmic Bomb lasted just long enough to beat Phalanx in the Lawrence Realization at Belmont Park yesterday. Competing in the fifty-fifth running of the mile and five furlong grind for 3-year-olds, Cosmic Bomb scored a thrilling victory over the hard-running C. V. Whitney color-bearer, while a crowd of 25,393 looked on.

Furniture by the Danish-born designer Jens Risom is presented for the first time as a complete, coordinated colection in a new display at Georg Jensen. It is a small group of only twenty-one different designs, but these are sufficient to fill the requirements of every room in the house.
One of the most important legal questions involving public utility rates since regulation of utilities was first attempted went before the Court of Appeals yesterday in Albany for the second time.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Sun-Telegraph today quoted Hank Greenberg as saying he "will not be with" the Pirates next year -- despite support from "at least one of the Pirate co-owners" for his installation as club manager.
The North River waterfront was the scene of intense shipping activity yesterday as six passenger liners arrived from European and Caribbean ports.
ALBANY, Sept. 29 (AP) -- New York State refused today to continue to act as agent for the Federal Government in carrying out the Civilian War Assistance program in the state.

Highlight of the collection of Peggy Roth of 400 Park Avenue, which was seen yesterday at the St. Regis Roof, was a group of wool costume suits in a soft dressy mood. Typical of this fall's full skirt trend was a violet wool dress that had tiers of tucks on its sweeping skirt and was topped with a trim basque jacket.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There is a feeling of bitterness in Denmark because American soldiers still are present in Greenland. I presume there has not been very much written about that question, which at present is the subject of diplomatic discussions.

Argus, Inc. Argus, Inc., resumed the payment of dividends with the declaration of two distributions of 7 1/2 cents each on the common stock, one payable on Nov. 1 and the second on next Feb. 2. The last disbursement was 10 cents in October, 1944. which was the sole payment for the fiscal year ended with July, 1945.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Constantin Tsaldaris, Deputy Prime Minister of Greece, pleaded here today for speedy action by the United Nations to save his country's independence. He said that even while the case was being debated here, Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania were continuing to arm bands of guerrillas that were terrorizing the northern Greek countryside.

According to the advance reports on yesterday's conference at the White House between the President and Congressional leaders of the two major parties, the meeting had been called to discuss Europe's economic crisis and to exchange views on the question of whether a special session of Congress should be called.

Plans to provide school facilities for the three public and two private housing developments, projected for the Lower East Side, at an approximate cost of $6,000,000, have been fully drawn, it was learned yesterday. Under the proposals at least twelve elementary and junior high schools will be available to 16,420 children, including an estimated 7,380 to live in the projects.

MOSCOW, Idaho, Sept. 29 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, announcing that he thought President Truman had presented "forcible arguments" in favor of further aid to Europe, said today that he, too, saw the need for more assistance, but warned that it must be of a kind that would help the stricken nations help themselves.

The need for the unhampered flow of news between all countries and the right to publish the news freely is stressed in majority and minority reports, made public yesterday, of the Sigma Delta Chi Committee on Freedom of Information.

Officially clarifying a problem that has bothered many exporters since Bulletin 413 was issued, tightening export controls, the Office of International Trade of the Department of Commerce has now issued an interpretation of "firm order" as required for the granting of an export license, it was disclosed here yesterday.

Edward T. McNally, who joined the BMT in 1911 as train clerk and telegrapher and has been assistant superintendent of the BMT division for the past year, yesterday was promoted to the $15,001 post of general superintendent of the New York City Transit System by the Board of Transportation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 29 -- Britain, Belgium, Brazil, Argentina and Canada joined today in rebutting Ukrainian charges that European refugees and displaced persons were being recruited for virtual "slave labor" in those five countries.

Burt Shotton, the silver-haired gentleman who was yanked out of retirement to pilot the Dodgers to their fourth pennant since 1900, was quietly confident yesterday that his imminent sixty-third birthday would be made a little happier by his team winning its first world series.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Following are the texts of the letters exchanged on Sept. 25 between United States Ambassador Walter Bedell Smith and Soviet Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov over an article in the Russian press criticizing President Truman:

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Rams geared Bob Waterfield's deadly aerials and unerring kicking to a crushing ground attack for a 48-7 National Football League victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers before 35,658 here tonight.

A City College arbitration board handed down a split decision yesterday in a year-old dispute between the United Public Workers, CIO, and William C. Davis, director of the college's Army Hall, over the dismissal by Mr. Davis of two workers.

Harold E. Stassen, speaking as president of the International Council of Religious Education, appealed yesterday for individual restraint in this country, particularly in food consumption, to prove to proponents of communism that collective force is not necessary to an economic system.

A vigorous approach by the United Nations toward economic reconstruction of the world's devastated areas was suggested last night by Dr. Herbert V. Evatt to lessen political tensions among nations. Dr. Evatt is Australian Deputy Prime Minister and head of the Commonwealth's delegation at the United Nations.

THE Yankees and the Dodgers will collide in the first game of the world series at the Stadium today, a statement that hardly ranks as an exclusive announcement. However, it certainly didn't look as though the two teams would ever simultaneously reach that destination when they first crossed paths in Havana last March.
Former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson yesterday assailed "partisan-minded" Congressional committees that "scare off" capable citizens from accepting vital Government jobs.

VIENNA, Sept. 29 -- The impression that Russia has no intention of negotiating an Austrian peace treaty at the November conference of Foreign Ministers except on terms she knows will be unacceptable has been growing in the minds not only of Americans here but also of the Austrian Government to something like certainty.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 29 -- Registration statements covering 190,049 shares of common stock and 50,000 shares of preferred were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies. Two other concerns planned to defer offerings.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept 29 -- Productive loans for foreign reconstruction should be financed by the sale of Government savings bonds to the public, Beardsley Ruml, chairman of the board, R. H. Macy Co., Inc., New York, proposed here today.

BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- The New York Giants and the Boston Yanks matched touchdowns within the space of forty seconds late in the first quarter, then did not score again in the National Football League inaugural for both teams before a crowd of 21,905 at Fenway Park tonight.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The board of stewards of the Grand Circuit Harness Racing Association today re-elected Octave | Blake of South Plainfield, N.J., president, and E. Roland Harriman of New York, Joseph A. Neville of Delaware, Ohio, Leo C. McNamara of Carmel, Ind., and Charles W. Thellis of Greenwich, Conn., vice presidents. James B. Johnson Jr., of the Castleton Farm Stables of Lexington, also was named a vice president.
The Steamship Motor Carrier Bureau, a unit formed to increase the efficiency of the Port of New York, will begin operations tomorrow, it was announced here yesterday.

United States support of Argentina's bid for a place on the Security Council is in line with Hemisphere policy, which is the rule of the majority. A majority of the Latin-American countries wanted Argentina to fill the seat being vacated by Brazil. The United States is going along.

Joseph V. McCarthy, the fellow who never played a game of major league ball in his life and bounced up from the "bushes" to pilot a National League flag winner and later, as skipper of the Yankees, become the most successful manager in history, will be riding the bench again in 1948.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -- New securities were registered today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

Robert Moses, Commissioner of Parks, who in twenty-five years of public life has survived the intermittent thrust and parry of political fencing, denounced the boss system yesterday, with some examples from his own experiences with party leaders.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Sept. 30 -- Birmingham's vast and diversified industries have agreed on a plan for staggering working hours to spread the electricity load during the winter, it was announced at a press conference here yesterday.

An appeal to members of 1,200 Protestant churches here to be ready to accept Government controls if necessary to provide aid to Europeans was made public yesterday by the Human Relations Commission of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

TIMOTHY PEMBER'S novel, "The Needle's Eye,"* is the ablest example of Communist propaganda in fiction form that I have ever read. Compared with it, most of the crude "proletarian" novels of the Nineteen Thirties seem only hysterical and childish. Mr, Pember's superiority isn't that he is particularly persuasive in his dialectics; he isn't.

The ruling of the United States Court of Appeals that, under the Taft-Hartley Act, employers are not required to bargain with foremen's organizations marks an important clarification of the new labor law. The logic of this unanimous decision is so "unmistakably clear," as the court said of the Act itself, that it seems highly unlikely that it will be reversed by the Supreme Court.

BOSTON, Sept. 30 -- A "well organized resistance movement" of the American people to force the Administration and Congress to change present policy, which he held was leading to war, was demanded by Henry Wallace here tonight.

Delegates of the United Nations General Assembly, meeting yesterday at Flushing Meadow, heard the Pan American Union cited as an example of how great and small nations may live in peace and security under a system of law.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 30 -- Russia is too poor to start a war and America certainly would never start a war, either aggressive or preventive, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, minister of Christ Church in New York City, told the seventh Ecumenical Methodist Conference here tonight.

Winning an art award for the first time, Henry Kallem of 47 West Twenty-eighth Street captured the $2,500 first prize yesterday in the fourth annual art competition, "Paintings of the Year," sponsored by the Pepsi-Cola Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- California told the Supreme Court of the United States that it would be useless to issue a decree regarding the use of the enormously valuable oil-bearing lands in the marginal sea off the coast of that state.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- A Congressional subcommittee on foreign aid that has been studying the British economic situation on the spot during the last four weeks believes that Britain should receive assistance under the Marshall plan, it was stated here today.

Industry has a major stake in raising the general health level in the United States, Frank W. Abrams, chairman of the board of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), told 1,200 civic leaders last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30 -- The Government today moved to end its agreements with private oil companies covering the distribution and sale of gasoline. The contracts will formally end six months from today.

The United Nations is distributing to broadcasting stations throughout the country twenty-second "spot announcements" designed to acquaint radio's mass audiences with the aims and achievements of the world organization, it became known last night.

THAT vaunted Yankee power exploded with all the force of a nickel firecracker in the opening game of the world series at the Stadium yesterday. It was a mild little pfftt, and it had an extremely low decibel content, but those four hits detonated just enough to blow the Dodgers out of the victory column and send the Bronx Bombers, main bombload still in the racks, winging off to a lead in the post-season classic.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month increased slightly over August, but the total was the smallest of any September since 1944. The largest day's business -- 1,257,910 shares on Sept. 17 -- was the only session in which sales crossed the million - share mark.

Swelled by the largest retirement of public utility and foreign bonds in any month this year, bonds posted for payment in September before maturity totaled $322,801,000, surpassing any similar month's figures since 1939, when the total was $383,440,000.

The scheduling of a meeting for this morning between a committee of Shanks Village student-veterans and State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein on the question of the students' voting rights touched off a political controversy last night.

New rules of procedure, which many United Nations delegates had hoped would speed debates in the General Assembly, were referred to two committes yesterday at the Assembly meeting at Flushing Meadow, virtually eliminating their chance of application at this session.

The $10,000 Futurity Trial, a tune-up for Saturday's big-money number for the 2-year-olds, was won yesterday at the wind-whipped Belmont Park by the Calumet Farm's Citation, who turned on the power in the last sixteenth to gain the decision by a bit more than a length.

A campaign to recruit at least 1,500 additional daytime volunteers to meet demands for Red Cross service in Manhattan and the Bronx will be conducted this month, Mrs. E. Rolland Harriman, chairman of volunteer services for the New York chapter, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The international affairs committees of Congress were summoned today to meet in joint session on Nov. 10 to receive a complete picture of the European economic and political situation which has prompted President Truman to ask $580,000,000 of emergency aid before this year's end.

In a letter to Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, the United Parents Association yesterday called for the immediate appointment of at least 300 teachers now eligible. Through its president, Mrs. Rose Shapiro, the UPA said that appointing these teachers from an eligible list of 380 waiting for appointments would aid in "abolishing overcrowding in the first grades and accommodate kindergarten age children."

RYE, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Tuning up for the twenty-second annual women's national senior championship starting tomorrow at the Westchester Country Club, members of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association today held a Scotch foursome event.

Amos J. Peaslee, secretary-general of the International Bar Association, advocated yesterday for the United Nations money-raising powers to make available a reliable, freely flowing medium of exchange to facilitate the movement of goods and persona across the borders of European nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- American Airlines, Inc., petitioned the Civil Aeronautics Board today to permit it and other of the large established carriers to inaugurate Sunday a new air freight schedule based on rates of 13 cents a ton mile.

Those who have been pushing outside the harbor lines in search of coot shooting have not had too much success thus far, but birds are moving in every day. Another two weeks should find the scooters quite plentiful along the Connecticut shore of the Sound.

Harold E. Stassen, the only avowed candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, turned down yesterday an invitation from Marshal Tito to visit the Yugoslav-Greek border as a member of a six-man committee of prominent Americans.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 30 -- After 107 years of campaigns for smoke control, this city began at midnight tonight a full-scale ban on the pall that is so familiar in this area. The measure went into effect without fanfare.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Grain markets made a strong start and a weak finish on the Board of Trade today. Early sales of wheat were as much as 6 3/8 cents a bushel higher than yesterday with all deliveries at new seasonal highs. Corn was up 2 1/4 to 5 5/8 cents.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 30 -- Numerous representative Arabs whom this correspondent has interviewed in recent days have said that they do not intend to pick a quarrel with the Jews of Palestine, but without exception they declared that the Arabs would fight to prevent the establishment of a Jewish state.

Avoidance of another major depression by steadily increasing productivity is the surest means to thwart Communist designs against the American economic and social system, Leo Cherne, executive secretary of the Research Institute of America, declared yesterday.

City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs delivered a strong attack yesterday on the proposed $18,000,000 physical health project designed by Harvey Wiley Corbett, New York architect, as a "living" war memorial for Manhattan.
LONDON, Sept. 29 -- Despite the exclusion of Britain from President Truman's stop-gap aid program and a general lack of business, prices in stock markets here today were firm.

Southern resort fashions made their debut yesterday at a luncheon given by the Celanese Corporation of America in the Cotillion Room of the Hotel Pierre. All were of Jersanese, a fabric which has long been used by this company. Yesterday's Jersanese was new in that it was brilliantly decorated in colorful designs, many of them created by artists well-known in the field of print design.

Without fear of contradiction, it may be reported that the largest crowd in world-series history was the most orderly. Although the 66,365 men, women and children, who occupied every seat in the Stadium and the 7,000 who found points of vantage as standees set an all-time record for the fall classic, disturbances were few, indeed.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- The war-ravaged countries of Europe face a $1,786,300,000 deficit in their 1947 needs for food, clothing, machinery and other requirements, according to a report released here today by Secretary General Trygve Lie of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Sept 30 -- President Truman may call a special session of Congress without waiting for legislative committees to complete their study of Europe's emergency needs if available funds are exhausted sooner than expected or a call seems warranted by any other combination of circumstances, it was stated at the White House today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The United States declared in a note to Poland today that the German bi-zonal level-of-industry agreement between the United States and Britain did not threaten the security of Europe.

The propriety of controlling rents when other costs are unregulated was debated yesterday by Joseph T. Sharkey, vice chairman of the City Council; William E. Russell, chairman of the Metropolitan Fair Rent Committee; Samuel S. Isaacs, president of the Greater New York Taxpayers Association, and Mildred Gutwillig, chairman of the New York City Consumer Council.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, indicated today that the new margin requirements at the country's big grain markets were still insufficient, in his estimation, to curb undesirable speculation.

The Freedom Train arrived yesterday morning at the Van Nest station of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, in the Bronx, where 10,000 persons gathered to welcome it and to hear Borough President James J. Lyons in a patriotic address.

Brooding over the iniquities of life, Donald Ogden Stewart, the Hollywood litterateur, Has written an amiable but footless charade, "How I Wonder," which was put on at the Hudson last evening. Mr. Stewart is plagued by a good many current maladies -- the third world war, the atom Bomb, academic freedom, discrimination against Negroes and also the poor.

BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 30 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio asserted today that there was "no foundation" for reports that he and former Gov. Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota had formed a coalition to prevent Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York from receiving the Republican Presidential nomination.

Three repertory troupes operated by the Virginia Barter Theatre and sponsored by the American National Theatre and Academy will present professionally acted plays by Shakespeare, Wilde and others in towns and small cities throughout the country, Vinton Freedley, president of ANTA, announced yesterday.
Details of a whirlwind campaign to open up new job opportunities for disabled veterans were announced yesterday by the chairman of a new committee of eighty advertising men.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 30 (AP) -- With an unearned run in the tenth inning, the Milwaukee brewers of the American Association scored their first victory in the little world series tonight, defeating the Syracuse Chiefs, 4 to 3. The International League representatives still lead in the series, though, two games to one.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Syracuse has returned to a graduate football coaching staff and has rewarded "Ribs" Baysinger, one of its most faithful sons and finest athletes, with the portfolio.
After a lapse of six years, world series history repeated itself at the Yankee Stadium yesterday as the 1947 baseball classic got under way before a record gathering of 73,365.

Parents, educators and the community all must work together for the better development of children, and youth, it was agreed yesterday in an all-day series of symposiums, workshops and forums by the 1,500 delegates and members of the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers, meeting at the Pennsylvania Hotel.
ALBANY, Sept. 30 -- Governor Dewey issued a call tonight for an emergency meeting of legislative leaders and Cabinet members Friday morning, when he will present a program for state action on food.

TO THE EDlTOR OF THE NEW YORK TlMES: This country by its traditions and its Constitution is dedicated to the belief that the free exercise of reason is essential in the working out of any course of action. Hence it is painful to observe such frequent lapses from sound and fair argument among men in public life and in the press and on the radio.

A well-assembled group of fashions was presented yesterday at Lord Taylor. Well-known designers were represented in the collection that ranged from suits and coats to a special group of important little black dresses and evening wear.

CAMDEN, N.J., Sept. 30 (AP) -- William G. Helis' Jobstown, the only stakes winner of the meeting in the field of eight, triumphed by a diminishing head in the featured one-mile Whitehill Purse today at Garden State Park.

A retrospective exhibition of work by the widely known American artist, Ben Shahn, opened with a preview last evening at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street. It will open today to the public and continue through Jan. 4.

Hunter Whiskey will launch today the largest advertising campaign in its eighty-seven-year history, using 50 per cent more newspaper lineage than ever before. The schedule covers daily newspapers in major metropolitan markets and leading trade publications as well as extensive dealer aids.

We hope there will be a prompt and complete investigation of the frustrated invasion of the Dominican Republic. It should be searching, and should not cease until every fact is made public. The Cuban Government might be wise to call in some official representatives from other countries to help in the investigation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 -- An effort to prevent, through action of the Coast Labor Relations Committee, the scheduled suspension of shipping activities in the Los Angeles-Long Beach harbor at midnight tonight failed here today.
Orvis Brothers Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange, have opened a branch office at 760 Broad Street, Newark, N.J. Roscoe L. Strickland and Howard W. Nichols will be co-managers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The National Labor Relations Board will have before it tomorrow the first clearcut case appealing from the ruling by the NLRB General Counsel, Robert N. Denham, on non-Communist affidavits.

Buyers for Month Up 187% Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,349, compared with 1,325 last week and 1,141 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Federal Judge Edward Conger dismissed yesterday for lack of jurisdiction the suit filed on Sept. 2 by four New Jersey motorists to test the validity of the 10-cent toll that has been exacted since Aug. 28 from motorists using the Saw Mill River Parkway.
"You have to win one before you can win four."

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- The Duchess of Atholl of Great Britain, former member of Parliament, spoke to the Women's World Fellowship Congress today on the systematic organized cruelty that still exists in Europe. She spoke of forced labor, people turned from their homes, concentration camps crowded with displaced persons and political prisoners still being tortured.
PARIS, Sept. 30 -- It is assumed here that the $580,000,000 stop-gap aid mentioned yesterday by President Truman would involve for France the abandonment of all dollar imports but coal and wheat.
Vincent L. Sinisi has been appointed sales manager of the building materials division of the A.C. Horn Company, Inc., Long Island City, a subsidiary of the Sun Chemical Corporation.
PARIS, Sept. 30 -- A military convoy carrying American sugar to the French zone of occupation in Germany pushed through Communist barricades at Verdun today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- The University of Chicago is planning to teach physicians how to treat victims of an atomic war. Dr. Raymond E. Zirkle, director of the school's Institute of Radio-Biology and Biophysics, announced yesterday that classes offering the first such instruction ever presented in the world's history would start here on Nov. 10.

ATHENS, Sept. 30 -- The Ministry of Public Order announced today that from the beginning of October, 1944, until the end of September of this year rebel forces had killed 45,214 Greek civilians, 316 officers and 3,715 men of gendarmerie and police.

Going Back to Noah's Ark Hezekiah Cobb, confirmed countryman and unterrified foxhunter, makes no pretense to intimate acquaintance with the pursuit of big game. He is not addicted to the use of firearms, because shooting foxes is a crime held in abhorrence by gentlemen who, ride to hounds -- even in a Ford or a jeep.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Earl Nelson of Trafalgar House, near Salisbury, Wiltshire, great-great-nephew of Admiral Lore Nelson, died in a Salisbury nursing home here today after a brief illness. He was 89 years old.

The ideal government, as Tacitus, the Roman historian, observed nearly 2,000 years ago, is one which can adapt itself to the changing needs of the times, ranging from peace to war, from domestic tranquillity to social strife, from a state of national depression to one of inflationary prosperity.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -- In a series of orders and opinions, the Securities and Exchange Commission today approved applications submitted by five companies, while two other companies filed requests for permission to sell $13,000,000 of bonds to finance planned construction.

TEHERAN, Iran, Sept. 30 -- The Iranian Majlis (Parliament) finished its debate today on Premier Ahmad Ghavam's national program and will probably give him a vote of confidence Thursday. This would open the way for his "report" on the proposed Iranian-Soviet oil combine, which he and Ambassador Ivan C. Sadchlkov discussed in Moscow.
The play-by-play description of the first game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday follows:

DENVER, Sept. 30 (U.P.) -- Lightning struck the freshman football squad in a field near the University of Denver's Hilltop Stadium today, killing one student and injuring eight students and two coaches.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Cubs' rebuilding program for 1948 was in full swing today with purchase and recall from minor league affiliates of twelve players. Prize catch apparently was Cliff Chambers, a lefty who notched his twenty-fourth victory against nine defeats as Los Angeles defeated San Francisco, 5-0, in, an unprecedented play-off for the Pacific Coast League crown last night.
Questions asked by young women having a first baby receive the latest answers in the United States Children's Bureau's newest publication, issued yesterday.

In the fifteen years since Herbert Hoover left the White House he has performed many public services. Now, at the age of 73, this respected elder statesman enters upon what he says must be his last. He has accepted the chairmanship of a commission set up by Congress to make a leisurely and intensive study of ways to simplify and make more economical our Federal Government.

SEOUL, Korea, Sept. 30 -- Dr. Syngman Rhee, rightist anti-Soviet leader, demanded today the immediate withdrawal of Soviet troops from Korea and the retention of the United States occupation force "until we organize our Government according to the will of the people."
CHICAGO. SEPT. 30 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
ALBANY, Sept. 30 (UP) -- Businesses operating in New York State have reached an all-time high of 530,000 Governor Dewey disclosed today.
Pakistan and Yemen joined the United Nations yesterday, pledging the full cooperation of their Governments toward making the world association succeed.

A walkout by 2,300 workers employed in the thirty branches of the Childs restaurant chain appeared certain last night after two strike votes by members of Local 42, Chain Service Employes Union of New York, AFL.

With the promulgation of four new minimum wage orders, the State Labor Department will complete today its progr of raising the lowest salaries in seven regulated industries a total of $10,000,000 a year. The seven wage orders protect 900,000 workers, although possibly only 215,000 are earning so little as to be benefited directly by the increases in minimum wage.

"Sloppy" Bond Market While the capitalist world ponders the cost of post-war rehabilitation abroad, the high grade bond market here keeps slipping in old-fashioned reaction to the pressure of increased supply of funds.
New issues of corporate and public authority revenue bonds aggregating $74,000,000 will be placed on the market here today by underwriting managers as follows:

ROME, Sept. 30 -- In a speech in the Constituent Assembly, defending the Government's economic policies, Foreign Trade Minister Cesare Merzagora revealed today that Italo-Russian conversations were in progress to re-establish commercial relations.

The first of October is a crisp reminder that a history-making winter is near at hand. The Governments and peoples of Europe are already shivering at the thought of what may happen between now and spring. They dread the coming months for the cold and misery, disease and disorder they are sure to bring.

In an agreement renewing for another year its contract with forty-four Eastern, shipping companies, the Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, agreed yesterday to defend the employers against any possible charges of violation of the supervisory employe provisions in the Taft-Hartley Act.

Two passenger ships from Europe brought a total of 1,918 travelers to the Port of New York yesterday. They were the Cunard White Star liner Mauretania, which docked at 8:45 A.M. at Pier 90, North River, and the Gdynia America liner Sobieski, which arrived an hour later at Pier 88, North River.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Russia's proportion of United States trade returned substantially to its pre-war ratio during the first six months of this year, the Census Bureau reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- In an official document, the purpose of which is to demonstrate that every step in the "foreign reconstruction policy of the United States," beginning with the Truman doctrine, is part of a consistent "pattern," the State Department has attributed to former Under Secretary of State Dean G. Acheson the first public statement of the Marshall Proposal.
Flotations of new securities increased in September, both over recent months and a year ago, with bond offerings the largest in three months and stock emissions the largest since July.

When the office of the Municipal Department of Licenses closed last night, licenses had been issued to most of the 3,178 operators of parking lots and public garages for the operation of their businesses in conformity with the recent local law signed by Mayor O'Dwyer.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 30 -- While moderate Zionists were condemning the terrorists who killed ten persons in the bombing of the Haifa police headquarters yesterday, two lesser acts of terrorism, one Zionist and one Arab, occurred in Palestine today.

Exiled leaders of eastern European Peasant parties conceded yesterday that their plea to the United Nations to act against Soviet "domination" of their countries would be merely filed without debate at this session of the General Assembly.

A long-range program of economic reconstruction that employs a lasting equilibrium between the nation's resources and requirements is necessary for the solution pf Great Britain's economic problem, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York finds in its monthly review of credit and business conditions.

Justice Cortland A. Johnson reserved decision yesterday in Supreme Court, Queens, on an application by Rector Homes, Inc., for a permanent injunction to restrain tenants in the Sunnyside district of Long Island City from interfering with the sale of sixty-one homes owned by the corporation.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 30 -- Strong winds hampered the entire field as the Westchester County Golf Association staged its final one-day pro-amateur event of the season today at Metropolis Country Club.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Sept. 30 -- Appeals for a fair price for coffee as a means of improving the standard of living in the coffee-producing countries of Latin America were voiced here today before some 500 delegates to the thirty-fifth annual convention of the National Coffee Association.

An audience of 1,500 filled Town Hall last night for William Horne's second local recital. The listeners included such celebrities as Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt and John Garfield, and many singers, for, in the eight years since his debut as a Naumburg Award winner, the young New York tenor has done much to rouse interest.
