CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- A new era In Chicago's transit history began today when the Chicago Transit Authority, a publicly owned corporation, bought and paid for the Chicago Surface Lines and the Chicago Rapid Transit Company (the elevated) and ordered its management personnel to take over the properties for combined operation, at 12:01 A.M. tomorrow.

A strike called yesterday by the Air Line Pilots Association, AFL, halted all operations of the American Overseas Airline, which operates between New York and Europe. Starting at 4:30 A.M. pilots and co-pilots refused to take out their aircraft and the walkout quickly became effective at points abroad.

TOKYO, Sept. 30 -- Barriers to the recovery of Japan's foreign trade, occupation officials are beginning to find, have been considerably raised by Britain's Aug. 5 suspension of sterling convertibility. The fact has become glaringly evident that Japan must buy most of the raw materials for dollars and sell to countries having no dollars.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board reported yesterday that it had refused to permit a group of New York workers to withdraw a petition asking the NLRB to "decertify" the union that represents the workers in collective bargaining.

A new group of handprinted decorative fabrics by Donelda Fazakas, noted for her freely drawn abstract designs, was shown yesterday by the Edward Fields Company, 509 Madison Avenue. They are part of a collection of more than twenty-five designs by the New York artist now available to decorators through the concern.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission voted today not to suspend tariffs filed by the Pullman Company, effective tomorrow, increasing certain of its charges with a view to producing increased revenues of $13,000,000 a year.

A business recession, beginning in the second quarter of 1948, is anticipated by 80 per cent of those responding to a questionnaire poll of the 3,500 members of the New York Credit Men's Association, it was announced yesterday. More than twenty diversified industries and services in and around New York City were represented.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- John K. Northrop, aviation pioneer and industrial authority on flying missiles, predicted today that from ten to fifteen years would elapse before perfection of these weapons and that as much as $250,000,000 must be spent in development alone of the heavier types.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at 11 A. M. and installed Byron Price as Assistant Secretary General for Administrative and Financial Services.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Furniture manufacturers were urged today to join other industrialists in seeking to improve the economic atmosphere in which they do business and to tell the story of production.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Sept. 30 -- The American Federation of Labor unions whose members are now working in motion-picture studios have formed a Hollywood AFL film committee to work out a program for the use of motion pictures in labor-public relations.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 30 -- Predictions that scientific research may lift an art as old as the Egyptians from the "cookbook" stage were voiced here today as the Fred M. Locke Ceramic Research Laboratory was dedicated at the Locke Insulator Corporation.

LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The Soviet Government has belatedly accepted Britain's invitation to a conference in London of special deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers to decide the fate of the former Italian colonies, the Foreign Office announced today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 30 -- Marshal Tito is building up Yugoslavia as though he expected "100 or 500 years of peace," but "we prepare for war as though it were starting tomorrow," he said to delegates to a veterans convention that opened here today.
Losing all its early sharp gains, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange turned weak yesterday and closed 37 to 48 points net lower than the day before.

Attendance records trebled opening-day figures at the Thirty-ninth National Business Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday and buyers from more than sixteen foreign countries were among the estimated 12,000 executives who attended the exposition.

Schoolboy farmers who returned to their fifty-acre farm "classroom" at Newtown High School, Elmhurst, Queens, this term earned $40,000 last summer while working on farms In neighboring states, it was announced yesterday. While 230 of the city's farm boys were doing this seventy-five other classmates spent the summer toiling on the modern farm where pupils in the Newtown High School agricultural course received their vocational training.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 30 -- Both Catholic secretaries general of the majority Slovak party, the Slovak Democrats, probably will lose their Parliamentary immunity and be tried for seditious activity, Slovak Democratic spokesmen declared today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Visas to permit members of the Senate Appropriations Committee, accompanied by an Assistant Secretary of State, to enter Russia to inspect the American Embassy at Moscow have been denied by the Foreign Ministry of the Soviet Union, it was disclosed today.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 30 -- The Hurricanes overcame a 5-to-1 deficit in the second half to defeat Long Island, 7-5, in the feature high goal polo match on Cochran Field at the Meadow Brook Club today. Martin Christensen led the winners with three goals.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- After a conference with President Truman today, Gael Sullivan said at the White House that he would remain as executive director of the Democratic National Committee. He had previously offered his resignation, to take effect along with that of Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan as chairman of the committee.

To Ambassador Bedell Smith's protest against the publication of a scurrilous attack on President Truman in the Moscow Literary Gazette, Foreign Minister Molotov replies that "the Soviet Government cannot bear the responsibility for this or that article," and dismisses the matter with this waiver.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Sept. 30 -- A carnival and bazaar being conducted at St. Acdan's Roman Catholic Church, which is the parish church of former Mayor Frank Hague of this city, closed down ahead of schedule tonight when three detectives from the office of Prosecutor Horace K. Roberson ordered that awards of cash prizes at the carnival's games be discontinued.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have just returned from Italy and feel impelled to share with my fellowAmericans some of the experiences I had and information I obtained about the attitude of the Italian Administration, Army and people toward refugees who sought shelter there before, during and after the war.

City Controller Lazarus Joseph announced yesterday that the city has borrowed $10,000,000 from twenty-six local banks on 0.75 per cent tax anticipation notes payable Oct. 20. The notes were sold on an allotment basis.

BERLIN, Sept. 30 -- About half of a sampling of 325 German prisoners of war recently returned from detention by the Russians suffered from hunger edema, a nutritional disease generally regarded as a sign of starvation. This was officially reported today by the Public Health, branch of the United States Military Government.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Our historic American doctrine of the separation of church and state appears seriously threatened, and many of our people are much troubled. The 5-to-4 decision some months ago of the Supreme Court upholding public pay for bus service to parochial schools feeds fuel to the flame.

PAWTUCKET, R.I., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Pinto and Titone's Maidez today won the $5,000 Endurance Handicap at two miles and seventy yards at Narragansett Park. Second choice of the crowd of 5,149, Maidez beat the odds-on favorite, J.H. Hammond's Free Speech, by a length in 3:36 3/5.

In a denunciation of Communist party activity within the National Maritime Union, CIO, Joseph Curran, president, charged yesterday that the party had "ruined" the NMU's organizing ability and "undermined" its ability to defend and improve its wages and conditions.

As part of a double-barreled action under the Taft-Hartley Law, New York millinery manufacturers announced their intention yesterday to seek $10,000,000 in damages from the striking union in the twelve-day Railway Express Agency strike.
Reconnaissance in the form of Navy offensive and defensive formations occupied Columbia's football squad in a two-and-a-half hour practice session at Baker Field yesterday.
The United Nations General Assembly, after electing Argentina and Canada to the Security Council by overwhelming majorities, plunged into a deadlock yesterday on the choice of a successor to Poland.

There's nothing pretentious about it. The speckled alder is just a humble, shrub-like tree that blends well into the environment. It grows along the banks of meadow streams and slough creeks; it shields the pools of clear-bottomed brooks that wind across boulderstudded pastures.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- Battening on Britain's economic ills and the fall in living standards, fascism and anti-Semitism are spreading in London and northern industrial cities.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Sept. 30 -- In plenary session tonight, the Economic Council of the combined British and United States zones of occupation unanimously passed a law under which all livestock and meat products required to sustain the population would be commandeered through the emergency period expected in the next few months.

Ella Goldstein, young Palestinian pianist, played in Carnegie Hall for the first time last night, having a large and enthusiastic audience. Her program included Beethoven's "Appassionata" Sonata, Brahms' Variations and Fugue on a Theme by Handel, Chopin's Sonata in B minor, Op. 58; the first New York performance of "Poem," by the Palestinian composer Rosowsky, and "Islamey," by Balakireff.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 30 -- A detailed proposal for the establishment of a United States Government corporation as the agency through which the Marshall Plan should be implemented, was outlined here today by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y.. Sept 30 -- A report on the critical condition of underfed Polish children has been placed before the Children's Emergency Fund for immediace action, it was learned here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept 30 -- President Truman was accused today by one of the principal officials of the Republican party of "confusion" and indecision in meeting the European aid crisis.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Truman said today following his first conference with Charles Luckman, chairman of the Citizens Food Committee, that the new voluntary program to save American food for European aid was getting off to a good start.
This article on frostings is the final one in a series of three on cake preparation. The first column dealt with butter cakes, the second fatless cakes of the sponge type.

The battleship New Mexico, which cost $17,348,200 to build in 1918 and was completely rebuilt between 1930 and 1934 for an unannounced figure, brought an offer of $381,600 at the New York Naval Shipyard yesterday, where vessel disposal officers opened bids for scrapping of the veteran dreadnaught.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Oaths of office were taken today by Dr. Vannevar Bush as chairman of the Research and Development Board and by Thomas J. Hargrave as chairman of the Munitions Board.

NEW DELHI, India, Sept. 30 -- The Prime Minister of the Dominion of India, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, in a public speech today accused Pakistan authorities of actively aiding violence against Hindus and Sikhs in the predominantly Moselm Dominion.

Fourteen table settings designed by a number of men who take the host's job seriously head the list of exhibits in the "Departments for Better Living" which will open officially tomorrow at Abraham Straus. These demonstrations of masculine homemaking artistry are interspersed among the silver, china and glassware sections located on the fifth floor of the new addition to the store.

Time credits in sterling and francs are being opened by some importers as a hedge against possible devaluation of these currencies, it was disclosed yesterday by S.D. Post, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, in an address at the forum held by the National Council of American Importers at the Hotel Astor.

Big Ralph Branca, the kid from Mount Vernon, failed yesterday in his first quest of the golden grail of a world series triumph, but neither Ralph nor any of his teammates feel that he will fail the next time -- and there is sure to be a next time.

A dozen witnesses before Robert W. Chrisp, who yesterday reopened the hearing by the Civil Aeronautics Board's safety division into the crash of the American Airlines experimental plane Alpha in Bowery Bay on Aug. 8, swore that its dead pilot, Capt William A. Davidson, could not possibly have been intoxicated, as found by a presentment of the Queens County grand jury on Monday.

Prices of the cheaper cuts of meat to the consumer rose markedly in most of the retail outlets of this and other cities yesterday and at the same time livestock prices at Chicago and other markets climbed higher with new record prices paid for steers in Louisville and Omaha.

The waterfront fire that started Sunday at 8 P.M. continued yesterday to eat away creosote-soaked pilings of the destroyed Grace Line Pier 57, at Fifteenth Street and the North River. However, Assistant Chief of the Fire Department Martin Carig said the blaze should be completely out by today.

Employes of the 150 Safeway Stores in the metropolitan area voted last night to go out on strike "at any opportune time." Selection of the strike date was left to union leaders after negotiations for a new contract had broken down at a meeting in the offices of the State Mediation Board, 270 Broadway.

The Nassau Daily Review-Star, Rockville Centre, L.I., filed a complaint yesterday against the International Typographical Union, AFL, charging it had violated the Taft-Harley Act by refusing to enter into collective bargaining and execute a written or oral agreement.
Fashion news centered below the hemline in Delman's showing of fall and winter shoes yesterday at Bergdorf Goodman. The designs followed the trend to high-rising vamps and closed toes.

The delegates to the United Nations General Assembly were preoccupied with other urgent matters yesterday, but in view of their obligation to concern themselves with all-important world events, the following report on the world series is offered for their information.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Truman appointed John T. Kmetz, a close associate of John L. Lewis, as Assistant Secretary of Labor today. He will succeed Philip Hannah.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 30 -- The right of Dr. Judah L. Magnes to speak for any considerable portion of Palestine Jewry was challenged today by a Jewish Agency spokesman. The latter was commenting upon the Hebrew University president's letter to THE NEW YORK TIMES opposing the United Nations Special Committee's partition plan for Palestine.

The stock market virtually completed yesterday the erasure of last week's recession. Prices rose 1 to about 3 points under enlarged demand, with the steels, motors, liquors and oils showing the way, the combined averages advancing 0.78 point.

A new germicidal unit, said to destroy airborne bacteria in as little as eight seconds, was announced yesterday by the Duro Test Corporation, North Bergen, N.J., manufacturer of fluorescent and incandescent lamps. The unit will be produced in two types -- one, to kill airborne bacteria through indirect radiation, and the other to destroy molds, bacteria virus and fungus through direct radiation on surfaces and in liquids.
lrving Maidman purchased the half interest held by his partner, Emil Friedlander, in the properties at 305-325 West Forty-second Street, extending through to 310-322 West Forty-third Street.

OLSZTYN, Poland, Sept. 30 -- Poland is trying to eradicate the German character of East Prussia as rapidly as she can -- and is succeeding. These efforts to Polonize the former land of the Junkers can be seen compressed in the establishment of this city as the capital of what now is the Polish Province of Mazury.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Business activity should continue at a high level for another year despite the adverse influences of high food prices, rising rents, and the threat of further wage increases, Dr. Jules Backman, New York University associate professor of economics, said today.

Coach Ed Danowski gave the Fordham varsity a preview of the type of offense it may face Friday night when he staged a long dummy scrimmage yesterday with the freshman squad using Georgetown plays. The Rams, who will launch an eight-game schedule, lost last year's contest with the Hoyas by an 8-7 count.

At 8 o'clock tills evening the curtain will rise on the first performance of "Command Decision" at the Fulton. Compared 'to other war plays, this one is different in that it espouses the cause of a "harassed officer, a brigadier general in the Air Force.

Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt, member of the American delegation to the United Nations Assembly, will serve as moderator of "World Security Workshop" when it returns to the ABC network (WJZ) on Oct. 5. The program will be offered at 12:30 P.M. Sundays.

The National City Bank of New York announced yesterday that it will move its Rockefeller Center branch from 9 West Fifty-first Street to the new building which the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company will erect on the site of the Vanderbilt mansion at Fifth Avenue and Fifty-first Street.

Seven ticket agencies in Harlem are operating as airplane "carriers" in violation of regulations of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, Jacob Freed Adelman, attorney for nine companies operating unscheduled flights to Puerto Rico, charged yesterday before Federal Court Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30 -- John L. Lewis, president of the United Mine Workers, would be instructed officially by the full convention of the American Federation of Labor here next week to "yield" to the present non-Communist affidavit filing: requirements of the Taft-Hartley Law, under action approved today by the Metal Trades Department of the AFL.
Joseph Freundlich was not among the 69,865 spectators in the Yankee Stadium who viewed yesterday's World Series game between the New York Yankees and the Brooklyn Dodgers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The text of a letter sent by President Truman today to chairmen of the Senate and House Committees on Foreign Relations and Appropriations follows: The situation in Western Europe has, in the last few months, become critical.
LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Assurance that the British Government has no intentions of "freezing" wage levels was given to a delegation of trade union leaders today by Prime Minister Attlee.

The United States, in its own interest, should take the lead in aiding the nations of Europe to rehabilitate themselves, Lewis W. Douglas, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, declared here yesterday on his arrival on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Col. Gen. Vasily V. Ulrich, president of the Soviet Supreme Military Tribunal, said today there was little danger of a new war. But he warned that foreign countries were attempting to send agents into Russia disguised as "scientific, industrial and commercial leaders and correspondents."

CHEYENNE, Oct. 1 -- Senator Robert A. Taft, re-stating his opposition to universal compulsory military training, asserted today that adoption of this system by the United States would "force the same policy on every nation in the world and prove an obstacle to peace."

Stimulated by a demand which reached a million-share volume for the second time in two months, the stock market made further forward progress yesterday. The steels and oils issues with gains of 1 to 2 points fared best, while the combined averages added 0.24 point due to mixed changes in the chemicals, mail orders and films and restricted gains in the motors.

The Vanguard Press has scheduled for spring publication an objectively critical book on Henry Wallace by Dwight Macdonald. As yet untitled, the book is an expansion of two articles about Wallace that appeared in "Politics," which Mr. Macdonald edits.

MINDEN, Germany, Oct. 1 -- Assured the large-scale use of imported ores for the first time since the war's end, German manufacturers are scheduled to ship 155,000 tons of steel products to the Netherlands next year, it was learned today.

Alter a two-hour conference yesterday with State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, a delegation of Shanks Village studentveterans announced they would seek a court ruling on their right to vote in the Rockland County communities where they now live.

Faced by steeply increased operating costs, wine and spirits wholesalers yesterday indicated their feeling that in recognition of their service in distribution, distillers should make some provision covering the wholesaler's higher expenses, since they control not only the price to wholesalers but also, under fair trade, the retail figure.

Mrs. William A. Davidson, widow of the pilot who was killed on Aug. 8 when the American Airlines experimental plane Alpha crashed in Bowery Bay, charged last night that District Attorney Charles P. Sullivan of Queens had blackened the memory of her husband to "divert attention from unfavorable publicity due to gambling conditions in Queens."

The Hundred Year Association speaks the gratitude of all New York City when it pays tribute to Frederick H. Ecker, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company. It awards its annual gold medal on the basis of his achievements chiefly in the field of housing, although his services to the community pass far beyond that boundary.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Air Force embarked on its new role as an independent organization today by streamlining the air staff and sending two of its leading war-seasoned strategists to the critical areas of Alaska and Germany.

"Music in My Heart," a musical play based on a romantic incident in the life of Tchaikovsky, will open tonight at the Adelphi Theatre at 8:15 P.M. Announcement is made that there will be no overture and that no one will be seated during the first scene.

GENEVA, Oct. 1 -- With fourteen new tariff agreements completed, Chile leads all other members of the Geneva trade conference in progress toward the objective of this marathon meeting, according to a secretariat announcement today.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Truman announced at today's first meeting of his twenty-sixmember Citizens Food Committee a goal of 100,000,000 bushels of bread grains saved by this country for European aid in the remaining nine months of this crop year.

The New York State Division of Housing moved yesterday to rid itself of a tenant whose presence in a North Tonawanda development has been an embarrassment to the division and to public housing generally. The tenant is the Mayor of the town, Miles W. Joyce.

DUBLIN, Oct. 1-- Congressman Jacob K. Javits and Assemblyman Samuel Rowan of New York paid a flying visit to Dublin today to take up with Government authorities the question of the high cost of sending relief gifts of coal and flour to Ireland.
The traditional fall moving day in the residential field passed almost without notice in New York yesterday and without any of the congestion and confusion once associated with this period.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Senator William F. Knowland, Republican, of California, urged President Truman today to limit the number of Russians entering the United States to "the exact number" of Americans who are allowed to enter the Soviet Union.

The play-by-play description of the second game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday follows: FIRST INNING DODGERS -- Stanky went down swinging. Reynolds fanned Robinson on four pitches.
C.A. Templeton has been appointed sales supervisor of the Dodge division of the Chrysler Corporation. He formerly was regional manager in Philadelphia.

ROME, Oct. 1 -- Pope Pius today praised democratic government and condemned totalitarianism in a brief address to members of the United States foreign trade parliamentary committee who are here investigating conditions in Italy.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 1 -- Henry Wallace asserted here tonight that James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, Robert Lovett, Under-Secretary of State, and Gen. William Draper, Assistant Secretary of the Army, were improper persons to hold their present jobs because of their previous business connections.

Twenty-nine restaurants in the Childs chain were closed shortly before noon yesterday when 2,300 employes left their jobs in kitchens, bars and dining rooms in a strike for higher wages, shorter work week and more holidays.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 17 to 33 points net higher than the day before. The market opened active, 6 points down to 16 points up, and eased to losses of 5 to 9 points on profit-taking and Southern selling.

Calling the Marshall plan a broad attempt to "buy off" western Europe with loans, Ferdinand C. Smith, national secretary of the National Maritime Union, CIO, attacked the Truman Administration yesterday in his report to the NMU's sixth biennial convention.

To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: The top politicians in both major parties are condemning inflationary prices, but instead of making an effort to give the public relief, campaign speeches are all we receive from them. They seem to forget that with little effort the statutes which require the Government to support the prices of farm products could be modified, or repealed, if an honest effort were made to do so.

New York is a city that offers unusual services -- a Canine College that educates dogs, Proxy Parents that pinch-hit for a missing mother and father on an evening, a Casserole Kitchen that cooks one's evening meal. The newest is Menu Planners, a two-woman firm that maps out dinners for six days out of the seven, lunch for Saturday and breakfast for Sunday at an average cost of 9 cents a week.

Increased sales promotion to develop higher production levels was urged yesterday by Gordon K. Creigrhton, assistant general manager of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, at a luncheon meeting of the National Notion Association in the Hotel McAlpin.

Sir Alexander Cadogan, United Kingdom delegate to the United Nations, asserted last night that the resurgence of absolute sovereignty in Soviet Russia was the source of present international difficulties.
A gun crank with a mild mechanical phobia can turn out some weird products, but one we saw yesterday was turned out by a man with plenty of leisure time and a desire for self-expression.

The city of Baltimore sold yesterday $21,200,000 of bonds maturing from 1953 to 1977 to a syndicate headed by the Bankers Trust Company and the First National Bank of New York at a bid of 100.077 for 1 1/2s, 1 3/4s and 1 3/4s, an interest cost of 1.532 per cent.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Wheat fluctuated in an extremely nervous manner within an unusually wide range on the Board of Trade, opening higher, only to break on selling induced by President Truman's statement that the export goal for this season would be 470,000,000 bushels.

As a result of the drought this summer in Central Europe, some foods may become more scare this winter than they were during the war, Brackett Lewis, executive director of American Relief for Czechoslovakia, declared yesterday.
Alfred P. Sloan Jr. told 800 of the nation's leading business men at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday that no major business recession was in prospect.

SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, Oct. 2 (U.P) -- Australian singles champion Dinny Pails arrived home from the United states by air today and tossed a bombshell into international tennis circles by charging that the Australian Davis Cup team was "torn by quarrels and ill feeling" when it lost to the United States in the challenge round.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Warning that war would be "inevitable" if the division of the world into Communist and non-Communist groups becomes permanent, the Archbishop of York today sharply attacked the Vatican policy "which treats Russia as the chief enemy of Christian civilization."

TOKYO, Oct. 1 -- Japan's major labor organizations have been called into a conference by the Government tomorrow for a discussion of emergency measures to be promulgated as a result of General MacArthur's demand for increased coal production under the proposed legislation for public control of the mines.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Oct. 1 -- Strength displayed by the coffee market at this time seems based "not only on American demand, but partly on the assumption that enough dollars will be advanced to Europe to enable it to purchase not less coffee, but more," Alan H. Temple, vice president of the National City Bank, told the annual convention of the National Coffee Association here today.

A parade of fall fashions, carefully ensembled, was presented yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by the Tailored Woman. Presenting a number of the season's silhouettes, the selection offered by this specialty shop was wide and varied.

Collectors of American Art, 106 East Fifty-seventh Street, will hold its first "open-house" reception of the season on Sunday afternoon from 5 to 7 o'clock at which time Daniel Reed, dramatist and director, will discuss the arts. Three prints already purchased for 1947 distribution to members will be on view as well as a group of paintings and sculpture and a one-man show of paintings by Carl Welch.
Grain prices resumed their upward spurt yesterday, livestock prices edged higher and milk and some vegetables joined the advance of food prices.

BOSTON, Oct. 1 -- More than 7,000 Catholic delegates of the Holy Name Society gathered on Boston Common tonight to start a five-day convention. President Truman sent "hearty greetings" and Archbishop Richard J. Cushing of Boston gave personal greetings.

Demolition on the East Side site for the United Nations, which was started in June, has been at a virtual standstill since Sept. 18 because of a jurisdictional strike between two American Federation of Labor unions over the operation of power cranes.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 -- While management of the public debt should allow the greatest possible freedom in the money and investment markets, the "major consideration" must be the effect of such management on the economy of the nation as a whole, A. Lee M. Wiggins, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, told bankers here today.

John Santo refused to take the witness stand at his deportation hearing yesterday and the Government moved at once to obtain a order from the United States District Court here to compel him to do so under threat of a possible contempt citation.
HAVANA, Oct. 1 (U.P.) -- The criminal branch of the Supreme Court tonight ordered all rank and file members of the broken up expeditionary force against the Dominican Republic released tomorrow.

Removal of taxes on business machines was stressed by individual exhibitors yesterday at the National Business Show at Grand Central Palace. They emphasized this step as one of the most urgently needed changes in governmental policy.

Superintendent of Insurance Robert E. Dineen has announced the withdrawal of approval of fifteen policy forms in use by seven insurance companies writing accident and health insurance in this state. The action was directec principally at operations of the companies affected in Harlem and certain sections of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Truman was told by his Council of Economic Advisers today that the inflationary price situation was an undoubted interruption in the adjustment of United States economy to post-war conditions.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Mrs. John T. Lawless of Greenwich, Conn., last year's runner-up, and Miss Katherine Foster of Westerly R.I., competing in the event for the first time, tied for the lead after the initial round of the United States Senior Women's Golf Association championship over the south course of the Westchester Country Club today.

The city's annual observance of Fire Prevention Week will begin tomorrow noon when Mayor O'Dwyer reads an official proclamation from the steps of City Hall, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle announced yesterday. During the week, which will end Oct. 10, demonstrations of fire fighting technique will be staged by the Fire Department in each of the city's five boroughs.

The question of the Italian colonies, left in suspense when the peace treaty was agreed on, is now up for decision. After the usual delay the Soviet Government has at last consented to discuss the matter at a meeting of deputies of the Big Four to open in London on Friday.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Three American Congressmen, paying tribute to "one of the greatest democrats of all time," laid a huge wreath today on the unmarked grave in Sofia, Bulgaria, of Nikola Petkov, executed nine days ago by the Communist-led Bulgarian Government, a reliable informant disclosed.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 1 -- Mrs. Harry McNaughton of the Seawane Harbor Club shot 41, 39 -- 80 to win low gross honors in the one-day tournament of the Women's Long Island Golf Association at the Sands Point Club today.

Patients in eighty-nine of New York's private hospitals are receiving at least basic nursing care, medical officials yesterday assured the public, although there is still a nation-wide shortage of nurses.

A record net profit of $21,132,358 for the fiscal year ended on June 30 was reported yesterday by United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., textile producers and factors, in the annual report to stockholders.

The Motion Picture Export Association announced yesterday that its directors had voted unanimously to "reject" proposals by the Danish Government under which "drastic financial limits" would be imposed on the volume of film business by American companies.

Margin Trading The New York Stock Exchange has resumed margin trading in stocks selling on the Exchange between $5 and $10 a share. The new rule, approved by the board of governors last Friday, marks the return of margins after an absence of two and one-half years.

EAST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 1 -- Three hundred veterans of World War II and their families moved into as many new homes today in a community known as Island Trees. When completed in 1948, it will be the largest development of its kind in the United States.

Three prizes and two honorable mentions were awarded yesterday for the best floral arrangements in antique containers at the New York Antiques Exposition, WaldorfAstoria Hotel. The judging was done "by three members of the Garden Club of America.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Oct. 1 (Aneta) -- During the week ended Sept. 19 a total of 140 vessels entered this port, while 137 departed, compared with 148 and 173 respectively the previous week, according to official reports published here today.

To the editor of the new york times: An attack on the nation's forty-hour work week law as an "economic straitjacket" was recently launched by Columbia University Prof. Paul H. Nystrom, appearing before a joint Congressional committee investigating high prices in the East.

Appointment by President Truman of Dr. Frank P. Graham, president of the University of North Carolina, as the United States member of the Three Nation Security Council Committee that will attempt to conciliate the conflict between the Netherlands Indies Government and the Republic of Indonesia completes a distinguished international panel.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Sunnyside, the Washington Irving home here that has been restored through $500,000 in Rockefeller benefactions, was opened for preview today in preparation for formal opening to the public Sunday.

The Chase National Bank, in its statement of condition on Sept. 30, reported yesterday total resources of $4,917,683,000, which was about $100,000,000 more than the $4,814,277,000 shown on June 30. A year ago the bank showed total resources of $5,010,436,000.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 1 (AP) -- The warden and four white guards at a Georgia highway prison camp were charged today, in a Federal court indictment under the civil rights statutes, with depriving eight slain negro convicts of their lives without due process of law.

Tyler S. Rogers, president of the Producers Council, National Association of Manufacturers of Building Materials and Equipment, yesterday called on the Federal Government to give all possible aid to the movement to standardize sizes of building supplies.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 1 -- Champion Rock Ridge Night Rocket, Bedlington terrier belonging to Mr. and Mrs. William A. Rockefeller of Greenwich, continued on the victory road today by getting best in show at the sixty-second Danbury Fair dog competition.

Capture of Chefoo by Nationalist troops may prove a more impressive victory for the Chinese Government than the fall of Yenan, the Communist capital. The occupation of Yenan was largely a token victory, for Chiang Kai-shek's advancing army merely moved in as the Communists, avoiding battle, retreated into the hinterland to re-form their ranks.

ROME, Oct. 1 -- Speaking in the Constituent Assembly this afternoon Minister of Industry Giuseppe Togni said that Italian industrial production, which was only 42 per cent of the pre-war level in February, 1946, had risen to 68 per cent in June of this year.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 1 -- One of the highest British officers in the Palestine police refused to give evidence today in the murder trial of a former subordinate, a young British war hero, on the ground that he might tend to incriminate himself.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- The Soviet Union cast two more vetoes -- its twenty-first and twentysecond -- in the Security Council here today and thereby blocked the admission of Italy and Finland to the United Nations.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Milwaukee's Brewers cashed in on Heinz Becker's big bat and some wobbly Syracuse fielding tonight to defeat the Chiefs, 6 to 4, and square the little world series between the American Association and International League at two games apiece.

Increases of more than $50,000,000 each in total resources and deposits are shown in the statement of condition of Guaranty Trust Company of New York as of Sept. 30, issued yesterday. Holdings of United States Government obligations were only slightly altered, but investment in loans and bills revealed a sharp rise.

Despite profitable operation of four subsidiaries, Lockheed Aircraft Corporation reported for the six months ended with June a net loss of $4,890,694 after taking into account a capital gain of $6,482,488 growing out of the disposal of certain fixed assets no longer needed in manufacturing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- C. Bedell Monro announced today his resignation as president of PennsylvaniaCentral Airlines (Capital Airlines) and the election of J.H. (Slim) Carmichael, a longtime pilot and the company's executive vice president, as his successor.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at 11:15 A.M. at Flushing Meadow, Queens, and postponed further voting for third vacancy in Security Council when deadlock over Ukraine and India remained on ninth ballot.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Roger F. Murray, an officer of the Bankers Trust Company of New York and a member of the Air Coordinating Committee of 1945, said here today that the armed services were neglecting plans for industrial mobilization of air power in future crises.

TOKYO, Oct. 1 -- Perhaps the most liberal expression of British sentiment toward Japan since the surrender was made before the Allied Council today by Patrick Shaw, new British Commonwealth member. Speaking of Japan's economy following the peace treaty, Mr. Shaw declared:

The five Democratic county leaders in New York met yesterday in the law offices of Edward J. Flynn, 60 East Forty-second Street, and decided unanimously to go all out for repeal of the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council.

The Department of Commerce yesterday rejected a proposal that this would be a favorable time for a Government-sponsored drive to increase sagging American exports, and made the counter-suggestion that both exporters and importers make every effort to promote imports into this country to enlarge foreign dollar reserves.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Christiana Stable's Sea Snack, only filly in a field of seven, drove to a length victory today over Shamrock Stable's Air Patrol -- the favorite -- in the twenty-ninth running of the Capital Handicap at Laurel race course.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Marriner S. Eccles, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that with "strong inflationary pressures in the economy," Government spending cannot continue as in the past "without severe costs and risks."

Off to a slow start early in the month, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores during September wound up with a gain of 19 per cent over the same month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Lamotte T. Cohu, president of Transcontinental Western Air, Inc., has been elected chairman of the executive committee, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board of directors. Committee members include Warren Lee Pierson, chairman, Noah Dietrich, director, and A. V. Leslie, director and vice president and treasurer.
BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 1 -- The Conservative party will begin its sixty-eighth annual conference here tomorrow.

NANKING, Oct. 1 -- The Government announced that Chefoo, main Communist port in Shantung, had fallen to the Nationalists today. The victory came after a week of sea and air bombardments that left fires burning in the city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Sept. 24, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Hanson W. Baldwin, military analyst of THE NEW YORK TIMES, declined yesterday "with some regret" the invitation of Marshal Tito to be a member of a six-man committee of prominent Americans to investigate the Yugoslav-Greek border question.

Technical advances in the art of warfare make a reserve of trained manpower more important than ever before, Maj. Gen. John W. Leonard, commander of the Armored Center at Fort Knox, Ky., said last night.

Hat Shipments Resumed Removal of striking truckmen pickets from streets in New York's millinery manufacturing district has made it possible to resume hat shipments to the trade, it was learned yesterday. Manufacturers indicated that they would use fast freight and local forwarders to make up lost time in getting out seasonal hats.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 -- Stagnation began settling down over the vast waterborne freight commerce of Los Angeles and Long Beach harbors today on the first day of the labor dispute over freight handling on or off ships.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 1 -- Another South Slav Peasant leader was put on trial here today on charges of espionage and treason. Dragolub Yovanovitch, leader of the Serb Peasant party, former Opposition Member of Parliament and former secretary of the National Front who was arrested on May 15, came up this morning before the Serbian Supreme Court in the presence of the same judge who presided at the trial of Gen. Draja Mikhailovitch.

Underwriting stand-by transactions involving a preferential offering of $19,910,100 of preferred stock to stockholders of the American Brake Shoe Company and the exchange refunding of $13,000,000 of preferred stock of the Kentucky Utilities Company will become effective today.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians: plans to lift the ban which he had imposed on concerts by the Rochester Civic Orchestra over the new Continental FM network. He stressed yesterday that his contemplated action should not be regarded as precedent for FM but rather was the result of special conditions applying to the particular series of concerts.
HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- The last bastion of the double wingback formation has surrendered.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Manufacturers' sales and the book value of their inventories increased during August, the Office of Business Economics, Department of Commerce, reported today.

Edward C. Maguire, Coordinator of Motion Picture Production Industry for Mayor O'Dwyer, asserted last night that private capital and real estate concerns were prepared to offer either a large building or a seventeen-acre plot of land to major motion picture companies for film production in this city.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The chief attraction in the stock markets here today was the reopening of the market in dollar securities. Actual business was small, but the volume of inquiries received by brokers suggests that public interest will broaden when the market settles down.

Gearing up industrial production to "preserve world peace by instant preparedness for push-button warfare," was the keynote of panel discussions in morning and afternoon sessions of the Army Ordnance Association yesterday. Six new important business and industrial policy changes to sharpen up industrial preparedness plans were suggested to more than 600 business executives by leaders in ordnance planning activities.

The French Line, which a year before the start of World War II employed between 7,500 and 8,500 seafarers on its passenger and freight ships, is served by more than 5,500 officers and crew members now, it was reported here yesterday.

The Board of Education approved yesterday plans for the construction of two new school buildings and an addition to another at an estimated cost of $4,001,000. Also approved was the submission of plans for modernizing facilities at four other schools estimated to cost $186,000.
The Dodgers did not get lost in the Yankee Stadium yesterday. Instead, the entire arena crashed right down on their heads.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President Truman's remarks to the opening session of the Citizens' Food Committee at the White House and the reply of Charles Luckman, the committee chairman. PRESIDENT TRUMAN This group of distinguished citizens has met to consider the grave food problem facing the world today.

Confronted by a renewed deadlock over the election of a successor to Poland on the United Nations Security Council, the General Assembly yesterday suspended its plenary sessions at Flushing Meadow and decided to resume its work in committees at Lake Success, starting today.

IN the next few weeks a good many persons are going to point their fingers at their friends and other bystanders and say "Zotz!" The pointers will be mostly Book-of-the-Month Club parishioners who have just received Walter Karig's book by that name* as half of a dual selection. The mystic word and gesture, to the initiated, carries lethal power.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The United States resumed full diplomatic relations with Bulgaria today.

A campaign goal of $15,000,000 to sustain its activities through June 30, 1948, was announced yesterday by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, which cited unprecedented operational costs in its hospitals and social welfare agencies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The National Labor Relations Board will overrule Robert N. Denham, NLRB general counsel, on the nonCommunist affidavit issue, it was reported today on high authority.

Nobody was saying anything about it openly, but the feeling among the Yankees was that they would sweep the Dodgers into defeat in the world series in four straight games. And, after what had happened at the Stadium yesterday, who except a last-ditch Brooklyn rooter could dispute them?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- President Truman urged formally today the calling of key Congressional committees "at the earliest possible date" to prepare measures for providing stop-gap relief to western Europe. He coupled his urgent request, made to the chairmen of the four international affairs and appropriations committees, with this warning:

NEW DELHI, India. Oct. 1 -- Tomorrow throughout India many millions will observe the seventyninth birthday anniversary of Mohandas K. Gandhi, to whom most of the credit is given for bringing India "freedom" through "non violence."

Secretary of Defense James Forrestal gave a blanket answer last night to the Russian charges, voiced recently by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, that American big business is seeking war. Mr. Forrestal, addressing a dinner meeting of the Army Ordnance Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, called the charge, and the premise offered to support it, "utter nonsense."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 1 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission today sanctioned the distribution by Cities Service Power and Ligtit Company of a special fund of approximately $100,000 to five officers and directors of the company and its parent, Cities Service Company.

The nation's gasoline stocks increased by 485,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the weekend they amounted to 82,472,000 barrels, compared with 81,987,000 a week earlier and 86,813,000 on Sept. 28, 1946.
Hank Behrman, slim, blond right-hander of the Dodger pitching staff, probably is the most widely quoted player on either world series team this morning.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 1 -- Painting a gloomy picture of world suspicion and distrust, Colgate Whitehead Darden Jr., inaugurated today as third president of the University of Virginia, called upon American colleges and universities to supply active leadership to make world, peace possible.

None of the war plays has come to the point so sharply as "Command Decision," which was acted with tautness and precision at the Fulton last evening. Going back to the bombardment groups that blasted Germany before the invasion, William Wister Haines has looked into the tortured mind of a division commander and dramatized the agony involved in making decisions that would cost the lives of American crews.
Columbia's football squad went through a full-scale scrimmage at Baker Field yesterday, preparing a tricky attack for its game with Navy at Annapolis Saturday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 1 -- Latin-American countries are expected to contribute $20,000,000 to the Children's Emergency Fund and virtually assure that the relief organization will obtain its full monetary goal, officials of the Fund predicted today.

Britain will pull through her difficulties and will remain a democracy, Viscount Jowitt, Lord Chancellor of Great Britain, assured 500 members of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York last night. He spoke at a special meeting in his honor in the association building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 1 -- If true to its spiritual heritage, Methodism today will call for a holy crusade, not against Russia, but against hunger, poverty, racial discrimination and inequality of opportunity, the Rev. Dr. Ernest Fremont Tittle of Evanston, Ill., told the Ecumenical Methodist Conference here tonight.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- The Communist party in Britain no longer wastes time describing the glories of the Soviet fatherland to British workers. Instead, according to one of its important officials, its propaganda tells "what stinkers Americans are."

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Rayon goods inventories which are on order but not in the hands of consumers constitute a bearish factor in the textile market, it was pointed out here today by Jackson Spears, vice president and director of National Mallinson Fabrics Corporation in an address before the Chicago Wash Dress and Apparel Association in the Hotel Palmer.

A preview of Vita Vision, a new photographic process for taking "three-dimensional" portraits, was held yesterday at Macy's for representatives of the motion picture industry and department stores all over the country.

About the time the Yankees Were completing their mop-up of the gentlemen from Brooklyn yesterday, the favorite in the $25,000 added Vosburgh Handicap at Belmont Park was in the process of routing his opposition.

BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- The growing protests on the part of the Germans against the impending dismantling of factories for reparations were answered emphatically and succinctly today by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor.

Arthur Schutzer, State executive secretary of the American Labor party, yesterday attacked the City Board of Elections for rejecting the certificate of nomination naming Victor Rabinowitz as the Labor party candidate for Representative in the Fourteenth Congressional District and accused the board's Democratic and Republican members of trying to keep the people from voting.

Implementing its program for the improvement of public education, health, world understanding and parent and family life education, the New York State Congress of Parents and Teachers adopted yesterday a broad platform of action for the coming year.

THE world series represents baseball in its ultimate state, the attainment of the very pitch of perfection. The fine, clean-limbed American boys, champions all, rise to heights of superlative play with yeoman feats both afield and at bat. Oh, yeah?

BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- In the first known incident of its kind the United States has carried to the Allied Control Council a protest against sharp criticism of the United States Military Government by a high Soviet official. The Russian told a German audience that United States capital was supporting a drive to another war and "criminal actiivity" in the economically combined United States and British zones.

Injuring three men, one severely, the weakened sixty-foot-high facade of the fire-swept Grace Line Pier 67 at Fifteenth Street and the North River collapsed inward at 9:45 o'clock yesterday morning, adding a huge mound of rubble to the debris left by the still-smoldering flames that have caused damage of $5,000,000 since Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- A seminam in search of maximum security for the American family, unprecedented in purpose and scope, will be held at the White House next year with the support of 110 national organizations, it was announced today.

The suggestion of the President's military aide, Maj. Gen. Harry H. Vaughan, that the present National Guard and Army Reserve organizations result in unnecessary and wasteful duplication and that some plan for their unification should be worked out is one that should be thoroughly explored, perhaps by a Presidential commission.

Many trade responses were reported yesterday to publication of the business outlook survey of the New York Credit Men's Association, copies of which were mailed last night to members of the organization.

Bowing to the threat of $10,000,000 in damage suits under the Taft-Harttey Law, striking Railway Express Agency drivers withdrew their secondary picket lines yesterday from the midtown millinery district.
The possibility that the National Mediation Board may intervene in the two-day-old strike of pilots that has grounded all American Overseas Airline planes throughout the world was seen yesterday.

ROTTERDAM, Oct. 1 (Aneta) -- The 21,500-ton luxury liner, Willem Ruys, new flagship of the Rotterdam Lloyd, weighed anchor today at Vlissingen for her first trial spin in the North Sea. The final technical trial cruise is scheduled to take place in the Bay of Biscay in November.

One of the two or three remaining large private collections of Washingtoniana, covering every phase of the first President's adult life, will be dispersed at auction on Oct. 17 and 18 at the Kende Galleries of Gimbel Brothers.

A first-mortgage loan of $750,000 at 3 per cent interest for ten years was obtained by the Dorsil Real Estate Enterprises, Inc., from a New York savings bank on the business property at 52-62 East Fourteenth Street, southeast corner of Broadway.
Boys and girls at Seward Park, site of the old Rutgers Farm on East Broadway at Jefferson Street, put down their spades and rakes yesterday and harvested eleven crops of vegetables.
The consolidated net income of the American Gas and Electric Company and its consolidated subsidiaries for the twelve months

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 2 (AP) -- The C.F. Mueller Company, spaghetti products manufacturers, organized as a $1,000,000 New Jersey profit corporation has become a non-profit Delaware concern with all income earmarked for the New York University Law School.

It was physically impossible for the Flatbush fans to match the attendance figures of the first two games at the Stadium. Ebbets Field just does not have the capacity. But, where the faithful Flock missed numerically, the enthusiasm of the 33,098 fortunate enough to gain admittance yesterday was obviously more feverish than it had been in the Bronx.

Massenet's "Werther," an opera which ordinarily does not profit by transplantation from its native French soil, was revived last night by the New York City Opera Company in the City Center and was received with exceptional enthusiasm by a big audience.

Eight hundred Protestant Christian education leaders yesterday heard several speakers emphasize the need for bringing 500,000 children of Protestant lineage here back into the church during a citywide conference at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fiftyfifth Street.

Price-conscious consumers from New York to San Francisco scored a resounding victory yesterday against one of the leaders of the food price spiral, butter, although the price level of basic commodities continued to advance; hog and cattle prices climbed again and grain prices gyrated.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The letter of the Rev. William H. Melish in your issue of Sept. 22, in reply to my letter in your issue of Sept. 11, calls for a brief comment.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 2 -- For five years scientists of the University of California, using laboratory animals, have been patiently drawing a picture of the biological effects of radioactivity from fission products.
The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, the pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, has declined a $2,000 increase in his salary, it became known yesterday.

Expectation was voiced in the distilling industry here yesterday that in the program being developed by the Luckman committee to conserve foods for relief of needy countries the liquor group will be among the first to be called into conference, possibly within a week.

ROME, Oct. 2 -- Guglielmo Giannini, leader of the Common Man Front, put in a bid tonight for the inclusion of his party in the Cabinet and threatening to vote against the Government if his demand is rejected. In a speech in the Constituent Assembly he laid claim for himself to the post of "Minister of European Unification," which he proposed should be created.

LONDON Oct. 2 -- A warning against the permanent monopoly of the atomic bomb by any nation was sounded here today by the Archbishop of York, Dr. Cyril Garbett in the final of his seven visitation lectures. He added, however, that "if one nation must have monopoly of this fearful weapon for a time then I agree it is well it should be the United States."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian External Affairs Minister, proposed today that the United Nations Economic and Social Council should review the world economic situation at each session, on the ground that economic threats to the peace required as timely action as military dangers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Department store sales in the week ended Sept. 27 were 24 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 2 -- "Indian Summer," with Ann Sothern and Alexander Knox, and "Out of the Past," with Robert Mitchum and Jane Greer, will be among the completed films which RKO is selling to the United Artists distrubuting corporation, it was learned today from an unofficial source.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Tom Neill smashed a home run over the right field fence, scoring Danny Murtaugh ahead of him in the ninth inning tonight to give the Milwaukee Brewers of the American Association a 6 to 5 victory over the Syracuse Chiefs of the International League and a three games to two edge in the Little World series.

One hundred and fifty retail food stores of the Safeway chain were closed by the company last night after union officials had refused to promise that they would give seven days' advance notice before calling a strike of the chain's 1,400 employes in the metropolitan area.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Food allocations to assist 4,155,000 needy children in twelve European countries and China were submitted to the Children's Emergency Fund here today by its ninenation program committee.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 2 -- The hapless natives of Bikini, uprooted once to make way for the atomic bomb tests, will be transplanted once again from their present home on Rongerik Island because they are "defeated, frustrated, poverty-stricken and hungry," a spokesman for the trust territory of the Pacific islands has announced.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 6,000 head, total 9.500; general market fairly active. 25 to 50 cents higher but closing slow with an estimated 1,000 head held over: sows very uneven, steady to 50 cents higher; ...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Charles Luckman, chairman of the Citizens Food Committee, Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson and Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman continued their conferences today on the new voluntary campaign to save food to aid Europe.

Nationalization of the American shipping industry if shipowners continue to maintain that they are unable to pay "decent" wages to seamen owing to low-cost foreign competition, was urged yesterday by Howard C. McKenzie, vice president of the National Maritime Union, CIO.

Bank of New York The Bank of New York reported as of Sept. 30 total deposits, including certified and official checks, of $315,519,565 and total assets of $347,937,538, compared, respectively, with $328,423,711 and $360,366,154 of June 30.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- New construction scored a better than seasonal gain during September, the Commerce Department reported today.

A further high record was set in borrowings of a commercial, industrial and agricultural nature from the New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System during the week ended last Wednesday. Figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed an expansion of $78,000,000 in such loans to a record mark of $4,675,000,000, or more than double the rise reported in the previous week.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe refused yesterday to strike out a request by the State Department that judicial recognition be given to the claim of immunity by the Dutch East Indies Government from the $3,087,241 damage action filed by the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company, Inc.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- The grain markets reversed their action on the Chicago Board of Trade today, opening higher with December, March and May wheat selling at a new seasonal high only to break the permissible limit of 10 cents from yesterday's close shortly before trading ceased, and corn and soy beans were down 8 cents at the extreme, also off the permissible maximum.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Herbert Hoover's suggestion that seventyfive war-built Liberty ships be turned over to Germany for the transportation of relief supplies from the United States was attacked by the National Federation of American Shipping today as short-sighted and ill-advised.

The American Friends of the Hebrow University, Inc., has acquired the six-story and penthouse residential property at 9 East Eighty-ninth Street from the Asia Institute and will use the property as its permanent home to serve as a coordinating center of activities and information.

The semi-annual statement of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and its subsidiaries, issued yesterday to shareholders by Sosthenes Behn, chairman and president, disclosed a consolidated net loss of $3,109,870 for the first six months of this year.

Random notes. The fall weakfish run in Great South Bay promises to produce better sport than the earlier fishing, and certainly is providing larger fish. Although not too many of them can qualify in the "tiderunner" class, Ed Buckley of the Freeport boat livery reports many of his anglers are taking weaks up to 8 pounds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Air Freight Forwarders Association today protested a pending cut in freight rates by some of the leading certificated airlines in what Charles P. Taft, as counsel for the forwarders, termed "open war" between the large lines and the new and smaller air freight lines.

BOSTON, Oct. 2 -- A message from Pope Pius XII calling for an informed Catholic laity to refute "the modern social errors that are undermining the precious heritage of Christian civilization" was read to the convention of the Holy Name Society here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Sept. 27 were 937,954 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 6,882 cars, or 7.10 per cent more than for the preceding week, 21,439 cars, or 2.3 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year, and 105,445 cars, or 12.7 per cent more than during the corresponding week of two years ago.

Because a Boston psychiatrist serving with the United States Army of Liberation in Nanking, China, could not forget the fine work done in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp by two Jewish refugee brothers, Izak and Leon Lanchart, they were reunited here yesterday with relatives they last saw in Germany and Poland ten years ago.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 2 -- A British Army general court-martial today quickly acquitted Capt. Roy Alexander Farran, wartime resistance fighter, of a charge of murder after the civilian prosecutor had agreed with the defense attorney that no case had been made out against the 26-year-old army officer.
ATHENS, Oct. 2 -- Reconstruction work has begun in the past few days on the port of Piraeus and on the Athens-Salonika road, Dwight Griswold, head of the American mission to Greece, announced today.

Bulletins from the perishable food market this week-end present an admixture of good and bad news, with downward changes reported in the retail prices of ham, fowl, turkeys and lamb, and increases in the tariffs of some of the less popular cuts of veal and beef.

"New World A'Coming," the dramatic aeries devoted to a consideration of minority groups, will return to WMCA at 9:30 P.M., next Tuesday. The inaugural broadcast will deal with an exposure of the activities of the Ku Klux Klan, as written by Sol Panitz.

What a difference one run can make! It was a trifle depressing to enter the Dodger clubhouse those first two days, but everything was different yesterday after the battling Brooks had snaked out a onerun victory over the Yankees -- and almost solely because of the two-inning shutout pitching of Fireman Hugh Casey.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Heard representatives of Bulgaria and Albania on Greek question and scheduled twentyone speakers for general debate on subject.

The rebuilding of Germany's productive capacity in exchange for a substantial increase in food for 48,000,000 occupants of the three western zones of Germany was recommended yesterday by Lewis H. Brown, chairman of the board of Johns-Manville Corporation, based upon data gathered in Europe during the summer.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 2 -- Comparing India's religious riots to the persecution of the Jews in Germany, Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru declared today that the present situation, if unchecked, might "sow the seeds of fascism or nazism."

LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Britain's "Westward Ho" project, which since April 21 has brought 26,600 European displaced persons here as laborers, now is planning to absorb workers from the British and United States zones in Germany and the British zone in Austria at a rate of 1,200 weekly.

New strongly worded statements were issued late yesterday by company and union officials in the 'American Overseas Airline pilots' walkout. Each put resumption of negotiations squarely up to the other side.

The City Rent Commission will station employes in every borough on Monday to continue the free legal advice to tenants and landlords that has been dispensed since Aug. 18 by volunteer attorneys, it was learned yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- The United States was accused here today of artificially creating a danger to peace in order to establish naval and air bases in Greece from which to make its influence felt throughout the Near East.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The most surprised man in Washington is still William Benton, the retiring Assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs, although the reason for it arose several days ago. With few exceptions, the news of his resignation was greeted throughout the press and the air-waves by a chorus of praise for his services, and what he had expected was the contrary.
The theft and sale of $4,000 worth of negotiable securities resulted yesterday in the arrest and arraignment of a former Republican candidate for Congress and a carpenter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Brig. Gen. William L. Richardson, Chief of Guided Missiles of the Air Force, predicted today that the United States would produce the prototype of a guided missile with a 200-mile range within a few years and prototypes with lesser ranges in about a year.

PITTSBURGH, Oct 2 (AP) -- Billy Meyer, one of minor league baseball's most successful pilots, today was named manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates in his first major league executive job. He received a two-year contract at the highest salary ever paid a Pirate field boss.
GENEVA, Oct. 21 -- A definite improvement in the chances for a break in the Anglo-American deadlock was reported today by the highest British and United States sources at the Geneva Trade Conference.

PELHAM, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- For the second consecutive week and the fourth time this season, Mrs. Edwin C. Longcope, Siwanoy Country Club champion, captured low gross laurels in the weekly one-day event of the Westchester-and-Fairfield Women's Golf Association today by scoring 42, 43-85 at the Pelham Country Club.

Saturday Holidays End Saturday trading on the New York Stock Exchange will be resumed tomorrow after four months of a five-day business week during the summer. The five and one-half days of trading will also be in order on the New York Curb Exchange in addition to out-oftown security markets and the over-the-counter markets.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 2 -- Following is the text of the statement made today to the Ad Hoc Committee on Palestine of the United Nations General Assembly by Dr. Abba Hillel Silver on behalf of the Jewish Agency for Palestine: ...

Daniel Ericourt, who has played in New York off and on for more than twenty years and who returned for a recital at Carnegie Hall last night, is a pianist of undoubted gifts. In a day of numerous virtuosos, he is not the least; in fact, his technical equipment is not equaled by many and is surpassed only by a few.
Demolition work on the United Nations site, held up since Sept. 18 by a jurisdictional strike, is scheduled to be resumed this morning.

Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder, who returned here from Europe yesterday on the United States liner America, urged Americans to cooperate fully with the Citizens Food Committee so that hungry Europeans may not go unfed.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- The stockmarkets here today tended to be uncertain, and as a result made a mixed showing.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- Individuals in this country salted away $1,800,000,000 in liquid savings during the second quarter of 1947, representing a rate of saving considerably higher than the $800,000,000 saved in the first quarter but still far below that of the last few years, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

THE world series traveling circus moved into Brooklyn for a three-day show yesterday and it gets funnier with every performance. The dear old Dodgers, who are totally unused to prosperity, let a six-run lead go to their heads, and quaffed too deeply of the elixir of success. As so frequently happens on such occasions, they soon developed a case of the blind staggers and barely reached home safely.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Mrs. Chase Going Woodhouse, executive director of the women's division of the Democratic National Committee, left today on a curtain-raising tour for the 1948 campaign -- 11,000 miles by automobile through seventeen states.

Poland is making headway in its three-year plan of economic reconstruction, and has achieved success so far in rebuilding industry to 80 per cent of pre-war, Edward Lipinski, chairman of the Bank of National Economy, Warsaw, said yesterday at a meeting held by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., at its offices here.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 2 -- Civic and industrial leaders, headed by Mayor Daniel B. Brunton, joined tonight with the president and directors of the Connecticut Valley Historical Society in the William Pynchon Memorial Building in a reception for the G. C. Merriam Company, marking the 100th anniversary of the publication of Webster's Dictionary by the 116-year-old publishing house here.

Three factors which will help to reduce the cost of housing and other construction are greater uniformity of zoning regulations, coordination of building regulations established by Federal agencies, and adoption of standard basic building codes by individual communities, according to a statement by Victor D. Abel, member of the committee on housing criteria of the American Institute of Architects.
The impossibility of overstating the economic plight of Europe was stressed yesterday by Moses W. Beckelman, vice chairman of the European executive council of the Joint Distribution Committee.
LONDON, Oct. 2 -- Diplomatic negotiations have been reopened in London with the objectives of resuming trade talks between the Soviet Union and Great Britain and of framing a new trade pact.

Social workers all over the nation now tend to condemn any system of public or private relief that calls for "prying into the private affairs of an individual a the sacrifice of most of his rights as a person," Joseph P. Anderson, executive secretary of the American Association of Social Workers, 130 East Twenty-second Street, reported yesterday for the 11,000 members of his organization.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- French Foreign Minister Bidault tackled today the problem of financially tiding his country over the interval from Nov. 1, when its existing dollar exchange will be exhausted, until the Marshall plan gets into operation.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 2 -- Broadcasting to South African farmers tonight, Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts announced an immigration scheme -- the second in eighteen months -- under which sorely needed agricultural workers would be brought from Europe.

Plans for a six-story forty-eightfamily apartment house at 54 Horatio Street were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings. Cost of the building is estimated at $200,000. The Boson Construction Corporation of 349 East 149th Street, the Bronx, is the owner, and Horace Ginsberg and Associates of 205 East Fortysecond Street are the architects.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 2 -- The Board of Directors of the Swedish State Bank urged in a memorandum to the King today the necessity for an immediate increase of Sweden's production and exports, the further import of labor from abroad, and an increase of individual savings to overcome a serious decline of the Swedish foreign exchange reserves.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Knight Dream scorched Lexington's "Red Mile" for a new world juvenile pacing record of 2:00 2-5 today on the Grand Circuit program. The Rhode Island rambler, owned by Percy and Jere Gray and Robert Armstrong of Providence, waited until the second heat of the two Gaits Farm Stake, a $3,000 test to lower the mark of 2:00 1/2 established over the same oval by Jimmy Creed in 1944.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Total United States exports declined slightly in August for the third straight month, but shipments for which foreign nations paid cash rose in value for the first time since May.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Miss Katherine Poster of Westerly, R.I., became the new champion of the United States Women's Senior Golf Association today. She added a 41, 43 -- 84 to her first-round 88 for a total of 172 in the twentysecond annuol championship at the Westchester Country Club today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- With the Soviet Union and the United States holding to their position in the deadlock over the choice of a successor to Poland on the United Nations Security Council, several Latin-American delegates are planning to make a new appeal to India to withdraw.

The stock market adopted yesterday a cautious attitude in the wake of the three-day advance and prices turned mixed, with gains of major proportions generally reserved for the oil issues. Although the day's trading leaned to the lower side in the number of issues to decline, the combined averages rose 0.05 point.

Annual reports are usually cold and statistical, but the recent report of The New York Academy of Medicine carries with its statistics a heart-warming story of the quiet professional battle for the advancement of medicine and improvement of the public health it is constantly waging.

READING, Pa., Oct. 2 (AP) -- A near-perfect round -- a 65 that carved six strokes from par to set a new Berkshire Country Club course record -- gave Jimmy Demaret a three-shot lead today in the first round of the 510,000 Reading open golf tournament.

Morris L. Ernst, counsel to the American Civil Liberties Union, reported yesterday that Soviet Russia is flooding the American zone of occupied Germany with newspapers emphasizing the Russian point of view.

PHILADEPHIA, Oct. 2 -- Five witnesses, representing a major retail grocery chain, two meat packing plants and two large dairies today told a Congressional subcommittee investigating the high cost of living that farmers and stock raisers are receiving the major share of present food price increases.

HAIFA, Palestine, Oct. 2 -- About 1,500 Jewish immigrants who arrived here from the Black Sea in a decrepit former American steamer were told tonight that they would be sent to Cyprus and not back to Europe as had been threatened.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Hanns Eisler, Hollywood composer, and his wife have been ordered arrested for deportation proceedings, the House Committee on Un-American Activities announced tonight. Warrants for their arrest have been issued by the Immigration Service.
