WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- To change the American Chain Cable Company's methods of selling would mean a restriction of markets, a loss of sales, an increase in prices and a decrease in the number of employes, the Federal Trade Commission was told today.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Oct. 2 -- Calling on leaders of industry, labor and agriculture to offer their services to the Government once again, Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, declared here tonight that the country faces a monumental task in achieving the twin goals of world peace and a lasting domestic prosperity.

George Fiske Hardy of 270 Park Avenue, consulting engineer, who was responsible for the design of many of the leading pulp and paper mills and hydroelectric power plants in the United States, Canada and Mexico, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital, after an illness of several weeks.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 2 -- Representatives from seventyeight nations signed today two important basic international agreements in the field of communications at a joint plenary session of the International Telecommunications Conference and the International Radio Conference at the Ambassador Hotel.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 2 -- The Communist party here is now giving its public support to a demand similar to one of the principal points of the Hungarian purge operation of last spring.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 2 -- Herman Fred Sieffert, 33-year-old veteran of World War II, received the state's first high school equivalency diploma at ceremonies held here today in the office of Dr. W. A. Kincaid, superintendent of Hempstead schools. Dr. Raymond Maure, principal of Hempstead High School, made the presentation, with Frank Pill Jr., testing agent for Nassau County, among those present.

A gala Anniversary Ball was given last night in the main ballroom of the Hotel Plaza as one of the principal entertainments in a series of events planned to mark the fortieth anniversary of the famous hostelry.

The inside story of Nazi officialdom, as revealed by Joseph Goebbels' diaries, is expected to be published next March by Doubleday, under the title, "The Goebbels Diaries." The more than 7,000 pages of typescript are being translated by Dr. Louis P. Lochner, author of "What About Germany" and for more than twenty years chief of the Berlin bureau of The Associated Press.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Paul M. Herzog, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, today raised questions which will be a source of much discussion as long as the board and the statutory office of General Counsel continue to exist.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- The United Kingdom and the Soviet Union urged yesterday that the organization's budget be limited at $30,000,000 -- as opposed to Secretary General Trygve Lie's estimate of $34,500,000 -- but their attempt to have such a ceiling agreed upon was voted down.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- The Headquarters Committee of the United Nations General Assembly cleared the way today for Warren R. Austin, permanent United States delegate, to approach Washington for a loan to finance the $65,000,000 world capital.

Reflecting heavier offerings in the South and continued favorable weather for picking and ginning cotton, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 6 to 26 points net lower than on Wednesday.

After ten years of study by educational specialists seeking to develop the "classroom of the future" for city schools the first of these modern rooms is now in operation at three temporary veterans' housing developments in Brooklyn and Richmond, Board of Education authorities announced yesterday.

BRANIEWO, (Braunsberg), Poland, Oct. 2 -- Just a few less than 1,200 Germans left this town for their Fatherland in a train of 40 box cars tonight under conditions far more considerate and human than their past rulers had shown the Poles transported to Germany during the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Interior Department's Bureau of Reclamation was accused today by Senator Styles Bridges, chairman of the Appropriations Committee, of having made plans to overspend by nearly $40,000,000 the appropriations voted for projects in the West in 1948.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 2 -- The American Legion housing committee defended its opposition to public housing today before the Mortgage Bankers Association and said its critics were "loud-mouthed propagandists." The Legion program has helped to restore the construction industry to something like normal after it had been "hamstrung by shortages and unrealistic Government controls," Don White of Washington, committee secretary, told the convention.

If there had been a yard or two less to travel, a different number would have gone up in the top spot after the forty-seventh running of the $25,000 added Grand National Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

Switching to Alumnium Now Many small metalworking plants here are switching to aluminum because the high prices of the limited quantities of steel available, compared to the firm low price of aluminum sheets, metal warehouses here disclosed yesterday.

Before the stage manifestation of 1946-47 were trotted into the records, Lee Shubert had a foreboding that there would be a shortage of attractions for his string of houses this season. So he hied himself to London on a shopping expedition.

Industry must be freed quickly from the shackles of "confiscatory" taxation if it is to find sufficient new capital to expand production to the point that will assure "new and better living for all Americans" and adequate supplies for peoples abroad.

Voluntary food rationing goes on trial Sunday night at 10:30 o'clock, when President Truman, Secretary Marshall and Chairman Luckman of the Citizens Food Committee will make their appeals to the public. If this move fails we shall have compulsory food rationing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- During the week ended Oct. 1 member bank reserve balances increased $203,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Management as a whole must discourage the few "short-sighted" employers who regard the Labor Management Relations (TaftHartley) Act of 1947 as a weapon to weaken labor, Paul Herzog, chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, declared yesterday.

Frank J. Sampson, leader of Tammany, announced yesterday the appointment of Abraham Kaplan, former State Senator and president of the Municipal Civil Service Commission, as chairman of the Speakers Bureau of the New York County Democratic Committee to direct the Manhattan campaign for repeal of the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- J.O. McClintock, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, warned today that contemplated shipments of grain to Europe threaten the American standards of living.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 2 (AP) -- ArtDale Stable's ebony-coated Gorget whirled to an exciting nose triumph today in the featured Euclid Purse at Garden State Park before a throng of 11,488 who installed him the $5.10 favorite.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Amvets (American Veterans of World War II) were urged tonight at their third national convention to support universal military training and combat "invasion of subversive forces in labor relations."

DETROIT, Oct. 2 -- The left wing group of the United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations announced today the retention, on private salary, of a public relations expert from Chicago to assist in its counter -attack against Walter P. Reuther, president of the union of more than 900,000 members.

Mayor O'Dwyer took a personal hand yesterday in efforts to settle the two-week-old Railway Express Agency strike. Under mounting pressure from business and labor leaders to end the tie-up in deliveries, the Mayor conferred with strike leaders at City Hall, but he made no announcement of his progress.
A lowly worm turned in Flatbush yesterday and in the process kicked up such a terrific uproar that it is unlikely the 33,098 who witnessed the spectacle ever will forget it.

A group of Protestant Episcopal and Roman Catholic leaders gathered yesterday to conclude an agreement by which the youthful charges of St. Barnabas House, a Protestant institution, will be sheltered in quarters leased for $1 from the Catholic Archdiocese of New York.

Record sales for many large office equipment machine manufacturers are forecast for this year, following large increases in important new applications in factory production offices, contracting firms, research and employment record offices, equipment manufacturing officials revealed yesterday at the National Business Show at Grand Central Palace.

TOKYO, Oct. 2 -- The leaders of Japan's principal labor organizations today sharply criticized the economic policies of the Socialistic coalition Government of Premier Tetsu Katayama. The attack was made at a conference called by the Cabinet to discuss emergency measures for increasing coal production in line with the Allies' recent demand under the bill providing for national control of the mines.
Lionel S. Shapiro has become associated with the sales department of Annlea Associates, Inc., brokers.

A state investigation to determine whether any considerable number of automobile drivers' licenses have been obtained in New York City by irregular methods has been under way quietly for nearly a month, it was disclosed yesterday.

The Sert Room of the WaldorfAstoria was formally opened for the season last night with a dinner dance arranged as a benefit for the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation, signalizing the inception of that organization's operating and building fund campaign for the establishment of a Sister Kenny Institute in New York State.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- A widely held theory at the United Nations is that, unlike the Security Council, the General Assembly can get things done and even show, from time to time, superior wisdom.

BERLIN, Oct. 2 -- The occupation powers took up again today the explosive issue of Soviet reciprocation for reparations from the western zones of Germany. They could do nothing about it but refer the question back to technical experts.

Let us hope that Tchaikovsky is not an easy grave-whirler. For the uses to which his scores have been put in "Music in My Heart" might set him to some furious spinning and thumping. As presented at the Adelphi last evening, it is stock operetta in the "Blossom Time" tradition, with pasteboard romance, uncomfortable comedy, some hushed genuflections toward royalty and conventional suggestions of musical comedy lechery.

DETROIT, Oct. 2 -- Assailing what he called the silence of the Truman Administration at a time of crisis, Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, Republican, of Connecticut, called tonight for the adoption by his party of an "effective, bold, emergency program" for 1948 which would meet not only domestic but international issues.

BROWNSVILLE, Ohio, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Two Ohio hill farms looked different tonight. Their 208 acres, cupped in a little amphitheater formed by a creek flowing into the Licking River, are ready to grow food as never before. The gullies are filled and the furrows follow around the hills instead of across them.

The play-by-play description of the third game of the world series at Ebbets Field yesterday follows: FIRST INNING YANKEES -- Stirnweiss singled off the right field wall. Henrich anged into a double play, Reese o Stanky to Robinson. Lindell went out on a high infield bounder, Jorgensen to Robinson.
PEIPING, Oct. 2 -- Government agents are believed to have disrupted an incipient Opposition movement within Government ranks in carrying out a series of sudden arrests here during the last week.

Lou Little listened to the description of a sturdy Navy football team at the Columbia football luncheon yesterday. The Lion coach, now in his eighteenth year as head of Morningside Heights team's football fortunes, was his characteristic pessimistic self as he heard Jerry Flynn, public relations man for Navy, dwell at length on the prowess of the Annapolis crew.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Friday, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Two blonde, 21-year-old German women planned to stow away as air freight aboard United Statesbound planes, but the scheme was foiled when one of them was found doubled up in a small trunklike box ready for a flight to New York, United States Army investigators said early today.
Every family should conduct fire drills at home, just as is done in schools, offices and other public places, the Greater New York Safety Council said yesterday.

Criticizing the management of the Broadway Theatre for "disregard of the law and bad faith," Magistrate Charles F. Murphy initiated three actions yesterday to dim the theatre's electric advertising signs so that tenants in the apartment building at 200 West Fifty-fourth Street can get "sleep and quiet and repose."
Recurrent rumors that the American price of gold is to be raised are fostered by "ambiguities" in the 1934 Gold Reserve Act, according to the National City Bank's Monthly Letter, issued yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2 -- In a sixteen-page opinion, the Securities and Exchange Commission today cited its reasons for ordering the rejection on Thursday of last week of the high bid of $4.05 a share submitted by Lehman Brothers, Goldman Sachs Co. and Wertheim Co. for 2,132,223 shares of common stock of the Interstate Power Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Generally lower prices for agricultural commodities caused a decrease of 1.2 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended on Sept. 27, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Commerce.

No End of Books "Books also accumulate as men decay -- and neglect to do anything about it." So the old man said as he rested his walking stick on our desk and sank into the armchair which is usually occupied by an esteemed colleague now on sick leave.

ROME, N.Y., Oct. 2 (AP) -- C.J. Blanford, Milk Marketing Administrator for the New York City area, today told officers and directors of the sixty-eight cooperatives in the six-state metropolitan milk shed that he had appointed G. Osmond Hyde, Washington lawyer, to survey their operations.

The road back in football is a hard one for Fordham. Those who look hopefully for the time when the Ram will regain his virulence and obstinacy of the years of the Seven Blocks of Granite need to be patient.

Although William Reid does not have the advantage of being a railroad man, we believe he will make a good chairman of the Board of Transportation. He brings to the job long experience in city affairs, and especially with its finances, a background that will surely not come amiss in dealing with our deficit-ridden transit system.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Exports of foodstuffs through July this year were $5,900,000 lower than in the same period of last year, the Commerce Department reported today.

ROME, Oct. 2 -- Pope Pius XII today urged the American Legion to fight for peace just as it fought for victory during the war. His appeal, which was made during a private audience to a group of forty-four American Legion members touring Europe, expressed the deep anxiety with which the Pontiff is following international events.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- A proposed trusteeship agreement for the mandated territory of Nauru, a Pacific island, was formally laid before the United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee today by Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Mayor William O'Dwyer blamed the Republican party tonight for the high cost of living. He said talk of consumer resistance in New York City was just "a fancy way of saying that people are doing without necessities of life because they don't make enough to afford them."

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 2 -- Speaking to an audience of 1,500 here tonight, Henry A. Wallace said that the country's greatest menace today came from our own inertia rather than from any foreign army or alien political and economic philosophy.

Striking employes of the Childs restaurant chain, who on Wednesday left their jobs in dining rooms, kitchens and behind bars for picket lines in front of all twenty-nine branches of the organization, were told yesterday not to expect a long strike.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 12 -- Dragolub Yovanovitch, leader of the Serb Peasant party, pleaded not guilty today to charges of having worked for a foreign espionage service and of having directed "illegal" propaganda against Yugoslavia.

The first temporary restraining order in the brief history of the new Taft-Hartley Act was obtained yesterday by the National Labor Relations Board. It directs the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, to call off a tenday-old strike of its members in the port of Albany.

Although it has been two years since the war ended, the demands upon the Red Cross for aid continue and this great organization again seeks help from the public in performing its tasks. The new appeal is for 1,500 additional daytime volunteer women to meet peacetime demands for Red Cross service in Manhattan and the Bronx.

More research is needed on the interaction of mind and body in illness, and childhood is the place to start, according to Dr. Percy H. Jennings Jr., pediatrician of Berkeley, Calif. He also thinks that knowledge at hand might be more widely used.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would appoint Deputy Transportation Commissioner William Reid as chairman of the Board of Transportation to succeed Charles P. Gross, who will retire on Oct. 21.

The United Nations has been presented with two new problems as a result of the Assembly's deadlock over the election of one more member to the Security Council and the double Russion veto against the admission of Italy and Finland to the United Nations itself.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- The first step toward the eventual stabilization of French currency, in conformity with the European recovery program under the Marshall plan, was taken today when Premier Paul Ramadier named a special "balance sheet commission."
An opulent array of furs presented yesterday by Dein-Bacher of the Waldorf at the WaldorfAstbria interpreted this season's trends through subtle changes in sleeves and collar treatments.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 2 -- The Conservative party made one of the most decisive deviations in its history today when it almost unanimously endorsed the politically liberal and advanced "industrial charter." This action was taken as the party's annual conference opened here.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, chairman of the American section of the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, today pledged the Agency's acceptance of the proposed partition of the Holy Land. He declared that the Agency would "assume this burden as one of the sacrifices designed to find a way out of the present intolerable impasse."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt today took up the cause of the United Nations advisory social welfare services, whose budget the United Kingdom sought to cut by more than $500,000.

CHICAGO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The American Finance Conference, national association of independent credit companies, proposed today that the industry set up its own credit control formula governing installment buying of consumer durable goods after Federal controls expire on Nov. 1.

In the first overseas passenger flight directly to a point in midManhattan, a giant four-motored Boeing flying boat bearing fiftytwo passengers and a crew of eight landed at the Marine Esplanade on the Hudson River at Seventy-ninth Street yesterday afternoon.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your leading editorial of Sept. 17, "Challenge to the Assembly," you say that Mr. Gromyko's "double veto" of the proposal to refer the Greek problem to the General Assembly, now meeting at Lake Success, amounts to a challenge to that body.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (U.P.) -- The State Department has received from the United States Embassy in Moscow high lights of another bitterly anti-American Soviet magazine article that describes Secretary of State Marshall as "a dreadful old man * * * the Shylock of Wall Street," it was learned today.

Agi Jambor, Hungarian pianist, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. In a diversified program ranging from Bach to the moderns, the gifted artist disclosed a warmth of temperament, technical skill and control of color and dynamics that gave her playing distinction.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 2 -- The Ecumenical Methodist Conference concluded here today with the adoption of a "message to the Methodists of the world" and a reorganization of the Ecumenical Council, the continuing body between sessions of the conference.

CASPER, Wyo., Oct. 2 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio, asserted in the final speech of his Western tour tonight that the democrats were meeting the big issues of the day with "wavering uncertainty and lack of principle." Against an opposition "bankrupt in ideas and consistent theory" the Republican party has shown "its ability to function as a party and its ability to carry out a definite program," he added.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- Jack Sabol, Westchester Hills pro, and amateur Leroy Franck teamed for a winning best-ball of 31, 36 -- 67, four under par, to lead a field of twenty-two tandems in the one-day tournament of the Westchester P.G.A. today at the Metropolis Country Club.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 2 -- Abbas Iskandari, Deputy from Hamadan, startled the Majlis (Parliament) today by requesting that Iran act immediately to take over the British -controlled, United States-exploited island of Bahrein in the Persian Gulf.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 3 -- The American home-building industry is responsible for the current housing famine, zooming costs, slums, overcrowding and the widening spread between income and shelter costs, Charles Abrams of New York, author, lecturer and economist, told the Mortgage Bankers Association of America today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Employment of glass filters in alternate layers to provide the reinforcement essential for the successful manufacture by lamination of plywood constructions suitable for use in place of metal won a patent award this week for Howard W. Collins of Newark, Ohio.

Official clarification of the interpretation of two canons, liberalized last September, which govern marriages of Episcopalians was urged yesterday by twelve Protestant Episcopal clergymen upon the House of Bishops of the church.

Plans for a six-story apartment building at 46-54 Overlook Terrace, in upper Manhattan, were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings, Horace Ginsbern Associates, architects, estimated the cost at $380,000.

Columbia University eventually will receive the greater portion, of the estate of Quincy Ward Boese for the establishing of scholarships and fellowships in the mechanical, physical and biological sciences or useful arts.

With the first no-hitter in world series history in the making a Ebbets Field yesterday, Cookie Lavagetto rewrote the script with two out in the ninth inning to establish the Dodgers as the first club in baseball's autumnal classic ever to win a game on just one hit.

Schools and their communities are going into a "full time" partnership that will make school buildings the hub of neighborhood activity. This is the intention of school officials now conducting tests in eleven city schools, Board of Education authorities announced yesterday.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 -- Members of the Holy Name Society numbering 60,000 gathered tonight at Braves Field for a candlelight holy hour. Earlier, the 7,000 convention delegates approved resolutions calling for United Nations action to aid Archbishop Stepinac, imprisoned in Yugoslavia, and to admit to the world organization Ireland, Portugal, Spain, Italy and Finland.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- With the Soviet delegation clearly in a cooperative mood, the conference of special Foreign Ministers' deputies on the future of former Italian colonies started smoothly and auspiciously today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Fordham, unable to win a single game last year in its post-war return to football, apparently is going to have to wait a while longer before gridiron glory returns to Rose Hill. There certainly was little immediate encouragement in the Rams' 1947 opener against Georgetown tonight.

A favored New York University football team squares off against Brooklyn College tonight at the Polo Grounds in an effort to take its fourth successive game in a series that began in 1944. The kickoff is set at 8:30.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association said yesterday that about twenty-five newspapers in the United States were now operating without contracts with their printers because of the "no-contract" policy adopted by the AFL International Typographical Union.

BAD SALZUFLEN, Germany, Oct. 3 -- The United States will be asked by the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization to accept approximately 250,000 European displaced persons, William H. Tuck, Executive Secretary of the organization disclosed today at a press conference.
RONNE ANTARCTIC BASE, Stonington Island, Sept. 30 (Delayed) -- Our geographical program is now under way, and we have started a scientific attack on the unknown sector of the Weddell Coast.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Charge that President Truman, instead of cooperating with the Republican Congress, had dealt in "questionable ethics," misled leaders and instructed agencies to resist legislative activities, came to light today in a report distributed by the Senate majority policy committee.

Five men arrested in a police raid on a so-called "swindlers' paradise" in a suite in the Hotel Marguery, 270 Park Avenue, on Sept. 11 have been named in indictments or criminal informations, the District Attorney's office announced yesterday.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 3 -- Various cures for the high cost of living were suggested today to a Congressional subcommittee that made Trenton one of its stops in a price-study tour of Eastern cities.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Two men accused of having offered $250 a week to State Police Lieut. Victor Clarke, commander of the Bethany Barracks, for permission to operate gambling games in the Naugatuck Valley were arrested here today on conspiracy charges.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark.. Oct. 3 -- The possibility of socialization of the power and light industry throughout the Southwest is a "political pall on the horizon of our liberties," C. H. Moses, president of the 582,000,000 Arkansas Power and Light Company, asserted today.

VIENNA, Oct. 3 -- While the experts of the Austrian Peace Treaty Commission have been arguing about Russian claims to the industry of eastern Austria as an alleged former German asset, the Russians have been systematically selling its products in western Europe under false certificates of origin.

Cheektowaga, N.Y., school districts announced yesterday the pending sale of bond issues totaling $1,395,000. On Oct. 15, Common School District No. 2 will offer an issue of $700,000 dated Nov. 1, 1947 and due Nov. 1 from 1948 to 1977.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, President of the United Nations General Assembly, will be the guest of Secretary of State Marshall at an important luncheon tomorrow. It is understood that Georges Bidault, Foreign Minister of France, also will attend if he returns from Washington in time.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 3 -- Delegates of the Netherlands, Mexico and New Zealand championed the Marshall Plan today in the Economic and Financial Committee of the United Nations General Assembly against the Polish charge last Saturday that the plan "bypassed" the peace organization.

LIKE many another able writer before her, Ann Petry has run into difficulties in writing her second novel. It is clear that "Country Place"* is not as good as "The Street." The material is here all right, in some abundance, and much of it is well presented in individual scenes. The one trouble is that the man chosen to tell the story is pretty difficult to believe all the time.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 3 -- John Payne, who has been at Twentieth Century-Fox since 1940, disclosed today that he has obtained a release from his contract with the studio, which still has four years to run. Fox has engaged Robert Young to replace him in "Sitting Pretty," the film in which he had been scheduled to start work this month.

MOSCOW, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper, declared today that many members of the United States Congress now traveling abroad are "interfering" in the internal affairs of foreign countries.

The Jewish Theological Seminary will observe the third anniversary of its weekly program, "The Eternal Light," at 12:30 P.M. tomorrow over NBC. The speakers will include Justice Edgar Nathan of the New York Supreme Court, who is chairman of the seminary's radio committee, and Niles Trammell, NBC president.

World Communion Sunday will be observed tomorrow by virtually every Protestant church in the New York area. This demonstra-tion of world-wide Christian fel-lowship will be dedicated to the millions of war sufferers abroad. Offerings will be taken to help fur-ther the overseas programs in thirty countries in Europe and Asia of the major denominations in the United States, working through Church World Service, the headquarters of which are in Geneva, Switzerland.

"An Introduction to the Russian Novel," by Janko Lavrin, has been scheduled for publication Oct. 15 by Whittlesey House. It is a concise summary of the development of the Russian novel from its beginning to the present day shown against the social, political and cultural background of the country.
INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 3 (AP) --A new issue of common stock planned by the Indianapolis Power and Light Company must be sold at competitive bidding, the Indiana Public Service Commission ruled today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 3 -- Two Catholic priests who were tried in Istria for their alleged part in a riot Aug. 24 that resulted in the death of a priest received prison sentences today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Alabama Negro leaders today proposed action to combat restrictive voting laws, to institute court suits for admission of Negroes to state colleges, and to end "racial discrimination" in public transportation.

A large new appliance market can be exploited by intensive education of consumers to the advantages of gas and electrical automatic clothes'driers, an'executive of a large national appliance distributing organization said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Administration moved toward a showdown with the country's grain exchanges today armed with a report of the President's Council of Economic Advisers that speculation in commodities had contributed heavily to rising food costs to the detriment of the domestic economy and foreign-aid plans.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 3 -- Indian summer weather brought out forty-one women-pro teams in a one-day tournament under the auspices of the New Jersey Women's Golf Association at the Crestmont Golf Club today.

Since we love our British cousins, wish to bridge the pond, cement relations and all that sort of thing, the problem of what to do about "Under the Counter" is perplexing. Probably it should be reviewed by the State Department. After running in London for a couple of seasons it turned up last evening at the Shubert Theater, with Cicely Courtneidge playing the Four Marx Brothers and Beatrice Lillie across the board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Secretary J.A. Krug formally denied today charges by Senator Styles Bridges of New Hampshire that the Interior Department's Bureau of Reclamation had made plans to spend more than Congress had appropriated.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Premier Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium stepped into the Balkan controversy today with a defense of the United States' aid-to-Greece policy and a direct appeal to the Slav states to accept a new United Nations commission of investigation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP)--The Maritime Commission today opened bids from four companies for construction of five combination passenger-cargo vessels for round-the-world service.

Announcement of new information services to be provided by the City Rent Commission was made yesterday by Paul L. Ross, chairman. The Mayor's Volunteer Lawyers Advisory Committee, which had stationed attorneys in the Municipal Courts since Aug. 18, ended its service yesterday afternoon.
The New York State Athletic Commission yesterday refused to renew the license of Nat Rogers, matchmaker of the Twentieth Century Sporting Club. In addition the board fined him $250.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Leo Durocher, suspended manager of the Dodgers, will not be permitted to accept the world series share voted to him by the Brooklyn players, but the Lip will draw his full salary for the 1947 season. That was revealed yesterday by sources unquestionably authentic, but which may not be quoted.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 3 -- One act of violence, a minor one, was officially reported today as the Arabs of Palestine went on a dawn-to-dusk general strike to dramatize their demand for independence and for the unity of the country.
From Europe this week came the report of the death of the consort of the late Prince Franz I, former reigning prince of the tiny principality of Liechtenstein.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Oct. 3 (AP) -- The 'Northeastern Poultry Producers Council asked the Government today to advocate a saving of grain on the farm instead of urging the public to stop eating poultry and eggs.

Cape Cod Houses Old buildings have an appeal. If the buildings were used as part of the region's economy they seem to have a special drawing power. Old gristmills, blacksmith shops, general stores, cooperages, harness shops and cider mills are a part of our history.

General Richardson's report on the present status of guided missile research is a sobering warning to the American people, and to Congress, that the day of push-button warfare still is far in the future. It may be years, he believes, before the United States has even a prototype of a guided missile that can be directed accurately at a target as close as 200 miles.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- J.O. McClintock, president of the Chicago Board of Trade, tonight branded as punitive and discriminatory the reported proposal of Secretary W. Averell Harriman's Foreign Aid Committee that grain exchanges increase the credit margin on grain buying to curb speculation.

Reports of the latest research into the causes and possible cures for allergy, known as one of the most baffling problems of modern medicine, were presented yesterday before 400 scientists meeting in the lecture room of the Museum of Natural History, Seventy-ninth Street and Central Park West.

James A. Foltz Jr., business manager, The Cleveland Press, and James D. Shouse, president, the Crosley Broadcasting Corporation, Cincinnati, were elected to the board of directors of the Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertising, Inc., at a meeting yesterday.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- Several hundred longshoremen at the port of Albany, on strike since September 23, returned to work today, less than twenty-four hours after a Federal court judge issued an order directing that the strike cease. It was the first such order issued under the provision of the Taft-Hartley law prohibiting secondary boycotts.

This is the season, and a big one, for grapes. In the backyard arbor the purple fruit grows more purple under the October sun, softens and sends up a heady fragrance. In market stalls the specimens are varied shades of red and green, blue as well as purple, round as a marble, oval, large, small.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Sixtyfive non-certificated carriers which operate large aircraft were ordered today by the Civil Aeronautics Board to comply with regulations as to filing rates and reports on operations or lose their letters of registration within fifteen days.

The National Maritime Union's sixth biennial convention adopted yesterday a resolution pledging the union to "boycott and refuse to recognize" the new "employerdominated" National Labor Relations Board and Conciliation Service. Adoption was by a rising vote of the convention.

Aided by two weeks of cool weather, sales of fur coats at retail made appreciable gains, according to a survey of the trade yesterday. Movement of stocks in stores, it was learned, has brought buyers into the market for replacements and manufacturers now working at full force are being hard pressed for quicker deliveries.

Butter, an erstwhile leader in the food price spiral, received the coup de grace from consumer resistance in the wholesale markets yesterday. After a week of fractional declines, the prices of the three top grades plunged 4 1/2 cents a pound.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Chief of Staff, announced today they had found no cause of action against Lieut. Gen. C.H. Lee for alleged maladministration of his command in Italy.

The first united campaign for funds of the Young Women's Christian Associations of Manhattan, the Bronx, BrooKlyn and Queens will get under way next Tuesday (Oct. 7) to raise $455,000 needed to defray the expense of the free and less-than-cost services provided during the past year for the city's young women by these associations and their branches.

Steps were taken yesterday to pave the way for the operation of the business of Motty Eitingon, Inc., mouton furs, under a new or modified plan.. The company has been operating under reorganization proceedings under chapter eleven of the Bankruptcy Act.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Syracuse Chiefs of the International League fought their way back to even terms tonight in the junior world series by defeating Milwaukee of the American Association, 3 to 2, behind the stout pitching of Howard Fox.

ADEMENTED Hollywood scenarist in the final stages of delirium tremens wouldn't have dared produce a script as utterly fantastic as the stark drama which was unfolded before the eyes of the Flatbush faithful at Ebbets Field yesterday. It bordered on sheer lunacy. As one stunned and incredulous press box tenant remarked: "Don't bother writing about it, because no one will believe you anyway."
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 3 -- Indefinite continuation of the port freight shipping strike appeared probable today despite the appointment of a new chairman for the Coast Labor Relations Committee.

For a brief interlude October marshals its strength and flings a patchwork quilt of gorgeous hues over the woodlands. In the northland ponds and lakes reflect the blue of the sky. Around sapphire waters that brood through sunny mellow days and crisp starlit nights are necklaces of jewels.

ALBANY, Oct. 3 -- Governor Thomas E. Dewey established today a State Food Commisison with an initial appropriation of $100,000 to help meet the food crisis caused by shortages, high prices and the need for large shipments to Europe to prevent famine there.

READING, Pa., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Scores soared today in the second round of the $10,000 Reading Open golf tournament, with smiling Jim Demaret skyrocketing to a 73 but clinging to a two-stroke lead. He carded 65 on opening day.

For the second time since Wednesday, when 2,300 employes of the Childs restaurant chain went on strike, the State Board of Mediation sought yesterday to make peace between the company and Local 42, Chain Service Restaurant Employes Union, AFL.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- The United Nations Security Council resumed consideration of the Indonesian case here today on the basis of an interim report from the six-nation consular commission in Batavia that fighting was still going on, despite the Council's cease-fire order.
ETOWAH, Terin., Oct. 3 (AP) -- T. Burkett Ivins, a controversial political figure ousted from office in the 1946 McMinn County election battle, was killed today in a mysterious automobile explosion.

Mohandas K. Gandhi has reached the age of 78 years. Nearly three decades have passed since the little lawyer assumed the center of Indian politics. Then he was middle-aged, and this in itself is a remarkable commentary on his vigor, which seems to survive stresses of many kinds, including fasts and imprisonment.

Army, about which there was much question, passed its opening test with flying colors last week. Now the spotlight shifts to Notre Dame, bracketed with, the cadet eleven as 1946 ruler of the college gridiron. The Irish swing into action for the first time at Pittsburgh today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- The Rev. Edward Lodge Curran, president of the International Catholic Truth Society, served notice here today that ne was bringing court action in an attempt to make the United Nations vacate the site of its proposed world capital in midtown Manhattan.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Many British Cabinet Ministers in key posts will be switched and others dropped entirely in sweeping Government changes to be announced in a few days by Prime Minister Attlee, authoritative sources said tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 3 -- The mobility of American families, which in some areas change their residences at the rate of six times a decade, was described here tonight as one of the four prime factors undermining the stability of the American home.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, at a meeting of the United Nations General Assembly's Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee here today, gave a preview of her expected reply to Soviet charges of United States "warmongering."

The stock market regained yesterday its poise under the second million-share turnover of the week and, paced by steel ana liquor shares," prices were enlarged 1 to 2 points and the composite rate was increased 0.84 point. Public participation was reported as still at a minimum, however, and most trades were attributed to the more professional element.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Trailing for three quarters, the Brooklyn Dodgers pushed over three touchdowns in the final period tonight to beat the Chicago Rockets, 35 to 31, in an All-America Football Conference game before 16,844 fans at Soldier Field.
OAKLAND, Calif., Oct. 3 (U.P.) -- The telephone bell jangled at the home of Mrs. Harry Lavagetto, 817 Fifty-second Street, Oakland, today. It was long distance, Brooklyn calling.

If Harry (Cookie) Lavagetto, 32-year-old veteran of the 1941 world series, lives to reach the century mark, he never will experience thrill compared with the one he got yesterday in that story-book ninth inning finish at Ebbets Field.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- A defense of Great Britain of her colonial system ended in a clash in the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee here today between colonial and non-colonial powers.

Buying orders about offset selling orders in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Closing prices were 1 to 10 points net higher than the day before. New Orleans lost 5 to 9 points.

BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- The United States Military Government approved today amendments to the law for liberation from national socialism and militarism -- the socalled denazification law. This step was taken in an effort to save three or four months in the process of purging the land of Nazis and punishing those culpable.

The five Republican county leaders in New York City are scheduled to issue a statement next week urging adoption of the proposed amendment to the city charter repealing the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council and substituting election by State Senate districts.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- As amended to give increased participation to common stockholders, the liquidation and dissolution plan of the American States Utilities I Corporation was endorsed unanimously today by the five-man Securities and Exchange Commission.

Thirteen colts and a pair of fillies have been entered in today's fifty-eighth running of the Futurity, Belmont Park's classic for 2-year-olds, and if they all put in an appearance the pay-off to the winner will be the largest since the 1933 edition of the sprint.

NANKING, Oct. 3 -- The Communist offensive in Manchuria appears to have begun. Nationalist sources reported today the outbreak of fighting north of Kungchuling, forty miles southwest of Changchun, and the breaking of the newly repaired Changchun railway in three places between Changchun and Szepingkai.

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- The plan for establishing a dollar pool to insure the greater convertibility of European currencies as an aid to intra-European trade has been virtually abandoned, it was learned today.

BRIGHTON, England, Oct. 3 -- The ugly shadow of anti-Semitism was thrown into strong relief today at the Conservative party's annual conference here. It has embarrassed party leaders greatly and tomorrow they are going to try to lay the ghost by debating and undoubtedly passing a resolution condemning fascism and communism.
The Department of Markets recommends a beef and kidney pie for tonight's low to moderate cost dinner. A menu that will cost $2.38 for a family of five is suggested to include:

Jobs for Disabled Veterans Week will get under way at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow in Columbus Circle. Military and business leaders are scheduled to open the program of interesting business firms in employing handicapped veterans. This was announced yesterday by Jack Denove, chairman of the Jobs for Disabled Veterans Committee, a volunteer group of New YorK businessmen.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Villanova College and Miami University, each capitalizing on a break for a touchdown and extrapoint conversion, fought to a 7-to-7 tie tonight in their intersectional battle before 26,500 at Shibe Park.
GREAT FALLS, Mont., Oct. 3 (AP) -- A 65-year-old sheepherder lay near death today after a fierce but losing midnight battle with a giant grizzly bear he found raiding his flock in the Montana hills.

BERLIN, Oct. 3 -- Representative John Taber, Republican, of New York, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, made it perfectly clear today he did not favor United States stop-gap aid to Europe.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Oct. 3 -- Eighteen English, Canadian, Australian, New Zealand and American Methodist ministers, who attended the seventh Ecumenical Methodist Conference here during the last nine days, departed today on a pilgrimage to Bethlehem, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The National Labor Relations Board today discussed the question of overruling Robert N. Denham, NLRB general counsel, on his non-Communist affidavit ruling.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 3 (Aneta) -- Prices were easier in moderate trading on the Stock Exchange. Industrials and shipping stocks were lower, while Indies plantations issues were mixed. Banking shares and state bonds were steady.

Forty years ago about this time newspaper readers were informed in a headline and story that a large new structure had been erected near an old skating rink on the west corner of Fifty-ninth Street at Fifth Avenue. The headline read: "The New Plaza a Hotel Wonder."
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 3 -- Navy is getting powerful tired of losing football games and it's a hungry, victory-starved outfit that Columbia will have to reckon with tomorrow in Thompson Stadium.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- Demands by the Soviet Union that political discrimination be avoided in the distribution of food brought the East-West split into the discussions of the executive board of the International Children's Emergency Fund here today.

The first conciliatory move in the four-day old strike of American Overseas Airline pilots came yesterday when the National Mediation Board invited both parties in the dispute to attend fact-finding discussions on Monday in Washington.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 -- Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, warned today that any re-establishment of price controls would have to be accompanied by a Federal regulation of wages. To a regional meeting of Republican women from nineteen States Mr. Reece said:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 --Henry J. Kaiser described to President Truman today a new plan of financing whereby he., hopes to increase the production of his Fontana' steel plant in California to 600,000 tons of sheet steel a year. It is now producing about 400,000 tons of various steel products.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 3 -- Anne Revere has resigned as treasurer of the Screen Actors Guild and Olivia de Havilland has been named by the guild board to fill her unexpired term of office. It is understood that Miss Revere resigned because she objected "as a matter of principle" to filling out an affidavit of non-Communist affiliation, under the requirements of the Taft-Hartley Labor Bill.

The first instance of quarantine here since the outbreak of cholera in Egypt and other Middle East areas occurred yesterday when twelve passengers who arrived aboard a Trans World Airlines plane were held at La Guardia Field because they did not carry inoculation certificates.

Flowers for the Home might well have been the title of the fourth annual fall show of the Garden Club of New Jersey, held in the Woman's Club of Upper Montclair. The two-day show, which closed last night, was for the benefit of the organization's work with hospitalized veterans.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 -- The first move by an employer to resort to the Taft-Hartley Law for relief from union "feather-bedding" practices has been made by the State Theatre in Hartford, Conn., in an unfair labor practices case. The theatre has filed a complaint with the National Labor Relations Board here.

Lee and Jacob J. Shubert, theatrical producers, have established a non-profit philanthropic foundation in memory of their brother, Sam S. Shubert, who was killed in 1905 in a train wreck, it was disclosed last night.

Michael Myerberg, who has put on such singular shows as Thornton Wilder's "The Skin of Our Teeth" and "Lute Song," a modern adaptation of an old Chinese play, will offer tomorrow evening at the Mansfield Theatre his dramatization of Robinson Jeffers' poem, "Dear Judas."
The play-by-play description of the fourth game of the world series at Ebbets Field yesterday follows:

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange will consider on Oct. 17 a proposal to amend the constitution of the Exchange to permit increased commission rates. If the plan, which was submitted yesterday to the governors, is approved, it will be submitted to the membership for a vote.

A high police official paid tribute yesterday to the artistry of James Barton, veteran Broadway actor with rich experience as a stage inebriate, and in so doing almost ruined a fire-fighting show put on by the Fire Department in City Hall Plaza to dramatize Mayor O'Dwyer's public reading of a proclamation designating Oct. 5Oct. 11 as Fire Prevention Week.

Market Interruption In one Wall Street bond room yesterday it looked as if the long-looked-for market turn had come. The traders, instead of sitting around in dejected toleration of a dull and heavy market, were hanging on to' the opert telephones, deeply absorbed in ,what was coming over the wire.

MILWAUKEE, Wisc., Oct. 3 -- Barely a five-week supply of iron and steel scrap remains in the hands of consumers and dealers, but a vast reserve of more than 1,000,000 "jalopies" remain in automobile graveyards and these average more than 500 pounds of castings in each car.
The sixteen - day - old express strike still was deadlocked yesterday despite further efforts by Mayor O'Dwyer to have the union agree to submission of the dispute to the National Mediation Board.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 3 -- Americans will not go on indefinitely paying high taxes to aid other peoples "without evidence that they are doing, their best to help themselves," Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. asserted here to night at a meeting sponsored by the Republican Assembly, an unofficial party organization.
A campaign to win support for economic objectives was opened last night by the New York Teachers Guild, Local 2, AFL.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

HAVANA, Oct. 3 -- Three United States citizens who held the rank of captain in the expeditionary forces that had planned to attack the regime of President Rafael L. Trujillo in the Dominican Republic, waited impatiently today in Camp Columbia with other prisoners for their expected release.

Two bamboo vials containing snails have arrived in this country from China to be used in research for means of combatting schistosomiasis, a disease peculiar to some parts of China and contracted there by 1,500 American soldiers during the war, it was announced yesterday.

Multilateral tariff and trade arrangements between eighteen countries doing 80 per cent of the world's trade are expected to become effective Jan. 1, it was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Clair Wilcox, director of the Office of International Trade Policy of the State Department.

DETROIT, Oct. 3 -- Asking for a strong attack on the Taft-Hartley labor law, the high cost of living and speed-up schemes, the leftwing faction of the United Automobile Workers of the Congress of Industrial Organizations sent today to the more than 900,000 members a counter-attack against Walter P. Reuther, president of the union.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- Grain markets on the Board of Trade fluctuated today in a nervous manner within a comparatively wide range, advancing early, only to break rapidly later with corn in the lead and then rally late in the session.

Enrollment totals for the fall semester at New York's four municipal colleges -- City, Brooklyn, Hunter and Queens -- are below expectations, and the over-all figure of 30,205 in the day sessions represents an increase of only 1,000 over last spring's registration, it was learned yesterday.

John Santo, international organizer of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, was ordered to testify at his deportation hearing in accordance with the Government's demand in a ruling handed down yesterday in Federal Court by United States District Court Judge Alfred C. Coxe.

BOSTON, Oct. 3 -- Gov. Robert F. Bradford of Massachusetts today refused bluntly to accept for placing on Boston Common a memorial bas-relief of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, the Italian anarchists executed here twenty years ago for murder during a payroll holdup.

Wholesome forces are working to reduce the cost of building, which hit a rate in August equivalent to 1,000,000 dwelling units a year, members of the Producers Council were told yesterday. As it ended a three-day meeting in the Commodore Hotel, the organization of building materials and equipment manufacturers heard speeches by David S. Miller, its newly elected president, and Edward R. Carr, president of the National Association of Home Builders.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Continuing general discussion of Greek question, heard Dmitri Z. Manuilsky of the Ukraine criticize United States, Britain and Greece.

The one place in the world where the food problem is not the all-engrossing topic is the United Nations. In national capitals harassed governments are chiefly engaged in eking out dwindling wheat supplies and begging for supplies to avert starvation and revolution.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- The recommendations by the majority of the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine are a "solution of expediency" recalling the Munich decision of 1938, Camille Chamoun, delegate from Lebanon, told the General Assembly's Committee on Palestine today.

After a six-hour conference at City Hall, a special citizen's mediation panel appointed by Mayor O'Dwyer said last night that some progress had been made toward a settlement of the two-day-old tie-up of 150 Safeway Store retail grocery outlets.
They locked the Yankee clubhouse door after yesterday's dramatic battle in which the Dodgers squared the world series at 2-all.

Attempts by management to obtain greater employe cooperation and productivity by education in the virtues of such intangibles as the free enterprise system-without first ascertaining worker attitudes toward the company and specific job environment-are futile, James C. Worthy, of the personnel department, Sears, Roebuck Co., declared yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 3 -- Most industrial shares in the stock market here finished the week firmly today, and gilt-edge stocks were not much changed, although there were minor declines in a few of the dated issues. However, as during most of the week previously, dealings were on a very small scale.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 3 -- The mystery of the "East Chester itch," which has kept many persons scratching since June and has hospitalized one woman, was solved today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the adoption of a. new rule, effective Nov. 3, to implement the provisions of Section 17 (G) of the Investment Company Act.

Rayon weavers and converters who have been subpoenaed by the Government to produce records on prices, goods allocation, and production for a Federal Grand Jury panel in New York next Wednesday, will require considerably more time to collect the data, according to trade sources yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 -- The ability to see, in a large number of industrial jobs, was described to members of the National Rehabilitation Association today as "only a convenience that enables the worker to get to and from the job easily."

Viscount Jowitt, Lord Chancellor of Great Britain, leaving here for England yesterday, reiterated his belief that there is no truth in statements by others that his homeland is falling apart. Such "hardship stories" about Britain, he asserted, are being vasrly overdone in the American press.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Truman received members of the Kon-Tiki expedition at the White House today and accepted from them the American flag that had flown from the mast of their balsa raft during its 4,000-mile voyage from Peru to the Polynesians.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Oct. 3--Queen Wilhelmina, whose golden jubilee as the Netherlands' sovereign is less than a year away, soon will relinquish temporarily her royal power to Princess Juliana for reasons of health, the Netherlands Government announced today.

Just when the fans and the experts were ready to write off the 1947 world series as the drabbest, most colorless and inept classic of all time, up stepped the Dodgers and Yankees yesterday to cause a wholesale reshuffle of adjectives. For the spine-tingling events at Ebbets Field -- ancient observers insisted -- was without equal.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 3 -- M.E. Coyle, executive vice president of the General Motors Corporation, predicted here today that the total passenger car production this year would not exceed 3,750,000.
Operators of more than 15,000 hotels and lodging houses in the city are filling out new shorter forms listing their tenants for filing on Monday with the Board of Elections.
Irving Abramson, national director of organization of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, was notified yesterday that his office was being "abolished" effective Monday.

Charles P. Gross, who will retire as chairman of the Board of Transportation at midnight on Oct. 21, forecast yesterday that "sheer necessity" would compel a fare rise on the municipal transit lines. In a prepared statement he charged, without using names, that political fear had influenced Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate to reject a higher fare.

The Allied Artists of America, Inc. will open its thirty-fourth annual exhibition with a private view this afternoon from 2 to 7 at the National Arts Club in Gramercy Park. Beginning tomorrow it will be open to the public and it will remain through Oct. 26.

Store Sales Far Ahead Department store sales in Manhattan and Brooklyn this week showed considerable variation as reported by individual establishments, but the composite gain over the corresponding week a year ago was somewhat in excess of 50 per cent, according to trade estimates yesterday.
OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 4 -- Canada's election to the Security Council of the United Nations has been accepted as an honor that entails grave responsibility.

Food and Politics In Washington last week there w intense activity. There were spec Cabinet meetings, extraordinary gatherings in the White House, urgent conferences in Government executive departments. A harried White House secretary commented, "It's worse than when Congress is in session."

COLUMBUS DAY falling on Sunday this year, Monday, Oct. 13, will be widely observed as a holiday. There will be a general closing of banks and schools, and many offices are planning to give their employes a three-day week-end.

Somehow or other it isn't the spring when yachtsmen do most of their thinking and complaining about waterways, channels and aids to navigation. Instead, the autumn months are popular ones for planning navigation improvements, petitioning for deeper channels and more protected anchorages.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Enthusiasm being shown here for the new Scarsdale chapter of the United World Federalists and its demand for a United Nations "with teeth" received impetus today in the formation of similar chapters elsewhere in Westchester County.
TO THE EDITOR:
KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. 4 -- Colgate's football team routed Kings Point, 29-0, in its opening game today before a crowd of 8,000.

OLSZTYN (Allenstein), Poland, Oct. 2 (Delayed) -- The Government bloc has a stranglehold on political activity in this territory of former East Prussia, now the Polish Province of Olsztyn. It is a pyrrhic victory, however.

BEFORE the war there was an annual World Bridge Olympic. Prizes were offered to players who could achieve par results (the pars being fixed by committees of experts) on sixteen prearranged deals. The principal thing that the World Bridge Olympic proved year after year is that throughout the world there hardly exists a bridge player so good that he can play errorless bridge for sixteen consecutive deals.
I WANT to break my journey at San Francisco, please."

Governor Dewey, Mayor O'Dwyer and Cardinal Spellman will review the Columbus Day parade up Fifth Avenue next Sunday afternoon, it was announced yesterday by the Columbus Citizens Committee, Inc., 30 Rockefeller Plaza, the sponsor in cooperation with the City of New York.

BLACKENED stalks on tender frost-nipped annuals spur the gardener to tidy up his grounds. The fall clean-up should not be delayed until black frosts kill back vegetation, for good grooming is not the end purpose of this chore.

To meet the needs of the 2,750,000 college and university students in the United States, it will be necessary to construct 326,000,000 square feet of space, or roughly the floor space Of 150 Empire State buildings, the Committee on Service to Veterans of the National Social Welfare Assembly reported yesterday.

DENVER, Oct. 4 -- When Lieut. Gov. Arthur W. Coolidge of Massachusetts recently made reference to Rocky Mountain governors as "Little Boy Blues who may become sheepless Little Bo-Peeps," he caused an explosion of Western rage which is still reverberating up and down the hills.

After two months' study of industrial, agricultural and cultural methods in this country Prince Abdorreza Pahlevi, younger brother of the Shah of Iran, will start for his native land next week. The 23-year-old Prince was graduated from Harvard University last June after three years there.

HOLLYWOOD. THE United Artists distributing company weathered another crisis in its affairs with the purchase last week of a group of films from RKO and the re-establishment of bank credit for its own contributing producers.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:
TO THE EDITOR:

BOSTON, Oct. 4 -- About 100,000 delegates and members of the Holy Name Society, which is holding its national convention here, are scheduled to march tomorrow for an estimated twelve hours in perhaps the largest parade Boston has ever seen and certainly the largest religious procession in its history.
LAST year American men spent $112,800,000 on razors and razor blades, yet so far as one authority on the subject is concerned, very few of them know how to shave themselves properly.

In 1939 the British Labor party expelled Sir Stafford Cripps for fighting the Chamberlain policy of appeasement. Cartoonist David Low noted the occasion with a drawing called "Blimp's Purge" which showed the famous colonel blowing out his mustaches and declaring, "Gad, sir, the Labor party is quite right to expel all but sound Conservatives."

For almost fifty years Wilhelmina, Princess of Orange, has been Queen of the Netherlands. When she came to the throne she was a beautiful and gracious child, still devoted to her dolls. An equal devotion to her people in prosperity and trouble, in peace and war has left her a tired old woman, weighed down with responsibility.
PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla., Oct. 4 -- W. Gibson Carey Jr., 51, of Greenwich, Conn., president of the Yale Towne Manufacturing Company, was drowned today while swimming in the surf here with friends.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- Prime Minister Attlee made public this week the first installment of the longawaited changes in his Cabinet. More are expected. The accent is on austerity and planning. Taken at its face value, the Prime Minister's statement announcing the first major reshuffling means that the accent is also now on youth.

Edouard Nies-Berger, organist of the Philharmonic-Symphony, presented a tour-de-force at Town Hall last night, when he played and conducted from the organ bench. The usual effort was part of a concert by a chamber orchestra of men from the Philharmonic, under Mr. Nies-Berger's direction.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 4 -- Princeton dealt a 21-7 defeat to Brown today in Palmer Stadium. Into the making of that score went a moderate amount of Tiger power, particularly in the first half, but not much excitement for 25,000 spectators, the biggest opening day crowd at Princeton since the Penn game of 1935.

The Save Washington Square Committee, an organization formed recently to oppose the building of the New York University Law Center on a site facing the Square, declared yesterday that it would appeal to the Legislature to bar N.Y.U. legally from any further expansion on the square.
THREE special awards are given at the annual show of the American Dahlia Society in New York City.

A three-day sale of a large quantity of Georgian and Regency furniture from various owners, including Mrs. Elizabeth H. Baldwin of Parkersburg, W.Va., will be held at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, from Thursday through Saturday.

HERE, deep down, is the old conflict between good and evil: the dedicated man opposing the acquisitive tempter; the human being of natural integrity versus the powers of corruption, the retired judge, Gaskony, against his apparent friend, Severidge.
BUCHAREST, Oct. 4 -- The fires of a fierce "Hate America" campaign are being fanned throughout the Soviet Union and its satellite states day by day, week by week.

The slowdown in real estate activity during the past few months, contrary to improved business conditions generally, is temporary, and the real estate market is in for a healthy, normal expansion of activity rather than a marked upward trend in prices, in the opinion of Bernard P. Day, president of Joseph P. Day, Inc.
LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The question mark of Moscow hangs over the London conference on the future of the Italian colonies, which opened here yesterday at Lancaster House.

THERE is a difference between honesty and sincerity, in literature as in politics. Most of our working novelists sincerely believe that there is some kind of truth higher than any facts; most politicians (especially those out of work) sincerely believe that there are some ends which justify any means.
To the Screen Editor:

LINCOLN, Neb., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Minnesota handled Nebraska mercilessly in the first half and the fourth period today to crush the Huskers, 28 to 13, in a Big NineBig Six interconference game before 36,000 spectators.
TOKYO, Oct. 4 -- Details of the Japanese Communist party's new program of making a "peaceful revolution" were given, today by Sanzo Nosaka in Zenei, Communist publication.

CHAKLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 4 -- With the inauguration this week of a new president, the University of Virginia has embarked upon an extensive expansion program to meet the tremendous post-war demands placed upon it. A student body of 5,000 -- just about double the normal enrollment -- has brought a host of academic problems.

JIMMY FORREST does not think of what he has done as murder, but as the justified slaying of the man who killed Jimmy's best friend, Rubin, with whom Jimmy, as a young boy, had sworn a pact of eternal loyalty, sealed with the blood of both.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Scoring almost at will, the University of California walloped St. Mary's, 45 -- 6, today before a capacity crowd of 80,000.

THE recent entente cordiale signed by Mark Hellinger and g the Selznick Releasing Organization, whereby the company will distribute six Hellinger productions over the next two years, is an augury of similar alliances in the future it was revealed last week by Neil Agnew, president of SRO.

DATED 1937-1947 to indicate ten years of operation of the Moscow-Volga Canal system are the Soviet Union's 15-kopees chocolate, 30k chestnut, 30k brown, 50k blue, 60k rose and 1-ruble purple received by New York Stamp Company.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J. Oct. 4 -- Rutgers put over two fast touchdowns in the first period but played sluggishly thereafter In downing Western Reserve, 21 -- 6, today. The Scarlet eleven displayed little offensive power after its first period surges but was never threatened because the visitors could not work up a, sustained attack.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Officials confirmed today that the United States was renouncing the Italian battleship and other naval vessels to which it was entitled under the peace treaty with Italy, but beyond that they would not go in commenting on the official Announcement made in Rome.

FIRE PREVENTION propaganda has been so continuously emphasized over the years that, as Fire Prevention Week is ushered in today for the twenty-fifth time, people are inclined to think fires must be decreasing in the United States.

IT is a kind of nostalgia that is evoked -- comparable to the feelings I once had when I revisited a villa near Florence after ten years to find nothing changed, not even the lizards on the wall -- by re-examining, in the company of Francis MacManus, one of the greatest of all Western writers.

One of the most ambitious programs for memorializing our war dead is to take the form of a broad scientific investigation of the Pacific Ocean area. This program, to be called The Pacific War Memorial, envisages the establishment of two dozen or more field stations on scattered islands of the Pacific.

THIS is the time of year when foreign students flock to our shores. Last year the total was 18,000 -- more than double the prewar figure -- and, although dollar shortages abroad are a present limiting factor, the State Department hopes to see it reach 50,000 within the next five years.

SANTA CLAUS, Ind., Oct. 4 -- The battle of the postmarks is raging here, long before the beginning of the annual crescendo of holiday mail from millions of persons who want to have their packages and letters bear the sentimental stamp cancellation of "Santa Claus."

HIGH POINT STATE PARK, N.J., -- Seventy miles from Times Square and less than two hours by car from the George Washington Bridge, High Point State Park is a wilderness retreat ideally suited to the nature lover or hiker who would like to spend a leisurely fall holiday among picturesque woodlands, mountains and lakes.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. THIS department has set up temporary headquarters on Cedar Tree Neck, in the cabin of which mention was made four weeks ago, when I reported that I was once more able to look at a book without a feeling of revulsion.

While royalty payments are being considered by some exporters as a means of receiving remuneration from foreign countries, this method offers no solution of the acute dollar shortage, according to views expressed last week in authoritative foreign trade" quarters.

PROBLEM novels almost invariably run in cycles, and here are two out of the current crop dealing with the color problem, the situation rising when Negro blood is mixed with white. While wholly different in conception and treatment, both these novels have as their central theme the predicament of a mulatto so light skinned that he, or she, could pass as a pure white.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Veterans Administration deplored today the "growing" tendency of tenders to require down-payments from veterans buying dwellings with the aid of GI loans.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The President's air policy commission will start at noon tomorrow on Mr. Truman's personal airplane for a one-week inspection tour of the principal aviation manufacturing companies in the United States.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 4 -- This capital and the surrounding Federal District are conducting a campaign against high prices and the black market, as most other capitals are doing. Here the battle is being waged with intense vigor. Instead of being obsessed only by high prices, the people here also have to contend with price controls.

LORETTO, Pa, Oct. 4 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman expressed confidence here today that "right will prevail in the world" and that "we shall peacefully achieve the solution of our problems, if we buT pray and pursue a righteous peace."

DESPITE the optimism of T. P. Wright, Administrator of Civil Aeronautics, the current record of production and sales of private aircraft is a disastrous one. Mr. Wright has renewed his prediction of 400,000 personal planes in use in the United States and a production of 150,000 a year by 1955.

THE way things are shaping up around this town it seems that the tired business man is going to have a bit of a wait before he gets a "break" from musical comedy. Indeed, looking back over the recent years he hasn't had much of a break at all.

ASTER frikarti, Wonder of Staffa, deserves to be well known and widely used. It has one bad fault -- lack of hardiness -- but many merits offset this. This variety starts to bloom early in August and continues untill killing frost.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- For the first time since last June the Supreme Court will meet on Monday in a brief session, first of its 1947-48 term.

BENNINGTON, Vt., Oct. 4 -- Dr. Frederick Burkhardt was inaugurated as the third president of Bennington College this afternoon before an audience of more than 500 including representatives from thirty-one colleges.

STEERING in the Greek tradtion between the Scylla of European famine and the Charybdis of zooming prices here, President Truman tonight will offer the middle course of voluntary rationing of food. Not toe much hope is held forth for this course which is planned to save 100,000,000 bushels of wheat unless a fervor is fanned that approaches wartime objectives.

THE hard work of the summer in Paris on the part of the representatives of sixteen countries has produced a plan for European recovery. This plan is now under discussion in Washington by the executive branches of the Government. If it survives, however amended, it will be subjected to the still more searching scrutiny of the Congress.

LAKE 'SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The United States moved today to ease the Balkan deadlock by agreeing to drop sharp charges of guilt against Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania provided that they committed themselves to accept a new United Nations border-watch commission.

The obligation to help European nations to recover from the effects of the war rests upon the United States, in the opinion of high school students who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR from New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

The drugs now being used to relieve the symptoms of allergy have side reactions that may, in some cases at least, produce more dangerous and uncomfortable effects than the allergy itself, it was reported yesterday during the conference on "Anti-histamine Agents in Allergy" at the American Museum of Natural History.

YOKOSUKA, Japan, Oct. 4 -- Women are now serving virtually as a parole board for the 250,000 inhabitants of this former Japanese naval base. Capt. Benton W. Decker, United States commandant, who introduced this system, declares it has been working perfectly.

BLEEDING HEARTS, Dutch iris, oriental poppies, chrysanthemums and fall asters appeal to a great many gardeners, especially at fall planting time. This quintet, however, also has disadvantages, and is often at its best if planted elsewhere than in the border.

THE last three of Concert Hall Society's limited editions for 1946-47 are at hand, and they maintain the high standards this enterprising organization has set for itself, both in the character of the music chosen to be recorded and the quality of the recordings.

EVERY soldier thinks that it was his unit that won the war -- without much help from other units, and usually in spite of them. With the private, it's his platoon that did the job; and the conviction goes right on up the line, through companies, battalions, regiments and divisions.

"A BINGER HARVEST," a collection of essays by that distinguished English writer, E.M. Forster, was first published in 1936, and has been unavailable during the war years. Harcourt, Brace makes it available now, for $3.50. Mr. Forster's "harvest" is a yield of some eighty pieces, and among the choicer ones are the now famous essays, "Notes on the English Character" and "Adrift in India."

THIS is the story of Dr. John Jones, an etymologist who specializes in Asiatic languages and is as dull as his name -- until he acquires the power of the Evil Bye, thanks to a mysterious package he receives from a former student, now a GI on duty in the Near East.
ANNAPOLIS, Oct. 4 -- Navy was still looking for its first football victory since the opening game of 1946 as Columbia defeated the Midshipmen on Thompson Field today, 13 -- 6.

In an effort to improve attendance in the schools, Miss Regina C. M. Burke, associate superintendent in charge of the elementary division, has sent to school officials a "handbook" devised to provide methods by which schools may be made more attractive to pupils.
