WASHINGTON. DR. ALEXANDER WETMORE, executive head of the vast and popular Smithsonian Institution, is one of the few subjects to whom a photographer would never have to say, "Now, smile at the birdie."
Mayor O'Dwyer's mediation committee of citizens headed by Terence J. McManus arranged a settlement yesterday in the three-day-old tie-up of 150 Safeway stores in the metropolitan area.
TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The home of Washington Irving, in the heart of the Sleepy Hollow country about which he wrote, was dedicated here today as a museum.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The Herter Congressional committee investigating Europe's economic status intends on its return to the United States to question the Treasury privately -- and perhaps publicly -- on its reasons for not giving Paris complete information on several hundred million dollars of French assets still blocked in United States banks, it was learned today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 4 -- The national board of directors of the Progressive Citizens of America called today for public ownership of the steel industry, which it charged with fostering a steel famine "as good business."

New York's professional football teams both face critical tests on the road today. The Yankees of the All-America Conference will go to Cleveland to meet the chaimpion Browns, who are undefeated in four games to date. WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Four United States clergymen who inspected European occupation zones this summer at the invitation of the Army, made strong recommendations today that this country act speedily to help Germany and Austria regain their political and economic feet.

SAVANNAH, Ga. -- Historic Fort Pulaski. on Cockspur Island, Ga., has been, restored as a national monument and opened to the public During World War II it served as a Savannah River in-shore patrol station, as a Navy replacement center and also as a Coast Guard separation center.

A MAJOR objective of engineers who are planning automobile power plants of the future is to build an engine which will convert at least two quarts of every gallon of gasoline into power. WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Government officials, including President Truman, worked today on the "big broadcast" tomorrow night through which the Administration hopes to impart a real impetus to its program against food waste.

Our Unchanging Churches It has occurred to this department how little the churches of New York have been affected by the tide of change that has engulfed us in comparison with structures devoted to purposes other than, religious. Take, for instance, as striking evidence of this near-immunity the churches of Fifth Avenue.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 4 -- The Sailors Union of the Pacific, American Federation of Labor, gave notice today that it no longer intended to respect picket lines established in a collective-bargaining dispute since July 11 by ship and dock foremen, members of the International Longeshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union of the congress of Industrial Organizations.

Foreign-flag steamship companies have become increasingly, aware of the value of modern cargo protection devices, and in the last few months many have either purchased or ordered dehumidification units for their freighters, O.D. Colvin, president of the Cargocaire Engineering Corporation, said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The Soviet Union today renewed its attack on the "reactionary press" of the United States and Britain in a debate before the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

Evander Childs tallied at least one touchdown in every period yesterday to hand Seward Park a 31-0 defeat in the nightcap of the opening high school football double-header of the season at Triborough Stadium, Randalls Island. In the opener, Christopher Columbus of the Bronx held Stuyvesant to a 6-6 deadlock.

THE local recital season will apparently open officially on Nov. 2, when Iris Mabry will give a recital at the International Theatre, assisted by Ralph Gilbert, pianist-composer under the auspices of Fern Helscher.

Calumet Farm,s Citation and Bewitch didn't scamper off with all the loot they could have grabbed in the fifty-eighth Futurity before 40,266 racegoers at Belmont Park yesterday, but they didn't leave much for the others.

The bleacher line for the sixth game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium saw twenty-two persons waiting at 7 P.M. last night for an opportunity to buy tickets when the gates open this morning. The line formed outside the bleacher gate at River Avenue near 161st Street.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The Canadian Pacific's Empress of Canada that berthed in the thick fog at Prince's Landing stage in Liverpool this morning was the first large liner to come into a British port totally on radar. She dropped anchor only four minutes late.

BLANCHE KNOPF, the distaff side of the publishing house bearing that name, returned the other day from a visit to the heart of Europe. She says the literary air is more alive there than she's ever known it. So much is going on, Mrs. Knopf says, and, though it may not last, though it may be wrong, it's going on.

PECTIN -- Drs. Henry Welch, Harold L. Hirsh and S. Ross Taggart of the United States Food and Drug Administration and the District of Columbia Health Department find that pectin can slow down the rate at which penicillin, streptomycin and other drugs escape from the body.

FALL planting of perennials can hardly be done without considering some new varieties. Where older, less beautiful kinds have been used, improved sorts may be substituted. In other spots, a new hybrid may offer just the right coloring, height and size.

TWO large group annuals lee off in the exhibition calendar last week the Pepsi-Cola's fourth, "Paintings of the Year," installed at the National Academy of Design, and the thirty-fourth annual show presented by Allied Artists of America at the National Arts Club.

THERE are various ways of writing history. At the end of the last century it was fashionable for Germans to write their history as if all trends had culminated in Bismarck and in the glorious year of 1871. More recently German historians constructed and simplified the complexity of the past as leading to the triumphant emergence of Hitler.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Hofstra made the first downs and Montclair the touchdowns today as the Flying Dutchmen bowed to the Jersey eleven, 12 to 7, in the season's inaugural for both teams.

Give your children destructible furniture or resign yourself to having them destroy your good furniture," says designer Joseph Aronson, on the subject of furnishing a child's room. (He doesn't mean that a child's destructive tendencies should be encouraged -- merely that up to a certain age opportunities for untrammeled play are more important than fine furniture.)

EUREKA, Kan., Oct. 4 -- Roger W. Babson of Wellesley Hills, Mass., 72-year-old statistician, is telling Kansans they are living in the Mecca of the atom age. The citizenry in this former citadel of isolationism is somewhat skeptical but willing to listen.

Resuming Saturday trading after a lapse of four months, the stock market continued its recent upswing for the sixth consecutive session, but profit-taking near the close brought mixed price changes. Volume on the Stock Exchange aggregated 440,000 shares, compared with 230,000 shares for the previous half-day session last May.

Research in science and technology is now as much a part of industry as manufacturing and selling. But how are a scientifically uneducated corporation president and a hoard of directors to know whether or not a million dollars ought to be spent in finding out if a fiber stronger than silk can he made out of coal, limestone and air or whether or not alcohol can be changed into a substitute for rubber?
The revival of the Port of Uddevalla, Sweden, as one of that nation's important shipping centers is being greatly assisted by one of this country's wartime shipyards, it was disclosed last week.

Machinery manufacturers a meeting and solving future recession problems now, leading executives revealed here last week. Actions taken during the past month, and continuing through the fourth quarter of this year, assure that future business volume will be diversified so as to avoid severe cyclical depressions of the past, will stabilize employment and multiply the types of customers serve by equipment manufacturers.

MUNICH -- Even the Soviet representatives chuckled when some wag among the United States occupation forces, surveying the results of the division of Germany by the great powers, came up with the dry comment, "the Russians got the food, the British got the industry, and we got the scenery."

INTO the hands of that vast horde who escape the present by plunging into the romantic upheavals of the past, this book will settle with a rewarding bulkiness. Its 413 pages are filled with the kind of factual, colorful background, the dangers and intrigues, the love interest (there are three beautiful women instead of the usual one) that are now the accepted ingredients of most historical novels.

FOUR New Yorkers were among the recipients of PSA honors at the annual banquet of the Photographic Society of America in Oklahoma City last night. In all, forty associateships were conferred, ten fellowships and one honorary membership.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 4. -- The South is rapidly catching up with its share of, industrial research facilities that will insure it a prosperous future and improve its educational, recreational and cultural advantages, according to Dr. Raymond B. Seymour, director of the Industrial Research Institute of the University of Chattanooga.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- A call on the country to utilize the "reservoir of skills and abilities" of disabled veterans and other handicapped workers was issued today by Cabinet members and agency officials to inaugurate the observation of National Employ The Physically Handicapped Week, Oct. 5-11.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Senate investigators secretly resumed today an inquiry into $40,000,000 worth of wartime airplane contracts awarded to Howard Hughes, Hollywood millionaire.

On an average day during September about 16,000 workers in New York City were on strike-approximately normal. Last week the number of strikers was more than 27,000. The increase was caused mainly by a flurry of strikes and stoppages that affected four areas of the city's economic life -- railway express, food stores, restaurants, airlines:
ROME, Oct. 4 -- All United States troops except small liquidating and graves service detachments will have left Italy by Dec. 2, an Army spokesman announced here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Deputy Prime Minister of Australia, sketched for United Nations delegates today a relationship between a tiny Pacific island, smaller than Manhattan, and starving Europe. He spoke at a subcommittee meeting of the Trusteeship Committee in support of the trusteeship agreement for the island of Nauru.

HERE on these pages, are graphic instances of the campaign against the United States being carried on in the Russian press. That campaign, reaching a new pitch of intensity recently, last week brought an official protest to the Kremlin from the American Ambassador at Moscow.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- President Truman, in a letter to Ned H. Dearborn, president of the National Safety Council, expressed the belief that the country's annual accident death toll could be cut to 75,000 by 1950, or 25,000 below the present level, "if everyone does his part."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Representative Charles A. Eaton Republican, of New Jersey, chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, declared tonight that the Russian Government was now engaged in an "obvious campaign" to "intimidate and to carry beyond its borders and through the forum of the United Nations its own conceptions of bow to rule men.

SAN FRANCISCO -- New motion picture equipment was featured here last week in the Civic Auditorium as the Master Photo Dealers and Finishers Association held the first phatographic and trade show on the West Coast.

The freight car construction program formulated last February through the efforts of the Office of Defense Transportation is failing rapidly. Instead of the 10,000 new freight cars a month for domestic use that the car builders were to deliver starting with September, indications are that the industry this year may not reach the goal of 7,000 monthly, which was to have started with June.

CINCINNATI, Ohio -- The autumn sailings of the oldtime river packet Gordon C. Greene, which travels the Mississippi River and its tributaries from Cincinnati to New Orleans, will give a new group of travelers the opportunity to contrast the wonders of modern air-age travel with the more leisurely pleasures of travel in the time of Mark Twain.
"The dusky night rides down the sky And ushers in the morn; The hounds all join in glorious cry, The huntsman winds his horn, And a-hunting we will go."

In the first full week of trading since last May, the stock market moved higher each day and closed yesterday with prices at their best levels since early September. Responding to both news from Washington and the views of business leaders, steel, oil and liquor shares set the pace for the rest of the list.
BLOOMJNGTON1, Ind., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Earl Maves of Wisconsin raced 70 yards today to gain a 7-7 tie with, an Indiana eleven which played in Wisconsin's territory most of the game.

THE observance of anniversaries can be -- and has often been -- turned into a solemn bore. Now and then, however, such an occasion is made the excuse for much beneficent activity, and it looks as if the twenty-fifth anniversary of the League of Composers, to be marked this season, will be the stimulus for a good many lively occasions.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 -- Senator Robert A. Taft went home tonight to Cincinnati. He said he was highly pleased with what he had found on his 12,000-mile swing through the Far West, but was not quit ready to announce his candidacy for the Republican Presidential nomination.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:
To the Screen Editor:

President Truman, in a message to the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York on its thirtieth anniversary, asserted yesterday that the services rendered by the federation "are among the best possible contributions that can be made to America by any people, for they help all of us to carry out the American spirit of helping our neighbors."

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, Oct 4 (AP) -- Reports that Russia is building "rock houses" in the cliffs lining the shores of Siberia opposite St. Lawrence Island have been received from Siberian natives visiting the American island, according to the Rev. E.R. Parker, Presbyterian missionary on the island.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 4 -- Dartmouth packed too much power and deception in its backfield this afternoon and Syracuse dropped a 28-to-7 decision to the Big Green of Hanover before a crowd of 18,000 in Archbold Stadium.
CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Tortay's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.

Registration for the election Nov. 4 opens tomorrow in the city. Although this is an "off year" so far as election of candidates for public office is concerned, six proposed amendments to the State Constitution, three housing propositions and an amendment to the city charter to repeal the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council and substitute election by State Senate districts will come before the voters.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Oct. 4 -- Approval of the recommendation of the Council of Economic Advisers for wheat and other food controls was given this morning by Henry A. Wallace in an address to students and faculty of Mount Holyoke College.

ATHENS, Oct. 4 -- Railroad and telegraph communications between Alexandroupolis (Dede Agach), near the Greek-Turkish border, and the rest of Greece were interrupted today after guerrilla bands had blown up two bridges near the village of Kirmi and had torn down scores of telegraph poles.
TO THE EDITOR:

BOSTON. THE gleam appeared in the eye of Oscar Hammerstein 2d on a morning of March, 1946, and he telephoned at once to his collaborator. Two hours later, over lunch in New York, Librettist Hammerstein suggested to Composer Richard Rodgers the root idea from which developed, eventually, the new musical play, "Allegro."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- Miguel Cuaderno, Finance Secretary of the Philippines Republic, today deplored the United Nations failure to produce a concrete plan for the economic development of Asia despite the example set by the Marshall recovery plan for Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- This week's nomination for accepter of ungrateful assignments seems to go unanimously to James Howard McGrath, the youthful Senator from Rhode Island, for agreeing to head the Democratic National Committee.
TO THE EDITOR:

THREE years ago Frederick L. Jones, who has recently been called as Professor of English to the University of Pennsylvania, published a two-volume edition of Mary Shelley's letters. With the appearance of the journal of Mary Shelley in an identical format, scholars may avail themselves of the third inch in Professor Jones' three-inch shelf of books on Shelley from the point of view of the poet's second wife.

WHEN Adam Egg began falling in love with the new cook Benjamina, watching her slender hands' with delicate nails brush back her blazing hair, he tried to remember a song that an oiler on the Nevada during the war used to sing about pale hands, pink-tipped like some kind of flower.

MANILA, Oct. 4 -- Philippine Republic authorities are evincing concern over increasing nation-wide violence caused by rivalries in the approaching elections. On Nov. 11 voters will ballot for provincial and municipal officials and eight Senatorial posts.

WRIGHT FIELD, Ohio. SUPPOSE you were the pilot of a single-seat jet fighter, like the P-80 Shooting Star or the P-84 Thunder-jet. Suppose you were scooting across the skies at 40,000 feet or higher at more than 600 miles an hour, and suppose something went wrong -- your engine caught fire, or enemy flak or a machine-gun bullet damaged the controls.

LONDON, Oct. 4 -- The United States would take a long-term option on badly needed strategic materials as a means of proffering indirect aid to Europe, according to the program expected to emerge from the House committee just completing its tour of the sixteen nations represented at the Marshall plan conference.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- The transfer of the United Nations General Assembly to Geneva next year was raised today as a strong possibility. Several member countries supported a suggestion by Sweden that a shift to Europe might cut operating costs.

A GOOD example of an honest effort in a currently popular category is "No Certain Answer," a first novel by Aubrey Toulmin Carney. It is a species of fiction that might be termed the modern story of "atmosphere," in which character and incident are of secondary importance.

ROME, Oct. 4 -- Italy faces a 1,200,000-ton wheat deficit before the next crop is harvested. By curbing the black market, which the Government has begun to do, it is hoped that the deficit may be reduced to 1,000,000 tons, but this is the minimum amount that Italy must receive from the outside if the present bread ration is to be maintained.

JUST nine years ago this week in this review: Henry Hazlitt reviewed on Page One a new book by Bertrand Russell ("Power: A New Social Analysis") in which the author put forth the provocative thought that power is as fundamental a concept of social science as energy is of physics.

Mrs. Sari Gabor Hilton, wife of Conrad N. Hilton, hotel chain owner, surrendered at pistol point yesterday morning a king's ransom in jewels to a lone bandit who forced his way into her nine-room penthouse apartment at 8 East Eighty-third Street.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- five-hundred student veterans and adult members of their families who tried today to register here for the fall elections were challenged by the two Republican members of the board of registry. Next week each of the veterans and their family members will take the issue to the Supreme Court in White Plains.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Department of Justice today announced the entering of a consent judgment at Hammond, Ind., in the Government's anti-trust action against eight manufacturers of railway springs and spring plates and a trade association in which they hold memberships.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 4 -- The University of Texas turned on the heat to smash North Carolina, 34 -- 0, today.

ROBERT RYLEE, whose "Deep Dark River" was a best seller a while back, may very well have another in "The Ring and the Cross." Certainly he has packed more fireworks of one-sort or another into this new novel than many writers do in twice as many pages.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 4 -- Negro leaders in this state voted unanimously today to support a program of litigation aimed at eliminating discrimination in voting requirements, public transportation and opportunities to obtain certain forms of higher education within the state.
To the Drama Editor:

The fortieth annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards to be held in San Francisco, Calif., on Nov. 9 to 14 will feature two panel discussions by experts, one on parking and business district problems and the other on community development.

ANTWERP, Belgium, Oct. 4 -- The United States Army transport Joseph V. Connolly sailed from here this afternoon with the first bodies of American soldier dead of World War n to return home from the European theatre.

During the period extending from today until next Saturday, the nation this year, as in the past, will observe "National Employ the Physically Handicapped Week." Through employer institutes, demonstrations and publicity, those concerned with rehabilitation and employment will point out to industry that the disabled person, selectively placed, is a safe, reliable and efficient worker.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 4 (U.P.) -- Wallace Wade scored perhaps his sweetest victory today when his surprisingly strong Duke Blue Devils decisively trounced the Tennessee Vols, coached by his old rival, Bob Neyland, 19 to 7, before a crowd of 40,000.

EDITH J.R. ISAACS' "The Negro in the American Theatre" is a heartening record of what a healthy democracy in action can achieve. Little more than three decades have passed since the incomparable Bert Williams became the first featured Negro player in a white company.

Favored by cool weather, retail trade here made sharp gains last week. Department store volume was estimated at around 50 per cent higher than in the preceding week. Comparison, however, was with the 1946 delivery strike period.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 4 -- The sun shone brightly at Pitt Stadium today, but Old Sol had competition n the person of Johnny Lujack, whose efforts transformed a tough opener into a romp as Notre Dame crushed the University of Pittsburgh, 40 -- 6. The All-American guarterback of 1946 was a one-man game this brilliant afternoon.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 4 -- Two Jews were murdered today by assassins who ambushed them as they returned home from work in an Army camp. The killers' trail led to the orange grove of an Arab sheik near Petah Tikva where it was lost.
TO THE EDITOR:

"The laws grow by litigation," says a legal maxim. Last week the new Labor-Management. Relations (TaftHartley) Act, 1947, was in the process of growing as legal opinions were being shaped on two of its most important provisions.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 4 -- In next to a midsummer sail-racing day out on Long Island Sound, Bus Mosbacher today annexed the Sparkman Trophy with the International Class sloop Susan. Bob McCullough won with Felicity in the contest for the prizes of the class officers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The United States today discussed to weather men from fifty foreign nations some tricks of weather observation and reporting -- including how B-29s make regular flights over the North Pole to check on meteorological developments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Citizens Food Committee, headed by Charles Luckman, is energetically planning its campaign to persuade America to save 100,000,000 bushels of wheat to keep Europe alive. Headquarters are being set up now in a suite of offices in the old State Department Building, next door to the White House.

Frank Shea, was mobbed yesterday in the Yankee clubhouse. The freshman pitcher from the Naugatuck Valley, Connecticut, absorbed the most terrific good-natured battering visited on a Yankee World Series pitcher since the days when Art Fletcher and Earle Combs were around to lead the celebrants. The demonstration that followed the 2-to-1 Yankee triumph at Ebbets Field was the greatest outburst of feeling in the series by the American League champions.

DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 4 -- In view of 5,000 persons in the grandstand at the Danbury Fair, two small dual-control training planes collided 800 feet over the edge of the packed grounds at 2:25 P.M. today. Each plane contained a pilot instructor and a woman student. All four were killed.

ALTHOUGH a few "its" still lurk in the prediction, the Port of New York Authority last week gave new assurances that the vast New York International Airport in Queens, better known as Idlewild, will be open on a temporary basis next spring.

CAPTAIN PULESTON here attempts to carry the work of Mahan down through World War II. He has read the old grand master of sea power so thoroughly that he even produces a reasonable facsimile of the style of the original, including sentences beginning with "And" to carry the clauses that cannot somehow be squeezed in any other way.
REHOBOTH, Md., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Presbyterians from the North and South will meet for the first time since the War Between the States at the Old Rehoboth Church on Monday and Tuesday.

A $3,000,000 inventory in this region of used and unused aircraft components will be offered by sealed' bid to all buyers in a Government surplus sale opening Oct. 10 and closing at 5 P.M. Oct. 30, Carl P. Malmstrom, WAA director, announced over the weekend.

The kitchen at the Plaza Hotel at 11 A.M. clatters with lunch preparations, the huge stoves make the room 20 degrees warmer than the hall outside, cooks move about looking like surgeons in their white attire.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A record Chicago professional football crowd of 51,123 today watched the power-laden Chicago Cardinals trim, the National Football League champion Chicago Bears, 31 -- 7, as Paul Christman tossed two touchdown passes and himself sneaked to a third score.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Repeated Arab assertions that war will engulf the Middle East if the United Nations General Assembly approves either partition or federation of Palestine are labeled as "empty threats" in an analysis of the military and economic situation of the Arab nations.

NEW DELHI, India., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Master Tara Singh, leader of the Akali Sikhs, predicted today a death total of 1,000,000 persons as a result of past and future communal disorders incident to the setting up of the Dominions of India and Pakistan.
Three top-ranking scientists have been appointed to key posts at the Brookhaven National Laboratories in Upton, L.I., the atomic energy research center, it was announced yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- The creation of a general staff to assist Secretary General Trygve Lie in drafting master spending programs for the United Nations was recommended here today by budgetary experts as a cure for the organization's financial headaches.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 -- The greatest mass demonstration ever inspired in New England by Christianity and reverance for the name of God engulfed downtown Boston for eight and a half hours today. An estimated 3,500,000 persons poured into the city to watch 130,000 Catholic men march in the fourth national convention parade of the Holy Name Society.

Eighteen airline passengers who arrived yesterday from foreign countries without cholera inoculation certificates were ordered quarantined by United States Public Health doctors, bringing to thirty the number ordered quarantined since Friday.
Price ceilings on livestock, and Government requisitioning of cattle if growers refused to sell at maximum legal prices, were recommended yesterday by the National Meat Industry Council.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, says that United States policy already is starting to move "in the general direction" of the use of Article 51, the self-defense article of the United Nations Charter, to make possible "protective actions" that would not be subject to the veto.

The Communist International [Comintern], also known as the Third International, was founded in 1919 by the Russian Communist party to further a world-wide revolution of the proletariat, an aim that many Russian leaders felt was essential to the success of Communist theory.

Little Al Gionfriddo, the 5-foot6-inch outfielder, who was tossed into the $300,000 Dodger deal with the Pirates on last Derby Day, may have been forgotten last Friday but nobody overlooked him yesterday.

Giving thanks to God for bountiful crops, British citizens and descendants observed yesterday afternoon the twenty-sixth annual celebration here of the old British Harvest Festival in Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Wall Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- Pre-war consumer buying habits are returning to the retail shoe trade, but to a large extent former purchasers in the low-priced brackets are now spreading their trade more evenly in the medium-price range, a survey sponsored by the National Shoe Travelers Association, Inc., and prepared by James H. Smith Co., revealed today.

The Columbia Broadcasting System's American School of the Air will open its eighteenth consecutive season of broadcasts today from 5 to 5:30 P.M. with the presentation of a new program, "Liberty Road," a series dramatizing human rights as understood and practiced in different parts of the world.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- Prime Minister Attlee is having trouble getting his proposed Cabinet changes accepted by some of the Ministers concerned. An announcement of the changes was expected tonight, but it has now been postponed for a day or two.

For the moment the struggle for freedom in Europe centers in Italy. There the Communists are making their most desperate effort to take over the state. But they lost a battle yesterday morning after a dramatic all-night session of the Constituent Assembly, which registered three separate votes of confidence in Premier de Gasperi's non-Communist Government.

Not Unknown to Fame The town of Litchfield in Connecticut is keeping open house this coming Saturday -- a day chosen because on the record of past performance the Eleventh of October ought to be the finest of the year in those parts. Let's hope it will be just that.

BOSTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- With the accurate-passing assistance of Clyde Le Force, the spectacular Bill Dudley put on a one-man football show to give the Detroit Lions a 21-to-7 National Football League victory over the Boston Yanks today before 19,580 fans at Fenway Park.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The United States Chamber of Commerce suggested today that "fairly uniform" rates of investment from year to year by large industries would be an effective step in a proposed business-labor-Government program to keep prosperity.

BATAVIA, Oct. 5 (Reuters) -- Indonesian soldiers took prisoner three Dutch soldiers aboard a United States naval Beechcraft communications plane that made a forced landing yesterday at Pameungpeuk, on the south coast of Java, it was announced here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Airline traffic in September was the greatest in the twenty-year history of the business, industry officials said today on the basis of preliminary reports.

The first gifts of religious articles from the Jews of America to the Jews of Russia were sent to that country yesterday on board the Sergei Kirov. The shipment, by the American Jewish Council to Aid Russian Rehabilitation, is earmarked for Preluke in the Ukraine.

The American Jewish Congress will file a brief as amicus curiae today urging the United States Supreme Court to hear the case brought by Arnold Bernstein, shipping operator, to recover $900,000 from a Belgian shipping company that bought a Bernstein ship after Mr. Bernstein was deprived of his ships by the German Government.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 5 -- Pliny W. Nourse, a retired farmer, and Mrs. Nourse of nearby Lanesboro celebrated their fiftieth wedding anniversary today by inviting the entire town to a reception. Several hundred persons attended.

SANTA ANA, Calif., Oct. 5 -- Buelah Louise Overell and George (Bud) Gollum were acquitted of murder charges tonight. The jury of six men and six women returned innocent verdicts for each defendant on both counts of slaying her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Overell, in an explosion on their yacht on March 15.

Two hundred thousand spectators lined Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon for more than three hours to watch 50,000 marchers, mostly Polish-Americans, in the eleventh annual Pulaski Day parade, which was featured by numerous banners and floats denouncing Soviet control of Poland.

With the national art spotlight on Pittsburgh, where the annual exhibition at Carnegie Institute opens on Thursday, the present week is one of the most congested ever to confront local galleries and museums, with notable group and one-man shows listed.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 5--The Communist party's principal political organ, Rude Pravo, charged today that the United States and British air forces had bombed Czechoslovak industrial plants during the war primarily to eliminate the commercial competition of those factories.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Following are the texts of the broadcasts made tonight by President Truman, Secretaries Marshall, Anderson and Barriman and Charles Luckman, chairman of the Citizen's Food Committee:

TOKYO, Oct. 5 -- Occupation officials moved today to show the Japanese people that they stood squarely behind the Katayama Government in the matter of crop collections. Addressing the conference of Prefectural Governors, Lieut. Col. J.H. Boulware of the natural resources section, declared that Gen. Douglas MacArthur was determined to collect the rice and sweet potato quotas already set.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 5 -- A deal is in negotiation between Universal-International and Sonja Henie for Miss Henie to return to the screen in "The Countess of Monte Cristo." a picture which John Beck will produce if an agreement is reached. Miss Henie's last film was "It's a Pleasure," released by RKO in 1945 and produced independently by International Pictures, which has since merged with Universal.
BERLIN, Oct. 5 -- Listeners' mail received by RIAS (Radio Station in American Sector) indicates that Germans in the Soviet zone fear the Russian and German Communist authorities.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 5--The fifteen-member executive council of the American Federation of Labor, at a session lasting almost three hours this afternoon, failed to iron out its differences and take a convention-eve stand on the lively issue involving non-Communist affidavits.

United States Inspected Foods Educational Service, Inc., will distribute 10,000 copies of a new giant four-color wall poster, "Do You Know the ABC of Buying U.S. Graded Canned Fruits and Vegetables?" to teachers of consumer studies in high schools, colleges, universities, graduate schools, state and county extension services and other adult education groups in the nation, it was announced over the week-end.

R. H. Macy Co., Inc., reported yesterday for thfe fiscal year ended on Aug. 2 a consolidated net income of $7,071,060 after charges and taxes. This was equal, after dividend requirements on the preferred stock, to $3.70 each on 1,719,354 common shares in the hands of the public.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Racking up three touchdown strikes, Quarterback George (The Kid) Ratterman led the Buffalo Bills to a 27-to-25 triumph over the Los Angeles Dons in an AllAmerican Football Conference game before 36,087 fans here today.

In an effort to promote international peace and understanding and pave the way for agreement on the issue of Greece, which in one form or another has been before the United Nations for nearly two years, the United States has accepted a compromise proposal long urged by France and Belgium.

In an indirect retort to recent Soviet charges that the United States seeks to control Greece, Warren R. Austin, permanent delegate to the United Nations, said in a broadcast yesterday that this Government had clearly shown by its actions that it did not intend to "dominate" any country.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 5 -- Unification of the armed forces has not sifted down very far into the field as yet but a straw showing the wind is already in the air. By the end of next month all Navy airplanes flying in the United States will have access to the nationwide flight service of the Air Force Air Transport Command.
A simple solution for family tensions caused by crowded homes was proposed yesterday by David Goldman, a member of the City College Psychology Department.

Harrison W. Flickinger, a vice president of the Republic Aviation Corporation of Farmingdale, L.I., who was a retired lieutenant colonel of the Army Air Force, died yesterday at the Nassau Hospital in Mineola, L.I., after a week's illness.

WESTBURY, L.I., Oct. 5 -- Having little use for the one-goal handicap they were awarded at the start, the Hurricanes scored a convincing 9 -- 3 victory over George Oliver's Westchester four in the final-round match of the twentysecond Monty Waterbury Memorial Handicap polo tournament on International Field at the Meadowbrook Club today.

WARSAW, Poland, Oct. 5 -- The leaders of world communism proclaimed today what amounted to the re-establishment of the Communist International [Comintern] to combat what they called United States "dollar imperialism."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Cyrus Eaton, Cleveland industrialist and banker, called upon Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman today for a demonstration of his support of the cause of regional financial independence.

SHANKS VILLAGE, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Spokesmen for student veterans, whose right to register was challenged yesterday by the Republican members of the registration boards at the three polling places in this area, complained today about the slowness of the process.

Rossini's "The Barber of Seville" was presented by the New York City Opera Company as the latest addition to its repertoire, last night at City Center. Much care obviously had been expended on the new production. It was attractively staged and costumed, and moved along smoothly.

It was a day for strolling in Washington Square. Indian summer, World Series baseball and outdoor art were in the air, but most of those who strolled knew that none of the three would be there much longer.

Out of a difficult poem by Robinson Jeffers, Michael Myerberg has constructed an,engrossing work of theatre. The poem is "Dear Judas". It was acted in the form of a masque at the Mansfield last evening. In honor of the quality of imagination that has gone into the production it would be a privilege to describe the result as triumphant.

It seems to be generally agreed that Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson is a high-minded gentleman and a competent administrator. When, however, it becomes a question of taking a firm position on a major issue where this might mean courting the displeasure of the politically, powerful farm group, this Cabinet member if one may judge by appearances, is still a Congressman at heart.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- A corn crop of about 2,450,000,000 bushels in the United States is indicated by private crop estimates, or slightly more than a Department of Agriculture report as of Sept. 15, comparing with 2,404,000,000 bushels on Sept. 1 and with the high record yield of 3,287,000,000 bushels in 1946.

The Comintern has come out again into the open, more militant and more powerfully backed than before. This is the significance of the news that the Communist leaders of nine European countries met last month in Poland to draft a new manifesto and unify their activities and their propaganda.
A $1,000,000 expansion of Veterans Administration mental hygiene clinics in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx was announced yesterday.

The Right Rev. William T. Manning, retired bishop of the Protestant Episcopal diocese of New York, joined yesterday in opposing New York University's plan to build a law center on the south side of Washington Square.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, a United States delegate to the United Nations, started yesterday a new series of broadcasts, to be heard weekly over a nation-wide hook-up of the American Broadcasting System, to give the American people a background on the work of the United Nations The program, conducted on the forum plan, is known as "The World Security Workshop."

A new group of modern furniture, larger in scale and more elaborately carved than most contemporary pieces, has just been introduced at Wanamaker's. The new collection was designed by Harold M. Schwartz. The pieces are available in oak in either a bleached tan or "great smoky" gray finish.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Neither White House nor State Department spokesmen would comment tonight on the news from Moscow of the formation of a Communist international organization to fight "United States imperialism."

BALTIMORE, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The San Francisco Forty-Niners came from behind with two quick touchdowns in the fourth period to gain a 28-28 tie with the surprising Baltimore Colts in a tingling AllAmerica Football Conference game today before a crowd of 29,556 persons.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- All deliveries of wheat sold last week at new seasonal high prices on the Board of Trade. The dominating influence was heavy and sustained buying of cash grain by Government agencies. Purchases of cash wheat for exports in various positions, including commercial transactions, are estimated at more than 20,000,000 bushels, which was sufficient to keep the slack out of the market despite large receipts of spring wheat at northwestern terminal markets.

With registration for the Nov. 4 election in this city beginning today, leaders and workers of all four political parties, Democratic, Republican, American Labor and Liberal, prepared yesterday for intensive work this week to get as large a registration of their party members as possible.

PARIS, Oct. 5 -- Communism and the resistance to it under the leadership of Charles de Gaulle came into open conflict in the French political arena here today. France's alliance with the United States and Great Britain is the stake.

ROME, Oct. 5 -- Smarting under the defeat of their efforts to overthrow the de Gasperi Government, the Communists charged today that they were betrayed by Giuseppe Saragat, right-wing Socialist. They said he was bribed by American dollars.

NANKING, Oct. 5 -- The Control Yuan charged today that "privileged corporations," headed by relatives of Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and former Premier T.V. Soong had obtained more than their "allowed quotas" of foreign exchange and had imported luxury goods that others were barred from importing.

CALCUTTA, India, Oct. 5 -- The famine that has long threatened eastern India is now a reality in many areas. The death roll from starvation on this side of India may, after November, be higher than that caused by communal rioting in the northwest.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Three prickly problems face the United Nations delegates this week.

AL GIONFRIDDO works as a fireman on the Pennsylvania road during the off season. In his spare time he makes miraculous catches at crucial moments in the world series. This refugee from a troupe of Singer Midgets sent the incredible Dodgers into the seventh game of the post-season classic by robbing Joe DiMaggio of a three-run homer with one of the most unbelievable catches ever seen anywhere.

Cotton textile exports, which so far this year have exceeded any full year in history, may easily reach a new high of 1,300,000,000 yards by the end of 1947, it was pointed out yesterday by textile exporters. If such a volume is attained it will be almost twice that of 1946 and more than 400,000,000 yards over the previous high record year of 1920.

A general tie-up of railroad freight deliveries in the metropolitan area will be recommended by leaders of the striking Railway Express Agency drivers at a meeting of the Teamsters Joint Council tomorrow , it was reported last night.

The bestowal of a special Papal benediction on the clergy and parishioners of St. Alphonsus Roman Catholic Church, 308 West Broadway, was announced yesterday at a solemn pontifical mass commemorating the one hundredth anniversary of the founding of the parish.
Incredible as it may seem to a bewildered world at large, the 1947 world series is still with us, and so are the Dodgers.

Max Lefcourt, buyer of men's shoes at Saks Fifth Avenue, has resigned to enter private business. His duties will be assumed by Robert Katzenstein. Emil Moos, formerly assistant to Mr. Katzenstein, will become assistant to Martin Cook, merchandise manager.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5 -- The Philadelphia Eagles scored in every period to defeat the New York Giants, 23 -- 0, before a crowd of 29,823 at Shibe Park today. It is doubtful if the Giants have ever spent a more miserable afternoon in their twenty-three years in the National Football League.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The movement in favor of a suspension bridge across the Narrows must spring from some worthy portion of this community, but up to the present time we have failed to perceive where, except in the few and far-flung real estate shops of the Borough of Richmond.

The final round of the open pairs event in the thirteenth annual Metropolitan Bridge Tournament was won last night by a pair of relatively unknown players, George Rosenblatt and Leander Levy, both of New York. Eighty-six pairs competed in the afternoon qualifying round for the Oswald Jacoby Trophy, and forty-two pairs in the evening.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 5 -- The congress of the Rumanian Social Democratic party, convened to ratify its fusion with the Communist' party, opened today. It was called to decide formally the party's acceptance of the "political, organizational and ideological unity of the working class" required by the Communists.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5--President Truman asked the American people tonight to observe meatless Tuesdays and use no poultry or eggs on Thursdays and to save a slice of bread a day.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 5 -- Distribution costs are still high but they can be reduced by combining more effective advertising methods with harder hitting selling in the field, advertising leaders revealed while attending the preview of "know-how" exhibits at the Chalfonte Haddon Hall here today, at opening sessions of the 38th annual Association of National Advertisers convention.

The latest vogue of voluminous dresses and long skirts was denounced yesterday by the Rev. Samuel M. Shoemaker in his sermon in Calvary Protestant Episcopal Church, Fourth Avenue and Twenty-first Street. He declared that the extra cloth could be used to keep the needy throughout the world warm.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- The British Government is "not losing any sleep" over the announcement that a new version of the comintern had been established with head quarters in Belgrade, an official spokesman said tonight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As a Christian friend of the Jewish people, I feel impelled to comment on Rabbi Morris S. Lazaron's sermon on the occasion of the Jewish New Year, reported in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 15.
Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen?. The need is desperate. The time is short. We must act.
The explosion which sent the Yankees down to defeat and tossed the World Series into the seventh and rubber game, had its echoes yesterday in the Yankee clubhouse.

SAARBRUECKEN, Germany, Monday, Oct. 6 -- Proponents of economic fusion of the coal-rich Saar with France scored an overwhelming victory in the election yesterday that decided the issue by indirect ballot. The voting reversed the result of the plebiscite of Jan. 13, 1935, that turned the Saar over to Adolf Hitler's Germany.

BATAVIA, Java, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Ameriean military observers who toured the East Java front from the Republican side reported today that the Royal Dutch Shell Oil Company's Tjepoe oilfield and refinery, where the Dutch had reported extensive fires several weeks ago, were now intact and working.
Man's moral sense lags far behind his scientific accomplishments, the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken asserted in his sermon yesterday at the Riverside Church.

BERLIN, Oct. 5 -- On the eve of his departure for the Washington conference to discuss the possible revision of the formula for sharing occupation costs in the bi-zonal area, Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today that dollar help by the United States to Britain and other countries obviously affected the bizonal economy.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 5 -- A bill proposing a Federal Elections Act that would require every State to hold primary elections for Congress, insure independent and minority candidates a place on the ballot, and prohibit educational tests for prospective voters is scheduled for introduction at the next session of Congress.

IN the imperial city of St. Petersburg in the year 1881 a group of terrorists succeeded in achieving their highest ambition, the assassination, of Czar Alexander II. That celebrated murder provides the final climax to Mark Aldanov's long and skillful novel, "Before the Deluge."* It also provides a hook on which the author has hung a number of conclusions about the meaning and result of violence and revolution in history.

Floyd Worthington, gifted baritone from St. Joseph, Mo., gave his third New York recital late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. His program was devoted almost entirely to songs of the lied variety. His composers included such well known masters of the form as Schubert, Grieg and Wolf, as well as the lesser known Franz, Loewe and Trunk.

Frank Goldman, international president of B'nai B'rith, appealed yesterday to President Truman to support the partition of Palestine as recommended in the majority report of the United Nations Commission on Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Exemption of low-priced jewelry from the 20 per cent excise tax would lead to tax avoidance and involve serious administrative difficulties, the Treasury Department reported today.

The thirty-seventh anniversary of the consecration of St. Patrick's Cathedral was observed there yesterday with pontifical mass celebrated by Bishop William R. Arnold, Military Delegate and former Chief of Chaplains, United States Army.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 5 -- That United States-Netherlands trade is not developing satisfactorily is the common opinion in trade and industrial circles here. In the first eight months of this year Dutch imports from United States amounted to 802,000,000 guilders, against exports of only 23,000,000 guilders, whereas in 1939 imports were 146,000,000 guilders against exports of 42,000,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You have no conception of the large amount of appreciation which exists among the members of the New York Library Association for the support which THE NEW YORK TIMES gives to our campaign for improved state-wide library service.

CHICAGO, Oct. 5 -- New construction and increased real estate values have added more than $3,000,000,000 in property valuations to assessment rolls in fortynine major population centers in the United States this year, the Public Administration Clearing House said today.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 5 -- TWO top members of the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union local 1-13 will fly to San Francisco tomorrow to press demands before the Coast Labor Relations Committee that it intercede in the dispute that has resulted in a tie-up of the Los Angeles and Long Beach harbors, union heads reported today.

Progressive management throughout the country is showing real evidence of restraint in its labor and personnel relations under the Labor Management Relations (Taft-Hartley) Act of 1947, Alvin E. Dodd, president of the American Management Association, said in an interview over the week-end.

A whacking hit of the 1929-30 depression season, "The First Mrs. Fraser" will be revived for the first time on Broadway with Jane Cowl in the role created by Grace George. The St. John Ervine comedy will be ushered in by Gant Gaither the week of Nov. 3 following a week's tryout in Philadelphia.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months, amount to $56,242,972,847. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

The Board of Transportation announced yesterday that it had submitted to the Board of Estimate a report showing an operating deficit of $18,000,000 for the city's unified transit system for the fiscal year ended June 30. Operating revenues fell $16,711,927 below operating expenses, and it was necessary to set aside an accident claim reserve of $1,288,073 for the surface lines, making a total deficit of $18,000,000.

NANKING, Oct. 5 -- The strategic railway hub of Szepingkai has been cut off on all sides by the capture of Kaiyuan, sixty miles northeast of Mukden, according to the Communist radio. A broadcast tonight said Gen. Lin Piao's Red forces in Manchuria controlled almost two-thirds of the ChangchunMukden Railway.

LONDON, Oct. 5 -- A better tendency accompanied by a slight expansion in business has occurred in the stock markets here. More settled labor conditions in the coal mines has helped to cheer the prospects, as also President Truman's move to hasten aid to Europe.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 5 -- The apse of Battell Chapel at Yale University was dedicated today as a memorial to sixteen former undergraduate deacons who lost their lives in World War II. The dedication of the remodeled apse occurred at a public worship attended by Charles Seymour, president, deans of the schools and masters of the undergraduate colleges.
A "vigorous campaign" to amend the Feinberg Law on teachers' pay was predicted yesterday by the Joint Committee of Teachers Organizations.

Tallying all of its points in the last half, Cardinal Hayes High School won its first game in two starts yesterday at Triborough Stadium on Randall's Island by downing Power Memorial Academy, 28 -- 7. The loss was Power's second straight of the season and its fourth in five contests with the winners.
Toys this Christmas will emphasize the joys of peace -- and so will their prices. The American Toy Institute said they would cost 10 per cent more.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 5 -- Arthur Knapp at the helm of the International class racing yacht Bumble Bee, and John Halstead, guiding his Class S sloop Fidget, were the winners in the fall regatta held today off the Larchmont club.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 5--Steel demand last week kept rolling at peak levels and most steelmakers were reported hard pressed to maintain output at 95 per cent of rated capacity, unchanged from the week before. There was no indication of any lessening in overall steel requirements from all types of consumers.
The world series is still with us and football has hardly entered full upon the stage, but already some of the proudest college citadels are in desolation, their hopes of empire blasted.

LONDON, Oct. 5 (AP) -- The Palace said the rest of the service would "follow the form used at the marriage of the King and Queen in 1923." The Archbishop of Canterbury and the Dean of Westminster will be the chief officiating clergymen and the Archbishop of York will read the address.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 5 -- No matter where the New York Yankees go in their All-America Football Conference travels, they shatter attendance records. Today they were at Cleveland Stadium, where 80,067 fans turned out for their struggle with the champion Cleveland Browns, but the success of the New Yorkers was limited to one of mere dollars and cents.

Ruggiero Ricci presented a program devoted entirely to modern vtolin works at his recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The offerings included three novelties. Jean Hubeau's Concerto in C major and Milhaud's "Farandoleurs" received their first New York performances, and Vittorio Gfiannini's unaccompanied Sonata was heard for the first time anywhere.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- The National Labor Relations Board is expected to make a 4 to 1 decision tomorrow upsetting the ruling of the board's general counsel, Robert N. Denham, on the requirement for signing non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley Act.

MOSCOW, Oct. 5 (U.P.) -- The text of a communique, published in the Soviet newspaper Pravda, announcing that a conference of Communist parties of nine European countries had been held in Poland: At the end of September in Poland took place an informational conference with the participation of the following Communist parties:

The play-by-play description of the sixth game of the world series at Yankee Stadium yesterday follows: FIRST INNING DODGERS -- Stanky lined a single to left. After two balls, Reese singled over second to short center, Stanky pulling up at second.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Oct. 5 -- "The National Bank of Switzerland has not the slightest ground for changing its dollar policy," declared National Councilor Dr. Mueller, new chairman of the board of the bank, in answering criticisms in Parliament. He added:

Two mysterious telephone calls, made two days before Mrs. Sari Gabor Hilton, wife of Conrad N. Hilton, hotel chain owner, was robbed of jewelry valued at more than $500,000 in her penthouse apartment at 8 East Eighty-third Street, came under police scrutiny yesterday, as detectives began a widespread hunt for the loot.

Newspaper men waiting last evening for an advanced release of President Truman's radio talk on the food crisis had the impression of a Chief Executive laboring under a responsibility almost too great for one man to bear. Mr. Truman evidently had trouble, as he has had trouble all along, in making up his mind as to precisely what ought to be said and done.

There was a firm undertone and a good turnover last week in the pound sterling, and the free currencies of Canada and Switzerland, the three foreign exchanges which have been the principals of recent market interest. In other sections business was only fair and rates were maintained at prevailing levels.

The return of cool weather seemed to have turned the trick in the retail field with stores from all sections of the country reporting increased volume and activity in all departments and reorder telegrams and rush orders piling in, according to the reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 5 (AP) -- A hard-charging line paved the way to a 17-14 Green Bay victory over the Los Angeles Rams today in a National Football League game before 31,613 fans at State Fair Park.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 5 (U.P.) -- The Catholic Parents Association, formed about a month ago to fight admission of Negro students to white Catholic parochial schools, voted tonight to end their opposition and disband the organization. The vote was taken after a stormy fifty-minute session.

In a plea for disabled veterans of World War II, Maj. Gen. Robert M. Webster, commanding officer of the First Air Force, stationed at Fort Slocum, told a rally in Columbus Circle yesterday that all the disabled veteran needed was a job.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 5 -- The collision of two small training planes here yesterday afternoon was attributed today to an error in judgment by one of the pilots, not to recklessness.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 5 -- Premier Ahmad Ghavam won an overwhelming vote of confidence in the Majlis [Parliament] today, receiving 93 out of 120 votes, with only twelve ballots actually cast against him. Eleven members did not vote and there were four blank ballots.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 (AP) Old, reliable Sammy Baugh threw three touchdown passes today to enable the Washington Redskins to come from behind and top the Pittsburgh Steelers, 27 -- 26.

READING, Pa., Oct. 5 (AP) -- Lanky Dutch Harrison, a fine golfer when the chips are down, slashed three strokes from par today in the final round of the $10,000 Reading Open to win by a three-stroke margin with a 277 total.

VIENNA, Oct. 5 -- Two Austrian Cabinet Ministers charged today that Austrian Communists, with the help of the Soviet Army of occupation, were planning to use here the "plot" technique already employed with such success in Hungary and now being tried out in Czechoslovakia.

Cotton prices In the domestic market last week moved irregularly, but ended the period showing small net increases. At, the close on Saturday, active futures contracts, on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net gains of 5 to 25 points, with the May, 1948, contract recording the largest gain.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 5 -- Heber Blankenhorn, a veteran investigator for the National Labor Relations Board, has resigned.

In the closest and one of the liveliest contests in the history of the Metropolitan women's pairs championship, the New York team of Mrs. Clementine Van Slochem and Mrs. Henrietta Hess led the field at the end of the first session yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- The United States again sought today to drive home its answer to Soviet attacks upon a "warmongering" American press.
ROME, Oct. 6 -- The revival of the Comintern is regarded in Italy as one of the most important political developments since the end of the war.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 -- President William Green told the opening session of the American Federation of Labor's annual convention today that wage increases won by organized labor since the end of World War II had kept the American economy from "spiraling into another depression to date."

Baseballs were flying up at the Stadium yesterday, but simultanepusly football was very much in the air at Toots Shor's. The occasion was the weekly luncheonmeeting of the Football Writers Association, wnich had for its principal speakers representatives from Illinois and Army.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Whether Greece, Trieste and other strategic areas of Europe will be held against Communists, or given up, has become one of the most important questions facing the United States and the world today. This is the conclusion of Representative Thomas A. Jenkins, Republican, of Ohio.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Disagreement on two major points of procedure blocked all progress today at the second meeting of the Foreign Ministers' deputies on the future of the Italian colonies. The Soviet Government has now agreed, however, to the dates proposed by Great Britain for the opening of the meetings of the deputies for the German treaty and of the Council of Foreign Ministers.
"That's it. That does it That's my retirement."

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, has decided against a temporary removal of his ban on the duplication of network musical programs over both standard and frequency modulation stations. He made known his decision at a meeting yesterday morning with officials of the networks.

Court action, suggestions for legislation, and informative services will be used by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith in a nation-wide campaign against racial and religious discrimination in housing. This was announced yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink, national chairman of the league.

Catholic colleges have a special mission to help mankind satisfy its hunger for brotherhood of man and redemption from sin, Msgr. Fulton J. Sheen, Catholic University professor and radio lecturer, told 500 alumnae of the College of Mount St. Vincent last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Before the conferences began in Washington today, industrial technicians both Inside and outside the United States government already had noted flaws in the response of the Sixteen-Nations Committee to the Marshall proposal. It may be that Sir Oliver Franks, chairman of the drafting committee at Paris, will be able during these conferences to explain away the flaws or cure them.

News patterns in wallpapers designed by Bent Karlby, Danish architect, are included in an exhibit of current work by associate members of the American Institute of Decorators which opened yesterday. The show, at the national headquarters, 41 East Fifty-seventh Street, will last for one month.

The United States Circuit Court Of Appeals granted a temporary stay yesterday afternoon of an order signed earlier in the day by Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe that dinected John Santo, international organizer for the Transport Workers Union, to testify at his own deportation hearing at 9:30 A.M. on Thursday.

The revelation of last night's allStravinsky program by the New York City Symphony under Leonard Bernstein at the City Center was the Violin Concerto in D. With Tossy Spivakovsky as the soloist, the concerto had an impressive performance, and its stature as one of the composer's significant scores became clear to a large audience.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 6 -- Irving C. Freese, the Socialist candidate, was elected Mayor of Norwalk today by a plurality of 3,856 votes over his Republican opponent, Robert B. Oliver, and 4,715 over Robert E. Howard, Democrat.

A proposal by the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad for a "restricted" forty-six-trip ticket good only from Mondays through Fridays was attacked yesterday by a commuting organization and several individual commuters at a Public Service Commission hearing.

Erno Valasek, 27-year-old Cleveland violinist, whose career was interrupted by three years of service in the United States Army, gave a recital last night at Town Hall. It was his first appearance here since February, 1942, when he played with the New York Philharmonic -Symphony as the second of the Edgar M. Leventritt Foundation award winners.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Spokesmen for two Latin-American countries, Panama and Uruguay, in statements before the United Nations Special Committee ion Palestine here today, favored the partition of Palestine, but the representatives of a leading Arab country, Iraq, violently opposed it.

LONDON, Oct. 6 (U.P.) -- One of contemporary music's most famous composers, Richard Strauss, broken and penniless, was ushered back into the limelight last night at a London concert, where he was applauded by an audience who still remembered his great music.

The number of employes furloughed by American Overseas Airlines in the New York area as a result of the week-old strike of 173 pilots and co-pilots, members of the Airlines Pilots Association, has reached 1,303, the company said last night. It also was learned that foreign employes of the company had cabled the Pilots' Association protesting against the strike and urging a prompt settlement on a basis of "fair play."

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Directors of the Chicago Board of Trade today acceded to Government demands to increase margin, or down payment, requirements in grain-futures trading to 33 1/3 per cent of the purchase price. The ruling applies to new trades only and is not retroactive, according to directors of the exchange.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The government moved to curb grain speculation today by forcing markets to increase margins to 33 1/3 per cent. The action was taken in telegrams sent to the ten major markets by the Commodity Exchange Commission
VIENNA, Oct. 6 -- Unless the Russian delegate, Kyrill Novikov, returns from Moscow with new proposals, the Austrian treaty commission will wind up its proceedings at the end of this week.

ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 6 -- The Marshall plan for aid to Europe was discussed in detail by four experts tonight before 1,000 persons in the auditorium of the Woman's Club of Orange at the 100th forum in the series "What's on Your Mind?" presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The public utilities division of the Securities and Exchange Commission recommended today disapproval of the amended reorganization plan of the American Light and Traction Company as proposed by its parent, the United Light and Railways Company.

The Social Service Employes Union, Local 19, United Office and Professional Workers of America, CIO, announced yesterday signing of a two-year agreement with the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies covering 200 employes.

As the Postoffice began to bog down yesterday under the avalanche of packages thrust upon it by the Railway Express Agency strike, Mayor O'Dwyer summoned strike leaders to a new City Hall conference this afternoon to seek settlement of the eighteen-day-old tie-up.

Allotments will be continued by manufacturers on men's worsted, gabardine and tropical worsted suits when lines are opened next week, it was reported here yesterday. No change has developed in the expectation that price increases of about 5 to 10 per cent will be made for the new season, with manufacturers seeking to limit rises wherever possible through added cost absorption.
The Yankees had a trump card after all, and as a consequence the Bronx Bombers are back once more in a long-familiar role as baseball champions of the universe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Senate majority whip, said today that he would insist upon being given full information concerning a reported $14,000,000,000 of foreign investment in the United States before he would commit himself on the Marshall Plan for assistance abroad.

The $18,000,000 operating deficit on the city's transit system for the fiscal year ended June 30 comes as no surprise. However, the rapidity with which the situation is worsening is emphasized by a comparison with the previous year, when there was an actual operating surplus of more than $8,000,000.

If big brewers continue to raise their prices, ten-cent beer will end in, the taverns of this city as well as in New Jersey and other eastern states, Arthur W. Gillette, president of the United Restaurant and Liquor Dealers of Manhattan, declared yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Western Military Government officials predicted today that the new Communist party offensive against the United States would start almost immediately in the German Ruhr, perhaps in the shape of strikes and demonstrations.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- The thirty-fifth National Safety Congress and Exposition opened here today with an attendance of 10,000 persons from every section of the nation who will exchange ideas and formulate new procedures for making schools, homes and industries safer places in which to work and live.

The Better Business Bureau of New York City will celebrate its twenty-fifth anniversary with a luncheon in the Waldorf-Astoria on Oct. 30, it was announced yesterday by Sheldon R. Coons, president. Mayor O'Dwyer will be the principal speaker.

Firm to higher prices featured the opening yesterday of spring lines by volume shoe manufacturers at the Hotel New Yorker. The larger shoe operators, including jobbers and chains, were active in covering requirements through December and January, although caution generated by peak leather prices was evident.

Gangway, owned by the Belair Stud, showed signs of promise in winning the one-mile Cossack Pursa at Belmont Park yesterday. Trained by Jim Fitzsimmons and ridden by Nichols Combest, the son of Gallant Fox ran away from them all in the event for 2-year-olds, scoring an easy victory in 1:38 1/5.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 5,000 head: total. 7,000. Most hogs sold fairly active and around 50 cents higher, but trade closed slow with part of advance lost on few hundred remaining hogs:

IN a succession of long, smooth, rippling sentences which flow across his pages like thick Jersey cream out of a jug, Robert Rylee has written in "The Ring and the Cross"* a bitter fictional denunciation of life in modern America. With sentimentality, with theatrical melodrama and with passionate emotion he has excoriated the powers that be in an industrial Texas city on the Gulf of Mexico.

Prospects for a quick peace treaty with Austria and eventual settlements in Germany and Japan have been dimmed by Moscow's formation of a quasi-Comintern and by the strong reaction this will provoke in the Western World.

Governor Dewey appealed last night for the voters to register so that they could support nine separate constitutional amendments or propositions to be submitted in the November election. The Governor announced his own support of eight of the measures that are virtually non-controversial, came out for the ninth, which has caused a partisan division, and failed to mention the tenth and principal item of controversy, the proposed repeal of proportional representation in this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Formation of a Communist international organization to fight "American imperialism," as announced in Moscow yesterday, was seen here as probably forcing the United States, with Britain and France, to make a separate peace with Germany.

MONTREAL, Oct. 6 -- Secretary of State Marshall came here today to receive u degree of Doctor of Laws from McGill University. He spent part of the time with the Canadian Prime Minister, W.L. Mackenzie King.
William J. Ahearn has been elected executive vice president of the Great American Indemnity Company.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Heard Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet representative, call for a rejection of the United States resolution on the Greek question and for immediate withdrawal of foreign troops and missions from Greece.

In their broadcasts of Sunday evening, the President, the Secretary of State, the Secretary of Agriculture, the Secretary of Commerce and the chairman of the newly appointed Citizens Food Committee, Charles Luckman, laid a solid foundation for a national food conservation program.

A minority report charging Communists bad dominated the activities of the recent Work Youth Festival at Prague and u majority statement opposing that viewpoint were issued here yesterday by delegates returning from the meeting.

A Masonic Fund for Medical Research and Human Welfare has been organized by the Masonic Grand Lodge of the State of New York to support intensive research into the causes and possible cures for rheumatic fever, it was announced yesterday.
The State Food Commission, which held its first meeting yesterday at the Hotel Roosevelt, promised New Yorkers a more healthful diet in return for voluntary reduction in meat eating.

BERLIN, Oct. 6 -- The United States Military Government made a big move today toward smashing the excessive concentrations of economic power in Germany, as called for by the Potsdam Agreement. The German Government of Wuerttemberg-Baden has been directed to sell at once eight coal distributing companies in an effort to remove them from the giant Ruhr mining cartels.

Department stora restaurant executives attending a two-day meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday wired Charles Luckman, chairman of the Citizens Food Committee, that they would give the Government's food conservaion program their full support.
Sixteen hundred teachers in the city's public schools voted yesterday for retention of the city's teacher promotion and salary rules.

DETROIT, Oct. 6 -- David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, announced today the appointment of a board of seven consultants "to speed up industrial opportunities" in the field of atomic power.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Maryland-owned colt Tacaro Briar, racing for Bob Hall, won the featured Ambassador Purse by coming in three-quarters of a length in front of King Ranch's Flash Burn, who held a two-length advantage over the prohibitive favorite, Twosy, at Laurel Park today.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 6 -- Except on the highest levels, Yugoslav officials knew no more about the new Communist international organization today than the man in the street.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 6 -- The American Federation of Hosiery Workers has been suspended from the CIO for refusing to pay a 50cent increase in individual membership dues.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, charged today that the United States had converted Greece into "a military base" and that there was "nothing left of independence and sovereignty in Greece."
Casual treatment of precious furs was the theme of the Ackerman-Blatt fashion show held yesterday at 60 East Fifty-sixth Street.
The question of Leo Durocher's status in baseball appeared to be reaching the answer stage last night, according to The Associated Press.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 6 -- Strong Indian Army, Navy and Air Force units landed on the Kathiawar Peninsula yesterday and surrounded the small princely State of Junagadh which has joined Pakistan under its Moslem ruler, the Government announced today.

Bread and rolls disappeared from the tables of some New York restaurants yesterday and grain prices broke in the Midwest trading pits as support was pledged in all parts of the nation for President Truman's program for voluntary conservation of essential foods.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The National Labor Relations Board today postponed the announcement overruling the board's general counsel, Robert, N. Denham, on the anti-Communist affidavit issue, but the four-to-one adverse vote was unchanged.
CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- The University of Chicago announced today that a drive to raise $2,570,000 still needed toward a $5,150,000 cancer research building and equipment program would begin Nov. 15.
Ventan Yablonski, Columbia's starting fullback and most frequent ball carrier, was missing from practice because of a knee infection as the Lions began preparing for Yale at Baker Field yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- A big decline in construction of housing units by Insurance companies was predicted today by industry executives fathered here for the annual meeting of the American Life Convention. Principal speeches on the first day's program extolled the virtues of ownership as opposed to mortgage investment in residential, commercial and industrial properties.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- The announcement of the revival of the Comintern was received today with dismay by many United Nations delegates, particularly those favoring a middle-of-the-road position here and elsewhere.

Led-by a Purple Heart veteran of World War II, who said he would not be alive today if it were not for Red Cross blood plasma, 162 members of the 187th Field Artillery, New York National Guard, "paid a debt to the home front" last night by enrolling in the Greater New York Red Cross Blood Donor Service.

Spearheaded by manufacturers of sportswear, New York garment houses began yesterday their resort and spring openings of women's and misses' apparel lines.
