The vanguard of buyers to view the lines and to check on deliveries of orders for fall has already come into the wholesale markets, it was learned, and it is expected that the openings will be attended by as many or more buyers than were present last year.

In 1927 the Bishop of Ripon created a sensation at the Leeds meeting of the British Association for the Advancement of Science by advocating a ten-year cessation of scientific and engineering research so that a breathless world could catch up with the laboratories. The scientists were outraged, and so was the public.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As secretary and counsel of the Cooperative League of the United States of America, we are concerned by the looseness of the use of the term "cooperative" and its misuse, to the great disadvantage of genuine cooperatives, particularly in the housing field.
"I'm sorry we didn't win it, but I have no regrets."

The Communist party here maintainted official silence yesterday on the conference in Poland of nine European Communist parties and on the meeting's manifesto decreeing an interchange of information and future voluntary coordination of activities.
Cotton futures trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was moderately active yesterday. Prices rose 35 to 50 points net on the day.
Before it has had time to recover from the surfeit of thrills provided by the most exciting world series in many years, New York is offered the prize college football games of the week.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Citizens Food Committee tonight gave out the White House lunch and dinner menus for the first two days of the meatless, poultryless and eggless cycle each week which has been asked of all citizens for the duration of the food emergency.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- The problem of regional unemployment can be solved only by a measure of state planning, Sir Stafford Cripps, new Minister for Economic Affairs, said in South Wales today. He revealed that the Government was building twelve factories in South Wales to be set aside for the employment of disabled miners under normal industrial conditions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today that an analysis of the reported wartime costs and profits of 4,017 assorted manufacturing corporations indicated that "most groups had lower net profits after taxes in the years 1942-45 than in 1941."

Well! Now perhaps we can all go back to work. For seven days there hasn't been much getting accomplished between 1:30 and 3:30 or 4 o'clock each afternoon. Not in New York's five boroughs, at any rate. Not in Brooklyn, most assuredly. Who could work with the Brooklyn Dodgers and the New York Yankees locked in breathless struggle every afternoon?

An amendment to the constitution of the National Maritime Union, CIO, to Bar "any religious, political, or other organization" from interfering in the affairs of the NMU was rejected yesterday by delegates to the union's sixth biennial convention, at Manhattan Center.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Silent since June, the Supreme Court burst into action today. Highlight of the start of the new term was a dissent by Justices Robert H. Jackson and Felix Frankfurter, sarcastically criticizing Justice Frank Murphy and charging a majority with, in effect, trying to put most Government agency orders over and above the law.

PARIS, Oct. 6 -- The new Communist manifesto for Europe has had its greatest immediate effect in France, where It changed overnight the entire domestic political outlook only twelve days before the nation-wide municipal elections, it was widely agreed here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- The Marshall plan and corresponding ones for eastern Europe and other regions should become mere parts of a world recovery project that the United Nations might administer above the level of political dissidence, Sir John Boyd Orr, Director General of the Food and Agriculture Organization, urged here today.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- Taking advantage of the glorious autumn weather and mindful that this was to be the last one-day event of the year, ninety women teed off over the Westchester Country Club south course under the auspices of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association today.

LONDON, Oct. 6 (AP) -- Seven world track and field records, two of them by Americans, have been approved by the International Amateur Athletic Federation, Lord Burghley, IAAF president, aninounced today.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Britain and the other governments in the sterling area have agreed on arrangements for "close and continuing consultation" on the problem of defending the Sterling area's gold and dollar reserves, the British Treasury announced tonight.

Heartened by the lack of serious injuries in the Brooklyn College contest, Coach Edward E. (Hook) Mylin will lead the New York University football team to Fenway Park, Boston, this week-end to engage a strong Boston University eleven in the Violets' second major test of the season.

TOKYO, Oct. 6 -- The Socialistled Government of Premier Tetsu Katayama has finally called for a showdown on Japan's tangled food situation and the reluctance of many of the nation's food growers to part with their supplies at the fixed Government prices, far below the black market levels.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- Former GI students who decline to pay back overpayments they received from the Government while they were attending school will have the amounts they owe deducted from any unemployment allowances they may apply for the Veterans Administration ruled today.

A man said to have wide experience as a swindler was brought from Newark and locked up in the Tombs yesterday to face charges of having taken in eight investors for a total of $19,500 in a fake real estate development scheme.

As President Truman said, the new food conservation program not only will permit larger supplies to be sent overseas but it also should force down prices at home, particularly those of meat and eggs, which have made such a big bruise in budgets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 6 -- Melvyn Douglas was named today by RKO to play the leading role in "Mortgage on Life," after he completes "Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House," which has gone before the cameras. Herman Mankiewicz, who will produce "Mortgage," is writing the scenario from a novel by Vicki Baum about a song writer and his feminine protege, a singer.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- It would scarcely be accurate to say that the Russians created consternation today with their revived Comintern and their new attack on imperialists and one-worlders.

Non-customers are invariably more critical of banks and banking than any other group in the population, Dr. Claude Robinson of the Opinion Research Corporation, Princeton, N.J., told members of the Financial Advertisers Association at the first formal session of their four-day convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 6 -- Arthur Miller, newly appointed waterfront arbitrator for the Pacific Coast, heard a demand from CIO longshoremen today for immediate reopening of the Port of Los Angeles.

CHICAGO, Oct. 6 -- Liquidation was on in the grain markets on the Board of Trade early today, with wheat down 10 cents, the daily limit, at one time, while oats were off as much as 6 cents and soy beans the 8-cent limit before a rally set in.

Declaring that the broad benefits envisaged in the RobinsonPatman act have not been realized, the National Association of Wholesalers in a declaration of policy yesterday demanded that a Congressional committee be appointed to investigate the act with the view to revising and strengthening it.

A new biography of President Truman by Frank McNaughton and Walter Hehmeyer, as yet untitled, will be published by Whittlesey House next spring. Mr. McNaughton is a member of the Washington staff of Time and Mr. Hehmeyer was formerly on the investigating staff of the Truman committee.

Registration in the city for the November election, which started yesterday, was far below the totals for the Gubernatorial year of 1946 or the Presidential year of 1944 at the close of the first day. A total of 212,364 registered, the figures showed at 1 A. M. today, compared with 308,470 last year and 436,321 in 1944.

ROME, Tuesday, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Senator Alben W. Barkley, Democrat, of Kentucky, told Americans early today that every dollar's worth of food sent to Europe would be "an investment in democracy and in liberty and in the right of peoples throughout all this Continent to have a restoration of their economy and their mode and standards of life."

The last illusions nourished on the hope that out of the blood and sacrifices of the Second World War there might arise a new world order, based on the common interest of all nations and able to banish forever the specter of new strife, have been dealt a mortal blow by the formation of the new Communist International headed by Soviet Russia.
The twentieth annual Gradual Fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine opened last night at its building, 2 East 103d Street.

The play-by-play description of the seventh and final game of the world series at the Yankee Stadium yesterday follows: FIRST INNING DODGERS -- Shea's first pitch was a called strike. Stanky fouled back of the plate, looked at a ball and singled to right.

BOSTON, Oct. 6 -- The executive council of the Textile Workers Union, CIO, voted unanimously today to file the non-Communist affidavits required to qualify the union for use of National Labor Relations Board machinery under the Taft-Hartley Act.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A new national farm policy of "sustained abundance," involving barn-bursting production, a tremendous added weight to the already heavy American table and an aggressive later search for export markets, was proposed today to Congress.

Strong opposition to the proposed New York State bonus for veterans of World War II was indicated yesterday by representatives of thirteen civic groups at a meeting of the Civic Conference Committee of New York at the Willkie Memorial Building, 20 West Fortieth Street.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 6 -- When Tom Marshall shook us at 4 A.M. we wondered why people were interested in waterfowl shooting, but when we picked up the rig of decoys at 10:30 we were unable to understand why people complained about getting up a little early on occasion.

Billy Southworth has received a new five-year contract to manage the Braves, it was announced last night by Lou Perini, president of the club. Perini said the contract calls for a salary "something in excess of $250,000."

BATAVIA, Java, Tuesday, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Indonesian Republic announced today that it would free three Dutch Army personnel arrested Saturday when a United States Navy Beechcraft plane in which they were passengers ran out of fuel and landed at Pameungpeuk airport in Republican West Java.

Churches have given youngsters a too "wishy-washy" type of religious education, Miss Dorothy Fritz, director of children's curriculum for the Committee on Religious Education, declared yesterday. Speaking at the fall meeting of the Presbytery of New York in the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church at Fifty-fifth Street, she told 100 ministers that what "we in the Presbyterian churches have given children has been all sweetness and light, not something they can bite into."

MOSCOW, Oct. 6 (Reuters) -- Declaring that United States imperialism was threatening peace, Ilya Ehrenburg, Russian war reporter and novelist, wrote in the Communist party organ Pravda -- quoted by the Moscow radio today -- that "imperialism is always a danger to our culture."

"Give the Veteran a Job Week" moved into high gear yesterday as the Jobs for Disabled Veterans Committee, an organization of advertising men, obtained from 500 business executives pledges to aid employment of former GI's.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- The Netherlands Government reaffirmed today its desire to achieve independence for Indonesia, a policy declared to have the support of "the great majority of the Dutch population."

At the Booth Theatre tonight, where he launched "The Two Mrs. Carrolls" several years ago, Robert Reud will unfold a London thriller called "Duet for Two Hands." Mary Hayley Bell is author of the drama about a poet who loses his hands in an accident and by a miracle of surgery receives two new ones-those of a man who has been hanged for murder.
Beyond the Horizon Consequences of reforms in morals, manners and legal arrangements for ordering our lives are not always clearly foreseen by reformers with their eyes on a limited objective.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- A director of the Office of Education expressed the fear today that the rising cost of a college education would soon keep large numbers of able students outside the campus gates.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- A practical action by the United Nations to benefit mankind was hailed today by Henri Laugier, Assistant Secretary General for Social Affairs, as he received twenty winners of United Nations fellowships in social welfare who arrived in the United States recently for a year's study.

Four motions to quash subpoenas calling for the books and records of the Spruce Falls Power and Paper Company, a Canadian corporation, in the Government's inquiry into the newsprint industry, have been rejected by Federal Judge Gaston L. Porterie of Louisana, according to orders received yesterday by the clerk of the District Court here.

New York State Democrats followed yesterday the lead set recently by Frank Hague in New Jersey, announcing their political backing of the Palestine partition plan and asking that the President and the United States delegation to the United Nations support it.

The National Furniture Traffic Conference today will request the consolidated freight classifications committee, representing all railroads, for a ninety-day extension of the "Nov. 29 absolute deadline" for compliance by furniture manufacturers with new packaging and shipping rules, Ray F. Bohman, conference president and managing director, disclosed yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 6 (AP) -- The retiring president of the American Gas Association conceded today that the public had another winter of gas shortages in store and asked the industry to arrange proper conservation measures.
Sales and net earnings of E.R. Squibb Sons established new high records in the fiscal year ended on June 30, Carleton H. Palmer, board chairman, reported yesterday to stockholders.

The League of Present Day Artists has just opened at the Riverside Museum, Riverside Drive and 103d Street, its sixth annual exhibition. This is the organization that some years ago began its career as the Bombshell Group, so-named as the result of prolonged controversy in the art columns of this paper.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Larger advertising appropriations are being budgeted for 1948 because of increased needs for more intensive coverage in domestic markets, and some national advertising budgets are up as much as 50 per cent over 1947, spokesmen revealed in interviews just before opening sessions of the thirtyeighth annual Association of National Advertisers meeting here at Chalfonte-Haddon Hall today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 6 -- Despite the pleas of the Panamanian and Venezuelan delegates for affirmative action on the genocide resolution, the United Nations General Assembly's Legal Committee voted today to refer it to a subcommittee for study and a decision on future procedure.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 6 -- An additional fund of $240,000 for improvements at the Westchester County airport at Purchase was set up here today, increasing the outlay for the field to more than $5,000,000.

WARSAW, Oct. 6 -- Polish Communist officials said today that to interpret the establishment of the International Communist Information Bureau in Belgrade as a revival of the Comintern was a mistake. Virtually all Communist diplomats and politicians here are making that mistake.

NEW ARK, N.J., Oct. 6 (AP) -- The New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association tonight ruled that members must have the sanction of the N.J.S.I.A.A. before participating in post-season games or tournaments not conducted by the N.J.S.I.A.A. or member schools.

LONDON, Oct. 6 -- Three factors combined to keep buyers away from the stock markets here today. They were a statement by Sir Stafford Cripps, emphasizing the urgency of the dollar position, rumors that Chaneeller of the Exchequer Hugh balton will be urged to raise the bank rate (presently 2 per cent) and the setting up of the new Communist international organization.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 6 (U.P.) -- Hanns Eisler, German-born composer, surrendered today with his wife, Louise, to immigration authorities on charges connected with their entry into the United States.
"No! No!" parents shouted last night when school authorities proposed the abolition of the elementary school diploma and the formal exercises that go with graduation.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 6 -- Two of the nation's leading authorities on tuberculosis presented varying views today on the efficacy of the vaccine BCG, a substance that is being used widely to combat the disease in Europe and South America.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The report of my address at the Kenyon College Conference published in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Sept. 28, has created a totally false impression among many readers. I should like to set the record straight by quoting certain portions of my prepared speech.

Although the role of the United States shipping industry can be a big one, our merchant marine is handicapped and may be retarded further by unsettled labor conditions and high operating costs. Frank J. Taylor, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, declared here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The Civil Service Commission acknowledged to a House Expenditures Committee today that names of Congressional figures had no business appearing in its confidential files of "leads" for possible subversive investigations.

The week-end developments in the domestic and foreign fields had little surface effect yesterday on the stock market. Prices drifted narrowly, except in a few scattered issues, and closed irregularly higher with the industrial price average up 0.70 on the day and the composite index 0.25 higher.

A large fingerprint, possibly that of a thumb, was found by detectives yesterday on a closet door in the apartment of Mrs. Sari Gabor Hilton, giving the police another clue in the robbery on Saturday of Mrs. Hilton's jewelry.

NANKING, Tuesday, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Tsingtao dispatches said today Government forces have taken Weihaiwei, last Communist-held port of the North, Shantung coast, after an amphibious landing coordinated with the assaults of land units.

Berl Senofsky, violinist, gave the Town Hall violin recital yesterday afternoon which was his award as winner of a 1947 Naumburg Foundation contest. His program consisted of a Vivaldi-Respighi Sonata, Bach's unaccompanied Sonata in A minor, Brahms' Sonata in D minor, Paganini's Caprices No. 7 and 17, Paul Creston's Suite for Violin and Piano, "Pantomime" by De Falla-Kochanski and Polonaise Brilliante by Wieniawski.

PRAGUE, Oct. 6 -- The manifesto by Communist parties of nine European countries, including Czechoslovakia, directed against the United States and Britain has caused leaders of other political parties here to react angrily.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 6 -- The threat that former Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota might stay away from the Republican rally on Oct. 16 at Columbus, Ohio, prompted Senator Robert A. Taft to decide rather hastily not to use the occasion to declare his presidential ambitions.

ALBANY, Oct. 6 -- Representatives of 40,000 civil service employes massed their forces today to seek immediate cost-of-living increases of approximately 25 per cent and protection from arbitrary dismissal under the Condon-Win Law.

Capt. Granville Conway, President Truman's coordinator of emergency export programs, said here yesterday that he had agreed to take over the job of coordinator of United States oil tanker movements because of the critical shortage of tankers now serving the world's needs.

Foreign Bond Switching Foreign bond men say that the sharp upward movement of Brazilian and Chilean bonds in yesterday's market stemmed evidently from Britain's restoration of free dealings in certain securities, effective on Oct. 1.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 6 -- After more than a year's delay, the Arab Land Company, a banking organization sponsored jointly by the seven Arab states, will soon begin operations in Palestine in an effort to prevent Arab lands from being bought up by Zionists.
DETROIT, Oct. 7 -- Planning ultimately to abandon the steel scrap market, the Ford Motor Company announced today a long-range $18,000,000 improvement program.

Governor Dewey said last night that relief and welfare were not the whole responsibility either of Government or private agencies, but rather a problem that both must share to obtain the fullest benefits for those in need of assistance.

Mexico's string of horses for the international military jumping competition at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden Nov. 4 to 11 arrived from Laredo yesterday. At the same time it was announced that the British would be unable to compete, but that the horses of Ireland's Army team were en route aboard the United States Lines' American Importer.

TORONTO, Oct. 7 -- R.M. Fowler, president of the Canadian Newsprint Institute, declared today that newsprint supply for United States consumers in 1947-48 is estimated as within 5 per cent of maximum demand, the probable shortage being 235,000 to 245,000 tons against about 5,000,000 tons of maximum demand.

The disunity within the National Maritime Union, CIO, brought into the open during the union's sixth biennial convention, threatened for a time yesterday afternoon to turn into complete disruption of the organization.

With his sense of the dramatic predominating, Walter Florell staged a millinery showing in the Oval Room of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel yesterday that expressed the extremes of today's trends. If hats were worn to the side, they literally perched over one ear; if they were large, they were oversized; if feathers were used, they appeared in super-abundance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Citizens Food Committee today made a telephone survey which showed that because of meat stock and planned menus on hand full effects of a meatless day would not be felt until next Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- The so-called "soap opera" was praised today as an unexpected source of safety in the home by Miss Grace Hornaday, secretary of the Women's Division of the Newark (N.J.) Safety Council.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Confidence that Congress' next tax, bill will revise the tax structure to encourage capital investment was expressed today by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange.

At a press conference that lasted less than twenty minutes, a record in itself for the Yankee organization of recent years, Del Webb and Dan Topping yesterday read Larry MacPhail right out of the party.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Truman was urged today by the Australian Foreign Minister, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, to call a preliminary conference on the Japanese peace treaty "as soon as possible."

To the editor of The New York Times: In the interests of historical accuracy some comment is offered on the Constitution Day story appearing is the times Sept. 18 edition. The story reads that the Sons of the American Revolution are "urging the enactment of laws in all states providing for the inclusion of the Constitution in the curricula of public schools."

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 7 -- It was reported without official confirmation today that Dr. Juliu Maniu and thirteen other leaders of the National Peasant party would go on trial Monday on charges of treason and espionage.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Concluded general discussion on Greek question with statements by representatives of Yugoslavia, Belgium, Sweden, Ethiopia, Cuba, Norway and Greece.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Bob Chappuis, Michigan halfback, has yet to begin defense of his Big Nine individual offensive championship, but he has plenty of competition from Quarterback Perry Moss, sharp - shooting Illinois passer.

The Citizens Union endorsed yesterday Benjamin J. Rabin and J. Edward Lumbard Jr., opponents for the Supreme Court vacancy in the First Judicial District, but gave its preference to Mr. Lumbard, nominee of the Republican and American Labor parties.
Underwriting transactions, involving the offering of more than $19,000,000 of securities to the public and to stockholders, will become effective today as follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Consideration of the Russian announcements of the revival of the Comintern and of a readiness to attend the meeting of Foreign Ministers in London in November for drafting a German peace treaty has convinced well-placed officials here that United States foreign policy now is confronted with a major test.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Ossie Bluege, manager of the Washington Baseball Club, has relinquished that position to become supervisor of the club's farm teams Jan. 1, Clark Griffith, president of the Senators, announced today. No successor has been selected, Griffith said.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 7 -- The executive council of the American Federation of Labor was faced today with the realization that the overruling of Robert N. Denham, general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, did not wipe out the council's serious troubles over anti-Communist affidavits.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the American Military Governor in Germany, arrived in Washington today with the data necessary for measuring Germany's potentialities for aiding European reconstruction under the Marshall plan.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- John Foster Dulles of the United States today strongly reaffirmed the right of the United Nations, as "The Town Meeting of the World," to make recommendations reflecting the moral judgment and conscience of the world.
Even "swank" Park Avenue has its drab side, a group of East Side residents averred yesterday.

To the editor of The New York Times: For some time now the situation of the Jewish Displaced Persons in Europe and the relationship of the Jewish people to Palestine has been high on the agenda of world opinion.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Accepting the proposals of the Soviet Union, the conference of the Foreign Ministers' depuites on the future of the former Italian colonies reached agreement today on which countries shall be allowed to state their views on the subject.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- One of the most obvious developments at the United Nations in the last year is the decline in manners and humor on the part of the delegates from Eastern Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Notional Labor Relations Board today issued the following announcement of its ruling that top officials of the AFL and CIO need not sign non-Communist affidavits in order for affiliated unions to comply with the Taft-Hartley Law:

Switzerland recently celebrated the centenary of its railways, an event which recalled the famous first run between Zurich and Baden back in 1847. That first train, appropriately enough, was heralded by the Swiss people as the "Spanish Brotli Bahn" -- the train of the Spanish. Buns.

To The Editor of The New York Times : We note with deep concern and appreciation your editorial item with respect to "Probation as Economy" in the issue of Sept. 24. It will be remembered that on March 6 you published our letter in which we presented the condition in like manner as Commissioner Probst has stated it.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 7 -- The trial of Dragolub Yovanovitch, Serb peasant leader, ended today, with the prosecutor declaring "the strength of our country permits the sentence to be not the most severe." Sentence will be passed tomorrow.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank, has been elected president of the New York Clearing House Association, it was announced yesterday, following the association's annual meeting. He succeeds Harry E. Ward, chairman of the board of the Irving Trust Company.

A 22-year-old veteran who has been unemployed ever since he was wounded three years ago in France became yesterday the first man to reap tangible aid from" the current campaign of the new Jobs for Disabled Veterans Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Administration, as represented by the Department of Agriculture, has determined to try to keep farm prices permanently on a high plateau and has set the unprecedented objective of putting a "floor" under food consumption in the United States.

Wholesalers cannot survive the current trend toward monopoly of distribution without Government aid in regulating competition, Sigfried F. Hartman, counsel to the National Association of Wholesalers, asserted yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Idaho Power Company, Boise, Idaho, plans a sale of stock to repay $3,000,000 of bank loans obtained between July 16 and Sept. 30 for its construction program. In a registration statement filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission it disclosed that it will make a public offering of 35,000 shares of $100 par 4 per cent preferred and 100,000 shares of $20 par common.
To the editor of The New York Times : I read with great interest the story in your paper of the work being done by the Save Washington Square organization.

The two-story garden apartment group at the northwest corner of Jackson and Clinton Streets in Hetnpstead, L.I., containing 113 suites, has been sold by the Gross-Morton Company to the Jackson-Clinton Realty Company. Fronting 219.2 feet on Jackson Street and 582 feet on Clinton Street, the property extends through to Webb Avenue, where it has a frontage of 195 feet.

The methods of conducting Congressional investigations were criticized yesterday by Federal Judge Simon H. Rifkind as contrary to the American conception of justice and an intrusion into the field of the grand jury.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7-Distillers meeting here tomorrow afternoon with Charles Luckman, chairman of the Citizens Food Committee, will tell Mm that they have reason to believe that eleven of the sixteen Marshall-plan countries are asking for 71,000,000 bushels of grains for brews and distillates, it was learned on good authority here today.

The Atlas Corporation, second largest stockholder of Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation, will assume management control with the withdrawal of the Avco Manufacturing Corporation from, the management and directorships if plans to segregate the non-aviation assets of the aircraft company are approved by stockholders at a special meeting in San Diego, Calif., on Nov. 3.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conductor, gave the first major orchestral program of the season last night in Carnegie Hall. This program in its material, arrangement and contrast, was a masterpiece of effectiveness. Everything on it, with a single exception, was guaranteed sure-fire.

P. D. Ouspensky, whose first novel, "Strange Life of Ivan Osokin," will be published by Holme Press next Wednesday, died last week in Surrey, England, after a brief illness. Mr. Ouspensky is the author of "A New Model of the Universe" and "Tertium Organum."

Sixty-two well-known American artists have been selected to compete in the 1948 La Tausca Art Competition, sponsored by the Heller Deltah Company, Inc. In addition, the eight artist members of the invitation jury are automatically eligible to compete.

Youth is America's number one problem and character building agencies to serve young people must receive first consideration, Grove Patterson, editor-in-chief of The Toledo Blade, said yesterday at a luncheon in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, marking the opening of the United Young Women's Christian Associations Appeal of Greater New York for $455,000.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Dr. Joshua Loth Liebman, rabbi of Temple Israel in Boston for the last nine years, has declined a call from Temple Emanu-El, New York, saying he would remain here to "continue my rabbinical work in New England."

"Name Your Poison," a halfhour documentary dealing with sanitary conditions in New York restaurants, will be offered by WOR at 9 P. M. Sunday. It will include recordings of inspections made by health inspectors at several restaurants.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- Ousting eleven Ministers and Under-Secretaries, including Emanuel Shinwell, Left Wing chairman of the Labor party and Minister of Fuel and Power, Prime Minister Attlee tonight announced extensive changes designed to strengthen the Labor Government administratively to meet the economic crisis.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Oct. 7 (AP) -- A strike threatening all major Canadian freight and passenger steamship transportation on the West Coast will start at noon Thursday, officials of the British Columbia Marine Engineers Union (American Federation of Labor) announced today.

BERLIN, Oct. 7 -- A young American newspaperman threw the Russian-sponsored German Writers Congress, the first since Hitler, into an uproar today with a slashing attack on totalitarianism's effects on freedom of culture.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The first phase of the Soviet Union's effort to censure the world's "warmongering" press was defeated here today.

STUTTGART, Germany, Oct. 7 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, Chief of Staff, has directed that the bread ration served to soldiers at the noon and evening meals be cut. The saving will be the American troops' contribution to ease the world shortage of bread grains.

Annual Meeting A deviation from the norm looms for this afternoon when stockholders of the Electric Bond and Share Company gather for their annual meeting. According to a press release from a union organization of architects, engineers, chemists and technicians, the stockholders "will see one of the most solidly determined picket lines" outside the building in protest against the company.

TOKYO, Oct. 7 -- United States Army staffs in Japan today are studying under field conditions the strategy necessary to repel invasion by any aggressor from the Asiatic mainland, across the Japan Sea.

Buyers' Total Higher Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,687, against 1,349 last week and 1,775 in the corresponding week last year, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

No other state can approach New York's splendid record of leadership in the production of subsidized lowrent, slum clearance housing built with public funds under public supervision. And, measured against unmet need, no state can equal our failure to set up the conditions that will enable private enterprise to hasten the solution of our tremendous housing shortage.

The Lehman Corporation made several substantial additions to its common stock portfolio in the first quarter of the fiscal year, according to a report as of Sept. 30 issued yesterday by Robert Lehman, the president.

The celebrated Leo Durocher case appeared still as much of an enigma as ever in Brooklyn yesterday, although prospects of early clarification were seen when Leo declared he difinitely expected to see Branch Rickey before departing for California.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 7 -- "Mr. Coronado." the screen story by Dale Van Every and Tom Kilpatrick which M-G-M has owned since 1938, has been taken off the shelf and assigned to Leon Gordon for production next year, with Spencer Tracy in the lead, the studio announced today.

The first of the "meatless" Tuesdays asked of the American people by President Truman was accompanied yesterday by the lively pinging of cash registers in butcher shops, and the serving of meats in hotels and restaurants throughout the land.
The name of Victor Rabinowitz, American Labor party nominee for Representative in the Fourteenth Congressional District in Brooklyn, was restored yesterday to the ballot in the forthcoming election.

The National Labor Relations Board, by a vote of 4 to 1, has reversed the ruling of its General Counsel, Robert N. Denham, on the controversial "Section 9 (h)" of the Taft-Hartley Act. This is the section that limits the right of petition by the labor unions until they have been certified as being untainted with communism.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The House Expenditures Committee learned today that a Civil Service Commission file of "leads" for possible loyalty tests of prospective Government workers was kept so confidential that the committee itself was "unfair" in disclosing that the names of Congress members were included in it.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- President Truman declared tonight to a group of fellow' Baptists that "a fair and just peace" in the world was "getting closer all the time, and we will eventually get it." Such a peace, he said, was all the United States had ever wanted.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Oct. 7 -- Charging the Truman Administration with neglect of the problem of stabilizing European currencies as an essential step in rebuilding war-torn economies, Harold E. Stassen urged tonight that the President call a special session of Congress to map a long-term approach to the task.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 7 -- Despite high prices, lack of raw materials, caution among wholesalers and threats of foreign trade restrictions, almost 84 per cent of America's leading companies expect 1948 sales volume to equal or exceed that of 1947, E.T. Batch-elder, secretary of the Association of National Advertisers, revealed here today during the thirty-eighth annual meeting.

After watching the New York University football players in a losing game with Temple and a winning one with Brooklyn College, Coach Hook Mylin yesterday came up with the opinion that his unviolent Violets had a chance against Fordham and Bucknell.

Establishment of an industrywide committee of steamship men to work on an advisory basis with the United States Maritime Commission was advocated here yesterday by Wilbur E. Dow Jr., senior partner in the admiralty law firm of Dow Symmers.
According to the final estimate of the waterfowl population made by Ducks Unlimited, the Canadian breeding grounds will contribute 110 million ducks to the southern migration.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The text of a draft resolution on the Greek question submitted by Sweden today to the Political and Security Committee follows:

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 7 -- The Waterfront Employers Association, agreed today to reopen Los Angeles and Long Beach harbors at midnight just one week after they had refused to call for CIO crews to load or unload freight cargo aboard any ship.

Registration in the city continued for the second day to run far ahead of the totals for 1943, the last political "off-year." Tabulation at 1 A.M. today showed that on the second day of the six-day period 286,893 persons had qualified to vote, bringing the two-day total to 499,257.

With baseball out of the way, New York's three big ball parks are now the exclusive stamping grounds of the football teams. The football Yankees yesterday settled down at the Stadium, while the Giants and Dodgers made good use of the Polo Grounds and Ebbets Field, respectively.
Governor Dewey gave enthusiastic support yesterday to a plan under which veterans would finance new homes with the help of the $50 to $250 state bonuses planned for them.
P. Val Kolb has been appointed divisional vice president in charge of the special markets division of newly - formed Winthrop - Stearns, Inc., subsidiary of Sterling Drug, Inc.

COLD SPRING HARBOR; L.I., Oct. 7 -- Among the first to finish in the field of forty-seven players, Al Brosch, Long Island open, champion from Cherry Valley, and Ernie Catropa of Willow Brook carded one-under-par 71's to share the lead as the annual Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association tournament opened today over the Cold Spring Country Club course.

By the narrow margin of one 1 and one-half points, Mrs. Paula Bacher of East Orange, N.J., and Mrs. Lewis M. Jaeger of New York won yesterday the metropolitan women's pairs championship of the American Contract Bridge League.

A request will be made to the woolen mills to restore their normal selling seasons, it was announced yesterday following a joint meeting at the Aldine Club of the retail relations committee of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U.S.A. and the manufacturers' relations committee of the National Association of Retail Clothiers and Furnishers.

The "Theripiano," a piano with controllable pressure adjustment for physio-therapy, was demonstrated yesterday at the annual meeting of the Musicians Emergency Fund at Steinway Hall. Ben Ross, Music for Hospitalized Veterans instructor, and Dr. Bruce Armstrong, staff physician at St. Albans Naval Hospital, co-inventors of the instrument, described their experiments with patients at the hospital.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 7 (U.P.) -- Haganah, moderate Zionist underground army, killed two Arabs in a reprisal bombing today while Arab forces renewed threats of war in Palestine.

It was Wild West day yesterday at Bellevue Hospital. A crowd of 2,700 patients, swelled to nearly 5,000 by staff members, relatives and friends, witnessed the twenty-second annual showing of the World's Championship Rodeo on the hospital grounds.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The Netherlands was accused by three speakers today of deliberately flouting the cease-fire order of the United Nations Security Council by carrying on warfare in Indonesia.

A Douglas DC-6, flown to New York from Los Angeles, was disabled temporarily at La Guardia Field yesterday when two of its landing-gear tires burst on landing on 5,000-foot Runway Four. None of its forty-three passengers and crew of four was injured.

A fall newspaper campaign will be started by Stokeley-Van Camp, Inc., tomorrow in 290 newspapers, according to Ray N. Peterson, advertising manager. With the flexibility afforded by newspapers, he said, his company will feature products that are most popular in various sections of the country as well as promote the over-all theme of "Quick Meals by Van Camp's."

A total of 142 children were placed in permanent adoptive homes during the last year through the State Charities Aid Association's child placing and adoption committee, Miss Sophie van S. Theis, executive secretary of the association, declared yesterday.

Bankers who pay automobile and appliance dealers commissions or "kick backs" on installment paper risk serious consequences, Kenneth R. Wells, assistant vice president of the American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, asserted yesterday in the second day's sessions of the annual convention of the Financial Advertisers Association.

The voluntary "Save Food Campaign got away yesterday to an apparently spotty start. National round-ups by Associated Press and United Press showed some cities, or city areas, obeying the "Meatless Tuesday" request to the letter. In other cities butchers reported near-normal business and some said they had an especially heavy run Monday by housewives stocking up for the meatless day.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Connecticut Democrats, although suffering a setback in the loss of Norwalk to a Socialist administration, were jubilant today because of inroads they made into normally Republican strongholds in municipal elections throughout the state.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Lieut. Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Ambassador to Russia, said on his arrival here today that the revival of the Communist International had not been a surprise.

Snow Goose honked high at Belmont Park yesterday. The 3-year-old daughter of Mahmoud and Judy O'Grady proved herself one of the best of the distaff side while striding to victory in the $50,000 added Ladies Handicap, a historic stake that had its first running at old Jerome Park back in 1868.

As proof of the drama's ethical virtue, Mary Hayley Bell has introduced moral standards to science in "Duet for Two Hands," which was acted at the Booth last evening. She does not think that a surgeon of low moral character should graft one man's hands on to another's wrists.

The number of business men visiting Japan, now limited to 400 at any one time, will be expanded at the earliest date possible, Peter McDermott, chief of the Pacific foreign trade division of the Supreme Command of the Allied Powers, said yesterday at the luncheon meeting of the Far East-America Council at the Hotel Biltmore.
The most Important part of the new food conservation program is to use as little meat as possible, and stretch it to make full use of every ounce of flavor and nutrients.

The College of Mount St. Vincent closed its four-day centennial celebration yesterday afternoon with an academic convocation in Cardinal Hayes Hall on the school's Riverdale campus. Seven hundred persons attended the ceremony.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Government buying of an estimated 3,000,000 to 4,000,000 bushels of cash wheat in various positions throughout the country sent the price of that grain up as much as 8 1/4 cents a bushel in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, the first day of operations under new exchange regulations calling for minimum initial margins of 33 1/3 per cent of the market price of the grain.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Food and nutrition specialists, following President Truman's plea to conserve food, described the problem today as possibly the most important single factor in the struggle for peace.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Greece will ask for increased food allocations from the International Children's Emergency Fund to meet the emergency caused by the flight of 90,000 children from strife - torn northwest Greece, Stephen Pesmantzoglou, Greek delegate to the fund's executive board, disclosed today.

RARELY since the invention of movable type has a book been published more peculiar and fantastic than "I Wait for Miracles,"* by Thomas Theodor Heine. Rarely have such various ingredients been mixed together before; large helpings of farcical burlesque, quantities of social satire, an abundance of wild fantasy and a whole series of political parables.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Publishers Association, in behalf of its 400 members, complained to the Regional National Labor Relations Board today that the International Typographical Union's new "nocontract" policy violated the Taft-Hartley Labor Law.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Senator Joseph H. Ball, Republican, of Minnesota, said 'today the International Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, was proposing "a very thinly veiled camouflage for the closed shop" in its Baltimore negotiations.

Manufacturers' quotas on medium-priced bedroom and dining room furniture will be retained until the second quarter of 1948, C.E. Hellgran, treasurer Kling Factories and former president of the National Association of Furniture Manufacturers, declared in an interview yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- The United States is expected to present its proposals for Korean independence within the next few days, it was reported today in official circles.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Sir Mohammed Zafrullah Khan, delegate of Pakistan, asked today that independence be granted to Palestine and that a democratic government be established there in accordance with the wishes of the majority of Palestinians.

Michael J. Obermeier, president of the Hotel and Club Employes Union, Local 6, AFL, whose deportation as an alleged alien Communist is being sought by the Government, was accused yesterday of having brought about the discharge of the "only anti-Communist official" of the local joint executive board of the Hotel and Restaurant Employes International Alliance.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday lost all their early gains and closed somewhat irregular 10 points higher to 17 points net lower than on Monday.

No appreciable progress was made yesterday by the stock market, which drifted narrowly throughout the session and closed mixed with only a slight emphasis on the lower side. An outcropping of strength in the paper and shipping issues was the only salient feature of the day which saw few wide changes, except in those sections, and a decline of 0.18 point in the combined averages.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 7 -- Membership of Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll's food conservation committee was completed today.

Isadore Rapoport, 56 years old, was sentenced yesterday by Judge Samuel S. Leihowitz in Kings County Court to serve two and a half to five years in Sing Sing for his part in the Mergenthaler Linotype Company swindle.

PARIS, Oct. 7 -- The reopening of the long gallery of the Louvre Museum was presided over today by Pierre Bourdan, minister of arts, and the gallery, the longest of art promenades, was crowded for the first time in nearly ten years.

Thor Heyerdahl, who led the Kon-Tiki raft expedition which drifted across the Pacific, recently returned to New York, and, for the first time, disclosed the narrow escape of Herman Watzingrer, second in command. He explained in an interview he did not want to report the dramatic rescue by wireless for fear that Mr. Watzinger's family would be disturbed.

Buoyed by the return to action of Vinnie Yablonski, regular fullback, and the discovery of Lou Kusserow's throwing ability and Bob Russell's punting skill in the Navy game, Columbia yesterday began full-scale preparations for Yale at Baker Field.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- George Melas, Greek Minister of State, told the Political Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today that the political independence and territorial integrity of Greece were in "grave peril" and appealed to the United Nations for protection.
LONDON, Oct. 7 -- International and home politics weighed heavily on the stock markets here today, and as a consequence trading was very light.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The State Department promulgated today a sweeping set of security principles in order to safeguard itself as "a vital target for persons engaged in espionage or subversion of the United States Government."

Mayor O'Dwyer, proclaiming October as Hospital Month, urged all New Yorkers yesterday to give generous support to the 1947 United Hospital Fund. The eighty-nine voluntary hospitals represented in the fund hold a strategic position in the health program of the community, he declared.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Warnings of a tight fuel supply situation, not only for the coming winter but for five years ahead, were given today by Max W. Ball, director of the United States Department of Interior, oil and gas division.

Plans for alterations in several Manhattan buildings and for erection of a small new office and storeroom buildings for the New York Central Railroad were placed on file with the Department of Housing and Buildings yesterday. The list included:

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 7 (Reuters) -- The Pakistan Government said tonight that the small west coast state of Junagadh had acceded to Pakistan voluntarily and the Government would not recognize anybody's right to interfere with its freedom.

CHICAGO, Oct. 7 -- Demand for most lines of advertising specialties and novelties has been heavier than many in the trade had anticipated, a check of representative manufacturers and distributors displaying products at the forty-fourth annual specialty fair of the Advertising Specialty National Association revealed today.

Roy Heir of Plandome and W.O. Barkley of the home club collaborated splendidly to card a low net of 63 in leading a field of twenty-two teams in the Long Island Golf Association's final amateur best-ball handicap tournament yesterday at the North Hills G.C., Douglaston, Queens.

Income tax evasions totaling $279,992 for the years 1940 and 1941 were admitted in Federal Court yesterday by the woolen jobbing company of Morris Kaplan Son, Inc., of 222 West Fortieth Street, two officers and an accountant.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Philip M. La Follette, former Governor of Wisconsin, has refused to accept a military governorship, it was learned today, because of the inadequacy of the $10,000 salary.

Algernon Lee, national chairman of the Social Democratic Federation, issued a statement yesterday saying that the announcement of the revival of the Communist International "furnishes a conclusive answer to those who continue to believe that a 'compromise' can be reached by appeasement of the Soviet Union."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission granted to the railroads today an emergency increase of 10 per cent on freight charges for all commodities except coal, coke and iron ore, for which special new rates were set.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- In the greatest one-year population spurt of its history, the United States gained 2,279,000 residents in 1946, to bring the total to 142,673,000, the Census Bureau estimated today.

The United Seamen's Service will discontinue all domestic services by the end of this year and will be forced to liquidate its facilities overseas as well by June, 1948, unless adequate financial support is forthcoming from shipping interests, it was announced yesterday.

WARSAW, Poland, Oct. 7 (AP) -- Poland's rapidly expanding foreign trade, now at 80 per cent of prewar transactions, is expected to reach $208,000,000 in exports and $254,000,000 in imports in 1947, preliminary governmental reports disclosed today.

NANKING, Oct. 7 -- Communist forces in Manchuria are tearing up tracks and burning ties along 120 miles of the Changchun-Mukden railway. They are engaged in this destruction from just south of Changchun, where the Reds mortar fire can be heard, down to Tiehling, iron mine town.

Condemning proportional representation as the "first beachhead of Communist infiltration," the Tammany executive committee adopted a resolution yesterday calling on the voters to "throw out this Stalin Frankenstein known as PR on Election Day."

Reflecting the largest annual production of typewriters in its history, sales of the Royal Typewriter Company in the fiscal year ended with last July increased $16,378,000 over the previous year with earnings almost seven times greater.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- A four-day conference of the National Planning Association opened in the Hotel Thayer tonight with a symposium on "Teamwork Plans for All-Around Development of the American Community."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- In line with the re-education of Germans, the Government today made public its policy concerning the exchange of informational, educational and cultural materials between the American zone in Germany and other countries.

Gen. Salih Omurtak, chief of the Turkish General Staff, arrived at La Guardia Field from Istanbul at 11:25 A.M. yesterday, accompanied by fourteen other officers, with whom he is to make a thirty-day tour of United States military installations and industrial plants.

LONDON, Oct. 7 -- The Communist party in Great Britain has approved the recent conference of nine European Communist parties held in Poland and its decision to create an information bureau in Belgrade, Harry Pollitt, the party's general secretary, said tonight in a speech at Ilford, Essex.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The arrival of the first "meatless" day under the administration's voluntary food-conservation program invites comparison with the somewhat similar experiment inaugurated and managed by Herbert Hoover in 1917 and 1918.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 7 -- Irving C. Freese, Socialist, who was elected Mayor yesterday by the greatest plurality in the history of the city in a sweeping upset, began immediately today to fulfill campaign promises to rid the city of "political bossism."

With the freshman eleven using Penn State plays, Fordham's football squad was tested yesterday against the single-wing offense the Nittany Lions will use in Saturday's contest at the Polo Grounds. Coach Ed Danowski learned yesterday that his injured right half-back, Ray Elster, who appeared briefly in the opener with Georgetown, would not be available this week.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 7 -- Mrs. Hamilton Pell of Seawane Harbor scored 44, 46 -- 90 to take top honors in the Class B event in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament at the Rockville Club today. Second place went to Mrs. George Uhe of the home club with 45, 48 -- 93.

A picture of New York as it appeared at successive periods before the turn of the century was shown last night in maps, documents, photographs and other views at the preview of a special exhibition at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, marking the fiftieth year of the consolidation of Greater New York.

A classicist to his finger tips, Maurice Evans sets great store by revivals. And without wonder. Didn't he score his greatest successes in them on this side of the pond? Of all the offerings acted here by the British-born star-manager-director, now an American citizen, only one was a new play -- "St. Helena," in which he impersonated the Little Corporal in 1936.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, Oct. 7 -- Robert Moses assumed the role today of a modern frontiersman and called upon his fellow-park lovers to take up arms against such things as mechanical amusement gadgets and airplanes that threaten to encroach upon their solitude.

Psychological, rather than glandular or metabolic disorders, are the primary cause of obesity, according to an address presented last night before the annual Graduate Fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine by Dr. Hilde Bruch of the Department of Psychiatry and Pediatrics, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Oct. 7 (AP) -- Curtis Elmer Vincent arrived here early today after a transatlantic flight with his 10-month-old son whom he took for a Sunday "walk," telling his English wife that he would see her "later." At Leeds, England, she said she would fly to the United States herself to contest his claim to custody of the child.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 7 -- Bo Oesten Unden, Swedish Foreign Minister, proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly establish a special committee to determine the "underlying causes" of the disputes between Greece, or the one hand, and Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria on the other.

THERE weren't many who believed the emotionally wrought Larry MacPhail when he announced his retirement at the end of the world series. But two persons who took him at his word with an alacrity that must have made MacPhail's head spin were Dan Topping and Del Webb. They accented his resignation last night and turned the Rambunctious Redhead out to pasture on his Maryland estate along with his herd of Angus cattle.

New bond issues totaling $30,354,000 of Atlanta, Ga., and Jacksonville, Fla., were placed on the market yesterday by banking syndicates after competitive sale. According to dealer reports at market closing, about two-thirds of the offerings already have been resold to investors.

Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, contradicted yesterday high officials of the education system who reported recently that the teacher shortage in city schools had ended. In a statement, calling attention to 333 open teaching positions, Dr. Jansen declared that "it would be erroneous to assume that the shortage of teachers is entirely a thing of the past."
ATHENS, Oct. 7 -- About 3,200 guerrillas have been surrounded by the Greek Army in the mountains in central Greece, Minister of War George Stratos said in an interview tonight.
CHICAGO Oct. 7 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets nere by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board began today a study of air cargo rates and problems which observers consider one of the most important ventures on which a governmental regulating agency has ever embarked.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Organization of the Western Hemisphere into a coordinated force for unified legislative measures to combat the revived Communist Comintern of Europe was proposed to Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. today by Representative J. Parnell Thomas, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

INWOOD, L.I., Oct. 7 -- Mrs. William R. Kirkland Jr. of Piping Rock won the low-gross honors with a 40, 38 -- 78 at the Inwood Country Club today in the next to the last one-day event of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association.

LONDON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Foreign Office declared today that Europe's Communist leadership had officially revived the Comintern and said the step represented "a clear deterioration of the international situation."

The twentieth annual Fall Rose Day was celebrated yesterday at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Three hundred rose-lovers attended lectures and rose exhibits sponsored by the Garden and the American Rose Society.

"Fan Mail" for Mr. Vishinsky Foreign correspondents Boris Izokov and Yuri Zhukov, who cover the United Nations General Assembly, meetings at Lake Success for the Moscow Pravda, sent a dispatch recently to their paper about the numerous letters received by that peppery Slavic visitor of ours, Soviet Russia's Deputy Foreign Minister Anorei Y. Vishinsky, as a result of his violent speech accusing the United States of warmongering and other misdemeanors.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 -- Of prime importance is Carnegie Institute's annual "Painting in the United States, 1947," which opens here with a preview tomorrow evening. A reception is to be held in the foyer of Carnegie Music Hall, where William Frew, president of Carnegie Institute, will announce the winners of prizes and honorable mentions.
All poultry was banished yesterday from the Thursday menus of public eating places throughout the country and restaurateurs predicted that an egg on the table would be a rarity today.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In view of the contradictory statements made in the discussion over the future of the Child Care Centers, it seems important to clarify some of the issues involved.

Following quantitative expansion, the pharmaceutical industry is entering a period of "qualitative selling," it was reported yesterday by Mrs. Helen Haberman, executive vice president of the William Douglas McAdams agency. She warned that surpluses will replace existing shortages, precipitating an era of sharp competition.

A schedule of liabilities and assets was filed in Federal Court yesterday by Michael Todd, theatrical producer, of 530 Park Avenue, who was named defendant in an involuntary bankruptcy proceeding last Sept. 19.

With Larry MacPhail having blasted himself out of the picture on a supercharge of his own powder, baseball yesterday subsided quietly into its annual period of hibernation with only one major question still unanswered. It concerns the future status of Leo Durocher and apparently it is a vexing problem that will not be settled for some time.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The continuing deadlock in the conference on the future of the former Italian colonies led today to a question in diplomatic quarters in London whether the new Communist tactics against the Western democracies was affecting the meetings of the Foreign Ministers' deputies.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- British scientists hoped tonight that they had broken a hole through the supersonic wall with a rocket. A twelve-foot robot was released this after-noon from a Mosquito bomber seven miles above the ocean off Cornwall and sent on a two-minute flight, which, if estimates were correct, would have given it a speed of from 800 to 900 miles an hour.

See Low-End Quota Return Quotas on low-end case goods may be Restored in the near future, manufacturers' representatives and buyers agreed yesterday. They pointed out, that orders are slowly outstripping output after many months of free ordering.

The action of the Interstate Commerce Commission in granting the railroads an "interim" increase of approximately 9 per cent in freight rates represents a praiseworthy move toward correcting a long-standing weakness in railroad regulation. This is the almost chronic lag between rising costs on the one hand, and compensating rate increases on the other.

Reah Sadowsky, who played at Carnegie Hall last night, is a pianist of remarkably good taste and sensitivity. It is a rare thing to find in a young musician so much poise and balance. Her tone is neatly, but never excessively, colored; she does not resort to excesses of speed or volume; her musical conceptions are modeled on sound principles.

VIENNA, Oct. 8 -- A French compromise proposal designed to settle the stalemate over the claim to German, external assets in Austria was made at today's session of the Austrian Treaty Commission. Since the commission is now preparing its report to the Council of Foreign Ministers there will not be time to discuss the proposal here.

Samuel Seabury disclosed last night that the late President Franklin D. Roosevelt, while Governor of New York, had favored the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- Sir Stafford Cripps warned today that Great Britain faced further import cuts, beginning with food and tobacco and possibly extending to raw materials, unless assistance under the Marshall plan was assured by next June.

WILMINGTON, Ohio, Oct. 8 -- Col. James M. Gillespie and his crew of six, with four passenger observers, landed their thirty-ton plane, "Hands Off," at the Clinton County Army Air Base here at 4:11 o'clock this afternoon. At 7:32 this morning, in Stephenville, Nfld, Colonel Gillespie, having lined up the, plane by hand on the runway, pushed a white button hanging in a box between the panels of his windshield.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Two former Army photographers have been seized on charges of theft of highly confidential photographs relating to development of atomic energy, J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, revealed tonight.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 8 -- Fortification of battle lines to combat cancer through, a more cohesive State-Federal program of research and control was forecast today by an official of the United States Public Health Service.

TOKYO, Oct. 8 -- The Allied occupation command acted today to wipe out the last remnants of the once all-powerful Japanese War and Navy departments. These are now known as the First and Secand Demobilization Bureaus, but they are still largely directed and staffed by former officers and men of the Imperial Armed Forces.

Parcel post packages were piled to the ceilings, had overflowed into corridors and lobbies and were even to be found in employes' rest rooms last evening when Postmaster Albert Goldman's "put on the brakes" order went into effect.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Charges of the Soviet Union, White Russia, Poland and Yugoslavia that the Marshall plan would return Germany to her old position of economic domination were rejected as "fantastic" here today by Willard L. Thorp, United States Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.

BOSTON, Oct. 8 -- Philip Murray today defended American Government officials from charges of "war mongering" leveled at them by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Deputy Soviet Foreign Minister and by the recent pronouncement issued by the revived Comintern.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- The Government's plan for rehabilitating Europe may result in a serious loss of American natural resources, Dwight L. Clarke, retiring president of the American Life Convention, said today. His address opened the first general session of the annual meeting of the organization, which tonight elected R.B. Richardson of Helena, Mont., president of the Western Life Insurance Company, to succeed him.

SCHENECTADY, Oct. 8 -- Reduction of British Empire trade preferences will occur only if countries outside the Empire offer concessions in their trading regulations, Rupert R. Ellen, Australian Government Trade Commissioner, declared here tonight.

Freight rate increases just granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission will add 15 cents a case to transportation charges on California citrus fruits delivered here, Paul S. Armstrong, general manager of the California Fruit Growers Exchange, said yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Homemakers who have been looking forward to plastic-covered walls that may be wiped clean with a damp cloth, can now find a variety of new materials and patterns in local stores. A new plastic wall covering pliable enough to bend around corners was introduced yesterday by the Pantasote Company.

A petition protesting against the building of the proposed New York University Law Center on a site facing Washington Square was presented yesterday to Chancellor Harry Woodburn Chase and Vice Chancellor LeRoy Kimball by representatives of the Save Washington Square Committee.

Charles F. Hayes, formerly with Bloomingdale's as buyer of fine jewelry, watches and diamonds, has been appointed buyer of all jewelry, watches and allied lines for the Spear Co. stores in New York and Pittsburgh.
In a heavy volume of business, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 27 to 53 points net yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that the city's bureau of analysis, created to bring about more efficient operation of city departments, had begun to function and would add fifty trained workers to its staff in a few weeks. His announcement was made at a luncheon in the Hotel Commodore of delegates to the annual conference of the Governmental Research Association.

MAMARONECK, Oct. 8 -- Economic trends in home construction costs are upward, but actual costs will be 10 to 15 per cent lower in 1948, Albert W. Lockyer, former president of the West-Chester County Realty Board and of the State Chapter of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers, said here today.

Crosley Motors, Inc., which began production of its low-cost automobiles in June, 1946, reported yesterday a net income of $476,065 on sales of $12,073,721 for its first full year's operation, which ended on July 31.

DES MOINES, Oct. 8 -- Republican meetings brought together here today Senator Taft and Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota, amid conjecture on the possibility that they would form the party's 1948 Presidential ticket.
DES MOINES, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft expressed doubt today that Congress would approve more than $4,500,000,000 a year for foreign relief under the Marshall plan.

Thirty-fourth Street pedestrian traffic for the year ended June 30, 1947, was 58,000,000 persons more than the 1941 total, according to a survey released yesterday by the Thirty-fourth Street. Midtown Association.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 8 -- Dragolub Yovanovitch, 52-year-old leader of the Serbian Peasant party, was sentenced here tonight to nine years at forced labor. The last of the South Slav peasant leaders to remain in opposition inside the Balkans, he was found guilty of conspiring against the state.
NAUGATUCK, Conn., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Frank J. (Spec) Shea, the Yankees' ace rookie hurler who won two games in the world series, received a hero's welcome home tonight from his fellow townsmen.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I, Oct. 8 -- The Westchester women, for the first time in seven years, won the Myra D. Patterson trophy as they defeated the Long Island and New Jersey golf teams over the Wheatley Hills course today.
L.L. Horch, New York regional director for the Department of Commerce, announced his resignation yesterday, effective next Wednesday, to return to private industry.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Telephones in the Army public information office of Lieut. Col. Orrin Krueger were loaded with long distance calls today. From Missouri, Iowa and Illinois, as well as all "over the East, there were requests for press reservations for Saturday's Army-Illinois game at the Yankee Stadium in New York.

NANKING, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- Communist forces have captured Kaiyuan, seventy miles northeast of Mukden, and battered their way to Tiehling, only forty miles north-east, a Government spokesman announced today.

French Foreign Minister Bidault, winding up his visit in the United States, had a last conference yesterday with Secretary of State Marshall and then made a new appeal to the people of the United States to speed economic aid to France.

ATHENS, Oct. 8 -- A proclamation by a secret plenary session of the Communist party of Greece today chided the Communists of the towns for "hesitation and vacillation" in raising the standard of the rebellion.

Corpus Christi, Tex., announced yesterday that it would offer on Oct. 28 issues of bonds totaling $4,480,000, consisting of $2,360,000 of tax-secured bonds maturing Jan. 1, from 1949 to 1977, and $2,120,000 of wafer revenue bonds maturing May 1 from 1949 to 1967.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 8 (AP) -- The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad Company sought from the Interstate Commerce Commission today permission to increase its regular interstate coach fares from 2.5 cents to 2.875 cents per mile.

The Rev. Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Representative for the Twenty-second (Harlem) Congressional District, opened a retail grocery store yesterday in the basement of the Abyssinian Baptist Church, 152 West 138th Street, as part of a campaign to bring down food prices.

Two of America's foremost soldiers voiced their concern last night for adequate hospital facilities throughout the country for the veterans of World War II and their families. Gen. Omar N. Bradley spoke, and Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower sent a message to a dinner opening the 1947 United Hospital Fund campaign in New York.

The City Rent Commission met yesterday and, after scanning the first 100 applications for eviction certificates, decided to approve forty-seven. This was announced by Paul L. Ross, chairman, who said that twenty-four of the certificates would assist in clearing the site of the projected East River Apartments, a large cooperative, whose builders have undertaken to find new homes for the families displaced from tenements there.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- Joseph A. Padway, general counsel of the American Federation of Labor, died tonight a few hours after suffering a stroke while addressing the annual convention of the AFL in the Civic Auditorium. He was 56 years old.
LONDON, Oct. 8 -- The British Government will press for an early discussion and a speedy settlement of the Austrian problem when the Council of Foreign Ministers meets here on Nov. 25.

Four hundred representatives of the New Jersey State Federation of Women's Clubs went on record yesterday as endorsing the revised State constitution. The action was taken at a one-day fall conference and luncheon in the grand ballroom of the Hotel New Yorker.

Studies in a number of laboratories, indicating that the adrenal glands, located astride the kidneys, play an important role in the maintenance of normal blood pressure as well as in the mechanism of community against infectious diseases, intoxications and environmental stresses, were described last night at the annual Graduate Fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine.

BERLIN, Oct. 8 -- Communists of Germany are galvanizing their forces in a double-barreled campaign to defeat the Marshall plan and to lend all possible support to the newly organized international Communist agitation through the so-called Information Bureau in Belgrade.

Franz Rupp, German pianist, who gave a recital shortly after his arrival here in 1939 and then turned to accompanying, gave his second New York recital last night at Town Hall. His listeners included Marian Anderson, the artist with whom he has been most closely associated, for he has been her accompanist for seven years.

QUITE early in his new novel, "The Saxon Charm,"* Frederic Wakeman makes his main point. It is that his leading character, a Broadway play producer called Matt Saxon, is a heel, a scoundrel, a monster -- what you will. That is established in a few blistering incidents and a savage psychoanalysis written by Saxon himself to explain how he went from mean beginnings to meanness on a colossal scale.

In the midst of the "Second Battle of Britain," which is again converting the country into a besieged fortress already reduced to below the lowest rations of the wartime period, the British Labor Government has just undergone the most extensive reorganization since it came to power more than two years ago.
Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle yesterday appealed to New York City's children to help the Fire Department reduce the annual number of fires.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 -- In an effort to "solve one of the knottiest problems of the American Federation of Labor's sixtysixth convention, how to give federal unions access to the National Labor Relations Board even if John L. Lewis abstains from signing a non-Communist affidavit, the convention's committee on laws gave serious consideration today to a proposed amendment to the AFL's constitution.

Loblaw Groceterias Extra dividends of 12 1/2 cents and regular quarterly dividends of 25 cents on Class A and B, all payable on Dec. 1, have been voted by the Loblaw Groceterias Company, Ltd. Like extras were paid in June and last December.

The metropolitan mixed pairs championship of the American Contract Bridge League ended early today in a first-place tie between Mr. and Mrs. David Nadell of Paterson, N.J., and Mrs. J.W. Donaldson of Tuckahoe, N.Y., and George linger of New York.

A disabled veteran with one leg, two fingers and half his face shot away has been restored to health, re-trained for a new occupation, and placed in a job paying him more than double his pre-war salary, State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi said yesterday.

MADRID, Oct. 8 -- Three members of the Smith-Mundt Congressional committee spent an hour and a half with Generalissimo Francisco Franco tonight at the Pardo Palace outside Madrid. The remaining members of the committee were reported to have declined to go.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member Hanks in ninetyour leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 1, the Federa Reserve Board announced today: An increase of $487,000,000 in loans, decreases of $280,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $247,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and an increase of $614,000,000 in United States Government deposits.

Two members of the Fordham varsity had to be assisted to the sidelines yesterday during a half-hour scrimmage between the freshman eleven and the regulars. Knee injuries were sustained by Steve Skapinec, a substitute guard, who handles the Rams' placement kicking, and Jim Maloney, substitute right end.

Senator Styles Bridges, chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, declared here yesterday before leaving for Europe with five other committee members that the Soviet Union's refusal to grant visas to them and other Government officials who wished to enter Russia to inspect the American Embassy at Moscow was a "glaring example" of "high-handedness."

The General Education Board, founded in 1902 by John D. Rockefeller, announced yesterday that it had appropriated $4,151,421 in 1946, mainly to strengthen institutions of higher learning in the South.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs, came to the defense of South Africa today as debate on the Union Government's refusal to submit a United Nations trusteeship agreement on South-West Africa entered its second day.
