WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- With the assertion that what Hungary needs "is not only patience but before all peace," Rustem Vambery in presenting his letters of credence at the White House today as Minister of Hungary asked President Truman "to bestow your benevolence upon the downtrodden Hungarian people and to grant Hungary a share in the helpfulness which is so characteristic of the magnanimous American nation."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 8 -- Eagle-Lion has acquired screen rights to "Hollow Triumph," a 1946 novel by Murray Forbes, from Charles R. Rogers, and has signed Paul Henreid to play the starring role in the film adaptation, the studio announced today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Dr. Hector David Castro, Ambassador of El Salvador to the United States, proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly ask the representatives of the Jewish Agency for Palestine and the Arab Higher Committee to make a new effort to agree.

After years of urging and persuading on the part of the late Dr. George E. Hale, after delays brought about by the technological difficulty of casting a huge blank of glass, after a World War that made it necessary to postpone much scientific research, the two-hundred-inch mirror is "figured."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Reversing a trend that began soon after the war ended, the flow of foreign students to this country has slackened and threatens to come to a virtual standstill, State Department officials disclosed today.

DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 8. -- Capt. John F. Lucey, internationally known oil man, who was a Republican figure and a friend of former President Herbert Hoover, died today in a hospital in Boston. His age was 72.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that dry hot weather in September trimmed 341,000 bales off this year's cotton crop which it now forecasts at 11,508,000 bales. Nevertheless, the indicated crop is nearly a third larger than last year's unusually small one of 8,640,000 bales.

Hats keyed to important midwinter occasions with emphasis on color and festive trimming were shown by Lenesta of 347 Fifth Avenue yesterday at the Hotel Pierre. Felt toques in subtle tones were accented with jeweled pins, contrasting ribbons or feather clusters, usually to one side.

While giving "reasonable" support to the United Nations, the United States must arm itself against possible foreign attack, Brig. Gen. Donald B. Adams declared yesterday before the opening session of the fifty-first annual conference of the New York State Organization, Daughters of the American Revolution.

An alternative to the British tax on earnings of American films was proposed yesterday by Sir Alexander King, Scottish theatre owner, who asked Hollywood movie company executives to guarantee a minimum return of "at least $12,,000,000" from exhibition of British movies in the United States and all the Americas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Two new devices were added to American heraldry today with the approval by President Truman of a seal for the new National Military Establishment and of a flag for James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense.

One hundred and twenty-five cadet midshipmen received diplomas and dual commissions as ensigns in the Naval Reserve and the Maritime Service yesterday at the ninety-second commencement exercises of the New York State Maritime Academy, Fort Schuyler, the Bronx.

The League Antiques Show sponsored by the Art and Antiques Dealers League of America began a ten-day run at the Hotel Shelton last evening. The exhibition presents to the public one of the finest collections of rare and beautiful antiques that has been seen since pre-war days.

The forces backing Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, CIO, in his fight against "outside" interference with the affairs of the NMU, began to show their power yesterday and succeeded in amending the union's constitution so that the definition of NMU policies, programs and procedures will henceforth be decided by the membership.

On the Sunny Side Corporate securities men, soured over the bidding up of the $75,000,000 Pacific Gas and Electric bonds, are getting free sympathy from fellow workers in municipal departments who are elated at the way the $15,000,000 Jacksonville revenue bond issue went.

Corn Exchange, Philadelphia The Corn Exchange National Bank and Trust Company of Philadelphia reported, as of Sept. 30, total deposits of $256,408,944 and total assets of $279,600,587, compared, respectively, with $247,263,760 and $271,546,086 on June 30.

WEST POINT, Oct. 8 -- Hans Christian Sonne, chairman of the National Planning Association, in an address before the National Conference on the Community at the Hotel Thayer here tonight, advocated forced savings as a remedy for this country's economic troubles.

Lost prices of major appliances shortly will undergo a "nominal" increase as a result of the emergency 10 per cent freight rate increase granted the railroads by the Interstate Commerce Commission, dealers and distributors said yesterday.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- The old Dutch Church of Sleepy Hollow, founded two generations before the Revolution, was celebrating its 250th anniversary today in ceremonies that will continue through Sunday. Restored by benefactions received from many parts of the country, it is joining Philipse Castle and Sunnyside in making tthe Tarrytowns a northern counterpart of Williamsburg.
The twelfth annual Girl Scout cookie drive is on. It began yesterday in Manhattan and the Bronx and a week earlier in Brooklyn. The sale will start in Queens Oct. 22 and in Richmond in January.

While interest in the coming encounter with Yale reached a fever pitch on the Columbia campus yesterday, Coach Lou Little sent his football squad through a three-hour drill at Baker Field. He concentrated on perfecting the Lion attack in anticipation of a sturdy Eli defense on Saturday.

Everett Fritzberg, pianist, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. His program contained the Bach-Busoni Toccata in C major; Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 81a; Rachmaninoff's Sonata, Op. 28; Chopin's Prelude in C sharp minor, Op. 45; the Schulz-Evler "Blue Danube," and two unpublished offerings, James G. Roy's Toccata in C major and Mark Wessel's Etude in G minor.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Continuous conferences among government officials, including representatives of the United States abroad who have returned to Washington to engage in them, are slowly developing the outlines of a European relief and recovery plan for the consideration of Congress.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- There is no apparent basis at this time for a general upward movement of savings bank dividend rates, Elliott V. Bell, superintendent of banks, asserted today. Speaking at the opening service of the fifty-fourth annual meeting of the Savings.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Oct. 8 -- Handing par a beating for the second straight day, Al Brosch of Cherry Valley moved into a four-stroke lead as the first half of the 72-hole Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship medal play tournament was completed today on the Cold Spring Country Club course.

Reviewing the program of the campaign for voluntary food conservation yesterday, Charles Luckman, Chairman of the Citizens Committee, found it getting "the whole-hearted support of the overwhelming majority of Americans." If this kind of support continues, compulsory controls will not be necessary to meet Europe's emergency.

The Police Department's Bureau of Identification closed its file yesterday on Jacob (Baldy Jack) Rose. The lanky informer in the Herman Rosenthal murder case of 1912 died in Roosevelt Hospital on Saturday of an internal disorder. He was 72 years old.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Oct. 8 (U.P.) -- Pope Pius told members of the United States House of Representatives Armed Services Committee today that only force could bring to terms some enemies of justice.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- The considered view of diplomats here who long have been in closest touch with European affairs is that the Communist manifesto issued from Poland Sunday was dictated by the Soviet Union against the interests of the Communist parties of France and Italy, which obeyed it.

Two attempts were made yesterday by the stock market to break through the narrow range of the last few sessions but on each occasion selling was encountered. The last burst of offerings came in the final hour and, under increased realizing, prices fell fractions to about 2 points for the widest decline since Sept. 23.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 8 (AP) -- The board of governors of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms today asked that the Government reduce "unnecessary governmental activities" to help lighten taxation.

TORONTO, Ont., Oct. 8 -- An American paper manufacturer, G. H. Mead of Dayton, Ohio, tossed a bombshell into the current conference here between a United States Congressional committee, the Canadian newsprint industry and the American publishers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Except to suggest that charges of Mr. Truman's former membership in the Ku Klux Klan had been "very effectively disposed of in the last campaign," the White House was officially silent today on defamatory allegations against the President published by the Italian Communist newspaper Unita.

PARIS, Oct. 8 -- Premier Ramadier today postponed tonight for twenty-four hours a broadcast on the financial crisis. It was stated that the speech had been approved by the Cabinet today but that the Premier would not go into details of his projected reforms.

Registration in the city appears headed for a new record for an off political year. At the end of the first three days, it exceeded the figures, in all the boroughs but Brooklyn, for the Mayoralty year of 1945, indicating a political interest unexplained by any of the issues at stake this fall.
Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, urged last night that the nation remain strong, not only in a military sense, but also morally, to cope with the immense problems of a world in flux.

A 40-year-old New Jersey bookmaker who welshed on a world series bet was stabbed fatally yesterday at Twenty-sixth Street near Seventh Avenue by a Bronx gambler, who was captured by a plain-clothes patrolman who fired a shot to stop his flight.

A threatened return of tie-in wholesale liquor sales is slated for strong repressive measures. They face not only a fight from retailers, who, are less able now than ever before to dispose of undesirable items in the combination deal, but also by the State Liquor Authority, it was revealed yesterday.

WARSAW, Oct. 8 -- The Polish Government ordered today retail price reductions of 5 to 20 per cent over a wide range of state-manufactured goods in a move, apparently with the two-fold aim of checking inflation and squeezing the small private trader a little tighter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The first ship carrying munitions to Turkey under the $100,000,000 arms program provided by the United States sailed from this country ten days ago, it became known here today as Gen. Saliah Omurtak, Turkish Chief of Staff, began a thirty-day tour of this country's military installations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- The Administration's new design for "sustained abundance" in food production would strongly support the Marshall plan and, would draw from that plan powerful reciprocal support, the Senate and House Committees on Agriculture were informed today.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 8 (AP) -- A.G. Vanderbilt's Newsweekly came in five lengths ahead of his nearest rival today to win the seventeenth renewal of the $10,000-added Maryland futurity at Laurel Park.

Gasoline stocks of the nation at close of last week declined to 81,607,000 barrels from 82,472,000 barrels the week before and 86,962,000 on Oct. 5, 1946, according to yesterday's report of the American Petroleum Institute.

BETWEEN the Doodger shenanigans on the playing field and Yankee upheavals in the front office, the baseball world has been spinning around at a dizzy rate for the past week or so. In the midst of all the madness, however, was one extremely sane move which was not given the attention it deserved, merely because it could not compete with the others for the headlines.

Large savings to business in New York were effected last year through legislation sponsored or supported by the Commerce and Industry Association, Thomas Jefferson Miley asserted yesterday in his annual report as secretary of the association.

The Book-of-the-Month Club has chosen "Red Plush," by Guy McCrone, as its December selection. The book, a story about a well-to-do Scottish family in Scotland in the Victorian era, is described as "a trilogy of novels in one volume."

The Knickerbockers' twenty-four-game, home schedule in the Basketball Association of America, released yesterday, shows a novelty in the introduction of afternoon contests at Madison Square Garden this season.

Random notes: Word has just arrived from the sandy fringe of the North Carolina Banks, via the Sharpe grapevine, that big channel bass have hit inshore in the Nags Head-Oregon Inlet area. The fish are schooling up inshore, preparatory to their fall move southward, but just how long they will remain within casting range of the beach no one knows.
CHICAGO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Fourteen-year-old Fred Rein, whose prize essay, "Manhattan, My Borough," earned for him the distinction of becoming Borough President for a day, died early yesterday morning at Willard Parker Hospital of poliomyelitis.

Swamped with packages dumped on it by the Railway Express Agency strike, the Post Office put a 6 P.M. limit yesterday on acceptance of parcels at its fortyeight stations in Manhattan, the Bronx and Pelham.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- A United States proposal for the creation of a special committee of the United Nations General Assembly to watch over Greece's northern border was approved here today by the Assembly's Political and Security Committee in a stormy session.

CHICAGO, Oct. 8 -- Grain prices on the Board of Trade advanced for the second consecutive day despite initial margin requirements of 33 1/3 per cent of the purchase price. Wheat was up 4 3/4 cents a bushel at one time, December selling at $2.90 1/4, which was up 15 3/4 cents from the low of Monday and within 3 3/4 cents of the seasonal peak.

ALIA, Lebanon, Oct. 8 -- Haj Amln el-Husseini, Mufti of Jerusalem and chairman of the Arab Higher Committee unexpectedly arrived in Alia, Lebanese mountainside resort, today. He came for a meeting of the Arab League Council, which is considering military measures to oppose a partitioning of Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- President Truman called upon American women today to make an "invaluable contribution" to the nation and to the world "by lending their wholehearted support to our food-saving program."
Bids totaling more than $500,000 were made at two realty auction sales conducted in Manhattan yesterday.

By the simple device of dipping back a half century in dramatic literature, Maurice Evans has given the season its first crackle of brilliance. He has come up with Bernard Shaw's "Man and Superman," which has been dozing on the shelf all these years, and he has had the good taste to put it on at the Alvin last evening.

With only one concession to his increasing age, Nathaniel Vickers, retired architect, prepared yesterday at his home, 78-11 Kew Forest Lane, Kew Gardens, Queens, for a family celebration today of his 101st birthday. The concession was his admission that after fifty years of play he has given up golf.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Acting Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett charged today that the revival of the Comintern was intended to prevent, if possible, the economic recovery of Europe.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 8 (AP) -- woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, said today that the American Newspaper Publishers Assocition overstepped its authority when it filed charges of Taft-Hartley Act violations against his union.

A first mortgage loan of $735,000 at 3 1/2 per cent interest for ten years was made by the Dollar Savings Bank to the New York Protestant Episcopal Public School on the nineteen-story and penthouse apartment building containing 109 suites at 5 Riverside Drive.

Furs of elegance were exhibited yesterday noon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by Russeks Fifth Avenue. The new look in this instance was the "close look," for Ralph Marano, who designed the wraps, believes that women should wrap their furs closely about them.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 8 -- A majority of the five-man Newark city commission is prepared to approve the proposed Port Authority fifty-year lease of the airport and seaport here, it was made evident today after an all-day discussion.

Thursday, Oct. 9, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Voted 34 to 6, with 9 abstentions, in favor of United States proposal to create a special committee to watch over Greek border.

"The Listener Talks Back," a program on which the radio listener will have an opportunity to voice his opinions on the broadcasting art, will make its bow at 9:15 P.M. Monday, Oct. 27, over the city's station, WNYC.

Reorganization of the Financial Advertisers Association under a new constitution and with the name changed to the Financial Public Relations Association was effected yesterday at the third session of the four-day annual convention at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria.

ROME, Oct. 8 -- Three days after publication of the Warsaw manifesto and announcement that the Comintern had come to life again in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, the Italian Communist party newspaper Unita made a scurrilous personal attack on President Truman this morning.

Several hundred stockholders applauded loudly yesterday when Curtis E. Calder, chairman of the Electric Bond and Share Company, told a record attendance at the forty-second annual meeting that directors would meet today to declare a dividend of 25 cents on the common stock, the first such payment in fourteen years.

LONDON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Bobby Locke, South African golf champion, predicted today that British Ryder Cup players could not accomplish as a team what he recently did as an individual -- defeat American professionals.
A recommendation that the United Nations be named trustee for Palestine "without delay" was made yesterday by Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism.

Notre Dame, Michigan and Texas are the big three in college football at this early stage of the 1947 campaign in the opinoin of more than a hundred sports writers who voted yesterday in the first Associated Press poll of the season to select the top ten teams.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Charles Luckman, chairman of the Citizens Food Committee, emerged today from a two-hour session with the distilling industry to announce that President Truman's proposal for a sixty-day emergency shutdown had gone over.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Details of the recent sensational raids in France when $2,545,200 in counterfeit United States money was seized along with twelve men, were given when Secret Service agents returned to Washington today.

Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, declared war yesterday on "economic gold-brickers." He said that the NAM and its 16,500 members were ready to give "the fight of their lives" to "the traveling salesmen of the isms hawking their wares at the factory gates, the schoolhouse doors and every crossroad of civilization."

Intensive preparation for its game against Boston University this Saturday in Fenway Park, Boston, continued yesterday at the University Heights practice field for New York University's football team. To this end a scrimmage between varsity and freshman squads was held, with the varsity emerging victorious.

The weight was just too much for the favorite in the Broad Hollow Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The two-mile fixture, which was run for the thirty-third straight year, attracted a slim field of only four jumpers, and Kent Miller's War Battle was assigned top weight of 165 pounds.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 8 -- Highly placed persons in the Pakistan Government and others interviewed here in the last four days declare unanimously that the fierce bloodshed and staggering migrations that have beset this sub-continent, since it was freed of British rule on Aug. 15, were the result of a highly organized plot, with the Sikhs at the core.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your excellent editorial of Sept. 26 warning the Governments of India and Pakistan not to make the mistake of imposing censorship either on foreign correspondents or on their own press has prompted me to write this letter.

LONDON, Oct. 8 -- South African gold-mining shares came under fire in the London market today with New Union continuing its decline of the last several days and finishing at half its 1947 high. Rooderand also continued to decline fractionally and Union Free State Gold followed the trend.

We don't know much about the debates of the early cavemen. Judging by the state of the skulls so far unearthed, they were usually settled by the blows of a club. Modern parliamentary procedure bars the use of the club. But the representatives of the new diplomacy from the Russian bloc of eastern Europe evidently believe they have found a substitute for its paralyzing effects in the insult.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- The art and ethics of horse-trading, political variety, has become a lively subject for debate at the United Nations.

ATLANTA, Oct. 8 (AP) -- A special committee of the State Legislature reported to Gov. M. E. Thompson today that the slaying of eight Negro convicts at a Georgia highway prison camp was necessary to end a mutiny and prevent a mass escape.
Shades of Night Since the end of daylight saving the shades of night have been falling faster and faster. Nature is quite considerate in this matter; she lops off only a minute or two each day.

"High Button Shoes," will open this evening at the Century Theatre under the auspices of Monte Proser and Joseph Kipness. Set in 1913, the musical comedy has been adapted by Stephen Longstreet from his novel, "The Sisters Liked Them Handsome," the story of the troubles of the author's family when they lived in New Brunswick, N.J.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 8 (AP) -- Blazing the six-furlong trip in 1:11, the best time of the year at Rockingham Park, J.H. Carr's 4-year-old Gray Star won the Bristol Allowance purse today before a crowd of 7,857.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Employes and unions have filed nearly 90 per cent of the cases before the National Labor Relations Board under the Taft-Hartley Law, an analysis of the docket from Aug. 22 to Sept. 30 showed today.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Oct. 8 -- Governor Dewey, calling for prompt utilization of the best scenic areas in the state for general public use, said tonight that New York's mountains, lakes and forests "were not designed by the Almighty to have a fence put around them to keep people out."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 -- Half the people of France may go without bread for two or three days a week beginning next February unless United States aid is forthcoming in the near future, a spokesman for the French Foreign Ministry said here today.
NANKING, Oct 8 -- China's railway network is so paralyzed that with the exception of the Peiping-Suiyuan line and the Canton-Hankow line not one major railway is open to through traffic.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 8 -- A national drive to get every American citizen's help to prevent business depressions at home, bulwark self-supporting countries abroad, defeat subversive aims of Communists and enhance business and economic security for all, was started here today.

The new issue of $75,000,000 of first mortgage 2% per cent bonds of Pacific Gas Electric Company was placed on the market at par yesterday, following effectiveness of registration, by the banking syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., which bought the bonds on Tuesday at competitive sale.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 8 (AP) -- Zinc production in Eastern States, with New Jersey the principal source, will be more than 15 per cent higher this year than last, Bureau of Mines figures indicated today.

The New York Football Yankees yesterday promoted a Brooklyn boy to the first team for their interborough battle with the Dodgers at the Yankee Stadium on Sunday. Coach Ray Flaherty announced that Bullet Ben Raimondi would start at left halfback in place of Spec Sanders if the Yankees received the kick-off.

The Philharmonic-Symphony Society opens its season tonight at Carnegie Hall with a concert conducted by Leopold Stokowski, for which the house is sold out. Not since the season of 1933-34, when Arturo Toscanini and Bruno Walter shared the podium, have the subscription sales been as heavy as for the forthcoming series, topping last season's by a total of 6 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- China has proposed to the United Nations General Assembly a new method of calling extraordinary sessions of the Assembly as an alternative to the United States' plan for an interim "Little Assembly," it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The capitulation of the distilling industry, if the twenty-one manufacturers who have not yet formally done so join their eighteen colleagues at yesterday's White House conference in yielding to what was rather more than a Presidential "request" for a sixty-day shutdown, will clear a tremendous hurdle for Charles Luckman and his food conservation committee.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 9 -- Prime Minister Jan Christiaan Smuts announced in a broadcast tonight that the Union of South Africa had agreed to lend Great Britain u80,000,000 [about $320,000,000] in gold to aid her in her present economic plight.

Community relations advertising appropriations, added to 1947 regular advertising programs, will account for a substantial over-all 1948 increase in advertising dollars, Association, of National Advertisers convention members disclosed at Atlantic City yesterday following an unexpected announcement by Lewis H. Brown, of Johns -Manville Corporation that he intended to increase his expenditures by 10 per cent to cover these enlarged activities next year.

MONTREAL, Oct. 9 -- While installment terms will be liberalized when credit restrictions are removed by elimination of Regulation W on Nov. 1, retailers are determined to continue the extension of credit on a "sound and conservative basis," A.L. Trotta, manager of the credit management division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association, said here today.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 9 -- A tour of the flight propulsion research laboratory of the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics and statements by officials here today revealed that the United States was well ahead at this time of Great Britain, and probably any other country, both in the production of high-speed missiles, aircraft and the power plants that make them possible.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, holds the construction of an oil pipeline in Saudi Arabia essential to national interest and of greater importance than similar work at home or in the Western Hemisphere, Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican, of Nebraska, said today.

Citing the transportation lessons learned from both world wars, Maj. Gen. Charles P. Gross told the Army Transportation Association last night that proper preparedness requires a permanent Transportation Corps and a war reserve of shipping.

"Business leadership in general is recognizing more and more the importance of human relationships," Swayne P. Goodenough, retiring president of the Financial Public Relations Association, formerly the Financial Advertisers Association, declared yesterday at the final session of the convention in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Dr. G. Everett Gaillard and Mrs. Walter Reynolds, who won last year, today repeated their victory in the annual Scotch mixed foursome tourney of the Westchester County Golf Association at the Hudson River Country Club.

Seven children who should know about the subject proposed yesterday their own substitutes for meats, poultry and eggs in connection with the food-saving drive. At the Children's Aid Society's West Side Center, 417 West Thirtyeighth Street, the youngsters, all of whom recently arrived from Europe, told what they ate in Europe during their permanently meatless war years.

BOSTON, Oct. 9 -- With the support of Philip Murray, Congress of Industrial Organizations president, a foreign policy declaration will be officially offered to the CIO convention next week omitting specific support of the Marshall plan except by remote inference.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 9 The United States turned down today the Soviet Union's official recommendation that warring Netherland and Indonesian troops in the East Indies be ordered to withdraw to lines drawn before the start of hostilities.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 4 were 942,523 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 4,579 cars, or 5.10 per cent more, than for the preceding week; 35,365 cars, or 3.9 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year, and 174,493 cars, or 22.7 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

A proposed capital outlay budget of $252,680,890 for 1948 was made public yesterday by the City Planning Commission, which also recommended that an additional $40,857,924 be raised by the imposition or sewer rents and special taxes to finance construction of sewage-treatment plants and school and playground projects not covered in the regular budget.

Steel production in the first nine months of this year was only 6 per cent short of the amount produced in the entire year 1940, record peace-time production year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
G. Lawson Ivie has been appointed general sales manager of Fieldcrest Mills, division of Marshall Field Co. He formerly was assistant general sales manager.

News that the Rumanian peasants are on strike was not needed to underline one of the most pregnant facts in the strangely unreal metamorphosis of eastern Europe. The countries on which Communist rule has been imposed as the result of the war are without exception peasant countries and without exception the peasants do not like the new regime.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the Bronx site for one of six city-aided housing projects, in which a total of about 5,700 apartments will be rented at an average of $12.50 a room a month. The Board deferred until Oct. 23 action on a Jackson Heights, Queens, site for a similar project.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- President Truman told his press conference today that meatless, poultryless and eggless days were "for the purpose of saving grain" and a matter "of vital importance."

Military preparedness by the United States should include careful fostering of this country's domestic fleet operating in coastwise and intercoastal waters, Frazer A. Bailey, president of the National Federation of American Shipping declared here yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Cigarettes to sell for 10 cents a package were envisioned today in the testimony of T.F. Flanagan, chairman, Associated Tobacco Manufacturers, before a Congressional subcommittee on the economic report as it brought its three-day hearings here to a close.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 9 -- The formal charges brought against two Catholic Secretaries General of the Slovak Democratic party in Slovakia and other aleged conspirators include a charge of plotting directly or indirectly with a foreign power.

Radio's statisticians have been busying themselves the last few days computing the number of listeners who heard one or more of the world series games and last night came up with figures indicating that several records were established.
Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the Port of New York Authority, accused railroads yesterday of attempting to block plans for the development of Newark Airport and Seaport.

Reconstruction and normal postwar improvements in the Philippines offer the best prospects for the American merchant marine in the Pacific area, according to Giles C. Stedman, vice president of the United States Lines, who has just returned from an extended tour of the Far East.

Carol Jones, mezzo-soprano from Chattanooga, Tenn., gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. The exacting program she presented included the aria, "Lascia eh'io pianga," from Handel's "Rinaldo"; the Laudamus Te from Mozart's Mass in C minor (K. 427); the Rondo from Rossini's "La Cenerentola"; Schumann's "Geisternaehe," "Der arme Peter," "Die Soldatenbraut," "Stille Traenen" and "Fruehlingsnacht"; four songs by Sibelius, and an English group.
The egg caused more trouble than the chicken on the first Thursday dedicated to abstinence from poultry and its product.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Oct. 9 -- Further pronounced gains in industrial production and in originating shipments last week boosted business in the Pittsburgh district to the best level since the beginning of August, according to the Bureau of Business Research of the University of Pittsburgh.

Ten-year-old Wanda Combs, from the little town of Clayhole in the Kentucky mountain country, affirms that her favorite stories are fairy tales. Yesterday, through a sight-seeing tour of New York and a visit with Mayor O'Dwyer, she admitted that these stories can come true for she found herself in a real fairyland.
The arrest of Alexander Stevens, an alien and reputed member of the Communist party, was announced yesterday by W. Frank Watkins, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.
GENEVA, Oct. 9 -- Tha completion of a gigantic multilateral tariff accord, often in doubt, is now regarded as a certainty by the negotiators in Geneva, it was learned today.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- The Political Bureau or directing body of the French Communist party, after a meeting today announced its full approval of the anti-American manifesto issued Sunday by the Communist parties of the Soviet Union and eight other European countries.

Choral works with small orchestra will be conducted by Robert Shaw in a new annual series of concerts devoted to compositions of this kind, to be given at Hunter College Auditorium, it was announced yesterday by Ira A. Hirschmann, president of F.M. Station WABF, which is sponsoring them.

The Chinese people, comprising more than one-fifth of the human race, are observing today the thirty-sixth anniversary of their revolution which began in Wuchang Oct. 10, 1911, swept away the Manchu dynasty and established the Chinese Republic. It would be pleasant to record that as a result of this momentous event, which transplanted China from the Middle Ages to modern times, the Chinese people are now enjoying peace and prosperity, and to congratulate them accordingly.

Commissioner Rhatigan would seem to have adequate reason for concern about the rise in relief rolls. The caseload for public assistance in the city's Welfare Department in August was 132,003. In August, 1946, it was 105,286. This is a rise of 25 per cent in a year marked by very high and, in some respects, record-breaking industrial and business activity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- With small advances in most commodity groups, average primary market prices Increased 0.6 per cent during the week ended Oct. 4, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Commerce. At 157.1 per cent of the 1926 average the bureau's index of commodity prices in primary markets was 0.6 per cent below the peak of two weeks earlier and 25.6 per cent higher than a year ago.
MOSCOW, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Decision has been reached here as to whether the Soviet Union will participate in the 1948 Olympics.

Registration in the city continued yesterday, on the fourth day of the six-day period that ends tomorrow, to soar toward a new off-year record. The number of registrants in the city on the fourth day was 326,122, bringing the four-day total up to 1,127,277.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows. HOGS Salable hogs, 7,000 head: total 12,000: market active; most sales of butchers steady to strong compared with Wednesday; sows and heavy butchers over 300 pounds steady to 25

AALEY, Lebanon, Oct. 9 -- In view of Great Britain's announced intention of evacuating Palestine, the Arab League Council unanimously recommended tonight that the seven League states send military forces to the borders of the Holy Land.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The National Petroleum Council repeated today a Government request for help in planning development of submerged oil lands.

The crippling effect of the threeweek-old Railway Express Agency strike on the city's business was intensified yesterday as the striking union moved to shut off air express movements at La Guardia Field.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Wheat prices continued on the upgrade on the Board of Trade today, December leading and being up 3 3/4 cents a bushel at one time and within 1 1/2 cents of the seasonal peak established last week. The close was slightly below the top, with gains of 1 1/4 to 3 1/4 cents a bushel.

The Federal Office of Rent Control issued a reminder yesterday of some of the regulations it administers. It reiterated that residential leases signed on or before Dec. 31, 1947, may include a rent increase up to 15 per cent, but only if the tenant voluntarily agrees to the rise.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- President Truman said today that Frank R. Creedon, Housing Expediter also administering rent control, was forced under the rent control legislation enacted last July to approve a general 5 per cent increase in rentals for Louisville, Ky., recommended by the area's Rent Advisory Board.

Has Leopold Stokowski, who, as officiating leader of the famous orchestra, opened the Philharmonic -Symphony season last nigh in Carnegie Hall, gone over to the conservative camp, or what? He has always been an innovator as well as a leading spirit in musical exploration.

ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 9 -- The State Food Commission, created by Governor Dewey last week to help cushion the impact of food shortages on the health of New York residents, announced today plans for prompt establishment of a central office in Albany and regional offices in New York City and Syracuse.

Despite a fourth mediation session scheduled for today at the State Mediation Board, striking employes of the Childs restaurant chain made preparations yesterday for a long walkout in their fight for higher pay, shorter hours and more holidays.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The dispatch by Delbert Clark on Niemoeller published in the times on Aug. 19 is shockingly inaccurate and in some instances misleading.

UNION CITY, N.J., Oct. 9 -- Photographs and films stolen from the Government's atom bomb laboratory at Los Alamos, N.M., nineteen months ago, were found by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a garage adjoining police headquarters here as the result of a routine search, it was disclosed today.

Armed became the leading alltime money winner of the turf by speeding to victory in the Sysonby Mile at Belmont Park yesterday. The 6-year-old gelded son of Bull Lea carried the colors of the Calumet Farm first across the wire in what was virtually a two-horse race against Oscar E. Breault's With Pleasure, 4-year-old son of He Did.
Institution of the first city-operated clinic for the prevention and detection of cancer was announced yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer.

Fifteen members of the special House (Herter) Committee on Foreign Aid returned yesterday on the liner Queen Mary after six weeks of intensive investigation in eighteen European countries with a single, unanimous decision reached. The decision was to be bluntly realistic in recommendations concerning both stop-gap United States assistance and the long-range Marshall plan.

Tests on normal human being's have revealed that bed rest and immobilization lasting more than ten days result "in rather serious effects" on metabolic and physiological function, it was reported last night at the annual Graduate Fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine.

A person can agree exactly with every one of the "Security Principles" announced by the State Department as governing its current check of its employes and still object to the final result, which seemingly is that an American citizen can be tried without a jury, without a bill of particulars being rendered, without being given an opportunity to confront his accusers.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Little Bettye Mims White of Dallas exploded one of the year's biggest links upsets here today, eliminating Mrs. Babe Zaharias, the world's top feminine player, in the Texas women's open quarterfinals, 1 up.

LONDON, Oct. 9 -- New financial measures designed to relieve inflationary pressures are scheduled for the next session of Parliament opening this month, Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said tonight. His statement was generally accepted as advance notice that an interim budget would be introduced this autumn.
FINDLAY, Ohio, Oct. 9 (AP) -- A fugitive gunman was shot in Trinity Episcopal Church today by a state highway patrolman after he had held the rector as hostage for an hour.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 9 (AP) -- Mrs. J.P. Iselin's Grey Steel, making his first start since mid-August, was an easy winner of the featured mile-and-a-sixteenth Monument Purse at Laurel Park today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Rustem Vambery, new Hungarian Minister, said at a news conference today that "Hungary, though in the neighborhood of the Soviet Union, must not be used as a baseball in the great world series in which the future of the human race is at stake."

A vigorous "build-up" for the home and for parents, to offset the blame now heaped on them, was advocated yesterday by Mrs. Lillian L. Hacker, associate in parent education, Teachers College, Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The President's Aviation Policy Committee will begin next week studies of plans by industrial leaders to implement American air defenses by long-range industrial planning, according to a schedule of hearings made public here today.

A press preview of the AnsonJones Company's first New York store took place yesterday afternoon. The shop, at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, is the first of a projected nation-wide chain devoted exclusively to dresses of a single price, $29.95.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- President Truman accepted with "regret" today the resignation of Charles R. Denny Jr., chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, who leaves the Government Oct. 31 to become vice president and general counsel of the National Broadcasting Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board announced today that injunction proceedings had been brought against the United Mine Workers (AFL) in Kentucky. This is the third such action under the secondary boycott provisions of the Taft-Hartley law.
An exhibition of 600 pieces of nineteenth century American glass -- mostly tableware -- was opened yesterday afternoon at the Metropolitan Museum of Art with a private view for members.

An underwriting syndicate headed by Goldman, Sachs Co. and Lehman Brothers will offer to investors today 79,177 shares of a new issue of 4 per cent cumulative convertible second preferred stock of Cluett, Peabody Co., manufacturer of men's shirts. The stock is priced at $102 a share.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- During the week ended Oct. 8, member bank reserve balances increased $108,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.
An increased volume of hedge selling in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday caused a setback in prices of 12 to 33 points on active months.

As part of a comparatively quiet day's meeting, the sixth biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, voted yesterday to assess each member $10 to assist in raising the union's strike fund to $2,000,000. The present strike fund is less than $600,000.
LONDON, Oct. 9 -- Following Sir Stafford Cripps' grim summing up of Britain's dollar position and reports of further gold sales to the United States, stock markets here today were depressed.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 9 -- The Argentine Foreign Office already has begun a study of the case of the two Yugoslav diplomats. They were due here late tonight after their expulsion from Chile as agents of a hemisphere-wide Communist network.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 9 -- In a three-and-a-half hour session which broke up tonight the executive council of the American Federation of Labor reached decisions on two major issues before the annual AFL convention, decisions which delegates expected would provoke sharp fights on the floor of the civic auditorium next week.

To hear Lou Little, Columbia coach, and Phil Moonves, Yale board of strategy representative, tell it, the other fellows football team is terrific. That was the impression the two speakers gave at yesterday's weekly football writers luncheon at Columbia's John Jay Hall.
Two favored teams easily won their way early today into the finals for the metropolitan knockout teams-of-four championship of the American Contract Bridge League at the Park Central Hotel.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 9 -- Training of male workers to serve as counselors to unmarried fathers, the formation of an organization to work with Government officials in bringing displaced persons to this country, and the establishment of pre-marriage and post-marriage clinics were proposed here today before the National Conference of Catholic Charities, which opened a five-day session.

The American Nurses Association, 1790 Broadway, reported plans yesterday for a campaign to arouse "the public to a clearer understanding of the present crisis in nursing." Speaking for 155,000 registered professional nurses, Ella Best, executive secretary of the group, analyzed the underlying factors of the problem and outlined a three-point program to enlist cooperation of other groups to help solve the difficulty.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- The tune, but not the words of the oft-repeated refrain, "that's a woman driver for you," was changed today at the National Safety Congress, the annual convention of the National Safety Council, when it was shown that women were safer drivers than men.

NANKING, Oct. 9 -- On the eve of the Chinese Republic's thirtySixth anniversary, Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek issued a statement tonight calling on the people to cooperate with the Government in combating the Communist onslaughts against the Nanking regime.

Despite a slackening of business, the stock market negotiated yesterday its best revival in about a week, with gains of fractions to more than a point. A better brand of leadership was supplied by some of the pivotal issues, which attracted better buying on the recovery and raised the industrial averages more than a point and the composite rate 0.66 on the day.

PARIS, Oct. 9 -- In a broadcast to the French nation tonight Premier Paul Ramadier announced a program of financial, economic and fiscal measures aimed at the immediate halting of inflation and to prepare a stabilization of the currency.
The investigation by the District Attorney of Kings County into socalled "stand-in" arrests in connection with the activities of bookmakers received impetus yesterday from an unexpected source.

BERLIN, Oct. 9 -- Representative Everett M. Dirksen, Republican, of Illinois, chairman of the Joint Investigative Committee of the Armed Services and Appropriations Committees of the House, urged today swift aid for Germany and the rest of Western Europe as a defense against the onward march of communism.

When women do their marketing today and tomorrow for the first week-end since the announcement of the food conservation program, they will find the major change in meat prices is in lamb, with three cuts from 2 to 4 cents a pound cheaper than a week ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 9 "Upward to the Stars," a screen story by Charles Martin purchased by M-G-M for $50,000 a year ago, will be filmed this winter with Van Heflin in the leading role, the studio announced today. Originally bought as a Robert Montgomery vehicle, "Upward to the Stars" was switched to Van Johnson's schedule after Montgomery left Metro.

BUFFALO, Oct. 9 -- It took no little bearing on the part of Buffalo's Katharine Cornell to attempt Shakespeare's "Antony and Cleopatra," although the Cornell prestige and powers were never at greater heights. From the day the bard first brought it forth the play has presented difficulties that have convinced some commentators it is better suited to the library than the theatre.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander ordered the suspension last night without pay of Patrolman Russell C. Wolf of the West 135th Street Station pending a departmental trial on charges he had assaulted Samuel Grossman, a business man, of 1016 Longfellow Avenue, the Bronx.

TORONTO, Oct. 9 -- Governmentsubsidized paper mills may be demanded by American publishers if Canadian newsprint prices rise above the present $90-a-ton level, the Canadian pulp and paper industry was warned today.

The Triboro Coach Corporation, operator of 135 buses on thirteen routes in Queens, warned the Board of Estimate yesterday that it would ask the city to "purchase and take over our property and equipment" unless it was relieved of some of the financial burdens of its franchise contract.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- British and American supported proposals to divert more disputes to the International Court of Justice were pranded by the Soviet Union today as another attempt to by-pass the United Nations Security Council.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Oct. 9 -- Al Brosch of the Cherry Valley Club, the Long Island open champion, captured the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association championship for the third time in his career today with a 279 nine strokes under par, over the Cold Spring Country Club course.

Municipal Market Comparisons between the municipal bond market and that for corporate bonds are often of little point because of the wholly different supply and demand factors that govern the issuing and buying of tax-exempt obligations.
Increasing dissatisfaction over Communist domination of the American Labor party has brought about the resignation of two leading members of its Bronx organization, it was learned last night.

Dr. Chaim Weizmann, former president of the World Zionist Organization and the Jewish Agency for Palestine, described the United Nations Palestine Commission proposal for partition of Palestine as a "very good plan" yesterday and expressed the hope that it would not share the fate of other plans in the past.

The National Association of Greeting Card Publishers, comprising sixty greeting card producers doing approximately 85 per cent of the industry's total volume, will conduct a concerted promotion effort to retain substantial wartime gains, S.Q. Shannon, managing director, disclosed yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- The Viet Nam Republic, in its fight for independence from the colonial administration of metropolitan France, has renewed its reports to have India sponsor the Viet Nam case in the United Nations Security Council, it was learned here today.

David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union, pledged yesterday that the 250,000 members of that union would vote against repeal of the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council in a statement made public by Richard S. Childs, chairman, and John J. Lamula, campaign manager of the Keep PR Committee.
Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, warned yesterday of the danger of failing to "recognize for what they are" groups within the country "opposed to our democratic traditions."

Sweden's trade deal with Russia is adversely affecting Swedish industrial interests, both because of the delay on the part of the Soviet in completing orders on the highly specialized products involved and the open question of whether Russian raw materials and long-term credits will materially benefit the Swedes, Max R. Sacra, export manager of Black Decker Manufacturing Company, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Senators today sought a way out of their seventh-place troubles by hiring a magician for their manager.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Oct. 9 -- Labor unions should be given a greater share in shaping industrial policies, Neil W. Chamberlain, assistant professor of economics at Yale University, declared today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Proceedings of the Special Committee on Palestine of the United Nations General Assembly came almost to a standstill this morning as a result of the unwillingness of the great powers to reveal their intentions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 4 were 19 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of last year:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- Heads of the Motion Picture Association of America met here today to discuss possible modification of the drastic 75 per cent British tax on the earnings of foreign films, including the Hollywood productions. Lewis W. Douglas, American Ambassador to Great Britain, was present by invitation of Eric Johnston, president of the association.

CHICAGO, Oct. 9 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio declared here today that heavy Federal taxation was one basic reason for high prices, and that the first task before Congress when it reassembled was to cut income taxes, an effort twice vetoed by President Truman.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- President Truman foreswore for the United States today any thought of territorial aggrandizement or economic domination through the Marshall plan of European recovery or any other phase of United States foreign policy.

The police of the West Fortyseventh Street station "examined" a psychhiatrist for more than an hour last night and then "treated" him with a prescription not customarily found in medical books. They delivered a severe verbal reprimand to the doctor and his wife for having left their 8-monthold daughter alone in an auto in the Times Square area.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 9 -- Financial and mining circles here agree that great significance attaches to the transfer of control over the New Union Goldfields group to the Anglo-Transvaal Consolidated Investment Company, Ltd., which has just been announced.

Men's Spring Hats Steady Leading lines of men's hats have been opened for spring at unchanged prices, with strong promotional and selling drives scheduled on the new offerings. In at least one instance a lower-price hat will be added to the regular lines.

The Citizens Union yesterday endorsed Peter Moraites, Republican candidate for State Senator in the Twenty-third District, as qualified and preferred to his five opponents. The election is to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Alexander A. Falk, Democrat, who resigned on appointment to the State Civil Service Commission.

Offensive and defensive maneuvers marked New York University's football workout yesterday for its game with Boston University at Fenway Park, Boston, on Saturday. The contest will be the Violets' third of the season.

ALBANY, Oct. 9 -- The Court of Appeals refused today to reconsider its May decision that Public Service Commission rulings are subject to court review of the facts as well as the law in cases where a company can claim the ruling has a "confiscatory" effect.

The number of fires started by children playing with matches has increased in many communities, according to the National Board of Fire Underwriters. Misuse of electricity now ranks second to matches and smoking in causes of fires.

Promising New Yorkers the equivalent of a trip to the Belgian Congo for the price of a subway ride to the Bronx Zoo next summer if everything goes well, Fairfield Osborn announced yesterday the zoo's first major African expedition.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 9 -- A broad program aimed at making state governments "more responsive to the needs of our citizens" was presented today at the opening session of a two-day meeting of the Southern regional conference of the Council of State Governments.

There were two debuts when the New York City Opera Company gave the season's first "Ariadne auf Naxos" last night at City Center, and both were ten-strikes. Wilma Spence as the Composer and Suzy Morris in her first principal role as Ariadne established themselves as singers of extraordinary gifts.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 9 -- When Yale leaves here Saturday morning for its date with Columbia at Baker Field, two of its leading operatives in the touchdown department will go along just for the ride.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- Four companies filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission registration statements covering offerings of 50,000 shares of preferred stock and 577,871 shares of common stock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission announced today that within thirty days it would establish regulations governing the export of equipment used in producing fissionable material.

A second volume of a proposed three-volume biography of James Madison by Irving Brant has been scheduled by Bobbs-Merrill for spring publication. Entitled "James Madison: The Nationalist," the book discusses the influence of the fourth President on America through the years of the Revolution. The first volume, "James Madison: The Virginia Revolutionist," appeared in 1941.

ROME, Oct. 9 -- L'Osservatore Romano today appealed to both Russia and the United States to moderate the tone of the statements of their spokesmen and the editorials of their press to prevent a further increase in the animosity between the pro-Communist and anti-Communist camps.

New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System last week set a new high record for loans for commercial, industrial and agricultural purposes, but the earning assets of the banks decreased, due to the sale of Government bonds and the lightening of short-term holdings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- With an estimated $140,000,000 available, the United States has embarked upon the most comprehensive program of student exchange ever undertaken by any nation, it became known here today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 9 -- To provide adequate medical care for all, especially 40,000,000 persons in this country who lack modern health services, Dr. Thomas Parran, Surgeon General, United States Public Health Service, recommended today that medical schools begin now to increase their annual output by 50 per cent.

Restatement of an Old Truth At the risk of being called laudator temporis acti, or something similar in Latin, Greek, English or possibly billingsgate, we wish to state that the course being taken by human beings in general and residents of the United States in particular seems to us to illustrate vividly the ancient truth that you cannot get something for nothing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am intrigued that Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr should have such prompt and authoritative knowledge of a secret and entirely German meeting before the press here knew of it.

Declaring that tax reduction by Federal fiscal authorities is the key "to our future national solvency," John W. Hanes, former Under-Secretary of the Treasury, warned yesterday that Federal subsidies, which, he noted are increasing constantly, threaten "to nullify all efforts at economy."

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Oct. 9-- The trend in the relative position of savings banks among savings institutions is much less favorable to the banks than the recent growth in the volume of their deposits appears to indicate, according to Dr. John Lintner, assistant professor of finance, Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration.

The upland game season in New York gets under way at noon today in the Adirondack area with the opening of the legal date on grouse and a number of New Yorkers who had spotted good covers during fishing excursions departed yesterday to try their luck.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The spokesman before Congress of the most powerful national farm organization cast its weight today against the major social plank in the Administration's proposed new long-time agricultural program.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- Rebuffing a conciliatory United States gesture, the Soviet bloc served notice here today that it would boycott the special Balkan committee of the General Assembly that was approved yesterday by the Assembly's Political and Security Committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 -- The International Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, attacked the Taft-Hartley law today on constitutional grounds in a reply to unfair labor practice charges brought by the Baltimore Graphic Arts League.

Looked upon by the cognoscenti as the latter-day counterpart of Gilbert and Sullivan (hear! hear!), Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d wear the purple with becoming modesty. Not only are they considered Broadway's foremost collaborators, but they also have an equally high rating as a perspicacious producing firm.

A stockholder's derivative suit filed yesterday, in Federal Court here charged Royal Little, president of Textron, Inc., textile manufacturer, with having siphoned off the assets of the company through the purchase and sale of numerous mill properties.

Eschewing progress to the arts for the moment, the producers of "High Button Shoes" have put together a very happy musical show in a very cheerful tradition. With Phil Silvers skipping through it like an old burlesque mountebank, it was acted at the Century last evening, much to the pleasure of a relaxing audience.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 9 -- The expulsion by Chile yesterday of two Communist agitators possessing diplomatic status was explained today in a Government announcement that named names and places.

NORWALK, Conn., Oct. 9 -- Mayor Irving C. Freese, elected Monday on a Socialist ticket, put in today his first full day of duty as the city's chief executive. He announced he had requested all minutes of meetings of the Police Commission during the last two years as a preliminary to discussing the operation of the department with the Commissioners and Chief Jeremiah F. Dorney.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 9 -- All twenty Latin-American Republics have expressed themselves in favor of establishing a United Nations commission to deal with their economic problems, David Owen, Assistant Secretary General for Economic Affairs, announced today.

LADELPHIA, Oct. 9 -- Simultaneous with the announcement that it is contemplating revamping the rules for corporate proxies comprising Regulation X-14, under Section 14 (a) of the Securities Exchange Act, the Securities Exchange Commission made public today a preliminary draft of the proposed revision.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 9 -- Carnegie Institute's annual, "Painting in the United States, 1947," concerning which some general comment was sent along yesterday, opened this evening with a preview. The opening of the galleries in the Department of Fine Arts was preceded by a reception in the foyer of Carnegie Music Hall, where this year's awards were announced by Carnegie Institute's president, William Frew.

In line with his plan to familiarize his charges thoroughly with the Penn State offensive system, Coach Ed Danowski staged a long dummy scrimmage yesterday for the Fordham varsity with the freshman squad directing its offensive from the single-wing formation of the Nittany Lions.

TOKYO, Oct. 9 -- Japan may increase her police force from 94,000 to 125,000 men, but first must decentralize their administration, Gen. Douglas MacArthur told Premier Tetsu Katayama, according to a letter released today.

Fortified by the Taft-Hartley Law's ban on "feather-bedding," three large Broadway motion picture theatres have renewed their fight against making stand-by payments to the New York musicians' union whenever out-of-town "name" bands appear on their programs.
Both Branch Rickey, who has been bossing the Dodgers for five years, and George Weiss, who has just begun his rule of the Yankee baseball empire, tuned in with important announcements yesterday.

The capital budget for 1948 proposed by the City Planning Commission crowds the $300,000,000 mark, as against about $252,000,000 suggested last year. The city departments asked for $585,714,453, and they would be getting $292,538,814. About $40,000,000 of this would be financed outside the city's debt limit, and new taxes and sewer rents are proposed to carry most of this added sum.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 9 -- The National Association of Cotton Manufacturers was told here today by Russell T. Fisher, its president and secretary, that "bad judgment on the part of retail buyers" was the reason for the present prices of textiles.

Friday, Oct. 10, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Heard Soviet bloc serve notice it would boycott special Balkan committee: Andrei Y. Vishinsky declared plan violated principle of equal sovereignty and was adopted by illegal procedure.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 9 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Company put the Securities and Exchange Commission on notice today that it will fight to the United States Supreme Court any ruling by the SEC that the company cannot keep both gas and electric companies under the Public Utility Holding Company Act.

After a two-hour appearance before the July grand jury investigating the source of the money used to keep Mrs. Doris Coppola away from this city in connection with questioning about the fatal Election Day beating of Joseph R. Scottoriggio, Mrs. Blanche Del Guidice was held yesterday in $7,500 bail as a material witness.
Price decontrol a year ago last June was blamed last night by Secretary of Labor Lewis B. Schwellenbach for the present high cost of living.
The statistics with which football reporters are bombarded these days plainly show what a great job Orban (Spec) Sanders is doing with the New York Yankees.
RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 9 (AP) -- In a move unprecedented in college athletics, John J. Wicker, local attorney and prominent University of Richmond alumnus, today took the Vernon Morgan case to court.

Founder's Certificate Awards will be presented by the Better Business Bureau of New York City, Inc., to fifty-eight New York City concerns at a luncheon commemorating the bureau's twenty-fifth anniversary in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Oct. 30, it was announced yesterday.

Robert Reud has decided against continuing the run of his London importation, "Duet for Two Hands," after tonight's performance at the Booth Theatre. The Mary Hayley Bell drama, headed by Francis L. Sullivan, Joyce Redman and Hugh Marlowe, opened on Tuesday and will depart after seven showings.

Governor Dewey, in his address at Cornell yesterday, put this country's obligations to its own citizens above its obligations to citizens of other countries. No one can quarrel with this principle. We do have to see to it that "no American is poorly fed as a bitter result of thoughtlessness or badly planned generosity on our part."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- A spokesman for the Jewish Agency for Palestine today denounced reported troop movements by Arab states as "bluff and bluster" and said that, under the leadership of the exiled Mufti of Jerusalem, Haj Amin el-Husseini, the Arabs were "brazenly emulating Hitler's tactics."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Distinct coolness toward a special session of Congress on European aid was made evident today by members of the special House (Herter) Committee on Foreign Aid who have returned to the capital.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 -- The Taft-Hartley law was denounced to the American Federation of Labor's annual convention today as "sabotaging the Marshall Plan and American policy in Europe," and steps were taken toward implementing threats of AFL leaders to bring the full machinery of the federation into action to defeat national political candidates sympathetic to "anti-labor measures."

Saturday,Oct. 11. 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Rejected Colombian proposal to eliminate finding of guilt against Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria in Balkan dispute; approved Canadian motion to accept United States slate of members of new Balkan committee, leaving open places reserved for Soviet Union and Poland, and rejected Colombian amendment to place six non-permanent members of Security Council on committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Compulsory allocation of basic commodities at the primary markets was laid down today by Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, as the first of a series of alternatives to success of the Administration's voluntary conservation program in lowering food prices.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Amendment 5, to be voted upon election day, dividing the now Second Judicial District into the new Tenth District of Queens, Nassau and Suffolk Counties and leaving Brooklyn and Richmond Counties in the Second District merits approval by the voters and not the disapproval advocated by Ferdinand I. Haber in his letter in your columns of Oct. 4.

PARIS, Oct. 10 -- The first decrees in the application of Premier Paul Ramadier's anti-inflation program, which were published today, provide: (1) For the postponement of all Government contracts for equipment and reconstruction until the budget has been determined.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 10 -- Warning that Russia is using news as a weapon for world domination, Neil MacNeil, Assistant Night Managing Editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, in an address here declared that the Soviet Union is sending out false propaganda in an attempt to promote its cause in international affairs.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Oct. 10 -- The National Conference of Catholic Charities adopted a resolution here today urging aid for starving Europe and pledging cooperation both in a foreign aid program and in the Government's food-saving campaign.

AALEY, Lebanon, Oct. 10 -- Minor Arab troop movements toward Palestine's borders started today. They obeyed a recommendation by the Arab League Council for "military precautions" in case the British evacuate Palestine.
Parents must set a good example for their children and so teach them to obey the laws of God and the community in which they live, Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander said last night.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- The Soviet Union attacked the whole foreign economic policy of the United States here today without offering any suggestion for economic compromise in Germany, Japan, Greece or elsewhere.

The labeling of footwear leathers, corresponding to the practice of clothing manufacturers in labeling fabrics, will be inaugurated by Town and Country Shoes on Oct. 20, it was announced yesterday by Vergil Lipscomb, president of the company.

ANNANDALE - ON - HUDSON, Oct. 10 -- A sharp attack on the American policy that discourages foreign students from coming to this country was made here by Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College.

Store Sales Gain 35% Although there was considerable variation due to the manner in which they met difficulties a year ago, the composite figure indicated for this week's sales of Brooklyn and Manhattan department stores was a gain between 35 and 40 per cent, it was estimated yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The report today of an added 54,761,000 bushels in sight from the 1946 corn crop was offset by an unexpected cut-down of about 50,000,000 bushels in carry-over, Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson, stated today, adding that no last-minute scale-down would be possible in the save-grain campaign.

MEMPHIS, Oct. 10 -- Representatives to the meeting of the Southern Regional Conference of the Council of State Governments were unable today to achieve complete agreement on the controversial question of Federal aid for education.
The board of directors of the United Service Organizations, Inc., approved yesterday a plan to close out all USO operations in this country and overseas on Dec. 26.

The majority of New Yorkers is not sufficiently serious about fire prevention, Hugo E. Rogers, Manhattan Borough President, declared yesterday at City Hall Park. Speaking at Manhattan Day ceremonies staged for the current Fire Prevention Week, he told 500 persons that this task "is everybody's job."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Crusading against interlocking directorates, the Department of Justice has found that 1,500 men hold directorships in more than one leading industrial concern and that sixty of these men are on the boards of two or 'more competing companies.

The question whether leaving a baby unattended in an automobile after dark constitutes legal abandonment will not be answered for another two weeks. Justice Jacob Panken, at a hearing in Children's Court yesterday, directed that Dr. Johann G. Auerbach and his wife, Barbara, appear before him on Oct. 24" for a ruling on the matter.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The Norden bombsight, top secret of the United States Navy for more than fifteen years, was one of 419 inventions on which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

The Yugoslav Government has not followed the example set by the Bulgarian Government in dealing with its outstanding peasant leader and patriot. The Bulgarians hanged Nikola Petkov on Sept. 23. The Yugoslavs have given Dragolyub Yovanovitch a comparatively light sentence of nine years at forced labor.

The appeal of Joseph Stack from the membership decision that ousted him as vice president of the National Maritime Union, CI0, six months ago after charges were preferred by Joseph Curran, president, was brought before the union's sixth biennial convention yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Labor-management relations have apparently reached an unusually felicitous level, judged by the number of strikes occupying the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

TOKYO, Oct. 10 -- A spokesman of Japan's two leading labor federations said last night that they had decided to use strikes only as a last resort in the country's present distressed state. They will mix political and economic objectives, they promised.

TSINAN, Shantung", Oct. 10 -- The Government's occupation of Chefoo, Weihaiwei and most other areas of the Kiaotung promontory was the final move in the initial phase of the Nationalist campaign to win Shantung.

SAN FRANCISCO. Oct. 10 -- Arthur C. Miller, West Coast maritime arbitrator, held today that longshoremen must pass through picket lines thrown about the Port of Los Angeles by their walking bosses -- the longshore foremen.

The stock market made yesterday some further progress on the recovery side, although the advance was restrained by the taking of profits in the final hour. Strength exhibited in the early trading by the steel and motor shares invited bidding in other sections, but the demand faltered near the close of the session.

BERLIN, Oct. 10 -- Soviet aims at thwarting the application of the Marshall plan to Germany through a form of industrial warfare took concrete shape today in a military order by Marshal Vassily D. Spkolovsky to increase the productivity of labor.

The dressed poultry market closed slightly lower yesterday after the first eggless-poultryless day under President Truman's food conservation program. But dealers pointed out that this market has been weak all week and they thought conservation and its effect in curtailing demand had little to do with it.

Boston, Oct. 10 -- With one dissenting vote the executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today adopted a report criticizing Communist leadership of the Mine, Mill and Smelter Workers Union. The lone dissenter was a representative of the smelter union.
ITHACA, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- The text of Governor Dewey's speech on food problems today was at follows:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- The Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today rejected a proposal to eliminate a finding that Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria, in violation of the Charter, had "given assistance and support to the guerrillas fighting against the Greek Government."

The physical requirements of the individual were adopted as the common standard in planning the United Nations buildings, Wallace K. Harrison, chairman of the United Nations headquarters planning board, said yesterday at a luncheon given in his honor by the American Institute of Decorators at the Architectural League.

Army and Illinois, principals in one of the top football games in the nation today at Yankee Stadium, crossed paths yesterday, but missed each other by several minutes. Dropping in at the Stadium for a final light workout, his unbeaten Cadets went through their paces and trotted off the gridiron.

Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek was charged with being 90 per cent responsible personally for the present chaos in China by Gen. Feng Yu-hsiang at a press conference yesterday at the Hotel Capital Hall, 166 West Eighty-seventh Street.

A recital of singular merits and curious inconsistencies was given by Gunnar Johansen last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Johansen is a fully equipped pianist and an excellent musician to boot. He has all the power and technique in the world when he wants to employ these attributes, and fire, too.

Teaching the Young Hezekiah Cobb, still a confirmed countryman, is not quite sure that he is any longer an unterrified fox hunter. It seems he has been visiting on Long Island and found himself in the midst of the cubbing season.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Investigation's in some 200 displaced persons camps of Europe have convinced a widely traveled House group that the solution of the problem should not await Congressional decision.

Brooklyn College went down to a 12-to-0 defeat at the hands of a battling Hofstra eleven before 4,000 persons at Ebbets Field last night. Touchdowns in the second and fourth quarters gave the Hempstead squad its margin of victory.

Prompted by the growing concern of New York business men, Mayor O'Dwyer appointed yesterday a three-man fact-finding committee to study the issues and facts of the twenty-two-day-old strike against the Railway Express Agency.
Seventeen local housing agencies will receive bids on Oct. 28 on issues of temporary loan notes aggregating $39,740,000.

Possible new approaches to treatment of diabetes have been Indicated by use of radioactive isotopes in experiments on animals, Dr. De-Witt Stetten Jr. of the Department of Biological Chemistry, Harvard Medical School, reported last night at the New York Academy of Medicine.

Property owners in New York received $34,699,994 for holdings taken by the city in condemnation proceedings in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 20. Charles E. Murphy, Corporation Counsel, reported yesterday.
