LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton's speech to bankers here last night had a two-way effect on the stock markets today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- The Rev. Dr. Michael Scott, active member of the passive resistance movement in South Africa, arrived here today as an adviser to the Indian delegation after having been delayed almost six weeks in receiving his visa to enter the United States.

Gertrude Lawrence, whose appearances on the air have been comparatively infrequent of late, will re-create her original role in "Lady in the Dark" at 9:30 P. M. next Sunday, Oct. 19, over the ABC network (WJZ). The broadcast, presented by the Theatre Guild on the Air, will originate from the Boston Opera House, where Miss Lawrence's supporting cast will include Bert Lytell, John Conte and Alan Hewitt.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- United Nations officials and delegates conceded glumly today that the long, bitter political debates, fought out to deadlock, would drag out the session of the General Assembly beyond mid-November.

With registration for the election on Nov. 4 ending at 10:30 tonight there was every indication that the total registration for the full six-day period would exceed 2,000,000, a quarter of a million more than the registration in 1943, the last comparable "off year."

With George Weiss handling the oil can and directing the mechanics, the Yankee farm machinery is rolling along smoothly and steadily, assuring the world champions of replacements for worn parts when, or before, the 1948 American League pennant race begins.

MOSCOW, Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- The newspaper Pravda said today the forming of the new Information Bureau in Belgrade by the Communist parties of the Soviet Union and eight other European countries was not a rebirth of the Comintern. It was the next step in the development of the international working class movement, Pravda asserted.

High grade investments were under pressure in yesterday's bond market. Sharp price declines occurred in the telephone bonds-issues of American Telephone Telegraph Company and subsidiaries -- and in such issues as Pacific Gas Electric, Standard Oil of New Jersey and Pennsylvania Railroad.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 10 (AP) -- Northeast storm warnings were ordered up around the southern end of the Florida Peninsula from Miami to Fort Myers this afternoon as a storm with winds approaching hurricane force swept up out of the northwestern Caribbean Sea toward Cuba.

Lowell Beveridge and Bob O'Neil each tallied twice in leading Horace Mann School for Boys to an impressive 24 -- 0 victory over Stony Brook School of Long-Island yesterday at Horace Mann, avenging the setback of their opener a year ago.
A menu, planned by the Department of Markets for a family dinner on Saturday, to cost $2.l0 for five persons, follows:

A field of seven will try for the big money at Belmont Park today. The occasion is the New York Handicap, valued at $100,000 added, and the runners who will try for the major part of the purse are Arnold Hanger's Rico Monte, Richard N. Ryan's Talon, Mill River Stable's Miss Grillo, Lazy F Ranch's Calvados, Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' Stymie, C. V. Whitney's Phalanx and Mrs, F. P. Magann's Jackamine.

The Government abandoned yesterday its legal fight to force John Santo, Rumanian-born international organizer of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, to take the witness stand at his deportation hearings.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- The colonial powers, led by Britain, and supported by the United States, were defeated by one vote today on a motion submitted by the Soviet Union in the United Nations General Assembly's fifty-sevenmember Trusteeship Committee.
Bernard Aron has been named sales manager and will be in charge of all advertising and sales promotion at the Piedmont Shirt Company, makers of Wings Shirts.

MANCHESTER, England, Oct. 8 (Delayed) -- Great Britan's cottor industry has begun to climb out of the black pit of the war depression. However, a long, hard path is still ahead, and many difficulties remain, especially through shortages of labor and coal.

Five Canadians who arrived here Monday aboard the Yugoslav ship Radnik have been refused permission to land because they lacked the "necessary United States transit visas." This was confirmed yesterday by W. Prank Watkins, district director of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 10 (Aneta) -- The Amsterdamsche Bank and the Incasso Bank, N. V., have agreed to merge pending approval of shareholders, it was announced today. The combined capital of both banks will be reduced from 85,000,000 guilders (about $32,000,000) to 70,000,000 guilders.

A court action that may test the constitutionality of the city's new eviction control law was instituted yesterday. Accusing the City Rent Commission of "unconscionable" delay in acting on an application for a certificate of eviction filed on Sept. 25, the owner of a Queens building asked the Supreme Court either to compel issuance of a certificate, or to adjudge the city lawunconstitutional and void.
BOSTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Boston College was just too much for Kansas State tonight as eight of the Eagles scored touchdowns for a 49-13 victory before a paid audience of 21,457 at Braves Field.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial "The Tolling Bell" illustrates once more the unique and suicidal American missionism which will ultimately destroy this country by depleting its resources and weakening its people. It further strengthens the view that this is the worst-led nation in the world.

Despite the handicaps imposed by the railway express delivery strike, manufacturers of women's apparel have been able to ship out a greater volume of goods this season than a year ago, according to a survey of New York's coat, suit, dress and millinery markets yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10-President Truman today presented an embossed scroll to Maj. Gen. Guy V. Henry to mark his second retirement from active duty after 50 years, 8 months and 23 days of active service. Kenneth C. Royall, General Eisenhower and several other associates of General Henry witnessed the ceremony.

CHICAGO, Oct. 10 -- Grain markets were irregular on the Board of Trade today. Wheat closed 1/2 cent a bushel lower to 1 1/4 cents higher than yesterday. December sold at a new seasonal high early, but lost most of the advance. July showed the most strength as little relief is expected for the dry areas in the South-west during the next five days.

Strike action against the Third Avenue Transit Company, effective 4 A.M. Monday, was authorized last night by the Transport Workers Union, CIO, in a move to win a new contract that would include a 25-cent hourly wage increase.

GREENSBORO, N.C., Oct. 10 -- Decentralization in the textile industry and the comparative lack of large integrated factors affect consumer prices adversely, J. Spencer Love, president of Burlington Mills Corporation, declared here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Undersecretary of Labor David A. Morse announced today the establishment of the Office of International Affairs in the Department of Labor and the appointment of Philip M. Kaiser as its director.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 10 -- Development of a new procedure whereby smaller doses of influenza virus vaccine may result in immunity without producing the febrile reactions commonly associated with vaccine inoculations was described today at a closing session of the seventy-fifth annual American Public Health Association.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 10 -- Unidentified assailants, speeding past in an automobile early this morning, fired several shots into the embassy of the Russian Ambassador. Windows were shattered but no one was hurt.

Sales of leading mail order and chain companies increased 19.9 per cent in September over the corresponding month of 1946, according to a compilation of forty-two companies made by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The increase in August was 8.8 per cent.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Each New York Yankee regular will get $5,800 as his share of receipts from the world series which ended last Monday, and each Brooklyn Dodger will collect $4,000, it was learned today as official figures were announced by Walter Mulbry, secretary-treasurer in the office of Baseball Commissioner A. B. Chandler.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 10 -- Claudette Colbert withdrew tonight from the role of Mary Matthews in Frank Capra's screen version of "State of the Union" because Liberty Pictures, producers of the film, refused to include a 5 o'clock quitting clause in her contract, Samuel Briskin, Liberty vice president, announced.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 -- The first of America's war dead came home today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Naval Academy's former secret society, the "Green Bowlers," has been absolved of charges that it was a "vicious" officers' clique, the unofficial service publication, Armed Force, said tonight.

American Overseas Airline, its operations halted for eleven days by a walkout of 173 pilots, notified fourteen international airlines, both American and foreign flag carriers yesterday, that its transatlantic fleet of aircraft is for lease on a short-term basis.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Mutual concessions eliminated today two points of difference that had slowed down the work of the Foreign Ministers' deputies who are meeting here to propose a plan for the disposition of the former Italian colonies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The strength of the Army continues to dwindle while the Air Force is more than meeting its manpower needs, according to official recruiting figures obtained today.
Still smarting from a 40-7 defeat in its opener with Georgetown, Fordham will make its local gridiron debut today against Penn State at the Polo Grounds. Kickoff time has been set at 2 P.M.

Just a year ago the convictions of top Nazis at the Nuremberg trials demonstrated that the world was grimly prepared to make men pay for their aggressive wars and crimes against humanity. Those ringleaders not only paid with their lives or chose suicide; they symbolized for both victor and vanquished a new tenet of international law -- that individual men as well as the state must be held to account for evil acts against society.

Having carried song-writing to its logical conclusion, Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II have gone one step further. They have composed a musical play without any of the conventions of form, "Allegro," which was sung at the Majestic last evening.

DETROIT, Oct. 10 -- The rehabilitation of the mentally handicapped can be achieved only if all professions join in detecting early signs of neurotic disturbances and fight to remove the social stigma connected with such illnesses, Dr. Luther E. Woodward of Ne k, consultant of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, asserted today to delegates attending the Michigan Welfare League and the Micnigan Society for Mental Hygiene.

A new artificial liquor shortage was seen yesterday in a "runaway" buying market, with retailers attempting, to load up in stock before the proposed sixty-day shutdown of distilleries to conserve grain goes into effect.

NANKING, Oct. 10 -- Dr. Hoilington K. Tong, head of the Government Information Office marked the thirty-sixth anniversary of the Chinese Republic today with a long article in the China Press condemning foreign press critics.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 10 -- "A decided drop in the inflow of new veterans but an overflowing reservoir of total collegiate students" was noted today in a report on attendance at American universities and colleges by Dr. Raymond Walters, president of the University of Cincinnati and nationally known statistician on higher, education.

College football puts on its New York show of the year today. In excess of 100,000 spectators are expected to fill Yankee Stadium and Baker Field, with the highest quality of action in store for them.

An anthology composed of American writings of a century ago in many fields has been edited by James P. Wood, entitled "100 Years Ago: American Writing of 1847." The advisory editorial committee on the first volume of The Centenary Series in American Literature was composed of:

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- Yugoslavia accused the United States today of harboring German and Italian war criminals who had committed multiple offenses during their occupation of the Balkan state.

The discovery of America 455 years ago will be celebrated tomorrow in the annual Columbus Day parade up Fifth Avenue. A total of 50,000 persons will march. The parade will start at 1:30 P. M. at Forty-fourth Street.
PARIS, Oct. 10 -- The Soviet Union has informed the French Government it is willing to discuss shipping Russian wheat to France in exchange for manufactured goods.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As the originator of the first Pacific War Memorial proposal of World War II and one of the charter members who founded the Pacific Memorial Foundation of Hawaii; I request the opportunity to comment on your editorial support of scientific field stations as a Pacific War Memorial.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Governor Dewey declared in a nation-wide radio broadcast today that preservation of the health of the American people was a "binding obligation" which took precedence over the admitted responsibility to feed the hungry of Europe.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 10 (U.P.) -- The Texas women's open today saw another upset when Miss Carol Diringer, Tiffin, Ohio, golf star, defeated Mrs. Bettye Mims White of Dallas, 2 and 1.

After forty-six years of production in Hawaii, the Hawaiian Pineapple Company, Ltd., is giving serious consideration to expansion in Cuba to take care of the greatly increased pineapple demand and to handle the development of additional markets in new fields, Henry A. White, president, stated in an interview yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.

The other evening we attended a meeting of the Metropolitan Rod land Gun Club, and we left the club-house amazed, at the volume of sport the club produced at a per capita cost that could only be described as negligible.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative, high-grade state, city and county bonds legal for savings banks in New York State now offered by dealers.

Now that much of the clamor which greeted the State Public Works Department's proposed $2,000,000,000 highway construction program has died down, it may be possible to examine the proposals in the light of present and prospective needs. Charles H. Sells, State Superintendent of Public Works, has reported that about $143,000,000 must be spent annually for the next fourteen years if New York's roads are to be made up to date, efficient and safe.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The American demand for wine, after a post-war spurt and subsequent slump that had wine men worried, is leveling off at about 49 per cent above pre-war consumption.

ROME, Oct. 10 -- One of the worst fights ever seen in the Italian Parliament took place this evening when a Communist Deputy Giancarlo Pajetta, stated that at that very minute Monarchists and Neo-Fascists were holding a meeting not 200 yards away and were playing the "Royal March" and singing Fascist songs.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Dreptapea Noua, newspaper of the governmental National Peasant party, said today that the Rumanian Cabinet had decided to hand over to the United States, Great Britain and France eighteen metric tons of gold in final payment of claims of Rumanian gold abroad they believe to be of German origin.

Sir Stafford Cripps has always been a unique, rather lonely figure in British politics. The man who now emerges as the key figure in the Labor Government was expelled from the Labor ranks in 1939 because he was too far to the left, or too independent, for the party stalwarts.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- Damaged by German bombs and showing the wear and tear of the austerity age, Buckingham Palace is being restored to something like its old time splendor for the November wedding of Princess Elizabeth.

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 10 -- More than five years after the crime that shocked the civilized world and made the name of the village of Lidice a synonym for Nazi barbarity, thirteen SS men [Elite Guards] and one woman entered pleas of "not guilty" in Nuremberg this morning to accusations that they had played major roles in this and other atrocities.

Thoroughly angered over the police beating of Murray Becker, Associated Press photographer, Mayor O'Dwyer late yesterday made arrangements to have the facts presented to the grand jury with a view to criminal prosecution of the policeman.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Approximately 100 veteran housing units have been allocated to Rutgers University by the State Department of Economic development, it was announced today at the quarterly meeting of the board of trustees of the State University.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The railroads filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission their tariffs carrying an emergency increase of 10 per cent in freight rates and charges, to go into effect on Monday. Excepted from the increases are protective services for perishables, demurrage on freight cars and drayage.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 10 -- Henry A. Wallace, former Vice President, demanded here tonight that President Truman make public the full text of the most recent report of his Economic Advisory Council and said "there is no excuse for suppressing the vital information which, we need to plan here at home."

ALBANY, Oct. 10 -- The argument that government aid to housing is the forerunner to communism and socialism was attacked tonight by Herman T. Stichman, State Commissioner of Housing. The commissioner spoke at the Siena Social Science Forum at Siena College, Loudonville, near this city.

The Mexican Army jumping team that will compete in the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden Nov. 4 to 11 arrived by automobile yesterday and immediately went to Squadron A Armory for practice.
OLEAN, N. Y., Oct. 10 (AP) -- State Senator Benjamin F. Feinberg urged bankers tonight to exert influence in support of the Dewey administration's widely assailed permissive local tax program.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Herschel V. Johnson will deliver the eagerly awaited United States statement on Palestine here tomorrow morning. He will speak before the Special Committee on Palestine of the United Nations General Assembly.

SUTTON-COLDFIELD, England, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Art Lees won the title "champion of champions" today on the eve of his departure for America with the British Ryder Cup golf team by defeating Australian Norman Von Nida four strokes in a 36-hole play-off for the Dunlop masters' tournament honors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- The National Farmers Union urged today an "immediate" special session of Congress to make effective the Marshall plan and to lay down sharp selective price controls and rationing to prevent any further rise in basic prices, including those for agriculture itself.

Country-wide coordination of motor, rail and air transportation facilities, so that all of these agencies will be available immediately in event of a national emergency, was urged yesterday at the closing session of the annual convention of the Army Transportation Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Arthur Garfield Hays, famed trial lawyer and counsel for the American Civil Liberties Union, was called a "nut" and threatened with a "sock in the nose" by a belligerent witness yesterday during a stormy examination in a pre-trial hearing of Gus Fusaro.

There wasn't a more thrilling football game all last season than the spectacular contest at New Haven in which Columbia erased a two-touchdown deficit at the half to defeat Yale, 28 -- 20. With excellent prospects for a repeat performance of that stirring script, the Light Blue and the Dark Blue will meet again today before a full house of 35,000 at Baker Field.

LONDON, Oct. 10 -- A protocol providing for the immediate return to Italy of $25,000,000 in gold uncovered in northern Italy by the United States Fifth Army was signed here today by representatives of the United States, Britain and Italy.

WHEN THE MOUNTAIN FELL,"* by Charles-Fernand Ramuz, is an unusual tale. It deals in violence but its prose never shouts. It is a parable but it is never quaint. It is the story of something that happened far away and long ago, a rockslide that buried the best men of an Alpine village, but it is as tragically compelling as the account of a recent mine disaster.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 10 -- Harry Reid of Indianapolis, president of Indianapolis Railways, Inc., was elected today president of the American Transit Association by the more than 1,500 members attending the closing session of the group's sixty-sixth annual convention here.

Monday Holiday Financial and commodity exchanges throughout the country will be closed on Monday in observance of Columbus Day, which this year actually falls tomorrow. Livestock markets Will remain open, however.
Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, itemized the strengths and weaknesses of the nation's defense policy last night and,found it seriously lacking on several counts.
Cotton futures turned easier yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange and closed 17 to 52 points net lower than the day before.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board issued five decisions today on new airline services between cities in the Middlewest, East and South.

With today the last opportunity for voters to register for the election on Nov. 4, workers of all political parties and many civic organizations increased their efforts yesterday to get city residents to register. In most cases the issue of proportional representation as a method of electing members of the City Council seemed to be the main factor in bringing out a much larger registration than in 1943, the last comparable "off year."
The metropolitan team-of-four championship was won early today by Morrie Elis, Tobias Stone and Mrs. E.J. Seligman of New York and Philip Abramsohn of Hollywood, Fla.

The free enterprise system is being threatened by the spread of foreign ideologies and inflation, and unless our Government succeeds in "bringing itself to establish an efficient use of our help in the restoration of world economy," communism will displace our form of Government, Senator Raymond E. Baldwin, Republican, of Connecticut, said last night.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Oct. 10 -- Joseph A. Beck, Pittsburgh attorney, told the Pennsylvania Water Works Association today that it is the duty of a water works operator to raise his rates to the point of reasonableness if service to the public requires the action.

OTTAWA, Oct. 10 -- Canada will have to pay between ten and fifteen millions dollars a year for atleast five years into the Treasury of Newfoundland if that island decides to join the Canadian confederation as the tenth province, according to evidence submitted during recent discussions between a Newfoundland delegation and members of the Canadian Government and their experts.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Full employment in a free society is "inevitably inflationary," Dr. William A. Irwin, economist of the American Bankers Association, told savings bank executives here today. Dr. Irwin, who spoke at the closing sessions of the fifty-fourth annual meeting of the Savings Banks Association of New York State, termed the present high level of employment a "major secondary factor" in the current inflationary spiral.

OTTAWA, Oct. 10 -- Canada will have to pay between ten and fifteen millions dollars a year for atleast five years into the Treasury of Newfoundland if that island decides to join the Canadian confederation as the tenth province, according to evidence submitted during recent discussions between a Newfoundland delegation and members of the Canadian Government and their experts.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Oct. 10 -- Full employment in a free society is "inevitably inflationary," Dr. William A. Irwin, economist of the American Bankers Association, told savings bank executives here today. Dr. Irwin, who spoke at the closing sessions of the fifty-fourth annual meeting of the Savings Banks Association of New York State, termed the present high level of employment a "major secondary factor" in the current inflationary spiral.

Asserting that "we hope to pull another Willkie stunt," Maurice Mumford, executive vice president of the Draft Elsenhower for President League, said yesterday that the league would seek election of delegates in a number of States, including New York and Wisconsin, to next year's Republican National Convention pledged to the nomination of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower.

Reflecting larger commercial borrowings, statements of condition of the fifteen largest banks here as of Sept. 30 showed a further improvement in banking operations for the second successive quarterly period.

Registration in the city reached a total of approximately 2,300,000, computation indicated at 3 A.M. today, with three Manhattan election districts still unreported. The total was regarded as amazingly high for an off-year, setting a new record and exceeding substantially the total of those who qualified to vote in the Mayoralty election two years ago.
The Erie Railroad is planning to add twenty-eight new units of marine equipment to its present fleet of 237 operating in New York Harbor, it was announced yesterday by R.E. Woodruff, president.

ROME, Oct. 11 -- A municipal election "will be held in Rome tomorrow and is expected to afford the first indication in many months of whether the Communists and Left Wing parties have been gaining or losing strength in recent times.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Bobby Layne pitched Texas to a 34-14 victory over Oklahoma today in the wildest of the forty-one games between those southwestern rivals.

On these pigskin-chrysanthemum week-ends, venerable scholars pore over the deeds of mighty men of yore, stretching back into history even before the days of the T-formation and the forward pass. How erudite in football are you? Answers below. 1. The annual Rose Bowl Game is played on New Year's Day in Pasadena, Calif.

SO much of our fiction nowadays sounds the trumpet of doom that it is refreshing to have a story like "Way of Life" come along. This time, Mr. Gibbs' heroes are soldiers whose integrity and intellectual seriousness set a good moral example: his heroines are understanding, always of noble mind, and always unafraid.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Administration's plan to help Europe rebuild its shattered economy had reached this week-end the most critical stage since its enunciation by Secretary Mashall last June at Harvard University.

FATHERS have been telling us of "awful" things their children do. Little girls, sweet and endearing one minute, are "brats" the next. Other youngsters -- around 6 to 8 -- lie, pilfer, use improper language and answer back. It all sounds like quite normal behavior and we think the fathers are bearing up the better because they know that it is.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Dropping direct charges of responsibility for the Balkan dispute, the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly called on Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria today not to give any aid to the guerrillas fighting the Greek Government.

Mayor O'Dwyer's special fact-finding committee in the Railway Express Agency strike yesterday won union and company agreement to a peace plan expected to send the men back to their jobs Tuesday morning.

VIENNA, Oct. 11 -- The Austrian Treaty Commission ended today at its eighty-fifth session nearly five months of discussion by signing a report to the Council of Foreign Ministers that, in the words of a United States delegate, "contained no resolution of any major issue."

BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 11 (AP) -- A 47-yard run, a 75-yard power drive and a 36-yard touchdown pass gave Missouri a 21-0 football victory over Colorado today, breaking the Buffaloes' string of seven home games without a defeat.

The twenty-first annual convention of the Propeller Club of the United States will open on Wednesday for a three-day meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The largest advance registration of delegates in the history of maritime gatherings was reported yesterday by officials of the club.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 11 -- Two sharply differing impressions have characterized the reaction of the Pacific Northwest to the Government's plan for saving food. Many housewives criticize the program of the President as too easy. They claim that already high prices have compelled them to observe more days without meat, eggs and poultry than Mr. Truman has requested.

The revival of the Comintern last week was regarded by responsible business leaders here as showing the importance attached by the leaders of world Communism to its never-ending efforts to influence the intellectual life of every country.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Oct. 11 (AP) Alabama's Crimson Tide, relying almost entirely on a ground attack instead of its vaunted aerial offensive, punched out a 26-to-0 victory over a hard-fighting Duquesne eleven today.

OMAHA, Oct. 11 -- Reaction in President Truman's Midwestern home region was generally favorable to his food saving suggestions, with the possible exception of the request to economize on eggs and poultry.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- Britons are traditionally masters of the art of compromise and so it is likely that what has come to be known here as the battle of the hemline will end in a draw. Skirts will yield to "foreign influence" but only by an inch or two.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 10 (Delayed) -- Special precautions are being taken here to protect the Scheduled Castes -- otherwise called the "Untouchables" -- without whose services in sanitation, scavenging, menial labor and city administration in the dominions of India and Pakistan would be hamstrung.

ROME (By Wireless). IF you happened to meet Palmiro Togliatti in the street, the chances are you would set him down as a moderately successful business man. There is nothing in his appearance to suggest that he is Secretary General of the Italian Communist party and an ominous figure in Italy's political life. To his henchmen he is known as Il Migliore ("The Best").

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Minnesota's football team, aided by a pair of fumbles and a bad pass from center on the part of Northwestern, swept to a 37-to-21 victory today in the opening game of the Western Conference season for both teams.

JOHN MASEFIELD's son was killed in the war in 1942. He wrote two "novels" before his death at the age of 32. He was not at all a novel writer, but in a London "where everybody's Aunt Lucy or Uncle George has written something or other," Lewis Masefield's two books came out.
MIAMI, Sunday, Oct. 12 -- A small tropical hurricane moved across the lower Florida peninsula early today and was expected to hit this winter resort capital within a few hours.

MANILA, Sunday, Oct. 12 (AP) -- For the second time in forty-nine years the American flag was hauled down at Corregidor today as the war battered island fortress passed to the jurisdiction of the Philippine Republic.

"DOWSON, ERNEST (18671900), author of a book of remarkable poems (1896) of which the best known is 'Non sum qualis eram . . .' with the refrain 'I have been faithful to thee, Cynara! in my fashion.'" Although, as this entry in "The Oxford Companion to English Literature" clearly implies, Dowson is best remembered as poet, it was characteristic of him that he preferred his prose to his verse.

NOT since 1922, when Carter G. Woodson finished his monumental "The Negro in Our History," has a complete history of the Negro in the United States been written. The project has been attempted only four or five times, though nearly 100,000 works on the Negro have been written in the last sixty years, all concerning one or another aspect of the Negro's experiences in America.

Plans for a new industrial center in the Steinway section of Long Island City were announced yesterday following the acquisition of a site of 360 lots along Nineteenth and Twentieth Avenues between Forty-second and Forty-eighth Streets.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Grains moved ahead today on the Board of Trade following over-night announcement by the Department of Agriculture of a smaller increase in corn crop prospects than had been expected by most grain analysts. Best gains were reduced in late trading.

QUITE a few years ago Joseph Szigeti and Bruno Walter made a recording of Beethoven's Violin Concerto that was one of the finest as far as musical values went. But the technique of recording had not progressed enough to get onto disks all the good musical things that the artists had tried to put into them.

SHOULD the American Repertory Theatre persist in the struggle to establish itself in our town, it will have to do so without the services of Cheryl Crawford. Last week Miss Crawford confessed she could see no future for repertory under present conditions and bowed out.

Philanthropic organizations will gain from the net proceeds of special performances of several plays and musical comedies within the next few weeks. On Tuesday night the performance of "Man and Superman," with Maurice Evans, will be a benefit for the American Friends of France, of which Miss Anne Morgan is honorary president and Mrs. Arthur Woods, president.

The statement delivered by Herschel V. Johnson, for the United States, before the Assembly Committee on the Palestinian Question yesterday must strike most Americans as a fair-minded and practical approach to a distressing problem. Our Government has accepted as a matter of course the unanimous recommendations of U.N.'s Committee on Palestine.

Smooth-striding Bill Lucas of Morris, No. 1 local favorite to win the N.Y.U. interscholastic crosscountry meet next week, breezed to a 90-yard victory in the second of three Public HighSchools Athletic League group runs at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Oct. 11 -- Harvard ventured south of the Potomac today for the first time in its long gridiron history and took its worst beating in years, a 47-to-0 shellacking by a University of Virginia eleven that produced a powerful running attack and sharp passing.

In the worst beating Fordham has absorbed since football was introduced to Rose Hill in 1883, the Rams were crushed by powerpacked Penn State, 75 -- 0, before 12,000 persons at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

JULE STYNE and Sammy Cahn, a couple of songwriters from Hollywood, sat in a hotel suite in New York explaining that they had forsaken their swimming pools and approximately $150,000 in joint annual loot to take a fling at the footlights.

The Arab action of threatening Palestine with military force was branded yesterday as an effort to turn the session of the United Nations Assembly into another Munich by Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninety-first Street.

Jersey yachtsmen are getting frothed up again with spume, scud and spray over the idea of a transstate canal. They hope the rest of the boating world will get appropriately excited, especially skippers who use the inland waterways to and from Florida and don't hanker for the twenty-three-mile outside ocean run between Sandy Hook and Manasquan Inlet.
BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- Boston University warmed up for its intersectional clash next week with Purdue by trouncing New York University, 38 to 7, before a crowd of 5,000 at Fenway Park this afternoon.

A mechanical "radio tube," built on the top of a small table, which has enabled electronic experts in a single day to accomplish designs for new radio tubes that ordinarily would have required as much as three months of trial-and-error laboratory work, was announced here yesterday by Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

FORT WILLIAM, Ont., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Chairman Clarence Brown of the Newsprint Committee of the United States House of Representatives predicted today that the price of newsprint would not increase before Jan. 1, but did not rule out the possibility of an advance thereafter.

FOR a good many years now Walter D. Edmonds has laid tint and color upon his cyclorama of New York canal boat days: piece by piece, it has become a detailed and spacious spectacle for the enjoyment of Americans who like their history this way.

BROOKS ADAMS' "America's Economic Supremacy" was first published in 1900. Reading it in 1947 in this new edition which comes to us with an introductory evaluation by Marquis Childs, the syndicated Washington newspaper columnist, one is startled by a series of prophecies that are currently abreast of the latest headlines.

To the Music Editor: During recent years the business done in record albums has reached enormous proportions. Unfortunately, it does happen once in a while that the owner of an album breaks one of the records.

JUST twenty years ago this week in this Review: Autobiographies had a field day: On Page 1 is the life of Roald Amundsen -- "The Saga of a Modern Viking," says the head. Dr. Will Durant tells his own story in "Transition," and as befits a philosopher, the reviewer remarks that "intellectual adventures have given Dr. Durant his greatest thrills."

THE France of 1940, as Elsa Triolet re-creates it with eyewitness details in these three Gon-court Prize-winning novels, was a country of divergent purposes. There were the "realists" who were too easily resigned; the opportunists who welcomed their new condition; the innocents who preferred to ignore it.

LONDON, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- With a 1-0 victory over Aston Villa today in a game at Highbury witnessed by 60,000, Arsenal remained at the top with twenty points in the English Football League's first division. Only one point in arrears was Preston North End, which emerged victor over Manchester City, 2 -- 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Mississippi State scored touchdowns in the last three periods and played heads-up football all the way to register a 21-to-14 upset over the previously undefeated University of San Francisco eleven today before 20,000 fans.

FRENCH chefs talk in terms of ounces and glazes, truffles and quenelles -- altogether, in a jargon that housewives cannot translate into their own brand of kitchenese. Louis P. De Gouy is different. He has had an enormous professional experience, and yet he can write cookbooks that are as understandable to homemakers as was Fannie Farmer herself.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Britain and Australia today submitted two proposals to the United Nations Security Council in another attempt to end the fighting in Indonesia by the establishment of a neutral zone.

In a detensive stalemate reminiscent of its deadlock with Notre Dame a year ago, Army extended its unbeaten sequence to thirty-one games yesterday as it fought Illinois to a scoreless draw at the Yankee Stadium.

NEW YORK, which prides itself on being the theatre center of the nation, falls short in one respect, according to some serious students of the drama. It has the theatres and the plays, and somehow the plays get produced and are seen.

Evander Childs scored its second straight victory yesterday trouncing Stuyesant by 33-14 in the first game of the scholastic football double-header before 7,000 fans at Randalls Island. In the second contest, Christopher Columbus conquered Seward Park, 12 -- 0.

BULL HOUSMANN might have been heavyweight champion of the world if he hadn't met the wrong woman -- a circumstance of which none reminded him, since Bull, in his forties, fat and booze-soaked, still had a punch like a mule's kick and didn't hesitate to throw it.

DR. WINTHER'S "The Great Northwest" fills the need for a compact, contemporary history of the Pacific Northwest. Bancroft's, still the original storehouse, is now more than sixty years old; Joseph Schafer's (1905; revised 1918) dates back over forty, and George Fuller's (1931) over sixteen incident-packed years.

Seeking to discourage jewelry smuggling attempts and incidentally to increase customs revenues, the Customs Service of the Treasury Department has taken the unusual step of advising incoming air and liner passengers how to escape high jewelry tariffs in a legal manner.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- Twenty British constables armed with Sten guns guarded the American consulate against possible Arab attack today after the United States announced its support of the partition of Palestine.

You can travel America for half a lifetime and still get a new thrill of pride and exaltation each time you leave salt water behind and head out across the breadth of the country. It's more than so many miles, or so many days, or so many towns and cities and farms.

FOOD tragedy had ham actors for parts last week as the conservation program to save Western Europe was unfolded. One of the first things discovered was that turkey was banished from the Thanksgiving meal.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 -- There is more than the usual degree of puzzlement in this area about the food situation and the appeals for meatless and eggless days.
"LOOK at the big lug," said Frank Frisch, nodding in the direction of Rogers Hornsby. "He's the only guy I know who could hit after dark and with the lights out."

STILLWATER, Okla., Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Southern Methodist University Mustangs counted three touchdowns in the first half, then desperately fought off a steadily improving Oklahoma A. M. football team to win, 21 -- 14, today before 18,000 fans.
SANTIAGO, Oct. 11 -- Chile, today rejected energetically the Yugoslav charge that she was under the control of a foreign power and without sufficient independence to act on her account.

A COMPOSITE camera which records several images through separate lenses in a simultaneous, instantaneous exposure, to produce a single three-dimensional picture, which is seen without a viewer, is due on the market next year.

Two thousand persons attending a Columbus Day dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night were told by speakers and through messages that Italy required increased aid from this country if communism were to be checked and the economic crisis survived.

An audience of 1,800 assembled at Carnegie Hall last night to welcome and applaud the Little Singers of Paris, or as they are known in their own country, "Lea Petits Chanteurs a la Croix de Bois." The young singers were led by the genial Abbe Fernand Maillet, who brought similar groups here in 1931 and 1935.

ALONG about this time even year a traditional mental depression settles on a great proportion of the country's wage-earners. Vacations, Sunday picnics and trips to the beach are things of the past. The sound of the happy voices of the children preparing for a summer day's outing is gone, and in its place is the householder's groans as he pries loose a window screen and urges a recalcitrant storm window onto its rusted hinges.

A PROSTITUTE who plied her trade in London's foreign quarter has been murdered, and Arthur Groome is on trial for his life. The chain of circumstantial evidence against him is exceptionally strong, although it has a few weak links.

THESE folk tales take the reader into a strangely fascinating world, the burning stretches of the great desert which Australians call "The Great Dead Heart." But it is, we discover, far from dead, inhabited by one of the most primitive peoples on earth and by animals and birds with such tongue-tickling names as bandicoot, witchedy-grub, kurreke tata and mopoke.

A confusion without parallel in the annals of capitalist finance held the high-grade corporate bond market here in a state of perplexity and near-paralysis as financial markets came to a close last week for the extended holiday week-end.

MADRID, Spain, Oct. 11 -- The Spanish Government announced today revised movie censorship regulations providing that all sessions of the censorship board shall be secret and the representatives of the Catholic Church authorities shall have complete veto power.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Led by the passing of Bill Bell, Muhlenberg College gained its third straight gridiron triumph today by crushing Swarthmore College, 67 to 7.

IOWA CITY, Iowa, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Little Al DiMarco and Emlen Tunnell furnished the one-two punch today as Iowa toppled Indiana, 27 to 14, in a Western Conference football game before 51,150 homecoming fans.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The current tense relations between the United States and Russia seem to be doing for the Eisenhower-for-President boom what jet propulsion did for aviation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct 11 -- Premier Paul-Henri Spaak of Belgium said today that Europe would run the risk of economic collapse this winter unless the United States provided economic help through the Marshall plan.

Under dark skies a gray funeral ship has brought the first of our honored war dead home to the land that bore them. They went out as young men dedicated to the defense of their country. They came back dedicated to eternity and the peace that passeth understanding. For us their return marks a rededication to the cause for which they died.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A scene of confused and frenzied activity the like of which hasn't teen witnessed hereabouts since the early days of the war was being enacted in a cluttered suite of offices on the second floor of the old State Department Building this week as the Citizens Food Committee strove desperately to find its feet and get moving in what it hoped would be the right direction.

WHAT can already be called an event of the 1948 season is a posthumous book by Virginia Woolf, entitled "The Moment and Other Essays" -- none of it hitherto published in book form and most of it never published at all.

THE National Council of State Garden Clubs, Inc., will hold its semi-annual meeting at the Mount Royal Hotel, Montreal, Wednesday through Friday. This is to be a joint session with several Montreal garden clubs and is the first such combined gathering of American and Canadian horticultural clubs.

UPPER Radstowe is one of those pleasant towns that nestle in the hollows of the English novel between the sea-girt crags of World War I and the grim, blasted heath, open to the sky, of World War II. There are no communities like these, nothing like this atmosphere of literate simplicity and restraint, almost unchanged since the days of Jane Austen, in any other literature of the world.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 11 -- An airplane tour for 300 miles over the northern and eastern borders of Palestine today failed to disclose any troop concentrations within twenty miles of either side. Jewish spokesmen said Arab reports of mobilizations were a "war of nerves."

Letting of the contracts for construction of the new building of the Serial Federal Savings and Loan Association at the southwest corner of Church and Vesey Streets was announced yesterday by George E. Palmer, president. Mr. Palmer said work would be started on Nov. 1.

Indications that farm land prices throughout the country and costs of building in New York City are leveling off are contained in an analysis of price studies just completed by the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

BUCHAREST (By Wireless). IN Bucharest they call her "Aunty Ana," but she is no poor, neglected relative. In fact, she is the intellectual leader of the Rumanian Communist party and a key strategist in the Government campaign to fix Rumania's place in the Russian orbit.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- The proposal for a partition of Palestine into two independent states, one Jewish and the other Arab, was endorsed today by Herschel V. Johnson, the United States representative of the Palestine Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

ATHENS. DWIGHT PALMER GRISWOLD, the former Governor of Nebraska, who came to Athens a few days less than three months ago to run the American Mission of Aid to Greece, is the most powerful and very likely the busiest man in Greece.

Plans for expanding two housing developments in lower Westchester County next spring were announced yesterday by Alan L. Carnoy, builder and head of the Alanwood Corporation with offices at 205 East Forty-second Street, in Manhattan.

Dr. Frederic Ewald Sondern, well-known retired clinical pathologist, and former president of the Medical Society of this state, died Friday night at Post-Graduate Hospital after a six-week illness. His age was 80. He resided at 180 West Fifty-eighth Street.

After the Germans developed their V-1 winged, jet-propelled rocket and their three-thousand-mile-an-hour wingless V-2 rocket, desperate and expensive efforts were made in Great Britain and this country to build miltary planes that would travel at 500 miles an hour and more.

Setting the pace in New Jersey's post-war program of permanent housing with the aid of state loans and grants, Englewood is completing a project for seventy veterans and their families which has attracted wide interest.

The country's most luxurious and costly cruise liner, the Corsair, was placed in service on the Pacific Coast yesterday by her new owners, Pacific Cruise Lines, Ltd. of Seattle. The Cox-McCandless Company, 342 Madison Avenue, representing the company here, announced that the Corsair sailed yesterday on her first cruise from San Pedro down the California and Mexican coasts to Acapulco.

TWO climbing roses have been outstanding on either side of an arbor this year in spite of unpredictable growing weather. Mermaid and Elegance have distinctive beauty and quality, and their fragrance is an added asset, since an arbor implies a place to sit and rest.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. WHEN one is in good health and spirits, there is keen satisfaction in acquiring -- or even in attempting to acquire -- a new skill. What would have been a bore or a minor ordeal in a period when one's reactions are dulled by illness or dejection becomes a fresh source of enjoyment.

Savings and loan associations of New York State, whose assets are nearing the billion-dollar mark, expect to hold the largest convention in their association's fifty-nine years of existence this week. The convention, across the border in Quebec, will begin formal sessions tomorrow and will continue through Thursday.

BALLET Society, the adventuresome subscription organization of Lincoln Kirstein, will get its second season under way next month. This year all its four major ballet programs will be presented at the City Center, which, though not ideal as a theatre, is thought to have compensations for a project such as this.

Tonight the President's program of food conservation comes to the end of its first week. Mr. Truman's plea, broadcast to the nation last Sunday night, that everyone forego the use of meat on Tuesdays and poultry and eggs on Thursdays, appears to have been received in an understanding and cooperative spirit both by the public and by the nation's hotels and restaurants.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed steady, 4 to 15 points net higher than on Friday. After opening with losses of 5 to 10 points, it steadied as brokers with mill connections were good buyers. There was an accumulation of hedge selling orders at the opening, but this was absorbed gradually.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 11 -- A hard-fighting but outmanned Dart-mouth football team today held Penn's powerhouse to one touch-down until the final period, thus giving the Big Green adherents among the crowd of 12,000 considerable false encouragement.
The eleven-day strike of 2,300 employes of the Childs restaurant chain was settled yesterday and some of the workers will return to work on Tuesday.

IT has been a generation since the appearance of Justin H. Smith's sparkling "War with Mexico," which challenged the idea that our war of the Forties was an aggressive one incited by conspiratorial expansionists and slavocrats and which disputed the judgment that President James Polk was a tool and a nincompoop.

NO volume could have nobler purposes and few could command a more glittering array of contributors than this, the fourth in an ambitious series edited by Dr. Anshen, scholar and writer on social, political and economic issues.
China's increasing chaos was another dark spot in the rapid development of the politico-military "two world" situation last week.

CHAPEL, HILL, N.C., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Two Deacon aerial artists, Tom Fetzer and his understudy, Bud Lail, passed vaunted North Carolina silly today as Wake Forest scored an upset 19 -- 7 victory over the Tarheels in a Southern Conference game.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- James Michael Curley is scheduled to come back to Boston about Christmas time from the Federal penitentiary at Danbury, Conn., and, unless the Federal authorities prevent it, he will at once resume the chief office of this major city.

PEIPING, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Communist forces today surrounded and shelled Tiehling on the railway forty miles northeast of Mukden, but Chinese Government planes hit back strongly, pro-Government newspaper accounts reported.

A suit filed last week by Trailerships, Inc., of 274 Madison Avenue, against Local 294, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, at Albany, may decide the fate of a multimillion dollar program for the rejuvenation of coastwise passenger ship service, it was learned yesterday.

A RECENT cartoon portrays a lady wearing an anxious expression and nothing else, sitting in a self-service laundry, waiting for her clothes to come out of a washing machine. In almost every one of 500 self-service laundries, known as "launderettes," which have sprung up in and around New York during the last two years, this whimsical sketch is tacked on the wall.

TOKYO, Oct. 11 -- The Soviet Union is rapidly industrializing and developing territories along the Turkish border and in the Kazak Republic of Central Asia, using German, Japanese and Hungarian prison labor, according to Japanese war prisoners.

A sharp distinction between the advantages of democracy and the tenets of fascism and communism was drawn yesterday by students of junior high schools who took part in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR from Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.
Retail trade gains here continued sharp last week. Department store volume was estimated at 35 to 40 per cent above the same period last year.

CHAMBERSBURG, Pa., Oct. 11 -- Norman Makin, Australian Ambassador to the United States, in an address at Wilson College this afternoon, called for renewed faith in the United Nations and cited the achievements of the world organization "in many important spheres."

IF anyone brings up the question what to plant in acid soil, he is likely to hear a jumble of contradictory opinions. First, he should be sure that he really is planting in sour ground, for many people think that they have this kind of earth when really it is not so.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The United States declaration supporting the partition of Palestine before the United Nations was hailed tonight by Dr. Abba Hillel Silver, chairman, of the American section of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, as "American statesmanship at its best and noblest."

THIS fifth novel of Vincent McHugh's is not a great one, nor perhaps even a good one. But it is a talented enough one to make the reader puzzle over why it isn't better. The book is fast (for all its gentle pace), warm (with a basic reservation), and its readability is high.

BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- The National Labor Relations Board figuratively hung up a sign this week, "open for business." By overruling its general counsel, Robert N. Denham, the board paved the way for a spate of cases. They will not be long in coming even though some unions will turn their backs on temptations to invoke the machinery of the Taft-Hartley Labor Relations Act.
The writer of the following letter is president of the Woodrow Wilson Foundation and is a director and secretary of the Council on Foreign Relations.

To the Screen Editor: THERE appears to be a great deal of discussion concerning the British film tax which generally overlooks a contributing factor. It always seemed to me that we somehow failed to estimate the temper and needs of the British.

Meeting in Washington last week a group of prominent educators comprising President Truman's board of foreign scholarships set the machinery in motion for one of the most gigantic student-exchange programs ever undertaken by this or any other nation.

THE high place African violets have won in the esteem of window gardeners is emphasized by the first national show of this one flower which was held in Atlanta, Ga. The original Saintpaulia ionantha has been developed by hybridizers so that there are now at least seventy-five named varieties.

WILMETTE, Ill., Oct. 11 -- An interior design for the Baha'i house of worship here has been approved and the work inside the finished superstructure will begin within a few months on a schedule calling for a completed temple by 1953, the National Baha'i Assembly has announced.

AMES, Iowa, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A badly outplayed Nebraska football team that was in Iowa State territory only three times during the game turned two breaks into quick touchdowns to trim an underdog Cyclone eleven, 14 to 7, in a Big Six Conference contest today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 11 -- Rutgers pulled the Tigers' teeth for the third time in seventyeight years in the oldest of all football rivalries today. The biggest crowd ever to sit in on a game here, 30,426, saw the Scarlet whip Princeton, 13 -- 7, and look like a real team doing it.

THE publication of Sir Osbert Sitwell's third book of memoirs, of which "Left Hand, Right Hand" and "The Scarlet Tree" were the first and second volumes, continues the unplacid lives of the Sitwells of Renishaw through the ironic glories of Edward VII's reign.

BELGRADE (By Wireless). OF all the Balkan Communist leaders Tito of Yugoslavia is the most effulgent. Perhaps no other Communist in Central Europe has captured the headlines more often than this five-foot-five boss of a turbulent land.
Junior colleges are essential in areas not now served by institutions of college level, according to a study made by the University of Wisconsin.

An official delegation of five members of the American Institute of Architects, including two New Yorkers, will represent the United States at the ten-day sessions of the sixth Pan-American Congress of Architects to open in Lima, Peru, on Wednesday.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- In a speech before an election mass meeting of his Popular Republican party Foreign Minister Bidault said today that France would get from the United States the coal, wheat and raw materials she needed until the Marshall plan started operating.

The present economic situation offers a challenge to American business. In last Sunday's Magazine Chester Bowles outlined one program that business men might adopt to preserve the private enterprise system. In this article Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, presents a differing point of view.

THE world which Louise Townsend Nichell explores in her poems is small, but the largest that we know. Within it she moves surely, easily, always on familiar ground. It is an anthropocentric world, in which time is measured in heartbeats, and in which the supreme miracle is the transmutation of human experience into poetry.

CASH prizes totaling $10,000 are offered in a series of photographic contests sponsored by The Camera Magazine of Baltimore in commemoration of its fiftieth anniversary next March. Open to all photographers, the contest features five divisions.

A SERIES of agreements that will be recognized as among the most important ever reached in the history of international air travel and commerce has just been signed in Brazil. The authors of the highly significant pacts are the traffic officials of the world's airlines, who have been meeting for the past two weeks at the Hotel Quitandinha at Petropolis, outside Rio de Janeiro.
Department store sales by reserve districts, as reported by the Federal Reserve Board, are listed in the following table which gives percentage comparisons with a year ago:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- The announcement of the United States decision to support the proposed partition of Palestine was welcomed here today by representatives of the Jewish Agency for Palestine. It was received with obvious disapproval by the delegates of the Arab states to the United Nations.

AALEY, Lebanon, Oct. 11 -- Additional secret military measures in support of Palestine Arabs were planned tonight by the Arab League Council. Deliberation on the Palestine problem concluded without a decision on economic sanctions against the United States and Britain.

Echoing denials issued by other private utility systems throughout the vast western area of the nation that a shortage of electric power will strike many sections of the United States next winter, W.C. Mullendore, president of the Southern California Edison Company, said last week that plans already are far advanced to meet every demand for power, despite the ever-increasing number of customers.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Cornell showed an explosive running attack which was almost matched by Colgate today before the Big Red emerged with its twenty-fifth victory in the 34-game series between these neighboring rivals by a score of 27 to 18.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- The coordination of economic exchanges between the French-controlled countries of North Africa and between their economic system and France was the principal subject examined today by the Conference on North Africa.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- It costs the Forest Service about $385 to fight the average forest fire. Not that there is anything very average about a forest fire. To get some of them under control, the service may have to spend as high as $100,000. Others, however, are put out after a short bit of work on the part of a ranger.

THE invasion of Poland found Mr. Pritchett, British editor, short-story writer, and essayist, in the midst of writing a novel. The war put a stop to that. "Without leisure or freedom to write what I wanted," says he, "I could at least read what I wanted, and I turned to those remarkable men and women: the great novelists of the past, those who are called the standard novelists."

MODERN publishing has rendered an indubitable public service by its continued effort to make the classics of our culture readily available in attractive and economical form. To this end it has explored and developed the possibilities of type and format and shouldered the vast editorial tasks involved in such a program.

The housewife, asked to conserve meat, poultry, eggs and bread within the framework of an organized program, was still without an answer last week to a more personal problem -- how to meet the rising cost of the food required to feed her family.

WASHINGTON. THIRTY million children in Europe and 30 to 60 million children in the Near and Far East -- children on two-thirds of the face of the earth -- are in dire need of help. They are living in caves made out of rubble, in areas where every dwelling has been destroyed by fire, in patched-up buildings and in wartime dugouts.

IN the showman's current lexicon there is one master principle: To mention the late war is to commit suicide at the box office. All the theatre's merchandising rules, however, have to be suspended when a good play comes to town.
BOSTON, Oct. 11 -- People here are cooperating to make the national food saving program a success.

A person who speaks of a "big red autumn moon" will be corrected by scientists who point out that the moon is no bigger and no redder at this season than at any other. At all seasons the moon appears larger when just over the horizon, for reasons not yet clear.

SOFIA (By Wireless). COMMUNISTS in the Balkans invariably seek the advice of the "Old One" before they make a new move on the political chessboard. The "Old One" is Georgi Dimitrov, Prime Minister of Bulgaria. Until the war ended he was secretary of the Communist International in Moscow.

Out-of-town manufacturers and retailers last week expressed serious concern over the prolonged express strike which was curtailing their activities, according to a weekly market report prepared esspecially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.

OTTAWA, Oct. 11 -- Canada's participation in the working of the Marshall plan may be made conditional on some arrangement for the improvement of her own dollar position, Finance Minister Douglas Abbott indicated at a press conference last night after his return from Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- President Truman was advised by his Scientific Research Board today of a critical shortage of scientific manpower which was classed as "dangerous not only to our national welfare but to national security."

PK TEST -- In a two-way test of PK (psychokinesis or the effect of the mind on matter) Dr. B.M. Humphrey of Duke University threw two sets of dice -- six red dice and six white -- all at one throw through a series of 5,400 throws. In one series of trials she willed all the six red dice to turn up ones, and the six white dice to turn up any face but one.
ATLANTA, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Georgia Tech, repulsed repeatedly by an under-manned Virginia Military Institute eleven, put together three drives for as many scores to conquer the Keydets today, 20 -- 0.

SUNDAY, OCT. 12, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- In continuing debate on Greek question, United States agreed to drop guilt charges against Yugoslavia, Bulgaria and Albania in favor of British amendment, and was accused by Soviet Union of horse-trading.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Citizens Food Committee brought the nationwide food conservation program to the cooperative efforts of communities today with telegrams to more than 1,000 mayors urging them to rally local support behind the program.

OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- With Quarterback Dave Curtin connecting for two touchdown passes, one that was good for a total of eighty-three yards, Coach Hugh Devore's St. Bonaventure Indians defeated the Kings Point Academy eleven today, 25 -- 0. It was the second victory for the Indians against one defeat.

By the margin of only two votes yesterday the sixth biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, supported the ouster of Joseph Stack, former vice president of the union, thus ending one of the longest and bitterest fights in NMU history.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- In his first public address since this week's Cabinet shakeup in which he was one of the victims, Emanuel Shinwell, former Minister of Fuel and Power and now Minister of War, expressed today his regret over the loss of his fuel post but emphasized his loyalty to the Labor party and willingness to carry on in his new job.
Wall Street is continuing its drive against the Federal Reserve Board and its demand for a 75 per cent margin requirement for the purchase of securities.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- Vanderbilt's man with the magic toe, Zach Clinard, place-kicked the Commodores to the head of the Southeastern Conference class today when his boots provided the margin of a stirring 10-to-6 victory over Mississippi.
LAUREL, Md., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Walter M. Jeffords' Loyal Legion merely toyed with his opposition in the thirty-third running of the $15,000 added Maryland Handicap at Laurel Park today.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 11 -- A Navy patrol plane radioed to the Hawaiian Sea Frontier here today that it had sighted three seamen on a drifting minesweeper 440 miles northeast of Palmyra Atoll at 10:25 A.M. and that "all seem in good health."

To the Music Editor: THE manner in which certain symphonic conductors make arbitrary cuts in their performances of symphonic works has always been of interest to me. In many seasons of concerts I have heard all sorts of things done to music and my inevitable conclusion is that the best conductor is the one who lets well enough alone.

ROME. I AM sitting, in Rome, at a table of the Caffe Greco, one of the truly historical European cafes. Among its patrons, at one time or another, were Hawthorne and Sainte-Beuve, Stendhal and Gogol and Henry James.

Surface considerations seem to indicate that the assumption of obligations implied in the Marshall Plan, if this be adopted by the Congress, will preclude major income tax reductions for some years to come. Certainly the prospects for any substantial reduction are not encouraging unless drastic, presently unforeseen, cuts can be made in Federal expenditures, or unless the revenues can be augmented by further expansion of the national income.

MANCHESTER, England, Oct. 9 (Delayed) -- The policy of full employment is proving to have grave drawbacks in Britain, and so many influential Britons have come to that conclusion that one must record the development. Four times within two days, in Manchester, the writer has heard the opinion that there is no hope of getting out of the present economic crisis until some unemployment spurs the workers to greater effort.

VIENNA, THIS capital city, with 1,700,000 inhabitants, boasts today the most international and polyglot screen of any metropolis. Occupied by four powers, a Western outpost behind the "Iron Curtain" and Russia's window into the outside world, the over-all motion-picture program of Vienna is not only more cosmopolitan than that of Paris, London or New York but also more varied than anywhere else.

FROM Bogota comes word that the centenary of the birth of Carlos Martinez Silva (1847-1903), author and diplomat, is being commemorated by Colombia with 10-centavos and 40e stamps. A newcomer to philately's gallery, Martinez Silva was noted for the wide scope of his knowledge and culture.
PLANS for a home, like fine wines, mellow with age -- a thought to console you if current costs have brought your home-improvement program to a dead stop. Nobody ever spent too much time planning.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Historical plays concerning New York State were brought to the attention of a group of university and college drama department representatives today at the opening session of a two-day state-wide meeting sponsored by the National Theatre Conference.
"WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The House Agriculture Committee left Washington tonight on a countrywide "grass roots" tour to obtain the ideas of farmers on a longrange agricultural program.

The share Market on the Stock Exchange dragged along yesterday and closed mixed with fractional price changes. Trading activity dropped below the previous two-hour session, the turnover aggregating 410,000 shares, compared with 440,000 shares a week before.

THE annual guessing game is on as to which opera will open the Metropolitan Opera season on Nov. 10. Our best information is that it might be Charpentier's "Louise," which is being revived this season for Dorothy Kirsten in the title role that used to be sung by Grace Moore.

A few weeks after atomic bombs were dropped on Japan, medical missions appeared in the ruins of Hiroshima and Nagasaki to study what had happened physiologically to animals and plants and to human victims who had died in new, strange ways or who were still languishing in hospitals.

The Building Research Station, Department of Scientific and Industrial Research (Great Britain) is making a thorough study of homes to discover the maximum comfort that can be achieved with a minimum amount of fuel, something of the highest importance in Great Britain because of the coal crisis.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Trailing by 12 points in the second period, the Syracuse University football team came back with a surprising burst of strength tonight to topple the Temple Owls, 28 -- 12, before a crowd of about 20,000.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- Photostatic copies of correspondence stated to have been seized in the baggage of Dalibor Jakasa, one of the two expelled Yugoslav diplomats, appeared on the front pages of today's newspapers here.

Coat and suit departments of retail stores continued to draw crowds last week, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Activity in the dress departments, the survey stated, stressed ballerina type dresses.

THIS major work -- It received the $10,000 Scribner Prize in American History awarded for a book "of major importance" that would at the same time "make history readable" -- is history painted on a ten-league canvas. One is impressed first of all with the ambitious design. We suspect that Allan Nevins, Professor of American History at Columbia University, has started out to rewrite James Ford Rhodes.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 11 -- The Pitt Panther, once the clawing scourge of the gridiron, yielded to mighty Michigan today by 69 to 0 as the Wolverines, scenting the roses of Pasadena, continued their streak of overwhelming victories.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Spain was excluded from a new and world-wide meteorological reporting organization today when representatives of thirty-two countries, territories, mandates and non-self-governing colonies signed a convention and a protocol placing interchange of weather data on a global instead of a regional basis.

It was Rico Monte and Talon at the finish of the rich New York Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. To some of the 41,565 observers it appeared that Rico Monte was first. To others it looked like Talon. To not a few others, it appeared as if nothing could split the two Argentine-bred runners after a grueling test of two and a quarter miles.

THE publisher describes this novel as the story of a Jew who tried to "pass" into the Christian world, changing his name from Theodore Cohen to Cannaday, only to be found out. The blurb is inaccurate to the extent that Cannaday.

THE motion-picture people have a slickly disarming way of excusing their frequent and deliberate distortions of historical fact. They say, quite frankly and bluntly, that they are phoney but that the public doesn't mind -- and that so long as their thimble-rigged productions bring in the customers, who are you to bawl?

BALTIMORE, Oct. 11 -- Wavy still is looking for its first football victory since early last season, but at least its string of ten straight defeats has come to an end. With a tingling last-ditch comeback, Capt. Tom Hamilton's gallant midshipmen pulled a lost game out of the fire and gained a 14-14 tie with favored Duke today.

PROBABLY not many readers realize what a long, long trail Tobacco Road has become by now. A listing of books by Erskine Caldwell at the front of his newest novel reveals twenty-two titles. Since four of these concern Russia or eastern Europe, they are, perhaps, not strictly Tobacco Road -- or, perhaps, they are.

MR. and Mrs. Robinson, who insist on being a folksy couple known as Ed and Carolyn, think there is no life like the country life. They deserted the city for two acres in Connecticut, found that they could make a living there, and became missionaries for their system, which is based on a goat, a garden, a freezer and a pig.

AIRLINES are answering the public demand for more passenger comfort with an increasing number of sleeper planes for overnight flights. Skipping former ports of call, planes now fly non-stop to London and Paris.

To the Drama Editor: I KNOW hundreds of actors who, like myself, would much rather spend $1,500 and actually do a role in a Broadway play than spend much more money and use precious time waiting for a big chance that may never materialize.

This fall undoubtedly will set new marks for the number of big game, upland game and waterfowl hunters in the field, for almost every state and several Canadian Provinces report record license sales thus far.

THE SCHOOL SYSTEM of Wilson County, Kan., received $75 from a woman who wrote that she had cheated in a teachers examination she took in 1894. She explained that the money was the salary she had received for her three months of teaching.

ALBROOK FIELD, Canal Zone, Oct. 11 -- Ground, air and naval officers are looking forward with great interest to the problem of unification of services in the Canal Zone. A directive, outlining the changes, is expected soon.

JERUSALEM (By Wireless) ON the way from Jerusalem to Haifa the roller-coaster road curls round a hillside tobacco field, dips down toward the valley floor and whips to the left, passing through an Arab village strung out along the slope. On a shelf above the valley there is a tiny roadside resthouse.

OCTOBER'S brilliance of foliage and fruit should be reflected in the gay tones of the flower border. As the days grow cooler and shrubs and trees around the garden turn to all shades of orange, scarlet and yellow, the pale tints of the earlier seasons may look faded and, indeed, even dirty by contrast with the vivid hues.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- A single-engine plane "bombarded" United Nations Headquarters today with 10,000 bold-type leaflets urging a partition of Palestine. The first attempt at influencing the delegates by air ended in a clear miss, as most of the messages drifted miles off the target.

A new technique in the construction of artificial dentures through the use of the patient's own teeth was described yesterday before the National Education Congress for Dental Technicians in the Park Central Hotel.

LONDON, OCT. 11 -- The Johnson speech in the United Nations committee mittee placing the United States behind the plan to partition Palestine into Arab and Jewish states, had prominent display on the front pages of all London evening newspapers and the early editions for Sunday.

The Protestant Children's Service, Inc., established ten months ago to aid the city's Welfare Department meet an emergency in the child care field, must raise $90,175 to cover its operating expenses for the current year, James G. Blaine, president, announced yesterday.

NORTH DAKOTA -- Dormitory In an effort to accommodate more women students, the University of North Dakota is going forward with plans to build a dormitory for 150 students. The university at present has 760 women students and 2,067 men, representing a record high.

To the Screen Editor: I read with interest the article on the revival of "Gone With the Wind" in the Sunday TIMES of Sept. 28. Why can't we have more revivals? The theatre is always having them and folks like them -- they are old friends.
Great Britain's financial dilemma appears to be headed for a solution in shorter order than the Marshall plan can be herded into practical operation.

Fred A. Healy, vice president and advertising director of the Curtis Publishing Company of Philadelphia since 1930, collapsed yesterday afternoon while attending the Army-Illinois football game in the Yankee Stadium and died a few minutes later.

Orazio Frugoni, 26-year-old Italian pianist, made a deeply, favorable impression at his recital given at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. The winner of many important prizes abroad, Mr. Frugoni was forced to interrupt his musical career in 1943, when, because of his anti-Fascist activities, he found it necessary to seek refuge in Switzerland.

Robert Langelier, 15 years old, of 165-01 Seventy-first Avenue, Flushing-Hillcrest, Queens, who lost his left eye in a gas explosion on Grand Central Parkway last Nov. 25, received $30,000 from the Consolidated Edison Company in an out-of-court settlement, it was announced yesterday.
