KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- Tennessee, tuning up for its traditional battle with Alabama next Saturday, broke into the victory column after two defeats by downing a scrappy University of Chattanooga eleven, 26 to 7, today.

DUBLIN. JUST sixty-five years ago this week -- On Oct. 14 to be precise -- Eamon de Valera first saw the light of day in a New York home on East Forty-third Street on the present site of the Chrysler Building.

IN the recent rash of books on the German "Opposition," this diary by the former German Ambassador to Rome stands out. Hassell was one of the leading figures in one of the Opposition groups and his diary records his experiences, impressions and insights from September, 1938, at the height of the Czechoslovak crisis, to two weeks before his arrest by the Gestapo in July, 1944.
World reaction to news about the Soviet Comintern has gone through a number of remarkable phases in the last generation.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 11 -- Yugoslavia today broke off diplomatic relations with Chile in answer to what it called Chile's "hostile attitude" and accusations that Yugoslavia had sponsored a Communist plot in South America.

The One-Room School Year by year they grow fewer. Buses and cars wind over the back-country roads and carry the children to central consolidated schools. But in sparsely settled regions many of the little, one-room district schools remain.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 11 -- Though out-rushed and outfought, Notre Dame defeated Purdue's battling Boilermakers today, 22 -- 7, because of Quarterback Johnny Lujack's passing wizardry.

Financial markets made slight progress last week despite an improvement in domestic affairs. They were little affected by President Truman's address launching the nation on a food-conservation program, but his remarks had a sharp repercussion in commodity markets.

Seeking a means of insuring themselves against losses resulting from possible declines in textile demand, merchants are showing an increasing tendency toward dealing in cotton futures, it was learned last week.
SEVERAL native shrubs are attractive enough to be cultivated on the home grounds. They can be included in the planting scheduled for the next month if desired.

The increased volume of air travel since the end of the war has necessitated aid to more than one hundred distressed plane passengers a month in this city this year, it was reported yesterday by the Travelers Aid Society of New York, 144 East Forty-fourth Street.
The live and dressed poultry markets showed yesterday the first effects of President Truman's voluntary food conservation program.

CHARLES-FERNAND RAMUZ, who died last May at the age of 69, has long been recognized in France, as well as in his native Switzerland, as a writer of stature: in 1945 he was a contender for the Nobel Prize in literature.

To build up a corps of teachers adequately trained to help the nation's youngsters prepare for daily living in a democracy is the most urgent task facing the schools today, according to a five-year experimental study by the Horace Mann-Lincoln Institute of School Experimentation, reported yesterday by Dr. Gordon Mackenzie, the executive director.

IT IS quite possible, though not altogether probable, that there will be more congested weeks in the exhibition calendar than the one through which this department has just struggled. The list before me, which includes a few shows that opened too late in the week to be attended to here last Sunday, measures about nineteen typewritten inches.

BERLIN, Oct. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. Clarence R. Huebner, Acting United States Military Governor, denied today a press report that high United States officials here believed most United States forces would be withdrawn from Berlin after the London conference of the Foreign Ministers in November.

LONDON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Overseas applicants will head the queue for tickets for the 1948 Olympic games, the British Organizing Committee said today in releasing a plan to allocate more than a million seats for the world's biggest sports show.
The writer of the following letter was Director of the Office of Economic Stabilization, and prior to that he served as Administrator for the Office of Price Administration.

WATER-COLORS played an important parts in the avalanche of shows which filled the galleries to overflowing last week. Charles Burchfield's new work at Frank Rehn's upholds his laurels. Several snow scenes in familiar vein reveal all the old mastery and a smalltown Bowery-like street scene ranks with his best work, as does the truly remarkable "Lavender and Old Lace" -- a fret-saw-style house among lilacs.

United States Television Corporation, producer of large screen television receivers for bars and public places for the last two years, has sharply altered production schedules in favor of home receivers, Hamilton Hoge, president, said last week.

PARIS (By Wireless). FRENCHMEN are not given to using first names, but to French Communists Maurice Thorez is always "Maurice." He has a natural ability for making friends and French workers like him because they feel he is one of them -- Maurice sprang from the working class.

TO THE EDITOR: The characteristics of a good college president were clearly defined in Dr. O.C. Carmichael's article, "What Makes a Good College President," but inadequate emphasis was given to the almost "crystal ball" type of vision required for the position.

ALBANY, Oct. 11 -- The annual field trials of the Albany Spaniel Field Trial Club opened today on the fine courses of Gallogly Farm at Feura Bush, with the first running of the special American Spaniel Club stake for novice American cockers.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 10 (Delayed) -- An accusation that the extreme Right Wing of the Republican party under former Premier Recep Peker had plotted the over-throw of the Parliamentary Government and the restoration of a single party dictatorship in Turkey by a coup was made in the leading Opposition newspaper Vatan today.
LONDON, Oct. 11 -- On the face of it one would think that Britain was going through a political as well as an economic crisis.

TUAMOTU ISLANDS. LOOKING back on our long drift in the Pacific, the six members of the KonTiki expedition agree that the leading statesmen of the world should be put aboard a raft and sent to sea for a few months. We believe it would give them peace of mind and a new outlook upon life and that they would return to civilization with common understanding and many new ideas.

MAINTENANCE and servicing of motor vehicles were stressed in discussions of the highway protective program at the National Safety Council's annual meeting in Chicago last week. Repeated warnings were given that the average passenger car has reached the dangerous age of ten years, and neglect during the late fall and winter could send the accident rate soaring.
The crippled forces of Eli Yale, forced to go along without Levi Jackson and Jack Roderick, recorded a mild upset by toppling Columbia from the unbeaten ranks yesterday at Baker Field.
WACO, Tex., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Baylor stunned Arkansas' big, undefeated Razorbacks with a lightning fourth-quarter rally today and came off with a 17-9 victory.

Marking actual resumption of private trade with Japan, the first shipment of Japanese merchandise has arrived in this country and will be followed by other shipments in the near future. Initial consignments comprised Christmas tree ornaments, toys, binoculars, hat bodies, porcelain and china, paper, leaf aluminum and goldleaf, it was reported in trade circles here last week.

Detective Katherine Barry -- tipping the scales at 118 pounds, and 5 feet, 5 inches tall -- and four men detectives had a rough time Friday night before they subdued three men and arrested them on narcotics charges.

WORCESTER, Mass., Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- Villanova's Scampering Scatbacks capitalized on the breaks in a fumbling clash with Holy Cross today and dumped their hosts from the unbeaten ranks by a 13 to 6 margin before 20,000 Fitton Field fans.

DUBLIN, Oct. 11 -- The CARE organization is now ready to operate in Ireland. Quietly and without any fuss or publicity CARE'S chief of mission, John Montgomery, with Mrs. Montgomery as his secretary, has been planning and organizing in Dublin since August to provide a cheap and efficient warehousing and distribution set up.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- In the face of a flat declaration from Pierre Ryckmans, delegate from Belgium, that his Government would not accept the recommendation if adopted by the General Assembly, the United Nations Trusteeship Committee voted today to require colonial nations to submit reports on the political progress of nonself-governing territories.

AS a writer, Selden Rodman has always gone his own way. Belonging to no clique, he has never had a claque. The books he himself has written are little known, in contrast with the books he has edited. With sublime neutrality, the limbo of public indifference has swallowed up equally his "Lawrence: The Last Crusade," a disturbingly bad book, and his "Airmen," an excitingly good book, legitimately modern in its assimilation of machinery into esthetics.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 11 (AP) -- The talented toe of Bill McKay enabled Bucknell University to register a 13-to-12 upset victory over the University of Delaware today. It was the second straight setback for the Blue Hens, who had been unbeaten through 32 consecutive games until last week.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 11 -- The first Tuesday of the President's aid-to-Europe program found a cross-section of meat dealers here reporting sales decreases of 25 to 50 per cent.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Pravda printed today the views of persons it called "ordinary Soviet citizens" praising creation of the International Communist Information Bureau in Belgrade, Yugoslavia and for the first time carried extensive foreign comment -- all from Communist leaders or their associates.

ATHENS (By Wireless). NICOS ZACHARIADES, dark, handsome and 47, is the man who would be Communist dictator of Greece. He neither smokes nor drinks, he has no humor, yet he is called "dynamic." Certainly he is elusive.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Cosmic Bomb drove another stake in his claim to the 1947 3-year-old turf championship today with smashing track record run to victory in the $50,000 added Trenton Handicap at Garden State Park.

Ground has been broken for the eighty-five-family garden-type apartment development of Tudor Court, Inc., on the site of the old Alexander Mansion on North Broad Street in Elizabeth, N.J. The property comprises two and one-half acres at the northwest corner of North Avenue.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 11 -- Questionnaires on church bingo, parimutuel betting and the use of state funds for the support of religious or sectarian schools, sponsored by the New Jersey Council of Churches, have been mailed to candidates for eight Senate and sixty Assembly seats in preparation for the Nov. 4 election, it was announced today.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 11 (U.P.) -- California's hard-driving Golden Bears, already visualizing the Pacific Coast football championship and a Rose Bowl chance, rocked Wisconsin, 48 to 7, today as Lyn (Pappy) Waldorf made a triumphant return to the midwest.
NO doubt some bridge players will tell you that West's play in the deal below is "purely automatic," while others will tell you that West's play proves there is nothing automatic in bridge.

HAVING labored for several months in Switzerland in the fall of 1946 on a film story of American youth, a yarn she wrote in novel form, Betty Smith will be seeing all that travail come to fruition next month. Titled "School Bus," the story should be going before the cameras on location in the South-probably Georgia -- under the production aegis of Praesens Films, Swiss company which made "The Last Chance" and "Marie Louise."

PULLMAN, Wash., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Michigan State's mighty mite, George Guerre, who didn't do any scoring, himself, set the running and passing pace today as the Spartans defeated Washington State College, 21 -- 7, in their intersectional football game.

LONDON. WITH respect to plays produced, the past month has been a dull one here; with respect to the changing conditions in our theatre, it has had considerable interest. With the coming of cooler weather audiences here have increased and the favorite plays are running well enough to show that the persons who spoke of a slump earlier had been giving way to panic.

THIS is the season to gather materials to use in dried arrangements. As the foliage of trees turns to brilliant red and gold, and as herbaceous plants die to the ground and underbrush along the roadsides collapses from frost, some strong stalks and seed pods will be seen standing out against the dull green fields.

The health of people of rural settlements, shown by United States Army physical examinations during both World Wars to be inferior, may be distinctly improved if the Salvation Army succeeds in its efforts to broaden and intensify its aid to rural communities. A drive to increase the number of Salvation Army Rural Service Units, of which there are now 2,300, has just been announced by the organization's national office at 120 West Fourteenth Street.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Rice Institute's Owls hit the comeback trail today, presenting a smooth-running and passing offense and a doubly tough defense to overwhelm the Tulane Green Wave, 33 to 0.

WHAT one admires first about "The Middle of the Journey," a first novel by the teacher and critic, Lionel Trilling, is its assurance -- its confidence in its own best qualities, literacy and intelligence, and the lucidity which is the consequence of these, and the rare grace with which it does precisely what it wishes to do.

THE Dallas Symphony Orchestra, which gave its first annual $1,000 commission to Paul Hindemith, has awarded its second to Walter Piston. His score will be premiered this season by the orchestra under Antal Dorati.

Only 10 per cent of the more them 12,300 students who enrolled for entrance examinations in thirteen Christian colleges in China for the academic year 1946-47 were able to get in because of lack of accommodations, according to the annual report to June 30, made public yesterday by the Associated Boards for Christian Colleges in China.

It will be the Yankees against the Dodgers again at the Yankee Stadium today. Lest there be any confusion concerning this announcement let it be promptly stated that football, not baseball, will be the medium of interborough conflict, with the New York and Brooklyn teams of the All-America Conference lining up for the kickoff at 2:15 P.M. before an anticipated crowd of 40,000.

LONDON, Sunday, Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Moscow radio said today that Soviet Foreign Minister V.M. Molotov had complained to Secretary of State George C. Marshall that the United States had not replied to a Russian proposal for withdrawal of foreign troops from Korea and thus was hindering a solution of the Korean question.

In his first public address since deportation proceedings were started against him, John Santo, international organizer for the Transport Workers Union, assailed yesterday "those evil forces that want to do away with the Bill of Rights."

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- A widespread impression here is that in formally endorsing the international Communist manifesto this week the French Communist leaders concurred in giving priority to international policy over domestic policy and to the interests of Russia over those of France and those of the French Communist party.

Erasmus Hall upset James Madison by scoring in the last two minutes, 8 -- 6, and Brooklyn Tech subdued DeWitt Clinton, 26 -- 6, in the school football double-header witnessed by 4,000 at Ebbets Field yesterday.
Next of kin of servicemen who died in the war are being invited to take part in memorial exercises to be held Oct. 26 in the Sheep Meadow of Central Park, it was announced yesterday.

U.S. Speaks Out On Nov. 2, 1917 -- when British forces were driving the Turks out of Palestine -- Britain's Foreign Secretary, Arthur J. Balfour, sent a letter to Lord Rothschild, the Zionist leader. The letter was a statement of British intentions.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Constituent Assembly denounced the Government of Paraguay today as "a regime of usurpation and terror" and a "menace to the democratic stability of the continent."

THE Ford Theatre got off to a precarious start last Sunday, the victim being Mark Twain. Amid the fanfare befitting the replacement for Arturo Toscanini in the 5 o'clock period on NBC, the program essayed a modernized version of "A Connecticut Yankee in King Arthur's Court," only to finish with what sounded a great deal more like a Norman Corwin script starring the Lone Ranger.

While bankruptcies recently have been running at a fairly even level, there has been a marked upswing in credit adjustment cases, it was learned last week. According to records of the New York Credit Men's Association, eighty-eight cases have been referred to its adjustment bureau in the first nine months of 1947, compared to nineteen in the corresponding period last year.

ERRONEOUSLY the writer of these lines described the brilliant concert given by Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra last Tuesday night in Carnegie Hall as the virtual opening of New York's symphonic season.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 9 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Premier Georgia Dimitrov said today that "rude attempts" at intervention by Britain and the United States had made it impossible for him to commute the death sentence of Nikola Petrov, executed Opposition leader.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System has scheduled a seven-week series of talks on the Bible designed "to contribute to the average person's understanding of the Books that make up the Bible." The series, filling the "Church of the Air" time from 10 to 10:30 A.M. on Sunday will be heard on the five Sundays in November and the first two in December.

THE opening show of the season at the Barzansky Gallery is entitled "Paintings for Museums" and includes some of the best work of artists in the group. Samuel Rothbort's winter landscape is an outstanding example of his personal impressionism.

HOLLYWOOD. KARL TUNBERG, who is producing "Up in Central Park" at Universal-International with Deanna Durbin in the leading role, has completed the screen adaptation of the 1945 Broadway musical comedy, and the photoplay will go before the cameras next week with William Seiter directing.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 -- President Juan Peron yesterday devoted a full-length radio speech to the menace of locusts to Argentina's agricultural economy. This unusual step reflected not only the pests' serious depredations, which may eventually be reflected in the world food shortage, but it also made clear that the foes of the regime have been using the plague as an argument in rural communities that the Government was ignoring them.

THE spectacular $5,000,000 fire which recently destroyed the Grace Line Pier 57 on Manhattan's North River waterfront has focused attention on New York City's piers whose condition, according to shipping men, is not helping the city hold its title as the busiest and biggest port in the world.

Jim Turpin went across for all three of Morgan State College's touchdowns as the Baltimore eleven defeated North Carolina College, 19 to 6, in a Colored Intercollegiate Athletic Association game at the Polo Grounds last night.
GENEVA, Oct. 11 -- After a week of progress so rapid that the completion of negotiations seemed in sight, the British and United States tariff talks were snarled again today.

WICHITA, Kan., Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Wichita University eleven registered a pair of third-quarter touchdowns today to come from behind and take a 21-to-13 victory over Drake before 8,000 fans. It was Wichita's first Missouri Valley Conference victory and Drake's second defeat.

LONDON (By Wireless). THE creation of a new Comintern focuses attention on the leaders of communism in Europe, seven of whom are shown on these pages. Most of them were members of the old Comintern; all are fully familiar with Russian policy and follow the party line as laid down by Stalin and Molotov.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A nation-wide survey of frequency-modulation broadcasters, made public today by the FM Association, discloses that 86 per cent of the respondents reported that they were operating at a loss and indicated that the responsibility lay in the ban on duplication of standard network musical programs on their facilities.

ROME, Oct. 11 -- The decision to revive the Comintern is held in Italy to mark a decisive turning point in Moscow's policy and methods toward non-Communist countries. It also has a noteworthy effect on the Italian political situation and especially on relations between the Communists and their Socialist allies.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- The complete story of the United Nations to date, compressed into a single 1,000-page volume -- the result of more than a year's work by a staff of researchers, writers and editors -- will be published within a fortnight, the Department of Public Information disclosed today.

MADRID, Oct. 11 -- Spain's most elaborate social event since the end of the monarchy is scheduled for tomorrow when the Duchess of Montoro, the Duke of Alba's daughter, will marry Luis Martinez de Irujo, son of the Duke of Sotomayor, in Seville.

MR. THOMPSON'S first book of poems, published in 1943, was recognized alike by discerning readers and reviewers as the very fine achievement of one of our younger poets. "Lament for the Sleepwalker," published this year, will confirm the judgment of Mr. Thompson's earlier admirers.

MISS GINNY SIMMS made the freehanded observation last week that, as a radio singer, experience had taught her the wisdom of confining her professional energies to singing. She thus affably threw in her vote with those of the radio critics who, a few months ago, suggested that she could beneficially abjure such additional microphone assignments as patter and hostess duties, which her role called for at the time.
A 17-year-old high school student of New York, overcome by an urge to travel, landed from the Staten Island ferry at 10 o'clock yesterday morning after a brief voyage on the big liner Queen Mary.

IT is my well-considered opinion that managers should meddle as little as possible with the purely musical and artistic phases of their profession. A QUALITY-type 35mm camera selling for $50.63, including excise tax, the Bolsey Model B 35mm (negative one by one and one-half inches) camera is announced by the Bolsey Corporation of America, 118 East Twenty-fifth Street, as a low-priced miniature built to high standards.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 11 -- The pent-up demands of property owners for relief from higher costs helped bring to Louisville the first 5 per cent rent increase in the nation. It took effect Thursday.

BERLIN (By Wireless). WILHELM PIECK, 71 years old, white-haired and robust, is the patriarch of German communism and front man of the party, revered by his followers. Small busts of him are purchased by the faithful in Berlin and other cities in the Russian-zone.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 11 -- Announcementt of the start on Thanksgiving Day of a countrywide collection of food for the starving peoples of Europe was made here today at the annual meeting of the National Conference of Catholic Charities.
FOOTBALL Major Eastern games culminated in two upsets and two ties yesterday. Yale toppled Columbia and Rutgers beat Princeton, while the Army-Illinois and Navy-Duke contests ended in deadlocks.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Brown Bears, showing their best offensive of the season, handed a weak Rhode Island State football team a 55-to-6 beating before 15,000 fans today at Brown Stadium.

ANNANDALE-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- Warning that chaos will break out in Europe unless immediate assistance is provided, former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman made a vigorous plea today for the support of the Marshall plan. WARSAW, Oct. 11 -- By a tremendous effort, aided materially by the UNRRA and other foreign relief, Poland has pulled herself out of the chaos left by the second World War to a position where she stands on the edge of self-sufficiency agriculturally, and is nearing her pre-war industrial output.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- The entire transport system, serving about 4,000,000 persons in Paris and its environs was threatened with paralysis beginning early next week after a strike of a dissident union caused partial stoppages today in the subway service.

Two naval air reserve training planes from Floyd Bennett Field, flying in a tight formation of six machines, collided north of Wading River, L.I., yesterday, then crashed and sank in Long Island Sound.

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 11 -- United States officers stationed at internment camps in advisory capacities charged recently that German administration officials were lax in their handling of the inmates. COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 11 -- Southern California's rollicking Trojans gave a spectacular display or power and precision today as they scored in every period to hand Ohio State's fading Bucks a 32-0 setback, their second of the season, before a capacity crowd of 76,559.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 -- The business pace appears to have leveled off during September after an August upsurge, a survey of business conditions made by the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago indicated today. A GOOD many late vacationists will be drawn to the Moth boat races at Elizabeth City, N.C., next week-end for the three-day regatta and an opportunity to see the beautiful tidewater area and the tempestuous Cape Hatteras region during the most pleasant season of the year.

Alfred and Herbert Teltschik, duo-pianists from Texas, made their New York recital debut yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. PARIS, Oct. 12 -- After his triumphant return to Algiers for the first time since the liberation of France, Charles de Gaulle today told Algerians that the Soviet Union now was seeking the "dislocation" of the French Union through agitation in North Africa.

BABYLON, L.I., Oct. 12 -- With the purpose of holding a flower festival next spring, officials and citizens of Babylon are to start this week on the task of choosing suitable public planting areas for at least 20,000 tulip and daffodil bulbs.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Trading in lard futures was enlivened last week by a broad export demand, with estimates that 3,000,000 to 5,000,000 pounds had been sold, and a further upturn in prices of hogs, which advanced to a new high record average of $29.15 a hundred-weight.

Four Americans who have achieved distinction in fields of activity related to the career of Theodore Roosevelt will receive the Roosevelt Distinguished Service Medal for 1947, James R. Garfield, president of the Roosevell Memorial Association, announced last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- The Federal Power Commission made public today a decision approving the grant of a permanent certificate to the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, to operate the "Big Inch" and "Little Big Inch" pipe lines for the transmission of natural gas to both the Philadelphia and Appalachian areas.

Russell Sherman, New York pianist, who made his debut two years ago at the age of 15, gave his second local recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The last part was heard by a family friend, who was also at the debut, Mayor William O'Dwyer.

October strides over mountains, meadows and upland fields. Each day he bivouacs farther south. It is the glory time of the seasons -- Nature's climax after months of growth and fruition.

New patterns of world trade must be built up by the United States to replace those shattered by two global wars and depression, according to a new report on "Rebuilding the World Economy: America's Role in Foreign Trade and Investment," issued today by the Twentieth Century Fund.

MADISON, N.J., Oct. 12 -- Tony Manero of the Hubbard Heights Country Club, Stamford, Conn., shot a 4-under-par 69 to annex the Tri-State P.G.A. championship at the Braidburn Country Club today. The tournament was a benefit affair for forty-two New Jersey Kiwanis and Lions clubs.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Retail store and mail order house spokesmen said today they expect little change in volume of installment purchases of hard goods -- stoves, refrigerators and other durable items -- with the ending of Government restrictions on consumer credit Nov. 1.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- Supplies of cash wheat in the United States on Oct. 1 as indicated by the report of the Department of Agriculture on farm reserves and the commercial visible supply on that date showed last week an unexpected disappearance of that grain since the new crop started to move on July 1.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 12 -- A freakish tropical disturbance that reached hurricane force and brought torrential rains to southeast Florida moved northeast over the Atlantic tonight, apparently ending its threat to the Coast.

With Pep La Monica showing the way, the Cardinal Hayes High School eleven rolled to its second straight triumph at Triborough Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday by humbling St. John's Prep, 30 -- 0. A crowd of 8,000 saw the winners tally in every period except the second.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The first United Nations mission to study the administration of a trusteeship by a member nation will submit its report to the Trusteeship Council tomorrow. The large crop of white potatoes now being harvested should be of more than ordinary interest this season in view of the budgetbreaking prices of other foods. SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- San Francisco's 49ers defeated the Chicago Rockets, 42 to 28, today before 23,300 fans. The victory projected the 49ers into a first-place tie with the Cleveland Browns in the Western division of the All-America Conference.

Dressing a new way, wearing make-up and interest in "dates' are signs that a girl is growing up and needs parents who understand her and can answer her questions, according to counsel newly compiled by the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association, 386 Fourth Avenue.

Mail orders last week continued heavy while market activity again was comparatively slow with re-orders noted on silk scarfs, un-trimmed hooded coats and some types of woolen piece goods, according to reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Rank-and-file drivers employed by the Railway Express Agency made no secret yesterday of dissatisfaction with the terms under which their strike of three and one-half weeks was settled, but union leaders predicted ratification of the settlement at meetings in New York and Jersey City this afternoon.

IT was a trifle disconcerting to return to the Yankee Stadium on Saturday and instantly notice a fellow draped languidly over the rail of the left-field bull pen. HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 12 -- Arthur Lyons, independent producer, has purchased screen rights to Thomas B. Costain's recent novel, "The Moneyman," for $300,000 and has signed Ida Lupino and Louis Hayward for the starring roles in the film version, he has announced.

Rocky Graziano will defend his middleweight championship against Tony Zale, former champion, in a return fifteen-round bout at Miami, Fla., on Feb. 12, Manager Irving Cohen announced last night, according to The United Press.

Stark, president of North American Utility and Construction Company, revealed here last week, after summarizing engineering data from surveys of twenty systems, in five states, engineered by his company.
PARIS, Oct. 12 -- The strength and strategy of the French Communists are affected by the unique character of their party, which is both national and international.

Two hundred and fifty members of the fruit and vegetable industry and its unions attended last night a testimonial dinner to Edward A. Hausman, executive secretary of the Allboro Retail Fruit Association at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

PEIPING, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Communist infantry, charging behind artillery barrages, assaulted the Manchurian railway town of Tiehling today but Chinese Government forces held out under strong air cover, Nationalist dispatches reported.

"This Time Tomorrow" is to be installed at the Barrymore Nov. 4, Featured billing in the Theatre Guild's presentation of the Jan de Hartog play is shared by Sam Jaffe, John Archer and Ruth Ford. "For Love or Money," due at Henry Miller's also on Nov. 4, has a prior claim to that date, having registered it first.
According to official sources here, the lists of plants to be dismantled in the United States and British zones announced Thursday.

Marine fossils uncovered by an expedition 10,000 feet up in the Peruvian Andes have arrived in New York, it was announced yesterday by officials of Columbia University and the American Museum of Natural History.
To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Free Territory of Trieste has been proclaimed, and the U.N. must choose its first Governor. Meanwhile tension on the spot continues.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 12 -- The date for the forthcoming International Maritime Conference has been set for Feb. 19, 1948, and the locale will be Geneva instead of London as originally planned, the United Nations Transport and Communications Division has disclosed.
PARIS, Oct. 12 -- No progress was reported today in efforts to prevent the threatened strike of Paris transportation arising from a wildcat strike of subway motor-men.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 (U.P.) -- William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said today that the carriers may have to ask for another increase in freight rates or passenger fares if operating employes win any part of their current wage demands.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 11 (Delayed) -- The game of hide-and-seek that President Juan Peron's Government is playing with the opposition journals, Vanguardia and Argentina Libre, continued this week.

Japan was described yesterday as our most important ally in the East, and our second most important in the world, next to Great Britain, by Dr. Charles S. Johnson, president-elect of Fisk University and member of the United States Educational Mission to Japan.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- The United States plans to place before the United Nations this week a step-by-step program for Korea's independence, including specific recommendations for the withdrawal of United States and Russian troops, it was stated here today.

The most extensive new-car advertising in its forty-eight-year history will be launched this year by the Packard Motor Car Company, it was announced over the weekend by Hugh W. Hitchcock, director of advertising. The program, which will use ten national magazines and 1,523 newspapers in 1,435 cities in the United States and Canada, also marks Packard's return to spot radio after a six-year absence.

BOSTON, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Scoring an every period, the hard-driving Pittsburgh Steelers today out-classed the Boston Yanks for a 30-14 National Football League victory before 18,894 paid fans at Fenway Park. The victory was the second for the Steelers and the defeat was the second for the Yanks, who have yet to win a game.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 12 -- A plea to American youth to help remedy the evils of social and racial inequality was voiced today by Pope Pius XII in a message sent direct from Vatican City to the solemn pontifical mass, celebrated in the municipal auditorium here by Francis Cardinal Spellman, archbishop of New York.

The forty-second session and fifth biennial convention of the New York State Nurses Association, held in conjunction with the State League of Nursing Education, will open today for five days at the Pennsylvania Hotel. Five thousand nurses from all parts of the state are expected to attend.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura of New York led seeded entrants into the second round of the men's singles division at the Pan-American tennis championships today, winning by default from Roberto Aguitar of Mexico.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- Proposals for the automatic transfer of European currencies to reduce the liability for payment in gold to settle trade balances between one European nation and another were contained in a report of a subcommittee of the Balance of Payments Committee of the Paris conference on the Marshall plan.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- France was accused here today by the North African Independence Movement of "provoking" the people of Morocco to the point where they were now prepared to fight for their country's freedom. The complaint was submitted to the United Nations with the "urgent hope" that it would be considered by the General Assembly.

A well-earned 3-2 victory over the Baltimore Americans, last season's winners of the Lewis Cup, gave Brookhattan its first success in the American Soccer League race before 3,000 fans at Sterling Oval yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Usually well-informed delegates said tonight that they had learned that the Soviet Union would endorse tomorrow the partition of Palestine as the only feasible solution in the uncompromising position of Arabs and Zionists.

That the present state of hypertension in relationships between the Soviet Union and the United States cannot last long without a shift in Moscow's present foreign policy methods is the belief of some of the most important policy-makers of the Administration.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 12 (AP) -- The Chicago Cardinals, putting together two scoring drives of 53 and 75 yards, edged the Green Bay Packers, 14 -- 10, today to take the undisputed lead in the National Football League's Western Division. A record crowd of 25,502 fans saw the game.

Threat of a strike this morning on the bus and trolley lines of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation, operating in the Bronx, Manhattan and lower Westchester, was lifted yesterday. Leaders of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, and officials of the company agreed at noon to arbitrate union demands, including a 25-cents-an-hour wage increase.
A thirteen-week series of transcribed dramatic shows, with mental hygiene as a central theme, will be presented by WNEW on Fridays from 10 to 10:15 P.M., beginning Oct. 17.

AMSTERDAM, Oct. 12 -- Considerable interest was aroused by an unofficial announcement last week of the coming merger of two of the Netherland's ''big five" banks -- the Amsterdamsche Bank and the Incasso Bank. After the wave of bank concentrations between the world wars that left few private banks, this merger would mean a further step toward intensive concentration.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 12 -- Syrian troops with mechanized equipment were sighted by Jewish settlers or Palestine's northeastern frontier today. Their presence was not immediately confirmed by the British military command in Palestine.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- President Truman has the general support of his Administration for his plan to raise a voluntary international police force to implement the partition of Palestine, but he has run into, strong opposition in Congress and the Army against using regular United States troops to do the job.

With sprightly step, to the blare of martial music, thousands of New Yorkers marched up Fifth Avenue yesterday afternoon in celebration of the 455th anniversary of the discovery of America by Christopher Columbus.

Seventeen years after becoming pastor of the Broadway Tabernacle Church, Congregational, Fifty-sixth Street and Broadway, the Rev. Dr. Allan Knight Chalmers announced yesterday morning that he was leaving the post to become Professor of Preaching and Applied Christianity in the School of Theology of Boston University.

Drawing a distinction between the worldly meaning of peace and the sense in which it is used in the Gospels, the Rev. Dr. Alec R. Vidler, warden of St. Deiniol's Library, Hawarden, England, declared yesterday that the peace of Christ meant "not the absence of open conflict, but the presence of hidden triumph."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Gen. Joseph T. McNarney, former United States military commander in Europe, today urged the United Nations to adopt quickly the majority recommendations for the partition of Palestine, and called for an all-out effort to see that the program of absorbing Jewish immigrants is promptly carried out.

Volume of business transacted in the foreign exchange market during the early part of the week was limited, but toward the closing days the demand increased. Price movement was narrow and changes over the previous week were slight.

BOSTON, Oct. 12 -- Russia's campaign of vilification of the United States was classed today by Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. as a mask over Communist programs reaching out over the world in the wake of Soviet-inspired "hatred, poverty and trouble."

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 -- The report of the Department of Agriculture issued late last week indicated that feeding of corn to livestock this year will have to be reduced drastically because the crop will be the smallest since 1936 and the carry-over of old corn was less than had been expected.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I have no quarrel with any reviewer's likes or dislikes, nor with his right to express his opinions freely. I must, however, as the publisher of "The Needle's Eye," by Timothy Pember, take issue with Orville Prescott's statement in his review of the book that it is an "example of communistic propaganda in fiction form."

EXETER, N.H., Oct. 12 -- The House Committee on Agriculture arrived in New England today at the start of an 8,000-mile "grass-roots" tour of the country to seek the recommendations of individual farmers on a new long-time farm program.
GENEVA, Oct. 12 -- Grave defects in methods, resulting in overestimates of Europe's dollar needs, have been found by United States technicians' report of the Paris conference on the Marshall plan.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., Oct. 12 -- The doors of fifteen old house stood open welcomingly yesterday in this quiet New England village as 1,500 visitors passed through them for a glimpse of homes made famous for their beauty and their early illustrious background.

Though leaders of all political parties and civic groups expressed gratification yesterday over the record off-year registration for the election on Nov. 4, opponents of the proposal to repeal the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council were particularly encouraged.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 12 -- Over ten miles of sailing in a splendid ten-mile Easterly breeze and tide splash enough really to enliven matters, Corny Shields drove his International Class sloop Aileen to victory today. Willy Axel Olaf Olsen won with Woodcock in Class S. The contests were part of the post-season regattas at the Larch-mont Yacht Club.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The staff of the Nurse Counseling and Placement Office of the New York State Employment Service were interested in the letter of Dr. A.J. Rongy which appeared in THE TIMES of Sept. 30, on the subject of the nursing shortage. Dr. Rongy proposes that more young men be trained as nurses to help alleviate the situation.

Twenty of the new customs inspectors promoted from the port patrol force of this district are to be assigned to baggage examination at La Guardia Field, Harry M. Durning, Collector of the Port, announced yesterday. Mr. Durning and other officials of the department swore in thirty new men last week.

TSINAN, Shantung, Oct. 12 -- An appalling, depressing example of what the last two years of civil strife has cost China is presented by central Shantung, of which Tsinan, the capital, is the political, industrial and commercial center.

A resolution recommending that clauses barring work stoppages be eliminated from contracts with ship operators was adopted here yesterday by delegates to the sixth biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO. The meeting, which enters its nineteenth day today, is being held at St. Nicholas Arena, 69 West Sixty-sixth Street.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 11 (Delayed) -- Although Karachi has been relatively free from communal disturbances, about 3,000 Hindus are leaving this city every day. Two-thirds of them go by crowded little steamers bound for Okha and Bombay.

LONDON, Oct. 12 -- With Sir Stafford Cripps expressing grimmer views than ever before about Britain's economic position, with confirmation of fears that an autumn budget from the Chancellor of the Exchequer is now certain and with the setting up of a Communist bureau in Belgrade, the markets for securities here had last week a more depressed appearance than in some time.

FOR proper pleasure and profit six weeks or so should be devoted to the leisurely and attentive study of Allan Nevins' monumental "Ordeal of the Union."* To race through its two massive volumes and 1,183 pages, with frequent consultations of clocks and calendars and with an uneasy conscience for fear of overlooking some wise comment or essential fact, is a frustrating business.

Although the season of the Westchester Racing Association at Belmont Park came to an end with Saturday's card, racing at the huge Nassau County plant will be extended two days more, today and tomorrow. The United Hunts Racing Association will take over the Belmont operations, representing its forty-third annual meeting.

ROME, Oct. 12 -- Italy is the most advanced outpost of the Western democracies against the advance of communism. She also is one of the most vulnerable. The pro-Communist and anti-Communist forces are evenly balanced, with only a slight prevalence of the latter.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- By an overwhelming majority, announced officially tonight as 91 per cent, the inhabitants of the Tende-Brigue [Tenda-Briga] area voted today approval of the Italian treaty clauses providing for the annexation of their territory to France.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 12 -- Despite the long shortage of scrap metal and the necessity for major repairs on blast furnaces, the steel industry last week was able to increase national production 1 1/2 points to 96.5 per cent of capacity. This rate, according to reports here, is within 1 point of post-war records.

WARSAW, Oct. 12 -- Vice Premier Wladyslaw Gomulka, one of the framers of the recent Communist manifesto, told a meeting of the Polish Communist party's Central Committee last night that United States foreign policy "now looks very much like the first attempt of Hitlerian aggression."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 12 -- While the highway fatality rate was reduced in the last twelve months, the accident frequency continues to mount with "alarming steadiness," according to a report placed before the National Association of Insurance Agents as it opened its fifty-first annual convention here today for its committee on accident prevention.

CHICAGO, Oct. 12 (AP) -- Quarterback Sid Luckman fired three touchdown passes, two covering 70 and 74 yards, to help upset the Philadelphia Eagles, 40 to 7, and give the Chicago Bears their first National Football League victory before 34,338 at Wrigley Field today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 12 -- Paced by the incomparable Sammy Baugh and the mercurial Eddie Saenz, the Washington Redskins sent the New York Giants down to their second straight National Football League defeat, 28 -- 20, in a wild-and-wooly encounter today.

DETROIT, Oct. 12 (AP) -- With Bob Waterfield hurling passes for three touchdowns, the Los Angeles Rams took a surprisingly hard-earned 27-to-13 National Football League victory today over the Detroit Lions before 45,747 fans, Detroit's second largest turnout in pro football history.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 12 -- Although the American Federation of Labor, assertedly under goading of a reactionary Congress, is pushing plans to jump wholeheartedly into politics, President William Green declared today that it "will not endorse a political party in 1948."

The scheduled airlines of the United States came closer to a competitive position with the railroads in the first half of 1947, it was reported yesterday. However, airline operating costs 31.36 per cent above the same period in 1946 were said to contrast with a railroad increase of only 5.3 per cent in operating costs.

Faith in God in the last analysis means being unable to see Him and yet believe in Him, the Rev. Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo declared yesterday in his first sermon as a member of the ministry of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets.

EASTON, Conn., Oct. 12 -- Helen Keller the blind-deaf author and educator, flicked a switch last night, lighting an electric lamp resting in a nine-foot-high oriental sacred stone on the rear lawn of her reconstructed home here, and expressed the hope it would remain lighted forever.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Army and Navy hurricane hunters can welcome a couple of Cuban grandmothers, a bride and groom and thirty-two other passengers into their ranks after a wild ride through the hurricane by a big four-engined passenger plane last night.

The American flag waving over Corregidor for more than twoscore years was never soiled by hostile hands. On May 6, 1942, it was hauled down and burned by its exhausted defenders before they surrendered to the Japanese, only to be replaced in triumph as our conquering armies swept the enemy from the Philippines.

ROME, Monday, Oct. 13 -- Rome's municipal election was held yesterday without remarkable enthusiasm among the voters. The percentage of registered voters who went to the polls did not come up to the expectations of the anti-Communist parties.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 12 -- Pakistan hopes that the United States technical assistance will enable, her to withstand expected future pressure, from the one side by Afghanistan, supported by the Soviet Union, and from the other by India.

Grover Whalen announced yesterday that he had presented to Mayor O'Dwyer and other Board of Estimate members last week plans for a Golden Jubilee celebration of the consolidation of Greater New York City. The board will consider initial appropriations for the celebration on Oct. 23.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 12 (AP) -- A 17-yard field goal by Ben Agajanian in the closing three minutes enabled the Los Angeles Dons to top the Cleveland Browns, 13 to 10, and give the All-America Football Conference champions their first defeat in twelve games in a bruising battle today before 63,124.

EASTON, Conn., Oct. 12 -- Helen Keller the blind-deaf author and educator, flicked a switch last night, lighting an electric lamp resting in a nine-foot-high oriental sacred stone on the rear lawn of her reconstructed home here, and expressed the hope it would remain lighted forever.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 12 (AP) -- Army and Navy hurricane hunters can welcome a couple of Cuban grandmothers, a bride and groom and thirty-two other passengers into their ranks after a wild ride through the hurricane by a big four-engined passenger plane last night.

The American flag waving over Corregidor for more than twoscore years was never soiled by hostile hands. On May 6, 1942, it was hauled down and burned by its exhausted defenders before they surrendered to the Japanese, only to be replaced in triumph as our conquering armies swept the enemy from the Philippines.

ROME, Monday, Oct. 13 -- Rome's municipal election was held yesterday without remarkable enthusiasm among the voters. The percentage of registered voters who went to the polls did not come up to the expectations of the anti-Communist parties.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Oct. 12 -- Pakistan hopes that the United States technical assistance will enable, her to withstand expected future pressure, from the one side by Afghanistan, supported by the Soviet Union, and from the other by India.

A serious shortage this winter of fuel oil and possibly gasoline, unless consumers adopt drastic economy measures, was forecast yesterday at the meeting of the Empire State Petroleum Association at the Waldorf-Astoria. A resolution was suggested urging a proclamation by President Truman that "all citizens conserve in all possible ways in their use of all petroleum products."

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 7,000 head; total, 9,500; most hogs sold fairly active, steady to 25 cents higher, but trade closed very slow with all advance lost and with 1,000 head held over;

Jorge Bolet, Cuban pianist, who served in his own country's Army and then in the Army of the United States, gave his first New York recital since his return to civilian life at Carnegie Hall last night. His appearance also marked the tenth anniversary of his debut as a Naumburg Award winner.

LONDON, Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- Princess Elizabeth saw some of her wedding presents for the first time today when she returned to London from her Scottish Highland vacation and visited St. James's Palace with the Queen and Princess Margaret Rose.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its decision of last June that the Federal Government has paramount rights to the submerged oil lands off the California coast.

ROME, Oct. 13 -- The Communists and other Left Wing parties are confident that the beleaguered Italian bastion of anti-communism will fall next April, when a general election is to be held. The anti-Communists are equally certain that their colors still will be flying long after then, if they can survive the coming winter.

In a very large measure "the hope of humanity lies in this hemisphere," George S. Messersmith, former Assistant Secretary of State, said last night. Mr. Messersmith was guest at a dinner in the University Club to mark the 455th "birthday of the Americas."
PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Oct. 13 -- The house of delegates of the American Dietetic Association notified President Truman today that they had pledged to support the national food conservation program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Government today directed commanders in the occupation areas of Japan and Germany to get and rush home a series of pictures and other illustrative material for use here in dramatizing the need of food to prevent starvation abroad.

Military police raided a party Saturday night at the Progressive Citizens Association, 214 East Broadway, to prevent military personnel from being involved in riot or disorder, Lieut. Col. John B. Lenninger, provost marshal of the First Army, said yesterday after an investigation into the detention of six civilians by army personnel.

TORONTO, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Scoring twice in the last period, the National Hockey League All-Stars came from behind to defeat the Stanley Cup champion Toronto Maple Leafs 4-3, tonight in the loop's first official all-star game. The attendance was 14,318.

For the first time this season the S.R.O. sign was up at the weekly luncheon-meeting of the Football Writers Association yesterday at Toots Shor's. With baseball wrapped in cellophane, the huge turnout of coaches, officials and scribes surprised no one.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Hardy navigators in the International Class on Long Island Sound, went out in another of their fall season races off the Larchmont Yacht Club today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- A sweeping proposal by India to require all nations to place their colonial territories under the international trusteeship system was immediately attacked today by the major colonial powers of the world.

Eight horses of the Irish Army jumping team arrived aboard the United States Lines' American Importer yesterday for the military competition at the National Horse Show, to be held in Madison Square Garden from Nov. 4 to 11. Ireland will be represented in the event for the first time in nine years.

THERE 'aren't enough people who are excited about Anne Goodwin Winslow. Her serene and lovely books may not be the kind which can excite people. But one does not have to be emotionally stirred up by a book in order to be excited by its merits as a work of art. And Mrs. Winslow's books are always artful, cool, precise, delicate, products of great technical skill and reflections of a distinctive personality.

Experimental evidence that may lead eventually to the development of protein food substitutes "tailormade" to fulfill the nitrogen requirements of the human body was presented before the New York Academy of Medicine last night by Dr. William C. Rose.

One of the most heated election campaigns in the history of The Lambs, whose membership is made up mainly of people connected with the entertainment industry, is in progress. It has been fanned to such proportions that more than 200 adherents of the regular ticket felt compelled to hold a rally yesterday afternoon at Sardi's to muster forces for the annual election on Thursday.

Nurses from all parts of the state began to arrive at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday for the first post-war joint convention of the New York State Nurses Association and the State League of Nursing Education. All sessions were closed business meetings for discussion of policy matters.

That seemingly inevitable camp follower of war and disaster -- pestilence -- can be routed if the will and the techniques are available. Col. Crawford Sams, chief of the Public Health and Welfare Section of our occupation forces in Japan and Korea, reports that cholera has been stamped out in both those countries, after 11,000 deaths in Korea from that disease last year.

HONOLULU, T.H., Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- Three American seamen, adrift for twenty days on a powerless minesweeper in the Pacific, were rescued by a Navy patrol boat today 400 miles northeast of Palmyra Atoll.

Twelve witnesses, including the two principals, were questioned yesterday at the District Attorney's office about the beating of Murray Becker, a photographer for The Associated Press. The questioning was conducted by assistant District Attorney Richard G. Denzer, who is investigating the case, with the possibility, that it may be presented to the grand jury.

Two-thirds of the local professional football entrants, the Giants and Yankees, spent yesterday in idleness, but the Dodgers, slated to meet the Buffalo Bills at Ebbets Field Friday night, went through a light workout. Coach Cliff Battles had his charges on the Flatbush grounds, where the session was limited to running, passing and calisthenics.

American Overseas Airlines announced last night that it would furlough tomorrow 1,300 employes made idle by the strike of 173 airline captains and co-pilots, now in its fifteenth day. The company indicated that a large number of those to receive leaves of absence were employes of foreign nationality abroad who had depended largely on food and other commodities made available to them through CARE and transported by the line.

Something of a record in the field of play marketing was established yesterday by Claire Leonard and Carl Cowl, authors' representatives, who sold two scripts by the same author -- Robert McEnroe -- to different theatrical outfits. An unusual angle, too, is the fact that the playwright has never been represented on the local boards.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 13 -- In the face of Arab military threats, Zionists here have confidently gone to work creating a shadow government and army for a Jewish state in part of Palestine. They are working on the assumption that the United Nations will sanction statehood for Jews or that the British Administration will depart without handing over power to anyone.

BOSTON, Oct. 13 -- President Philip Murray, in his keynote speech to the ninth convention of the Congress of Industrial Organizations today, appealed to the convention of the American Federation of Labor, meeting in San Francisco, to join with the CIO and the Railroad Brotherhoods for joint political action in 1948.

At the request of President Truman and Charles Luckman, chairman of the Citizens Food Committee, the Advertising Council will conduct a nationwide advertising information program in support of the food conservation drive, it was reported last night by Charles G. Mortimer Jr., chairman.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 13 -- A bomb was tossed on the doorstep of the United States consulate general in Jerusalem today following the United States declaration of last week favoring a partition of Palestine. The explosion caused extensive but superficial damage.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- A member of a special House subcommittee investigating European displaced persons said today that the group intended to urge Secretary of State Marshall to place the DP problem before the United Nations for immediate action.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union charged here today that the United States wants to use the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund as instruments of its own foreign policy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- The No. 1 job of management today is to restore the lines of communication between employes and management and to extend them, Harold F. North, industrial relations manager of Swift Co., declared today in an address before the opening session of the annual convention of the National Association of Suggestions Systems.

Picasso, whose later and more controversial work has been much in evidence of late, is represented this time by work done before 1907. The Knoedler Gallery is the scene of the event, which has been arranged as a benefit for the Public Education Association.

TAIAN, China, Oct. 10 (Delayed) -- The guillotine of the Chinese Communist revolution in this part of North China is a long thick pole about as tall as a onestory house, with a rope and slide arrangement at the top.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- Dr. William A. Irwin, New York City, economist for the American Bankers Association, said today that America is regarded everywhere as the workshop of the world, and the only hope for preserving the things for which our type of civilization has always stood.

A step toward real world community can be accomplished through Christian ideas that underlie democracy, Dr. Henry Smith Leiper, associate general secretary of the World Council of Churches, told an audience of 800 last night at the National Recreation Congress at the New Yorker Hotel.

MANILA, Oct. 13 -- President Roxas today announced conclusion of an agreement with the Westinghouse International Corporation by which the latter will establish a $2,000,000 electrical manufacturing plant in the Philippines to make fluorescent and incandescent lamps and eventually generators for local use and export.

One of the outstanding fur collections of the season was presented yesterday at the St. Regis by Revillon Freres. Full swirling skirts, handled with the fluidity of fabric, vied with sleeky wrapped silhouettes. A brief wrapped jacket, lined with colorful wool, was another feature introduced.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The abrupt announcement today that the Duke and Duchess of Windsor had not been invited to Princess Elizabeth's wedding to Lieut. Philip Mountbatten on Nov. 20 raised quite a few eyebrows in London's less fashionable pubs.

NANKING, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Communists today pressed their attack on Tiehling, forty miles northeast of Mukden, but were driven back each time by low-level bombing and strafing runs of Government planes, Nationalist dispatches from Manchuria reported.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today told railroads serving the New York Harbor area, and the steamship lines, to cooperate in making arrangements for the transfer of small shipments from railroad stations and piers to coastwise and intercoastal piers.
The "outrageous" traffic congestion in Manhattan was cited yesterday as justification for higher taxicab rates by operators of large and small fleets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The advance of communism into western Europe has been "stopped cold" for the past two to three months and "could be turned into an ebb tide very easily," Representative Karl E. Mundt, Republican, of South Dakota, said today upon his return from Europe.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Oct. 13 -- The Mayor of this city of 20,000 population has found a novel way of easing the housing shortage. He evicted himself today from City Hall and turned his office over to a war veteran, his wife and 9month-old son.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that Midwestern Corn Belt farmers plan to feed fewer beef cattle for the slaughter market this winter.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Only Jaroslav Drobny, Czechoslovak champion, had to go three sets today as the top four seeded players in the Pan American Tennis tournament breezed into the third round of the men's singles play.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- The commonwealth began a revaluation of its assets today as Governor James H. Duff opened Pennsylvania Week with a pledge to do everything possible to "improve the health, add to the happiness and better the well-being of our people."

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- The Portland (Ore.) General Electric Company filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission today covering $6,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, series due 1977.

Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, said yesterday that all necessary resources of the college would be made available for the special school for key municipal employes outlined Sunday by Mayor O'Dwyer.

ROME, Tuesday, Oct. 14 -- The Communist-dominated People's Bloc more than maintained the position it won last November and again came out ahead of all other parties in Sunday's municipal election in Rome. It nosed the Christian Democrats out of first place by 4,000-odd votes.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 -- A survey of American listed corporations released today by the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed a steady increase in sales for 1,243 companies during the second quarter of 1946 and the first and second quarters of 1947.
PARIS, Oct. 13 -- French officials said today that their troops, moving from Moncay, on the Tongking coast, had reached Kao Bang, 150 miles inland along the frontier between Indo-China and China.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- The Soviet Union endorsed today the proposed partition of Palestine. Russia's support for the plan, together with the United States endorsement of partition, appeared to make it certain that a two-thirds majority of the United Nations General Assembly would approve the suggestion for establishment of two independent states in the Holy Land.

A prolonged dry spell, marked during September, has carried over into the current month and resulted in a slight lowering of the water level of reservoirs and wells, weather bureau figures revealed yesterday.

For the first time in more than three years, a college eleven other than Army, Notre Dame or Texas gained top rating when Michigan was voted the nation's No. 1 football team yesterday in The Associated Press weekly poll.

Tuesday, Oct. 14, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Rejected Soviet resolution calling for removal of all foreign troops in Greece, for establishing a committee to supervise foreign economic aid and for finding Greece guilty of fomenting border trouble.

Although the problem of establishing the independence of Korea is now before the General Assembly of the United Nations, the Russian Government continues to press for an immediate American answer to its proposal for the withdrawal of both Russian and American troops from that country at the beginning of next year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- One hundred members of the Westchester County Historical Society visited points of interest in Mamaroneck, Larchmont and Mount Vernon today on their annual fall pilgrimage.

The future of European shipping depends on the international political situation as much as any other phase of Continental economy, according to Hans Christian Henriksen, assistant managing director of the Norwegian America Line.

The Citizens Union yesterday urged the voters of the state to reject the proposed soldiers' bonus, which will appear for approval on the November ballot. The group contended that the amount of money to be given to each veteran was too small to be of lasting benefit to him, yet as a total it would be a drain on state finances.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Congratulations on your excellent editorial entitled "A New York Housing Plan" in THE TIMES of Oct. 8. You have ably presented a major issue that deserves support and action. The confidence you show in Commissioner Stichman is shared by many publicspirited New Yorkers.

The Railway Express Agency and the New York Post Office predicted a rapid return to normal operations yesterday as 5,000 striking express drivers voted to resume work on the basis of a peace plan proposed by Mayor O'Dwyer's special fact-finding committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Great Britain and the United States were accused here today by the Ukraine of deliberately giving asylum to, protecting and even assisting war criminals, traitors and quislings in their German occupation zones.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- The Baltimore Colts revealed today that the letter of protest from Club President Bob Rodenburg to Commissioner Ingram contained six points instead of merely one.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court of the United States today maintained its decision upholding the conviction of Joseph S. Fay, Newark building trades union leader, and James Bove, another union leader, by a "blue-ribbon" jury.
Assaults on the five-cent fare developed from two directions yesterday.

Columbia's hopes for an upset victory over Penn on Saturday took a terrific jolt yesterday when it was learned that Werner Hasselman, the Lions' biggest and best tackle, will be out indefinitely with a torn ligament in his left knee.

Because of increased operating costs, the Protestant Children's Service is in serious financial difficulties, James G. Blaine, president of the service and of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies, said yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Fortunately for the world and this country, there is a percentage of great men who, when they pass on, leave a rich heritage behind for mankind. Some have invented mechanical devices, some have made scientific discoveries, others have made great spiritual contributions.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 13 -- A commercial and financial treaty between Argentina and Italy was signed this morning in the presence of President Juan Peron. The treaty grants Italy a loan of 700,000,000 pesos, about $175,000,000, for the purchase here of foodstuffs and raw materials.
LONDON, Oct. 13 -- A fresh advance by Government securities and the continued weakness of industrial shares marked the trading in the stock markets here today.

Three former members of the Anglo-American Committee of Inquiry on Palestine joined yesterday with three writers who have a first-hand knowledge of conditions in the Middle East in declaring there was no substance whatever in the threats of Arab aggression against Palestine.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- Field Marshal Sir Archibald MontgomeryMassingberd, chief of the Imperial General Staff from 1933 until his retirement in 1936, died today at Gunby Hall, his home in Spilsby, Lincolnshire. He was 75 years old.

Tourist List came home first in the $20,000 added Temple Gwathmey steeplechase handicap at Belmont Park yesterday and Little Sammie was second. This pair finished in that order only because they were the only two in the four-horse event who did not suffer a mishap while negotiating the gruelling course of about three miles.

The faction of the National Maritime Union backing Joseph Curran, its president, in his fight against internal disruptive forces, scored again last night when delegates to the sixth biennial convention voted for the acquittal of Harry Alexander and R.J. Sullivan, union officials at New Orleans, on charges of discrimination.

The mortgage money market is far from the saturation point, according to Nathan J. Sonnenblick of the Sonnenblick-Goldman Company, who expressed the belief that real estate mortages today are an attractive investment both for individuals and lending institutions.

Lost in the Shuffle A recent visitor to this corner -- one more interested in public characters than in following the news from day to day as he should, of course, complains that he loses some of his favorites among these persons in midcareer, and, like little Bo-Peep with her sheep, he doesn't know where to find 'em.

PARIS, Oct. 13 -- If the United States aid to France is insufficient, the economic situation in this country will grow rapidly worse, and either the Communists or the de Gaullists are likely to profit the most, since the moderates would be unable to govern.
SHANGHAI, Oct. 13 -- Far removed as Shanghai is from the civil war battlefields, the National Government is fighting one of its biggest battles in this crowded, noisy metropolis of 4,000,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- With the result clearly forecast by the vote Saturday in favor of the United States resolution on the Balkans, the United Nations Political and Security Committee rejected today the Soviet proposal on the Greek question by a vote of 40 to 6, with 11 abstentions.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 13 (AP) -- A length and a quarter ahead of Mort Stuart's Halbarail and still gaining at the finish, the Marlett Stable's Column, a 3-2 choice, this afternoon won the Columbus Day Handicap at Rockingham Park before a crowd of 28,353.
LONDON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- A reported threat to assassinate Foreign Secretary Bevin alarmed Britain today, but Scotland Yard dismissed it with the terse comment, "he is protected."

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 13 -- The South, "regarded ten years ago as the number one economic problem of the nation, is now the center of phenomenal economic growth and activity," Gordon R. Clapp, chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority, told the National Conference of Catholic Charities which closed its annual meeting here today.
ATHENS, Oct. 13 -- Prime Minister Themistocles Sophoulis announced to the Greek people in a radio address tonight an austerity program designed to start Greece on the road toward self-support.
A six-story wing, connected by extensions to Columbus Hospital, 227 East Nineteenth Street, will be constructed at 224-28 East Twentieth Street, Anthony J. DePace, architect, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The Export-Import Bank made $93,000,000 immediately available to France today to purchase coal and other industrial materials. Meanwhile the Administration intensified its search for emergency funds pending Congressional action on President Truman's proposal for $580,000,000 for stop-gap aid to Europe.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Deputy Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky is not the most popular delegate at the United Nations but he is certainly one of the best actors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- The keynotes of the current conventions of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations reveal that, though the two branches of union labor are often in disagreement, they are united in the effort to restore themselves as the dominant political group in the United States.

Wartime recipes for liver, tripe, frankfurters and other meat products were taken out of drawers yesterday by many restaurant and hotel chefs for the observance today of the second meatless Tuesday of President Truman's grain conservation program.
Several clothing manufacturers are sending men's spring clothing lines on the road at open prices, pending determination of any wage increase, it was reported here yesterday.

We do not see that each gyration of Leonard Bernstein on the platform is entirely essential to the most effective conducting, but it must be admitted that he very successfully conducts. The program of the concert he directed last night in the City Center of Music and Drama included Bach, Debussy, Piston and Schumann.

National Radio Week is to be observed from Oct. 26 through Nov. 1. For the occasion the National Association of Broadcasters made public yesterday a variety of statistics on the present status of broadcasting as well as an analysis of the different types of programs regularly provided by the nation's stations.
Random notes: The reports on the opening day of the grouse and woodcock season in the Adirondack area were far from exciting, although a few hunters were fortunate enough to find birds.

Columbia University's Bureau of Applied Social Research under the direction of Dr. Paul F. Lazarsfeld has submitted to the Puerto Rican Government a detailed plan for a study of Puerto Rican migrants in New York. This was announced yesterday by Dr. C. Wright Mills, director of the labor research division of the bureau, who will direct the study if it is undertaken.

Relief is not yet in sight for New York University's football team. Having absorbed a 38 -- 7 beating at the hands of Boston University last Saturday in Fenway Park, Boston, the Violets have to face mighty West Virginia on Saturday in the Yankee Stadium.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 13 (AP) -- A Federal court hearing on the secondary-boycott sections of the Taft-Hartley Act was recessed for ten days today after National Labor Relations Board and union attorneys raised points that may result in a test of the constitutionality of part of the law.
The captains and the kings of the gridiron have departed and there is an inevitable let-down in interest after the clash of Illinois and Army and of Yale and Columbia.
The modern furniture department at Altman's has burgeoned from a few rooms on the seventh floor to a whole section occupying one-third of the new eighth floor that opened yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Lowell B. Mason, Federal Trade Commissioner, today submitted to members of the bar his proposals for streamlining the commission's operation to permit business to progress with the increasing needs of the country and the world.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 13 -- Declaring that a majority o people in the United States undoubtedly are attempting to have Government control everyone's destiny, J.E. Lincoln, president of the Lincoln Electric Company, Cleveland, said tonight that "We can be sure there will be some form of totalitarianism within a comparatively few years."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 13 -- Carl Kruger, who is currently producing "The Last Nazi" with footage from the German film "Triumph of the Will," has announced that his next venture will be "The Long Flight," a story of B-29 Army bombers, in which he will utilize Air Forces film available for 10 cents a foot on a non-exclusive basis.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 13 -- Organic unity between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations is a prerequisite to joint political action by the two great bodies of organized labor, President William Green of the AFL asserted today.

Although the slackening off of retail dress sales could be the forerunner of a decline in apparel volume, such as was experienced last year, manufacturers are not too apprehensive about it, a survey of the trade showed yesterday.

Ten women in various fields of activity received honorary membership in Hadassah yesterday at its opening New York Chapter rally for 10,000 new members at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Certificates were presented "in recognition of outstanding services in the field of human welfare."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- It was the Marshall Plan for the rehabilitation of Europe that divided Europe into blocs of eastern and western states, Zygmunt Modzelewski, Polish Minister of Foreign Affairs, declared here today.
