MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 13 (AP) -- The latest tropical storm which ravaged rich agricultural and resort areas of southern Florida began a slight recurve toward the Middle Atlantic Coast tonight after whirling 500 miles out to sea.

THE unnecessarily ample football folk assembled yesterday at Toots Shor's Elite Eatery in their first full-dress meeting of the season. With the world series finally out of the way, reformed baseball writers donned their vests and became football experts, that alone accounting for the overflow crowd. They found it pleasant to be back at the old stand again, open for business as usual.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Oct. 13 -- Foreign countries are selling beer and liquor in the United States despite the well-publicized grain shortages overseas. William O'Shea, head of the Small Brewers' Committee, charged today at the convention of the Master Brewers' Association.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Aug. 24 John MacCormac, your correspondent in Prague, asserted: "A week ago the Communist Youth Front's paper, the Mlada Fronta, announced * * *." Allow me to correct that statement.

There were no losers yesterday in the "junior Olympics," in which youngsters from the lower East Side competed with more than thirty children of officials of the United Nations from all over the world.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 13 (AP) -- John J. Wicker Jr., Richmond attorney, said tonight he believed Charlie Justice "is entirely eligible under Southern Conference bylaws regardless of any professional contract he may have signed before entering college."

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 -- Reese J. Highfield, secretary-treasurer and business agent of Akron (Ohio) Typographical Union No. 182, said today that the executive council of the International Typographical Union, AFL, had instructed local unions to submit, under the TaftHartley Law, offers to negotiate contracts which contain provisions obviously unacceptable to newspaper publishers.

DURHAM, N.H., Oct. 13 -- A willingness to accept as a national obligation a program for grand scale agricultural production to feed the hungry of Europe was indicated today by representative New England farmers before the House Committee on Agriculture.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 13 (AP) -- Disclosure that Charlie Justice once signed a contract with a professional football club put in jeopardy today the future eligibility of the University of North Carolina star halfback.

TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 13 (AP) -- Converted bombers of Operation Cirrus radioed "mission completed" today and headed homeward to MacDill Field after the first attempt of science to attack a hurricane with dry ice.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union has begun a $1,000,000 expansion project for its Union Health Center at 275 Seventh, Avenue, it was learned yesterday from Dr. Leo Price, the center's director. Half completed at present, construction and installation work is expected to be finished by next summer.

Columbus Day business in local retail establishments yesterday was estimated far in excess of a year ago and called "a very exceptional Monday," with buying spread over practically all departments of the large stores. It was described as "a good, old-fashioned Columbus Day, with buying across the board, whole family units making the rounds from department to department taking turns in filling their needs."

TOKYO, Oct. 13 -- The skies are beginning to clear for Japan's private foreign trade. While American buyers are outspokenly critical of occupation's arrangements and pessimistic regarding the possibility of ever doing any volume business, they admit present conditions are much brighter.

Mayor O'Dwyer said yesterday that before making a decision the Board of Estimate would study carefully the plans for a Golden Jubilee celebration of the consolidation of the greater city, in 1898. All members of the board have received copies of the prospectus from Grover A. Whalen, chairman of the Mayor's jubilee committee, Mr. O'Dwyer said.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 13 -- Following is an unofficial translation from Russian of the Soviet Union's statement on the Palestine question, made before the United Nations General Assembly's special committee today by Semyon K. Tsarapkin:

New Yorkers who registered last week for the general elections to be held in this state on Nov. 4 were being handed, along with the little reminder card notifying them on which page and line their names appear on the voting record scrolls, a long printed form containing the details of six proposed amendments, three propositions and one local referendum.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the validity of a District Court order forbidding union picketing and boycoting of a delicatessen here. Its eventual decision may involve important interpretations pertaining to injunctions against unions.

Big mason jars of lemon drops, horehound candies and peppermintmolasses "bulls-eyes" give an old-fashioned, country store atmosphere to the Fireside Candy shop, 8114 Third Avenue in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. It's an authentic note, too, for most of the confections that Mr. and Mrs. Francis Bryant make in the kitchen behind this display room are the kind that have been favorites ever since grandmother tied a hair-ribbon on her braids.

VIENNA, Oct. 13 -- Soviet occupation authorities today removed the police chiefs of Sankt-Poelten, Wiener Neustadt and Baden, in which nearly half the population of Lower Austria live. The authorities announced the three would be replaced by Russian appointees.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- Coordinated air and truck freight service was anticipated for operation within a few months with announcement today of agreement on a plan reached between Air Cargo, Inc., freight representative of the certificated air lines, and the American Trucking Association's special committee on air cargo.

LONDON, Oct. 13 -- The Labor Government carried its appeal for more productivity in the present national crisis to the public today in the first of a series of front page advertisements in the nation's daily papers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 13 -- President Truman sent telegrams today to the Governors of the forty-eight states asking their immediate cooperation in the voluntary food saving program to meet "the desperate need of hungry people in other countries."

The "Big Inch" and "Little Big Inch" pipe lines, as most people will readily recall, were built during the early days of the war to bring oil overland from Texas to Eastern consumers and shipping points at a time when German submarines were taking a heavy toll of the coastwise tankers which normally perform this task.

Radio components manufacturers are seeking to lower prices by increasing employe productivity, Jerome J. Kahn, chairman of the parts division of the Radio Manufacturers Association, revealed yesterday. Mr. Kahn placed individual employe productivity in the components industry at 78 per cent of pre-war and reported that steady improvement is developing because of the return of acute job competition among workers.

CHICAGO, Oct. 13 (U.P.) -- Representative Clarence J. Brown, Republican, of Ohio, told publishers of newspapers today that they probably would be able to get more newsprint next year, but at somewhat higher prices.
Richard H.S. Crossman, member of the British Parliament and former member of the Anglo-American Commmittee of Inquiry, predicted last night a final and complete defeat of Britain in Palestine.

LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Capt. Steve Albulet, pilot of the Trans-Canada Airlines plane that shepherded the Bermuda Sky Queen to a weather ship in mid-Atlantic, said in a telephone interview tonight that he thought "all was well" as he ended his vigil over the forced-down plane.

Winston Churchill, wartime Prime Minister of Great Britain and now leader of the Conservative opposition, warned last night that "at some moment or other" Soviet Russia and its satellites might quit the United Nations.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- In a joint application, the Central Kentucky Natural Gas Company and the United Fuel Gas Company, subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, today asked the Securities and Exchange Commission to authorize Central Kentucky's proposal to sell some of its property to United Fuel at its book value of $1,084,924.

Plans for a nine-story and penthouse apartment building at 15-21 West Eighty-fourth Street, to contain seventy-four suites, were filed yesterday by Horace Ginsbern Associates, architects, who estimated the cost at $750,000. Other plans included:

The dispatches from Tokyo regarding the testimony of Marquis Koichi Kido, Emperor Hirohito's closest adviser before and during the war, call attention to the fact that the mammoth trial of twenty-five of Japan's ranking war criminals, which began May 3, 1946, is still continuing.
Despite heavy hedge selling, a continued strong demand from southern mills raised the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday to net gains of 15 to 40 points.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Great Britain's intention to assure "much higher industrial production" for Germany under a new plan was explained by Prime Minister Attlee today.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Oct. 14 (AP) -- There was a great silence -- officially -- about the Charlie Justice case on the University of North Carolina campus today, and it appeared that Carolina's views would not be aired until the meeting of the southern conference executive committee in Durham Saturday to decide on the eligibility of the speedy Tarheel back-field star.

DES MOINES, Oct. 14 (AP) -- In a decision affecting thousands of parochial school children of rural Iowa, the Iowa Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that public school buses may not carry private and parochial school children. It said that no United States constitutional issue was involved.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Six career consuls reported to the United Nations Security Council from Batavia, Java, today that Dutch troops had been ordered to go ahead, within their own proclaimed lines, with mopping-up operations against Indonesian forces despite the Council's two ceasefire orders.

Dr. Nickolaus L. Engelhardt will retire on Nov. 1 as associate superintendent in charge of the division of housing and business administration of the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday by the Board of Superintendents. Dr. Engelhardt will leave the $12,500-a-year post that he has held since Dec. 1, 1942, to form a private school-planning institute in which he will act as consultant to school systems of the country.

Buyers' Total Lower Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,567, compared with 1,687 last week and 1,584 in the similar week a year ago, according to listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Seven leaders of the aviation industry invited to testify today before the President's Air Policy Commission joined in picturing the air might of the United States as disintegrating because of lack of any long-range planning or financing for experimentation and development.

when the smoke cleared away and the inquiries were, over, the Pennsylvania Game Commission began juggling with figures on the game kill and the accident reports for the last hunting season, and they have turned up some results that should prove interesting to any hunter.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 14 -- Overwhelming support of the Marshall plan was expressed implicitly here today by the United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee. By a vote of 36 to 2, with eight abstentions, the committee removed implied criticism of the Marshall plan in a resolution that had been presented by Dr. Oscar Lange, vice chairman of the Polish delegation.

Coast Guard seamanship averted last night what might have been the Atlantic's worst air tragedy. By 10 o'clock the cutter Bibb had saved forty-four of the sixty-two men, women, children and crew of the Boeing flying boat Bermuda Sky Queen, down since daylight in waves thirty-five feet high, 760 nautical miles northeast of New-foundland.

Foreign Redemptions The French Republic announced yesterday that it will redeem $3,984,700 of its 7 per cent United States dollar bonds due Dec. 1, 1949, at the call price of 105 on Dec. 1. However, holders of the bonds resident in the franc area will receive payments not in American dollars but in the French franc equivalent of the dollar obligation, calculated at the prevailing official rate of exchange.

Total 1948 production of all types of radio and television receivers will range between 12,900,000 and 15,300,000 units, a definite drop compared with the estimated 1946 output of 16,000,000, according to a consensus yesterday of leading producers attending the Radio Manufacturers Association fall meeting in the Hotel Roosevelt.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Alfred A. Knopf, Inc., which was authorized by Kahlil Gibran or by his heirs to publish his works in English, has scheduled for publication the authorized English versions of Gibran's early Arabic writings. The translations will be made by H.M. Nahmad.

BISMARCK, N.D., Oct. 14 -- A group of representative North Dakotans side-stepped today the question of bringing European displaced persons to this state, whose population has been dwindling for nearly twenty years.
DALLAS, Tex., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Admiral Chester W. Nimitz announced today that he would retire from active naval duty in the middle of December.

The best rally in a month took place yesterday on the stock market and, stimulated by the liveliest interest in almost five months, prices jumped forward fractions to more than three points. The sharp recovery that carried the average rate to the mid-August level, a position it has frequently approached in the last two weeks, was attended by the finest type of leadership exhibited during the summer or early fall.

The ship's bell of the old ferryboat Elizabeth, once the pride of the Central Railroad Company of New Jersey, has taken its place among the marine mementos gathered in the Port of New York Gallery of the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.
Wednesday, Oct. 15, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Began consideration of United States proposal for year-round "Little Assembly."

Columbia's two big question marks -- the condition of Gene Rossides' throwing arm and how well Werner Hasselman can be replaced at tackle -- received careful scrutiny from Coach Lou Little and his assistants at Baker Field yesterday.

ROME, Oct. 14 -- The final results of Sunday's municipal election in Rome emphasize the polarization of votes toward two greatly contrasted parties -- on the Left toward the Communists and their allies, and on the Right toward the Christian Democrats.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, charged today that the United States was attempting to "steamroller" its proposal for a "Little Assembly" of the United Nations after it had found that "a liquidation of the veto was legally impossible."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (U.P.) -- Justice Robert H. Jackson proposed today that the Supreme Court ignore previous confusion-laden ruling's on divorce cases and write a clear-cut decision on "quickie divorces" that "simple people can understand and live by."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- The Yugoslav delegation proposed today in the United Nations General Assembly's Special Committee on Palestine that all Jewish, refugees now interned in the stockades of Cyprus be admitted to Palestine immediately without regard to "present immigration quotas or future provisions."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Every aspect of homemaking from running up a gay tea cloth for the kitchen table to planning a new house from scratch is represented among the 250 exhibits at the All-Westchester Better Homes Exposition, which opened here today.

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 14 -- Seven German men within the last two weeks have expressed their willingness to yield an eye apiece to help blinded United States soldiers regain their sight. But it seemed today that someone had perpetrated a hoax, as no such offers will be accepted.

Plans for widening lower South Street for the Battery-Brooklyn tunnel approach Call for alteration of five and possibly six East River piers between Broad Street and Old Slip, it became known yesterday.

A friend in need is a friend indeed. Fulfilling those specifications to the hilt is Noel Coward, author of the "Tonight at 8:30" series and John C. Wilson's buddy and business associate. Inasmuch as Mr. Wilson is shackled -- hand and loot -- to a formidable schedule and couldn't squeeze in the direction of "Tonight at 8:30," starring Gertrude Lawrence, Mr. Coward agreed to stage his own material.

LILLE, France, Oct. 14 -- Charles de Gaulle's Reunion of the French People is expected to make an excellent showing in the local elections in the industrial North of France, which are to be held soon.

Threats to religious and civil liberties were emphasized yesterday afternoon by speakers at gatherings in connection with the 140th annual meeting of the Baptist State Convention in Brooklyn. The threats were seen as likely to arise in the United States from Roman Catholic insistence on bus transportation at public expense for parochial school students, the maintenance of a representative of the President at the Vatican and from loyalty tests of Government employes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Stating that he would not consider taking second place on the Republican ticket, Harold E. Stassen announced today that he would vigorously step up his campaign for the Presidential nomination with a nine-state tour next month.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The conference of the Foreign Ministers' deputies on the future of the Italian colonies reached a wide measure of agreement today on its first important task. This was to fix the size, scope and terms of reference of the commission to be sent to Libya, Eritrea and Somaliland to ascertain the inhabitants' wishes on the fate of their lands.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The stock markets here were generally quiet today. Speculators who had rushed to buy gilt-edge issues cashed in early today and as a result prices weakened. Before the close, however, a good rally developed and, with the exception of the "Dalton 2 1/2 per cent" and Old Consols, which were a quarter down, the close was higher on the day.

A list of passengers and crew members aboard the Bermuda Sky Queen, according to British Overseas Airways, British agent for American international Airways, and other sources, follows. The list contains sixty-nine names, the number that American International Airways says was the total aboard.

Spurred by advance reports of improved deliveries of metal products, buyers have increased pre-exhibition registrations 65 per cent over last year, officials of the 1947 National Hardware Show revealed here yesterday. The show opens at Grand Central Palace today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- George L. Reed, former international housing adviser for the National Housing Agency and later housing attache in London, was appointed today as housing adviser for the American Mission for Aid to Greece.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The article on "Poles Making Over" in your Oct. 1 issue is bad -- to put it mildly. What is worse, it represents the German standpoint, absolutely mendacious.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Breaking on top in the featured sixth race, Baxter Stable's Ackley won the $3,000 purse by covering the six furlongs in 1:12 3-5 before 5,518 persons today at Rockingham Park.

MADRID, Oct. 14 -- Nearly the entire group of doctors and lawyers arrested last month in Galicia, in northwest Spain, were reported today to have been freed, but reports have come in of new arrests of 136 persons and of the shooting of three others by the police in widely separated areas.

It took United States Attorney John F.X. McGohey barely two hours yesterday afternoon to complete the Government's case against Leon Josephson, admitted Communist, who is accused in an indictment of having refused to be sworn and testify last March 5 before a sub-committee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

BOSTON, Oct. 14 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations dedicated itself today to a campaign to obtain repeal of the "infamous (Taft-Hartley) act and of the reactionary program of which it is a part." By unanimous vote the 700 delegates also pledged their organizations to work with other unions and progressive groups to insure the defeat of those members of Congress who voted for the law.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- One half of the credits France obtains through the Marshall plan will be devoted to reconstruction, Premier Paul Ramadier said today in a speech at Dunkerque, where the Premier presided at ceremonies celebrating the reopening of the commercial port.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 14 (AP)--A ruling on the constitutionality of the Taft-Hartley Labor Relations Act was passed over, but a long battle over parts of the new law took shape today at the first National Labor Relations Board hearing on charges that a union engaged in unfair practices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The United States Army, in an official bulletin for troops, said today that Russia occupied an advantageous military position for launching attacks in any direction. The publication, "Armed Forces Talk," is one of a series used in troop information and education programs.

PARIS, Oct. 14--A strike that Premier Paul Ramadier denounced as "a political maneuver" deprived Paris and its suburbs of all subway and bus services today. Thousands traveled to and from work standing in trucks or in tourist buses hastily mobilized by the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- Charles Luckman, chairman of the Citizens Food Committee, appealed today to the American Dietetic Association's 8,000 members for cooperation in the national food conservation program.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- In his book, "Speaking Frankly," released to the public tomorrow by Harper Brothers, James F. Byrnes reviews the foreign policy of the United States from the Yalta conference in 1945 to his retirement as Secretary of State after the New York conference in 1946; looks prophetically and hopefully into the future of American-Soviet relations; and in so doing makes a number of sensational revelations in deceptively mild language.

Large baking companies In New York and New Jersey expressed yesterday willingness to cooperate in any Government program to conserve wheat for Europe when a workable plan was evolved by the President's Citizens Food Committee.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, said today that Communist parties were determined to make impossible decent conditions of life in the countries they were trying to seize because they recognized that chaos and disorder provided the atmosphere necessary to control.

Aerial tactics received added attention at New York University's football practice yesterday as the Violets prepared to face undefeated West Virginia in the Yankee Stadium on Saturday. The Mountaineers are overwhelming favorites to remain in the unbeaten class.
LONDON, Oct. 14 -- Admiral of the Fleet Sir Osmond de Beauvoir Brock, Chief of Staff of Admiral Lord Beatty in the first World War, died today at Winchester. He was 78 years old.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 -- George Munger and his Pennsylvania football coaching staff were analyzing Columbia plays today when the head mentor looked up from a diagram board to greet a visitor. He said, "Maybe you think it's a little early in the season to get steamed up, but I'm figuring out a way to beat Columbia."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Today the people of this country face a choice similar to that which confronted them before the Second World War. For ten years the democracies had allowed the Nazis and Fascists to engage in psychological and physical aggression until they became so strong that they were willing to risk war.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 14 -- The autumn is distilling time in Scotland when the barley is harvested and they begin making the malt and the long process starts that ends in bottles of good Scotch whisky.

"Child's World." a new series featuring Miss Helen Parkhurst, founder of the Dalton School in New York, is announced for a premiere at 7 P.M. Sunday, Oct. 26, over the ABC network. The program will be devoted to a discussion between Miss Parkhurst and a group of children, ranging in age from 8 to 15, on such topics as older brothers and sisters, allowances, lying, privileges, secrets, friends and school.
Insufficient emphasis is given throughout the country to youth programs for girls, Attorney General Tom C. Clark declared yesterday.

In a stirring finish that saw the eventual winner fight off a determined bid by a 25-to-1 shot, Mrs. Ogden Phipps' Look Around captured the $10,000 added New York Turf Writers Cup Hurdle Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Oct. 14 (AP) -- A 200-mile stretch of the Carolinas' coastline was threatened by a hurricane late tonight and residents of coastal islands began evacuating their homes in the face of winds ranging upward of ninety miles an hour.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- First Baseman Stan Musial and Pitcher George Hunger of the Cardinals entered St. John's Hospital today for surgery to correct ailments which handicapped them during the 1947 season.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 14 -- Bennett S. Chapple Jr., Pittsburgh assistant vice-president, United States Steel Corporation of Delaware, addressing the thirty-seventh semi-annual meeting of the Nation Association of Sheet Metal Distributors in the Hotel Marlborough-Blenheim, said that in the past two years the steel industry has established a record for peacetime steel production, unequaled since the turn of the century.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- E.H.B. Bartelink, radio engineer of the General Telephone System, today charged that the Federal Communications Commission had failed to recognize fully the need for frequency allocations to expand mobile and subscriber radio-telephone service.

LONDON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Jackie Paterson of Glasgow won the first round today in his legal fight to prevent the winner of the bout next Monday between Dado Marino of Honolulu and Rinty Monaghan of Ireland from being recognized as world flyweight champion.

Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera," which opened the Metropolitan Opera season in 1940, has been chosen to open the sixty-third season, which begins Nov. 10, Edward Johnson, General Manager, announced yesterday afternoon at his annual press conference, naming the artists and outlining the plans of the new season.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Forty-two members of the Negro cast of "The Swing Mikado," a barnstorming, non-Equity company, which, closed in St. Paul on Oct. 6, are trying to contact Jules Pfeiffer, the producer, in an effort to collect notarized lOU's ranging from $35 to $100.

A revolutionary method of teaching arithmetic that will change the old "monkey-rote" approach to one of "life-like" situations is now being tested in city schools, it was made known yesterday. Before its official introduction into the elementary schools next February, 110 teachers are learning the techniques while teaching under the new methods.

As a result of capacity production by all plants, earnings of the Mathieson Alkali Works in the first nine months of this year rose to $2.36 a share from $1.58 a year earlier despite increased costs and transfer of $200,000 to reserves for contingencies, the report disclosed yesterday.

Robert E. Strawbridge Jr. of Old Westbury, L.I., former internationalist, has been re-elected chairman of the United States Polo Association, it was announced yesterday after a meeting of officials of the organization at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

For the second consecutive year, a record high number of births are in prospect for 1947, Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein predicted for New York yesterday on the basis of nine months vital statistics.

Park Avenue does not want the proposed Greater New York Golden Jubilee. The Park Avenue Association got a flood of protest calls yesterday from Park Avenue hotel men, residents and from street-level shops.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Despite isolated instances of non-compliance about the country, of which he said he was well aware, Charles Luckman, chairman of the Citizens Food Committee, said today that he was confident its voluntary food conservation program would succeed.

TSINAN, Shantung, Oct. 12 (Delayed) -- One of the most significant recent developments in this central Shantung zone of savage struggle between the Communists and the old order is a genuine, spontaneous people's anti-Communist movement.

Pointing out that no foreign country is in a position to threaten our textile industry, Harold Bernstein, chairman of the export group of the Textile Distributors Institute, urged textile men yesterday to support reduction of duties to help increase imports.

In two sessions marked by bickerings, charges, counter-charges and general disorder, the sixth biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, meeting in the Manhattan Center, yesterday struggled toward the end of its meeting, which is now scheduled for this afternoon.

The Board of Estimate in executive session yesterday committed itself to reducing from 7 to 5 per cent of gross receipts the franchise payments by the Triboro Coach Corporation, thus paving the way for the purchase of the Triboro company by the Green Bus Lines, Both companies operate in Queens.

The heroic battle waged against gale winds and high seas by the crew of the Coast Guard cutter Bibb in the North Atlantic rescue of personnel from the Bermuda Sky Queen was described in graphic detail last night in a radio broadcast from the weather-ship by her commanding officer, Capt. Paul Cronk.

Monday, Oct. 13, 1947, may be remembered as one of those rare days on which the United States and Russia agreed about something -- namely, the principle of the partition of Palestine. Russia's acceptance of the partition plan indicated no change in her obstructionist policy in other fields, as Mr. Vishinsky took pains to remind us in his bitter attack on our "Little Assembly" proposals yesterday.

Warning against a tendency in some sections of the petroleum industry to seek state or Federal assistance, intervention or direction in problems purely of an industry nature, M.J. Rathbone, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, declared last night that this course might lead to nationalization.

Charm and femininity were evilenced in the collection of French originals and made-to-order millinery presented yesterday at Bergdorf Goodman. From the French designers came beguiling little bonnets reminiscent of the eighteenth century, dashing pillboxes with feathered trims and romantic hats with sweeping ostrich plumes.

The text of the address of Winston Churchill, which was delivered by transcription through the Columbia Broadcasting System to the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation dinner at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel last night, follows:

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 14 -- Three of the five major Czechoslovak parties defied the Communists on the vital issue of Parliamentary independence today and won despite the dramatic appearance in the House of Vaclaw Nosek, Communist Minister of the Interior and head of the police, who attempted to use his influence.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- From early morning until the sun went down behind the hills of Westchester, 130 women found great enjoyment in their last Women's Metropolitan Golf Association one-day tournament today. The event was held on the Westchester Country Club south course.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 14 -- An exhibition of arts and crafts useful as design sources was opened this evening at the Newark Museum with a preview for members. Also opened was a display of forty portraits of early Americans lent by private owners and museums.

BOSTON, Oct. 14 -- The United States is proving it is not a, "warmongering nation" by its attempts to reach international agreement on use of the atomic bomb, William L. Laurence, NEW YORK TIMES science reporter and atomic bomb expert, told the Boston Advertising Club today.

New issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $11,800,000, were awarded yesterday to underwriting managers following competitive sale, as follows: Texas Power and Light Company -- $8,000,000 of thirty-year first-mortgage bonds to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at 100.63 for 3s.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Grain prices moved higher on the Board of Trade today with wheat in the lead, the latter rising 2 3/4 to 6 1/4 cents a bushel, July leading, due to continued dry weather in the West and Southwest, and a forecast for unusually high temperatures and little or no precipitation during the next five days.

Italians regard municipal elections in Rome as a barometer of political trends in the nation. The Communist-led Leftist bloc was not only confident of making wide gains in Sunday's election but of winning a national victory next spring, which would leave it in control of the government.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 14 -- "Our Son Pablo," a novel by Alvin and Darley Gordon, published in 1946 by Whittlesey House, has been purchased for the screen by RKO and will be filmed next year, the studio announced today.

The provision of proper recreational facilities supported by the public and sponsored by the government on all levels for the suitable use of leisure time in the present atomic age was forecast last night by Dr. William F. Russell, dean of Teachers College, Columbia University.
The Coast Guard cutter Bibb, engaged in yesterday's rescue of passengers and crew members of the flying boat forced down in the Atlantic, is no stranger to such operations.

A banking syndicate headed by Phelps, Penn Co. won yesterday at competitive sale bond issues of the city of Minneapolis, Minn., aggregating $4,650,000. For an issue of $2,000,000 refunding bonds due Nov. 1 from 1948 to 1967, the winning bid was 100.5 for 1.30s, and for $2,650,000 housing, public relief, authorium and other purpose bonds maturing over the same period, the high bid was 100.053 for 1.30s.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 14 -- A new development in the art of soap-making has been achieved with the addition to Rinso of a "sunlight" ingredient known as "Solium," it was announced today by the Lever Brothers Company, manufacturer.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 14 -- Zionist apprehension over the Arab states' decision to send troops to the Palestine border had generally subsided today, and, as a consequence of the Soviet Union's pro-Zionist declaration in the United Nations, Palestine Jews were more optimistic than ever of attaining statehood.

Mushrooms at 65 cents a pound aren't an especially economical vegetable, but this price, which is reported by the City Department of Markets, is 20 cents lower than that for the previous week, and relatively little for a food that always is a luxury.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Cobbler, an unbeaten colt, today won the six-furlong Middle Park Stakes, known as the "2-Year-Old Derby" and regarded as an important test for entries in next year's classic races.

American industry cannot afford to throw in the sponge and forget about Latin-American markets because of current import restrictions or exchange difficulties, Morris S. Shipley, vice president of the InterAmerican Research Service, said yesterday.

With five leading Canadian amateur hockey teams, including the Dominion champion, slated to skate at Madison Square Garden this winter, the New York Rovers are booked for a sixteen-game home stand in the 1947-48 season, it was announced yesterday.

Stout Steve Owen, who likens his current position in the National Football League to that of a monkey on a stick, "sometimes you're up and sometimes you're down," made three changes in his starting line-up yesterday. Preparing for Sunday's home-opener against the Boston Yanks at the Polo Grounds, the New York coach switched assignments during a morning workout under Coogan's Bluff and told about it at a luncheon at noon.

Washington followed the voting in Rome with almost as much attention as if it were a local election. This American concern in a municipal poll in Italy is a strange phenomenon, as interesting in its way as the popular reactions to the sixteen-nation recovery plan.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Mary Arnold Prentiss of Los Angeles and Armando Vega of Mexico today won the sixth Pan-American tennis tournament mixed-doubles championship. Mrs. Prentiss and Vega defeated Miss Beverly Baker of Santa Monica, Calif., and Edward Moylan of Trenton, N.J., 4 -- 6, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Independent retailers are responsible to a considerable extent for the consumer belief that the retailers are as much to blame for inflation, John W. Dargavel, secretary of the National Association of Retail Druggists, charged today in an address before the first annual convention since the war.

The Manhattan College basketball team will engage in twenty-six contests this coming season, it was announced yesterday by the Rev. Brother Eusebius, director of athletics. The team again will be coached by Ken Norton, who in his first year as a college mentor last year guided it to a 500 record in twenty-six games.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 -- John L. Lewis pleaded in vain today with some 700 fellow delegates to the American Federation of Labor's annual convention not to "debase" themselves by amending the federation's constitution to give Federal labor unions protection under the Taft-Hartley law.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- By the slim margin of 25 to 23, with 3 abstentions, a diluted Indian resolution, expressing the hope that colonial towers would place under the international trusteeship system such of their territories as were not ready for self-government, was adopted today by the United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee.

George S. Messersmith, former Ambassador to Argentina and newly elected chairman of the board of directors of the Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., has been elected a director of the Societe d'Electricite (Sodec) just as the latter company is about to join issue with the Spanish Government over control of the assets of the Compania Hispano Americana de Electricidad (Chade) of Madrid.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Senator Clyde M. Reed of Kansas announced today that he is postponing "for a month or more" hearings on the administration of railroad reorganization laws because of a "change in ICC policy."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Counselsel for the National Labor Relations Board has issued his first complaint charging a union with restraint and coercion of employes in their right of self-organization.

There is promise of progress in relieving the impairments of old age although there are many important questions about the problem still unanswered, Dr. Nathan Shock of Baltimore said last night at a session of the Graduate Fortnight of the New York Academy of Medicine.
MADISON, N.J., Oct. 14 -- The value to this country of aid to Britain was debated here today on the weekly program of station WQXR, "What's On Your Mind," sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

GENEVA, Oct. 14 -- The measures taken by countries bordering on Egypt to prevent the spread of cholera have been exaggerated, in the opinion of quarantine experts of the World Health Organization which is holding a special meeting here.

ALBANY, Oct. 14 -- Governor Dewey assured President Truman today that the New York State Food Commission would cooperate fully with the Citizens Food Committee "in any sound program it may put forward."

A prospering astrologer, faith healer and self-styled minister was arrested yesterday in his Greenwich Village apartment and church on the complaint of State Attorney General Nathan L. Goldstein that he was practicing medicine without a license.

The need for close cooperation among nursing groups, the medical profession, the community and all nations in the long-range program for world health was discussed in various phases yesterday by speakers at the joint convention of the New York State Nurses Association and the State League for Nursing Education.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Grasslands Hospital of Eastview, owned and operated by Westchester, was accused today by the Fox-Eklof Post of the American Legion, Croton-on-Hudson, of "careless, irresponsible, cruel and reprehensible" treatment of a veteran who died Sept. 7.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., is about to enter the capital market for long-term debenture borrowing of about $20,000,000, most of which will go for modernizing its main store here and for expanding operations in new stores in other cities.

Foreign traders can speed the advent of a secure peace in the world through the exchange of culture, goods and services, James A. Farrell Jr., president of the "American South African Line and of the Maritime Association of the Port of New York, declared last night.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I always read copies of your newspaper though they usually reach our side some one month or more later, but their interesting, immortal articles give me a real enthusiasm, regardless of date of issue.

ATHENS, Oct. 14 -- Napoleon Zervas, former Minister of Public Order and wartime leader of the right-wing resistance movement, withdrew today his support of the Sophoulis Government and threatened to reorganize his Nationalist guerrillas to fight the Communists.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, said today a $26,250 "fraud" had been uncovered in accounts of the Federal Public Housing Authority and Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican, of Wisconsin, said they show in addition either a $608,261 book-keeping error or a "defalcation."
The Philharmonic -- Symphony's total operating costs for the year 1946-47 were $1,003,778.41, it was reported in the Symphony Society's annual meeting at Steinway Hall yesterday.

Little meat was served yesterday in the major restaurants, hotels and cafeteria chains, but plenty of it was eaten in grill rooms, sandwich shops and hamburger and frankfurter stands throughout the city.

LONDON, Oct. 14 -- The domestic consumption of gas and electricity must be cut at least 10 per cent below last winter's average if Britain is to avoid arbitrary cuts in household supplies, Hugh Gaitskell, Minister of Fuel and Power, warned today.
The new three-story business building at 253-5 Seventh Avenue, between Twenty-fourth and Twenty-fifth Streets, has been purchased by Henry Goelet, operator.

Deviations From the Main Road We have noted, sometimes with and sometimes without satisfacfaction, that often when we browse among news items, impelled by a determination to devote the major part of our browsing to important happenings in the world, we find our attention arrested instead by tidbits belonging in a humbler category.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- William L. Clayton has resigned the post of Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs and his decision has been accepted reluctantly by President Truman.
Several sales of acreage in the Northport area of Long Island were reported yesterday by the Walter C. Hewitt Organization, brokers and developers.
SEATTLE, Oct. 14(U.P.) -- Discovery of the highest undersea mountain in the North Pacific was announced today by Capt. Robert A. Studds of the United States Coast and Geogetic Survey.
CHICAGO, Oct. 14 -- Results of operations transplanting healthy corneas to the diseased or damaged eyes of persons who already have vision of 20/100 or better "do not warrant the risk."

Lavern Roach, 158 1/4, Plain-view, Tex., won a unanimous decision over Jack Kenny, 162, Newark, in the main bout of eight rounds at the Broadway Arena last night. In the six-round semi-final, Jimmy Pierce, 141 1/2, Vancouver, B.C., outpointed Joey Varoff, 139 1/4, East Side.

Seventy-three of the city's first post-war sit-down strikers, all who remained of ninety-nine who refused on Monday to leave the plant of the Industrial Container Corporation at Fiftieth Street and Second Avenue, Brooklyn, were served early today with Supreme Court show-cause orders, in a move to deprive them of their jobs.

Elmer Haslett, brought action in Supreme Court yesterday seeking reinstatement in his $8,350-a-year job as Director of City Airports. He was removed last July by Commissioner Frederick G. Reinicke of the Department of Marine and Aviation, after his dismissal had been recommended by Herbert Wechsler, Columbia University law professor and temporary deputy commissioner, because of violations of the City Charter and Civil Service Law.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 14 -- More than 7,250,000 persons have been displaced in the communal disturbances of the Punjab and elsewhere since Aug. 15, according to figures compiled today by the Indian Army.

The embargo on railway express shipments to New York was eased yesterday, but the ban on local pick-ups continued as 12,000 Railway Express Agency employes labored to clear away the 500,000 undelivered packages that piled up here during the twenty-five-day drivers' strike.

EVER since the war ended, predictions have been made at this time of the year that there would be wholesale trading along the baseball front before the new season started. But there weren't enough deals completed to have made an appreciable difference anywhere. However, the same predictions are being made again in even louder tones than before.

Vigorous measures will be taken if tie-in sales develop as a result of the sixty-day distillers' holiday, Carroll E. Mealey, deputy comnissioner of the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Treasury Department warned last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct 14 -- The question whether noncomplying unions should be allowed to participate in representative elections when employers petition for them raised the possibility today of another National Labor Relations Board decision reversing its independent general counsel, Robert N. Denham.

Major league baseball attendance Climbed to a new all-time high of 18,954,832 in 1947, according to an unofficial count that showed an 8 per cent increase over a year ago, according to The Associated Press. The 1946 paid total was 18,534,444.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 14 -- The Mercer County Grand Jury was directed today by Supreme Court Justice William A. Wachenfeld to investigate charges that Mayor Donal J. Connolly of Trenton, took illegal fees to arrange issuance of beauty culture permits.

Coach Ed Danowski staged a ninety-minute offensive scrimmage for the Fordham varsity yesterday as he began mapping a revised line-up for Saturday's contest with Rutgers at New Brunswick, N.J. Due to the large injured list, the starting backfield will include two men who did not figure prominently in the early plans at Rose Hill.

A prowler who tried to break away from two Holmes patrolmen in Trinity Church early yesterday morning was critically wounded when he was hit by three of ten bullets fired as he tried to escape flashlight beams by ducking behind pews.

GENEVA, Oct. 14 -- The resignation of United States Under Secretary of State William L. Clayton, it was learned here today, is the result of insistence by his family that the hard-driving architect of United States foreign economic policy at last give some attention to his health.

In agreeing to shut down their plants for sixty days, beginning at midnight Oct. 25, leaders of the nation's distilling industry have given concrete evidence of their intention to back up the President's food conservation program. At the same time the advisory committee of the National Restaurant Industry has reaffirmed its support of the drive and announced a seventeen-point program of its own.

TOKYO, Oct. 14 -- Marquis Koichi Kido, who as Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal was Emperor Hirohito's closest adviser before and during the war, took the witness stand in his own defense today before the International Military Tribunal that is trying Gen. Hideki Tojo and twenty-four others on charges of conspiring to dominate Asia and the Pacific through aggressive war.

BUFFALO, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Delegates to the convention of the Episcopal Diocese of Western New York today elected the Rt. Rev. Henry I. Louttit, Suffragan Bishop of the South Florida Diocese, as Bishop to succeed the retired Rt. Rev. Cameron J. Davis.

Three newcomers to the City College football squad were promoted to first-string positions as the Beavers took their daily drill yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. Coach Harold (Doc) Parker sent Irwin Slater to right tackle, Stan Plesent to fullback, and Stan Raderman to left half.
Matthew G. Ely, president of Horace S. Ely Co., was elected for a third term as president of the Real Estate Board of New York at the meeting of the board of governors yesterday.

EASTVIEW, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Dr. E.L. Harmon, director of Westchester County's Grasslands Hospital here, declared this afternoon that criticism of the hospital in connection with the death on Sept. 7 of Morris Delaney, at war veteran, was unwarranted.
Racing returned to Jamaica for the final stages of the metropolitan season despite a strike of grooms and exercise boys that showed its effect in twenty withdrawals on the seven-race care yesterday.

Escalator Clauses Asked Demands for escalator clauses in some long-term sales contracts are being renewed by metal products manufacturers, spokesmen revealed here yesterday, in describing trends for 1948. While many companies are making efforts to avoid reinstating such clauses for upward pricing of products, rising costs may force their use unless downward price trends develop soon, spokesmen explained.
CALCUTTA, India, Oct. 15 -- A new Hindu-Moslem crisis is likely next week when both communities celebrate two of their biggest and most characteristic festivals.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 6,000 head, total 9,000; market narrow, moderately active and around 25 cents hlgher on all weights butchers; top $30; bulk of good and choice 190 to 300 pound kinds
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- The United States was accused here today by Camille Chamoun of Lebanon of having supported the partition of Palestine to appease Jewish voters in this country.

A number of hunters who have been getting in shape for the opening of the waterfowl season by doing some coot (scoter) shooting have been paying fines through their failure to read the waterfowl regulations before leaving shore.

"Coach, I can tell whenever that Coulter is going to block me. He gets all tensed up just before the ball is snapped," said Phil Ragazzo, second-string right tackle, to Steve Owen of the New York Football Giants in the middle of their scrimmage yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Some 1,000 American ships, most of them slow and many in disrepair, form the pool from which vessels would be drawn if this country should decide to turn surplus shipping over to needy European nations, Government officials said today.

Albert Gross, 64-year-old exconvict who pleaded guilty to extracting exorbitant fees on pier subleases and then gave testimony that helped convict his two former associates, received suspended sentences yesterday that saved him from serving at least five years in prison.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Topics of the Times of Oct. 5, "Our Unchanging Churches," I found most interesting and agree with it only partly. Quoting from the next to the last paragraph: "But there they still are, Fifth Avenue's churches, sturdily challenging the years!

Residents of Tenth Street in Greenwich Village want no part of the interstate traffic that rumbles through the streets of New York in outsize trucks and trailer trucks. Dishes rattle, walls crack and sleep is disturbed when these trucks, bearing mostly the licenses of other states, pass through the narrow sixty-foot street.

In 1950 Wellesley College will be seventy-five years old. Its alumnae, now nearly 20,000, have made their influence felt for the general good in communities throughout our nation and in many foreign countries. They have been leaders in a wide range of the professions, in science, the arts, in good government, social services and in business.
DUBLIN, Oct. 15 -- Premier Eamon de Valera disclosed tonight Government proposals to meet the gravest economic and labor crisis that has confronted this administration yet.

The board of directors of the Radio Manufacturers Association yesterday unanimously adopted a resolution opposing a recent proposal by City Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs calling for mandatory licensing of radio technicians and repairmen in New York City.

President Truman and Congressional leaders were urged yesterday by fifty-one members of Columbia University's Faculty of Political Science to reassemble Congress "at the earliest possible date" to help Europe. The faculty members warned in a telegram that "if much delayed, help will come too late."

While Orban (Spec) Sanders of the New York Yankees continued as the dominating individual performer in the All-America Conference, ranking at or near the top in all the major offensive departments, the weekly statistics of the National Football League show honors to be well distributed.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 15 -- Rumania staged today her own unique spectacle of opening her Parliament with a young king in a soldier's suit reading from the throne a message that had been written by a Communist-dominated Government.

Coach Lou Little of Columbia had kind words for his reserve linemen and his squad's high spirits when the Lions finished a long scrimmage at Baker Field yesterday. The team is preparing for Saturday's meeting with Penn at Franklin Field.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 15 (AP) -- New Jersey received approximately $1,371,000 more in race track revenue for the 1947 season than it got in 1946, the State Racing Commission announced today. The commission reported the state's share from the four tracks this year had reached $7,574,623.16.

Secondaries The revival of volume trading at stable price levels on the New York Stock Exchange is bringing to market a succession of secondary offerings under the management of major underwriters, and therewith a revival of an old point of argument: to what extent should the Exchange approve member participation in secondary distributions of listed stocks?

LOCUST VALLEY, L.L., Oct. 15 -- The Women's Long Island Golf Association met this morning to elect officers for 1948 and followed with a special, one-day tournament at Piping Rock today. An unusually large field of fifty-seven competed over the perfectly groomed layout, with moat of the prizes going to home club players.

The Atlantic District of the Lutheran Women's Missionary League voted yesterday to allot 75 per cent of funds collected in the district to European relief. The district action came after an unexpected debate at its sixth annual convention in the Immanuel Evangelical Lutheran Church, Eightyeighth Street and Lexington Avenue.

LANCASTER, Pa., Oct. 15 -- Much latent resistance to the vast outpouring of aid to Europe implicit in the Marshall plan is being neutralized in the two most financially conservative agricultural areas of the United States by the prospect of the indefinitely high farm profits that would march with that plan.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The National Mediation Board today proposed arbitration of the dispute that caused the recent strike of Railway Express Agency teamsters in New York. The parties said they would reply to the proposal by noon tomorrow.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Britain has all but exhausted her dollar loans and cannot count upon any more credits or borrowing, Sir Stafford Cripps, Minister for Economic Affairs, said at a South Staffordshire Women's Labor party rally today. He added that Britain simply must pay her own way and to do so the nation must diminish her imports and increase her exports.

It is now definite for "Ever Since Paradise," the J.B. Priestley play currently at London's New Theatre, to be Vinton Freedley's first Broadway presentation of the season. The entire British company, headed by Roger Livesey and Ursula Jeans (husband and wife in real life), will be brought over.

The Jewish Board of Guardians child guidance institute served 3,405 children last year, Mrs. Sidney C. Borg, president of the Board of Guardians, announced yesterday at its headquarters, 228 East Nineteenth Street. Although this was a 42 per cent increase over the previous year's caseload, lack of funds forced the agency to turn away 923 applicants.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Early termination of negotiations for the control of the Newark airport and seaport by the Port of New York Authority, under a fifty-year lease, appeared remote today as opposing forces submitted to the city commission 20,000 signatures on petitions demanding a referendum on the controversial issue.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias of Denver led at the half-way mark of medal play in the two-division Hardscrabble women's open golf tournament today with a score of 150 after thirty-six holes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Editorials in THE TIMES have correctly stated that success of the present emergency food effort depends on consumers, business men and farmers receiving definite information about what they should do, supported by an understandable record that compliance is not only a patriotic obligation but self-protection.
ROME, Oct. 15 -- Palmiro Togliatti, Italian Communist leader, today accused President Truman of attempting to impose the American capitalist system on Europe.

Thursday, Oct. 16, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Continued discussion of United States proposal for yearround "Little Assembly" and received Australian proposal to refer it to subcommittee for study; also heard representatives of Uruguay, China, Yugoslavia, Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Turkey and El Salvador.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The stock markets here today made an inauspicious start to the new account. Although speculative buying lifted the gilt-edge group, the industrials again, declined.

The New York Youth Concerts Association presented the first of its series of six symphony concerts for junior and senior high school students yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The program, performed by an orchestra of sixtyfive pieces, with Wheeler Beckett conducting, attracted an audience of more than 2,500 enthusiastic youthful listeners from the New York area.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Five more nations lined up today behind the United States plan for a "Little Assembly" but the Slav group continued to hammer away at the proposal as a scheme that would wreck the chance for any Anglo-American-Soviet cooperation.

By scientific market research, management executives are simplifying complex problems to solve them one-by-one at low cost before downward trends in sales develop within local markets, Charles W. Smith, marketing consultant, McKinsey Company, New York management engineers, told more than 300 members of the American Marketing Association at the Hotel Sheraton yesterday.

Hardware manufacturers reported active ordering by more than 22,000 buyers registered by early afternoon at the opening of the National Hardware Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday. In describing the unexpectedly large influx, Fred Steunkel of Wilson Hardware Manufacturing Company, Chicago, disclosed that in his booth alone more than 150 jobbers, from as far away as Texas and Maine, stopped in to visit within, the first two hours.

The annual report of Northrop Aircraft, Inc., issued to stockholders yesterday by Richard W. Miller, chairman of the board, and John K. Northrop, president, showed a net profit for the year ended with last July of $240,573, out of which a dividend of 25 cents a share was declared for payment yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- There are many persons here who question former Secretary of State James F. Byrnes' judgment in proposing a showdown with Russia in Eastern Germany. First, because it seems a somewhat rash challenge, and second, because it chooses an area of conflict where Russian power is strongest and ours is weakest.
Accounts The John G. Paton Company, makers of Golden Blossom Honey, to Alley Richards, Inc. Newspapers will be used.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 15 -- Liaqat Ali Khan Prime Minister of Pakistan, in a statement from Karachi has set forth Pakistan's understanding that there is to be no deliberate transfer of minority populations in the Punjab, but only an organized evacuation "of those who wish to go."

William H. Jackson, president of the New York Hospital and chairman of the sixty-ninth annual campaign of the United Hospital Fund, issued a statement yesterday in which he emphasized that the voluntary hospitals of New York face today "the most critical emergency in their history."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- As Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and once flag officer to Admiral Halsey, enters the back stretch of the Republican contest for the Presidential nomination next year he is more clearly visible to the grandstand than any of his rivals.

Vincent McHugh's book of poems, "The Blue Hen's Chickens," which the Society to Maintain Public Decency charged was an obscene book, was cleared by a New York County grand jury which voted against returning an information, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Two leading figures in the field of airplane maintenance asked the President's Air Policy Commission today to provide specifically for a place for this arm of the industry in long-range defense programs.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15 -- Levi Jackson has received a clean bill of health, but there will be a new fullback in the starting line-up when Yale plays Wiseonsin in the Bowl Saturday before a crowd prospectively estimated at 70,000.

Stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company approved yesterday an issue of about $360,000,000 of convertible debentures. At the meeting Walter S. Gifford, president, told stockholders that the full $9 annual dividend requirement will have been earned by the end of this year.

The debate at Lake Success over the American proposal for a standing "Little Assembly" to assist the United Nations in guarding world peace has already revealed that in spite of reservations regarding details the great majority has become convinced that some such action is necessary and that the proposal is steadily gaining ground.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The present unusual prosperity will allow the American people to reduce the national debt of $259,750,000,000 and thus strengthen the nation's financial structure "if we have the stamina," Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder said here this afternoon.

BOSTON -- The prepared text of the address by George C. Marshal Secretary of State, to the convention of the Congress of Industrial Organisations here today follows: This is my first opportunity as Secretary of State to discuss our foreign policy before a special gathering of American labor.
RANGOON, Burma, Oct. 15 (U.P) -- Former Premier U Saw and nine others charged with the mass assassination of eight Government Ministers last July 19 went on trial today before a special tribunal.

LONDON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The upper and lower houses of the Convocation of Canterbury were engaged today in drafting an "address to the King," which, in effect, will be an approval of the betrothal of Princess Elizabeth to Lieut. Philip Mountbatten.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is no exaggeration to state that the most important question overhanging the fate of Europe is whether German economy, particularly that of the Ruhr and Rhineland, shall be integrated into a Western European system, or shall be treated as a separate entity without regard to the consequences of such policy to the rest of Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UP) -- The Department of Justice may file a civil anti-trust suit against major investment banking houses, it was disclosed today, in an effort to break up an allegedly illegal system which hampers competition in the underwriting of security issues.

Charging that Local 6 of the Hotel and Club Employes Union, AFL, is dominated by Communists, Miguel Garriga, international vice president of the local's parent organization, urged its members yesterday to oust their present leaders.
The Citizens Union issued yesterday a statement recommending an affirmative vote on Amendment No. 2 to the State Constitution for the extension of absentee voting.

The whole world must have thrilled to the rescue 760 miles off Newfoundland in the North Atlantic by the men of the Coast Guard cutter Bibb of the passengers -- two of them babies -- and the crew of the big Boeing flying boat Bermuda Sky Queen after it had made a sea landing because of a fuel shortage in high seas and near gale winds.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 15 (AP) -- Pentagon Stable's The Doge, a surprise winner, and Greentree Stable's Coincidence, having a good following among approximately 13,500 race fans today, took split divisions of the $10,000 added one-mile Laurel Stakes.

The first list of Japanese import requirements has been received from the supreme commander of the Allied powers in Japan by the Office of International Trade, it was disclosed yesterday at the New York regional office of the Department of Commerce.

Leon Josephson, who as a Communist was part of the pre-war German underground seeking the elimination of Hitler, was jailed yesterday afternoon to begin a one-year sentence for his refusal to testify on March 5 before a subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Oct. 15 (AP) -- A missing Iowa National Guard C-47 transport plane was found smashed against a snow-covered slope of Pike's Peak today, three of its crew dead and four injured.

Riding out of storm-tossed waters into a relatively calm sea, the Coast Guard cutter Bibb was steaming last night from mid-Atlantic for Boston with all sixty-nine passengers and crewmen of the "ditched" flying boat Bermuda Sky Queen safe aboard. Eighteen persons who rode out the night aboard the leaking, derelict plane crowded into a last life raft at dawn yesterday to join their fifty-one companions who had been transferred the night before.

The mid-October rally gained further momentum yesterday, although two flurries of realizing stemmed the force of the advance. Prices rose to the best levels since early August, accompanied by trading which approached the 2,000,000-share mark.
Mayor O'Dwyer called yesterday for the return of Federal price ceilings and food rationing to keep New Yorkers from "going hungry in the midst of plenty because foodstuffs are out of their reach."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- The Soviet Union proposed here today that each displaced persons camp in Europe be ruled by those who "enjoy the confidence" of the Governments whose nationals were in that camp.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 15 -- Contradicting today's statement by Hungarian Premier Lajos Dinnyes that only a cultural agreement had been discussed and signed, an official Yugoslav statement issued here tonight declared that "both countries agreed that in the near future they shall begin discussions with a view to concluding an agreement on mutual aid and friendship.

Slackening the pace of football drills at Fordham yesterday, Coach Ed Danowski conducted a dummy scrimmage during which the freshmen ran through Rutgers' formations. Lack of capable reserves is hindering the Ram mentor in his efforts to arrive at a starting backfield for Saturday's contest at New Brunswick, N.J.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Jaroslav Drobny, Czech ace, and Torsten Johansson of Sweden scored a decisive first-round victory in the men's doubles of the sixth Pan-American tennis tournament today. They defeated J. Gandara and Sebastian Martinez of Mexico, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee, by a vote of 27 to 20, called on the Union of South Africa today to submit a trusteeship agreement on the mandated territory of South-West Africa by next year.

Preparing to face a West Virginia team that ranks among the leaders in almost every offensive department, New York University's football team held an intensive scrimmage with the freshman eleven yesterday at Ohio Field on the University Heights campus.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The White House has decided in favor of an austere social season, with all state dinners canceled, in keeping with the national food-saving campaign.

BOSTON, Mass., Oct. 15 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall declared today that the basic issue in the world was whether men are to be left free to organize their own existence or are to be placed under the dictatorship of small groups of men who have arrogated to themselves arbitrary power.

Nurses as individuals and as a specialized group must break out of their "professional seclusion," recognize the tie-up of politics and everyday life and "be prepared to take the initiative with respect to all economic, social and political problems" affecting their interests, Ralph E. Becker, chairman of the Young Republican National Federation, told a meeting of nurses yesterday.

William H. Clayton has given such unstinted and invaluable service to the Government for seven hard years that perhaps it is ungrateful to cavil at his resignation. Nevertheless we wish he could have stayed at his post until the Marshall proposal is translated into action.

LONDON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Henry Cotton will lead a test line-up of his Ryder Cup team against ten British amateur golf stars tomorrow in a dress rehearsal for the series with the United States professionals at Portland, Ore., just sixteen days away.

DUNFERMLINE, Scotland, Oct. 15 -- The days of cheap coal in Britain are gone forever. A few days' investigation into the coal situation in Scotland, and especially in this rich mining region, is enough to confirm the suspicions that have steadily been forming in London and the industrial northwest.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Retiring today as director of the Institute for Advanced Study here, Dr. Frank Aydelotte touched on some of the high lights of his administration during the last eight years, including his association with Dr. Albert Einstein.

The sixth biennial convention of the National Maritime Union, CIO, one of the longest in the history of labor organizations, closed yesterday afternoon after three and a half weeks of bitter fighting between the forces of Joseph Curran, president, and what he called "Communist - inspired disruptive forces."

MONTREAL, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Maurice Richard and Butch Bouchard, Montreal stars, neither of whom had signed his contract by midafternoon, were named today by Coach Dick Irvin as starters in tomorrow night's game between the Canadians and New York Rangers which opens the local National Hockey League season.
TOULOUSE, France, Oct. 15 -- The Communists are expected to lose some strength in southwest France in the local elections on Sunday next.

WARSAW, Oct. 15 -- Under the Government's benevolent eye leaders of the Communist, Socialist and Peasant youth organizations of Poland have agreed to coordinate their activities, it was learned today.

CINCINNATI, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Brooklyn Dodgers did not deal in Leo Durocher, their former manager, for a share of the world series pot. His name is missing from the lists of players sharing in world series receipts announced today by Walter Mulbry, secretary -treasurer of baseball.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 15 -- Both Catholic secretaries general of the Slovak Democratic party, Dr. Jan Kempny and Dr. Milos Bugar, appeared before the Parliamentary Immunity Committee late this afternoon and asked to have their immunity removed, so that they could stand trial on charges of conspiring against the Czechoslovak state.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 8: Increases of $84,000,000 in commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans and $304,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks, and a decrease of $312,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted.

Brooks Brothers, retailers of men's clothing and furnishings, has leased for use as a downtown branch a large portion of the second floor in the building at 111 Broadway through Douglas Gibbons Co., Inc., brokers. The lessor was represented by the Charles F. Noyes Company, Inc., agent.

Though many Britons appreciate a gift of fresh meat more than anything else, the cost of sending this food air express, which is the only way that guarantees its remaining fresh, has been too great to allow much to go abroad.
LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The fourpower conference on former Italian colonies reached an agreement today on how it would hear the views of the interested Governments on the future of these territories.

A banking syndicate headed by Phelps, Fenn Co. submitted yesterday the highest bid for an issue of $5,000,000 of various purpose bonds of Houston, Tex., maturing from 1948 to 1972. The winning bid was 100.19 for 2s and 2 1/4s, a net interest cost of 2.1391 per cent.

The dates of the matinee series of the new production of Wagner's "Ring" cycle at the Metropolitan this season were announced at the meeting of the Metropolitan Opera Guild held yesterday morning in Town Hall. "Das Rheingold" will be presented Jan. 7; "Die Walkuere," Jan. 13; "Siegfried," Jan. 21, and "Goetterdaemmerung" Jan. 29.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Wage earners who for the last two years have been demanding higher pay were compared today by Paul H. Nystrom, Professor of Marketing at Columbia University, to "boys chasing their shadows."

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- In a communication sent today to the Citizens' Food Committee in Washington, the National Association of Retail Grocers submitted these five specific grounds for a growing conviction that the people of Europe are not doing all they can to help themselves:

A meeting between President Truman and Premier Stalin "before our foreign policy becomes subject to the pressures of a fateful election campaign" was urged in a statement signed by 100 Americans and released by the National Council of American-Soviet Friendship, 114 East Thirty-second Street, yesterday.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 15 -- Fred Astaire will come out of retirement to play opposite Judy Garland in M-G-M's "Easter Parade," the studio announced tonight. Astaire will begin work tomorrow morning, taking the role from which Gene Kelly was eliminated Monday because of a broken ankle.

For seventy-three minutes during yesterday morning's rush hour, 5,000 passengers jammed into three trains of the IRT West Side subway were trapped fifty-one feet below the East River in a tunnel joining Brooklyn and Manhattan.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- Resolutions looking to the creation of international machinery to safeguard the freedom of association of trade unions and to establish minimum standards of living for all the workers of the world were considered today in the Social, Cultural and Humanitarian Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The United States advanced another $50,000,000 toward French economic and political stability today amid indications that more would be found available to the Executive Branch if needed before Congress could appropriate stop-gap emergency relief funds.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Dillon S. Myer, Federal housing official, testified today that Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, had no basis for saying a $26,250 "fraud" had been uncovered on the books of the Federal Public Housing Authority.

DETROIT, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Two goals by Rookie Jim McFadden helped the Red Wings to a 3-0 edge in the second period and Detroit survived a late Chicago rally to beat the Black Hawks, 4 to 2, tonight in the first National Hockey League game of the 1947-48 season.

The New York County Lawyers Association made public yesterday a report of its Committee on the Judiciary, which listed Justice J. Edward Lumbard, Republican and American Labor party candidate for Supreme Court Justice in the First Judicial District, to be "exceptionally well qualified" and urged his election.

The plant of the Industrial Container Corporation in Brooklyn was still held last night by seventythree sit-downers, none of whom intend to appear personally in court this morning in response to a show cause order obtained by the employer.

Formation of a new company, the Cities Service Research and Development Corporation, was announced yesterday by W. Alton Jones, president of the Cities Service Company. The new company, Mr. Jones said, will direct the research activities which have been carried on by individual companies in the Cities Service system for more than thirty years.

Maurice Mumford, executive vice president of the Draft Eisenhower for President League, and Winston H. Thornburg, president of its New York State branch, declared last night that there would be no slowing up of the campaign to make Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower the Republican nominee for President despite reports that he might not be able to retire as Chief of Staff until long after Jan. 1.

PARIS, Oct. 15 -- A strike of seamen and dock hands at all ports in France and Algeria was predicted for tomorrow by leaders of the marine unions after a conference at the Ministry of Transport tonight.

Reappearance of an Old Friend We had not seen our friend Mr. Featherweight Brainstorm for some time when he breezed into our office the other day. He charged straight at our desk, as he always does, with the singleness of purpose of a locomotive.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 15 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Harry S. deVore, president of Central College at Fayette, Mo., died last night of a heart malady while attending a conference of the Methodist Church. He was appointed president in May, 1942.

Early last week the National Labor Relations Board, overruling an earlier decision by its general counsel, decided that top American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations officials were not required to file non-Communist affidavits before individual unions could make use of the collective bargaining machinery of the NLRB under the Taft-Hartley Act.

Gunthers held a showing yesterday noon in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The collection covered a wide field of fashion, starting with the sturdy type of winter suit and coat. An artichoke green coat had a row of self-covered buttons at either side of the skirt.

THERE was an item in yesterday's paper that Dizzy Dean had received his unconditional release from the St. Louis Browns.
