It was merely a formality because the Great Man had been hired to pitch only one game for the lowly Brownies and his appearance on the last day of the season was calculated to act as a shot of adrenalin to a dying box office.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- The telephone industry may require a greater amount of new capital funds in the next five years than any other industry in the United States, R.A. Lumpkin, president of the United States Independent Telephone Association, declared today at the opening of the organization's fiftieth annual convention.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 -- The convention of the American Federation of Labor confirmed today a proposal of its executive council to raise an election year "publicity and education" fund of $1,000,000.

Hilde Somer, who played at Carnegie Hall last night, is developing into one of the best pianists of the younger generation. The temperament and vitality that were so striking six years ago, when she was 19, still give her playing an uncommon force and drive.

TORONTO, Oct. 15 -- The atomic bomb is a "has-been" as a weapon of war. Known methods of bacteriological warfare provide the "final" offensive weapon and enable even a small country to "kill all living persons on any continent very quickly" Dr. G. Brock Chisholm, executive secretary of the World Health Organization, said last night.
Indian Summer resulted yesterday in bringing before Magistrate James M. Fawcett in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, cases ordinarily heard on hot July and August days.

Jobbers and retailers in the market to buy spring underwear are placing substantial orders for first-quarter 1948 deliveries, according to trade sources yesterday. These purchases reflect confidence in current prices, it was pointed out, as well as the desire to avoid being caught without adequate stocks as was the case this fall.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Representatives of the country's brewers and bakers were unable today to work out with the Citizens Food Committee mutually satisfactory plans for voluntary conservation of grain. Charles Luckman, chairman of the committee, said consultations with these groups would go forward tomorrow.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- The Most Rev. Geoffrey F. Fisher, Archbishop of Canterbury, roundly condemned today the views of Dr. Edward W. Barnes, Bishop of Birmingham, who in his book "The Rise of Christianity" discounted the belief in miracles.
Chaplains still are needed in the peacetime Army, Maj. Gen. Luther D. Miller chief of chaplains, declared yesterday.

Controversial storm clouds piled higher over Park Avenue yesterday as a result of the disturbance started by plans for a Greater New York Golden Jubilee in that thoroughfare from April to October, 1948.

MANILA, Oct. 15 -- Declaring that the Philippine Government was financially unable to maintain and guard the various United States wartime military bases turned over to it by the United States Army and Navy, President Manual A. Roxas has asked a group of visiting United States Congressmen to consider a proposal for American financial assistance to provide for the maintenance of these bases for emergency use in connection with Philippine defense plans.

The National Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots, AFL, is preparing an appeal to the Administrator of the Fair Labor Standards Act for reversal of a ruling under which night relief officers on ships are being limited to a forty-hour work week.

John K.M. McCaffrey, moderator on "Author Meets the Critics," plans to essay the role of commentator, too. Beginning next week, he will be heard at 9:15 A.M., Monday through Friday, over WNBC, offering his views on the current films, books, plays, etc.

The New York University Division of General Education will institute an experiment in adult education tonight when it opens at the Louis Marx Toy Manufacturing Company, 200 Fifth Avenue, a course in "How to Read and Think" exclusively for employes of that company.

Herschel V. Johnson, deputy United States representative on the United Nations Security Council, declared yesterday afternoon that the recent invective of Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, would have precipitated a war in any previous generation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- A Free German Army of more than 100,000 men, formed under the Red banner, awaits in the Soviet Union a turn of destiny that would permit it to march back to the German fatherland, it was learned today from official sources.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 15 (AP) -- A hurricane from the Atlantic battered this city with 80-to-100-mile winds and the neighboring Georgia -South Carolina coast with damaging tides and waves today, then blew itself out tonight in south Georgia.

GENEVA, Oct. 15 -- The establishment of a European power grid system and the development of power production without the use of standard coals are two projects chosen for immediate investigation by the Power Committee of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

VALHALLA, N.Y., Oct. 15 -- This unincorporated hamlet in the Bronx River valley, embracing 2,300 persons and five square miles of rolling countryside, recently found that its highway accident rate was threefold higher this year than in 1945.

Like many other colleges in the country today, Wellesley College in Massachusetts has not been able to balance its budget and is using up reserves, Mrs. Mildred McAfee Horton, its president, reported last night.

Only by creating dissatisfaction among the public with the products it now has can industry keep the United States economy functioning at a high level, Paul G. Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation, told a dinner meeting of the Society of Industrial Designers, Inc., in the Hotel Ambassador last night.

The nation's power and light industry expects to meet all demands for electricity this winter, despite an uncomfortably narrow reserve capacity of 5 per cent, according to Charles E. Oakes, president of the Edison Electric Institute.

The new twelve-day meeting of the Metropolitan Jockey Club got off to a bad start yesterday at Jamaica Race Track when a union of grooms and exercise boys staged a strike for union recognition and a written contract.

Successful treatment of 71.4 per cent of children too deeply disturbed to be helped in their own or in foster homes is reported in a study of cases handled over a ten-year period at the Ryther Child Center in Seattle, Wash.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 15 (AP) -- A three-horse blanket finish thrilled 6,844 racing fans in the featured event at Rockingham Park today as Mount Desert Stable's 3-yearold Halomer was adjudged the winner by a nose.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 15 (U.P.) -- President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla and Defense Minister Guillermo Barrios assured striking coal miners today that their lives and jobs would be protected from the "Communist pressure and terror" that is keeping them from returning to the pits.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 15 -- Whatever attitude Britain may take, David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine told Hebrew newspaper men in Tel Aviv today: "Judah will arise anew as an independent state and the Jews will return freely to their own land."

Lenin, a slight man with a high, domed forehead and piercing eyes, was the giant of the early twentieth century. His ideological philosophy and his political policy were and remain the basic guides to Moscow policy today. In January of this year, Georgi D. Aiexandrov, head of the Communist party propagandist bureau in the U.S.S.R., publicly and flatly reasserted this.

TOLEDO, Oct. 15 -- With no end in sight to the spiraling of motor vehicle prices, their continuing upswing eventually will strip the automotive market of hundreds of thousands of potential buyers, James D. Mooney, president of Willys-Overland Motors, said today at the annual institutional program of the company.

CHICAGO, Oct. 15 -- Otto Kerner Jr., United States attorney, received leave today from Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy to file an amended criminal information charging James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, with violation of the Lea Act, which prohibits coercion of broadcasters by unions.

A powerful merchant marine for the country's peacetime economy and for its defense in emergency was the theme of speakers in opening sessions of the twenty-first convention of the Propeller Club of the United States at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed irregular yesterday, 13 points lower than the day before on October and 7 to 16 points net higher on the other months.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 15 -- A beam of neutron radiation so powerful that it required the erection of a ten-foot concrete wall to protect the scientists working with it has provided the first experimental evidence on the nature of the forces binding the neutrons and protons inside the nuclei of atoms -- in other words, the fundamental forces underlying the very existence of the physical universe.

Three ranking officials of the Young Women's Christian Association in Queens have resigned, it was disclosed yesterday, with two of them joining in charges that the national policy of the organization and its national offices were tainted with Communist or Left-Wing tendencies.

An attendance of 14,000,000 youngsters and adults was recorded in the last year by the summer playground, after-school recreation and community center programs of the division of community education of the Board of Education. In a report yesterday to Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, Mark A. McCloskey, the division's director, described extracurricular activities ranging from swimming classes to orchestras.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, contended today that the country is confronted with excessively high prices "as a direct result of the policies followed by the Administration for a decade and a half -- policies which were aggravated, but not created, by the war."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth S. Wherry of Nebraska, chairman of the Senate Small Business Committee, said today that the committee will bare the "full facts" behind the proposed export of critically short steel pipe to the Middle East even if it cannot stop the shipments.

CAMDEN, N.J., Oct. 15 -- Attorney General Walter D. Van Riper's authority to conduct the investigation into gambling and alleged police laxity in Camden County was upheld today in Common Pleas Court by Judge R.A. Sheehan.

ATHENS, Oct. 15 -- The threat by Napoleon Zervas, former Minister of Public Order, to call out his "Nationalist Andartes" [Mountain Fighters] to fight Communists, if the Government persists in its "appeasement" policy was derided in Government circles today as mere talk and a political maneuver.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The resignation of William L. Clayton as Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs was officially announced by the White House today. It became effective at 6 o'clock tonight.

The nation's gasoline stocks at the close of last week increased 595,000 barrels to 82,202,000 barrels from 81,607,000 barrels in the previous week, but were 5,522,000 barrels below the corresponding week of 1946, when stocks at refineries totaled 87,724,000 barrels, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.
MONTREAL, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The New York Rangers, striking swiftly when opportunity offered, defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 2-1, here tonight in the opening game of the National Hockey League season.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 16 -- With John L. Lewis and his United Mine Workers delegation absenting themselves from the convention, William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor since 1924, was re-elected today for another year's term.

Two Queens families -- one that of a winner of the Medal of Honor -- lost their homes yesterday. The five members of the family of Tech. Sgt. Joseph E. Schaefer, including two brothers who also are veterans, scattered to live with relatives and friends in Queens and New Jersey.

Many tickets have been purchased for the benefit performance of "An Inspector Calls," a new play by J.B. Priestley, next Wednesday night at the Booth Theatre, which has been, taken over by persons interested actively in the work of the Bethany Day Nursery.

Representatives of American business leadership will leave for Paris beginning today to participate in the study of the proposed World Trade Charter, which will be conducted Nov. 5 by the Council of the International Chamber of Commerce.

With Fordham's football squad already sorely depleted toy injuries, Coach Ed Danowski learned yesterday that Lou Mauro, reserve fullback and No. 2 passer, would be lost for tomorrow's contest with Rutgers. A report on the condition of Bob Burke disclosed that the Rams' starting quarterback suffered a concussion and a punctured ear drum in the Penn State game and would be lost for the season.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- President Truman today attributed much of the increases in food cost to gambling on the grain exchanges and revealed that Attorney General Tom C. Clark was investigating them.

A thick "sea fog" that closed down over the city yesterday tied up shipping in the harbor, disrupted airline schedules at La Guardia Field and delayed ferry service from twelve minutes to seven hours until it cleared in the late morning.

ARMY vs. V.P.I. -- If you want to scramble the order of those initials, it could easily be switched to V.I.P. or Very Important Persons, which Virginia Polytechnic definitely is not -- at least in a football way. The main value of this epic struggle is that it should give Red Blaik a chance to wind up his attacking forces and send them spinning down the field.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

The Pan American World Airways Clipper America, making the last leg of a flight from London with one of its motors inoperative, arrived over La Guardia Field shortly after noon yesterday and was held in the "stack" for fortytwo minutes before a safe landing was made.

GENEVA, Oct. 16 -- The British Cabinet has approved the Anglo-American tariff settlement, thus assuring completion of the eighteen -nation trade agreement before the end of October, it was learned authoritatively here today.

Enlarged activities brought on by the war have placed the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross "on the threshold of a new era," Colby M. Chester, chairman, asserted yesterday at the organization's forty-first annual meeting in the chapter house, 315 Lexington Avenue.

Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, announced last night that CED is expanding and stepping up the tempo of its research and planning program to help prevent a major depression in the Nineteen Fifties.
A tempest in a teapot is a mild means of describing the furor caused by five Massachusetts hunters who came back from Nova Scotia with their limit of deer.

DETROIT, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The American Council of Christian Churches today assailed Russia as "a voracious insatiable tyrant bent upon the enslavement of the peoples of the earth" and accused the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America of "peddling" Marxian doctrine.

An independent stockholders' committee, headed by Joseph D. McGoldrick, former City Controller, is soliciting proxies for the Thompson-Starrett Company, Inc., annual meeting to be held on Nov. 24. The committee plans to vote its proxies in favor of a slate of eleven directors, none of whom is now a member of the board.

LAUREL. Md., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Paradise Farm's Dog O'Sullivan closed with a fine burst of speed to beat Boojie by three parts of a length in the mile and seventyyard featured Columbia Purse at Laurel Park today.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Leaders of the Church of England opposed today a resolution welcoming the United States of Europe "with a common foreign, military and economic policy."

With strategy dictating an allout aerial attack by New York University in its game against powerful West Virginia at the Yankee Stadium tomorrow. Coach Edward B. (Hook) Mylin rejoiced yesterday in the news that Jerry Eisenman, the ace passer of the Violets, would be ready for at least part-time service.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Mrs. Mary D. DuBois of Salem, re-elected today as president of the New Jersey Women's Christian Temperance Union, said it was a reasonable request that "liquorless" days be added to the present national food conservation program.

Friday, October 17, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Poland and White Russia opposed United States proposal for year-round "Little Assembly," Greece, the Netherlands and India supported it and Lebanon and Sweden reserved judgment.
By contrast with Wednesday's inaugural when the card was riddled by withdrawals, racing at Jamaica assumed a normal basis yesterday with good-sized fields.

Reversal of the trend toward integrated operation in the cotton textile industry has reached the point where upward of 40 per cent of woven cottons are sold in the gray, it was learned yesterday in Worth Street. Just prior to price decontrol, it was estimated that less than 25 per cent of total cotton textile output was sold as gray goods in the primary market.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 16 -- Senator Robert A. Taft and Harold Stassen made a double-barreled attack on the Democratic party from the same rostrum tonight.

Ample supplies of all classes of meat arriving in wholesale markets here, coupled with a small demand, make it possible for stores this week-end to feature many cuts at prices from 2 to 8 cents less than those for last Friday. Shoppers also will notice a downward trend in the tariffs on broilers, fryers and roasters as well as butter, all of which dropped 2 cents a pound from their average a week ago.

FORT SMITH, Ark., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Zaharias of Denver shot a 68-eleven under women's par and three under men's par -- today to take a sevenstroke lead in the medal division of the Hardscrabble Country Club's women's open golf tournament.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- French Foreign Minister Bidault said at a press conference today there was a possibility that the Paris aid conference might be resumed. At the same time he expressed his personal regrets at the resignation of William L. Clayton, United States Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.

Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh returned yesterday on the French liner De Grasse after a two-month visit to France, England and Germany to gather material for a series of magazine articles. She said that everyone coming from Europe has the same impression -- that the United States must send food and other help immediately.

Two hundred representatives of educational and welfare agencies and trustees of the Hudson Guild attended yesterday the dedication of the guild's new day-care nursery in Unit Two at the John Lovejoy Elliott housing project, 455 West Twenty-sixth Street.
ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that a false charge that a person is a Communist, or is a Communist sympathizer, is basis for a libel action.
A Federal Recreation Service to coordinate the recreation programs of states was advocated yesterday by Mrs. Eugene Meyer of Washington at the National Recreation Congress in the Hotel New Yorker.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- This Government has abandoned plans to reconvene the Committee for European Economic Cooperation to remedy deficiencies in its Paris report on the Marshall plan, it was learned today. Instead, the Administration plans to make whatever revisions may be required in the Paris estimates and present them to Congress as a joint effort.

Under the combined pressure of rising relief needs and rising living costs, the Welfare Department has informed the city that it will require $224,000,000 for the year beginning July 1, an increase of $82,000,000 over the current relief budget, it was learned yesterday.

Arnold F. Kivi. 26-year-old former Army sergeant who stole confidential photographs from the atomic installations in Los Alamos, N.M., wa sentenced yesterday to eighteen months imprisonment in a Federal penitentiary by Judge Mortimer W. Byers in Federal Court, Brooklyn.

The public has been over-sold on hospitalization and under-sold on the importance of preventive health measures, Miss Mary Ella Chayer, Associate Professor of Nursing Education, Teachers College, Columbia University, declared yesterday.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Oct. 16 -- A new concept of the functions of flour constituents which may revolutionize and simplify flour chemistry as applied to baking, starch-processing and other industries, has been evolved by J.W.R. Byfield and his assistant, J. Clarkson, of Christchurch, it was disclosed today.
SALEM, N.H., Oct. 16 (AP) -- C. Lussky's Spirsilla won her first race in two years at Rockingham Park today when she took the featured Greenwich Purse.

The report of the American Brake Shoe Company issued to shareholders yesterday by William B. Given Jr., president, showed net earnings for the first nine months of this year totaling $3,525,199 after taxes and all charges.

The City Planning Commission's proposal to finance construction of seven new school buildings and a number of parks and playgrounds outside the city's constitutional debt limit as adjuncts of low-cost housing projects came under heavy fire yesterday at a public hearing on the proposed 1948 capital budget of $252,680,090.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 11 were 8 per cent above those in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of last year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Campaigning began here today by the Y.M.C.A. for $330,000 to finance an expansion program that would establish the White Plains "Y" as one of the most comprehensive small-city youth organizations in the country.

The Aetna Industrial Corporation has completed negotiations for the purchase of all outstanding capital stock of the Oscar Heineman Corporation of Chicago, fifty-four-year-old yarn-processing enterprise, Walter W. Weisman, chairman of the board of Aetna Industrial, announced yesterday.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Moscow observers said today that the current State Planning Commission report indicated the Soviet Union will have several million tons of grain for export this fall and winter.

The board of governors of the Commodity Exchange, Inc., announced yesterday that a committee has been appointed to study and revise, where necessary, the Exchange's raw silk futures contract. Action of the board was prompted by the expectation that trading in the commodity, suspended since July 25, 1941, "for purposes of national defense," soon may be resumed.

ROME, Oct. 16 -- The Left Wing socialist party, after three days of discussion by its executive committee, announced today that it would continue to work hand in glove with the Communists and that the "unity of action pact" binding it to the Communist party would remain in force.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and closed irregular, 7 points higher to 5 points net lower than on Tuesday.
Bernard Litvak, manager of fabrics and patterns at L. Bamberger Co., has been promoted to merchandise assistant to Harry Zucker, executive vice president of ready-to-wear.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Average primary market prices increased 0.6 per cent with higher prices in most commodity groups during the week ended on Oct. 11, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Commerce.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- December wheat advanced 5 3/4 cents a bushel from yesterday's closing price to $3.05 in the early trading on the Board of Trade today, equaling the highest price at which any future has sold since 1917. It showed 30 1/2 cents above the low on Oct. 6, or the day before the Exchanges raised initial margin requirements on speculative trades to 33 1/3 per cent of the purchase price.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Following is the text of a British resolution proposed to the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee today on the establishment of an interim committee to serve while the Assembly is not in session:

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 16 -- Vaclaw Nosek, Communist Minister of the Interior, rushed to the tribune of Parliament today and, amid jeers directed by Communist Deputies at members of other parties, charged one of the Slovak Democrat party leaders, Fedor Hodza, with participating in the destruction of evidence of sedition in the office of Deputy Premier Jan Ursiny, a Slovak Democrat.

With shoe manufacturers in a quandary as to pricing policies for spring, indications are that a number of producers will show new lines on an open price basis with quotations effective as of date of shipment. This suggestion has been advanced in trade quarters as one way of meeting the present situation and is expected to be evidence at the National Shoe Fair in Chicago from Oct. 27 to 31, inclusive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- President Truman, at his news conference today, described his current voluntary food-conservation program as an attempt to accomplish under free enterprise something which police states could carry out only by compulsion of individuals.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Sixteen spokesmen for business, commerce, aviation and taxpayers, linked today the future development of this city with its willingness to approve the Port of New York Authority plan for the airport and seaport here, which it proposes to take over under a fifty-year lease.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- A reduction of nearly 60 per cent in the number of plants to be dismantled in the United States and British zones was announced today as a result of the upward revision of permissible industrial production in western Germany.

ALBANY, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Conservation Department said today the forest-fire hazard was "growing more serious hourly," as unseasonably warm, dry weather continued. Actual timber fires were reported under control. Fire fighters still were combating sub-surface conflagrations.

Its 1,000,000th charity patient was received yesterday at the Foot Clinic of New York, 55 East 124th Street, an organization chartered under the State Department of Social Welfare and caring since 1910 for sufferers from chronic foot ailments.

The overwhelming impression of last night's concert of the Philharmonic -Symphony in Carnegie Hall was Mr. Stokowski's reading of the Tchaikovsky Fifth Symphony. This was so in spite of the familiarity of the symphony, and in spite of the fact that Mr. Stokowski took his own way with the score, changing details, altering tempi beyond anything indicated by the composer.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- The United Kingdom urged the United Nations here today to begin at once to establish a suitable authority to take over the administration of Palestine and usher in its independence.
CARMEL, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Slaughter W. Huff, former president of the Third Avenue Transit Corporation and its affiliated companies in New York, died this evening at his home here. His age was 80.

LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Just like everyone else, the royal family is having trouble over the invitations to the wedding on Nov. 20 of Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten, trouble complicated by public kibitzing.

Gitz Rice, who wrote two of the memorable songs of the first World War, "Dear Old Pal of Mine" and "Keep Your Head Down, Fritzie Boy," died yesterday afternoon in his home at the Hotel Winslow, 45 East Fifty-fifth Street. He was 56 years old.

A bold attempt by an 18-year-old Dane to enter this country as a United States citizen was revealed yesterday in an indictment handed up in Federal Court, Brooklyn. The prisoner, John Ohlson, who arrived at Staten Island last Sept. 19 from Bremen as a stowaway aboard the Nelson W. Aldrich, allegedly used stolen credentials in carrying out his role.

The pace of the advance in the stock market was slowed yesterday as the list met profit-taking. The close left the price index about at the level of Wednesday's figure. Only a few wide price changes were recorded, fractional alterations predominating in a session marked by selective strength in the industrials and oils, and weakness in the rails and utilities.

Samuel Bacon Murdock, general passenger agent since 1930 of the Seaboard Air Line Railroad, with offices at 12 West Fifty-first Street, died early yesterday morning in Polyclinic Hospital after an illness of several months. His home was at the Hotel Sheraton.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- The British delegation unexpectedly put forward its own plan for a United Nation "Little Assembly" tonight, narrowing down the original United States plan, but agreeing with it in essentials and principles.

Gustav Rasmussen, Danish Minister of Foreign Affairs, arriving here last night on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth, declared that he planned to discuss with Secretary of State, George C. Marshall the withdrawal of United States forces from Greenland.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Frankie Parker of Los Angeles and Francisco Segura of Ecuador, seeded first and third, moved into the semi-finals of the sixth Pan American tennis tournament today with victories over Armando Vieyra, Brazilian champion, and Francisco Guerrero Arcocha of Mexico, respectively.

NANKING, Oct. 16 -- Authoritative sources predicted today that Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer's report on China, which has not yet been made public, would contain a proposal for substantial aid to the National Government based on streamlining the oversized Chinese Army.

So many of the difficulties within the United Nations reside in the breach between the Western democracies and the Soviet Union that other basic differences may pass unnoticed. Yet one of these divergencies becomes steadily more apparent: that existing between a cautious and preoccupied West and a growing body of Oriental opinion which sees the United Nations as a means of satisfying national aspirations.

The egg was dropped yesterday from the fare of many restaurants where the serving of eggs one week earlier had marred the observance of the first poultryless and eggless Thursday of President Truman's food conservation program.

Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican, of New Jersey, co-author of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law, said last night he would offer at the next session of Congress a proposal making it a Federal offense "to interfere with the civil rights of any worker to go to his job if he so desires."
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16 -- How two Yale University experts on alcoholism sought to exonerate a dead airline pilot of guilt in a fatal crash last summer was revealed today.

The Civil Aeronautics Board got ready yesterday to conduct a "thorough" two-sided inquiry into the operations of the Bermuda Sky Queen, the huge Boeing flying boat that was forced down in the mid-Atlantic Tuesday when its fuel ran low.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Small Business Advisory Commitee of the Department of Commerce recommended today modification of tax policies affecting business, a study of the applicability of union contracts to small enterprises and undertaking of a program to guide nation-wide indutrial mobilization.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 16 -- Vigorous opposition to the Communist party, to the lowering of immigration bars and to the Federal housing program was voiced tonight by James F. O'Neil of Manchester, N.H., national commander of the American Legion.

The State Labor Department is preparing a bill for the next session of the Legislature that would guarantee a minimum wage to the 200,000 domestic servants in New York State, State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi said yesterday.

Even now when the theatre, often regarded as a fabulous invalid, is supposed to be staggering, the powers-that-be are a their wits-end trying to find a house large enough to shelter the celebrated D'Oyly Carte Opera Company.

BOSTON, Oct. 16 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, predicted today that the American Federation of Labor would cooperate with the CIO and the railway unions in the political field for the 1948 campaign.

TSINAN, China, Oct. 15 (Delayed) -- Despite recent Government military gains over the Communists in Shantung, a permanent victory over the Reds in this key North China province cannot be regarded as a certainty.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Notre Dame and the University of Michigan tonight were extended bids to the first Great Lakes Bowl game which the Knights of Columbus plan to hold here in December.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 16 -- Studies on purified viruses offering the first experimental evidence that the process of mutation, fundamental mechanism underlying evolution, may some day be brought about by chemical means were described here today at the centennial celebration on Yale University's Sheffield Scientific School.

BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- At least one of the two concessions the French demanded when rebuffed on a protest against the upward revision of the industrial level in the United States and British zones has been granted by the United States and Britain, it was learned today.

The Republican organizations in the city joined formally yesterday in the fight for repeal of proportional representation. This action, following that of Democratic party leaders, placed both major party political machines in the forefront of the move to end the system, with the substitution in its stead of a system of electing Councilmen from the twenty-five Senatorial districts inside the city on the basis of formal party nominations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- France was advised today that the United States would transfer to the French Government thirty-one former German naval ships and a 40,000-ton floating dock that had belonged to Germany. The ships were awarded to this country by the tripartite naval commission set up during the Potsdam conference.
An emissary arrived yesterday from the land of the Brobdingnagians bearing gifts for Lou Little and his Lilliputians.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Michigan's mighty Wolverines, thrice victorious by lopsided scores in pre-season games, open their Big Nine football championship campaign Saturday top-heavy favorites to wallop injury weakened Northwestern and keep their eyes glued on a Rose Bowl battle on Jan. 1.

PARIS. Oct. 16 -- A break in the ranks of the subway and bus strikers, who had tied up Paris transport since Tuesday, came today when the independent and Catholic unions voted to return to work. Two bus lines resumed operations this afternoon, and more buses and some trains were expected to run tomorrow.

Charles A. Hilms, 50 years old, vice president and general manager of the Triboro Coach Corporation of Queens, which has been seeking financial aid from the city, fell or jumped to his death yesterday afternoon from a washroom on the twenty-eighth floor of the forty-eight-story Continental Bank Building at 30 Broad Street.

Utility Investment Forums The first in a series of two-day round-table meetings to discuss relations with holders of utility securities got under way yesterday at the Irving Trust Company when senior executives of the bank met officers of utility companies, investment houses and leading statistical organizations.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 16 (U.P.) -- A Government announcement tonight said the thirteen-day general coal miners strike had virtually ended at 3:30 P.M. when the miners had begun a mass movement back to the pits.

America has the ships and the operating machinery to implement the Marshall foreign aid plan regardless of its scope, Vice Admiral William Ward Smith, chairman of the United States Maritime Commission, declared yesterday.

The Park Association of New York City indicated informally yesterday that it is opposed to the idea of the Park Avenue parkway strip from Forty-sixth to Fifty-seventh Streets being taken over for Grover Whalen's project for a Greater New York Golden Jubilee next year.

Developments yesterday on two widely separated fronts in the food campaign pointed up the seriousness of that situation, both in its world-wide and its domestic aspects. From Moscow it was reported that the Soviet Union's grain harvest this year would be 58 per cent greater than that of 1946.
Underwriting managers here announced yesterday offerings of more than $12,010,000 of securities to the public, or to stockholders, as follows:
While roller skating in the park yesterday, Little Mike, the trained chimpanzee, got into trouble for the first time during his year's residence at the Central Park Zoo.

THERE is a convention carefully observed by some authors that if they write anything about India, whether fiction or journalism, they must make their politics absolutely clear. If they have not included a chapter denouncing the British Raj and all its works and another chanting the praises of the Congress party, or two chapters reversing these opinions, they feel that they have let their readers down.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- An expert on the economies of the building construction industry testified today that enforcement of unions own decisions in jurisdictional disputes was preferable to adjudication by a Government agency.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 16 -- "Gallows Hill," a photoplay described as a free adaptation of Nathaniel Hawthorne's "The Scarlet Letter," will be the first of three pictures which Albert J. Cohen and Jack Goldberg have contracted to produce for United Artists release, it was learned today.

Hoping for the best, and hoping that the best will be the kind of football he believes his team is capable of playing, Cliff Battles sent his football Dodgers through their final workout yesterday in preparation for their battle with the Buffalo Bills on Ebbets Field at 8:30 tonight.

DETROIT, Oct. 16 -- Although automotive production this year will be the third largest civilian output in the history of the industry, as estimated today by the Automotive Manufacturers Association, there still remains a need for about 7,000,000 motor vehicles which must be met before normal marketing conditions can prevail.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- The United States and Britain gave their support today to a French resolution accepting the protections and rights for trade unions that forty-four nations laid down as basic principles at the International Labor Conference in Geneva last summer.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- Richard F. Uhlmann, first vice president of the Chicago Board of Trade, said today that President Truman's comments on American grain exports were "definitely not in accord with the facts." He was replying to a statement by the President in Washington attributing much of increased food costs to speculation in grain.
PARIS, Oct. 16 -- The Manufacturers and Wholesalers Association of San Francisco gave a world premiere showing of spring models today in the ballroom of the Hotel Georges V.

Headed by Miss Peggy Lodge, a London school teacher, the All-England field hockey team arrived on the Queen Elizabeth yesterday for a fifteen-game tour which will carry it through eight states. Fifteen players and a coach, Miss Dulcie Scougal of Scotland, made up the party.

Packages which look good at close hand may be obscure when viewed by television, James H. Nash, package design counsel for a number of food manufacturers, warned yesterday. This factor takes on added significance, he said, with the increase of television installations.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct 16 -- In a memorandum opinion, the Securities and Exchange Commission rejected today the motion of its public utility division that the reorganization plan of American Light and Traction Company be disapproved on the grounds that it does not constitute an expeditious method of compliance with section 11 of the Holding Company Act.

With motion pictures taken at the rate of 3,000 exposures a second and shown in slow motion, the Sperry Gyroscope Company and the Museum of Natural History combined interests yesterday to solve a mystery at least fifty million years old -- the question of how a fly flies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- Vulnerabilty to enemy attack, loss of heavy industry to the ocean coasts and a continued population shrinkage as compared to average national growth are prices the Middle West is risking for lack of a modern St. Lawrence waterway.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 11 were 956,862 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 14,329 cars or 1.5 per cent more than for the preceding week, 57,419 cars or 6.4 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 202,303 cars or 26.8 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.
TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 16 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll pledged today the cooperation of New Jersey citizens in the national food conservation program.

Incensed over the refusal of a group of horsemen to compromise a labor dispute with their grooms and exercise boys, Mayor O'Dwyer was reported last night as ready to call for the abolition of horse racing in New York City.

ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- Dr. Herman E. Hilleboe, chairman of the New York State Food Commission, announced today that the group opposes rationing within the state, but that it will study the question "as needs and resources change."

From Duluth comes the news that at Beaver Bay, Minn., on the north shore of Lake Superior, a plant is to be erected at a cost of $77,000,000 which is to concentrate high-grade iron ore from taconite. The immense deposits of iron ore in the Mesabi range, deposits which have been dug up with steam-shovels alone, were once washed out of taconite, a rock.

Federal Judge John Hartigan sentenced Salvator'e Tannuzzo, truck driver, of 160 Liberty Avenue, Brooklyn, to fifteen years in prison yesterday after he had been found guilty of the hijacking last Nov. 19 of a truckload of furs valued at $60,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today set dates for eight hearings at various points on the pending petition of the railroads for increased freight rates of 38 per cent in the east and 28 per cent elsewhere.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- During the week ended Oct. 15, member bank reserve balances increased $87,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
LONDON, Oct. 16 -- Although business in stock markets here today was on the small side, the tone was slightly more cheerful.

Continuing their steady climb, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $101,000,000 last week to another new high of $4,810,000,000. According to the data for the week ended on Wednesday, released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, a wide variety of borrowings was included in the total.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 16 -- The Dominion of India will reinforce troops surrounding the princely state of Junagadh which has acceded to Pakistan by landings tomorrow at the port of Jafarabad on the southeastern side of Kathiawar Peninsula.

Buffalo's 20-15 victory over Baltimore in an All-America Conference football game at Buffalo last Sunday was written into the record books officially yesterday by Commissioner Jonas H. Ingram, who declined to sustain a four-point protest lodged by the Baltimore club, The Associated Press reported.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 16 -- Marking another step in American interest in South-African gold mines, a new company known as South Africa Mines Selection, Ltd., was registered here today with capital of $10,000,000 in 5,000,000 shares of $2 each.

El Paso, Tex., awarded various bond issues aggregating $3,970,000 due Dec. 1 from 1948 to 1947 to National City Bank and associates at a bid of 2.4997 per cent for a combination of interest rates resulting in a net interest cost of 2.4997 per cent.
ROCKFORD, Ill., Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Navy Club of the U.S.A. announced today that it would sponsor a campaign for refitting the Constellation, oldest ship of the United States Navy now afloat.

About one-third of the outstanding dollar bonds of the Kingdom of Denmark's 6 per cent issue due in 1942 will be paid off on Dec. 1 with the proceeds of a credit of $7,000,000 obtained by Denmark last month from Swiss banking houses, according to an announcement made here yesterday by Count Benedict Ahlefeldt-Laurvig, financial counselor of the Danish Embassy in the United States.

LONDON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Playing with the big American ball, Henry Cotton's Ryder Cup team beat a team of amateurs today but found plenty of gaps to be filled before the real showdown with United States professionals at Portland, Oregon, Nov. 1 and 2.
SHREVEPORT, La., Oct. 16 (AP) -- William D. (Pol) Perritt, former pitcher for the New York Giants of the National League, died here last night at the age of 55.

PARIS, Oct. 16 -- Two hundred tapestries representing the production of five centuries of French art have been lent by the French Government for exhibition in the United States at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, it was announced officially today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 -- Large quantities of fruit and vegetables rotted, on trees and in the ground in Germany during last summer because adequate materials were not available for home canning, Miss Jane C. Ebbs of the subsistence division in the office of the Quartermaster General at Washington, told the American Dietetic Association today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The country's brewers agreed tonight to limit their use of grain including a 25 per cent cut in corn consumption, without necessarily lessening the output of beer and ale, the Citizens Food Committee announced.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 16 -- Over Soviet opposition, a sub-committee of the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee approved today a draft trusteeship agreement on the Pacific isle of Nauru, which had been submitted to the United Nations by Australia, New Zealand and the United Kingdom.

The wave of strikes in France is timed to preface the municipal elections next Sunday. There is ample economic ground for the workers' demands for increased wages in the inflationary spiral that is squeezing all the purchasing power out of the franc, but the timing of the strikes is certainly political.

ATHENS, Oct. 16 -- Representatives Donald L. Jackson, Republican, from Santa Monica, Calif., and Olin D. Teague, Democrat, from Bryan, Tex., returned from a seven-day tour of the Greek frontier regions today with the prediction that "unless there is some offensive action by the army, the guerrilla fighters are going to take over."

ALBANY, Oct. 16 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey issued a proclamation today closing the drought-ridden Adirondack forests to the public. He proposed, however, that open hunting seasons be extended, where feasible, by the number of days lost.

Stabilization of building costs, rather than their reduction, is essential in tackling the housing problem, according to Max H. Foley, architect and member of a special committee appointed by the American Institute of Architects to confer with a Congressional committee.

The fortieth annual convention of the American Mission to Lepers, Inc., paid tribute last night to William Jay Schieffelin, for forty years president of the organization, at a dinner given at the Henry Hudson Hotel. Dr. Emory Ross, executive secretary of the Africa Committee of the Foreign Missions Conference of North America, presided.
CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
HAWICK, Scotland, Oct. 16 -- Scotland is going fashionable and modern -- even in the traditional woolen trade that has made the name of tweed from this historic borderland so famous.

BISMARCK, N.D., Oct. 16 -- ThE first step toward coordinating the programs of all Federal and state agencies for flood control and development of the Missouri Riveir Basin and presenting to Congress a definite outline of over-all financial needs was taken today in an unexpected move by the Missouri Basin Inter-Agency Committee.

So long as Russia has a chance to talk "with the whole world listening," the Soviets will not withdraw from the United Nations, Dorothy Kenyon, United States delegate to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, declared yesterday at a luncheon at the Town Hall Club.

A new series featuring classical music and information about the world of books is announced for a premiere on Nov. 1 over WQXR. Presented jointly by the station and the Doubleday book stores, it will be heard from 2:05 to 3 P.M. Saturdays.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 16 --To further finance the largest construction programs in the history of the company and its subsidiaries, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering the issuance of up to $360,000,000 of 10-year, 2 3/4 per cent convertible debentures, dae Dec. 15, 1957.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 16 (AP) -- Turpentine 62 1/2C; offerings, 122 barrel; sales, 2 barrels; no receipts: shipments 24 barrels; stocks 10,791 barrels.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The flood of memoirs on events of the past epochal decade has barely begun. Hence the inevitable phase of controversy has not been reached. But those books which have been published thus far, or are in process of publication, include accounts of conversations and incidents which will certainly be challenged as to truth and accuracy by persons who appear unfavorably in the chronicles.
OCt. 16......251.0 220.3 272.7 333.2 328.2 205.1 The Index Is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials.

Record-breaking attendance by dealers continued at the National Hardware Show at Grand Central Palace yesterday, but surprising developments in improved deliveries sharpened buying interests still further, retailers and wholesalers said. Prompt deliveries on electrolytic tin-plated steel sheets, offered by Joseph Wiseman, president of Gary-Pioneer Steel Corporation, Gary, Ind., were cited as a typically noteworthy disclosure of the exposition.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Oct. 16 -- Turkey was described as a "bulwark of defense" for democracy in the Near East and Mediterranean by Henry Villard, representing the State Department at ceremonies here this afternoon, marking the delivery of the first of eighty-eight locomotives being built by the Vulcan Iron Works of Wilkes-Barre for the Turkish Government.

MANVILLE, N.J., Oct. 16 -- The first large laboratory and pilot plant building of an ultra-modern research center which the Johns-Manville Corporation is erecting on a ninety-three-acre tract across the Raritan River from its factory here was opened for inspection today by a large group of distinguished scientists and research directors from other companies and by editors and writers of New York and New Jersey.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

JERUSALEM, Oct. 16-An invitation from David Ben-Gurion, chairman of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, to the two Jewish terrorist forces to disband and join in defense of the Palestine Jewish community against Arab military threats was published in the Hebrew press today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 -- While reiterating his prediction that he would go into the Republican National Convention next year with "at least" 100 delegates from six states in the Upper Mississippi Valley, Harold E. Stassen, former Governor of Minnesota and the only avowed Presidential candidate, said today he had not decided whether to enter the Illinois preference Presidential primary.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

Are Manners Deteriorating? Soviet Russia's fiery Deputy Foreign Minister, Andrei Y. Vishinsky, has won widespread notoriety at meetings of the General Assembly of the United Nations by his addiction to what has been called on this page "debate by insult," in which he has been efficaciously assisted by Delegate Ales Bebler of Yugoslavia, a young newcomer in the ranks of Slavic foes of politeness.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission announced today the establishment of a division of raw materials, and appointed Dr. John K. Gustafson of Salt Lake City as its director.

A far-reaching change in City College's tactics on offense was indicated by Coach Harold J. Parker after the conclusion of a keenly waged two-hour scrimmage between first-stringers and reserves yesterday at Lewisohn Stadium. Most important feature of the new pattern of attack is the abandonment of the kicking game which the Beavers' mentor had stressed in the team's first three contests.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- The problem of the two-year deadlock over Korean independence and the withdrawal of American and Russian troops from that country was dropped into the lap of the United Nations by the United States today.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Australia has offered to sell 75,000,000 bushels of wheat and flour to the United Kingdom, John Strachey, Minister of Food, announced today.

ROME, Oct. 17 -- The Cabinet took today what it believed to be an important step toward the "pacification of all Italians" by having approved a bill reinstating all Government employes who had been dismissed after the war's end on charges of having been Fascists.

Brooklyn's Dodgers of the AllAmerica Football Conference played their best game of the season and achieved a 14-14 deadlock with the Buffalo Bills at Ebbets Field last night. To accomplish that, the Brooks needed a recordbreaking 84-yard touchdown run from scrimmage by Hunchy Hoernschemeyer, who joined them in the three-cornered deal for Glenn Dobbs.

The first concrete test that will gauge the extent of deterioration of Soviet-American relations since the creation of the International Communist Information Bureau will come in London on Nov. 25 when the Big Four Council of Foreign Ministers resumes meetings.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A nonbuying attack by the women of America on the price spiral was urged in a resolution adopted today by the National Board of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, largest organized women's group in the country.

Store Sales Gain Put at 40% Mixed influences on department store sales in Manhattan and Brooklyn this week and wide variation in trend of sales of individual establishments were noted in trade estimates yesterday, but a composite gain of between 40 and 45 per cent was indicated.
ATHENS, Oct. 17 -- Ten out of fifty-two Communists sentenced to death by court-marital last month were executed by firing squads at Salonika today.

Appleton-Century has signed a contract with Theodore Plievier, the German writer and author of "The Kaiser's Coolies," for his new novel "Stalingrad." The story was originally published in Germany where it sold more than 1,200,000 copies. The concern plans to bring out the English v translation next year.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 -- Philip Murray solemnly pledged today that he would oppose unalterably any merger of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations if it meant that any CIO affiliate's jurisdiction would be impaired in the process.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 17 -- President Juan D. Peron received one of the greatest demonstrations of his career this evening when a vast throng filled the Plaza de Mayo to hear him speak on the second anniversary of his return from a brief enforced exile during the Farrell regime.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A witness before a House Labor sub committee declared today that while the elimination of restrictive practices in building construction would help to lower costs, the only satisfactory cure for the country's housing ailment would be a vast research program which the Government itself probably would have to undertake.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17 (AP) --Eugene B. Casey, 42-year-old millionaire who was, one of President Roosevelt's wartime executive assistants' "with a passion for anonymity," today was sentenced to pay 30,000 in fines and serve a prison term for failure to pay income taxes.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Jean E. Sutherland, nursing consultant, New York State Employment Service, in her letter published Oct. 13, gives her opinion regarding men in the nursing profession.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Under the lead of British Government bonds, the stock markets here today tinished the week cheerfully.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The Bermuda Sky Queen, giant flying boat which had to land at sea with sixty-nine passengers Tuesday, was carrying passengers illegally, the Civil Aeronautics Board announced this afternoon.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Baltimore Local 12 and its parent International Typographical Union, both charged by the National Labor Relations Board with failure to bargain collectively in good faith, offered today to resume contract negotiations with the Graphic Arts League provided a Government representative attended the talks.

Arthur Creech Jones, British Colonial Secretary, yesterday told a luncheon discussion, arranged by the Committee for African Students in North America, at the National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, that only the best students should be selected for American study.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Foreign Minister Jan Masaryk has rejected attempts to put Czechoslovakia back in the race for a seat on the United Nations Security Council, it was learned tonight, and the deadlock between the Ukraine and India is expected to continue when the General Assembly reconvenes Monday at Flushing Meadow.

Opposed by a West Virginia team that appears almost impenetrable through the middle, New York University's gridiron forces are prepared to take to the air at Yankee Stadium today when they clash with an unbeaten and heavily favored Mountaineer squad before an expected crowd of 20,000.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Oct. 18 -- Maj. Gen. Albert E. Brown, chief of the "United states delegation to the Joint United States-Soviet Commission, this morning suggested a recess of the commission and the return of the Soviet delegation to Pyongyang (Heijo), capital of the Soviet occupation, zone of Korea.

ROCKY MOUNT, N.C., Oct 17 -- Strong resistance among representative tobacco farmers of the South to a basic point in the Administration's proposed agricultural policy -- reduction of price supports over the long run -- was manifested today to the House Committee on Agriculture in the third hearing of its transcontinental field trip to determine the wishes of farmers on legislation.

PITLOCHRY, Scotland, Oct. 17 -- Scotland is engaged in a dramatic struggle to revive the Highlands before they become a desert. From these beautiful and barren Hills the world has been enriched by the brains and energy of highlanders whose own land is too poor to hold them.

Despite the assertion of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower that he doesn't want to have anything to do with politics and the statement of Maj. Gen. Floyd L. Parks, Army public relations chief, that the Chief of Staff neither seeks nor desires political office, the Draft Eisenhower for President League will continue its activities.

Export credit collections paid by Latin-American countries during September continued their downward trend, declining slightly from the August levels, according to the monthly survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, issued yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The National Publishers Association, Inc., the National Council on Business Mails, Inc., and the Postmaster General filed briefs today with the Interstate Commerce Commission asking it to deny a motion of the country's railroads for a stop-gap increase of 35 per cent in railroad mail rates of pay while the ICC considers a petition of the roads for a long-range increase of 45 per cent in the mail rates.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 17 -- Despite the difficult problems it faces, the United Nations will grow strong enough to keep peace in the world Dr. Oswaldo Aranha, president of the General Assembly, and former Brazilian Ambassador to this country, predicted here today.

The nineteen-day-old strike of 173 pilots which has halted all operations of American Overseas Airline was called off last night. Airliner captains agreed to return to work as the National Mediation Board announced in Washington that representatives of the company and the Airline Pilots Association, AFL, would open joint conferences in New York with the board.

ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- The campaign for repeal of the 1947 law permitting counties and larger cities to impose special taxes for education and other purposes suffered a setback today when a committee representing the New York State Conference of Mayors asked extension of the law to all cities and villages.

With the announced retirement to inactive status in December df Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz and General of the Army Dwight W. Eisenhower some time next year, all but two of the seven men who held the top United States military posts in the Second World War will have turned over their jobs to someone else.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A railway car seat, with space in the upright or back portion for articles of clothing, was patented this week (No. 2,429,959) by Harry L. Decker of Ardmore, Pa., who assigned his rights to the Pennsylvania Railroad Company. This invention was one of the 431 listed in this week's Official Gazette of the United States Patent Office.

Low-cost dinners for the weekend have been planned by the Department of Markets with recipes and costs scaled to families of five. For today's main meal, the menu, costing $2.42, calls for: Sauted beef liver Boiled potatoes, mashed turnips Anise and radish salad Bread and margarine Half and half lemon pudding
DETROIT, Oct. 17 -- Demands for American-built motor vehicles in foreign markets continue to increase despite the tightening of import restrictions in England and several of the European countries.

America cannot test on its maritime laurels but must continue to build ships and maintain its trade routes on the seven seas, W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce, declared here last night. While urging steady replenishment of the merchant marine to keep it modern, he said that this country should not balk at selling more of its surplus and unneeded tonnage to foreign countries.

The London press is sharply critical of former Secretary of State James F. Byrnes for suggesting in his book, "Speaking Frankly," that if the Soviet Union refuses to join its allies in concluding a German peace treaty and to withdraw its troops from Germany, such action would constitute a threat to the peace of the world.

YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Oct. 17 -- Dr. Margaret Mead, associate curator of ethnology at the Museum of Natural History in New York, said today at the dedication of a new building to the long-term study of man that such study was a direct contribution to peace.

BERLIN, Oct. 17 -- There appeared today a ray of hope that the industrial dismantling program announced yesterday for the United States and British zones might lead eventually to an agreement with the Soviet Union on all German affairs.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Francisco (Pancho) Segura, Ecuador's champion, upset the defending champion, Frank A. Parker of Los Angeles, today in the semifinals of the sixth Pan-American tennis championship.

LONDON,Oct. 17 (AP) -- British Government sources said tonight it was likely that Britain would obtain in supplementary pacts rights in the defense of Burma and possibly the right to maintain bases in that ceuntry.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -- Pennsylvania's undefeated team meets Columbia on Franklin Field tomorrow in the thirtieth game of a football series that started in 1878. With the crowd expected to reach 70,000 the Red and Blue is favored to gain its third victory of the season, out has a lot of respect for the Lions who experienced some bad breaks last week losing to Yale after defeating Rutgers and Navy.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Oct. 17 -- German political and union leaders began today a wide campaign to get the United States and British Military Governments to postpone the effective date of the dismantling of the industrial plants listed yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 17 -- The constitution of the Council of Profit Sharing Industries, a new national employer group which will "promote profit-sharing as a means of preserving the American system of free private enterprise," was ratified today by sixteen charter members at a meeting of organizing committeemen.

In setting up a broad program, of student exchange, President Truman's Board of Foreign Scholarships has rendered an important service. Under the Fulbright-Act, passed at the recent session of Congress, foreign countries are permitted to pay for surplus property bought from the United States in the form of scholarships up to a total of $20,000,000.

New Capital Market Interest in next week's market for new capital centers on the scheduled sale of $100,000,000 of forty-year debentures of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company at competitive bidding on next Tuesday.

NANKING, Oct. 17 -- A new legal base for the presence of American troops in China was established here today when the State Council ratified the Foreign Office statement that these troops were on Chinese soil "with the consent of the Chinese Government."
Sydney R. Saul, for the last twelve years with Vim Electric Company, Inc., has been appointed sales manager in charge of the radio and appliance division of the Times Square Stores Corporation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 17 -- A high Government source said today that Brazil would break diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union as a result of Moscow's not apologizing for an attack in the Government newspaper Izvestia upon President Eurico Gaspar Dutra.

The United States proposal for appointment of a United Nations commission to oversee an election in Korea which would establish a representative government that could then negotiate for withdrawal of United States and Soviet troops seems to offer a better hope for a peaceful transition of Korea to self-government than any alternative that has been offered.

Merritt Parkway to New Haven and United States Route 1 to Philadelphia will be clogged with traffic today. The big football crowds-about 70,000 each -- are headed for the Bowl and Franklin Field, to attend the Yale-Wisconsin and Penn-Columbia games.

MARSEILLE, France, Oct. 17 -- The Communists in all probability will lose considerable prestige in Sunday's nation-wide local elections -- elections that may do much toward establishing France's political atmosphere for the next few years.

Arnold Eidus, 24-year-old American, went to Paris at his own expense last winter, and in a contest with sixty-five violinists of many countries walked off with the Jacques Thibaud International Violin Competition. In his program at Carnegie Hall last night it was clear why he captured first prize.

Prominent jurists, leaders in Jewry and public officials were among the 350 persons who attended a funeral service for Abram I. Elkus, former United States Ambassador to Turkey, yesterday in the Chapel of Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.
Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, presented yesterday to four teen-age company officers awards for the best annual report by a company in the Junior Achievement plan.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- P.L. Thomson of New York was re-elected president of the Audit Bureau of Circulation here today as the group ended its thirty-third annual Circulations here today as the dent was H.H. Kynett of Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- A plan for altered techniques designed to conserve 3,000,000 bushels of wheat a month was agreed to today by the Citizens Food Committee, the American Bakers Association and the Associated Retail Bakers of America.
NUREMBERG, Germany, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Gen. Eric Naumann, Whose Elite Guardsmen killed thousands of Jews on the eastern front, told a war crimes court today that he saw nothing wrong in that.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 17 -- Despite its inadequacies, and in some measure as the result of the initiative of the Australian delegation of which he was chairman the United Nations Charter as adopted is a considerable improvement over the Dumbarton Oaks proposals, Dr. H.V. Evatt declared here tonight.
The Eighth Annual Chicago Tribune Fashion Show, presented recently in Chicago, was held again yesterday in the Crystal Ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton Hotel.
SALEM, N.H., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Mrs. Tom Haskos' Sunspark carried top weight of 117 pounds today while winning the featured sixth race of an all-claiming card at Rockingham Park.

ALBANY, Oct. 17 -- Dr. James Bryant Conant, president of Harvard University, said tonight that war between Russia and the United States was not inevitable, despite existence of a divided world, and that agreement on international control of atomic power might be the step needed to convert into peace the current "armed truce."

Laymen's Sunday, an annual event, will be observed tomorrow in Protestant churches in the New York area and other parts of the country, under the sponsorship of the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World. In many churches a layman active in church work will preach the sermon.

Terming both Democrats and Republicans as members of political organizations that may become war parties, Henry A. Wallace declared yesterday that he will favor the formation of a third political party if the United States continues its bi-partisan foreign policy.

In a move designed to facilitate adoption of a new plan to reorganize Motty Eitingon, Inc., mouton furs, under Chapter XI, Referee Irwin Kurtz yesterday announced he would sign an order early next week adjudicating the company as bankrupt.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Two executives announced today their resignation from the Tucker Corporation, Chicago's new automobile manufacturer. They are Hanson A. Brown, executive vice president, secretary and a director, and James D. Stearns, treasurer and controller.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Burma will become an independent nation completely outside the British Commonwealth under the terms of a treaty signed in London today by Prime Minister Attlee and Premier Thakin Nu of Burma.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Solid fuel exports from the United States during 1947 are expected to exceed 40,000,000 gross tons, Charles A. Owen, president of the Coal Exporters Association of the United States, said today in an address before the annual convention of the National Coal Association.

Working at top speed on orders which appear to reflect heavy consumer demand, manufacturing furriers expect to surpass their volume of last year, it was learned yesterday. With prices showing an increase over 1946 and those quoted early in the season there is no doubt that dollar volume will be exceeded even though unit volume falls short, according to manufacturers.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: May I be permitted to reply to certain misrepresentations in the letter of the Rev. William H. Melish on the subject of religious freedom in Yugoslavia, printed on Sept. 22 ?

A four-and-a-half-day sitdown at the Industrial Container Corporation, 4912 Second Avenue, Brooklyn, came to an end yesterday as seventy-three adherents of Local 65, Wholesale and Warehouse Workers, CIO, evacuated the plant in deference to an injunction issued by Supreme Court Justice Henry Clay Greenberg.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- James Terry Duce, oil company executive, testified today that major American oil companies consider it "safe" to invest $125,000,000 in a 1,100-mile oil pipeline in the Middle East. He said the United States oil industry expects the world to be "very peaceful."

The Rosenbach Company, famous antique and book dealer, is auctioning off its entire stock of furniture antiques, paintings, color prints, silver, and textiles and henceforth will devote itself to dealing only in rare old books and manuscripts, it became known yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Congressional sources said today there was the "strongest probability" that the Republicans would submit a revised tax reduction program at the session of Congress beginning next January.

Difficulties resulting from the three-day-old-strike of grooms and exercise boys forced directors of the Metropolitan Jockey Club yesterday to call off today's schedule of races at the Jamaica Race Track.

The close on the stock market yesterday was at the approximate level of the two previous sessions, despite a spurt in the railway issues which, in ordinary circumstances, would have confirmed the previous recovery of other groups. Most major divisions showed mixed price changes, and, while the rail averages advanced 0.34 point on the day, the composite rate was reduced by 0.03 point, indicative of the small alterations throughout the list.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 17 -First night jitters ruled here tonight when Margaret Truman made her cross-country concert debut at Syria Mosque before a packed house, which included her mother, Mrs. Harry Truman, and Secretary of the Treasury and Mrs. John W. Snyder.

Caught in the Traffic Getting about town, either on foot or on wheels, is a complicated business these days, if we stay on the surface while we are doing it. Apparently there are more people in town than there ever were, more of them going places, and more of them doing it in motor cars.

A daring daylight hold-tip in the downtown jewelers' district and six other armed robberies were listed as solved yesterday with the arrest of seven members of a loosely knit gang whose depredations, the police said, brought them more than $100,000.

ARCOLA, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Encouraged by the warm sun and the fact that this was the last one-day tournament on the schedule, eightyfour golfers turned out for the Women's New Jersey Gold Association event over the Arcola Country Club course today.
The mystery of the cornerstone of the Charles M. Schwab mansion on Riverside Drive soon may be solved.

LONDON, Oct. 17 -- The United States has done "a monstrous injustice" to the Arabs of Palestine to gain votes of Jews in New York, Izzedeen Shawa Bey, head of the Palestine Arab political mission in Britain, said today. He added that the United States would feel the repercussions of its action in every part of the Middle East in which it had interests.

CHICAGO, Oct. 17 -- Government buying cash wheat was much, less aggressive today and prices in leading American markets eased quickly with the December delivery of that grain leading. The latter closed at the low point on the Board of Trade, showing a loss of 3 3/4 cents a bushel, with the deferred months off 3/4 to 2 1/4 cents.

Big merchandising buyers from the nation's leading department stores visited the National Hardware Show in Grand Central Palace yesterday. Exhibitors reported in some cases that orders from these and other buyers had been booked in such quantities that they had been forced to cut back ordertaking.

The City College football squad will try for its second consecutive triumph at Ebbets Field tonight in a clash with a slightly-favored Hofstra team. Kick-off time is 8:30 o'clock, with a turnout of about 10,000 expected.

Lewis W. Douglas, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, who came here two weeks ago for State Department conferences, was among 1,829 passengers who boarded the Cunard White Star liner Queen Elizabeth last night for a sailing that was delayed by fog.

Rejection of the percentage promotion and superior merit provisions of the Feinberg State Salary Law as the basis for rating New York City teachers was recommended yesterday to the Board of Education by the board's Committee on Instructional Affairs.

Recreation programs for the benefit of war veterans and members of their families, both on college campuses and in conjunction with programs sponsored by the Veterans Administration, have been extended this year, the National Recreation Congress was told yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker.
Further strains on family food budgets were foreseen yesterday as increases were predicted in the prices of bread and perhaps butter.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Registering a par-breaking 70 after having taken a 74 for their morning round, Frank Strazza of Round Hill and Maurice Walsh of the home club posted 144 to capture the Metropolitan Professions Golfers Association's scotch foursomes championship at the Suningdale Country Club today.

The Building Trades Employers Association balked yesterday at inclusion of an "escalator clause" in the agreement that is to stabilize construction labor costs for two and a half years. In a counter proposal to one offered several weeks ago by the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, AFL, the association offered wage rises for fifteen of thirty-eight trades, but a spokesman said:

Dense fog, which limited visibility to zero for most of the night and early morning, continued yesterday to disrupt ocean shipping, ferry boat and airline service in the metropolitan area for the second day. Weather Bureau officials held out little hope for relief before Monday.

The Whitney Museum is opening to the public today, to remain through November, a centennial exhibition of paintings by Albert Pinkham Ryder (1847-1917). Fiftythree paintings have been lent for the occasion by museums and private collectors, making it the largest exhibition of the artist's work ever held - considerably arger than the memorial exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum nearly thirty years ago.

The grain savings that can be attained in the home and in industry in the present three-way campaign are obviously not comparable with grain consumption by animals on farms and in feeding lots. As this newspaper recently pointed out, grain has been disappearing on the farms during the past three months at the rate of about 4,750,000 bushels a day.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Governor Dewey ordered the flags of the capitol and other public buildings in the capitol district at half-staff today in honor of sixteen war dead arriving at the Schenectady Army distribution center. The bodies were returned from the Pacific area aboard the Honda Knot which arrived in San Francisco, Oct. 10.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 17 (AP) -- Scoring a neck decision in a driving finish, Mrs. Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s Trough Hill won the $10,OO0 added Butler Steeplechase Handicap at Laurel Park today, setting a new stakes record for the event, over about two miles.

I have refused to answer any press inquiries since I resigned because I felt that it was only fair that press releases should be issued by Mr. Topping, the new president of the Yankees. However, many absolutely false or inaccurate statements have appeared in the press, many of them either quoting or attributed to Mr. Del Webb.

A three-way program, designed to help in the nurse recruitment program and to improve working conditions in the profession, was adopted yesterday by the directors of the New York State Nurses Association, Mrs. Mabel Detmold, newly elected president of the organization, announced.
Racing continued at Jamaica yesterday with early arrivals as well as late comers noting no interruption in the program.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 17 -- Colgate and Princeton, each seeking to rebound from defeats last Saturday, will meet for the sixth time in their thirty-six-year-old rivalry before a crowd of 30,000 in Palmer Stadium tomorrow.
