Douglas Aircraft Directors of the Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc., declared yesterday a dividend of $2.50 a share, payable on Nov. 24, the only dividend in the current fiscal year, which will end on Nov. 30. In the previous fiscal year, shareholders received $7.50, consisting of disbursements of 55 on Sept. 20 and $2.50 on Nov. 23.
DETROIT, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Spokesmen for an estimated 3,000 theatres today accused Hollywood of threatening to subject the nation's movie fans to a "Roman holiday" of advanced price pictures.

Alicia Markova, Anton Dolin and their little ballet ensemble, with Andre Eglevsky as guest artist, opened a three-day engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House last night before an audience that filled the house to overflowing and gave every indication of enjoying itself.

Patient research coupled with great technical skill in the use of high-speed motion cameras has at last solved an age-old mystery -- how a fly flies. The American Museum of Natural History, through its Curator of Insects and Spiders, Dr. C.H. Curran, and the Sperry Gyroscope Company joined forces to bring about this achievement.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 17 -- This state is now in the midst of a heated Gubernatorial campaign that revolves principally about local issues and at the same time is filled with possible prophecies concerning the national party trend in 1948.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your report of Governor Dewey's speech before the National Conference on State Parks reveals an alarming lack of understanding on the part of the Governor with respect to the nature of our state forest preserves and the absolute necessity of protecting them with strong constitutional safeguards.
Two hundred parents and children turned out at the Central Park Zoo yesterday in Indian summer weather to celebrate the third birthday of Little Mike, the roller-skating chimpanzee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 17 -- Rosalind Russell will report to Columbia in January for the starring role in a modern comedy which Virginia Van Upp is writing, it was learned today. Miss Van Upp will also produce the picture which, as yet, is untitled.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 (AP) -- In a wild game marked by pass interceptions and clipping penalties, the Temple University Owls tonight ended Muhlenberg College's three-game undefeated football streak with a 7-6 triumph as a crowd of 27,000 alternately booed and cheered the officials.

Continental Illinois The Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company reported as of Oct. 6, total deposits of $2,228,000,090 and total assets of $2,417,711,559, compared respectively, with $2,185,408,382 and $2,374,270,926 on June 30.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17 -- It is the "grave mandate" of our universities to train man's mind to master material things while at the same time enlarging his spirit to appreciate immaterial ones and thus become the master of himself.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 17 -- Registration statements covering $30,000,000 of bonds, 162,500 shares of preferred stock and 308,320 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by four companies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 (AP) -- Unitarian Church delegates condemned totalitarian governments today, but declined to approve a resolution criticizing both the United States and Russia.

With "ersatz" beer forecast for local taverns in the grain-saving program to feed hungry Europe, brewers' spokesmen said yesterday that there would be no loss of employment resulting from the 25 per cent cutback in grain consumption by the industry.
Latest surveys on the extent of the "doubling up" of families give statistical evidence that little progress yet has been made in solving the nation's post-war housing problem.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Invasion of Yugoslavia by "Quisling" bands from Greece and Austria has been tolerated by British and United States authorities in those countries, the Yugoslav delegation to the United Nations charged here today.

Many persons have their own cherished systems of foretelling the weather. "Moon farming" has its adherents today as it did in pioneer days. Plant potatoes in the dark of the moon and corn in the light of the moon is still standard procedure with good farmers. If squirrels' tails are unusually bushy and skunks come around corn cribs in October it may mean a long, cold winter.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- A blunt warning that the Jews of Palestine would be ready to fight in self-defense if war should break out there was sounded today by Moshe Shertok, head of the Political Department of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, but he coupled it with an appeal to the Arabs for conciliation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- The curiosity of a veteran pilot who wanted to find out what would happen if he engaged the "gust locK" of a DC-4 passenger plane while in flight caused the extraordinary situation on Oct. 7 near ElPaso, Tex., when a plane with forty-eight passengers and a crew of five flipped over on its back, the Civil Aeronautics Board reported today.

Miss Glen Thompson, daughter of Col. John Moore Thompson, USA, and Mrs. Thompson of Fort Jay, Governors Island, was married there yesterday afternoon to Lieut. James Lloyd Hayden, USA, in the Roman Catholic Chapel of Our Lady Star-of-the-Sea by the Rev. George Zentgraff of St. Boniface's Church in New York.

Relief for thousands of families against whom eviction proceedings have been started was seen yesterday in a ruling by Municipal Court Justice Harold J. McLaughlin in Brooklyn in which the jurist took issue with the regulations of the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission predicated on the Sharkey Law.

Amid a congenial atmosphere that contrasted sharply with his stormy exit from baseball at the close of the world series, Larry MacPhail, retired president of the world champions, returned to the Fifth Avenue offices of the Yankees yesterday to read his valedictory to a group of baseball writers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Following is the text of a draft resolution of 'procedure for establishing the independence of Korea, submitted by the United States today to the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee:

The Liberal party in a letter signed by Ben Davidson, executive director, challenged Governor Dewey yesterday to say whether he is for continuance of the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council or whether he stands with the five Republican county chairmen in New York City for its repeal.

Emilio Osta, pianist from San Francisco, gave his second New York recital last night at Town Hall. The youthful artist, of Basque origin, presented a program containing the Preludes and Fugue in B flat major and the Prelude and Fugue in C sharp major from Book 1 of Bach's "Well-tempered Clavier"; Beethoven's Sonata, Op. 31, No. 2; a Chopin group, and a final group devoted to Spanish works by Granados, Albeniz and others.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 -- Determined to lose no time in setting up the machinery for warring next year on members of Congress who supported the Taft-Hartley bill, the American Federation of Labor's executive council decided today to call the heads of the AFL's 105 national and international unions to Washington for an organizational conference on Dec. 5 and 6.

BOSTON, Oct. 17 -- A fighting Tiger from me bayous of the deep South escaped with his life by the margin of a point after touchdown tonight at Braves Field as crippled Boston College battled brilliantly before yielding a 14-13 decision to Louisiana State.
LONDON, Oct. 17 -- Britain's crown jewels were back in the Tower of London today and will go on public exhibition again for the first time since 1939.
TOKYO, Oct. 17 -- About 665,00 Japanese prisoners of war are stil held in the Soviet Union, accordIng to the Japanese Foreign Office and the Board of Demobilization.

NYACK, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Republican party officials and Republican election inspectors were accused today of having entered a conspiracy to deprive 500 studentveterans and their wives of the right to vote this year.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 17 -- Senator Robert A. Taft said today that nothing had come to his attention that would require a reexamination of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law at the forthcoming regular session of Congress.

LONDON, Oct. 17 (U.P.) --Britain's 10-man Ryder Cup golf team tucked away their sporty new blue, blazers and nylon umbrellas today and pocketed 75 pounds sterling (5300) in expense money in preparation for their departure for the United States tomorrow aboard the Queen Mary.

New York Housing Authority yesterday sold an issue of $21,559,000 of temporary loan notes dated Nov. 10, 1947, and due on May 10, 1948, to the Chemical Bank Trust Co. and associates at a bid of 0.81 per cent.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- The Soviet Union today lost its campaign to broaden the membership of the United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East and to make it possible for non-self-governing territories to apply directly for associate membership rather than through the responsible colonial powers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 -- Former Secretary of State Byrnes issued a statement today quoting Winston Churchill as having given the Soviet Union, verbal assurance in 1944 that it would have "a largely preponderant voice in Rumania and Bulgaria. * * *"

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 17 -- With only a few reserved seats remaining, a crowd of 70,000 is expected to jam Yale Bowl tomorrow when the Elis and Wisconsin clash. It will be their first meeting and the first intersectional football for Yale since it lost to Michigan in 1938 and 1939.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange held yesterday within a comparatively narrow range and closed 15 points higher to 1 point lower than the day before.

Saturday, Oct. 18, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Heard Andrei A. Gromyko declare Soviet Union would not compromise on United States proposal for year-round "Little Assembly" after Britain offered "middle - of - road" plan.
A special meeting of stockholders of the Jim Brown Stores, Inc., formerly known as the Brown Fence and Wire Company, has been called for Nov. 19 to act on a proposed recapitalization plan.

Declaring that acceptance of the charter of the International Trade Organization in its present form would be "extremely unwise," Senator Albert W. Hawkes, Republican, of New Jersey, last night urged a new Tariff Commission with power to make or change rates within limits set by Congress.
PARIS, Oct. 17 -- Indirectly through the transfer of an award to Belgium. France obtained today $104,000,000 worth of gold recovered by the Allies in Germany.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, announced today he was sending a telegraphic protest to the Department of State in connection with the use of Mexican nationals as "strike-breakers" on the Di Giorgio ranch near Bakersfield, Calif.

Flashing a powerful aerial attack, Horace Mann crushed St. Paul's of Garden City, 34 -- 0, yesterday on the winner's gridiron. It was the second victory for the home forces, who registered three of their five touchdowns on passes. Marvin Rubin, speedy quarterback, completed six of his eight aerials.

What is a "cheap" food? Miss Mabel Rollins, Associate Professor of Home Economics at the New York State College of Home Economics at Cornell University, set out to discover this in 1943. Her study, which took two years, is being published at a time when it could not be more pertinent in view of current food prices.

PARIS, Oct. 17 -- The Government succeeded in settling the maritime strike today, but it failed to get either the subway or the buses running in Paris because of the active resistance of the strikers.

The democratic tradition of the United States, as originally enunciated in the historical documents now being carried across the country on the "Freedom Train," is to be dramatized in a new WNEW series. "The American Heritage." Beginning Oct. 26 and continuing on a weekly schedule thereafter, the programs will be on the air from 4 to 4:15 P. M. Sundays.

How well are the schools of New York building these citizens of a United Nations world? How well are the people of this biggest, richest, most open-handed city in the world carrying out the responsibility to the schools? The Citizens Committee on Children, made up of education, specialists, judges, social workers, housing and labor experts, finds the New York school system far from ideal.
Sweeping changes in relief policies to insure tighter control over the spending of public funds are being instituted by the Welfare Department, it was learned yesterday.

"Dear Judas," Michael Myerberg's dramatization of the Robinson Jeffers' poem, will be withdrawn after tonight's performance -- the sixteenth -- at the Mansfield Theatre. The decision to end the run was made in Chicago yesterday by Mr. Myerberg, who is there for the opening of his revival of "The Late Christopher Bean," with ZaSu Pitts and Guy Kibbee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 17 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko finally and flatly turned down today any attempt to reach agreement on a modified version of the United States "Little Assembly" plan.

WARSAW, Oct. 17 -- Eight Labor members of the British Parliament declared tonight that Premier Stalin had told them in Russia that he had no thought of making war and wished to settle political and economic issues with the United States.

Mayor O'Dwyer formally opened his new municipal school in management and analysis last night. The class of seventy-five men and women jammed the hearing room of the Board of Assessors on the twenty-second floor of the Municipal Building.

The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange approved yesterday an amendment to the constitution of the Exchange calling for a conversion from a rate-per-share basis to a moneyinvolved basis on stocks selling at 50 cents a share and above.
Featured by continued price-fixing for Southern mills, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday at the best levels of the day or 19 to 26 points net higher.

DEFLATION -- A traveler just returned from New Mexico reports having his supercilia arched by a sign, in gaudy neon, over the entrance to an Albuquerque hotel. It reads: "Two Guests for the Price of One."

Signing of a contract to mark the transfer of ownership of the well-known John Murray House at the southwest corner of Madison Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street featured the Manhattan realty transactions reported yesterday.

The sixteenth annual Forum on Current Problems, sponsored by The New York Herald Tribune, will open tomorrow evening at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. "Modern Man: Slave or Sovereign" will be the general theme at four sessions, which will be held tomorrow evening, Tuesday afternoon and evening and Wednesday evening.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The Soviet Union and its supporters in Eastern Europe announced today an official boycott of a United Nations subcommittee set up to work out a compromise on the United States "Little Assembly" plan.

A NATION-WIDE plea is being made for twenty million vegetable gardens to aid in increasing food production during 1948. Preliminary work on these gardens should be started just as soon as possible this fall.

EVERYTHING about this book, not only the title, has something miraculous. It is a first novel, written secretly in exile by a really youthful author at the age of 74 and is already being published successfully in seven European languages other than English.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 18 -- Lafayette College scored a 27-7 victory over Bucknell today, with Secretary of State George C. Marshall among the 9,000 spectators to see the Maroon gain its second victory in four games.

TO have a city backyard that will be a real garden next year, this is the time to plan and plant. Whether the space is open and sunny or surrounded by buildings and shaded, it will be transformed in spring if the work is done right away.

GENEVA, Oct. 18 -- Barring a last-minute hitch, Britain, Canada and South Africa will sign an exchange of notes at the end of the Geneva Trade Conference releasing one another from the obligation to maintain the imperial-preference tariffs under the Ottawa accords of 1931.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- Organized labor is preparing for the most important political campaign in its history. Both major labor organizations, in convention this week, staked their political future on the outcome of the 1948 election.

THE making of separation negatives for three-color printing processes, such as Kodak Dye Transfer, is simplified by a new tripack film combination consisting of three separable films which are exposed as one in any conventional camera taking sheet film.
ROBERT NATHAN, the novelist, dug into a soft-boiled specialty in the Plaza's dining room and unburdened himself of some hard-boiled remarks about the writer, writing and Hollywood.

Last week was a quiet one, highlighted by mail orders on rayon fabrics, novelty gifts and toys, with few buyers present, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buyers.

ON his fiftieth birthday Mr. Goldman, a writer for the slicks, a scrivener for Hollywood and a fashioner of whodunits, decided to pause from his labors and write a precis of his life. His half century anniversary date was a good time for such a deed, for that birthday was in a way a remarkable one.

The Thoroughbred Unit of Local 814 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, is the union label for 700 grooms and exercise boys who work for 170 owners of race horses. A groom is a "horses' valet"; he feeds them, rubs them down, saddles them. An exercise boy usually is an underage or obsolescent jockey who rides on training or trial runs.

READERS of history have for years found engaging and instructive the studies of the tactics and the campaigns of war -- those books with maps so pains-takingly marked with the route of Stonewall Jackson's brigades or the fleet array at Jutland.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A wellinformed Latin-American diplomat said today that British Foreign Secretary Bevin had advised two Spanish leaders that Britain wants Spain included in the Marshall plan but with Generalissimo Francisco Franco and the Communists excluded from the Spanish Government.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- The light but speedy linemen of Illinois couldn't shatter the massive Minnesota forward wall today, but they furnished perfect protection for the passes of Perry Moss and the Big Nine champions beat the previously undefeated Gophers, 40 to 13.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 18 -- Walter M. Jeffords' Loyal Legion ran back to his winning effort of last week in the Maryland Handicap to capture the thirty-fourth running of the $25,000 added Washington Handicap today. The 3-year-old galloped home eight lengths before Mrs. E.H. Augustus' Blue Yonder.

IN a little while it will be a hundred years since the wondering James Marshall at Sutter's Mill held in his palm some flakes of gold, and for a brief moment became the most significant figure on the planet. In the rush that followed, when he and Sutter were trampled out, history was changed.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct 18 -- A Yugoslav resolution and a Soviet amendment accusing the United States and Britain of giving sanctuary to Axis war criminals were thrown out today by the Legal Committee or the United Nations General Assembly in favor of a British resolution pointing in the opposite direction.

Harvard University research workers have devised a hearing aid that will work for all deaf or hard-of-hearing people. "Regardless of the nature of their particular defects, most patients hear best with an instrument which amplifies all frequencies uniformly, or with moderate emphasis of the higher frequencies," the researchers reported in "Hearing Aids! An Experimental Study in Design Objectives," published by the Harvard University Press.

The Industrial Relations Section of the Department of Economics and Social Institutions at Princeton University celebrated its twenty-fifth anniversary recently by announcing contributions of $371,283 from fifty-seven companies and six national unions, more than doubling its previous endowment.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- Final steps in Brazil's move to break off diplomatic relations with Russia have been taken and formal announcement of the breach will be made Monday, a Foreign Office spokesman said today.
CAMBRIDGE, Oct. 18 -- Harvard's crippled football team rebounded from its harrowing Southern trip of last week by upsetting favored Holy Cross, 7 to 0, before a crowd of 28,000 this afternoon.
CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

IT taken a long time to get recordings of complete operas at the Metropolitan Opera House. Other companies overseas have been making such recordings for years. There are sets of Mozart's "Don Giovanni" and "Marriage of Figaro," made by the Glyndeborne Company; a group of Russian artists recently recorded Tchaikovsky's "Eugene Onegin," leading Italian opera houses, such as the Rome and "Milan theatres, have made recordings of the Italian operas.

SALT LAKE CITY, Oct. 18 -- Wearing bright new orange and black paint, Engine 903 of the Western Pacific Railroad pulled out of here at the head-end of the San Francisco-bound Exposition Flyer the other day -- and thereby hangs a tale.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Corney Shields today took the fifth race among the International Class sloops for the Haebler Trophy. It was his second victory in the series of six contests, the last of which will be held tomorrow, when the Larchmont Yacht Club winds up its long warm-weather season of racing.

TO THE EDITOR: It will be difficult for anyone to disagree with Chester Bowles' article, "Challenge to the Business Man." There is no question that our present predicament as to high prices is the handiwork of selfish people on the one hand and stupid, ignorant leadership on the other, both in business organizations and the national legislature.

NANKING, Oct. 18 -- An intensified land expropriation policy of Communist-controlled areas in China loomed tonight following an announcement on the Communist radio that the party's Central Committee had ratified a new land-reform program abolishing ownership rights of "all landlords" and cancelling "all debts" in the countryside.

Members of the real estate boards of New York, Brooklyn, Long Island, the Bronx, Westchester and Staten Island, together with real estate brokers from New Jersey and Connecticut, will leave the Pennsylvania Railroad station on a special train on Nov. 4 for the fortieth annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards in San Francisco during the week of Nov. 9-14.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 18 -- A reduction in the overall strength of the British Army was responsible for the recent assignment of Arab troops of the Trans-Jordan Frontier Force to Jewish areas of eastern Galilee, an official statement from the Palestine Government said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The excitement created by the first reports that the Arab states were massing troops near the frontiers of Palestine has now quieted down, and it is evident that if both the United States and the Soviet Union really insist upon partition, that solution almost inevitably will be accepted by the United Nations General Assembly.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Fairly aggressive buying entered wheat futures of the 1948 crop on the Board of Trade today as weather in the Southwest continued clear and no rain was forecast for this week-end. Contracts representing this year's crop also advanced, although gains were not as extensive as with July and September wheat.

BATAVIA, Java, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Netherlands won what appeared to be an important political victory today when fifty Indonesian political, religious and commercial leaders voted to cooperate in organizing a West Java Government in the rich agricultural area occupied by Dutch forces.

Two highly useful ends can be served by the liquidation of the automobile graveyards which are so common in this country. Edwin Berringer, executive secretary of the Institute of Scrap Iron and Steel, Inc., told the members of the Gray Iron Founders Society the other day that a scant five weeks' supply of iron and steel scrap remains in the hands of consumers and dealers.

Outstanding advances granted by the Federal Home Loan Banks to their member savings and loan associations and other home-financing institutions has risen steadily since last April and now stand at more than $345,000,000, it was reported yesterday by Harold Lee, governor of the Federal Home Loan Bank System.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Dr. Kurt Schumacher, chairman of the Social-Democratic party in Western Germany, said today that a recently announced Allied plan to dismantle industrial plants in the United States and British zones was "a step to defeat the Marshall plan."

ROME, Oct. 18 -- Italian Communists are very secretive about their affairs. This correspondent recently submitted a questionnaire to Palmiro Togliatti, Communist leader, dealing with possible changes in Communist strategy after the publication of the Warsaw manifesto.

Modification of the veto power of members of the Security Council of the United Nations was proposed yesterday by several high school students at the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast from the studio of WQXR.

LONDON, Oct. 18 (Reuters) -- Scoring its goals in the first fifteen minutes England today blanked a less experienced Wales eleven, 3 -- 0, for its first victory since 1934 in a peacetime soccer international on Welsh soil.

THE National Chrysanthemum Society and the New York Botanical Garden are cosponsors of the third annual chrysanthemum display and program to be held at the Museum Building, Bronx Park, this Friday, Saturday and Sunday.

Two major items in the news of the past few days belong together. One is Secretary Marshall's speech before the Congress of Industrial Organizations. The other is Secretary Krug's report on what the United States can contribute to Europe's recovery, made public this morning.

IT appears from the Metropolitan announcement of the principal features of its forthcoming opera season, which begins Nov. 10, that um-ah-er- we shall not after all hear the American premiere of Prokofieff's "War and Peace" this season.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Kentucky's Wildcats had their backs and their T-formation functioning to perfection today to defeat the hitherto unbeaten Vanderbilt Commodores, 14 to 0, in a Southeastern Conference contest.

Two undefeated Bronx elevens, Evander Childs and James Monroe, battled to a scoreless deadlock yesterday in the feature contest of a Public Schools Athletic League double-header at Triborough Stadium on Randall's Island. In the other game, De Witt Clinton scored its second triumph in three starts by defeating previously unbeaten Christopher Columbus, 12 -- 0.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 18 -- With iron ore shipments aiming at a new all-time record for a non-war year, the movement of the three major commodities or the Great Lakes, ore, coal and grain, is running about 24,500,000 tons ahead of the corresponding period in 1946, the Lake Carriers' Association disclosed today.

CANAL POINT, Fla., Oct. 18 -- Flood waters brought on by a prolonged season of rain and two hurricanes have turned this extremely fertile farming area of the Everglades into one of desolation and confusion, and no immediate relief is in sight.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Princeton defeated Colgate, 20 -- 7, before 31,000 persons at Palmer Stadium today. And, despite the statistics -- figures seldom may lie, but often they are misleading -- the Tigers were clearly superior.

SO far as Gerard Swope is concerned there has never been a "forgotten man." Human rights have always loomed large in his mind and as the former head of one of the great corporations of America, he has been the spokesman not only for industry but also for labor.

The American Federation of Labor (7,600,000 members) is sixty-six years old, has a non-partisan tradition in politics. The Congress of Industrial Organizations (6,000,000 members) is twelve years old, frequently split between Right and Left wings, but generally committed to a policy of active campaigning for parties it considers friendly -- usually the Democrats.

Several card parties will be held in the near future to raise funds for various charitable organizations. Mrs. Harold C. Richard will give a party and tea on Dec. 3 in her home at 1060 Fifth Avenue, for the benefit of the Sheltering Arms Children's Service.

In a discussion of the problem of displaced persons in Europe Herbert H. Lehman, former Governor of New York and one-time director general of the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration, branded yesterday as fiction the contention that the United States was "so overcrowded that it can no longer absorb immigrants."

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 18 -- The largest annual Scouting get-together in the East took place in the natural amphitheatre adjoining Young's Memorial Cemetery here this afternoon when 2,000 Boy Scouts from Long Island, New Jersey, Connecticut and lower New York State and fifty Sea C scouts took part in the twenty-eighth annual pilgrimage to the grave of Theodore Roosevelt.

IT is good to get out occasionally from the arena where the combat over Picasso's later and more extreme work goes on constantly -- to turn back to his early painting, over which a clearer perspective is possible. Such an opportunity is afforded by the current exhibition, "Picasso Before 1907," at the Knoedler Galleries.

Uppermost in the minds of speakers and delegates to the annual merchant marine conference in New York last week was the growing conviction that the maritime industry was at a crucial turning point. Speakers at the general sessions and the panels, including the country's leading authorities on sea transport, reiterated in a veritable refrain the warning that the American-flag merchant fleet laced a doubtful future.

Further extension of branch facilities by mutual savings banks in this state is essential to the maintenance of their current position among savings institutions, John Adikes, newly elected president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- An abstract comprising the principal points in the report of Secretary Krug on the resources of the United States and their relation to the Marshall plan for aid to Europe follows:

ROMAIN ROLLAND was born in 1868, Andre Gide in 1869. Both were brought to Paris by doting mothers, in their sickly adolescence, there to be educated to greatness. They achieved a cosmopolitan greatness, after long years of obscurity and opprobrium.
The big question is still this: What will this country do about the Marshall plan -- and how much and when?

The return of critically needed iron and steel scrap from reservoirs now held at Army installations is being speeded by a joint industry-governmental drive, Robert W. Wolcott, chairman of the Steel, Foundry and Scrap Industries Committee for Expediting Iron and Steel Scrap, revealed here yesterday.

France is going to the polls today to elect local officials for 38,000 municipalities. These officials, in turn, Will elect the Council of the Republic, the French parliament's upper chamber, which does not play an important part in the legislative process. But the elections today will be significant.

Six months ago, the United Nations approved a plan to get aid to the one group of persons in the world who are above all political controversy -- the children. It directed that a world-wide appeal be made to provide scritically needed food, milk, medicine and clothes and shoes to some thirty million children in Europe and more than thirty million in Asia.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 18 -- When asked point-blank this afternoon about the impending break, Foreign Minister Raul Fernandes would not deny or confirm it, but he seemed to be angry at the newspaper headlines stating that the severance of ties had already taken place.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Arab and Zionist representatives made their final appeals to the United Nations Special Committee on Palestine today. Their views were as opposed and as unwavering as they were at the beginning of the debate.

Thrilling football marked the double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday as 5,000 fans saw Manual Training defeat Abraham Lincoln, 14 -- 6, and Brooklyn Tech make it four in a row by routing Erasmus Hall, 34 -- 13.
LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 18 -- Following are excerpts from the statement by Jamal el-Husseini, chairman of the Palestine Arab delegation, before the United Nations Committee on Palestine:

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Oct. 18 -- Halfback Coy McGee, 158-pound Texan, provided the spark which swept unbeaten Notre Dame to a methodical 31-0 triumph over stubborn Nebraska today before a capacity 56,000 crowd at the home opener of the Fighting Irish.

THE least detached and gingerly of novelists, Marcia Davenport writes with senses and sympathies tuned to the highest pitch of awareness: her new novel is a song of love to Manhattan, which accompanies an impassioned recital of one week of decision in the life of an unhappy woman.

SALEM, Ore. IN Oregon the process of law-making never stops. It goes on 365 days a year. It takes place not only through the Legislature but by the circulation of petitions on street corners, wharves and mountain tops.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, today banned "once and for all" the making of recordings and transcriptions by the union's 225,000 members in the United States and Canada.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- London's wholesale food trades, prolific breeding ground for unofficial strikes, produced a new stoppage this week that, officials feared, might spread along London's docks.

THE late Samuel Hoffenstein of "Pencil in the Air" still was the ageless Hoffenstein of "Poems in Praise of Practically Nothing" and "Year In, You're Out." With this conspicuous exception; the Hoffenstein who dropped into poetry during the Twenties soared into poetry in the Forties.

THE volumes that, to date, comprise Chandler Rathfon Post's monumental "History of Spanish Painting" began to appear some years ago. The project, an immense labor of love in the field of specializing scholarship, has gone through many spirit-trying vicissitudes.

The arrest of a Chappaqua bank cashier for the alleged embezzlement of $21,000 over a period of fourteen years was announced here yesterday by Edward Scheidt, special agent in charge of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's New York office.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The official army newspaper said today that Constantin Bratianu, head of the opposition National Liberal party, and a group of other party leaders were under questioning by the Bucharest Military Tribunal.

OILS, water-colors and drawings by Segonzac and Dufy make up the opening exhibition of the season at the Carroll Carstairs Gallery -- recent work, brought back this fall from France. The Segonzac still-life (oil) is a very accomplished painting indeed, admirable in construction, beautiful in color arrangement and notable in its textural quality.

AS you walk in the front door of the red brick house with the deep white overhang, you can look from the flag-paved hallway straight through to a quiet patio. In California? No, this house stands on a busy corner in Long Beach, L.I.

A tense aerial football battle between City College and Hofstra resulted in a 26-14 victory for the Long Island eleven before 7,500 spectators at Ebbets Field last night. At least one touchdown was scored in each quarter of the keenly waged struggle, which saw five of the tallies registered on pass plays.
The Long Island College of Medicine dedicated yesterday its new six-acre campus facing Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn.

STILLWATER, Okla., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Twenty-year-old Johnny Rauch, who pitches a football as if it were a silver dollar, shone just as brightly as he passed to two touchdowns and set up another to give Georgia a 20-7 victory over Oklahoma A. M. here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Renewed demands rose in Congressional circles today for prompt action to relieve the countries of Western Europe.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 18 -- Accused of obstructing and interfering with a $100,000 public relations program, two members of the three-man board of trustees of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen were removed from office by the trainmen's executive board last night.

THE four Western big-game hunting states -- Wyoming, Montana, Colorado and Idaho -- are expecting a 25 per cent increase over pre-war years in the hunting seasons now getting under way. All told, it is believed that more than 300,000 hunters, women as well as men, will ride the trails in the forest wildernesses of these states in search of elk, moose, antelope, Bighorn sheep, mountain goat, mountain lion, brown bear and grizzly.

COLORADO SPRINGS, COL. IT is very pleasant when everybody in a town like this gets into a rosy glow about a new community project. The Civic Players, an amateur theatre group run by a young man named Orvis Grout, has caused the glow.

WHILE the motion picture industry may not be pleasing all of the people all of the time, it is pleasing a goodly sum of the people most of the time and it is not going downhill in public, estimation by a long shot.

Wall Street is decrying last week's Presidential investigation into the grain market as a political manipulation without economic foundation. "Speculation" is a word that has been given sinister meaning to an ill-informed public, the financial world says, and in the eyes of the layman it is synonymous with gambling.

BIG, shiny scarlet fruits make Rosa rugosa a conspicuous shrub now. This rose with the leathery foliage grows into an upright, graceful bush four to six feet high, and it is a beautiful plant to own. It can be set out in October or November.

Leopold Stokowski and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra have joined the "Cavalcade of Stars" who will appear at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night, Oct. 28, at the all-star benefit being organized by the Musicians Emergency Fund for its work among hospitalized veterans.

IT'S a long way from Shangri-La to Oak Ridge, Tenn., but James Hilton has come the full distance. In "Nothing So Strange," this past master of the plaintive and the poignant has dramatized one of the gravest issues of an atomic age: the scientist's dilemma in a world he made -- and never intended to make.

LONDON (By Wireless). THE policy of the Communist party both inside and outside the Soviet Union has often varied; but it always has varied according to plan. Recently it has varied to a remarkable extent and in a remarkable way.

NO matter whether they are grown in a home green-house or a sash-covered pit or on a closed porch or a sunny windowsill, great is the beauty in winter of some of the flowering bulbs. Daffodils, tulips and hyacinths are not difficult to plant and tend.

DRAWINGS are the surest insight to an artist's intention, character and skill. Paintings are more formal, finished statements. They have been planned, fussed over, changed and refinished. The original intent is often altered or disguised, and then, too, time works inexorable changes in color.

The Mayor's Committee headed by Grover A. Whalen, in charge of the memorial program honoring the return from Europe of the first group of 6,200 World War II dead, yesterday urged the next of kin of servicemen who died in the war to apply as quickly as possible for seats at the ceremonies to be held in the Sheep Meadow, Central Park, at 2:15 next Sunday afternoon.

MIAMI, Fla. -- Dedication of Crandon Park on Biscayne and Virginia. Keys and opening of Rickenbacker Causeway during a three-day Tequesta Festival beginning on Nov. 9 are expected ultimately to change the Greater Miami picture greatly.

TO THE EDITOR: You published on Sept. 28 a letter on Palestine from Charles Issawi of the Arab Office, Washington. Mr. Issawi writes: "The answer * * * is that between 1920 and 1946 over 400,000 Jews and less than 19,000 Arabs entered Palestine."

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- Hurlin' Harry Gilmer made his fourth and final game against Tennessee his greatest today when he passed and ran Alabama's Crimson Tide to a 10-to-0 victory before 32,000 fans.

THOUGH soft cries of dismay arise at intervals from the trade book publishers (costs high, sales off, etc.), the technical book field is doing nicely, thank you, and with practically no complaints whatever. Indeed, the technical books (carry-all term for legal, medical, scientific and assorted school books) are in even finer fettle than during the boom days of the war, which is saying a good deal.

FOR eight years or so Mollie Panter-Downes has been writing the week-to-week story of what was happening in England. This continuing chronicle has appeared as the "Letter From London" in The New Yorker. It has been quite the best of all the regular reports, sane, intelligent, perceptive and warm with human understanding.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Tripling money spent by the United States on medical research, by expenditure alike of public and private funds, was recommended today in a report of the President's Scientific Research Board, which President Truman personally endorsed.

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Municipal elections throughout France will take place tomorrow, simultaneously with the outbreak in Paris of a potentially national labor struggle that is the bitterest since the end of the war.

MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 18 (AP) -- A hurricane with winds of 115 miles an hour and mounting in size and fury took a northwest turn in the Atlantic today without offering an immediate threat to the continental United States.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The Soviet Union was decisivelv defeated today in an attempt to block the allocation of funds for the creation of the new Balkans Commission of the United Nations.

"STARS IN MY CROWN" is the glossy, pleasant fusion of numerous literary cliches, with period and regional contours, molded into a leisurely, sentimental novel of characterization. Kindly in approach and autobiographical in detail, the author sketches in his star performer -- a Methodist preacher -- against a background of indigenous post-bellum Tennesseans and some purely curiosity pieces.

The role which imports are to play in future American foreign trade will come to the fore strongly in the next few weeks, particularly when the tariff cuts worked out as part of the eighteen-nation agreements at Geneva are made public about Nov. 15.

GENEVA, N.Y., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Whitey Kunkiewicz, triple-threat sophomore from Torrington, Conn., sparked undefeated Trinity College to a 25-7 victory over Hobart today before a Hobart homecoming crowd of 3,000.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: 'A letter published in THE TIMES of Sept. 28 over the signature of a Yale professor of law, supporting Mr. Bevin's fantastic bid for gold dollars to pay for aid to Europe, has filled me with amazement and distress.
LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Britain is not prepared to sacrifice freedom, democracy and the validity of moral values in an effort to take a short cut to material prosperity, Prime Minister Attlee said today.

THERE is something to be said in favor of the maligned backseat driver. According to the National Highway Users Conference, this type of passenger can be a vital factor in preventing highway accidents. A word of sound advice often can prevent a serious traffic mishap.

A pea-soup fog, which rolled in from the Atlantic Ocean and covered the city yesterday morning, disrupted sea and air travel for the third successive day. The weather continued unseasonably warm for the fourth day.

THE dramatic and completely successful rescue of sixty-two passengers and seven crew members of a Boeing flying boat in mid-Atlantic last week brought the United States Coast Guard into the spotlight and at the same time illuminated the situation on weather ships along the most traveled international airway.

SITTING down with Louis Fischer's "Gandhi and Stalin," one wonders what fruitful ideas can come from a comparison of two such disparate personalities and political leaders. One soon discovers, however, that Mr. Fischer is not concerned with a detailed study of two men.

MARKS LEVINE'S paper, presented at the recent symposium on American music sponsored by Composers-Authors Guild of which I had the honor to be the moderator, and published in last Sunday's NEW YORK TIMES, was excellent in many respects.
West Virginia's football team rolled on its unbeaten way at the Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon to register a 40-to-0 triumph over N.Y.U.

JUST fourteen years ago this week in this Review: Putnam's had published Sholom Asch's "Three Cities," and on page one Louis Kronenberger wrote: "In spite of its weaknesses and defects 'Three Cities' is one of the most absorbing, one of the most vital, one of the most richly creative works of fiction that have appeared in our day."

NANKING, Oct. 18 -- One of the few Chinese Government agencies that has succeeded in winning almost unqualified respect here is the Ministry of Communications, headed by the Harvard-educated Gen. Yu Ta-wei.

PARIS -- The first major postwar step to make tourist travel possible, sensible, comfortable and reasonable was taken recently in Paris. After a four-day convention the International Congress of National Tourist Agencies has established the International Union of Official Travel Organizations, which it is hoped will be empowered by the Governments of the forty-one nations taking part in the union to bring order out of the world-wide confusion which continues to plague the tourist trade.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 18 (AP) -- The mighty Texas Longhorns displayed a brutal ground attack today to smash the University of Arkansas, 21 to 6, and mark their fifth successive victory of the season and their first in Southwest Conference play.

The Citizens Union appealed yesterday to voters to vote "no" on Proposition No. 4 to amend the New York City Charter by abolishing the proportional representtion method of electing members of the City Council and substituting election by State Senate districts.
HOLLYWOOD. EDDY HOWARD knows the feeling of the Forgotten Man. He's never been reduced to selling apples, but in the music-band-radio business eighteen months ago he was practically a dead pigeon.

Palestine At Lake Success last week it seemed likely that the final United Nations decision on Palestine would be partition. Russia joined the United States in supporting the division of the Holy Land into separate, sovereign Arab and Jewish states -- as recommended by the majority report of the U.N. Special Committee on Palestine (UNSCOP).

Retail sales here continued to show a high rate of gain over a year ago. Department store volume was estimated at 40 per cent over 1946. The trucking strike of last year, however, continued a major factor in comparisons. Columbus Day sales activity was broad.

Robert Lenox thought he was paying a high price on March 18, 1818, when he bid in at auction for $500 five acres of common land now bounded by Fifth and Park Avenues, and Seventy-first and Seventy-fourth Streets. While he believed its value would rise, it is doubtful he had in mind any such figure as $50,000,000, which is its estimated worth today.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 18 -- With Argentina apparently re-established in the good graces of the Americas and proud of her new role as member of the Security Council of the United Nations, President Juan D. Peron has informed his constituents that the Five-Year Plan he presented to them a year ago this month must not be taken too literally.

WASHINGTON. LITTLE more than a year after Robert M. La Follette Jr. of the "Fighting La Follettes" of Wisconsin suffered political eclipse in a GOP primary, his name once more is being called to public attention.

To the Screen Editor: "IT is interesting to note," writes Edmond J. Bartnett, in his otherwise highly informative article, "Religious Movies Sprout Like Wild Flowers," published in THE TIMES, Sept. 21, "that while Catholics are producing no films of this type * * *."

PARIS, Oct. 18 -- Despite the Government's offer of concessions, the Paris transport strike remained deadlocked today, and the situation was fast shifting toward a generalized demand for increased wages throughout the country.
Agreement of Russia and the United States on the Palestine partition encourages a belief that the nations can cooperate on other international problems, rabbis said in sermons here yesterday.
OMAHA, Oct. 18 -- The Government and its advisers face a tough task in seeking to convince the Midwest farmer that he can save the grain needed for relief shipments to Europe.

TO read today a new historical study of the Dreyfus Affair is to be reminded of how far civilization has retrogressed since fifty years ago, when a novelist like Zola, by his pamphlet, "J'Accuse!" could set half of France fighting the other half over the case of one Jewish officer who had been unjustly convicted of treason.

THERE are some things you expect in a Frank Slaughter novel, modern or historical. Whatever the century, you anticipate the presence of a brilliant surgeon (more or less like his newest hero). You expect vividly described operations -- the kind that always highlight Dr. Slaughter's stories and leave the lay reader limp with excitement.

BERLIN, Oct. 18 -- The belief grows in both United States and British circles here that the Soviet Union will come to the London Foreign Ministers conference next month with broad and at least outwardly attractive proposals for settling the German question.
MIAMI, Fla., Oct. 18 -- Resort cities along the southeast Florida coast many of them handicapped by flood waters, are working overtime to get their houses in order for the coming winter season.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 18 -- With an awesome display of strength, Pennsylvania's mighty legions rolled up four touchdowns on Columbia in a little more than seventeen minutes today. This laid the foundation for an ultimate 34-to-14 triumph before a crowd of 70,000 at Franklin Field.

A slim, wounded war veteran charged yesterday that he was punched and kicked by a detective while he was trying to patch up a domestic quarrel with his wife in front of the main desk of the West Twentieth Street station house.

HANOVER, N.H., Oct. 18 -- Hal Fitkin, sophomore halfback from Toledo, Ohio, broke up the ball game in the last twenty seconds here this afternoon when he took a pass from Quarterback Joe Sullivan on the Brown 6 and raced wide around his own left end to

MOZART seems to be the composer the young opera companies like to cut their teeth on. The Nine O'Clock Company began with "The Marriage of Figaro," and the Lemonade Opera with "Don Giovanni." And along comes another company that has prepared both these operas, plus "The Magic Flute."
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Undefeated and untied Wesleyan crushed Swarthmore, 40 to 7, today in a football game which made up for its one-sidedness by producing several long runs.

The extent to which Government orders for wool goods will affect supply and prices in the coming months came in for considerable discussion in the trade last week. It appears to be the one factor, wool textile men said, which might disturb an otherwise stable outlook in the woolen and worsted picture.

The market for high-grade corporate bonds is still teeming with readjustments provoked by its most drastic readjustment of yield relationship in recent years. Price levels are awaiting the ministration of a market influence decisive enough to dispel the uncertainties in which the secondary transactions are still substantially inveloped, and to rationalize the underpricings and overpricings that are said now to abound.

MADRID, Oct. 15 (Delayed) -- Two Spanish economists returned today from a visit to the American and British zones of Germany and reported that they saw bright prospects for Spanish trade with those areas.

The High Plains rise from the uplands of the Missouri Valley and roll gently, in a constant uprise, to the foot of the Rockies. Those plains are now russet with a late Autumn, the russet of wheat stubble and what stockmen call "standing hay," native grass cured on the stem.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The American economy is physically capable of undertaking "a considerable program of foreign aid" without jeopardizing the national security or living standard, Secretary of the Interior Krug reported today in an inventory of United States resources.

ALFRED HAYES, author of a successful novel of liberated Rome ("All Thy Conquests"), turns now to contemporary America, to consider, in staccato detail, the torments of an aging union organizer: set in a background as drab as his protagonist, mixed with the familiar ingredients of the labor novel, "Shadow of Heaven" emerges as a strange cacophony indeed.

One of the major problems facing the public school system today is that of getting the superior students to enter the teaching profession, in the opinion of Dr. John Dewey, America's noted philosopher and world renowned educator. It is imperative, he holds, that teaching be made so attractive that the best minds will want to be teachers.

NANKING, Oct. 18 -- The Chinese Communists in Shantung were receiving a limited amount of Russian material aid through Chefoo before the port was captured recently by Nationalist troops, according to Michael Keon, Australian journalist.

IN no country in the world is more deference paid to "public opinion" than in the United States. Legislators claim to follow it; special organizations exist to measure it; newspapers, radio networks and other media of mass communication seek to reflect and influence it. The underlying assumption behind the appeal to public opinion is that, whatever else good government is, it is better when it is an expression of public opinion.

PARIS. PARIS, "City of Light," pre-eminent center of the arts and sciences, has stolen a march on Hollywood. It claims to be the only city in the world that has a full-fledged university dedicated solely to the study of making movies.

MONTREAL, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens won their first game in two starts in the new National Hockey League season tonight, defeating the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 -- 2. It was the second straight loss for the Hawks.

MORE than almost any other city in America, Boston inspires the two extremes of feeling. Seldom if ever does one hear it said, "I can take Boston or leave it alone." Either you embrace it for its tranquil tempo, its high cultural traditions, the charm of its wandering streets, its Common, its lovely buildings; or you want to pound it in the ribs for its unprogressiveness, its snobbery, its intellectual intolerance.

A BOX camera on a tripod and two No. 1 amateur flood lamps in metal reflectors -- this is all the equipment Earle Forbes of 157 East Forty-sixth Street uses to make pictures of professional quality. Mr. Forbes, a former dancer, who specializes in spare-time photography of dancers, actors and general portraiture, discussed his methods in a talk last week at the Manhattan Camera Club.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- A joint economic and social committee of the United Nations General Assembly voted overwhelmingly today, against Soviet Union objections, to approve special "hands-off" agreements with the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund.

An increased tempo of building operations now marks the 5,000-acre development at Smoke Rise, near Butler, N.J., where the first house was completed last week and the occupants started moving in on Thursday. Eight other houses are nearing completion, with two of them to be ready before the end of next month and the other to be occupied by the end of the year.

The playing heard from Alexander Borovsky at his piano recital yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall differed in important aspects from that of his previous appearances in this city. With advancing age, his performances have now taken on a new mellowness, and lost most of the dry quality formerly prevalent in his work.

GEORGE WASHINGTON is estimated to have written between 20,000 and 25,000 letters, long widely scattered. The William H. Taft papers in the Library of Congress contain several hundred thousand pieces. The number of scripts to be deposited in the Franklin D. Roosevelt Library at Hyde Park is uncertain, but the papers have to be measured in quarter miles, for as early as 1942 it was officially reported that they aggregated 2,464 "linear feet."

LONDON, Oct. 18 -- Leaving for New York on the Queen Mary today after a month in Europe Representative John Taber, Republican, of New York, chairman of House Appropriations Committee said he still held the view that "England will have to work harder."

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Held scoreless in the first quarter by a courageous Virginia Tech line, Army's hard-driving backs finally found themselves and then proceeded to romp to a 40-to-0 triumph over the Southerners before 20,000 persons at Michie Stadium today.

OUTSTANDING among modern shows of the week are the paintings by Boris Margo at the Betty Parsons Gallery, shown simultaneously with his cellocuts exhibit at the Brooklyn Museum. Known as an experimenter, Margo does not need to be working in an unusual medium, such as the cellocuts of his own invention, to demonstrate originality and daring.

A new family of compounds that have been tested on human subjects and found to be effective against disease-producing organisms never satisfactorily treated before was reported yesterday by two Puerto Rican scientists at the close of a two-day conference on filariasis conducted by the New York Academy of Sciences.
AUTUMN brings one of the loveliest perennial cornflowers into blossom. The large lacy flowers of Centaurea amara start opening in August and continue to bloom until frost.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A well-known radio commentator, in his broadcast on Sunday, Oct. 12, made the following statement:

As many instrumentalists of the Philharmonic-Symphony as could crowd onto the Town Hall stage gathered there yesterday morning to entertain and enlighten a house full of youngsters. Walter Hendl, young assistant conductor of the orchestra, conducted and announced the program.
ATHENS, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Three Athens newspapers said today that a complete shakeup in the Greek high command had been effected at a military council meeting which opened two days ago at Volos.

BRIDGE players who use the Blackwood ace-showing convention, as most bridge players do, will profit from the application of this rule: Before bidding four no trump at any time, pause long enough to consider each response partner may make; what that response will mean, and what your own rebid will then be.

The United States Tax Court recently held, in a divided opinion, that in spite of the fact that a "foundation," created by provision of the last will and testament of the founder as a scientific organization, was directed to pay to the founder's widow a specified amount of money and an annuity for life, it may still be exempted from income tax.

AN equinoctial storm coming down from Canada in September swept across Idaho, and brought the first snow to the Teton Mountains of Wyoming. In a marsh at Jackson's Hole, in the valley of the Tetons, the wind that preceded the snow toppled a dead cottonwood tree where an osprey perched.

LONDON. THE measures taken by the British Labor Government to meet the economic crisis have brought to the forefront a question which has always existed in the minds of many men and women in America, in Europe and in Britain itself.

EASTON, Pa., Oct. 18 -- Deploring "inadequate teaching" of history in American high schools and colleges, Secretary of State George C. Marshall urged here today that greater emphasis be put on history by the educational systems of the country.
TO THE EDITOR: Re Chester Bowles' article, "Challenge to the Business Man," in THE TIMES Magazine:

SIR ALEXANDER MAXWELL, chairman of the British Tourist and Holiday Board, arrived in New York a few days ago looking not the least bit austere about England's tourist industry. This has been an excellent year so far, and next year should be better, with more shipping and with the summer Olympic games to be held in London.

BY coincidence three exhibitions in the nature of memorials opened last week. One of these was of paintings by Alien Tucker (1866-1939), one of the most widely loved and inspiring artists of his generation.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Oct. 18 (AP) -- George Taliaferro, Indiana's three-way ground-gainer from Gary, performed as if he were taking a screen test for the all-America team today as the Hoosiers mauled Pittsburgh, 41 to 6, before 25,000 Dad's Day fans.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 18 -- Rising food and living costs are jeopardizing the welfare of America's disabled veterans and their families, John L. Golob, national commander of the Disabled American Veterans, said today in an appeal for dependency allowances for wives and children of handicapped ex-servicemen.

It ought to be a principle of the regulation of air travel that a near catastrophe shall be as rigorously investigated as an actual tragedy. This will apparently be so in the case of the Bermuda Sky Queen, whose passengers and crew were rescued at sea at great risk and with heroic skill by Capt. Paul Kronk's Coast Guard cutter Bibb.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- North Carolina Halfback Charlie (Choo Choo) Justice, his amateur standing cleared only a few minutes before kick-off, celebrated today by sparking his team-mates to a 13-to-7 victory over previously unbeaten William and Mary before an overflow crowd of 19,000.

IN a statement that has been much quoted since it was first made two weeks ago. Secretary George C. Marshall remarked that our foreign policy had entered the American home and taken a seat at the family table. He might have said that it has gone farther than that -- into the kitchen that supplies the table, where it stands by the cook as she does her tasks.
OF all the gifts we can give our children, says Lawrence K. Frank, probably the first in importance, and surely the most precious, are confidence and courage.

Marshall plan goals for industrial equipment, while imposing in their totals, when broken down into details of components set targets which could be attained without re-subjecting America's heavy industries to their former rigid strait-jackets of priorities, allocations and governmental controls, industrial leaders here revealed yesterday.

TIN PAN ALLEY -- nowadays no alley, but a broad and busy thoroughfare stretching from midtown Manhattan to Hollywood -- is currently the scene of a revolution. Or maybe it's a counter-revolution. Since the early Thirties the nation's musical fare has been almost exclusively swing and other malformations of honest jazz; today swing has virtually disappeared and "sweet" is in a meteoric ascendant.
A work stoppage will take place tomorrow morning in the BatteryBrooklyn tunnel when 1,200 sandhogs will meet to demand wage increases and "safe and proper working conditions."

Responsible business men agree with Secretary of State George C. Marshall's interpretation last week of the underlying reason for the Soviet dictatorships' newly intensified propaganda warfare against the remnants of European capitalism and the still flourishing supports of American free enterprise.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- The Coast Guard cutter Bibb, which rescued sixty-nine passengers and crew from the transatlantic clipper Bermuda Sky Queen today plowed at twenty knots through heavy seas toward a welcome in Boston Harbor tomorrow.

HERE is vivid, observant reporting on post-war Germany, melted down to make a base for a novel with Hollywood symptoms. Lionel Shapiro has a good sense of theatre; his principals, American Major Lashley and French Themis Delisle, meet during an excellent court-room scene.

LAKE PLACID -- Revival of the one-day and week-end ski trains by the New York Central Railroad to up-state winter sports centers and establishment of a unified ski technique to be taught at all ski schools in this state were announced at the Winter Sports Forum held here last week.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 18 -- Korea is watching with mixed fear and hope the United Nations Assembly discussions of her future which are to begin next week.

In the first week of the United Hospital Fund's sixty-ninth annual campaign $591,258 were raised, it was reported yesterday by William H. Jackson, chairman of the appeal in behalf of eighty-nine voluntary hospitals and nursing homes throughout Greater New York.

HOLLYWOOD. HENRY MORGAN, who can antagonize sponsors faster than any other comedian on the air, is making his screen debut at the Enterprise Studio in "So This Is New York" with a minimum of antagonism toward his employers.

Hard-pressed to meet the unrelenting demand for gas, utilities in the metropolitan area are preparing to intervene in their own behalf when the Federal Power Commission opens hearings on the application of the Trans-Continental Gas Pipe Line Company on Oct. 27 for permission to construct a 26-inch pipeline from the Texas gas fields to markets 1,400 miles east along the Atlantic seaboard.

DURHAM, N.C., Oct. 18 (AP) -- An alert Duke aggregation posted its third victory of the season here today by turning back an aggressive Maryland eleven, 19 -- 7, before 15,000 shirt-sleeved football fans in Duke Stadium.

"THE GREAT LIGHT" is a novel with a Purpose. This purpose is to advance the thesis that "the familiar world is not the real world and it is not absolute. Behind it is another world of the spirit, and we shall only find it by creating it, a little here, a little there."

WITH a month of the fall season under its belt, business appears to like the taste of things better than it did a short while ago. Trade managed to hold its margin over last year in dollars if not in units, and industry sees no important signs of faltering.
The electorate of New York City on election day will vote on the question of proportional representation as a method of electing City Council members.

WHEN, at the start of the war, Peter Olden, the protagonist of Hans Habe's novel, entered the OSS, he had lived in America for thirteen years. Born in Duesseldorf on the Rhine, he knew the German language and German psychology intimately.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 18 -- Rutgers walloped Fordham's Rams by 36 -- 6 today to the surprise of practically nobody in a crowd of 10,000. It meant merely that the Maroon's gridiron misfortunes were still occurring in this renewal of a rivalry that had lapsed in 1923. Fordham lost that year, 42 -- 0.

HONOLULU -- Everything is normal in Paradise -- "plenty pilikia," as the natives say. Pilikia is the Hawaiian word for trouble, a full set of which is owned by the organizers of Aloha Week, which will begin next Sunday.
An agreement ending the four-day strike of grooms and exercise boys at the Jamaica Race Track was reached last night in the offices of the State Labor Relations Board.

PRAGUE, Oct. 18 -- Socialists protested sharply today against a remark attributed to the head of the Communist-dominated Confederation of Labor that those who rebelled against that unit should be sent to the mines or placed on construction work.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 18 -- Alert, powerful Penn State trampled a stubborn Syracuse eleven, 40 to 0, today.

TULSA, Okla., Oct. 18 (AP) -- A Georgetown University eleven that had the situation in hand from start to finish administered a 12-to-0 defeat today to the once potent University of Tulsa Hurricane. A crowd of 10,000 saw the home team suffer its first loss on its own field in three years.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 18 -- The Mexican Government maintains that it has arrested its unfavorable trade balance and the consequent depletion of its dollar reserves. That depletion had threatened the devaluation of the peso by enforcement of the strict embargo on "luxury" imports from the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct 18 -- President Truman and other high Government officials, including members of the Supreme Court and the Cabinet, are scheduled to attend tomorrow a ceremony marking the establishment of Covenant-First Presbyterian Church in Washington as the national capital church of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A.

New skills of daredevil drivers, better boats and engines, hyped-up fuels and improved lubricants are responsible for a score or more of probable new speed-boat records at 1947 regattas. American Power Boat Association officials are now considering the batch for new recognition.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Urging that further efforts be made to bring about the participation of the Soviet Union in the long delayed conference to draft the peace treaty with Japan, Dr. Wang Shih-chieh, Chinese Foreign Minister, today explained his proposal for a compromise solution.

Wall Street, which since the Pecora investigation by the Senate that laid the groundwork in the early days of the Roosevelt Administration for strict Federal control over banking and financing, is now ready to undergo the full scrutiny of the Department of Justice after a three-year investigation of major investment banking houses.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Carnegie Tech which lost all of its football games last season today dropped its opening contest of this year to a stronger West Virginia Wesleyan eleven, 27 to 6.

FUERTH, Germany, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Irma Mohaupt, 22 years old, born in the United States, told today a story of escape after three years in a Russian work camp, how she walked until her feet were swollen and eventually had reached freedom in the United States zone.

TORONTO, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Hockey's world champions, the Toronto Maple Leafs, were held to a 2-2 tie in their opening National League game tonight by the Detroit Red Wings as 13,674 fans, including Viscount Alexander, Canada's Governor General, presented the Stanley Cup to the Leafs then faced off the puck.
Bakers in three more cities joined others in New York and Baltimore yesterday in a weekend advance of the price of bread.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 -- It is possible that a special legislative committee, seeking solutions for Boston's apparently insoluble parking problems, may recommend in the next session that Faneuil Hall Market, a living relic of Colonial and Revolutionary times, be eliminated.

To the Screen Editor: Mr. Fitzroy Davis' lament in last Sunday's TIMES with reference to the rapid professional demise of our screen actresses has also been my pet grievance for a long time. I doubt very much if the fickleness of our American public is to blame.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 18 -- A Northwestern Wildcat that refused to become the fourth sacrificial lamb for monstrous Michigan went down fighting, 49 to 21, today, after giving the Wolverines more anxious moments than they had endured all season.

With members of the international military jumping teams of Canada, Ireland, Mexico and the United States as guests of honor, the annual Horse Show Ball will be given on Nov. 6 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria immediately after that evening's session of the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden.

THIS is an extremely interesting book from two quite different points of view. In a technical sense, it is an almost perfect example of what ghost-writing can and should be. J. Bryan 3d, whose name quite honestly appears on the title-page, is never present in the text, which comes right out of the mouth of "the old man" himself.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Charley Conerly passed for three touchdowns and plunged over for another to give the Mississippi Rebels a 27 to 14 victory over the Tulane Green Wave before 40,000 spectators today.

Sleepy Hollow Revisited The restoration and opening to the public of the old Washington Irving house near Tarrytown in the Hudson Valley, of which one has heard and still hears so much, are luring many people to pay it a visit and causing many more to harbor in their minds the laudable intention of doing so.

MIAMI -- Human Relations A Department of Human Relations, said to be the first of its kind, has been established by Miami University. The initial course, "Patterns of Human Relations," will survey the problems of majority and minority groups in the United States today.
ARTURO TOSCANINI will start his tenth year as conductor of the NBC Symphony when he inaugurates the 1947-48 season with an all-Beethoven program this Saturday from 6:30 to 7:30 P.M.
THE first of various countries' promised stamps in commemoration of the fourth centenary of the birth of Miguel de Cervantes Saavedra reached Leon Monosson last week.

A NEW single-unit 16-mm. sound projector in the lower priced field is announced by Universal Camera Corporation, 28 West Twenty-third Street, for early release. Called the Tonemaster, the projector has an 8-inch dynamic speaker, heavy-duty five-tube amplifier, built-in microphone and record plug-in connections, triblade shutter assuring flicker-free projection and increased light efficiency, 2,000-foot reels, controls centrally located; reverse-draft cooling system; single lever rewind; compact aluminum carrying case; 50-foot speaker cord.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Oct. 18 -- A preliminary survey by United Nations officials in Geneva indicates that to hold the General Assembly in Geneva, as has been suggested, would be feasible as far as meeting facilities are concerned but difficult for housing the delegates.

NO stranger to the arts of the West Coast, Clare Boothe Luce will return to Hollywood next month to start work oil the adaptation of "The Screwtape Letters," a project close to her heart and the corporate interests of Twentieth Century-Fox.

THERE are some major and central reasons, along with whatever ancillary ones, for a faith that Joseph Conrad is going to be read more rather than less in the coming decades. In the twenty-three years since his death it has become rather the fashion to treat him as Bernard Shaw used to treat Shakespeare: that is, as an author outgrown.

ONE of the most charming features of Mrs. Winslow's writing is a rich reticence, not chilling but most inviting. When she makes a specific point about life in the South in "A Quiet Neighborhood," she does so casually without laboring it.

Last year Dr. W. Goetsch, Austrian biologist, announced his discovery of vitamin T, a new complex. He extracted "T" from various insects, especially termites. It turned out that the insects did not produce the vitamin themselves but obtained it from yeast and fungi on which they fed.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Oct. 18 -- Lehigh broke a 23-year spell today by defeating the Gettysburg Bullets on their home gridiron for the first time since 1924 by a 9-7 count.

The International Emergency Conference to Combat Anti-Semitism did not call for "radical revisions in the story of Christ's crucifixion," as reported recently, the National Conference of Christians and Jews declared here yesterday.
The proposal for use of bonus money by veterans in this State to participate in cooperative housing ventures has evoked criticism from some realty interests.

PARIS, Oct.18 -- It appeared likely this week that a battle on the industrial front would take place between the Ramadier Government and Communists acting through the trade unions they control. It would amount to a test of strength between the economic power of the Communists and the civil power of the present Government led by Socialists.
NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- Kansas and Oklahoma, co-champions last year of the Big Six Conference, battered each other to a 13-13 tie today before 34,000 fans.

ODDLY enough for Broadway, last season's chatter about new legitimate theatres rising in our midst may yet turn into foundations and concrete. Robert W. Dowling of the City Investing Company, one of those who offered the "promissory note" last season, confides that two major architectural firms now are in the process of drawing up blueprints.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 (AP) -- Tom Fetzer threw two passes that went for touchdowns, and then tossed two others that set up scores, to lead unbeaten, untied Wake Forest to a 39-7 Southern Conference victory over George Washington today.

A LARGE body of choral literature, including some of the great composers' finest efforts, has been sadly neglected here, despite the fact that several choruses perform annually. A step that may help a bit to correct the situation is the formation of a new ensemble under the direction of Robert Shaw, young American conductor of the Collegiate Chorale.

THIS book should interest laymen as well as the professional soldier, for it provides an easy way to learn more of West Point, its Military Academy and those graduate leaders who contributed to the growth and building of our nation.

WILLIAM McCLEERY, who is a successful Broadway playwright, is also a successful bedtime story-teller, a role into which he was goaded, helped and made triumphant by his 5-yearold son, Michael, who, tiring of Goldilocks, demanded to hear about a wolf.

To the Drama Editor: THE complaints you have brought to our attention are symptoms of the heaviest demand for tickets in theatrical history -- a demand we are doing our utmost to meet with satisfaction to all.

PARIS. JUST when the current drama season opened in Paris is difficult to say. By the end of the first week of October, thirty-eight boulevard playhouses, four musicals and the five state-operated theatres were open for business and generally playing to full houses.

In the course of the Silliman lecture which he delivered at Yale last Week, Prof. Ernest O. Lawrence made the important announcement that in the Radiation Laboratory of the University of California a bright light had been thrown on one of the darkest questions in physics.

Members of Police Emergency Squad 4 broke down the door of a room on the fifth floor of the Polish Consulate at 149-51 East Sixty-seventh Street last night to take into custody a clerk of the Polish Delegation to the United Nations who had gone berserk.

The victory of the "rank and file" forces backing Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, over strongly entrenched Leftist opposition at the CIO affiliate's sixth biennial convention is being hailed in local maritime circles as a step toward labor stabilization in the shipping industry, it was said yesterday.

The City of New York receives more than half of all the revenues to local governments by the state and the charge made by some that it is "short-changed" is hyprocrisy, Charles D. Breitel, counsel to Governor Dewey, said last night in an address at the twenty-sixth annual dinner or the West of Central Park Association in the Hotel Biltmore.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 18 (AP) -- An aroused Ohio State team, which didn't look too good in the first half, found itself in the final period today and roared to two touchdowns on long drives to tie favored Iowa, 13 to 13, in a Western Conference game before 72,993 fans.
