YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Heard Russian bloc announce it would not participate in subcommittee set up to study United States proposal for yearround "Little Assembly."

WHEN Maurice Evans proposed staging Bernard Shaw's "Man and Superman" most theatregoers had a pleasant sense of anticipation. But probably few of us foresaw the tingling enjoyment the current performance provides.

Columbus Day in New York department stores and specialty shops was marked by a pre-Christmas rush, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Coat, suit and dress business soared, the survey stated.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Oct. 18 -- Lieut. Gen. Sir Brian Robertson, Deputy Military Governor of the British zone, refused today German requests for any extension of the two-week time limit during which appeals may be made against the final reparations list.

THE dance season of the Y.M. and Y.W.H.A., Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street, will get under way this week when Asadata Darora and his new Shogola Cloba group gives two performances, on Wednesday and Thursday evenings.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 18 -- The Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors' attempt to find out how many of its 20,000 employes are Communists, avowed or otherwise, has bogged down in legal difficulties.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States cited today possible cuts in Federal expenditures, taxes and the public debt for the next fiscal year and said it appeared that the major savings would have to be found in the items for national defense, veterans and international affairs.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 18 -- Victory number nine failed to come up for Yale today and there's nothing for the East to do but to admit that it's true what they say about the Big Nine.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Punching over two touchdowns on short drives in the first half and playing a sterling defensive game, the University of Rochester scored its third football victory of the season by defeating Tufts College before 7,000 today, 14 to 0.

The 28,500-ton liner Edinburgh Castle of the Union Castle Line, launched last Thursday at Belfast by Princess Margaret, is the second luxury liner to be put into the waters recently by the line to replace tonnage lost during the war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Corporation returns now publicly available indicate higher profits in the first two quarters of 1947, compared with the final quarter of last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.
PHILADELPHIA. UNLESS something happens over the week-end, during travel through the improbable fastnesses of New Jersey, "Medea" should be arriving on Broadway on schedule, that being tomorrow night.

Etchings and engravings by old and modern masters, the collection of Mrs. Dudley Olcott of New York, together with prints from another private collector, will be auctioned at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Ga., Oct. 18 (AP) -- Virginia, held at bay for three full periods by a Washington and Lee line, exploded for three touchdowns in the fourth quarter today to rout the Generals, 32 -- 7. It was the fourth straight victory for the Virginia eleven, which is undefeated.

The possibility of extending to all peoples freedom to decide their own destinies, "even to the extent of going contrary to their governments," is the greatest assurance for the maintenance of peace, Dr. Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil, president of the United Nations General Assembly, declared yesterday.

MR. SEAGLE'S short history of law is written in the form of a series of biographical sketches, each describing a commanding legal personality at work amid the social and economic forces of his time. Few subjects are harder to popularize than jurisprudence, yet Mr. Seagle (himself a lawyer now in Government employ) has made the wordiest and murkiest of sciences not only intelligible to the lay reader, but even intellectually attractive.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 18 -- An apparently irresistible force is about to collide with a seemingly immovable object in Palestine. The force is Zionism and the object is Arab opposition to it.

ATLANTA, Ga., Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- Georgia Tech struck from far out to defeat Auburn, 27 to 7, today before 37,000 fans, but between touchdowns the Engineers had their hands full with an ancient foe inspired by game-legged but game-hearted Travis Tidwell.

Editor New York Times Book Review: THE recent article entitled "The English Literary Scene Today." by Louis MacNeice, seems notable chiefly for its confusion of thought on one hand and a talent for contradicting himself on the other.

Colgate University's Washington study plan, designed to promote a better understanding of Congressional and governmental activities among students through actual observation, has been resumed after a lapse of five years.

Brooklyn College broke into the victory column in convincing fashion yesterday, turning back the Wagner eleven by 39 -- 14, at the Kingsmen's field. The point total was the highest for the Kingsmen since 1937, when they downed a Wagner team by 50 -- 0.

THIS beautiful, unusual, richly informative book is a trailblazer in its special field. Rutherford Platt, Burroughs Award winner and author of "This Green World," is more than a competent observer of nature. He has also the ability to paint word pictures that link the little-known eras of long ago to the living present.

PARIS, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A commission of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today recommended setting up machinery for assuring "a free flow of words and images across national borders."

PARIS, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- The International Air Transport Company, a French charter line, announced today that forty-two persons, including eight children, were believed lost Thursday when one of its two-engined airliners crashed in the Mediterranean near Cartagena, Spain, en route from Marseille to Oran, Algeria.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- Government economists say that home building has headed into "the biggest fall season in history."

TO THE EDITOR: Re Mary Bagnara's letter criticizing the "slur" which Carlo Levi (in his article, "Peasants Stir in Groping Italy") casts upon the Christian Democratic party: It is true that the party is made up, in part, of good Catholic people who are opposed to communism.

THE resignation of Charles R. Denny as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission underscores the extraordinary turnover among capable men who have held that important post in recent years. When he formally leaves office the end of this month Mr. Denny will have been the commission's sixth chairman since 1934 and its third in the last eight years.

CHICAGO, Oct. 18 -- When Col. Robert R. McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, returns from his round-the-world trip which will include a visit with Gen. Douglas MacArthur in Tokyo, political leaders of both major parties hereabouts are hoping he'll have the answer to this question:

AT the end of the war Edmund Wilson, New Yorker literary critic, author of "Memoirs of Hecate County," turned his percipient and cultivated mind upon some parts of the wreckage of Europe. Curiously enough, he seems to have given little attention to France, which readers of his work through the years know to be a country decisive in his culture.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- A large measure of whatever legislative success the Marshall Plan and its related schemes for aid to Europe may encounter -- and the prospects today are good -- can be accounted as the fruits of the idea of sending Congressmen around the world to investigate conditions.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- The New Rochelle branch of the American Association for the United Nations exchanged strong "notes" today with Council 339 of the Knights of Columbus over the former's invitation to the Rev. William Howard Melish to address the group at a meeting next Tuesday night.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 18 -- Generating a winning temperature that almost matched the 82 degrees in which a crowd of 35,500 sweltered at Schoellkopf Field, Navy today won a football game for the first time since beating Villanova on Sept. 26, 1946, at Annapolis.

"Away with themes of War! Away with war itself! Hence from my shuddering sight, to nevermore return, that show of blacken'd, mutilated corpses! That hell unpent, and raid of blood -- fit for wild tigers, or for lop-tongued wolves -- not reasoning men! And in its stead speed Industry's campaigns with thy undaunted armies, Engineering! Thy pennants, Labor, loosen'd to the breeze.

On a sixty-acre site in the Kew Gardens Hills section of Queens, initial work is due to start within ten days on a new apartment community, which is expected eventually to represent an investment of $11,000,000.

Although the word "conservative" long has been popularly associated with New England, it is a term that is inaccurate when applied to its activities in public health fields, the care of the blind, the deaf and the crippled, tuberculosis and cancer.

The New York Football Giants, who have suffered unaccustomed indignities on the road, look for better things today when they open their twenty-third season in the Polo Grounds against the Boston Yanks. A crowd of 40,000 is expected at the contest, which is slated to start at 2:05 P.M.

FROM now through November, a big item on many gardeners' calendars is tulip planting. In tiny gardens or big estates, in nooks or large formal beds, the small brown bulbs are set out during these fall weeks, with anticipation of a colorful tuliptime next spring.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -- If assured of full-scale conservation of grain at the source by poultry raisers and poultry feed producers, the Citizens Food Committee probably will eliminate the poultry phase of its food-saving program.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- Michigan State took a liking to the rain today and splashed its way to a muddy 20-to-0 victory over Iowa State before a drenched homecoming crowd of 20,987 fans at Macklin Field.

WHY did the charming, historic town of Salem, Mass., win such affluence and commercial eminence between the Revolution and 1812? How did Salem houses escape being the monstrosities which get-rich-quickers built elsewhere? "In just one way," says Mr. Phillips.

WARSAW, Oct. 18 -- The two weeks that have passed since the proclaiming of the new Communist "Information Bureau" in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, have shed little light on the character of the new organization.

Six hundred ninety-five women in their twenties, ranging in profession from clerk to school teacher and in dress from the chic "new look" to slacks and bobby socks, converged yesterday morning upon George Washington High School. They had one goal -- to pass the police examinations held every four years.

LONDON. PRAVDA recently burst into full-throated song on the subject of the visual arts in general and on the painting of pictures in particular. Rather than attempt a precis of the article I prefer to quote a few of its more trenchant phrases, for its flavor depends as much on its agitated tone of voice as on the matter contained in it.

SOME novels are pure inventions, others partially so, and the pseudo-historical story is necessarily both. The high current interest in the written past is probably a wish for escape from what cannot be called an entertaining historical present, and so it was to be expected that Louis Bromfield, ever audience-conscious, should also have his fling with the dear dead days beyond recall.

BIRCH ISLAND COVE, Me., Oct. 18 -- We arrived here early Friday morning to be greeted by a bright sun, cloudless skies, no wind and an edict from the Governor of Maine closing the woods to all hunting until such time as an adequate rainfall eliminated the forest fire hazard.

MEDIA, Pa., Oct. 18 -- Before a record-shattering crowd of 14,000, Mrs. Randolph Scott's Compass Rose today won the Foxcatcher Plate, feature race of the eighty-eighth annual fall meet of the Rose Tree Fox Hunting Club, for the second consecutive year.

BOSTON, Oct. 18 Purdue University's Boilermakers really boiled today and hammered out nine touchdowns to crush Boston University's Terriers, 62 -- 7, before an alumni day crowd of 11,446 at Fenway Park.

TOKYO, Oct. 18 -- Renewed suggestions in the United States that Emperor Hirohito abdicate because of the account of his pre-war and wartime activities that was given by Marquis Koichi Kido before the International Military Tribunal have been attracting some attention, here today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In the sad picture offered by Western Europe at present, Germany plays by far the major role, not necessarily in the sense that her misery exceeds that of some other states, but because her condition is one of the main reasons for widespread distress elsewhere.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 18 (U.P.) -- Hungarian Premier Lajos Dinnyes said today that he believed the United States and Russia eventually would find a "common ground" for political agreement, despite their present lack of cooperation.

DETROIT, Oct. 18 (AP) -- A sizable segment of the nation's automobile industry will get back into production next week and probably lift output volume back again to somewhere around 70,000 cars and 25,000 trucks, it was said here today.

ROME, Oct. 18 -- The Italian Labor Confederation today announced a twenty-four-hour general strike "as a first measure" to protest against the failure of industrialists to conclude a new labor contract with the metal workers and of the Government to grant state employes automatic salary increases.

I HOPE we can learn from books, for only through literature such as this can Americans participate in China's anguish, and gain before too late some understanding of the roots of her revolution. Robert Payne writes as a poet, sensitive to color and feeling, responsive to the passions and terrors and philosophies of people immediately around him.

ALTHOUGH there was no indication that any conscious embarrassment was felt in neighboring theatres exhibiting recent product from Hollywood, the revival on Broadway last week of "The Birth of a Nation" could have caused a blush or two, especially at the Rivoli, the Capitol and Loew's Criterion.

THE so-called war between the two major professional football leagues certainly falls into the category of a "cold war," the newest and most striking bit of terminology to hit print in many a moon. No blood is being spilled nor cities leveled. But the gridiron folk have been sadly remiss in one respect. Their invectives have not been sharp enough nor barbed enough.

Burma, last of the Asiatic nations to be swept by force into the British imperial domain, now becomes the first to withdraw peacefully from the British Commonwealth. Under a pact sealed in London's historic little house at 10 Downing Street, the new nation on Jan. 6 regains the full freedom it lost nearly a century ago.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Oct. 12 Benjamin Fine gave a comprehensive description of the meeting of educators appointed by President Truman as a board for the implementation of the Fulbright Act. The act provides that nations where surplus United States war property accumulated might purchase a certain amount of it, the proceeds to be used to establish international scholarships.

THE United States has been called the land of the juke box, the gin mill and the best-selling novel. Our roots go far deeper than these superficial symbols, however; the United States is also the land of going to church, eating family turkey at Christmas, and the best-selling best seller here is still the Holy Bible.
A CENTENARIAN in Benton Harbor, Mich., bought $2,000 worth of Government bonds to mature in ten years.
The erroneous assumption that the withdrawal of Russian armies from occupied Europe will "solve" the present politico-military crisis is a dangerous fallacy.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. IN recent columns this department has been discussing, from one angle or another, the present state of creative writing in the United States and in Britain. One facet of the situation, to which I have so far made only passing reference, is the part played by critics and reviewers, and by the editors of those papers and magazines which devote all or part of their attention to the current literary output.

American Overseas Airlines dispatched its first transatlantic flight in nineteen days yesterday morning as the company and the Air Line Pilots Association, AFL, resumed contract negotiations in New York.

Navy finally won a football game and Yale lost one. Forget Michigan's forty-niners and their goal rush for the moment. Leave the bouquets unil later too, for the other big fellows -- Notre Dame, Texas, Illinois, Army, California.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your front page story of Oct. 6 that Senator Vandenberg says that "the United States policy is already starting to move * * *" toward mutual defense treaties under Article 51 of the United Nations Charter is interesting and important.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- A sharp falling off in the make of lard plus liberal shipments resulted in a reduction of 8,446,000 pounds in cold storage stocks of that commodity during the first half of this month, the total being reduced to 76,555,000 pounds compared with only 2,399,000 pounds a year ago.

The rise in food prices since the end of OPA has frequently led to charges of profiteering by industry. These charges are now being repeated by many persons. The staff of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report has included some very interesting figures dealing with this problem in its recent survey of "Food Prices, Production, and Consumption."

Jack Mannix and Lou Faillace each crossed the Maroon goal line twice as Brooklyn Prep's football team annexed its fourth victory in as many starts by routing Fordham Prep, 30 to 0, before 1,500 fans at Fordham Field yesterday.
GENISSIAT, France, Oct. 19 -- The long-dreamed-of project of harnessing the power of the Rhone River as it rushes from the Alps to the Mediterranean is nearing completion.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- Spearheading a drive to put the entertainment business in the Republican column in the 1948 elections, announcement was made yesterday of the organization of a Hollywood Republican committee.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Is Wall Street on the eve of another boom and at last yielding to what is described here as the undiminished strength of inflationary pressures? Will investors flood back to the market that they so long have neglected, and will British investors, who now are able to take a larger, although still a very restricted, interest in dollar securities, be tempted to take a hand in an American bull market?

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Jaroslav Drobny, Czechoslovak Davis Cup star, came from behind today to defeat Francisco (Pancho) Segura of Ecuador, 4-6, 7-9, 6-3, 6-4, 6-3, and win the men's singles title in the sixth Pan-American tennis tournament.

ST. PAUL, Oct. 19 -- For the first time the Jewish War Veterans of the United States have elected a Midwesterner as the national commander. Col. Julius Klein, 46 years old, Chicago public relations consultant and former newspaper man, has been chosen.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 -- Three bacteriologists of the University of Southern California disclosed tonight that, working with the aid of funds from the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, they had developed an "immunizing agent" resistant to some forms of poliomyelitis in monkeys.

A twenty-four year old mortgage for $350,000 was burned yesterday at ceremonies in the St. James Protestant Episcopal Church of Fordham, Jerome Avenue and 190th Street, the Bronx. The mortgage was for the St. James Apartments, 2525 Morris Avenue, erected adjacent to the church during the housing crisis following World War I, to provide homes for members of the congregation.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 19 -- Regional matters of vital importance to the state governments of the South were put on the agenda when the eighth annual Southern Governors Conference opened its three-day session here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- A Senate investigation of the crash of an Eastern Airlines plane on May 30 which killed fifty-three persons found today that "faulty inspection may have been the cause." This was the finding of Carl Dolan, professional staff member for the Senate's aviation subcommittee.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The champion Cleveland Browns, tagged with their first loss in twelve games last week, escaped today with a 31-28 victory over a surprisingly strong Chicago Rockets team in an All-America Football Conference tussle before 35,266.

A new 685-foot, fireproof concrete and steel pier, mounting a twenty - five - ton Gantry crane, which has just been completed at the Hoboken Division of Todd Shipyards Corporation, was opened officially yesterday. Known as Pier D, the new structure was designed especially for shipyard service by Todd engineers.

Representative Emanuel Celler predicted yesterday that the next few years would bring some form of "Government-financed medical and health assistance for all, despite opposition from the medical profession."

Two highly controversial matters -- a renewed effort to break the deadlock on the Security Council election, and final action on the Greek situation -- are on the agenda of the United Nations General Assembly, which will hold plenary session's at flushing Meadow at 11 A. M. and 3 P. M. today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Sept. 29 THE TIMES printed a very interesting letter from Col. Stanley Washburn, who since 1904 has had such remarkable experience with Russia and the Russians.

Aggressive purchasing of metal products, under policies similar to those maintained during the third quarter, will fee continued during the fourth, quarter of the year, purchasing executives representing large industrial users revealed here over the week-end.

When President Truman called two weeks ago for higher trading margins in the grain markets he accompanied his demand with a threat that unless the exchanges took action in the matter the Government would step in to limit trading.

Representatives of the electrical transcription industry here asserted yesterday that they did not expect their field to be affected seriously by the ban imposed by James G. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, against the making of recordings and transcriptions by members of his union.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- President Truman said today that people who believe in the Golden Rule and the teachings of Christ's Gospel should stand by their principles to assure "an honorable, decent peace" for all nations.

Since Pearl Harbor thirty-five members of the New York Fire Department have lost their lives on war fronts and forty-nine have died fighting fires in the city, Fire Commissioner Frank J. Quayle reported yesterday.

For three hours wore than 200 horse owners and trainers sat in a section of the grandstand at the Jamaica race track yesterday afternoon to discuss the "code of honor" that ended the strike of exercise boys and grooms Saturday night.
The low-cost dinner suggested by the City Department of Markets for tonight will cost $2.50 for five persons.

Between forty and fifty bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church will attend the consecration of the Rev. Dr. Horace W.B. Donegan as suffragan bishop of the Diocese of New York, in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine at 10:30 A.M. on Oct. 28.

The sixth annual Freedom Award of Freedom House was presented last night to Secretary of State George C. Marshall. His predecessors in office and his contemporaries in the fight for world peace hailed his services as Chief of Staff in the recent war and his present role as peacemaker.

PARIS, Oct. 19 -- Hope was held out today by Government officials for settlement of the nine-day Paris transit strike. The Ramadier regime is preparing to deal tomorrow with the claims of all Paris unions for a 15 to 20 per cent wage increase.

Two hundred delegates from eighty-seven Hebrew youth organizations and community centers in the city, Westchester, Nassau and Suffolk attended the annual convention and dinner of the New York Metropolitan Section, National Jewish Welfare Board, yesterday at the Pennsylvania Hotel.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 -- The story of twenty-four dreadful hours during which men, women and children floundered in an icy mid-Atlantic before all were taken off their wrecked plane was told by survivors of the Bermuda Sky Queen and their rescuers on their arrival here today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- With his skillful sailing of his sloop Aileen, Corny Shields today won his third race of the six-race series in the International Class for the Haebler trophy at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

Immediate international action easing "red tape" causing delay additional costs and other severe impediments to the movement of goods from one country to another was urged over the week-end by the International Chamber of Commerce.

Not often does a pair of producers as young as Robert White-head and Oliver Rea come along to pit their wits against the Missouri-like Broadway attitude with a revival of one of the world's oldest tragedies. Though the plan may seem startling', the team is sponsoring "Medea," last revived here in 1920, for its local managerial debut this evening at the National.

The citizens of France voted yesterday in 38,000 local elections. Ostensibly they were choosing city governments, but actually they were taking sides on the issue that divides the world. For the second time in a week, first in Rome and now in the peculiarly variegated and self-centered towns of France, a municipal vote has taken on the importance of an international event.

OTTAWA, Oct. 19 -- Canada's position as the only dollar country in the British Commonwealth and that of South Africa as a gold producing country are responsible, it is said here, for the agreement made at Geneva for gradual removal of "bound margins," one of the outstanding features of the Ottawa trade agreements of 1931-32.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 -- Steel production last week for the country approached previous post-war peaks when the ingot rate advanced 1/2 point to 97 per cent of rated capacity. If such a level could be maintained for a year total steel output would match or at least come close to the record made in 1944, when more than 89,000,000 tons of ingots were produced.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Sharpshooting Sid Luckman pitched three touchdown passes to pace the Chicago Bears to a 33-24 National Football League decision over the Detroit Lions before 36,105 at Wrigley Field today.

DUNDEE, Scotland, Oct. 18 (Delayed) -- Dundee used to be described as the "city of jute, jam and journalists." That was flattery. It really was just a city of jute, for all practical purposes, and when depressions came Dundee suffered even more heavily than other depressed areas.

MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The California Federation for Civic Unity was reorganized today from the old State Council for Civic Unity. It plans to send out field workers to oppose racial discrimination.

A special session of Congress should be called immediately to meet the problems caused by Russia's "cold war" against the democracies, the Rev. Dr. Henry Darlington, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, declared yesterday.

Three hundred and ninety-seven persons, from 14 to 78 years old, journeyed to Kent, Conn., Saturday afternoon for the New Haven railroad's tenth anniversary Old Fashioned Husking Bee. A special train consisting of engine, six coaches, refreshment car and a special car for the press transported them from Grand Central Terminal to the scene of the bee and did not return them to Manhattan until the early hours of yesterday morning.

Words of Great Men Lives of great men remind us -- among other matters -- that most of them have said things that the rest of us remember. History has produced many great men and many memorable sayings to which their names are attached.

Eddie Katz, violinist, was heard in a recital last night at Town Hall. His program comprised the Brahms Sonata in A major; the Bruch Concerto, No. 2, in D minor; Mozart's Sonata in B flat (K. 378), and a group containing William Kroll's "Banjo and Fiddle," the Prokofieff-Heifetz "Masks," the Gershwin-Heifetz "Prelude," No. 3; Achron's "Hebrew Melody," and Bazzini's "La ronde des lutins."

PANAMA, Oct. 18 (Delayed) -- This Government cannot cancel the Panamanian licenses of the ships Pan York and Pan Crescent, reported loaded with unauthorized Jews bound for Palestine, because the British request for this did not furnish authentic proof of the charges, according to a communication issued by the Foreign Office here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Prices of corn averaged higher last week, but part of the strength came from sympathy with wheat and on buying induced by a tight situation in the cash market and comparatively light country offerings of both old and new corn.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- The fact-finding committee that investigated the dispute at the Grimethorpe colliery, where the miners' refusal to work two feet extra on their daily stint brought out almost all South Yorkshire miners |in a sympathy strike, reported-privately today.
Norman Sherman has joined Manhattan Mannequins, Inc., as partner and business manager.

NEWARK, Del., Oct. 19 -- Delegates to the Eastern Theatre Conference here today unanimously approved a resolution calling for the inclusion of a representative of the theatre on the United States national commission of UNESCO.

With bread prices rising today one cent a loaf and milk companies warning that they may increase the price of milk again, Governor Dewey was asked yesterday to call a special session of the State Legislature to set up a "Little OPA."

Park Commissioner Robert Moses is opposed to the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council and is expected to announce some time this week his willingness to support the movement for its repeal.

Prices of cotton for future delivery in the domestic market showed a generally advancing trend last week. At the close of trading on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net advances of 60 to 91 points, the largest gain for the season on the basis of weekly comparisons.

Only those who have watched death creeping hungrily toward them can know what goes on in the human heart. Mrs. Edgar Ritchie knows. She, her husband and her three-year-old boy are among the rescued passengers of the Bermuda Sky Queen brought to port yesterday on the stout ship Bibb.

Despite drastic changes in her position abroad, Great Britain remains a powerful imperial nation. This is true despite the evacuation of the lower Nile Valley, relinquishment of colonial rights in India and the pledged withdrawal from Palestine.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The hustling and alert Los Angeles Rams handed the Chicago Cardinals their first defeat of the season, 27 to 7, before a Memorial Coliseum crowd of 69,631 today, setting a new attendance record for a National league football game.

Charles M. Martin, captain of the Bermuda Sky Queen, all of whose passengers and crew were rescued by the Coast Guard after coming down in the Atlantic, arrived at La Guardia Field last night on an Eastern Airlines plane from Boston.

Hardware and mill supplies, secondary wiring materials, canvas leggings and gas masks, chemicals and compounds, paints and industrial machinery are among more than ninety offering's of Government surplus property originally valued at $113,000,000 now scheduled to be sold by the War Assets Administration.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a brief recently submitted to the Senate Committee on Labor and Public Welfare, Donald Richberg voiced strong opposition to a bill proposing to establish a permanent commission to abolish employment discrimination based on race, color, creed or national origin.

Consolation for the decreasing supply of summer vegetables, corn, eggplant and such, is the appearance on the market of the winter squash and pumpkin that are among autumn's reasons for being, at least to New Englanders, who class this food somewhat above caviar.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Earl O. Shreve, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, today found a large share of the blame for spiraling prices in "the current superabundance of money."

Based on increases in fabric and trimming costs and assuming no change in labor costs, retailers may expect increases on men's clothing for spring to run from $1.25 to $1.50 on worsted and gabardine suits and $2 on tropical worsteds, according to the open letter issued for publication today by Jerome I. Udell of Max Udell Sons Co., clothing manufacturers.

PARIS, Monday, Oct. 20 -- Charles de Gaulle's new anti-Communist movement polled more votes than any other party or group in the nation-wide municipal elections in France yesterday. Incomplete returns early today indicated that de Gaullists might have obtained 40 per cent of the votes cast.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Jersey City Giants broke a two-game losing streak today at Roosevelt Stadium by defeating the Richmond Rebels, 10 to 0, in the American Football League. It was Richmond's second defeat in three starts.

More use of the International Court of Justice set up by the United Nations at The Hague was advocated yesterday by the executive council of the International Bar Association at a meeting in the Hotel Plaza.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The article by Gertrude Samuels in your issue of Oct. 12 was as deeply inspiring to Chester Bowles, Mrs. Roosevelt, Mme. Joliot-Curie and myself as it must have been for you and your readers. No finer statement has been made of the causes to which Mr. Bowles and his colleagues on our international advisory board have dedicated themselves.

F.O. MATTHIESSEN'S "The James Family"* contains nearly 400,000 words by and about one of the most remarkable and enduringly interesting families in American history. A biography of "a family of minds in action," Professor Matthiessen calls his book, which is "also a comprehensive anthology." Since his description is accurate, this huge and intellectually stimulating book is unlike any other "biography" which I have ever read.

The report of Secretary of the Interior Krug, making it plain that with proper management the United States is well able to support the foreign aid program proposed under the Marshall plan without jeopardizing our resources or standard of living, provides another powerful impetus for putting that plan into effect at the earliest possible moment.
An admitted former policy collector charged yesterday that three plainclothes patrolmen had kicked and punched him for thirty minutes in his candy store at 101 West 143d Street.

LAKES SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Delegates from the Arab states said today that, despite the United States and Soviet endorsement of the partition of Palestine, they had received enough definite pledges to block such a decision by the United Nations General Assembly.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 19 -- A mood of heavy weariness with all European problems and of great reluctance to take up the obligations that are to be assumed to be coming inevitably under the Marshall plan is running rather strongly through much of the South.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 19 -- Irving Rapper, who has been off salary at Warner Brothers since his refusal to direct "Christopher Blake," has obtained his release from his contract with the studio, he revealed, today. He had been with Warners for twelve years, having joined the studio as a dialogue director, and his contract would have expired in 1952.

The world is faced with a vital conflict between two ideologies and until this is resolved there can be no assurance of lasting peace or real economic stablity, Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall declared in an address last night.

Three hundred poultrymen, principally from New Jersey and New York, attended yesterday an annual conference sponsored by the Jewish Agricultural Society in the Educational Alliance, East Broadway and Jefferson Street; at which the saving of feed grains to help Europe was discussed.

The wedding of Princess Elizabeth to Lieut. Philip Mountbatten on Nov. 20 will be reported over the CBS hook-up by Edward. R. Murrow, who will leave here for London to cover the event Mr. Murrow's account will be included in his Monday - through - Friday commentaries from 7:45 to 8 P.M., which, from Nov. 17 through 21, will originate in the British capital.

A board of nine directors for the Nashville Corporation, recently organized to acquire the non-aviation assets of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft (Convair) Corporation, has been announced for publication today in a proxy statement prepared for mailing to Convair stockholders preliminary to their meeting on Nov. 6.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- A couple of fawns have confused and embarrassed officials of the Bear Mountain Trailside Museums here by their undiscriminating eating habits and bad manners. As of today, John Orth, director of the museums, has given up on the fawns after worrying about them since Sept. 15.

John Henry Titus, who for many years claimed authorship of the original version of the poem "The Face on the Bar Room Floor," died last night in Bellevue Hospital. His age was 94, according to his wife, who said the venerable poet's death resulted directly from shock and injuries suffered in a recent Florida hurricane.

It takes moral and physical courage to be vigorously anti-Communist in today's Czechoslovakia. Externally the Czechs are menaced on three sides by Russian troops. Internally the key positions in their coalition Government are controlled by Communists. In the last election, in May, 1946, the Communists and their left-wing allies received 51 per cent of the popular vote.

This is America's hour "to pray and sacrifice" so that the light of Christ's teachings may be spread throughout the world, Auxiliary Bishop Thomas J. McDonnell, national director of the Society for the Propagation of the Faith, declared yesterday.

Because of outmoded pier facilities, New York already has suffered from competition with other American seaports and will lose more ground unless the waterfront is modernized soon, according to Sanderson Porter, engineers.

Anton Dolin's choreographic version of "Camille" had its local premiere at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday evening in the second program of the brief season of Alicia Markova and Mr. Dolin and their little ensemble. The work is called "The Lady of the Camellias" and is set to music from "La Traviata" in an arrangement by the company's expert musical director, Robert Zeller.

More than a score of new group and one-man shows provide another overflow week in the local art season. Today's openings include paintings by Alfred Maurer at Bertha Schaefer's Gallery; four one-man shows of paintings and illustrations at the clubhouse of the Society of Illustrators and recent paintings by Martyl at the A.C.A. Gallery.

The Soviet Union's economic potential as a great world power has been exaggerated by "biased" official Soviet statistics into a "badly distorted" version of economic growth, according to analyses by a group of leading statisticians made public yesterday by Prof. Seymour E. Harris of Harvard University.

Taking cognizance of the disastrous effect on moving traffic of even one disabled vehicle on the generally crowded Henry Hudson Parkway, the State Department of Public Works will construct twenty-eight emergency turnouts on the road, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Hawaiian Dado Marino and Irish crooner Rinty Monaghan will battle tomorrow night for a lot of money and the right to be hailed as world flyweight champion.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Performing under mid-summer conditions on mushy ice, the Boston Bruins opened their twenty-fourth National Hockey League season by outscoring the New York Rangers 3 -- 1, before 13,900 jammed and sweltering spectators tonight at the Boston Garden.

Mischa Elman played an enormous program, one which asked everything of a master violinist, last night in Carnegie Hall. This program, considerably too long for its own good, included the Bach-Nachez Partita in E minor, the Brahms Sonata in D minor, the Spohr "Gesangscena," the Debussy Sonata, the Saint-Saens "Havanaise" and the Paganini 24th Caprice, as transcribed by Mr. Elman, with emendations of his own, and a plane part.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Unless the great powers "set aside all selfish interests and suspicions" and resolve to promote enduring peace, war will become "inevitable," Emanuel Shinwell, Britain's new Secretary of State for War, said in Stafford today.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 19 -- The Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of Fordham University, told a communion breakfast of the Fordham University Club of New Jersey here today that Fordham "does not ever again want a football team rated among the nation's ten heaviest."

CHICAGO, Oct 19 -- Eight hundred members of Local 16, Chicago Typographical Union, voted unanimously today to reject in its entirety a proposal by the publishers of Chicago daily newspapers looking to renewal of the employment contract which expires at midnight Tuesday.

A tiny plot of land in Riverside Drive, off Eighty-fourth Street and overlooking the Hudson River, was dedicated yesterday as the site of a memorial to six million Jewish men, women and children killed under Nazi rule.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Coming from behind a 0-10 deficit, the Los Angeles Dons romped to an easy 38-10 victory over the Baltimore Colts today in an All-America Football Conference game played before 36,852 spectators.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 -- In its September statistical bulletin, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today that the new corporate issues offered for cash sale in July totaled $601,000,000, the highest monthly figure this year excepting in June, when such issues aggregated $738,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The United States Air Force announced today that its combat units could fly anywhere and in any season in the Arctic regions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Issuance of a charter to employes of the New York Board of Transportation was announced here today by the International Association of Machinists.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Oct 19 -- A new method of combating icing on airplanes by using a rainmaking technique to clear clouds was described here today by scientists of the General Electric Company's Research Laboratory.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Villanova College, outplayed statistically, struck with two lightning-like thrusts to edge out a bruising University of Detroit football team, 14 to 12, today before 15,572 at Shibe Park.

BOSTON, Oct. 19 -- Planes, small boats, city dignitaries and a crowd of relatives and friends welcomed today the sixty-nine survivors of the ditched transatlantic airplane, Bermuda Sky Queen. Stories of tumultuous seas, a night of horror and the bravery of rescuers were told when the survivors arrived aboard the Coast Guard cutter Bibb.

How the mighty have fallen! Eastern champions of the National Football League last season, the New York Giants made their 1947 home debut yesterday at the Polo Grounds and never look weaker as they submitted to 14-0 setback by the Boston Yanks.

Mayor O'Dwyer asked union leaders last night to withhold a threatened work stoppage this morning by 1,200 sandhogs in the Brooklyn-Battery tunnel "in the public interest," pending the submission of a report by his Labor Relations Division on the issues in the dispute.

As part of a nation-wide program, Laymen's Sunday was observed here yesterday In Protestant churches under the sponsorship of the Laymen's Movement for a Christian World. In various churches the sermons were preached by laymen.

Election of Charles P. Taft, president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America; Dr. Everett Needham Case, president of Colgate University, and Dr. Sarah Blanding, president of Vassar College, as trustees of the Committee for Economic Development, was announced over the week-end.

A sermon on the responsibilities of the Christian ministry by his father marked the services for ordination to the priesthood of the Rev. Louis W. Pitt Jr. of Manchester, N.H., yesterday morning at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 19 -- Aroused over another death from barbiturate poisoning, Dr. Amos O. Squire, Westchester County Medical Examiner, urged tonight the adoption of state legislation, to prohibit the "re-sale or refilling of prescriptions for barbiturate drugs."

The Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, has postponed plans for erection of a new wing, because of rising costs of construction and operation, it was announced yesterday by John Hay Whitney, chairman of the board of trustees.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $55,351,773,852. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

CHICAGO, Oct. 19 -- Buying of cash wheat by the Government dominated the action of the grain markets last week as it had done for some time. Despite Administration efforts to check the upturn, December wheat soared to a high record of $3.05 a bushel for that delivery, equaling the top made by the March delivery and, with that exception, the highest price since 1917.

WARSAW, Oct. 19 -- Polish security police officers have arrested in recent weeks a number of prominent officials of state organizations during intensified police action to eliminate Opposition elements, it was learned today.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The International Children's Emergency Fund, a United Nations organization, has started food shipments to twelve European nations, but "only about one in five of the children in Europe that need help are now getting help," Mrs. Eleanor Roosevelt said today.

Herbert Sorkin, violinist, presented an unusual and exacting program at his second New York recital, given Saturday night in Carnegie Hall before a large and responsive audience. The works he had chosen for performance comprised Bartok's Second Sonata; Bach's unaccompanied Sonata in C major; Villa-Lobes' Second Sonata-Fantasia, which received its first New York hearing; the Debussy Sonata, and Stravinsky's "Suite" on Pergolesi excerpts.

A $250,000,000 long-range program for the complete rehabilitation of the city's waterfront facilities to insure the continued supremacy of New York as a world port was made public yesterday by the World Trade Corporation. The corporation was created by the Legislature in 1946 and was asked by Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate last May to make a survey and submit a definitive proposal.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities will start hearings tomorrow to determine the degree of penetration if any, of communism into the film colony and its output.

DETROIT, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings cashed in on Jerry Couture's second-period goal and Ted Lindsay's score later in a furiously fast and hard-checking National Hockey League game to shut-out the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 0, here tonight before 13,863 fans.

The first of New York's war dead from the Pacific arrived here yesterday. They came from San Francisco aboard a six-car train which reached Pennsylvania Station at 9:18 A.M. and then went to the Army's New York Port of Embarkation in Brooklyn, from where the bodies will be shipped to the next of kin.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Oct. 19 -- Col. Gen. Enver Hoxha, Albania's chief of state, is not having an easy time these days, according to travelers returning from Tirana. Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia has had to come to his aid, particularly with shipments of wheat, and undoubtedly will have to do so for some time.

An Afghan hound that had done a considerable amount of winning already opened the metropolitan indoor dog show season with another victory when Champion All Khyber, belonging to Mrs. Leah P. McConaha of Great Neck, gained best-in-show at the twentieth event of the Queensboro Kennel Club yesterday.

TOPSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 19 -- Mrs. Gilbert L. Steward, the former Anne Beekman Ayer, prominent in North Shore, Boston and New York society, was fatally injured today in a fall while horseback riding on the estate of her uncle, the late Gen. George S. Patton Jr., in Hamilton, not far from her estate, Windyriver, here.

LONDON, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Word has got around London that black market operators have offered as much as u750 [$3,000] each for invitations to the marriage of Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten on Nov. 20. Presumably they would wish to resell at a profit.
MOSCOW, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Pravda declared today that James F. Byrnes was a "war instigator" and said that Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman aspired to be the leader of "American imperialism."

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- In the face of the report that Britain, Canada and South Africa would at the end of the Geneva Trade Conference exchange notes announcing the principle of imperial tariff preferences as between them, officials of the Board of Trade and of the Foreign Office here professed tonight to be without knowledge of such a development.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 19 (AP) -- The western New York Little Three football campaign opened today in typical upset fashion as an underdog Canisius eleven pinned a 17-14 defeat on heavily favored St. Bonaventure before a crowd of 19,504 in Civic Stadium.

In today's bulletin of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., Thomas Jefferson Miley, association secretary, adds his voice to those who have expressed opposition to the Park Avenue site tentatively selected for the proposed Greater New York Golden Jubilee.
ROME, Oct. 19 -- The flag of revolt against Italian Socialists' subservience to the Communists has been raised by a small group of left-wing Socialists led by Ivan Matteo Lombardo.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 19 -- Amid the cheers of thousands, mostly young school and college students, the All-England women's field hockey team conquered the United States 1946 eleven by 2 to 0 on the field of Adelphi College today.

PRAGUE, Oct. 19 -- A statement of policy released today by the Social Democratic party established documentary contradiction of recurring reports that the Socialists were to be absorbed by the Communists.

In a period of contemporary fretting over the position of the hem line and other such matters, the countryman is somewhat diffident about bringing up the subject. But when a news item categorically states that the best sweet cider is made from McIntosh it is time for a public airing of the issue.

ATHENS, Oct. 19 -- Greece this autumn has for sale to the world some $200,000,000 worth of agricultural products, including an exceptionally good tobacco crop and one of the largest amounts of olive oil in her history.

LONDON, Oct. 19 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton's reappearance upon the scene as a stanch supporter of very low money rates has given a strong stimulant to gilt-edge stocks, while his announced intention of introducing a supplementary budget has had the opposite effect on industrial securities.

Projects for reconstruction and conversion of manufactured gas plants in several European countries have been worked out on a basis which will save important quantities of fuel and conserve dollar exchange reserves, Virgil Stark, vice president, North American Petroleum Gas Corporation, revealed in an interview over the week-end.

The wholesale markets last week were mainly concerned With getting merchandise on order delivered, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices. The already difficult situation, the reports stated, was further aggravated by the recent express strike to the extent that stores throughout the country pointed to loss of business in many items "on order" or "in transit" instead of "on their shelves."

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 19 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers staged a roaring fourth-period comeback today to score twenty-one points and defeat the Philadelphia Eagles, 35 -- 24, before 33,538 frenzied fans. Johnny Clement ran 23 yards for the touchdown, which put the Steelers ahead, and Steve Lach bucked over for another from inches out to clinch the game with fifteen seconds left.

The Denver Chemical Mfg Co., Inc. will advertise its medicated poultice dressing, Antiphlogistine, in a more expansive nationwide campaign starting Jan. 1, in daily land weekly newspapers, Women's magazines and leading medical journals, it was announced over the week-end.

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 19 (AP) -- Scoring early and late, the Green Bay Packers recorded a 27-10 victory over the Washington Red-skins in a National League football game today before 28,572 fans at State Fair Park.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 19 -- Cash dividend payments publicly reported by United States corporations in September totaled $559,300,000, the Department of Commerce reported today. This was more than a fifth greater than for the same month a year ago.

Directors of the Sunray Oil Corporation and the Mission Corporation, announced yesterday that they had approved the merger of Pacific Western Oil Corporation and the Mission Corporation into the Sunray Oil Corporation. Mission is a subsidiary of Pacific Western, and the board of directors of the latter company are scheduled to meet today to act upon the merger.

Recent publicity has highlighted the long-term project of a vast intercity system of high-speed modern roads. Individual states have already made beginnings on ambitious plans that will provide the finest thoroughfares that modern science can devise. This road-making program will require years to complete.

As the result of a streamlining of her keel "butts," the HollandAmerica liner Nieuw Amsterdam is expected to exceed her pre-war service speed of 21 1/2 knots after she leaves Rotterdam Oct. 29 for her first commercial crossing to the United States since 1939, it was announced here yesterday.
The scarcity of low-priced fullfashioned hosiery was attributed by the Government yesterday to a conspiracy between the country's largest manufacturers of fullfashioned hosiery and hosiery machinery.

Warning signals of diminishing liquidity, particularly in small businesses, have begun to appear, Martin R. Gainsbrugh, chief economist, National Industrial Conference Board, warned yesterday. Business executives concerned with extension of credit, he said, would do well to place emphasis on balance sheets rather than operating statements.

FREDERICTON, New Brunswick, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Unanimous approval for construction in New Brunswick of a large newsprint mill, at a cost of $65,000,000 or more, was given at a New York meeting Thursday by a group of Eastern and Central United States newspaper publishers, E.C. Atkinson announced here after his return from the meeting today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- Sound tax reforms cannot safely be postponed, Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, warned today in an address before the annual meeting of the Controllers Institute of America.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 -- The prospect that the current shortage of steel will last "for a long time to come" was cited today as one reason why we won't see a depression in this country "for many years" by Francis B. Foley, president -elect of the American Society for Metals, sponsors with three other groups of the National Metal Congress and Exposition in session here.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 20 (U.P.) -- A heavy oil barge rammed and sank a light pleasure cruiser in the darkness of Norfolk Harbor early today, killing two persons and sending a third to a hospital with shock and injuries.
G. Gwyn Vaughan has been appointed to the new position of national director of Book of Knowledge sales. He formerly was vice president in charge of sales promotion and advertising.

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- Substantial agreement on all but one point was reached today by the four-power conference on procedure for the former Italian colonies. The investigating commission that will visit the African areas in question will probably leave Britain the first week in November.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 20 -- Relations between the Dominions of India and Pakistan as regards the two premier Princely States, Hyderabad and Kashmir, which remained independent when the two Dominions were set up on Aug. 15, are approaching the boiling point.

The United Nations General Assembly took four more fruitless ballots yesterday, at a plenary session at Flushing Meadow, Queens, in unsuccessful efforts to elect one nation to the Security Council and two to the Trusteeship Council.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The settlement of one strike and the development of another marked the labor situation in Britain today.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The stock markets here today were quiet, pending the reassembly of Parliament -budget fears holding buyers back.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Leon Jouhaux, one of the general secretaries of France's Communistdominated General Confederation of Labor (CGT), indicated today that supplemental elections to be held next Sunday might reverse the results of yesterday's elections, in which Charles de Gaulle's new anti-Communist Reunion of the French People polled more votes than any other party or group.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Red Sox tonight named Johnny Murphy as a scout, ending the playing career of the veteran right hander who during a dozen years of relief hurling for the Yankees gained the reputation as one of the best "firemen" in major league baseball.

Another British importation will make its local bow this evening at the Booth Theatre, where J.B. Priestley's "An Inspector Calls" will be unfolded under the auspices of Courtney Burr and Lassor H. Grosberg. The play, which London's Old Vic put on last October with Ralph Richardson in the title role, returns Thomas Mitchell to the stage after twelve years in the films.
John Reed Kilpatrick, president of the Madison Square Garden Corporation, faced 15,000 excited children yesterday.

The Hillside Development Corporation has purchased a tract of land in Great Neck, L.I., for improvement. William and Vera L. Cornell and Eileen V. Hallberg were the sellers of the property, which had been in the Cornell family for about seventy-five years.

Ten witnesses took the stand yesterday at the resumption of the Santo deportation hearings to offer eager testimony that John Santo and the Transport Workers Union, CIO, had made them better Americans by obtaining wage increases and improving working conditions.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 20 -- RKO has purchased screen rights to "Every Girl Should Be Married," a recent magazine short story by Eleanor Harris, as a vehicle for Cary Grant and Barbara Bel Geddes, the studio announced today. Don Hartman will produce and may direct the film as his first assignment under his new RKO contract.
PEIPING, China, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Changchun, capital of Manchuria, lay in darkness tonight and listened to gunfire from the east, where Communist troops cut the electric lines leading to the city.
A month back the football bookings of the year to circle in red included Notre Dame against Iowa, Texas against Rice, Pennsylvania against Navy, Army against Columbia and Georgia against Alabama.

The "SRO" sign went up yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History at the opening of its first music fair, with 1,000 of the 20,000 school children enrolled through Oct. 31 making a day of it. Sponsored jointly by the museum and Parents Magazine to teach children correlation of music and natural history, the fair brought 1,800 ticket requests for each day.

Asserting that "unjustified police brutality has become a serious public issue," Councilman Benjamin Davis Jr. filed a resolution yesterday calling upon the City Council to hold a public hearing "because the Police Department has failed to take proper action to curb and suppress it." The matter will be acted upon today.
Mayor O'Dwyer asked the Port of New York Authority yesterday to survey waterfront facilities here and submit a report by Jan. 1.
Big Upset in The Plaza Our city scout, who has been neglecting that part of town of late, has come in to report on the present state of affairs at Fifty-ninth Street and the Plaza.

Robert Moses and three other officials of the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, responsible for building the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, indicated yesterday that they would hold the line firmly against demands for higher wages issued by 1,200 sandhogs on the project.
Three separate investigations, all stemming from Washington, are now in progress to determine the causes of inflated construction costs and the continued shortage of housing.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to review reorganization proceedings for the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway Company.

BROODING on affairs of pith and moment and mourning the unhappy lot of man, as who has not in recent years, Lloyd Morris has set himself the melancholy task of examining the social changes of half a century, from 1896 to 1946, to see "why, in fifty years of progress such as no nation in the world has ever known, did disillusion overtake the American mind and heart?"
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today challenged members of Congress "to clarify the Federal-state relationship" immediately on their return to session.

Crushed at the hands of West Virginia last Saturday, New York University's football team received an additional blow when it was revealed that Larry Weinstein, star defensive right end, suffered a torn ligament in the left ankle and will be out of action indefinitely.

A wholly delightful concert, which in the quality and spirit of the performances, and the character of its program, sounded a refreshingly new note in the musical life of the city, was given by the Little Orchestra Society, which then inaugurated its career, last night in Town Hall.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A Soviet plan to industrialize Russia's Armenian Republic by inducing Armenian natives -- now United States citizens -- to renounce their citizenship and return to their former homeland was reported today by Dennis W. Delaney, United States Internal Revenue Collector.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 20 -- The Soviet delegation to the Joint United States-Soviet Commission on Korea announced today that it had been instructed by Moscow to return to Pyongyang, capital of the Soviet occupation zone in north Korea.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 19 (Delayed) -- Scotland looks upon England with a jaundiced eye. The phrase one hears most of all across "the industrial belt" of the Lowlands from Glasgow to Dundee, and even in the Highlands, is "devolution of powers."

Renewing his fight against a United States proposal to set up a frontier committee in the Balkans, Andrei Y. VishinsKy, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, repeated yesterday his demand for the withdrawal of American military instructors and British troops from Greece.

A tract of forty-five acres in Rahway, N.J., extending along Milton Boulevard to Madison Hill Road, has been purchased for improvement with about 200 houses. The purchaser was the Oakhurst Manor Estates, Inc., headed by Maxwell M. Plotkin, and the property will be developed by the Oaks Development Company.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 20 (U.P.) -- Although the Foreign Office announced that a formal statement on the breaking of diplomatic relations would be made soon, "very probably" tomorrow, informed circles and all the newspapers considered

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, announced today that the Senate War Investigating Committee would investigate this country's failure to implement an integrated industrial mobilization plan early in the recent war.

Secretary of Defense James Forrestal warned Soviet Russia last night that Americans "hate the very idea of war," but believe that even war is preferable to alternatives such as living under a police state. He said we have no desire to impose our idea of government on the Russians, and certainly do not propose to have theirs imposed on us.

The New York Football Giants, victory starved and floundering, hope to have an important announcement today. Stout Steve Owen said yesterday that a deal with another National League club is in the making, and, if completed, will give the Giants a much-needed top-flight passing star.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- From the day in June when Secretary of State Marshall at Harvard turned into a proposal to Europe the formula of an economic foreign policy which UnderSecretary Acheson had outlined before a Mississippi audience in May, administration officials have accepted the fact that Congress and the American public would require supervision of the use of any credits extended to assist European recovery.

With the contract covering 13,000 New York milk drivers and distribution plant workers scheduled to expire at midnight Friday, labor officials representing the city, state and Federal Governments indicated yesterday that they would keep close watch on the progress of negotiations in the hope of averting any stoppage of deliveries.
PARIS, Oct. 20 -- The French Communist party proposed today that the Socialists join forces with it to bar Charles de Gaulle's path to power.

Office managers can correct thirteen causes of high costs and reduced productivity of office employes, Henry A. McCashin, systems department, R.H. Macy Co., Inc., New York, told more than 600 members of the Office Management Problems Conference of the American Management Association, which met at the Commodore Hotel yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Two more promises to examine the constitutionality of restrictive racial covenants on real estate were made by the Supreme Court today.

ALBANY, Oct. 20 -- Representatives of civic, labor, business and educational groups, attending today the first open hearing of Governor Dewey's commission apointed to consider the need for a state university, presented arguments for and against the proposal.
Fluctuating over a moderate range, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday gained 7 to 23 points net on the day.

MONTREAL, Oct. 20 (AP) -- A strike affecting about 125,000 employes of Canadian railroads has been called for Nov. 3, F.H. Hall, chairman of the negotiating committee of seventeen associated railway unions, said today.

An art gallery in miniature for $1 will be available near the end of this month for the student, the child with a doll's house, or the adult with a flair for decoration. The Metropolitan Museum of Art announced yesterday its new project in the field of color reproduction -- the issuance of twenty-four prints of famous paintings and objects of art in its collections, in a large perforated sheet of posterstamps.

Tammany's drive for the repeal of proportional representation will start Thursday night, with a meeting of district captains and party workers at Textile High School, it was announced yesterday at Tammany headquarters, 331 Madison Avenue.

A delegation of thirty students, representing organizations at the four city colleges and Columbia and New York Universities, asked Dr. Ordway Tead, chairman of the Board of Higher Education, last night for a public hearing on the pending resolution to bar subversive groups from city campuses.

R. to Get New Lever Product A new Lever Brothers Company product, the name and nature of which will be announced later, has been assigned to Ruthrauff Ryan, Inc., according to an announcement yesterday by John R. Gilman, company vice president. Mr. Gilman also announced that the company's Lifebuoy Soap account will be transferred to Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell and Bayles, Inc., effective Jan. 1, 1948.

CASCO BAY, Me., Oct. 20 -- The last day of the split season on ducks and geese began and ended with an unclouded sun. And although almost every rock ledge and point in the area in which we gunned had at least one hunter, not more than a score of shots were heard all day.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 20 -- Southern farmers, with powerful Congressional support already assured, are gathering strength to counter-attack all efforts to alter in any aspect the basic New Deal policy for agriculture.

Bidding for Bonds Both caution and precision were to be read in the bidding yesterday for two issues of public utility bonds. Competition for the $4,500,000 Metropolitan Edison Company issue was close, with Kidder, Peabody Co. winning out by only a few cents per $1,000 bond.

The Transport Workers Union announced yesterday it would submit a new demand to the Board of Transportation for a 30-cents-anhour wage increase for the city's 33,000 transit employes, if the membership of Local 100 approved the demand at a mass meeting scheduled for 8 P.M. Thursday at Manhattan Center.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: For just over two months, the Punjab and Delhi have been in the grid of widespread disturbances creating a tremendous flow of refugees, men, women and children, from one Dominion to the other. The question of relief and rehabilitation of these refugees has become by far the most serious of the problems with which the new States of Pakistan and India are confronted.

In anticipation of a hurricane -- gridiron variety -- the Navy flew storm signals yesterday, well in advance of Saturday's cruise to Franklin Field. Captain Tom Hamilton, who coaches the Middies' eleven, was unable to be present at the weekly luncheon meeting of the Football Writers Association at Toots Shor's, but Dick Duden, of Hamilton's staff, did a fair-tomiddlin' job of sounding the warning.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Only the United Nations can now solve the deadlock over the independence of Korea, Under-Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett has notified Foreign Minister V.M. Molotov in a note made public by the State Department today.
PARIS, Oct. 20 -- A settlement of the strike that has tied up Paris transport for ten days was announced tonight in an atmosphere of renewed agitation for increased wages.

If Medea does not entirely understand every aspect of her whirling character, she would do well to consult Judith Anderson. For Miss Anderson understands the character more thoroughly than Medea, Euripides or the scholars, and it would be useless now for anyone else to attempt the part.

SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 20 -- Two New York state educational institutions and several residents of Milton, N.Y., are to share in the estate of the late Charles S. Weston, banker and philanthropist, the filing of his will disclosed today. No appraisement of the estate has yet been made but it was estimated to be worth over $2,000,000.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 20 -- Four famous Americans are treated imaginatively in a posthumous book by Gertrude Stein, entitled "Four In America," which will be issued tomorrow by Yale University Press. It depicts George Washington as an author, Gen. Ulysses S. Grant as a religious leader, Wilbur Wright as a painter and Henry James as a general.

While a three-alarm fire swept the second floor of St. Elizabeth's Parochial School, Broadway and 187th Street, shortly after noon yesterday, twenty-three students and a nun were led to safety by a patrolman.

The comprehensive $250,000,000 program for improvement of New York City's piers and other trade facilities submitted to the Board of Estimate by the World Trade Corporation gives the public its first detailed view of the gigantic job that must be done to modernize our waterfront.

Clergymen throughout the country are being asked to sign a statement calling for a full and free hearing for the forthcoming report by the group of seven Protestant clergymen who visited Yugoslavia, it was learned yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Although he was knocked down twice by Dado Marino, Irish crooner Rinty Monaghan was awarded the 15round decision over the Hawaiian today and won acclaim virtually everywhere but in Britain as the world flyweight champion.

Bob Hope is the current favorite of listeners to evening radio entertainment, according to the latest determinations of the C.E. Hooper organization, reducing "Radio Theatre" from first to third place in the biweekly measurement of popularity on the kilocycles.

TOKYO, Oct. 20 -- Although Japan's industrial production figures continue to show small gains, economists believe that the next several months will be almost certain to show declines. Coal and power shortages already have forced shutdowns of metal and fertilizer plants in Kyushu, and this trend reportedly is spreading to other parts of the country.

Three freight cars of the pleasant subtropical fruit, the persimmon, arrived yesterday from Southern California. It was not the largest single shipment of the season, which started a fortnight ago, but one that marks the beginning of the peak period.

The Government of the Philippines will propose to the United Nations Security Council this week that the long-dormant Military Staff Committee step into the Indonesian dispute and bring to a quick end the three-month war in the Netherlands Indies, it was learned yesterday.
American Overseas Airlines signed a contract yesterday with the Air Line Pilots Association, AFL, ending twenty-three months of negotiation, which included an eighteen-day strike this month.

A struggle between American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations unionists for control of the Industrial Container Corporation's workers was marked yesterday by a picket line scuffle in which five AFL men were hurt slightly.

All office space in the Tishman Realty and Construction Company's new twenty-two-story building at 445 Park Avenue has been rented, Norman Tishman, vice president, reported yesterday with the announcement of a lease taken by the Lever Brothers Company.

Steel operations this week are scheduled at 97.1 per cent of ingot capacity, the highest rate since of the week of June 19, 1944, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The current rate virtually assures a new peacetime production record of around 7,500,000 tons for the month of October.
The Staten Island grand jury voted yesterday to investigate ferry service between that borough and Manhattan, Robert E. Johnson, Richmond District Attorney, announced.

TOKYO, Oct. 20 -- Joseph B. Keenan, American chief prosecutor, charged today before the International Military Tribunal trying twenty-five Japanese accused as major war criminals that Marquis Koichi Kido, former Lord Keeper of the Privy Seal and Emperor Hirohito's close adviser before and during the war, was attempting to shelter himself behind the throne.

The status quo was restored at Jamaica yesterday, after the oneday interregnum that saw activities of the turf canceled at the Baisley Boulevard oval on Saturday. It was an uncommon Monday in one respect, though, for the program was headed by a $25,000 stake race, the Roamer Handicap, and the feature test was backed by the Frizette, an event that was worth $15,000 added.

VIENNA, Oct. 20 -- The announcement yesterday by the executive committee of the Czechoslovak Social Democratic party that it would refuse the invitation of the Communists to form a united workers' party made the Reds' score in their campaign to absorb socialism in Central Europe two victories against five defeats.

MANILA, Oct. 20 -- Jose P. Laurel, puppet President of the Philippines during the Japanese occupation, went on trial today after repeated postponements. He is answering 143 counts of treason, for which the maximum penalty is death.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Convened at 11 A.M. at Flushing Meadow.
LONDON, Oct. 20 -- The resignation of Alfred Duff Cooper as British Ambassador in Paris was announced tonight. He will be succeeded by Sir Oliver Charles Harvey, a career diplomat.

Their confidence bolstered by the way they played Penn to a standstill in the final three quarters Saturday, Columbia's aerial-minded Lions began preparations at Baker Field yesterday for the attempt to snap Army's thirty-two game defeatless string.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Oct. 20 -- The story of Lidice was told again today in the main courtroom of the Palace of Justice. Of the scores of crimes charged against Lidice thirteen men and one woman, officials of the Nazis' main Race and Settlement Office and of other Nazi organizations, as their trial opened, this tragedy occupies a chapter by itself.

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., Oct. 20 -- Al Brosch of the Cherry Valley Club added the Long Island Professional Golf Association 36hole medal play championship to his list of honors for the year today, along with the Long Island Open title and the Metropolitan P.G.A. medal play crowns, with a score of 72, 76 -- 148, over the Wheatley Hills Golf Club course.

BERLIN, Oct. 20 -- The charge of incitement by an officer of the Russian Military Government of ill-feeling against the United States among the Germans was passed back to Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the United States Commander, today by the Soviet commander, Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovski.

Michael Hollander, president and chairman of the board of directors of A. Hollander Son, Inc., an international concern of fur dressers and dyers with headquarters in Newark, N.J., died here yesterday in Doctors Hospital after an illness of several years.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 20 -- James P. Warburg, banker and former Deputy Director of the Office of War Information, declared here tonight that if the American people had a clear picture of the facts they would be willing to help in the reconstruction of Europe even if it involved food rationing and price controls for a limited time.

In banning the manufacture of records and transcriptions, James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, has set the stage for an economic and legal tussle with implications extending far beyond the realm of music. In effect, the union leader has served notice that he now is ready for a showdown with all industries which exist by reason of the fact that they provide music by mechanical means.

ABILENE, Kan., Oct. 20 (AP) -- A field of 363 young greyhounds were entered in the Sapling Stake, which got under way today as the largest and richest national coursing meet in history worked through its third day of sun-up to sun-down trials among dogs from the United States, Europe and Australia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Weekly earnings and nonagricultural employment reached record levels in mid-September, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

A determined bid was made yesterday by the stock market to break into the high price area established last July. Under an expanded demand for several key industrial issues, prices advanced about a point. A few recent favorites suffered from adverse corporate developments, notably American Woolen which came under realizing on the release of income figures for the third quarter.

Six thousand service men and veterans will escort the body of one of the nation's World War II dead from Pier 61, North River, next Sunday afternoon to memorial services in Sheep Meadow, Central Park.
