A relatively minor resolution, the purpose of which was undisputed, brought sharp words and disagreement between the United Kingdom, supported by the United States, and the Soviet Union yesterday in the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow.

Two well-known factory branches are forcing small independent appliance dealers to accept unwanted appliances and radios in return for supplies of fast-selling refrigerators, an executive of a large local independent distributor disclosed yesterday.
The Fifth Avenue Association announced yesterday that it opposed using Park Avenue as the site of the proposed celebration of Greater New York's Golden Jubilee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Citizens Food Committee rejected tonight the petition of the poultry and feed industries to call off poultryless Thursdays. Charles Luckman, committee chairman, said that the proposal of the industries for alternate cooperation in the food conservation program was not sufficiently specific in the methods by which grain would be saved.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman declared tonight that Russia had been waging a word attack on the United States since soon after V-J Day and that "the Communists believe in the inevitability of armed conflict."
Mrs. Elizabeth Gray Vining, tutor to the Crown Prince of Japan, gave intimate details of teaching democracy to the Japanese last night at The New York Herald Tribune's sixteenth annual forum.

THE football fraternity was buzzing excitedly yesterday over the provocative speech which had been delivered the day before by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, the president of Fordham University. The distinguished educator had said that the university was not interested in a topflight eleven and lashed out, bitterly in some instances and good humoredly in others, at the gamblers, the subway alumni, the Polo Grounds management and the sports writers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The Tennessee Gas and Transmission Company asked the Federal Power Commission today for permission to increase the capacity of its natural gas pipe line system by 455,000,000 cubic feet a day to serve new customers in eastern New York and New England.

The battleships Missouri and New Jersey and the aircraft carrier Philippine Sea will be among the vessels to hold "open house" here this week-end in connection with the observance of Navy Day on Monday, it was announced yesterday.

Fast thinking and equally fast foot work by two guards on the eighty-sixth floor observation tower of the Empire State Building saved the life yesterday of a would-be jumper who was hanging by his hands from the south parapet.

New bond issues of public utility companies totaling $14,500,000 were awarded at competitive sale yesterday to underwriting managers as follows: Alabama Power Company -- $10,000,000 of first mortgage bonds due in 1977 to First Boston Corporation, Merrill Lyncn, Pierce, Fenner Beane, White, Weld Co., the Robinson-Humphrey Company and Sterne, Agee Leach, at 100.391 for interest of 3 1/4 per cent.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 20 -- Great Britain's efforts to help herself and aid in the recovery of Europe were defended today by Lord Inverchapel, British Ambassador to the United States, before 1,500 business, economic and Government leaders at the opening session of the thirty-fourth national foreign trade convention.

The strategic center of the world is now the North Pole. Gen. C.A. Spaatz is convinced that "we are wide open at the top," meaning the Arctic. To Maj. Gen. C. LeMay, who planned the program of Arctic Exploration that the Army Air Forces are now carrying out, "our frontier now lies across the Arctic wastes of the polar region."

A proposed full-time International Law Commission of fifteen experts on the world's principal legal systems probably will start on a much smaller scale, Dr. Ivan Kerno, Assistant Secretary General in charge of the United Nations legal department, reported Last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- The Justice Department announced today it had asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to order refunds from 719 railroads, contending they should have charged lower rates for wartime shipments of inert explosives.

WARSAW, Oct. 20 -- The United States Embassy protested to the Polish Government today over the five-hour detention by security police Friday night of Mrs. Wanda Sroka, an American national employed in the administrative section of the embassy.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Oct. 20 -- In the last pro-amateur tournament of the season held under the auspices of the Westchester P.G.A., thirty-four teams toured the Wykagyl layout here today.

The New York City Symphony last night at the City Centre joined the parade of orchestras honoring Mendelssohn, who died a hundred years ago. To mark the centennial Leonard Bernstein played the composer's "Reformation" Symphony and the Violin Concerto, with Arnold Eidus as the soloist.

The seventh semi-annual New York Antiques Fair opened yesterday afternoon at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street. Its 140 dealers' booths make it one of the largest shows in recent years, according to the management, C.J. Nuttall and Dorothy Hazen.

ESSEN, Germany, Oct. 20 -- After a six-week delay, Military Government authorities are preparing to implement the report issued as a result of British-United States talks in Washington on increasing Ruhr coal production, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- While they conceded the presence of a core of persons of "un-American" or reputed Communist leanings in the film industry, principally among screen writers, three Hollywood producers asserted today that Communist efforts to penetrate the movies had been checkmated in their productions and that the bulk of the industry was overwhelmingly patriotic.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Oct. 20 -- Darkness fell in Bermuda tonight with electric power out everywhere except at military bases, telephonic communications torn to shreds, roadsides strewn with debris and an accurate estimate of the damage in a hurricane that swept the colony today impossible to attempt as yet.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Postmaster General Robert E. Hannegan asserted today that "under the law parcel post rates may be changed only by Congress or with the consent of the Interstate Commerce Commission, after investigation."

LONDON, Oct. 20 -- On the eve of the opening of the new session of Parliament tomorrow, Great Britain's Labor Government found itself sharply divided at a Cabinet meeting today on whether the legislative program for the coming year should include reform of the House of Lords.
Andor Foldes, one of the most musical of our younger pianists, gave a recital at Carnegie Hall last night. The event was notable for thoughtful programming and some remarkable playing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The representatives of Soviet Russia have introduced at Lake Success something new in international negotiations -- namely, open and unrestrained vituperation, accusations without supporting evidence against a friendly nation, expressed with an emotional invective and a convenient disregard for facts that is so thorough it approaches the incredible.

The price of bread rose yesterday one cent a loaf for most New Yorkers as wheat reached its highest price since the days of the first World War. Commercial bakers and grocers raised bread prices in an increasing number of cities across the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 20 -- Regstration statements covering bonds and stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. One concern asked the SEC for permission to withdraw a statement involving preferred and common shares.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Secretary of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 9,500 head: total, 12 500; market slow: around 50 cents lower on all weights butchers: sows scarce. 25 to mostly 50 cents lower: top of $28.85 paid sparingly: bulk of good and choise 190 to 300-pound hogs,
WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- Official Washington, which had been hoping for a strong non-Communist Government in France, was, nevertheless not happy about the political comeback of Charles de Gaulle.

CHICAGO, Oct. 20 (AP) -- Standard Oil Company of Indiana today announced that price increases ranging from four-tenths cent to lone cent a gallon will become effective in an eleven-state area on next Wednesday, on tankwagon wholesale prices of naphtha, gasoline, kerosene and certain distillate type fuels.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 20 -- The plea by the major airlines that no new routes be authorized by the Government until current services had been surveyed in the light of potential business was met with sharp rebuttal today from a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York before the President's Air Policy Commission.

With trainmen on the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad voting nineteen to one in favor of a strike, J.J. Hammill, general chairman of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen for the New Haven system, said last night a walkout of the union's 5,000 members would be ordered for "some day between Tuesday and Friday of next week."

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 20 -- Dempster McIntosh, Bronxville, N.Y., president of the Philco International Corporation, said today that his firm's 150 distributors and 10,000 dealers in 100 fpreign countries will receive $40,000,000 in retail sales of this year's Americanmade Philco products.

BOSTON, Oct. 20 -- All business must fight for a lower price level if free enterprise and a prosperous standard of living are to be maintained, Jack I. Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., said here today.

KANSAS CITY, Oct. 20 (U.P.) -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson said today that the world food shortage was worse than a year ago and warned that the gap between world needs and supplies would be serious even if exporting countries increased shipments as much as now appeared possible.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 20 (AP) -- Five candidates for the rich Selima Stakes, to be renewed here Saturday, galloped one mile and 70 yards in the Mall Purse, fifth and featured event here today, and the winner turned up in King Ranch's Airosa, a maiden going into the race.

New Trans-European Train Cherished memories of pre-war rail journeys in continental Europe undoubtedly stirred in the minds of veteran globe-trotters when they read a few days ago that a new express train service was to connect Stockholm with Istanbul.

Eugene F. Moran, a veteran New York maritime figure who is a commissioner of the Port of New York Authority, expressed opposition yesterday to the construction of marginal wharves proposed Sunday by the World Trade Corporation.

The city began yesterday to be conscious of the fact that an election is approaching, and that the principal issue at stake is whether the system of proportional representation used in the election of City Council members should be retained.

Bishop Otto Dibelius of Berlin and Brandenburg, Germany, told members of the American Committee for a World Council of Churches yesterday afternoon that German Protestant groups are preparing for affiliation with churches of other countries.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- As part of a general program for corporate simplification and recapitalization of North Penn Gas Company and the latter's subsidiaries, the Pennsylvania Gas and Electric Corporation of Jersey City, and five of its subsidiaries filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission an outline of a number of proposed transactions, designated as "Plan No. 1."

Columbia's offense and defense received attention from different directions yesterday, as the Lions practised halting Army plays at Baker Field, while statistics released by the Athletic Office gave promise of increased Light Blue striking power.

BERLIN, Oct. 21 -- Military Government officials here predicted today an increase in the proportion of civilians among American personnel in Germany despite the Washington announcement of suspension of plans for the State Department to take over responsibility for the occupation of Germany from the Army.

An agreement for complete medical care of 8,000 painters in Manhattan and the Bronx was signed yesterday. The principals were the Association of Master Painters and Decorators of the City of New York, representing employers; the Brotherhood of Painters, Decorators and Paperhangers of America, District Council 9, AFL, acting for union members, and the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York.

The Kremlin's policy of unbridled abuse of the heads of states with which it disagrees ideologically has brought it a dividend in reverse in Brazil, in severance of diplomatic relations. What could have been an important listening post, if nothing else, on a continent whose underprivileged classes offer a fertile field for communist propaganda has been lost to Moscow because of the Soviet leaders' growing addiction to name-calling.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- Premier Paul Ramadier's associates said tonight that he would not take the initiative toward reshaping the Cabinet unless the Popular Republican Ministers, whose party suffered a smashing defeat at Sunday's municipal elections, should resign.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Chilean Government announced tonight that it had broken diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- Adolphe Menjou and two other witnesses depicted today the Hollywood motion-picture community as being deeply tainted and split by communism but increasingly alert to the dangers.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The British Government, it was learned today, has told the United States that it would like to begin drawing on the last $400,000,000 of its United States loan as soon as possible.

Rhubarb used to be looked on as an antidote for spring fever. Now it is being regarded by at least one scientist, Dr. Clive M. McCay of the Animal Nutrition Laboratory at Cornell University, as a protector of tooth enamel.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 21 -- In the little town of Raanana, on the coastal plain between Tel Aviv and Nathanya, a new children's village and farm school was dedicated today by the Mizrachi Women's Organization of America. More than 170 awe-struck youngsters, most of whom had known only concentration camps as their homes, stood by as a new foundation was laid for their future lives.

The possibility that Fordham will have to cancel or transfer from the Polo Grounds its scheduled football games with Lafayette and New York University developed yesterday in the controversy started toy the speech at the Fordham University Club of New Jersey communion breakfast by the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, president of the university.

Thousands of families against which eviction proceedings were started before passage of the city rent laws were assured of delay yesterday by amended regulations of the Temporary City Housing Rent Commission.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 21 -- There is still a large, unsatisfied market for durable goods such as automobiles, radios, and furniture as well as houses, according to a study made for the Federal Reserve Board by the Survey Research Center of the University of Michigan, released here today.

A series of thefts of building materials, which had the effect of delaying the completion of the Student Veterans Housing Project at Shanks Village, N.Y., appeared to have been cleared up yesterday with the arrest by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents of Frank Wallace, 47 years old, of Blauvelt, N.Y.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Another 2-year-old filly was added to the already large probable field for the irch Selima Stakes, to be renewed Saturday, when J. Warfield Rodgers' Discord turned on a brilliant burst of speed to beat Wee Nip by a neck in the mile-and-seventy-yard feature at Laurel Park today.

Thousands of grateful New Yorkers who have been sick enough during the past year to receive nursing care can testify to the invaluable services performed by the Visiting Nurse Service of New York. Last year this organization provided part-time home nursing attention for 84,439 permanent and temporary invalids, making altogether 348,662 home nursing visits, and in addition gave health instruction to many groups.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Oct. 21 -- The Southern Governors Conference served notice on Congress today that the South would seek its approval of legislation authorizing state compacts for establishing co-operative ownership and operation of regional schools for certain forms of higher education.

In Sears, Roebuck Co., it is up to the individual to achieve his highest effectiveness and earnings, beyond guaranteed base rates of pay, D.S. Valentine, staff member, told more than 600 members of the Office Management Conference of the American Management Association at Hotel Commodore yesterday.

VIENNA, Oct. 21 -- The Austrian Government has submitted to United States officials here a balance-of-payments statement for 1948, indicating a deficit of $141,000,000 for the five months" that must elapse before the Marshall plan can get under way.

Several parties for debutantes have been arranged for late December. Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Simonds of 145 East Seventy-fourth Street will give a dinner dance for Mr. Simonds' daughter, Miss Elizabeth Sprague Simonds, on Dec. 20 in the Roof Garden of the St. Regis.

When passions are aroused there is always a danger that facts will be forgotten or distorted. It is only natural, therefore, that the wave of violence that has swept India and Pakistan should have left a legacy of mutual recrimination that does not always reveal balanced judgment.

Responding to recommendations of Mayor O'Dwyer and the National Mediation Board, President Truman announced in Washington yesterday his appointment of a three-man emergency board to study issues involved in the dispute between the Railway Express Agency and 5,000 unionized drivers in New York, Jersey City, Weehawken and Hoboken.

Representatives of eighteen clubs, with a total membership of more than 3,000, convened last night at the Dartmouth Club as the New York City Ski Council held its first meeting' of the 1947-48 season.

PARIS, Oct. 21 -- After the municipal elections, which revealed a fundamental change in the national sentiment of the French public, Premier Paul Ramadier's Government today was facing renewed difficulties. At issue was the question of rising prices and wages, which has sapped the Government's strength throughout this year.

Industry-wide consulting engineering services to more than 1,100 paper merchants are to be expanded under plans now being advanced, W.G. Leathers, assistant secretary, National Paper Trade Association, revealed in an interview yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- Navy can banish any thought that it is going to catch Pennsylvania's undefeated, untied eleven off guard when the teams meet before a capacity crowd of 78,000 at Franklin Field next Saturday in the big football game of the week in the East.

SHANGHAI, Oct. 21 -- The delivery of the final consignment of supplies from the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration to areas controlled by the Chinese Communists is still an unsettled issue. New discussions on the question have been held in Nanking, Maj. Gen. Dowell W. Rooks, director general of UNRRA, announced here today.

State unemployment insurance officials, preparing to cut a tax-rebate melon of $145,000,000 for employers with stable job records, reported yesterday that the reserve in the State Unemployment Insurance Fund had reached a record peak of $1,042,266,315 at the end of August.

By combining' morality and mystery, J. B. Priestley has written a mild and ingenious little drama, "An Inspector Calls," which was acted at the Booth last evening'. Looking back to 1912, when peace appeared eternal, Mr. Priestley has trapped some complacent British people into a series of nasty confessions.
No workers reported for duty yesterday at the Brooklyn plant of the Industrial Container Corporation, scene of a picket-line scuffle Monday in which five men were injured.
The United States Trust Company has been appointed registrar of the Robertshaw-Fulton Controls Company's $1 par value common, and $25 par value preferred stock.

BOSTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- One of Maine's most destructive woods fires was controlled late tonight after razing almost 200 buildings, mostly summer cottages, in the Goose Rocks, Cape Porpoise and Wildes district of Kennebunkport Township.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Senate War Investigating Committee heard testimony today that twenty of the nation's largest oil companies rolled up excessive profits of $59,856,000 on war-time projects.

Housewives, municipal employes, clergymen and merchant seamen were among the 671 persons who reported yesterday to nine centers here for tests that may qualify them for New York State high school equivalency diplomas.

Footsteps echoed yesterday through the dusty corridors of the Charles M. Schwab mansion at Riverside Drive and Seventy-third Street, as the first step toward its demolition started with the sale of its interior fittings. Nearly 100 persons visited the once-resplen-dent building modeled after a French chateau that was the home of the late Bethlehem Steel magnate -- the curious, the dealers, the souvenir hunters, the prospective purchasers.

Use made of any American financial or economic aid to India, whether in the form of a Government loan or private investments by banks and industrial concerns, should be supervised carefully by American experts, Robert Alfredson, export manager, Pal Personna Blade Companies, Inc., said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The National Labor Relations Board today directed the holding of collective bargaining elections in the first two cases covered by the Taft-Hartley Act. The directives were issued on petitions of unions in New York State.

A fourteen-month schedule for the Italian motorships Vulcania and Saturnia, covering twenty-seven sailings from New York to the Mediterranean, was announced here yesterday by American Export Lines as general agents in this country for the Italian Line (Societa Anonima di Navigazione).

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The University of Pittsburgh's faculty committee on athletics today agreed to hear a demand from students that football "suicide schedules" be scrapped or the manpower provided to meet them. Dr. R. E. Sherrill, chairman of the committee, said the session will be scheduled for a future date at a meeting of the faculty group tomorrow.

Twelve hundred tugboat and ferryboat workers affiliated with the United Railroad Workers of America, CIO, have accepted a 15 1/2-cent hourly wage increase in negotiations with six railroads operating cargo and passenger craft in New York.

Sir Hartley Shawcross, Attorney General of Great Britain, urged last night use of the machinery of the International Court of Justice at the Hague. To avoid war, he asserted, the United Nations must try more and more to base itself upon a firm foundation of international law.

The Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr, Professor of Applied Christianity at the Union Theological Seminary, told the New York Herald Tribune's annual Forum yesterday that defense of American democracy against Russian communism required not only military preparedness, but also an ideology of freedom and justice on our part, and a new faith adequate for "community building on a world scale."

From frequent use of the veto, Russian tactics in the U.N. have now been expanded to include the boycott. The Soviet Union and its supporters in Eastern Europe have announced that they will have nothing to do with the "Little Assembly," even though that new agency will apparently be set up by the votes of a very large majority of the U.N. members.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Pending further study of the King's speech to Parliament, buyers kept out of stock markets here today. As a result conditions were quiet.

Pacific Telephone Telegraph Bond men say the sale of the $100,000,000 debentures of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company for reoffering on a 3.07 pep cent yield basis looks like the tonic for which the high-grade bond market has been asking in recent weeks.

BOSTON, Oct. 21 -- "Don't sell Europe short," despite the acute crisis which that continent now faces, Norman Armour, Assistant Secretary of State for Political Affairs, counseled here today at the concluding session of the Boston conference on distribution.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 21 -- The International Typographical Union Presented its demands today with the design of proving their reasonableness and of disproving charges of refusal to bargain in good faith.

A proposed local law that would prohibit dense smoke and provide heavy penalties for violators was reintroduced in the City Council yesterday by Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey. The leader of the Democratic majority said he would press for action by the Committee on General Welfare to which it was sent and that he expected public hearings would be held.

IF Steve Owen began to hum, "Happy Days Are Here Again," yesterday morning at the Polo Grounds, no one could blame him. His quest for a topflight forward passer is ended. Paul Governali, an old Blue from Columbia, is the newest member of the New York Football Giants. For the first time since Frank Filchock was rendered null and void by Commissioner Bert Bell, the undergraduates at Eighth.

MANHASSET, L.I., Oct. 21 -- Five hundred teachers, mothers and students attended the 102d forum of THE NEW YORK TIMES' "What's on Your Mind" series this afternoon as it was broadcast over WQXR from the auditorium of the Manhasset High School.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Internal Revenue Bureau officials said today members of the armed forces who were taken prisoner on United States Pacific island possessions during the war and later transferred to enemy-held territory are exempt from taxes on income accumulated while in enemy territory.

Although they can't prove a thing, for the simple reason that the two teams don't face each other this season, many of the nation's sports writers expressed confidence yesterday that Michigan would beat Notre Dame if the two should meet on a football field.

The Twentieth Century Sporting Club yesterday cabled an offer to Rinty Monaghan, Irish boxer, and Dado Marino of Hawaii, principals in the fifteen-round world flyweight title match in London Monday night; asKing whether they would be interested in a return championship battle at Madison Square Garden next March or April.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Britain's Labor Government calmly tossed a highly explosive issue into the pageantry that marked the opening of Parliament today by unexpectedly announcing its intention of introducing at this session a bill to curb the powers of the House of Lords.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 21 -- With feeling running high because of "border" incidents, the High Commissioner for Palestine, Sir Alan G. Cunningham, visited the Syrian frontier today and asked both Jews and Arabs to maintain order and avoid any "rash" action.

Plans for the remodeling of five multi-family houses in the Bronx to provide low-rent living quarters were filed yesterday by the New York City Housing Authority. The houses are on Morris Avenue, Alexander Avenue and 148th Street.

Paul Governali, who resides close enough to the Polo Grounds to pitch forwards from his rooftop to the gridiron under Coogan's Bluff -- almost -- yesterday was revealed as the long-sought topflight passer, who, it is hoped, will extricate the New York Football Giants from the rut they've been in all season.

Combined total sales of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., textile firm, for the nine months ended with September, increased 45.71 per cent to $102,302,872 from the $70,207,875 volume for the corresponding period a year ago, Leon Lowenstein, chairman, reported to stockholders yesterday.

The problem of cancer is the problem of growth and hence the problem of life itself. It is a problem that demands research by chemists, physicists, biologists, pathologists, surgeons, endocrinologists, geneticists, even mathematicians. There is not a science which is not called on to contribute knowledge that its votaries have acquired.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- President Truman summoned Congressional leaders of both political parties today to a White House conference Thursday "for a further discussion of emergency foreign aid," apparently in the hope of avoiding a special session of Congress.

Aid rendered by American people in the next eighteen months will determine whether Europe makes a recovery or goes down in chaos and totalitarianism, Dr. Isador Lubin, United States representative on the Economic and Employment Commission of the United Nations, declared yesterday.

In Lowell; Mass., today a funeral service will be held for the Rev. Brother Gilbert, who discovered the baseball talent of George Herman (Babe) Ruth at St. Mary's Industrial School, Catonsville, Md., more than forty years ago. The Babe is too ill to attend.
A third day of restricted diet -- Wheatless Monday -- may be added to the national food conservation program, it was said yesterday in the food trade here.

Six National League players and four American Leaguers make up the 1947 major league all-star team, selected for The Associated Press by 233 baseball writers throughout the nation, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Refusal to use contraceptives for the intelligent spacing of children and to limit the size of families is sinful, and a church which condemns the use of contraceptives "speaks only for itself" and not for Christendom, Bishop G. Bromley Oxnam of the New York Methodist Area, said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Citizens Food Committee took under advisement tonight a new proposal by the poultry and feed dealers of the nation to conserve 30,000,000 bushels of grain by next April 1 in return for immediate termination, of poultryless and eggless Thursdays.
LONDON, Oct. 21 -- United States business men resident in Britain offered today to help the nation's export drive.

Response to the recently presented national campaign to inform the American people on the benefits of their economic system has brought between four and five thousand inquiries to the Association of National Advertisers from business, community and educational organizations wishing to participate in some form of the project, it was learned yesterday.

A poster painted by Frances Carlsen, 17 years old, a seventh-term art student at Washington Irving High School, has been chosen as the official poster for Open School Week, which the New York public school system will observe from Nov. 9 to 14.

Following is the text of an amendment submitted to the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee yesterday by Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, Australian Minister for External Affairs, altering a Soviet resolution on "measures to be taken against war propaganda and the inciters of a new war":

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- J.A. Higgons Jr., executive vice president of the National Association of Commodity Exchanges today said that the Truman Administration charges that grain speculation caused high prices were "unjust." The spokesman for the grain trade added: "and we are hurt and angry."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 21 -- "Cleopatra Arms," a screen story ay Everett Freeman, has been purchased by Warner Brothers for $25,000 as a vehicle for Dennis Morgan and Lauren Bacall to follow "Key Largo" on Miss Bacall's schedule, it was learned today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 21 -- Wheat prices were up 2 to 4 cents and corn around 2 cents at one time or the Board of Trade today, December wheat selling at $3.10 3/4 for a new record high before sufficient pressure developed to bring about a recession.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board issued two orders today affecting Pan American Airways and the United States Steamship Lines. They are designed to emphasize the separation between air and surface sea carriers.

Running amok in a congested neighborhood of Greenwich Village, an unidentified man, believed by the police to be a veteran suffering from war neurosis, fired a deadly spray of bullets into a group of twenty-five or thirty men, women and young persons seated on the front steps of a five-story tenement at 215 West Tenth Street, near Bleecker Street, at 11:35 o'clock last night.

Charlie Conerly, a former marine, seems to have the situation well in hand at Mississippi, where he has sparked Ole Miss from, eleventh in Southeastern Conference play last year to a contending No. 2 spot this season.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

ONE fine day in the summer of 1946 in a little village not very far from London a shameless hussy of a dog ran away to the woods and the attentions of several amorous hounds and mongrels. Laura Marshall knew that she would have to find time to search for Stuffy, who was probably up at the gypsy's cabin on Barrow Down.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- More Government support for the maintenance of a military air reserve of pilots and a parallel encouragement of development of engineers were urged today by witnesses appearing before the President's Air Policy Commission.

With several of the yacht classes on Long Island Sound showing the worse for wear, with cracking ribs and squeaking seams from natural old age and over-ambition, the seeds for a new group of substantial size were sown last night at the New York Yacht Club.

Memorial Hospital, the world's greatest center for cancer and allied diseases, is "attempted to establish something never before done -- a cancer university for the advanced study of cancer in man," it was shown yesterday in the quadrennial report of the hospital by its president, Reginald G. Coombe.

CUSHNOC, Me., Oct. 21 -- If you have never watched a Maine beagle trial your experience in the field is not complete. While it is not an event to attend in your go-to-meeting suit, the 'briar scratches and branch whipping. merge into the general excitement and are merely temporary setbacks.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 21 -- The Brazilian Government formally announced today that it had severed diplomatic relations with Russia.

Information pertaining to entries for the 1947 George Foster Peabody Radio Awards, in booklet form, will soon be mailed to radio stations and other interested agencies by the Henry W. Grady School of Journalism of the University of Georgia.

Washington, Oct. 21 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board faced a new challenge today to decide the place of air-freight carriers in the whole air-transport picture with the filing of another protest over further contemplated freight-rate reductions by major airlines.

MONTREAL, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- Max Bentley, the 150-pourrd shotmaker who jumped from the Saskatoon Quarters, a Canadian amateur team, to the Chicago Black Hawks of the National Hockey League in 1939, today was in a familiar position at the head of the circuit's individual scoring list but he shared the spot with two players of the Montreal Canadiens, Toe Blake and Maurice Richard.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned irregular yesterday and closed 21 points higher to 11 points lower, with near months relatively stronger than the distants.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 21--Judge Joseph Buffington, who served forty-six years on the Federal bench, believed to be a record, died today in the Fairview Sanatorium here of pneumonia. He was 92 years old.
LONDON, Oct. 21 (U.P.) -- Amid a fanfare by heralds in medieval tunics of gold and scarlet, Princess Elizabeth was presented to the British Empire today as its next ruler.

John Santo, Rumanian-born director of organization for the Transport Workers Union, CIO, whom the Government seeks to deport as an alien Communist, was labeled by Army Intelligence as "disaffected" and a person to be closely watched, his commander for twenty-one months in the Aleutians testified yesterday.

David E. Lilienthal, chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, said last night that the American people were "prepared to stake everything" to keep their way of life "alive and flourishing." He added that the principles of American Democracy were "basically opposed" and "demonstrably superior" to "those modern versions of tyranny" that destroyed the Germans and Japanese and "now threaten the peoples of all Europe and Asia."
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:
CHICAGO, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

Harold E. Stassen, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, proposed last night a unity between capitalism and the "sincere Socialists of the world" to rejuvenate and rebuild economic freedom.
An employer offer of a blanket wage increase of $5 a week for 13,000 New York milk drivers and distribution plant workers was rejected as inadequate last night by a union spokesman.

Details of the marine and aerial escort arranged for the transport Joseph V. Connolly as she comes into the inner harbor next Sunday morning with the first 6,200 war dead from Europe, were announced here yesterday.

The stock market backed yesterday into an irregularly lower trend after making selective gains. While the declines were viewed in financial circles as technical, considerable attention was paid to the attempt made on Monday to penetrate the highs of July.

The general health of central Harlem has improved 20 per cent since 1931, reports compiled by the Central Harlem Health Center showed yesterday. Deaths have dropped from fifteen to twelve a thousand, and "the general attitude of the population toward health education has also improved," spokesmen for the center declared.

Charles T. Douds, regional director of the National Labor Relations Board, announced yesterday the withdrawal of injunction proceedings brought under the Taft-Hartley Act to halt a strike called in the port of Albany by the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 21 -- The first annual fashion, festival of The Philadelphia Inquirer was presented here tonight with the brilliance of a gala, theatrical premiere. Threads of a modern Cinderella story, spun with specially composed music and ballet dances, were woven into a fashion show of current styles from New York, Philadelphia and Paris.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 21 -- A Soviet delegation to the Joint United States Soviet Commission left here today. The chief delegate, Col. Gen. T.F. Shtikov, departed by Soviet Army plane, accompanied, by Counselor First Class G.I Tounkin and Maj. Gen. N.G Lebedev.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 21 -- More than 2,000 coal miners battled troops today in pits running more than four miles out under the Pacific Ocean. They repulsed the first military attack with dynamite blasts but were reported to have surrendered in response to an ultimatium from the military zone commander.

CRISTOBAL, C.Z., Oct. 21 -- Some delays to shipping are expected in connection with the mysterious work stoppage of cargo handlers in this Atlantic canal port, according to an official statement made at the Panama Canal today. Workers are being transferred from other Canal and Panama railroad units to replace regular stevedores.

Net earnings of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company for the first nine months of this year were $8,727,826, or $3.42 a share, compared with $2,616,681 or $1.02 a share in the corresponding period of last year, it was reported yesterday to directors at their meeting held in Toledo.

"Unseen Harvests: A Treasury of Teaching," edited by Claude M. Fuess and Emory S. Basford, has been scheduled for publication on Nov. 5 by Macmillan. The volume contains 153 selections from the world's literature concerning teaching, school days and college life.

motion picture camera, which, it is contended, take's pictures at as high as 11,000,000 frames a second, was shown for the first time yesterday to the Society of Motion Picture Engineers meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The State Department announced today that the United States at the request of Brazil would represent Brazilian interests in the Soviet Union because of the severance of diplomatic relations between Rio de Janeiro and Moscow.

The city of Detroit received only one bid yesterday for a new issue of $8,634,000 transit revenue bonds scheduled to mature serially from 1948 to 1960. The bid, 100.16 for 3 1/45s, an interest cost of 3.227 per cent, was submitted by Blyth Co., Inc.; Lehman Brothers, First Boston Corporation and First of Michigan Corporation.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Surmounting a last minute change in the part of the leading man and a postponement to correct scenic and lighting effects, "Finian's Rainbow" staged its British premiere at the Palace Theatre tonight.

Representatives of three major faiths united yesterday in an appeal for support for the three public housing propositions that will be on the November ballot. Their statements were released by Loula D. Lasker, chairman of the Board of the Citizens Housing Council of New York.

Governor Dewey and Republican legislative leaders have served notice on Mayor O'Dwyer and the heads of up-state cities that any new attempts to get increased financial aid from the state for local government are foredoomed to defeat at the next session of the legislature.

Decentralizing Ford Motor Company purchases has increased the number of orders placed in the New York area by about 500 per cent since 1946, Fred H. Schumann, Edgewater plant purchasing agent, told more than 500 members of the New York chapter of the National Association of Purchasing Agents at the Builders Exchange Club last night.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- The United Nations special committee on Palestine decided today to set up three subcommittees to facilitate its work. One group will use as a basis the special inquiry committee's unanimous recommendations and the majority report advocating partition; another will consider the Arab proposals for an independent Palestine, and the third will be a "conciliation" committee.

Full confidence in the intention of the United States Government to obtain a practical form of implementing the partition plan as a solution of the Palestine problem was voiced last night by former Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- Declining public confidence in the United Nations has fostered a "war psychosis" that is threatening the future of the organization, the United Nations publicity chief said today.

Reports of extreme starvation in France and Italy were discounted yesterday by Dr. Victor Heiser, formerly associated with the United States Public Health Service and the Rockefeller Foundation, who arrived here on the Italian liner Vulcania after a four-month motor tour of the two countries.

Overriding last-ditch Soviet opposition, the United Nations General Assembly approved yesterday at Flushing Meadow a United States resolution to set up a permanent Balkan committee, with headquarters at Salonika, to aid in bringing about a settlement of disputes between Greece, on the one hand, and Yugoslavia, Albania and Bulgaria, on the other.

Risolater, owned and trained by G.H. (Pete) Bostwick, the manabout-horses who once was the nation's top steeplechase rider and still is a top-notcher on the polo field, won the best of the day's races at Jamaica yesterday.
ROME, Oct. 21 -- Political observers in Italy notice two remarkable points of similarity between last Sundays municipal elections in France and the election held in Rome one week before.

ALBANY, Oct. 21 -- Governor Dewey extended to all the state's woodlands tonight his original forest-fire proclamation closing the Adirondacks to recreational use. The broadened ban goes into effect at midnight Wednesday.

Over-all planning that includes coordination of hospitals is necessary to meet the problem, of bed shortages, according to the current issue of the Bulletin of the Hospital Council of Great New York. The Bulletin notes changing demands for various types of hospital accommodations and suggests plans which, it says, would benefit both the community and the hospitals.

Buyers' Total Turns Lower Out-of-town buyers registered in the market here in the week ended yesterday totaled 1,385, compared with 1,567 in the previous week and 1,296 in the corresponding week of 1946, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.
For a football coach whose team has lost three of its four games this season, E.E. (Hook) Mylin of New York University is far from being in the doldrums.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Germany's future, including her possible contribution to general European recovery is believed to have been discussed by Foreign Secretary Bevin and Jean Chauvel, Secretary General of the French Foreign Ministry, during the latter's visit to London.

A vast backlog of badly needed city construction projects -- schools, subways, hospital and sewage disposal facilities -- awaits an agreement between builders and labor to stabilize costs and permit negotiation of reasonable contracts from which "padding" has been eliminated, Mayor O'Dwyer informed the New York Building Congress yesterday.
RIO DE JANIERO, Oct. 21 (AP) Following is the text of the Brazilian Foreign Ministry statement explaining the severance, of relations with Russia and the note to Russia:

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 21 -- One day before the opening of the Soviet-sponsored "warmongering" debate, the Australian delegation today asked the United Nations to take positive measures to counter war propaganda and false charges of schemes of aggression.

ATHENS, Oct. 21-- A Greek Army offensive against rebel forces, scheduled to begin about Nov. 15, the date of the expiration of the present amnesty, was planned at a conference of Greek Army, United States and British military mission chiefs at Volos last week, according to information published in most of the Athens press today.

There was some piano playing of distinction yesterday when Wanda Paul made her Hew York debut at Town Hall. In a diversified program of Mozart, Debussy, Brahms and Chopin, the young pianiat displayed ability to adopt a distinctive approach for each work.
Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, leveled sharp criticism at private enterprise yesterday for failing to "carry the ball" in the current housing crisis.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:
Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today three new issues of public utility bonds aggregating $114,500,000, as follows:
LONDON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of the address by King George VI opening the British Parliament today:

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 21 -- One hundred designers in the Los Angeles Fashion Group showed their predictions of fashion futures last evening at Earl Carroll's Restaurant. California clothes for the cosmopolite in any clime Was the underlying theme.

By the narrow margin of 15 votes, the Association of the Bar of the City of New York voted last night to urge the electorate to support J. Edward Lumbard, Republican-American Labor party nominee for the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District, against Representative Benjamin J. Rabin, nominee of the Democratic and Liberal parties.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 21 -- The importance of a healthy balanced world trade to the welfare of the United States and the world was emphasized today by spokesmen for labor, industry and agriculture, who urged an increase in imports to stimulate economic recovery.

New York is providing long-term, care for fewer children today than at any time in the last five years. Edward E. Rhatigan, Welfare Commissioner, said yesterday that his department now provides for fewer than 15,000 children, against the peak load of 22,000 at the beginning of the war.

Wednesday, Oct. 22, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Full Assembly met at 11 A.M. at Flushing Meadow and resumed debate on Greek question. Heard representatives of Australia, Greece, White Russia and France.

The Public Education Association charged yesterday in its fifty-second annual report that the State Legislature had failed to meet the educational needs of the children of New York State in a year of financial crisis for the schools.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 -- The statement of United States policy in the international field, made last night before The Herald Tribune Forum by the Secretary of Defense, James Forrestal, wrapped up in a very few words what has been the import of numerous official pronouncements since the impasse with Soviet Russia became static.

LONDON, Oct. 21 -- Prime Minister Attlee, speaking for Britain's Labor Government, and Anthony Eden, speaking for the Conservative Opposition, joined today in blaming the Soviet Union for the serious deterioration in the international situation.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Oct. 21 (AP) -- Head Coach Howard Odell of Yale, commenting on his team's 9-0 defeat at the hands, of the Wisconsin eleven last Saturday, expressed the opinion in an address at a meeting of the Touchdown Club here last night that the Eli's were deprived of a touchdown in the early part of the game.

The realignment in France is a major event in the political evolution of post-war Europe. The picture remains a moving picture, so it is rash to assume that the Gaullist victory represents the final line-up. Voters continue to float from port to port, seeking anchorage in strange waters.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of the Chilean note handed to the Soviet Ambassador, similar to one sent to the Czechoslovak envoy:

The following statement was issued last night by Walter J. Black, president of the Fordham University Alumni Association: The officers and directors of the Fordham University Alumni Association have been shocked at press reports of the communion breakfast of the Fordham University Club of New Jersey last Sunday, at which the Rev. Robert I. Gannon, S.J., president of the university, was an impromptu speaker.

Fifty years ago New York established its first high school for boys in the annex of an elementary school in Thirteenth Street, almost in the back yard of Macy's department store, which then was on Fourteenth Street. The school was one of three secondary institutions of learning set up at the time by the city, and had an original enrollment of 300 students.

LAKES SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- The fifty-seven members of the General Assembly's Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee unanimously approved today the report of the Children's Emergency Fund, which maps out the relief agency's plans to feed needy children in twelve European countries and China.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- President Truman has declined to order the confidential files of the Civil Service Commission opened to a House subcommittee investigating loyalty of Civil Service applicants.

Everyone has troubles, including the opening day duck shooters on Long Island who read the Federal Migratory Waterfowl regulations but failed to check them with the state regulations on the shooting hours.

Bond Market The high-grade corporate bond market continued yesterday to get a lift from the successful marketing of the new $100,000,000 Pacific Telephone and Telegraph issue, whose oversubscription was announced formally early in the trading day by the syndicate manager, Halsey, Stuart Co.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- Marquis Koichi Kido today told the International Military Tribunal that is trying him with twenty-four other Japanese indicted as major war criminals, that he feared the assassination of three specific men close to the throne should a "mistake" be made in the negotiation of the Axis pact with Germany and Italy.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Forty thousand employes of eleven plants of International Harvester Company were told today by John L. McCaffery, company president, that some of the top officers of their union, the United Farm Equipment and Metal Workers, CIO, "are irresponsible radicals who have no respect for their contracts and who are more interested in disruption than in labor-management peace."

Events in France are moving at breakneck speed. The swing in popular sentiment registered in last Sunday's elections, although directly affecting only municipal administrations, made a change in the national government inevitable. Even without the political upset, however, Premier Ramadier had to call Parliament together to deal with an inflationary situation that is fast becoming unmanageable.
William Reid, career man in city service since 1913, was sworn in yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer to serve as chairman of the Board of Transportation to succeed Charles P. Gross, retired.

NEWARK, N.J., Oct. 22 -- This city today transferred control of its airport and seaport to the Port of New York Authority under a 50-year lease, after a three to two vote on an enabling resolution by the City Commission, ending a year and a half of controversy.
Members of two independent teams are tied for the leadership in the National college football individual scoring race with 54 points apiece, The Associated Press reported yesterday.

Bernard M. Baruch, elder statesman, dropped affairs of state yesterday to serve as a "guinea pig" for hard of hearing veterans. He warned them not to be "diffident, ashamed or afraid to wear a hearing aid," because "it is a curious thing that nobody pays any attention to your hearing aid but you."
Secretary of State George C. Marshall told the closing session of The New York Herald Tribune's annual forum last night that the time for action on European reconstruction was at hand.

Without serving a single court summons, sanitary inspectors have persuaded owners of 101 industrial plants in New York to improve furnace equipment and make it smokeless, Health Commissioner Israel Weinstein reported yesterday. The improvements cost $2,662,440.

MOSCOW, Oct. 22 -- Col. Gen. Andrei A. Zhdanov in a declaration published today called upon Communists and their sympathizers everywhere in the world to join in a battle against what he charged were attempts by the United States to achieve "world domination by American imperialism."

ROME, Oct. 22 -- Umberto Terracini, one of the most prominent Italian Communist leaders and President of the Constituent Assembly, was sharply rebuked today by his party for statements he made to a United States news agency in which he suggested that both the United States and Russia refrain from interfering in the internal affairs of European countries.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Eastern European nations, led by the Soviet Union, have decided to stay out of the year-round "Little Assembly" if it is finally set up by this session of the United Nations General Assembly, it was reported here today.

Closer cooperation between public and private welfare agencies to enable them to meet higher operating costs and to avoid duplication of activities was advocated yesterday by civic, economic and financial leaders at the annual institute sponsored by the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United states Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 7,500 head, total 10.500: market very slow: all weights of butchers mostly 50 to 75 cents lower: sows 75 cents to mostly $1.00 lower: load or so of choice 240 to 250
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers and Bullet Bill Dudley, who agreed they could get along without each other, today were proving their point.

Forest fires in ten states resulted in millions of dollars' damage yesterday as the New England area alone battled several outbreaks and counted property losses above the $3,000,000 mark, The Associated Press reported.

Prompt and vigorous United States assistance to restore the German economy was advocated yesterday by Lewis H. Brown, chairman of the board of the Johns-Manville Corporation, as the only alternative to the ascendancy of communism or war with Russia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Federal tax reform is imperative if high level employment is to continue, J. Cameron Thomson, president of the Northwest Bancorporation, said today to controllers attending the annual convention of the Controllers Institute of America.

Considering the great influence which American moving pictures exert in every part of the world, it is inevitable that Hollywood should be a special target of Communist penetration. We have no doubt that party members are actively at work in the industry, that they have in some cases obtained positions of considerable importance and that they neglect no opportunity to put in a plug for Mother Russia when the chance occurs.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private clementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

LONDON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Some of Britain's highest amateur athletic sources predicted today that Russian athletes would compete in the 1948 Olympic games, ending a thirty-six year snub of the quadrennial sports classic.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 22 -- Despite pressure from Brazil and Chile to join them in breaking relations with Russia or in some form of anti-Communist pact, Argentina has decided not to do so.

A second posthumous book by Theodore Dreiser will be brought out by Doubleday on Nov. 6 under the title "The Stoic." This is the last novel of the trilogy that includes "The Financier," published in 1912, and "The Titan," published in 1914.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- President Truman is expected to decide the question of a special session of Congress at his conference tomorrow with legislative leaders and then make known his decision at a news conference.

Arrangements for the international match between the Manhattan Chess Club and the La Plata Jockey Club of Argentina, to be conducted by radio-telegraph recording Nov. 2, have been completed, it was announced yesterday.

WILLIAM DUEOIS' "The Island in the Square"* is a novel of the generation that followed Hemingway's famous Lost Generation -- and was in many ways equally lost. It is the story of a man only a few years younger than this roaring century looking back at the crucial years before 30, at the bright illusions, the momentous turning points, the dead ends.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The Distillery Workers Union revived today its demand that the Citizens Food Committee call off the projected sixty-day shutdown of distillery mashing operation, scheduled to start at midnight next Saturday.

Groups of citizens facing realities, seeing human problems at their ugliest and working together to correct them, can do more toward saving the world than "the joint wisdom of statesmen," Mme. Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, chief of the Indian delegation to the United Nations and India's Ambassador to the Soviet Union, declared yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- A deadline of Oct. 29 was fixed today by the Palestine committee of the United Nations General Assembly for the submission of detailed proposals for the partition of Palestine and for the alternate Arab plan of a unitary state.

It may take Paul Governali a while to find himself with the New York Giants but, at practice at the Polo Grounds yesterday, it was at once apparent that Steve Owen's latest acquisition already has made one valuable contribution to his new club.

The range of movement by the stock market yesterday was the two extremes established earlier in the week. After a moderate show of firmness, the list faltered in the final hour under realizing. Closing price alterations were generally in fractions and the combined averages declined 0.18 on the day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Communist infiltration is done through the mind, and never openly until the mind has been conditioned by carefully slanted propaganda to receive it in its real character. To accelerate that mental condition in the United States has long been the deliberate effort of a group in Hollywood which in various ways influences the output of the motion -picture studios.

GALION, Ohio, Oct. 22 -- Law-enforcement machinery of this city of 10,000 population broke down tonight as a mob of union labor sympathizers surrounded the plant of the North Electric Company here and held 350 company employes prisoners inside the plant gates.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- There was a growing feeling in political circles in London tonight that the British Labor Government had made a serious tactical mistake in raising the issue of the House of Lords in the middle of the present grave economic crisis.

TOKYO, Oct. 22 -- The Japanese Government in a public statement tonight charged that large numbers of unionized Government employes were sabotaging the public services in an attempt to break through the officially fixed wage levels.
A showing of fashions for women that combined dignity and charm with this season's trends was presented by B. Altman Co. yesterday at the store.

Intensive scrimmage between varsity and freshman teams was ordered yesterday by Coach Edward E. (Hook) Mylin to prepare his New York University football players for the tough contest they face with Georgetown at Griffith Stadium, Washington, Friday night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Acting Secretary of state Robert A. Lovett revealed today that the State Department was proceeding in the hope that the negotiation of a peace treaty for Japan would be undertaken by the end of this year.

After he has gotten a trifling first act out of the way, John van Druten goes straight to the heart of one of his best dramas. "The Druid Circle" he calls it; it was capitally acted at the Morosco last evening. Like "Young Woodley," it is a play about young people in school, based no doubt on Mr. van Druten's personal experiences as a pedagogue.
Two figures representative of United States grain interests issued replies yesterday to President Truman's recent criticism of the role of grain markets in the rise in grain prices.

In his recent address on the food problem, President Truman pointed out that "most of the upward pressure on prices is a result of competition among Americans for scarce goods." The following day Secretary of Labor Schwellenbach told the AFL convention that industry's large profits, not increases in wages, were to blame for higher prices.

City dwellers hereabouts sometimes dismiss forest fires as a menace limited to the Far West. Today they should be awake to the hard fact that the entire northeast section of the United States faces the worst fire hazard it has known in twenty years. Five states, including New York, have already closed their public timberlands.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Black Diamond Steamship Corporation today described the United States Lines and the Waterman Steamship Corporation as "interlopers' on the North Atlantic routes to Belgium and Holland before the Maritime Commission.

The Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on the plea of the New Tork City Omnibus Corporation to set aside a ruling by Supreme Court Justice Ferdinand Pecora sustaining the interpretation made by the Transport Workers Union, CIO, of an arbitrator's pension award.

PRAGUE, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- A Foreign Office statement said tonight that Chile broke off diplomatic relations with Czechoslovakia for "obviously imaginary reasons" and deplored the action as deviating from "international rules adopted for relations between civilized countries."

Underwriting transactions involving the offering to stockholders of $13,872,778 of new common stock of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio and $1,700,000 of new capital stock of the Camden Fire Insurance Association will become effective today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 22 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, renewed his bitter attack on American "warmongers" today and added two members of President Truman's Cabinet, Secretary of Defense James Forrestal and Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman, to the Soviet list.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 22 -- The whole town's talking about a pint-sized Princeton halfback of 162 pounds.
PARIS, Oct. 22 -- Coral and geranium pink mouton is the feature of Hermes' mid-season collection, mainly devoted to ski togs.

The diversity of the decorative accessories exhibited by K.T. Liang, Inc., at the official opening of a new shop at 16 East Fiftyfourth Street yesterday emphasized the fact that the label, "Chinese," covers a multitude of styles in design.
The National Mediation Board intervened yesterday to prevent a strike of 5,000 trainmen on the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

Delay in "breaking out" ninetysix tankers from the Government's idle fleets is worrying oil concerns and Government shipping authorities, it was reported here yesterday. The fuel oil shortage is becoming worse because of the world shortage of tanker tonnage, and refining workers in the New York area were said to be concerned about threatened personnel layoffs.

ALBANY, Oct. 22 (AP) -- A State Health Department official said today that 1947 was "one of the heaviest years" on record up-state for poliomyelitis and that the incidence among adults had increased sharply.

LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Over the violent objection of William Gallacher, Communist member, the House of Commons today adopted a resolution to present an address of congratulation to King George VI on the marriage of Princess Elizabeth to Lieut. Philip Mountbatten.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 22 -- Ernest T. Weir, chairman of the board of the National Steel Corporation, asserted tonight that strikes "caused in large part by incredibly stupid Government policies" were the real cause of the postwar shortage of steel.

New record sales and earnings for the third quarter of this year prompted directors of the St. Regis Paper Company yesterday to vote resumption of quarterly dividend payments on the common stock after a lapse of sixteen years. Roy K. Ferguson, president, reported that the board had authorized a regular dividend of 15 cents a share and an extra disbursement of 10 cents a share on the stock, both payable on Dec. 1.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 22 -- First-class passenger accommodations of "pre-war standards" are being installed on twenty-one Victory ships used as freighters in transpacific, round-the-world and intercoastal routes, the American President Lines announced today.

Directors of the Continental Can Company, Inc., yesterday declared a year-end dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock, payable Dec. 15. This brings the total payments for this year to $1.25, or 25 cents more than 1946 disbursements.

In his recent inaugural address as the third president of the University of Virginia, Dr. Colgate W. Darden Jr. disclaimed any intention of seeking to develop a great center of learning in the foothills of the Blue Ridge. Instead, he visualized the future of Mr. Jefferson's university as that of the most powerful instrument in the possession of the state for the advancement of its people.

PARIS, Thursday, Oct. 23 -- Premier Paul Ramadier's three-party Cabinet suddenly decided yesterday to call Parliament in a special session Tuesday and meanwhile to revamp itself within a smaller compass.

Arthur L. Amundsen, district manager of the Brooklyn shelter of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, brought joy to two broken-hearted children when he announced yesterday that their 1-year-old dog, Rex, part chow and part spitz, had been saved from the death chamber.

WARSAW, Oct. 22 -- General Zhdanov admitted at the meeting of Communist leaders that the Soviet Union was not yet in possession of the atomic bomb, it was disclosed today. The text of his keynote speech was published as a special supplement to Glos Ludu, the Polish Communist party newspaper.

Careful restrictions on the entrance of all persons into Lewisohn Stadium went into effect yesterday afternoon as Coach Harold J. Parker conducted a secret practice session for the C.C.N.Y. football squad. The nature of the drills was not disclosed.

Melvin Ritter, violinist from Cleveland, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The gifted young artist was heard in a program containing the Vitali-Auer "Chaconne"; Bruch's Concerto, No. 2, in D minor; the Strauss Sonata; the Paganini-Hartman "Moses" Fantasy, and Szymanowski's "Notturno e Tarantella."
LONDON, Oct. 22 -- Business generally was at a low ebb in the stock markets here today.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 22 (U.P.) -- President Gabriel Gonzalez Videla, in a broadcast statement said that in breaking relations with Russia and Czechoslovakia the Government was "protecting Chile's higher interests, hemisphere security and democracy."'
SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 22 -- Chilean police began a wholesale roundup of Communist leaders today, following the diplomatic break with Russia and Czechoslovakia.

DETROIT, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Kaiser-Frazer Corporation reported today for the third quarter of this year a net profit of $8,277,308, equal to 51-74 a share. The profit offset losses incurred during the first six months of the year to produce for the nine-month period a net profit of $6,089,269.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Fireballer Bob Feller, the American League's only twenty-game winner in 1947, was paid $87,000 in base salary and bonuses, President Bill Veeck of the Indians announced today.

A young woman, who gave her name as Helen Baxter and said she was 18 years old, was arrested last evening on forgery and grand larceny charges in connection with an elaborate scheme of check cashing by means of false identification. The police admitted that they might never have caught her if she had not bought a dog.

Rosalyn Tureck seems to like to vary the order in which she plays Bach's "Goldberg Variations." She played them at the second concert of her Bach series of 1944, and she played them at the final concert of her series a year ago.
Voting to meet next year at the Hague, site of the permanent Court of International Justice, the International Bar Association ended its first three-day conference here yesterday.

Henry H. Curran, Associate Justice of the Court of Special Sessions, has applied for retirement, effective Nov. 26, it was announced yesterday at City Hall. The Board of Estimate will act upon his application this morning.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If we are really interested in saving grain, the obvious thing to do is to kill off some of our cattle and hogs and use the grain they would otherwise eat for human consumption. I suppose that a steer or a hog consumes from three to six times as much grain as a human being.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 22 -- The thirtyfourth annual national foreign trade convention proposed today a "twelve-point" program to promote world productivity and trade and lay the basis for lasting peace and prosperity.

Foundry production, now 40 per cent above 1943 levels, has reached a peacetime peak which can be maintained only by most active cooperation of merchant pig iron producers and foundrymen, industry spokesmen disclosed here yesterday.

John J. Scanlan Jr. 26-year-old longshoreman with a police record, was arrested yesterday on a charge of homicide in Tuesday night's wild shotting on a crowded Greenwich Village tenement stoop in which a man and woman were slain and two men were wounded.

BERLIN, Oct. 22 -- Four shiploads of potatoes for United States personnel in Germany arrived during September, with only 36 per cent of the cargo edible and another 16 per cent edible only if eaten immediately.

Because it's so simple to prepare, soluble coffee has been especially useful for people living in quarters without kitchen facilities. Its one drawback has been that cream (for those who like the beverage this way rather than black) can't be kept without refrigeration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Justice Department announced today it is releasing for free use of American business forty-six patents representing the "know how" of I.G. Farben, German dye trust, in the production of nylon.

Bookings for thirteen musical productions slated to play in Cincinnati this season have been canceled because of a dispute between the Messrs. Shubert and the musicians' union, it was learned yesterday. The difference, it was said, arose over the Shubert's refusal to hire musicians in connection with dramatic presentations.
Sixty consecutive minutes of comedy are being prepared for WJZ-ABC presentation Monday nights, beginning next week, with Groucho Marx and Opie Cates heading respective half-hour shows.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 22 -- Representatives of the Nizam of Hyderabad, independent Princely State, and of the Dominion of India are reliably reported to have settled upon a one-year "standstill agreement" between Hyderabad and the Dominion by which the State would retain its own sovereignty for that period.

Former Republican Representative Clare Boothe Luce urged the State Department last night to reconsider its decision not to make public the report of Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer on his recent mission to China and Korea. She said she failed to see how "publication of the truth" could be harmful to those countries.

VIENNA, Oct. 22 -- The Soviet Union's actions in Austria came under heavy fire today from many sides. They were sharply criticized by Lieut. Gen. Geoffrey Keyes in a letter to the Austrian Trades Union Congress, by Austrian Foreign Minister Dr. Karl Gruber in a Vienna newspaper and by speeches in the Austrian Parliament.

CHICAGO, Oct. 22 -- Wheat made a strong finish after a period of easiness early, old crop deliveries rallying as much as 5 cents a bushel from the low and went into new ground since trading in them started with December at a new thirty-year high.

Columbia's football team rushed preparations yesterday for its clash with unbeaten, unscored-on Army at Baker Field Saturday, which will take place before one of the largest "audiences" in Columbia history.

THE ASSOCIATED PRESS dispatch from Hollywood bluntly stated, "Branch Rickey, headman of the Brooklyn Dodgers, has signed for a part in a movie starring Jackie Robinson." That does it. The Mahatma of Montague street has become a cinema star, a "glamour puss," no less. He's right up in the motionpicture heavens with James Stewart, Van Johnson, Robert Montgomery, Clark Gable and all the rest.

Nationalization of between 60 and 75 per cent of the British chemical industry will occur by 1950 or 1951, C.C. Concannon, chief, drugs and chemical division, Office of International Trade, United States Department of Commerce, predicted yesterday.

Igor Stravinsky, long a demigod in the world of serious music, has made a bid for juke-box recognition. The composer, whose artistic accomplishments have never made him contemptuous of money, has adapted one of his famous ballet themes into a torch song to "boost his ASCAP rating," it was learned last night.

Fordham University's athletic policy was outlined yesterday and will appear tomorrow in The Ram, Fordham student publication. Released by the Rev. Kevin J. O'Brien, faculty director of athletics, the statement reveals Fordham's desire to operate on a "strictly collegiate basis."

During a prolonged gathering of member club delegates to the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound, which was started yesterday afternoon in the New York Yacht Club and continued through dinner there, the growth of sailing was set forth in figures over the last summer.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange turned strong yesterday and closed at about the best levels of the day, 19 to 52 points net higher.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 22 -- The International Typographical Union, AFL, raised the question today whether the National Labor Relations Board could order a union to bargain when union officers had not filed the required affidavits disclaiming Communist beliefs.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 22 -- Henry A. Wallace told Jewish journalists here today that "I have long believed that there would never be peace in the world until there was peace here in Palestine."

Breaking all previous records, bicycle deliveries for 1947 now are expected to exceed, by a "comfortable margin" the industry output goal of 2,000,000 units set as a target for domestic sales, John Auerbach, executive secretary, Bicycle Institute of America, Inc., revealed here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- The Northern States Power Company was granted permission today by the Securities and Exchange Commission to borrow $12,000,000 from banks before Oct. 31 to improve the company's financial position. The loans, evidenced by promissory notes, will bear interest of 1 1/2 per cent per annum.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 22 -- Executives of the steel, foundry and scrap metal industries met Government officials here today to discuss ways of overcoming the shortage of scrap, which was said to threaten "a calamitous blow to steel production."

Forty Pacific war dead left Distribution Center 1 at the Army Base in Brooklyn yesterday for the homes' of next-of-kin. These were the first of the 296 bodies that came into New York last week, by way of San Francisco, to be moved.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 22 -- Months of effort by the House Education and Labor Committee and other agencies to end the year-old jurisdictional dispute of affiliates of the American Federation of Labor in Hollywood appeared tonight to have reached a dead end.

The cotton textile industry will enter 1948 with unprecedented financial strength, according to Dr. C.T. Murchison, president of the Cotton-Textile Institute, yesterday. Industry earnings, however, he said, will be plowed back into corporate investment to re-equip and modernize mills and to conduct necessary research.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Commerce, Department reported today production of newsprint in North America during August continued at the July level, but consumption increased ten per cent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, testified today that a blueprint for a total mobilization of the nation was being embodied in a set of proposed laws which would be available for immediate enactment if another war broke out.

ALBANY, Oct. 22 -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond, chairman of the joint legislative committee on problems of the aging, urged today that each community in the state establish recreational centers for the elderly.

They were yelling "ooh-la-la" in the jockeys' quarters five minutes after the running of the $20,000 added Interborough Handicap at Jamaica yesterday, and little Louis Olah was being pounded on the back and bashfully receiving congratulations from all hands.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Manuel Maestro of the Spanish Embassy accused me in his letter to you, dated Sept. 17, of inaccuracy, which he implied was willful. May 1, as an American reporter, rather than as your Madrid correspondent, reply through your columnns.

The Executive Director of the Air Reserve Association, William C. Lewis, touched a sensitive nerve of our national defense establishment when he called the attention of the President's Air Policy Commission to the sad state of the Air Force reserve program. What he said of it is almost equally true of the Army Ground reserve and, in a lesser measure, of Navy and Marine reserves.
