HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 22 -- The local office of Sir Alexander Korda, film producer, received word today of two deals the producer has concluded in England. Sir Alexander has signed Robert Donat to play the leading role in a screen version of Terence Rattigan's play, "The Winslow Boy."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- Actors, writers and others in Hollywood were named today as members of the Communist party or as Communist sympathizers. The accusations were by Robert Taylor, screen actor, and by other movie figures as the inquiry of the House Committee on Un-American Activities into the extent of Communist penetration into the film industry went into its third day.
Jay Rhodemyre, a towering 198pound center from the University of Kentucky, yesterday was named lineman of the week in the first Associated Press poll of the season.

Visitors to the First Army recruiting caravan that opened its exhibit of weapons and devices last night will have the opportunity to send radio messages to "anyone anywhere in the United States and to service men anywhere overseas." The exhibit will be open to the public daily from 4 P.M. to 10 P.M. until next Wednesday, at the Ninth Infantry Regiment Armory, 125 West Fourteenth Street.

Blind persons with Seeing Eye dogs have an unusually low accident rate, Morris S. Frank, a vice president of The Seeing Eye and head of its division of the blind at Morristown, N.J., declared yesterday.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Former Secretary of State James F. Byrnes proposed tonight that the United States, Britain and France act ''now" to call a fulldress German peace conference regardless of the attitude of Russia.

Thursday, Oct. 23, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Began general debate on Sovient proposal on ''measures to be taken against propaganda and inciters of new war," presented by Andrei Y. Vishinsky.

A small collection of handwoven home accessories by Dutch craftsmen, was placed on exhibit yesterday at The Netherlands Chamber of Commerce in New York, Inc., 41 East Forty-second Street. Sample rugs, fabrics and wall hangings in the group represent the work of 140 members of the Craft Guild of Handwoven Applied Art of Holland, which includes commereial firms as well as institutions such as homes for the aged.

PRAGUE, Oct. 22 -- The police asked the States Attorney in Prague today to issue a warrant for the arrest of Fedor Hodza, the third of three secretaries general of the Slovak Democratic party. M. Hodza had charged the police in his address last Thursday in Parliament with being an instrument of the Communist party and with having persecuted his party.

"With the election on Nov. 4 less than two weeks away, proponents and opponents of the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council yesterday increased their efforts to bring out a large vote on proposition No. 4 to repeal PR and substitute election of Council menibers by State Senate districts.

Television has a long way to go before it proves itself an important advertising medium, particularly in view of prevailing high costs and record competition for the advertising dollar, Paul West, president of the Association of National Advertisers, told members of the American Television Society yesterday at their first regular monthly meeting in the Hotel Commodore.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 22 -- Palestine's Jewish National Council has established a Legal Department, which, eventually, may be charged with drafting a constitution and a legal code for a Jewish state, it was announced today.

The cost of medical care in the voluntary hospitals of this city has risen 35 per cent in eighteen months. Hence the increase in the bills that patients must pay. Producers and consumers have done their best to adjust themselves to the trend. But a voluntary hospital is a nonprofit institution and not a business.

Chemical Price Rise Looms Further increases in prices of chemicals were forecast here yesterday by industrial purchasing agents, who said that increased freight rates could be held responsible for most price boosts in this field.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 15:

BOSTON, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Although outshot by 20 -- 12, the Boston Bruins pulled out a 3-1 National Hockey League victory over Montreal's Canadiens tonight before a capacity crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden. The winning goal, rapped in by Milt Schmidt during the second period, was against short-handed opposition.

Mayor O'Dwyer disclosed yesterday that Corporation Counsel Charles E. Murphy was studying the legality of a plan to eliminate pollution of the waters surrounding the city by constructing six new sewage disposal plants and financing the work by issuing $79,000,000 of water-supply bonds exempt from the city's constitutional debt limit.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- R.H. Macy Co., Inc., of New York City filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering $20,000,000 of twenty-fiveyear, 2 7/8 per cent sinking fund debentures, which are to be offered to the public at a price to be announced by amendment.

Because of the high prices of many basic foods, the Red Cross in Brooklyn will begin, on Nov. 3, a course in nutrition for expectant mothers and others of children of pre-school age. The purpose is to enable such mothers to provide the maximum, amount of nutrition within their food budgets.

In an unusual action, Cardinal Spellman emphasized yesterday the National Legion of Decency condemnation of the motion picture "Forever Amber," by announcing that "Catholics may not see this production with a safe conscience."

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 22 (AP) -- Bomar Stable's Piet, scoring by a nose in a three-horse blanket finish, survived a foul claim today to capture the twentieth Spalding Lowe Jenkins Stakes. Mrs. John T. Maloney's Big If was second by a nose over G.M. Jacobson's Big Dial, whose jockey, Doug Dodson, lodged the objection.
Tokens of appreciation for aid sent by Stuyvesant High School to a school in Amiens, France, were presented yesterday to the students here.

NANKING, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Enthusiasm over Government victories in the Fushum coal mining area was tempered today by the announcement that a revolt had broken out in Sinkiang Province on the Russian border.

London's Wedding Preparations They are sprucing up Buckingham Palace. Its grand gates, one hears, have been painted; and there is much other activity of artisans and laborers in and around it, in preparation for the wedding next month of Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Oct. 22 (AP) -- The Rev. Dr. Reinhold Niebuhr of the Union Theological Seminary, New York City, said tonight that predictions made by atomic scientists about the dangers of the atom bomb "led to hysterical paralysis" in the United States.

Settlement of the seventeenweek-old strike at the Atlantic Basin Iron Works of Brooklyn, was announced last night by Michael J. Carroll, executive secretary of Local 39, Industrial Union of Marine and Shipyard Workers of America, CIO, after a long meeting at the company's Manhattan offices.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- With a Lockheed test pilot at the controls, a Navy P2V Neptune has recently undergone the most stringent flight tests ever given this type of aircraft, the Navy Department announced today.

Park Commissioner Robert Moses has written to Grover A. Whalen, chairman of Mayor O'Dwyer s committee for the city's Golden Jubilee celebration next year, that the Whalen plan to use Park Avenue is "extravagant, undesirable and destructive."

Retail meat prices, which have been notching downward for the last few weeks because of curtailed buying by many housewives, will go still lower in this city during the next week or ten days, industry spokesmen agreed yesterday.

The New York Board of Rabbis, in a resolution adopted yesterday, condemned Rabbi Benjamin Schultz of Temple Emanu-El in Yonkers for three articles he wrote for The New York World-Telegram on alleged Communist infiltration into religious groups.

TORONTO, Oct. 22 (AP) -- Toronto's Maple Leafs rallied tonight to whip the New York Rangers, 3 -- 1, before 12,970 fans for their first triumph of the National Hockey League campaign. The Leafs moved up into third place in the standing.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 2 -- The United States called on the United Nations Security Council today to make another appeal to The Netherlands and the Republic of Indonesia, to get together to end hostilities in the East Indies.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week increased 23,100 barrels to a new peak of 5,268,400, according to the American Petroleum Institute. This compares with 5,245,300 barrels daily in the previous week and 4,732,600 in the week ended on Oct. 19, 1946.
NANKING, Oct. 22 -- With China's first national elections only a month away, there is no sign in Nanking of the fervor that might be expected to precede such an event.

Rather than face trial on libel charges brought by an American Federation of Labor union, the Wholesale and Warehouse Workers Union, Local 65, CIO, has agree to retract publicly the statements it made against officers of the AFL group.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 22 -- The Iranian Majlis [Parliament] voted 102 to 2 tonight to reject Russian demands for an oil concession and instead to initiate a fiye-year oil exploration program from which all foreign capital would tie barred.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -- A new "air pattern" for the New York area, designed to reduce congestion at the airports, will be inaugurated Nov. 1, the Air Transport Association announced here today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- The Civic Theatre and the Civic Opera House were put on the "unfair" list by James C. Petrillo's Chicago Federation of Musicians today. This means that from now on, according to a union spokesman, no orchestras or musicians will be allowed to play in either theatre.

A return to self-reliance and a reinvigoration of American moral stamina was suggested last night by Earl O. Shreve, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, as the answer to attacks on the American business system.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- The flat rejection of a Soviet resolution calling for the punishment of "warmongers" was demanded today by Warren B. Austin, permanent United States representative to the United Nations.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 23 -- The Rumanian Government today summoned into court the last of the country's Opposition parties and demonstrated in several other ways that uncensored ideas were a source of danger and a cause of extreme discomfort to this regime.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Now that President Truman has called Congress into special session on Nov. 17, the hope is being openly expressed in official quarters that Secretary of State Marshall will return to the capital as soon as possible.

Lillian Uttal, 44 years old, free lance and lyric writer under the name of Diana Johns, was found dead in her room in the Woodward Hotel, 210 West Fifty-fifth Street, yesterday afternoon. She apparently was a suicide, the police said.

Shoe Advance Seen Certain New advances in hide and kid leather levels make price advances on spring shoes certain at the National Shoe Fair in Chicago next week, reports here yesterday indicated. Spot hide prices have now moved up to 33 cents a pound, compared with 29 1/2 cents on Oct. 1 and 26 1/2 cents on Sept. 1.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- The British Government has been urged by the London Chamber of Commerce to sponsor an arrangement under which foreign trade would be financed through an international clearing house.

In commemoration of the centenary of Mendelssohn's death, that composer's "Scotch" Symphony was performed by the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, under Leopold Stokowski, at its concert last night in Carnegie Hall.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- France's trade deficit for the first nine months this year was given today as 98,153,000,000 francs in the official statistics of the French customs service. [Thursday's foreign exchange transactions placed the value of the franc at $.00845 in United States currency.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 23 -- The first hearing by the National Labor Relations Board of a complaint charging violations of the Taft -- Hartley Law's provisions against secondary boycotting got under way before a trial examiner here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- President Truman called Congress by proclamation today to meet in special session on Nov. 17 to appropriate funds for emergency relief in western Europe and to curb the high cost of living at home.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 23 -- Dr. H.V. Evatt, Australian Foreign Minister, delivering the second Holmes Memorial Lecture at Harvard University, said tonight that the abuse of the right of veto in the Security Council had brought the Council into disrepute and had damaged the reputation of the United Nations as a whole.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- With remarkable regularity, officials of the government draw up plans to keep the public from getting legitimate information, and with the same regularity the scheme never gets beyond the planning stage. This probably will be the history of the newest effort -- a code drawn up by the Security Advisory Board of the State and Defense Departments and now in circulation before being submitted in final form for the President's approval.

FAIRFIELD, Ill., Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- Four gunmen today ambushed and killed Carl Shelton, a leader of the Shelton gang which battled rival bootleggers with Army tanks and a bomb-carrying plane during the 1920's in an incredible Midwest gang war which cost at least forty lives.

The Port of New York Authority agreed yesterday afternoon to the request of Mayor O'Dwyer that it make a survey of the city's waterfront facilities, and appropriated $200,000 for the conduct of the study.

A five-story business building valued at $125,000 at 179 Madison Avenue was sold by the Bank of New York and Trust Company, as trustee, to a client of Carb, Reichman Luria, attorneys, in a deal reported yesterday by the Charles F. Noyes Company, brokers in the transaction, who also arranged for the new owner a $75,000 mortgage loan at 4 per cent interest.

Replying to Mr. Vishinsky's charge of American "warmongering," as Mr. Austin undertook to do yesterday on behalf of the United States, is bound to resemble somewhat the business of nailing a custard pie to a barn door. There is something hopeless about the effort.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- During the week ended Oct. 22, member -bank reserve balances decreased $192,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

As a middle-aged woman landlord began yesterday to serve a five-day jail sentence for violating the city rent control law, the District Attorney's office studied the minutes of the case for possible further criminal action on charges of perjury.

Isidor Bieber's Our Tommy, named for one of Trainer Hirsch Jacobs' youngsters, ended a tenrace losing streak at Jamaica yesterday by winning the Class C Marchmont Handicap, a $5,000 added number for 3-year-olds.
Some of the world's outstanding statesmen, military leaders and educators paid tribute to a mouse yesterday.

The development of well-designed furniture, appropriate for modern homes and within price reach of the man earning $75 a week is the objective of a $50,000 international competition announced last night by Nelson Rockefeller, president of the Museum of Modern Art, at a dinner held at the Rainbow Room of the RCA Building, Radio City.

Contracts involving expenditures of $8,062,400 to eliminate smoke nuisance have been let by 102 privately operated heating plants, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday. He also said the Board of Transportation's $8,500,000 program for enlargement of the Fifty-ninth Street power plant of the IRT subway division contemplated smoke nuisance elimination.

Recuperating from a broken leg, a large owl was resting comfortably yesterday at the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, Twenty-fourth Street and Avenue A, following its capture on Tuesday in the new Stuyvesant Town - Metropolitan Life Insurance Company development.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 23 -- Chilean armed forces today occupied the United States-owned copper mines known as Chuquicamata and Potrerillos in the northern provinces as a further step toward safeguarding foreign national interests where Communist-controlled labor syndicates threaten normal operations.

ABSECON, N.J., Oct. 23 -- The Indian-summer weather attracted sixty-two women stars for the start of the last thirty-six-hole two-day tournament of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at the Seaview Country Club course here today.

Travel in Europe has nothing to compare with going through customs at La Guardia Field, it was asserted yesterday by Sir Alexander Hyslop Maxwell, director of the British Travel Association, upon his arrival from London on a British Overseas Airways plane.

It may seem rather brash for the only team in the National Football League that has yet to win a game to be thinking in pennant terms, but that is exactly how the New York Giants were figuring yesterday as they set up special defenses for the Pittsburgh Steelers, whom they meet at the Polo Grounds on Sunday.

Substantial liberalization of down payment requirements involved in instalment sales of furniture, appliances and other homefurnishings will be instituted by department and furniture stores following expiration of Regulation W on Nov. 1, Kenneth Richmond, vice president and treasurer of Abraham Straus, declared yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At Monday's hearing in Albany of the State Commission to Examine Into the Need for a State University, the Association of Colleges and Universities submitted a statement which, in its cynicism and disregard of fact, is wholly unworthy of its signatories and the institutions they represent.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Old crop deliveries of wheat on the Chicago Board of Trade closed today at their highest point and in new seasonal ground. December went to a thirty-year high as the result of a resumption of buying of cash wheat by the Government.

Until the final quarter has ended at Baker Field tomorrow afternoon and the score has become a matter of record, there will be no admission by Coach Lou Little that Red Blaik's Black Knights from West Point can beat the Columbia Lions.

A $47-a-week hardware salesman, who the State Attorney General's office says blossomed into a stock market investment analyst, was arraigned yesterday in Felony Court on a charge of dealing in stocks and bonds while insolvent. Magistrate Joseph B. Glebocki held him in $1,500 bail for grand jury action.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Lower prices of meat, fats and oils chiefly were responsible for a fractional decline of 0.1 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended Oct. 18, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 5,500 head; total, 9.500. Market closed fairly active and generally 25 cents higher on all weights of butchers hogs; sows uneven but mostly steady; top on hogs.

Hard hit by injuries in key positions, the New York University football team will have to take to the air tonight if it intends to make Georgetown its second victim of the season in the arclight battle at Griffith Stadium, Washington.
LONDON, Oct. 23 -- With substantial buying of gilt-edge issues in the stock markets here today gains of as much as 1/4 point were recorded throughout the list.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Industry and Government coal experts concluded after an exchange of data today there is no general shortage of solid fuel, but that preferred grades will be tight in a few localized areas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The United States Lines and the Waterman Steamship Corporation continued today before the Maritime Commission their attack on a proposal that the Black Diamond Steamship Corporation receive a subsidized route from North Atlantic ports to Belgium and Holland.

The appointment of Col. Russell (Red) Reeder as assistant to the graduate manager of athletics at West Point was announced yesterday by Maj. Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, superintendent of the United States Military Academy.
Fordham University's frequency -modulation station, WFUV, will be dedicated on Sunday afternoon by Cardinal Spellman at exercises to be held in Keating Hall on the university campus.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- An all-time high of 3,000,000 children, representing an increase of 50 per cent in the last twenty-five years, are attending Catholic schools and colleges this fall, Msgr. Frederick G. Hochwalt, general secretary of the National Catholic Educational Association, disclosed here today.

Although the cotton futures market failed to hold all its early gains yesterday, trading on the New York Cotton Exchange was heavy and closing prices were 7 to 46 points net higher than the day before.

Some engrossing music was performed by the talented young violinist. Anahid Ajemian, at Town Hall last night. It was her second appearance there, the first having been her award as winner of a Naumburg prize in 1946. She courageously seized the opportunity to play much new music for the large audience.

Old wharves are a familiar part of the scene along the coast. In small harbors where surrounding hills and jutting backbones of sand offered protection from waves and gales, men of long ago built plank wharves by the water's edge and their own homes on narrow, winding streets that lead back from the ocean.

Mrs. Grace Babcock has sold her estate property of thirteen and onehalf acres on a private road in Mill Neck, L.I., to Lowell P. Weicker of New York City. The main residence contains twenty rooms, and there is a large garage with living quarters, a superintendent's cottage and a small stable J. Ralph Bloomer was the broker.

After long deliberation and thorough preparation, President Truman has at last called a special session of Congress to provide emergency aid for Europe in line with the Marshall plan. This action comes none too soon. The economic and political crisis in Europe is mounting at a rate which creates the danger that under the impact of hunger and Russo-Communist sabotage it may develop into a panic with serious consequences for the whole Western world.

Seventeen newspaper men from ten states will attend a seminar for Sunday and Feature Editors offered by Columbia's American Press Institute starting Monday, and continuing for three weeks, Floyd Taylor, director of the institute, announced yesterday.

Important theatrical ventures don't materialize quickly. To give themselves plenty of time, Margaret Webster and Carly Wharton have jointly acquired for production next season a prize-winning script bearing the plaintive title of "A Cry of Players," written by Will Gibson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Three Hollywood stars, leaders in the Screen Actors Guild, stated today that their profession contained a "militant, well-organized, well-disciplined minority" of Communist leanings. They declared that the group was tiny and had made no headway.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- The United States and the Soviet Union joined today in opposing Argentina's proposal to enlarge the United Nations Economic and Social Council from eighteen member nations to twenty-four.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- The arrival of a group of Senators in Berlin today evoked a series of criticisms against visiting Congressmen from various United States Military Government officials. The complaints do not apply to all or even most of the Congressional investigators, it was emphasized.

NANKING, Oct. 23 -- Shifts of plainclothes Government secret police were today stationed around the local headquarters of the Democratic League and league members were closely followed by plainclothes agents whenever they left the building.

The Washington Toll Bridge Authority will accept bids until Dec. 2 for $14,000,000 of Tacoma Narrows revenue bonds. On Nov. 17 the authority will offer $3,650,000 of Longview Toll Bridge revenue bonds dated Dec. 1, 1947, and due on Dec. 1, 1977.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works reported yesterday that net income for the nine months to Sept. 30 was $1,238,918, equal to 60 cents a common share. No comparison was available since the company, in the June quarter, changed its policy of reporting earnings.

Fearful that the city's traditional "Great White Way" may become the "Great Dim Way," the Broadway Association, Inc., announced yesterday it was prepared to join with the Broadway Theatre, Broadway and Fifty-third Street, in fighting for the right of the theatre to keep its advertising signs alight after midnight.

Persuasive arguments for compulsory periodic motor car inspection, which has been recommended for New York by the Governor's commission, were stated before the National Safety Congress by Thomas N. Boate of the National Conservation Bureau. Mr. Boate pointed out that during the first year of New Jersey's experiment with this plan there were 413 fewer fatalities in that state than in the year before.

TOKYO, Friday, Oct. 24 (U.P.) -- The death sentence of Pfc. Carl J. Havalda of Owosso, Mich., has been commuted to life imprisonment by President Truman, and the life sentences of four other enlisted men convicted with him of murdering five Japanese have been reduced to thirty years each, Far East Air Force headquarters announced today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- New metals capable of withstanding intense heat and radiation must be developed before atomic energy can be used to produce electric power on a commercial scale, Dr. Robert F. Bacher, member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission, said today.

Despite an increase of 10 per cent in sales and billings, the Douglas Aircraft Company showed an operating loss of $9,250,037 before Federal income tax credits and a net deficit of $1,170,037 for the first nine months of the year, compared with a net profit of $3,154,142 in the same period of 1946, Donald W. Douglas, president, announced yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- A protective committee for holders of the $7 and $6 cumulative prior preference shares of the Standard Gas and Electric Company petitioned the Securities and Exchange Commission today to dismiss the reorganization plan filed three weeks ago by the company, charging that it is solely "an instrument of confusion and obstruction."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Two members of President Roosevelt's Cabinet and a top general were accused today of hindering the preparatory phases of the American war effort by Louis A. Johnson, former Assistant Secretary of War.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- Registration statements covering proposed offerings of $14,500,000 of bonds, 100,000 shares of preferred stock and 340,652 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 23 -- The Screen Writers Guild will petition the National Labor Relations Board Monday for a special election to prove that the majority of its members desire a guild shop as a result of a preliminary poll in which 5,675 out of 8,500 members have already indicated preference for the Guild shop, the actors' organization announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The text of a statement by President Truman today announcing he will convene Congress in special session Nov. 17: I have met this afternoon with a group of Congressional leaders. I presented to them detailed information concerning the alarming and continuing increase in prices in this country and the situation regarding the need for emergency foreign aid.

BAD PYRMONT, Germany, Oct. 23 -- A complete split between the trade unions of the western zones and of the Soviet zone on the formation of a national federation of workers was averted today by a margin of one vote. As a result of the vote of twenty-three delegates from all four zones and Berlin, the proposal for the establishment of a national federation was deferred until next spring.

The New York City Opera Company made another brave effort last night to establish that it belongs in the operatic big leagues when it put on Mozart's "Don Giovanni," one of the resplendent ornaments of Western art. The result is a production of many merits.

Distillers Discuss Campaign Strong sentiment has developed among leaders of the distilling industry for a joint national advertising campaign aimed at acquainting the public with the past and present status of their business, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Republican leaders in Congress laid the responsibility for calling a special session of Congress in mid-November directly at the door of President Truman today.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 23 -- The House Committee on Agriculture decided provisionally tonight to continue its transcontinental tour, despite President Truman's calling of Congress into extraordinary session.
Against an attractive background of interiors styled and designed by Dorothy Draper, Frank Brothers held a preview yesterday of their new shop at 9 East Fiftyseventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Attorney General Clark today announced the filing of a civil antitrust suit against five corporations charging "conspiracy to monopolize and restrain trade" in the cast iron pressure pipe industry.

Six members of the Board of Education heard for three hours yesterday a series of impassioned speeches for and against a resolution that would bar the Communist party, the American Youth for Democracy and Nazi or Fascist groups from using public school buildings as meeting places.

Nearly a year ago a French halforphan, Jacques Hugh Vinet, 11 years old, whose father died in Dachau concentration camp, was adopted by the junior council of the Children's Aid Society's James Center at 154. Hester Street, just too late to send him anything for Christmas.

The whole movement for a proposed union of the Protestant Episcopal Church with the Presbyterian Church in the United States of America, which has caused bitter dissension for the last few years in both bodies, but which has been dormant for some time, will be reopened at a series of public hearings next Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Loading of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 18, 1947, totaled 954,249 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 2,613 or 0.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 22,483 or 2.4 per cent more than for the corresponding week of last year, and 180,442 or 23.3 per cent more than during the corresponding week of 1945.
The 165 Corp obtained a first mortgage loan of $255,000 for ten years at 3 1/2 per cent from the Dollar Savings Bank on the apartment house at 165 Seaman Ave through Henry Waltemade Inc.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 23 -- William Perlberg, producer of the Twentieth Century-Fox film, "Forever Amber," which was condemned yesterday in New York by the Roman Catholic Legion of Decency and by Cardinal Spellman, said today that he believed the story was translated to the screen in splendid taste.

The greatest obstacles to success of the Marshall plan are not the scarcity of money or materials here, industrial equipment spokesmen disclosed here yesterday. The trouble is, they revealed, that most standard American machines, such as for mining, cannot be taken from stock designs here and used in European mines, and other products made to American standards, in a wide variety of fields, cannot be fitted to special European tolerances and dimensions.

TOKYO, Oct. 23 -- The Socialist coalition Government of Premier Tetsu Katayama was under violent attack by organized labor today as a result of its warning to unionized public service employes to desist from mass absenteeism and "wildcat strikes" in their drive for higher wages.

Commissioner Herman T. Stichman of the State Division of Housing announced yesterday that he expected the formation within a week of the first veterans' housing company to operate a multiple dwelling in this city under the state limited dividend housing law.

Harper has scheduled for publication on Wednesday two books by members of the Huxley family. One is "Touchstone for Ethics, 1893-1943," compiled by Julian Huxley from his own writings and those of his grandfather, T. H. Huxley.

ELLSWORTH, Me., Friday, Oct. 24 -- Most of Bar Harbor's 4,300 residents were evacuated by land and sea early today as the worst forest fire in Maine's history roared through the town, wiping out scores of homes and many business blocks.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Michigan's high-powered Wolverines, overwhelmingly triumphant in their first four games, are set for their severest test to date in the battle with Minnesota's rugged Gophers in the most important of three games Saturday involving Big Nine championship possibilities.

A Coast Guard commander who has spent twenty-four years in the development of air-sea rescue techniques took over a routine Civil Aeronautics Board crash hearing for thirty minutes yesterday afternoon to describe the disintegration of the emergency system safeguarding airways and ship lanes.

The Continental Can Company, Inc., and its subsidiaries had consolidated net earnings of $10,848,346 for the twelve months ended Sept. 30, according to a statement issued yesterday by Hans A. Eggerss, president.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Citizens Food Committee definitely refused today the petition of the National Poultry Producers Federation to abandon poultryless and eggless Thursdays. Charles Luckman, its chairman, promised, however, that the program of voluntary abstinence would not be continued "one day longer than absolutely necessary to meet international requirements."

BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- The Federal taxing program prevents accumulation of sufficient capital from private savings to maintain the nation's pre-depression rate of growth, Don G. Mitchell of New York, president of Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., told 2,000 industrialists today.

The stock market made little progress yesterday after a bulge in the steels failed to attract simlar action in other key sections. Aside from the steels the leadership was inferior to that recently experienced, with a resultant drop in interest.

NANKING, Oct. 23 -- Numerically superior Communist forces in Hopeh Province have destroyed three Government divisions at Wangtu, twenty miles south of Paoting on the broken PeipingHankow railway, it was disclosed tonight.

More than 150,000 persons, including 10,000 or more next of kin, are expected in Sheep Meadow, Central Park, Sunday afternoon at memorial services for the first war dead from Europe, due in the harbor on the transport Joseph V. Connolly.
The Board of Estimate approved yesterday the retirement application of Henry H. Curran, Associate Justice of the Court of Special Sessions, to become effective Nov. 26.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 23 -- The Nobel Prize in Medicine was awarded jointly tonight to Dr. Carl F. Cori and his wife, Dr. Gerty T. Cori of Washington University, St. Louis, and to a Buenos Aires scientist, Dr. Bernardo A. Houssay.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 23 -- Confident, perhaps overconfident, of a Republican victory in next year's Presidential election, members of the committee on convention arrangements of the Republican National Committee gathered here tonight for a meeting tomorrow and Saturday.

PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Premier Paul Ramadier made it clear today that he would urge Parliament Tuesday to grant him a renewal of authority to continue his battle against both the threat to France's economy, which he believes comes from the Communists, and the threat to the Constitution, which he believes comes from the de Gaullist movement.

The Taft-Hartley act reflects not only a reversal of the trend toward Government intervention in business, but public opinion that labor union excesses must be curbed, Dr. Leo Wolman, professor of economics, Columbia University, declared yesterday.

Berkshire Fine Spinning A quarterly dividend of 35 cents and a year-end extra of $1 on new common stock, payable Dec. 1, was voted by the Berkshire Fine Spinning Associates, Inc. This is equal to $1.05 on the old stock, which was split three for one in December.

The deadline for renewal of the contract covering 13,000 milk drivers and distribution plant workers approached yesterday with no certainty that milk deliveries to 10,000,000 persons in the metropolitan area would not stop at midnight tonight.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 23-Dr. Bernafdo A. Houssay, one of Argentina's most distinguished scientists, is well JsTiowra in tlie "United States, which, he said tonight, he last visited in April. He is a member of many international learned societies, including the American Philosophical Society.
Tailored coats and suits with soft details were presented yesterday at the Hotel Plaza in a customorder collection by Knize of 20 East Fifty-sixth Street.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- Dr. Willard L. Thorp, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, said today that the Truman Administration was carefully studying whether adoption of the Marshall plan for Europe would require reimposition of controls over the free domestic economy of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Department store sales in the week ended Oct. 18 were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following list percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

Friday, Oct. 24, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- In continued discussion of Soviet resolution against "warmongers," heard representatives of Philippines, United States, Canada, Haiti and Poland.

The New York Curb Exchange Securities Clearing Corporation will open on Nov. 3 a new section to be known as the delivery department, it was announced yesterday. It will provide for centralized delivery of securities between its member firms and banks and brokerage firms that are not members of the Curb Exchange.

Career men and bureaucrats in the State Department blocked effective American assistance to oppressed and persecuted Jews in Nazi-dominated areas of Europe for eighteen months during the war, Henry Morgenthau Jr., former Secretary of the Treasury, charged yesterday.

Several cafeterias put poultry back on the menu yesterday, but nearly all the major restaurants kept their pledge to observe poultryless and eggless Thursdays until they are canceled by the President's Citizens Food Committee.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 23 -- The touchy political nerve of Ohio, the "mother of Presidents," was jumping tonight in anticipation of the announcement tomorrow by Senator Robert A. Taft that he would seek the Republican nomination for President.
Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, indicated last night the organization is not unalterably opposed to a fare increase.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Winston Churchill charged the Labor Government in general and Defense Minister Albert V. Alexander in particular today with "gross mismanagement and incompetence" in handling Britain's fighting services.
ALFRED vs. Brooklyn College -- All that this reporter knows about Alfred is that he was an English king who drove the Danes out of England. Although that proves nothing here, one vote for Brooklyn.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 23 -- Bohumil Lauschman, Minister of Industry, a Socialist and chief of the Czechoslovak nationalized industry, told Parliament today it was impossible to establish whether the nationalized industries were working at a real profit or a loss because of the failure of the present balance which the investment itself properly included.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- It was summer-in-October today and thirty-six players -- one of the largest fields in the history of the tournament -- marked the occasion by vying for the Westchester Professional Golfers Association championship over thirty-six holes at the Knollwood Country Club.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- A plan that in effect would require the United States to pay the income taxes of its own citizens in United Nations employ was voted today by the Administrative and Budgetary Committee of the General Assembly.

The Board of Estimate postponed yesterday without discussion its decision on the request for an appropriation of $100,000, recently made by Mayor O'Dwyer's special committee in charge of plans for the city's Golden Jubilee celebration in 1948.

So far this year, strike activity in New York State is running about half the volume in the similar period of 1946, which was the all-time peak year in industrial stoppages, it was announced yesterday.

The report of the Consular Commission at Batavia on nonobservance of the Security Council's two August "cease fire" requests to the Dutch and the Republican Government in the Netherlands Indies has at last been presented to the Council. It appears to be an objective and well-thought-out report.
The first union security elections held in this area under the Taft-Hartley Law resulted yesterday in unanimous votes in favor of the union shop.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 23 -- A special train to Pakistan will take the last 5,000 Moslem evacuees from Delhi tomorrow and the camps where these unfortunate members of the minority community have lived since the September riots will be closed.

LONDON, Oct. 23 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Minister for Economic Affairs, told the House of Commons tonight that Britain's living standard must be driven down to aid the nation in her battle for economic survival.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Lawrence B. Bell, president of the Bell Aircraft Corporation, yanked a shroud from a then secret Messerschmitt plane in a Berlin underground plant in 1938, Louis A. Johnson, a former Assistant Secretary of War, said today.

Prime Minister Attlee's proposal to introduce legislation in the Commons to curb the powers of the House of Lords has stirred up a hornet's nest in Britain. Such legislation has long been on the agenda of the Labor party. What has dismayed the Government is the almost unanimous opposition of the press against pushing it through at this time.
The City College football squad was cautioned yesterday by Coach Harold J. Parker to avoid overconfidence in its game with Wagner at Staten Island tomorrow.
BOSTON, Oct. 23 (U.P.) -- The Ford Motor Company's surplus decreased $14,136,372 during 1946, according to its balance sheet filed today with the Massachusetts State Tax Commissioner.

Coincident with the welcome news of Newark's decision to sign the lease, so long under discussion with the Port of New York Authority, for the operation of Newark Airport comes the announcement of a broad plan for better air traffic allocation in the metropolitan area.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, a national civil rights organization, of 20 West Fortieth Street, New York, today filed with the United Nations formal charges of widespread discrimination against Negroes of the United States in social and economic affairs.

HISTORY, which once consisted so largely of heroic deeds and histrionic attitudes and then was rewritten in terms of taxes, tariffs and economic theories, has been having its face lifted and its glands rejuvenated for some years. Those who shrink from undiluted facts can find vast quantities of facts made more palatable by coatings of sensational melodrama in historical fiction.

Without any blare of trumpets, forty men -- bankers, lawyers, insurance men and underwriters -- will observe an anniversary on Nov. 1 by simply boarding a bus on that morning and going to their offices as usual.
The right of a public storage garage to increase private passenger car rates was challenged yesterday in a test case sponsored by the Automobile Club of New York.

ATHENS, Oct. 23 -- Premier Themistocles Sophoulis announced today that the Greek Government had been officially notified of the United States Government's decision to send to Greece United States Army liaison officers to be attached to the General Staff and army units.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y. Oct. 23 -- Thousands of children will die before the United Nations Appeal for Children can organize its world-wide collection campaign, Chester Bowles, chairman of the appeal's international advisory committee, frankly admitted here today.

John J. Scanlan Jr., 26-year-old longshoreman, was arraigned before Magistrate Joseph Glebocki in Felony Court yesterday on a charge of homicide in connection with the killing of two persons and the shooting of two others in front of a Greenwich Village tenement on Tuesday night.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Oct. 23 (AP) -- A weary but determined band of South Carolina Gamecocks staved off a nearly successful fourth-period Clemson rally to defeat the favored Tigers, 21 -- 19, before a capacity State Fair crowd of 25,000 today.

After a snort period or slipping down the price scale as a result of accumulated supplies caused by consumer resistance, meats held steady at retail this week, the City Department of Markets reported yesterday.
Instead of having the conventional fashion presentation yesterday Zoe De Salle exhibited her fall and winter styles on composition manikins, placed around her showroom, at 18 East Fifty-third Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Committee for the City's Golden Jubilee has presented a report illusrated in the papers of Oct. 12. which again, though unintentionally, calls attention to the property adjoining the United Nations site west of First Avenue. This is the area which the United Nations asked that the city donate, I believe, for its protection and possible future use.

The Market's New Bonds Continued buoyancy in the new issue of Pacific Telephone and Telegraph bonds is ascribed in trading circles to the persistence of a short interest not yet fully accommodated. One hundred million dollars in new bonds coming into the present market looked like a colossus before the bidding, but after the quick sell-out it was a different story.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 -- Blaming waterfront unrest on the Communist party, Frank P. Foisie, president of the Waterfront Employers Association of the Pacific Coast, said today that the prospect for peaceful labor relations on this coast's waterfronts was not bright.

Argentina's five-year plan of industrialization will lead to closer technical, economic and social ties with the United States Ernesto Lix Klett, Argentine distributor for several leading American companies, said here yesterday.
The sixth edition of "Fashions of the Times," the fashion production sponsored by The NEW YORK TIMES, went into final rehearsals yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today struck from the list of registered "irregular air carriers" -- those operating large airplanes on contract service -- a number which failed to comply with an order to file by Oct. 17 a statement of tariffs and other required information.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Following is the text of the speech made today by Warren R. Austin, United States representative, before the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee: Mr. President:

Differing opinions on the plight of Europe were expressed here yesterday by Representative John Taber, Republican, of New York, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, and Viscount Bruce, chairman of the World Food Council.

Industrial and business loans in New York City registered last week the fourteenth consecutive rise, setting a new record level of $4,889,000,000, the report of the New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System revealed yesterday.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- The offensive phase of Army football is about to get underway. Up to now the West Point season has been distinguished by the virulence of its defense. The order for an all-out attack, with the air arm engaging prominently in the action, is expected to be sounded when the cadets move on Columbia at Baker Field tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Gov. Earl C. Warren of California, one of the forty-five state Governors who voted unanimously for universal military training at a recent meeting in Salt Lake City, called here today for early enactment of such legislation as a bulwark of peace in the world.

ALBANY, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Thirty forest fires, including one out of control on Shawangunk Mountain near Ellenville in Ulster County, burned in New York State tonight as winds up to twenty-nine miles an hour added temporarily to the hazard.

Lawrence R. Kahn has been appointed merchandise manager of Oppenheim Collins' New York and Brooklyn main floor departments, intimate apparel and all the new children's departments through the teen-age group. He formerly was assistant general merchandise manager of Bloomingdale's.

The two-story factory building with a one-story extension at 253-257 Freeman Street, Brooklyn, has been sold by William C. Geisman to the 255 Freeman Street, Inc., for cash above a purchase money mortgage of $21,750. The building is tenanted by the Enequist Chemical Company.

A challenge from across the seas arrived with the British professional golfers yesterday on the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary to oppose the United States team for the Ryder Cup at the Portland Golf Club, Portland, Ore., on Nov. 1 and 2.

Sixty-two presidents of American, Canadian, and Hawaiian universities and colleges will be present at 2:15 P.M. today in Barnard Hall when Frank D. Fackenthal, acting president of Columbia University, will induct Millicent Carey McIntosh into office as the fourth dean of Barnard College.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Both subcommittees of the Palestine Committee of the United Nations General Assembly began their work today, but made little headway before adjournment.

Tammany Hall instructed its district captains and party workers last night to campaign in their home districts for an affirmative vote on all ten proposals up before the electorate in November. The proposals include six state constitutional amendments, three state propositions on housing funds, and the local referendum on proportional representation.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 23 -- The dollar crisis has now hit Sweden and the Swedes will have to do without United States films, automobiles, nylons and plastics and Swiss watches because of the urgent necessity of further reducing imports from the hard currency countries.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The first hint the husband-and-wife team, of biological chemists, Drs. Carl and Gerty Cori, received of their Nobel Prize award came in a telegram early today from a friend and fellow laboratory worker in Stockholm.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The political-military situation in the Kathiawar Peninsula, already a point of issue between the Governments of India and Pakistan, became more complex today with the announcement that the Dominion of India commissioner had taken over direct control of the State of Manavadar.

LONDON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A Foreign Office spokesman, commenting on a statement of the Syrian Defense Minister that 10,000 Syrian troops would engage in exercises on Palestine's frontier, said today that "Syria is well aware that while Britain remains in Palestine, we remain responsible for the maintenance of law and order there."

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 23 -- Assailing bigotry as contrary to the American tradition, Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York paid high tribute to the chaplains of all faiths serving God in the armed forces in an address before the St. Bonaventure Club of Central New York at the Hotel Syracuse here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Although their unions have refused to file non-Communist affidavits to qualify for access to the National Labor Relations Board, the NLRB general counsel will nevertheless investigate complaints by members of these unions and will prosecute employers under the Taft-Hartley Act if the complaints are sustained.

Roy Conacher, highest scoring left wing in the National Hockey League, was acquired from the Detroit Red Wings yesterday by the New York Rangers, who sent Ed Slowinski, rookie forward, to the motor city team in exchange.

With the exception of duck hunting in certain defined areas, the season on all game birds and animals in New York State will be closed for the duration of the present dry spell, and will be opened as it was closed, by proclamation issued by Governor Dewey.

The board of trustees of Hampton Institute, Hampton, Va., voted yesterday to send a committee to that institution Nov. 1 to investigate conditions that brought about a vote of "no confidence" in the administration of Dr. Ralph P. Bridgman, president since 1944.

ALBANY, Oct. 24 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and legislative leaders arranged today an allocation of $210,000 from the State Emergency Fund to assure continuation of the school lunch program during the last quarter of 1947 and to supplement Federal funds which are insufficient to meet the Federal share of the program for that period.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Nov. 4 the citizens of New York will be called upon to decide whether or not they will continue Proportional Representation as a method of election to their City Council.
Michael James Pope has been promoted to manager of Rogers Peet's store at Broadway and Thirteenth Street. He succeeds the late Theodore W. Wolff.

Mayor O'Dwyer intervened yesterday in a situation that threatened a possible halt of milk distribution in the metropolitan area over the week-end. Prompted by the expiration last midnight of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters' contracts with metropolitan milk dealers, the Mayor appointed a new citizens mediation panel of three to meet with the union and the dealers.
BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- Records of thirty-five years of cancer research were lost in the raging fire which demolished the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory in Bar Harbor last night.
In Praise of Autumn An enthusiastic, friend rushed into our office the other day, docked by our desk-side, and proceeded to sing a paean in praise of autumn.
Following is the text of President Truman's radio address last night on the special session of Congress as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange plunged to net losses of 45 to 93 points yesterday in one of the most active sessions in many months.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 24 -- Determined not to be drawn into politics, Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived here shortly after noon today for a week-end of homecoming festivities at Kansas State College, of which the general's brother, Milton S. Eisenhower, is president.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The Soviet Ambassador to the United States, Nikolai Vassilevitch Novikov, has been "relieved of his duties" by the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet, the Moscow radio announced tonight. He will be succeeded in Washington by Alexander Semyenovitch Panyushkin, formerly Ambassador to China.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- A decisive majority of the nations drawing up the plans for the United Nations Little Assembly lined up today for writing in the two-thirds rule, despite a United States warning that it might turn out to be a "crippling" provision.

VIENNA, Oct. 24 -- The Soviet commander in Austria told the Allied Council today that the Russian distribution of Austrian oil was of no concern to the Allied group. He said the matter had been settled in the Potsdam accord.

For years the medical world knew that without a sweetbread or pancreas an animal succumbs to diabetes, but it did not know until Bernardo Houssay, distinguished Argentine physiologist, came along that the removal of the anterior lobes of the pituitary gland inhibited the diabetes.
DENVER, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Colorado school children had the last laugh today -- their teachers averaged a failing grade of 67 on a test in American history.

The movie-going public, not the Roman Catholic Church, must decide the moral fitness of the motion picture version of "Forever Amber," Spyros Skouras, president of Twentieth Century-Fox, asserted yesterday in replying to the condemnation of the film by Cardinal Spellman and the National Legion of Decency.

The steady stream of propaganda emanating from Moscow has recently contained some statements which under other circumstances might be interpreted as overtures toward a new rapprochement between Russia and the rest of the world to ease the mounting tensions that now dominate the international scene.

The Corn Products Refining Company and its subsidiary sales companies had a net income of $13,092,583 in the nine months ended on Sept. 30, after all charges, including $11,127,650 provision for taxes, according to the report of Morris Sayre, president, mailed yesterday to stockholders.

President Truman's call for a special session of Congress to appropriate funds for emergency relief in western Europe received the hearty support yesterday of Senator Millard E. Tydings who declared on his arrival here on the United States liner America that, "by and large, American aid up to now has strengthened democracy in Europe and has been a bar to more police states."

How the day-dreams of a schoolboy paid off as he helped save his family's fortune was unfolded yesterday in Bronx Magistrates Court. As a result, an alleged burglar, whom 14-year-old Angelo Voyiaziakis says he saw entering the Voyiaziakis apartment while he was gazing out of his classroom, was held in $2,500 bail for the grand jury on a charge of stealing $2,650 in savings bonds belonging to Angelo's father.

The fifth non-jury show of oils and water-colors by artists living or working in Greenwich Village, has opened at the Village Art Center, 224 Waverly Place, to remain through Nov. 16, from 2 to 6 P.M. daily, and until 9 P.M. on Mondays and Thursdays.

William Reid, chairman of the Board of Transportation, indicated yesterday that the 33,000 employes of the municipal transit system, which is piling up substantial operating deficits under the 5-cent fare, stood little chance of obtaining requested pay rises under existing conditions.
Army marches on Baker Field and Navy drops anchor at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, today and crowds of 35,000 and 78,000 will fill the stands for two of football's top offering's in the East.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- Two General Confederation of Labor delegates to the conference with the Congress of Industrial Organizations in New York Oct. 28 have not been able to obtain necessary United States visas, a confederation communique charged today.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Dr. Jorge Garcia Granados, Guatemalan Ambassador to the United States, declared today that a Jewish state in Palestine is the only solution to the problem of anti-Semitism in Europe and its consequent evils.

Can the United States let children anywhere in the world starve in this year of richest harvests? Dare we, because of political controversies, let children die by default because of lack of food and life-giving milk and medicines? This is the essence of Chester Bowles' grim warning at Lake Success.

The education of students for daily living was announced yesterday as the "creed" for the coming administration of Barnard by Millicent Carey Mclntosh as she was installed as the fourth dean of the college.

The Port of New York Authority, facing airport and pier construction expenditures expected to lead to the issuance of an estimated $370,000,000 in revenue bonds over the next thirteen years, adopted a resolution yesterday to stiffen the earnings coverage under which the Authority may issue its general and refunding bonds in the future.

Irwin Shaw, screen writer, issued a statement yesterday through his counsel, Lloyd Paul Stryker, denying statements by Jack Warner of Warner Brothers Studios about Mr. Shaw which were put on the record of the Congressional committee investigating un-American activities last Monday.

A quarter of a century ago, when the "bucket shop" was as common as the bank, the Better Business Bureau of New York began the quiet battle it has waged to this day against frauds, rackets, sharp and shady business practices and the quick-witted characters who profit from them.

NANKING, Oct. 24 -- About 100 Communist groups, consisting of local administrators, political organizers and propagandists, have crossed the Lung-Hai railway from the north to establish Red bases in central China.

Edward E. Rhatigan, Welfare Commissioner since Jan. 1, 1946, resigned late yesterday afternoon, less than an hour after he was summoned to City Hall to confer with Mayor O'Dwyer and the Mayor's three-man Executive Committee on Administration.

The Disaster Relief Program set up by the Red Cross and the armed services got its first post-war test in the East yesterday. Soon after the "alert" had been received from the beleagured New Englanders, soldiers, medical men and supplies, communication units and fire-fighting equipment were dispatched from this area.

John Boyle passed Manual Training to a 6-0 triumph over Samuel J. Tilden High School before 6,000 fans at Ebbets Field yesterday. It was the fourth successive victory for the unbeaten Park Slopers and the second setback in five starts for Tilden.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 24 -- Thirty-seven members of the crew of the Richfield oil tanker Sparrows Point were rescued from life-boats after the tanker collided with the Canadian freighter Manx Fisher in heavy fog early today fifteen miles off Point Sur, near here.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- Faced with the probability of a greater demand for tickets to the Republican National Convention next June than ever before, the committee of arrangements, a subcommittee of the Republican National Committee, was primarily concerned today with allotment of space in the convention hall to delegates, alternates, press, radio, television, motion pictures and spectators, as well as hotel accommodations for visitors.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Government cost the citizens of the United States $56,873,000,000 in the fiscal year 1946, the Department of Commerce reported today. This total encompasses the general revenue of all Federal, State and local governments.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the House of Commons today that he accepted full responsibility for the United States loan agreement. "I take the blame; I take the credit," he said.

The first phase of the Government's attempt to deport Rumanian-born John Santo as a subversive alien was ended yesterday after almost six weeks of hearings. The session was held at 70 Columbus Avenue.

Losses from the worst forest fire in Maine history are estimated at $8,000,000 for houses alone and fire insurance companies in the state have had a rush of new business in the last few days as a result of the fire.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Truman is expected to ask the special session of Congress on Nov. 17 to give him specific controls over the use of scarce goods and to extend some other wartime powers to deal with the price inflation menace.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Bernard M. Baruch asserted today that the "foot-dragging and fumbling" which marked the mobilization for World War II had unnecessarily wasted thousands of lives, extra billions of dollars and months of time.

President Truman, declaring that "a period of crisis is now at hand," reminded us anew that there are now four branches of the United States Government. There is the Executive. There is Congress. There is the Judiciary. There are the people, to whom the President appealed, and whose voice is decisive.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Palestinian Government has issued a statement about the redeployment of its forces on the northern frontier and in eastern Galilee. The statement purports to allay the fears of the Jews, who had complained about the bringing of Arab troops into predominantly Jewish territory.

Store Sales Gain Put at 35% Though individual stores differed widely in their comparisons of this week's volume with a year ago, it was estimated yesterday that Brooklyn and Manhattan department store sales ran about 35 per cent.

BERLIN, Oct. 24 -- Eight members of the touring Senate Appropriations subcommittee unanimously oppose further reparations deliveries to the Soviet Union and six of the eight favor a halt in plant dismantlings for reparations, they revealed at a press conference here today. The ninth member of the group touring Europe was absent.

Officers of the Irish Army, always known as the "team to beat," arrived yesterday aboard the United States liner America for the international military jumping contests at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden Nov. 4-11. Col. Kent C. Lambert of Governors Island, representing Gen. Courtney H. Hodges and Alfred G. Tuckerman, secretary of the show, were on hand to meet the Irish.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The United Nations General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee today approved a proposal made by Egypt toward the creation of an Economic Commission of the Middle East by a vote of 44 to 0, with three abstentions.

Conrad Thibault, who sang in recital at the Town Hall last night, is a baritone of intelligence and good taste. He understands many kinds of song -- old Spanish, German, French, American -- and he sings without hokum, even where the temptation must be great to emote or to go cutely humorous.
Substantially larger earnings for the first nine months of this year, as compared with the corresponding period of 1946, were reported yesterday by three large oil companies.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Awakening to the serious political implications of their decision yesterday to ask the United States to pay an assessment that Congress might reject, delegates to the United Nations General Aassembly reversed their previous vote today.

Hampered by shifting winds and lack of water, several fires raged out of control in Southeastern New York last night while hundreds of small, stubborn fires ate through tinder-dry woodland and heavy underbrush in the metropolitan area.

On the ground that "excessive and improper use of outdoor advertising signs has become a public nuisance," the Citizens Zoning Committee announced yesterday that it would sponsor a movement for more restrictive laws, better enforcement and elimination of abuses, and removal of many such displays.

The distribution of medical and surgical supplies to those in need in Europe and Asia will be continued under the auspices of the Medical and Surgical Relief Committee, according to an announcement yesterday by Admiral William F. Halsey, USN (retired), president of the organization.

Despite theatre difficulties, the Equity Library Theatre, which has served as a showcase for actors for the last four years, anticipates a busy season. Plans have been formulated for the presentation of at least twenty productions during the next five months at the rate of a show a week.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- Seeking to notch its second Ivy League victory in as many starts, Princeton's injury-ridden football squad will face Cornell in Palmer Stadium tomorrow before a crowd of 35,000.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 24 -- Two Americans are the principal whipping boys in the Rumanian Communist press today. One is Actor Robert Taylor; the other is a newspaper man, Reuben Markham.

For the thrill of watching fire engines in action, according to the police, Manuel V. Candanedo, 21-year-old unemployed laborer, of 1486 Vyse Avenue, the Bronx, admitted that he had set four of six suspicious tenement house fires in the Westchester section of the Bronx early yesterday morning.
ROME, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Cardinal Salotti, who died here today, was prefect of the Congregation of Rites, which regulates church festivals and the offices of new saints.

Sylvester Ryan, chief assistant district attorney of the Bronx and president of the Bronx County Bar Association, is reported slated for appointment by President Truman as a Federal judge for the Southern District of New York in place of Francis G. Caffey, who is retiring at the end of this month.

This port has 4,120 working harbor craft divided into thirty-seven categories and offers a cross-section of virtually every conceivable type of floating equipment, according to a survey made by Eads Johnson, New York naval architect.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Negotiations for the settlement of a labor dispute involving the city's six daily newspapers and the 1,500 members of the Chicago Typographical Union's Local 16 today reached what the printers termed "a deadlock" at the "third and final" meeting of representatives of the two groups.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today it had found that an important reduction in the domestic use of wheat started even before the save-grain-for-Europe campaign began.

BRYCE CANYON, Utah, Oct. 24 -- A United Air Lines transport plane, on its way from Los Angeles to New York and carrying fifty-two persons, smashed against a hillside here today, scattering wreckage over a wide area and killing all of those on board.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On Oct. 1 you published a letter under the caption "Sectarian Education," which stated that "our historic American doctrine of the separation of church and state appears seriously threatened, and many of our people are much troubled."

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Supreme Court Justice Frederick G. Schmidt ruled tonight that war veteran university students living at Shanks Village in Orangetown, Rockland County, are not entitled to vote there, but he ordered election officials of the county to meet tomorrow to receive the registrations of wives and other non students living in the village.

ABSECON, N.J., Oct. 24 -- A high wind greeted the sixty-two women golfers this morning as they started the last round of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's two-day tournament over the Seaview Country Club course.

Two hundred and five Navy ships in forty-one Atlantic and Gulf ports will hold open house for visitors during the week-end in observance of Navy Day on Monday. President Truman and Governor Dewey have issued proclamations setting the day aside -- its twenty-sixth annual observance.
SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 24 -- Plans for an attack by Korean Soviet-trained forces on south Korea after the withdrawal of United States and Soviet troops were charged here today.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 24 -- Senator Robert A. Taft entered today what he termed a "wide-open" race for the Republican nomination for President in 1948.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent issue of THE TIMES, the Rev. Dr. Joseph Thorning protests against the equivalent use of the terms "Soviet Union" and "Russia." His motivation is admirable -- to avoid identifying the Russian people with the Soviet regime.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- A joint Treasury-Congress report proposed today that the tax system be changed to provide more incentive to start new business enterprises

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Prices of grains for future delivery broke the permissible limits today on the Board of Trade and closed at the bottom with wheat off 10 cents a bushel, corn and soy beans, 8 cents, and oats, 6 cents, as the result of general liquidation induced by reports that new and drastic measures would be asked of Congress by President Truman to bring down the cost of living.

First-quarter rayon gray goods allotments will show an increase up to 7 1/2 per cent on the more closely woven filament yarn numbers, it was indicated yesterday in a survey of the trade. These increases, which are considered nominal, will enable non-integrated manufacturers to obtain a nigher return without assuming the risk of the integrated operator in finishing the goods.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Led by Spec Sanders and Claude (Buddy) Young, the New York Yankees overpowered the Chicago Rockets in an All America. Football Conference game tonight, 28 to 7, before a crowd of 20,310. It was Chicago's ninth straight loss.

A $63,000,000 distribution of the stocks of two subsidiaries of the North American Company will be made to the company's common stockholders on Dec. 22, it was announced yesterday after a meeting of directors at which the distribution was voted.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- Although they blew numerous opportunities, throughout the game, the Boston College Eagles tonight pushed over a touchdown in the third period to score a 6-0 shut-out over their old rivals, the Villanova Wildcats, under the lights of Braves Field.

October's flower, the chrysanthemum, received a fitting salute yesterday when a three-day show opened at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park. Presented by the garden in cooperation with life National Chrysanthemum Society, the typical indoor display includes specimens and flower arrangements, while a short stroll across the grounds leads to the lower borders where chrysanthemums are growing.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 -- Conclusion of peace settlements with Germany, Japan and Austria is of the first importance in removing obstacles to the successful functioning of the United Nations, Dr. H.V. Evatt, Foreign Minister and Deputy Prime Minister of Australia, declared here tonight.

The big-money event of the Metropolitan Jockey Club meeting, the $75,000 added Gallant Fox Handicap, is the chief offering today at Jamaica, and its ten-horse line-up is headed by the Argentine-bred pair of Talon and Miss Grillo, who will run coupled in the betting.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Truman, Secretary of State Marshall and other Cabinet officials will spearhead a drive for the Marshall plan support at a White House conference Monday. More than a hundred business, industrial and labor leaders have been invited to attend.
For a dinner tonight that would cost $2.95 for five, the Department of Markets outlines the following menu:

Discontinuance of the consignment method of bread distribution to retail grocers, recommended to the baking industry as a grain-saving device in the present European food emergency, would actually result in loss of the grain ingredients and an ultimate financial loss to merchants, food retailers declared here yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The Soviet Government has taken the former Brazilian Ambassador in Moscow and his Embassy staff "under surveillance" and is holding them as hostages for the safety of the Soviet diplomats in Rio de Janeiro, the Moscow radio announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Nearly 3,000 out of 60,000 to 70,000 local unions have filed financial reports with the Secretary of Labor as required under the Taft-Hartley Act, it was announced today by Secretary Schwellenbach.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- President Truman's action in calling a special session of Congress to consider European aid not only was hailed with great relief by all but Communists in France but it has also spurred the efforts of Western Europe to increase self help.

Random notes. Sparse Grey Hackle, whose occasional missives tend to be rather sharp but normally quite cheerful, seems to have perched a chip on one shoulder and is waiting anxiously for someone to open hostilities. His latest note is almost belligerent.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The National Security Committee, representing some fifty recognized national organizations under the chairmanship of Owen J. Roberts, former Associate Justice, of the Supreme Court, concluded plans for militant backing of legislation to provide for universal military service at the end of a two-day session here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- An improved apparatus for determining the vapor content of a gas was one of the 300 inventions on which patents were issued this week by the United States Patent Office.

A heavy proportion of the products sold today would make more money if they sold at a lower price, Chester Bowels, former Office of Price Administration Administrator, said yesterday. He told a luncheon meeting of the American Marketing Association in the Hotel Commodore that business faces its greatest challenge in keeping prices at a "reasonable" level.

Among the passengers on the DC-6 plane that crashed in Utah yesterday were Jack Guenther, managing editor of Look Magazine; Donald Terhune, Los Angeles representative of the magazine, and Clement D. Ryan, president of Whitney's Department Store in San Diego, Calif.

Scoring in every period but the second, the Poly Prep eleven conquered Adelphi Academy, 25 -- 0, at Adelphi Field yesterday. It was the third triumph in four games for Poly and the fourth straight setback for Adelphi.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Truman said tonight that the United States must overcome "by prompt and courageous action" obstacles to our prosperity and to world peace.

Several homefurnishings chains have temporarily abandoned special order selling of living room furniture from now until Christmas and some smaller department stores are ready to follow suit, buyers reported yesterday. They explained that manufacturers' deliveries on sofas, chairs and suites ordered in stores by customers from swatches are now running from four to six weeks "at best."

The stock market canceled out yesterday all of the advantages won during the last two weeks under a succession of selling waves which produced the widest break in more than five months. Values were lowered on the average of 2 1/2 points in the industrials although the composite rate's reduction was held to 1.65 points.

Senator Taft's announcement of his candidacy for the Republican nomination to the Presidency cannot be said to have caught anybody by surprise. It was written down in all the political future books. His letter expressing willingness is marked by that quality of diffidence that pleasantly characterized his father.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- Four companies filed registration statements today with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering proposed offerings of 150,000 shares of preferred stock and more than 684,000 shares of common stock.

Oil Shares In the event that the merger of the Sunray Oil and Pacific Western Oil Companies and the Mission Corporation are concluded, there is a chance that the Tide Water Associated Oil Company may buy all or part of its shares now held by Mission and Pacific Western.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The Soviet Union, White Russia, the Ukraine and Bulgaria have refused the United Nations' invitation to the World Conference on Trade and Employment opening in Havana on Nov. 21, it was learned here today.

Savannah, Ga., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Nov. 12 on $2,500,000 of water and sewer revenue certificates bearing interest of 2 1/2 per cent, dated Aug. 1, 1947, and due Aug. 1 from 1948 to 1982.

A LOT of people are beginning to look back at the war period as the good old days. They will fix you with a beady eye and ask why humanity won't fight as hard to maintain peace as it will to win it. They speak of the spirit of courage and tenacity and unselfishness that is most prevalent in wartime, forgetting the misery and the murder that is war.
