The steady stream of trucks arriving here daily with apples -- Jonathans, Delicious, Cortlands and McIntosh -- from up-state orchards, and the freight cars from the West bringing increasingly heavy shipments of this fruit, assure plentiful supplies for National Apple Week, which starts today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- From all parts of the country, fire fighters and disaster relief workers are converging on the New England areas whence all reports received here indicated tonight that the forest fires raging therein are increasing rather than diminishing in intensity.

Anatol Kitain, pianist, was heard in a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. The program was composed of the Bach-Goedecke Prelude and Fugue in G major; Beethoven's Sonata in D major, Op. 10, No. 3; Franck's "Prelude, Choral and Fugue"; a Chopin group; Guarnieri's "Brazilian Dance"; Turina's "Contes d'Espagne"; Liszt's "Mephisto Waltz"; Debussy's "Reflets dans l'eau" and Etudes by Alkan and Scriabin.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Oct. 24 -- Only a few hundred men remained tonight in this famed summer resort of 4,300 residents. The gale-swept forest fire -- now under control here -- had destroyed about seventy-five homes, including about a dozen palatial mansions.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- A member of the House Committee on un-American Activities, Representative Richard B. Vail, Republican, of Illinois, today reproved the press and the motion-picture industry for critical expressions on the activities of the committee.

'Free Enterprise' Theme Sought A spokesman for the Advertising Council reported yesterday that determination of a central theme slogan for the "free enterprise" campaign is proving a major problem in preparing to get the program under way.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The prospect of holding next year's United Nations General Assembly session in Europe went up considerably today, it was learned, when Secretariat chiefs decided not to "oppose" the proposed shift and the United States delegation moved informally to give it full support.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. counseled his fellow-Americans yesterday never to let up in their efforts to establish peace through the United Nations, even though their attempts might, at times, seem abortive and unsuccessful.

BALBOA, C.Z., Oct. 24 -- The Association of West Coast Steamhip Companies has inquired about the transportation through the Panama Canal of commercial cargo by the Colombian naval training ship Cucuta without the payment of tolls.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 24 -- Strong support for freezing into permanent national policy the essentials of the New Deal farm program was manifested here today before the touring House Agriculture Committee in its first Midwestern field hearing.
Columbia's freshman football team, rounding into shape after starting practice only a month ago, won its first game in three starts by beating Cheshire Academy, 20 -- 0, at Baker Field yesterday.
CHICAGO, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Names of persons on the United Air Lines DC-6 transport plane which crashed today at Bryce Canyon, Utah, were announced by the airlines as follows:

There will be no rush of industrial buying by purchasing agents trying to "beat the gun" on new legislation aimed at installing allocation systems during the coming special session of Congress, purchasing spokesmen revealed here yesterday.

"John Ferguson," the St. John Ervine play, which in 1919 was the Theatre Guild's first major success, has been chosen to start the Guild's new series of television production over WNBT. It will be presented from 8:30 to 9:30 P.M. on Sunday, Nov. 9.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Georgetown's football team had what it took tonight to beat New York University, 25-0, before 9,564 spectators in Griffith Stadium. It was the thirteenth meeting of the universities.

Army's four-year string of thirty-two games without a defeat -- and the inviolate goal-line of the 1947 cadet eleven -- will be under heavy fire today. Columbia's fast-striking forces are set for an all-out effort to find chinks in the armor of the invincible Black Knights.

Saturday, Oct. 25, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Continued general debate on Soviet resolution against "war mongering" and heard representatives of Turkey, India, the Ukraine, Dominican Republic, Guatemala, Costa Rica, New Zealand, the Netherlands, Yugoslavia, Cuba, Greece, Venezuela, Sweden, Egypt, China, Panama, France, White Russia and Soviet Union.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- The twenty-fourth meeting of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association opened today with good dogs, good cover, good birds and good guns, but with scenting conditions spoiled by warm weather and dryness, which caused a ban on smoking.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Oct. 24 -- Six hundred men, including four companies of the 104th Regiment, Third Battalion, National Guard, with Col. Marshall O. Potter of Adams in command, were fighting hard tonight to keep the October Mountain state forest fire out of the Pittsfield watershed.
WARSAW, Oct. 23 -- Officials of the Polish Coal Board said today that the Soviet percentage of this country's coal exports would decrease from 40 per cent this year to 26 per cent in 1948.

LONDON, Oct. 24 -- Brick, cement and tobacco shares were marked down today in the stock markets here following Sir Stafford Cripps' statement on restrictions on building and cessation of purchases of United States tobacco. However, holders declined to sell and prices improved, tobaccos rallying well above their lowest marks.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The replacement here of Nikolai V. Novikov by Alexander S. Panyushkin as Soviet Ambassador will be watched particularly for any significant changes it may hold for Russian policies and tactics.

New York's vast post - war construction program involving $1,300,000,000, and including many improvements that are imperative now, still is "just a dream" largely because the Federal Government and the state have "let the city down" on expected financial aid, Newbold Morris, member of the City Planning Commission and former president of the City Council, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Government is considering underwriting British purchases of American tobacco and buying American tobacco for use in German factories, Representative Cooley, Democrat, of North Carolina, said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 24 -- George Montgomery, who obtained a release from his contract with Twentieth Century-Fox in September, has been signed by Benedict Bogeaus to play opposite Dorothy Lamour in "Lulu Belle," a film which Columbia will release.
LEBANON, Pa., Oct. 24 -- Striking for four touchdowns, the Flying Dutchmen of Lebanon Valley College turned back Hofstra tonight, 27 to 7.
LONDON, Oct. 24 -- The Cunard White Star liner Mauretania will be taken from the transatlantic run next January to March to make dollar-only Caribbean cruises from New York.

Deans, administrative heads and representatives of faculty organizations at the four city colleges gave almost unanimous testimony yesterday in opposition to the proposed Schultz amendment to the by-laws of the Board of Higher Education, which would bar subversive groups from municipal college campuses.

Just as the marooned Ben Gunn dreamed of a bit of toasted cheese, so the people of foreign lands must have dreamed of American cigarettes during their years of occupation. Wherever the armies went American cigarettes were among the first things about which the people spoke.

LAKE SUCCESS, Oct. 24 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt appealed today for increased freedom of the press, rather than punishment of alleged warmongers, but Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, brought his attack on the American press to a climax with an assertion that the refusal of the United States to take action was "encouraging" propaganda for war.

PARIS, Oct. 24 -- While party groups deliberated regarding their attitude toward the revised Ramadier Government, Communist leaders today denounced the Premier for "preparing the way for de Gaulle." The Communists said they would resist Paul Ramadier "on all fronts" if a "trial of force" should come.

BOSTON, Oct. 24 -- Sheets of fire, like those which destroyed much of Maine's Bar Harbor, were racing tonight through the tinder-dry treetops toward many New England towns. Some places were evacuated as the toll of dead mounted and the damage rose.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 24 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, said today that he wondered how THE NEW YORK TIMES had "dared" to print the whole text of his speech to the United Nations General Assembly on Sept. 18.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 24 -- Striving for its fourth straight victory, undefeated, Pennsylvania meets Navy's improved team on Franklin Field tomorrow before a capacity crowd of 78,000, including the midshipmen from the Naval Academy.

Hosiery manufacturers will use very little of available productive capacity on full-fashioned silk stockings for the balance of the year, according to trade sources yesterday. Capacity made idle by the nylon yarn shortage, it was indicated, will be allowed to remain idle, owing to consumer apathy toward silk.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 -- The vanguard of Dartmouth's home-town following from Hanover, N.H., swept into town today to start a two-day week-end that will be climaxed by the fifty-first football game between the Indians and Harvard at the stadium tomorrow.

World Order Day will be observed tomorrow by Protestant churches of the country. Tomorrow was chosen because it is the Sunday nearest Oct. 24, the anniversary of the founding of the United Nations. The step was taken in anticipation of the setting aside of Oct. 24 as United Nations Day. A resolution asking this action is before the United Nations General Assembly and its adoption is expected this season.

DETROIT, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Getting away fast on three first-half touchdown gallops by Halfback Joe Wright, the University of Detroit squared its season football record at three victories and three losses by beating Duquesne, 38 to 6, before 17,547 fans tonight.
The Mayor's Committee and military men staged on Sheep Meadow in Central Park yesterday a rehearsal of details of the memorial service to be held there at 3 P.M. tomorrow for returned war dead.

JUST half a century ago the huge new granite building of the Library of Congress -- its exterior a gray monochrome, but its interior bright with marble, bronze and colorful murals -- threw open its doors to students. Monday, Nov. 1, 1897 (so David C. Mearns, able historian of the Library, tells us), was rainy.

A FEW DAYS ago New Yorkers experienced a couple of days and nights of thick fog (f.4 or f.5, the worst on the fog scale). Ferry passengers grumbled, air travelers fretted and motorists got cricks in the neck leaning out the window in an attempt to see. But, as any State-of-Mainer could tell them, New Yorkers don't know what fog is.

High prices not only are making it more difficult for millions of families to make ends meet but, directly or indirectly; are contributing to marital tensions, separation, divorce and the insecurity of children, the Family Service Association of America reported yesterday.

Lafayette made it three in a row by subduing Erasmus Hall, 19 -- 0, and Brooklyn Tech chalked up its fifth straight at the expense of James Madison, 33 -- 12, in a schoolboy football double-header before 10,000 at Ebbets Field yesterday.

A five-month study of higher education has been undertaken by Dr. Paul Klapper, on leave of absence as president of Queens College, New York. Aided by a grant from the Carnegie Corporation, the study will seek to determine what changes in academic and administrative practices have been brought about by present-day conditions.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 25 -- When the great Netherland liner Nieuw Amsterdam sails for New York from Rotterdam Wednesday she will be testimony that the Netherlands still possesses the resources and energy to accomplish a task of such magnitude.

With annual sales now topping $2,000,000,000 and limited only by scarcities of pig iron and scrap, larger imports of Swedish iron and European scrap are being weighed as emergency measures to enable American gray iron foundries to obtain raw materials needed to fulfill objectives of long-range plans, spokesmen disclosed here yesterday.

The Holland America Line flagship Nieuw Amsterdam will arrive here on her first post-war trip after reconditioning Nov. 5, with more than $500,000 in essential operating equipment aboard which was purchased in this country, the company announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Sales of home appliances through lumber and building materials companies have expanded rapidly since the end of the war and may reach a volume equal to half of the major appliance business, a spokesman for the building trades revealed today.

THE centennial exhibition of paintings by Albert Pinkham Ryder at the Whitney Museum is in its own right an outstanding art event. Beyond that, it is on many counts a most provocative exhibition, for it establishes Ryder as a pioneer in one of the main streams of current American painting -- expressionism.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft declared today that he might go along with a limited aid-to-Europe plan, but he expressed strong doubts about any permanent multi-billion-dollar arrangement.

Hereabout, in the gullible Twenties, a latent discontent had given encouragement to the so-called "modern" art, simply because it was in revolt against whatever powers that were then running a rather smug esthetic set-up.

Those who have traveled the upcountry areas of New England, New York, New Jersey or Pennsylvania during the past few days will long remember the ominous and terrible beauty of what they saw -- the swiftly fading colors of the forested hillsides, like ancient Persian carpets; the dust and smoke folded in among the mountains; the furious dance of leaves along the roads; the sense of halting and expectation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- The Soviet Union renewed today its detailed attacks on the "monopolistic" United States press. The Soviet delegate disputed the contention of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt that most newspapers in the United States are independent.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Penn State's powerful football team remained among the unbeaten today after turning back a rugged West Virginia eleven, 21 -- 14, for its fifth straight victory.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Dr. Ales Bebler, Yugoslav representative, declared today in the debate before the United Nations Political and Security Committee that THE NEW YORK TIMES had distorted his statement of yesterday, "and accordingly the greatest United States newspaper is not reliable."

LISBON, Portugal, Oct. 25 -- United States Admiral R.L. Conolly watched this morning a military parade by the side of President Oscar de Fragoso Carmona, Premier Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, members of the Portuguese Cabinet, Sir Frank Simpson, vice chief of the British Imperial Staff, and other foreign guests.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 25 -- The exchange of minority populations in the Punjab, with inclusion of relatively small numbers of evacuees from other Provinces, will approach 10,000,000 persons, it is estimated in authoritative quarters here.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25 -- Within a matter of days all Soviet diplomatic personnel will be out of Brazil and Chile. The Soviet Ambassador to Argentina, Mikhail Grigoreivitch Serguiev, is going home on leave "soon."

THE Schapira Coffee Company sells tea, too, its newest product being a tea sampler, which it is reviving after a wartime absence. This edition is an improvement over the first, presenting the contents in a more practical and attractive manner.

BRYCE CANYON, Utah, Oct. 25 -- Piecing together the charred, broken remnants of the DC-6 airliner that carried fifty-two persons to flaming death was undertaken today by Federal and company investigators seeking the cause of a fire that started in the plane's baggage compartment.

THE late Alfred Maurer, having worked with Chase and having won a first prize at Carnegie in 1901, suddenly shot off to France for more than a decade and came back a confirmed modernist. In many respects his development is analogous to that of Picasso and some of his work -- quite independent of the prodigious Pablo -- resembles some of the disquieting examples of Picasso's later years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Eric Johnston, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, called on Congress today "to overhaul its procedure in committee investigations" in which the "precious heritages" of democracy, protections and safeguards for the individual "are denied or shortcircuited."
To the Music Editor: Last week, while in New York, I attended a performance of "Eugene Onegin" by Tchaikovsky in the City Center.

BOSTON, Oct. 25 -- Even as plans for rehabilitating wide fireravaged areas of New England were being pushed today, freshly rising winds spurred thousands of weary men to new efforts against stubborn flames which sprang from smoldering embers or started along new fronts.

IT is a matter of some significance to observers of contemporary religious thought that the revival of interest in the writings of the early Church Fathers, a revival associated by many with the activities of Pusey.

WITH half a dozen hits already piled up in the space of a single month -- something of a record -- Broadway has had good reason to look upon this fading October with considerable favor. Still, there remains much concern for the theatre in various quarters.

THE ubiquitous Picasso is represented again this week, on this occasion by lithographs of the last two years, at the Buchholz Gallery. If there are still deluded people who think that he cannot draw, let them go to this show and be silenced.

MADISON, Wis., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Earl (Jug) Girard passed for two touchdowns and raced 63 yards for another today to lead Wisconsin to a 35 to 12 victory over its neighborhood rival, Marquette, at Camp Randall Stadium.

When two Germans, Hahn and Strassmann, in December, 1938, split the uranium atom with neutrons and released an enormous amount of energy, physicists all over the world realized the implications. Here was a discovery that made it possible to produce a weapon of terrifying power, with Europe on the brink of a war into which the United States would probably be drawn.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Against the maze of plans and counterplans which characterize the Western World's attitude toward Germany, and especially the conduct of the United States from the "Green Pasture" plan and JCS 1067 to the "new level of industry," Mr. Morgenstern's remarks in THE TIMES on Oct. 19 appear as a ray of hope.

To the Drama Editor: AS one who was raised with a reverence for those talented people who express themselves in playwriting, I was shocked to read your Oct. 12 article by the authors of "The Heiress." In this piece they blame all of the misfortunes of their prior production of this play on the producer and director.

WHILE the big show of moviedom hyperbole was being put on in Washington last week before the House Un-American Activities Committee by a few of Hollywood's more excitable folks, some pretty good sideshow competition was offered right here on Broadway.

DR. JOHN BAIN SUTHERLAND, a rugged fundamentalist who glories in the bloodand-thunder aspects of football, will bring his case-hardened Steelers of Pittsburgh into the Polo Grounds today. Perhaps the good doctor arrives a week too late. Last Sunday his battlescarred veterans undoubtedly would have trampled all over the helpless, hopeless and ineffective Giants.

Three Russian-operated lendlease ships that the Soviet Government has refused to return to this country have entered United States tramp trades, offering cut rates in an already demoralized freight market, it was reported yesterday.

Marion Bauer, American composer, teacher and writer on music, who has been represented on many chamber music programs, had her first work played by a major symphony orchestra last night when Leopold Stokowski conducted her "Sun Splendor" with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall.

COMMEMORATING both the opening of "Freedom Road" and the special observance of a Thanksgiving Day in memory of Gen. George S. Patton's liberation of Luxembourg from Nazi occupation, Luxembourg has released four stamps honoring the American Army general.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Roy Samuel Hopkins, designing engineer of the Eastman Kodak Company who held seventy-eight patents, eighteen of them in Canada, the remainder in this country, died in his home here last night after a long illness at the age of 66.

ANY past age is apt to seem tranquil from the spectacularly uneasy vantage point of today. We are inclined to feel that we are sitting in the waiting room of chaos and right up near the head of the line. To reverse a popular saying, no one else ever had it so bad.
Howard Cullman, backer of Broadway plays, called yesterday for the construction of more comfortable theatres and also suggested that bars be established in the existing theatres.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- Los Angeles is launching a comprehensive, campaign to regain, literally, its much-touted place in the sun.

The House Committee to Investigate Un-American Activities is unconstitutional in its set-up and conduct, and represents a first step to a complete blackout of freedom of expression in this country, Robert W. Kenny, former Attorney General of California, charged yesterday.

AMHERST, Mass., Oct. 25 -- The Amherst eleven bowed at Pratt Field today, 20 -- 0, as Weslyan's powerful line and speedy backs showed early superiority. After losing the ball on a fumble on their first scrimmage play, the winners recovered four plays later to surge 79 yards to a touchdown.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Plants with capacity for producing more than 95 per cent of the country's whisky and industrial alcohol are closing at midnight tonight for sixty days. Industry officials generally predict no shortages or liquor price rises, citing large stocks on hand.

WASHINGTON. ALL a labor conciliator has to know is: how labor feels; how management feels; what the law of the land is; how human nature operates. If this seems an exacting set of qualifications it may be said at once that they are presented in impressive array in the person of Cyrus P. Ching, who recently became the nation's No. 1 conciliator.

WARSAW, Oct. 25 -- An attempt to form a Left-Wing Socialist international that would cooperate with the recently established Communist Information Bureau is in the making, on the initiative of the Polish Socialist party.

WARSAW, Poland, Oct. 25 -- Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, leader of the opposition Polish Peasant party, "disappeared" from Warsaw several days ago and has fled the country, it was officially announced tonight.

The housing outlook for 1948 will be discussed at a home builders' conference to be held on Nov. 17 at the Hotel Commodore by the Home Builders Council of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The council, of which Henry J. Shaheen is the chairman, consists of the New Jersey Home Builders Association, the Long Island Home Builders Institute, the Home Builders Association of Northern New Jersey and the Home Builders Association of Westchester.
LONDON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- European royalty has an important rendezvous in London for the wedding of Princess Elizabeth, Nov. 20.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 25 -- Gov. James L. McConaughy announced today that he would call a special session of the General Assembly in February to make "desirable changes" in the new 3 per cent sales and use tax law. The Governor admitted that the yield for the first quarter, which is still being counted, would exceed the State's actual needs.

WITH a theme of "Perspectives in Medicine," the 1947-48 series of the New York Academy of Medicine "Lectures to the Laity" again will be broadcast by WNYC. The opening lecture is scheduled for Thursday, when the speaker will be Lewis L. Strauss, trustee of the Institute for Advanced Study at Princeton and member of the United States Atomic Energy Commission.

DETROIT -- In opening its packet of post-war surprises with the 1948 models, the automotive industry is revealing trends to greater engine power, increased visibility, extension of automatic transmission, and lower and wider body styling.

Councilman Michael J. Quill demanded yesterday the removal of Robert Moses as City Coordinator of Construction, charging that Mr. Moses was the "restraining influence at City Hall that is holding up low-cost housing."

The largest cities of the nation are feeling the pinch of the housing shortage most keenly and every major center of population is experiencing a scarcity of certain key materials needed for residential construction work.

JACKSON, Miss., Oct. 25 -- The six Democratic candidates for the Senatorial seat of the late Theodore G. Bilbo are preparing to enter their final week of campaigning with every indication that the contest is still wide open.

LONDON, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- President and Mrs. Truman's wedding gift to Princess Elizabeth, was received at Buckingham Palace today -- a crystal vase of Steuben, glass with the centerpiece of its fine engraving depicting a merrygo-round at a country fair.
New York and vicinity escaped a milk strike yesterday but milk prices will be 1 cent a quart higher tomorrow as a result.

ALTHOUGH the 1947-48 winter cruise season will offer neither the variety nor the number of cruise possibilities provided by pre-war years, the cruise Industry nevertheless is coming back rapidly. Certainly it offers more opportunity this year than at any time since the lush days before 1939.

WHETHER it be a matter for cheers or complaints, the taxicab industry began in New York forty years ago this month. Harry N. Allen got angry at the driver of a horsedrawn hansom cab because he dared to charge $5 for a haul of three-quarters of a mile, and thus it all started.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 25 -- Rea estate men here are watching with keen interest the development of plans for a new all-Negro town of more than 2,000 families four miles north of Louisville on the Indiana side of the Ohio River.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The conquest of the Far North in a new dimension -- its turbulent and frigid air -- was claimed last week by the United States Air Force.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- The Soviet Union's "anti-warmongering" resolution lost a key parliamentary battle tonight and was headed for certain defeat Monday. By a vote of 29 to 12, the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly rejected a Soviet-supported move by Venezuela to send the Soviet resolution and three milder anti-war proposals from Canada, France and Australia to a subcommittee for study and conciliation.
AMES, Iowa, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Missouri's big and fast Tigers defeated Iowa State by 26 -- 7 today for their second straight Big Six Conference football victory.

ALTHOUGH Mr. Kamenka has practiced architecture in this country as well as in London and on the Continent, he does not confine himself in his new book to technical discussion of housing design and planning. He takes up building regulations, tenant services in multi-family structures here and abroad, population trends, and the relative merits of apartments and private homes.

PEARL HARBOR in 1941 and a refugee ship on the submarineinfested Pacific make up the exciting background of this novel by Pearl Frye. The author, who is already well known as an artist, was in Hawaii at the time of Pearl Harbor and blocks in her background with complete authenticity.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 25 -- Five Jews, believed to be Haganah members who "disappeared" on Tuesday while out for a walk along the northern Palestine frontier, are in the hands of Lebanese authorities, it was disclosed tonight. All were said to be in possession of arms.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- More than four hundred persons attended the annual Tuxedo Autumn Ball tonight in the Tuxedo Club. Eight local debutantes were the honored guests at the ball and their mothers made up the ball committee.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I can make no claim to being an authority on China. Ten months as a child-welfare consultant in Shanghai, Nanking, Canton and Peiping no more qualifies me than does the forty-fiveminute interview which Representative Cole had with the Generalissimo qualify him to speak authoritatively on the desirability of military aid to China.

WHEN, greatly to his surprise and somewhat against his will, Harry Truman was catapulted into the Presidency in April 1945, political analysts ransacked his record in mad search for cues to his future actions.

As the cost of living increased during the first nine months of this year, the demand for improved wages and hours continued to be the most important cause of strikes in New York State, it was shown yesterday on the basis of statistics compiled by the State Board of Mediation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- For every dollar he puts into construction costs today's home-builder gets only 75 cents worth of house, according to Representative Ralph W. Gwinn of New York, chairman of the House Labor Committee's special subcommittee on housing.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 25 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower warned here today that "unless we are impelled by the neighborly spirit that moves men to share their lot, however meager, with those in need, we shall not salvage our civilization from the ruin of war."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The National Park Service is acquiring, near Towson, Md., one of the finest Georgian mansions in the United States through a "generous private gift" to the nation.

THE four women and a man who have come to watch their family belongings sold at auction this particular Friday noon seem ordinary enough. There is nothing in their appearance to mark them off from hundreds of other families in hundreds of other novels about upper-middle-class life.

BOSTON, Oct. 25 -- In an atmosphere that carried no chill and before a crowd of 35,000 the Big Green team from Hanover emerged from its fifty-first meeting with Harvard with a 14-13 triumph at Harvard Stadium today. And coach Tuss McLaughry doubtless was shaking the hand of big Dale Armstrong tonight.

HONOLULU, Oct. 25 -- Four Honolulu district magistrates who handle the city's police cases closed their courts Wednesday on the ground that there were no authorized public prosecutors to conduct cases.

PRINCETON -- Telephone Lectures A novel idea in education has been introduced by a professor at Princeton University who has invited the nation's leading political figures to address political classes over loudspeaker attachments to long-distance telephone trunk lines.
NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Tulane's thrice-defeated Green Wave found somebody it could beat today and beat 'em badly, winning 40 to 0, from the impotent Auburn Plainsmen before 30,000 spectators.

MEXICO CITY -- The Mexican Government, even more than this country's hotel men and others directly interested in tourist business, is looking forward eagerly to the coming winter season and the expected flood of American tourists.

PEARL HARBOR, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Commodore George A. Seitz, military governor of the Marshall Islands and wartime commandant of the aircraft carrier Bunker Hill, died in the Naval Hospital here last night of a heart ailment, the Navy announced today.

MONTREAL, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins met their first defeat of the National Hockey League season tonight as they were whitewashed by the Montreal Canadiens, 5 to 0. Goalie Bill Dunham recorded his first shut-out of the season before a paid attendance of 10,835.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Oct. 25 -- The myth of Michigan was exploded today by the Golden Gophers of Minnesota. They outplayed the Wolverines and but for a series of bad breaks could have come up with the greatest reversal of the season instead of going down to a heart-breaking 13-to-6 defeat before more than 85,000 fans at the Ann Arbor homecoming.

HERE is a well-written first novel that will appeal to many different reading tastes. Some will like it because its expertly contrived story deals with real people in real situations. Others will applaud it for its nostalgic picture of the twittering Twenties, and for its solid recreation of the life of a newspaper man and the world of the theatre.

When considering the problems of handicapped children, there is a natural inclination to think only of children who have visible disabilities. The problems of the child with a withered arm, an artificial leg or a deformed spine, are apparent.

THE annual Long Island Fall Flower Show will be held at the estate of Mrs. Walter Jennings in Cold Spring Harbor his Friday through Tuesday. Exhibits from, near-by estates, about sixty garden clubs and individual entrants make this Long Island's largest annual show.

Twenty-one months ago the United Nations first considered the question of refugees. Ten months ago the General Assembly approved a constitution for an International Refugee Organization which recognized "that genuine refugees and displaced persons constitute an urgent problem which is international in scope; [that they] should be assisted * * * either to return to their countries of nationality or * * * find new homes elsewhere."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 --The United States Atomic Energy Commission, outlining today its information policy, stated that it would restrict any data having a destructive or warlike potentiality but foster disclosure of data benefiting general public and scientific understanding.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN some college kids get together and decide to put on a play, it's hardly news. But when, two years later, they're still at it, operating one of the most unusual theatrical projects in the country with a degree of commercial success, it seems worthy of passing note.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Charles de Gaulle contests the legitimacy of the Ramadier Cabinet and questions its ability to govern in the troublesome weeks that he believes are coming, it was said tonight by close associates of the former President. They had just been in consultation with him.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- A Holy Cross eleven which had sputtered all fall was finally ignited in Archbold Stadium today and easily rolled over an undermanned Syracuse team, 26 -- 0, before 20,000 fans.

THE Jersey City Philharmonic, going into its ninth year under its founder, J. Randolph Jones, will play twice as many concerts this season as last. In the past it has given five concerts-three for adults and two free ones for children, paid for by the city.
City College's football squad evened its season's record with a 12-6 victory over Wagner before 3,500 spectators at the Staten Islanders' Grymes Hill gridiron yesterday.

THOMAS DEWAR WELDON in his book writes about political theory as "a study in political conflicts." He believes that political theories are closely related to actual States, and that the most important truth about the world of politics is that there are genuine differences about political principles which the important nations exemplify.

Columbia 21, Army 20! A typographical error? No -- a thousand times no -- and the 35,000 fans at Baker Field yesterday will attest to the authenticity of Columbia's greatest gridiron achievement: a totally unexpected victory that overshadowed even the magnificent Rose Bowl conquest of Jan. 1, 1934, when the Lions beat Stanford.

TORONTO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Exploding for four goals in the second period, the Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the tail-end Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game here tonight, 5 to 1. The victory, before a paid attendance of 13,493, enabled the Leafs to climb into a first-place tie with Detroit.

De Gaulle Comes Back For most of his life Gen. Charles de Gaulle, 57, a cold, ascetic man, has been crusading for various causes. Before World War II he was a prophet -- without honor in his own country -- of mechanized warfare. After France's defeat the tall (6' 4") General led the Fighting French and, more than four years later returned in triumph to Paris.

AMONG the different kinds of flowers called "forget-menots" are a few adapted to a variety or uses in the garden. Setting out plants or starting seeds of some of these in the fall is practicable for even the beginning gardener, because they are easy to grow.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 25 -- A movement of formidable proportions has sprung up all the way along the northern tier of Plains and Mountain States advocating the admission of displaced persons from Europe to make up for farmers and agricultural workers who have migrated from the region during the past decade.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 25 -- After a week that saw large scale special sales in most major stores, department store dollar volume slipped again in the week ended Oct. 18. The result was that the dollar volume for the four weeks period ending that date was only 4 per cent ahead of the same period last year.

Leston W. Cloak, president of the American Inboard Association and a New York veteran of three decades of speed-boat piloting, will leave by car and trailer Wednesday to join on the Rio Grande other inboard and outboard drivers headed for the two Mexican international regattas next month.

TO render an old axiom specific, hell hath no fury like Judith Anderson as Medea. For Medea is a woman who has been spurned, and Miss Anderson, always a superb actress, is now crowning her career with an inspired performance of rage and revenge.
ABOUT 2000 B.C. Indian armies used a device that threw a flame against the foe.

As business leaders studied President Truman's call for quick action by Congress to end inflation, cut prices and feed Europe, a section of the meat industry declared yesterday for vigorous measures to achieve the President's objective.

FRIENDS of Washington Square -- including Bishop William T. Manning, who now resides in that vicinity, and Howard Lindsay, of "Life with Father" -- are protesting because New York University, which has had its rightful place on the east side of the Square since the early Thirties of the Nineteenth Century -- proposes to take over for its Law School the south side as well, where many people now have their modest homes.

ROME, Oct. 25 -- The decrease in wholesale prices, which began to manifest itself in northern Italy about a week ago, has caused some retail prices to drop also. It is calculated that the cost of living for the middle-class family in Milan is about 3 per cent lower today than it was a week ago.

During the first half of 1947 corporate profits reached an all-time high. Corporate profits before taxes were at the annual rate of $28.2 billion; after taxes the total was $17 billion. According to the Department of Commerce, these totals reflected, in part, the inventory profits which attended the rising price level.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- For the first time in the twentyfour-year history of the oldest spaniel field trial meeting in America, that of the English Springer Spaniel Field Trial Association, the event failed to finish today.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 25--Rutgers showed too much for Lehigh today. The Scarlet warriers from the banks of the Raritan had things their own way as they ran through to a 46 -- 13 triumph over the Engineers before a crowd of 12,000 fans.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 25 -- As part of the celebration marking the eighty-ninth anniversary of the birth of Theodore Roosevelt, the Town Board of Oyster Bay conducted formal ceremonies this afternoon in the Theodore Roosevelt Memorial Park.

IN the days when Victor Herbert was one of the shining lights of the musical theatre along Broadway -- it was Broadway farther south, then -- no one held it against a composer that he belonged to the long-haired set. Herbert was a concert 'cellist, a symphonic conductor and a composer of what for want of a better phrase might be called "art music" or "serious music."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- While the Truman Administration awaited a report from the Harriman nonpartisan committee of nineteen that is expected to cite a need for domestic economic controls in connection with continuing foreign aid, the Republican Congressional leadership today called a session for Nov. 14 to act on its own program for combating high prices and inflation.

NOSTALGIA has become an almost obsessive emotion of our time, and no wonder. In a world whose present is marked by universal uneasiness, it is agreeable to look back on those days when, not more than half a century ago, the mood of most people, at least of those in the comfortable classes, was one of serene security.

WHILE this narrative of the ministry of Hilary Laurens in a fashionable city church makes a warm, attractive story it also assumes a certain importance by reason of its subjectmatter and also by reason of the literary competence of its author.

THIS book, so notes the title page, describes the work of "A Negro Painter in America," but apart from this modest statement and two family photographs there is nothing throughout the sympathetic presentation to accentuate his racial origin.

THOUGH the greatest emphasis for earliest spring flowers is placed on bulbs, several perennials are worthy of consideration for added color from, late March through April. Their varied forms can be used to good advantage in flower borders, beneath shrub plantings, as edges for walks or drives, or as specimens near doorways.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Oct. 25 -- Alert Purdue never made a mistake today and knocked down an Illinois football machine that had gone ten games without defeat, 14 to 7, before an alumni-packed crowd of 42,000 home-coming fans.

EVANSTON, Ill., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Indiana's Bob Young ironically "pitched" both touchdowns as Northwestern upset the Hoosiers, 7 to 6, for the Wildcats' first Big Nine victory in three starts, before 42,000 homecoming fans at Dyche Stadium today.

BERNARD DE VOTO has aptly characterized 1846 as "The Year of Decision," when the United States first assumed truly national stature. Momentous decisions were made by humble folk as well as by Polk and his vacillating Cabinet in that year, when Oregon and California were becoming household words and one of the greatest mass migrations in human history was getting under way.

ALFRED, N.Y., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Alfred University Saxons, paced by Paul Curran's dead-eye passes and a fine all-round running game, took an early lead and fought off a last-quarter attack to defeat the Brooklyn College eleven tonight, 20 -- 19, for their third victory in five starts.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 24 (Delayed) -- The board of directors of Ankara University has voted to refer to the National Assembly for an interpretation a ruling that may bar five professors from teaching in Turkey.

Hollywood, D.C. The House Committee on Un-American Activities "is authorized to make * * * investigations of the extent, character and objects of Un-American propaganda activities in the "United States * * * and shall report to the House the results of any such investigation, together with such recommendations as it deems advisable."

FOR THIS WEEK: Mulch between rows of strawberries, and other bush fruits such as raspberries and currants. If manure is used, take care that it does not get into the crowns of strawberry plants. . . . Cut down the tops of asparagus and mulch the bed with rotted manure! . . . Bring indoors a quantity of soil, compost and a little sand for winter use.
SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Federal Government accused a Wilkes-Barre, Pa., corporation today of fleecing prospective home owners, mostly returned war veterans, out of about $156,000.

THIS country has, in its native literary heritage, three important manifestoes -- three bugle calls to the American writer. The first and the greatest was Emerson's address. "The American Scholar," which he delivered before the Phi Beta Kappa Society in Cambridge, Mass., on Aug. 31. 1837.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 25 -- The National Labor Relations Board's first hearing into the twin charges of secondary boycotting and picketing of an establishment where there is no labor dispute between management and employes in violation of the Taft-Hartley law was completed today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- A House Armed Services Committee declared today after a foreign tour that it was "imperative that the United States be strong on land, sea and air." The group, headed by Representative Dewey Short, Republican, of Missouri, said "it would be supreme folly for our nation to reduce its armed forces at this critical moment in world history."

A series of forum luncheon meetings to provide a picture of the community's needs in the medical and welfare fields will be held on behalf of the thirtieth annual campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York, Mrs. Herbert L. Carlebach, chairman of the Women's Division, announced yesterday.

The principle of law that a transaction conducted with a view to effecting an income tax saving must have "a business purpose," first stated by the United State, Supreme Court in Gregory v. Helvering (293 U.S. 466), has been used and abused.

LEXINGTON, Va., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Washington and Lee's superior manpower showed in the second half here today as the Generals roared to a 32-0 triumph over Davidson for their third straight Southern Conference victory before a homecoming crowd of 6,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The voluntary food conservation drive is now considered by those directing it to be fairly under way at last. With the inevitable preliminary fumblings out of the way, a grass-roots form of campaign has been launched to rally public opinion behind the effort.

DETROIT, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- The automobile Industry expects its 1948 production of cars and trucks to equal the all-time high year of 1929 when more than 5,350,000 units" were made. However, the expectations may be tempered by the labor situation, the cost of living and the available supply of sheet steel.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 25 -- A dazzling exhibition of passing by an unheralded substitute quarterback named Lynn Dorset carried Cornell from a two-touchdown deficit to a thrilling 28-21 triumph over Princeton today.
The city will honor today the first war dead from Europe, due to reach Pier 61 at West Twentyfirst Street on the transport Joseph V. Connolly at 11 A.M.

Fear of an involuntary curtailment of its current high-level production rate within the next two months disturbed the domestic steel industry last week as shortages of materials increased and inflated costs continued to eat into profit margins.
KINGS POINT, L.I., Oct. 25 -- Taking full advantage of the few scoring opportunities presented to them, Fordham's football forces fasted victory for the first time in eleven games this afternoon.

The loss of one man -- Frankie Filchock -- toppled the New York Giants from their lofty perch of a year ago. Today at the Polo Grounds, against the Pittsburgh Steelers, evidence will be presented that may indicate whether one man -- Paul Governali -- can lift them to the heights again.

HOLLYWOOD. HOLLYWOOD'S response to the beginning of the investigation of the film industry by the House Committee on Un-American Activities in Washington last week was the inevitable bewilderment of a group divided against itself.

MALVERN, Pa., Oct. 25 -- Coming from behind in the last quartermile, Tourist Index, owned by Allison Stern of New York, today won the two-and-a-half mile brush race for the Fairy Hill Challenge Cup at the Radnor Hunt Club's first fall meeting over a course laid out in a natural amphitheater on the club's grounds.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Electrifying 64,197 fans with a spectacular 86-yard pass play that set the stage for the winning touchdown, Southern Methodist University's Mustangs defeated hardcharging UCLA today, 7 to 0, and remained on the nation's select list of untied and unbeaten elevens.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Coal stocks in France were greater in September than they were during an average month, of 1938, Serge Bromberger, special writer for Figaro will report in tomorrow's edition of the paper.

LONDON, Oct. 25 (Reuters) -- By drawing at home today with Everton, 1 -- 1, Arsenal not only retained top place in the English football League's first division, but equaled the Tottenham Hotspurs' 1919 record of battling through the first thirteen matches of the season without defeat.

IN this notable work a distinguished historian-biographer turns his attention for the first time from the Old World to the New, and devotes his fine talents for research and interpretation to a man and a time far too little known in the United States, or anywhere else, for that matter, including the republics to the south of us.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct 25 -- France and China renewed efforts in the United Nations today to curb the powers of the proposed "Little Assembly" by suggesting that it be barred from considering "disputes."

DURING 1947, a year sadly to be remembered for its sameness, radio experienced only one dynamic development. After a sickly childhood and difficult adolescence, the documentary suddenly grew up and found itself glamorous and loved.

VERY early in life Mr. Clune, veteran New York State reporter and columnist, came to a decision that marks him as just about unique among the newspaper brotherhood. He admitted to himself that his home town was quite important enough and colorful enough to absorb his journalistic talents.
Earle Calhoun and Slawson Hobbs, two old realty companies specializing in West Side residential properties, yesterday announced consummation of a consolidation plan.
NANKING, Oct. 25 -- Secret police surveillance of Democratic League headquarters here continued today. League members are still being followed wherever they go.

HOLLYWOOD. THE first actress ever to receive the title of Dame of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire, Dame May Whitty, regrets a little that the honor came to her before it did to Ellen Terry, but consoles herself with the knowledge that they received it for quite different accomplishments.
James Burnett Lowell, a retired banker and broker, and grandson of James Russell Lowell, the poet, died Friday in his home at 812 Park Avenue at the age of 74.

TO THE EDITOR: A paragraph in THE TIMES Magazine mentions Stradivarius violins. Lest hundreds of excited people mistakenly believe they have found a genuine Stradivarius in their attic, let me hasten to tell them that there are hundreds of thousands of ordinary commercial fiddles all over the world.
The twenty-sixth annual observance of Navy Day started here yesterday with public visits to thirteen Naval vessels in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

THE hobgoblins will dance on Friday evening and the witch will climb on her broomstick for a nocturnal whirl through the sky. It is the eve of All Hallows or All Saints' Day, fine excuse, if such is needed, for a children's party.

Sunday, Oct. 25, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Continued general debate on Soviet proposal against "warmongering" and heard representatives of Belgium, Czechoslovakia, Union of South Africa, Brazil, Colombia, Cuba, Bolivia, the Ukraine, Australia, Britain, Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union.

BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- Germany thirty months after the Nazi collapse is a boiling cauldron whose contents are not always readily identifiable, especially as at least four cooks are continually trying to elbow one another out of the picture.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 -- Reports from larger stores throughout the Far West showed a wide variation in retail sales activity during the past week.
The thirty-one-family garden apartment group under construction on Union Avenue between Jackson Avenue and the Passaic River, in Rutherford, N.J., will have a number of interesting features.

Retail business last week continued strong despite unseasonal weather, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers. Some of the cold weather departments were naturally retarded, the report stated.
AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 25 (AP) -- The University of Texas Longhorns pieced together an uneasy 12-0 triumph over a valiant Rice Owl eleven today before a record Southwest Conference game crowd of 48,400.

An increase in the number and dollar volume of open-market sales of Manhattan properties was recorded during September over the previous month, according to the regular survey of the Real Estate Board of New York.

Although the hunting season was just getting started when the forest fire hazards closed the woods and fields throughout most of the northeastern coastal States, several interesting hunting tales found their way to this desk.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 25 -- Paced by Art Fitzgerald, who hitherto had been used mainly on defense this season, Yale experienced little difficulty in overwhelming Springfield College, 49 -- 0, before 15,000 fans, in Yale Bowl today.

With the discovery of the bacterial origin of much disease and the development of laboratory diagnostic aids there began the introduction of what we call "science" in medicine. But as medicine became more scientific costs rose.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Truman today proclaimed the entire State of Maine a disaster area and provided for assistance through the Federal Works Agency.
Major Sports Results FOOTBALL Columbia's 1-point victory, ending Army's four-year string of thirty-two contests without a defeat, headed a parade of upsets yesterday. Scores of leading games:
Fire danger still menaced Southeastern New York last night with two new woodland fires reported near the isolated preserve of the Kensico Reservoir, four miles north of White Plains.

JUST sixteen years ago this week in this Review: Speaking frankly if a bit belatedly, Frederick Palmer exonerated Newton D. Baker, Wilson's muchmaligned Secretary of War, in a two-volume tome that made front-page...

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Rabbi Philip S. Bernstein of Rochester, N.Y., who formerly was Adviser on Jewish Affairs to the United States Army Commanders in Germany and Austria, declared today in his final report to Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall that "the opening of Palestine to largescale immigration is indispensable to the solution of the displaced persons problem."

A NEW attempt to provide relief for the New York metropolitan, region's air traffic jams will be started this Saturday following months of study of the problem by the major scheduled airlines, the Civil Aeronautics Administration and the Air Transport Association.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 25 -- The Pitt Panthers, thumped by four rivals this season, burst the shackles of defeat today and gave old grads in a crowd of 55,217 a flashback to past football glories by upsetting favored Ohio State, 12 -- 0, in a stirring climax to homecoming festivities.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- The hard-running Kentucky Wildcats ran straight into trouble today against a highly keyed Michigan State eleven, but managed to squeeze out a 7-to-6 triumph in a game that was doubly bitter for the Spartans because their dynamic little halfback, George Guerre, was carried off the field with a broken leg.

FINAL, returns are not in on the reaction of the sovereign State of Texas to Robert Rylee's "The Ring and the Cross," a somewhat less than flattering portrait of sundry persons and forces in a city that is Houston in thin disguise.

Joseph D. McGoldrick, former city controller, will be chairman of the New York City Rent Advisory Board, according to a list of appointments announced yesterday by National Housing Expediter Frank R. Creedon and released through the local office of Rent Control, 350 Fifth Avenue.

The Palestine problem will be "a tinder-box for another world war" if it should develop into a dispute over oil among the United States, Great Britain and the Arab nations, it was declared yesterday at the Youth Forum conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast from the studios of WQXR.

Cape Cod Roads The old roads on Cape Cod have a distinctive appeal and charm. The upper Cape, to be sure, has a few big crossstitches of macadam sewn onto the sandy soil; the lower Cape has one long black thread that runs north from Orleans and is tied to the hook of Provincetown harbor.

HOLLYWOOD. LARKIN STREET, San Francisco, where the Hanson family in "I Remember Mama" lived from 1910 to 1914, has been re-created and its occupants reborn in Hollywood The dictator and nominal mayor of Larkin Street is George Stevens, who was borrowed by RKO to direct "Mama," which Harriet Parsons is producing.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Oct. 19 my old friend, Dr. Stephen Duggan, makes the point that owing to currency restrictions, exchange of students and teachers is likely to be more and more a one-way street. May I, as a British citizen, not unfamiliar with your colleges and universities since 1922, when I brought the first debating team from Oxford to the United States, underline his argument?

BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- For more than two years the decisions at Potsdam for dismantling German factories for reparations have been put off or only partly executed. Meanwhile, there has been a progressive relaxing of Military Government toughness and a rapid turnover of governmental authority to the Germans.
NANKING, Oct. 21 (Delayed) -- The traditional structure of the Chinese village is being systematically refashioned in Communistcontrolled areas through fundamental changes in social relationships.

THE traveler to that spectral town. Virginia City, New (ringed by the gaunt, brown Washoe hills), after he has noted its antique charm, is impressed by its fatigued air. For the very hills, at the exhaustion of a vast outburst of energy for eighteen years, gave out one last breath and expired.

The current movement of gold to the United States has lifted the gold stock of this country by nearly two billion dollars this year, the largest gain since 1940, and has brought the total close to the peak holdings reached in 1941.

Autumn in New England is traditionally a pageant of unmatched color, but late autumn this year has given the Mountain West its own magnificence. It has been a green and gold spectacle, with flashes of red and a dusting of crystals; and it has extended from the foothills of Colorado down through New Mexico and Arizona and west into Utah.

FEW young painters have given greater evidence of growth in the last five years than Martyl, whose recent canvases may be seen at the A.C.A. Gallery. From rather loose use of somber color she has moved on to well-knit compositions in higher key.

A COMPETENT novel inevitably borrows dignity and vigor from such important projects as the clearing of the wilderness or the winning of the West or the American Revolution or the Civil War. This is true of Edward Stanley's forthright dramatization of some events of the Revolution in which the personal history of a young printer was involved.

CREDIT either Mayor O'Dwyer's campaign to lure a modicum of Hollywood's production to our town, or, what is more likely, the natural course of events, but the news is that within two weeks shooting will start on a feature picture to be made here in its entirety.

The successful flotation of the new $100,000,000 issue of Pacific Telephone Telegraph Company forty-year debentures has imparted to the market for highgrade securities a tone which it had lacked conspicuously in recent weeks, but the investment world still feels out of place amid the trappings of anything but a bull bond market, and is viewing the marketing coup as a stabilizing influence that is more constructive than conclusive.

IN August, 1938, Albert Teetjens, master butcher of Wandsbeck (Greater Hamburg), an upright party comrade and esteemed member of the SS, found himself in bad financial circumstances. Neither he (the simple, devoted believer in the Unalterable Party Program) nor his pretty wife Stine could understand it.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 25 -- Arrival in Hawaii this week of the reconverted freighter Hawaiian Builder, after a voyage from San Francisco, marked the completion of the first trip by a ship which represents the vanguard of a freighter fleet designed for the Hawaiian trade of the Matson Navigation Company.

Many prominent persons have reserved boxes and seats for the "Cavalcade of Stars" to be given Tuesday night at the Madison Square Garden, under the auspices of the Musicians Emergency Fund, of which Mrs. Lytle Hull is president.

JOAN DAVIS, whose comic efforts last season reached a rather low ebb, has bounced back with engaging eclat in her new program, at 9 o'clock Saturday evenings over the Columbia Broadcasting System. Thus far it has proved a half-hour which gets away from the usual hackneyed routines and strikes out spiritedly in the direction of absurd situations with a novel twist.
ALBANY, Oct. 25 (AP) -- New York colleges and universities are packed to the peaks of their ivied towers with an all-time high enrollment 8 per cent above last year's record levels.

LIBERTY -- A bystander at a recent parade in New York went away convinced that a free society had a good chance of survival in this country. He had just noticed a couple of uninhioited 12-year-olds cheerfully trying to toss wads of paper into the mouth of a tuba -- in the Police Band.
Once again the warning signals against inflationary tendencies have been hoisted by the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- As the committee on arrangements for the Republican National Convention ended its meeting today, Walter S. Hallanan of West Virginia, its chairman, announced the appointment of seven subcommittees.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Oct. 25 -- Lafayette defeated Washington and Jefferson today, 20 -- 12, after trailing until the second period. Frankie Stanczak set the pace for the Leopards with his brilliant aerials.

Mea Culpa HAVE a friend condemned by his university to lecturing for life. By way of mental adjustment to his sentence he has invented a pastime which he plays with his 5-year-old son. The game is called "Lowell Lecturing."

MR. FINE'S book is a volume to frighten the guilty and appall the brave. For if the democratic state is to survive, it can survive only in terms of the spread of general intelligence among its citizens, and general intelligence in the modern state is something to be developed by education.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Pending reports from trained agency investigators, officials of the Civil Aeronautics Board suggested today that preliminary indications pointed to the passengers' luggage as the cause of yesterday's crash of a burning air liner in Utah.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange recovered yesterday some of Friday's losses, and closed unchanged to 33 points net higher.

Bill Lucas of Morris continued his dominance over Eastern school boy harriers yesterday at Van Cortlandt park by capturing the twenty-second annual Manhattan College interscholastic run. Lucas, in winning by 60 yards, was clocked in 13:27.2, one of the fastest times ever turned in for the two-and-one-half-mile course at Van Cortlandt park.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Tennessee's running and passing attack clicked like a well-oiled machine for three quarters today as the Volunteers mauled little Tennessee Tech, 49 to 0.
CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Heavy liquidation entered the grain pits on the Chicago Board of Trade today, forcing the December wheat contract below $3 a bushel at times for the first session this week.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 25 -- In a sharp attack on existing educational practices, Dr. John Spangler Kieffer, inaugurated today as the seventeenth president of St. John's College, declared that the liberal arts were being replaced by natural sciences in the college curriculum.

Early planning of municipal services in rapidly expanding suburban developments is urged by Henry J. Davenport, president of the Home Title Guaranty Company. Schools already are crowded in certain communities and sewage disposal 'is an acute problem, he declared.

FOND MOTHERS -- Dr. C. Anderson Aldrich of the Mayo Clinic asked 623 mothers "What habits has your baby of which you do not approve?" Four hundred and twenty-six said that their little Jessies and Johnnies needed no improvement. The mothers who did not find their babies faultless complained of thumbsucking more than anything else.

FOLLOWING the fortunes of an estate and its family is a favorite pastime with Frances Parkinson Keyes -- and evidently with her readers too. Again in "Came a Cavalier" (as in "The River Road" and earlier books), the estate emerges as a stronger, more firmly integrated entity than any of the characters whose lives it shapes.

The announcement by James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, that his union "once and for all" would stop the making of records and transcriptions as of Dec. 31 presages an unprecedented economic, legal and technological tussle on the question of "canned music."

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 300 head: total 3,300 (estimated). Compared with week ago: Barrows and gilts $1.25 lower on all weights: sows. $2.25 lower.
LONDON, Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- Film circles said today that the new 75 per cent tax on imported film earnings had falied to reduce the flow of almost $6,000,000 a month from Britain to Hollywood.
A program to replace obsolete Magistrate Court buildings with modern structures is being studied by the city, Edgar Bromberger, Chief City Magistrate, said yesterday.

LEXINGTON, Va., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Virginia's well-oiled football machine rolled to its fifth victory today, trampling Virginia Military Institute's keydets, 35 -- 6, and thereby spoiling a homecoming for some 12,000 of the V.M.I. faithful.

Work will begin this week on the New York public school system's first School of Performing Arts, which is expected to be opened next February as a training center for talented youths seeking careers as playwrights, actors, musicians, radio artists and dancers.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 25 -- Amid the crash of Army and Illinois, Pennsylvania maintained its place among the football elect with a convincing demonstration of its superiority over Navy today. The final score was 21 to 0.

NORMAN, Okla., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Texas Christian's Horned Frogs, swelling themselves into a defensive dragon with an offensive bite, battered the favored University of Oklahoma, 20 -- 7, here today on a rain-soaked gridiron.

THE amateur with limited lighting facilities for shooting action indoors can often get pictures by going counter to the rules and "pushing" the film's capacity to the limit, according to Muky Munkacsi, specialist in fashion action photography.

Throughout his forty-three years on the American stage Dudley Digges had the good fortune to appear in some of our finest plays and to associate with the aristocrats of his profession. This was because he himself ranked among the best. No actor of our time will leave a warmer or gentler memory.

ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 25 (U.P.) -- Harry Gilmer turned in his usual brilliant passing exhibition today and sprouted wings on his ankles for good measure to lead Alabama to a soul-satisfying 17-to-7 victory over Georgia before 48,000 fans.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- A touchdown in the final quarter enabled Colgate to tie Brown at 13 -- 13 today and the traditional game ended in a deadlock as the Raiders failed to complete two subsequent drives.
BAR HARBOR, Me., Oct. 25 -- National Guardsmen are checking every building left standing in Bar Harbor tonight to prevent looting after an attempt to rob the Bar Harbor Savings Bank.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The National Fatherland Front Committee declared today that the United States was attempting to destroy Bulgaria economically and that Bulgaria's place was in the "anti-imperialist camp headed by the great Soviet Union."

SIDNEY MARGOLIUS' "How to Buy More for Your Money" points several ways to take the sting out of the word. The volume consists of three practical sections, each designed to transform harried housewives and husbands into highly skilled domestic purchasing agents.

New building and higher realty values have added more than $3,000,000,000 to property assessment rolls in forty-nine major centers of population throughout the country this year according to a survey just completed by the National Association of Assessing Officers.

MANHATTAN, Kan., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Nebraska's Cornhuskers rushed over a pair of fourth-quarter touchdowns to snatch a 14-7 victory from the Kansas State Wildcats today. The Big Six Conference game was played before a Homecoming Day crowd estimated at 17,000.

UNCOMMONLY gifted men, as Edmund Wilson demonstrated in "The Shock of Recognition," reveal the character of their gifts in their relationships with one another, and when several such men are found in one family, the revelation is peculiarly sharp.

Arturo Toscanini gave his first concert of the season late yesterday afternoon when he inaugurated the winter series of the NBC Symphony Orchestra in Studio 8-H, Radio City. A studio audience of 1,100 welcomed him to the podium and gave him a standing ovation at the close.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky is convinced, or says he is, that the United States is intervening in the politics of other countries for its own ends and for the purpose of confounding the Soviet Union and all its works.

HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 25 -- Trinity notched the fourth victory of an unbeaten and untied football campaign today by overpowering an outmanned Williams College team, 33 to 0. It was Williams' fourth straight defeat.

A FLOWERING hedge of shrubs that provide display from early spring until winter makes a handsome planting along an edge of the front lawn. Repeated at either side of the property, it is doubly effective. This next month is the time to do the work.

Retail trade continued to score substantial gains here last week. Department store volume was estimated as about 35 per cent over the like week of last year, although distortions due to the 1946 delivery strike were again a factor in comparisons.

Significant progress toward correcting what is termed the "weakest link in the frozen food industry" -- transportation at the required uniformly low temperature -- was reported this week, revealing developments in two directions, here and in Europe.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 25 -- After decades of talk but little action, Los Angeles appears to have been goaded by San Francisco rivalry into projecting a foreign trade zone for its port.

NOW that the season of cold and blustery weather approaches, the Look at America Series (with no little Yankee shrewdness) tempts us to travel (or more especially to book buying) with a volume on the warm, the sun-drenched South.

THE expert bridge players (who are numbered in the thousands) take the play known as the squeeze for granted, and it bores them. The average bridge players, of whom, there are millions, find the squeeze bewildering, so it bores them, too.

The Committee for Economic Development last week announced the election of a woman, a churchman and two college presidents to its board of trustees. This was regarded as highly significant of the growing importance being attached by responsible business leaders to cooperation with intellectual groups for mutual survival of American free enterprise, free labor, free government and intellectual freedom in a world increasingly menaced by the totalitarian crusade of Communism.

REQUESTS for reservations to Florida for the coming season are already pouring into Atlantic Coast Line, Florida East Coast and Seaboard offices here in large numbers, according to railroad officials, who are planning the maximum use of every available piece of equipment.

READERS of Mr. Gould's earlier reminiscences of a "Yankee Storekeeper" will want to know at once whether his new book contains the same wealth of spontaneous if noisy humor and more of his tall stories of simple country matters like horse-trading, the weather, and good food.

CHICAGO, Oct. 25 -- Most of Chicago's six daily newspapers experienced work slowdowns by printers and some curtailment of production volume today as a result of the tense situation created by deadlocked negotiations for a new contract between the publishers and Local 16 of the Chicago Typographical Union.

THE current black-and-white show at the Salmagundi Club is well up to its predecessors. Drawings -- so revelatory of the true artist -- include luminous little New Hope landscapes by Harry Leith-Ross; dynamic tree forms by Gene Kleb; Henry Gasser's haunting streetscenes; Syd Browne's harbor studies; a red crayon nude by A. Henry Nordhausen and portrait heads by William Auerbach-Levy and Keith Shaw Williams.
Manhattan College's cross-country team gained its second dualmeet triumph of the season yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, defeating Seton Hall by a perfect score, 15 -- 40.

Sweeping changes in the administrative staff and operating methods of the Department of Welfare will be made by Commissioner Benjamin Fielding, successor to Edward E. Rhatigan, it was indicated yesterday at City Hall.
Navy Day, 1947, which is celebrated tomorrow, finds the United States Navy at the beginning of a technological revolution which will alter profoundly all past concepts of sea power.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- The rapid pace of deterioration in the world never disclosed itself more plainly than when, in the last few days, one of its effects persuaded President Truman to adopt political courses he was trying by every means to avoid and to make fundamental changes in the details of these courses.

After three years of job counseling to more than 14,000 veterans, City College's vocational advisement unit will extend its service to the public beginning tomorrow, Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college, announced yesterday.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Oct. 25 -- The International Refugee Organization revealed today that it proposed to ask members of the United Nations to accept definite quotas for the admission of displaced persons as the only means of liquidating the problem in the foreseeable future.

THE new Argus Model "21" miniature camera, taking standard 35mm film and featuring a new type view finder called the Markfinder, was introduced last week at a press reception by the O.W. Ray Corporation, New York and New Jersey distributor.

With ten consecutive seasons of good business behind it, the New York garment industry is prepared to meet financially the contingencies that are in store for it in the uncertain future economic picture, it was pointed out last week by bank credit men on Seventh Avenue.

To Congress and People It is within our power to lead the world to peace and plenty. -- PRESIDENT TRUMAN. The U.S.S.R. will put all effort into seeing that the Marshall plan is not realised. -- ANDREI A. ZHDANOV.

THE parent forewarned is a parent forearmed, in the opinion of specialists in child guidance. Among others, Dr. Benjamin Spock has long advocated that pediatricians tell parents what to expect in a baby's behavior and tell them ahead of time.

Copper consumption in September was substantially above shipments to fabricators, reversing the recent trend, copper producers reported this week. Actual consumption in the United States during the month was estimated at 108,413 tons of new refined copper in products of brass mills, wire mills and other fabricators.

A recent report from the Bureau of Agricultural Economics of the United States Department of Agriculture indicates a marked improvement in farm living conditions between the years 1940 and 1945. Urban dwellers, representing 83,860,000 of our total population of 143,000,000, are in general unaware of the lack of modern conveniences on a large proportion of the nation's farms.

"THERE was no 'mauve decade in San Francisco * * * the veins of the Golden City ran scarlet," Evelyn Wells, novelist and biographer of Fremont Older, states in her book. "Champagne Days of San Francisco." In supporting evidence of this assertion she follows the monkeyshines of three semi-fictional characters called only the Senator, the Judge and the Banker, through the Nineties and into the opening years of this century.

TO THE EDITOR: I did not sleep much last night. I had read Gertrude Samuels' story in THE TIMES Magazine. I hope that many others had the same experience. * * * There are powerful women's organizations in the United States which I am sure would take on the added task of raising a quota of a day's pay from each of their members.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- When the French Parliament reconvenes in special session next Tuesday, Premier Paul Ramadier will present his revised Cabinet as a buffer between the Communists and all the anti-Communist forces ranging themselves behind Charles de Gaulle.

HOLLYWOOD. THE controversy over the position of Negroes in motion pictures, recently accentuated by rulings of Lloyd Binford, Memphis censor, had repercussions in Hollywood last week in a dispute between Paramount Pictures on one hand, Roy Chanslor, author and scenarist, and Paulette Goddard on the other.

Large American retail organizations are ready and eager to increase imports of foreign goods as a step in world trade recovery, but find they are more or less stymied in expanding their purchases by high prices, shortages, exchange difficulties and political barriers abroad, it was indicated here last week.

ELLSWORTH, Me., Oct. 25 -- Although taxed by forty-eight hours of relief work among the 3,000 evacuees from fire-swept Bar Harbor, the town of Ellsworth toiled on tonight, caring for 300 more homeless from near-by communities.

Delays of industrial mobilization like those early in World War II will be avoided in any future emergency, if it should occur. New methods now being used in Pittsburgh plants provide procedures which could be extended on a nation-wide scale if ecessary, Gen Brehon Sbmervell, president of Koppers Corporation, and formerly Commander of the Army Service Forces, revealed yesterday in a statemnt to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

A LITTLE flower border along a much-used path is a daily joy. The one pictured leads from the living terrace to the cutting garden, the garage court and the kitchen door of a home in Bronxville, N.Y. Thus It is passed many times a day throughout the year.

James Monroe's high-geared eleven rolled to its second triumph of the season against no defeats by downing Christopher Columbus, 27 -- 0, in the feature game of a P.S.A.L. double-header yesterday at Triborough Stadium on Randall's Island.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- The biggest clash between the Conservative and Labor parties since the latter assumed power in the summer of 1945 faced the Attlee Government this week. The issue arose over the Government's attempt to curb the powers of the House of Lords.

MOSCOW, Oct. 25 (U.P) -- The Literary Gazette, Soviet magazine specializing in political criticism, turned its guns again today on Brazil's President, Gen. Eurico Gaspar Dutra, charging that "he was decorated by Hitler -- and Truman."

PRAGUE (By Wireless). IT is evening. Crowds saunter up and down the broad Vaclavske Namesti which is the heart of Prague.
