Bookshops and newsstands display a wide assortment of British, French and American books, newspapers and periodicals. One big motion-picture house advertises Chaplin in "The Dictator."

NORWICH, England, Oct. 24 (Delayed) -- Agriculture has been hard hit, not only here in Norfolk which grows 17 per cent of the food of England and Wales, but all over Britain. Nature is the real villain in the piece but there are plenty of other troubles.

Warning of an acute shortage in permanent anti-freeze solutions for motor vehicles was given yesterday by J.R. Crossley, vicepresident of the Automobile Club of New York. His findings were based upon a survey by the organization that included 1,100 service stations, filling stations and auto accessories stores in Manhattan, Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

HOLLYWOOD. "GONE WITH THE WIND," which is currently being shown throughout the United States for the fourth time, is the most successful motion picture ever made -- at least from the standpoint of popularity. In theatres scattered from the Atlantic to the Pacific it is enjoying a revival unequaled in the annals of the film industry.

A CHILDHOOD passion for tales of metamorphosis accounts for this very adult anthology. Ten entries have survived Mr. Spectorsky's meticulous winnowing, each of which conforms to the three editorial prerequisites: there shall be no supernatural explanation; each tale must serve to illuminate some truth about man or beast; the story shall be so skillfully told that natural skepticism is held at bay throughout the telling.

"There he goes! He's sixth! He's fifth! He's fourth! He's going to win it! "The shouts went up at Jamaica yesterday in the ninth running of the $75,000 added Gallant Fox Handicap, and the horse that had the 44,735 customers in a dither was Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' old Stymie.

The stock market last week was in the process of consolidating its newly won gains until President Truman announced a special session of Congress for Nov. 17 to consider high prices at home and emergency aid abroad. Although it occasioned only mild surprise in financial circles, possible implications set off a wave of selling in the worst break in six months.

AMERICANS know their GMen, the agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, but the T-Men remain practically obscure, although it's an established fact that 64 per cent of all peacetime criminals are in Federal prisons because of these law enforcement agents of the Treasury Department.

THE centenary of the death of Mendelssohn occurs Nov. 4. Some days previous to that, or last Thursday night, the Philharmonic-Symphony under Mr. Stokowski's direction observed the anniversary by the performance of the "Scotch" symphony.

BRET HARTE'S collected works run to some twenty volumes. To bring the best of so prolific a writer within the limits of a single volume would seem to offer serious problems in selection. With this volume, however, selection appears to have presented one difficulty only-that of finding anywhere in Harte's writings a dozen other stories to accompany that half dozen by which he is generally known.

"There he goes! He's sixth! He's fifth! He's fourth! He's going to win it! "The shouts went up at Jamaica yesterday in the ninth running of the $75,000 added Gallant Fox Handicap, and the horse that had the 44,735 customers in a dither was Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs' old Stymie.

The stock market last week was in the process of consolidating its newly won gains until President Truman announced a special session of Congress for Nov. 17 to consider high prices at home and emergency aid abroad. Although it occasioned only mild surprise in financial circles, possible implications set off a wave of selling in the worst break in six months.

AMERICANS know their GMen, the agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, but the T-Men remain practically obscure, although it's an established fact that 64 per cent of all peacetime criminals are in Federal prisons because of these law enforcement agents of the Treasury Department.

THE centenary of the death of Mendelssohn occurs Nov. 4. Some days previous to that, or last Thursday night, the Philharmonic-Symphony under Mr. Stokowski's direction observed the anniversary by the performance of the "Scotch" symphony.

BRET HARTE'S collected works run to some twenty volumes. To bring the best of so prolific a writer within the limits of a single volume would seem to offer serious problems in selection. With this volume, however, selection appears to have presented one difficulty only-that of finding anywhere in Harte's writings a dozen other stories to accompany that half dozen by which he is generally known.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 25 -- While President Juan Peron and Sefiora Peron today received the predicted enthusiastic reception in Resistencia, where the National Cotton Festival opened, the Peronista party continued to suffer from its internal disputes.
"Whodunit?" -- that seems to be the key to the long-drawnout debate over war-mongering which the eloquent Mr. Vishinsky has brought to the current session of the United Nations Assembly.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 25 -- Most delegates to the United Nations General Assembly take at face value the announcement that the Soviet Union will boycott the new committee on the Balkans the Assembly set up this week.

Despite the utility industry's repeated statements recently that all demands for electricity would be met in the coming winter, consumers were worried last week by two developments. First was the voluntary power curtailment by several large industrial customers of the Niagara Hudson Power system in the Buffalo area.
AFTER FLYING into a house at Turners Hill, England, and rifling a box of candy, a repentant jackdaw returned the next day and placed a potato in the box.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 25 --The Government has announced a new and uncompromising purge of all elements, including those now in the coalition Government who cannot accept unconditionally the "new social order which we are preparing for this country."

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Aroused Arkansas matched the nation's moat potent air attack with free-wheeling, strike-throwing Clyde Scott this rainy, miserable afternoon and stunned favored Mississippi, 19 to 14, in a thrill-packed contest played before 28,000.

Prices of shares on the New York Stock Exchange closed firmer yesterday in quiet trading after a moderately lower opening. Trading volume dropped to the smallest total for a Saturday since the resumption of trading after the summer holidays, amounting to 400,000 shares, compared with 480,000 shares a week before.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Texas A. and M. bounced back from three straight defeats today to knock Baylor out of the nation's unbeaten ranks, with a convincing 24-0 decision that kept the Aggies in the Southwest Conference championship race.

ASKED to discuss whether we eat too much, on reflection one finds this question not so simple as it sounds. It might be said that each should find the answer for himself after consulting his family physician, his bathroom scales and his conscience.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Little Phil Slosburg, the East's leading offensive back, scored two touchdowns today as Temple University defeated Bucknell, 21 to 0, and won possession of "the old shoe" for the third straight year.

EDITH PIAF, "the pathetic waif of the back streets," pulled her pink Jean Farell gown snug last week in a perfume-misted suite on Park Avenue. She let her eyebrows writhe in terror at the prospect of her American debut at the Playhouse Thursday evening, when she will give New York its first glimpse of the New Look in torch singers, direct from Paris.

LONDON (By Wireless). THE forthcoming marriage of Princess Elizabeth, heiress presumptive to the British throne, to Lieut. Philip Mountbatten, R.N., former Prince of Greece, raises some delicate problems for King George VI and Elizabeth, his Queen.

The majority leaders in Congress are today facing a test of their statesmanship. President Truman, in his radio address Friday night, correctly defined the issues with which they will have to deal in the special session beginning three weeks from tomorrow. Perhaps there is only one issue -- that of making our economic system a constructive force.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Bob Feller's All Stars came from behind in the eighth inning today to score four runs and defeat the Pacific Coast Stars, 6 -- 3, in the third of a four-game exhibition baseball series at Mexican League Park.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- As early as June, 1941, German U-boat 203 attempted to attack the United States battleship Texas and in September of that year the Germany Navy no longer differentiated between United States and British ships in any area.

WAKE FOREST, N.C., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Fred Folger Jr., a triplethreat back, led undefeated but once tied Duke University to a 13to-6 victory over previously unbeaten Wake Forest in a Southern Conference football game played before 25,000 fans here today.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Oct. 25 -- Lord Pakenham, Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster and Minister responsible for the British zone of Germany, told the highest German administrators today that reparations plans "reflect the unalterable policy of the British Cabinet."

THE United States Travel Division, a successor to the United States Travel Bureau which was discontinued during the war, was re-established last week as a unit of the National Park Service. An advisory committee is now working with the Park Service to formulate the policy and program under which the Travel Division will operate.

THE overshadowing news in the world of records is that virtually no new ones may be made in this country after the first of the year. The American Federation of Musicians, through James C. Petrillo, its president, has announced that its members will no longer have anything to do with making records after Jan, 1.

GATHERING and burying the dead on the battlefield -- both ours and the enemies -- is a morbid business, and those who have done it have received little attention and little praise. Yet it is a job that takes training and skill, and for those families whose kinfolk have been killed, it has been a comfort beyond measure.

To the Drama Editor: I SHOULD like to point out that although actors shout about the deterioration of the presentday theatre and pity the plight of the poor actor, it is a mere handful who respond when faced with constructive measures.

A patrolman, eight years on the force, and a civilian companion, a former soldier with a police record, were under arrest yesterday charged with having extorted $7 from an English butler under threat of arresting him in Central Park on a spurious morals charge.

OPA was wound up on Nov. 9, 1946, and President Truman might have twisted the dagger by calling Congress into special session on that date. Instead, he selected Nov. 17 last week and nevertheless put price inflation at home ahead of emergency aid for Europe on the legislative agenda.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 25 -- The grim shadow of famine is creeping over India in her third month of freedom. Millions will be hungry -- that is, hungrier than they are now -- and many may die of starvation a few weeks from now. But there will be no repetition of the wholesale calamity of 1943 when 1,500,000 persons perished in Bengal.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 25 -- The United States was the first of the great powers to' endorse a Jewish state in Palestine, and it now should insist that similar action be taken by the United Nations, Mrs. Samuel W. Halprin of New York, the only American woman member of the executive board of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, said in an address here tonight.

THERE are some facts about the Missouri Valley that many of us might not know without reading this book. For example, the western plains "are what they are largely because of a sea which linked the waters of the Gulf of Mexico and the Arctic Ocean 110 million years ago."

DENVER, Oct. 25 -- New rumors of an alarming reduction in Western cattle herds owing to cattlemen's fear of lower prices are largely discounted hereabout by cattle experts. Such rumors, they say, stem from public misinterpretation of Department of Agriculture figures on herd reduction.

Cardinal Spellman dedicated the Fordham University frequency modulation radio station, WFUV, in a ceremony yesterday afternoon at Keating Hall on the school's Bronx campus, where the station is situated.

SOUTH HADLEY, Mass., Oct. 26 -- By unanimous vote today at a session of a two-day conference on the Mount Holyoke campus, student representatives from more than thirty New England colleges and universities adopted a constitution for the Northern New England Region of the National Student Association.

WARSAW, Oct. 26 -- The Government sponsored Left Wing group of the Polish Peasant party -- the PSL -- moved swiftly today to take over the entire party organization. Its action came on the heels of the reported flight from the country of Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, leader of the party and bitter foe of the Government.

Reading from a Bible printed in 1611 and used in 1768 at the dedication of the first building of the John Street Methodist Church, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Bruce Moss, pastor, conducted services yesterday in the present church at 44 John Street celebrating the 179th anniversary of that dedication.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 26 -- A crowd of Trenton veterans, members of civic organizations and citizens tonight prevented the Communist party of Mercer County from holding a meeting at which Gerhart Eisler, so-called Communist leader in this country, was to have spoken.

The American people will no longer retreat from "crypto-fascists" attacking their civil liberties, but will stand and fight for basic democracy, Senator Claude Pepper, Democrat, of Florida, declared yesterday at the closing session of the conference on cultural freedom and civil liberties at the Hotel Commodore.

DETROIT, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Defenseman Glen Harmon, playing a leftwing position for the Montreal Canadiens, hammered in two long shots in the second period tonight as Montreal won a 4-to-2 National Hockey League decision from the Detroit Red Wings before 14,323 fans.
ROME, Oct. 26 -- The Communist press is greatly perturbed by the drop in wholesale prices in the last few days, especially in northern Italy.

In commemoration of the Greek determination to resist Axis invaders in 1940, a memorial service was held yesterday noon in the Holy Trinity Greek Orthodox Cathedral at 317 East Seventy-fourth Street. This year's observance of the anniversary coincided with the feast day of St. Demetrios, patron saint of Salonika.

Just about one mile from the Polo Grounds stands the Thirtysecond Precinct station house. It was there that Paul Governali, the lad with the talented arm, should have gone yesterday before reporting to the Giants for his debut against the Pittsburgh Steelers.

Scheduled to vacate the Royale next Saturday night is "Our Lan,'" the week's second closing. As previously recorded, the other withdrawal will be the Barrymore's double bill of "The Medium" and "The Telephone."

BERNE, Switzerland, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Swiss Telegraph Agency said tonight that, judging from incomplete returns from the Parliamentary election, "it appears that middle-class parties are victorious."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- President Truman, accepting in behalf of the nation a memorial to a onetime "displaced person," the distinguished statesman and public figure, Oscar S. Straus, called today for a renewal of the "tolerance and reason" that brought such citizens to the United States.

Advertising for Advertisers The first advertisement in a full, page campaign in daily newspapers and trade magazines to advance the idea of supporting advertising campaigns with more intensive sales promotion and merchandising plans will appear in today's NEW YORK TIMES, it was announced over the week-end by Deutsch Shea, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- In presenting the case for the Marshall plan, key spokesmen of the Truman Administration, meeting tomorrow in secret conference with leaders of industry, business and labor, undoubtedly will seek to win support for any emergency adjustments of the national economy that expanded foreign aid may force.

The church must have real spiritual values to answer its many enemies today, the Rev. Dr. Horace W. B. Donegan, rector of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at Seventy -first Street, declared yesterday in his last sermon as rector.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: On the editorial page of your issue of Oct. 15 a letter appeared signed by Dorothy Livingston Arnold with reference to the article on "New Classrooms of the Future in Use."

Edward Tikkanen, 18 years old, of 366 Forty-first Street, Brooklyn, was held on a charge of grand larceny at the Fort Hamilton police station last night, after being arrested in the afternoon following a chase of more than a mile, during which a pedestrian was injured.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Corn showed a weak undertone most of last week on the Board of Trade. In addition to fears of legislation likely to affect the usage of this grain adversely there was a falling off in the demand from the East and a belief that a rapid readjustment from an old to a new crop basis would develop quickly in the spot market.

AUSTIN, Minn., Oct. 26 -- Some influential members of the midwestern farm bloc in Congress are at the point or a final decision to attack the Marshall plan both at its flank and center and also to seek to draw the strings tight on interim emergency aid to Europe.

If reports from Washington concerning the progress of AngloAmerican talks are to be credited, the United States may take over from Britain nearly all dollar costs of the occupation of western Germany.

WASHINGTON. Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- The Citizens Food Committee announced today that it would send a "Train of Friendship" from the West Coast to the East Coast to collect food gifts for hungry Europeans. Chairman Charles Luckman said the freight train would "show the people of Europe that the people of the United States are anxious and willing to assist them."

It was the third "Boheme" of the season, but last night's performance at the New York City Centre nevertheless made news on four counts. There were two expected debuts, a surprise one and the conclusion of a three-part operatic marathon.

ALBANY, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Governor Dewey made public today a State Department of Commerce report showing that 83 major industrial and commercial concerns operating in the state have, since the end of the war, spent $226,950,000 in additional investments and created 48,860 new jobs through expansion programs.

PATERSON, N.J., Oct. 26 (AP) -- A 32-yard field goal by Alex Schibanoff enabled the Jersey City Giants to defeat the Paterson Panthers, 3 -- 0, today in an American Football League game at Hinchliffe Stadium. Paterson had a slight statistical edge recording sixteen first downs to the Giants fourteen.

VIENNA, Oct. 26 -- The third and most successful annual meeting of the Austrian Socialist party since the foundation of the Third Republic closed today with an appeal by Gen. Julius Deutsch to accept a separate Austrian peace from the Western powers if a fourpower treaty could not be drafted.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The Federal Reserve Board today issued a serious warning as the ending of its controls over installment buying drew near. By resolution of Congress last July the Board's regulations cease after Nov. 1.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Representatives of twenty-two Little Theatre groups meeting at Cornell University today voted to form a state organization, to be known as the New York State Community Theatre Conference.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 26 When the United Nations Political and Security Committee meets here tomorrow to renew discussion of the Soviet Union's resolution on "warmongering," it will receive a conciliatory joint resolution offered by Australia, France and Canada.

To lead a continuous national campaign against accidents, a coast-to-coast committee has been formed, it was announced yesterday by William A. Irvin of New York, chairman of the board of trustees of the National Safety Council, 405 Lexington Avenue.

Cotton prices in the domestic market last week moved steadily upward until Friday when they lost most of their earlier gains. At the close of trading on Saturday active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed net changes for the week ranging from an advance of 60 points to a decline of 20 points.

The General Electric Company, the nation's largest producer of electrical equipment, has decided to abolish the profit-sharing plan under which it distributed $3,000,000 among its 160,000 employes earlier this year.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- The Navy is going to find out how its rocket-carrying Douglas Skyraiders would do in a full-dress sea-air "war" during the next two weeks.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The greatest harm is being done to the liberal movement by those professed anti-Communists who indiscriminately accuse all people with progressive ideas of being Communists.

NORWICH, England, Oct. 25 (Delayed) -- A fowl pest has struck Norfolk's poultry, and it was learned today that the Labor Government was planning to ban the marketing and sale of all poultry in England.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- The semi-official Communist newspaper Romania Libera demanded today that the Government intervene to end what it called oil field "sabotage" by United States and British companies. The newspaper cited a recent declaration by the Oil Workers' Union, charging that the companies were hampering" production.

Among the major lines of Government surplus property being offered by the War Assets Administration in New York State and northern New Jersey are electrical supplies, metals, wearing apparel, aircraft and wrist watch bands, it was announced over the week-end by Carl P. Malmstrom, regional director of the WAA.
The Rev. Christopher J. Weldon, assistant executive, director of Catholic Charities, preaching yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, likened the United Nations to a "tower of Babel."

It was a quiet week in the foreign exchanges, which produced a softer tone in the pound sterling for spot and forward positions. However, dealers were unwilling to place any significance on the setback.

The joint service established sixteen months ago by the States Marine Corporation and the Hellenic Lines, Ltd., has been dissolved by mutual agreement, it was learned yesterday. Under the terms of the separation agreement, the last jointly handled departure will be made by the Grigorios C. III, leaving here Nov. 3.

PRAGUE, Oct. 26 -- Best reports available here today indicate that the former Slovak puppet official, Dr. Ferdinand Durcansky, was at the center of actual Slovak conspiracy efforts that have resulted in recent weeks in attacks on the Slovak Democratic party.

Mrs. John De Witt Peltz of New York, whose family has been part of the Bar Harbor summer colony since 1878, said yesterday that reports from eye-witnesses of the fire there indicated that a large part of the Maine community had escaped damage.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears, with Sid Luckman throwing three touchdown passes, rolled over the Redskins today for a 56-20 National Football League victory.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Oct. 26 -- This community expects to save its picket fences and signboards from being removed and to prevent other youthful depredations on Halloween by carrying out next Friday evening on an augmented scale, a program that operated with marked success last fall.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Joe Muha's booming kicks bottled up Bob Waterfield and the Los Angeles Rams today and the Philadelphia Eagles treated a record Shibe Park crowd to a 14-7 upset over their National Football League rivals.

American shipbuilding is at its lowest ebb since the Maritime Commission embarked on a peacetime replacement program in 1936, according to figures reported in the quarterly compilation by Lloyd's Register of Shipping.The report covers returns for the period ended Sept. 30, for all countries excepting Russia, Germany and Japan.

A contribution of $250,000 to the New York University - Bellevue Hospital Medical Center fund has been authorized by the directors of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, it was announced yesterday by Nevil Ford, vice president of the First Boston Corporation and general chairman of the $15,575,000 center campaign.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 26 -- Robert Taylor has been named by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer for the leading role in "Colorado," which Joseph Pasternak will produce next spring from a novel by Louis Bromfield. The story, which deals with a mining family in the Eighteen Eighties, was recently purchased by Metro for a reported $125,000.

TWO of the most notable books of 1947 are about the mountain men and the Rocky Mountain fur trade. A.B. Guthrie's "The Big Sky," certainly one of the half dozen best novels of the year, was a remarkable fictional recreation of a vanished way of life. Bernard De Voto's "Across the Wide Missouri,"* certainly one of the half dozen best historical works of the year, is an exhaustive investigation of the identical subject.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, AFL, is expected to meet some time this week with the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association to try to settle the dispute over a new contract between the publishers and Local 16, Chicago Typographical Union.

GENEVA, Oct. 26 -- A special effort to resettle intellectuals and professionals among displaced persons is being launched by the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization in cooperation with voluntary relief agencies.
Forty-eight thousand war veterans and representatives of patriotic organizations marched yesterday in a Queens County parade as part of the twenty-sixth, annual observance of Navy Day today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities was challenged today to tell the names of motion pictures that it regarded as tainted with Communist propaganda or "absolve the industry" from such charges.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 26 (AP) -- An aggressive Green Bay line slammed the door on Bill Dudley today to give the Packers a 34-to17 victory over the Detroit Lions. A crowd of 25,197 saw the Packer's final appearance at City Stadium this year.
Yale University is scheduled to oppose the University of Pennsylvania in the opening game of the 1947-48 Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League campaign on Friday, Dec. 13.

One flag-draped coffin at the memorial services in Central Park yesterday stood for the 6,248 dead young men who came home in the Joseph V. Connolly and for the 250,000 who died under the American flag during the second World War. Seven hundred thousand others received wounds, and of these many thousands will carry with them to their graves the disabling scars.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The State Department had not received by tonight an official report on the disappearance of Stanislaw Mikolajczyk. Polish Opposition leader from Warsaw.
ABILENE, Kan., Oct. 26 -- Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower concluded a three-day visit to his home state today with a brief stop at his boyhood home.

Still stunned by the suddenness of his ouster as Welfare Commissioner, Edward E. Rhatigan asserted yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer had been thoroughly familiar with the shortcomings of New York's relief program months before he demanded Mr. Rhatigan's resignation.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 26 (AP) -- The latest blaze in Maine leveled thirty-five homes at Dayton Village, but flames were controlled after leaping the Saco River five miles west of the city of Saco, adjacent to industrial Biddeford.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Oct. 26 -- The English all-star touring field hockey team today registered its fourth straight victory by beating a picked eleven from the North Jersey Association, 12-0. A crowd of over 2,000 saw the match at the Montclair Athletic Club.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- Wholesale meat prices have dropped 4 to 17 cents a pound from the peak reached during, the summer, the American Meat Institute reported today. It said the decreases should soon be reflected on the retail level.

SOUTHAMPTON, England, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- James Camb, a 30-yearold deck steward on the liner Durban Castle, was arrested today, charged with the murder of Eileen Gibson, 21-year-old English actress who disappeared while returning to England from a starring role in South Africa.

Efforts to halt a forest fire racing through the pines atop Shawangunk Mountain in Ulster County were abandoned last night as towering flames spread to within two miles of the resort community of Lake Minnewaska. The fire was heading in the general direction of Kingston, seventeen miles northeast.

Mayor O'Dwyer made public yesterday a report by his Executive Committee on Administration, crammed with sharp criticism of the administrative and operating procedures of the Department of Welfare. The department chief, Edward E. Rhatigan, resigned suddenly last Friday at the Mayor's request.
BEDDEFORD, Me., Oct. 26 -- Tragedy, heroism and grim humor move side by side through the fireblackened highways of Maine.
Francis X. Dealy has been apointed vice president in charge of sales for Republic Filters, Inc., Newark, N.J.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 26 -- Steel demand last week was reported the strongest since the end of the war. In some parts of the country the shortage of steel was so serious that gray market sales were running at top speed and the volume of conversion deals was expanding rapidly.

Activity in the wholesale markets last week was limited, with few buyers in town and mail comparatively light, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK times by leading resident buying offices.

A special service in observance of the twentieth anniversary of the organization of the congregation was held yesterday at St. Martin's Protestant Episcopal Church, Lenox Avenue and 122d Street. The Rev. Dr. Frederic S. Fleming, rector of Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, dedicated a new altar and reredos designed by Leslie H. Nobbs.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 26 -- It is the duty of Christians and Jews in the United States to make the Government recognize that it is to its own enlightened self-interest to support a Jewish state in Palestine, Dr. Carl Herman Voss told the annual convention of Hadassah, the woman's Zionist organization of America, here today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a letter to THE TIMES former Price Administrator Chester Bowles presents an argument on the problem of high prices in which he attempts to refute "several opinions * * * which I feel are in serious error." However, Mr. Bowles' analysis is based almost entirely on assumptions which mask accepted facts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 (U.P.) -- The Foreign Policy Association, a private research organization, said today that Korea was being driven toward communism by the "nondemocratic and often reactionary" methods of the Military Governments there and its Korean officials.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- The majestic Palace of Versailles near Paris emerged today as a likely meeting place for next year's United Nations General Assembly after several South American and Arab countries had joined a growing list of nations looking to Europe for the 1948 site.

Representatives of the city's largest milk companies insisted yesterday that today's cent-aquart increase in the cost of milk was' necessary, even though figures used in the course of negotiations that led to higher wages for 13,000 drivers and distribution plant workers Indicated that an increase of a half-cent would have been sufficient.

BERLIN, Oct. 26 -- Berlin will continue to be the headquarters of Gen. Lucius D. Clay regardless of the outcome of the London conference of Foreign Ministers, the Commander in Chief of the United States Army in Europe and the United States Military Governor for Germany, told the United Press in an exclusive interview today.

The Brooklyn Prep football team defeated Mount St. Michael on the latter's field in the Bronx yesterday, 12 to 7. The losers made the first score in the opening period, but Brooklyn Prep countered with a tally in the same frame and added another in the second to gain the triumph.

On Nov. 3, 1936, the people of New York City voted a new Charter replacing the 65-member Board of Aldermen with a much smaller City Council and, on a separate question, set up a system of Proportional Representation voting by boroughs to elect the members of that Council.

The National Better Business Bureau will advocate a nation-wide public education campaign to terminate "fictitious" radio trade-in allowances at a meeting of the merchandising committee of the Association of Better Business Bureaus to be held in a few weeks, Kenneth B. Willson, operating manager, disclosed in an interview over the week-end.

LOU LITTLE wore a grin which was so wide that it practically made a complete circumference of his head. "Oh, boy! Oh, boy!" he repeated dazedly. "Can you imagine that?" Physically he was in the Columbia dressing room, violently pinching himself to make sure he was awake. If the truth must be told, however, he wasn't there at all.

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Oct. 26 -- In' commemoration of the eightyninth birthday of Theodore Roosevelt tomorrow, representatives of President Truman, the Navy, the Fleet Reserve Association, the Naval Order of the United States and school children of this community placed wreaths at the hilltop grave of the late President at Young's Memorial Cemetery this morning.

YONKERS, N.Y., Oct. 26 -- Ted Vogel, Tufts College junior, established himself as an almost certain member of the American Olympic marathon team when he put on a Garrison finish in the final mile to overtake Tom Crane, Springfield College student, to win the National A.A.U. championship today.

The Miracle of Thirty-fourth Street is good entertainment of its kind, but it's way up north on 218th Street, in the Baker Field workshop, that they turn out the ultimate in blood and thunder melodrama. There the impossible becomes the prosaic, and excitement reaches such a frenzy that the constabulary join in the rush to uproot public property they are assigned to protect.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 -- Strong patrols continued on duty tonight in the 2,000 charred acres of woodland in the Falmouth area, where the last of the Massachusetts forest fires was brought under control just twenty-four hours ago.

Among the art events opening this week are two notable loan exhibitions scheduled as benefits. One is "Still-life from Chardin to Cezanne," at the Arnold Seligmann -Helft Gallery, to aid the Quaker Emergency Service. The other is of paintings and prints by Mary Cassatt, at the Wildenstein Galleries, for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 26 -- The beginning of the end of the 13months-old Hollywood studio strike came today when Motion Picture Painters Local 644, dominated by Herbert K. Sorrell, strike leader, voted to permit its members to seek work again in the studios.

Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander yesterday asked the public to reserve judgment on alleged assaults on civilians by policemen during recent weeks until a full investigation of each case is completed.

Speakers at the memorial ceremonies in the Central Park Sheep Meadow yesterday for the returning dead of World War II urged without exception the redemption of the pledge of a free and strong America implicit in their sacrifice. Those who spoke included Governor Dewey, Secretary of the Army Kenneth C. Royall, Mayor O'Dwyer and Vice Comdr. Albert A. Cree of the American Legion.
A ten-year plan to solve the present and future traffic needs of the Bronx was announced yesterday by Borough President James J. Lyons.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills remained in the thick of the fight for the AllAmerica Football Conference Eastern Division title today by thumping the hapless Brooklyn Dodgers, 35 -- 7, before 23,762 spectators in Civic Stadium.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Los Anglese Dons, operating with the greatest of ease behind their tremendous line, smothered the Baltimore Colts, 56 -- 0, before 27,000 All-America Football Conference fans today in Memorial Coliseum.

WINNIPEG, Oct. 26 (Canadian Press) -- Shipment of rye into Canada by United States farmers anxious to take advantage of the higher prices offered here could exceed its current estimated volume four times without adversely affecting Canadian farmers, grain officials close to the situation said here today.

OLEAN, N.Y., Oct. 26 (AP) -- The St. Louis University Billikens, coleaders of the Missouri Valley Conference and victors over Drake and Georgetown, got their lumps today from the Brown Indians of little St. Bonaventure -- a 47-13 pummeling before 9,200 fans in Forness Stadium.

drawer containing a movable backgammon set in matching wood, and also equipped with an unusually broad center leaf to extend it dining size. Her "Cloud" chest consists of two sections of four drawers each, separated by a center section of seven small drawers.

ALBANY, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Promotion of the principles of "tolerance, equality and fair play for all citizens" is vital to the well-being of the nation, Henry Epstein, former solicitor general of New York State, said today.

PORTLAND, Me., Oct. 26 -- Maine's disastrous forest fires, which have taken a toll of thirteen dead, made thousands homeless and affected nearly fourscore communities, were under check today for the first day in seven.

HALIFAX, Oct., 25 (Canadian Press)-Clouds of heavy smoke from forest fires in Maine and the Maritimes reached sixty miles to sea, Capt. G. E. Cove reported today when he brought the liner Aquitania into port. "There was certainly a strong smell of smoke," he said.
The Commerce and Industry Association of New York has forwarded to Mayor O'Dwyer a detailed plan for the erection of a permanent building to commemorate the city's Golden Jubilee next year.

The Phillips Petroleum Company, in its statement of operations covering the first nine months of this year, issued for publication today, disclosed a net profit of $25,706,157 after taxes and all charges including $2,500,000 provision for contingencies.
The Army transport Joseph V. Connolly came back to New York yesterday carrying 6,248 coffins lying row on row in her four holds.

A voice of fine potentialities was disclosed by Nota Camberos, Greek soprano, at her recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. It was a lyric voice, which, when best produced, was pure and sweet, with a velvety bloom on it, and it was employed with expressiveness and refinement of feeling.

LONDON, Oct. 26 -- The long process of acquainting the country with the serious economic position into which it has collapsed and with the steps that the Government is taking to meet and overcome the situation continued last week.

Central Park's expansive Sheep Meadow, which in past Sundays has been the scene of youthful boisterousness and cavorting, was transformed yesterday into a meeting place of cathedral solemnity as thousands attended the memorial service for the soldier dead just returned from Europe.

BOSTON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins, thanks to Joe Carveth's third period goal, gained a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight before 13,900 at the Boston Garden. It was the fourth straight National Hockey League setback for the visitors, who have been hampered by the loss of their star linesman, Bill Mosienko.

Thomas Paget Headland, English industrialist and distributor of engineering equipment, left New York last night to tour the Midwest manufacturing centers with a proposal to keep American trade names on dollarless foreign markets.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 26 -- Irgun Zvai Leumi, terrorist organization, warned Haganah, the Zionist underground militia, in a broadcast today that unless attacks on its members ceased there would be a fratricidal war "with all its horrors."

Widely circulated rumors of impending price rises in durable goods products are completely unfounded, New York industrial distributors revealed here over the week-end. D.C. Stagg Jr., an official of Patterson Brothers, 15 Park Row, declared that so far as that company is concerned, "I cannot see any large price increases impending and do not expect any price increases to speak about."

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 -- Grain prices on the Board of Trade turned downward late last week as the result of liquidation brought about by President Truman calling a special session of Congress, presumably to seek legislation to bring about lower prices on a long list of commodities.

ZURICH, Oct. 26 -- Last Thursday was described by leading bankers of Milan, Italy, as the "black day of the Bourse" in that city. It marked the culmination of a fight against inflation which had been waged inexorably for the last five months by the Budget Minister Luigi Einaudi, who is also governor of the Banca d'ltalia.
LONDON, Oct. 26 (AP) -- British newspapers commented caustically today on the United States House Committee on Un-American Activities and its Hollywood inquiry, which has been Page 1 news in Britain.

According to present schedule, the Russian propaganda resolution accusing the United States of "warmongering" is to come up for a vote in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today, and judging by the preliminary votes it is headed for a decisive defeat.
Several churches held services yesterday in honor of the war dead, and in others ministers referred to the war dead in their sermons.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Oct. 26 -- Civilian authorities, leading citizens and the Red Cross were emphatic today in their views that this famed town, one-fifth of it a pile of hulking ruins, will be reconstructed in the near future and regain its prominence as one of America's most beautiful summer resorts.

With the Democratic and Republican organizations of the five counties of this city committed to support of Proposition No. 4 to repeal the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council, proponents of PR will put on an intensive campaign this week in an attempt to offset this major party support and defeat the proposition.

NANKING, Oct. 26 -- For the first time China is assembling aircraft engines. The plant is near Kunming, wartime headquarters of the United States Fourteenth Air Force. Thirty-six 1,000-horsepower engines for C-47 transport planes have been produced.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Cleveland's Browns, sparked by the brilliant quarterbacking of Otto Graham, scored a 14-7 victory over the San Francisco 49ers today to tighten their grip on the lead of the western division of the All-America Conference.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 26 -- Kashmir, India's second largest Princely State, is in revolt, according to reports reaching here. A well-organized army of Moslems is said to be getting the best of a battle against the Maharajah's Hindu troops.

Citations for meritorious service were awarded to 208 members of the Police Department in general orders released yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander. Seven of the men were cited for conspicuous bravery, one posthumously.

Two years ago today, when the United States celebrated its first postwar Navy Day, our Navy was the greatest in the world, in number of ships, in personnel, in fire-power. It was not only the greatest; it was larger than the combined navies of all the rest of the world.
AMSTERDAM, Oct. 26 -- The Netherlands Indies economy continues to take first place in discussions in trade and financial circles.

CHICAGO, Oct. 26 (AP) -- Paul Christman's passing riddled Boston's defenses for three touchdowns as the Chicago Cardinals, co-leaders of the National Football League Western Division, trimmed the Yanks, 27 to 7, before 22,286 at Comiskey Park today.

Joseph Rabushka, 18-year-old, violinist from St. Louis, gave a recital last night in Carnegie Hall. When the talented musician made his debut in this city four years ago, he impressed by his musicality, but his tone was small, and his interpretations were still in the formative stage, as was natural for one of his years.

Oldest Inhabitant Status Our city scout is -- naturally -- concerned with anything that happens to Washington Square, and the prospect faced by the dwellers in the old houses on the south of it is the more interesting because New York University, which may place these good people in the category of displaced persons, is an older inhabitant of the Square than any of them.

To the editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES: According to your issue of Oct. 14, the New York Telephone Company is celebrating' the twenty-fifth anniversary of the opening of the first dial central office in your city. That was, then, in 1922. How progressive a city New York was -- in the estimation of New Yorkers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 26 -- The responsibility of the United States as a great world power entails the maintenance of ready forces to insure peace, President Truman said today in a Navy Day message.

The James J. Hoey Awards for Interracial Justice for 1947 were presented yesterday to Julian J. Reiss, former member of the New York State Commission Against Discrimination, and Clarence T. Hunter, president of the Catholic Interracial Council of St. Louis.

Americans are sometimes bewildered by the instability of French politics. But there is one district in France that seems as stable as a rock. It is the city of Lyons. There Edouard Herriot, one of the most respected elder statesmen of his country, has just been re-elected Mayor after thirtysix years of service in the same office.

The former Canadian Pacific liner Duchess of Bedford, being refitted after service in World War II, will rejoin the company's fleet in transatlantic service next summer, according to W.M. Neal, chairman and president of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company.

Seventy-five of the 100 economists polled in a recent survey by the F.W. Dodge Corporation, predicted a business recession beginning next spring, Thomas S. Holden, president of the fact-finding organization, announced yesterday.
Australia's extraordinary ambassadors -- three platypuses at the Bronx Zoo, Betty, Penelope and Cecil -- are swimming for cover. Winter is closing in and they can't take the low temperatures.

The home games of the championship New York Knickerbockers in the Basketball Association of America have been scheduled for broadcast by WHN for the second consecutive year. The team's first contest in the 1947-48 season of the professional league is slated for Nov. 13.

Additional information furnished to Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe in the $3,087,241 Martin Behrman seizure case included an affidavit by Prof. A. Arthur Schiller of Columbia University Law School in which the Netherlands Indies Government is classified as "merely a juristic person created in 1912 by Netherlands statute," it was disclosed yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, Oct. 26 -- A highly placed United States military authority here said today that the report of the North Korean Communist plans to att`ack South Korea in force after the withdrawal of the Soviet and United States Armies was correct.

Statements of policy by two leading sales finance companies, and a warning against relaxation of credit terms by Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, were issued yesterday in anticipation of the expiration on Saturday of Regulation W, the consumer credit control.

Printers throughout the nation are resentful of the action of paper merchants in reducing or eliminating discounts for prompt payment of bills, Donald L. Boyd, president of Printing Industry of America, Washington, D.C., emphasized last night.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 27 -- A group of ten University of Pennsylvania students carried out a thorough painting operation on the Princeton campus early this morning, splashing Red and Blue on ten university buildings and most of the campus sidewalks.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 27 -- Forty-one cities and towns in ten Southern states employ Negro policemen, according to a survey just made by the Besearch Department of the Southern Regional Council.

BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- As Maine's disaster refugees began streaming back to their devastated communities today, scores of forest fires, which had cost fifteen lives, $32,000,000 in damage and 110,000 acres of seared woodland, remained controlled up to a late hour tonight.

Government appropriations and private donations to the fight against cancer reached a record high of $31,000,000 in the last year but, "measured against the job that must be done, present private and Government funds are still inadequate."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Commenting upon early dispatches from the French municipal elections, THE NEW YORK TIMES on Oct. 21 appraised the result on an international plane as a defeat for Russian totalitarianism "and in that sense also a victory for the United States and the Marshall plan. * * *"
Notre Dame, still supposedly playing "under-wraps," has moved to the head of the class in the weekly Associated Press poll of football writers, supplanting stillunbeaten Michigan.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 27 -- Sikh troops of the Dominion of India who were flown to Kashmir early today are engaged on mountain battlefields against Afridi and Pathan tribesmen and Mohammedan insurgents who rose against the Hindu Government of the predominantly Moslem Princely State on Wednesday.

The run-off elections in the smaller French communities, where the old parties are more firmly entrenched and where local issues and personalities play a larger role, have helped the Socialists and Radical-Socialists to make a better showing than in the big cities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Preston T. Tucker, president of the Tucker Corporation, announced today he will exercise an option in his Government lease to buy the former Dodge-Chicago airplane engine plant, plus some machinery now at the plant, for approximately $40,000,000.

Substantial new orders, swelling the already-heavy backlog of manufacturers, were placed yesterday at the opening of the Office Equipment Dealers' convention at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. New lines of, desks, chairs, cabinets and standard equipment in office furniture were shown, with emphasis on new finishes, colors that avoid eyestrain, and desks that won't show cigarette burns.

Representatives of the yacht clubs of Europe and America gathered yesterday at the Royal Thames Club, Knightsbridge, London, to discuss, among other things, the proposed new racing rules, which have been tried out in this country the last year and which, when put into final form, it is hoped will be adopted universally.

Today Pan American World Airways celebrates its twentieth birthday. It is also the twentieth anniversary of scheduled overseas air service for passengers and mails. The occasion marks an extraordinary accomplishment in courageous and farsighted pioneering; a saga of the same texture, compressed into briefer compass, as that of the opening of the West and the conquest of world trade routes by American clipper ships of the surface sea.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- Undisturbed by political friction the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization has progressed toward restoring intellectual activity in war-devastated countries and in new educational projects, Dr. Julian Huxley, Director General, reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The serious foreign-policy issue, or "crisis," now before the American people is accompanied, as usual, by a sort of minor public-relations crisis at the State Department.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- The United Nations subcommittee charged with preparing a "packaged" plan for separate Jewish and Arab states in Palestine took up today the question of boundaries.

The Geneva meeting to draft a charter for the International Trade Organization has been successful "far beyond our hopes," Willard L. Thorp, assistant Secretary for Economic Affairs in the Department of State, asserted last night. Mr. Thorp spoke at a meeting sponsored by the League of Women Voters, at Hunter College Playhouse, Sixty-eighth Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The National Labor Relations Board, by a three-to-two vote, today set a precedent by ruling that in all cases filed under the Wagner Act the union must qualify for access to the board under the provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Hattie Carnegie presented yesterday, at 42 East Forty-ninth Street, her midwinter collection of hats and her first array of semiprecious jewels. Each model wore a piece of two of the jewelry and one of the new hats.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A Federal Power Commission examiner denied today a motion for dismissal of the application of Trans-Continental Gas Pipelines Company, Inc., to build a $150,000,000 natural gas pipeline from Texas to the East Coast.

BAR HARBOR, Me., Oct. 27 -- Electricity, water and fuel were back to normal today as the first contingent of 200 evacuees, a majority of them merchants and including a few women, returned here to get their establishments ready for business.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- If the present French, money inflation continues, all Government economic planning will be impossible, according to the draft of the first official report to be issued soon by the Monnet plan group.

BERLIN, Oct. 27 -- The United States is "embarking on a worldwide campaign to combat Communist propaganda, it was learned here today. Steps to implement this drive in Germany, considered one of the focal points in the conflict between democratic and totalitarian forces, already are being fashioned by Military Government authorities.
Acme Wire A common dividend of $1, payable on Nov. 15, was voted by the Acme Wire Company. The company paid 50 cents each in February, May and August.
KINGS LYNN, England, Oct. 26 (Delayed) -- One of the licensed retailers of milk in this ancient port and market town is a farmer who happens to be King George VI.

The General Electric Company reported yesterday that benefits lost to its employes through abolition of the concern's profit-sharing plan would be "far more than compensated for from the standpoint of regularity and total returns" by a new pension plan voluntarily put into effect by the General Electric management.

A number of new products to aid in building maintenance are on display at the first annual Building Maintenance Supplies Exposition, which opened yesterday at the Grand Central Palace. The show is open to building owners and managers and realty people.

TOKYO, Oct. 27 -- Suzuki San, the ordinary Japanese citizen, busily canvassed today the official figures of the new supplementary national budget finally released by the Government last night for enactment by the Diet. He sought to find out who will pay for the cost of running Japan for the balance of 1947.
The sixth edition of "Fashions of the Times," the fashion production sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, which opens today and will continue through Friday, has an international aspect.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 27 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced that registration statements covering 1,290,000 shares of common stock were filed with it today by four companies.
Upholding the principle of local autonomy, the Medical Society of the County of New York refused, after a heated debate last night, to condemn county societies that exclude Negroes from membership.

Money Market Firmer Federal funds were firmer yesterday, with quotations at fifteensixteenths to 1 per cent. The New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System, which had excess reserves on Wednesday night of $115,000,000, found this surplus reduced to a deficit of $86,000,000 on Thursday, it was disclosed.
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Charles de Gaulle brought the crisis of the French Republic to a climax today by calling for a national election through dissolution of the Assembly "as soon as possible."

Thousands of United States citizens caught by the war in Poland have received little consideration from the Russians and many have been forced to work in coal mines, Frank Sielski, a former employe of the Hudson Motor Car Company, charged yesterday on his arrival, here on the liner Ernie Pyle.

WARSAW, Oct. 27 -- Polish authorities said tonight that they had been informed that the Peasant party leader, Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, and his party of seven had reached Sweden after fleeing across the Baltic in a small boat, and were preparing to go from Stockholm to London.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- As part of his program to broaden public understanding of the Administration's foreign policy President Truman revived today a wartime technique and held a seminar for more than a hundred leaders in various fields of national life.
Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, former Polish Deputy Premier, expected to be murdered, he told this writer only a short while before he fled Warsaw, where he was leader of the Opposition Peasant party.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 27 -- President Edouard Benes, in the first volume of his memoirs issued today, prophesied a possible second Munich in "an entirely new form, and then a new catastrophe," if East and West continue to disagree violently.

'Dress-of-Month' Tested The "Dress-of-the-Month Club," new Chicago organization which has been running test copy in that city, has tentatively scheduled a similar campaign soon for newspaper supplements in the New York area, it was learned here yesterday.

The stock market yesterday again turned indecisive, with some firmness exhibited by the steel shares but a general leaning to the lower side. Price changes were small except for a few issues and the composite rate showed a slight advance due to gains registered in some of the high-price stocks.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Oct. 27 -- The first week's results of the "Greenfield experiment'' in brand names promotion are now known, and sales are up 30 to 100 per cent or more in many stores cooperating in the county-wide joint merchandising program of manufacturers, distributors and dealers here.

The past week-end, although it was a wasted one for most of the waterfowl hunters, provided some pleasant surprises for a number of surfcasters in Rhode Island and at Montauk Point, where lower water temperatures brought striped bass inshore.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 27 (AP) -- A midshipman is being held under restriction at the Naval Academy pending investigation of possible "scalping" of tickets for Navy football games, an academy spokesman disclosed today.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- The Labor Government must curb the powers of the House of Lords now or "be at the mercy of their Lordships" for the rest of this Parliament, Herbert Morrison, Lord President of the Council, said tonight in a speech to his constituents at Lewisham, London.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- On the ground that Southeastern railroads and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen have not obeyed the 1944 decisions of the Supreme Court, twenty-two Negro locomotive firemen today filed suit in the Federal Court for the District of Columbia seeking reinstatement and damages.
Chicago "Sanitary District, Illinois, will receive bids Nov. 6 on $10,000,000 of construction bonds dated Dec. 1, 1947, due Jan. 1, 1967, and callable Jan. 1 from 1950 to 1966.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Leon Henderson, former head of the Office of Price Administration, tonight attacked the present Congress and declared that, to prevent another war, "Congress must be told that the American people will not stand for its isolationism."

Dry and unseasonably warm weather continued yesterday and for the fifth day in the last eight a heat record was broken. After hovering at 75 degrees for more than an hour, the temperature moved up to 76 at 2:20 P.M. The previous high for Oct. 27 was 74.1 degrees set a year ago.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The announcement of the revival of the Comintern calls for the creation of a Democrintern: The Comintern seeks by concerted efforts to strengthen communism throughout the world by means of false propaganda and promotion of political, social and economic chaos.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Civil aviation in this country has a good future, subject only to the hazards of general economic conditions, in the view of the Civil Aeronautics Board as expressed today in a report to the President's Aviation Policy Commission.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Oct. 27 (AP) -- A story of death threats by Georgia prison camp guards before eight Negro convicts were shot to death in an outbreak July 11 at the Glynn County convict camp was given to a Federal jury here today.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 27 -- Following a virtual threat of civil war by Irgun Zvai Leumi, terrorist band, Hagannah, Zionist underground militia, said today that it would not be intimidated by anything Irgun Zvai Leumi said or did. "We will not retreat before threats or the use of arms, and every single act of violence will be punished," Haganah said.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- In seeking from the United Nations an indirect condemnation of the Truman Doctrine, Yugoslavia, championed by the Soviet Union, drew today from the United States a spirited defense of its foreign aid policy, particularly as applied in Greece.

The concerts of the New Friends of Music are to be broadcast this season exclusively over frequency modulation station WABF, it was announced yesterday by Ira A. Hirschmann, president of the station and founder and president of the New Friends.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -- Frederick Ullman Jr., RKO producer, and Ted Tetzlaff, director, left today by train for New York to prepare for filming RKO's "The Window" at the Pathe Studios there.

The New York Yankees of the All-America Football Conference, who will have the local field to themselves when they engage the Baltimore Colts at the Stadium Sunday, started preparations for the contest yesterday. Coach Ray Flaherty, immensely pleased with the manner in which his charges defeated the Chicago Rockets last week, called it "our best game."

EVER since the publication of "The Case of Sergeant Grischa" in 1927 it has been apparent to readers the world over that Arnold Zweig is one of the ablest of living German novelists. Since then, whether in pre-Hitler Germany or in exile in Palestine, Mr. Zweig has continued to produce a series of ambitious and intellectually solid novels.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 27 (AP) -- Ocean Brief, consistent daughter of Roman and Miss Brief, kept up her winning ways today when she won the Diplomat Purse at six furlongs, sixth and featured race, to register her fourth straight victory.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The Association of the Bar of the City of New York has, by its "endorsement" of Justice J. Edward Lumbard Jr., enormously weakened its influence with regard to the election of nominees for the judiciary and has done a large disservice both to the electorate and to its own prestige.

VIENNA, Oct. 27 -- Russia and her allies are practicing a new technique to further the growth of Communist parties in other countries. It is to deal in certain international matters with the chiefs of those Communist parties, rather than with the elected heads of governments themselves.

Reflecting increased production and sales, the Studebaker Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $5,152,043 in the nine months ended with last September, in contrast to a net loss of $251,770 after giving effect to a tax credit of' $9,951,000, for the first nine months of 1946.

The second anniversary of the Uptown Center of the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, Inc., was celebrated yesterday with a luncheon at the Hotel Concourse Plaza, Grand Concourse at East 161st Street.

Tuesday, Oct. 28, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Rejected a Soviet "warmonger" resolution and unanimously adopted a measure calling on member nations to use available means of publicity to promote friendly relations based on the purposes and principles of the Charter.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your excellent editorial of Oct. 20 with reference to the canker stain disease of plane trees and the news item which prompted the editorial give the impression that the discovery of this menace has been made quite recently and that the spread of the disease is a new development.
PARIS, Oct. 27 -- The nine-party Communist Information Bureau, formed recently in Poland, is open to any Communist party in the world, the French party secretary, Jacques Duclos, said tonight.

Ossy Renardy had his violin with him in the Army. He is said to have played more than 400 concerts for his fellow soldiers, and at times he played in jazz orchestras. His recital last night at Carnegie Hall before an audience of almost 2,000 showed that he also must have frequently played for himself alone, refreshing his spirit in communion with the master composers.

Low-end dress manufacturers have virtually abandoned lower price numbers in their litres for spring, according to a survey of the Seventh Avenue market yesterday. With few exceptions, the new lines will contain dresses selling at $5.75 and upward at wholesale.

An underwriting group headed by Reynolds Co. will place on the market today issues of common stock and $25 par value convertible preferred stock of RobertshawFulton Controls Company, manufacturer of devices for the automatic regulation of temperatures and pressures, and a subsidiary of Reynolds Metals Company.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 27 -- What some local observers interpreted as "the beginning of the end" of the thirteen-month jurisdictional strike in the major motion picture studios came today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Oct. 27 -- Al Ciuci of Fresh Meadow, president and tournament chairman of the Long Island P.G.A., finished the season with one of his rare appearances and took top honors in the pro-amateur best ball event over the Garden City Country Club course today.

The greatest art loan on record from the French Government is scheduled to arrive in New York on Saturday aboard the French cruiser Georges Leygues for exhibition in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The heavily insured and irreplaceable cargo contains 200 tapestries dating from the fourteenth century to the present day.

BERLIN, Oct. 27 -- The United States and British Governments finally announced today approval of the agreement on Ruhr coat production reached seven weeks ago in Washington. It provides for German operation under Western Allied supervision.

Store Sales Herb Up 36% Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week were 36 per cent higher than the corresponding period last year, according to the report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- The grain markets on the Board of Trade has rallied sharply after early weekness today, with wheat closing 1/2 cent a bushel lower to 1/2 cent higher and December up over 4 cents from the day's low. Corn was 1/4 cent higher to 3/4 cent lower and oats 1/4 cent higher to 1/4 cent lower.

Vera Appleton and Michael Field, a first class duo-piano team, exhibited some remarkable, performing and seemed to enjoy themselves in their fifth annual Town Hall concert last night. The program featured the first performance of Norman Dello Joio's "Duo Concertante."

An even 250 entries have been received for the children's competition to be held on the matinee of Saturday, Nov. 8, at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden. The show runs Nov. 4 through 11 and the intervening Saturday traditionally contains the children's matinee, always highlighted by the championships in equitation and jumping.
The Port of New York Authority announced yesterday an outline of the survey of the New York waterfront that it began last week at the request of Mayor O'Dwyer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- A ten-member advisory council was created today to consult with the Citizens Food Committee on information on meal planning and food conservation.

Long known to tourists as "The Switzerland of the East," Kashmir, the second largest princely state of India, is in serious trouble because of political rivalry between the two new nations of the Indian Union and Pakistan. Yesterday the Kashmir government put itself under the protection of the Union, but this may not be the end of the story.

To judge by the large audience at Abba Bogin's piano recital at Town Hall yesterday afternoon, many people put their trust in the Naumburg Foundation's ability to select young, musicians of talent. And to judge by the pianist's performance, they are more than justified.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- The United States plan for a "Little Assembly" won its first major test in the United Nations today when a subcommittee voted, 8 to 3, to give the proposed interim committee full power to take up any dispute submited to the General Assembly.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 27 -- The temperature today reached the freezing point in Bucharest for the first time this season, but the Government clung to its decision forbidding the use of fuel oil, natural gas or coal for heating private homes or apartment houses anywhere in Rumania.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- In Nebraska, the only state with a unicameral Legislature, another political innovation is afloat, its purpose being to give to "the popular Presidential primary some of the significance originally intended." A state-wide bipartisan committee has been formed to put the names of all those importantly mentioned for the Presidency on the ballot which will be handed to Nebraska voters April 13, 1948.

JUNEAU, Alaska, Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Coast Guard rushed three boats to a spot between Mary Island and Annette Island today on the possibility that an oil slick reported there might be a clue to the Pan American World Airways clipper plane missing since Sunday with eighteen on board.

SYDNEY, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Australia's horse trainers are sharpening up their thoroughbreds for the classic two-mile Melbourne Cup race, this nation's top turf event. First place will be worth $22,680 and second $6,480.

Daphne Du Maurier, British author of the best-selling novel "Rebecca," took the witness stand in Federal Court yesterday to defend herself against charges that she stole the plot for the book from two little-known works of the late Edwina DeVin MacDonald.

Eleven new woodland fires flared yesterday in Westchester suburban communities as southeastern New York registered its thirty-second day without general rains. However, heavy dew and lack of wind checked the spread of other longburning fires in the state.

NANKING, China, Tuesday, Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- The Democratic League, a coalition of leftist minority parties, has been outlawed for "abetting the Communist rebellion against the Government," an Interior Ministry spokesman announced today.

A three-man emergency board, appointed by President Truman, began a hearing yesterday in the dispute between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, and the Railway Express Agency, Inc., that tied up deliveries in the metropolitan area for twenty-five days in the last month.

With Rose Bampton as the soprano soloist and Leonard Bernstein conducting, the New York City Symphony gave an incandescent, unforgettable performance of three fragments from Alban Berg's "Wozzeck" at the City Center last night.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Following is the statement issued in Paris today by Charles de Gaulle: In the face of dangers that threaten France from within and without, the nation has just shown in what direction it is turning.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 27 (AP) -- The British Ryder Cup golf team stepped off the train here today, ate a quick lunch and then -- without even a practice shot -- set right out to solve the Portland Golf Club course.

While the Columbia campus still buzzed with emotional after effects following forty-eight hours of wild celebration and while Lou Little's football squad took an unusually light workout at Baker Field as a reward for its upset victory over Army, cold statistics, released yesterday by the athletic office, revealed that the Lions broke several all-time Columbia records as well as Army's defeatless string Saturday.

For outstanding contributions in fields of endeavor in which the late President Theodore Roosevelt was interested keenly, Roosevelt Distinguished Service Medals were presented last night to Gen. Omar N. Bradley, Veterans Administrator; Judge Learned Hand of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals; Jeremiah Milbank, industrialist and philanthropist, and Arthur Hays Sulzberger, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES.
LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Millions of pounds were lopped off values of gold mining shares in the stock markets here today, following sensational disclosures regarding the position of New Union Goldfields.

Roy Conacher, 31-year-old topscoring left winger in the National Hockey League last season, who was acquired by the New York Rangers last Thursday in a player deal with the Detroit Red Wings, has decided to retire from the game, Manager Frank Boucher announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 27 -- Conservation of food by the serving of meals that save grain yet please palates and spare pocketbooks is the keynote of the fourth annual Newspaper Food Editors Conference, which opened today for a five-day session, in this center of fine Creole cookery.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Shoe retailers were warned today that higher prices, which are in prospect, will mean declining unit volume, but at the same time they were urged to maintain inventories by ordering more frequently.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Britain will withdraw all her troops in Burma but will receive exclusive rights to maintain a joint military mission there, according to the terms of the British-Burmese treaty signed Oct. 17 and made public today here and in Rangoon.

Robert Moses picked out yesterday what he termed two major laws in the system of proportional representation now used in electing City Councilmen. A proposition for repeal of PR is to be voted on at the election a week from today.

The Middle West moves to the center of the football stage this week with the South and Southwest breaking into the act on the wings. After the excitement of Baker Field a lull falls upon the East though there is the prospect of one of the pitching duels of the season between Gene Rossides of Columbia and Lynn Dorset of Cornell in Schoellkopf Crescent at Ithaca.

The Army transport Joseph V. Connolly completed her long voyage home with the war dead from Europe yesterday, tying up at the Army's New York Port of Embarkation in Brooklyn a day after the city's memorial exercises in Central Park.

Establishment of a peacetime adaptation of the educational provisions of the GI Bill of Rights, offering to every citizen education "to the limit of his ambition and capacity," was suggested yesterday by Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of New York University, in his annual report to the University Council.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Continued British opposition to Soviet claims to reparations from current German production was emphasized tonight by Foreign Secretary Bevin, making another stalemate in the Council of Foreign Ministers probable, if not inevitable.

Columbia's stunning upset of Army last Saturday was merited, Lou Little told the Football Writers Association at its weekly luncheon-meeting at Toots Shor's yesterday. Bill Swiacki's catching of Gene Rossides' passes "swung the balance our way," he said, but it was easy to detect in the coach's tone a feeling of relief that his Lions do not meet the cadets again this season.

An executive of the New York Life Insurance Company and an employe of the General Aniline and Film Corporation celebrated yesterday their fiftieth anniversaries with their companies. Both men started as office boys.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities, ruling that John Howard Lawson, screen writer, had refused to answer whether he belonged to the Communist party, moved today to bring a citation of being in contempt of Congress against him.

PARIS, Oct. 27 -- Russian blouses play quite a part in Molyneux's midseason showing. About finger tip in length, their fullness is held into the waistline by a narrow leather belt. In smooth woolens they match a slim or sparsely gathered skirt, although there is one for the cocktail hour in gold lame over a black skirt.

For Thy Sake, Tobacco Hezekiah Cobb, relaxing after a good day out with the hounds, remarks that Sir Stafford Cripps, in cutting off American tobacco from the English, has removed one of the ties that have bound the two nations together since, in the course of human events, they ceased to be one in 1776.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- The Republic of Indonesia appealed again today for United Nations arbitration to settle its dispute with the Netherlands and end the warfare in the East Indies.

The price of milk went up yesterday one cent a quart, the second such increase this month, and the two top grades of butter advanced a quarter of a cent a pound at wholesale. Meat prices, however, were one to three cents a pound below the levels of last week in some stores as consumer buying continued light.
ATHENS, Oct. 27 -- Forty-five person's, including two Americans, were killed in a crash of a Swedish airliner on Mount Hymettos, outside Athens, during a thunderstorm last night.

CHICAGO, Oct. 27 -- Two Chicago morning newspapers experienced production difficulties tonight as a result of slowdown tactics by members of Local 16 of the Chicago Typographical Union, whose negotiations for renewal of a work contract reached a deadlock last week.

Expansion and improvement of the Sunday issue of the country's newspapers was urged yesterday by Carl W. Ackerman, dean of Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism. He welcomed seventeen newspaper men attending the opening session of a three-weeks seminar for Sunday editors and feature editors given by Columbia's American Press Institute.

BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- The Attorneys General of a number of states disputed here today the assertion of Tom C. Clark, United States Attorney General, that the Supreme Court's decision in the California tidelands case did not transfer dominion over harbors and inland tidal waters from the states to the Federal Government.

new home has been found for the once-displaced Experimental Theatre, which operates under the guidance of the American National Theatre and Academy. It is the Maxine Elliott Theatre, on Thirtyninth Street, used for years as a broadcasting studio.

The report presented yesterday in Washington to the International Emergency Food Council by Secretary General D.A. FitzGerald was not, and could not properly be, directed at the United States Congress. Nevertheless, Congress will do well to pay minute attention to it.

GENEVA, Oct. 27 -- The administration of the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization was subjected today to a barrage of criticism from several governmental representatives for proposing to exceed its previously agreed budget.
