The suggestion that future immigrants from Puerto Rico bear letters of recommendation and "perhaps cards from the police" was made yesterday by Fernando Sierra Berdecia, Commissioner of Labor for the Government of Puerto Rico.

Elimination of lumber export controls or any further increase in export allocations by the Office of Export Controls of the Department of Commerce would within a short time cause a serious domestic lumber shortage in grades used in home construction, Norman P. Mason, president of the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association, declared in an interview yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 27 -- The Soviet resolution calling for the punishment of "warmongers" as criminals was rejected overwhelmingly today by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, Instead, the committee approved, 56 to 0, a resolution condemning all forms of propaganda in any country that might encourage a threat to the peace or an act of aggression.

Gino Buonvino, Italian heavyweight champion from Bari, gained his most impressive victory since coming to this country when he took the unanimous ten-round decision over Jimmy Carollo of Corona last night in the feature bout at the St. Nicholas Arena before 2,710 spectators.

Tenants who rent parts of their apartments to one or two persons do not violate obligations of their tenancy in ordinary cases, according to rulings of the City Rent Commission under the Sharkey eviction control laws. This was emphasized yesterday by Paul L. Ross, chairman of the commission, in comment on the case of a Brooklyn woman who had let one room in her four-room apartment to a veteran and his wife.

One objective of Charles de Gaulle's Reunion of the French People is the establishment of a system of capital-labor "associations" under which political parties would not be "permitted to interfere" in the affairs of labor unions.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 27 -- Because, in the opinion of certified auditors "some transactions in the company's books require an explanation," the Supreme Court in Johannesburg granted today a rule to be argued on Nov. 18 to place New Union Goldfields under judicial management.

SALES, N.H., Oct. 27 (AP) -- The Kenmore Stable's veteran sprinter Hy-Charlie took command at the stretch turn to win the $3,000 Lebanon Claiming Purse before a crowd of 6,907 today at Rockingham Park.

The regional office of the National Labor Relations Board announced yesterday that the first "decertification" election to be held in this area under the TaftHartley Law had been scheduled for Monday among seventy-four employes of the Staples-Smith Display Company at 166 Smith Street, Brooklyn.

SANTA FE, N.M., Oct. 17 (AP) -- The crushed bodies of two Los Alamos atomic energy project secretaries, killed while on a weekend mountain climbing trip, were found today at the bottom, of a ravine below an icy slope on 13,275foot North Truchas Peak.
Reflecting a strong spot situation in the South, prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange gained 14 to 29 points net yesterday.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Oct. 27 -- Dual battles of ideas, internationalism against isolationism and a continued strong Government hand in agriculture against a wish to retrench toward lower Federal price pegs, are swaying indecisively across the Corn Belt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- The thirty-five nation International Emergency Food Council delayed today its dissolution into the new eighteen-nation Food and Agriculture Organization World Food Council in view of the gravity of the current world food crisis.

Our Tommy gave his followers a thrill in winning the Continental Handicap, the feature race on the Metropolitan Jockey Club's program at Jamaica yesterday. Under an excellent ride by Jockey Conn McCreary, the 3-year-old son of Sir Lancelot came through with a rush in the stretch to take the major share of the purse by the matter of four lengths over E.P. Taylor's Windfields.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Karl Anderson, an official of the State Department, told Senators today that a decision to export steel for a trans-Arabian oil pipeline was a "wise thing" despite the shortage of steel in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Through a short decree, the Supreme Court today made effective its decision of last June that the Federal Government has paramount right to the valuable oil lands in the marginal sea off the California coast.
Keep America strong, speakers urged yesterday at city observances of the twenty-sixth annual Navy Day. In addition to tributes to the Navy, various programs stressed the service's role in peacetime.

NANKING, Oct. 27 -- The United States and China signed today an agreement giving Americans wide supervisory powers over the distribution of China's $30,000,000 share of the $350,000,000 postUNRRA appropriation.

LONDON, Oct. 27 -- Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten, who will be married Nov. 20, will divide their wedding trip between the new forest in Hampshire and the Highlands of Scotland, it was announced from Buckingham Palace tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- Lieut. Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, commanding general of the Second Army, will become director of plans and operations in the Army General Staff, the Army Department announced today.

The Conservative party victory in municipal elections in Norway Oct. 20 was interpreted here yesterday by Carl Joachim Hambro, former president of the Norwegian Parliament, as a popular demonstration on the part of the people against Governmental control of the financial and business life of the country.

Welfare Commissioner Benjamin Fielding said yesterday that he would eliminate pressure groups of all kinds from the city's $142,000,000 relief administration. The statement was made as he began revising the Department of Welfare on his first full day as its new head.

BOSTON, Oct. 27 -- The entire Marshall plan of aid to Europe will be placed before Congress when it meets in special session Nov. 17 and "possibly" will be approved by Dec. 19, when Congress may be expected to adjourn for the Christmas holidays, Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican leader in the Senate, predicted here today.

A "tough situation" that cannot be ignored exists in the city's general hospitals, Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday in making public a letter from Dr. Edward Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals. The letter declared that "desperate overcrowding" is prevalent in the department's hospitals, most of which are operating at above 100 per cent normal capacity.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 27 -- Although plans for formal picketing had been abandoned, a group of individuals organized a mass demonstration tonight in front of the Jersey City State Teachers College where Dr. Frank Kingdon announced to a rally of 1,500 persons his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New Jersey in 1948.
Fashion's spectacular turn to romanticism received the top headline yesterday at the premiere of the sixth edition of "Fashions of the Times."

Random notes. A bonefish scaling 4 1/2 pounds supplies plenty of excitement, but if taken at Bimini or the Florida Keys is nothing to get excited about. The same fish, taken in New York waters, is another story.

VIENNA, Oct. 28 -- Execution of the Marshall plan should be supervised by a sort of international Reconstruction Finance Corporation on which the United States would be represented, according to Senators Styles Bridges and Wayland C. Brooks of the Senate Appropriations Committee.
The Statue of Liberty, symbol to many millions of their entrance into a new world of freedom, celebrated its sixty-first birthday yesterday.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Late in 1941 representatives of the United States Government in the Philippines assured American citizen groups residing and working there that no cause for alarm existed, hence no necessity for evacuation. The reason subsequently given was that a wholesale evacuation by American citizens would alarm and cause panic among the Filipinos.

By a vote of 102 to 19, the National Republican Club adopted last night a majority report of its committee on city affairs, advocating the repeal of proportional representation at Tuesday's election. The report, adopted at a meeting at 54 West Fortieth Street, condemned the system as expensive, as fostering Communist representation, and a City Council that "has been an ineffective debating society which devotes its time to many extraneous matters."
The sixth annual Brooklyn-Long Island Cat Show opened its two-day exhibition yesterday at the Hotel Granada in Brooklyn.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Great Britain will surrender to Yugoslavia all nationals of that country that she now holds if Marshal Tito's Government has established a prima facie face of active and willful collaboration with the Axis against them.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Began general discussion of question of independence of Korea, presented by United States, and heard Soviet Union, Australia, China, the Ukraine, Yugoslavia and Britain.

ROME, Oct. 28 -- Guglielmo Giannini today resigned the presidency of the Common Man Front, which he had founded. His flirtations with communism and his hostility toward Premier Aicide de Gasperi's government brought him into conflict with a majority of his party and with most of its Deputies in the Constituent Assembly.

By a 5-to-2 vote, the Board of Education defeated yesterday a resolution that would have barred the Communist party, the American Youth for Democracy and Nazi or Fascist groups from using public school buildings as meeting places.

"Fashions of the Times," seen in its sixth edition last night in Times Hall, provided the audience with a preview of coming cruise and spring fashions. Based on the theme of a dream sequence of a fashion director of a large store who, in her fantasy, was preparing a fashion show, the pageant unfolded the panorama of trends as leading New York designers have developed them.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Robert E. Cantwell Sr., criminal attorney who defended 500 persons accused of murder before he retired in 1929, died at his home in near-by Oak Park yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. His age was 77.

Communist Councilman Benjamin Davis of Manhattan blocked immediate consideration in the City Council yesterday of a resolution urging New York City members of Congress to approve the Marshall plan as requested by President Truman, at the forthcoming special session.

The dramatic finale of "Fashions of the Times" was devoted to a new color theme -- Amberlight. As indicated by the name, the color is in the range of the various tonal intensities of the mineral. Four shades were stressed. They represented the palest golden yellow, a deeper shade of gold, a reddish orange and the shadowy brown of the depths of amber.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 28 -- The Swedish Government is reducing paper cellulose exports to the Continent by 50 per cent from Nov. 1 with the idea of selling more of the product to the United States to obtain more sorely needed dollars.
Directors of the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau approved yesterday a resolution calling for immediate construction of a convention auditorium and exhibition hall for the city.

Damage suits amounting to $116,000 have been filed in Federal Court, Southern District, by three ship lines against three locals of the International Longshoremen's Association, AFL, under the Taft-Hartley Act, it was learned yesterday.
While Willie Howard, veteran comedian, made hundreds laugh last night at the Latin Quarter, night club at Broadway and Fortyeighth Street, tragedy awaited him off stage.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Gen. Alexander A. Vandegrift, commandant of the Marine Corps, announced today that he had asked to be retired from active duty Jan. 1.

The undergraduate bodies of two New York University Colleges have, through their student councils, officially requested that Prof. Lyman R. Bradley be reinstated as chairman of the Department of German at the Washington Square College, it was reported yesterday.

Christmas Club funds to be distributed by the nation's mutual savings banks within the next few weeks will total $25,000,000 more than a year ago, mounting to the record figure of $149,230,789, it was reported yesterday.

Fear of state medicine, local jealousies and prejudices between medical groups, and "violent dislike and distrust toward governmental activity in cancer research and control" were listed last night at the annual dinner meeting of the American Cancer Society at the Hotel Commodore as three among ten obstacles to further progress in cancer control.

Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of City College, announced yesterday that a special faculty board would meet Friday to investigate charges of racial segregation in the college's Army Hall dormitory. Army Hall is the former Hebrew Orphan Asylum at 138th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, now used by students of City College, New York University, Fordham and Columbia.

With Miss Virginia Leigh as Chairman, a debutante committee has been organized to assist with plans for the Metropolitan Opera Guild's pre-season performance of "Don Giovanni" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Nov. 7. The special performance has been arranged under the auspices of the Guild to advance its project of raising $100,000 for a complete new production of the "Ring" cycle of Wagner's operas.

GALION, Ohio, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The House Committee on Education and Labor took action today in the dispute at the plant of the North Electric Company here. It announced a hearing for Thursday morning and two committee members indicated that they would investigate the strike situation starting tomorrow.

The classes for hunters at the National Horse Show, which will move into Madison Square Garden next Tuesday, not only will contain much of the event's quality but the greatest number of entries. An announcement yesterday said that the hunter division had drawn 117 horses for an entry of 540, topping last year's nominations of 455.
Losing all the early gains, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange ran into stop-loss orders yesterday and closed 7 to 27 points net lower.

BOSTON, Oct. 28 -- High wages are producing a demand for products greater than American industry can supply, and this has "inevitably forced a rapid increase in prices," Senator Robert A. Taft declared in a speech here tonight in which he called for "holding both wages and prices down except when increases are absolutely necessary."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: As the Ambassador representing the United States in France during one of M. Herriot's Premierships, I was delighted with the well-merited recognition accorded him in your editorial "A French Elder Statesman."

The concern that Coach Lou Little has expressed about Columbia's ability to stop twice-beaten Cornell right after ending the three-and-a-half-year unbeaten record of Army, was reflected in yesterday's scrimmage at Baker Field.

GENEVA, Oct. 28 -- Expressing concern at the trend of discussions in the current meeting of the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization, Joel H. Fisher, general counselor of the American Joint Distribution Committee, warned today that voluntary relief agencies could not be expected to relieve the IRO of its basic responsibilties.

A sharp rise in dealers' prices of good machine tools is inevitable, the Machinery Dealers National Association was told yesterday by Louis Botwinik, of Botwinik Bros., New Haven, Conn. There is going to be very little desirable, standard, general purpose equipment available, Mr. Botwinik, who was acting chairman for the industry affairs committee of MDNA, said in an address at the semi-annual regional meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was indeed very much surprised at the statement on PR attributed to Robert Moses as reported in your edition of Oct. 19. "There is no answer to all this but the old geographical representation on the basic principle that a man's neighbors know him best."
All the glitter that is Broadway marked ceremonies yesterday when the Pepsi-Cola Center at Forty-seventh Street and Duffy Square was turned over to the people of the city.

Two children thrown from a smoke-filled building twenty feet to the ground were unharmed yesterday because Mrs. Marie Kendall, the wife of Patrolman Walter Kendall of the 17th Inspection Division, had listened intently to the stories her husband told of his work and applied the principles of rescue she learned from them.

In a short time the public will be asked to contribute to a permanent fund urgently needed by the National Probation Association, 1790 Broadway, New York 19, to carry on its effective work of strengthening juvenile courts, promoting probation and combating juvenile delinquency.

RYE, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- The English field hockey team romped to the fifth straight success of its United States tour by defeating the Stuyvesant Field Hockey Association, 12 to 2, on Rye Country Day School's turf today. A crowd of about 2,000, mainly schoolgirls from Westchester and Connecticut, transported in special buses, watched the match.

J.C. Evans, former chief engineer of the Port of New York Authority, has been promoted to the post of chairman of a newly established board of five engineers who will advise the bi-state agency on its engineering responsibilities in its pending terminal construction program, it was announced yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- Registration statements covering 771,000 shares of stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by five companies.

BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, disclosed at a press conference today that he had asked the Department of the Army to permit him to retire "some time during the next calendar year." He emphasized that he expected to remain at his job here for a substantial time to come.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The call for an improvement in the methods of Congressional investigating committees is now coming from groups and individuals who showed no concern on previous occasions when inquisitors from Capitol Hill were abusing witnesses, flagrantly disregarding private rights and tearing up the Constitution.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Goldman, Sachs Co.; Kidder, Peabody Co. and Piper, Jaffray Hopwood will place on the market today $20,000,000 of new debentures and preferred stock of the Minneosta Mining and Manufacturing Company, maker of "Scotch tape," coated abrasives and other products.

LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Bear covering by the Cape and London brought about late today a sharp recovery from yesterday's break in all gold mining shares on the stock markets here. Prices fluctuated widely at the opening, but covering was sufficient for many shares to close with modest gains in the day.

There was a surprising air of joviality around the Polo Grounds press room yesterday, where Coach Steve Owen, his aides and a group of scribes had gathered for lunch after the Giants had their workout.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Senator Homer Ferguson, Republican, of Michigan, said today that public hearings of the Senate War Investigating Committee dealing with the $40,000,000 in Government airplane contracts with Howard Hughes would be resumed Monday.

Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, general secretary of the National Conference of Christians and Jews, announced yesterday election of Charles E. Wilson, president of the General Electric Company, as Protestant co-chairman of the conference.

A program of action for the coming year for the American women's division of the Organization for Rehabilitation Through Training was outlined yesterday by the organization's president Mrs. Maurice Finkelstein, at luncheon in the Hotel Commodore marking the twentieth anniversary of the founding of the group.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- There was a lack of selling pressure in the grain markets on the Board of Trade today and it took but moderate buying to start prices on the upgrade, with the highest level reached near the close. Final prices on wheat were up 3 to 5 cents above yesterday's close.
CHICAGO, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (AP)-- A Congressman recently returned from Europe today charged Communists with sixty-three "incidents of armed aggression" resulting in many casualties to United States forces in the Trieste area.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Maintenance of an economic system "operating at high and rising levels of production" is more important to small business than any form of special tax concession, the Treasury Department stated today.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 28 -- The second day of the fourth annual Newspaper Food Editors Conference, which is to end Friday, was a full one for the seventy-three women who came to the Crescent City from publications all over the country.

Devil's Island, France's penological pesthole for almost a century where thousands of prisoners paid for their crimes in the rain and heat, was a paradise compared to present day French jails, Salvation Army Brigadier Charles Pean said yesterday.

LONDON, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Bookmakers will lose a pile of pounds -- on top of the weight they've already lost worrying -- if one of the favorites wins the mile and a furlong Cambridgeshire Handicap tomorrow at Newmarket.

Branch Rickey, president of the Dodgers, and Leo Durocher, the 1946 manager whose one-year suspension by Commissioner Albert B. (Happy) Chandler ended with the world series, met in the Brooklyn club's Montague Street offices yesterday -- but nothing happened.

Big If, a 2-year-old who cost Mrs. J.T. Maloney of Warrenton, Va., $8,500 at the 1946 yearling sales at Saratoga, earned more than double that amount at Jamaica yesterday when he marked up his first stakes success of a twelve-race career.

One of the fallacious arguments used in defense of Proportional Representation is to summon up the prospect that we shall be returning to the "old Board of Aldermen composed of sixty-four Tammany Democrats and Joe Baldwin." That is not the case. The new system of electing the City Council ignores the old districts, and bases the election on the State Senate districts established by the Legislature.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Charles de Gaulle's statement was an order to the French Parliament that may already have had the effect of diminishing his popularity, Leon Blum, Socialist leader and counselor of Premier Paul Ramadier, will say in an editorial in Populaire tomorrow.

The "down to the sea" movement in Palestine, born eleven years ago when the Arabs closed the harbor of Jaffa, has progressed to the point where Jewish interests are planning a determined bid for part of the Mediterranean shipping trade formerly held by the Axis.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Shipping and stevedoring executives representing a major segment of the country's allied maritime industries will present to members of Congress on Thursday data showing that American shipping is seriously threatened by the piling of "overtime on overtime" in longshoremen's pay.

The Phillips Petroleum Company announced yesterday that it is planning to put out a new issue of 1,000,000 shares of common stock to be offered first to company stockholders on the basis of one share of new stock for each five shares held.

EL PASO, Tex., Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., co-author of the Taft-Hartley labor law, said today he would press in the next regular session of Congress for new legislation aimed at such union chiefs as John L. Lewis and James Caesar Petrillo.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Security Advisory Board of the State Department-Army-Navy-Air Force Coordinating Committee, which is preparing minimum standards for the handling and transmission of classified, or secret, information in all government departments and agencies, has modified its definitions of secret material to place them more in line with what are considered strict needs of the Government, it was announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The security of the United States demands potential control of the air "to a considerable distance beyond our boundaries," Dr. Vannevar Bush, chairman of the Government's Research and Development Board, told the Air Policy Commission today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The Joint Committee on Approaches to Unity of the Episcopal Church held an open hearing today on the proposed union with the Presbyterian Church. The testimony presented will be studied in executive sessions tomorrow and Thursday.

As the State Board of Social Welfare prepared yesterday to open this morning an investigation of the city's relief administration, Welfare Commissioner Benjamin Fielding announced that any of the 7,000 employable relief clients who arbitrarily had refused work would be dropped from the rolls.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 28 -- Howie Odell, Yale's personable young football coach, is justly famous as a tactician. One of the game's most progressive thinkers, his deceptive version of the T-formation and his ingenius defensive variations have had much to do with the restoration of the Elis to their traditional place among the nation's gridiron leaders.

The Empire Theatre might as well be given over to the plays of Terence Rattigan. Surely, no one would object as long as they are successful. Certainly not the new owner, Jacob Freidus, spectacular young real estate operator, who merely had the foresight to buy the property in 1946 for a cool million during the run of the theatre's last tenant, Mr. Rattigan's "O Mistress Mine," an enormous hit in which the Lunts appeared.
One of the yearly local football clashes that troubles most prognosticators is the C.C.N.Y. Brooklyn College game, with the next of that series scheduled Saturday night at Ebbets Field.

Construction contracts awarded during the first nine months of 1947 in the thirty-seven states east of the Rocky Mountains amounted to $5,626,111,000, a decline of 6 per cent for the figure for the same period last year, according to reports compiled yesterday by the F.W. Dodge Corporation.

After the trees have dropped their leaves and the first killing frosts have deepened the browns of the grasses on meadows and upland fields there comes an interlude of beauty in the open woodlands. Stand on the height of a hardwood ridge a mellow mid-autumn noon and feel the peaceful drowsiness of the season.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 28 -- A plan for the distribution to stockholders of all of the assets of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company of Delaware, a subsidiary of the Louisville Gas and Electric Company of Kentucky, and the subsequent dissolution of the Delaware company was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Oct. 28 (AP) -- The American Legation demanded tonight that the Hungarian Ministry of Foreign Affairs disclose specifically the police charges against Miss Elizabeth Pallos, 31-year-old American citizen, arrested in her apartment late last night and held incommunicado.

A dental laboratory worker found guilty in a 2-to-1 decision in the Court of Special Sessions of unlawfully practicing dentistry escaped a thirty-day jail term by paying a $500 fine when he appeared yesterday for sentencing before Presiding Justice Irving Ben Cooper.
In support of a common cause, Tin Pan Alley and Carnegie Hall used, for a time last night, the same address; Madison Square Garden.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- Members of the British Ryder Cup team got in a few more practice licks today over the Portland Golf Club's soggy layout and were pleased with their chances to take the cup back home. The matches will toe played Saturday and Sunday.

Senator Taft was speaking to the Republican Women's Club of Boston when he said that the whole program of European aid, the long-term as well as the emergency appropriations, would come before the special session of Congress, and might be disposed of before Christmas.

PARIS, Oct. 28 (AP) -- Thousands of Communists were beaten back by police with clubs, when the Communists attempting to break up an anti-Communist meeting in Wagram Hall, besieged the meeting place. They were routed only after they had broken through three police lines and a wooden barricade.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Oct. 28 -- Jefferson Circuit Judge W. Scott Miller ruled here today that President Truman's Citizens Food Committee does not have the authority to stop production of whisky to save grain to feed Europe.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 28 -- Four thousand delegates attending the closing session of the annual convention of Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, adopted today a statement of policy in which they joined the Jewish Agency in "its reluctant acceptance of the principle of partition of Palestine."

BOSTON, Oct. 28 -- Fire that had enveloped a two-mile square area of Beverly Farms woodland, threatening homes and estates with a combined value of nearly $8,000,000, was brought under control tonight by firemen and volunteers from ten communities.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- The Soviet Union demanded today the simultaneous withdrawal of United States and Soviet troops from Korea "at the beginning of the year," and proposed that elected representatives from both the United States and Soviet occupation zones be allowed to participate in discussions of the Korean question at this session of the United Nations General Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Limiting Marshall plan disbursements to $4,500,000,000 in the first year's operations as proposed by Senator Robert A. Taft would mean the difference between continuing European emergency relief and beginning European recovery, Administration officials explained today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- In a conciliatory move, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, United States delegate, appealed to the Soviet Union tonight to end its series of charges against the "war-mongering" American press, to acknowledge the basic differences between Eastern and Western countries and to seek instead some means of cooperation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- The United States fought today to prevent the continued narrowing down of the powers of the proposed United Nations "Little Assembly" from eliminating its right to appoint commissions of investigation.

The overvaluation of foreign currencies in relation to the dollar, low interest rates and other internal controls on production imposed by European governments are preventing the revival of normal two-way international trade and delaying economic rehabilitation of the world, Henry Hazlitt, economist and business columnist, declares in a new booklet published today.

In Search of New Words Igor Stravinsky, one of the most meritorious living creators of music that is "highbrow" -- to use an adjective which, though brash and inadequate, conveys to most of us a meaning that more suitable adjectives do not -- has decided to try henceforth to make both art and money.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 28 -- The Governor General, Earl Mountbatten, and the Prime Minister of the Dominion of India, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, will fly to Lahore, Pakistan, tomorrow morning to confer with Governor General Mohammed Ali Jinnah and Prime Minister Liaquat Ali Khan on the situation in Kashmir.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 28 -- The qualifying round in the first New Jersey pro-women's match play championship golf tournament was held on the Crestmont links today.

Two years ago the Bulgarian envoy in Moscow asked the Soviet Foreign Office whether the U.S.S.R. considered it possible that Britain and the United States might be able to "force" a Mikolajczyk upon Bulgaria.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 28 -- The United Nations Special Committee on Palestine is scheduled to receive tomorrow complete proposals from its two subcommittees, but neither group made sufficient progress today in morning and afternoon meetings to meet this deadline.

As the warm weather continued here, Forest Fire Control Headquarters in Albany reported yesterday for the first time in eighteen days that all fires in New York State were under control, according to The Associated Press.

PARIS, Oct. 28 -- Premier Paul Ramadier today asked the National Assembly for a vote of confidence at the end of the most tumultuous and impassioned session that the legislative body had experienced since the war. The Assembly will vote Thursday on the Premier's appeal.

Caution again was the rule yesterday in the stock market, although a selective recovery developed before late realizing reduced some of the gains. Price variations were confined generally to fractions, with the list on an even keel at the close.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 28 -- The Hebrew University has offered to send tens of thousands of units of serum to Egypt to help stem that Moslem country's spread of cholera, which took 3,000 lives last week. Jewish doctors were offered by Hadassah but Egypt has not accepted.

NANKING, Oct. 28 -- Such qualitative superiority as the Chinese Nationalist army once enjoyed over the Communists is fast being whittled away by the depletion of ammunition for American lend-lease weapons, the loss of many of these weapons in battle and casualties among seasoned troops.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- In a move designed principally to placate the Solid South, the Democratic National Committee, meeting here tomorrow for the kick-off in the campaign to re-elect President Truman, is expected to grant a bonus of four extra convention votes to each state that voted Democratic in the last Presidential election.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- A slowdown by printers tonight delayed the first edition of Marshall Field's morning Chicago Sun by one hour and fifteen minutes. Under an agreement among Chicago newspaper publishers, Col. Robert R. McCormick's rival Chicago Tribune delayed its first edition by the same length of time.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Wednesday, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Denmark's Communist party lost nine of its eighteen Lower Chamber seats in yesterday's nation-wide parliamentary elections, final returns showed early today, while the Social Democrats and the Agrarians gained major election honors.

The American Newspaper Publishers Association's Bureau of Advertising has expanded its monthly grocery inventory project to a coast-to-coast status, it was announced yesterday. Addition this month of Los Angeles, San Francisco, Oakland, Portland and Toledo to the list of inventories in full operation brings to eleven the number of cities participating.

To fill in that yawning gap between Wilde and Coward, the well-educated mummers of On-Stage put on the late Saki's "The Watched Pot" in Cherry Lane last evening. After a relentless search of the records, Tecumseh swears that it has never been done in New York before.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 28 (U.P.) -- The Mexican Baseball League tonight admitted defeat in its battle with United States major leagues for talent and promised no more player raids. Jorge Pasquel, who directed the raids on United States teams, was reduced to a secondary capacity as part of a general retrenchment program.

Formation of the Veterans Hospital Camp Shows, Inc., designed to take over and continue the hospital work of USO-Camp Shows, which is slated to conclude operations on Dec. 31, was announced yesterday by the Hollywood Co-ordinating Committee of which George Murphy is president.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Oct. 28 (AP) -- A Naval Academy spokesman announced tonight that Midshipman Frederick W. Lauer Jr. of Wilmette, Ill., had been discharged from naval service chiefly for "irregularities in the handling of tickets for the Penn-Navy game of last week-end."

Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation were making an inventory yesterday of a truck and a half load of merchandise said to have been acquired by Mrs. Barbara Moloney, 49-year-old bookkeeper, in connection with the alleged passing of 400 worthless checks for $50,000 in states from Connecticut to Florida.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- More than 99 per cent of the nation's distillers, measured by capacity, are cooperating in the sixty-day shutdown of mashing to save grain, the Citizens Food Committee announced late today. The estimate was based on reports furnished by the Alcohol Tax Unit of the Treasury Department, which has agents in all distilleries.

BERLIN, Oct. 28 -- In clear-cut language, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the United States Military Governor, announced today the new United States program for combating pro-Communist and pro-totalitarian propaganda in Germany.
Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator, made yesterday an announcement eagerly awaited by a group of youngsters. He reported that the youngsters would ride across a highway in their own house.

Harold Green, 159 3/4, Brownsville, knocked out Vic Amato, 161, South, Brooklyn, in 1:35 of the fourth round of the feature bout scheduled for eight rounds last night at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn, before a crowd of 5,100. The victor dropped his foe twice for nine counts before finally halting him.

GLEN RIDGE, N.J., Oct. 28 -- The novel as a propaganda medium was discussed today before the Women's Club of Glen Ridge by Fannie Hurst, author; Bennett Cerf, publisher, and Orville Prescott, book critic. They spoke on THE NEW YORK TIMES radio forum, "What's On Your Mind?"

Two hundred state and county volunteer leaders from the Eastern division of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis met yesterday with foundation officials in the Hotel Pennsylvania to draw up plans for the 1948 March of Dimes.

CLINTON, N.Y., Oct. 28 (AP) -- Dr. Richard H. Hutchings, retired superintendent of the Utica State Hospital and one-time president of the American Psychiatric Association, died today in his home here at the age of 78.

Had his armored columns not been halted at Verdun in August, 1944, by a change in battle plan, and in September by a decision to support a British operation, the late Gen. George S. Patton Jr. could, in his opinion, have driven on across the Rhine and saved thousands of lives expended in later fighting, it was revealed yesterday by his journal.

A new spurt of buying in Worth Street, headed by converters and the bag trade, has stepped up business for cotton textiles for delivery in 1948, it was learned yesterday. Commission men reported considerable activity on print cloths, carded broadcloth, fine goods, and all classes of sheetings.
Buildings to be occupied by the new owners and properties taken for investment were involved in the leading realty deals reported yesterday on the East Side of Manhattan.
An underwriting group headed by the First Boston Corporation will offer to investors today a new

With all indications pointing to a sell-out gathering, the professional hockey season in New York opens tonight with the New York Rangers making their home debut against the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden.

HOUSTON, Tex., Oct. 28 -- More than a score of ships engaged in exercise Seminole, a mock invasion of the Florida coast, were gathering in Galveston harbor in preparation for sailing for Florida waters Thursday.

In addition to announcing an increase in the quarterly dividend on the common stock of the United States Lines, John M. Franklin, the company president, reported that earnings for the first nine months of this year almost doubled those of the corresponding, period of 1946.

Sales of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., in the first eleven weeks of its new fiscal year continued to increase over those of a year ago, Jack I. Straus, president, informed stockholders at their annual meeting held yesterday.

Two notable benefit exhibitions open simultaneously with previews tonight at nine o'clock. The first comprehensive exhibition of paintings and prints by Mary Cassatt ever to be held in New York has been assembled at the Wildenstein Galleries for the benefit of the Goddard Neighborhood Center.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities voted to recommend contempt citations against three more Hollywood screen writers for refusing to testify today whether they were Communists.
LONDON, Oct. 28 -- Princess Elizabeth is a fortunate young woman. Among her wedding presents, displayed in St. James' Palace this afternoon, are eighty pairs of nylon stockings.

"Big Steel" Dividend Reflecting a sustained period of profitable operations and "our faith in the future," as its chairman put it, the United States Steel Corporation yesterday raised its quarterly dividend on the common stock 25 cents a share to $1.25 and voted an extra disbursement of 75 cents a share on the same stock.

Officials of the Manhattan Storage and Warehouse Company breathed collective sighs of relief yesterday when they succeeded in their second attempt to auction the Gustave Dore collection of paintings and prints that had lain in their vaults for forty-nine years.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation yesterday declared a dividend of $1.25 a share on the common stock, an increase of 25 cents over the quarterly rate prevalent since 1940, and also voted an extra disbursement of 75 cents a share, the first special distribution since the third quarter of 1929.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 -- Clouds hovering over Maine will be sown with dry ice tomorrow in the hope that they will rain and extinguish smoldering forest fires. Navy officials said two planes probably would be used in the first attempt to put out fires with the dry-ice method.

Increased charges for use by advertisers of television transmitter and program facilities and revision of basic policy on the role of the advertiser in video programming were announced yesterday by Reynold R. Kraft, sales manager of NBC television.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 28 -- Paramount is planning a musical remake of "Ruggles of Red Gap" as Betty Hutton's first vehicle when she returns to the studio next year from her maternity leave of absence, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 28 (UP) -- The Government today moved into the tobacco market to stabilize prices by buying up an estimated $25,000,000 worth of flue-cured leaf which normally would have been sold to Great Britain.

Another two months of meatless Tuesdays, poultryless Thursdays and other voluntary food conservation measures will attain the goal of 100,000,000 bushels of saved wheat to keep Europe's people from starving this winter, Charles Luckman, chairman of the President's Citizens Food Committee, said here yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 28 -- Further expansion, of currency and bank credits must be stopped, M.S. Szymczak, member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, warned this evening in an address before the final session of the mid-western credit conference of the American Bankers Association.

Formation of the National Office Furniture Association was authorized yesterday in a resolution adopted at the concluding session of the convention of the Office Equipment Dealers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Moe Turman of the Metwood Office Equipment Corporation was elected president of the new organization.

WARSAW, Oct. 28 -- The new leaders of the Polish Peasant party [PSL] began wrapping their seizure of power in the cloak of legality today by announcing the formation of a temporary executive committee and the calling of a party congress that would have no alternative but to make its temporary nature permanent.

The Rev. Dr. Horace W.B. Donegan was consecrated as suffragan bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York in a setting of stately religious splendor yesterday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 28 -- A principal phase of the National Labor Relations Board's first attempt to sustain twin charges of secondary boycotting and illegal picketing in violation of the Taft-Hartley law suffered a setback in Federal Court today.

NANKING, Oct. 28 -- Dr. Lo Lung-chi, head of the banned Democratic League, denied at the United States Embassy today that the league had aided the Communists. He appealed for justice and a "world investigation" of the Interior Ministry's charges.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a letter printed in THE TIMES of Oct. 8, Elizabeth Harmeling protests the plans of New York University.

New Jersey has the largest number of "substandard" teachers in its history, Dr. John H. Bosshart, New Jersey Commissioner of Education, said yesterday before 1,900 delegates and members at the forty-seventh annual convention of the state's Congress of Parents and Teachers at Manhattan Center.

Practical cornering of the peeler log market by plywood producers is responsible for prolongation of the shortage of millwork, framing and siding, one of the most serious bottlenecks in expanded home construction, C.B. Sweet, vice president of the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association, declared yesterday.

Communist propaganda thrives on misery. By retarding peace and opposing recovery it seeks to spread misery in all free lands until, in desperation, they accept the "fuller and richer" life promised them under Red control. It is instructive, therefore, to inquire how full and rich that life has been in countries already taken violently into the Russian embrace.

BUCHAREST, Oct. 29 -- Dr. Juliu Maniu and eighteen others went to trial today before a military court on charges of high treason, espionage on behalf of the United States and Britain and conspiring to overthrow the Government by armed force.

Day of Days The eighteenth anniversary of the collapse of the bull stock market of the late Nineteen Twenties and of the largest day's trading on the New York Stock Exchange in its history -- 16,410,030 shares -- took place yesterday.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 29 (AP) -- William G. Helis' Earshot, second choice in the wagering, defeated the favored Snow Goose today by a nose in the Queen Isabella Handicap at Laurel, after Robert W. Grant's Sun Bath captured the Chevy Chase Handicap in record time for the Laurel infield course at about two and a half miles.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- Russian sources declared here today that the new anti-Communist propaganda campaign officially disclosed yesterday by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, is not new at all. The Russians, refraining from official comment, asserted that anti-Communist and even anti-Russian articles had been appearing constantly in United States licensed newspapers in Germany and especially in the Military Government publication Neue Zeitung.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (U.P.) -- The Federal District Court was asked today to allow twelve movie personalities to address an Independence Hall meeting Saturday to protest conduct of the House committee's investigation of communism in Hollywood.

Three thousand United States Army wives in Germany are aiding German families through the American Occupation Women's Voluntary Service, Mrs. Anthony J. Drexel Biddle Jr., who founded the organization in Frankfort on the Main, declared yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Both the Soviet Union and the United Kingdom sharpened the statement of their conflicting views on the Marshall plan for Europe in the final report of the Economic and Financial Committee to the United Nations General Assembly, which was approved by the committee today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The State Department will review its whole conduct of press relations when a new assistant Secretary of State for Public Affairs is appointed, Robert A. Lovett, Acting Secretary of State, said today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings scored four times in the first period, then made another goal to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 to 2, in the opening National Hockey League game at the Stadium before 16,738 fans tonight.

The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $75,658,274 on net sales of $941,733,864 in the third quarter of 1947. The net profit, which is equal to $1.65 a common share after provision of $3,232,078 for preferred dividends, compares with $24,644,813, or 71 cents a share in the corresponding period of last year when sales aggregated $622,618,885.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals held yesterday that if the Government wants to block the efforts of the Aluminum Company of America for an adjudication that Alcoa's monopoly of the aluminum ingot field has ended, it must appeal to the United States Supreme Court.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that registration statements covering $28,000,000 of Bonds and 547,694 shares of preferred and 200,000 shares of capital stock had been filed by three companies.

NEWMARKET, England, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Fairey Fulmar, a 28-to-1 outsider with apprentice Tommy Gosling in the saddle, threaded his way through a huge field of thirtynine thoroughbreds today to win the Cambridgeshire Handicap by a neck from luckless Joan's Star.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- The United States again served warning here today that it might favor some reduction in the area of the independent Jewish state proposed by the majority report of the United Nations Special Committee of Inquiry on Palestine.

LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Harold S. Vanderbilt, American yachtsman, prevailed upon European delegates to the International Yacht Racing Union conference today to try the new American "right of way rules" proposed by the North American Yacht Racing Union.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 29 -- Violence has taken a grave turn in three large Indian royal states, with implications involving the Dominions of India and Pakistan.

Country 'Tis of Thee He had read, he said, what this corner had to say about the autumn as the right time for vacations -- especially at the seaside. And he'd like to add a postscript. In his opinion, the right time to go to the country, landside or seaside, is when most of the city folk who go to the country to escape from the city have decided to go back where they belong.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Prompt provision for more American aids to agricultural production in Germany and other countries of western Europe would go far toward meeting the emergency food situation abroad, according to Norris A. Dodd, Under-Secretary of Agriculture.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Administration's European recovery program appeared destined for a head-on collision with Republican tax reduction plans today as Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder insisted that Congress provide revenues sufficient to cover its cost and leave a margin for debt reduction.

By-Pass Jobber of Wash Frocks Wholesalers are getting only a fraction of the cotton wash dresses which they formerly handled, according to trade sources yesterday. Manufacturers are selling higher priced goods directly to retailers, it was said, and have been able to deliver only small quantities of dresses selling for less than $23 per dozen which were the chief lines jobbed.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Oct. 8 "A New York Housing Plan" suggested an approach for our present housing difficulties that is, in our opinion, worthy of serious consideration.

WARSAW, Oct. 29 -- Socialist Premier Joseph Cyrankiewicz, after referring sarcastically to Peasant leader Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, leader of the Peasant party [PSL], as "the newest Polish export," warned the Catholic Church today that the Government would not tolerate its use of religious freedom for political purposes.

Calling the exclusive patronage conference contract rate system an instrument of "monopolistic international shipping trusts," Matthew S. Crinkley, vice president of the Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., declared last night that these contracts embody provisions that are in violation of the provisions of Section 14 of the 1916 Shipping Act.

A "Give-A-Book Certificate" plan by which customers may purchase bearer certificates that may be redeemed by recipients in book stores in any part of the country was announced yesterday by Gilbert E. Goodkind, executive secretary of the American Booksellers Association, 31 Madison Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- As the Democratic National Committee met today to choose its 1948 convention city, Mrs. Harry S. Truman, answering in writing a question put to her in writing weeks ago, said she ''expects to be there."

The New Jersey Congress of Parent-Teacher Associations called upon the State Legislature yesterday "to levy such taxes as may be necessary to provide a complete program of education in all schools of the state."

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 29 -- Business, government, labor and agricultural leaders of New Jersey predicted today that the state could look forward to a year of continued industrial prosperity and high employment in 1948.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a dispatch from your correspondent in Stockholm, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES on Oct. 24, one of Sweden's leading bankers, who, however, remained anonymous, was quoted as having declared that "Sweden is bankrupt."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- John Foster Dulles, United States representative on the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly, submitted a proposal today providing that the Assembly set up a special commission immediately to go to Korea and "insure" that Korean representatives were duly elected and were not mere appointees of the occupation authorities.

Sportswear designs shown yesterday in the sixth edition of the "Fashions of the Times" were fresh and lively. Spirited as the tempo in which they were shown, they heralded daringly bare bathing suits and all-enveloping coats. Glittering fabrics were shot with metal threads that could brave the water.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The capital of the United States "is a graphic illustration of a failure of democracy" rather than a shrine of civil liberty, the President's Committee on Civil Rights declared today.

The twenty-six Hollywood delegates who made a flying trip to Washington to attend the current hearings on the motion picture industry made an unexpectedly long stay in this vicinity yesterday after being scheduled to stop over for only half an hour on their homeward journey.

Arthur C. Train, lawyer, novelist and creator of the fictional Yankee attorney "Mr. Ephraim Tutt," who died on Dec. 22, 1945, left a gross estate of $1,364,418 and a net of $1,244,573, according to a transfer tax appraisal filed yesterday.

Rinehart reports that Jon Godden, sister of novelist Rumer Godden and author of "The Bird Escaped," has had her second novel published in England, entitled "The House by the Sea." It is the October choice of the British Book Society.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The White House approved today Maritime Commission plans to proceed with disposal of tanker tonnage to foreign buyers despite mounting opposition to such sale and warnings that the United States had a serious shortage of fuel-carrying tonnage.

One of the most serious objections to the Proportional Representation system of electing our City Council is that it fragmentizes the electorate into a number of splinter parties or independent candidacies based on shades of political opinion, racial loyalties, isms, or religious grounds.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The British are prepared to move out of Palestine in six months if no settlement, agreed upon by the Jews and Arabs, is reached by the United Nations, it was learned today.
Mrs. Lillian C. Patterson, mother of Bronx County Judge Lester W. Patterson, was honored yesterday at a luncheon as the borough's outstanding citizen of the year.
The liner America, flagship of the United States Lines fleet, left Pier 61, North River, at 4 P.M. yesterday with 754 passengers, bound for Cobh, Cherbourg and Southampton.

Immediate steps to implement the proposals of the President's Committee on Civil Rights, as set forth, in its report, were urged yesterday by former Supreme Court Justice Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the American Jewish Committee.

Terrence Rattigan's "The Winslow Boy" put on at the Empire last evening, is such a good play that one naturally wishes it could have been perfect. On the theme of a callous injustice done to a small boy, Mr. Rattigan has written a stunning first act.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox of the American League and Leslie O'Connor, general manager of the club -- himself a rigid enforcer of baseball rules for twenty-four years -- today were suspended from baseball by Commissioner Albert B. Chandler for refusing to pay a $500 fine for signing a player still in high school.

With the Big Four Foreign Ministers scheduled to meet in London next month in what will probably be the last attempt to reach by this means a joint agreement on peace settlements for Germany and Austria, special importance must be attached to the Russian maneuvers in the Korean question, now before the United Nations.
Accounts Tola Productions, producers of "The Roosevelt Story," to Weiss Geller for national advertising with Joseph Curtis, vice president, as account executive.

Lou Gray, Queens appliance dealer, recently dropped from the cooperating appliance dealer organization of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will appeal to the Public Service Commission to terminate present administration of the Edison dealer plan unless he is reinstated immediately, Gerard I. Nierenberg, his attorney announced yesterday.

The Standard Oil Company of New Jersey announced yesterday an increase of 3/10 of a cent a gallon in the price of gasoline and 8/10 of a cent in heating oil, kerosene, diesel and other distillate fuels effective today. The company said the advance resulted from the recent rise of 20 cents a barrel in crude oil prices and from higher freight rates.

Twice in public statements this week Senator Taft has had occasion to touch upon the subject of the Marshall plan. And in both instances, it seems to us, his remarks have betrayed a lack of awareness of the dimensions of this issue that is, to say the least, mildly discouraging.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Cuba and the United Nations have signed a special preliminary agreement, setting forth the arrangements for servicing the largest international conference ever held away from United Nations headquarters under United Nations auspices, it was learned here today.

THE author of "Mr. Lincoln's Cameraman," Roy Meredith, has created another firstrate book of text and pictures, "The Face of Robert E. Lee."* This is a fascinating study of Lee as he really looked and as people imagined him, in life and in legend. And although Mr. Meredith says flatly that he has made no attempt to tell the story of Lee's career, a good deal of it emerges from these pages.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The tariff and trade agreement to be signed in Geneva tomorrow was described by President Truman today as "a landmark in the history of international economic relations." The State Department issued a statement no less enthusiastic.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorials "The Call to Congress," "Above Partisanship" and "A Time for Statesmanship" are welcome expressions of the opinions of many of us, the group you describe as those "who vote for men and measures rather than for parties."
CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows.

Max F. Balcom, president of the Radio Manufacturers Association, yesterday intimated that public demand for frequency modulation programs does not yet justify production of FM receivers on a scale repeatedly requested by FM broadcasters.

With municipal hospitals "bursting at the seams" from overcrowding, the public must support the sixty-ninth annual United Hospital Campaign to enable voluntary hospitals to continue operating, Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, commissioner of hospitals, declared yesterday.

The first monthly panel of lawyers to volunteer for training as special deputy attorneys general to prevent election frauds began their course of instruction yesterday under State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein at the State Office Building.

The shocking disclosures at yesterday's public hearings, the forced resignation of Commissioner Rhatigan, the findings of the Mayor's Executive Committee on Administration, the cleanup orders issued by the new Commissioner, all confirm what should have been instantly realized last spring -- that the Welfare Department needed a major reform.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Secretary of State Marshall returned from New York today after seven weeks of attendance at sessions of the General Assembly of the United Nations. He will resume the active direction of the State Department before departing for the meeting in London on Nov. 25 of the Council of Foreign Ministers, at which the drafting of a German peace treaty will be pressed.
The fashion industry drew new adjectives out of its vocabulary yesterday to describe its unanimous approval of the sixth edition of "Fashions of the Times."

All the rest were spattered with mud, but Maine Chance Farm's cerise, white and blue silks, carried by Beaugay, were in no need of a dry-cleaning job after the running of the $20,000 added New Rochelle Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

Gray was a high favorite for spring in the "Fashions of the Times," Sixth Edition, which continues on its way in afternoon and evening performances at Times Hall. The curtain will fall on the final performance tomorrow night. The neutral color was used by some of the leading lights in the field of New York's design.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Oct. 22:

The Youngstown, Ohio, City School District announced yesterday that on Nov. 17 it would open bids on $2,700,000 of bonds dated Dec. 1, 1947, and due on June 1 and Dec. 1, 1949 to 1968. Interest is not to exceed 2 per cent.

Edith Piaf, the torch singer from Paris, will make her American debut this evening at the Playhouse under the auspices of Clifford C.Fischer, veteran importer of foreign talent responsible for the visits to this country of such notables as Harry Lauder, Sarah Bernhardt, Alice Lloyd and Polaire.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- When the Eightieth Congress resumes its study of the proposal for universal military training of American youth, some of the arguments against it will be emotional, some philosophical and some practical -- in the atter category being the contention of certain military experts that it will have no defense value in the atomic age.

Hector McNeil, British Minister of State and acting head of the United Kingdom delegation to the United Nations, predicted yesterday that the difficulties besetting British business men would disappear.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- In his first major policy decision as Democratic National Chairman, Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island stopped the Democratic National Committee from making a blistering attack on the record of the Republican-controlled Eightieth Congress.

NANKING, Oct. 29 -- The Government's intention to suppress "vigorously" the Democratic League and all its branches was reiterated at a press conference today by Dr. Hollington K. Tong, chief of the Information Office.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 29 -- Dr. Judah L. Magnes, speaking at the opening of the twenty-third year of the Hebrew University today, condemned "Zionist totalitarianism" which, he said, is trying to bring the entire Jewish people under its influence "by force and violence."

Heeding the advice of Hospital Commissioner Edward M. Bernecker, his personal physician, Mayor O'Dwyer has canceled all night speaking engagements for the next two months, it was disclosed yesterday at City Hall.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Australia urged today that the United Nations "Little Assembly" receive the right to debate controversies lying "dead as a doornail" on the agenda of the Security Council.
TORONTO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs defeated the Montreal Canadiens, 3 -- 1, tonight in the first meeting of the two Dominion rivals in the 1947-48 National Hockey League schedule.

Traders in stocks attempted yesterday to capitalize on the United States Steel Corporation's dividend developments of the day before, but ran into late selling which produced an easier close. Weakness which appeared in the motors, liquors and rails during the afternoon had a somewhat unsettling effect which spread to the steel division, so that peak gains were reduced.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The President's committee on civil rights declared today the time has come to create a permanent, nationwide system of guardianship for the civil rights of Americans.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Insurance Rates and Regulations, announced today that the committee will conduct its first hearing on Nov. 13 and 14 in the rooms of the Association of the Bar of New York in New York City.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The President's Committee on Civil Rights urged today the exposure of Communists and "native fascists" by enlarging the power of the Federal and State Governments to compel such groups to register.

Wrong on two counts are reports concerning the future football talent at Fordham, where, according to gossip, there are on the campus forty freshmen who can beat the varsity. The truth of the matter is that the number is thirty-eight and they only hold the varsity even.

ROME, Oct. 29 -- Several hundred Communist shock troops paraded this morning through the main streets of Milan, where the Communist-dominated labor unions staged a three-hour general work stoppage as a political demonstration against the present Christian Democratic government.

Great improvement can be shown in the ready-to-wear volume next spring if retailers, manufacturers and mills will get together in a three-way discussion to improve the supply problem, Charles G. Nichols, vice president and general manager of G.M. McKelvy Company, Toungstown, Ohio, declared last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Government aid is essential to the maintenance of an aviation industry keyed to the defense needs of the United States. Donald W. Douglas, major builder of civilian transport airplanes, testified today before the President's Air Policy Commission.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Opposition to the British Labor Government's legislative program, including a plan to curb the powers of the House of Lords, fizzled out tonight as the Commons threw out Winston Churchill's hostile amendment by 348 votes to 201.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- Poland warned the United Nations Security Council today that continued fighting in Indonesia might require drastic "enforcement measures'' by other countries to restore peace, and demanded that Dutch civil and military forces be withdrawn at once from all Republican territory.

BOSTON, Oct. 29 -- Rain came at last to the forest fire areas of New England today to an extent sufficient to assure continued control of the flames, although not to eliminate danger. A big question, however, was whether some of the rain was man produced.

LONDON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Britain's Amateur Athletic Board today named 196 "possibles" from whom Britain's team for the Olympic games in London in 1948 will be chosen. There will be between sixty and seventy on the track and field team.

Declaring that the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council has proved to be a mockery of democracy, Vincent R. Impellitteri, President of the Council, yesterday urged voters of the city to abolish PR by voting "yes" on proposition No. 4.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The National Labor Relations Board, in its first decision affecting filing requirements under the Taft-Hartley Act, ruled today that a noncomplying union cannot appear on a ballot for bargaining representatives when the election is sought by a complying union.

While the New York Yankees do not figure to have too much difficulty in subduing the Baltimore Colts at the Yankee Stadium next Sunday, this contest in many ways is one of the most important of the season for the local entry in the All-America Conference.

GENEVA, Oct. 29 -- The final results of six and one-half months of Geneva tariff negotiations show 123 separate trade agreements completed involving nineteen countries or customs areas and more than half the world trade.

Ending a long fight against racial discrimination in the Railway Mail Association, AFL, the union's New York branch announced yesterday that it had installed a Negro as its corresponding secretary, the first Negro officer in the organization's history.

Under an agreement reached by Great Britain and Yugoslavia all displaced persons now in British camps against whom Tito's government can establish a "prima facie case" of collaboration with the Axis during the war are to be returned to their native land.

The prospects for American trade with South and East Africa remain exceptionally good and should continue so for years, Sylvester J. Maddock, vice president of the Seas Shipping Company, declared last night prior to his departure for a six-month survey of his company's connections in Africa.

The wheels of an East Side vegetable pushcart spun like the "wheel of fortune" for Henry Lustig. They spun into the wheels of a horse-drawn vegetable wagon, thence to a wholesale vegetable business on West Fifteenth Street and lastly into New York's swanky chain of restaurants, Longchamps.

The raising of cash margins on the grain exchanges is not a device to save grain but to affect prices, but "even from that standpoint it is largely irrelevant," the Guaranty Trust Company of New York said in its monthly Survey, issued yesterday.

The Panama liner Ancon sailed from Pier 64, North River, at 3 P.M. yesterday with a new pennant fluttering from her forepeak, the Merchant Marine Naval Reserve emblem. It was presented to her skipper a few hours before departure as a symbol of her suitability as a naval auxiliary and the fact that at least 50 per cent of her officer complement are members of the Naval Reserve.

Production, distribution and sales operations should be coordinated so that employes may expect steady earnings through stabilized employment, executives unanimously agree in a survey by the National Industrial Conference Board, it was announced yesterday.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 29 -- Hans van Meegeren, the Dutch painter who shocked the art world by foisting a series of false Vermeers, Pieter de Hoghs and other old masters on experts, finally was placed on trial in District Court here today.
A peacetime high in net sales, amounting to $492,179,242 for the nine months to Sept. 30, was reported yesterday by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation. Third quarter sales totaled $179,840,606.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 29 -- John M. Dring, clerk of the Newport Probate Court, said tonight that adoption papers had been filed by William A. Peckham, Newport attorney, making Brig. Gen. Ralph C. Tobin of New York, United States Army, retired, the adopted son of Mrs. Hamilton Fish Webster, wealthy Newport widow.

"If we just keep kicking, we should push them back," said Coach Lou Oshins of Brooklyn College yesterday as he summarized his outlook of the Saturday night contest at Ebbets Field that will send his team against C.C.N.Y.

College presidents were taken to task yesterday by Magistrate James A. Blanchfield in Flatbush Court, Brooklyn, for not knowing the difference between a minor civil offense and grand larceny. He chided the college officials for turning down students applying for admission who had been found guilty of minor violations.

With the private showing of new training film to be used venereal disease control, the Army announced yesterday that it had begun a program designed to raise the moral and ethical tone of millitary service.

Declaring that many "begging" letters are now reaching individuals in this country from Europe, the Church World Service, Inc., 37 East Thirty-sixth Street, urged yesterday that if the writers are unknown the letters be turned over to one of the regular relief agencies for investigation.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Britain's entire production program is in jeopardy because the nation has not reached its necessary coal output levels for winter supplies, Sir Stafford Cripps, Minister of Economic Affairs, said today.
Meeting fairly heavy Western and commission house liquidation, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed virtually at the lows of the day, 18 to 62 points net lower.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 29 -- Resentment is strong in the wheat belt against what is described as a continuing effort by the Truman Administration to "beat down" farm prices, especially in grain and livestock.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court called tonight for full observance of the Constitution's Bill of Rights "even when we deal with the minority that seek to confuse and divide us."

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 -- Liquidation developed today in the grain markets on the Board of Trade here after a moderate advance in the early trading. Wheat broke the permissible limit of 10 cents and closed at 9 3/4 to 10 cents lower, with December the only major delivery to finish above the bottom, although at the low it was 22 5/8 cents below last week's high.

The Rev. Dr. J. Frederic Berg, acting pastor of the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, has recommended that a permanent pastor be called to minister to the church, it was made known yesterday.
TOKYO, Oct. 29 -- The United States and Russia clashed again today over the repatriation of 761,000 Japanese war prisoners still held in Soviet-controlled areas.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Five widows of former Presidents of the United States are still alive.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- James M. Petrillo's edict against the broadcasting of radio network programs over FM stations was attacked today in a proposal filed with the Federal Communications Commission by the FM Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Following is an abridged text of Section IV of the report of the President's Committee on Civil Rights, containing specific recommendations and in introduction to them: A Program of Action: The Committee's Recommendations THE TIME IS NOW Twice before in American histry the nation has found it necessary to review the state of its civil rights.

A fund of $500,000 will be required to rebuild the Jackson Memorial Laboratory, destroyed by fire last week at Bar Harbor, Me., it was estimated yesterday by Dr. C.C. Little, under whose direction the laboratory was developed as the most important of its kind in the world.

Forecasting a business of from 54,000,000 to 60,000,000 ton-miles of air freight for the scheduled airlines of the United States this calendar year, Fred M. Glass, president of Air Cargo, Inc., denounced yesterday the admission of unscheduled air carriers and freight forwarders to the field.

The city administration's determination to build more public housing, and to cooperate wherever possible with private builders, was expressed yesterday by Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore, who represented Mayor O'Dwyer at cornerstone ceremonies for Marcy Houses, Marey and Park Avenues, Brooklyn.

SALEM, Ore., Oct. 29 -- Earl Snell was in the midst of his second term as Governor, having been re-elected in 1946 after serving four terms in the State House of Representatives and two as Secretary of State. He was a Republican.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 29 -- The Government has devised a new scheme by which newspapers can facilitate the entry of blocked newsprint in return for selling to the Government a variable percentage of it.

UNCLE MIKE JACOBS, a sentimental gent who has been known to shed tears of joy at the sight of a dollar bill, begins his second decade as fight impresario at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. By way of celebrating the occasion, Gus Lesnevich will attempt to beat Tami Mauriello for the fourth time. In most sports a victor wins permanent possession of a trophy by taking three legs on it.

OTTAWA, Ont., Oct. 29 -- The tariffs and trade agreement that Canada will sign tomorrow in Geneva was described here today by a government spokesman as "an immense diplomatic and techncal achievement at a time like this which is certain in the long run to be enormously beneficial to a country like Canada, which depends on multilateral trade."

Proposals to solve the problem of increasing immigration from Puerto Rico to New York and other metropolitan centers were outlined yesterday by Puerto Rican officials who were the guests of Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in the Criminal Courts Building.

Pacing a tenth floor suite in the Sherry Netherland hotel like a caged movie lot lion, Samuel Goldwyn admitted last night that he had not yet joined the long line of Hollywood celebrities testifying before the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities because he cannot get the chairman to include him in.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Harold Wilson, president of the Board of Trade, announced in the House of Commons today the conclusion of United States-British tariffs agreement. At the same time he branded as "untrue" suggestions that the Geneva negotiations had "in any way weakened the economic cooperation of the Commonwealth."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 -- Gary Cooper today revealed that he expected to sign a multiple picture contract with Warner Brothers and to close a similar deal with Paramount, rather than enter the field of independent production, as he had previously intended.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Social Security Administration said today that New Mexico and Arizona must provide aid to needy Indians or forfeit $5,000,000 a year in Federal grants for impoverished white people.

The story of a mink-coated, minkhatted ''relief client" who lived at city expense in a hotel at $7.50 a day despite assets of $60,000 was spread on the record of the State Board of Social Welfare yesterday as it opened an attack on administration of a $142,000,000 relief program by the New York City Welfare Department.
Scrap price and supply trends this week will definitely reveal whether a crisis in deliveries is here now or can be postponed until next winter, spokesmen disclosed here yesterday.

A life-size saver bust of Enrico Caruso was presented to the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon by Mrs. Dorothy Caruso, the famous tenor's widow, at a ceremony held in the lobby of the family circle, where the gift has been placed.

For the third consecutive week the nation's crude oil production last week reached a new peak, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The output averaged 5,295,350 barrels daily, an increase of 26,950 over the 5,268,400 in the preceding week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The National Petroleum Council today requested Justice Department clearance before starting any study of concerted measures to relieve oil and gas shortages.
