WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 29 -- One upset and some fine golf marked the first two rounds of match play in the New Jersey prowomen's championship at the Crestmont Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Following is the text of Presidnet Truman's statement in connection with the receipt of the report of his Civil Rights Committee: The President's Civil Rights Committee has just submitted its report. I am going to read and study this report with great care and I recommend to all my countrymen that they do the same thing.

Although sales of the Pittsburgh Plate Glass Company for the third quarter of this year reached a new high record of $67,075,872 earnings were less than those in the preceding quarter, Harry B. Higgins, president, disclosed in his report mailed to stockholders yesterday.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Roman Catholic bishops of Germany said today that they had protested to the Allied Control Council against the "kidnapping" of more than 2,000 German children in the Soviet zone and the internment of thousands of other ciivlians as a violation of "divine and human justice."

Communist expansion in Asia may become even more menacing than in Europe, but its advance in the Far East can be halted with less than the cost of the Marshall plan, Admiral Thomas C. Hart, retired, asserted last night.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- The outbreak of rah-rah spirit that has the vigilantes and gendarmes alerted on both campuses points to a rising fever over the PennPrinceton football game.
PARIS, Oct. 29 -- A vote of confidence in Premier Paul Ramadier by the National Assembly tomorrow was considered assured when the Popular Republican Parliamentary group decided today to support him.

ALBANY, Oct. 29 -- Governor Dewey announced today that the state has agreed to take over, on April 1, the 205-bed Onondaga County Tuberculosis Sanatorium as part of its long-range program for eradication, of the disease within twenty years.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 29 -- After detailing the work of several international agencies during the present food crisis, Mrs. Ursula H. Duffus of the State Department told seventy-three delegates to the fourth annual Newspaper Food Editors Conference tonight that all the agencies could only serve to coordinate what we ourselves and our Governments want.

Of course, it's much too soon to tell, but the cry of "the same old Rangers" rang out at Madison Square Garden last night as New York's entrant in the National Hockey League made its home debut of the season by losing to the Boston Bruins, 3 to 1.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- American drama scored another success in London tonight when Philip Yordan's Negro play, "Anna Lucasta," opened at His Majesty's Theatre.

LONDON, Oct. 29 -- The conference on the future of former Italian colonies today approved the itinerary and time-table of the four-power commission of investigation that is to investigate on the spot the wishes of the inhabitants of Mussolini's former empire.

KLAMATH FALLS, Ore., Oct. 29 -- Gov. Earl Snell and two other top-level officials in Oregon's state government were believed tonight to have perished with the pilot of a private plane which crashed in rugged country near the California border while on a hunting trip.
LONDON, Oct. 29 -- Under influence of fairly heavy South African buying substantial rises again were recorded in gold mining issues on the stock market here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- A plan for decentralizing the appeal to farmers for grain conservation through the employment of state and local agricultural agencies was announced jointly today by the Department of Agriculture and the Citizens Food Committee.

A new junior-size center occupying a whole floor was opened officially yesterday by Abraham Straus in Brooklyn with a fashion show preview. The center is the first step toward the store's fashion modernization program made possible by an eight-story addition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (U.P.) -- Senator Owen Brewster, Republican, of Maine, said today that the only return the United States had received on an $80,000,000 wartime investment in Arabian oil was an "apparent obligation" to defend American oil companies and the "right" to buy oil at their prices.

LIVERPOOL, England, Oct. 29 (Canadian Press) -- The Empress of Canada swung at anchor in the Mersey River tonight while ashore Canadian Pacific Railway agents sought by "secret measures" to enable the vessel to cross the Mersey bar and sail for Montreal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Four more Hollywood writers and executives were put on a contempt list of a House Subcommittee on UnAmerican Activities today. Like four other screen writers before them, they refused to say whether they were Communists.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 29 -- With British, United States and Soviet support, a compromise French resolution condemning the spreading of false news and slanderous reports that might disrupt international relations was adopted here today by the overwhelming vote of 49 to 1.

Thursday, Oct. 30, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- In continued discussion of Korean question, heard representatives of Poland, Canada, Czechoslovakia, Belgium, Soviet Union, Australia, United States, White Russia, France, Ukraine, China, Haiti and Yugoslavia.

An early recall of CBS's weekly "Open Hearing," during which Federal legislators and Government spokesmen discuss current issues, was announced yesterday by the network, in anticipation of the special Congressional sesssion to convene Nov. 17.

Belgium has sufficient dollars for current use, but is giving careful consideration to its import-export picture from the standpoint of dollar reserves as well as the question of possible import controls. George Moens de Fernig, head of the food mission sent to the United States by the Economic Union of the Netherlands, Belgium and Luxembourg (Benelux) said yesterday.
Plans for a New York City Golden Jubilee got a sharp blow yesterday in a letter from Hugh E. Rogers, Manhattan Borough President, to Edward B. Lockwood, president of the Park Avenue Association.
New York restaurant men said yesterday they would serve neither poultry nor eggs today despite a new attack by the chicken growers against this phase of the food conservation program.

Some of those who decided to go south for the fishing rather than north for the shooting axe patting themselves on the back, especially the surfcasters who timed their arrival at Ocracoke with that of the channel bass.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The White House announced a diplomatic departure today in the form of a mission on science and technology to be attached to the United States Embassy in London. If successful, it is planned to include similar missions in other capitals abroad.

The Hundred Year Association, comprising concerns that have been in business here for a century or more, made its annual award of a medal last night to Frederick H. Ecker, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, at a dinner in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Grain markets fluctuated nervously on the Board of Trade today and closed with wheat 3/4 to 3 1/4 cents a bushel lower than yesterday; corn, 1 1/4 to 2 3/4 cents up, and oats, 1/2 cent down to 3/8 cent up. Barley was unchanged.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- An anti-monopoly suit will be filed soon in the New York Federal court against the four major radio networks, according to word here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- In literature and journalisim for many years traveling legislators have been depicted as menaces to worthy public causes, joy-riding junketers at the expense of taxpayers, meddlesome ignoramuses who return to their duties confirmed in their ignorance, and generally a pain in the neck to hard-working administrators abroad and their more intelligent colleagues at home.

The exuberant Madame Reine staged a party in her salon at 4 East Fifty-seventh Street yesterday afternoon in honor of Maurice Chevalier, whose songs inspired many of the new spring hats that were shown to a large invited audience.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 30 (AP) -- An American student of Tibetan culture has been missing since midSeptember on a trip to a Tibetan monastery and may be dead, his wife said today.

A commitment of $5,460,000 to insure a mortgage of that amount on the second section of buildings in Glen Oaks Village in Queens has been issued by the New York Office of the Federal Housing Administration through Thomas G. Grace, state director.

The central point in the report of the President's Committee on Civil Rights is the reaffirmation of an old principle -- one too often misunderstood, ignored and even jeered at in these days. This is, as Thomas Jefferson wrote in the Declaration of Independence, that "all men are created equal."

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Kenmore Stable's. Zo-Bo hit the turn seven lengths in front in the sixth race at Rockingham Park today and hung on to win by slightly more than two lengths before a thoroughly chilled crowd of 4,506.

Rapidly approaching the $5,000,000,000 mark, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the New York City reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System advanced last week for the fifteenth consecutive time, rising $107,000,000 to a new high level of $4,996,000,000, it was announced yesterday.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 30 -- A proposed American Legion housing plan, hailed by its sponsors as the answer to the problem of providing adequate low - cost housing for World War II veterans, was adopted today by the Legion's National Executive Committee assembled here for their annual three-day fall conference.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The executive board of the CIO-Utility Workers Union removed James L. Daugherty, California regional director from that body today because he refused to sign a nonCommunist affidavit, which would qualify the union for access to the National Labor Relations Board.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I am afraid that your editoris "Hunger Cannot Wait," printed in THE TIMES of Oct. 25, failed to take into consideration some very important points.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- Eviction of the Brazilian mission from Berlin was demanded today by the Soviet commander, Marshal Vassily D. Sokolovsky, in consequence of the breach in diplomatic relations between Brazil and the Soviet Union.

GENEVA. Oct. 30 -- William Hallam Tuck, executive secretary of the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization, successfully resisted today a renewed attempt to establish a special committee to exercise surveillance over his administration.

Fordham's passing game -- offensive and defensive -- received special attention yesterday as the varsity wound up its drills for tomorrow's Boston University contest with a dummy scrimmage against the freshmen. Thirty-one players will depart this afternoon at 3 o'clock from the 125th Street Station for Boston.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- President Will Harridge of the American League today projected his organization into the controversy raging between A.B. Chandler, commissioner of baseball, and the Chicago White Sox and Leslie O'Connor, Sox general manager.
GENEVA, Oct. 30 -- Twenty-three nations signed the final act of the Geneva Trade Conference in the Council Room of the United Nations Palace in Geneva at 10 A. M. today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Department of Agriculture today allocated for export in December 871,800 long tons or 33,669,000 bushels of wheat, flour, barley, oats and grain sorghums.

NEW ORLEANS, Oct. 30 -- Homemakers have a big stake in the investigations into nutrition now being conducted in university laboratories. What is discovered in the sanctum of science can determine what is set on the diningtable to the improvement of health throughout the country.

ROME, Oct. 30 - The Government scored a minor victory in the Constituent Assembly this evening when it defeated a Communist and left wing Socialist maneuver to present another motion of no confidence in Premier Alcide de Gasperi and his Cabinet.

When representatives of twenty-three of the world's principal trading nations assembled at Geneva last April 10 it was with the purpose of carrying out two tasks, each a formidable one in its own right. The first was to complete the work begun in London a year ago of writing a definitive charter for the International Trade Organization.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Minister of Economic Affairs, said today that the present average of 2,700 calories daily in the food supply of Britain was too low and further cuts could not be made without "great difficulty." He said strenuous efforts would be made to avoid any such cut in rations and he hoped, the caloric quota could be raised in 1948.

Around this time the booking moguls generally go berserk in their efforts to straighten out booking jams. Not at present, though. For instance, "Angel in the Wings," the summer circuit revue first known as "Heaven Help the Angels," has a choice of no less than three houses -- Coronet, Mansfield and Royale.

RICHMOND, Va., Oct. 30 (AP) -- A tale of buried treasure valued at between $10,000,000 and $11,000,000 in gold or silver bullion and belonging to the Confederate States of America came out of the Governor's office today.
Wall Street struck back quickly yesterday at the charges of monopolistic conspiracy leveled by the Government at seventeen of the largest investment banking concerns.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Oct. 25 were 954,627 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 378 cars, or .04 per cent, more than for the preceding week; 12,370 cars, or 1.3 per cent, more than for the corresponding week last year, and 99,848 cars, or 11.7 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

Urging an immediate and complete revision of our school and college curriculums, Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College, charged yesterday that the American educational system has become a massive quiz program.

The State Board of Social Welfare achieved its first tangible result from investigating the city's relief administration yesterday when Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, ordered the family of a $100-a-week automobile salesman dropped from the relief rolls as ineligible.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- President Truman will ask Congress to approve an interest-free Treasury loan of $65,000,000 to the United Nations for construction of the East River capital in midtown Manhattan, the United States delegation announced here today.

Friday, Oct. 31, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Voted 41 to 0, with seven abstentions, to adopt United States resolution calling for temporary commission to observe election of representatives in Korea to confer with United Nations representatives of future government.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- A Senate inquiry developed testimony today that an Americanowned petroleum company sold oil to the French for 90 and 95 cents a barrel at the same time it was charging the United States Navy $1.05 a barrel.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Fluctuations in the business cycle can be moderated, Paul G Hoffman, president of the Studebaker Corporation and chairman of the Committee for Economic Development, declared today in an address before the annual meeting of the American Bakers Association.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Citizens Food Committee stood firm again today against requests that it modify its definition of poultryless Thursday to except turkeys. The request was filed by the Turkey Growers Association several days ago.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Oct. 30 -- City authorities and the Junior Chamber of Commerce have arranged a rapid-fire program of entertainment for tomorrow night that they hope will keep the small fry in such a dither of excitement that they will forget to, tear the city apart in good old Halloween fashion.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- After a week of word-by-word examination, a detailed blueprint for the proposed United Nations "Little Assembly" was completed today and made ready for presentation to the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Oct. 30 -- The "Hoboken March of Progress" celebration that has been going on throughout October came to a soggy and confusing end tonight when a heavy rain disrupted the final program, scheduled to be held outdoors.

Simon Schuster is rushing into print the report of the Truman Civil Rights Committee. Published in pamphlet form and entitled "To Secure These Rights," it will sell for $1. A special introduction has been written by Charles E. Wilson, chairman of the committee.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Former Secretary of State Cordell Hull, who fathered the reciprocal trade agreements in this country, in a statement today hailed with "profound gratification" the "conclusion of the successful trade agreement negotiations at Geneva as a continuation "on a broad scale" of the program begun here in 1934.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Oct. 30 -- Mrs. William Hockenjos Jr. and Bud Geoghegan of Crestmont, and Miss Laddie Irwin of Glen Ridge and Emery Thomas of Forest Hill reached the final round of the first New Jersey lady and pro alternate shot match-play championship at the Crestmont Golf Club today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Initial reparations claims filed by eleven Pacific Allies against Japan were reported today, on the basis of one key estimate, to add up to approximately $54,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that dollar volume of September sales at retail stores totaled $9,285,000,000, about 13 per cent more than the corresponding month of last year.

CRAIGELLACHIE, Scotland, Oct. 30 -- Whisky is being distilled today in sixty of northern Scotland's 100-odd distilleries. How long the distillation process will continue is a matter of major concern to 2,500 persons directly dependent upon distilling and double that number who derive a living indirectly from, the production process.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Average primary, market prices rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended on last Saturday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Generally higher prices for non-agricultural commodities more than offset lower agricultural prices.

None could have guessed when Frances Folsom was a child of 11, just after her father's death, that she was destined to be the first woman to marry a President of the United States in the White House. Yet from that hour her path led there. Her father's law partner, Grover Cleveland, was a rising young man in Buffalo politics.

Backstage at "Fashions of the Times" there is drama, too. Not all the action is spotlighted for the capacity audiences filling Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street, to see the fashion production sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, that ends its four-day run this evening.
Two of racing's upper-bracket taxpayers -- neither of whom has bet a peso on a horse in years -- were the most prominent persons in the Empire City-at-Jamaica proceedings yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Repeal of the 15 per cent Federal tax on Pan-American travel, elimination of the "black market" in money exchange and reduction of restrictions by the United States on traffic in and out of this country were urged today at the opening of the annual general assembly of the Inter-American Federation of Automobile Clubs here.

An infant's size iron lung was rushed fifty miles through heavy rain from Ridgewood, N.J., to Far Rockaway, Queens, last night by New York City and New Jersey State policemen to save the life of a 4-month-old boy.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 30 -- Through broad areas of the United States the strongest and most effective attack being made upon the whole design for American aid to Europe's relief and reconstruction, and the most dangerous to the Administration's objectives, is being made by word of mouth.

Restores Presto Cooker Quotas Beginning Nov. 1 all Presto pressure cookers will be placed on an allotment basis for an indefinite period, Morton Philips, vice president of the National Pressure Cooker Company, disclosed yesterday. Mr. Philips explained that the action is being taken to assure equitable distribution to retailer's in the face of increased demand and inadequate production.
Herbert N. Frank, formerly manager of distribution planning, has been named assistant to Wesby R. Parker, general manager of the General Foods Sales Division.

Much of the interest attaching, to the National Horse Show that begins its eight-day run at Madison Square Garden next Tuesday centers in the competition for the jumper championship, which is looked upon as wide open.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 30 -- The local stock market took its worst drop In years today on news that the Swedish Government had appointed a committee to draft a law temporarily freezing part of corporative earnings. As an antiinflationary measure, the proposal is aimed as a brake on increases in dividends, salaries and fresh investments.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- Again overriding last-ditch Soviet opposition, the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly today approved a United States proposal to establish a United Nations commission that would facilitate and observe the election of Korean representatives. The vote was 41 to 0, with seven abstentions, and the Soviet bloc and several other countries not voting.

The program of Mr. Stokowski's concert last night in Carnegie Hall, when the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra gave the premiere of Elie Siegmeister's First Symphony and put by its side various more or less antiquated pieces of the repertory, was very instructive, and in nothing more instructive than the matter of what kind of music best survives the passage of time.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 30 -- A seven-year $2,000,000,000 program of reclamation involving fourteen western states was outlined today by Secretary of the Interior Julius A. Krug to the annual convention of the National Reclamation Association.

EACH successive volume of Van Wyck Brooks' "history of the literary life in America" adds another major unit to the grand design on which Mr. Brooks has been at work so long, with such scholarly industry and such verbal felicity. But as the structure grows its final form seems to grow more and more dim, and, alas, less and less imposing.

Exploring Africa. like a lot of other time-honored activities, is just not what it used to be, said Dr. James L. Clark at the Museum of Natural History yesterday on the eve of his sixth departure for the Dark Continent.

The curtain goes up on "Jack and the Beanstalk" at the BarbizonPlaza Theatre tomorrow at 2:30 P.M., presenting the first of a series of classics for young people by the Children's World Theatre. Performances will be repeated Saturdays and Sundays at 2:30 P.M. through Dec. 7.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Four of the turf's brightest stars were entered today for the eleventh Pimlico special tomorrow, but for all the talk about a horse named Armed it might just as well be another of those 1942 Whirlaway walkovers.

About 32,000 commuters jammed the ferries and other transportation facilities at the height of the rush hour last night, because of the all-day disruption of service on the Hudson Manhattan Railroad between downtown Manhattan and Jersey City.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 -- The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that student-veterans and their families residing in the Shanks Village temporary housing project while attending New York City colleges may vote in Rockland County.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Registration statements covering $5,000,000 of debentures and 41,270 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Word has just arrived from Bob Elliott of the Maine Development Commission that the situation there is improving rapidly and that the woods are expected to be open to hunting within a few days.

Going into the final months of a year which has produced a substantial volume of business, dry goods wholesalers are emphasizing the need to maintain fast-moving inventories only, it was pointed out yesterday by downtown jobbers.

This week-end's activity in professional football will open tonight, with the Brooklyn Dodgers opposing the Chicago Rockets in an AllAmerica Conference game at Ebbets Field. Despite the lowly status of the teams, this shapes up as an interesting contest.

Seventeen of the country's leading investment banking partnerships and corporations, which have controlled the management of 68.9 per cent of the securities issued between 1938 and last April 30, were named defendants yesterday in a civil complaint by the Department of Justice accusing them of violating the anti-trust laws.

CLYDEBANK, Scotland, Oct. 30 -- All Clydebank took time off today to give a roaring welcome to Princess Elizabeth, who, escorted by her fiance, Earl Mountbatten, launched the 34,000-ton Cunard White Star liner Caronia.

Prints loom large in "Fashions of The Times." This is a literal statement for, to get across the magnificent achievement of artists and textile houses producing prints, a unique method of displaying them was devised for "Fashions of The Times," which will end its showings in Times Hall tonight.
MANILA, Friday, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A typhoon, which roared across Samar Island and caused distress to at least three ships, headed toward Manila today.
Cotton futures became moderately active again yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, and closing prices were virtually at the best levels of the day, 3 to 38 points higher.

CHANDLER vs. O'Connor -- The ballot box will have to get a different kind of stuffing today because the battle between A.B. (formerly Happy) Chandler and Leslie O'Connor seems to outrank for the moment such battles as Navy-Notre Dame and Michigan-Illinois. These are two broken-field runners who are very hard to pull down in the open, each a master at faking and feinting.

New Treasury Call The United States Treasury issued yesterday an additional call on its War Loan accounts -- this time against the larger, class B banks only. The call, requiring 8 per cent of such deposits as of the close of business on Oct. 29, must be met on Nov. 6.

DUBLIN, Oct. 30 -- Ireland is likely to be involved in an immediate general election as a result of by-election returns, made known here tonight, indicating a marked reverse in the support of Premier Eamon de Valera's administration.

Speedy action by three cooperating Federal agencies in New York and adjoining states will make available several hundred emergency homes for families in Bar Harbor and other sections of Maine which have just been ravaged by forest fires, it was learned last night.

More than twenty-three million electric motors and generators of all types up to 200-horsepower were on unfilled orders of the electrical manufacturing industry on June 30, comprising a 15.2-month backlog, E.E. Helm, chairman of the motor and generator section, National Electrical Manufacturers Association, disclosed yesterday in an interview at the St. Regis Hotel.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 -- Gertrude Atherton, the novelist, celebrated her ninetieth birthday anniversary today by receiving a gold medal from San Francisco, with an inscription commending her services to California literature.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Two internationally recognized authorities on dirigibles today urged the President's Air Policy Commission to recommend Government support for a revived program of dirigible building as a basic part of the defense program of this country.

Undismayed by his three losing attempts thus far Tami Mauriello, Fordham heavyweight, will make another effort against Gus Lesnevich of Cliffside, N.J., when they square off in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 -- Hundreds of Armenians who have held United States citizenship for ten to twenty years are prepared to renounce their American rights in order to return to Soviet-dominated Armenia, it is reported by officials. Thus far, it is understood, their departure has been delayed by the Department of State.

Daniel Burke, president of the American Bible Society, presented 10,000 Russian Bibles yesterday afternoon at Bible House, Park Avenue and Fifty-seventh Street, to Metropolitan Gregory of Leningrad and Novgorod. He also presented 5,000 Russian New Testament and Psalms books, 100,000 Russian Gospels and 1,000 Greek New Testaments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Dr. Colston E. Warne, an unpaid consultant to the Council of Economic Advisers, made known today his refusal to sign, on principle, the loyalty questionnaire being distributed to all Federal employes.

Brazil will adjust its tariff rates shortly in accordance with the present depreciated value of the cruzeiro, it was announced here yesterday by the Brazilian Government Trade Bureau. It was explained that, when the Brazilian specific tariffs were fixed in 1934, 12.69 cruzeiros equaled $1, while depreciation of the cruzeiro since that time has made the dollar equal to 18.67 cruzeiros, signifying an actual reduction of Brazilian import duties of 47 per cent.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- In a farewell interview, Col. Hugh B. Hester, chief of the United States Military Government Food and Agricultural Branch since 1945, declared that the German food situation was "more stabilized" than at any time since the end of the war.

CALCUTTA, India, Oct. 30 -- Calcutta has weathered another communal crisis with the conclusion of a series of pijas (Hindu festivals) today. Now East and West Bengal can look forward, unlike most other provinces in India, to a measurable future of HinduMoslem peace.
PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 30 -- "You said I was scared, didn't you? All right, then, I'm scared."
Old-Time Geographer It is extremely unlikely that there is any student in P.S. 36, now struggling manfully with his geography book of ungainly size, who ever heard of Jesse Olney, A.M.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 30 -- Ethel Barrymore has expressed her willingness to play Liza Gant, the mother, in the projected screen version of Thomas Wolfe's novel, "Look Homeward, Angel," Seymour Nebenzal, producer of the film, announced today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- During the week ended Oct. 29, member bank reserve balances decreased $178,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board announced today.

The stock market surpassed yesterday the break of last Friday, and in one of the severest setbacks in recent months prices retreated fractions to 4 points or more before steadying influences reduced some of the declines. Only a few issues managed to escape the pressure which produced a net loss of 2.05 in the industrial averages and of 1.22 in the composite rate.
The dignity of Park Avenue will not be ruffled by central mall exhibits or elevated moving sidewalks when the city celebrates its Golden Anniversary next year.
PARIS, Oct. 30 -- Premier Paul Ramadier won a vote of confidence in the Assembly today, 300 to 280.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The House of Commons, sitting in judgment tonight on one of its members, Garry Allighan, Laborite, voted by 187 to 75 to expel him for "dishonorable conduct."

From the point of view of showmanship, probably Edith Piaf ought not to be standing alone on the blank stage of the Playhouse at the end of a trivial variety show. The atmosphere is too formal and cold. She is a singer of French ballads in a frank and intimate style that scrupulously avoids showmanship.

Earl Bunting, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, urged yesterday an attack on high prices through labor-management cooperation to reduce production costs. Speaking at a luncheon of the Rotary Club of New York at the Commodore Hotel, he said teamwork could bring about lower prices.

LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The United States and British Governments have been in consultation for some time on measures to be taken in Germany if no agreement is reached on that country's future when the Council of Foreign Ministers meets here next month, it was learned today.

VIENNA, Oct. 30 -- The Austrian Government was rebuked today by Col. Charles S. Miller, United States chief of the Preparatory Commission for the International Refugee Organization, for continually representing the 500,000 displaced persons now being accommodated in Austria as an unmitigated burden on the country's economy.

PARIS, Oct. 30 -- France maintains her objections to the levelof-industry plan for the United States and British zones of Germany and this is delaying other accords on Germany. Among these are agreements on the dismantling of German factories and the allotments of German coking coal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Striking back at the Department of Justice today, the Investment Bankers Association of America said the Government's accusations were leveled because the organization and its members had opposed compulsory competitive bidding for securities.

ATHENS, Oct. 30 -- A battle involving more than 5,000 guerrillas and the Eighth and Ninth Divisions of the Greek Army has been going on behind a veil of military secrecy in the region of Metsovo, northeast of Yanina, near the Albanian border, for the last ten days.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A subcommittee of the House Committee on Un-American Activities disclosed today an unsuccessful attempt by Soviet agents to obtain data on a "highly destructive weapon" in 1942 and 1943.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- At least fifty-one nations will compete in the Olympics next summer -- the largest number in the modern history of the games, the British Organizing Committee reported today. Burma and Jamaica were the last two acceptors, raising the total to fifty-one -- one more than attended the Berlin Olympics in 1936.

The traditional school building is outmoded and should be changed to serve more adequately the needs of the neighborhood in which it is situated, officials of the Board of Education have reported in a manual of school planning which is to be issued soon.

The executive boards of the American Labor party and the Liberal party are prepared to reexamine their traditional stand in opposition to a fare rise on the municipal transit lines, it was learned last night.

After a demand by the Greater New York CIO Council that he state his position on the proposition to repeal the proportional representation method of electingmembers of the City Council, Mayor O'Dwyer announced yesterday that he would take no sides in the controversy.

Directors of the Davega Stores Corporation voted yesterday to recommend to stockholders approval of a plan of recapitalization which would include authorization of $2,500,000 of $20 par value preferred stock, issuable in one or more series.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- By a vote of 31 to 5, the General Assembly's Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee approved today a resolution looking to the preparation of world-wide principles on trade union rights.

The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad will spend $6,000,000 for the purchase of forty-six new passenger cars and for the reconditioning and modernizing of 104 old cars if the road's applications for fare increases, pending in four states, are granted.
Columbia's football team entrained for Ithaca, N.Y., yesterday, anticipating a rugged game with Cornell at Schoellkopf Crescent tomorrow.

The State Department's proposal to stop shipments of Scotch Whisky from Great Britain to the United States to save grain for Europe's needy was assailed yesterday by Harrx L. Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc.

City College's football team tapered off yesterday for its meeting with Brooklyn College at Ebbets Field tomorrow night, but interest and preparation for the battle rose to a fever pitch in a "Beat Brooklyn" rally during the afternoon.

An equitable system of dealing with the social and economic aspects of migratory farm labor in the Atlantic Coast area as a means of increasing the world food supply was advocated yesterday at a conference of Federal and state officials.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Championship football honors of the Big Nine and Michigan's drive to a Rose Bowl bid will be at stake in the super-charged Michigan-Illinois game at Champaign on Saturday. The contest will be witnessed by a sell-out crowd of 71,119.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I was glad to see in your Oct. 17 issue, that recommendations are being made by the Small Business Advisory Committee to amend the tax provisions concerning "improperly" undistributed profits of corporations. In my opinion, Section 102 is one of the worst sections of the Internal Revenue Code.
There are now more than a half dozen sites in this harbor upon which modern piers could be constructed with little or no interference to existing operations, it was found yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 30 Three defendants in the Maniu reason trial here testified before the Bucharest Military Tribunal today that two American officers of the Office of Strategic Services had met with them last year to plan a secret semi-military organization to resist the pro-Soviet proram and, eventually to overthrow the present Rumanian Government.
ROME, Oct. 30 -- Pope Pius XII deplored attacks that he said totalitarian regimes were making against the Church for political reasons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics survey of fifty foods in fifty-six large cities showed a retail price increase of 1.8 per cent between mid-July and mid-August, setting a record high of 196.5 per cent of the 193539 base period, the Labor Department stated today.

Hollywood's Committee for the First Amendment has bought more network time to voice its opposition to the hearings of the House subcommittee on Un - American Activities, which is currently concentrating its attention on film personalities.
BELLMORE, L.I., Oct. 30 -- A man and a woman lost their lives this evening in the collision of their automobile and a westbound Long Island Rail Road train at the Center Avenue grade crossing here.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Oct. 30 -- The display windows of seventy-five stores in this community's business district served as canvases today for 150 high school and elementary school students. The youngsters were permitted by the local merchants to give full vent to their artistic impulses in the hope that they would restrain more impulsive ones despite the temptations offered by Halloween.

Larmon Heads New Ad Group A new committee on advertising, headed by Sigurd S. Larmon, president of Young Rubicam, Inc., and composed of twelve other leaders of the advertising field, was appointed yesterday by the United States Associates of the International Chamber of Commerce.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 -- George Eltenton named in testimony before the House un-American Activities Subcommittee in Washington today in connection with alleged attempts of the Soviet Government to obtain information on atomic energy development at Berkeley in 1942, was employed until three weeks ago as a physicist at the Emeryville (Calif.) plant of the Shell Development Company.

The twenty-week-old strike of Hanscom Baking Corporation employes, the city's longest current walkout, was settled yesterday with the signing of a new contract between the company and Local 50 of the Bakery and Confectionery Workers International Union, AFL.

To maintain present national levels of industrial production and insure maximum fortification against a "boom and bust cycle," Government policies should be modernized to bring capital goods amortization and depreciation allowances into line with actual plant practices, Tell Berna, general manager, National Machine Tool Builders Association, declared in a statement yesterday to THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The realization by a Customs inspector that a seaman is not likely to do any painting without a brush led to an important seizure of silver fox fur pieces, perfume and jewelry, it was learned here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that fifty issues of securities with a total value of 51,018,235,000 became effective under the Securities Act of 1933 during last month.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- Gold and Malaya Rubbers shares stood out as active features in generally quiet trading today.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 30 -- While relations between India and Pakistan appeared today to have stiffened as a result of the fighting between Indian troops and anti-Government forces in the Princely State of Kashmir, the heads of the two Dominions scheduled a conference Saturday in Lahore, Pakistan, on the Kashmir crisis.

KLAMATH FALLS, Ore., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The bodies of Oregon's Governor, Earl Snell, Secretary of State Robert S. Farrell Jr. and the Senate President, Marshall Cornett, were found today with that of their pilot, Cliff Hogue. The wreckage of Tuesday's night's plane crash was reached this morning at the base of a cliff in Green Valley, about seventy miles east of here, near the California border.

Mayor O'Dwyer in a surprise move to revitalize a long-slumbering city department announced yesterday appointment of Edward C. Maguire, former director of the City Division of Labor Relations, as Commissioner of Commerce.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Two destroyers and a Walrus aircraft turned back a large Normandybound invasion force when D-Day was postponed for twenty-four hours in 1944, and prevented a disastrously premature warning of the landing reaching the Germans, a report by the Allied Commanderin-Chief of the expeditionary naval forces said today.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: After having traveled to Italy every year between 1928 and 1938, I had the opportunity to revisit that country last August for the first time since the war.

Yi-Kwei Sze, Chinese bass, gave his first American recital last night at Town Hall under the sponsorship of the China Society of America. The 31-year-old artist, who was graduated in 1937 from the National Conservatory in Shanghai, where he studied with a Russian voice teacher, came to this country a year ago and continued his training here.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio declared today that interim aid for Europe was "nothing more than a sixmonth edition of the Marshall plan" and, as such, should be considered at one and the same time as long-range foreign assistance.

Youth heartily put its stamp of approval yesterday on the new trends, as seen in the sixth edition of the "Fashions of the Times," and received a charming new sophistication in the bargain. Endorsed were graceful longer hemlines, skirts full of swirling motion, the barrel silhouette and waists whittled to even a smaller size by little cinches.

Stockholders of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation will be asked at a special meeting on Dec. 23 to approve a proposal to split the common stock three-for-one, E.G. Grace, chairman of the board of directors, announced yesterday. Holders of record of Nov. 10 will be eligible to vote at the meeting.

Stars of the entertainment world put on a three-hour show of comedy and music last night at Madison Square Garden as their contribution toward the erection of the New York University-Bellevue Medical Center on the East Side.

Lack of planning to care for aged in New York State is a form of "legal euthanasia" and should be replaced by a "comprehensive program" of state and community care, the Welfare Council of New York was told yesterday.

Premier Ramadier won the first battle yesterday in the three-front conflict now going on in France, when the National Assembly sustained his reorganized Cabinet by a vote of 300 to 280. In doing so he not only beat off the challenge of General de Gaulle to dissolve the Assembly and call a new national election but also demonstrated that he can muster considerable reserves of strength in an emergency.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The American Ryder Cup golf team today tried out Scotch-foursome play on the Portland Golf Club course with pairings subject to change tomorrow as the best combinations are sought.

Interest in loft, office and store space over a wide area was indicated in commercial leases reported yesterday. Only three of the thirteen stores remain unrented in the two-story store and office building under construction by Sam Minskoff Sons on the Thirtyseventh Avenue blockfront between Seventy-sixth and Seventyseventh Streets in Jackson Heights, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- The text of the statement by Chairman J. Parnell Thomas announcing indefinite adjournment of hearings by the House Un-American Activities Subcommittee on Communism in Hollywood was as follows: The hearing today concludes the first phase of the committee's investigation of communism in the motion picture industry.

Carpet prices probably will rise 3 to 5 per cent before spring because of increased production costs, James DeCamp Wise, president of Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company, predicetd yesterday following the annual meeting of the Carpet Institute, Inc., in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

MONTREAL, Canada, Oct. 30 -- An economic union between Canada and the United States as a possible long-range solution to Canada's trade and financial problems was proposed here today by John Abbink of New York, president of the McGraw-Hill International Corporation and past chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council, Inc.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 30 -- Ralph Bradford, Washington, D.C., executive vice president, United States Chamber of Commerce, today called for development of an international policy, now beginning to be discerned, that is not based on fear or appeasement but upon strength and fearlessness.

A recommendation that all public assistance programs in New Jersey be integrated into a single state agency was made yesterday at the opening session of the threeday annual conference of the New Jersey Welfare Council, meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.

NANKING, Oct. 30 -- The Chinese armed forces, whose size and expenditures are placing a considerable burden on the national economy, now has an annual payroll of 16,800,000,000,000 Chinese dollars, it was learned today.

LOS ANGELES, Calif., Oct. 30 -- Winding up its five-day convention here with a rush of resolutions, presentation of awards, speeches and installation of new officers, the American Trucking Association today swore into office the first new president it has had since it was organized fourteen years ago.

CHICAGO, Oct. 30 -- Four major distilleries have agreed that during the sixty-day voluntary shutdown of the industry to save grain for emergency European relief, their employes will suffer no layoffs or downgrading in pay, according to Joseph O'Neill, general president of the Distillery, Rectifying and Wine Workers International Union, AFL.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 30 -- The disputes between the colonial and non-colonial powers that took up much of the time in Trusteeship Committee debates probably will be resumed tomorrow on the floor of the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow.

SOME people can take the Civil War or leave it alone. They realize its importance in American history; they are not indifferent to its dramatic interest; they read some of the outstanding books about it. But they don't understand why other people collect Civil War facts as if they were stamps or butterflies or dollars or women.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that, effective Monday, brokers' commissions for the buying and selling of securities traded on the Exchange will be calculated on the basis of money involved.

Henry Fonda, who quit the stage ten years ago to cut himself quite a niche in motion pictures, is seriously contemplating a return to the legitimate field. Reports have it that if commitments permit, he will essay the title role in "Mister Roberts," the play based on Thomas Heggen's novel of the same name, dealing with life aboard a Navy supply ship in the Pacific.

Evidence that the X-ray diagnosis of tuberculosis, in certain sections of the country at least may give an erroneous indication of the presence of the disease, was presented yesterday before the New York Academy of Sciences.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The terse message, "No survivors," from a Coast Guard climbing party near the top of snowtipped Mount Tamgas on Annette Island, confirmed late today the deaths of eighteen persons aboard a Pan American Airways airliner which crashed last Sunday.

The conservative parties in Norway have won a victory in the recent municipal elections as portentous as the municipal elections in 1945, according to advices received yesterday by Norwegian Conservative circles here.

NANKING, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Independent and pro-Government newspaper accounts from Manchuria today said that Chinese Government troops had cleared the Communists from the entire 175-mile route of the Changchun-Mukden railway.

MANILA, Oct. 21 -- The Philippine Government has made public a revised version of the Beyster Commission report which blueprints an industrialization program calculated eventually to make the Philippine Republic independent economically as well as politically.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Oct. 31 -- With rain forecast it is likely that Michigan and Illinois will have to contend with a muddy gridiron when the mighty elevens of the Big Nine clash for the thirty-third time tomorrow. Memorial Stadium, site of the traditional struggle, will be jammed to capacity by a turnout of 71,119.

A proposed 1948 capital budget of $244,541,292 was adopted yesterday by the City Planning Commission, which also approved a report recommending a completely self-sustaining fare on the municipal transit lines as the most effective single step the city could take to relieve "a grave crisis growing out of its inability to finance essential public works."

Four of the "President Class" combination cargo-passenger vessels, all more than twenty-six years old, were offered for sale yesterday by the Maritime Commission, for scrapping purposes only. The ships were used as troop transports during World War II.

Switzerland is making extensive preparations to welcome a record crowd of visitors and competitors for the fifth Winter Olympic Games to be held at St. Moritz, in (the Canton of Grissons, next Jan. 30-Feb. 8. This was disclosed yesterday by Werner Grob, manager of the successful Swiss ski team that invaded America last winter, who arrived from his homeland aboard the Cunard White Star Liner Queen Elizabeth.

Organization of the Lustron Corporation of Chicago, which expects to become the nation's first company to produce low-cost, long-life housing on an automobile assembly line basis, was set yesterday after the company completed financing giving it a total capitalization of $16,340,000 and established a seven-member board of directors, according to an announcement by Carl G. Strandlund, president.

The United Nations General Assembly rejected last night an attempt by the Soviet Union to separate the non-self-governing territories of Asia and the Far East from the control of their administering powers in international affairs.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The three-state Cooperative Grange League Federation Exchange today gave up its Federal income tax exemption rights by amending its membership requirements.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct. 31 -- Premier Tage Erlander said last night that, even with the greatest economy in imports Sweden probably would have to purchase next year United States goods exceeding by 500,000,000 to 600,000,000 crowns (approximately $140,000,000 to $150,000,000) the value of exports to that country.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Grain markets showed a strong undertone on the Board of Trade from the opening today and, although trade was relatively light early the markets turned upward sharply in the late trading on buying induced by reports of severe dust storms in northwestern Oklahoma and a Weather Bureau report confirming high winds in that state and the Texas Panhandle.

After two years of negotiations, the headquarters agreement between the United States and the United Nations was ratified yesterday by the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow and will probably become effective in about a week.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Oct. 31 -- A rump committee of officers of the retail, wholesale and department store union, CIO, including seven members of the union's executive board, today termed proceedings here to investigate certain charges against International President Samuel Wolchok of New York "a sham and designed for rocket speed whitewash."

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 31 (AP) -- British team captain, Henry Cotton, paired with Arthur Lees, will lead Britain's quest for the Ryder Cup in tomorrow's opening matches in the revival of the international golfing event on the Portland Golf Club course.
The fate of the Germans, Italians and quislings accused of the crimes of World War II split the Allied governments yesterday in one of the angriest debates of the United Nations General Assembly.

LAGRANGE. Ga., Oct. 31 -- The great Callaway Mills. valued at $33,750,000, will operate after Dec. 1 purely for the benefit of its 7,500 employes and for charitable, educational and religious institutions, it was announced today following a special stockholders meeting Thursday.
Off to a slow start this season and going nowhere in the AllAmerica Conference race, the Brooklyn Dodgers proved last night that at least they are masters of the Chicago Rockets.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (U.P.) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board adopted a regulation today authorizing removal of parachute flares, which are believed to have figured in the Utah crash last week, from all Douglas DC-6 airplanes.

A series of minor explosions in the basement of the seventy-story RCA Building in Rockefeller Center, beginning at 10:40 o'clock last night and continuing intermittently for about half an hour, sent choking clouds of black oily smoke billowing through the ground floor lobby and along the West Fiftieth Street side of the building, which stands between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Truman, in emphasizing the value of international highways for preserving peace, said today that it was when "we swell up and think we are better than somebody else that we can't get along with our neighbors."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Teachers' salaries over the country have been raised an average of 13 per cent over last year, but this increase has been "canceled by the sharp rise in the cost of living," John W. Studebaker, United States Commissioner of Education, told the Citizens Federal Committee on Education today.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 31 -- James Bruce, United States Ambassador, took formal notice today of repeated charges that Argentina was the victim of an "economic blockade."

Advocating a more flexible admissions policy for American colleges and universities, speakers at the Twelfth Educational Conference charged yesterday that many bright students cannot enter college because of rigid entrance requirements.

Net profit of the Monsanto Chemical Company and its subsidiaries in the nine months ended Sept. 30 increased to $12,395,367 after taxes and all charges from the $6,987,663 earned in the first nine months of last year, according to the report of Edgar M. Queeny, board chairman, mailed yesterday to stockholders.

PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP) -- A California Institute of Technology scientist disclosed today what he termed the first laboratory confirmation of the theory that atomic bomb exposure could lead to inheritable defects which might produce human deformities in Japan for the next 1,000 years.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- The United States today withdrew its proposal for the establishment of a United Nations constabulary force to keep order in Palestine until partition takes effect, and urged that Great Britain, as the mandatory power, continue this responsibility until authority was transferred to the proposed Jewish and Arab states.

Even with three tradition steeped and highly-interesting Ivy League battles on tap, the heavy traffic in college football will by-pass the East today. The nation's foremost gridiron experts are flocking to the Midwest, South and Southwest for the lead stories.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday lacked a trend and closed 3 points higher to 10 points lower.

Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, said last night that universal military training followed by less intensive training in the National Guard or organized reserves was the best insurance the United States could have for the maintenance of permanent peace.

Greater New York's Golden Jubilee celebration will enter its first phase today with the official opening of a temporary postal substation on the ground floor of the old Sub-Treasury Building at Wall and Nassau Streets.
For the first time in more than five years the price of sugar will be free today of all Federal controls.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Counsel for 14-year-old Fred Walter Smigelski of Newark challenged today the right of the Hudson County Court of Oyer and Terminer to try the Smigelski boy on a charge of murder.
Fordham University enrolled yesterday as students a young Palestinian Jew and his wife who hope to make American culture and its techniques play a more dynamic role in the culture of their homeland.

PRINCETON, N.J., Oct. 31 -- Princeton and Pennsylvania, each limited to two effective days of practice by week-long rains, will play their grudge battle in Palmer Stadium tomorrow. The game will be the climax to a fortnight of campus paint raids and an almost daily interchange of official letters between the two schools.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Ray Beasley ran for three touchdowns, two of them In the first (four minutes of the game, to lead Virginia Tech to a 42-6 victory over George Washington tonight. It was the losers' sixth straight, and worst, defeat of a victoryless season, and snapped a V.P.I. four-game slump.

Immediate and unqualified rejection by Arab spokesmen at the United Nations General Assembly session at Flushing Meadow greeted the announcement yesterday of the United States plan for the partition of Palestine around July 1, 1948.

TRENTON, N.J., Oct. 31 -- The appointment of Arthur T. Vanderbilt as a member of the New Jersey Circuit Court was announced today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll. Mr. Vanderbilt is dean of New York University Law School, a past president of the American Bar Association and the Republican leader of Essex County.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Comfortable hotels for 40,000 old or infirm persons who need care will be estabished throughout Great Britain under the provisions of the Government's National Assistance Bill, which was published today with an accompanying explanatory White Paper.
Europe is in a state of complete economic collapse and American withdrawal from the Continent will mean its immediate absorption by Communists, Senator H. Alexander Smith declared here yesterday.

Reformation Day will be observed tomorrow by Protestant churches of all denominations. Under the Manhattan and Bronx Divisions of the Protestant Council of the City of New York a service will be held tomorrow at 8 P.M. in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

The Appellate Division of the Supreme Court unanimously affirmed yesterday the decision of Justice Ferdinand Pecora upholding the position of Local 100 of the Transport Workers Union, CIO, in its dispute over a pension arbitration award with the New York City Omnibus Corporation.

Today there are enough of the perishable foods at prices a few cents lower than they were last Friday so that a careful shopper may make selections that will bring the cost of this week-end's marketing to a total a dollar or so less than it was seven days ago.
NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- The Indian Ministry of Commerce has begun what it describes as a "dynamic policy" to build up a sizable merchant marine.

Edmund Kurtz, who played at Carnegie Hall last night, is a 'cellist with a command of the mechanics of the instrument he plays. He has, to begin with, a tone of warm, sensuous quality that seldom loses its luster, thanks in part to the fine, old 'cello he plays and thanks also to his talent for handling it.

Horace Mann School's football team continued unbeaten, untied and unscored upon by vanquishing Poly Prep of Brooklyn, 14 -- 0, yesterday at Poly Field. It was the fourth straight success for the winners, who scored in the first and last periods while holding the Dyker Heights eleven to a single threat.
The stricter regulation of sleeping pills, which becomes effective in this city today, won the approval yesterday of the New York Academy of Medicine.

The football meeting tonight between C.C.N.Y. and Brooklyn College at Ebbets Field will feature a struggle between the Kingsmen's host of capable backs and a superior Beaver forward wall, City Coach Harold J. Parker predicted yesterday.

In a vigorous defense of the new Feinberg Teachers' Salary Law, Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, declared yesterday that the statute can be made to work and that it could result in "lasting professional advantages" to teachers.

The Picasso exhibition at the Knoedler Galleries for the benefit of the Public Education Association, has broken all records for attendance at the galleries with 20,000 paid admissions to date. A self-portrait, painted in 1906 and never before shown in this country, has been added to the exhibition, which closes on Nov. 8.

Squirrels vs. Telephones From Leesburg, Va., came a report the other day that squirrels had cut off telephone service along seven miles of a cable between that town and the village of Waterford. "The squirrels," it said, "sharpening their teeth on the lead-encased cable, punctured it in several places.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 31 -- Quakers of the United States and Britain -- members of the Society of Friends that for 300 years has stuck to the tenet of brotherly love while the world has been torn by many wars -- received the Nobel Peace Prize today.

Conviction of Dr. Juliu Maniu and eighteen co-defendants by the Bucharest Military Tribunal was described as a "foregone conclusion," here yesterday by two former Rumanian Foreign Ministers, who, themselves, are on trial in absentia in the case.

GENEVA, Oct. 31 -- The Netherlands delegate, Dr. Hilda VerweyJonker, withdrew from the International Refugee Organization's Preparatory Commisaion meeting today in protest against the refusal of the executive secretary, William Hallam Tuck, to accept the creation of an intergovernmental advisory committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- Foley Brothers of Pleasantville, N.Y., one of the largest contracting companies in the country, has forfeited $100,000 because its experts, in submitting a bid for building piers for a bridge across the Schuylkill River here, forgot to figure in the cost of forms in which to pour the concrete.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 6,000 head total 1,500 Early trade around 25 cents lower but later market and close slow and 25 to 50 cents lower on all weights of butchers hogs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A dramatic eleventh-hour capitulation by the CIO United Automobile Workers today broke a logjam of union objections which had piled up against the signing of non-Communist affidavits as a step to qualify for access to the National Labor Relations Board.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 -- Haakon Chevalier, former member of the University of California faculty named in testimony before a subcommittee of the House UnAmerican Activities Committee in Washington yesterday, has been subpoenaed to appear before California's counterpart of the Congressional committee when it resumes a hearing in Oakland on Monday, it was disclosed today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- Registration statements covering $3,000,000 of debentures and 1,107,435 shares of common stock were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by three companies.

Despite the mud and dull setting. Maine Chance Farm's War Date won the $5,000 added Class C Ciencia Handicap for fillies and mares on the Empire City card at Jamaica yesterday in a style that belied conditions.

Influences "antagonistic to the Soviet Union" have caused a stalemate in negotiations for reconciliation between the Russian Orthodox Church in America and the Moscow patriarchate, Metropolitan Gregory of Leningrad and Novgorod told Religious News Service here yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- "The Long Way Home," a screen story by Millard Lampell, has been purchased by United States Pictures, the Milton Sperling production company at Warner Brothers, as a vehicle for Lilli Palmer, Sperling disclosed today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Oct. 31 -- A crowd of 60,000 is expected to watch the thirty-first football meeting of Yale and Dartmouth in Yale Bowl tomorrow. The Elis are favored to win for the fourth consecutive year and gain their twenty -first triumph in the series which began back in 1884.
Forty-one police sergeants were promoted yesterday to lieutenants, a captain to a deputy inspector, and a deputy inspector to inspector by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

New York plants are preparing to start annual inventory-taking operations earlier than usual, industrial executives revealed here yesterday, because over-stocks of some semi-finished parts of products have increased the amount of work to be done to levels far above normal.

The four networks and the Radio Writers Guild yesterday concluded a basic agreement establishing new working conditions for freelance script writers. The pact becomes effective Nov. 15 and will run for six and a half years. The minimum fees, however, may be renegotiated every two years.

For voters in different parts of this city there are thirty judicial offices to be filled on election day. Following out usual practice, we present as a trustworthy guide to the merits of candidates for these thirty offices the recommendations of the city's leading bar associations.
YESTERDAY'S MEETINGS General Assembly Met at 11:28 A.M. and designated Oct. 24 as United Nations Day.

PRAGUE, Oct. 31 -- Communists succeeded today in forcing the resignation of the Slovak semiautonomous administration in which the Slovak Democratic party held two-thirds of the seats. The Slovak Cabinet of eight Slovak Democrats and four Communists resigned after a meeting of the Communist-dominated partisan front organization this morning.

Welfare Commissioner Benjamin Fielding went into Doctors Hospital suffering from exhaustion yesterday afternoon as the life of the New York County October grand jury was extended to Jan. 9 to deal with any criminal activity that may emerge from the current inquiries into the city's relief administration.

Totals of new securities offered publicly here in October, although smaller than in the preceding month, were larger than a year ago. A total of $393,939,000 in thirty-six bond issues were marketed, compared with $544,219,000 for thirty-eight offerings in September and $309,384,000 for twentytwo flotations in October, 1946.

A resolution against proportional representation was adopted by a three-to-one vote yesterday after a stormy session at the 134th convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs at the Hotel Astor. For forty-five minutes the 200 delegates, representing 50,000 members in 190 clubs, argued for and against PR.

Government by "crisis" was denounced last night by Governor Dewey as the resort of "bunglers and incompetents" in an indirect attack on the Truman Administration's handling of domestic and foreign questions.

NRDGA, NAEA to Cooperate The National Retail Dry Goods Association and the National Advertising Executives Association have decided to form a joint committee to develop cooperation between the two groups, it was learned yesterday from Howard P. Abrahams, manager of the NRDGA sales promotion division.

Automobile manufacturers, taking advantage of competitive bids, are getting pile fabrics at prices which constitute a loss to upholstery fabric weavers, it was pointed out in the trade yesterday. Current prices, ranging from $2.15 to $2.75 per yard, are higher than pre-war, but do not reflect the 115 per cent increase in labor and 100 per cent increase in material costs, textile men said.
The sixth edition of "Fashion of the Times" ended a triumphan four-day run last night amid a continuing flow of congratulation from the industry.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Government controls over consumer installment credits will terminate tomorrow night, leaving the matter of "easy payments" to the retailer and the buyer.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- With a miniature reproduction of the Freedom Train as its latest attraction, the Westchester Model Club opened an annual exhibition here tonight of the "Eastern Lines" model railroad it operates in an abandoned station of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Oct. 31 -- A prediction that the Taft-Hartley Act would be changed "if it does not work out in practice" and "if it fails to serve the best interests of a majority of the people" was made here today by William T. Gossett, vice president and general counsel of the Ford Motor Company.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 31 --calumet Farm, as expected, won its fourth Pimlico Special today -- but not with the horse nearly everyone had expected to waltz off with the winner -take-all jackpot of $25,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A Congress of Industrial Organizations official, estimating Congress members are paid $7 to $12 an hour, compared that with the 40cent pay minimum fixed by law and stirred up a hornet's nest today at a House Labor Subcommittee hearing.

The serious overcrowding of our municipal hospitals described by Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Hospital Commissioner, in an urgent and appealing report to the Mayor, does not present a pretty picture. To visit the hospitals and see these sick and suffering patients, beds side by side or head to foot, jamming the corridors, filling the solaria and even the aisles of the wards, is even more disheartening.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 -- Captain Tom Hamilton and his Navy football team detrained here this morning from Annapolis and a few hours later Tom was telling a Touchdown Club luncheon group: "We came here to knock their ears off."

Sir Gerald Campbell, former British Consul General at New York and author of a book of memoirs, "Of True Experience," published by Dodd, Mead, is expected here for a tour. He will speak at the Columbia University Institute of Arts and Sciences on "Britain's Battle for Recovery" Nov. 10.

Is cancer hereditary? If the geneticists are certain that it is not, in the sense that color-blindness, hemophilia, white or black skin are hereditary, it is partly because of the experiments that they have been able to carry on with mice which they obtained from the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory and which had been inbred for a quarter of a century so that their lineage was known.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Representatives of the sixteen European nations involved in the Marshall plan have handed an aide-memoire to the State Department outlining their views on how any United States aid to Europe could be effectively supervised.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Marcel Cerdan, Casablanca clouter, survived three last-round knockdowns and maintained his perfect American ring record with a loudly booed ten-round decision over Anton Raadik of Estonia before 9,172 at the Stadium tonight.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Oct. 31 -- The New Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals reversed today a Supreme Court ruling that had required the Mayor and Municipal Council of this city to advertise for bids on city-owned beach-front concessions.

Week o' Hallowe'en Have the October days preceding Hallow'en any astrological affinity with the financial marketplace? Some chartists are taking time out to go into this following the filing of the long-pending suit against certain investment banking firms on Oct. 30.

PORTLAND, Ore., Oct. 31 -- The airplane accident which took the lives of Oregon's Governor, Secretary of State and Senate President not only wiped out the top men of the state administration, but also changed Oregon's political picture entirely.

VIENNA, Oct. 31 -- The Oesterreichische Zeitung, Soviet Army newspaper in Vienna, accused the United States yesterday of claiming from Austria the huge Hermann Goering steel works in Linz while it said that British occupation forces had demanded the equally important Alpin Montan Company, another part of Austria's big iron and steel complex.

SALEM, N.H., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Thomas Haskos Evening Flight defeated Sidney Bernstein's Senator C by a nose in the feature at Rockingham Park today. John L. McKnight's Bold Tie was third, three and a half lengths farther back.
BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- A state prison parolee was arrested on a charge of armed robbery after gunmen today seized the second large payroll taken in a daylight robbery in Boston in two days.

Officials from sixteen states in the Atlantic Coast area recommended yesterday that the Federal Government fully reimburse the states for public assistance granted non-residents, at the close of a conference dealing with the problems of migratory farm labor.

Complaints charging 140 owners and trainers who race horses in New York State with refusing to bargain collectively with Local 814 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, AFL, were issued yesterday by the State Labor Relations Board.

A resurgence of strength in the steel division produced yesterday a sympathetic rebound of limited proportions on the stock market after the sharp setback of Thursday. Although interest proved to be narrow and trading diminished sharply, the industrial averages rallied 0.73 point and the composite rate gained 0.49.

The creation of Air Freight Terminal Systems, Inc., said to be the first international chain of depots to handle air cargo of independent air carriers and shippers, was announced here yesterday by E.J. Daly president of the new corporation.

Adding a final fillip to the dashing costume's exhibited this week in the sixth edition of the "Fashions of the Times" were the imaginative accessories that told a style story. Shoes, bags, gloves, jewelry and all the others contributed to the fashion panorama.

A home relief recipient of $198 a month, whose probation report showed that he used part of the money for bookmaking was sentenced yesterday to a thirtyday workhouse term and a fine of $300 or thirty more days by Chief Magistrate Edgar Bromberger in Probation Courts.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Mrs. Grace Comiskey, president of the White Sox, maintained her silence today in the wake of the authorized removal of Leslie O'Connor, general manager, from baseball's Executive Council, but a club spokesman said the Sox "can't lose" in court and O'Connor "won't back down" in his fight against suspension.
Peter Arno, the cartoonist, was arrested late yesterday afternoon on a charge of having threatened the doorman of a Park Avenue hotel with a .38-caliber pistol.

What has changed in France as the result of the extraordinary come-back of General de Gaulle? Premier Paul Ramadfer, the mild, dry little Socialist whose courage and tenacity have maintained a semblance of government during a grueling year, has won by a hair a short extension of power.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- Denouncing Standard Gas and Electric Company's new plan as vague and indefinite, the Securities and Exchange Commission threatened today to dismiss it. Simultaneously it ordered the company to show why it should not be required to either liquidate and dissolve, or recapitalize on a single-stock basis.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange in October expanded to the largest of the year but was the smallest for a corresponding month since 1944. Sales exceeded the million -share mark in fifteen out of the twenty-two full-day sessions, with the largest total, 1,929,440 shares, on Oct. 14.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Seeking to show that the United States Navy was overcharged for oil from Arabia, Senator Owen Brewster of Maine today turned up what he said looked like a "serious misrepresentation" by American oil interests.
ATHENS, Oct. 31 -- An emergency tax program to raise 600,000,000 drachmas [about $120,000,000] in additional revenue between now and June 30, 1948, was announced today by the Greek Government.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The importance of proportional representation in our City Council elections well merits the editorial space you have been giving it, but I am not impressed with your arguments against it.

ATLANTA, Oct. 31 -- Declaring that business men throughout the country are more conscious of the export field now than ever before, James A. Farley, chairman of the board, the Coca-Cola Export Corporation, warned here today that the export business is not a simple one.

ALBANY, Oct. 31 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, assured by the Conservation Department that the danger of forest fires has been ended by three days of rain, rescinded today his proclamations of Oct. 17 and 22 closing all forests, woodlands and open lands in the state for hunting and recreational purposes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Revised military requirements, including foreign aid, have caused the armed forces to retain $5,000,000,000 in goods which they had planned to declare surplus, the War Assets Administration reported to Congress today.

PARIS, Oct. 31 -- Maurice Thorez, Communist leader, left tonight for Moscow to represent the French Communists in celebrating the thirtieth anniversary of the Russian Revolution, the French news agency reported. If the report is confirmed, M. Thorez will thus have the opportunity to learn at first hand the Kremlin's reaction to the present situation in France.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Oct. 31 -- Dr. Julius Maniu flatly denied today in his trial any desire to overthrow the Government of Premier Petru Groza by violent means. But he assumed full responsibility, Dr. Maniu said, for attempting to smuggle four National Peasant leaders from the country and for furnishing secret information to the British and American Legations here.
GLOUCESTER, Mass., Oct. 31 (AP) -- During most of his life Capt. Irving Johnson's destination has been somewhere beyond a watery horizon, and times have not changed.

A long-sought plan for major changes in the vocational high schools of New York State, providing for at least half of the school time to be used in "productive work," is being considered by the United States Department of Education, George F. Pigott Jr., Associate Superintendent of Schools for Vocational Education in New York City, said last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- A lengthy Treasury Department study on the question of taxing currently tax-exempt farmers' cooperatives, made public today, indicated considerable official doubt on whether there is a practical or desirable means of assessing taxes on them.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- The American Friends Service Committee, co-winner of the 1947 Nobel Peace Prize, has administered some $60,000,000 for relief in more than twenty devastated countries since World War I, it was stated today, following the announcement that it had been selected to share the Nobel award with the London Friends Service Council.
