ATHENS, Ga., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Georgia rolled to three touchdowns in the first half and then toyed with the Clemson Tigers after that to rack up a listless 21-6 football victory on a fog-shrouded field tonight.

The United Nations Security Council in an all-day meeting at Flushing Meadow yesterday moved a step nearer to a decision on the Indonesian question by rejecting Soviet and Australian resolutions and appointing a subcommittee to bring into harmony three amendments to a mild United States proposal.

Gus Lesnevich cut Tami Mauriello down from a heavyweight to a helpless hulk in their scheduled 10-round fight at Madison Square Garden last night. The 32-yearold Lesnevich, spotting his Bronx rival eight years and more than twenty pounds, nevertheless did such a masterful job of butchery on Tami that referee Ruby Goldstein intervened after thirty-three seconds of the seventh round to name Lesnevich the winner by a technical knockout.

An anomalous picture of India, highlighting reconstruction and progress against a background of violence and terror, was given here yesterday by a former mayor of Bombay, who is a Moslem member of the Congress party.
Tallahassee, Fla., announced yesterday that it would offer on Nov. 10 an issue of $1,500,000 of hospital building bonds dated Sept. 1, 1947, and due Sept. 1 from 1950 to 1967 and callable in 1965.

Speaking from a sound truck at Lexington Avenue and East 116th Street, "lucky corner" of the late Fiorello H. La Guardia, Frank J. Sampson, leader of Tammany, urged adoption last night of Proposition No. 4 to repeal the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council and substitute election by State Senate districts.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A campaign by Senator Kenneth S. Wherry, Republican, of Nebraska, to block the sale of 100 Government-owned tankers to foreign governments -- once carried to the White House -- was laid before Senate and House leaders of both parties today.

Plans for marketing in "one package" all of the basic lumber and some other materials needed in the average small home, and arguments favoring strict limitation of exports of building supplies needed to meet the housing shortage in this country were heard at the annual meeting of the board of directors of the National Retail Lumber Dealers Association yesterday.

Devy Erlih, 18-year-old French violinist, made his American debut in a recital given last night at Town Hall. The program he presented consisted of the Brahms Sonata in D minor; the Grave and Fugue from Bach's unaccompanied Sonata in A minor; "Deux danses Bulgares" and "Ostinato" from Bartok's "Microcosmos." in the soloist's own transcription; Paganini's "Caprice," No. 24; the Debussy Sonata; Delvincourt's "Danceries," and Ravel's "Tzigane."

DUBLIN, Oct. 31 -- About nine hours after he had learned of a new reverse to his party -- a byelection defeat in Tipperary -- Premier Eamon de Valera broke his silence to tell the country that he proposed to hold a general election early next year.

NEW DELHI, India, Oct. 31 -- Moslem insurgents were fighting Hindu and Sikh infantrymen of the Indian Army today about sixteen miles from Srinagar, capital of Kashmir state. The invading tribesmen and rebels are making a drive for the airport, which is the only source of reinforcement and supply to the defending troops.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 (AP) -- American League club owners, at a six-hour closed session, bowed today to a request by Commissioner Albert B. (Happy) Chandler that Leslie M. O'Connor, general manager of the suspended Chicago White Sox, be replaced on baseball's executive council.

Cooler Weather Spurs Trade The turn toward cooler weather favored retail trade expansion here this week and increased the recent margin of gain over the coresponding period a year ago. Department store sales were estimated as ranging around 50 per cent over 1946.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Rear Admiral Charles A. Pownall, naval Governor of Guam, reported substantial progress today in rehabilitating that island, but Navy Island policy in general was assailed by the Institute of Ethnic Affairs.

TOKYO, Oct. 31 -- Ichiro Hatoyama, the man whom the occupation purged on the eve of his becoming Prime Minister of Japan, has filed an appeal with the central screening appeal committee for reconsideration of his case, it was learned today.

A mortgage loan of $1,000,000 has been made by the Dollar Savings Bank to the Great Lakes Carbon Corporation on the twentytwo-story store and office building at 18-22 East Forty-eighth Street. The loan is for fifteen years, at 3 3/8 per cent for the first ten years and 3 3/4 per cent for the remaining five years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The United States already has extended post-war assistance to foreign countries totaling $16,250,000,000, exclusive of anything which may be done under the Marshall plan, according to a compilation based on figures from the Bureau of the Budget made public today by Senator Harry F. Byrd, Democrat, of Virginia.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Representatives of the five operating railroad brotherhoods today called for immediate consideration of their demands for a 30 per cent wage boost, declaring that "further neglect and delay could disturb railroad operations."

Official ending of Regulation W at midnight tonight will bring no radical change in credit-granting procedures of leading local stores, officials here said yesterday. Voluntary control of credit will be on a "sane" basis, with no headlong rush into a "battle of terms," they declared.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 -- "Sam Ego's House or Angels Aghast," William Saroyan's first post-war play, received its premiere here last night when it was presented by the Circle Players, with a semi-professional east under the direction of Mabel Albertson.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The charge of Representative Marion Bennett, Republican, of Missouri, that a "brass curtain" of censorship has hidden violent clashes between Communists and United States soldiers in the Trieste area brought a denial today from the United States Army commander there.
MOSCOW, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Brazilian Ambassador Mario de Pimentel Brandao said tonight he and his staff had received Soviet permission to leave Moscow and planned to depart Sunday.

Spring blossomed where millinery was concerned in "Fashions of the Times," Sixth Edition, which folded its wings last night after eight applause - bringing performances. Leading creators peering into the future outlined the silhouettes which they foresee for town and country, in 1948.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- An agreement to negotiate a new treaty of commerce and navigation between Britain and Italy was reached today by Count Carlo Sforza, Italian Foreign Minister, and Foreign Secretary Bevin.

A northeast storm accompanied by high tides, driving rain and wind gusts up to 45 miles an hour whipped the metropolitan area yesterday and put dock and other low-lying areas awash for hours. It flooded streets and cellars, marooned motorists and bungalow occupants in outlying districts, hampered ferry service and kept the Coast Guard busy retrieving small boats that had broken their moorings in Sheepshead Bay, Jamaica Bay and Long Island Sound.

The officers and crew of the Coast Guard cutter Bibb, which rescued sixty-nine persons from the Boeing clipper Bermuda Sky Queen forced down in the North Atlantic, were honored yesterday by the Maritime Association of the Port of New York.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Murray Thompson, Rockland County Democratic chairman, said tonight the Democrats would control the 1948 Board of Supervisors as the result of the Court of Appeals ruling yesterday that qualified Shanks Village student veterans and their families could register and vote next Tuesday.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 31 -- Fresh from their upset of Army, the Columbia Lions will endeavor to morrow to do something they haven't accomplished since their Rose Bowl season, 1933, and that is defeat Cornell on Schoellkopf Field.

Red tape is putting wholly unnecessary obstacles in the way of free flight of travelers by air between the United States and other countries of the world. A subcommittee of the Air Coordinating Committee has taken four flight trips to the corners of the nation, Canada, the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico, and held hearings in each area visited.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Another "world clock," equipped to serve not only as a local but a global time-teller, and many new, or improved, devices for the guidance in flight and safe landing of aircraft were among the 381 inventions patented this week in the United States Patent Office.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 31 -- Harland Bartholomew, a city planning engineer and consultant, will leave on Sunday for Bar Harbor, Me., to begin work on the rebuilding of the resort, which was partially destroyed by forest fires last week.

The mutual trust and confidence that characterize relations between Canada and the United States should set an example to the nations of the world of the path to peace, W.L. Mackenzie King, Prime Minister of Canada, declared yesterday.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 -- Three scientists stated today that "bureaucratic obstructions and legalistic uncertainties" had worn the nerves of some of their colleagues seeking to have the results of their researches declassified by the Atomic Energy Commission for publication.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Relaxing its opposition to admission of European displaced persons, the American Legion national executive committee recommended today that these persons be permitted to come to the United States in limited numbers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Frank R. Creedon resigned today as Federal Housing Expediter to accept a position in private industry connected with a construction program for the development of atomic energy. He supervised the construction of the plant at Oak Ridge, Tenn., where the atomic bomb was constructed during World War II.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Reorganization of the governmental structure of the District of Columbia to provide local suffrage and virtual municipal autonomy was recommended today by a Congressional committee.
The General Federation of Women's Clubs, representing 2,500,000 members in 17,500 American communities, has adopted a six-point program designed to raise the level of education in this country.

BAR HARBOR, Me. -- The inhabitants of this once beautiful summer resort town (population 4,378) on Mount Desert Island returned last week, after the forest fire had burned out, to find one-fifth of their town a mass of hulking ruins.

A GREAT number of our fellow -citizens, most of them women, are mysteriously soothed and gratified by the mere presence of an Englishman. Goats -- the instance is cited without prejudice -- are said to have a similar effect on high-strung race horses.

MOTORISTS who pass through Athenia, N.J., just west of Passaic and fifteen miles from New York City, are often amazed when they see camels, antelopes and other wild animals in one of the near-by fields.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Latent hostility to the Marshall plan is a very real fact out over the country even though as a general policy the plan is strongly favored in all public forums.

Criticizing the Committee on Un-American Activities for its conduct of the investigation into the movie industry, Rabbi William F. Rosenblum in a sermon in Temple Israel, 210 West Ninetyfirst Street, said yesterday, "The President might not go far wrong in having the Committee on Civil Rights investigate the uncivil conduct of the Committee on UnAmerican Activities."

GLAUCOMA -- DFP, a potent poison gas developed during the war, is now being used medicinally to treat glaucoma, an eye disease that often causes blindness, Col. John R. Wood, chief of the medical division of the Army Chemical Corps, reports to the American Chemical Society.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Penn's formidable football team would not allow anything resembling last year's upset by Princeton and swept the Tigers before it today with a hard-running gams to win by 26 -- 7.
EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 1 -- In a perfunctory performance, under a leaden sky today Wisconsin trampled over a luckless, hopeless Northwestern team, 29 to 0, before a Dad's Day crowd of 43,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- General Manager Leslie O'Connor of the Chicago White Sox declared today the club owners of the American League were not "backing" Commissioner A.B. Chandler when they voted unnanimously yesterday to replace O'Connor on baseball's Executive Council.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- No people are more law abiding than the British, This is an axiom that those who have lived on the European Continent or in the United States during the prohibition and war rationing will stake their bottom dollar on.

NEW DELHI, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Royal Air Force observers say that armed Pathan Moslems, swarming into the princely state of Kashmir, are advancing in such strength as to threaten the capital of Srinigar itself.
ITHACA, Nov. 1 -- Lou Little got back into the Ivy League today.

THIS encyclopedic handbook is the first of three volumes. At a time when Jews receive such undue publicity in proportion to their population (about 3 per cent of the United States total) a handbook consisting of essays on the various aspects of Jewish history, literature and cultural contributions is welcome indeed.

THE status of the American merchant seamen has improved greatly since 1897 when, in the famous Arago case, protection from involuntary servitude was denied seamen under articles, by a Supreme Court decision, on the grounds that "seamen are treated by Congress as deficient in that full and intelligent responsibility for their acts which is accredited to ordinary adults."
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Man o' War set another record in death tonight, becoming the first thoroughbred to be embalmed in preparation for burial.

"DECORATIONS in a Holiday Mood" is the title of the two-day program which will be held in The New York Times Hall on West Forty-fourth Street, New York, on Nov. 18 and 19. Meetings will be held each afternoon at 2:30 P.M.
The United Nations General Assembly last night voted to urge the Union of South Africa, through her Premier, Jan Christiaan Smuts, to submit a trusteeship agreement for South-West Africa.

WILLIAM WISTER HAINES, whose "Command Decision" will go down in theatrical history as the block-buster that killed the Broadway jinx on war plays in the fall of '47, illustrates two fables in reverse and illustrates them rather neatly.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Poultry and livestock feed supplies the remainder of this year and through next summer will be 5 per cent short of estimated requirements, according to the feed survey committee of the American Feed Manufacturers Association, but through substitutions and more efficient use of feeds meat producers probably will be able to bridge the gap and save grain to meet the nation's foreign food commitments.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Vanderbilt put on a first-half scoring spree then coasted the rest of the way to defeat Auburn, 28 to 0, on rain-soaked Dudley Field today.

While consumer reaction to the end products manufactured from integrated textile mill operation will be slow in making itself felt, it will manifest itself in a demand for greater diversification of goods, patterns and finishes, it was pointed out last week in the trade.

PARIS. THAT bold team of theatrical innovators, Jean-Louis Barrault and Andre Gide, have unveiled their adaptation of Franz Kafka's "The Trial" in Paris. While it could never be said that this puzzling Play attains a knockout in two acts, it is being hailed as a stunning production and the first stimulating event of this slow-moving season.

Messiaen's "L'Ascension," which received its New York premiere by the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra, under Pierre Monteux, last April, was performed for the first time by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, with Leopold Stokowski conducting yesterday evening at Carnegie Hall.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 1 -- United World Federalists, Inc., opened its first national convention today to draw up a policy and program of national action in a drive for world government.

At the last meeting of the Harvey Society held in the New York Academy of Medicine's building, Associate Professor Abraham White of Yale announced that he and his colleagues, Drs. T.F. Dougherty and Jeanne H. Chase, had discovered how hormones of the adrenals (walnut-sized glands on top of the kidneys) control the production of antibodies in lymphocyte cells, several thousand of which are present in each drop of blood.

The first contingent of Armenian -Americans, leaving this country for repatriation in the land of their forefathers, sailed from here yesterday afternoon on the liner Rossia. There were 150 in the group, including forty children.

THE B minor Mass of Johann Sebastian Bach is one of the towering masterworks of musical literature, and Victor has done itself proud in making a new recording worthy of the score. It is not a perfect recording, since much of the solo work leaves something to be desired.

In an effort to revitalize China a reduction and commerce, government and commercial interests, both here and abroad, are exploring the possibility of bringing about a stable currency situation in that country by the injection of silver into the monetary system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Senator Alexander Wiley, Republican, of Wisconsin, said today that the State Department was now reviewing its policy on issuing permits for Russian officials to enter this country.

COLORISTS are much in evidence in the galleries this week. Pulsing with chromatic excitement are the walls of the George Binet, the Chinese, the Salpeter and the Barzansky Galleries, all of which are presenting one-man shows.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- With other members still reserving their views on the new United States plan for carrying out the partition of Palestine, a Palestine subcommittee of the United Nations General Assembly today took up Zionist proposals for modifying the economic union between the proposed Arab and Jewish states.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Although township tickets alone are before the voters this fall in Rockland County there is more general interest than in many years, with the partisan control of the Board of Supervisors at stake and with political leaders of both sides predicting victory.

The voters of New York State will pass on six proposed constitutional amendments and three propositions at Tuesday's election. In addition, voters here will have a tenth question on the ballot in the form, of a referendum on a proposed amendment to the City Charter that would end the system of electing City Council members by proportional representation.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Virginia's quick-striking Cavaliers put together five touchdowns on sudden thrusts to roll over Richmond's courageous but outclassed Spiders today, 34-0, before a crowd of approximately 12,000.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 1 (AP) -- A versatile University of Missouri football team, featuring strong line play, scored in every period to crush the Nebraska Cornhuskers by 47 to 6 today and take sole possession of first place in the Big Six Conference race.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, MASS. IT had been this department's intention to celebrate its second return to the island (and I don't mean Blackwell's) by some account of the attempt which has been made to prove that it was Cuttyhunk, and not "the vex'd Bermoothes" which Shakespeare had in mind when he wrote "The Tempest."

WASHINGTON. WHEN Mrs. Martha Taft spoke up for her husband in Seattle during her tour of the West, the whole country started talking about her. Now that Senator Robert A. Taft has announced himself a candidate for the Republican nomination for President, this talk undoubtedly will go on and on -- at least until the Republican National Convention next summer and perhaps beyond.

Growing shortages in certain key materials and irregular distribution practices in a competitive market have arisen again to plague builders in most sections of the country just when they have succeeded in pushing production of homes up to a new peak.
The real estate men of the country will be asked to promote a program calling for decontrol of all residential rents on Feb. 29, 1948, which is the date the Housing and Rent Act expires.

Performances of current Broadway productions have been taken over by various philanthropic enterprises to raise funds in the near future for furthering their work. The Tuberculosis Preventorium for Children at Farmingdale, N.J., will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Antony and Cleopatra," with Katharine Cornell and Godfrey Tearle in the leading roles, on the night of Dec. 4 at the Martin Beck Theatre.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 1 -- Notre Dame kept its place at the head of the football parade with a 27-0 victory over Navy today. At the same time it cleared the deck for the big showdown with Army at South Bend next Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Senator Owen Brewster of Maine contended today that some United States oil companies had avoided taxation on profits of more than $100,000,000 from Arabian oil fields by operating through companies incorporated in foreign lands.

Settling down to a long stay at home, the New York Yankees will oppose the Baltimore Colts today in the first of five successive games at the Yankee Stadium. While the opposition is not distinguished, the local All-America Conference entry views the contest as an opportunity to win new supporters in its battle for patronage against the solidly intrenched New York Giants of the National League.

BY now it should be fairly evident to newspaper readers with open minds that a dangerous perversion of privilege has been happening in Washington. The high-handed tactics and techniques which, for two weeks, had been indulged by the House Un-American Activities Committee in its so-called investigation of Hollywood, prior to its recess on Thursday, shocked perceptive people who looked for justice and clarity.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 -- Rains came late this week to blot out the threat of New England's multitudinous forest fires -- the most severe in recorded history. And immediately efforts that had been devoted to fighting flames were shifted to dealing with relief and the multiple problems of rehabilitation.

As the extra session of Congress draws nearer (tomorrow it will be only two weeks away) the arguments for emergency aid to Europe, for longterm help in rebuilding Europe's economy and for future economic cooperation with all willing nations continue to pile up.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration is finding that disabled veterans in on-the-job training are proving to be more satisfactory workers, on the average, than their able-bodied fellow-trainees.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- As one of the most heated election campaigns in the city's history drew to a close, leaders of the Republican and Democratic organizations concentrated tonight on plans for drawing a heavy vote to the polls Tuesday.

The poor diction of teachers and the "slangy, idiomatic talk" of American college students represent major blocks to foreign students who are attempting to master the English language at colleges and universities in the United States, it was declared yesterday at the thirty-fourth annual College Conference on English in the Central Atlantic States.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- The United States has notified the three other occupying powers that after April 30, 1948, no further claims for the restitution of non-cultural loot in the American zone would be recognized, it was learned today.

IN these environs, a wellborn young lady is counted on to progress from a Good School to the Junior League to matrimony and then immure herself in the Colonies (the club and the restaurant). Occasionally an exceptionally pretty one has raised her voice in a night club until her friends tired of the performance and the management was compelled to hire a girl who could sing.

WASHINGTON. CHARLES LUCKMAN, the 38-yearold soapmaker from Cambridge, Mass., who heads the President's Citizens Food Committee, has had a remarkably successful business career. He attributes his success partly to chance. "Almost every new job I've had has meant stepping in to clean up a mess," he says.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- North Carolina, finally clicking in a manner to justify its preseason build-up, crushed Tennessee, 20 to 6, before 41,000 fans today, handing the Vols their fourth defeat of the season.

The piano recital given by James Frisian yesterday afternoon at Town Hall was devoted to the performance of the entire Book I of Bach's "Well-tempered Clavier." To play all twenty-four pairs of preludes and fugues of this half of the great masterwork on one program was a formidable undertaking, not only as a feat of memory and a test of endurance, but also because of the technical and interpretative exactions involved.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association, has invited Benjamin Britten to come over to attend the opening of its production of his opera, "Peter Grimes," which will occur sometime after the New Year. The role of Peter is still uncast, but one of the singers being considered is Set Svanholm, who has already sung the part in Swedish.

PRAGUE, Nov. 1 -- United States investors claiming compensation for nationalized properties will get a maximum of about one-third of their claims. Most of important United States claimants to property confiscated by the state under the nationalization laws already have reached preliminary agreements accepting a loss of two-thirds of the face value of their claims as a means of getting something out of their investment.

None can fail to acknowledge the justice of Norway's award of this year's Nobel Peace Prize to the Society of Friends. The prize is to be divided between the Quaker communities of the United States and Great Britain, but the money itself will undoubtedly be distributed among miserable people in lands still suffering from the ravages of war.
James H. Shells, Acting Investigation Commissioner, has sent investigators into the field to check on the handling of relief cases, he announced yesterday.
With a small volume of business, cotton futures on the New York. Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 3 to 14 points net lower than on Friday.

TOKYO, Nov. 1 -- Improvements in the oil-exploration methods introduced by occupation geologists have increased Japan's petroleum potential an estimated 20 per cent, according to Lieut. Col. Hubert G. Schenck, chief of the natural resources section.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1 -- A convict who escaped from state prison six weeks ago was captured by the police early today after he had leaped from a fourthstory window of an apartment house.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 1 -- Indian Army troops have occupied Babariawad and Mangrol, two small states in the Kathiawar peninsula of western India, the Indian Government announced tonight. These states, formerly tributaries of Junagadh, have acceded to India but are still claimed by Pakistan.

THE question of sowing annual seeds in fall always comes up at this time of year. Annual flowers are generally thought of as being sown in spring, to bloom in summer and wither in late autumn. Some of them, however, can be given a nead start now, so that they will grow faster and stronger next year.

The Thomas Committee on UnAmerican. Activities has suspended its inquiry into political opinions in Hollywood. One feels the same sense of relief that one did last August when the Brewster War Investigation Committee's subcommittee, also temporarily shut up shop.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Something between a gasp of surprise aid a sigh of resignation, swept the State Department this week as it appeared that Gen. Lucius D. Clay intends to launch a counteroffensive in Germany against Communist propaganda.

AN exhibition as large as the current one of sculpture by Chaim Gross, at the Associated American Artists Galleries, is a severe trial for any artist. This is doubly true when the artist's style and subject-matter tend to vary little from year to year.

Cool weather spurred retail trade here last week. Department store volume was estimated at close to 50 per cent over the same week last year. Comparison, however, was with the closing period of the delivery strike in 1946.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your issue of Oct. 26 Sir Kenneth Lindsay speaks of the need for student exchange and of the necessity now for "carefully devised interchange plans."

SALT LAKE CITY. SOMETHING new has been added to the ranks of the nation's disk-jockeys in the person of Chief Quartermaster James L. Hardy, United States Navy. "Love That Sea" is his theme rather than "Love That Soap."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The United States today is sending less machinery and equipment to Russia than it did in the years before Pearl Harbor.

"SWORDS of Silence" is a popular history of the Hung League from its foundation to the present, with special emphasis placed on its role in the overthrow of the Manchu dynasty and Sun Yat-sen's attempts to use the society in promoting revolution.

THERE'S a concert to be held on the afternoon of Nov. 11, at Town Hall, one that holds special interest for me. The Cultural Division of the National Negro Congress is presenting two unknown Negro artists for the first time, in what they aptly call an "Open Hearing."

JUST seventeen years ago this week in this Review: On Page 1 was a book with a thesis, Hallet Abend's "Tortured China," the thesis being that China is a nation in distress and only international intervention can help her. . . .

OMAHA, Nov. 1 -- Sampling of opinion regarding the Washington investigation of alleged communism in Hollywood has indicated three things: (1) Midwesterners generally approve of the inquiry's anti-Communist twist because, as one smalltown Nebraskan said, "We cannot afford to ignore a potential fifth column."
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 1 -- United States and British Military Government authorities have resumed their "get tough" policy with the German administration, it was learned today.

ONE important segment of Italy's productive economy has been staging a quiet but promising comeback. This is the field of handicrafts, important to a country of skilled hand workers whose livelihood depends upon their ability to make and sell their specialized product.

THERE were strange goings-on at 38 Rue de Louvre and Al Laney has put them all into his story of an "incredible" newspaper. The Paris Herald, was indeed incredible, as any of its interim graduates can testify, including this reviewer, who apparently packed Mr. Laney into a Paris taxi one day back in the midNineteen Twenties and led him to the slaughter.

LAST week's announcement that the concerts of the New Friends of Music would be broadcast exclusively this season over Ira Hirschmann's frequency modulation station, WABF, underscores a state of affairs which perhaps has escaped the attention of many New York radio listeners.

BEING a writer these days is a complicated business. You are liable to wake up one morning and see by the headlines that Jack Warner has proclaimed to a Congressional committee that you are "un-American" and that he has fired you for trying to inject "un-American doctrines" into the work you did for his studio.

Kashmir, second largest Princely State in India (80,000 square miles, 4,000,000 people) is a land of snowcapped mountains and fertile valleys. Its situation astride the Himalayas at the northern tip of India gives it strategic importance. It borders on Afghanistan to the west, China to the east and Russia to the north.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Carroll Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared today that the onus for inflation and high prices fell upon President Truman and the Democratic Administration that "planned it that way."

The type of legislation that may be enacted by Congress during the special session was uppermost in the minds of security traders during the past week. Favorable news of earnings, dividends and splitups, the best in years, seemed to have only a momentary effect.

THE Rialto, for the last twelve years home for Hollywood's cinema hobgoblins, murderers and minor-league Sherlock Holmeses will join New York's coterie of first-run foreign film outlets on Thanksgiving Day. While the contracts are without signatures at the moment of writing, it is "ten to one" the John Hancocks will be appended momentarily to the necessary legal documents, it was learned last week.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- California's Golden Bears, considerably tarnished after their unhappy encounter with Southern California, bounded back with just enough force today to topple the University of California at Los Angeles, 6 to 0 before 80,266 fans at Memorial Coliseum.

BECAUSE Bill Mauldin is a good writer as well as a good cartoonist, I had better begin by reporting how his new book divides up. Like "Up Front," "Back Home" is partly text and partly pictures, but the proportions are reversed.
LIMA, Peru, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- A strong earthquake shook central Peru today and first reports disclosed that at least four persons were killed and an undetermined number injured.

THREE of us, His Honor, Mayor Breen of Dayton, Ohio; Miriam Rosenthal, manager of the Dayton Symphony Orchestra, which, under its leader, Paul Katz, is going places, and your reporter, were seated in the dining room of the Biltmore Hotel in the Midwestern city.

With only 3 per cent showing lower business volume for October in the reports of the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, a record low for 1947 monthly reports was established. Increased volume was reported by 43 per cent, continuing the upswing noted in August and September, according to the composite opinion of purchasing agents disclosed for publication today.

It is not only in great cities like New York that men and organizations are at work in noise abatement. In this age of machines there is a constant and encouraging effort to reduce the din they make. During the stay of the General Motors "Train of Tomorrow" in New York a visitor was astonished as he caught a glimpse of motion through the glass of one of the "astradomes."

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 1 (AP) -- With Lu Gambino, the Southern Conference's top point-getter, scoring three touchdowns, Maryland whipped West Virginia for the first time today, 27-0, before a capacity homecoming crowd of 16,500.

At the annual dinner of the American Cancer Society last week a check for $10,000 was handed to Dr. Clarence C. Little, director of the Roscoe B. Jackson Memorial Laboratory of Bar Harbor, Me. Another donation of $50,000 comes from the Damon Runyon Fund.
DETROIT, Nov. 1 -- Edward J. Jeffries Jr. appeared to be headed today for his fifth term as Mayor of Detroit.

Fitting it in between an appearance up-state and a tour of the Middle West, the unflagging and much-loved Fritz Kreisler gave his annual recital yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. The house was filled to its 2,700 capacity, and the warm and continuing applause of the audience proved that the appeal of the 72-year-old violinist is as hardy and durable as his constitution.

THE meaning of liberty is at the core of many debates in the United Nations as it has been in the arguments of philosophers and political leaders throughout history. Abraham Lincoln applied himself to the question more than once.

ATLANTA, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Georgia Tech struck like a lightning bolt for a touchdown the first time it got the ball today and spent the next 54 minutes fighting off a surging Duke team to score a 7 to 0 victory before 38,000 fans.

SEATTLE, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The mighty football machine of Southern California maintained its steady drive toward the Rose Bowl today by crushing the stubborn University of Washington Huskies, 19 to 0. The Trojans powered 93 yards to a second-quarter touchdown and added two in the final period.

In the most ambitious post-war expansion program yet announced for suburban development, Levitt Sons, builders, announced yesterday that they had acquired sufficient additional land at their Island Trees project in the Hempstead -Farmingdale section of Long Island to increase the size of this community from 2,000 to 6,000 small houses.

IN less than a month Christmas shopping will be under way and retail predictions are that it will establish another alltime high. Some two months of the fall season have passed without bringing up the problems which were considered likely, so optimism rules in retail quarters.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 1 -- The advance arrival this week-end of hundreds of delegates from thirtytwo countries gives some indication of the importance of the second General Assembly of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, which will open here Thursday.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The United States proposal that the partition of Palestine take effect about next July 1 drew an unfavorable reception in informal comment by British officials today. There was no official assessment of the plan for publication.

Plans for converting the temporary United States Naval Hospital at Linden Boulevard, St. Albans, Queens, into a permanent establishment, with the construction of a group of buildings with 1,000-bed capacity at a cost of $15,000,000, were announced yesterday by Third Naval District Headquarters, 90 Church Street.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (NANA) -- Two horse-loving Senators blocked this week a State Department plan to return 130 thoroughbred stallions captured from the Germans by United States troops.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Alabama, riding the crest of a comeback campaign, rose to its top performance today to smack down a favored Kentucky football team, 13 -- 0, and end its long series with the Wildcats with a record of 24 victories and one tie in 26 games.
EASTON, Pa., Nov. 1 -- Lafayette College upset Syracuse University, 14 -- 7, today after turning two fumbles into first-half touchdowns.

TOKYO, Oct. 30 (Delayed) -- The members of Japans eleven princely families who a fortnight ago abandoned their imperial titles and became commoners, have begun to seek a living in the fields open to ordinary citizens.

AMSTERDAM. THE Netherlands has set an important precedent in establishing a criterion to judge musicians charged with collaborating with the enemy -- a problem that has plagued postwar denazification officials all over Western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Twelve leaders of the Protestant Church in the United States joined tonight in a call for "Christian insight" and "calm faith" to relieve the tensions growing out of war and to clear the way for peace.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The American Legion National Executive Committee heard a warning today that World War II members might "stage a Boston Tea Party" as a result of committee action eliminating its World War II consultants.

WE have heard a good deal in recent months about loyalty and Americanism. Spokesmen on one side proclaim that the American way of life is in imminent danger from any one who questions the eternal rightness of the capitalist system. Spokesmen on the other side proclaim that a sinister witch-hunt is already transforming the United States into a totalitarian police state.
The street rioting in Paris last week may well be the prelude to a winter of political storm and stress in France.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- A unified command for the Caribbean defense system, with Lieut. Gen. Willis D. Crittenberger in charge, was announced today by the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

THOSE readers familiar with some or all of Manuel Komroff's dozen-odd volumes know that his stories and novels have had both oriental and occidental settings, that they have been both historical and modern. His bestselling, most ambitious novel, "Coronet," covered two continents and three centuries.

MR. BACALL and Miss Sloane point out in their little volume that the marriage contract differs from other contracts between two parties in that its dissolution cannot be effected without the consent of a third party -- the State.

Store-wide activity last week was good, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Coat business was good, the survey stated, and dress departments were busy, with ballerina styles winning acceptance.

CALIFORNIA'S producers of dried fruits have received from 23 to 57 per cent less for their products than they did last season. Prices have slid so low that they are almost at prewar levels. 1/2 cups cold water Sugar and lemon juice 1) Cover figs with boiling water. Let stand for five minutes drain and snip off stems with scissors. Cut into tiny pieces.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1. -- Full credit for garnering both the Republican and Democratic National Conventions for Philadelphia in 1948 is given to the go-getting spirit of the All-Philadelphia Citizens Committee.
LONG BEACH, L.I, Nov. 1 -- Attention will focus here election day on Local Amendment 3, a referendum upon the Proportional Representation method of electing the five members of the City Council.

HOLLYWOOD. RECENTLY I attended a meeting of studio costume designers to discuss an award to be presented-for the first time by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to the individual designer of the best clothes for a motion picture during the past year.

ST. PAUL compared Christian marriage with the union of Christ with His church, adding: "The mystery here is great." This book by the Belgian priest, Abbe Kothen, expands the implications of this analogy into a deeply devotional interpretation of what the author calls the fundamental unit of society, the family.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Bottling up the Hawaiian ace, Herman Wedemeyer, in the clutches, University of Detroit staged two long touchdown marches and grabbed a third score on Wally Gruber's 40-yard breakaway sprint to whip St. Mary's Gaels, 19 to 6, in their intersectional football game today.

Two of the most spectacular "shows" in Washington since the Republicans won command of Capitol Hill have been Congressional investigations. Both drew large crowds of spectators. Each came to an abrupt halt under somewhat similar circumstances.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 1 -- The industrialization of the South can be accelerated if adequately trained technologists and first class research facilities are made available in the region, Dr. Raymond B. Seymour, director of the university of Chattanooga's industrial research institute, declared today.
PROBABLY the most universal garden impulse is to plant a tree. That is the first thing many people do when they acquire a new home, and it is a good idea, since trees take a long time to grow.

While developers continue to open additional sections in an effort to meet the demand for new housing in Bergen County, brokers there and in other sections of New Jersey report an equally strong tone in the "used" dwelling market.

THIS is the story of a movement, told by a woman who helped to get it started, and has spent forty years of her life taking an active part in its continuance and progress. So closely is the life of Mary White Ovington woven into the work of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People that to talk of one is to talk of the other.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 2 -- With only a handful of results still to be declared, the Conservatives by early this morning had scored sweeping successes over the Laborites in municipal elections throughout England and Wales.

Art reference books in serveral languages collected by the late Dr. A. Philip McMahon will be auctioned tomorrow at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 30 East Fiftyseventh Street. Included are a set of "Allegemeines Lexikon," Post's comprehensive history of Spanish painting and a set of the revised edition of "Paulys Real-Encyclopadie."

THIS is Bernard Devoto at his best, and when you have said that, you have said a lot. In fact, you have come pretty near to using the adjective magnificent. As he has proven repeatedly, this author has a passion as strong as a Chinook wind -- as just, and as lucid, as the mountain-clearness of the original American idea.

ANKARA. TURKISH letters have become intensely America-conscious since the war and even more so since the enunciation of the Truman Doctrine. In the past, literate Turkish public opinion was definitely Britain-conscious, so that the change is a novelty.
DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 1 (U.P) -- Union and company officials held last-minute meetings today in an effort to prevent a threatened strike that would close Dayton's three daily newspapers.

EVERY few years, following some disconcerting pattern, the newspapers rudely dislodge us from our complacent attitude toward American justice by revealing that a citizen has been convicted and is serving a long prison sentence for a crime which he never committed.

BRUNSWICK, Me., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Bates College opened defense of its Maine State intercollegiate football crown today with a 9-to-7 victory over Bowdoin in a hardfought game played before 4,000 fans at Whittier Field.

BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- A flood of positive "sales talk" for non-totalitarian government such as has not been seen since the wartime will be the chief manifestation of the "new" policy announced last Tuesday by Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor.

Despite current inflationary conditions, there is no likelihood that the Federal Reserve authorities will order an advance this year in the present reserve requirements of the New York and Chicago member banks, informed financial observers stated last week.

The Association of Scientific Workers, a militant body of British scientists, has for years been urging one Government after another to make more use of science by properly planning, organizing and directing research. Never was the need of research more pressing than it is in the present crisis, argues the spokesman of the association, none other than its president, Prof. J.D. Bernal.

PRAGUE, Nov. 1 -- Czechoslovakia must make every effort to obtain a loan in the United States because of the intense pressure of Soviet demands for heavy industrial and other essential goods, according to those charged with keeping track of such developments here.

The Brooklyn Division of Todd Shipyards Corporation last week completed one of the fastest major ship repair jobs since the days of World War II when repairs often were finished overnight. The yard set the 7,061-ton cargo vessel Jessmore back in the water, ready for service, in six days.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 1 (AP) -- A Marquette fumble in the final quarter set up a Michigan State touchdown to enable the Spartans to squeak through to a 13-7 victory before 23,856 fans in perfect football weather today.

From the French The paper-bound book is a symbol of France almost as well known as the tricolor. A visitor to France in the days before the war soon learned that Frenchmen insisted on cheap books and cheap food; it was possible, it seemed, for any Frenchman to be well read and well fed for little money.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 1 -- Nassau County will elect officials in its three towns and two cities Tuesday. All but one of the county's five major civil subdivisions -- Long Beach -- will name complete local slates.

WARSAW, Nov. 1 -- The Government benches in the Polish Parliament stand slightly raised along the base of the semicircular chamber. Below them is a section reserved for the Polish Peasant party (PSL), theoretically the Government's opposition.

GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- The fourth meeting of the International Refugee Organization Preparatory Commission ended today after delegates had been, soberly warned by Chairman Henri Ponsot to reflect upon the sad consequences their quarrels and disunity would have on war victims.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Ten Hollywood individuals, threatened with contempt of Congress proceedings by the House Committee on Un-American Activities, today asked Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. to nullify the action.

Significant problems in the field of education will be considered when the second General Conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization opens in Mexico City on Thursday. Destined to be highly important, it will continue through Dec. 3.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Westchester will go to the polls Tuesday to elect 211 local officials, with the entrenched Republican machine facing possible upset in only a few of the 425 election districts.

Presaging early culmination of a stockholders' battle in the $750,000,000 Standard Gas and Electric Company, Leo T. Crowley, chairman and president since 1938, yesterday submitted his resignation from both posts, effective on Nov. 29.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 1 -- Brown and Holy Cross fought a rugged nip-and-tuck battle today with the Bears coming from behind in the last quarter to beat the Crusaders. 20 -- 19 before 18,000 thrilled fans.

PARIS, Nov. 1 -- The final figures for the municipal elections of Oct. 19 and 26 today report a reduction of more than 6,000 in the number of Communist seats and a drop in their percentage of Council -seat holding's of 2 per cent.

Several parties have been planned for debutantes of the season in forthcoming weeks. Mr. and Mrs. Chester Alwyn Braman of Brook Meadow, Old Chatham, N.Y., and 580 Park Avenue, will give a dinner dance on Nov. 28 in the Crystal Room of the Ritz-Carlton for the Misses Eleanor Roosevelt Braman and Gladys Pomeroy Stevens, both of whom will be introduced to society formally at the Junior Assemblies.

ONE of the twenty stories in this latest volume of Mr. Farrell's shorter fiction is called "The Philosopher." If the story is put beside an essay in Farrell's recent collection of critical articles, "Literature and Morality," it is easy to discover that his philosopher is George Herbert Mead, Dewey's great disciple at the University of Chicago.
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Actual replacement of London's bombedout buildings is, more than two years after the end of the war, still much plan and little reality.

MEASURED in terms of the number of flights, the frequency and regularity of schedules and the number of miles and passengers flown, 1947 up to now must be considered a good year by the commercial airlines of the United States.

New York City's Department of Welfare currently aids about 263,000 needy persons -- 7,700 of whom have jobs but can't subsist on their low earnings. On the average the department allots $54.76 a month to aged recipients, $54.43 to the blind, $32.66 to dependent children, $29.12 to needy veterans, $36.93 to adults on home relief.

Reports received in this country last week indicate that Norway has just made a perceptible swing to the right. In 1945 the labor parties received a total of 52.4 per cent of the votes cast. This year there have been no general elections, but advices from Conservative sources state that the Conservatives won 52 per cent of all votes cast in the local elections.

WITH the revival of amateur interest in 35-mm, miniature photography, evidenced by the introduction of several new cameras in this category and the growing demand for them, the question of the importance of fine-grain development of the miniature films is again being raised.

SCANDINAVIA'S oldest and largest lager beer institution, Carlsberg Breweries at Valby near Copenhagen, will be a century old on Nov. 10 and Denmark will observe the "birthday" by issuing a 40-ore postal commemorative.

ON Nov. 6, 1897, a bright, intelligent, laughing baritone of 20 named Giuseppe De Luca made his debut as a professional singer. He sang Valentine in "Faust" in the opera house of Piacenza, a town just south of the Po, that, like all other Italian towns, took its opera seriously and knew good singing when it came along.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Sylvester J. Ryan of New York was appointed by President Truman today to be United States District Judge for the Southern District of New York. He succeeds Francis G. Caffey, who has retired.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 1 -- Arthur M. Brandel, part-time correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES and his wife, Mary Lester, correspondent for the United Press, were ordered today by the Yugoslav Ministry of the Interior to leave the country.
To the Music Editor: I BELIEVE the point raised by Mr. Fred Epstein in his letter to THE TIMES on Oct. 12 calls for further explanation.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Stu Holcomb's Purdue Boilermakers defeated the Iowa Hawkeyes today, 21 to 0, so smoothly that it was hard to decide whether the Purdue defense was something pretty special or Iowa was plumb out of offensive weapons.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 1 -- Three county officials, ten supervisors and complete slates of town officers will be elected in Suffolk County next Tuesday. Preponderantly Republican, a large majority of the candidates is seeking reelection in order to retain control of the Board of Supervisors.
With Pleasure, never out of the pay-offs in his fourteen starts this season, accounted for the biggest share of the loot in the $25,000 added Scarsdale Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

In addition to the several million hunters who tramp the woods armed with the latest thing in high-power rifles hoping to get a shot at a deer or bear there is a small group that is bent on doing things the hard way.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Tino Wave, even-money choice in the twenty-sixth running of the Jersey Hunt Cup, steeplechase that featured the annual race meeting of the Essex Fox Hounds, breezed away from the opposition today as though it had been composed of a bunch of laggards.

AFRICA is still, in many ways, a dark continent, but it is surprising how much of his own particular brand of light the white man has brought to it. Only three months ago I flew out to the Belgian Congo with a Catholic missionary from Ghent who ran a high school for Bantu students at a spot fourteen days up the Congo by river-boat from Leopoldville.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The row over the procedures employee by the House Un-American Activities Committee is the latest manifestation of a perennial -- a hardy perennial -- that goes back almost to the birth of Congress.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Oklahoma Aggies had too much power and deception for Temple's football team as they overwhelmed the Owls, 26 to 0, today.

Struggle in France In Washington the great debate over the "Marshall plan" -- the "European Recovery Program" is now the official title -- is getting under way. Already, two weeks Before the special session of Congress meets, the political overtones are distinctly heard.

Rising production of homes has served to ease the prices charged for "used" houses in some communities, but the increasing cost has boosted the prices of new dwellings further, according to the semi-annual market survey of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.

TO THE EDITOR: In THE TIMES Magazine Catherine Gavin announces her discovery, after traveling 2,000 miles in the United States, that "the Americans do not love the English." After reading her article I am driven to suspect that the fault does not lie entirely with the Americans.

A RINGING challenge to America was delivered yesterday by a delegate to the United Nations. For a change, though, it wasn't a Russian who was doing the delivering. Nor did the challenge bristle with indignation, vituperation and scathing invective. It came from a merry-eyed son of the British Empire, Col. William R. Hodgson of Australia.

THIS brace of turkeys (and we use that word in its saddest theatrical sense) may be bracketed for several valid reasons. Though both profess to deal with a robust art, both are bloodless to the point of anemia. Though both are fashioned by novelists who should know better, both approach their subject from a level that destroys the drama in advance.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 1 -- Adoption of a new State constitution, already endorsed by the Republican and Democratic leadership, provides the sole state-wide issue before New Jersey voters at the general election Tuesday.

HOLLYWOOD. AFTER thirteen months on the picket lines, the striking painters and set decorators of the Conference of Studio Unions decided last week that they had played virtually all their cards in their jurisdictional fight with the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Nov. 1 -- American universities have a great obligation to train their students to defend the tradition of the free man in the world-wide debate between the peoples of the Western European civilization and Soviet Communism, Frederick H. Osborn, Deputy United States Representative on the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, declared here today.

The better coat and suit market last week was quite active as buyers commenced to buy spring merchandise, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Company, resident buyers.
Brooklyn College will extend the facilities of its Veterans Advisement Unit tomorrow to children and adults in the community.

THOUGH Hannah Lees has proved her willingness in some of her writing to tackle topics other than those connected with medicine, she seems naturally to gravitate around Aesculapius' wand. "The Dark Device" concerns an ice-skating star who develops a complex and hies herself to a psychiatrist.

LIKE Hammacher Schlemmer and June and moon, W.E. Woodward and the word "debunk" usually go side by side and are interdependent. The author of ''Meet General Grant" and "A New American History" is the abrasive who cheerfully scratches the gilt from the lilies of history, which probably is a good thing, although it has not left him free of enemies.

THE Bell Howell Filmo 8mm magazine-loading camera features a two-lens turret on a panel as wide as the camera and with one lens above the other, instead of the conventional-round three-lens device. The new turret is pivoted at the center to bring the wanted lens into operating position.

Letters to President Truman and King George VI of England, stamped with the first cachet marking the Greater New York Golden Jubilee celebration, were mailed yesterday in ceremonies attending the opening of a temporary postal substation on the ground floor of the old Subtreasury Building, Wall and Nassau Streets.

Boys and girls learn to read better, catch up in arithmetic, test higher in their IQ and make more friends when their teachers have received training in understanding children, according to studies reported on yesterday at a conference of the Caroline Zachry Institute of Human Development.

A period of stabilization of prices, inventories and production volume looms in industry for the next quarter as a result of assurances last week by Irving S. Olds, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, that no consideration had been given to an advance in steel prices, distributors and industrial executives revealed here yesterday.

THE gift of musical talent has never carried with it any guarantee of spiritual profundity, superior character or even of extraordinary intelligence. This fact has always surprised a great many people who, confusing music with morals, imagine that great musicians must somehow necessarily be great human beings.

BUCHAREST, Nov. 1 -- Dr. Juliu Maniu and Ion Mihalache were barred today from further opportunity to cross-examine fellow defendants who have sought to lay all blame for alleged treason activities upon them.

The Home Owners Foundation, which now claims 60,000 members, is planning a series of meetings shortly in various parts of the country to foster a legislative program aimed at elimination of what the organization calls "socialistic housing schemes and bureaucratic control of the nation's homes."

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., lost $908,308 net after deductions for taxes and all charges in the quarter ended with September, according to the report issued on Friday by Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker, president and general manager. In view of this loss, directors yesterday decided to omit the semiannual, dividend of 25 cents a share normally paid in December.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE TIMES of Oct. 26 is a letter from Professor Ernest G. Osborne, who states he spent ten months as a childwelfare consultant in several of the large cities of Nationalist China. Professor Osborne criticizes the statements of Henry P. Van Dusen, president of the Union Theological Seminary, and former Ambassador William C. Bullitt, on the grounds that they each spent only two months in China.

The seminar in education for International understanding, held last summer at Sevres, near Paris. France, for the purpose of bringing together persons from various nations whose common interests would be productive of good results for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, was declared yesterday by seminar officials to have been ''constructive and pleasant."
PARIS, Nov. 1 -- France, which her citizens often call "ungovernable," came this week squarely up against a crisis not merely of parliament or of the government but of the republic.

Another chapter in the football rivalry between Brooklyn College and City College was written into the books last night as an inspired Kingsmen eleven, driving every minute of the way, downed the Lavender by 38 -- 7 at Ebbets Field.

CRESCENT CITY is a goodsized and wholly fictitious river town on the north bank of the Ohio. But fictitious or not, readers of William E. Wilson's new novel are sure to remember Crescent City as a very real place and the home of a remarkable fictional hero.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 1 (NANA) -- Snow, leaves and grass are just a snap of the finger in the life of Bernard L. Larson of this city. They're no trouble at all, he says. Mr. Larson recently invented a power-operated machine that picks up snow and tosses it to winds, gobbles all leaves in sight at a gulp and even mows the lawn.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Calm approval and some sharp condemnation marked the reaction in this part of the country to developments at the Congressional inquiry into communist influence in Hollywood's film industry.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 1 -- There is a civil war going on in Palestine today which could develop into serious proportions. Chances are that it will not get out of hand but all depends on the fanatic Irgun Zvai Leumi.

"A MAN'S house is his art," says D.S. Defenbacher, director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis. "At least," he adds, "a house is the nearest to art that most men will ever come." y objective, the collection rs good evidence of the nendous variety of contemporary ideas on home planning as well as some interng interpretations of regional traditions.

VIENNA. THIS undernourished European capital is subjected to as varied a broadcasting fare as the most opulent metropolis. Austria, half in the west and half behind the "Iron Curtain," receives an overdose of radio programs from five nations.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 1 -- Amid continuous heckling, the hurling of stench bombs and numerous disorders, including fist fights, the Progressive Citizens of America this afternoon held one of the most tumultuous meetings ever witnessed at historic Independence Hall Square.
Thirteen American steamship companies have notified the Maritime Commission they planned to cancel charter agreements on 100 Liberty and Victory ships now used principally in the bulk trades.

The New York Rangers got back on the winning road last night. They beat the speedy Detroit Red Wings, 4 to 3, at Madison Square Garden in a National Hockey League game that had the crowd of 15,714 gasping with excitement down to the final whistle.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 1 -- Some hard running by Dick Daley and loose Hofstra tackling combined to give American International of Springfield, Mass., a 23-to-13 triumph over the Flying Dutchmen today.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Alternating between bone-crushing line plays and a fancy aerial attack, once-beaten Boston College outplayed a stubborn Georgetown football eleven for a 27 -- 6 victory today before a chilled crowd of 19,264 at Braves Field.

To the Drama Editor: NEWS that ANTA'S Experimental Theatre has shelved Barrie Stavis' "Lamp at Midnight" in favor of Bertolt Brecht's "Galileo" offers an interesting, if depressing, commentary on the distance between pretension and practice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The purchase of that washing machine or television set is strictly a matter between you and the dealer from now on unless Congress changes its mind at the coming special session. The Government got out of the installment credit control business today.

ON Oct. 23, 1917, the leadership of the Bolshevik party sent a secret directive to its branches. This directive wound up with this statement: "So, recognizing that armed insurrection is inevitable and that time is quite ripe for it, the Central Committee proposes to all party organizations to be guided by this and from this standpoint to consider and solve all practical problems."
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 1 -- Man o'War, America's foremost thoroughbred, died of a heart attack today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Indiana's Hoosiers, paced by rambling, deadeye George Taliaferro, struck suddenly in the first period and then held off an embattled Ohio State eleven in the final half before emerging with a 7-to-0 triumph in today's Big Nine Conference battle of tail-end football teams before 75,882 spectators.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 1 -- Thirty minutes of the most bruising, vicious football witnessed all season, relentless give-and-take pounding that left both sides close to exhaustion, produced two touchdowns for Michigan and one for Illinois today. Thereafter, it appeared, neither possessed the energy for a sustained advance.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 1 -- Scoring three times in the third period, the Rutgers University football team rolled to a 31-7 triumph over Harvard today. A stadium crowd of 20,000 saw the Crimson suffer one of its worst setbacks on the home gridiron.

FROM his own experience as a miner (and from the stories told him by his father and his grandfather, who were miners before him) Harold Heslop has fashioned a gripping, passionate novel of the English coal miners who opened up the treasures of the earth beneath Durham County through the long years of the Victorian era.

A FALL chore that is often made to sound highly involved and technical is grading. Where the ground needs to be raised or lowered so that flower beds will be more attractive, or an area is to be leveled so that a lawn can be made, or the property in some way is changed so that its contours will be pleasing and practical, grading is required.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 1 -- Dynamic offensively at the start and quick to take advantage of Dartmouth lapses, Yale rolled up three touchdowns and a field goal in the first three periods today for a lead that held fast against the furious late surge of the Indians.

You drop down out of the green mountains and the desert country lies ahead, the last broad span before you can smell the fog and the salt air of the Pacific. You face stark mountains and eroded hills and valleys where the shorelines of ancient seas are still visible.

Physical fitness has always ranked along with happiness, security and success as one of the major objectives of life that most persons desire. Like its companion goals, however, physical fitness itself is a vague term that lacks definition, and concrete standards.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- President Truman was urged today in a report of his Council of Economic Advisers to seek renewal of some war-time powers to deal with a threatened inflation of industrial prices under the combined impact of heavy domestic demand and a $20,000,000,000 European recovery program.

Tyson Creamer of Baltimore Polytechnic Institute, competing in his first New York meet this fall, was the surprise winner of the New York Athletic Club's third annual interscholastic crosscountry run at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 1 -- Eleven months after the United Nations voted to establish an International Refugee Organization to carry on the work of UNRRA and other agencies, the fate of Europe's displaced persons remains one of the most pressing human, problems.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hops. 300 head; total 3,300 (estimated). Compared with week ago: Butcher hogs, all weights. $1.75 to $2 lower; sows around $1.50 lower.

PROMPTED by an ever-increasing demand for power plants with greater energy and lower gasoline consumption, automotive engineers are now making a series of experiments with all-aluminum engines. According to a report of the Aluminum Company of America, preliminary results show that test-cars have demonstrated a 10 per cent gain in power because of better heat distribution, greater cooling properties and a higher compression.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- When the President put antiinflationary measures before foreign relief as part of the legislation he will ask the special session of the Eightieth Congress to consider, and promised to submit a program, all hope of a bipartisan approach to the problems before the session vanished automatically.
NANKING, Nov. 1 -- Foreign Minister Wang Shih-chieh declined to say today whether China planned a formal claim to the Ryukyu Islands in the peace settlement with Japan.

HYATTSVILLE, Md. AT sidewalk booths throughout Prince Georees County, just outside Washington. D.C., interested passers-by a few days ago were picking up copies of a pamphlet in which Albert Einstein discussed what the American people must do to "find courage to surmount the fear" of an atomic era.

NOT everybody agrees about the merits of "Allegro." This is a shocking state of affairs that shows how far we are from totalitarianism in the Broadway arts. Sooner or later we shall have to be investigated. But while there is time, let me put on record high regard for the new musical play by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein 2d.

LONDON, Nov. 1 (Reuters) -- London's famed Arsenal club retained first place in the English Football League's first division today although held to a scoreless draw by Chelsea in a London Derby before a crowd of 67,000.

MATT Weinstock, who could not have been there at the time, reports that El Pueblo de Nuestra Senora La Reina de Los Angeles de Porciuncula was founded on Sept. 4, 1781, by a handful (44) of reluctant colonists from the Mexican state of Sonora through inducements of land, money, livestock and implements.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 1 -- After a campaign in which charges have been aired with abandon, San Francisco will elect a Mayor Tuesday to succeed Roger D. Lapham, shipping executive who said four years ago he would be a "onetermer" and has stuck to it.

VERMONT ski operators and state officials last week organized the Vermont Winter Sports Council at a meeting in Montpelier sponsored by the State Development Commission. The council heard Gov. Ernest W. Gibson promise the support of his administration to "encourage the development of skiing areas, but private capital must build up and operate them at the present time."

ROME, Nov. 1 -- Pope Pius today asked a group of United States Senators, who are members of the Immigration and Naturalization Committee, to aid in relieving the plight of suffering European peoples. His statement contained an implied appeal that the United States adopt a liberal immigration policy for the resettlement of refugees and displaced persons.

The city's traditional Armistice Day tribute to the dead of World War I this year will be coupled with ceremonies to remind the nation of the strength and readiness of the Organized Reserves and its importance in the security pattern.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 1 -- Army's revivified football forces put on their highest scoring jamboree of the season today, romping over Washington and Lee, 65 to 13, before a crowd of 21,050-in Michie Stadium.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 1 -- The United States scored a grand slam over Britain today in the opening of the Ryder Cup golf series, racking up four points to none in Scotch foursome matches ranging from routs to sensational comebacks.

ROBERT E. LEE, "by far the most photogenic of all the general officers of both armies, North and South," Roy Meredith tells us, was one of the least represented pictorially, so reluctant was he to sit for any kind of likeness. Despite this difficulty, Mr. Meredith has uncovered a surprising amount of material and compiled a gratifyingly comprehensive record of General Lee in pictures.
FOOTBALL Notre Dame routed Navy and Michigan beat Illinois yesterday in their bids for national honors. Scores of leading games: Alabama 13 Kentucky 0 Army 65 W. L 13 Boston Coll 27 Georgetown 6

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 1 -- Southern Methodist's high-riding Mustangs, taking the upper hand on the opening kick-off, knocked Texas out of the unbeaten ranks today and preserved their own perfect record in a breathless 14-to-13 football battle that was decided on the margin of a missed kick.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: While the embers of Maine's forest fires still blacken her ground, let us draw a lesson which goes beyond the well-worked slogans of fire prevention.

ORLANDO, Fla. -- An increasing number of Florida's winter visitors take time off from surf and beach to visit the local show gardens. There are ten of these public gardens, and they are now getting last-minute touches before the vacationists arrive.
ATHENS, Nov. 1 -- A general strike, next Thursday, was announced today by Fotios Makris, president of the Association of Athenian Trade Unions.

NOW that nearly all travel restrictions have been lifted, those early civilian casualties of the war, the expeditionary film-makers, are crystallizing story ideas and plumbing sources of sponsorship and support for contemplated ventures.

PARIS (By Wireless). IN his fascinating book, "A Study of History." Arnold Toynbee dwells upon the historical phenomenon that he calls "withdrawal and return." This consists of retreat into a wilderness or to a mountain top by a "creative pioneer" who, after a time, conies back into the world filled with new insight and inspiration for his leadership of "the inert majority."

A "Course in Smells," said to be the latest thing in adult training, is being offered at the New York University Division of General Education to persons in the aromatics and perfumery trades, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO -- The seller's market which has kept the vacation and travel industry doing a capacity business since the war ended seems to be turning into a buyer's market. The change may be evident this winter, more among those who follow the sun south than among the winter sports enthusiasts, and it probably will be felt more generally next summer.

TULANE -- Visual Aids A five-year visual aid training and production program, which will cost approximately $200,000, has been established at the Newcomb Art School of Tulane University. The program calls for the training of undergraduate and graduate students in the production of visual aid material, as well as in the production of special materials, for the Louisiana State Board of Health and the New Orleans Health Department.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Used car sales have slumped sharply in some parts of the country but are expected to rise again by spring with little or no relief from high prices, a survey of dealers in fifteen major markets indicated today.

IN one way, at least, Martha Foley's "Best American Short Stories of 1947" is a successful book: it is a good reflection of a bad time. Most of the stories represent frustration, broken dreams, and quiet desperation against a background of violence or harsh monotony.

THIS latest of Mr. Kroll's novels opens in 1778. Josiah Clinch, a North Carolina farmer, packs his family and belongings and sets out for a rich valley in uncharted territory to the west. His wife, Rachel, dies of exposure and, after hardships that would gray Daniel Boone's hair, the destination is reached.

A week ago this column discussed a decision, of the Circuit Court of Appeals holding that in the liquidation and dissolution of a corporation, where the corporate property was distributed in kind as a liquidating dividend and the stockholders sold the property, the appreciation in value of the property was not taxable to the corporation.

SUDDENLY there are four shows coming to town this week because Producer Harry Rosen made a last-minute decision to risk the slings and darts of Broadway with "Trial Honeymoon." Mr. Rosen's bringing his offering in tomorrow night, the same time the Theatre Guild will be daring The Street with "This Time Tomorrow."

The sale or other transfer of more American dry-cargo tonnage to foreign maritime interests will be one of the most bitterly fought features of the rehabilitation plan now under study, according to informed shipping men and officials in Washington who are conversant with current discussions.

When the United Nations General Assembly opened last Sept, 16, Secretary General Trygve Lie's timestudy experts predicted a six weeks' session. The prediction was based on the Assembly's probable budget of work -- including a "reasonable" agenda of new items and proposals, and the probable speeches to be made.

DETROIT, Nov. 1 -- R.J. Thomas, vice president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, apparently standing alone, refused today to sign a non-Communist affidavit along with twenty-two other members of the union's executive board.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 1 (AP) -- William and Mary's football team played its greatest game of the year today to defeat Wake Forest, 21 to 0.

A rental housing project to accommodate 666 families is under way in East Paterson, N.J., where ground was broken last week. According to the Roth-Schenker Corporation, builders, the garden-type project is the largest in Bergen County and the second largest in New Jersey.

The twenty-seventh annual meeting of Boy Scouts of America, Region 2, comprising New York and New Jersey, was held yesterday at the Hotel Astor, with 1,000 adult members attended morning, luncheon, afternoon and dinner sessions. The Scout leaders discussed the welfare of 190,000 boys of both states who are members of 7,892 Cub Packs.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at 11:05 A.M. and approved Austria's application for membership in International Civil Aviation Organization by 39 to 5, with two abstentions.

Sweeping changes in the planning of future neighborhoods are predicted by the Urban Land Institute, which has just published a handbook for community builders, forecasting, among other things, blocks from 1,800 to 2,000 feet long, sidewalks running along the interior lots behind the homes, and parking lots adjacent to churches.

MR. MEYER has written a valuable and disturbing book. He believes that the United Nations is headed for destruction, and that the only way to prevent the struggle for power between the United States and the Soviet Union from producing a third world war is to remodel the United Nations and make it a true world government.

TO the writer of this column a sheet of paper was handed early last week, with the remark, "Here's your bridge hand for next Sunday." What was written on the paper was this: South is declarer at a six notrump contract, and West opens a non-committal spade -- the eight.
