The United Nations Security Council, meeting in Flushing Meadow yesterday, adopted a compromise resolution intended to halt fighting in Java and to lead to a peaceful settlement of the Indonesian question. The compromise was one based on the United States resolution in which amendments of the Belgian, Chinese and Australian delegations had been merged.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 1 -- The unpopular 3 per cent salesand-use tax, enacted this year by the Republican General Assembly, is a major factor in the municipal elections to be held in the four largest Connecticut cities Tuesday.
TO THE EDITOR: It is unfortunate that Eric

Rare items of old English silver, including designs from the reign of Elizabeth through the period of George IV, brought record prices yesterday at the final auction of this property of the estate of the late J.P. Morgan.
In a thrill-packed football struggle, those arch, rivals from neighboring sections, Lafayette and Abraham Lincoln, battled to a 7-7 tie before 8,000 fans yesterday at Lincoln Field in Coney Island.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Although grains maintained a steady undertone on the Board of Trade today, initial gains extending to several cents a bushel in wheat were reduced by the close of the market. Corn and oats followed wheat in a slow week-end trade.
The 10,000-ton cruiser Georges Leygues, whose guns blasted the beaches of Normandy and Provence in the 1944 Allied invasions, sailed into New York harbor yesterday bearing the fruits of peace.
Under the leadership of steel and motor issues, the share market on the New York Stock Exchange closed irregularly higher yesterday.

DUFFTOWN, Scotland, Nov. 1 -- With Scotch whisky commanding black market prices of $60 and more a gallon the problem of the pilferage of liquor by racketeers has become a major problem for the distillers and the railroads alike.

Although six proposed amendments to the State Constitution and three housing propositions are to be voted on at the election next Tuesday, interest of the voters in New York City has centered in Proposition No. 4 to repeal the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council and substitute election by state Senate districts.

Officers of Freedom House, in a declaration sent yesterday to Representative Charles A. Halleck, House majority leader, and Representative John W. McCormack, Democratic leader, called for a new Committee on Subversive Activities in place of the present House Un-American Activities Committee.

The quickest way to implement the Marshall plan is to subcontract the whole job to American business firms on the same basis that American war-production was handled, a small group of leading industrial executives concluded during an informal conference here after an engineering meeting yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 1 (U.P.) -- Tom (Shorty) McWilliams, who hasn't always lived up to his reputation as a great football player, was the star today, smashing over for two touchdowns and setting up another as Mississippi State over powered Tulane, 20 to 0, before 35,000 fans.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 1 -- A late ground attack, culminating in a touchdown, gave a favored Muhlenberg eleven a 21-14 victory over Lehigh in Taylor Stadium today.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 -- The Boston University Terriers, rebounding after overwhelming defeats by Purdue and William and Mary, unleashed a devastating ground attack at Fenway Park today to crush Fordham University, 26 -- 6, before 2,703 chilled onlookers.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 1 -- Powerful Penn State, held to 13 points in the first half by a spiritet Colgate team, burst forth in a fivetouchdown fury in the second half today to bowl over the Red Raiders. 46 to 0, before a crowd of 15,000.

An investigation into the mysterious death of Daniel F. McCarthy, a member of the New York Stock Exchange, was started yesterday by the Missing Persons Bureau here after his battered body had been washed ashore at Leonardo, N.J.
LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 1 -- Howard Hughes' huge eight-engine flying boat, the largest airplane ever built, was floated for the first time from its drydock on the Long Beach waterfront today.

STILL, SMALL VOICE -- A glimpse into the secret lives of the city's librarians was vouchsafed a surprised patron of the Forty-second Street Library the other day. Riffling through the card index for a book on witches, she was brought up short by a standard library filing card securely in place between "Wit and Humor, Breton" and "Wit and Humor, Canadian."

DANIEL, EATON'S motive for going to China "was certainly no enthusiasm about saving anyone. He had never believed in any such theological necessity." This made him a rebel, "a dissenter, different from his fellow missionaries," because he could not, like them, "declare salvation through Christ the only way to God."

THIS has been a happy and productive year for Max Weber, judging by the array of about twenty new canvases at the Paul Rosenberg Gallery. Weber preserves an amazingly youthful spirit, and, although most of the work shown is along lines he has made familiar, there is still evidence of a tireless search and of willingness to experiment -- and no indication of settling into a comfortably proven formula.

THE Horticultural Society of New York's fortieth annual autumn exhibition, to be held at the Hotel Pennsylvania this Thursday through Saturday, has some entries for displays covering fifty square feet each. Commercial, professional and amateur gardeners are scheduled to show chrysanthemums, orchids, roses, and other flowers as well as vegetables and fruits.

A request for intervention by the United Nations to carry out "free and unfettered elections" in Yugoslavia has been made to the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow. Queens, by the Serbian Central National Committee, it was learned yesterday.

Fungus infections, particularly those that develop on the surface of the skin, nails and hair, are so common that they can be considered a universal human disease and in the treatment of them science is not much ahead of where it was 100 years ago, Dr. Marion B. Sulzberger told the final session of a conference on medical mycology at the Museum of Natural History yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Count Carlo Sforza, Italian Foreign Minister, left London today for Rome after a fairly successful visit but the British Foreign Office showed a fear of Italian political stability that somewhat hampered negotiations. In fact there was last-minute reluctance to renounce Britain's share of the Italian Navy and it almost wrecked the talks.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Completion of the Inter-American Highway far ahead of schedule was visualized tonight as a result of international guarantees to prevent aggression from without and strife from within which would endanger the stability of any country in the Western Hemisphere.

MR. Blum's compendium does everything for the Broadway season but pass judgment on it. All the statistics as to cast lists, producers, authors and designers are gathered in this handy packet. And for those plays that closed, the number of performances are given.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J. -- New Jersey has joined the list of states offering resident and nonresident nimrods a special deer season for bow-hunting only. Among the Eastern states New York was a pioneer in this experiment, having established a special bow-and-arrow season for Westchester County some years ago.

NANKING, Nov. 1 -- New First Army troops, marching north along the broken Changchun-Mukden railway, have recaptured Kungchuling, forty, miles below Changchun, and are approaching a junction with other units of the same army pushing south, it was reported tonight.

THE Publishers' Row boys being anxious to get their wares on the market well before Christmas, this is the last big publishing month of 1947. Herewith, accordingly, are a few of the more promising titles impending between this Tuesday and Nov. 31, inclusive:

Thirty-eight vacancies in elective offices, all but eight of which are in the judiciary, are to be filled by the voters of the city in Tuesday's general election. As to twenty -four of the thirty judicial vacancies there are no substantial contests, the same candidates having been picked by the Democrats and Republicans and either or both the American Labor and Liberal parties.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: If there ever was a time, internationally speaking, when we do not see the wood for the trees, it is in respect of the Russian problem. We concern ourselves with the trees of ideology and fail to stress the wood of imperialism.

THE Super D Graflex 3 1/4 by 4 1/4, featuring an automatic diaphragm and built-in open-flash synchronization is again reaching store counter after a wartime absence. The automatic diaphragm permits focusing and viewing with the lens wide open, thus giving the photographer the advantage of observing a bright ground-glass image rather than the dim one caused by a small lens opening.

Dr. Robert Hutchins, president of the University of Chicago, in an exclusive interview here yesterday, assailed the Army's campaign for universal military training as another example "of American foreign policy based on reliance on force."

WOMEN are saturated with realism; they are intense realists. I am a thoroughgoing realist myself, and at times this attitude of mind makes it rather hard for me to deal with men, who are virtually all romanticists. Men win by attempting the impossible.

A series of festivals dedicated to the music, drama and dance of the countries making up the United Nations will start here on Wednesday. The programs are sponsored by World Festivals for Friendship and will be held at the Central Needle Trades High School, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.

The majority of the staff of the Holland-America Line's flagship Nieuw Amsterdam, now on way to New York on her first post-war passenger voyage, are veteran employes of the line, it was said yesterday. Many of them served in the 36,667-gross ton vessel during her short period of pre-war service, and also during her wartime duty as a troop transport.

PRAGUE, Nov.1 -- Slovak Democratic party leaders repudiated today the resignation of the Slovak Cabinet. They said that the resignation had been engineered by Gustav Husak, Communist chairman of the Cabinet, at a time when several members of it were absent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The text of the summary by the Council of Economic Advisers of its report to the President on the impact of the foreign aid progran upon the domestic economy follows: SCOPE AND PURPOSE

The President's Committee on Civil Rights in its report last week drew a distinction of much importance to business men, concerned as they are with Communist propaganda aimed at the destruction of American free enterprise first and eventually of American democracy as a whole.

A series of festivals dedicated to the music, drama and dance of the countries making up the United Nations will start here on Wednesday. The programs are sponsored by World Festivals for Friendship and will be held at the Central Needle Trades High School, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.

The majority of the staff of the Holland-America Line's flagship Nieuw Amsterdam, now on way to New York on her first post-war passenger voyage, are veteran employes of the line, it was said yesterday. Many of them served in the 36,667-gross ton vessel during her short period of pre-war service, and also during her wartime duty as a troop transport.

PRAGUE, Nov.1 -- Slovak Democratic party leaders repudiated today the resignation of the Slovak Cabinet. They said that the resignation had been engineered by Gustav Husak, Communist chairman of the Cabinet, at a time when several members of it were absent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The text of the summary by the Council of Economic Advisers of its report to the President on the impact of the foreign aid progran upon the domestic economy follows: SCOPE AND PURPOSE

The President's Committee on Civil Rights in its report last week drew a distinction of much importance to business men, concerned as they are with Communist propaganda aimed at the destruction of American free enterprise first and eventually of American democracy as a whole.
VOTERS of New York State will decide on Tuesday whether they will permit two small sections of the state forest preserves to be opened for construction of new ski trails.

On Tuesday in an old-five-story building at 290 Third Street, 600 boys between the ages of 8 and 17 will have their own private election for offices in the Boys Brotherhood Republic," the smallest republic in the world."
Based on volume thus far and with indications pointing to heavy Christmas trade, retail sales this year will rise above $100,000,000,000 for the first time in the history of the United States.

High school students participating yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES expressed approval of the two-party system as an aid to democratic government, but several advocated independent parties "to stir up issues."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Voting machines will click in many states Tuesday, but political sources view the off-year state and municipal elections as offering little for the 1945 forecasters.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 2 -- Appointment of Dr. Louis B. Wright as director of the Folger Shakespeare Library in Washington, D.C., and plans for the library's development were announced today by President Charles W. Cole of Amherst College on behalf of the college's trustees.

New York stores are featuring decorative schemes for laundries that are being brought up from basements to take places beside kitchens. Improved equipment to make washing and ironing easier also is being shown.
TOKYO. Nov. 2 -- Last week's Cabinet squabbles over economic matters have resulted in two important developments.

With the exception of a few minor changes the list released yesterday by the Metropolitan Opera Association of subscribers to box seats in the "Diamond Horseshoe" at the Metropolitan Opera House for the forthcoming season is practically the same as for several years.

"Manon," "Tannhaeuser," "The Magic Flute" and "Tosca," four operas that were not heard at the Metropolitan Opera last season, will be given during the first week of the new season, General Manager Edward Johnson announced yesterday in revealing the casts for the first week.

Adhering to the vagaries of show business, two plays will pass in review tonight -- "This Time Tomorrow" (curtain at 8), at the Barrymore, and "Trial Honeymoon" (curtain at 8:40), at the Royale. Those who like to recal such things will doubtless remember there hasn't been a simila Broadway conflict since last Dec 26, when two musicals, "Beggar's Holiday" and "Toplitzky of Notre Dame" were trotted out for critical evaluation.

Termination of Regulation W means the end of "unfair rationing by credit," Arthur O. Dietz, president of Universal C.I.T. Credit Corporation, installment sales company, asserts in a special statement issued yesterday for publication today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Robert A. Lovett, Under-Secretary of State, denied today to seven former employes of the State Department, dismissed in June for what were broadly assigned as security reasons, the opportunity either to get a hearing on formal charges or to resign without prejudice.

Forty-nine representative American communities, ranging from metropolitan to rural, have been selected by the Public Library Inquiry for a cross-section study of the country's library facilities, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Robert D. Leigh, director of the inquiry, which has offices at 70 East Forty-fifth Street.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market last week generally moved to lower levels. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were off 15 to 58 points, with the May, 1948, delivery suffering the greatest loss.

The nineteen movie writers, directors and actors who flew from Hollywood last week to appear before the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities will urge their labor and guild organizations to campaign to have the contempt citations against ten of their group voted down when Congress convenes Nov. 17, it was announced yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 2 -- The Rumanian Government utilized today its repressive powers to keep more than 100 witnesses from appearing for the defense in the trial of Dr. Juliu Maniu, leader of the Peasant party, and eighteen associates on treason charges.

The New Friends of Music presented the first concert of the group's twelfth season late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. The organization's programs for the series are devoted to works by Bach, Beethoven, Mendelssohn and Hindemith, and at the opening event all but the first-named of these composers were represented by an important opus, on a schedule that was well devised, meaty and skillfully performed.

The New York University Center for Safety Education will conduct research studies in twenty states to determine "diagnoses for the disease of chronic traffic violations," Dr. Herbert J. Stack, director of the center, announced yesterday.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 2 -- The largest aircraft ever built, Howard Hughes' eight-engined flying boat, flew for the first time today. With Mr. Hughes himself at the controls, the 200-ton plywood colossus rose seventy feet in the air for a distance of a mile on the third of three test runs in Los AngelesLong Beach Harbor.

With Buddy O'Connor setting the scoring pace with a "hat trick," The New York Rangers sent the Toronto Maple Leafs down to defeat in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, 7 to 4.

Acting for the first time in his capacity as Suffragan Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York, the Right Rev. Horace W.B. Donegan officiated yesterday at a confirmation service at the Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, Broadway and 155th Street.
GENEVA, Nov. 2 -- Another post-war attempt to establish a general international code governing commercial rights in civil aviation will get under way here Tuesday.

Newer thinking in infant care is catching on because many mothers would like to give their babies more attention than prevailing rules permit, according to Dr. Leo H. Bartemeier of the Henry Ford Hospital, Detroit, Mich.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 2 -- The thirtieth anniversary of the Balfour Declaration promising Jews "a national home in Palestine" passed peacefully today with the attention of Jews and Arabs centered on the United States proposal for partition of Palestine next July 1.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Liquidation was on in oats early last week in the grain markets, prices being off 3 1/2 to 6 1/8 cents a bushel from the finish of the previous week at one time. Pressure attributed to Canadian interests was a factor. However, the market rallied later with other grains and closing trades yesterday on the Board of Trade were 1 3/8 cents lower to 1/2 cent a
C.D. Clawson, president of the Ferro Enamel Corporation, has been named president of the Porcelain Enamel Institute to replace Richard H. Turk, vice president of Pemco Corporation.

William Z. Foster, general secretary and head of the Communist party in this country, and Earl Browder, former general secretary, are enrolled members of the American Labor party, Alex Rose, a leader of the Liberal party, declared yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The United States Air Force announced today that the Republic P-84 "Thunderjet" fighter plane was ready for combat. The new plane has passed firing tests of its six guns at the Republic Aviation Corporation's plant at Farmingdale, L.I., and is now "fully qualified for operational service."

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Trade in lard futures was rather slow on the Board of Trade last week, and the market was easily influenced. The nearby deliveries showed comparative easiness while the deferred were firm. Scattered liquidation was in evidence in the November delivery due to anticipations of fairly liberal tenders of the cash product on November contracts.

COLLEGIATE football advanced into the November homestretch without a major upset being registered over the week-end. Unusual? Not especially. Perhaps you never noticed it before, but October is the month for upsets. By the time the second half of the season rolls around the teams have been shaken down sufficiently so that the false favorites and the overrated squads have been properly identified.

The municipal elections in England and Wales -- the Scots are still to be heard from -- follow the French, Norwegian, Danish and Swiss in reflecting a new trend in the European democracies. In the Continental countries the vote was against the Communists.

LONDON, Nov. 2 While the unpleasant affair of the New Union Goldfields collapse has adversely affected stock market sentiment, it is now believed its effects will be less widespread than had appeared probable. Some return of confidence in the market immediately concerned is now taking place.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- International cooperation should begin in the home, the Walter A. Kennedy family here believes. To prove it, the Kennedy's opened their home at 223 Woodland Avenue for two benefits to help a woman in La Roehelle, France.
The Communist party of the United States has decided, after a month's wait, not to affiliate openly with the Communist Information Bureau.
ROME, Nov. 2 -- The Communist party organ Unita this morning gave great prominence to a message that Henry Wallace, who is at present in Rome, sent to the Communist-Dominated Union of Italian Women.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Frankie Albert's sharpshooting -- good for four touchdowns -- was entirely too much for the Los Angeles Dons today and the San Francisco 49'ers rolled to a 26-16 victory before 53,726 All-America Football Conference fans in Memorial Coliseum.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- Lanvin glamorizes the shirtmaker frock in an important midseason showing. Skirts about twelve inches from the floor are dramatically wide but wearably so. Some are full circles, some made up of unpressed pleating' and others gathered with a wide band of tucks about the hemline.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 2 -- Pronounced Communist activity in Indonesia, manifest in underground resistance to the Dutch and in long-term planning to dominate the economy of the archipelago, is being closely' watched by the Netherlands.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 2 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has acquired optional screen rights to a new novel which Louis Bromfield is writing under the title, "What Vinnie Knew," for publication next year by Cosmopolitan Magazine and Harper Sons.

Theatre parties continue as a popular means of raising funds for carrying on the work of various philanthropic enterprises. Officers and members of the board of the Winfield Day Nursery have taken over the performance of "The Winslow Boy" on the night of Nov. 24 at the Empire Theatre.

Completion of negotiations for a new first mortgage loan of $14,750,000 on the forty-story Equitable Office Building at 120 Broadway were announced over the week-end in a transaction that also is expected to result in the reorganization of the corporation in progress for several years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Representative Harold Knutson, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said tonight that the recommendation of the President's Council of Economic Advisers that present taxes be maintained would not deter him from pushing once more a bill to cut Federal levies toy $4,000,000,000.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y. Nov. 2 -- "The claim of the totalitarian state to be master of men's souls and bodies presents tire greatest threat to civilization today," Cardinal Spellman said here this afternoon.

Customs guards, the Police Department and the Travelers Aid Society joined forces yesterday to help an Army sergeant find his British fiancee. They succeeded after the 26-year-old soldier had spent a few hours biting his finger nails in a police station.

DETROIT, Nov. 2 -- Sadder indeed is the news concerning the New York Football Giants today. Seeking their first victory of the National League campaign, the New Yorkers flubbed two grand opportunities in the opening period and went on to absorb their fifth straight defeat, this one a 35-7 drubbing by the Detroit Lions.

UNION CITY, N.J., Nov. 2 -- An underdog St. Michael's High eleven defeated All Hallows of New York, 14 -- 7, before 5,000 at Roosevelt Stadium today. It was the New York team's first defeat of the season. After trailing from the first quarter as a result of Ed Bateman's touchdown, the victors came back strongly in the final period to score twice on drives of 72 and 65 yards.

During recent months, average terms of installment contracts appear to have been below the permissible limits, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reports in its Monthly Review, just issued. This condition, it was explained, resulted either because the principal lenders and merchants have not taken full advantage of the maximum terms permitted under Regulation W, or because customers have made payments more rapidly than required.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We recommend to the voters that they vote "Yes" on Constitutional Amendment 4 on the ballot on election day.

One of New York's largest and most far-reaching charities is currently engaged in its annual campaign for funds with an appeal that should reach the heart and pocketbook of every New Yorker. The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, 71 West Forty-seventh Street, New York 19, is seeking $15,000,000, the largest maintenance sum in its history, to carry its 116 affiliated health and social agencies through June 30, 1948.

ROME, Nov. 2 -- The Communists and the Left-wing Socialists emphasized the closeness of their collaboration by announcing today that they would jointly celebrate the thirtieth anniversary of the Russian Revolution.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Otto Graham threw three touchdown passes today, one leading to a gain of ninety-nine yards, to Mac Speedie for an All-America Conference record, as the Champion Cleveland Browns whipped the Buffalo Bills, 28-7, before a record Buffalo football crowd of 43,167.

BOSTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Sid Luckman tossed four touchdown passes, three of them to lanky Ken Kavanaugh, to pull his Chicago Bears into a 28-24 National Football League victory over the Boston Yanks today before 24,894 at Fenway Park.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 2 -- The gasoline shortage that has been talk to most persons became a reality for motorists in and around this city today. For the first time since the war gasoline was rationed, though on a scale so limited that it did not upset or seriously impede Sunday driving.

Subversive groups never will be permitted to seek "shelter" for their "unpatriotic and traitorous meetings" in the Catholic schools of America, Msgr. John S. Middleton, secretary for education of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, declared yesterday.

There are brooks that tumble down rocky hillsides and brooks that wind through quiet meadows, brooks that chuckle beside country roads and brooks that sing in laurel-sided ravines. But when the time of black frosts arrives and the maples, birches and beeches have dropped their leaves to enrich the woodland carpet the countryman likes to walk along the bank of the woodland brook.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles scored in the first two minutes -- and in every period -- to hang up an easy 38-14 National League football victory over the Washington Redskins today.

Special taxes collected by the city in the fiscal year ended June 30 totaled $157,656,433 or more than twice the amount they yielded in the previous fiscal period, according to the annual report of Controller Lazarus Joseph, made public yesterday.

ROME, Nov. 2 -- With the slogan "God, country, family, freedom and honor," a new anti-Communist movement of which the world perhaps is destined to hear a great deal in the future has been launched in Rome.

Iris Mabry, with Ralph Gilbert as pianist and composer, gave a solo dance recital last night at the International Theatre, and if, as the first recital of the season, it can be considered as setting the standard for what lies ahead, we are in for a stimulating season.

The top row of the voting machines for tomorrow's election is confined to the six proposed constitutional amendments, three state-wide propositions, and the local referendum on proportional representation, running from left to right.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Nov. 2 -- Award of a contract to the Republic Aviation Corporation for $15,000,000 worth of its Thunderjet planes brought elation today among Republic officials as well as the 5,400 employes.
Increased, commission rates, which will become effective on the New York Stock Exchange today have aroused some of the bitterest debates in the annuals of the Street.

LONDON, Nov. 2 -- Conservative party leaders, jubilant over their sweeping gains from the Labor party in yesterday's municipal elections for England and Wales, renewed more strongly today Winston Churchill's recent demand that the Government resign.

Work on the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel will stop at 8 A.M. today, with every indication that it will not resume until a dispute between 1,200 unionized sandhogs and the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority has been eaded.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 2 -- The Green of Notre Dame and the Maize and Blue of Michigan continue to fly on high above the football ramparts, but the Lone Star of Texas no longer is up there.

Consumer Education Cited Educational work of the Committee on Consumer Relations in Advertising, Inc., to increase public confidence in advertising, should begin to "show a profit" in present efforts of industry and business to win the battle of distribution, Dr. Kenneth Dameron, committee director, declared over the week-end in announcing that Part V of the committee lesson series, "The Consumer-Buyer and Distribution," will be available before the end of the year.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 -- Evidence of the 'wholesale hoarding of food by the Germans has been uncovered in the United States zone as a result of the pressure by bi-zonal authorities for better deliveries. If the results of sporadic raids are any index, far more food is availiable in Germany than has ever been admitted or the Allies ever dreamed.

The Rev. Dr. William Pierson Merrill, pastor emeritus of the Brick Presbyterian Church, chided yesterday the large percentage of church members "who do not think it worth while to spend the time, money and effort necessary to maintain these agencies of worship."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- The United States will propose that part of the Negeb, the desert area in the south of Palestine running to the Egyptian border, be assigned to the proposed Arab state or, if this is not feasible, to some kind of' international administration rather than to the Jewish state, reliable sources said tonight.
Week Ended Oct. 31, 1947 Pound sterling for spot and forward positions pointed off again last week with the chief weight of the decline found more in the spot document than in the bill rates.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 2 -- In its drive for world government, United World Federalists, Inc., completed today at the final session of its first annual convention a formal organization of the group and adopted seven guiding principles for a world federal government.
The largest "class" of vice consuls ever sent by the State Department into the foreign field will visit New York in the next two weeks for the ninth and final week of 'their indoctrination.

Mayor O'Dwyer made public yesterday a letter from Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, declaring that a serious shortage of personnel for care of patients required the filling of 7,608 positions in the near future at an estimated annual cost of $13,740,950.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Extension of remaining export and import controls beyond the present expiration date of Feb. 29, 1948, was recommended today by W. Averell Harriman, Secretary of Commerce.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 2 -- Mississippi's Senatorial contest for the five-year unexpired term of the late Senator Theodore G. Bilbo comes to a close Monday with each of the five candidates apparently confident of victory.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 2 -- Problems affecting the municipalities throughout the country were placed on the agenda today for discussion in the American Municipal Association's twenty-fourth annual conference, opening tomorrow.

The Pordham University A.A. made a clean sweep of titles yesterday in the annual Metropolitan A.A.U. junior cross-country championship at Victory Field in Queens. Led by individual winner John Lynch, the Ram squad captured team honors with a low point total of 26.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Elmer Angsman, ex-Notre Dame back, scored two touchdowns after setups by the Paul Christman-Mal Kutner battery combination as the Chicago Cardinals outfought Bob Waterfield and the Los Angeles Rams, 17 to 10, in a National Football League game today.

Winning only one game of ten, losing four and drawing five, a team representing the Manhattan Chess Club lost an international radio match to the Jockey Club of La Plata, Buenos Aires yesterday. The North American side went down to disastrous and unexpected defeat in the twelve-hour session by a score of 6 1/2 to 3 1/2.

Bob Hope retained his hold on first place in the order of popularity among night-time radio programs, according to the latest findings of the C.E. Hooper orgaization, while Fred Alien's newest score boosted his show from eleventh to second place.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- President Truman today asked municipal officials throughout the nation to make "concrete proposals" for relieving the housing shortage, which he called "foremost among the many pressing problems facing the nation."

To prevent further rises in the price level, it is essential to close the gap between the money supply and the production of goods by stepping up production and preventing any further expansion in the money supply, the National Association of Manufacturers declared over the week-end.

Thirteen lots of aluminum, worth $84,000 in cost value, comprising ingots, sheets, wire, rod, tubing and extrusions; sixty-three lots of steel in bars, strips, angles and plates, with a cost value of $18,000, and more than 850,000 pounds of demolition blocks suitable for underground construction work are among the new listings offered for sale by the War Assets Administrations beginning today, Carl P. Malstrom, regional director, announced over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- Following are the texts of a letter to George C. Marshall, Secretary of State, from Thurman Arnold, Abe Fortas and Paul A. Porter, counsel for dismissed employes of the State Department, and of a letter in reply sent by Robert A. Lovett, Under-Secretary of State:

The 1947 rate of foundry coke production, oven and beehive combined, if continued will actually produce about 3,869,000 tons of foundry coke this year, setting an output record above the previous high of 1918 when 3,861,677 tons were made, it was revealed by Samuel Weiss executive secretary of the American Coke and Coal Chemicals Institute, in a report received here last week from the Gray Iron Founders' Society, Inc., Cleveland.

Roland Hayes is a singer people do not tire of. So when the 60year-old tenor gave his annual recital last night at Carnegie Hall there was a warm band of admirers on hand who stood at his entry, applauded every number warmly and kept him coming back for bows until long after the house lights were turned up.

Figures on current corporate profits "are not all that they seem," the National City Bank of New York asserts in its Monthly Letter, issued today. The figures, the bank explains, frequently reflect inventory profit and are "overstated" through inadequate estimates of replacement costs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The Philco Corporation of Philadelphia is charged in a complaint by the Federal Trade Commission of using a sales promotion plan involving a lottery scheme, deception of the public and "disparagement of competitive products."

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- A scarcity of cash corn at terminal markets during the 1947-48 crop year is foreseen by the Department of Agriculture, which suggests in a tentative estimate that the amount of corn as grain that leaves farms this season will be around 500,000,000 bushels.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 (U.P.) -- The Federal Security Agency reported today that progress was being made in rehabilitating disabled civilians as well as war veterans. It estimated that 60,000 men, and women, disabled in civilian life, would be fully restored to self-supporting jobs during the current fiscal year 1948.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- Retailers have little to say about food prices, for their share of the consumer's dollar is the relatively small fraction of 15 cents, while 85 cents goes back to the wholesale supplier, Patsy D'Agostino, president of the National Association of Retail Grocers, said today in a statement released from the Association's headquarters here.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Some years ago Judge Seabury said he had two things against me -- my close friendship with Governor Smith and my dislike for proportional representation. Time has caused no change in my attitude toward either of these subjects.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $55,045,075,852. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

That there is a positive value to United States propaganda efforts to penetrate the curtain of hostilecontrolled information available to the populations of the Soviet Union and satellite nations is increasingly confirmed by the state-directed organs of those countries.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 2 -- "The world of religion owes an incalculable debt to Judaism," President Truman said in a message issued today by the Union of American Hebrew Congregations in commendation of its American Jewish cavalcade.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 2 -- Premier Jawaharlal Nehru of the Dominion of India suggested in a radio broadcast tonight that the United Nations should supervise a referendum in the State of Kashmir to determine whether this Princely State -- currently the scene of a small war -- should accede to India or to Pakistan.
NEW ROCHELE, N.Y., Nov. 2 -- The Iona School extended its victory skein to sixteen games today with a 14-to-6 triumph over Mount St. Michael of the Bronx, before a crowd of 12,000.
The Anchor Club of the Police Department, composed of members of the Knights of Columbus, held its twelfth annual memorial service yesterday afternoon at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

A vigorous fight between the "colonial" powers and their sympathizers, and many of the smaller nations, backed by the Soviet bloc, is expected to occupy the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow today.

No other horse ever won such fame as Man o' War. None was more beautiful, with lovelier lines of grace and power. None was more beloved by an admiring and faithful public. Few have lived so long. The American scene seems a little vacant with Man o' War gone to the Elysian Fields where all good horses go.
CHICAGO, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens tonight defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 2, for Chicago's sixth consecutive defeat since the start of the season.

BERLIN, Nov. 2 -- The radio and the theatre will be the principal vehicles for the accelerated program of "selling" a non-totalitarian government to the Germans. Each field already is encountering difficulties that in some cases are the result of "United States Army policy and in others are caused by a shortage of funds and personnel.

In a turn of the tide as dramatic as that in France, the British electorate administered yesterday a crushing defeat to the British Labor party which cannot remain without influence on the British Government and its policies. The defeat was inflicted in municipal elections and does not, therefore, change the immediate situation in Parliament, which only a few days ago upheld the Labor Government by a vote of 348 to 201.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 -- For the second Sunday the inquiry of the House Un-American Activities Committee was attacked in a radio broadcast, "Hollywood Fights Back."

DETROIT, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings knocked the Boston Bruins out of their undisputed National Hockey Leauge lead tonight by treating a crowd of 13,375 fans to a 2-to-1 victory over the pace-setters.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 2 -- Cavendish Cannon, United States Ambassador, sent a note to the Yugoslav Foreign Office today protesting the Yugoslav expulsion order against Arthur M. Brandel, part-time correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Spurred by predictions of Democratic and Republican leaders that repeal of proportional representation will be carried by a large majority, supporters of PR arranged yesterday to keep up the fight for its retention until the last possible moment and to have many thousands of watchers and workers at the polls tomorrow.

After an ownership of a few weeks, Loomis J. Grossman, operator, has resold the new one-story taxpayer on a plot 60 by 165 feet at 319 Main Street, Huntingdon, L.I., to Huntington Enterprises, an investing client of Jerome L. Greene, attorney, in a transaction negotiated by Henry Baker Co., brokers.
We summarize here the recommendations which this newspaper has made to its readers regarding questions and candidates to be voted on tomorrow.

NANKING, Nov. 2 -- An omnibus "holding company" for China's secret societies, which have an estimated total membership of 20,000,000, has been organized here to combat the Communist influence and tighten Nationalist control both over cities and countryside.
PEIPING, China, Nov. 2 (AP) -- The battle for Kiri continued in full fury today, with the main struggle for possession of a commanding height of land twelve miles southwest of that Manchurian city.

Whether Protestant Episcopal clergymen may hereafter marry divorced women whose ex-husbands are living will be threshed out at a special meeting of the House of Bishops of that communion in Winston-Salem, N.C., this week.

PARIS, Nov. 2 -- France and Britain will discuss empire coordination, especially in their African colonies, as a means of overcoming their common dollar deficits at trade talks opening tomorrow. The discussions will be held by the Anglo-French Economic Committee, which meets periodically to study trade and balance of payments.

LONDON, Nov. 2 (AP) -- Mr. Churchill issued this statement today on the results of the elections: I wish to express my warm thanks and congratulations to all voters who took part in the nationwide protest against Socialist mismanagement of our affairs.

A musicianly debut recital was given at Town Hall yesterday afternoon by Francine Falkon, contralto, who won the singers' award in the New York Federation of Music Clubs' contest last spring. A sizable audience greeted the young singer with uncommon enthusiasm.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- A country-wide ban on the sale of liquor at gasoline filling stations was urged today at the resolutions committee meeting of the American Automobile Association here.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 2 -- The Argentine Army has succeeded to a limited extent in relieving the congestion of the Port of Buenos Aires, which a month ago was notorious.

The feature of the fifty-fifth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, to be held here Nov. 12 to 15, will be an address by Admiral William H. P. Blandy, USN, Commander in chief of the Atlantic Fleet, on "The Future Value of Sea Power."

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- World War II cost the principal belligerents, both Allied and Axis, more than 15,000,000 in dead and missing in military personnel, George C. Marshall, Secretary of State, wrote in "Ten Eventful Years," the Encyclopedia Britannica's new fourvolume history of the period 1937 through 1947.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 2 -- Numerous international holding companies originally registered in the tiny principality of Liechtenstein to escape the increasing taxation in their own countries are on the point of transferring their headquarters to Tangier, the intenationalized zone of North Africa opposite Gibraltar.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The State Department has survived what Under Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett has called "hell week" and can now discern the main points and problems of what is to be known officially as the European Recovery Program.

Flameproof drapery fabrics made largely of Fibreglas now are being printed in designs and colors suitable for home use. New dyeing processes and combinations of glass fibers with treated cotton, rayon or wool are among recent advances that are taking the fire-resistant fabrics beyond the hotel and night club class to which they have been limited.

Sprinkling a bit of salt and pepper on foods to flavor them is such a simple matter that no one hesitates about doing it. Herbs and spices, on the other hand, are not used nearly as much, although they contribute just as distinctively to the flavor of many dishes.
There is a tradition to the effect that as a general rule it is a journalistic impropriety to discuss the merits of a case at law while the latter is still before the court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 -- The State Department has survived what Under Secretary of State Robert A. Lovett has called "hell week" and can now discern the main points and problems of what is to be known officially as the European Recovery Program.

PITTSFIELD, Mass., Nov. 2 -- That organized skiing, both recreationally and competitively, will enjoy its biggest season since before the war, was predicted today as the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association concluded its two-day convention at the Wendell-Sheraton Hotel.

The commuters, housewives and local business people who live in Valhalla, an unincorporated Westchester hamlet in the Bronx River Valley, believe they have found a solution to the traffic problem that has been plaguing them -- education, engineering and enforcement.

The gold medallion of honor of the Women's International Exposition will be presented tonight to Governor Dewey at a dinner in the Oak Room of the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street. The twentyfourth annual exposition will open in the armory at noon.

TYNDALL FIELD, Fla., Nov. 2 -- The joint Army, Navy and Air Force maneuver began here today as a naval shore party and elements of an "enemy" infantry division swarmed ashore under a pall of clouds which hid their operations.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 2 -- Dr. Bernardo Alberto Houssay, who will leave here Dec. 3 to receive his share of the Nobel Prize in Medicine in Stockholm, was subjected last night to an unprecedented bitter attack in the Government organ Epoca.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Monday, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Nineteen high Nazis from all walks of life in Hitler's Third Reich were indicted on war crimes charged today in what may be the last case to be prosecuted here by United States authorities.
A permanent committee of distinguished citizens will be set up to aid and guide the Welfare Commissioner in operating the city's $142,000,000-a-year relief organization, it was learned last night.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 2 (AP) -- America successfully defended its right to the Ryder Cup when it defeated Britain, 11 points to 1, today, in the most devastating rout in the history of the international golfing event between professionals of the two nations.

Spec Sanders tallied three touchdowns yesterday to lead the Newi York Yankees to a 35-to-21 victory over the Baltimore Colts. Buddy Young and Bruce Alford also delighted a Stadium crowd of 21,714 with long scoring dashes as Ray Flaherty's impressive club took undisputed possession of the lead in the All-American Conference's Eastern Division.

Some thirty museum and gallery exhibitions are scheduled to open this week, providing the local art world with a wide variety of attractions. The Metropolitan Museum will place on view, opening to the public on Friday, the Henry L. Phillips collection of Japanese prints -- pictures of the everyday world as seen by Japanese artists of the seventeenth, eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

The Metropolitan Museum will place on view, opening to the public on Friday, the Henry L. Phillips collection of Japanese prints -- pictures of the everyday world as seen by Japanese artists of the seventeenth, eighteenth and nineteenth centuries.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Nov. 2 -- Henry E. Abt, president of the Brand Names Foundation, Inc., of New York, which has joined the local Chamber of Commerce in sponsoring the community's brand name cooperative merchandising experiment which ended its second week yesterday, today cautioned against jumping to conclusions too fast.

A COUPLE of summers ago two mysterious strangers appeared in New York. They were interested in everything under the sun and moon, from the folkways of Manhattan to radio's frantic folklore. They were both wonderful conversationalists, though their points of view were strikingly disparate. Presently they fell in with a philosophical taxi driver and a scholarly newspaper man.
CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 2 (AP) -- A 9-foot-2-inch tide swept through the low-lying sections of Charleston today as heavy seas lashed the entire coastline of the Carolinas.

Protestant churches of all deominations observed Reformation day in special services in the city and throughout the country yesrerday. The observance Commemorated the historic date in 1517 then Martin Luther nailed on the castle Church door in Wittenberg, Germany, his ninety-five theses attacking the sale of indulgences.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We have read the thought-provokin editorial, "Decline of the Mesabi," i the Oct. 17 issue of the times.

Lieut. Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, World War II commander of the famed Eighty-Second Airborne Division and'later the XVIII Airborne Corps, will receive the salute of the military teams to open formally the National Horse Show tonight in Madison Square Garden.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Arthur M. Brandel, part-time correspondent for THE NEW YORK TIMES, accompanied by his wife, left today by train for Trieste after being ordered out by the Yugoslav Government for what it said was "offensive" writing.
CHICAGO. Nov. 3 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

SHIP BOTTOM, N.J., Nov. 3 -- Although the extended period of warm weather delayed the arrival of some species of waterfowl, primarily mallards and scaup, Barnegat Bay seems to have no scarcity of birds, and the baymen anticipate a good season.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- The French Cabinet today adopted a series of tax reforms designed to increase the national revenue by some 70,000,000,000 francs (about $591,500,000), principally by new methods of assessment, collection and punishment of evasion.

Samson Francois, whirlwind French pianist, gave stylish performances of two concertos in his first American appearance with the New York City Symphony, under Leonard Bernstein last night at the City Center. The first was the Prokofieff Fifth, played here by the composer with the Boston Symphony fourteen years ago, and the second was Liszt's First.
TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 3 -- (AP) -- A proposal to create a New Jersey Port Authority to counteract New York State's World Trade Corporation was rejected today by Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- (AP) -- A 15 per cent rent increase for about 900,000 Chicago area tenants was recommended today, and the action was promptly criticized by labor and City Council leaders and by a rent advisory board member who resigned in protest.

Those Argentine horses sure like distance. New York racing fans are familiar with the exploits of Talon, Lord Grillo, Rico Monte and Pujante over a piece of ground, and a crowd of 22,078 saw another importation from the South American republic do a fair bit of running to take the Patroon Handicap, a mile-and-a-half test that featured the program of the Empire City Racing Association at Jamaica yesterday.

It must have been with considerable satisfaction that Howard Hughes ordered the throttles of the eight engines of his 200-ton flying boat pushed forward to flying speed and felt her lift from the water and then cruise on smoothly for a mile or more. It had taken five years and $25,000,000 (of which 7,000,000 was his own money), but the thing would fly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- New radio stations today have about a fifty-fifty chance of earning a profit, with those in small communities at considerable advantage over those in metropolitan areas, the Federal Communications Commission reported today.

In the largest monthly increase since August, 1946, sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores in October rose to a new peak 38 per cent over the corresponding month last year, according to the survey made yesterday by The New York Times.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 3 -- The emergency period in the country's housing problem will last another eight to ten years and it will require the construction of 1,500,000 dwelling units annually for the next ten to twelve years to take care of the housing shortage.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 3 -- Jack Guinn, Associated Press correspondent here since January, 1946, was notified by the Hungarian Government today that he must leave the country within twenty-four hours or face charges of "espionage and smuggling out of criminals."
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Gross farm income is substantial enough to support a sizable increase in railroad freight rates on agricultural and livestock products, two Western railroad officials said today.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 3 -- Gunmen killed a Jewish police corporal and wounded three British policemen in three shooting incidents in Palestine today. One of the gunmen was killed.

Their confidence bolstered still further by the shutout of Cornell on the heels of the thrilling triumph over Army, Columbia's regulars were allowed to take things easy yesterday while the reserves started preparing for Dartmouth with a contact scrimmage on Baker Field.

Tuesday, Nov. 4, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at 11 A.M. at Flushing Meadow and resumed consideration of draft resolutions on information from non-self-governing territories proposed by trusteeship committee.
TYNDALL FIELD, Fla., Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Army's Second Armored Division rolled smoothly through its Florida Gulf Coast invasion exercise today, but it had to get its running gears wet in the surf.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The Senate Spiall Business Committee plans to hold hearings within ten days to check the reasons why the Maritime Commission is selling so called surplus tankers to foreign buyers despite the Ship Sales Act of 1946, which gives preference to United States buyers.

AiOARD B-29 OVER THE ATLANTIC, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- Sixty superfortresses, defending Bermuda against a mock attack by a United States Navy task force, intercepted and "bombed" the surface raiders 400 miles from their goal today in a test of United States sea and air power.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Villanova College and the University of Kentucky were chosen today as football opponents in the first annual Great Lakes Bowl game at Cleveland Stadium Dec. 6.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 3 -- The issue of the next national election is "whether the majority of the people are going to be able to write, the laws they want, or whether the country is to be run by labor-union leaders," Senator Robert A. Taft told 400 Kiwanians at a luncheon today.

The decision of the voters on constitutional questions, rather than on individual candidates, will hold the major interest today in this city, New York State and neighboring New Jersey. In the rest of the nation scattered contests from coast to coast will be in the political spotlight.
Judges sitting in Kings County Court are dissatisfied with the present system whereby control of the court's calendar is vested with the District Attorney.

Efforts by India and the Soviet Union to have the United Nations bring pressure on Britain, Belgium, the Netherlands, France and other colonial powers to submit political information on their colonies were finally blocked yesterday by the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Calumet Farm's 5-year-old mare, Twosy, splashed six furlongs through the mud at Pimlico today to end up her track career with a $101,375 bankroll.

THERE isn't anybody now writing who remotely resembles Maritta Wolff, the Michigan prodigy who burst upon the literary world seven years ago with her extraordinary novel, "Whistle Stop." Little Miss Wolff was 22 at the time and as thoroughly informed about the seamy side of life in a Midwestern factory town as if she had spent fifty years in police Maritta Wolff courts, reformatory schools, honkey tonks and slums.

Strange fruit adorned the program of the Little Orchestral Society last night in Town Hall. There was no particular sequence of matter or manner in the compositions presented, which was well, since if there is anything that is fatiguing it is usually the program arranged according to classification and chronology.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 3 -- Following is the prepared, text of the address delivered by Senator Arthur M. Vandenberg today at the University of Michigan convocation marking the centennial of Dutch colonization in Michigan:

Opposition to the St. Lawrence Seaway Project is being organized by the American steamship industry, it was reported here yesterday. Legislation to authorize the project is expected to come before Congress at its special session beginning Nov. 17 or at the regular session starting in January.

During the war a technical phrase whose use had previously been more or less confined to economists and fiscal experts gained a considerable measure of popular currency. This was the phrase '"inflation gap," and what it meant was this:
The immediate immigration of at least 150,000 European Jewish refugees into Palestine was urged last night by former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman in an address at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- One of the biggest player deals in National Hockey League history was negotiated today when the floundering Chicago Black Hawks traded brilliant Max Bentley, league leading scorer for the past two season end another player for five Toronto Maple Leaf stars.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 3 -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg raised his voice today in "the fervent prayer that we may ever strive for an unpartisan American foreign policy."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Details of Ambassador Cannon's request of the Yugoslav Government to reconsider its expulsion of Mr. Brandel and his wife were made public by the State Department today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- America must be more realistic about international financial arrangements and stop one-sided deals that result in exchanging dollars for good will, Marshall M. Smith, president of the E.W. Bliss Company, Detroit, said today.

The National Beer Wholesalers Association of America is prepared to offer its fullest cooperation in President Truman's program for feeding Europe, speakers declared yesterday at the opening session of a three-day convention at the Hotel Commodore.

With what blithe optimism some producers enter the Broadway arena! Or is it contempt? Certainly last September when "The Magic Touch" ventured to open the local season there were those who thought it was all for the best -- nothing could be as bad after that.

World Heavyweight Champion Joe Louis sporting a mustache and about 216 pounds, and Jersey Joe Walcott yesterday affixed signatures to formal contracts for their fifteen-round clash at Madison Square Garden on Dec. 5.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Nov. 3 -- The first payment of the equivaent of $367,000 to voluntary relief organizations under Allied reparations agreements was announced by the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The national and state governments have a responsibility to provide free education for children homebound by handicaps just as tor children able to go to public schools, Lawrence J. Linck, executive secretary of the National Society for Crippled Children and Adults, declared today.

The decision of the American Communist party not to join the Cominform, as Russia's revival of the Comintern is called, was certainly not made against the will of Moscow. But it is transmitted to the American public here in a curious statement by William Z. Foster and Eugene Dennis, top party officials, which is a revelation of the Communist dialectics wherein the end always justifies the means.
Criticism, of the State Board of Social Welfare's inquiry into the administration of the city's relief program was voiced yesterday by executives of the State Charities Aid Association.
For a meatless dinner tonight, in keeping with the national food pledge for aid to Europe, the Department of Markets suggests a vegetable plate on a menu that would cost $2.34 for five.

The Coca-Cola Company reported yesterday in a statement for the first nine months of this year that it had a surplus for the common stock of $23,810,416, equal to $5.79 a share on the common stock after all charges, taxes and dividends on the Class A stock.

Internal warfare in the Hotel and Restaurant Employes International Union, AFL, was highlighted with an announcement yesterday that the executive board of the Hotel and Club Employes Union, Local 6, had voted to ask the parent organization to remove Miguel Garriga as international vice president.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 3 (AP) -- The California, legislative committee investigating un-Americanism heard allegations today that ghost writers with strong leftist leanings were assigned to do speeches to be delivered by Gov. Earl Warren and others at a 1945 Hollywood Bowl memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt.

One Garden After Another Annual arrival today of the Horse Show at the Garden -- there have been only a few years, mostly war years, in the stretch of sixty-four, in which the procession has been interrupted -- brings back to old New Yorkers a flood of memories.

GENEVA, Nov. 3 -- The simultaneous realization of existing national recovery plans would end the acute shortages of basic foods and materials in Europe by 1950 or 1951, according to the Secretariat of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

Fred Allen, now enjoying one of his most successful seasons on the air, will be heard under different sponsorship after the first of the year, it was announced yesterday. His present employer, Standard Brands, Inc., will relinquish the program after the broadcast of Dec. 28.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- This country can show the world what the individual man can achieve without "surrendering his soul to the state," James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, told delegates to the annual meeting of the American Automobile Association here today.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 3 -- The Government radio tonight broadcast an official defense of President Juan Peron's newsprint policy. The commentary took the form of a reply to the news story of THE NEW YORK TIMES last Thursday and the editorial on last Saturday, of which excerpts appeared in Prensa yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Cardinal Dougherty today threatened with a year's boycott two Philadelphia theatres exhibiting pictures classified by the National Catholic Legion of Decency as "wholly objectionable."

Assurance that there would be no interruption of electric or gas service because of labor trouble next year was given last night by the Consolidated Edison System and the Brotherhood of Consolidated Edison Employes, CIO.

Dr. Israel Weinstein resigned yesterday as Commissioner of Health and Mayor O'Dwyer swore in Dr. Harry S. Mustard, director of the School of Public Health, Columbia University, as head of the Health Department.

Study of the emotional troubles of patients would avoid many extractions of teeth and tonsils, Dr. Edward Weiss, Professor of Clinical Medicine at Temple University, told the First District Dental Society last night in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Evidences of the recent high operating rate of the nation's steel industry are contained in reports, issued yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute, showing that shipments of ten principal steel products in the first nine months of 1947 topped the total output for the full year of 1946.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 3 -- The possibility of averting another war depends in "overwhelming measure" on Western Europe's, success in repelling "encroachments of the police state," Norman Armour, Assistant Secretary of State, told the Economic Club of Detroit today.

Commercial banks which recently increased their service charges on special and regular checking accounts, are dissatisfied with the policy and are considering adjustments, it was learned yesterday. The banks, acting to meet increased costs, had raised minimum balance requirements and added a "maintenance" charge of 25 cents a month to the special, "ten-cents a check" accounts.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The return of competitive conditions in the plumbing and heating industry was foreshadowed today as the "Central Supply Association devoted the opening session of its annual convention to discussion of salesmanship and fundamental economics.

First details of greatly expanded steel pipe manufacturing in Italy, to meet large scale international needs, were disclosed yesterday when one of the principals described contracts recently signed between American and Italian business organizations in engineering and durable goods fields.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Stanislaw Mikolajczyk ended his journey from fear in a firelit room in a quiet London suburb tonight. Poland's last Opposition leader, who arrived in a Royal Air Force plane, fled Warsaw two weeks ago, he said, to escape, being "shot and killed like a sheep" by the Communist-dominated Polish Government.

The beams of the two-story frame dwelling at 292 Prospect Avenue, Brooklyn, may be warped, and the whole structure likely to topple over at any moment. But it has been home for a long time to Mr. and Mrs. Andrew McDonald and nine of their ten children.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 3 (AP) -- A gradual lifting of the swamp-fever quarantine that has been in force at the Rockingham Park race track since August was decided upon today by a three-man committee representing the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association.

Plans for alterations to St. Vincent's Hospital and its nurses' residence at a total cost of $153,750 were filed yesterday with the Department of Housing and Buildings by Eggers Higgins, architects, of 542 Fifth Avenue. Cost of alterations to the nurses' residence at 148-58 West Twelfth Street is listed at $106,500.

The stock market yesterday folowed a sluggish and irregularly lower course in a typical pre-holiday session. Strength in some of the industrials, notably the steels, inspired some scattered bidding but on balance the list leaned to the lower side despite an increase of 0.11 point in the combined averages.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The moral problem of many Frenchmen is how to remain satisfactorily "Left" enough in politics to suit the Gallic intellectual instinct and to accomplish this without being swept toward either the Soviet or American millstone -- or be ground between them.

No action can be taken to-rein-state Lou Gray, Queens appliance dealer recently dropped from the cooperating appliance dealer plan of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., since Mr. Gray has neither complained to the company about termination of his status nor applied for reinstatement, Brig. Gen. E. F. Jeffe, vice president in charge of sales, explained in an interview yesterday.

In less than twenty minutes, and without a dissenting vote, the United Nations General Assembly approved yesterday at Flushing Meadow a compromise resolution condemning all forms of propaganda likely to provoke a bread of the peace.

The season's first conflict between the Giants and the Yankees, one representing the National Football League and the other the All-America Conference, confronts local fans next Sunday. The Giants will be at the Polo Grounds, entertaining the Philadelphia Eagles, as the Yankees take on the San Francisco Forty-Niners.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Tribune said tonight the White Sox tomorrow will pay the $500 fine assessed against them in order to win reinstatement in the American League before the league draft meeting on Monday, Nov. 10.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 3 (AP) -- A five-birdie start gave 27-year-old Glenn Teal, unattached Jacksonville, Fla., professional, a four-under-par 68 and top honors in the North and South Open Golf Tournament's qualifying play today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- The meat packing industry and virtually all of its widely varying component companies are in what is probably their strongest peacetime economic and financial position, according to Business Conditions, publication of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.

Standard Oil of New Jerseey Directors of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) yesterday authorized the payment on Dec. 12 of a dividend of $2 a share, making disbursements this year $4, compared with $3 received by stockholders in 1946.

Governor Dewey last night praised women for their "keen and devoted service" in the state Government. Accepting a gold medallion of honor as the Governor who had done the most to further the interests of women in his state, Mr. Dewey said:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- The legality of "bootleg" union shop contracts has become a matter of controversy.

Purchase of 130 new gasoline - powered buses by the Board of Transportation without public bidding was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate in executive session. The board will act formally on the authorization on Nov. 13.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- To a tired and stooped Babe Ruth, greatest home-run hitter of all time, was given the first annual service award of the Boys Town-Greater Omaha Round Table Organization tonight for his contribution to the advancement of youth.
Increases In meat prices, at wholesale and retail, led a broad advance yesterday in living costs in New York.
Prices were firm to higher yesterday at the opening of spring lines for delivery through January by the Guild of Better Shoe Manufacturers at their showrooms here.

At dawn yesterday, a. plane, Romance of the Skies, landed at La Guardia Field from Hurn Airport, Bournemouth, England. Aboard were thirty-nine passengers from Bournemouth, leaving England to start life anew in the United States and the dominions of Canada, New Zealand and Australia.

Ground for Manhattan's first post-war public school was broken yesterday at 130th Street and Fifth Avenue where Public School 133 will be erected at a total cost of $2,500,000, including the site and equipment. The school is expected to be ready for occupancy in February, 1949.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- The American-trained New First Army, fanning out from Szepingkai, has captured Sian and Sifeng, in southern Manchuria, and is marching toward besieged Kirin, military officials said today.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Glenvil Hall, financial secretary to the Treasury, told Commons tonight, before the vote on film tax orders, that the Labor Government welcomed suggestions from the United States motion-picture industry for an alternative.
LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Cheerfulness in the stock markets here today was attributed to the result of the municipal elections. Although substantial rises were recorded, business was not on a large scale.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 3 -- This is the week they close the book on the rivalry that has furnished so much of the thrill and glamor of football and started the greatest stampede in the direction of the box office the sport has known.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The French Government today honored eighteen Americans for services rendered France and her people.

The former Bister property, fronting 812 feet on North Barry Avenue, in Mamaroneck, N.T., has been sold by F. Richard Dolan to the Kolk-Miller Construction Company. Peter C. Doern Jr., Inc., was the broker. The new owner plans to start work this week on the construction of five and sixroom dwellings on the property.
Twelve hundred sandhogs employed on construction of the $71,000,000 Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel quit work yesterday in a wage dispute with the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 -- A "historical calendar, 1938 to 1945," occupied more than one-fourth of today's issue of the Abend, United States-licensed Berlin newspaper. It purported to give the Germans for the first time the uncolored facts about Russo - German relations from the time of the Munich pact and appeared to be the first gun in the licensed German press in the announced propaganda campaign against the Soviet Union.
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Setting a blistering early pace which eliminated opposition. C. Lussky's Spirsilla won the $3,000 Endicott Allowance purse before 7,513 fans at Rockingham Park today.
NANKING, Nov. 3 -- The Communist party, which is seeking to win the impoverished peasantry, has ordered a tightening of army discipline.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- James F. Byrnes proposed to President Roosevelt in 1943 that the United States acquire a one-third interest in a British-owned oil field in Iran (Persia) to help offset United States lend-lease to Britain, the Senate War Investigating Committee said today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A railroad official said today that Florida railroads intended "to maintain such (freight) rates on citrus fruits as may prove necessary to meet truck-boat competition * * *."

MOSCOW, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Pravda published today a letter from four workers in a Moscow factory saying that "an unknown person in a torn sheepskin coat" had been discovered photographing the factory and turned out to be Maj. Gen. Robert Hilton, the British military attache in Moscow.

Planning for mental health on a world scale, with this country's major concern for children, was announced yesterday by Dr. Frank Fremont-Smith, vice persident of the International Committee for Mental Hygiene.

Getting off to what was thought to be a comparatively slow start, employes of the "New York City Housing Authority distributed yesterday more than 12,000 application blanks to families seeking admission to five low-rent housing projects that will open next month.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- Following is the text of the Soviet Union's statement on the Palestine question presented today by Semyon K. Tsarapkin before a United Nations subcommittee:

Financed by a $175,000 gift from the Merrill Foundation for Advancement of Financial Knowledge, the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration will study the effects of taxes on business, Winthrop H. Smith, managing partner of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Beane and president of the foundation, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- Fees to "redcaps" in the nation's railroad stations are due to go from 10 cents to 15 cents for each piece of hand "baggage if tariffs being filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission are granted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (UP) -- Three attorneys who once held high Government posts tonight accused the State Department of violating "the spirit of the Bill of Rights" and of making a play for public and Congressional favor in the dismissal of ten employes as bad security risks.

ATHENS, Nov. 3 -- The Conservative newspaper Estia charged today that the activities of certain services of the American aid to Greece mission "are diametrically opposed to the United States Government's policy and necessitate the presence here of two or three Federal Bureau of Investigation Coperatives.

A jury of scribes, listening to Lieut. John Green's report of Army's feelings about next Saturday's clash with Notre Dame, returned a quick verdict of "crocodile tears" against Coach Earl (Red) Blaik's spokesman yesterday at Toots Shor's.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 3 -- The Maniu treason trial moved into its final stage late today amid strong indications that the Communists' next target will be Georges Tatarescu, Independent Liberal party leader, who is currently Vice Premier and Foreign Minister.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 3 -- An alternate plan of reorganization, eliminating competitive bidding for new bonds and common stock, was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by the Interstate Power Company, a subsidiary of the Ogden Corporation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 (AP) -- The Big Nine will adhere to its plan of sending a different team to the Rose Bowl for three successive seasons, even if the 1949 representative is a third-place finisher in the Conference race.

The campaign to move next year's session of the United Nations General Assembly to Europe was formally placed before the fifty-seven member states yesterday with the support of the Soviet voting group and the steadfast opposition of the United Kingdom.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- A specialist in private research urged the electronics industry today to avoid waiting for Government guidance and control and to take the lead in pooling its scientific and industrial brain power under the incentive of our free economy to meet the challenge of the future.

The arrival in England of Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, the Polish peasant leader, ends the anxiety aroused by his sudden disappearance two weeks ago. The cheers with which the British House of Commons greeted this news will be echoed elsewhere throughout the free world.

FOOTBALL is a sacred and exclusive topic of conversation among the over-stuffed citizens who handle the destinies of the gridiron game, but occasionally a baseball man will muscle his way into the gathering and disrupt those brisk discussions of the block-and-tackle pastime. That's what happened yesterday when Max Carey, the old Pittsburgh outfield star and one-time Brooklyn Dodger manager, stolled into the middle of the football party.

On the scale of national politics, it seems to us that the Republican party could dispense quite easily, and to its profit, with a good many of the pronouncements of Mr. Carroll Reece, chairman of its National Committee. Mr. Reece succeeds too often in putting his party's worst face forward.

Bankers Trust Company has been named paying agent for principal and interest for gold debentures, 5 per cent series, due on April 1, 2030 of The West Penn Electric Company (Inc.). In addition, the bank has been appointed agent to accept subscriptions for common stock of Carolina Power Light Company, and is acting as agent for the stockholders in the purchase and sale of warrants.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- The United Nations "Little Assembly" plan, proposed by Secreary of State Marshall in his address at the opening of the General Assembly in September, was put in final form today for submission to the Political and Security Committee.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Scattered liquidation developed in the wheat market on the Board of Trade today as the result of a slow demand for the cash article and a forecast for light rain in the dry areas in the West and Southwest.
The city and state mobilized their law-enforcement forces yesterday to assure an election without fraud in New York today.

To the editor of the new york times : The tirades of Mr. Vishinsky against alleged American "warmongers" are still in the air.
