A Soviet resolution on Vishinsky's lines was recently rejected in the U.N. Assembly's Political Committee. But another one condemning "all propaganda likely to encourage threats to peace" received a unanimous vote, including that of U.S.S.R. and its satellites.

With prices on some types of cottons fpr near-by delivery at their highest in twenty-years, textile manufacturers indicated yesterday that there was little they could do to effect reductions. They were emphatic in their condemnation of a revival of price control at the manufacturing level and equally outspoken against any move for voluntary price action.

Campaign for British Razor, A national campaign, using magazines and newspapers with dealer tie-ins, will be started Nov. 9 to introduce the British-made Wilkinson non-electric dry shaver, the Reiss Advertising Agency disclosed yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 3 -- Congress will be asked to take action to prevent James Caesar Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, AFL, from halting production of phonograph records, Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr., Republican, of New Jerseys said today.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 3 (U.P.) -- The Indian Government announced today that Hindu troops, flown to Kashmir to repel a Moslem invasion, had recaptured Pattan, seventeen miles from Kashmir's capital, Srinagar.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- An analysis today by the newspaper Figaro of the popular vote in towns of more than 9,000 persons in the Oct. 19 municipal elections showed a greater setback for the Communists than was at first apparent. The first figures had indicated that the Communists had held their own in the popular vote.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Nov 3 -- Death sentences were meted out to four former German Elite Guard officers by a United States war crimes court today. Prison sentences up to twenty-five years were ordered for nine other defendants. [Press services reported that a total of eleven defendants received prison sentences.]

LONDON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Britain took the defeat of its Ryder Cup golf team, at Portland, Ore., as it has received a succession of golf setbacks since the war ended -- embarrassed, but keen to try again.
The index is Based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials.

LONDON, Nov. 3 -- Now that the dust of the municipal election with its Conservative victory has settled down, it became clear today that the Labor party had not accepted the verdict as a national defeat. There will be no general elections before 1950, according to present intentions, and this can be affirmed on the highest authority.

Paul E. Fitzpatrick, Democratic State Chairman, predicted yesterday that the Democrats would be successful in 70 per cent of the forty-eight Mayoralty elections in the state today. He declared that the "Democratic trend is a result of the general dissatisfaction by the voters with the Republican high prices and the local sales taxes."

Barnard Straus, co-producer of last season's "Temper the Wind," which scored a succes d'estime despite an abbreviated career, will put on this evening a comedy called "For Love or Money" at Henry Miller's Theatre. F. Hugh Herbert, who wrote the hit "Kiss and Tell," is the author of the work, dealing with the love of a middle-aged actor, recently widowed, for a young girl.

Bidding Cover and Spreads Although bidding for public utility bonds yesterday was marked by wide variation, it was said that the "cover" between the winning and next-high bids, and the compensation spreads charged in setting the offering price, are not likely to affect distribution adversely.

Alexander A. Nelidow, member of an ancient patrician family of Russia and a partner in Belgrave, Ltd., 122 Bast Forty-second Street, wine importers and merchandising counsel, died on Sunday in Le Roy Sanitarium after a brief illness. Mr. Nelidow, who lived at 1165 Fifth Avenue, was 62 years old.

Seven hundred delegates to the monthly delegate-assembly of the United Parents Association voted down last night a proposal by school authorities to abolish the eighth-grade public school diploma. At the same time Mrs. Rose Shapiro, association president, read a letter from John J. Loftus, assistant superintendent, saying that in view of parent opposition to the plan it had been shelved for the time being.

Natural rubber latex is now being produced in sufficient quantities from Malaya and Sumatra indicate that expanding deliveries will be maintained, Dr. W. E. Cake, assistant managing director, plantation division, United States Rubber Company, revealed yesterday.
New issues of public utility securities totaling more than $25,000,000 were awarded yesterday at competitive sale to underwriting managers as follows:
Both, on the ground and in the air the airlines here are making every effort to meet the problems of congestion and delay that annually afflict the air traveler as winter weather sets in.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 3 -- In a heavy turnout in today's special referendum, the voters of Stamford approved consolidation of the overlapping town and city governments. The vote was 10,101 for consolidation, with 7,455 opposed.

Reports that relief funds had been authorized in two cases to pay special union assessments to fight the Taft-Hartley law came under investigation yesterday as Welfare Commissioner Benjamin Fielding authorized a denial that any such funds had been paid.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 3 -- John G. Winant, wartime Ambassador of the United States to Great Britain and a former Governor of New Hampshire, shot and killed himself tonight in his home on Pleasant Street. He was 58 years old.

VIENNA, Nov. 3 -- The hope of the Austrian Communist party that it could make political capital out of the return of Austrian war prisoners from Russia -- since it was that party's intercession with Premier Stalin's rather than that of the Austrian Government, that obtained it -- seems to have been sadly disappointed.

Frederick R. Brown has retired after nineteen years as director of sales of Viscose process rayon, yarns and associated products for E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. of Wilmington, Del. He will be succeeded by Philip F. Brown, no relation, his assistant since 1935.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 -- As all cooks know, the order in which ingredients are added determines the savor of a stew and how well it will be digested by the consumer. This is just as true of a government program, particularly that for European recovery which has prematurely gone by the name of the Marshall plan.

BERLIN, Nov. 3 (AP) -- British and American Army intelligence sections cooperated to fly Stanislaw Mikolajczyk from Berlin to London after the Polish Peasant party leader arrived here in his escape from Poland, an American Military Government source said tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 (AP) -- A new official declaration of United States foreign policy heaped blame today on the Soviet Union for failure of the United Nations to "grasp the fruits of peace and victory."

Slowing of trade buying brought a reaction yesterday in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange, and final prices were 24 points lower to 3 points higher than Saturday's closing levels.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 3 -- The Westchester County Planning Commission filed with the Board of Supervisors here this afternoon a tabulation and analysis of sixty capital projects costing $2,118,700 that various c unty departments ask to have undertaken in 1948.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 3 -- The Soviet Union proposed today that Britain surrender the mandate in Palestine by Jan. 1 and withdraw all her troops by April 30, 1948. Under supervision of a commission named by the United Nations Security Council, the proposed Jewish and Arab states would use armed militia to keep order in their territories during the transition before independence, the Russians suggested.

In "This Time Tomorrow," Jan de Hartog is wrestling with something profound. Under the protection of the Theatre Guild, four very earnest actors gave it a thoughtful performance at the Ethel Barrymore last evening. But your inquiring reporter, aided by a, dynamic advisor in the adjoining seat, does not know exactly what Mr. de Hartog is driving at, unless he is assuring the Gotham theatre-goer that there is no death and that mankind is immortal.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 3 (AP) -- Stockholders at a special meeting today authorized changing the name of the Schiff Company to the Shoe Corporation of America and approved other important changes in the corporate structure of the big retail shoe chain.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 3 (AP) -- Throngs of hardboot admirers of Man o' War today viewed the neatly groomed 'Big Red' thoroughbred lying in state at Faraway Farm.

In the hope of learning more about the mysterious region of multi-colored lakes sighted from the air in Antarctica last year, the United States Navy is completing preparations for a special expedition to the area, it was learned yesterday.

The first deceftificatibn election held in the metropolitan area under the Taft-Hartley Law resulted yesterday in retention by a Congress of Industrial Organizations union of Its right to represent workers employed by a Brooklyn display company.

The prime purpose of the National Orchestral Association is to give orchestral training for young instrumentalists, but under its leader, Leon Barzin, it also manages to give adventurous and interesting concerts. The first of its eighteenth season last night at Carnegie Hall was no exception.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 3 -- The Garden City Antiques Show opened this afternoon at the Garden City Hotel with the largest number of displays in its history. A majority of the forty-five dealers come from Long Island towns, with more than a third of them newcomers to the show. Flora Campbell Koones, the director, said.

As a venture in providing a subtle yet distinctive seasoning that is easy to use, Cheney's Choice, an unusual salad mix that we have mentioned before, proved popular enough to encourage the Howard W. Cheneys of Los Angeles to experiment with methods for simplifying the use of other flavorings.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 3 -- "Woman Hunt," a screen story by David Stephenson, Eagle-Lion story department chief, which Fred Niblo expanded into a photoplay for the studio, is being revised by Robert Kent to make the film a vehicle for Richard Basehart, E-L disclosed today.

Conceding the necessity of this country's assistance in feeding Ejirope' s post-war hungry, Raymond Moley, associate editor of Newsweek, said yesterday that Congress at its forthcoming special session would have some pertinent figures to debate with Administration spokesmen on their foreign relief estimates.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 (AP) -- The feud that raged for seven days between Leslie M. O'Connor, general manager of the Chicago White Sox, and A.B. Chandler, Commissioner of Baseball, over the signing of a 17-year-old Chicago high school pitcher ended today with O'Connor's "surrender."

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The death of Mr. Winant, the shy, awkward and compassionate former Ambassador who came to Great Britain as a friend in her hour of need, has affected the people of this land to an extent that few of his countrymen will understand.
Tests that promise to improve harbor safety and increase traffic in bad weather will be conducted tomorrow nigth on a "blindfolded" tug operating across channel traffic by radar.

In signalizing the formal inception of New York's new winter social season, the National Horse Show drew to Madison Square Garden for its opening performance last night a distinguished assemblage of horse lovers from all over the country and foreign nations as well.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Suits to block final approval of the recent merger of the Mission Corporation into the Sunray Oil Corporation were filed in the United States district courts in Los Angeles and Reno, Nev., today by W.G. Skelly, former president of Mission and of the Pacific Western Oil Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Reduction, of all personal income taxes and more than forty other changes in the Federal revenue code, including one to permit husbands and wives to halve their combined income in filing returns, were recommended to the House Ways and Means Committee today by a citizens advisory group.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 4 (AP) -- The American fanner is becoming "self-centered and self-satisfied" and has "amazingly little concern for people beyond his local parish," William G. Mather, Professor of Rural Sociology at Pennsylvania State College, declared today Addressing the fourth annual National Convocation on the Church in Town and Country, Professor Mather declared:
LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The abolition of flogging sentences and of hard labor are among the extensive reforms set out in the Government's Criminal Justice Bill, the text of which was published today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- The subcommittee set up by the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Commitee to redraft the United States plan for a "Little Assembly" completed its final report today with a fourpower appeal to the Soviet Union and its satellites to abandon their boycott of the project.

Lawrence A. Baker of Washington, D.C., closely associated with tennis for more than twenty years, has been nominated to succeed Holcombe Ward as president of the United States Lawn Tennis Association for 1948, it was announced yesterday by the amateur tennis governing body.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 4 -- Complete withdrawal of Soviet forces from North Korea within three months was predicted here by authoritative sources. [Private advices to THE NEW YORK TIMES suggested the withdrawal might come in the immediate future.]

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Harry I. Maxson of Dallas, Tex., presented to Trinity College today the football with which his alma, mater defeated the College of the City of New York in 1907 by a score of 94 -- 0, the highest ever made by a Trinity team.

LONDON, Wednesday, Nov. 5 (U.P.) -- The chief victory for the "Progressives," candidates supported by Scotland's Unionist party which is the North British branch of the Conservatives, was in the industrial port of Dundee -- the constituency of Laborite Food Minister John Strachey -- where six Labor councilmen were defeated and control passed to the Progressives.

MARSEILLE, France, Nov. 3 (Delayed) -- The end of Marseille's first week since the liberation without a Communist controlled Government found the city's No. 1 Communist still doing business at his old City Hall office in spite of the efforts of de Gaullists to get rid of him.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 4 -- A plea for state leaders to show increased courage in effecting improvements in rural education was sounded here today by Herold C. Hunt, Chicago Superintendent of Schools.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- A committee of about 100 representative citizens, after an encouraging sendoff from President Truman began work today on a continuing program to find employment for the physically handicapped.
ROME, Nov. 4 -- The Government announced today its intention to hold a general election March 7.
New Jersey voters ratified the new state Constitution by an overwhelming majority at yesterday's election.

Newspaper Ads Up 9.64% Advertising in all New York City newspapers during October aggregated 13,711,711 lines, compared with 12,506,235 in the corresponding month of last year, or a gain of 9.64 per cent, according to a compilation of Media Record figures.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- The death of John G. Winant was announced to the Economic Committee of the United Nations General Assembly today by Dr. Hernan Santa Cruz, its chairman, who paid tribute to Mr. Winant's work on the Economic and Social Council.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Last tributes befitting "de mostest hoss" were paid to Man o' War today at a burial ceremony attended by an estimated 2,000 persons at Faraway Farm.

Despite optimistic reports to the contrary, the mystifying case of Leo Durocher and the Dodgers still seems to be exactly where it was the day Leo the Lip, his season's suspension served, was declared to be back in baseball's good standing and then left standing on Branch Rickey's doorstep.

PRAGUE, Nov. 4 -- Czechoslovakia's republican regime entered a crisis tonight. The National Front coalition system of government, which has prevailed since liberation, appeared in greater danger of collapse than at any time since 1945.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 4 -- This city chose today as its new Mayor Elmer E. Robinson, 52-year-old judge of the State Superior Court, voted $75,000,000 in bonds for civic improvements and ordered the retention of its historic cable-car system.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Nov. 4 -- After an experience of two years with proportional representation, Long Beach voted 2,884 to 1,783 by unofficial tally today to return to the former system of choosing city councilmen under party designations.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- The complete domination of Poland by Communist dogma and totalitarian terror was predicted today by Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, leader of the Opposition, who arrived here yesterday after escaping from his native country.

BRUNSWICK, Ga., Nov. 4 (AP) -- A Federal Court jury deliberated for eight minutes today and then freed a former Georgia prison camp warden and four of his guards of charges that they killed eight Negro convicts last July without cause.

Arthur Osman, president of Local 65, Wholesale and Ware-house Workers Union, CIO, denied yesterday that any of his 14,000 members had received relief funds to pay union assessments to fight the Taft-Hartley law.

Prospects for an agreement to stabilize labor costs in the construction industry were dimmed yesterday, when it became known that American Federation of Labor building unions had decided to reject employer proposals for a two-and-one-half-year wage freeze.

Willie Beltram, 137, Bronx earned a close decision over Bobby Ruffin, 140 1/4, Astoria, in the feature bout or ten rounds at the Broadway Arena last night. It was a savagely fought bout with the winner gaining a. split verdict. Ruffin, surprised at his opponent's longrange tactics, was dropped for a no-count in the seventh.

The one-time kingpin bootlegger, Irving Wexler, alias Waxey Gordon, was characterized yesterday in Felony Court as a "relic of a past and dim age" when he was arraigned with four other men on charges of dealing in stolen property.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Denny Shute of Akron, Ohio, and Ed Furgol of Detroit posted twounder par 70's today to share the first-round lead in the forty-fifth North and South open golf tournament. They held a stroke lead over six rivals as the formidable, 6,879-yard No. 2 course, with its par 72, resisted the efforts of ninety-two performers.

Buyers' Monthly Total Lower Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,648, against 1,311 last week and 1,388 in the corresponding week a year ago, according to lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Pleas for uniform divorce laws to curb the rising divorce rate in this country were voiced yesterday on the "What's on Your Mind?" radio forum over Station WQXR sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES. Charging that the "Reno circus," Florida and Mexico divorce laws exerted a bad influence on the couples involved and on the children of broken marriages, the speakers advocated legislation designed to prevent marriages "from going on the rocks."

SOUTH BEND., Ind., Nov. 4 -- Along toward half past four, Central Standard Time, on Saturday, Johnny Lujack should be a thoroughly weary young man. The way chores keep piling up on him it appears that the most famous quarterback in football will do everything but carry the waterbucket and smelling salts for his coach when Notre Dame plays Army here before 56,000 fans.

Supporters of the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council, repealed in yesterday's election, refused last night to take the decision of the voters as final and announced their intention to try to reinstate it before the election of the next Council in 1949.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security -- Resuming debate of Korean independence question, received revised United States proposal suggesting troop withdrawal with in ninety days of Korean independence and recommending that United Nations commission report to "Little Assembly."

Beginning with funeral, F. Hugh Herbert makes his way one step at a time through quite an assembly of stock situations in "For Love or Money," which was acted at Henry Miller's last evening. Possibly he has been studying too many bad movies.

Domestic steel companies, announcing higher dividends and substantial additions to the industry's previously reported billion-dollar expansion program, last week felt real optimism for the first time since the end of the war.

Times Square was just a crossroad for the weary and the rainsoaked last night -- the slowest and dullest election night in the Rialto' s long history. Throngs stayed away In impressive numbers. With no personalities to cheer, with no special screen bulletin board for election returns, the crowd thinned to a point far below that seen in the Square on most Tuesday nights.

A 42-year-old woman and two of her nine children were holding out yesterday for the second day in their Brooklyn home from which the1 city is trying to evict them because the building has been condemned as dangerous.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Nov. 4 -- Democratic candidates for Governor and other state offices piled up increasing leads tonight as returns from today's Kentucky election poured in here.

VIENNA, Nov. 4 -- A special meeting of the Austrian Cabinet has been called for Thursday to discuss a new Communist party tactic in Lower Austria that has taken the form of summarily initiating land reform without the consent of either the Provincial Government or the owners of the farmland involved.

Stanislaw Mikolajczyk needed no disguise but a pair of dark glasses in his flight from Warsaw to Berlin because he looks like any farmer you would meet on the roads of Poland or in the eastern part of Germany that is now settled by Poles. Nor were the glasses needed except for the government police, for wherever he went he was among friends.

F. van Wyck Mason has delivered to Lippincott the manuscript of his new historical novel, "Eagle in the Sky," which will complete Ms tetralogy on the American Revolutionary War. The Literary Guild's February choice, it is tentatively set for Feb. 4 publication.

There Were Three Carusos Many New York residents of long standing, when they read a few days ago that a silver bust of Enrico Caruso had been presented by his widow to the Metropolitan Opera House, surely put aside temporarily the perusal of their morning papers in order to pay, during a few moments of retrospective day-dreaming, a silent tribute to that most renowned and glorious and spectacular of all grand opera singers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- For four hours, the Soviet Union and its supporters hammered away today at United States administration in Southern Korea, accusing this country of ruling by terror, setting up a police state and pushing its own "expansion" policies.

New York University's Armand Osterberg captured individual honors yesterday in the sixteenth annual metropolitan intercollegiate cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park but Manhattan College ended the Violet reign of seven consecutive years as team titleholders.

Yesterday's rain failed to keep applicants for apartments in five low-rent housing projects from besieging offices of the New York City Housing Authority. Approximately 18,000 persons have taken applications for the 7,165 apartments in the projects scheduled to open next month.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- The Taft-Hartley Act is hurting the building trades now, declared Daniel D. Carmell, general counsel of the Illinois State Federation of Labor, in an address before the annual convention of the Central Supply Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The National Labor Relations Board dismissed three union petitions today, opening the way for constitutional tests of the Taft-Hartley law's requirements of non-Communist affidavits and financial reports.

TEN years after its first publication in Poland, where it won a coveted prize as the most distinguished book of the year by a Polish writer, Zofia Kossak's "Angels in the Dust"* is now available in this country in an excellent translation. Mme. Kossak, who was condemned to death in the infamous concentration camp of Oswiecim and rescued by the Polish underground, has written many historical novels.
Turkey in steak form, an innovation that we mentioned earlier this fall when it was introduced successfully in the West, is now available here for the first time.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- In the last six contests for Governor of Kentucky the Democrats have won four times and the Republicans twice, the state being normally Democratic. This normality is revealed in national as well as in local elections, only two Republican candidates for President -- Coolidge in 1924 and Hoover in 1928 -- having carried Kentucky since 1896.

Random notes. Grouse hunters, who had planned a trip to New Brunswick but were forced to abandon the project due to the closing of the woods, will have a chance for a full week of shooting after the forests are reopened.
MONTREAL, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Maurice Richard and his veteran Montreal linemate, Toe Blake, are tied for the lead in the National Hockey League's individual scoring race today at nine points apiece.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Britain's business men can save the nation economically if the Labor Government gives them the freedom and scope to do so, Lord Woolton, chairman of the Conservative party, said tonight.

TOKYO, Nov. 4 -- Allied spokesmen are increasing their warnings to Japanese to purge coal mines of "labor agitators, subversive elements and parasites." These are held responsible for the failure to produce fuel on which the whole reconstruction program, rests.

Wholesale price increases averaging between 5 and 8 per cent will be announced by many bedroom and dining room furniture factories between now and the January furniture markets, an executive of a leading buying office predicted yesterday. Manufacturers' representatives and other retailers agreed that price increases from now on are inevitable but declined to estimate percentages in most cases.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 4 -- For slapping a battle-shocked soldier in Sicily General George S. Patton Jr. apologized, under orders, to a whole army, but in his own mind there never was any doubt about the justification of this act which kicked up a storm back home.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- New York has the most acute parking and garage problems of the nation's cities and has done the least toward solving them, William J. Gottlieb, president of the Automabile Club of New York said today at the annual meeting of the American Automobile Association here.
Plans for the sale of /property now occupied by two subsidiaries which would be leased back to them on long-term contracts, were announced yesterday by Federated Department Stores, Inc.

Despite the sad fact that his Giants have not won a game this season Stout Steve Owen was trying to point out some bright spots during last Sunday's shellacking by the Lions in Detroit when he talked to the scribes at yesterday's luncheon in the Polo Grounds press room.

The voters of New York City, in the third attempt, repealed the proportional representation method of electing members of the City Council by a majority of 349,721 and substituted election by State Senate districts.
The constitutional amendment providing for a state bonus to veterans of World War II received overwhelming approval at yesterday's election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Estelle Warner of the United States Public Health Service said today that Iowa had failed for ten years to follow regulations of a grants-in-aid merit system and would lose Federal funds at the rate of about $2,000,000 annually unless it complied.
Supplies of milk for the metro-politan area may drop critically low in the next three weeks unless special steps are taken, it was reported yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- The United States expressed its opposition today to a Soviet proposal to condemn the Western Allied occupation authorities in Europe for allegedly obstructing the return of displaced persons to their countries of origin and recruiting refugees for foreign labor.

Greater love hath, no spurned woman than to give up an erring husband to a harpy and then to welcome back the wretch on the rebound with the compassion and forebearance of a saint. That sums up St. John Ervine's comedy, "The First Mrs. Fraser," which receives its first Broadway revival -- after a lapse of eighteen years -- at the Shubert this evening.
Yesterday was the wettest Election Day here since 1911, Weather Bureau records showed. From midnight until the polls closed at 7 P. M. the precipitation totaled 1.97 inches.
Not even the rain dimmed the elegance of the crowd at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden last night as luxurious furs and gowns lent brilliance to the throng entering the arena.

TO THE EDITOR OP THE NEW YORK TIMES Your Nov. 2 editorial on "How to Fight Communism" charges the Congressional Committee on Un-American Activities with Violating "respect for individual rights and constitutional processes." The implicatibn is that this committee, in its hearings on Communist infiltration of the motion-picture capital, has somehow departed from the normal, court-tested procedures followed by other legislative committees.

The National Horse Show, white tie and tails event of sports, had its formal opening in Madison Square Garden last night. The blending of sport and social graces occurred before a crowd of 10,000, many of them members of society in the restricted sense, many more plain citizens there to watch the fancy doings inside the ring and to get a close-up of fashion on parade.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Grain markets turned upward after an early dip on the Board of Trade today and showed a strong undertone in the late trading. Wheat rose 1 1/4 to 3 1/4 cents, with old crop months leading despite a lack of moisture in the Southwest. Corn gained 1 1/4 to 3 cents higher, oats 1 1/2 to 1 7/8 cents, and soy beans 1 to 2 cents.

Late plans at CBS call for the "Adventures of Ozzie and Harriet" to switch from 6 P. M. Sundays to 9.30 P. M. Fridays, probably the latter part of this month. The Friday night time is being vacated by "The FBI in Peace and War" after the broadcast of Nov. 21, following which the program will be heard Thursday at 8 P. M.

LONDON, Nov. 4 (Reuters) -- British, newspapers and periodicals, answering a questionnaire by the Royal Commission on the Press, have agreed that public taste is slowly rising. It is getting more interested in serious public affairs.

Initial orders for spring, 1948, on top grades of women's and misses' apparel are substantially larger than those placed last season, according to leaders in that field yesterday. However, what is more significant, they said, is the fact that orders are being placed in a spirit of confidence as contrasted with the overly cautious attitude shown heretofore.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 - A Census Bureau study issued today said'that few of the country's 140 metropolitan areas had reproduction rates sufficient to maintain their white populations at present numbers. The study asserted also that the structure of large cities, with few exceptions, made them "ideal" for destruction by atomic bombs, and the tendency of people to congregate in large urban areas had not changed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Government contended in the Supreme Court today that an order of the National Labor Relations Board to reinstate two foremen, with back pay was still valid, despite the Taft-Hartley Law.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 4 -- The Citizens Charter Committee, a reform group which sponsored Hartford's new city manager charter, swept into office today all six of the candidates it endorsed for the powerful new city council.
The two-day-old strike of sandhogs on the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel was denounced as a breach of contract yesterday by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority.

WATERBURY, Conn., Nov. 4 -- Raymond E. Snyder, 41-year-old undertaker, scored a major upset in Connecticut municipal politics today when as a candidate for Mayor he led the Republicans to their first victory since 1921 in this traditional Democratic strong-hold.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 4 -- A 10 per cent salary increase for employes affected by its earlier refusal to bargain with the New York local of the American Newspaper Guild, CIO, was announced today by Newsday, Nassau County's largest newspaper.

Dr. Harry Stoll Mustard, the city's new Health Commissioner, spent a full day yesterday in his office at 125 Worth Street. He conferred with former Commissioner Israel Weinstein, who resigned on Monday, and with, several other officials of the department.

The statement that "the Argentine Government is exercising an iron grip on the freedom of the Argentine press" was characterized as "widely exaggerated" by Dr. Erwin J. Wassermann of Buenos Aires, in commenting yesterday on the recent action of the Argentine Institute for the Promotion of Commerce to control newsprint, which was announced in newspapers here last Thursday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N. Y., Nov. 4 -- Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Under-Secretary for External Affairs, today criticized the United States plan for carrying out the partition of Palestine solely through action by the United Nations General Assembly.

Benjamin J. Rabin, elected yesterday to the Supreme Court in the First Judicial District for a full fourteen-year term, is a Democratic Representative in Congress from the Bronx who ran with the nomination of his own party and also that of the Liberal party.

LONDON, Nov. 4 -- Orange Free State gold shares were in good demand at the opening of the stock markets here today following the overnight publication of high as say values of the Middle Wit-watersrand samples.

In the balloting at the mutuel windows William L. Brann's Escadru was voted the one most likely to succeed in the $20,000 added Ardsley Handicap at rain-soaked Jamaica yesterday. He made good with ease, to the complete satisfaction of a plurality of the Election Day gathering of 28,534.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 4 -- The Rumanian Government today demanded the maximum sentence of life imprisonment for Dr. Juliu Maniu, aged Peasant party leader, and his co-defendants who face treason charges, but it requested lesser penalties for ten other men in the current trial before the Bucharest Military Tribunal.
Notre Dame was rated as the No. 1 college football team in the country for the second consecutive week on the basis of returns from The Associated Press "poll yesterday.
Henry A. Wallace, editor of The New Republic, returned to New York yesterday after a visit to Palestine and Europe. Mr. Wallace arrived at La Guardia Field aboard a TWA plane from Rome at 5:15 A.M.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 4 -- Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer has purchased an option on screen rights to "Alexandra," a novel by Gladys Schmitt, and has assigned George Haight to prepare a screen adaptation as probable vehicle for June Allyson, the studio announced today.
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 4 (AP) -- Leading all the way and drawing away at the finish to win by a length, Tommy Queen's Plucky Boy won the feature of an all-claiming card at Rockingham Park today.

Rain caused all schoolboy football games scheduled in the metropolitan area to be called off yesterday. The twin, bill at Ebbets Field, a highlight which was to have matched Erasmus Hall with Manual Training and Boys High with Brooklyn Tech. was set for Friday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- Uncertainty over the attitude of American investors has stymied a substantial loan from the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to Poland for increasing its coal production and providing Western Europe with greatly needed fuel supplies.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Nov. 4 -- Suffolk County voters, in a light turnout, maintained today the nine-to-one Republican majority among the area's town supervisors, who constitute the County Board of Supc visors.

We believe the cause of sound government has been served in the passage of Proposition IV, by which New York City voters yesterday rejected the Proportional Representation system of electing the City Council.

An innocent looking stapled series of mimeographed sheets, on which are listed thousands of names of American securities and other identifying marks and carrying only the heading "Scheduled Securities," have become a part and parcel of every brokerage house, bank and surety bonding company in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The Maritime Commission's sale of surplus tankers to foreign buyers assumed the proportions of a major political issue today as Senator Robert A. Taft telegraphed to the commission a request that contracts be held in abeyance until Congress reconvened Nov. 17.

Adoption by the New Jersey electorate yesterday of the state's new Constitution, drafted last summer at New Brunswick, was clearly foreshadowed by the fact that both Republican and Democratic state organizations were for it. Governor Driscoll and the Republicans will welcome especially, the forthcoming court reform.

THE King is dead and he leaves no successor. Man o' War, the mightiest thoroughbred the turf has known, was affectionately laid to rest yesterday beneath the blue grass pastureland where he romped so majestically during his declining years. It was a heart attack which caused the death of Big Red. At least that's what the veterinarians said.

The report of Hearn Department Stores, Inc., and its subsidiaries issued to stockholders yesterday by Leonard Ginsberg, president, disclosed a net profit of $520,759 for the year ended on July 26, last, after all deductions including $235,000 provision for Federal taxes on income.

Consignees of freight coming into railway receiving points in the New York area have contributed to the delay in delivering goods, according to a report of the traffic group of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants, released yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Charles Luckman, head of the Citizens Food Committee, told a press conference today that meatless Tuesdays and poultryless Thursdays alone would achieve the committee's goal of saving 100,000,000 bushels of American grain for winter relief overseas.
Thirty-one Portuguese fishermen were rescued dramatically yesterday morning from the gale-swept North Atlantic by crew members of the New York-bound Army transport Charles A. Stafford.

It is good news that the voters of New York State have again supported the principle of subsidized low-rent housing. The additional debt involved in the propositions yesterday was only $135,000,000, but rejection of the program now, when new housing of all kinds is more urgently needed than ever before, would have been a sickening disappointment.

During 1947 and 1948 net profits of New York City banks are likely to be almost 20 per cent below the levels of 1946 and 40 per cent lower than the 1945 peak, according to a study issued yesterday by the economics department of the Bankers Trust Company.
CHICAGO. Nov. 4 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- At the suggestion of the Secretaries of State, War and Navy, I recently visited Western Europe, to make a study of the conditions prevailing there. To conserve travel time, the Army provided me with a plane.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 4 (U.P.) -- Funeral service will tie held here tomorrow for John G. Winant, 58 years old, former Ambassador to Great Britain, who committed suicide in his home last night. A nervous breakdown resulting from overwork and "the growing disillusionment of today" were believed by friends to have contributed to his death.

A reduction in costs of all imported beverages will result, if recently approved Geneva tariff negotiations involving future trade agreements are ratified during coming months, Gerald F. Dunne, executive director of the Metropolitan Package Store Association, Inc., told more than 1,000 members at their annual meeting at the Park Central Hotel yesterday.

Boys and girls 2 to 6 years old presented yesterday afternoon an international fashion show at the twenty-fourth annual Women's International Exposition in the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

Bartenders took advantage of the Election Day closing of the bars yesterday to participate in a union election of their own. More than 3,000 bartenders defied the rain to cast ballots for or against a proposal to establish a single union local to represent New York bartenders.

Dr. Stephen Duggan, president of City College's Associate Alumni, announced yesterday the names of four alumni who will receive 1947 Townsend Harris Medals for "outstanding attainment in significant fields of human endeavor."

Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens, Netherlands Ambassador to the United States, and city and Federal officials will go down the bay in a tug early tomorrow to welcome the Holland-America Line's rebuilt liner Nieuw Amsterdam.

Heavy rain, which made a quagmire of the practice gridiron at Baker Field yesterday, limited Columbia's football squad to light preparations for the Dartmouth game in a drill devoted to running through offensive and defensive formations.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 4 -- Maj. Gen. Philip B. Fleming, administrator of the Federal Works Agency, told 450 delegates to the American Municipal Association convention today that the indicated cost of needed new state and local public construction, including highways and buildings, was about $75,000,000,000.

PARIS, Nov. 3 -- Full-fledged or virtual Communist regimes for Czechoslovakia and Rumania in the near future are foreshadowed in reports reaching high quarters here from trustworthy sources in Prague and Bucharest.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 4 -- The need for Christian unity has never been more pressing, the Rev. Dr. Samuel McCrea Cavert, general secretary of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, declared today at the opening of a four-day special meeting of the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 4 -- In the event of an Arab attack on the Jewish community of Palestine Irgun Zvai Leumi would start an offensive against the Arabs and would be prepared, under certain conditions, to fight alongside Haganah with which it is now feuding.

Several policemen chased an armed, fleet-footed 19-year-old youth over a half-mile of crowded Harlem streets and across empty lots yesterday, firing several shots before they captured him. During the chase a pedestrian suffered cuts of his left leg when he fell to the sidewalk.

BELLPORT, L.I., Nov. 4 -- The former Methodist Church of Bellport, which served the community here for seventy-five years until it was vacated about a year ago, will be moved, probably tomorrow, thirty miles west by scow, to Massapequa, where it will serve another Methodist parish.

Men's spring clothing orders are being rapidly placed by retailers, with estimates in well-informed quarters here yesterday indicating that 75 per cent or more of volume for the new season has already been booked. It is expected that the remainder will be cleaned up rapidly, both in orders booked by men on the road and by retailers operating in the market here.
NEW CITY, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- In one of the closest contests in years, the Republican parly retained control of the Rockland County Board of Supervisors today, winning three of the five townships.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Republicans again won a majority of public offices in Westchester today when voters elected 211 county, district, city and town officials. Chill air and intermittent rain cut sharply into the pluralities, however.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 4 (AP) -- Herold (Muddy) Ruel was dismissed today as manager of the Browns and Zach Taylor, former coach of the club, was signed to a one - year contract as manager, William O. Dewitt, general manager, said.

STUTTGART, Germany, Nov. 4 -- By completing both, denazification and the dismantling of war plants during the winter, the Germans in the United States zone will be in a position by spring to effect a rapid economic recovery, Gen. Lucius D. Clay, United States Military Governor, told the Council of German Ministers today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- The dollar shortage as well as the cereals shortage must be dealt with to feed hungry nations, today's organization meeting of the new World Food Council of the Food and Agricultural Organization of the United Nations was told by its chairman, Viscount Bruce, and by the FAO Director General, Sir John Boyd Orr.

In previous recitals Leonard Shure, the pianist has followed the practice of playing only a limited number of major works. In his appearance last night at Carnegie Hall he carried it a step further than he has done in the past.
GENEVA, Nov. 4 -- The total manpower deficit of the European, countries is 1,130,000 workers, according to a special survey made by experts of the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

Three significant developments in production engineering here yesterday revealed that 1948 models of durable consumer goods will display major mechanical improvements, coupled in some cases with lower prices, and in many fields with larger supply.

Negotiations, between the Bethlehem Steel Company and the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, have progressed to a point where a, settlement of the nineteen-week-old strike may be expected within the next twenty-four hours, it was learned here yesterday.

Of the thirty judges and justices elected to office yesterday by the voters of this city a substantial majority are veterans with experience on the bench. The newcomers are men of ability and integrity. The city was fortunate in the choice of candidates presented to it by the political parties.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Continuing efforts to end the United Nations refund of income taxes paid by its American workers were defeated in the General Assembly's budget committee today after the United States delegation indicated it would again urge Congress to grant tax exemption to those workers.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Dr. Clarence O. Cheney of 11 Burling Avenue, former president of the American Psychiatric Association and former medical director of the New York Hospital Westchester Division, died tonight in the White Plains Hospital from the effects of a cerebral hemorrhage suffered two days ago. His age was 60.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 4 -- Nassau County voted in its traditional Republican fashion in today's rain-drenched election, but the Democratic party achieved one, important upset, electing Luke A. Mercandante as Mayor-Supervisor of Glen Cove.

WHITE PLAINS. N.Y., Nov. 4 -- Dr. Clarence O. Cheney of 11 Burling Avenue, former president of the American Psychiatric Association and former medical director of the New York Hospital Westchester Division, died tonight in the White Plains Hospital from the effects of a cerebral hemorrhage suffered two days ago. His age was 60.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 4 -- Nassau County voted in its traditional Republican fashion in today's rain-drenched election, but the Democratic party achieved one, important upset, electing Luke A. Mercandante as Mayor-Supervisor of Glen Cove.

Efforts on the part of the Australian Government to increase the output of pearly shell by encouraging the modernization of the industry were described yesterday by Rupert R. Ellen, Australian Trade Commissioner, at his offices here.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- Tooling for new models of all products is now beginning to come out in full force and the tool and die industry will be "extremely busy for the next three to five years," according to a consensus, today of delegates to the three-day convention of the National Tool and Die Manufacturers Association.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 4 -- In a speech, in which he praised President Juan D. Peron as "a great leader of a great nation," United States Ambassador James Bruce last night revealed that at the Argentine President's invitation the American business community here was preparing a plan on the basis of which further United States capital might be encouraged to come to Argentina.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I cannot allow to go unchallenged the letter on the wartime meat black market written by Norman Draper of the American Meat Institute in your Oct. 27 issue.
BOSTON, Nov. 4 -- Massachusetts voters went to the polls today in Boston and twenty-seven other cities, in twenty-five of which Mayors were being selected.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- A plan of reorganization filed by the American and Foreign Power Comjany, Inc., was disapproved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission. Tne SEC did not kill all prospects of the plan being consummated, however.

The refusal of the crew of the Marine Shark to sign yesterday caused cancellation of the vessel's voyage to the Mediterranean, it was announced. The ship is a Government-owned C-4 "emergency class" passenger vessel operated by American Export Lines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 -- In a reversal of a position it took seven months ago, the Federal Communications Commission today denied the application of The New York Daily News for a frequency-modulation radio station and gave the license instead to the Radio Corporation of the Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 4 -- The smooth-running Republican machine, fulfilling advance predictions, scored an overwhelming victory in today's off-year municipal election to retain control of the nation's third largest city, which it has ruled for sixty-three consecutive years.

Although many must have voted yes with mixed feelings, and among these yes voters were veterans who shared the misgivings, a New York State bonus to veterans has been approved at the polls. The question whether we owe a debt of gratitude to the men and women who served in our armed forces in a time of peril to the nation was not at issue.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 4 -- Judge John Cornelius Stennis, 46 years old, clung to a small but continuing lead tonight in a tight race for the unexpired United States Senate term of the late Theodore Bilbo. With 1,047 of Mississippi's 1,716 voting precincts reporting, Judge Stennis had 35,847 votes. Waging a ding-dong battle just behind were Representative William Colmer of Pascagoula with 33,480 and Mr. Bilbo's one-time personal attorney, Forrest B. Jackson, with 29,513.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 4 -- India and Pakistan have exchanged testy telegraphic notes accusing each other of breaching "international conventions" by violations of neutrality in connection with the fighting in Kashmir, it was learned tonight.

Parents were urged yesterday by the Board of Education to visit New York's public schools next week as part of the observance of Open School Week, to get acquainted with teachers and to ask questions about their children's progress.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 4 -- In recognition of the international importance of food, the Girl Scout organization is instituting agriculture as a new field of scout activity, it was announced today as the Girl Scout National Council opened its twenty-ninth convention here.

FLUSHING, the Netherlands Nov. 4 -- Two trees were planted on Walcheren today. The soil of the bleak and war-battered old island was turned by Princess Regent Juliana and British Prime Minister Attlee in the presence of Prince Bernhard, Premier Louis J.M. Beel and a distinguished gathering of diplomats and military.

Public offering of $6,000,000 of Portland General Electric Company's first mortgage bonds, 3 1/2 per cent series due in 1977 will be made today by Salomon Bros. Hutzler and Stroud Co., Inc., at 103 per cent and accrued interest.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- Grocery store operators today were urged by Paul J. Cifrino, general manager of a Dorchester, Mass., supermarket to make an extensive survey of their operations with a view of readjusting prices, increasing volume and effecting savings for food consumers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 4 -- The nation's airline captains demanded today basic changes as safety measures in the fuel and electrical systems of new scheduled transport planes that travel 300 miles an hour. They asserted that recommendations for these changes had been ignored, although the dangers inherent in currently operated airplanes have been pointed out repeatedly before Congressional committees investigating air carrier safety.

The tragic close of John G. Winant's career stands in sharp contrast to his long and shining record in public affairs and private benevolence. Here was a man who truly loved mankind and tried all his life to make the lot of his fellow-men better and happier. His effort will inspire others who tread the same hard path.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 5 -- Relations between the United States and Argentina, more felicitous now than at any time since the strain of the war years and the critical period that followed, presently have one highly important point of difference to reconcile.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., estimated its net profit for the first nine months of this year at $66,000,000 after taxes and all charges, equal to $2.12 a share, according to the report issued to stockholders yesterday by B. Brewster Jennings, president.
Albany, Nov. 5 (AP) -- New York's veterans of World War II may apply for their state bonus Jan. 2 and thereafter.

Over a protest by Park Commissioner Robert Moses that they were opening the way to an extensive invasion of residential areas, the other members of the City Planning Commission adopted yesterday an amendment to the zoning regulation that would permit doctors, dentists and osteopaths to set up offices in residential areas, even though they do not live on the premises.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- The French Cabinet today adopted a new and far-reaching financial policy by deciding to balance the budget, even though this necessitated dropping the Government subsidy that hitherto had kept down the price of coal.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The current debate in Washington is not over whether there will be an American European aid program, but over how large that program will be and how it will be controlled.
ATHENS, Nov. 5 -- The Greek General Confederation of Labor last night called off the general strike that was scheduled to begin tomorrow. Agreement had been reached on general wage increases.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

A book about Dr. George Crile, one of America's great surgeons and medical researchers, has been scheduled for publication by Lippincott next Wednesday. Entitled "George Crile: An Autobiography," it has been edited with sidelights by Mrs. Grace Crile, who collected her husband's voluminous writings to form this two-volume work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Citizen's Food Committee announced today a new food conservation drive that one of its members said would soon take the place of meatless Tuesdays and poultryless Thursdays, probably by the end of this month.

BERLIN, Nov. 5 -- The partition of Germany and a separate peace for the western two-thirds is advocated by Dr. Kurt Schumacher, Social Democratic chairman and favorite politician of the United States and British Governments. He announced this startling reversal in a secret meeting of the Social Democratic leaders soon after his return from the United States.

Against the background of its pre-Civil War building at 211 East Seventy-ninth Street, the New York City High School of Industrial Arts put on view last night the modernistic work of its students and graduates as the school celebrated its eleventh anniversary.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 5 (AP) -- An uproarious hearing before a California legislative un-American committee was climaxed today by a contempt vote against an avowed pro-Communist witness, who refused to permit himself to be sworn.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 5 Army finished its heavy work for Notre Dame today with a brisk, sharp offensive scrimmage in which passing was emphasized. The cadet squad, thirty-nine strong, will depart for South Bend by special train at 10 P. M. tomorrow night after a final light drill on its home field.

Issues of public school and road bonds of Baltimore County, Md., aggregating $5,300,000 were awarded yesterday to a banking group headed by Drexel Co. at an interest cost of 1.919 per cent. Other bids ranged in interest cost from 1.946 per cent to 2.046 per cent.

There is nothing sensational about the violin playing of Joseph Fuchs. When you listen to him, you concentrate on the music he plays, and the music comes out clean and sane and imaginative. He builds a program of substance, as he did at Carnegie Hall last night, and proceeds to convey its musical essence.

Relaxation of consumer credit terms has resulted in some increase in sales volume of several home furnishings lines, a spokesman for a leading home furnishings retail organization reported yesterday. He emphasized that "it is still far too early to figure the long-range effect of easing credit terms on home furnishings sales.

One of our readers who is chairman of a refreshment committee that must plan the fare for a series of afternoon teas this winter writes that she is in a quandary. Customarily assorted sandwiches and tiny cakes are served on such occasions, out since the group wishes to comply in spirit and deed with the food conservation program, substitutes for these grain-consuming foods must be found.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson told the annual Agricultural Outlook Conference tonight that enactment of the Marshall plan for European rehabilitation would mean four more years of farmerresponsibility for much of the success of foreign policy.

Democratic party leaders in the state were buoyed up generally yesterday by the election results but their claims of a sweep were offset by the fact that in fifteen cities where upsets of the existing political regime occurred as the result of contests the Republicans gained eight Mayoralty seats while the Democrats gained seven.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Secretary of State Marshall refused today to view pessimistically the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers that will assemble in London Nov. 25 in an effort to draft peace treaties for Germany and Austria.

The announced boycott by the Soviet bloc of United Nations' action on Korea -- action voted yesterday by the Political Committee of the Assembly by the overwhelming poll of 46 to 0 -- presages a definite showdown between the U.S.S.R. and the rest of the world when the U.N. Commission moves to set up a unified government in Korea.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Cosmic ray research from a B-29 high above the California mountains has revealed new information about the structure of an atom that upsets previous theories, the Navy stated today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The ascendency of de Gaullism in France is a portent of the moment when only Britain and the United States, of all the great powers or former great, will possess representative governments. The birth of another dictatorship should cause the thoughtful American to look carefully to his own political freedom.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Nov. 5 -- The local election yesterday eliminated the American Labor party, smallest active political group here, from a position of influence in municipal affairs in this city. This aggressive group, with fewer than 500 enrolled voters, lost a place in the City Council and saw the defeat of the proportional representation system of voting, which had given it a key spot in city hall for the last two years.

Largely because of the heavy favorable vote in New York City, all nine constitutional amendments and propositions submitted to the voters of the entire state were approved in Tuesday's voting, late tabulations confirmed yesterday.
The fortieth annual fall flower show, known officially as the autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York, will open at noon today in the Penn Top of the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday made public without comment a letter from Commissioner Frederick G. Reinicke of the Department of Marine and Aviation resigning his office, effective Dec. 1. The Mayor said he would name a successor shortly before the end of the month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Economic and political conditions in Austria, while far from satisfactory, are promising. Austria is not considered an enemy country, but enjoys a "liberated country" status. She has a national government elected by its people.

Branch Rickey and Leo Durocher may or may not work side by side next summer directing the affairs of the Dodgers, but they still seem able to click as a combination. Early yesterday morning the pair jointly shot a goose.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Following is the text of the resolution on the problem of the independence of Korea adopted today by the United Nations General Assembly's Political and Security Committee: THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY Recognizing the urgent and rightful claims to independence of the people of Korea;
For the second time since a sitdown strike closed the plant more than three weeks ago, the Industrial Container Corporation resumed production yesterday at 4912 Second Avenue, Brooklyn.

Dr. Harold Lenz, dean of students at Queens College, was attacked from two quarters yesterday because of his testimony last month before a committee of the Board of Higher Education in opposition to a pending motion to bar subversive student organizations at the four city colleges.

A new 10 per cent increase in express rates will be necessary to offset the wage rise of 15 1/2 cents an hour recently granted by the Railway Express Agency to 90 per cent of its employes, L.O. Head, president of the agency, testified yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- Grain markets moved up rapidly today on the Board of Trade. Although the best prices were not maintained, wheat finished with net gains of 1 1/2 to 3 cents a bushel. Corn was up 2 1/2 to 3 cents. Oats gained 7/8 to 1 3/4 cents.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Thirteen prize winners of the fifty-eighth annual American exhibition of abstract and surrealist art were announced today. The paintings will be on public exhibition through Jan. 11 at the Art Institute of Chicago.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 5-A new element entered today into consideration of the outcome of Saturday's football game between Notre Dame and Army. Everyone, it seems, had overlooked the weather.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Deputies to Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain, the Soviet Union and France will meet here tomorrow in a preliminary conference to the second and perhaps final attempt by the Council of Foreign Ministers to map a united future for Germany.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 5 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark denounced tonight those who attack this nation's foreign rehabilitation plan as an attempt at world domination or to annex more land and urged them to consider that it the United States opened its gates "half the world might be depopulated, reminding us of a gold rush of bygone days."

Plainclothes Patrolman Edward F. Morton, suspended from duty Oct. 10 on charges that, while intoxicated, he seized a night supervisor at Harbor Hospital and pushed her against a wall, was tried on departmental charges yesterday at Brooklyn Police Headquarters.

The aims of American foreign policy are outlined anew in two pamphlets being issued by the State Department reviewing current aspects of that policy and the development of the Marshall plan. As summarized in these pamphlets, our aims are: 1. To press for the necessary peace treaties, in order to enable the world to return to a peacetime basis and lift from the backs of many nations the burden of occupation armies without sacrificing security.
At least 158,400 apartments in the city and Long Island will be freed from rent controls on Jan. 1, figures released yesterday by the Office of Rent Control here indicated.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 5 -- George Raft, who will leave for Morocco Nov. 20 to appear in "Outpost Morocco," which Sam Bischoff is producing for United Artists release, will return to Hollywood in January for another Bischoff film, "Mississippi Gambler," the producer announced today.

THE ups and downs of a rebellious celebrity are candidly set forth in "Back Home."* This is Bill Mauldin's excellent new book of cartoons and commentary. It is a companion piece to his classic "Up Front," carrying him through his adventures as a cartoonist in the first two years of this aggressive peace. It is a good book, honest, hard-hitting, cantankerous and remarkably revealing.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The country's three largest grain exchanges, disclaiming responsibility for the recent rise in grain prices, today asked for a "sweeping" Congressional investigation not only of their activities but also of the Government's grain buying program.

PESTEHURST, N.C., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Jimmy Turnesa, second youngest of the seven, golfing brothers from New York, went hunting this warm fall afternoon and his bag included five birdies and an eagle as he racked up a 66 to grab the 36-hole North and South open golf tournament lead by four strokes with 137.

Underwriting transactions involving the offering of issues of commercial, industrial and public utility securities valued at more than $57,000,000 will become effective today as follows: R.H. Macy Co., Inc. -- $20,000,000 of twenty-five year 2 7/3 per cent sinking fund debentures at 99 1/2 to yield about 2.90 per cent, by a syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers and Goldman, Sachs Co.

The National Labor Relations Board ruled yesterday that it was powerless to aid New York warehouse workers who had sought protection against dismissal from their jobs for refusal to contribute one week's pay to a union fund to fight the Taft-Hartley Law.

Welfare Commissioner Benjamin Fielding ordered a twofold check yesterday on regular and supplemental relief allowances as well as on laundry allowances, while the state prepared to resume its inquiry this morning into his department's handling of a $142,000,000 relief program.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Britain assured the independence of 15,000,000 Burmese and took another long step toward the dissolution of the largest modern empire tonight when the House of Commons approved second reading of the Burma independence bill.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov 5 -- A storm in a cocktail glass began brewing in the United Nations today when chagrined diplomats, in parched protest against the closing of their bar yesterday during election hours, posed a "liquor immunities" problem that may have to be carried to the International Court of Justice for final settlement.

The lively anthem of Mexico rang in Madison Square Garden last night and in the afternoon, too, as members of that nation's army team took both international military events that high-lighted the second day of the National Horse Show.

Twenty-two games, twelve of them in defense of the Eastern Intercollegiate League championship it won last year, comprise Columbia's basketball schedule for the coming season, Ralph Furey, director of athletics, announced yesterday.

A campaign for $300,000 to construct a B'nai B'rith Hillel Foundation building near Brooklyn College, to serve all groups on the campus "irrespective of race or creed," was started yesterday at a ceremony in the college.
Penn State's Nittany Lions top the nation in both offense and defense after six straight victories.

A small aluminum-colored flying "automobile" bearing a Connecticut license plate landed at La Guardia Field yesterday. Three and a half minutes later with its wings and propeller removed it was driven into New York by its driver-pilot-owner-inventor-manufacturer.

MARSEILLE, France, Nov. 5 -- Marseille and Genoa soon will complete details of a trade agreement of the type that this city's business men believe represents the self-aid urged by the United States in connection with the Marshall proposals.
The three-day pheasant season opens this morning in Ulster, Dutchess, Orange, Putnam, Rockland and Westchester Counties, but the average New York hunter is due to find few birds and little open land.

WASHESTGTON, Nov. 5 -- Whether American gold should be used to help stabilize European currencies is one of several "critical decisions" which Secretary of State George C. Marshall said today must be made by this week-end in preparation for Congressional hearings on the European recovery program beginning Monday.
PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Dedicated to winter sports, Madeleine de Rauch's midseason collection includes the practical for sliding down mountainsides and the picturesque for hotel or chalet life.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "The Welfare Mess" you raised the question whether the state has been too generous in the percentage of welfare costs which it pays.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Riot squads met the old Bay Line steamer City of Norfolk when it docked this morning after its overnight trip up the bay and jailed five European seamen who had been shackled in the engine room following a battle royal.

New York's influx of Puerto Ricans is creating serious problems for the city's public school system as well as for welfare, housing and health authorities, Frederic Ernst, associate superintendent in charge of the academic high school division, declared yesterday.

Five-Cent Pipe What this country needs, said the visitor, pulling out his tobacco pouch, is not so much the good five-cent cigar of fragrant memory, but a good five-cent corn cob pipe. Why, he said, filling his briar from the pouch and punctuating his remarks with the pipestem, things have come to such a pretty pass that a man now has a hard time finding a corn cob pipe for a dime.
NANKING, Nov. 5 -- A Nationalist general and eight other persons have been arrested in Mukden, Manchuria, on charges of spying for the Chinese Communists the Government announced today.
After a much needed rest, New York University returns to the gridiron on Saturday to face Bucknell at the Yankee Stadium.
BUCHAREST, Nov. 5 -- The Rumanian Parliament, in extraordinary session, voted today a lack of confidence in George Tatarescu, Vice Premier and Foreign Minister.

The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld yesterday an order by District Court Judge Alexander Holtzoff overruling a motion by sixteen bakery companies for dismissal of suit seeking more than $1,000,000 in overtime pay.

A study of the vote by which New York City repealed the Proportional Representation system of electing its City Council reveals some interesting points, especially when a comparison is made with the tests of other years on this same issue.

A detachment of ninety-six officers and blue-uniformed sailors from the French cruiser Georges Leygues stepped briskly up Broadway from the Battery to City Hall yesterday noon to the stirring music of a French drum and bugle corps that played the "Sambre et Meuse," the "Lorraine" and the "Foreign Legion" marches.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Both the Republicans and the Democrats today hailed results of Tuesday's off-year elections in statements issued by their national chairmen.

The Save Washington Square Committee, in a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer made public yesterday, called on the City Planning Commission to bar the building of the projected New York University Law Center on a site facing Washington Square Park.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, India, Nov. 5 -- After several defeats at the hands of Indian Army troops, the invading tribesmen and insurgents in Kashmir apparently have fanned out into the countryside where the defenders are seeking them in the rolling gray hills and brilliant-hued forests of the enchanting Vale of Kashmir.

Too much, family life in this country depends for its common denominator on what its members hear over the radio, Mark A. McCloskey, director of the division of community education at the Board of Education, declared yesterday.
Two deductions may be made from the results of Tuesday's election in the city and state.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 5 -- A proposal to raise the annual dues of the Girl Scouts from 50 cents to $1 will be placed before the twenty-ninth annual convention here. It will be submitted as a constitutional amendment and will be voted on tomorrow afternoon.

GREENFIELD, Mass., Nov. 5 -- Five important objections have resulted from the unique "Brand Names" project initiated here on Oct. 20 by the Greenfield Chamber of Commerce in cooperation with the Brand Names Foundation of New York, local officials reported today.

One solid certainty of the Mississippi election is that neither Representative John E. Rankin nor anybody like him will occupy the Senate seat vacated by the death of Mr. Bilbo. As Mr. Rankin picks himself out of the dust left by all the other Democratic candidates, Mississippi can pride herself on giving him the worst drubbing of his career.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 5 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman of New York today celebrated here the Pontifical Mass of Requiem for Archbishop John J. Cantwell of Los Angeles, who died last Thursday at the age of 72.

Mexico is planning a bilateral credit system involving barter trade with several countries under the supervision of a new Committee on Commercial Interchange and Bilateral Credits, according to a report in banking circles here yesterday.

Net income of the Philco Corporation for the nine months ended with September amounted to $5,632,005 after taxes and all charges, including $2,500,000 inventory reserve and a reserve for future research expenditures, John Ballantyne, president, reported to stockholders yesterday.

A laborer digging a foundation for a lumber yard at 517 West Forty-second Street was buried for an hour yesterday at the bottom of a fifteen-foot-deep ditch, but survived the ordeal to go home after being seated at Roosevelt Hospital.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 5 -- The American farmer may be faced with competing effectively in the world market or leaving the farm, under world trade proposals as now advanced, the convention of the National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation was told tonight by one of its lawyers, Marion R. Garstang, of Washington.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The National Labor Relations Board has before it the problem whether to place on the election ballots in representation cases the name of a union which has failed to file nonCommunist affidavits and the financial and other data required under the Taft-Hartley law.
The American Viscose Corporation reported yesterday a consolidated net income of $5,843,581 for the quarter ended on Sept. 30, equal to $2.71 a share on 2,047,854 shares of common stock outstanding.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. predicted on his return to the capital tonight that the country would receive personal income tax relief in 1948 regardless of a possible third Presidential veto.

Inflation Dilemma As the Government bond market experienced yesterday another mark-down under the weight of nominal offerings, the $64 question in bond houses was. Now that the Victory 2 1/2 s have gone through an assumed "support point" of 101 1/2, how much farther can they be expected to settle before bids, or buying talk, is forthcoming from official sources?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- Reduction of at least 15 per cent in motor vehicle accidents throughout the country to prove that "life is not the cheapest commodity on the highways" will be an outstanding objective of the American Automobile Association during the next twelve months.

More than $350,000 was collected in New York in the last year for French relief by American Aid to France, Inc., which in addition shipped 2,000,000 pounds of supplies to France during that time, the organization announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Howard Hughes enterprises were accused today by Senator John J. Williams, Republican, of Delaware, of apparent "tax delinquencies" aggregating $5,919,921, the accusation coming as the Senate War Investigating subcommittee resumed its inquiry into Mr. Hughes' war contracts.

A special series of five broadcasts analyzing Russian culture, history, aspirations and strategy will be offered on consecutive evenings next week by the CBS network. The programs, to be heard at 6:15 P.M. Monday through Friday, will take the form of interviews by Lyman Bryson, CBS counselor on public affairs, with authorities in the specific fields.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, warned here today that the very existence of the United Nations was at stake in the United States' proposal for a "Little Assembly."

The United Lithuanian Relief Fund of America moved yesterday to strengthen its efforts to acquire Quoddy Village at Eastport, Me., from the War Assets Administration as a site for a university for displaced students now studying at the Baltic University near Hamburg, Germany.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: A few days ago in the Orozco Room of the New School for Social Research a tribute was paid to the thought and career of Horace M. Kallen in the form of a Festschrift of Essays -- Freedom and Experience -- presented to him by friends and colleagues.

Adoption of the three housing propositions, which will greatly expand the city's state-aided program, was commended yesterday by Herman T. Stichman, State Housing Commissioner, and Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority.
GENEVA, Switzerland, Nov. 5 -- The United States provisionally rejected today Canadian compromise proposals for solution of the problem of international air routes.

$200,000 for Oil Burner The Williams Oil-O-Matic division of the Eureka Williams Corporation yesterday announced its largest winter advertising and selling program at a meeting of several hundred dealers at the Astor Hotel.
Dr. Harry S. Mustard, putting in what he called his first "active" day as Commissioner of Health, indicated yesterday a special interest in expanding the municipal health services for children.

Clarence H. Swallow has been appointed treasurer of the Majestic Radio Television Corporation and Majestic Records, Inc. He formerly was vice president in charge of finances and a director of the National Bronze and Aluminum Foundry Company, Cleveland.

The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center honored its own last night. Elevator operators, cleaning women, technicians, nurses, physicians -- 214 in number -- right on up to members of the board of governors of the joint administrative board such as Vincent Astor and Cornelius N. Bliss all received tribute for their more than fifteen years of loyal service.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 -- The Republicans made a gain of three seats in the California Legislature at special elections yesterday while San Francisco was voting overwhelmingly to retain its cable car system and electing Judge Elmer E. Robinson of the State Superior Court as mayor.
