WARSAW, Nov. 5 -- The Polish Government announced tonight that three persons who attempted to escape the country with the Peasant party leader, Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, had been captured. It said that one of them, Wincenty Bryja, had admitted that Mr. Mikolajczyk's escape was planned with "officials of one of the embassies in Warsaw and realized with their active and direct aid."

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- An appeal to the United Nations over the violations of treaty obligations by the satellites of the Soviet Union in Eastern Europe is being drafted by Britain and will be presented "if and when" she feels she has a "cast iron case," Viscount Jowitt Lord Chancellor, told the House of Lords today.

There was a double interest in the fashion show that Macy's presented yesterday in the Oval Room at the Ritz Carlton. The styles were in excellent taste from top to toe and were, moreover, in the medium-price range. While no actual prices were mentioned, fashion reporters were informed that the "midseason highlights were lightly priced."

The text of Governor Dewey's address at the dinner of Farbes Magazine at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night follows: We meet during a period when most reasonable men are concerned for the future of our domestic affairs and are genuinely troubled as to the proper course of our nation in foreign affairs.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 5 -- Mississippi, the heart of the deep south, and Kentucky, a border state with deep-rooted southern traditions, came though yesterday's elections with results that tallied uniformly with last-minute predictions.
LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 6 -- The liner Queen Mary, with 1,900 passengers aboard, will sail for New York this afternoon -- one day late on her scheduled voyage because of a strike among her crew.

WINSTON SALEM, N.C., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Following is the text of the address tonight by former Secretary of State Byrnes before the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church: Wherever thoughtful men and women gather tonight, it is certain there will be some discussion of our foreign relations.

Governor Dewey, in a major foreign policy address, said last night that America had no other choice than to aid, under the Marshall plan, nations in Europe and Asia that may later rise again to be bulwarks of human freedom.

A plan under which car dealers can install complete tire sales departments through investing from $5,000 to $10,000 in a new type of "changeover" sales program, was presented to more than 300 car dealers by Howard Bellows, eastern divisional sales manager of the General Tire and Rubber Company, Akron, Ohio, during a sales conference at Essex House yesterday.
Latest election returns from points throughout the country indicated last night that the Republican trend, which swept the party into control of both houses of Congress last year, has been checked.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 5 -- Former Secretary of State Byrnes renewed tonight his proposal that a peace conference to discuss the "chaotic" situation in Germany be called early in 1948 with or without Soviet cooperation.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 5 -- With prolonged debate, and possibly a deadlock, threatening in the Palestine question, plans are being prepared to keep the Special Palestine Committee of the United Nations General Assembly in session, if necessary, after the other delegates go home, it was learned today.

ROME, Nov. 5 -- Salvatore Rebecchini, member of the Christian Democratic party, was elected Mayor of Rome tonight by votes of forty-one of the city's eighty Municipal Councillors. His nearest rival was Giovanni Selvaggi, Republican party candidate of the Communist-dominated People's Bloc, who got thirty-five votes.

PARIS, Nov. 5 -- Pierre Courtade, writer for the Communist newspaper Humanite, whose visa from the State Department to cover the United Nations General Assembly restricted him to New York and the United Nations centers, has written his first impressions about the United States.

American Airlines, Inc., reported yesterday a net profit of $1,272,514 for the third quarter of this year, against $492,585 in the same period of 1946. For the first nine months of the current year, however, American's operations resulted in a net loss of $1,014,779, after a tax carryback credit of $1,390,000.

PRAGUE, Nov. 5 -- The Czechoslovak Government emerged from the crisis of the National Front coalition regime with a victory for the Communists in their battle against the majority party in Slovakia, the Slovak Democratic party.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 5 -- The House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church decided today to refrain from interpreting in any way the church's recently revised canon on marriage and divorce.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 8,500 head: total, 16,000. Market opened slow, later trade and close moderately active: all weights and sows steady: bulk of good and choice 190-270 pound butchers

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The Federal Government today asked the Federal Court for the District of Columbia for permission to intervene in the suit of twenty-two Negro locomotive firemen seeking reinstatement and damages on the ground that the Southeastern railroads and the Brotherhood of Locomotive Firemen and Enginemen have not obeyed the 1944 decision of the Supreme Court prohibiting discrimination.

11,000 persons a month are aided with transportation problems through the Travelers Aid Society of New York, Mrs. George Hamlin Shaw, vice president, declared yesterday. She told 200 volunteers at the opening meeting of the women's division to aid in the society's $400,000 maintenance appeal at Louis Sherry's, 300 Park Avenue, that the society's work is as important now as during the war.

THE closer one gets to the Army-Notre Dame game the stronger grows the feeling of gloom and depression. No series in football ever produced such nation-wide interest, such drama, such excitement and such teeming color as the one between the cadets and the Fighting Irish. This is all the more extraordinary when you consider what a completely lopsided affair it has been.
Heavy satins, glittering lames and rustling taffetas vied for honors in the after-dark fashions presented yesterday at the Hotel Pierre by Russeks.
LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Admiral Sir Montague Edward Browning died at his home in Winchester yesterday at the age of 84.
TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 5 -- New Jersey had a new Constitution today and a few sharp little headaches from election upsets.

LONDON, Nov. 5 -- Reports that the committee of the Johannesburg Stock Exchange is investigating the boom in Middle Witwatersrand gold shares that preceded publication on Monday of high gold values caused speculators to take profits in the stock markets here today.

TULSA, Okla., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Senator Robert A. Taft, Republican, of Ohio, declared tonight the Administration seemed so little concerned for the success of its food saving program "that one may well suspect that the failure of the plan to bring about savings is to be used as a reason for compulsory control."
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 5 (AP) -- Mullingar, owned by Mrs. Christine Flack, triumphed today in the $5,000 H. D. (Jim) Monroe Memorial Handicap at Rockingham Park.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 5 -- With the unofficial total vote showing a decisive victory in the city charter committee's campaign to retain the proportional representation system of voting, George F. Eyrich, leader of the local Republican organization, said today that "we won't try again to oust P.R."

American Export Lines, operators of the Government-owned vessel Marine Shark, have asked the National Maritime Union, CIO, to live up to the terms of its contract and send another crew to the ship, it was reported last night. The crew refused to sign on and the vessel's sailing, set for Tuesday at noon, was canceled.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Alarm was voiced by spokesmen for organized small business men today at the growth of what they termed an "unfair competitor -- the tax-exempt cooperative."
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed near the session's best levels yesterday, 23 to 48 points net higher.

BOSTON, Nov. 5 -- The victory of the new Boston Teachers Alliance, which obtained election of its entire slate of candidates for the school board and defeated Clement A. Norton, who as chairman of the board last spring opposed pay increases askey by 3,800 teachers, was one of the high points of elections in this state.

A consolidated net profit of 54,048,000 for the nine months ended on Sept. 27, after taxes, minority interest in earnings of $436,000 and a reserve of $1,000,000 for contingencies, was reported yesterday by Textron, Inc., and its subsidiaries, including Textron Southern, Inc.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins tonight took first place undisputed in the National Hockey League by handing the Chicago Black Hawks their seventh straight defeat, 2 to 1, despite the strong efforts of the Hawks' newly acquired line, which scored their lone goal before 16,203 fans.
ALBANY, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The New York State Teachers Association said today that an additional $176,000,000 was needed annually to bring the state's schools to prewar standards.

Preparation for Sunday's Yankee Stadium battle with the San Francisco Forty-Niners continued yesterday with unusual vim and vigor as the New York AAFC leaders galloped through a long drill on the soggy stadium turf under the direction of Coach Red Flaherty and his assistants.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Adopted, 46 to 0, with four abstentions, amended United States resolution to establish temporary commission on Korea. Rejected, 20 to 6, with seven abstentions, Soviet proposal for immediate troop evacuation.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 5 (AP) -- The St. Louis Browns, aiming at a rebound from their cellar finish last season, today completed their field directorate for 1948 with the sighing of their newly announced manager, Zach Taylor, and two coaching assistants to one-year contracts.

CHICAGO, Nov. 5 -- The Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association filed charges today with the National Labor Relations Board under terms of the Taft-Hartley Labor Management Law against Local 16, Chicago Typographical Union and its parent organization, the International Typographical Union, AFL.

The stock market was unable yesterday to generate any momentum on the higher side except in scattered instances and heaviness which hung over most of the list throughout the day produced an easier close. Sharp losses were registered in some of the pivotal stocks but the combined averages only receded 0.13 point on the day.

Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe, dismissed yesterday a suit brought by the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company, Inc., for $3,084,241 damages allegedly sustained by the company in the seizure of its ship, the Martin Behrman, by the Royal Dutch Navy last March.

With Lou Kusserow, the team's Chief running threat, probably lost for the Dartmouth game on Saturday and perhaps longer, Columbia had its first heavy scrimmage of the week at Baker Field yesterday. The Lions worked chiefly against Indian plays.

Following the pattern of gray goods sales, cotton yarn prices have taken a sharp turn upward, according to a survey in the primary markets yesterday. Numerous sellers of combed and mercerized yarns have withdrawn their prices, it was learned, awaiting definite developments on new labor rates in Southern mills.

Henry A. Wallace, in his -- first public address since his recent return from Palestine, asserted last night'that the common interest of Jews and Arabs there bar any conflict "unless outside interests stir it up."

It was "Attaboy, Teddy!" at Jamaica again yesterday, for Theodore F. Atkinson, the bootin' man from Toronto, marked up another triple to move farther ahead in the race for riding honors at the Empire City Association's meeting.

After an absence of six years, Jane Cowl has been thoughtful enough to return to the stage. In association with Henry Daniell, she is appearing in a revival of St. John Ervine's "The First Mrs. Fraser," which opened at the Sam S. Shubert last evening.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- The chairman of a Senate subcommittee investigating the Federal Public Housing Authority called today for a thorough audit of the agency's books for the fiscal year 1945.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 5 -- Results of yesterday's voting in the large Ohio cities had state political leaders walking around in circles today.
The Coast Guard cutter Duane was reported yesterday to be standing by the battered Canadian freighter Louisburg in the stormy North Atlantic 400 miles northeast of St. John's, Nfld.

Medium Shoe Brands Duplicated Stepping up of shoe price lines because of advances occasioned by peak leather prices has created somewhat of a merchandising problem for retailers, it was reported here yesterday. Stores handling several brands have found that, while the low and higher price brackets are not particularly affected, price rises have brought price competition and duplication in the medium ranges which did not exist before.
Determination of federal tax policy at the present time presents two questions. One of these has to do with the kind of legislation we should adopt; the other concerns the timing of that legislation.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 5 -- Democrats gained twenty-five cities in the 102 municipal elections in Indiana yesterday. They won control of thirty-eight cities previously Republican and lost thirteen previously Democratic. The Democrats before Tuesday had held twenty-eight cities despite the upsurge of Republican strength in 1944 and 1946.

VIENNA, Nov. 5 -- Zoltan Pfeiffer, leader of the Hungarian Independence party, has escaped from Hungary and, according to the Wiener Kurier, the United States Army newspaper here, has sought refuge with friends in Vienna.

The Musicians Union, Local 802, having charged the League of New York Theatres with failure as a bargaining agent, has served notice on the league that it will not do business with the organization in future negotiations. Instead, the union plans to negotiate with individual producers.

Approximately 9,500,000 Christmas Club members will receive $747,000,000 -- a new high record -- from 5,500 banking, savings and other organizations, beginning Dec. 1, it was estimated yesterday. The estimate was made by Douglas T. Johnston, president; Edward F. Dorset, executive vice president, and Mrs. Herbert F. Rawll, vice president of Christmas Club, a corporation.

The hegira of the political exiles continues. The latest opposition leader to flee his country under threat of arrest is Zoltan Pfeiffer, head of the Hungarian Independence party. In issuing a warrant for Mr. Pfeiffer and invoking court action to oust his party from the Assembly, the Communistdominated regime moves to silence its last open opponents.

New unit furniture, artfully constructed so that chests and bookcases may be combined harmoniously, was introduced yesterday at Modernage, 16 East Thirty-fourth Street. The pieces, together with settees, chairs and tables, were designed by Martin Feinman.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 5 (AP) -- Lazy F Ranch's Nathaniel, 3-to-5 favorite, won the Heiser Handicap at Pimlico today in a close finish among three racers. Nathaniel drew away by half a length in the Closing strides before a crowd of 12,940.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration announced today that it had ordered, as a fire precaution, the removal of insulation from the baggage section of Douglas DC-6 planes.

Though the foods the shopper buys today for the week-end generally are at about the same prices as they were last Friday, a few items such as medium-sized grade A eggs, smaller turkeys and some cuts of meat are a little cheaper than they were then.

To meet the relief needs of Lithuanians in Europe, $1,400,000 will be required by the United Lithuanian Relief Fund of America, Inc., it was announced yesterday at the second annual meeting of the agency at the New Yorker Hotel.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 6 -- The second general assembly of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, at its ceremonial opening here today, heard a grave warning from President Miguel Aleman that science and warfare surely would destroy the world civilization unless they were diverted to constructive peacetime uses by education and culutural influences.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Approved modified United States proposal for year-round "Little Assembly" by 43 to 6, with six abstentions. Soviet bloc announced it would not participate in new group.

WARSAW, Nov. 6 -- Czechoslovak authorities surrendered Wincenty Bryja and two other members of the Polish Peasant party group attempting to escape with M. Mikolajczyk after a special Polish Government emissary went to Prague to press for their return, it was learned tonight.

The Marshall plan to aid European nations, holds a serious threat to the future of the American merchant marine "with respect to both economic security and national defense," a statement issued yesterday by the National Federation of American Shipping declared.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange lost all early gains yesterday and closed 2 to 12 points net lower than the previous day.

Unbeaten Evander Childs was held to a 6-all tie by a stubborn Christopher Columbus High eleven yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. The former now has won two games and engaged in a pair of deadlocks while Columbus ends a curtailed campaign with one triumph, two losses and as many ties.

The State Veterans Bonus Bureau expects to start mailing out checks to eligible veterans on Jan. 2, 1948, the day that applications will begin to be accepted, Leo V. Lanning, bureau director, declared here yesterday.
A net income of $6,797,453 for the first nine months of this year was reported by the Household Finance Corporation in a statement to stockholders signed By B.E. Henderson, president.

Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias, who turned professional this year after monopolizing the honors in women's amateur golf competition, here and abroad, announced yesterday she was planning to take part in the men's national open tournament next year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- The modified proposal for a "Little Assembly" was approved here this afternoon by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly in a tempestuous session. The vote was 43 to 6, with six abstentions.

PINEHURST, N.C., Nov. 6 (AP) -- A 74, 73 finish today was good enough to clinch for Jimmy Turnesa, Elmsford, N.Y., professional, top money of $1,500 in the forty-fifth North and South open golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 284, four under par.

Price increases ranging between 3 and 5 per cent which, according to a recent prediction, carpet manufacturers are preparing to issue by next spring are not justified because producers are able to absorb rising labor and materials costs, department and homefurnishings store buyers declared yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 6 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the United States Military Governor, emphatically has renewed his "goldfish bowl" policy for Germany, it was learned today. At a closed all-day meeting of Army public information officers called here from throughout the United States zone, he ordered them to give out news regardless of the consequences.

Murray Beaker, Associated Press photographer, and Patrolman James P. Harrington of the East Fifty-first Street Station, gave conflicting testimony yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Court concerning a case involving alleged police assault on the night of Oct. 6.

An industrial reconstruction board for Europe, constituted similarly to the recent War Production Board, should be organized and headed by an outstanding civilian chief, Senator Homer E. Capehart of Indiana urged in a keynote address before more than 150 leading members of the four billion dollar foundry industry during the fiftieth annual meeting of the National Founders Association at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 6 -- The reappearance of all three of Notre Dame's injured backs in uniform on the practice field buoyed the hopes of the Fighting Irish to day, forty-eight hours before the kick-off against Army on Saturday.

"The Fox and the Rabbit,' staged by the Folk Tale Marionettes, will open tomorrow a new series of children's programs sponsored by the Riverdale Neighborhood and Library Association. The performance will be given at 2:30 P.M. at Public School 81, 256th Street and Riverdale Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, has appointed an interdepartmental committee on reserve components, which will study the possibility of removing the National Guard from the control of the forty-eight Governors, it was learned today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- The Standard Power and Light Corporation threatened today to ask a Federal court to set aside a provision of an order issued on Oct. 30 by the Securities and Exchange Commission which the company said deprived it of the right to elect certain directors of its $700,000,000 subsidiary, the Standard Gas and Electric Company.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- Following is the text of the resolution on the proposed United Nations "Little Assembly" approved here today by the General Assemblies Political and Security Committee: THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY

Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that he would ask the 1948 Legislature to amend the Rapid Transit Law to give the Board of Transportation the power and duty, without any requirement for a public referendum, to increase the fare on the municipal transit lines sufficiently to cover all their operating costs.

Since its establishment in 1938 the Institute for Religious and Social Studies has offered annual courses and seminars to academic and lay leaders of the community. Sponsored by the Jewish Theological Seminary, the Institute performs a valuable service in bringing influential scholars together, to discuss openly and freely vital issues of the day.

Enthusiasm for ski wear ran high yesterday at Bloomingdale's at a preview in the new shop on the second floor. The shop was planned with Fred Picard, an authority on ski wear and equipment, as its advisor. It will open to the public on Monday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- Most authorities consulted here today interpreted Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov's statement that there was no longer any "secret" about the atomic bomb as merely a claim that the Soviet Union had learned the technique of atomic production.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The California delegation to the first post-war convention of the Young Democratic Clubs of America, set for next week at Cleveland, will ask adoption of a platform plank seeking a vastly expanded Federal housing program.

OTTAWA, Nov. 6 -- Newfoundland has received the offer of admision into the Canadian confederation on terms that are considered here fair and equitable but constitute, in so far as the financial arrangements are concerned, the maximum that the Canadian Government would be prepared to recommend to Parliament as a basis of union.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The executive branch of the government displayed no alarm today over the intimation by Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov that the Soviet Union had the secret of the atomic bomb. Instead officials remained satisfied that it did not have the key to the production of the weapon.

The stock market was unable yesterday to hold its ground, retreating under only moderate pressure, in selective trading. The session developed a two-way pattern of price changes, with some of the prime industrials higher and the combined averages down 0.39 point on the day.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- The Chicago hearing of the Joint Congressional House Committee on High Building Costs, reached an early and unexpected climax today when Charles M. Hines, head of one of the country's largest lumber firms, complied with a request to reveal certain trade secrets after being threatened with contempt action.

Louise Meiszner, 23-year-old pianist, who won the Leventritt Award in 1945, gave her third New York recital last night at Town Hall. Her program consisted of Haydn's "Andante and Variations" in F minor; Mozart's Sonata in D major (K. 576); Schumann's Sonata in G minor; Chopin's Scherzo in B-flat minor: Liszt's "Hungarian Rhapsody," No. 12, and shorter pieces by Rachmaninoff, Bartok and Griffes.

The "fate" of Joseph R. Scottoriggio, East Harlem Republican district captain, was sealed the night before election last year at a "conference" in the home of Michael (Trigger Mike) Coppola, it was charged yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 6 -- The Government of Premier Petru Groza today ousted George Tatarescu as Vice Premier and Foreign Minister and forced the resignations of this three National Liberal party colleagues who held Cabinet portfolios.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- A United States proposal to limit national contributions to the United Nations budget was deferred today for another year.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- The United States today modified its proposal for the partition of Palestine, suggesting that certain functions be performed by the United Nations Security Council in an effort to meet the criticisms of the Soviet Union.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Russian Minister of the Armed Forces, urged the Soviet's defense forces tonight to "be in constant militant preparedness" against the "instigators of a new war."

BOSTON, Nov. 6 -- A committee of 100 Protestant leaders, the majority laymen, will convene in the fall of 1948 to build the framework of a constitution for a United Church of America, Dr. E. Stanley Jones, prominent clergyman and missionary, disclosed today.

After three successive weeks of record production, the nation's crude oil output dropped last week to an average of 5,274,250 barrels daily, a decline of 21,100 from the preceding week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. In the preceding week production averaged 5,295,350 barrels daily, a record, and in the similar week last year it was 4,758,550 daily.

Mayor O'Dwyer and Governor Dewey sent special messages of tribute to City College yesterday to commemorate the opening of its second century of existence. The messages were made public by Stephen Duggan, president of the college's Associate Alumni, which will hold a "Second Century Dinner" tomorrow night at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

Seymour N. Siegel was sworn in by Mayor O'Dwyer late yesterday afternoon as director of radio communications for the city, a post entailing the management of WNYC and WNYC-FM. He had been serving as acting director since January, 1946, following the resignation of Morris S. Novik.

The 36,667-ton Atlantic line Nieuw Amsterdam of the HollandAmerica Line made her triumphant appearance in New York Harbor yesterday to reopen the company's de luxe service between New Yorh and Rotterdam.

Persons accustomed to frequent use of trains and buses have come to know quite a little about Travelers Aid. Such persons know that if they find themselves stranded, without funds or without sufficient knowledge of the character of their destination, they can go to the Travelers Aid for sympathetic attention and help.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Business men's complaints against the conduct of wage-hour administration field inspectors prompted a House Labor Subcommittee to decide today to call in some of the inspectors for questioning.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, leader of the Polish Peasant party, emphatically denied today that his escape from his country had been aided by a foreign embassy in Warsaw, as charged in a communique issued there yesterday by the Polish Government.

"Wim, wigor and witality" were amply in evidence at the concert conducted by Charles Muench, returning as guest leader to the PhilharmonicSymphony Orchestra, last night in Carnegie Hall. These qualities were excellently employed in the robust performance of Roussel's Suite in F, which opened the program.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Nov. 6 -- Indictments against Mayor George A. Smock 2d and three members of the Asbury Park City Council charging infractions of the law in leasing beach front properties without public bidding were nolleprossed by County Judge John Girdano in Freehold today.

A New York County grand jury investigating since last March the manipulations of William B. Benjamin, convicted of swindling finance companies of $493,000, yesterday returned a second indictment charging Edwin A. Carlson, an official of the Title Guarantee and Trust Company, 176 Broadway, with first-degree grand larceny.

The City College football team will face against heavy odds as it tries to even its season's record in a contest at the West Chester Teachers College field tonight. Not only have the Teachers won all seven starts this year, but they also have been waiting, since last March, to teach the Beavers a lesson.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Main interest in the stock markets here today again was centered on Middle Witwatersrand gold shares. The Cape again was a heavy buyer and after some sharp fluctuations in early dealings the price steadied, to close with a net gain. The shares have doubled in value in the last four days.

NANKING, Nov. 6 -- Attacks aimed directly at Nanking and Shanghai and their connecting communications routes are planned by the Communists for next spring, according to foreign sources recently in contact with the Reds in North China.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- Many United States merchants seeking to buy luxury goods in France have found the average price asked by the French about 100 per cent too high, Daniel J. Reagan, counsellor for Economic Affairs at the United States Embassy, said at a press conference today.
LONDON, Nov. 6 -- A strong Soviet objection to the inclusion of one item on the agenda marred the otherwise even course of the first meeting of deputy Foreign Ministers on Germany today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 6 -- The Wisconsin Hydro-Electric Company, Amery, Wis., received permission from the Securities and Exchange Commission today to reclassify 11,953 shares of preferred and 10,552 shares of common stock into a single class of 132,800 shares of new $12 par value common stock.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- President Truman, said today that he would ask the session of Congress starting on Nov. 17 to take up, as its first business, emergency aid for western Europe, and then to look into the domestic economy with its problem of inflation curbs.

The Political Committee of the United Nations gave its endorsement yesterday to Secretary Marshall's proposal for the establishment of a "Little Assembly" by a vote of 43 to 6. Russia and her satellites cast the negative votes.

Vashti, a 3-year-old filly held in high regard by William Woodward, chairman of the Jockey Club and boss of the Belair Stud, made good handsomely in the $4,000 Oakdale Purse at Empire City-at-Jamaica yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 6 (AP) -- King Ranch's Bridal Flower, bred by the late Col. E.R. Bradley, was a tenlength winner in the eleventh running of the $10,000 added Lady Baltimore Handicap, involving a field of seven fillies and mares, at Pimlico today.

LITERARY criticism as practiced by Maxwell Geismar is a strenuous occupation. No other contemporary practitioner of the much-abused profession of writing about writing does so with more conscientious care to ponder well all the lesser works of the author concerned, with a more earnest endeavor to penetrate into the inner recesses of the literary mind and personality, or with greater verbal exuberance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Unsatisfactory and, in cases, austere though it is, the economies of Britain and France are relatively more secure than are those of the European countries that lie adjacent to Russian-dominated nations. So is that of Italy.

The New York Stock Exchange will present a weekly radio program of classical music over WQXR, the radio station of THE NEW YORK TIMES, as part of its campaign to acquaint the public with the Exchange's role in the country's economic life, it was announced yesterday.
BERLIN, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Russians detained an Associated Press photographer and a Stars and Stripes reporter for three and a half hours today before releasing them.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 6 -- Governor Alfred E. Driscoll said today he and New Jersey members of the Port of New York Authority were in complete accord that New York harbor should be developed as a two-state enterprise.

PEIPING, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Warring Chinese Communists gained another objective in the battle for Manchuria today with word that they had forced withdrawal of Government troops from the major coal, iron and steel town of Anshan.

One of the busiest days the port has experienced since the war was marked yesterday by the arrival of four transatlantic liners and a number of smaller vessels carrying 4,962 passengers. Customs and immigration agents assigned to baggage duty and passport inspection on the four larger ships said the traffic emphasized the inadequacy of the Federal staffs in the port district.

Further War Loan Call Acting to meet the scheduled redemption of $100,000,000 of its bills on Nov. 13, the United States Treasury yesterday issued a call on its "war loan" accounts with the Class B banks for an approximate amount.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Nov. 1 were 940,746 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 13,881 cars, or 1.5 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 18,434 cars, or 2 per cent more than in the corresponding week of last year, and 88,784 cars, or 10.4 per cent more than during the corresponding week of 1945.

The Metropolitan Museum will open to the public today an exhibition of Japanese prints consisting of examples in the Phillips Collection. This collection, assembled by Mr. and Mrs. Henry L. Phillips between 1911 and 1922 in Japan, New York, London and Paris, came to the museum by bequest in 1940 and is being shown as an entity.

MONTREAL, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens shut out the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3 -- 0, tonight, the victory giving the Canadiens sole possession of third place in the National League. A crowd of 11,246 saw the game.
When the football teams of Dartmouth and Columbia meet for the eighteenth time at Baker Field tomorrow afternoon "there won't be much to choose between the two teams," says Lou Little, Lions coach.

Bound by a constitution that features strict freshman and transfer rules and bars excessive aid to athletes, fifty-three colleges have been enrolled as charter members in the revised Eastern College Athletic Conference, it was announced yesterday by Commissioner Asa S. Bushnell.

As the State Board of Social Welfare taxed the city Welfare Department yesterday with inadequate handling in 91 per cent of 200 relief cases, Vice Chairman Joseph T. Sharkey of the City Council sponsored a local law that would establish two years of city residence as a qualification for home relief, veteran assistance or oldage assistance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Evidence intended to show a calculated design among some Army Air Force materiel officers to let Howard Hughes "hang himself" in trying to produce a wartime photo reconnaissance plane recommended by Elliott Roosevelt was put today before the Senate War Investigating Subcommittee.

The Horse Show Ball, traditionally the principal feature of many fetes given in conjunction with the National Horse Show, was held last night in the flag-draped, flower-bedecked setting of the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The ball was formally opened at about midnight, shortly after the close of the evening session of the horse show at Madison Square Garden.

Random notes. After sitting in at the luncheon meeting of the Feather Dusters Club, a loosely knit and unincorporated group within the Engineers Club, we are convinced that in order to get any really good hunting or fishing you should be an engineer, not a rod and gun writer.

The cotton textile industry has driven ahead single-mindedly to provide the type of goods needed to meet the domestic and world-wide shortage, W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, declared yesterday in a mid-year, report to association members.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 6 -- Charles Luckman, head of the Citizens Food Committee, cited today a number of developments which, he said, indicated the accelerating success of the drive to conserve grain to alleviate Europe's shortage this winter.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 -- Business in the Pittsburgh district last week continued to advance on a broad front, according to the Bureau of Business Research, University of Pittsburgh. Gains were reported in industrial production, originating shipments and trade after adjustment for the usual seasonal changes.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6 -- Admiral Ben Moreell, retired, president and chairman of the board of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, said here this afternoon at a press conference that he does not think that Government rationing of steel is inevitable.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 6 -- The California un-American Activities Committee was told today by its counsel, Richard E. Coombs, that the radiation laboratory at the University of California, center of atomic research on the Berkeley campus, was carelessly guarded and wide open to sabotage.
Dr. Richard Carroll, superintendent of manufacturing operations at the Rensselaer, N.Y., plant of Winthrop-Stearns, Inc., has been promoted to divisional vice president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Two important contributions were made in Washington today toward order and clarity in carrying out the foreign aid policy and attacking the domestic problems to which it is intimately related. The contributions were bi-partisan.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- The secret of the atom bomb, chief weapon of "expansionist plans" of the United States, "has long ceased to exist," Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov told a cheering audience of the Communist elite in Moscow tonight in the climax of a speech marking the thirtieth anniversary of the seizure of power in Russia by the Bolshevik party.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 6 -- Jess Harper arrived in town, today from his Kansas cattle ranch. That makes it official. Jess was at hand for the beginning of the Army-Notre Dame series and he will be one of the chief mourners on Saturday when the now traditional affair will be buried with full military honors.

In New York's first event of its kind, Dr. William Jansen was formally inducted as Superintendent of Schools last night before an audience of 1,700 persons representing industry, commerce, labor and civic affairs.

Fifty-seven mortgage loans totaling $535,800 have been obtained by the L.M.S. Construction Corporation, Leon Silberstein, president, on a group of one-family houses under construction in Wantagh, L.I., on Atlantic Boulevard and Byron and Willow Streets. J. Halperin Co. were the brokers.

Record-breaking attendance at Metropolitan Opera productions in New York and on tour brought in the highest receipts in the company's history during the fiscal year that ended May 31, it was announced yesterday.

PRESQUE ISLE, Me., Nov. 6 -- Part of the potato crop is endangered in Aroostook County, Me., the biggest single "potato basket" of the nation, Herbert W. Moore, secretary of the county potato growers and shippers committee, said tonight.

PARIS, Nov. 6 -- French measures to prevent food prices from soaring in the wake of the authorized coal increases were announced today by Jules Moch, Minister for Economic Affairs. In a broadcast to the nation, he asked public support in the fight against price increases.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 6 -- A "Clothes-for-Friendship" program under which the 1,300,000 Girl Scouts in the United States will send 100,000 kits of clothing to children in Europe and Asia next year was announced today at the scout organization's national convention.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Grain markets made a firm start and a tame finish on the Board of Trade today, wheat closing 1/2 to 2 1/4 cents lower. Corn lost 3/4 to 1 1/4 cents and oats were off 7/8 to 1 3/8 cents. Soy beans advanced 1/2 to 1 1/2 cents and barley was unchanged.

Claudia Pinza, soprano, daughter of Ezio Pinza, Metropolitan bass, will make her debut as Micaela in a special non-subscription performance of Bizet's "Carmen," Tuesday night, Nov. 18, at the Metropolitan Opera House. The other principals in the cast will be Rise Stevens in the title role, Ramon Vinay as Don Jose and Martial Singher as Escamillo.

WEST POINT, Nov. 6 -- Eight hours before he herded thirty-nine cadet football players aboard the special train to South Bend, Ear (Red) Blaik, Army coach, denied for the umpty-umpth time today that he personally was responsible for the impending break between the institutions.

HONOLULU, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Eight B-29 Superfortresses, bound from Fort Worth, Tex., to Tokyo, today abandoned the training mission and will return to the mainland because they are not equipped for the type of gasoline available in forward areas, officers of the Air Fore said.

The two-year-long dispute over possession of $5,000 found hidden in the lining of a fur coat in summer storage was settled yesterday when Police Department property clerk Frank Leuci returned the money to the owner of the coat, Mrs. Sadie Ullman of The Dover Apartments, 687 Lexington Avenue.

City Councilman Peter V. Cacchione, first avowed Communist ever to hold elective public office in New York State, died suddenly yesterday of a heart attack. His death came only two days after the people of the city had voted to abolish the system of proportional representation, under which Mr. Cacchione was three times elected to the City Council from Brooklyn.

A resolution was introduced yesterday at the City Council meeting requesting the Board of Higher Education and the president of Queens College, Dr. Paul Klapper, to demand the resignation of Dr. Harold Lenz, dean of students at Queens College.

Seven American Protestant clegymen who visited Yugoslavia last summer at the invitation of the Yugoslav Government made public yesterday a formal report on their observations and the information they gathered under the title, "Religion in Yugoslavia."

'Truth' Ad Wins Praise Response to the full-page ad, "A. Truth About Advertising," run by Deutsch Shea, Inc., in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 27, has brought to date some 624 telegrams and letters endorsing the advertisement and asking reuse of the material, it was reported yesterday by Arnold R. Deutsch, president of the agency.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 6 -- The issue between left and right forces within the United Automobile Workers, CIO, was joined squarely tonight with the disclosure that the forces of Walter P. Reuther, bitter anti-Communist president of the union, would seek a clean sweep of every office at the eleventh constitutional convention opening here on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Average primary market prices dropped 0.4 per cent during the week ended Nov. 1, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Marked decreases for agricultural commodities more than offset the continued rise in non-agricultural commodities.

The Chicago Sanitary District awarded yesterday an issue of $10,000,000 bonds due Jan. 1, 1967, with $9,350,000 subject to call from 1950 to 1966, to a banking group headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Harriman Ripley Co., Inc., at a bid of 101.047 for 2 1/4 per cent interest. Other bids ranged from 100.93 to 100.133 for the same rate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Senator Brien McMahon, Democrat, of Connecticut, member and former chairman of the Senate Atomic Energy Committee, said today he did not believe that the Soviet Union had yet achieved the production of any atomic bombs, although he added that he had long contended it would at some future date.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 6 (AP) -- Separation of the aviation and nonaviation holdings of the Consolidated Vultee Aircraft Corporation was approved today at a special stockholders' meeting.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Angered by a newspaper's charges that they were snooping and impertinent in their inquiries here, members of a United States Senate subcommittee seeking data on the needs of Britain and Europe hit back at their critics at a press conference today.

It is possible that vaccination of the population as a whole may be effective in preventing another disastrous epidemic of influenza, Dr. Francis G. Blake, Sterling Professor of Medicine at the Yale University School of Medicine, said last night before a meeting of the New York Academy of Medicine at 2 East 103d Street.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- A few hours after Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov had accused Britain and the United States of obstructing United Nations control over atomic energy, a United States spokesman today placed entire responsibility for the delay in world disarmament on the lack of cooperation of the Soviet minority of nations in the peace organization.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- During the week ended Nov. 5, member bank reserve balances increased $229,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Production for export in England is now being stepped up sharply and a much larger volume of merchandise will be available for the American market next spring, it was reported here yesterday by Gerald C. Bentall, British department store official, at a luncheon held in his honor by Affiliated Traders, Ltd., at the St. Regis Hotel.

The first Gutenberg Bible to reach these shores 100 years ago this month will be exhibited for two weeks starting tomorrow in the main lobby of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

Mayor O'Dwyer yesterday took his longest step toward ending the fivecent fare on the ailing New York City transit system. He proposes to carry to the Legislature, as part of his 1948 legislative program, a request for amendment of law that will place in the Board of Transportation the power to set a fare to meet operating expenses.
The brilliance characteristic of autumn skies and gardens was transferred to the Penn Top of the Pennsylvania Hotel yesterday, where the fortieth annual autumn exhibition opened.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Baseball's executive council voted today to recommend to the joint meeting of major league club owners in New York Dec. 11 that the "American Legion rule" be included in "the body of the rules of baseball" and that the clubs be prohibited from "inviting or suggesting" that players report voluntarily for spring training before March 1, the official fixed time.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, India, Nov. 5 -- Indian Army troops engaged 300 to 400 invading tribesmen and local insurgents in a spirited rifle, mortar and machine gun battle from 2 A.M. until dawn today about four and a half miles from this city, the capital of Kashmir State.

DETROIT, Nov. 6 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings climbed back into a tie with Boston for the National Hockey League lead tonight by downing the New York Rangers, 2 to 1, with all the scoring in the opening period.

When it was decided, early in 1948, to introduce into the United States the system of democracy prevailing in certain countries in Eastern Europe the Federal Government acted with speed and decision. It was clear that the majority in Congress, and possibly the majority among the electorate, had been conspiring to defeat the will of the people.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 6 -- The life of Al Capons, which has been banned as a screen subject whenever it has been submitted to the Production Code censors, has cropped up again in the form of a photoplay by John Moffitt, based on a story by Westbrook Pegler, which has been submitted to Joseph I. Breen, code administrator, for approval.

Hand-painted and hand-screened fabrics by June Groff and Donelda Fazakas were put on display yesterday at the Women's International Exposition, now being held at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at Thirtyfourth Street.

A survey made for the International Wool Secretariat by Dun Bradstreet sliows that a majority of retailers and cutters hold the view that woolens are losing out to other fabrics, according to Norton Savell, managing director of the Secretariat, yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- For the second time in two days, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, United States delegate, clashed today with delegates of the Slav states in defending the Western Allies' administration of displaced persons camps.

Maintaining their unbroken record of expansion for the sixteenth consecutive week, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans by the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve went up $90,000,000 during the week ended on Wednesday.

In his statement of Oct. 23, when he announced that he was calling Congress into special session on Nov. 17, President Truman declared that this course of action was dictated by two "compelling reasons."

Little Credit Rise Yet No sudden increase has developed in credit volume since termination of Regulation W in the retail field, credit executives here said yesterday. Credit inquiries and applications have increased this week, particularly after election day, but this is a usual seasonal phenomenon and no unusual significance was attached to it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The forthcoming report of the President's Committee on Foreign Aid will recommend creation of a new Federal agency to administer the Marshall recovery program and urge that American loans be without any conditions restricting the freedom of choice of Europeans in their political and economic forms.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Nov. 6 -- James M. Landis, chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said today that public expenditure of ten to twenty million dollars in developing an adequate "feeder" airplane program would save spending three to four times that amount needed to enlarge existing airports.

Missing no bets in their effort to end a losing streak that has reached five straight games, the New York Giants announced yesterday that Bobby Morris, fleet right halfback from Southern California, had been recalled from the Jersey City Giants of the American Football League.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock marKets here by the United States Dept of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 13,000 head, total 24,000: market slow: early trade 50-75 cents lower but later trade and majority of sales 75 cents $1.00 lower: sows also 75 cents-$l.00 lower:

Four crates of radar equipment and twenty-six cases of radio parts were sent from here three weeks ago to Yugoslavia under consignment to the Yugosiav Red Cross, it was made known yesterday by customs officials.

Crime movies and radio programs offer too many pointers on criminal methods to youngsters, members of the Women's City Club of New York declared yesterday at an open meeting at the New Weston Hotel on radio crime programs.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 6 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll started an inquiry today into alleged abuses of civil liberties in New Jersey after Communists and a candidate for national office appeared to have been barred from holding meetings.

The Association of Uptown Converters, representing 100 textile converting concerns, announced yesterday that it would extend its "complete support and backing" to any member company that refused to discharge workers for failure to contribute one week's pay to a union fund set up to fight the Taft-Hartley Law.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 6 -- Continuance of residential rent controls in Westchester after their scheduled expiration date of Feb. 29, 1948, was advocated today by the County Rent Advisory Board. The controls have been effect since Nov. 1, 1944.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The National Labor Relations Board today cracked down on unions which have held contracts but which have refused to sign nonCommunist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley Act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Five New York shipping executives were among twelve wartime officials who received Presidential certificates of merit today for "outstanding fidelity and meritorious conduct" in their service.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- The possibility of Congressional action on personal income tax reduction during the forthcoming session was ruled out today by statements of President Truman and Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr.

VIENNA, Nov. 6 -- The Hungarian Communist party, it has been learned from an absolutely reliable source, has received instructions from Moscow to liquidate all effective opposition to its plans by the end of November. This order is believed to be the immediate sequel to the formation of the Communist Information Bureau in Belgrade, Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- A recommendation by the Chicago Rent Advisory Board for a general 15 per cent increase in rent levels in the Chicago area was rejected today by Tighe E. Woods, Acting Housing Expediter.

Since the spring of 1945 the William Brown Meloneys haven't bothered much with show business. Preceding their temporary retirement, Mr. Meloney put on three plays in two seasons ("Outrageous Fortune," "Doctors Disagree" and "Soldier's Wife"), each written and directed by the distaff member of the team, Rose Franken.

The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared a series of menus to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: Fish come in fillets nowadays, which eases the shopping and preparing of today's baked fish and spinach Peace Plate. Moreover, you have your choice of fillets; for cod, flounder, sole, halibut or haddock fillets are all included on November's fish line.

Inventories of wanted fabrics in the popular priced sportswear field are practically non-existent, Henry J. Perahia, president of the National Skirt and Sportswear Association, declared yesterday. The industry is being supplied on almost a hand-to-mouth basis, he said, with important colors missing.

CHICAGO, Nov. 6 -- Joseph M. Dodge, president of the American Bankers' Association, today warned bankers an attempt may be made to shift the blame for inflation from Government policies to the country's banks.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recent actions of the Soviet Government have given rise to expressions of fear that war is inevitable. Among these actions have been Soviet efforts to block the Marshall plan and sabotage European recovery, the formation of the new Comintern and the stepped-up propaganda offensive against the United States.
The art dealers and painters of Fifty-seventh Street are lining up their pictures behind the sixtyninth drive of the United Hospital Campaign.

Appointment of a research advisory committee to the United States Children's Bureau, and organization in the bureau of a central clearing house of information on child life were among recommendations of a nation-wide group of specialists revealed yesterday by Dr. Martha M. Eliot, associate chief of the bureau.

Unusual ways of decorating home interiors with papers now being handblocked in Pescia, Italy, were shown yesterday by Elisabeth Draper, Inc., 785 Madison Avenue. The dainty papers revive the tiny formal designs of the noted Remondini Carte Fiorite collection first incised at the time of the Doges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 1 were 14 per cent above those in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- With both sides of the House of Commons supporting the measure, the Government's Overseas Resources Development Bill went through its second reading tonight. The measure provides for two Government's sponsored corporations authorized to borrow up to L165,000,000 (about $660,000,000) to finance the development of overseas natural resources for the benefit of Britain.

American Smelting and Refining The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday the declaration of a stock dividend of one-fifth of an additional share of common stock for each share held, payable on Dec. 23. In addition, directors voted a cash dividend of $1.50 on the common stock, to be paid on the same date.
The United States and Mexico divided honors yesterday in the National Horse Show's spectacular international military competition at Madison Square Garden.

LONDON, Nov. 6 (AP) -- Following are excerpts from Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov's address is Moscow tonight, as broadcast by the Moscow radio in Russian and translated here by the Soviet Monitor: All real friends of peace -- and they constitute the majority of people of any country -- can rely on the fact that the Soviet Union will defend to the end the interests of universal peace.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 6 -- President Truman indicated today that the Citizens Food Committee setup headed by Charles Luekman might be long-range rather than temporary, despite any problems presented by poultryless Thursday.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. -- The Protestant Episcopal church in the United States was lled upon today to repudiate its 'Ivory tower' label and to begin immediately a ministry of peronal evangelism geared to reach he unchurched masses of the American people.

LONDON, Nov. 6 -- Kate Kinnear Irwin, an emphatic South Irishwoman with more determination than political predictability, has thrown the antique dealing center of Kensington Church Street into something of a furor by displaying prominently in her antique shop window the sign, "We do not serve Americans here."

Harold E. Stassen said flatly last night that the nomination for the Vice Presidency on the Republican ticket for 1948, with Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower or Gen. Douglas MacArthur, as Presidential nominee, was unacceptable to him because he is "running for first place" and can count on 100 of the 130 votes of the delegates to the Republican national convention from six states in the Midwest.

MASSAPEQUA PARK, L.I., Nov. 7 -- The fifty-ton edifice of the former Methodist Church of Bellport arrived here soon after noon today after an uneventful thirty-five-mile trip on two scows through the calm waters of the Great South Bay.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Although President Truman sent congratulations today to the Soviet Union on the thirtieth anniversary of the October Revolution, for the first time he confined his expression to one of good wishes to the Russian people from the people of the United States.

A total of $1,277,000 toward the United Hospital Fund emergency drive for $2,400,000 has been raised, Roy E. Larsen, fund president, declared yesterday at a mid-campaign rally in Rockefeller Center. So pressed were many voluntary hospitals to meet expenses, he reported, that the fund was obliged to advance sums so they could cover operating costs.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Pledging their support to a sound state tax program, the New Jersey Educational Association urged today new taxes to finance all state services.

GOLDEN MEADOW, La., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Fall tornadoes, which skipped about over Louisiana and East Texas overnight, left a toll of four dead, a baby missing and possibly a score of persons injured. Property damage was estimated at many thousands of dollars as the storms roared down on scattered communities, razing nearly two-score homes.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- Maggy Rouff's collection is devoted to Christmas party gowns, Riviera ensembles and winter sports. Spectacular crinoline skirts, in magnificent fabrics, especially gleaming satins, are set on tight bodices that drop gracefully off the shoulder but have short puff sleeves.

American imports of Wedgwood dinnenvare for the current year will exceed those for 1946 by 25 per cent and "will steadily increase during the first quarter of 1948," Hensley Wedgwood, president, Josiah Wedgwood Sons of America, Inc., American branch of the English china producer, said yesterday.

James Monroe's powerful eleven kept its undefeated record intact yesterday by trouncing Seward Park 26 -- 7, on its home gridiron. It marked the President's third victory in four games, the other ending in a tie with Evander. Seward suffered its fourth loss without a triumph this season.

FOSSTON, Minn., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Two juvenile "bad men" who obtained six rifles and 10,000 rounds of ammunition in an all-night burglarizing spree held off a band of citizens and authorities for two hours today in western thriller style.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Poultryless Thursday was scratched from the conservation calendar late today by the Citizens Food Committee.

Long-distance scoring punch, enabled New York University's freshman football team to defeat Columbia's junior varsity, 24-0, at Baker Field yesterday. The Violets. tallied three times in the first half and added their final score on the first play of the fourth period.

The Greyhound Corporation has abandoned, at least for the time being, its plan to built a $10,000,000 fourteen-story bus terminal land office building at Eighth Avenue and Thirty-third Street, it was learned last night.
Less aggressive trade demand caused cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday to close 1 to 13 points net lower than the day before.

The same ingenuity that the housewife is using today to comply with the food conservation program by avoiding waste is exercised on a much larger scale in the kitchens of establishments like the Hotel Edison. However, it's not the one-man job it is at home, we learned yesterday when we talked with Irving Kramer, managing director of the Edison, and Paul Scagliola, the head chef.

MOSCOW, Nov. 7 -- The Soviet Union's traditional military-civilian parade marched thrgugh a sleetbeaten Red Square on the thirtieth anniversary of the Bolshevik revolution today before a distinguished audience of Soviet leaders and foreigners, but conspicuously absent were the Ambassador and representatives of the armed forces of the United States.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The National Marine Shipbuilders Association of America, an independent union revived at a struck Bethlehem shipbuilding yard here, today petitioned the National Labor Relations Board for a collective bargaining election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, now retired, the air materiel officer who approved a war contract for Howard Hughes, acknowledged today that after the start of investigations into that arrangement he had vainly importuned Mr. Hughes for $50,000 "on an investment basis."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, announced today the membership of an inter-service committee which will study the reorganization of the reserve components to fit them for modern warfare.

Giuseppe de Luca, giving his Golden Jubilee concert last night in Town Hall, was performing just fifty years and a day after his operatic debut, at the age of 21, as Valentin in Faust in Piacenza, Italy. Few if any other famous singers have had as long and distinguished a career as he.

Despite austerity, British travel and tourist organisations are preparing to welcome next year more than 200,000 United States visitors -- and their precious exchange dollars -- as a result of the British Travel Association's "Come-toBritain-in-1948" advertising campaign, an association spokesman disclosed yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 7 -- A new dispute between the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union and the Waterfront Employers Association delayed the loading of eleven ships in this port today, but an order from James Kearney, president of Local 10 of the union, issued late this afternoon, was to send longshoremen back to work at midnight.

More Gold Talk Although emphasizing that no details have been provided, financial observers asserted yesterday that reports that the United States was considering the export of $3,000,000,000 in gold for European currency-stabilization purposes, had a "dream-like" quality.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Nov. 7 -- The statement that Marshall plan action is indispensable to the economy of the Netherlands is contained in a commentary on the national budget, issued today over the signatures of Premier Louis J. M. Beel and Minister of Finance Pieter Lieftinck.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Nov. 7 -- A strike at the plants of WilkesBarre's two daily newspapers, the Wilkes-Barre Record, morning, and the Times Leader Evening News was averted tonight when representatives of the WilkesBarre Publishing Company and Local 187, Typographical Union, settled their differences after a nine-week discussion.

GENEVA, Nov. 7 -- Three sharply defined views on the control of international air traffic developed, at today's meeting of the International Civic Aviation Organization's commission on a multilateral air convention.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Grain markets showed a strong undertone on the Board of Trade today. Official reports indicate that comparatively little moisture was received in the dry sections of the winter wheat belt, and with a lack of selling pressure wheat futures closed 3 to 4% cents a bushel higher than yesterday.

Such is the popular hysteria engendered by the Army-Notre Dame game-and this is one of the prime reasons for the discontinuance of the series after today -- that advance news of many other worthy contests the country over virtually has been drowned in the flood of stories emanating from South Bend and West Point.

Reporting on operations of the American Zinc Lead and Smelting Company and its subsidiaries. Howard I. Young, president, informed stockholders yesterday that the company has concluded negotiations for a five-year $3,000,000 term loan with four banks.

Secretary Forrestal's appointment of an interdepartmental committee to study and make recommendations on the cumbersome and overlapping reserve systems within the military establishment, especially the duplication of effort between the National Guard and the Organized Reserves, gives hope for a long-overdue reorganization and unification of our second line of defense.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei T. Vishinsky told the Russian people today that Moscow would continue its struggle against "war propaganda" and "instigators" of a new world conflict.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- The pent-up resentment of many members of the United Nations against the use of the veto to bar new members from the organization found an outlet today in twenty-three resolutions and a flood of angry speeches before the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 7-- Denying assertions that the radiation laboratory at the University of California, a center of atomic research, was wide open to sabotage, A.P. Pollman, area manager for the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that "all areas where classified work of the commission is conducted are under adequate protection."

HANOI, French Indo - China, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Survivors said today that native Viet Nam forces ambushed a forty-truck French convoy on Oct. 30 near the Chinese border near Tkhat Khe, killing up to thirty French soldiers and fifty Annamese laborers working for the French Viet Nam casualties were unknown.

WEST CHESTER, Pa. Nov. 7 -- West Chester Teachers College turned Crazy Horse Joe Carlozo loose against City College of New York before 5,000 fans on Wayne Field here tonight and he romped to four touchdowns in a 47-0 victory.
WASHINGTON. Nov. 7 AP -- The Department of Agriculture said today there is a possibility that its flue-cured tobacco buying program, as announced Oct. 28, may not be carried out.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Minnesota's first taste of 1947-48 winter weather came today in blinding snow and high wind which slowed traffic, closed some schools and disrupted communications.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Nov. 7 -- The Girl Scout organization, with its membership of over 1,250,000, can be an important national force in the current war of ideologies, Mrs. Paul Rittenhouse of New York, national director of the organization, said today.

One thousand representatives of industry, labor, the judiciary and the public attended a dinner last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in honor of Edward C. Maguire, who was sworn in on Thursday as City Commissioner of Commerce, and who was former director of the City Division of Labor Relations.
SOUTH BEND. Ind., Nov. 7 -- Thirty-four years after Jesse Harper took a group of eighteen players to West Point, the call was returned by an Army football team today.

The stock market pushed closer yesterday to the low level reached last week when moderate selling found no sustained support. The retreat was accompanied again by a slow business, and price alterations, except in a few thin-market issues, remained in the fractions, with the combined averages lowered 0.62 point on the day.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 7 -- Fisk University, which was established here in 1866 by the American Missionary Association and the Western Preedmen's Association, inducted today as president, Charles Spurgeon Johnson, head of the department of social sciences since 1928.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 -- A kleig-lighted Hollywood gala party, replete with bands and movie stars, tonight sped the Friendship Food Train on its tenday cross-country tour to gather contributions for Europe.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- The Soviet Union today charged Utterly that the United States and Great Britain had flagrantly vioated all international agreements an refugees. The attack, launched by Valerian A. Zorin of the Russian delegation, preceded the seting up, by the Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee, of the United Nations General Assembly, of a drafting subcommittee to reconcile the views of four conflicting resolutions.

PARIS, Nov. 7 -- The National Federation of the French Press voted today at its annual congress in Marseille to renew its efforts to get representation on the administrative council of the Havas agency, which controls most of the newspaper advertising in France.

Funeral services for Peter V. Cacchione, one of the two Communist members of the City Council, will be held at noon tomorrow in Livingston Hall, Schermerhorn and Nevins Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Cacchione's fellow Communist in the City Council, Benjamin J. Davis, will preside.

The consumer, service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: Time-and-fuel saving get top billing in today's menu combination. The feature is stuffed hamburgers, with Hubbard squash and raisin-rice pudding sharing oven space.

Emmet Lavery, president of the Screen Writers Guild, who testified last week before the House unAmerican Affairs Committee that he was not a Communist, acknowledged yesterday the right of Congress to hold investigative hearings, but advocated that the law be changed to grant more rights to those who testify.

Ray Lev, who is in the first rank of young American pianists, had to sit for minutes before starting her Carnegie Hall recital last night, waiting for late-comers to settle down in the top balcony. But as soon as she began, the large audience became attentive, and was rewarded with a program full of variety and performing of artistry.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 7 (Reuters) -- Hungary must refute as "unfounded" Lord Vansittart's statement in the British House of Lords Wednesday about violation of the human rights clause of the peace treaties, Ivan Boldiszar, Hungarian Under - Secretary of State, said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The stark fact is that, in varying degrees, the peoples and nations of Europe are enduring serious economic ill health.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 7 -- The United States Ambassador today disabused the Peronista press of a notion that it had nursed. James Bruce reiterated his contention that Argentina was not the victim of a United States "economic blockade."

When the autumn exhibition of the Horticultural Society of New York closes this afternoon on the Penn Top of the Pennsylvania Hotel, it will have set a new record quietly. This is the oldest flower show in New York and has been presented consecutively for forty years.
PARIS, Nov. 7 -- Strikes were extending throughout the public services of Paris today as Government measures to control food prices provoked protests among the dealers in the Paris markets.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The open letter of Eric Johnst demanding that Congress reform investigatory procedure, poses am a challenge to fair-minded legislate which they have ignored too long.

Spring buying which was accelerated with opening of better coa and suit lines will reach its peal in the next twenty days, according to resident buying offices yesterday. There is a marked tendency to buy, it was emphasized, and order -placing was general almost immediately after lines were shown.
SPRINGFIELD, Vt., Nov. 7 (AP) -- Meat rationing without price controls was proposed today by Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican, of Vermont, as the only way he knew to check spiraling prices.

All types of lenders in the consumer installment credit field are generally "holding the line" and there was little or no expansion of terms in the first week after the expiration of Regulation W, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday.

Trade-Gains Here Level Off Recent retail trade gains here leveled off this week. Department store volume was expected to show little average change from the like week a year ago. Comparison, however, was with the extremely large sales figures of the week which followed the end of the trucking and delivery strike in 1946.

The report of the committee of seven ministers Who visited Yugoslavia recently to learn the extent of religious freedom in that country, was presented yesterday morning at the Broadway Congregational Tabernacle, Broadway and Fifty-sixth Street, at a closed meeting of more than 250 clergymen, a number of whom asked questions about the observations and conclusions in the findings.

Armistice Sunday will be observed by many religious organizations tomorrow. Catholic War Veterans will attend the 10 A.M. solemn mass tomorrow in St. Patrick's Cathedral. The sermon will be preached by the Rev. Charles J. Hacherl, national chaplain of he Catholic War Veterans.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Eleven labor leaders appeared before the Joint Congressional Housing Committee today to "clean their skirts" of "unjustified" charges that union "feather bedding" and restrictive practices have increased home building costs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Gov. Ernest Gruening of Alaska declared today that the Northern Territory "has been, and is being, grossly discriminated against" by the Federal Government in "many matters, including ground, sea and air transportation."

The Erasmus Hall football team held Manual Training to a 12-12 tie in the thirty-ninth annual meeting of the two teams before 16,083 fans at Ebbets. Field last night. In the opener, Brooklyn Tech recorded its sixth successive triumph by defeating Boys High, 21 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The making of peace with Western Germany by the Western Allies in event of a breakdown of the meeting of the Council of Foreign Ministers in London late this month was regarded as a strong possibility in diplomatic circles here today.

Network television service on a coast-to-coast basis within two years was foreseen yesterday by Prank E. Mullen. NBC executive vice president. He appeared on the "Swift Home Service Club," which yesterday became the first com mercial program to be sponsored regularly on a video chain.

Seeking their second victory of the season, against an offense minded Bucknell University eleven, New York University's forces are a slight favorite to triumph in the fifth meeting of the teams today at Yankee Stadium. The kick-off is at 2 P.M., and a crowd of 12,000 is expected.

LUDINGTON, Mich., Saturday, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Coast Guard reported early today that the crippled freighter Jupiter had been able to drop anchor about three miles off-shore in stormy Lake Michigan and was virtually out of danger.

Net profit of the Chrysler Corporation and its wholly-owned United States subsidiaries in the nine months ended with last September rose to $47,873,089 from $10,292,645 reported for the first nine months of 1946, according to the statement of K.T. Keller, president, mailed yesterday to stockholders.

The possibility that the transit fare rise favored by Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate may apply to the municipal bus and street car lines as well as the subways arose yesterday when it was learned that the Mayor had directed his Executive Committee on Administration to re-examine the recommendation made in its report of July 1.

Moore-McCormack Lines, Inc., in a report for the first nine months of this year, showed an increase in net earnings after taxes to $7,134,986 from the $2,610,257 net earned in the corresponding period a year ago.

A series of unhappy events has plagued India since Aug. 15 when Britain turned over power to the two Dominions of the Indian Union and Pakistan. Now the two nations have reached the critical stage where they must take stock of their conflicts and decide on future consequences.

The housing shortage caught up, yesterday, with 14-day-old twins whose parents had been trying for a year to find a new home. The newborn boys, with three older children, were taken by their parents to the Welfare Department's shelter at 8 East Third Street.
Children throughout the United States are promoting world peace through their own "Marshall Plan" which calls for sending Christmas and Hanukkah gifts to youngsters in sixteen countries overseas.
PARIS, Nov. 7 (U.P.) -- Peace in battle-torn Indo-China by Christmas was predicted by French and foreign diplomatic officials in Paris today.

The Federal Social Security Administration, which contributed $22,718,000 toward meeting New York's relief budget in the last year, is keeping a close watch on, the progress of current state and city investigations into the work of the Welfare Department, it was learned yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 7 -- The National Cooperative Milk Producers Federation condemned the International Trade Organization today as a step by which the State Department was driving the country into new international entanglements that might take years of unpleasant consequences to end.

No stone, not to mention a considerable amount of the soft Yankee Stadium turf, is being left unturned by Coach Ray Flaherty and his assistants in bringing the football Yankees up for tomorrow's important All America Conference battle with the San Francisco Forty -Niners.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 7 -- United States District Judge Richard S. Rodney today ruled against the Government in the anti-trust suit against the Columbia Steel Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation.

Short range shipboard radar received its first public operational test in this area. Thursday night when a New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad tug hauled two fully loaded car floats from the Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, yards to the Greenville, Jersey City terminal under simulated zero visibility conditions.

Col. Franklin F. Wing Jr. of the United States Army team made the Bowman Challenge Cup put up by the late John McEntee Bowman in 1930 his permanent property before a cheering whistling crowd of 13.500 in Madison Square Garden last night.
