MEXICO CITY, Nov. 7 -- Italy, Austria, Hungary and Switzerland were admitted into the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization by the second General Assembly during a plenary session held this afternoon in the Normal Teachers College.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Nov. 7 -- A resolution sharply critical of "inquisitorial" investigations into the personal beliefs of an individual was unanimously adopted today by the House of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the United States at the close of its four-day special meeting.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- The Soviet Union will continue its determined fight against the United Nations "Little Assembly" by campaigning to block funds for its budget, it was reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Members of the House Labor subcommittee investigating the wagehour act suggested today that if unions want the 40-cent minimum wage raised to meet higher living costs they should be ready to advocate a lower minimum when living costs go down.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- United States proposed that Assembly pass on qualifications of each of eleven pending applicants for United Nations membership and make recommendations to Security Council.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 7 -- Mme. Ana Pauker, one of the two Rumanians who helped recently to set up the nine-nation Communist Information Bureau and who is reportedly the only person in this country who can reach Soviet Premier Stalin by telephone at any time, became Foreign Minister of Rumania today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y.; Nov. 7 -- If the United Nations General Assembly decides to hold its next session in Geneva, the move would add $1,336,344 to the organization's budget, according to the estimate of financial experts here.

The official American survey of Japanese industrial facilities has proceeded about on schedule and probably will be completed for the Secretary of the Army early next year, Clifford S. Strike, president of Overseas Consultants, Inc., New York engineering firm, revealed in a telephone interview from Hartford, Conn., yesterday.

The Marine Shark, Governmentowned vessel operated by American Export Lines, will be placed in the laid-up, fleet as the result of her crew's 'refusal to sign on, it was learned yesterday. The vessel's voyage to the Mediterranean was canceled on election day, following the crew's action.

Recent Conservative party victories in British municipal elections were described here yesterday by Sir Norman Angell, author and lecturer, as the "natural reaction against promises of a party" before it came into power.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- Bituminous coal production reached almost 13,000,000 tons last week, the Office of Defense Transportation estimated today on the basis of carloading reports.

An anthology about doctors, entitled "400 Years of a Doctor's Life," will be issued by Henry Schuman on Monday. The volume was collected and arranged by Dr. George Rosen and Dr. Beate Caspari-Rosen, selecting passages from the writings of more than eighty doctors and arranged to form composite portraits of typical physicians.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- An increase this year of $48,276,931 in the assessed valuations on real estate in Westchester was reported today by the County Tax Commission, making a new total of $1,545,970,557 to be used in determining 1948 taxes.

Organized participation in public affairs was urged upon 500 Roman Catholics at a luncheon yesterday afternoon at St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church, Duane Street and Cardinal Hayes Place, by the pastor, Msgr. Joseph A. Nelson.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Nov. 7 -- Indian army troops killed from 300 to 500 raiders in a pitched battle this morning about five and one half miles from Srinagar, capital of Kashmir State.

BRIELLE, N.J., Nov. 7 -- Harry Kroh, newly elected Mayor here, promised today that there will be no more "secret meetings" in City Hall and during his term in office municipal business will be conducted "out in the open."

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 -- Charles Luckman, head of the Citizens Food Committee, said tonight that the newly announced plan for saving grain in the poultry industry was the result of a three-week struggle with the poultry producers in which the nation's dinner tables were the arena and "poultryless Thursday" was "our only weapon."

The City of Worcester. Mass., sold a new issue of 1,020.000 of water and sewerage bonds due Oct. 1 from 1948 to 1957 to the Chase National Bank and Salomon Brothers Hutzler at a bid of 100.385 for 1 1/4s. The bonds were priced on reoffering to yield from 0.70 per cent to 1.25 per cent, according to maturity.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 7 (AP) -- Ridgewood Stable's Double Jay, voted last year's leading 2-year-old but a disappointment so far this season, notched his most important victory today by taking the $25,000 added Riggs Handicap at Pimlico.

Two Government agencies, the State Department and the Advisory Committee on Voluntary Foreign Relief, expressed surprise yesterday concerning the shipment from here three weeks ago of surplus radar and radio parts to the Yugoslavian Red Cross.

The purchase of 130 new buses by the Board of Transportation without public bidding was approved yesterday at a special meeting of the Board of Estimate. The buses, which conform to city specifications, will be placed in operation in Brooklyn and Queens.

Detailed but sometimes confused questioning aimed at determining whether American International Airways had violated economic as well as safety regulations of the Civil Aeronautics Board marked the opening here yesterday of the CAB hearing into the forced landing of the Bermuda Sky Queen in the North Atlantic last month with sixty-nine persons aboard.

ROME, Nov. 7 -- Left-wing Socialist leader Pietro Nenni and Communist Jeader Palmiro Togliatti attacked the foreign policy of the United States in speeches de Evered today at the celebration o the thirtieth anniversary of the Rusian revolution.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 7 (Aneta) -- The price trend on the Stock Exchange reversed that of the last several days and with few exceptions stocks generally showed higher levels. Royal Dutch Petroleum rose 3 3/4 points, reducing further the sharp decline of mid-week.

CHICAGO Nov. 7 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs. 6.000 head: total. 10.500. Market steady to 25 cents lower: mostly steady with average of yesterday but 25 cents or more under early trade Thursday: top $25.25 for

Refusal to work is not in itself a reason for dropping clients from the relief rolls, according to testimony of witnesses yesterday before the State Board of Social Welfare committee inquiring into the city Welfare Department's administration of relief.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 7 -- O. John Rogge, former special assistant to Attorney General Tom C. Clark, charged today that the latter's office had been intentionally "leaking to picked newspaper men" reports about the special Federal grand jury investigation of subversive activities which has been in progress in New York since June.

BERLIN, Nov. 7-- The thirtieth anniversary of the October Revolution was celebrated by the Soviet commander in Potsdam tonight with more than 1,000 representatives of the Western powers in attendance at a reception.

International amity can be strengthened through international student exchange programs as demonstrated by the "transatlantic campus" set up between Norway and the United States, the ambassadors of both countries declared yesterday.

The abolition of war and all its weapons is the only certain way to protect civilization from the modern agents of destruction, George W. Merck, former head of the wartime Biological warfare program, said last night before the American Section of the Society of Chemical Industry at the Hotel Commodore.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- The dress that Queen Elizabeth will wear for the wedding of Princess Elizabeth and Lieut Philip Mountbatten on Nov. 20 will be colored apricot and gold and will have a pointed train. The Queen also will wear the Order of the Garter.

Marking the first broad phase of its investigation of current practices in installment sales financing, the New York State Joint Legislative Committee on Installment Financing on Monday will send detailed questionnaires to 900 automobile dealers and about 250 banks and finance companies in this city.

Three days after the unanimous adoption by the U.N. General Assembly of a resolution meant to discourage what Mr. Vishinsky called "warmongering," Mr. Molotov has let fly in Moscow with an address in which he describes British and American policies as "steeped in open imperialism."

Television receivers of a "portable" type, said to be capable of reproducing video and sound programs from electrical impulses conveyed to them over wires from centralized television tuners in the suilding, will be installed soon in forty rooms of the Hotel Roosevelt and charged for at the rate of $3 daily for guests desiring the service, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- The House Select (Herter) Committee on Foreign Aid agreed unanimously today that a new Government corporation, endowed with sweeping powers, would be required to administer any program of foreign aid, temporary or long range, which the Congress might authorize.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (AP) -- The Chicago Rockets gained their first victory in eleven attempts this year in the All-America Football Conference when they upset the Baltimore Colts, 27 to 21, before a frigid crowd of 5,395 in Soldier Field tonight.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 7 -- The Delaware Power and Light Company, Wilmington, Del., and the Georgia Power Company, Atlanta, Ga., each filed a registration statement today with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering issues of $10,000,000 of thirtyyear bonds.

Six men and three women who for various reasons never had an opportunity to finish high school but who feel that it is never too late to get an education, received their state high school equivalency diplomas yesterday in a ceremony held at the Board of Education.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Apparently deadlocked over the Soviet Union's plan for the partition of Palestine and the United States' proposal to accomplish this aim, a United Nations group composed of representatives of the United States, Russia, Canada and Guatemala will meet here tomorrow to attempt to reconcile the opposing views.

Mr. Molotov evidently made a sensation in Moscow when he announced at the thirtieth anniversary celebration of Soviet rule that the secret of the atom bomb "has long ceased to exist." It took a moment for the statement to sink in; then pandemonium broke loose. The listeners sprang to their feet and cheered wildly.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- A process for the mildew-proofing of textiles was one of the 468 inventions patented this week in the United States Patent Office.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 7 -- With the tax reduction issue now definitely barred from the special session agenda, House Republican leaders laid strategy today for making the greatest possible political capital out of it in the 1948 Presidential election year.
Columbia will play Dartmouth at Baker Field today without the services of its stellar ball carrier, Lou Kusserow.

WARSAW, Nov. 7 -- Official Poland celebrated the thirtieth anniversary of the Russian Revolution with unprecedented fervor today, hailing Moscow as the "mainstay of peace." Premier Stalin was acclaimed as the "leader of world peace."

MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 7 -- One of the most graphic documents that has yet come to light in support of testimony that Adolf Hitler and his closest associates grossly underestimated the war potential of the United States was released this afternoon at Nuremberg.
Reports on the Chesapeake waterfowl opening were excellent, although the puddle ducks seemed to outnumber the divers by a large margin.

Testimonials of the rehabilitative influences of the Salvation Army's men's social service centers were given last night by a former Methodist minister and a retired Salvationist, among several other speakers, at a service here commemorating the golden jubilee of the centers.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- While British official comment today on Soviet Foreign Minister Molotov's speech yesterday was confined to a regretful reference to its "unfortunate" timing, public opinion as expressed in newspaper editorials saw it as intended mainly for internal consumption.

America's foundry production is now more than 130 per cent above 1939 levels, and if further availability of scrap, pig iron, skilled labor and coke is provided, 1948 output will set another new hign record, officials of the National Founders Association revealed in reports to more than 150 members during the second day of their 50th annual meeting at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday.
SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 7 (AP) -- "A strike under the guidance of any union unwilling to declare its allegiance to the United States should be enjoined," County Judge Will Leach said today.

The Broadway premiere of "The Gentleman From Athens" will take place on Thursday evening, Dec. 11, at the Mansfield Theatre. Arrangements for booking the attraction into the Michael Myerberg playhouse were concluded yesterday. Featuring Anthony Quinn, Edith Atwater, Gavin Gordon and Alan Hewitt, the Emmet Lavery comedy opens its pre-New York run at the Playhouse in Wilmington, Del., on Nov. 28.

WOOSTER, Ohio, Nov. 7 (AP) -- A Common Pleas Court jury today awarded an Amish farmer $5,000 in damages after he contended that four church officials had imposed an Amish "mite" or boycott against him and that he had been socially ostracized for the past five years.

VIENNA, Nov. 7 -- A reliable Rumanian source stated here today that King Michael of Rumania, was expected to be an early victim of increased Communist pressure at Bucharest, for which this signal was given by the recent formation of the Communists' International Information Bureau.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 7 -- George F. Addes secretarytreasurer of the United Automobile Workers, Congress of Industrial Organizations, called tonight for a "fighting program" for 1948, one of the key features of which would be the building of an international strike fund of 55,000,000.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 7 -- Dr. Ivan Kerno, Assistant Secretary General of the United Nations in charge of legal affairs, will head the secretariat attached to the special committee on the Balkan question that the General Assembly is sending to Greece, Secretary General Trygve Lie announced today.

Stymie will be at Jamaica today -- but he'll stay in his stall in the barn up beyond the far turn. The world money champion is trough for the season; Trainer Hirsch Jacobs made that announcement after the winner of $816,060 "didn't look right" in his morning setting-up exercises yesterday.

The Metropolitan Opera stole a march on itself last night by putting on a performance of "Don Giovanni" several evenings ahead of the formal opening on Monday. With "Don Giovanni," the company was putting its best foot forward.

TO THE EDITOR OF NEW YORK TIMES: Nearly everyone who spoke to me of England, after my return a few weeks ago, said: "It must be a pretty grim place. Is there so much starvation? Do you think they will ever come back?"

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 -- Year-round production in industry was praised today by an official of the International Harvester Company, who cited benefits under the program through improved labor relations, greater dealer and branch office confidence and more efficient operation of facilities.

LONDON, Nov. 7 -- Middle Witwatersrand gold shares opened with a fresh burst of activity in the stock markets here today despite an overnight warning from the controlling company that nothing was known about good results from borehole tests.

CHICAGO, Nov. 7 (U.P.) --Publishers Auxiliary, a newspaper trade publication, said today that first returns from a poll of country editors showed a majority favored President Truman for re-election. It said 98 per cent of them believed he would be renominated.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 7 -- Marlene Dietrich has been signed by Paramount to star with Jean Arthur and John Lund in "A Foreign Affair," which Charles Brackett will produce and Billy Wilder will direct from a photoplay by Wilder and Robert Harari.

Moby Dick Spouts Again Lured by the book Van Wyck Brooks wrote a short time ago about the world of Washington Irving, and also by the recent opening to public inspection of Irving's Tarrytown home, this column has re-read some of the writ ing's of that urbane master, and savored, with particular delight, The Legend of Sleepy Hollow.
Blanket increases in pier rentals paid by steamship lines to the city for use of docking facilities will be applied in the near future, it became known yesterday.

JUST the other week Christopher Isherwood was saying that if he had to be any other writer (in terms of his writing and not of his personal life) he would like to be Chekhov. Mr. Isherwood, I assume, meant that he felt the warmest personal admiration for the Russian's work.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Overcoming a 6-0 halftime deficit, the University of Rochester notched a third period touchdown to shade Vermont, 7 -- 6, before 4,000 here today for its fourth straight football victory and sixth in seven starts this season.

Reduction by 60 per cent of the cost of treating tuberculosis patients with streptomycin with no lessening of the effectiveness of the drug is reported in Science by. Drs. H.J. Corper and M.L. Conn of the Jewish Hospital at Denver, the country's oldest medical center for free treatment of tuberculosis on a non-sectarian basis.

LONDON -- Travel agency plans for attracting tourists to the fourteenth Summer Olympic Games to be held in Britain from July 29 to Aug. 14, 1948, are as yet only half formed. Final outcome depends, according to the agencies, on the amount of shipping available next year.

WHEN Picasso strode forth to retaliate against the bombing of an ancient Basque village by Franco and his Nazi cohorts, he wielded the sheet-lightning and the scalding pitch of a prophet. Descending to the very pit of destruction, he threw out his forked intelligence and impaled the brute forces trying to stamp out the life of the Spanish people.

Recent dispatches from Costa Rica have told of political troubles there, some of which have culminated in violence. DUBLIN, Nov. 8 -- Dublin's famous Abbey Theatre was the scene tonight of an unexpected protest against the present low standards of its productions during presentation of Sean O'Casey's play "The Plough and the Stars."
BUCHAREST, Nov. 8 -- Rumania celebrated today the second half of her unique two-day holiday combination, the anniversary of the Russian revolution and the name day of King Michael.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- The administration of the industrial areas of the Ruhr and the Rhineland by an international organization that would include the United States but exclude the Soviet Union is advocated by the International Committee for the Study of European Questions.

The troubled conditions in the world have placed a greater emphasis on the need for unity among the Americas, according to political and diplomatic leaders of North and South America who joined yesterday in the annual luncheon sponsored by the Pan American Women's Association.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The newspaper of the Czech National Socialist party accused Communist Premier Klement Gottwald and his supporters today of attempting to set up in Czechoslovakia a "corporative system, as Mussolini did in Italy."

With the first group of houses nearing completion, a sprawling community of 1,000 homes that will represent an investment of $10,000,000 is under development at Wantagh, L.I., on the road to Jones Beach. Plans for speeding up the work were announced yesterday by N.K. Winston of Winston-Holzer Associates, the builders and developers, who has just returned from the West Coast where his firm is buying an interest in an Oregon lumber mill.

Rebuilding of unit sales of merchandise promises to be a major undertaking of retailers ranging from chains to department stores and specialty shops, it was indicated here last week. The actual decline in unit volume, ranging from 5 to 15 per cent or more, has been obscured by the rise in dollar sales to a new peak, but is of major importance in the promotional and expense picture of many retailers.
PUCCINI'S opera, "La Tosca," will inaugurate this season's Metropolitan Opera broadcasts over WJZ and the American Broadcasting Company network. Air time will be 2 o'clock next Saturday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The formal appearance of Gov. Thomas E. Dewey of New York, still the leading candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1948, in the forum where a national debate of great issues has been going on for some time, came at a moment when the Democrats were beginning to acquire confidence that President Truman will be reelected regardless of the make-up of the Republican ticket. CHICAGO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- With the 1948 crop wheat contracts in the lead, grains pushed slowly upward again today on the Board of Trade. Some mill buying was noted in wheat, but there were no reports of activity in the cash wheat market by the Commodity Credit Corporation.

TO THE EDITOR: While no disparagement of Professor Nevins' interesting and informative article on the Library of Congress, "10 Million Readers, 23 Million Books," nor on the Library of Congress itself, is intended, I should like to say, "Why don't you speak for yourself, John?"

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Southern California's Trojans trudged on toward the Rose Bowl today, subduing a surprisingly stubborn band of Stanford Indians, 14 to 0, before 59,749 fans in Memorial Coliseum.
LIEUT. COL. LAUREN SHAW, commander of the Illinois National Guard, offered Guardsmen a 2-cents-a-pound on-the-hoof bounty for recruits brought in.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Careful analysis of the voting in the municipal elections which resulted in wholesale defeat of the Labor candidates indicates that its significance is rather less than Tory spokesmen would like the public to believe and considerably greater than the Socialists are willing to concede.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 8 -- The police this week have banned two more political meetings on technical grounds. The circumstances seem impossible of justification from the point of view of believers in what are commonly considered basic civil rights in a democracy.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, said today he was convinced that John L. Lewis, through his daughter, Kathryn L. Lewis, had poured "hundreds of thousands" of dollars into a left-wing campaign to defeat the head of the UAW for re-election.

So clearly are the lines being drawn, however, in this battle of words and ideologies that shooting may once again supplant the shouting unless positive American leadership is promptly and prudently exerted to help restore good sense and sound government in Europe.

DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Missouri's ball-hiding backfield beat a path around Duke's ends and clicked with passes over its secondary today to run up a stinging 28-to-7 upset victory, the biggest margin ever scored over a Blue Devil team coached by Wallace Wade.

DETROIT, Mich., Nov. 8 -- Broad criticism of automobile manufacturers, new and used car dealers and state departments as contributing factors in the automobile black market were contained in the report of a grand jury investigation made public here today.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- "The common people of New York State want good public schools but the state has yet to provide a sound basic plan to make them possible," Arthur Boehm of Schenectady, president of the Empire Federation of Teachers Unions, AFL, told the group's annual convention here today.

Last October the Bombay correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES reported that the Indian Government's foremost research station, the Haffkine Institute in Bombay, was working night and day to produce three million cubic centimeters of cholera vaccine for Egypt. About two weeks later news came from Palestine that the Hebrew University of Jerusalem had offered to send anti-cholera vaccine to Egypt in tens of thousands and even millions of units.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- Authoritative reports reaching here on the Anglo-American conference on the finances of the economically merged United States and British zones disclose that the principal obstacle in the way of an agreement is the unwillingness of the British to promise the convertibility, if required, of more than L50,000,000 [about $200,000,000] accumulated through export proceeds here.

SALT LAKE CITY. ALTHOUGH ranchers, miners and business men in and around 125 towns in eight western states are as yet unaware of the fact, a band of eleven hopeful troupers plans to make the initials B-M-T as well-known between the Rocky Mountains and the Sierras as in Flat-bush, Bensonhurst and other way stations on New York's grimy subway.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- Although the Pennsylvania power house blew a fuse or two at Franklin Field today it finally proved to a throng of 78,000 fans that it was a better team than Virginia's Cavaliers by scoring a 19-to-7 triumph to remain among the unbeaten and untied.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 8 -- The Amherst College football team defeated Rensselaer Polytechnic, 7 -- 6, today in a driving rain. All the scoring occurred in the first six minutes, as the field was soon churned to a morass of six-inch mud.

Marking the thirtieth birthday of the Russian revolution, crack Soviet Army troops marched through Red Square under the eyes of top members of the Politburo. Thousands of civilians also marched, carrying placards denouncing the United States.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 8 -- The largest unauthorized transport operation of Jewish refugees to Palestine is ready to get under way from Rumanian shores, according to eyewitness reports today.

The song was the thing at Town Hall last night, when Richard Dyer-Bennet, latter day minstrel, sang to the accompaniment of his own guitar. The young performer, who has devoted years to the study of his art and runs a school to teach it, gripped the large audience with the intensity and simplicity of his messages.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 8 -- Labeled by local experts and any number of disgruntled alumni as "the weakest Harvard football team in years," the Crimson eleven proved the critics right today. Limited to a net gain of four yards along the ground, the crippled Cantabs bowed to Princeton, 33-7, in a one-sided Ivy League game that emphasized the victors' superiority in every department.

IN the introduction to this book -- a book written by General Patton from the diary he personally kept until four days before his fatal automobile accident -- Douglas Southall Freeman writes, "It is to be hoped that General Patton will be among the first to attract a competent biographer and that others will leave him alone.

SLUMP or no slump in the production of Broadway musicals, this is obviously going to be another big year for the dancers in "show business." Already on view are "Allegro," which is in a class by itself since Agnes de Mille staged not only the dances but the entire production; "High Button Shoes" with Jerome Robbing as choreographer and director of all the musical numbers, and "Music in My Heart" with ballets by Ruth Page.

Despite the end of the war, the teacher shortage continues to be the major problem facing American education today, according to outstanding educators writing in the special November number of Survey Graphic, out yesterday.

IN showing the Henry L. Phillips collection of Japanese prints the Metropolitan Museum has provided the public with a wholly delightful exhibition. And, although this is incidental to the occasion from the museum's point of view, it has provided the artist and the art-minded with an exhibition which is decidedly provocative in relation to contemporary art.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Michigan State showed off its most powerful ground attack of the season as the Spartans literally snowed under Santa Clara, 28 to 0, today before 21,867 chilled fans who sat through snow flurries that at times almost obscured the playing field.

MR. Joe Louis is better known than Mr. Robinson Jeffers. Yet Mr. Jeffers, celebrated by fewer persons than the Brown Bomber, is a better writer. Which is by way of saying that the two best -- this is opinion, as opposed to provable conviction -- writers in this nation write anonymously -- Mr. E.B. White of The New Yorker, and Mr. Simeon Strunsky, the TIMES' Topicker.

The state executive committee of the Liberal party, after several hours of debate, announced yesterday its opposition to Mayor O'Dwyer's plan to ask the Legislature to empower the Board of Transportation, without a referendum, to increase the transit fare sufficiently to cover the operating costs of the entire municipal system.

THERE were (this novel informs us) certain private places in Victorian England devoted to sheltering children born out of wedlock. It is to a home of this sort that young Elizabeth "Smith" is brought by the lugubrious Mr. Mould, who represents the mother of a certain errant young lady of high birth.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Francis Cardinal Spellman's recent denunciation here of bigotry as contrary to American tradition and his rebuke to "men in the clothing of shepherds whose religion seems to have one principal dogma, discrimination of Catholic children, depriving them of public welfare services available to other American children," will bring a reply tomorrow in a statement to be distributed in Protestant churches of Onondaga County.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- As the political contest between East and West intensifies, western Europe, chief prize of this ideological battle, faces a general grain shortage and uncertain fuel supply in the third post-war winter. By millions of ordinary Frenchmen, Germans, Belgians and Italians the strength of communism and capitalism will be measured during the coming winter by what representatives of the two systems can do to alleviate their lot.

The story of a flight crew with-limited knowledge of Boeing flying boats and practically no experience in flying the North Atlantic was brought out slowly and painfully yesterday as the Civil Aeronautics Board continued its hearing into the forced landing of the Bermuda Sky Queen off Newfoundland last month.

The major problem confronting the free American industrial system today is that of making the worker feel that he is not merely a cog in a machine but a human being with an interest in the system and its problems, representatives of both management and labor agreed yesterday.

COLLEGE STATION, Tex., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Southern Methodist University resurrected its famed "aerial circus" today, blanking Texas A. M., 13 -- 0, to roll on, undefeated at the head of the Southwest Conference.

With the arrival Thursday of the liner America, flagship of the United States Lines, the 26,314-ton vessel will have rounded out her first year of regular transatlantic passenger service, completing seventeen round-trip voyages and carrying more than 32,000 passengers.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 8 (AP) -- A fourth-period Nebraska gamble that failed breathed new life into a Kansas football team today and the Jayhawkers pulled the ball game out of the fire with forty seconds left, winning13 to 7.

A recent proposal by Thomas G. Spates, vice president of personnel administration in the General Foods Corporation, that a course in human relations be made a requisite for a baccalaureate degree is meeting a lukewarm reception in educational circles as far as immediate action is concerned, it was learned last week.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Another blow was struck at Britain's dwindling diet today when John Strachey, Food Minister, announced that starting tomorrow potatoes would be rationed for the first time.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 8 -- Three fourth-period touchdowns by Harvey Grimsley of Orange, N.J., gave Rutgers University a 20-0 victory over Lafayette College today before 11,000 fans. The victory enabled Rutgers to retain the Middle Three crown.

'DECORATIONS in the Holiday Mood," a two-day program to be held in Times Hall on Nov. 18 and 19, will have a flower arrangement show in the lounge as well as talks and demonstrations. The four competitive classes, more than have been held in previous years, include decorations for Thanksgiving and Christmas, entrance hall arrangements for Christmas and corsages.

New York City's education system, facing many difficult problems in the immediate years ahead, has for one of its major objectives the development of closer relations between the schools and the community.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., Nov. 8 (AP) -- North Carolina, led by elusive Charlie Justice, scored almost at will to overwhelm North Carolina State, 41 to 6, in a Southern Conference football game played before 40,000 fans today.

IF actors were as vain and producers as mercenary as the cynics would have them, the actors would disdain self-improvement and the producers would disdain improvement of anyone but themselves. Without risking any generality to the contrary, it may be reported that some of Broadway's best players have joined enthusiastically to take lessons in acting.

Two performances of the Ice Follies of 1948 at the Madison Square Garden in the near future have been taken over to raise funds for philanthropic enterprises. Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys in Millington, N.J., will be the beneficiary on the night of Nov. 20.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (Science Service) -- The moon will come between the earth and the sun on Wednesday, Nov. 12. At that time the shadow cast by the moon win blot out a part of the sun's surface. An eclipse of the sun will result.
To the Drama Editor: SINCE John Gassner's opinion in praise of "Lamp at Midnight" was quoted in last Sunday's Mailbag, I feel it is in order to reproduce here a letter from Mr. Gassner:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- Taking cognizance of allegations made by the Standard Power and Light Corporation and its subsidiary, the Standard Gas and Electric Company, the Securities and Exchange Commission advanced today to next Wednesday the date for considering at a hearing here whether there should be any modification of its order of Oct. 30, which would prevent Standard Power and Light from voting on directors of Standard Gas and Electric on Dec. 3.

A DEBATABLE point in radio criticism always has been the question of when a program should be reviewed. Is it fair to render an opinion on the basis of one broadcast or is it the sounder policy to hear three or four installments before judging whether a show will make the grade?

ALL over the West in recent months whiskers have been blooming again. They have been cultivated for patriotic purposes, as part of frontier anniversaries and other civic uproars honoring the days of the beavered pioneers.
Almost one inch of rain, accompanied by winds that at one time reached sixty miles an hour, swept the metropolitan area yesterday, resulting in widespread damage.

IN his collection of biographical studies, "Genius and Character," published a good many years ago, Emil Ludwig, who then modeled himself upon Plutarch, attacked the historical novel as anti-historical, as "the bugbear of the genuine portraitist."

New York's subway riders poured 2,500,000,000 nickels ($125,000,000) into the city's transit turnstiles last year. This amount was 370,000,000 nickels ($18,500,000) less than the amount it cost the city to operate the transit system. During the present fiscal year ending next June 30, the deficit is expected to be $27,000,000; in the following year, $31,500,000.

FOR THIS WEEK: Pull up plants of annual flowers. Little if any bloom may be still expected even from petunias or verbena.... Since there has been rain, scatter grass seed on any thin spots in the lawn. Sowing of clover is better postponed until spring.... Mulch newly planted fruit, shrubs and trees.... Gather decaying apples and wormy fruit of any kind, and bury them at a distance to reduce trouble next year....
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 8 (AP) -- A high powered University of Delaware football team rolled to its third straight victory today, conquering Western Maryland College, 26 to 0, before a crowd of 5,000.

WAR pieces may be very distracting when there isn't a war on. They take such enormous and horrible things so seriously. How can one get back into the Battle of London -- how long ago was it? MR. MERRICK'S principals are Dunoan, a wartime merchant seaman, and a girl named Eve. To neither one of them had love meant much until they met at a seamen's club, where she was a volunteer parttime librarian.

IF you are so pessimistic as to believe that the good old days have really reached the vanishing point, the proof of it has come with the increase -- by 10 cents -- of the 49-cent price for books "remaindered" in the Concord Bookshops in Times Square.

WITH "Vivere in Pace" ("To Live in Peace") slated for its local premiers at the World Theatre on Nov. 24, this department checked with Gar Moore, an American actor and one of the featured players in the Italian importation.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 8 -- Mississippi's election of scholarly, conservative John Cornelius Stennis, 46-year-old, farm-born Circuit Judge, as successor to the late United States Senator Theodore Gilmore Bilbo, means, in the words of the victor, a "new day, new viewpoints and new faces" from this stronghold of Southern customs and traditions.

In just three months after its transformation from a former war plant to a center of peacetime industry, sprawling Plant No. 3 of the Wright Aeronautical Corporation at Fair Lawn, N.J., has taken in its fifteenth concern. The industrial "beehive" of thirty buildings on a forty-three-acre tract across the river from Paterson is humming with the activity of its five owner concerns and ten tenants.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Notre Dame's Frank Leahy and Army's Earl Blaik, following the Fighting Irish's triumph today over the cadets, agreed they had never before seen such a feat as Terry Brennan's 97-yard run-back of the opening kick-off for a Notre Dame touchdown.
FOOTBALL Scoring on the opening kickoff, Notre Dame routed Army yesterday in the last contest before suspension of relations between the schools. Scores of leading games:

Election day business last week in retail stores was good, despite the rain, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. Coat, fur, blouse and children's sections were reported active, as were housefurnishings and Christmas card departments.

SALEM, Ore., Nov. 8 -- Oregon, customarily placid and staid in contrast to its maverick neighbors along the Pacific seaboard, was stirred this week by some of the most unsettled and turbulent political conditions in its history. People were still stunned by the airplane crash, in the wilderness near Grizzly Peak which took the lives of Oregon's three ranking public officials.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Research scientists and Eastman Kodak executives yesterday viewed a three-dimensional panorama of the devastation wrought by Allied Air power on German cities.

"THE GOLD COOK BOOK" by Louis P. De Gouy will be found in many a kitchen where people want to cook rare dishes, strange and fine ones, foods that have foreign names, and so-called exotics. This book tells you how to make them at home.

Announcement last week by the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest producer of steel, that it has raised $60,000,000 through the private marketing of a bond issue to underwrite a portion of its huge improvement program may herald the start of a new era of steel financing, industrial observers believe.

OVER the ever-buzzing grapevine the other day came word that the Messrs. James Russo and Michael Ellis, stage managers for "Finian's Rainbow," are preparing a dish of Strindberg incarnate for midwinter.

ONE afternoon in 1844, in the little English town of Rochdale, twenty-eight weavers got together to try to better their miserable lot. The result was the establishment of the first consumer cooperative. The effects of this tiny economic revolution after more than a century have been chronicled by Bertram Fowler in his new book, "The Cooperative Challenge."

OTHER People's home -- town newspapers are like other people's kitchens: there's always a peculiar smell. Nothing bad -- just noticeably different; and, of course, you realize that yours smells peculiar to other people. To a Bostonian, for instance, the prose of Bill Cunningham is just something that arrives every morning, like the milk.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 5 -- In a frank bid to win over the young voter, Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder, Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson and other key figures of the Truman Administration will go to Cleveland next week to address the national convention of Young Democratic Clubs.

Books that once belonged to French royalty and other French personages are in the collection of the late Karrick Riggs that will be auctioned tomorrow and Tuesday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Making capital of the enemy's mistakes and triumphing over the hostile elements as well, Columbia's fast-developing football team hung up its third straight victory by defeating Dartmouth's scrappy young eleven, 15-0, at Baker Field yesterday.

IT is the belief of Hoffman Nickerson, a member of the General Staff of the United States Army during both World War I and World War II, that the world has been going steadily downhill since the time of the Middle Ages.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I arrived in America in July, 1945, after five years in Paris, and three or four weeks in England. I was prepared with the necessary explanations of the Armistice, of the Vichy revolution and of the apparent collaborationism of Petain, as well as with what I imagined would be the unnecessary explanation of de Gaulle's prestige in France.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The National Consumers League for Fair Labor Standards asked today for a 65-cent hourly minimum wage, with industry committees authorized to recommend higher standards for particular industries "as economic conditions warrant."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Howard Hughes brought forward witnesses today to commend his work as a war contractor and to accuse his Senate inquisitors of unfairness to him and of overtenderness toward the alleged contributions of the Army to his production difficulties.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Continued general debate on admission of new members to United Nations.

IN SPITE of the profusion of spring bloom, one of the most talked-about flowers in our garden was the lovely botanical tulip, Tulipa clusiana. Early last October, we had planted several groups of twenty-five bulbs apiece along a faded pink brick path that extends to the road from the house.

THIS story, laid in a mental hospital, is knowing, witty and not too gloomy. While a hospital for mental disorders can hardly shed sweetness and light, the one considered here caters to the limousine trade, and the physical surroundings, at least, are not harrowing.

A FEW years ago Sterling North wrote for children a heart-warming tale of a boy and his pet lamb, "Midnight and Jeremiah." It was a good story -- good enough, indeed, for Walt Disney -- and apparently so dear to the author's heart that he has expanded it and adjusted it here and there into a novel for adult consumption.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg has taken quiet steps to remove himself further from the race for the Republican Presidential nomination, friends of the Senator said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Lester B. Pearson, Canadian Under-Secretary of External Affairs, moved today to break the deadlock between the United States and the Soviet Union on how the proposed partitioning of Palestine is to be carried out.

APART from the prevention of war, the most urgent and the most important problem facing the nations today is the food shortage. Although much publicity has been given to the plight of Europe, many people do not yet fully realize the extent of the world shortage. It is the chief immediate problem before the new World Food Council which opened its first session in Washington last week.

TECHNIONThe 1947 issue of Technion, year-book of the American Society for the Advancement of the Hebrew Institute of Technology in Haifa, has an all-star list of contributors. Three Nobel laureates, Drs. A.H. Compton, I.I. Rabi and Harold C. Urey, discuss the significance of the atomic bomb.

OF the recent spate of records for the piano, the most arresting musically is Rudolf Serkin's performance of Beethoven's F minor Sonata, the Appassionata (Columbia, three twelve-inch disks). Mr. Serkin plays with disciplined power and intensity of expression, capturing the sweep and drama of the music.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Holy Cross missed three scoring chances and lost a touchdown by an offensive penalty in the first half before tallying in the opening minute of the finale to gain a 6 -- 6 tie with a stubborn Colgate eleven in a steady rain before 10,000 fans today at Fitton Field.

TORONTO, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The score was lopsided here tonight as the world champion Toronto Maple Leafs trounced the New York Rangers, 7 -- 2, in a National Hockey League game, but the excitement was plentiful. One of the 14,301 fans in attendance died of a heart attack in the first period and in the second session Ranger Center Edgar Laprade suffered a minor concussion.

IN this day of no-apartments-to-let signs, one of the meanest jobs in town is to be a city marshal. The city's eighty-three marshals are Municipal Court officers whose duties include the carrying out of court-ordered evicions.

An important step in the promotion of interfaith understanding has been taken by New York University, with the creation of a new Professorship of Hebrew Culture and Education, the first of its kind in the United States.

LIONELLO VENTURI is one of the few serious and informed art critics now alive, and nothing he says on art can go unheeded. The present book, already extant for several years in Italian and French, is his most important publication since "History of Art-Criticism" and takes its point of departure from the theories advanced in the latter work.
ATHENS, Nov. 8 -- News from Greece these days is often gloomy. Here is some good news.

BALLET THEATRE opens its fall season at the City Center on Wednesday of next week. Thirty-one performances are scheduled, with Mondays omitted each week and Tuesdays out the first two weeks because of performances by the City Symphony on those evenings.

WASHINGTON -- From Mexico down through Central and South America to the lower reaches of Argentina there is a shortage of new passenger automobiles which, on the basis of population, exceeds that even in the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of Oct. 26, under "Science in Review," Waldemar Kaempffert discusses a recent report by the German physicist, Werner Heisenberg, together with my popular book, "Alsos." Both deal with the question why Germany failed in making an atom bomb, but the report and the book emphasize different reasons for this failure.

AN album of eighteenth century American portraits has been assembled at the Harry Shaw Newman, (Old Print Shop) Gallery. These are such work as was done in the vicinity of New York for the Hudson Valley burghers and patroons and unerringly fix their provincial stolidity and enormous self-assurance in a mode, Flemish in tone, of naive realism.

The impassioned actors in Joachim 'Maass' soul-drama neither weep nor laugh so much as they implore the heavens in a moving but rather obscure mysticism. Xenia Tyllmann and her sons -- Franz, the cynic; Grigol, the poet, and Ernst, the paranoid -- are an unusual German family, living before World War I.

Nassau and the other Bahama Islands are making extensive preparations for an expected increase of tourists this winter, according to Harold Christie, chairman of the Nassau, Bahamas Development Board. Mr. Christie said figures on tourist arrivals at Nassau during the first eight months of this year showed a 100 per cent increase over a comparable period in 1946.

Wishful thinkers in each major party found something to encourage them in last Tuesday's elections. They were bound to do so. There is, however, no discernible "trend" for or against either major party. The reason is clear: the record on which the voters must make up their minds has still to be written.

THE first color slide viewer for 2 1/4-by-2 1/4 and 2 1/4-by-3 1/4 inch transparencies has appeared on the market as the PB Master Viewer, distributed by The Raygram Corporation. The device incorporates metal springs to hold slides for vertical and horizontal viewing; lens in focusing mount; magnification two and one-half times, and a diffusing screen mounted in polished aluminum frame.

No calculating machine is worth the oil to lubricate it if it cannot memorize or "store" necessary information. Add up the right-hand column of a series of digits and you get, say, 22. You write down "2" and retain in your mind "store," or put down on paper the 2 that must be carried to the next column.

There are more than 155,000 governing units in the United States, ranging from Federal down to school-district levels. They hold, in all, some 130,000 elections a year -- most of them on the Tuesday after the first Monday in November.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Sir Alexander Paterson, one of the world's greatest authorities on prison reform, died in his home here last night at the age of 62.

A new community of thirty-seven brick and frame combination bungalows, to be known as Briarwood Homes, is under way in the foothills of the Watchung Range, off Highway 29 in the Westfield Road sectiqn of Scotch Plains, N.J. Emanuel M. Spiegel, president of the Home Builders Association of Northern New Jersey, who is erecting the houses, expects to have them ready for occupancy at an early date.

Although some 8,000 minor league ball players will be eligible for draft, most baseball men are not looking for any startling prizes to be uncovered when representatives of the sixteen major league clubs meet tomorrow morning before Commissioner A.B. Chandler in Cincinnati for the annual drawing.

IF ever anyone concocts a recipe for hit plays and movies it will be Elia Kazan. His scientific approach to the theatre has made him the only director regularly employed today by both Hollywood and Broadway. No sooner had he completed the movie. "Gentleman's Agreement," than he began rehearsing the play.

ST. MORITZ, Switzerland -- A record crowd of international visitors is expected at the fifth Winter Olympic Games, which will open here for ten days on Jan. 30. This will mark the second time that St. Moritz has been host to the games.

SOME characters were born for fantasy, serenely making themselves at home in the far reaches of the imagination; settled, comfortable citizens of another state of mind. Other figures like Henny Sherman, protagonist of "The Grass Is Always Greener," have fantasy thrust upon them.
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Belrate, R.B. Carroll's 3-year-old, won the featured $5,000 White Star Purse at Rockingham Park today.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Indian troops trying to drive invading Moslem tribesmen out of Kashmir today captured the strategic town of Baramula, twenty-five miles west of Srinagar, and the Moslems are fleeing west toward the borders of the North-West Frontier Province, an Indian communique said tonight.

BOOTBALL -- the Great Autumnal Madness -- is a sport that provokes its followers into violent rages and apoplectic fervor. This statement is merely a timid warning that what is to follow is merely one man's opinion Mine.
CHICAGO, Nov. 8 -- The American Municipal Association has reported that big cities throughout the country are taking action to solve "housing shortages" in local jails.
LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Spiritualism as a religious force received the approval of seven members of a ten-man lay and clerical committee in a long-suppressed Church of England report published today.

RUTH BRINDZE, who has written on such diverse subjects as "How to Spend Money" and the sins of radio, has made a very complete revision of her "Seamanship Below Deck," first published for the yachting clan eight years ago.

ROME, Nov. 8 -- Guglielmo Giannini's Common Man Front seemed to be about to fly apart today as the result of action taken early this morning by the party's national council, which expelled the leader of the anti-Giannini wing, Deputy Enzo Selvaggi.

TO THE EDITOR: In his interesting article on the continued popularity of the film version of "Gone With the Wind" Lloyd Shearer fell into error on one detail. He stated that Margaret Mitchell, author of GWTW, "stayed at home" on the night of the premiere of the picture in Atlanta, Dec. 15, 1939.

"TAKE This Woman" is the story of a marriage and a nervous breakdown and a couple of other things besides, and it's all believable and fresh. The couple were Lisa and Trump. They had two good-looking kids, a nice house (quite important) and more than affection for each other.

HAVING neatly apprised the reading public last year of the latest advances in the complex world of surgery in "The New Science of Surgery," Dr. Frank G. Slaughter (a man whose literary psyche keeps his soma moving at a lively clip) has been equally diligent in delving into the comparative mysteries of psychosomatic medicine.

WASSAW, Nov. 8 -- The first meeting of the newly organized Communist Information Bureau in Belgrade has been called for early next month, it was learned today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The new Loyalty Review Board is expected to throw light soon on the effectiveness of the Government's first general attempt to purge itself of "disloyal" and "risky" employes.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- Some of the nations expecting reparations from Germany are beginning to question the selection of the year 1936 upon which to base the revival of German industry, it was learned today.

PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 7 -- Reconstruction of Maine's fire-devastated communities, sprawled from Biddeford Pool on the southern coast easterly to Bar Harbor, is proceeding but the difference in community requirements is deciding the pace with which the activity is undertaken.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 8 -- India will ask the United Nations General Assembly for a "round-table conference" of India, Pakistan and South Africa, to settle her racial dispute with South Africa, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg of Michigan said today that he might ask the Senate to ratify during the special session of Congress the Inter-American Security Treaty signed at Rio de Janeiro last summer.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- Premier Paul Ramadier, without direct negotiations with the strikers, today offered terms to the French municipal employes in the hope of ending the strikes that had extended throughout the public services in the whole Department of the Seine.

Lieut. Col. Charles A. Symroski gained the first leg on the new International Military Special Challenge Trophy for the United States by doing some spectacular riding before the biggest crowd of the National Horse Show, 14,000, in Madison Square Garden last night.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Nov. 8 -- Reports have reached here of a large-scale invasion of Gilgit Province in northwestern Kashmir by Moslem tribesmen from the Swat princely state, allied to Pakistan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The President's Committee on Foreign Aid, in its report today, cast grave doubts on the ability of the United States to meet stated requests for steel and fuel of the sixteen European countries participating in the recovery program.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Gen. Nicolas Radescu, former Rumanian Prime Minister, who arrived here tonight aboard the Greek vessel Nea Hellas with 1,248 other passengers, expressed surprise upon learning of the appointment of Mme. Ana Pauker as Rumanian Foreign Minister, first woman to hold that office.

Thirteen states have now adopted community property laws. Within the last three years five of this number -- Oklahoma, Oregon, Nebraska, Michigan and Pennsylvania -- have enacted such laws primarily with a view to saving income taxes for their taxpayers.

Americans, living and dead, who by their sacrifices have helped to assure the security of the United States, will receive the city's tribute Tuesday when special homage is paid at Armistice Day services to the 300,000 service men who made the supreme sacrifice in World War II.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Nov. 8 -- Astonishing success in absorbing displaced persons into the British economy has been reported to Geneva headquarters of the International Refugee Organization by British officials in charge of the program.

Public officials, land developers and the aircraft industry must recognize the effects which airports and airplanes can have on residential areas if they are to avoid the errors made in highway development during the early days of the automobile, according to the Urban Land Institute.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., Nov. 8 -- In a game highlighted by splendid backfield play, Lawrenceville downed the Hill School eleven today, 13 to 0, before an overflow Father's Day crowd. The victory was the twenty-third for Lawrencevilie in a series dating back to 1894.
