THE three novels by the Polish writer Zofia Kossak which have been translated into English have all dealt with the Jerusalem of the Crusades, and in the order in which they have been published in this country they have moved backward in time through the late Middle Ages.

The first German business men to come to the United States since before the war arrived yesterday afternoon at La Guardia Field. The group of five merchants came here under the auspices of the Department of Commerce and traveled on permits of the American Military Government in Germany.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Following is the text of a statement by President Truman, released tonight by the White House together with the report of his Committee on Foreign Aid:

The last of the color has not yet blown out of the maples, and the oaks, as always, still cling to their leathery leaves. But the woodlands are opening up. You can see tree patterns against the sky, the tracery of bare limbs, each species in its own design. But as the woodlands open overhead they close in underfoot.

LONDON. IT will no doubt have been reported in New York that "Finian's Rainbow," in marked contrast to its predecessors "Oklahoma!" and "Annie Get Your Gun," had a reception here from press and public that fell something short of enthusiasm.

GEDDES MUMFORD was born in New York in 1925 and was killed in Italy in 1944. Lewis Mumford's narrative of his son's nineteen years may be considered a memorial not to one boy only but to all the others as well, who, with their gifts and their promise, went down to darkness in the last -- must we say latest? -- war.

ALL too frequently after a building is erected, a mural painter, an easel painter and a sculptor are called in as an after-thought and told to fill some unsuitable space with something decorative. The results are, speaking mildly, somewhat short of perfect.

"Taking some of our own medicine" may figure in the price inflation recommendations which President Truman will place before Congress shortly, along with his proposals on foreign aid. We have been telling Europe its salvation lies in production, and experts looking over our own problems believe we might do some more producing ourselves if we are to conquer the forces of inflation.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 8 -- Army's first courtesy call on Notre Dame resulted in disaster today as the curtain was lowered on the most famous of all football rivalries.

MAKE no mistake about this latest novel by George Victor Martin. Once you've read it, whether you like it or not, whether you approve of it or not, you won't easily forget it. Unlike the author's first book, "Our Vines Have Tender Grapes," this is not a pretty tale.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 8 (AP) -- The University of Illinois football team, scoring its first touchdown fifty-five seconds after the opening gun, overwhelmed Western Michigan, 60 to 14, today in a non-Conference game before 24,042 shivering fans in Memorial Stadium.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Labor Premier John Cain of the State of Victoria early today conceded yesterday's legislative election to an Opposition coalition composed of the Libera and Country parties.

Riding comfort, mechanical performance and advanced styling are emphasized in the new medium and lower-priced units of the Nash 1948 line announced yesterday by the Nash Motor division, Nash-Kelvinator Corporation. The offerings include three body types in the medium field Ambassador and four in the lower-priced "600."

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 -- Georgia Tech remained among the unbeaten football teams today by overcoming a Navy aggregation in the fourth period, 16 -- 14, after the midshipmen had led twice in a thrill-packed game.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 8 -- Since President Truman's food-saving program was announced retail prices for fresh fish in this city have risen as much as 15 cents a pound and local wholesalers and dealers declare it is the result of a definite plan of Boston and New Bedford fishermen's unions.

JAN VALTIN, remembered for his autobiography "Out of the Night," offers in this eloquent first novel an absorbing narrative of flight and pursuit, a tender and tragic love story, some criticisms of American mores, a tribute to human courage, and a challenging commentary on what he terms the freedom of Motion.

THIS novel of "old" San Francisco opens in 1919 and ends in 1921. The protagonist is a 10-year-old girl named Alice Barton. In the first scene Alice tries to sneak a free ride on a streetcar at Haight and Fillmore Streets -- a transfer point.

The Army Air Force has decided to maintain an Air Reserve Training Detachment at Newark Airport despite urgent pleas on the part of the Port Authority to relocate the outfit, it was learned here yesterday.

HAD Frederick Townsend Ward not stopped a sniper's bullet at the walls of Tseki in 1862, he might have gone on to rival the later exploits of "Chinese" Gordon and stolen some of his limelight. But brief though it was, Ward's career was apparently impressive enough to earn him the Manchu rank of "genral" and give rise to an assortment of bizarre legends.

As the Government monetary authorities continue their activities to dampen the inflationary fire, and with the prospect that such efforts will be intensified, banking observers now are asking to what limits the officials are prepared to move to reach their objectives.
MADISON, Wis., Nov. 8 (AP) Wisconsin's Badgers, relentless in all phases of offensive play, smothered Iowa today, 46 to 14, to remain in the Big Nine Conference gridiron title race.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Villanova's Wildcats completely bewildered Marquette with a withering ground attack today to whip the Hilltoppers, 25 to 7, in an intersectional football game in below-freezing temperatures before a homecoming crowd of 12,000.

Financial markets, interrupted by the election day holiday, marked time last week as political jockeying held sway prior to the session of Congress that will begin a week from tomorrow. While developments on measures which will affect the national economy and rehabilitation of Europe were debated, both political parties agree that the session will be confined to price inflation and foreign aid.

Nearly 7,000 realty men and representatives of allied trades are gathering in San Francisco for the fortieth annual convention of the Natiorial Association of Real Estate Boards, which opens with informal sessions today and runs through the week.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- A meek English flower-lover had two silver cups today as evidence of his victory over the London gamblers who poisoned his prize chrysanthemums in an effort to "fix" the Macclesfield flower show.

Steven Kennedy, Pittsburgh baritone, gave a pleasing, varied and well-planned recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. It was his first appearance here in eleven years, for he has not sung-locally since his debut in October, 1936.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Fleet Harper Davis set off on two long touchdown jaunts today to give a smooth Mississippi State team a 14-to-0 victory over Auburn, but the dogged Plainsmen stopped threat after threat near their goal to keep the score respectable.

William H. Pouch, president of the Concrete Steel Company and of the Greater New York Council of the Boy Scouts of America, and Mrs. Pouch, prominent New York clubwoman and president-general of the National Society of Patriotic Women of America, celebrated their Golden Wedding anniversary yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The University of Maryland, surging toward football eminence at last, flattened an inept Duquesne University eleven, 32 -- 0, here today and flashed a great running back in the process.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 8 -- Under a gray dismal sky the Army-Notre Dame series came to an end today, finishing in pretty much the same fashion as it started with a solidly won victory for the Fighting Irish. Frank Leahy's heroes were the superior ball club on every count and only Army's dogged spirit and determination kept the Cadets in the battle.

APPRECIATION of brightly berried shrubs growing in the garden is very real on a gray November day, and several of these remain effective all winter. Many actually offer a triple harvest. In addition to outdoor beauty, they provide cutting material when flowers are about gone, they show lavish blossoming during the summer, and they have brilliant foliage in the fall.

The physical volume of new construction in 1948, based on estimates by economists of the Producers Council, is expected to be about 13 per cent higher than in 1947. Although the dollar volume for 1947 is estimated to be 25 per cent above 1946, the rise in physical volume-this year is placed at only 5 to 10 per cent.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- Sentimental San Franciscans showed the nation this week that the figurative tolling of bells and the playing of dirges in memory of the city's historic cable car system were premature gestures.

HERE is a book which will stand with "Captain From Castile" and "The Black Rose" and yield little to either of those fast-moving historical thrillers. It is a book for those to whom the Crusades are merely a dusty chapter in medieval history.

THESE poems by the late Mary Webb (author of "Precious Bane"), who died in 1927, were recently discovered among her husband's papers. Walter de la Mare admires them; but then, Yeats admired Dorothy Wellesley's.
BUCHAREST, Nov. 8 -- Gen. Constantin Sanatescu, who was Rumania's first Prime Minister after she surrendered in August, 1944, died early today. His age was 62. He had been ill for several months.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. LAST week I was speaking of the dissatisfaction recently depressed by The Times (London) Literary Supplement with the socalled experimental writing contained in certain English and American avant-garde periodicals.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization cannot cooperate "with full effectiveness in the presence of fascism, imperialism, intolerance, suppression of freedom or exaggerated nationalism," Dr. Julian Huxley, director general the organization, said today before the General Assembly of the UNESCO.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 8 (U.P.) -- Texas spotted Baylor a first-period touchdown today before getting its offensive into proper momentum but there was no stopping the Longhorns after blond Bobby Layne opened up with passing and running which resulted in a 28-to-7 victory.

READERS of bridge columns are too often regaled with examples of the unassailable logic whereby a declarer finds the winning play. They may enjoy an example of logic which, unassailable as it was, had one defect: it didn't work.

THERE have been rumblings of discontent in the American Guild of Musical Artists for some time. Last April a group burst into print with a number of grievances. They asked for a special meeting to iron them out. The group was not large enough to get a special hearing, but many of the points were taken up at the regular membership meeting in May.

WITH a certain frenzy and a spoofing instinct strong enough to sleep outdoors without a poncho, Mr. Hellman looks at our world with insulting dubiety, amazed compassion and a splendid sense of the unstable. Then, instead of putting the brakes on, he spins us up a little faster.

THERE is but one real criticism to be made of Ross Santee's books -- there aren't enough of them. He has written only six or seven since -- thirty-odd years ago -- he gave up all notion of becoming a cartoonist and returned to Arizona and the life of a horsewrangler and cowboy.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Yugoslavia has filed with the United Nations Security Council copies of notes accusing the United States and Britain of "unjustifiable and hostile action" in Trieste, it was disclosed today. The notes propose the establishment of a United States-British-Yugoslav military government headquarters to guide Trieste's administration.
Local professional football fans today will have the first of three opportunities this season to make a direct choice between the National League and All-America Conference varieties of the game.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Calumet Farm's Citation topped off a brilliant 2-year-old campaign today by capturing the twenty-sixth Pimlico Futurity at 2-5 odds by a length and a half before 19,000 fans at Old Hilltop.

NEW pattern for camera club shows is being demonstrated through November at the Camera Club, 121 West Sixty-eighth Street, where the First Women's Invitation Exhibition displays the work of women photographers.

RONNE ANTARCTIC RESEARCH EXPEDITION MAIN BASE, Stonington Island, Marguerite Bay, Nov. 4 (Delayed) -- Commdr. Finn Ronne and his party left this base by air today for the advanced exploration base at Cape Keeler on the Weddell Sea coast.

LONDON, Nov. 8 -- Deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers, meeting here this morning for their second session on the German peace treaty got exactly nowhere. One after another of the subjects on the agenda was placed patiently before them by Patrick Dean, British deputy in the chair, and one by one they were put back into their folders without agreement.

A Manuscript in Every Drawer As is generally known, every newspaperman has a drawer manuscript in a drawer in his desk. It may be a novel, a play or, since biography began to pay so well, a biography.

THE Chinese called opium, "foreign mud," and here is a fascinating account of the Opium imbroglio at Canton in the Eighteen Thirties and the Anglo-Chinese War that followed. It is a black chapter in the unwritten history of the East India Company, and the attempts by Western powers, England in particular, to subjugate the Chinese people as they had previously conquered and subjugated the people of India and Indo-China.

Incoming buyers last week were mainly concerned with keeping present stocks in balance and purchasing for early spring sales, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.
Community planning has become widely accepted by architects and other specialists in recent years, but the general public has remained apathetic, it was asserted yesterday.

MICHIGAN -- Japanese Center The University of Michigan's Center for Japanese Studies has entered its first year with an initial enrollment of graduate students who had previously received some training in the Army's Japanese language training program. As now organized, the center offers a central "core" course which gives the student a broad picture of Japan and its culture.

RECENTLY five doctors received the Lasker Award from the American Health Association for their work in "combating the most frequent causes of disease and death." One of these doctors is a woman of 78, the only woman ever to have received this honor.

TO THE EDITOR: Thank you for having brought before the readers of THE TIMES Sidney Hook's level-headed analysis, "Is the United States a Republic or a Democracy?" In reference, I should like to present an extension of Dr. Hook's philosophy.

PARIS. WHEN Lieut. Gen. George S. Patton Jr. and his forces prepared to land at Casablanca five years ago last Friday. Gen. Auguste Nogues, French Resident General in Morocco, made a great show of guarding the Sultan of Morocco from the "invaders."

JERUSALEM, Nov. 8 -- Setting up a new national state can be announced in a few words, but actually establishing it in running order is a highly complex problem. Just how complex it is has been forcibly impressed upon the Jews of Palestine as they prepare for the state they hope soon to have.

One thousand alumni of City College attended a dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night to mark the opening of the school's century pt existence. Guest speakers were Adolf A. Berle Jr., chairman of the Liberal party; Vincent Impellitteri, president of the City Council, and Dr. Harry N. Wright, president of the college.

The decision to have World Bank engineers approve industrial rehabilitation and construction projects in devastated areas of Europe appears to have been made, industrial spokesmen here revealed yesterday.

LONDON. THE British motion picture people seem to be serious about this matter of England owning London in general and the London of Dickens in particular. They staked out their claim most emphatically in "Great Expectations" and now they plan to put on the finishing touches of ownership in "Oliver Twist" which the Cineguild group of the J. Arthur Rank Organization is currently filming at Pinewood studios.

PROVO, UTAH. UNTIL 6:15 P.M. last Sunday evening, this pleasant Mormon community was famed chiefly for the scenic 12,000 foot-high Mount Timpanogos which lies to the east, and the huge, war-built Geneva Steel plant, sprawling along the shorts of Utah Lake to the west.

A section of the huge World's Fair parking lot site at the northern end of Flushing Meadow Park has been acquired by the Mayor's Special Traffic Committee for a "highly experimental" attempt at easing midtown Manhattan's traffic congestion, it was learned yesterday.

OUTDOOR chrysanthemums are going into the final phase this month of a long period of bloom. Time was when 'mums bloomed only in late autumn, but during recent years gardens have shown the results of hybridizers' efforts to extend the flowering season.

EXETER, N.H., Nov. 8 -- Exeter emerged from a hard-fought game against Andover today with a 12-to-6 victory, but the sixty-seventh annual contest between the two preparatory schools was in doubt till the final whistle.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 8 -- Brown hurled an upset at Yale today in a bowl of mud. The underdog Brunonians exhibited a commendable aggressiveness that enabled them to make their own breaks and go on to carve out a 20-to-14 success over the Blue warriors.

Between January and May boat shows are going to dot the American horizon. It won't make very much difference where skippers may be traveling or vacationing this Winter and coming Spring. They are reasonably certain to run into a boat show somewhere.

WATER-COLORS and drawings by Rofer de la Fresnaye make up a lively exhibition at the Jacques Seligmann Gallery. Small as most of these items are they reveal many things -- the artist's cubist affiliations, his sureness of line, his economically witty expression (witness "L'officier!") and his essentially classic descent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The 136-day old strike of 22,000 shipyard workers in the Atlantic Coast yards of the Bethlehem Company was settled early today with the granting, among other things of a 12-cent-an-hour wage increase.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- A three-judge Federal court issued late yesterday a temporary injunction against an inter-railroad rental charge of $2 a day for freight cars ordered by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The injunction is to remain in effect until the court can pass on the legality of the rate.

MONTREAL, Nov. 8 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings took undisputed hold of first place tonight by defeating the Montreal Canadiens, 3 -- 1, in the first Montreal meeting this season of the two National Hockey League clubs.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 8 -- Wesleyan continued on its undefeated way this afternoon, beating Williams, 12 to 6. In winning for the second year the coveted Little Three crown, the victors gained their fifteenth straight victory and seventeenth without a defeat.

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- If the trade arrangement proposed in the recent note from the Soviet Union offering wheat for French manufactured goods goes through, it will revolutionize the trade relations of the two countries. Also, however, France may have considerable trouble in providing the goods desired.

THE Postoffice Department made available last week a photograph of the 3-cent stamp which will be issued on Dec. 5 to mark dedication of the Everglades National Park in Florida. The design comprises the Florida peninsula with a great white heron in the foreground.

Checking on a report here last week that 182 Soviet Russian buyers were in the market for heavy machinery, railroad, oil and power equipment, representative mamufacturers in these lines said they had nothing available for Russia now, and raised the question: "If accepted, would such Russian orders be given export license now?"
THIS book on Christian living in an "insane" era contains more than a suggestion that Canon Bell has shifted his position on what is salvable in contemporary civilization.

NANKING, Nov. 8 -- More than 30,000 Communist troops under Gen. Nieh Jung-chen have launched a full-scale assault on Shihkiach wang, strategic communication hub in west central Hopeh, it was reported tonight.

A Government delegation of South India tanners, here since Oct. 23 to explore the possibility of expanding trade between India and the United States, sailed for England yesterday on the Mauretania, satisfied that the visit had been fruitful.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- The Middle Atlantic Section of the National Jewish Welfare Board, with which are affiliated Jewish community centers and YMHA's and YWHA's, opened here tonight its 38th annual meeting, with 200 delegates from Pennsylvania, Delaware, Maryland, Virginia and the District of Columbia in attendance.

THE inevitable return of America's commercial airlines to de luxe travel after the strict utility service of wartime and the period of post-war readjustment will begin this week, when American Airlines puts sleeper plane schedules into operation between the East and West Coasts.

LONDON. IN the Poet's Comer at Westminster Abbey next Sunday a memorial tablet is to be unveiled to the memory of Henry Francis Lyte, author of one of the most popular and beloved of hymns, "Abide With Me."

THE subtitle of this book is "The Life of Captain Bob Bartlett," but it might well be "An Introduction to a Study of the Far North." For, though Mr. Putnam, in his easy, conversational style, gives an admirable sketch of the life of Cap'n Bob, he also ranges through the vast field of literature on polar exploration and opens wide vistas for those who wish to investigate that subject in detail.

OF the seven sports taken up in this book, golf is represented by Sammy Snead, hockey by Bill Durnan, track by the dash man Herb McKenley, football by Blanchard and Davis, boxing by Ray Robinson, and aviation, which is sometimes considered more a means of commercial and military transportation than an athletic activity, by Howard Hughes, the airplane designer and motion-picture producer.

HOLLYWOOD. THE latest maneuver on the labor front in Hollywood, a petition filed with the National Labor Relations Board by forty-eight members of various film unions asking for a mandatory settlement of the thirteen-month-old jurisdictional strike under the Taft-Hartley Act, has raised a question of interpretation of the act which finds the NLRB and the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes in direct opposition.

TOKYO, Nov. 8 -- The unemployment that Japan has managed to stave off during the two years since the surrender threatens to become a dangerous problem within the next few months, according to officials of the Tokyo Metropolitan Government.

On major issues on which the United States and Russia disagree, the United Nations General Assembly has developed a pattern of operation. It is this: The U.S. proposes a resolution; Russia opposes it; the majority of U.N. members vote for it; Russia boycotts the final action.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were moderately active yesterday and final prices were 5 to 17 points net higher than on Friday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall is expected to go before the House and Senate Foreign Affairs Committees Monday with an estimate of needs for aid to China -- and possibly other areas -- as well as aid to Europe.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 8 -- With more than 150 of next year's models on display, the thirteenth annual national trailer coach show today opened an eight-day stand in Philadelphia's Convention Hall under the sponsorship of the Trailer Coach Manufacturers Association.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- The 12,000 city employes enrolled in a health service system, which is compulsory for those on the city payroll, have been informed by letter that 922 physicians serving them have threatened to resign on Monday.

IRENE BEASLEY'S multiple role as mistress of ceremonies, singing star and producer of "Grand Slam," the musical quiz heard daily on CBS at 11:30 A.M., represents just another unexpected twist of fate, the kind she has learned to expect in the course of her long career.

With the huge war-built fleet of tankers of the United States Government now reduced to a comparatively low level through sales and other disposals, the amount of fuel oil and other petroleum products that may be made available to the North Atlantic Coast area this winter will depend in part on the extent to which the remainder of these vessels is used to meet the requirements of the Northeast.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 8 -- The 12,000 city employes enrolled in a health service system, which is compulsory for those on the city payroll, have been informed by letter that 922 physicians serving them have threatened to resign on Monday.

IRENE BEASLEY'S multiple role as mistress of ceremonies, singing star and producer of "Grand Slam," the musical quiz heard daily on CBS at 11:30 A.M., represents just another unexpected twist of fate, the kind she has learned to expect in the course of her long career.

With the huge war-built fleet of tankers of the United States Government now reduced to a comparatively low level through sales and other disposals, the amount of fuel oil and other petroleum products that may be made available to the North Atlantic Coast area this winter will depend in part on the extent to which the remainder of these vessels is used to meet the requirements of the Northeast.

LONDON, Nov. 8 (Reuters) -- Nearly a million fans converged on football stadiums in Britian today with the largest crowd -- 62,000 -- squeezing into the Arsenal stronghold at Highbury Park in London. The Gunners, unbeaten this year in the English League race, cheered supporters with a 2-1 victory over the strong Blackpool eleven.

LUDINGTON, Mich., Nov. 8 (AP) -- A little Coast Guard cutter raced 150 miles through 25 to 30 foot waves today and snatched a disabled freighter and her crew of 28 to safety from the treacherous reefs of Lake Michigan's "graveyard of ships."
NANKING, Nov. 8 -- The ancient sport of shadow boxing, which goes back 4,000 years to the reign of Emperor Huang-Ti, has come upon lean and skimpy days.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 8 -- In probably the wildest and most unusual finish Ohio Stadium has ever witnessed, Coach Wesley Fesler's battling Ohio State Buckeyes defeated Northwestern, 7 to 6, today in a Western Conference fray by scoring a touchdown and extra point fully three minutes after the final shot had sounded.

THE rose planting season extends from now into early December. This gives plenty of time to select roses of different types for various locations. Hybrid tea roses, naturally enough, receive a great deal of attention, but many other forms deserve separate consideration.
CAPE COD, traditionally a summer vacation region, will extend its season through September and October, 1948, if an ambitious plan recently announced by the Chamber of Commerce materializes.

Arrangements have been completed for the Autumn Ball to be given on Nov. 18 in the main ballroom of the Plaza as a benefit fr the Hospitalized Veterans' Music Service. Mrs. Charles Amory heads the general committee for the fete, which is sponsored by Harry Winston, Inc.
"MODERN furniture is fine for apartments. But we nave an old house in the country. You wouldn't put anything but antiques into that!"

PARIS, Nov. 8 -- A new international organization of artisans and small producers to encourage and develop individual and small-scale production has been formed this week by delegates from eleven European nations.

PARIS (By Wireless). WHEN Pierre deGaulle, brother of Gen. Charles de Gaulle, was chosen in France's local elections on Oct. 21 as a municipal councilor for Paris, his party, the R.P.F. (Rally of the French People) won a majority of seats, fifty-two out of ninety.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Nov. 8 -- -- Lehigh University, defeating United States Merchant Marine Academy from Kings Point, L.I. in Taylor Stadium here this afternoon, registered its fourth victory in seven games. The score was 20 -- 6.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Establishment of an independent Government agency as part of a "strong and flexible" organization to administer the European assistance program, recommended today by the President's Committee on Foreign Aid, is similar in many respects to that proposed yesterday by the House Select (Herter) Committee on Foreign Aid.
A varied assortment of narcotics and paraphernalia for their use were confiscated yesterday after raids on two apartments in a five-story building at 53 West Fifty-second Street.
WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 8 (AP) -- William and Mary's Indians defeated Virginia Military Institute's Keydets by the narrow margin of 28-20 today.

LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 8 -- In the contest between the Soviet Union and the United States, the other members of the United Nations, including even the other members of the Big Five, necessarily play a subordinate role. What do they think of the tactics followed by the United States at this session?

CATSKILL, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- A check-up on the deer hunting possibilities in Sullivan and Greene Counties, which will play host to thousands of big city hunters during the Catskill deer season, indicates that the hunter who has delayed in making reservations may have to bed down in a barn.

ITHACA, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- Carl (Red) Holland, 165-pound substitute halfback, carried Cornell to a 12-6 victory over its arch upstate rival, Syracuse, with a winging 90-yard run on a pass interception in the third period on muddy Schoellkopf Field today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- President Truman's Committee on Foreign Aid proposed today a European recovery program costing up to $17,000,000,000 and aimed at "the prevention of World War III."

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Kentucky made a break pay off for one touchdown and scored another on a long run to turn back a hard-fighting West Virginia team, 15 to 6, before 26,500 spectators today.

UNWISELY, perhaps, Mr. Henderson has not kept his initial literary symptoms localized. Throughout his "novel of suspense in Mexico" he has managed to collect as varied a group of south-of-the-border Americans as could have been found in any Third Avenue bar.
ROYAL TYLER of Boston was the first man in America to write a play and have it produced. The Henry and Hallam Players presented his "The Contrast," a five-act comedy, in New York in 1787.
A patrolman on sick leave was beaten and his service revolver was taken from him early yesterday morning by a youth to whom he had refused to give a cigarette.

JUST nineteen years ago this week in the Review: "Meet General Grant," by W.E. Woodward, led the rest. The reviewer admired Mr. Woodward's gift of phrase, cited as an example: "What Grant needed was not a circumstance but a predicament.

THE unwelcome and unacknowledged role of national poet that was filled in academic dignity by William Vaughn Moody at the turn of the century, and, fugitively, thirty-nine years later by Archibald MacLeish, remains empty. Karl Shapiro, a sturdier poet than either Moody or MacLeish, has more qualifications for the post than any contemporary.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley said tonight that incomes could not be increased enough to keep pace with the cost of living and urged the Republican Congress to "do something and do it soon."

THERE was a certain amount of food for thought for politicians in the elections last week. The party which made a sweep last year and claimed many things may come to the conclusion that a sweep next year is not so easy as it imagined.
MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Nov. 8 (AP) -- With Paul Farrell, a substitute halfback, running wild, the Middlebury College football team gained a 26-12 victory over Union today in driving rain.

To the Drama Editor: IT just shows how tastes can differ. Mr. Matthews excoriates Bertolt Brecht's "Galileo" and adulates Barrie Stavis' "Lamp at Midnight" which deals with the same subject. I read the latter play last February and found none of the virtues that Mr. Matthews, Miss Webster, Mr. Gassner or the Old Vic seem to find in it.

LAMONT BUCHANAN never played a game of football in his life, but his interest in the sport led him to write a first-class book on the sport. "The Story of Football" traces, in prose and pictures, the pigskin parade from its very beginning.

When New York City began financing relief in 1931 with a ten-million-dollar allotment, few city officials foresaw that relief expenditures would snowball to their present level of $142,000,000 a year.

Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, left Doctors Hospital yesterday morning and will return to his desk at department headquarters, 902 Broadway, tomorrow morning, eager to speed reorganization of the department. Mr. Fielding, who became Commissioner Oct. 24, went to the hospital six days later suffering from physical exhaustion.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 8 -- "A drive for human rights, not merely tolerance" was proposed today by Marshall Field, Chicago publisher, at a seminar on human rights and international relations at Fisk University.

Philip Walter Henry of Scarborough-on-Hudson, N.Y., New York consulting engineer and vice president of Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, who had worked on large engineering projects in many parts of the world, died Friday night in Presbyterian Hospital, after a brief illness.

THE prospects for speedy resumption of friendly trade relations between the British Government and the American motion-picture industry appeared brighter last week than at any time since last August when the British imposed a 75 per cent tax on earnings of imported movies and the Hollywood companies retaliated by halting shipments of new films.

LAKE CHAPALA, Mexico, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Jack O. (Pop) Cooper of Kansas City, Mo., seven times world champion speedboat pilot in the 135-cubic-inch inboard class, pushed his craft to another victory today in preliminaries opening the annual regatta here.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll declared tonight that if the teachers in New Jersey wanted more help from the state they must show that they were trying to help themselves by economizing in the various school districts.

The report of the Harriman Committee on Foreign Aid, made public yesterday, is the next-to-final step in the preparation of an executive program to be submitted for Congressional approval next week. Let us place it in its proper perspective. This is the third of three reports rendered by committees appointed by the President on June 22.

Developments at the recent national conventions of the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor have virtually killed chances of formal cooperation between the two labor groups in this state in the 1948 elections, it was learned last night.

THERE is no particular reason to dilate here upon the features as thus far announced of the 1947-48 Metropolitan Opera season which opens tomorrow night. This season, already heavily subscribed, promises to result in one of the biggest box-office intakes in recent Metropolitan history.

VIENNA, Nov. 8 -- A whole company of Hungarian soldiers, led by an officer, crossed the Austro-Hungarian frontier late yesterday afternoon, according to Austrian reports today, with the intention of seeking refuge in the British zone of Austria.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 8 (AP) -- Minnesota's persistent Gophers, sparked by Halfback Billy Bye, put on a second-half drive that brought them a 26-to-21 victory over Purdue's fighting football team today.

BERLIN, Nov. 8 -- Yesterday was the thirtieth anniversary of the "Great October Revolution." As top officials of the "monopoly capitalist" powers drove to Potsdam to help Marshal Sokolovsky celebrate, each ardently hoped for a great November revolution in London whereby the sorry tangle in Germany could be straightened out.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 8 -- Army's favored cross-country team retired the Junius T. Auerbach Trophy today in the ninth annual running of the Nonagonal Games Association's cross-country championships over Princeton's rain-soaked five-mile course.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 8 -- Nineteen men and one woman, all lawyers and scholars, were named today as the highest administrative tribunal to determine the basic loyalty of questioned Federal employes and the growing issue of maintenance of democratic rights in ascertaining loyalty.

A number of musicians are giving series of programs this season showing the development of the literature for their particular instruments. Efrem Zimbalist, the violinist, is one of them, and late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall he gave the first of five programs tracing the development of the literature for the violin.

The people of the United States should provide food for the starving populations of Europe on the basis of humanitarianism and brotherhood and to guard against the spread of communism, according to junior high school students who participated yesterday in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast by WQXR.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 8 -- George Grune sparked the White Plains Tigers to a 58-to-8 victory over the Hazle (Pa.) Township high eleven this afternoon for their fourth victory of the season.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 8 (AP) -- Charley Conerly, ace aerialist of college football, presented another dazzling performance today as he led Mississippi to a 43-13 victory over Tennessee.

THIS second novel of Fynette Rowe's is a partially successful enlargement of the range of her first book, the Avery Hopwood Award winner of a year or so ago, "The Chapin Sisters." That book was concerned entirely with the tradition-frustrated lives of two old sisters in an up-state New York town, and was a stylish, effective period piece.

Sixteen Protestant leaders made public a statement yesterday calling on all Christians to join them in an effort to promote peaceful American-Soviet relations. The signers included several who visited Europe last summer.

ROME, Nov. 8 -- Lieut. Gen. Lucius D. Clay, Military Governor the United States zone in Germany, arrived in Rome this afternoon by air from Berlin to attend the official opening tomorrow of the exhibition of masterpiece stolen by the Germans during the war.

A GARDEN pool is an important addition to the property. It tends to become either a beautiful center of interest or else a horrible mistake. As the garden's barest outlines become visible now in late autumn, it is possible to plan a pool without being misled by conflicting lines and masses of trees, shrubs and flowers.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 9 (AP) -- William J. Conners Jr., 52, publisher of The Buffalo Courier-Express, and four other persons injured last night in the emergency landing of a chartered airplane a St. Catharines, Ont., were brought tonight to a hospital here for further treatment.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Jamming four goals past Harry Lumley in the opening period -- one a bouncing tip-in and another an arching screen shot from 25 feet out -- the Toronto Maple Leafs leaped into second place in the National Hockey League by whipping the league-leading Detroit Red Wings, 6 -- 0, tonight.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 25 -- Russia seeks to weaken the Near Eastern bastion. One of her methods is to prevent the economic progress of Turkey by compelling the Turks to maintain a large military force. In this she has the aid of the Turks' own ineptitude and failure to put their own house in order.

WARSAW, Nov. 9 -- The Socialist party today opened a countrywide campaign to explain to its rank-and-file membership its policy of cooperation with the Communists and, indirectly, to point up its self-asserted position as a major factor in the shaping of presentday Polish life.
LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Great Britain's thoughts were on her dead of two World Wars today as the nation joined in Remembrance Day ceremonies throughout Britain and the empire.

Six thousand persons lined the sidewalk and an overflow crowd of 2,500 filled Livingston Hall, Brooklyn, yesterday for the funeral service of Peter V. Cacchione, first Communist elected a member of the City Council. Mr. Cacchione died of a heart attack in his home at 8570 Bay Parkway, Brooklyn, on Thursday after attending a session of the Council.
Nothing reveals the character of a man so much as what he does for and with money, the Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken told his congregation yesterday morning at the Riverside Church.

GENEVA, Nov. 9 -- The stage is nearly set for the next major economic development in Europe, the revaluation of the French frane, and possibly several other Western European currencies. The decision to make a drastic cut in the franc's value in terms of dollars was taken at an official, although not at a political, level recently.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- A limited international government functioning in the field of security among the Western powers, pledged to nonaggression, was suggested today as the immediate answer to the threat of atomic warfare, in an article in Air Affairs, a quarterly published by the International Society of Air Affairs.

Now that the Civil Aeronautics Authority permits, with safety regulations, the private use of captive balloons, the New York region of the War Assets Administration will sell 120 surplus barrage balloons, inflatable and usable for display and advertising purposes, it was announced over the week-end by Alwyn A. Throckmorton, WAA regional director.
Harald Kreutzberg, who has not danced in this country in nine years, returned last night in a recital at the Ziegfeld Theatre, assisted as of old by Friedrich Wilckens at the piano.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Closing its fourth annual convention today, the Empire State Federation of Teachers Unions, AFL, declared that public education throughout the state was in a precarious condition and would remain so until the state made adequate financial provision for it, based on sound taxing principles.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Although lard futures ranged higher last week on the Board of Trade, the upturn was small compared with that of edible oils, the latter being up as much as 2 1/2 cents a pound while the deferred deliveries of lard gained only around 1 cent.

Prices of cotton for future delivery in the domestic market held last week within a relatively narrow trading range. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed for the period net advances of 5 to 36 points, against net losses of 17 to 43 points in the preceding week.

Dr. Florence R. Sabin, 76-yearold physician and scientist, received the annual Federation Award of the American Woman's Association at the twentyfirst Annual Friendship Dinner held yesterday noon at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel. Almost 1,000 women were present from fiftyfive clubs in the metropolitan area.

The Mexican Army team's captain, Lieut. Col. Humberto Mariles, piloted Resorte to a thrilling triumph in the $1,000 International Military Stake at the National Horse Show in Madison Square Garden last night before 8,000 spectators.
ROME, Nov. 9 -- A wave of political violence is spreading over northern Italy. Almost every day persons who oppose left-wing parties are beaten. In several cases bombs and firearms are used.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- One of the three political parties tolerated by Soviet occupation authorities split wide open yesterday. The Berlin Liberal Democrats, in a stormy meeting, flatly refused to have anything further to do with the national leadership so long as it offered no opposition to Russian policies.

TOKYO, Nov. 9 -- After three months' debate the cabinet has made a tentative move toward meeting Government workers' demands. The Cabinet agreed to ask the Diet for 3,000,000,000 yen for winter allowances, leaving the wage level unchanged.

The second General Assembly of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, now meeting in Mexico City, is scanning an adverse balance sheet. The twelve months that have passed since its first meeting in Paris last November have seen new barriers raised against free interchange of thought throughout the world.

The Joint Distribution Committee has appropriated the record sum of $69,591,000 in the first eleven months of this year to carry out programs of relief, resettlement and reconstruction, it was announced yesterday. This constitutes the most extensive assistance operation ever undertaken by a private, voluntary agency, according to Moses A. Leavitt, executive vice chairman of the committee.

FRANK LEAHY is a perfectionist at heart and anything less than perfection leaves him completely unmoved. Although Notre Dame was not quite letter perfect on Saturday, the Old Master still was applauding with both fists. He stood in the dressing room beneath the artistically designed stands in the shadow of the Golden Dome and kept muttering ecstatically:

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks ended their seven-game losing streak in the National Hockey League tonight in a welter of scoring as they defeated the New York Rangers, 8-5, before 16,631.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The Administration tomorrow begins formal presentation of its casetor assisting the non-Communist nations of Western Europe.

Ratification of a new wage agreement by Bethlehem Steel Company shipyard workers at yards in Hoboken, N.J., and Mariners Harbor, Staten Island, ending a 136-day strike, was announced yesterday by Locals 12 and 15 of the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers, CIO.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Paterson Panthers scored on a 24-yard pass from Steve Nemeth to Connie Berry in the last minute and a half of play today to set down the Jersey City Little Giants 24 -- 17, and go into first place in the eastern division of the American Football League.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 9 -- Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, won an overwhelming vote of confidence today as the union, one of the largest in the world, opened its eleventh constitutional convention.
LAKE SUCCESS, Nov. 9 -- United States experts are drawing up a program for irrigation and reclamation projects in Arab countries of the Near East, it was learned today.

With the approval of bond issues for bonus payments to veterans of World War II by voters in New York and Ohio last Tuesday, the number of states that have acted to sell bonds for such purposes was increased to seven, Connecticut, Illinois, Michigan, New Hampshire and Rhode Island previously having sold bonds to make the payments, according to the Daily Bond Buyer.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 9 -- Dr. Emanuel Neumann of New York, president of the Zionist Organization of America, said today that while the two-thirds vote needed in the United Nations to approve the setting up of a Jewish state in Palestine "may not be there at the moment, I believe it is attainable."

For the first half, the Giants made a close fight of their game with the Eagles yesterday. Then the New York defense, usually a strong point, disintegrated before Philadelphia's dazzling speed and the score built up to a final 41-to24 as the locals went down to their sixth straight National League defeat.

Activity in the wholesale readyto-wear markets last week was brisk as a great many buyers arrived to view spring lines, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Paced by John Mannix, who registered three touchdowns, Brooklyn Prep gained its seventh successive triumph by defeating Chaminade, 34 to 6, at Boys' High Field yesterday. Mannix' scores brought his season total to 60 points, second best in the city.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $54,943,781,852. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Rank and file members of labor organizations of city employes, including those of the Board of Transportation, are leaning strongly toward a higher fare on the municipal transit lines as their only hope for pay rises, it was disclosed yesterday.
Twenty-four harmless snakes arrived yesterday in New York with eight boy and girl members of the Snake Club of Sarasota, Fla.

BOSTON, Nov. 9 -- In its fifth wage demand to the New England cotton textile industry in less than two years, the CIO Textile Workers Union of America today asked employers in 125 Northern mills for a wage increase of 15 cents an hour for 90,000 workers.

Inquiry by the Department of Investigation has determined that no relief funds were paid by the Welfare Department to meet union assessments levied to fight the Taft-Hartley law, it was disclosed yesterday.

Hudson Plans Big Campaign The Hudson Motor Car Company will introduce its new car "with the strongest national and local point-of-sale newspaper advertising in the company's thirty-eightyear history," M.M. Roberts, advertising and merchandising director, announced over the week-end.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 9 -- Howard Walls, former curator of the Library of Congress Film Divsion, has been appointed curator of the film archives of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and will leave for Washington Wednesday to arrange for an initial shipment of paper rolls of early films owned by the Congressional Library to the academy here for transfer to celluloid.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The major city political machines p over a fraud on those among the electorate who thoughtlessly voted for reapeal of the PR system. Repeal was engineered and deceitfully promoted by a group of smart and designing politicians anxious to restore their hold over the Council.

While importers here awaited further news of widely circulated reports that the State Department had asked distillers in Great Britain to cease distilling operations during the "distilling holiday" here, the latest complete report of The Scotch Whisky Association of Great Britain was revealed to THE NEW YORK TIMES by Harry L. Lourie, executive vice president of the National Association of Alcoholic Beverage Importers, Inc., Washington, D.C.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Eugene Nadelman, White Plains attorney and president of the Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild, won first prize in the oil painting class of the guild's seventeenth annual independent show, which had its preview today in the exhibit hall of the Westchester County Center here.
Frank A. Thomas, president of Thomas, Field Co., Charleston, W. Va. has been elected president of the Wholesale Dry Goods Institute, Inc., to fill the unexpired term, of the late G.L. Rosenthal.

Some of the sixty-nine voluntary hospitals in the United Hospital Fund, faced with the most serious financial crisis in their history, have been forced to request an immediate advance on their quota of the 1947 campaign contributions, Charles P. Cooper, chairman of the fund's trade committee, announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- Comparatively few merchants have eased terms for installment plan purchases since Government controls on consumer credit were lifted a week ago, a survey showed today. For this reason, plus shortages and consumer resistance to high prices, there has been no rush to buy and little change in total sales across the nation.
ROME, Nov. 9 -- Methods used by German armies to plunder Italian art treasures were disclosed today by documents that United States Ambassador James C. Dunn presented to the Italian Government.

"How I Wonder," Donald Ogden Stewart's first Broadway play in seventeen years, is dropping out of contention Nov. 22. Starring Raymond Massey, the play will vacate the Hudson after tarrying almost eight weeks or sixty-three performances. The house isn't to remain dark long, however, for on Sunday afternoon, Nov. 23, the mighty "Voice of the Turtle" will take up residence there.

DETROIT, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Breaking up a pair of third-period threats to avert a costly upset, the Chicago Cardinals, playing without their star running back, Charley Trippi, edged the Detroit Lions 17 to 7 here today to protect their Western Division lead in the National Football League.

The Communist party made known yesterday its program for the special session of Congress to be convened Nov. 17. The program adhered rigidly to the manifesto of the Communist Information Bureau, although the party announced last week that it would not affiliate formally with this successor of the Comintern.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Recent articles in the press, leading editorials and public discussions as to what should be done at once to promote residential housing have evoked in the mind of the writer a recollection of what had been done in the past to relieve the demand for housing.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- A national program for intensifying Jewish adherence to Judaism and for advancing public understanding of the Jewish faith and culture among all Americans was drafted today by 167 delegates from every part of the country who attended a conference on "Fostering a Dynamic Judaism in America," sponsored by the Jewish Theological Seminary of America.

The Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving, in his first sermon as rector of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church, said yesterday that the cause of world peace would be helped if those who believed in the power of God were to give evidence that He had influenced their own lives significantly.
CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Four national welfare and medical groups recommended a program today for aiding the 25,000,000 Americans who are reported to have chronic diseases.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I hope you will allow me to take issue with your editorial on Nov. 3 in which you hail the substantial Conservative gains in the British municipal elections as part of the turn of the tide against communism in Europe.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- It is generally taken for granted in informed circles here that the devaluation of the French franc must come, probably before the end of this year, to bring its official exchange rate somewhere near its actual exchange rate and purchasing power.

LAKE CHAPALA, Mexico, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Merlyn Culbert of Dayton, Ohio, won the 225-cubic inch inboard class in the finals today of the annual inboard-outboard regatta and put his name on the first leg of the 8,000 peso ($1,600) ornamental silver Jalisco Cup donated by the Jalisco State Government.

The New York Area Council of the American Veterans Committee adopted yesterday, after considerable discussion, a resolution proposing that economic aid for European reconstruction be administered by the United Nations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 -- The sharpest debates in the history of the National Association of Real estate boards were shaping up today as 7,000 delegates gathered here for the fortieth annual convention.

The American Jewish Conference, a temporary organization representing more than sixty national Jewish organizations and every major community in the United States, announced yesterday its intention to establish an over-all permanent body.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 9 (AP) -- The disabled freighter Jupiter, 3,000 tons, arrived here today in tow of the Coast Guard cutter Mackinaw after a hard battle against the elements to save her from crashing into the rocky Michigan shore near Ludington.

Disputing the idea that manufacturers are making "fantastic profits," the National Association of Manufacturers declared over the week-end that spectacular figures on both aggregate dollar profits and on return on net worth are completely misleading as gauges of actual industrial profits and their effect on prices.

The spotlight of trading interest in the foreign exchange market last week centered on the sharp decline in the Portuguese escudo, permitting the pound sterling and the free currencies of Canada and Switzerland to slip under the gleam which has focused on those documents for a month or more.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The heads-up Boston Yanks, striking sharply on four quick thrusts, upset the Los Angeles Rams, 27 to 16, today in a National Footbal League game before 19,415 spectators at Memorial Coliseum.

Starting this morning, and continuing throughout the week, the city schools are to be the willing hosts to the people of the community. Although one is free to visit the schools at any time, the Open School Week, which is now a national tradition, has been set aside as a special occasion with added inducements.

TOO many books were published last month. Some of the best were knocked down and trampled on by others of no perceptible merit, so that literary justice miscarried in several notable instances. One of the most flagrant was the case of "The Indefinite River,"* by Preston Schoyer. a fine and moving novel which received hardly any attention, much less the chorus or praise it deserves.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- Creation of a "committee to stop world communism" was announced today by the Polish American Congress.

An application office for Jacob Riis Houses will be opened by the New York City Housing Authority today at 9 A. M. at 22 Jackson Street, Manhattan, it was announced yesterday by Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the authority.

The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: A less tender cut of meat can challenge a steak any day if it's done up in the guise of Danish Goulash. Such a dish makes conservation fun and pays off in taste dividends.

Mayor O'Dwyer issued yesterday his Armistice Day proclamation while the war dead were honored in many of the city's churches. The Organized Reserve Corps and the Veterans of Foreign War will sponsor two parades in Fifth Avenue tomorrow, weather permitting.

A total of $750,000 in gifts from private institutions has been donated to the New York University College of Medicine for medical research projects, Dean Currier McEwen announced yesterday in his annual report to Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, chancellor of the university.

Gen. Salih Omurtak, Turkish Chief of Staff, who completed a thirty-two-day visit to United States military installations and industrial plants, asserted yesterday in a statement released before his departure last night from La Guardia Field for London that the tour had shown the visitors how to use and train personnel for the "modern weapons and equipment Turkey is buying from the United States to strengthen its own armed forces."

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The Communist leadership of the Paris Trade Union Federation has called upon the workers to attend en masse the funeral of Alfred Puzzuoli. The Communists allege he died as the result of injuries inflicted by the police when they broke up a Communist attempt to halt an antiSoviet meeting in Salle Wagram on Oct. 28.

Three journalists of South and Central America will receive Maria Moors Cabot Gold Medals from Columbia University tomorrow for "significant contributions to international friendship among the peoples and nations of the American continents."

The output of the United States economy increased about threefold between 1899 and 1939, according to new indexes of output, employment and productivity released yesterday by the National Bureau of Economic Research.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- Gen. A.A. Vandegrift, Marine Corps commandant, today heralded the 172d birthday of the "Leathernecks" with the reminder that marines must remain prepared in war and peace "since we have found that the peace must often be enforced."

Yesterday was a big one in the young life of the Yankees. The New York entrant in the AllAmerica Football Conference staged a thrilling rally to defeat the San Francisco Forty-Niners, 24 -- 16, at the Stadium. And, for the first time, they outdrew the Giants of the National League, their rivals for the affection of New York's fans.
NANKING, Nov. 9 -- The final step in the Government's banning of the Democratic League, the third most influential political group in China, was taken by the Interior Ministry today.

Denis N. Pritt, Labor party member of Parliament, declared here yesterday that "the get tough with Russia policy will not work" and predicted that the "AngloAmerican line-up against the Soviet Union" would not be maintained by Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- Delegates to the annual meeting of the Middle Atlantic section of the National Jewish Welfare Board pledged at the final session today the support of their constituent Jewish community centers to the President's food-conservation drive.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- Henry A. Wallace, former Vice President, said tonight that the United States would not seek peace "as long as the present combination of Wall Street men and military men is in charge of the Democratic party and the foreign policy of this nation."

A city claim for "millions of dollars" from the Federal Government for damage done to city piers during the war was recommended yesterday by Controller Lazarus Joseph in a report to the Board of Estimate. Funds thus obtained, he recommended, should be earmarked for waterfront rehabilitation.

Two years ago last February, as the Third, Fourth and Fifth Marine divisions were preparing for the coming assault on Iwo Jima, some of the men were set to work making small white wooden crosses. They took the crosses with them on the attack transports and unloaded them on the beaches along with the tanks and mortars and artillery and men.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 9 (U.P.) -- The Friendship Train moved through its second state tonight, halting here to take on two more carloads of food for hungry Europe before proceeding on its cross-country trip.

AMSTERDAM, Nov. 9 -- Important Government decisions regarding the Dutch price policy are imminent. The Government not only has decided to disallow further increases in wages, but it also seems to have determined to prevent any further rises in prices and to endeavor to apply the large profits of industries toward reduction of domestic prices.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Prices of oats averaged higher in the grain markets last week with corn and on buying induced by reports that consumption of this grain on farms was increasing because of its relatively low price compared with corn.

The nineteen men and one woman appointed on Saturday to serve as a Loyalty Review Board under the Federal Civil Service Commission can be depended upon to respect the civil rights of Federal employes. From Chairman Seth W. Richardson down along the line they are persons who are not in the least likely to become hysterical.

The Metropolitan Opera Association, will open its sixty-third season tonight with Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera," which has inaugurated the Metropolitan season only twice before, in November, 1916, and on Dec. 2, 1940, when the work was remounted and restored to the repertoire.

ALBANY, Nov. 9 -- John F. Sonnett, Assistant United States AttorneyGeneral, declared here today that in the United States, the economic freedom of the individual, as well as his political and religious freedom, was properly the concern of government.

Many children looked upon as mental defectives, including a percentage in state institutions, are mentally normal but emotionally disturbed to the point where innate abilities are blocked, Bernhard Scher, director of the Edenwald School for Boys, project of the Jewish Child Care Association of New York, said yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Monday, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Prime Minister Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru said today the Dominion of India had taken over, on a "temporary" basis, the administration of the predominantly Hindu Princely State of Junagadh, whose Moslem ruler acceded originally to Pakistan.

The end came on Saturday to Army's period of greatest glory on the gridiron. The one-point defeat by Columbia on Oct. 25 brought its four-year stretch of invincibility to a close, but it was the disaster at South Bend that definitely disclosed that West Point has run out of the super material of the Blanchard-Davis epoch.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Delegates arriving here today for the fifty-third annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs were amazed to learn that the controversial resolution on displaced persons on which they had expected to vote was suddenly withdrawn by its sponsor.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 9 (AP) -- Brooklyn's hapless Dodgers came within one point of engineering one of the major upsets of the pro football season today, bowing to the champion Cleveland Browns, 13 to 12, in a bruising All-America Football Conference game before 30,279 in Municipal Stadium.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Confirmation of a confident belief that the United States Government has concluded an agreement with Great Britain that will increase American use of natural rubber substantially in the future is still awaited. Meanwhile British authorities on the rubber industry contributed last week to the discussion that has been proceeding for some time on this subject and on the great importance of rubber to Britain's dollar earnings.

The New York Rangers last night announced that Frank Boucher, manager-coach had made an official protest to the National Hockey League president, Clarence Campbell over what he described as the extra rough play of Toronto's Wild Bill Ezinicki, The Associated Press reported.

BERLIN, Nov. 9 -- Voluminous statistical material prepared by United States Military Government economists and released today indicated that the Soviet Union had taken about $1,250,000,000 worth of reparations out of current production in the Soviet zone in Germany since the beginning of the occupation.

Prudencio Camacho, a 31-yearold able seaman, was one of seven volunteers who left the Army transport Charles A. Stafford in a lifeboat on the stormy North Atlantic last Tuesday to go to the aid of a little schooner that was at the mercy of a full gale and pounding waves.

New Yorkers are being offered the opportunity to contribute to a cause which seeks to provide recreational facilities for thousands of girls from overcrowded homes and congested streets. The annual fall campaign of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, 133 East Sixty-second Street, New York 21, opened on Oct. 14 and will close Dec. 10.

Hope for an agreement on implementing the partition of Palestine grew dimmer yesterday. It was learned that some, at least, of the United States experts who had spent the week-end studying the Canadian compromise proposal viewed it with disfavor.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 9 -- Leaders in the field of ceramics and sculpture took part today in a luncheon and forum held in connection with the opening of the twelfth national ceramics exhibition at the Syracuse Museum of Fine Arts.

LONDON, Nov. 9 -- Sentiment in financial and business circles has improved markedly as a result of the recent municipal elections. This is especially the case in regard to the stock markets, where the response has been surprising. The Socialist Government, it is being said, is on the way out, and although it may not go until 1950, many believe it certainly will go then.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The National Guard rallied to the de fense of the capital today agains a simulated strike of "enemy" bombers in the Guard's most ambitious post-war demonstration of it air and anti-aircraft arm.

A few hours after the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary docks here tomorrow most of her 1,200-man crew will begin extensive shopping tours of West Side food markets. Daily purchases of $12,000 to $15,000 are expected.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 -- Steel ingot output for the country dropped last week 1 point to 96 per cent of capacity. According to reports in the trade this was a normal fluctuation.

Led by the individual winner, Tommy Quinn, the New York Athletic Club monopolized honors yesterday in the annual Metropolitan A.A.U. senior cross-country championship run at Van Cortlandt Park. The Wing Footers captured the team title easily with an almost perfect score of 16 points.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- A world shortage of cocoa beans, with the British and Brazilian Governments controlling two-thirds of the available supplies, has placed American candy makers in a squeeze between, high costs for ingredients and prices consumers will pay for candy, confectionery industry spokesmen quoted at 52 cents.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: At Lake Success on Oct. 23 Chester Bowles, chairman of the International Advisory Committee of the United Nations Appeal for Children, stated that "unless governments in a position to assist take the initiative thousands of children under the age of 15 in the war devastated countries of Europe and Asia will not survive until funds collected in February can be put to use."

PRAGUE, Nov. 9 -- Strong anxiety is felt here that the fundamental political split in the nation may cause an open break either in the Cabinet or in Parliament this week. The essential cause of the expected crisis is that the Communists and Marxist Socialist cannot compromise on their demands that non-political organizations be represented in the Government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 (AP) -- President Truman was asked today for "an immediate, positive statement of the actual, official administration position on the free, competitive enterprise system." The request came from the National Federation of Small Business which made public a message to the President.

It is becoming increasingly clear that Array service did little harm to the technical equipment of most of the rising young American pianists whose careers were interrupted by the war. Joseph Battista, one of the most promising of them, provided another case in point yesterday afternoon when he gave his first post-war New York recital at Town Hall.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 -- Corn snowed relatively more strength than did wheat last week in the grain markets. Buying was induced by wet weather in parts of the Central West and by reports that the acre yield was disappointing in the Central West, compared with previous expectations.
LONDON, Monday, Nov. 10 -- Newspaper comment on the Harriman Committee's proposals for aid to Europe was generally favorable today.

More than forty new art exhibitions will open in local galleries this week, headed by a showing of oils, pastels and drawing's by Degas. This event, at the DurandRuel Galleries, has been arranged as a benefit for American Aid to France and will open with a preview, from 4 to 7 o'clock this afternoon, at which an admission charge of $5 will be made.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 9 -- Memorial Auditorium, the largest hall in Sacramento, has been leased for a state convention next Aug. 7 of the Independent Progressive Party of California, it was announced today.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- The strike of employes in the municipal public services, which had disrupted garbage removal, water supplies and sanitation in the hospitals for nearly a week, ended today. The strikers accepted the Government's assurances, which complied with most of the workers' demands.

MANILA, Nov. 9 -- President Manuel Roxas returned here today from a brief barnstorming trip to the Central Philippine provinces to prepare for last-minute parades and rallies preceding: next Tuesday's general elections, which will either cement or weaken his control over the political machines in the forty-eight provinces.

The New Friends of Music presented the Griller String Quartet and Joseph Schuster, 'cellist, in its second concert of the season at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon. Hindemith's Sonata for 'Cello and Piano, Op. 11, No. 3, between Beethoven's Quartets, Op. 95 and Op. 18, No. 3, provided some of the most rewarding listening in a program full of superior music-making.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 9 -- The majority of 186 German plants earmarked for reparations in the United states zone of Germany were designed entirely for producing war material, according to a Military Government bulletin that has just arrived here.

The machine gun hold-up in Boston on Oct. 30 in which six bandits made off with a payroll of $107,977 from the B.F. Sturtevant Company, a subsidiary of the Westinghouse Electric Company, was being cleared up rapidly last night.

Duke Ellington is the latest musical personality to be attracted by the emoluments of disk jockeying. He has accepted a fiveyear agreement with WMCA for a daily two-hour series, excepting Sundays, to be broadcast by transscription. Moreover, the disks are to be made available to other stations on a national scale through the local outlet, according to the announcement.

MANHASSET, L.I., Nov. 9 -- Having gone "night-clubbing" part of last night to arrest four youths, the police hereabouts today began extensive exploration of sewer catch basins of the North Shore to find jewelry the youths had allegedly discarded after a series of robberies.

BANGKOK, Siam, Nov. 9 -- A group of Siamese military officers led by Field Marshal Luang Pibul Songgram, wartime puppet dictator under the Japanese, seized control of Bangkok early today and announced that the Government of Premier Luang Dhamrong Nawasawat had been overthrown.

A discussion of the practical development of the all-aluminum seagoing ship is scheduled to take place at the fifty-fifth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers to be held at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel from Wednesday through Saturday.

Seven hundred and fifty members of the congregation of the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession, Trinity Parish, at Broadway and 155th Street, witnessed yesterday the dedication of a Colorado pine tree. It will be a memorial to the twenty members of the congregation who lost their lives in World War II.

PALANDARI, Kashmir, Nov. 7 (Delayed) (U.P.) -- Three thousand troops of Sir Hari Singh, the Hindu Maharajah of Kashmir, are bottled up in the mountains and face almost certain annihilation, rebel leaders said today in this primitive mountain town which is their headquarters.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Steelers weathered a heavy last-half aerial attack by Sammy Baugh today to defeat the Washington Redskins, 21 -- 14, before 36,257 fans and retain their slim lead in the Eastern Division of the National Football League.

CHICAGO, Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears staged two brilliant goal-line stands and blocked a game-tieing field goal try in the last 18 seconds to defeat the Green Bay Packers, 20 -- 17, in a National Football League thriller before an overflow crowd of 46,112 at Wrigley Field today.

PARIS, Nov. 9 -- Schiaparelli's midseason collection, which confirms the new length, eleven inches from the floor, is particularly handsome and wearable, replete wtih new ideas, among which figure pudding bowl hats of illusion net, fur and flat black feathers.

Two French symphonies figured on the program presented by the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra, under Charles Muench, yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. These were the Saint-Saens Symphony in C minor, No. 3, and the Honneger Symphony, No. 2.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 9 -- The Trailer Coach Manufacturers Association adopted tonight a series of basic standards which its members must meet to further the association's program to "clean-up and modernize" the majority of the 5,000 trailer parks in the country.

Catholics are "sick and tired of the hackneyed accusation that they are trying to unite church and state and bring the state under the subjection of the church," Msgr. Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, declared yesterday at the twelfth annual Armistice Day memorial mass of the Catholic War Veterans.

As the Marshall plan evolves into the European Recovery Program it becomes the blueprint for an economic partnership without precedent in international relationships. The Marshall plan was only a call for a plan, and the fade-out of the name is important because an operation called Recovery will be hard to combat in any part of Europe.

Never was Marian Anderson more the artist, or her singing more appealing and communicative, than at her recital last night in Carnegie Hall. There was a noble purity of spirit in her approach to her offerings that made them deeply affecting, as well as a sensitivity and finesse equaled by few vocalists of the day.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 9 (AP) -- The Buffalo Bills closed their home season today by handing the Los Angeles Dons their first shut-out in two years of All-America Football Conference competition, 25 -- 0. The crowd of 21,293, watching the game on a snow-covered, muddy field, brought Buffalo's home attendance to 217,706, an increase of 99,752 over 1946.
School-day memories were revived yesterday for thousands of parents who took advantage of the invitations issued by the Board of Education to inspect New York's public schools this week.

LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Nov. 10 (AP) -- A senior official of the International Olympics Committee tonight suggested the possibility that Russia will hold separate Olympic Games for the Soviet sphere of influence.

Representatives of the top two teams in both divisions of the All-America Football Conference will meet with Commissioner Jonas Ingram tomorrow to discuss plans for the championship play-off. New York and Buffalo in the East and Cleveland and San Francisco in the West will participate in the session at the Commodore Hotel, it was announced yesterday.

Liberty and democracy are losing their force in American education so that "young people today do not know what to believe in religion, politics and economics," Boyd H. Bode, professor emeritus of education at Ohio State University, said here yesterday.

Following is the text of the remarks of Bernard M. Baruch after the presentation to him of the Woodrow Wilson Award at the Woodrow Wilson Foundation's twenty-fifth anniversary dinner, held last night at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel:
Apartment seekers from all boroughs found their way yesterday to a new basement office on the Lower East Side of Manhattan.

Giovanni Papini, author of "The Life of Christ," has written a series of letters under the name of a fictitious Pope who "lived in an age similar to ours," expressing his thoughts on religion and present day conditions. The volume has been titled "The Letters of Pope Celestine VI to All Mankind" and will be published by Dutton on Jan. 5.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. announced today he would hold a hearing tomorrow morning to determine whether contempt citations recommended against ten Hollywood writers, directors and producers should be turned over to the District Attorney for prosecution.

METZ, France, Nov. 10 -- The first bonds offered by a French Department to help defray the cost of war-damage repairs were placed on sale today in the Department of Moselle. The Department occupies the French border region of Lorraine.
Chapter IV of the Sixteen Nation Report on the Marshall Plan deals with the subject of "Internal Economic, Financial and Monetary Stability." Section 68, under that chapter, reads in part as follows:
