DETROIT, Nov. 10 -- Premium gasoline derived from natural gas and coal will keep American automobiles operating for hundreds of years after the nation's reserves of crude petroleum have been exhausted.

For the benefit of American Aid to France, the Durand Ruel Galleries have opened an exhibition of oils, pastels and drawings by Degas. Under the honorary sponsorship of the Consul General of France, M. Ludovic Chancel, and with a distinguished list of sponsors, a preview was held yesterday afternoon.

Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio declared last night that United States aid to Europe in the amounts proposed by Secretary of State George C. Marshall and in the Harriman report would menace domestic economic stability and encourage European governments in unsound policies.
The Friendship Food Train sped eastward yesterday, its string of loaded box-cars growing longer and longer as it picked up foods that will help the hungry in France and Italy through this winter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The text of a proposed emergency foreign aid bill, submitted by the State Department today along with Secretary Marshall's plea for stopgap and long-range economic aid program, follows:

A disposition to consider housing a local problem, in which the principal assistance to be provided by the Federal Government would be in a lessening of taxes and restrictions, was indicated yesterday by two members of the Congressional Joint Committee on Housing.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- A group of holders of common stock of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, including eleven associates of the investment banking firm of Dillon, Read Co., New York, realized a "paper profit" of $9,825;000 this afternoon on an original investment of $150,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The Maritime Commission went ahead with its now highly controversial plans to sell 100 surplus tankers to foreign-flag operators -- ships whose construction today would cost an estimated $450,000,000 -- at a time when no American operator apparently would take one of them as a gift, Vice Admiral W. W. Smith, chairman of the commission, said today.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to ''save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

BANGKOK, Siam, NOV. 10 (U.P.) -- Khuang Aphaiwong, Siamese Premier briefly in 1944 and again in 1946, and a recognized democratic leader, was named Premier of a new Cabinet today by the military clique that seized power in a pre-dawn bloodless coup yesterday.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES :

The long-drawn-out strike in the Bethlehem Steel Company's shipyards in this area came to an end yesterday with ratification of an agreement covering wages and working conditions by workers in the company's two Brooklyn yards.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The Labor Government began in the House of Commons today its historic task of whittling down the delaying powers of the House of Lords from two years to one. The Conservative Opposition fought manfully without the leadership of Winston Churchill, who is confined to his home with a cold.

Reconsideration of the Government's monetary policy to determine its influence on the inflationary trend and "the price we are willing to pay for easy money" was recommended yesterday by Sherwin C. Badger, vice president and financial secretary of the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company. He spoke to 450 bank officers and trustees at a meeting of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The State and Army Departments announced today that persons persecuted during the Nazis' reign could henceforth obtain restitution of property robbed from them in what is now the United States occupation zone of Germany.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Prime Minister Attlee, speaking at the most austere banquet given by the Lord Mayor of London in Britain's peacetime history, said tonight that the world knew of Britain's difficulties but did not sufficiently understand the magnitude of the nation's efforts to overcome them.

VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., ,Nov. 10 (AP) -- Federal agencies are admitting that the Government "must find some way to work more constructively with business," the American Trade Association Executives was told by their president at their annual meeting today.

The stock market operated yesterday within a narrow range and in a fashion typical of a pre-holiday session. The results of the trading: were inconclusive and provided no indication as to the immediate course of prices. A slightly irregular higher trend prevailed at the clese, with the combined averages up 0.40 point on the day.

The gala premiere last night of the Metropolitan Opera's sixty-third season drew to the world's pre-eminent lyric theatre an assemblage of distinguished guests, upholding as in decades past the traditional splendor of the Metropolitan's first night.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Four labor leaders, a trade association president and an ex-union business agent who is now a business man were subpoenaed today to appear before the House Labor subcommittee to answer conspiracy charges and other allegations made by Fred H. Fry, a Chicago contractor.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 -- Low productivity and high cost of labor, restrictive trade practices by some manufacturers of building materials and building codes which show favoritism to certain products have replaced Government controls as the chief drawbacks to an adequate supply of housing at a reasonable price, leaders in the industry reported today at the annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Immediate and urgent action to provide $597,000,000 of new aid to Europe was urged upon the reconvening Congress today by Secretary Marshall.
Celebrating the centenary of the founding of Cartier's in 1847, the shop held a preview yesterday of its latest creations, on exhibition until Nov. 15, showing classic and unique modern designs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Howard Hughes swore today that vain attempts to obtain a loan of $200,000 from him to finance a $10,000,000 bond deal were "made in wartime by the air materiel officer, Maj. Gen. Bennett E, Meyers, who approved one of the disputed Hughes war contracts.
Following is the text of Senator Robert A. Taft's speech on the Marshall plan and American foreign policy delivered before the Ohio Society here last night:

With a cargo that included 214 cases of relief supplies for the Netherlands, the Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam left the Fifth Street pier, Hoboken, at 4:15 P.M. yesterday, carying 604 passengers bound for Southampton and Rotterdam.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:
The Index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- New rules of procedure for the United Nations General Assembly were completed today by a legal subcommittee. They include a new voting system that it had been hoped would solve the deadlock on the election of a successor to Poland on the Security Council; but prevailing opinion here today was that it would not solve the impasse.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange made net gains of 57 to 76 points yesterday, influenced by a smaller-than-expected cotton crop estimate from the Government, and talk of heavier-than-expected requirements for European aid.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Representatives of Britain's film industry were understood today to have urged Harold Wilson, President of the Board of Trade, to use his influence to seek a reduction in current British duties on American films.

The American people must not be "deceived" by reports of "some political observers" that the food situation in Europe is improving, the Rev. Dr. Edwin T. Dahlberg, pastor of the First Baptist Church, Syracuse, N.Y., and president of the Northern Baptist Convention, said last night at Riverside Church.
CINCINNATI, Ohio, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Twenty-six bush leaguers got their chance at baseball's big time today, as thirteen clubs paid $245,000 for them in the annual draft.

The Bermuda Sky Queen, which crash-landed in the Atlantic Oct. 14 alongside the Coast Guard Cutter Bibb, which saved all its personnel, was overloaded by two and a half tons when it left Foynes, Eire, the night before, witnesses said yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- Far from being a "dead issue," the controversial displaced persons resolution was very much alive and kicking today as the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs opened officially.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The United Nations reopened discussion of relations with Franco Spain today -- only to run into an opening campaign to block a full debate on the perennial topic.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The United States and the Soviet Union reconciled their basic differences over Palestine today to support a new United Nations plan for enforcement of partition under which Britain would end both her mandate and her military occupation of the Holy Land by next May 1.

A campaign to increase the shipping of gift packages to Italy was opened yesterday in the offices of the Italian Consul General at 7 East Eighty-fourth Street. Vincent R. Impellitteri, president of the City Council, purchased the first package as he urged support of the drive to aid the needy in Italy.
Mayor O'Dwyer officiated yesterday at the closing of a dormitory for service men opened during World War II by the Masons of New York in Masonic Hall, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Nov. 10 -- A vastly superior Montclair High School football team triumphed over the West Orange High Cowboys, 26 -- 0, in the tenth renewal of their series at Woodman Field here today.
Luxurious jewelry, furs and gowns helped to make a gala scene before the footlights last night at the opening performance at the Metropolitan Opera.
Detroit, Mich., issued yesterday invitations for bids to be submitted by Nov. 26 for $6,329,000 of transit revenue bonds dated Feb. 1, 1947, and due on each Feb. 1 from 1945 to 1960.

LONDON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Gordon Richards, the office boy who answered a want ad for a stable boy's job and became the world's champion winning jockey, set another British turf record today by riding his 260th winner in one season.
In victory or defeat, with or without Doc Blanchard and Glenn Davis, Army continues to be a power to reckon with on the football field.
A Surprise From Mr. Byrnes A friend of this department, who was talking recently of Mr. Byrnes' current book, "Speaking Frankly," had this to say:

BRUSSELS, Nov. 10 -- Fourteen nations, with eight others sitting in as observers, participated today in the opening session here of the conference known as a study group for a European customs union. It is an offshoot of the recent Paris conference on the Marshall plan and is said to have been inspired by William L. Clayton, former Under-Secretary of State for Economic Affairs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Following is the text of President Truman's covering letter and of the State Department's report to Congress, made public today, on United States aid to Greece and Turkey:

Recent experiences in Colorado prove that the people can have good government if they want to work for it. Dr. Florence R. Sabin of Denver said last night before the American Woman's Association meeting in the Hotel Barclay. Dr. Sabin, who was selected as the November "Woman of the Month" received a certificate to that effect from. Mrs. Natalie C. Linderholm, president of the woman's group.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 10 -- Following the exclusive endorsement of Walter P. Reuther by Philip Murray, the convention of the United Automobile Workers, CIO, voted its support of its chief executive this evening by agreeing to comply with the requirement of the Taft-Hartley Labor Law that union leaders file affidavits affirming their non-Communist standing.

NEWCOMB, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The hunter who demands wilderness solitude would find everything his heart desires at Camp Santanoni For the only other living things we encountered during our first day in these hills were a bear and three deer, but there is more to the story.

Lieut. Bob St. Onge, a fair-to-middlin' center at West Point several years ago, told the Football Writers Association at its weekly luncheon-meeting at Toots Shor's yesterday that Army hopes to "take" Pennsylvania on Saturday. However, Earl (Red) Blaik'a emissary conceded it would not be an easy assignment.

With demand for corsets and brassieres continuing strong, manufacturers find themselves in a price squeeze owing to rising costs of fabrics, trimmings and other materials, according to exhibitors at the spring Corset Brassiere Show at the Hotel New Yorker.

Consumer resistance to highpriced electric ranges with "too many unnecessary gadgets" is becoming apparent, retailers and distributors stated yesterday. They emphasized that all range models are moving satisfactorily because of continuing' shortages but pointed out that many customers have decided to pass up deluxe models and wait for less expensive standard merchandise.

Hotel and restaurant buyers are contracting for about double their normal canned food purchases now, O. C. Stuhmer, sales manager of H. J. Heinz Company, Pittsburgh, Pa., food packers, revealed in an interview at the opening of the 32d National Hotel Exposition at Grand Central Palace yesterday.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Approved six resolutions recommending admission to United Nations of Ireland, Portugal, Trans-Jordan, Italy, Finland and Austria.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Nov. 10 -- The first strike called by the International Typographical Union, AFL, in support of its "no contract" policy failed to halt publication of today's issue of The Nassau Daily Review-Star.

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- With the account ending tomorrow and the budget speech to follow on Wednesday, public interest in the stock markets here today was at a very low ebb. Business was confined generally to leveling up by jobbers.

Verdi's "Masked Ball" opened the 1947-48 season of the Metrorpolitan Opera Association last night in the historic theatre at Broadway and Thirty-ninth Street. It also opened the Metropolitan season of 1914 and the Metropolitan season of 1940. One is driven to ask why?

BERLIN, Nov. 10 -- An open revolt in the Social Democratic party has been revealed here as result of the espousal by Kurt Schumacher, the party's leader, of a separate peace for the Western zones of Germany. It is believed that Herr Schumacher's popularity and skill as a leader will prevent any deep party split.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Support of the National Association of Manufacturers for a foreign-aid program for Europe, operating through a specially created Federal corporation and safeguarded by a number of "specific conditions," was announced today by Earl Bunting, president of the organization.

Mrs. Mildred E. French of the Wayside Farm in Broomall, Pa., who bakes Aunt Martha's whisky and gin-with-rum cakes, which have been mentioned here in other seasons, has utilized liquor as a flavoring again. This time it is in an assortment of candies that are named, rather appropriately, Tipsy chocolates.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 10 -- More than 900 physicians resigned today, as predicted, from the doctors' panel of San Francisco's Health Service System, which provides medical care for 18,000 city employes and their dependents, but spokesmen for the system asserted that it would continue in operation.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 10 -- Three hundred private agencies in the United States are giving financial support today to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, compared with only forty organizations interested in its work a year ago.
The servicemen who sacrificed their lives in war so that freedom might live will receive homage today from the city, military and civic organizations, and churches in special Armistice Day services.

A second piece or silverware went into the keeping of the United States Army in perpetuity last night when Capt. Jonathan R. Burton, riding Air Mail, won the international individual military championship challenge trophy at the National Horse Show before 12,000 in Madison Square Garden.

In its efforts to rectify at least some of the wrongs committed by the Nazi regime, the American Military Government in Germany has now promulgated a law providing for the greatest possible restitution of their property to all those who, after Hitler's accession to power, were unlawfully deprived of it for reasons of race, religion, nationality, ideology or political opposition.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 10 -- RKO and United Artists have announced the cancellation of the deal whereby U.A. expected to purchase four completed pictures, "Out of the Past," "Station West," "Return of the Badmen" and "Indian Summer," from RKO.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Oklahoma must admit a qualified Negro applicant to its state university's law school.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- A case involving overtime pay for longshoremen, arising in New York City, and which is of great concern to the Federal Government, was promised a Supreme Court review today.

Use of city relief funds to pay assessments levied by any union or group was specifically forbidden yesterday by Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, who returned to his desk after a week's stay in Doctors Hospital.

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 -- Long profit-taking in wheat and other grains, with a lull in the demand resulted in lower prices all around on the Board of Trade today, although there was a moderate recovery from the low spots. Commission houses were buyers of wheat, especially the deferred deliveries on the setbacks, and selling was largely of a local character.

A third degree assault charge against Patrolman James P. Harrington of the East Fifty-first Street station, and a charge of disorderly conduct against Murray Backer, Associated Press photographer, were dismissed in Mid-Manhattan Court yesterday by Magistrate Arthur Markewich.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Robert R. Young, chairman of the board of the Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, and Robert J. Bowman, its president, filed today a brief with the Interstate Commerce Commission in support of their proposal that they be permitted to hold directorships in the New York Central, with an ultimate merger of the two systems in view.

MINEOLA, L.I., Nov. 10 -- Tax rates for general county and state court purposes remained unchanged, while the rate for the county police is up 10 cents on every $100 of assessed valuation, in the proposed budget of J. Russel Sprague, county executive, filed today with the clerk of the Board of Supervisors.

Whether or not Secretary Marshall's remarks at Harvard last June incorporated a "Plan" has been in dispute. Secretary Marshall himself insisted they did not. Now there can be no more doubt. The economic, political and psychological energies released by the Harvard speech have been tremendous.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES :
Marked decreases in the numbers of students studying foreign languages in New York's public schools are causing concern among officials at the Board of Education, it became known yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- A thirteen-member United Nations subcommittee today moved a step nearer to ending an impasse on the fate of remaining European refugees and displaced persons.
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 10 (AP) -- Tim B, out of the Mt. Desert Stable and with Chris Rogers aboard, accounted for the Tamworth, headline event of this afternoon's racing at Rockingham Park.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt had his colors carried to their second stakes triumph in two racing days when Newsweekly, a home-bred son of New World and Spot News, annexed the twelfth running of the Sagamore Stakes, named after the winning owner's breeding farm.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

An elaborate Christmas show for children featuring a Santa Claus billed as "the tallest in the world," circus acts, a candy castle, Mother Goose animals, an Eskimo and an Indian village, carol singing and instructional exhibits will take place at Grand Central Palace Dec. 20 through Dec. 28.

With a prayer for a revisitation of Woodrow Wilson's spirit to lead the nations to world order, Bernard M. Baruch last night uttered a solemn warning that despite "clashing ideologies" the United Nations must be made to succeed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Farmers who try to read the Federal Register, formal Government publication, would never need crop insurance, for they would never get time to plant any crops, Justice Robert H. Jackson stated sarcastically today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- A series of resolutions that would place the General Assembly on record as favoring the admission of Ireland, Portugal, TransJordan, Italy, Finland and Austria to the United Nations was approved here today by the Assembly's Political and Security Committee.

PRAGUE, Nov. 10 -- Czechoslovakia's Communist Premier, Klement Gottwald, is returning to Prague tomorrow to a sharpened Government crisis as a result of his failure to impose on the Democrats, the majority party in Slovakia, his proposal for the transfer from Slovakia to his Central Government of the ultimate authority to appoint delegates to the Slovak Board of Ministers.
JACK LAVELLE, breezier and jollier than usual as a result of the outstanding scouting job he had just completed for Notre Dame on Army, bustled briskly into the middle of the huddle.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Former Governor Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota asserted today that it was still "too early" for him to say whether he would, support Senator Joseph H. Ball, who went to Congress originally as his appointee, in Mr. Ball's bid for re-election next year.

Market Holiday Security and commodity markets throughout the United States will be closed today in observance of Armistic Day. In Canada, grain and security markets will shut down for Remembrance Day. London markets will operate as usual.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The United States is still shipping lendlease and UNRRA relief goods to the Soviet Union despite the growing political and economic differences between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- Although of necessity the United States $300,000,000 relief program in Greece has shown few results thus far, it is "responsible for the fact that Greece is still free" and has averted economic collapse there, President Truman reported to Congress today.

NANKING, Nov. 10 -- Government troops have evacuated Chengting, ten miles north of Shihkiachwang, in their four-day battle with attacking Communist forces for control of the strategic Niangtze [Amazon] Pass in Hopeh Province.

BARAMULA, Kashmir, India, Nov. 10 -- This quiet city in the beautiful Kashmir Valley was left smoking, desolate and full of horrible memories by invading frontier tribesmen who held a thirteen-day saturnalia of looting, raping and killing here.

James J. McGuinn of 118 Eighth Avenue, Brooklyn, regional representative, Bureau of Old Age and Survivors Insurance, of the Social Security Administration and member of the Social Security staff since its founding in 1936, died of a heart attack in the City Hospital, Worcester, Mass., on Sunday, according to word received here yesterday.

Notre Dame strengthened its position as the No. 1 college football team, of the country by its convincing burst of power against Army, according to most of the 169 writers participating in the weekly Associated Press poll.

PARIS, Nov. 10 -- The stop-gap aid for France of $328,000,000 that Secretary of State Marshall proposed today fell short by some $29,000,000 of the amount the French had requested in last summer's European conference. It was therefore thought that this Government might be compelled to cut down its short-range imports.

Field Marshal Luang Pibul Songgram, virtual dictator of Siam from 1938 to 1944, has again seized power in a bloodless coup. Whatever the motivation for the overthrow of the government of Rear Admiral Nawasawat, and however the present political crisis in Siam may develop, one observation seems fairly safe.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 10 -- The treason trial ended today when the Bucharest military tribunal restricted Dr. Juliu Maniu, Ion Mihalachae and Dr. Ili Lazar in their final pleas in their own defense.

Voluntary food conservation in the United States must continue even after the emergency goal of 100,000,000 bushels of wheat for Europe has been met, Don Belding, vice chairman of the President's Citizens Food Committee, said yesterday.

A conflict between a provision of the President's Reorganistion Plan Number 3 of 1946 and the subsequent Administrative Procedure Act has made it virtually impossible for the Coast Guard to carry out its duties relating to hearings affecting safety regulations at sea, it became known yesterday.

Foreign traders and exchange specialists here yesterday foresaw some benefits for French export trade if the franc is devalued by the end of the year, as forecast in reports from Geneva and Paris. They were inclined to agree with the prediction, but expressed doubt of similar action by Great Britain or Belgium.

The New York premiere of the first motion picture produced by the Protestant Film Commission was held yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, at Fifty-fifth Street, under the auspices of the Protestant Council of the City of New York.

With domestic steel mills operating at an average rate of 97.6 per cent of ingot capacity during the month, steel production in October amounted to 7,564,302 net tons of ingots and steel for castings, a peacetime record, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Nov. 10 -- William H. Davies of 657 Boulevard, Mayor of Westfield in 1933-34, and retired treasurer of the Delaware Hudson Railroad, with which he was associated for sixty years, died yesterday at his home of a heart attack.

Riding the crest of record public support, the Metropolitan Opera formally opened shop last night for its sixty-third season. The opera, chosen to suit the occasion, was Verdi's "Masked Ball," which is set in the lavish Swedish court of the eighteenth century and which, in the masked ball scene, vies successfully with the splendid accouterments of an opening night audience in 1947.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 10 -- Registration statements covering $4,000,000 of bonds and 245,000 shares of common stock were filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission today by two companies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The statement made to the Joint House-Senate committee today by Secretary of State Marshall, read in combination with the reports on foreign aid by the Herter and Harriman committees, establishes in fact a surprising forecast of last week.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 10 -- Tighter control over food imports was announced today by Dr. Hans Schlange-Schoeningen, Director of Food and Agriculture in the British occupation zone of Germany. He also disclosed that collections from the potato harvest had barely achieved 50 per cent of the Western zones' target.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 10 -- The Soviet Union is in no position to start a war at this moment or within the foreseeable future, according to Brazil's former Ambassador to Moscow, Mario de Pimentel Brandao, and his first secretary, Manoel Pio Correa, who arrived here tonight.
LONDON, Nov. 10 -- The average Briton is eating today much less than was considered the minimum necessary to keep an unemployed man in health during the worst days of the economic depression in 1933.

Douglas Johnson, pianist, gave a recital last night at Carnegie Hall. He was heard in a program containing Haydn's Sonata in E flat; Schubert's "Impromptu" in G major, Op. 90, No. 3; Prokofieff's Sonata, No. 3; Schumann's "Etudes Symphoniques"; a Chopin group; the Auber-Liszt "Tarantella di Bravura"; Liszt's "Valse Oubliee," and two novelties, Eugene Kurtz' Sonatine and Willis Charkovsky's "Allegro."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The decline in exports during September was particularly large in chemical products, textile manufactures, machinery and dairy products, the Department of Commerce reported today.

Dan Golenpaul, producer of "Information Please," filed a complaint yesterday with the National Labor Relations Board accusing the American Federation of Musicians, headed by James C. Petrillo, of two violations of the TaftHartley law.
OGDEN, Utah, Nov. 10 (AP) -- America's Friendship Train comprised today thirty-one carloads of foodstuffs as it headed east from Ogden, Utah's Gov. Herbert B. Maw in command.

Lawrence K. Frank, director of the Caroline Zachry Institute of Human Development here since 1945, and Miss Catherine Mackenzie, parent-child editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, will share the fourth annual $1,000 Lasker Award of the National Committee for Mental Hygiene, Dr. George S. Stevenson, the committee's medical director, announced yesterday.

Walter S. Franklin, vice president in charge of traffic for the Long Island Rail Road, told George A. Arkwright, Public Service Commissioner, yesterday that despite additional revenues from other sources, the railroad would have an estimated deficit of $3,750,000 for this year.

Isaac Stern and Leonard Bernstein collaborated last night in presenting two unusual and seldom-heard violin concertos at the eighth concert of the New York City Symphony's season at the City Center. One was by Haydn. The other was the second violin concerto of Karol Szymanowski, Polish-Ukrainian composer, who died ten years ago.

In a reversal of a decision which it made several months ago, the Federal Communications Commission has denied the application of The New York Daily News for a frequency-modulation radio station and given a license instead to the Radio Corporation of the Board of Missions and Church Extension of the Methodist Church.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- The Government offered today to buy up hens which do not lay many eggs and put them into "deep freeze" for later use. The move is designed to save upwards of 30,000,000 bushels of grain for Europe in the next eleven months.

Expressing doubt that the current volume can be maintained in the fur industry, the Associated Fur Coat and Trimming Manufacturers, Inc., warned its members yesterday that they may be headed for setbacks in the coming year.

WASHINGTON, Nov 10 (AP) -- Secretary of State Marshall's prepared statement on a European recovery program, presented today to a joint meeting of the Senate and House committees dealing with foreign relations, follows:

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The "$64 question" of how to check the upward flight of living costs was discussed tonight at the 105th forum of the "What's on Your Mind?" series conducted by THE NEW YORK TIMES.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Robert Kenny, counsel for ten Hollywood figures accused of contempt by the House Un-American Activities subcommittee, protested today the "short notice" of Speaker Martin in calling a certification hearing.

A bevy of glamorous fashion models literally picked up their rugs and walked in a unique, mobile floor-covering show held yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore. The rug parade followed the fall luncheon meeting of the home furnishings division of the Fashion Group.

Delayed until today by Saturday's unusual cancellation of a collegiate football contest on account of rain, New York "University will oppose Buckneli at the Yankee Stadium. The Violets are slight favorites in the fifth meeting of the teams. The kick-off is at 2 P.M. and a crowd of 10,000 is expected.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (U.P.) -- A New York attorney waved copies of a detective magazine carrying stories on "Bargains in Bodies" and "Girl Slave to a Love Cult" before the Supreme Court today and demanded a rule that would ban "such trash."
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 -- The European Recovery Program is in brief as follows:

CHICAGO, Nov. 10 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 13,000 head, total 18,500; market opened slow, 25 to 50 cents lower but later trade was moderately active, with most sales around 25 cents lower than on Friday:

LONDON, Nov. 10 -- Flatly opposing the United States and Britain, the Soviet Union proposed today that discussion of an Austrian peace treaty be placed last on the agenda of the Council of Foreign Ministers for the meeting opening here Nov. 25.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 10 -- The Soviet Union and its satellites failed today to block consideration by the United Nations General Assembly of estimated budgets for the proposed Korean Commission and the year-round "Little Assembly."

Armistice Day ceremonies at Arlington Cemetery, with President Truman, and Secretary of State Marshall's appearance before the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs, will be covered today by the combined television facilities of WABD, WCBS-TV and WNBT, according to Lawrence Phillips, director of the DuMont television network.

HAROLD E. STASSEN is a politician who seems to enjoy sticking his neck out. When his rival candidates for the Republican Presidential nomination were all coyly blushing and modestly looking down at their shoe laces Mr. Stassen spoke up in meeting and admitted right out loud that he would like very much to be President.

Harmonica played a merry tune for her supporters in the Chrysanthemum Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. With a crowd of 27,516 fans on hand for the next-to-last day's turf proceedings in the metropolitan area, the 3-year-old daughter of Snark ran neatly to take the feature event by four lengths and satisfy her hackers to the tune of $7.10.

GENEVA, Nov. 10 -- Four major air powers today presented new capacity clauses on which they had agreed over the week-end in the International Civil Aviation Orginization Conference on a multilateral civil aviation agreement.

Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, advocated yesterday permissive incorporation of member firms. Mail balloting on a constitutional amendment relating to the issue will end on Nov. 20.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES :

Oscar Homolka, who scored several seasons ago on the Main Stem as the gruff, but basically kind Uncle Chris in "I Remember Mama," has signed the necessary papers by which he will be starred in the forthcoming "Strange Anniversary."

Perhaps some Brooklynites realized that a historic Flatbush tradition was shattered on Sunday, but they did not say much about it. For the first time since 1796 the bell of the Reformed Protestant Dutch, Church of Flatbush failed to summon the faithful to Sunday services at Flatbush and Church Avenues.
RAHWAY, N.J., Nov. 10 -- The two-story stable that Joel La Farge built about eighty years ago in what is now the heart of Rahway, at 265 Hamilton Street, is a museum today.

New mattresses made of foamed latex, heavier steel coils and layers of hair, in various combinations, are being offered to meet the demand for firmer bedding reported yesterday by buyers for several bedding departments here. Sales of bedboards with purchases of new sleeping equipment were criticized by several spokesmen, who declared they implied a deficiency in the quality of the bedding.

Sales of leading mail order and chain store companies increased 17.7 per cent in October over the corresponding month of 1946, according to a compilation of forty-four companies made yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES. The inrcrease in September was 19.9 per cent.

The Young Men's Christian Association goal in its 1948 campaign for funds will be $449,471, it was announced last night at its ninety-fifth annual dinner, attended by 700 persons at the Roosevelt Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 10 (AP) -- President Truman sent to Congress today a report on lend-lease operations covering final settlements with the Netherlands and the Union of South Africa.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- The key to "our success abroad and our prosperity at home" is production, Carrol Reece, chairman of the Republican National Committee, declared here tonight before the Abraham Lincoln National Republican Club.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The gap between Russia and the United States on the question of Allied representation at the peace conference on Germany widened today as the fourth meeting of the Big Four Foreign Ministers' deputies ended, as had its predecessors, in frustration.
Eleven thousand reservists, members of veterans' and other groups marched through city streets yesterday to Armistice Day memorial services.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration introduced today a house-building inspectipn procedure designed, it said, to improve the quality of new homes for veterans.

Smashing of the stolen-car racket on a country-wide scale and stricter examinations for drivers' licenses to reduce accidents were urged yesterday at the fifteenth annual conference of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators in the Hotel New Yorker.

Capitalism is in greater danger today than ever before, but the imminent threat is from socialism rather than communism, the convention of the Grocery Manufacturers of America was told, yesterday. The warning came from Thomas R. Reid, a United States delegate to the International Labor Conference in Geneva.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Out under conditions that migrating geese with well - oiled and weather - resistant feathers shunned, the dinghy sailors at the Larchmont Yacht Club carried on today in their second of the uncertain-season's championship regatta here.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 -- Following the resignation of 934 physicians from the panel of the San Francisco Health Service System, which provides medical care for the 12,000 city employes and their dependents, letters were put in the mails today inviting nonmembers of the County Medical Society to join the panel.

The eighty-nine voluntary hospitals in New York are faced with the largest fiscal operating deficits in their histories because of the upward spiraling of food and service costs, the United Hospital Fund reported yesterday.

A Voice From the Country Hezekiah Cobb, unterrified fox-hunter, who, as you may have heard, now follows hounds in a Jeep, has been in town for the Horse Show. He has not, he says, seen so many people-riding horses since everybody rode horses, or so many people driving horses, in a coon's age.

With the beginning of winter already felt in western Europe, the immediate extension of interim relief for the needy nations there should be started at a pace parelleling the legislative action of Congress, Earl O. Shreve, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, asserted yesterday.

The battleship New Mexico, veteran of ten Pacific island invasions, became the center of another type of battle yesterday that promised to reverberate through the halls of the Navy Department and the White House.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 11 -- Dr. Ford Ashman Carpenter, internationally known meteorologist and aeronaut, died here last night at Queen of the Angels Hospital after an illness of several weeks. His age was 79.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Andrei A. Gromyko, Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister, today attacked the policy of the United States and Great Britain toward the Franco regime in Spain, which he accused of sheltering thousands of Nazi refugees.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- A two-year agreement between the Lustron Corporation, prospective producer of low-cost, steel-enameled prefabricated houses, and three American Federation of Labor building trades unions was announced here today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- India has decided to withdraw from the race for membership on the United Nations Security Council, it was learned tonight, and indications were that the Ukraine might be elected to succeed Poland without opposition.

The major part of Senator Taft's address before the Ohio Society dealt with the Marshall Plan. Yet the impression conveyed was not that of a single continuing thesis but of an assortment of short theses which, although loosely tied together, were treated as though each of them existed in a complete vacuum.

A bright, prosperous future for the Territory of Hawaii was predicted yesterday by Miss Eleanor Prendergast, an authority on the history of the islands, who is visiting the mainland after completing thirty years in government service in Honolulu.
HONOLULU, Nov. 11 (AP) -- E.J. (Dutch) Harrison, in front all the way, won the $10,000 Hawaiian open golf tournament today with a blistering 13-under-par 275.

Nothing since the opening of the General Assembly has enlivened and heartened the United Nations like the accord between the Soviet Union and the United States on Palestine. In the exhilaration that swept through the corridors at Lake Success following the mutual concessions made on this issue, one had a sudden and poignant vision of what might have been, and what might be, if Big Two agreement were the rule instead of the startling exception.

When the football Giants face the Steelers in Pittsburgh next Sunday Tex Coulter, who was transferred to end by Coach Steve Owen, may find himself back at the tackle post at which he starred for Army. Owen indicated this possibility at the weekly luncheon in the Polo Grounds press room yesterday when a second knee injury to Frank Cope, which apparently has ended his usefulness for the season, was mentioned.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Representative George H. Bender of Ohio called on the House Committee on Expenditures in the Executive Department today to investigate proposals to impose on Federal civilian agencies the security restrictions on information which apply in the armed forces.

Further testimony that the flight of the airplane Bermuda Sky Queen, forced down in mid Atlantic last month, should never have been undertaken was presented before Robert W. Chrisp and a panel of the Civil Aeronautics Board's safety division here yesterday.
The toll of a near-by bell rolled lightly across Madison Square Park at 11 A.M. yesterday as the city and veterans' organizations paid silent homage to New York's war dead before the Eternal Light.

Orders for labor-saving equipment in large quantities were reported yesterday as record crowds of hotel and restaurant buyers continued to jam Grand Central Palace at the thirty-second National Hotel Exposition, manufacturers disclosed yesterday.

Small hats, close-fitting and feminine with flowers and feathers, were presented for spring and resort wear yesterday by Peg Fischer at the Ritz-Carlton. This designer likes youthful bonnets, pretty little sailors that tilt to the back of the head, and saucy cloches and bretons.

Propelled by high motives, two non-profit organizations will merge forces to present plays at the City Center, Jan. 5-Feb. 14. Joining hands with the municipally-operated house will be Theatre Incorporated as the producing ally of the City Center Theatre Company.

The Society of American Etchers, Gravers, Lithographers and Woodcutters, Inc., opened its thirty - second annual exhibition yesterday with a preview reception in the galleries of the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

MONTREAL, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Judgment was withheld today in the case of William Ezinicki pending presentation of arguments by prosecution and defense, specifically Frank Boucher of the Rangers and Connie Smythe of the Maple Leafs.

The Simmons Company has raised the list price of its Beauty-rest mattress from $49.50 to $59.50, effective Nov. 24, it was learned yesterday. Retailers regard the action as the first step toward a general increase in wholesale bedding prices ranging up to 10 per cent.

The Friendship Food Train grew to forty-two cars yesterday when eleven carloads of contributions to Europe's hungry from citizens of Idaho, Oregon, Washington and Wyoming were added at two Wyoming cities.
Details of a plan designed to start a wave of apartment construction throughout the country were made public yesterday by the National Committee on Housing.

The great riders of the Mexican Army team won the foremost team event of the National Horse Show, the International Military Perpetual Challenge Trophy competition, to climax that glittering equine carnival before 12,000 in Madison Square Garden last night.
SANTANONI, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- The four inches of snow that fell during the night should have made for perfect deer shooting, but instead it made hunting more difficult than normal.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 11 -- Dr. Juliu Maniu, leader of the Opposition Peasant party and a former Premier, and Ion Mihalache, vice president of the party, were convicted of treason tonight by a Bucharest military tribunal and sentenced to life imprisonment.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 -- Supplies of fuel oil next winter and of gasoline next summer will be about 5 percent less than the demand, provided the oil industry equalizes its output of the two products during the next seven months so that each product will be brought to the market in approximately the same ratio to their respective demands.

American Airlines announced here last night that it had suspended all Douglas DC-6 services, effective at midnight, and at the same time in Chicago the United Airlines was grounding craft of the same type "until any possible hazards have been eliminated from the planes."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- In some news photographs of the hearings before the joint House-Senate committee on the preliminary and long-range phases of the European recovery program there can be observed a worried countenance under a broad cranium on which the once-abundant dark hair is very sparse indeed.

An increase in the five-cent fare sufficient to meet the deficit in operation and maintenance of the city's transportation system has been approved by the executive committee of the Civil Service Forum and will be submitted to delegates at a meeting next Tuesday.

Recent research on growth and development has "profound importance" for youth organizations as well as for schools and homes, Lawrence K. Frank, director of the Caroline Zachry Institute of Human Development, declared yesterday. He spoke at the first of a discussion series on "The High School Years," at the Parents League of New York, 50 East Sixty-ninth Street.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 11 -- The selection of Sophomore Bob Raines as starting fullback for the Princeton game was the top news at Yale football headquarters today.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- After meeting an onslaught by Winston Churchill in his most terrific fighting form, the Labor Government rammed through the House of Commons tonight the bill to reduce the delaying powers of the House of Lords from two years to one.

George Washington, Fort Hamilton and Newtown annexed the team titles yesterday in the Public Schools Athletic League boroughs cross-country championship runs at Van Cortlandt Park. The Bronx divisional race was held last Friday with Bronx Science gaining the team laurels.

aBishop Loughlin of Brooklyn captured its sixteenth consecutive team title yesterday in the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association city cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park with a low-point total of 74. Donald Anderson of Fordham Prep was the individual winner with, a 13:50.6 clocking for the two-and-one-half-mile course.

Thomas F. Farrell, chairman of the New York City Housing Authority, announced yesterday that bids on $11,121,000 of temporary loan notes to be issued by the authority will be received at its office at noon on Nov. 19. Proceeds will be used to continue financing of the Farragut Houses in Brooklyn and the Governor Alfred E. Smith Houses in Manhattan.

Buyers' Total Higher Visiting buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday numbered 1,924, compared with 1,848 last week and 2,477 in the corresponding week last year, according to the listings appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

While completely in accord with its objectives, foreign traders here await with keen interest the buying set-up that will be created to carry out the European Recovery Program, it was reported here yesterday. Both the Harriman and the Herter committee reports have urged formation of a separate Government corporation to handle the ERP, and the belief here is that Congress when it convenes next Monday will eventually act on this recommendation.

The thirty-one man complement of the Portuguese schooner Maria Carlota now in New York after being rescued by an Army transport in the North Atlantic last week when their vessel foundered in a gale, will be paid in full on their return to Portugal, it was announced here yesterday.

The United Nations has "proved itself to be little more than a debating society and a rather poor one at that," Col. Roelif H. Brooks, chaplain of the 107th Regiment, New York National Guard, and rector of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, declared yesterday morning in an Armistice Day sermon there.

Warren R. Austin, permanent United States delegate to the United Nations, declared here last night that the Soviet Union was probably a long way from producing any atomic bombs. He also emphasized that the United States would give up its atom information only when Russia agreed to an effective system of international control.
SRINAGAR, Kashmir, India, Nov. 11 (Reuters) -- Standing in the main square of Srinagar, Kashmir capital, Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, Indian Prime Minister, told cheering crowds today:

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Russell E. Singer, executive vice president of the American Automobile Association, protested in a speech before the American Petroleum Institute today against what he called "a growing trend toward spending motor vehicle revenues on purely local routes rather than concentrating them on highways of general traffic use."

THERE was an item in the paper the other day and it was pretty well buried beneath the flood of type on the Army-Notre Dame game. It was an announcement that the Touchdown Club of New York will pay tribute next week to Pop Warner for his outstanding contributions to the game. What a host of memories the grizzled old strategist evokes!

DOBBS FERBY, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Dobbs Ferry high combined its vaunted two-ply aerial offensive, starring Bart Caldara and Frank De Paolo, with a smooth running attack to. win, 20 to 0, over Alexander Hamilton of Elmsford today.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Robert T. Lansdale, State Social Welfare Commissioner, asserted here tonight that the New York City Department of Welfare had taken up "experimental" theories and inculcated them in "young, untrained workers" in violation of the Social Welfare Law.

In Minneapolis, in the test kitchens of General Mills, which are pretty and also practical enough to make any housewife critical of her own cooking quarters, there is a great to-do over a new pressure saucepan being made by this company.

GENEVA, Nov. 11 -- The United States announced today that it would not accept any obligation in the multilateral air convention to grant routes, into or across United States territory to other countries.

CAPE KEELER, Palmer Land, Antarctica, Nov. 7 (Delayed) -- We completed tonight the first, short exploratory flight eastward from this base over the Weddell Sea. The three-hour flight revealed some 15,000 square miles of Weddell Sea area never before seen by man.

The role of the press in promoting international friendship in the Western Hemisphere was emphasized yesterday at Columbia University as Maria Moors Cabot Awards were given to three outstanding South American journalists.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, retired, denounced today as a "damnable lie" testimony that as a wartime air materiel officer he had pursued a war contractor, Howard Hughes, for jobs and heavy loans.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 11 -- Lieut. Gen. Robert L. Eichelberger, commanding the Eighth Army, declared :

Before a whopping big crowd of 45,036 dauntless seekers of winners, who straight-armed theire way to the mutuel windows to make investments totaling $3,442,593, the last show of the New York racing season was presented at Jamaica yesterday.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security -- Resuming debate on France Spain, heard representatives of Poland, the Netherlands, Venezuela, Pakistan, Peru, India, Belgium, Yugoslavia, Canada, Mexico, United States, Chile, the Soviet Union, France, White Russia Brazil, the Philippines, Guatemala, Cuba, Panama, the Ukraine China, Ecuador and Britain Adopted, 23 to 17, with ten abstentions, Cuban proposal for subcommittee to draft common resolution on Spanish question.

The Broadway Association announced yesterday its opposition to the plan for using a section of the World's Fair parking site for free parking to relieve traffic in mid-town Manhattan. The association said that a better idea would be to build the proposed sports arena, convention hall and 2,000-car garage in the Columbus Circle area.

President Truman said a few days ago that, of the "many pressing problems facing the nation today," housing was foremost. If that is his firm conviction we assume that Congress will be asked, early in the regular session, to come to grips with this problem and develop a comprehensive program for meeting it.

Twentieth Century-Fox will release next year the most ambitious program of pictures in the company's history, it was announced yesterday by Andrew W. Smith Jr., general sales manager. A total of forty-eight feature films, including eighteen from independent producers, comprise the 1948 release schedule.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- Indications were tonight that the Administrative and Budgetary Committee of the United Nations General Assembly would approve the proposal that next year's session of the Assembly be held in Europe. The decision will theoretically be made on purely budgetary grounds, but the votes will undoubtedly reflect the views of each delegation on the proposal as a whole.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Nov. 11 -- The State Mediation Board intervened today to seek a settlement of the two-day-old strike of thirty-three members of the International Typographical Union, AFL, against The Nassau Daily Review-Star.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Rabbi Wolf Gold of New York, member of the Jewish Agency Executive, declared here today that agreement by the United States and Russia on a Jewish state in Palestine, was "the beginning of a new era in the history of the Jewish people."

The Yankees took over the rushing lead in the All-America Football Conference as a result of last Sunday's performance against the San Francisco Forty-Niners, who previously had been tops, this week's statistics reveal. The New Yorkera also copped the scoring lead, with 279 points to Cleveland's 276 and Buffalo's 253.
NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 11 -- Mayor Irving C. Freese, elected in the Socialist party's sweep of the Oct. 6 city election, today replaced members of the fire and police commissions.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- With his head bared to a cold, drizzling rain, President Truman observed the traditional minute of silence before the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery today. At the end of the memorial minute, he placed a wreath of yellow chrysanthemums before the tomb.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- British official circles expressed today the "liveliest apprehension" over the possibility that Communist agents might be filtered into the ranks of unauthorized immigrants to Palestine who are now gathered in Rumania.

With the horse show having galloped off the premises, the New York Rangers will present two and possibly three new faces tonight when they meet the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League contest at Madison Square Garden.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 11 -- Speaking at Independence Square, Kenneth Royall, Secretary of the Army, declared that the world is in a state "which we cannot sensibly face without adequate military force. We must never lose the hope and the belief and the desire that there be peace. We must preserve our faith, but added to faith must be the reality of works.

Simon Barere provided an evening of lovely piano playing for his admirers last night at Carnegie Hall. It was the first of two recitals the Russian pianist has planned to give this season, for in recent years he has been playing both in the fall and spring.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- King George invested Princess Elizabeth with the Order of the Garter at Buckingham Palace today. The Princess thus becomes the fourth woman to receive this highest order of knighthood in the British realm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. heard for an hour today pleas that he quash contempt proceedings against ten film writers and executives. He later said that he would consider the arguments, but he indicated doubt as to whether he had discretion in the matter.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Despite the Soviet Union's opposition to the Marshall plan, the explosive subject will be introduced at an important executive bureau meeting of the World Federation of Trade Unions shortly, it was announced here today by James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

A larger portion of coat and suit house production next spring will be concentrated in two-piece rayon suits in direct competition with the dress industry, it was predicted yesterday in the trade. Popularity of the ballerina skirt, manufacturers pointed out, has raised the potential of the two-piece garment as shown by buyers' approval on models presented for spring.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- While awaiting a response by Britain to the United States-Soviet plan for a partition of the Holy Land, a United Nations subcommittee on Palestine turned today to settlement of the boundaries of the proposed Jewish and Arab states.

ROME, Nov. 11 -- Rome remained without gas today as a result of a nation-wide strike of gas workers. The strike has been organized on a "progressive" system whereby it becomes effective immediately in a few principal cities and spreads gradually to the rest of the country.

CHICAGO, Nov. 11 (AP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks of the National Hockey League were strengthened today by purchase of Roy Conacher, highly rated left winger, from the Detroit Red Wings. Conacher, sold by Detroit to the New York Rangers recently, refused to report and subsequently announced his retirement from hockey.

PARIS, Nov. 11 -- The newspaper the Monde asked today whether the political aims of the Marshall plan as defined yesterday by Secretary of State Marshall were those of the countries that would receive United States aid. It contended that most of those countries were more divided on this point than were the American people.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 11 --The executive committee of Vaad Leumi, Palestine's Jewish National Council, voted at a meeting today to conduct a drive to raise new funds for defense among all sections of the Jewish community. The goal is the collection of u500,000 ($2,000,000) in voluntary contributions before Dec. 31.
New York faces serious consequences to its health and general welfare unless national and city authorities can divert the unprecedented influx of Puerto Ricans from the slum areas here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio said today that he was "absolutely opposed" to extending the $2,657,000,000 in additional foreign aid that Secretary of State George C. Marshall testified is essential for the balance of the fiscal year.
ATHENS, Nov. 11 -- No matter what the subject is, one cannot go wrong in Greece this autumn if one reports that the situation is deteriorating.

While Columbia's football squad sloshed through a scrimmage at Baker Field yesterday in preparation for its contest with Holy Cross Saturday, some transplanted Worcesterites were revealed as Columbia's statistical leaders.

A sellers' market has returned in automobile tires, distributors and dealers revealed here yesterday, and distributing and merchandising companies are rushing to buy to get as far up on order books as possible before large oacklogs have accumulated at factories.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (U.P.) -- Isador Lubin, former Commissioner of Labor Statistics, today urged a raise in the legal minimum wage to 75 cents an hour and asserted that firms claiming they can not pay that amount are not entitled to special economic protection.

Considering the results, George A. Reid, a 40-year-old Philadelphia advertising copywriter, should put his talents to better purposes, the police agreed yesterday after Reid was held in $500 bail in Week-end Court on a petit larceny charge in connection with passing a worthless check for $30.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Reflecting the financial district's expectation that Chancellor of the Exchequer Hugh Dalton will re-emphasize his cheap-money policy when he introduces his emergency budget tomorrow, gilt-edge issues recorded sharp rises in the stock markets here today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- Three hundred million dollars of new aid to China entered the American foreign assistance picture today.

Facilities for the diagnosis of virus and rickettsial diseases are being organized for the Health Department by the Public Health Research Institute of the City of New York, Inc., it was announced yesterday in the annual report of the research institute presented by David M. Heyman, president.

Net income of the Celanese Corporation of America for the nine months ended with last September, was $16,626,579, or $2.60 a common share, compared with $11,573,513, or $1.68 a common share in the first nine months of 1946, Harold Blancke, president, reported in the statement mailed to stockholders yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 11 -- "Colonel Kusmin," Russian propaganda play, heralded as violently anti-American, opened in the Soviet sector of Berlin tonight in a subdued version. While there are criticisms of American policy in Germany, with praise of Soviet policy, only a sensitive American would be greatly offended.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 11 A United Nations committee reached a decision today on one of its oldest and most controversial questions: the fate of refugees and displaced persons.

As Congressional committees begin consideration of the Marshall Plan, President Truman has issued his first report on a related program under the Truman Doctrine now being applied in Greece and Turkey, The two programs are closely related. They are alike in their aims, and the experience with one will inevitably have considerable bearing on the other.

Formation of an Advertising Agency Credit Group, comprising twenty-seven leading agencies affiliated with the New York Credit Men's Association, was announced yesterday by H. Parker Reader, association president Dixon P. Griswold, assistant treasurer of McCann-Erickson, Inc., heads the new group, which will serve as a source for clearing credit information and special data of mutual interest to financial executives of advertising agencies.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 11 -- Prospective home buyers and builders who have been hoping for an early break in the inflated costs of housing are likely to wait in vain, leading appraisers and developers declared today at the annual convention of the National Association of Real Estate Boards.
MONTREAL, Nov. 11 (AP) -- Syl Apps, veteran center of the Toronto Maple Leafs, enjoys a one-point margin in the National Hockey League's individual scoring race today.

De Witt Clinton toppled its Bronx rival, Evander Childs, from the undfefeated ranks yesterday with a convincing 27-0 victory in the second game of an Armistice Day twin bill at Randalls Island. In the opener, another unbeaten Bronx eleven, Monroe, kept its record unsullied with a 7-0 triumph over Stuyvesant.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The World Bank and International Monetary Fund have disapproved proposals of the President's Committee on Foreign Aid that they take an active part in Marshall-plan financing through large-scale reconstruction loans and stabilizing Western European currencies.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 11 -- Echoing Soviet charges at Lake Success, Polish and Czechoslovak delegates to the Assembly of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, today accused the American press of war-mongering and "irresponsible freedom of misinformation."

Carl Whitmore, president of the New York Telephone Company, told the Bond Club on Monday that the company will spend more than $250,000,000 this year and next to complete its post-war expansion program. Some time next month, he added, the company will reach a mark of 4,000,000 telephones in service, compared with 1,000,000 twenty-five years ago.

One of football's rarities, a 100-yard touchdown run with an intercepted pass, helped N.Y.U. to defeat Bucknell by 19 -- 6 before 5,000 at the Yankee Stadium yesterday. The game, washed out last Saturday, was played in rain and mud.
PARIS, Nov. 11 -- With ceremonies in all parts of the country, France today observed the twentyninth anniversary of the Armistice of 1918.

Junior Weyant, 20 years old, has been in an Army hospital since he lost his-left leg in the Normandy invasion. Last night he sat in the Glass Hat night club happily watching the dancers on the floor, nodding his head slowly in time to the music.

A "cost control" program using business methods in military procedure has been put into effect by the Air Force under the unification plan, W. Stuart Symington, Secretary of the Air Force, said last night. He spoke to Aviators Post 743, American Legion, at its annual Armistice Day dinner in the Biltmore Hotel.

MANILA, Wednesday, Nov. 12 -- The opposition Nacionalista candidates for Senatorial and provincial offices began piling up a surprising lead over the Liberal party of President Manuel A. Roxas as early incomplete returns began to indicate a political upset in the republic's first general elections.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Ernest T. Trigg of Philadelphia, president of the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association, said today that the nation's paint industry, in addition to improving its merchandising methods, must also continue to improve the quality of its products just as rapidly as new raw materials and advanced technology make that possible.

A group of 154 investment banking firms headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., will make a public offering today of 3,564,000 shares of the common stock of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation in a financing program that will provide part of the funds for Texas Eastern Transmission's purchase of the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines from the Government.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Walter P. Reuther scored two major victories today in his march toward full control of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.

THERE are two Betty MacDonalds who write books and who keep their senses of humor in excellent working order. The one you already know about is the Betty MacDonald whose misadventures among eggs are now world famous. The other one is Elizabeth P. MacDonald, whose friends have called her Betty all her life, but who can't sign her book that way because the egg Betty got there first.
With two of their five children, a couple evicted from their Brooklyn home on Friday spent two nights riding subways and faced another such experience last night.

The Maritime Commission authorized the sale of 171 war-built vessels at a total sales price of $250,000,000 during the quarter ended Sept. 30, according to its report to Congress released here yesterday.

PRAGUE, Nov. 11 -- President Eduard Benes solemnly warned the Czechoslovak people today against turning aside from the effort to find a synthesis between economic coordination and individual freedom. The peace of the world, he said, may depend on their success or failure.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- General Dwight D. Eisenhower today termed a "reasonably balanced" air force one of the strongest assurances that the United States would be respected by the rest of the world.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- The smartest fashion gathering London has seen in many years will be on hand for the wedding of Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten on Nov. 20 despite the genjeral austerity conditions.

Paced by Harold Seidenberg, hard-plunging halfback who accounted for two touchdowns, Lafayette High School's eleven remained in the ranks of the unbeaten yesterday when it downed Midwood, 28 -- 0, in the opening game of a double-header before 4,000 persons at Ebbets Field.

The first test of strength in the battle for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1948 will take place in the New Hampshire primary on March 9, with a battle between Harold E. Stassen of Minnesota and Governor Dewey of New York.

The basic idea of the proposed Marshall plan has been used by credit executives in the wholesale and manufacturing fields for more than half a century and has been found sound, it was declared by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly business review, released today.

A five-man trial committee elected by the general executive board of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, recommended yesterday that charges against Samuel Wolchok, the union's president, be dismissed as "utterly without foundation."

Coverage by the New York television stations yesterday of the Armistice Day ceremonies at Arlington Cemetery and the meeting of the Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs failed to materialize, apparently as the result of confusion between the telecasters and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

Delayed a day by striking British seamen in home ports and carrying a record peacetime list of passengers, the Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary docked here yesterday ready to establish another record and sail again this afternoon on her eastward crossing.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 11 -- All strife and speculation about the controversial displaced-persons resolution pending before the 200 delegates attending the annual convention of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs died today as the sponsor of the measure publicly withdrew it.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 11 -- Danny Kaye's first two pictures at Warner Brothers will be an adaptation of Gogol's 100-year-old play, "The Inspector General," and a screen version of Gene Fowler's "Father Goose," a biography of Mack Sennett, according to present plans.

JERSEY CITY, N.J., Nov. 11 -- Lincoln High overpowered Bayonne Tech, 5 -- 6, today. Johnny Mauro, Irvin Laws and George Goceljack scored two touchdowns apiece for the winners, who tallied in every period.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 11 (AP) -- Notre Dame's head football coach and athletic director, Frank Leahy, answering published reports that he had offered to resign, declared today he "would consider" it an honor to remain at Notre Dame "for a long period of time."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- The International Emergency Food Council voted its own dissolution here today. The functions, administered largely by the same staff, will be assumed by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization as soon as a majority of the countries composing it have ratified today's action.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 11 -- An expansion program of $3,500,000, which will include $1,000,000 for an Engineering School, will open up a new chapter in the education of Negroes by southern states, officials of the Tennessee State College declared here today.

ALBANY, Nov. 11 -- Governor Dewey, officially welcoming the Freedom Train to the capital city of New York, warned in a brief talk today that liberty was a process that demanded "the active cultivation and day-by-day participation of all who want to make it real."

KINGS POINT, L.I., Nov. 11 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy won its second football game of the season today by beating Brooklyn College, 22 to 14. It was the Kingsmen's fourth defeat against two victories.

There was a large attendance last night at the final performance of the fifty-ninth season of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden, and many of the hosts and hostesses entertained at dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria before the event.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12 -- Glenn Ford was named today by Columbia for the role of Don Jose opposite Rita Hayworth in "The Loves of Carmen," an adaptation of Prosper Merimee's 1847 novel, "Carmen," which Charles Vidor will direct starting Saturday on location at Lone Pine, Calif. Virginia Van Upp is polishing the screen play, which was originally written by Helen Deutsch.

BANEASA, Rumania, Nov. 12 -- Piloting his own American-made Beechcraft plan, King Michael I of Rumania, accompanied by Queen Mother Helen, took off at 8:06 o'clock this morning for London to attend the wedding of Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The outlook for next winter's wheat has been darkened by a serious delay in fall planting, the Department of Agriculture reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -- With private enterprise "virtually liquidated" in Europe, the people have lost almost all hope of ever regaining a semblance of decent living accommodations, Frank W. Cortright, executive vice president of the National Association of Home Builders, declared here tonight.

Massenet's "Manon" returned to the repertory at the Metropolitan Opera House last night after being away since March 11, 1943. Since a return after an absence of one season is called a revival these days, this must be termed a revival without question.

Mayor O'Dwyer and a diversified group of other witnesses joined yesterday in urging that Congress recognize its obligation to help alleviate the housing shortage and adopt the Taft-Ellender-Wagner housing bill.

A bid by the National Maritime Union to a unity meeting between Congress of Industrial Organizations and American Federation of Labor maritime unions was rejected yesterday by one AFL sea group. The conference was to have been held in New York next week.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The executive board of the Social Democrat party announced today the composition of the new Danish Labor Government under the party's leader, Premier Hans Hedtoft.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Though the objections by Senator Taft to the European Recovery Program of the State Department are addressed to its details, including cost, and not directly to its substance, the item of financing is so important that the objections, if sustained by Congress, could make the program a wasteful and inefficient expenditure, in the opinion of many expert observers.

Declaring that the people of Hungary face a choice between flight from their country and complete surrender to the circumstances of Russian domination, Zoltan Pfeiffer, a former antiCommunist leader in Hungary, arrived yesterday at La Guardia Field with his family.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- The Indian delegation to the United Nations today formally announced India's withdrawal from the contest for membership on the Security Council, thus paving the way for the election of the Ukraine at the meeting of the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- George C. Marshall, Secretary of State, set deadlines today on the enactment of the short and longrange European aid programs.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Capt. Tom Hamilton, Navy's football coach, today issued a formal statement saying he wanted in no way to detract from Georgia Tech's victory over the middies last Saturday in which a touchdown pass has been questioned.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- A new tax program designed to drain some u208,000,000 (about $832,000,000) from expendable funds in the pockets of the British taxpayers was detailed to the House of Commons today by Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Cleervue Television Corporation yesterday introduced its first television receivers at a dealer and press exhibit in the Hotel Russell. The line comprises four models, one of which was not shown at the exhibit. Deliveries to retailers will begin next month, with 300 weekly slated for the East Coast and 100 weekly for the West Coast, according to Irving Kane, president.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Despite urgent appeals by the United States, British and French deputies, the Soviet Union refused today to give priority to the completion of the Austrian treaty on the agenda of the Council of Foreign Ministers.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- The United Nations budget for 1948 of more than $32,500,000 was approved today by the Administrative and Budgetary Committee of the General Assembly after lastminute attempts to make further cuts had been voted down.

The Cunard White Star liner Queen Mary sailed at 6 P.M. yesterday, establishing a new record for a port turn-around for a ship of her size. In 25 hours 35 minutes the 81,235-ton liner discharged 2,002 passengers and mail, took on another consignment of 1,525 eastbound passengers, thousands of pounds of stores and mail, and left her West Fiftieth Street terminal for Southampton again.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 12 -- Charles Lucxman, its chairman, called today a full membership meeting of the Citizens Food Committee for Friday with the explanation that "it is becoming increasingly clear that we face for a long time to come a world food shortage."

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 12 -- Samuel W. Traylor Sr., industrialist and nationally known mining expert, died this morning in Stuart, Fla., according to word received here by members of his family. Mr. Traylor had gone to Florida with his wife to spend the winter.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- India today introduced a resolution under which the United Nations General Assembly would call on South Africa, India and Pakistan to begin immediate discussions of steps to improve the treatment of Indians in South Africa.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The text of Secretary of Commerce Harriman's statement on foreign aid to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee follows: I appreciate the opportunity to appear before this committee today to state my views on one of the most important questions now faced by our country -- the problem of whether and to what extent we shall assist in the economic recovery of western Europe.

The Marshall plan is not aimed at the Soviet Union but at maintaining and strengthening peace, Prof. William T. R. Fox of Yale University declared yesterday in an address before the autumn meeting of the Academy of Political Science.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Sir Stafford Cripps, Minister for Economic Affairs, today placed "the whole future of the sterling group and its ability to survive" on a quick and vast development of colonial resources.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, retired, swor today that he had made a paper profit of $90,000 on Government bonds bought on margin in wartime with the personal assurances of Henry Morgenthau Jr., then Secretary of the Treasury, that he "couldn't go wrong" in such a venture.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -- In a star-chamber proceeding which was wholly unexpected, the executive heads of the National Association of Real Estate Boards have decided to plead guilty to the antitrust charge of rate-fixing, as contained in an indictment recently obtained by the Department of Justice in Washington.
