Official statistics concerning the 188-day racing season were released yesterday by the New York State Racing Commission. The season, which ended at Jamaica on Tuesday, showed a decrease both in volume of betting and in attendance, although competition was generally of a high order.
Tremendous rises in construction and other costs may force the Board of Education to curtail its proposed $28,000,000 school building program for 1948, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Secretary Marshall told a news conference today that the National Advisory Council, of which he is a member, had reached no decision on a proposal of the sixteen Western European nations for a currency stabilization fund of $4,000,000,000 under the foreign-aid program.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Prompt development of foreign sources of oil is a "must," if world demand for petroleum is to be satisfied, B. Brewster Jennings, president of the Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, declared tonight before the annual convention of the American Petroleum Institute.

MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 12 -- According to a new version of the death of Field Marshal Gen. Erwin Rommel published today by German language newspapers, the "Desert Fox" committed suicide by poison after the discovery of his connection with the 1944 plot against Adolf Hitler's life.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 12 -- American women are clinging to their preference for traditional colonial or Cape Cod designs in new houses despite the lure of bold new styles, according to many leaders of the women's branch of the National Association of Real Estate Boards, in convention here.

So many requests were received from readers for copies of the articles on carving that appeared in this column last winter that we decided to put them into permanent form. "How to Carve Meats and Poultry" is the result. It is a 6x9inch booklet, and its seventeen pages contain reproductions of twenty-nine photographs with detailed explanations.
Riding along on a five-game winning streak, the Chicago Bears appropriately lead the National Football League in total yardage since the start of the campaign.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Over the objections of the United States, the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly voted today for the second time in a year to ask United Nations condemnation of the Franco regime in Spain.

Nippy clear weather moved into the metropolitan area yesterday in the wake of a northwest gale marked by gusts up to fifty miles an hour and a drenching early morning rain. The winds, high tides and rain caused considerable minor property damage in outlying districts of the city and the suburbs and a few injuries.

A story that a German spy named Fritz Scheffer had confessed setting the fire that burned the French liner Normandie at her West Forty-ninth Street pier on Feb. 9, 1942, will appear in next Sunday's issue of France Amerique, a weekly French, language newspaper published here.

For the first time, 100 room and smaller hotels are now actively buying and paying cash for commercial sizes of automatic laundry machinery, R. E. Robinson, sales engineer of Troy Laundry Machinery Division of American Machine and Metals, Inc., revealed here yesterday during the third day of the thirty-second National Hotel Exposition at Grand Central Palace.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Former President de Gaulle declared today his Reunion of the French People would seek alliances with the United States, Britain and other Western nations to resist the threat to the world from the Soviet Union.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Received Indian resolution reaffirming Assembly's action of last December, calling on South Africa to improve treatment of Indians.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The sale of sixteen surplus American tankers to Italy is being held up pending a Congressional investigation of the Administration's ship selling policy.

GALLUP, N.M., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Representatives of Douglas Aircraft Corporation undertook key roles today in seeking the origin of a fire which disabled one of the company's DC-6 transports yesterday and led directly to the grounding of others.

With censure of the Police Department and what was described as its "do-nothing attitude" toward traffic control, twenty-five leaders of business, labor and other fields formed the Traffic Action Committee yesterday and pledged themselves to "get something' done" about the city's traffic conditions.

WARSAW, Nov. 12 -- France and Poland signed today an agreement under which French owners of nationalized property in Poland would receive $57,000,000 in compensation, about one-seventh of the estimated value of Frenchowned investments taken over by the Polish State.
A new $100,000 medical unit, designed to provide extensive yearround medical care for wage earners, opened formally yesterday at the New York University College of Medicine, 477 First Avenue.

A feeling of good cheer permeated New York University football circles yesterday for the first time in many weeks after the Violets' second triumph of the season, a 19 -- 6 Armistice Day victory over Bucknell.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- One of the nation's leading club women, Mrs. William Dick Sporborg of New York, today accused a member of the executive board of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs of calling her "a Communist" and warned against a repetition.

A serious shortage of trained personnel because of lack of funds is causing the Health Department to fall far short of proper standards in many of its public health services. Dr. Harry S. Mustard, Health Commissioner, declared yesterday in a letter to Mayor O'Dwyer.

VIENNA, Nov. 12 -- Foreign Minister Dr. Karl Gruber told the Austrian Parliament today that his Government was absolutely determined neither to sign a treaty that did not guarantee Austria's economic independence nor reach any "understanding" with the Soviet Union that would put the minority in a position of power.
There are too few lobbyists representing private citizens in Washington, Representative Ralph W. Gwinn, chairman of the housing subcommittee of the House Labor Committee, declared here yesterday.

BERLIN, Nov. 12 -- While denying a report that he advocated the partitioning of Germany, Dr. Kurt Schumacher, chairman of the Social Democratic party, reiterated today his opposition to any collaboration with other German parties on national policy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- The Southern Newspaper Publishers Association, representing almost every daily newspaper in fifteen Southern states, today accused the International Typographical Union, AFL, and 112 of its locals of violating the TaftHartley Act.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall said today that publication of the first of the German Foreign Office documents that were seized by the American and British forces and are now being edited by Allied historians in Berlin is expected to take place next year.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14 years a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The Ballet Society opened its second season last night at the City Center, and considering, as one must do with this enterprising organization, that its ensemble consists of students from the School of American Ballet and that its orchestra, under the direction of Leon Barzin, is also in the student category, it was a highly creditable performance.

TOKYO, Nov. 12 -- Immediate establishment of a Japanese exchange rate is essential, occupation officials have been told by high Russian and British members of the Allied Council. General MacArthur's headquarters, when presenting the subject for Council discussion Oct. 15, argued strongly for delay.

Supply pipelines in top brand radios are rapidly filling up and leading manufacturers have removed retailer allocations except for a few especially popular models, it was learned yesterday. Dealers pointed out that supply approximately equals demand but emphasized that the situation cannot be compared with the market glut common to off-brand lines.

Asserting that the United States had attained world leadership and must accept the responsibility that goes with it, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, widow of the former President, declared last night that this country must help in the rehabilitation of devastated countries overseas, even at great sacrifice.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 -- A strong prospect for a negotiated peace promised tonight to avert the battle threatening in Newark Bay between the proud but retired battleship New Mexico and a couple of municipal fire boats.

Hugh Giles, organist of the Central Presbyterian Church at Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, will be ordained as a clergyman there today at 5 P.M. by the Presbytery of New York. The musician, who is 36 years old, has held his present post for eleven years.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The new account was opened quietly in the stock markets here today, buyers preferring to hold off until the supplementary budget delivered in the House of Commons by Hugh Dalton, Chancellor of the Exchecquer, could be digested.

A comprehensive program of research into the social, economic and medical aspects of human reproduction -- the first coordinated study of that subject to be undertaken in the United States -- was announced here last night.

Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner, made public yesterday a supplementary report of the Mayor's executive committee on administration that he said he would use as a basis for reorganizing the city's Department of Welfare.

Harold E. Stassen called yesterday for public support of President Truman's program of voluntary food conservation, but urged its "constructive modification" and found fault with other policies of the Administration on local and foreign food problems.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 -- Harold E. Stassen made a strong bid here tonight for the support of the large Michigan delegation to the Republican National Convention, as the group's second choice after Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg. Conferring at Dearborn Inn with leading Michigan Republicans, Mr. Stassen indicated that he did not intend to contest for Republican support in Michigan, and urged that the state support Mr. Vandenberg as first choice.

NEWCOMB, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- Weather is one of the most important factors in successful deer hunting and, while we were aware of this in the past, the point was never driven home so sharply as during the past few days in this area.

Columbian Carbon Declaration of a year-end dividend of 10 cents together with the regular quarterly of 50 cents on the stock of the Columbian Carbon Company, both for payment Dec. 10, increases 1947 disbursements to $2 from $1.60 paid in 1946.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Michel Carlini, de Gaullist Mayor of Marseille, was punched today in the City Hall in the course of a series of violent disorders there and at the court house.

BOSTON, Nov. 12 -- Sixty-mile winds, driving torrential rains before them, lashed the New England coast today, piling tides across sea walls and causing the greatest damage since the 1944 hurricane, with losses estimated in the millions.

BUFFALO, Nov. 12 -- Society should protect itself against financial loss resulting from theft through a system of compulsory collective insurance, it was recommended here today at the New York State Conference on Social Work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Navy needs its entire authorized air strength of 5,793 airplanes for some time to come in its sphere of national security, Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz, chief of naval operations, told the Air Policy Commission today.

An employer-union delegation designated by the Canadian Government to select 2,000 garment workers for immigration into Canada from displaced persons camps in Germany and Austria reported here yesterday on successful completion of its mission.

The nation's gasoline stocks last week declined 85,000 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end supplies were 82,007,000 barrels, compared with 82,092,000 a week earlier and 86,991,000 a year ago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets made by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 11,500 head; total 18,000. Market moderately active, steady to mostly 25 cents lower than yesterday; weights under 200 pounds about steady but market 25 to 50 cents

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, under Dr. Koussevitzky, gave its first New York concert of the season in characteristically brilliant fashion last night in Carnegie Hall. The program was unusual, beginning with the vast Eighth symphony of Anton Bruckner, undoubtedly that composer's greatest work in the classic form.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 12 (U.P.) -- President Bill Veeck of the Indians indicated today that Bob Feller would receive less money next season than the $87,000 major league top the fireball pitcher pulled down in 1947. Veech said Feller would receive the same base salary -- $40,000 -- but that the attendance figure starting Bob's bonus would be raised.

Paint Group Ads Financed Completion of financing for a cooperative advertising campaign by the paint and lacquer industry was announced at the opening session of the National Paint, Varnish and Lacquer Association's annual convention Tuesday in Atlantic City by E.T. Trigg, the group's president.

According to electric range production statistics compiled for the first nine months of 1947 by the National Electrical Manufacturers Association, 250,000, or 36 per cent, of a total of 700,000 shipped during the period retailed for less than $200, J.R. Poteat, chairman of the association's electric range section said yesterday.
Newark, N.J., announced yesterday that it would consider bids on Nov. 25 on bond issues totaling $3,827,000, dated Dec. 1, 1947, and due Dec. 1 from 1948 to 1967.

We take exception to a remark of Sir Hartley Shawcross, Britain's able and distinguished delegate to the General Assembly of the United Nations. Speaking before the Foreign Press Association on Tuesday evening, Sir Hartley asserted that Britain, wanting One World, would not permit herself to be "tyrannized or subjugated by either of the competing extremes of communism or of unbridled capitalism."
WEST POINT, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- A new starting left tackle will appear in the line-up when Army aces Pennsylvania at Franklin ield, Philadelphia, on Saturday.
Apparently the Charlie ConerlyBarney Poole pitching and catching combination for Mississippi was the hottest thing to hit Tennessee since the Oak Ridge A-bomb hatchery.

New issues of industrial company and public utility company bonds totaling $24,500,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting managers as follows: Peabody Coal Company -- $12,500,000 of first mortgage fifteen year 4 per cent first mortgage bonds at 100, by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

The Pacific Coast League has requested quick action by baseball's executive council to place it one step above its present Triple A rating now and to gain major league status in three years, The Associated Press reported yesterday.
The new building of the Kate Depew Strang Prevention Clinic at 419 East Sixty-seventh Street was opened formally yesterday. It is a unit of the Memorial Hospital Center.

Representatives of five AllAmerica Football Conference clubs met at the Hotel Commodore yesterday and set the date for the championship play-off as Dec. 14 and the place either New York or Buffalo -- depending upon whether the Yankees or the Bills win the Eastern title.

Ventan Yablonski, whose home town, like that of Holy Cross, is Worcester, Mass., was named yesterday as Columbia's game captain for Saturday's meeting with the Crusaders at Baker Field. Simultaneously, Columbia's athletic office announced that several thousand reserved seats are still available for the contest, Columbia's next-to-last of the season.

The New York Exchange for Woman's Work, 541 Madison Avenue, opened its enlarged and redecorated showrooms for old glass, china and furniture yesterday afternoon with a reception to members and friends. Receiving the guests were Mrs. Robert Ream, president of the exchange, and members of the committee of the Old Pattern Glass Studio who are in charge of the department.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 12 -- Gasparilla, scoring the first victory of a ten-race career, quintupled his earnings today in the forty-second running of Pimlico's $25,000 added Walden Stakes for 2-yearolds.

Fears that the proposed zoning resolution amendment that would permit doctors, dentists and osteopaths to set up offices in strictly residential districts though they do not live there might fee the first step in a process of breaking down the protections now afforded to residents of those areas were expressed yesterday by the Citizens Zoning Committee and the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.

The stock market slumped yesterday to the low marks of Oct. 1 and, in the widest sell-off so far this month, prices sagged 1 1/2 points or more in the industrials and about a point in the combined averages. Weakness in two of the key pivotal issues led to selling in other sections, although greatest activity centered in the medium and low-price stocks.

The Socony-Vacuum Oil Company, Inc., announced yesterday that in its Eastern marketing territory it will allocate deliveries of gasoline to its dealers in November and December on a basis of 4 per cent less than the quantities delivered in the similar months last year, subject to necessary adjustments to reflect current trends.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The American Federation of Labor will support the idea of creating a Deminform (democratic information) bureau as a rival to the recently created Cominform (Communist information) bureau, it was reported today.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- H. Preston Coursen, counsel for the Standard Power and Light Corporation, said today that if the company was not allowed to vote the stock it held in the Standard Gas and Electric Company, at the latter's annual meeting on Dec. 3, it would be possible for "a single stockholder, with a single share, to gain control of Standard Gas."

TORONTO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The rejuvenated Chicago Black Hawks scored their second National Hockey League victory in four days tonight, downing the Toronto Maple Leafs, 5 -- 4, with the help of five players they obtained from the Leafs in a trade just last week.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Jack Kramer, twice national amateur tennis singles champion, and hero in America's last two Davis Cup matches with Australia, today joined the professional ranks at an annual salary of $50,000, largest contract ever offered to a tennis star.

With no alleviation of dollar sortages in sight, barter transtions are steadily increasing in mber and volume, particularly foodstuffs, reports in foreign ide circles yesterday here indited. Some ten or more countries e now engaged in barter transcions, of either bilateral or trigular types.

Harry Shub, violinist, had prepared an unusual and exacting program for his recital last night at Town Hall. The Bloch Sonata and the Delius Concerto were the principal offerings. These were preceded by Vivaldi's Sonata in G minor and followed by three modern French works, Satie's "Things Seen on the Right and Left," Jean Cras's "Habanera" and Poulenc's "Bagatelle" in D minor.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan began an inquiry yesterday into the $100,000 "commission" said to have been mentioned by Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers in a talk in October, 1946, with Benjamin Fielding, then Commissioner of Licenses.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- The Firemen's Insurance Company, Newark, N.J., registered today with the SEC 120,462 shares of $5 par value common stock that will be offered to the company's common stockholders at the rate of two new shares for each thirty-one held.

The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: Today's Peace Plate is Braised Lamb Shanks and Noodles, a thrifty course-in-one dish that jollies up one of the less-tender cuts of meat.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 12 -- The sweep was complete tonight in favor of Walter P. Reuther at the top level of management of the United Automobile Workers, CIO.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Personal income rose to the "extraordinary" annual rate of $210,000,000,000 in September, an increase of $15,000,000,000 over August, the Department of Commerce reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- An air warning network of the kind which might have prevented the Pearl Harbor disaster is now being planned for use in an emergency, James Forrestal, Secretary of Defense, said today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- An experiment in international education, conducted by the United Nations, was formally inaugurated here today with the official opening of the United Nations Nursery School for children from 3 to 5 years of age.
Basketball will make its seasonal debut at Madison Square Garden tonight, with the professional New York Knickerbockers opposing the Washington Capitols. A crowd of 14,000 is expected to attend.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Women's ski togs should have a feminine silhouette, according to Marcel Rochas. Therefore he cuts the waistbands of Norwegian trousers and jackets exactly like his waspwaist corset.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- The predominantly Arab port city of Jaffa should be taken out of the proposed Jewish state in Palestine and established as an enclave belonging to the Arab state, Subcommittee 1 of the United Nations General Assembly's Palestine Committee decided tonight.
Lord Inverchapel, British Ambassador, replied last night to the section of American business opinion here that holds we should make an end of nationalization a condition of further aid to Britain.

The Security Bureau, Inc., as part of its campaign against "junk boats" in this harbor, has presented a series of recommendations to Patrick Meehan, Acting Commissioner of Licenses, designed to tighten up the operation of these craft here, it was learned yesterday.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 12 -- A United Nations General Assembly session in Europe next year seemed a virtual certainty tonight after an informal poll of delegations.

The nature of action which may be taken to close down the output of grain neutral spirits by three distillers that are still producing will be considered at a meeting of the Distillers Coordinating Committee of the Citizens Food Committee to be held in Washington tomorrow.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 12 (U.P.) --The lone survivor of a ship sinking said tonight that the body of a comrade was tossed to a pack of sharks to appease the man-eaters which dogged his liferaft while he drifted helplessly for two days.

Early Drive for Gift Sales This month is expected to produce an unusually large volume of early Christmas buying at retail, reports here yesterday indicated. Despite the fact that Thanksgiving, which marks the traditional opening of the holiday period, is still two weeks away, offerings of merchandise in the gift category have increased and holiday decorations and atmosphere in local stores are serving to focus attention on early buying.

ONE winter's day at Springfield College in 1892 Dr. James Naismith, then an undergraduate, was asked to devise some sort of game which would provide exercise for the athletes who had nothing to do between football and baseball seasons. So he invented basketball, never dreaming that it would one day become the most popular and widely played sport in the world.

New techniques must be developed for educating hundreds of thousands of unhappy and neurotic adults to rear their children so they will be more happy and adjusted than their parents, Dr. Lawrence S. Kubie, Professor of Clinical Psychiatry at Yale University, declared yesterday.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 12 -- The Joint Defense Council of India and Pakistan announced today that the British Government would close the Supreme Commander's headquarters Nov. 30 instead of April 1, 1948, as originally planned.
Jeannette Connolly has been appointed fashion coordinator for both men's and women's glove divisions of Meyers Make, Inc., glove manufacturers since 1864.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- President Truman will deliver in person his message to the special session of Congress at 1:30 P.M. next Monday, it was announced at the White House today. The message will be in two parts, covering both the emergency European aid program and recommendations to block further inflation in the United States.
Chuck Bednarik, center on the University of Pennsylvania's unbeaten and untied football team, yesterday won the award as lineman of the week in The Associated Press poll.
Dr. Erich Lindemann, Associate Professor of Psychiatry at Harvard University, asserted yesterday that community health and welfare depended largely upon accord between clergymen and psychiatrists.

ROME, Nov. 12 -- Lawlessness and violence on a considerable scale broke out yesterday and today in Genoa, Milan and some minor centers in northern Italy. The rioting followed a speech delivered by Palmiro Togliatti, the Communist leader, to the Central Committee of the Communist party, in which he announced an "intensification of agitation against the Government, both inside and outside the Constituent Assembly."

"Raintree County," a first novel by Ross Lockridge Jr., is the January selection of the Book of the Month Club. The novel, which will be published by Houghton Mifflin, won the Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Novel Award contest for this year. The club has named as a reserve selection "The Great Mischief," by Josephine Pickney, to be brought out by Viking.

The first of a series of Sunday night benefits to raise funds for the American National Theatre and Academy, the organization established to help the theatre as a whole, will be held at the Ziegfeld Theatre on Jan. 18, it was learned yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 -- The American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., amended its reorganization plan today to meet the request of the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shift of allocations from the public holders of the company's second preferred and common stocks to the public holders of the first preferred.

A stray dog bit seven boys and created panic among 300 youngsters yesterday noon in the schoolyard of St. Raymond's Parochial School, Castle and Zerega Avenues, the Bronx. The seven were treated at Fordham Hospital and sent home.

November is the brown month. There is brownness on the meadows, swamps and uplands. Brittle brown leaves cling to the scrub oaks on pasture hillsides and brown windrows of leaves are banked against walls, rail fences and in ravines at the edge of sidehill orchards.
Football proceeded in a normal way at Fordham yesterday, which means that there was no extended drill for the game with Lafayette at the Polo Grounds on Saturday.

Thomas D Campbell of Hardin, Mont., long known as the world's largest individual wheat grower, proposed in an interview here yesterday that the Government fix the price of wheat as sold by farmers in Chicago and other grain terminals.

Compelled to raise the price of cotton dresses owing to increased fabric costs, New York manufacturers will have little merchandise to offer retailers' low-end dress departments, it was pointed out yesterday.

There is no excuse for future allocating of American machine tools, even under the argument that such step would conserve scarce steel, leading spokesmen for the machine tool industry declared here yesterday. They cited large open capacity for production which would enable "any standard general purpose machine tool to be furnished in two or three weeks."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Research and Policy Committee of the Committee for Economic Development offered today a longrange tax and budget reform program urged to reduce business fluctuations to a minimum.

Pound Sterling Stability Foreign exchange traders expressed satisfaction yesterday over the clear-cut statement by Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, Hugh Dalton, that the pound sterling would not be devalued. The statement, it was explained, insures the continuance of at least the degree of stability in foreign exchange transactions which the dollar and pound have provided, against a background of otherwise constantly shifting currency rates.

After making a pretty good fight of it against the Boston Bruins for two periods, the New YorK Rangers had the roof fall in on them in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.
Cotton futures continued their upward climb on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday, closing unchanged to 21 points net higher.

The Packard Motor Car Company had a net loss of $131,478 in the first nine months of this year after estimated tax carryback credits of $1,800,000 allowable this year because of factory operating losses, George T. Christopher, president and general manager, reported in the statement mailed to stockholders today.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- By a vote of 8 to 1 the National Committee of the General Confederation of Labor adopted tonight a manifesto, proposed by Communist Pierre Lebrun, giving the Government until Dec. 19 to accept the demand for a general increase in wages throughout France retroactive to Nov. 1.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The recent statement of Mayor O'Dwyer regarding the "tough condition" that exists in the city's general hospitals was based on facts contained in a letter from Dr. Edwavd Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 12 -- Representatives of 140,000 Jewish displaced persons, hurriedly called here for a special conference, pledged unanimous support today to the executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine "in our and their struggle for a Jewish state in Palestine."

BOSTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Hit by the worst weather conditions in the 15-year history of New England horse racing, the Lincoln Downs card at Lincoln R.I., was canceled and Rockingham Park in Salem, N.H., was unable to put on its last three events today because of a howling snowstorm.

NANKING, Nov. 12 -- The birthday anniversary of Dr. Sun Yatsen, founder of the Chinese Republic, was highlighted for Nanking officialdom today by the news of Secretary of State Marshall's plan for $300,000,000 assistance for the Central Government.

In his testimony before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Secretary Marshall emphasized again that the economic restoration of Germany, "the heart of Europe's economic life," is essential to European recovery. German restoration must proceed simultaneously with that of the rest of Europe.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Having quite recently returned from an extended stay in Italy, where I lived for many years before the war, I read with great attention the report of Dr. Victor Heiser in the times on his finding's during a long automobile trip through that same country.

Present statutes governing the navigation of vessels in fog do not take into account any of the modern electronic devices that make possible safe navigation in bad weather and should be changed, it was said yesterday by Vincent A. Catoggio, chairman of the admiralty committee of the Bar Association of the City of New York.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Selling pressure on wheat on the Board of Trade was light today after an irregular trend in the early trade, and toward the close buying broadened, advancing prices sharply on reports that the Commodity Credit Corporation ha resumed buying at Minneapolis, and on unfavorable reports in regard to the Southwest crop.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, will meet next Wednesday with the networks to consider a new contract. The present contract expires on Jan. 31. It is no secret that if possible Mr. Petrillo would like to conclude an over-all agreement covering standard radio, television and FM.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York, endorsing Governor Dewey's proposals on foreign aid, asserted today that they represented the "first concrete program advanced for implementation of the Marshall plan."

JERUSALEM, Nov. 12 -- Five persons were killed in new outeaks of terrorism in two places Palestine today. The dead include one British police sergeant, two Jewish girls and two Jewish youths. Two more terrorists and three policemen were wounded.

George Romney, managing director of the Automobile Manufacturers Association, declared yesterday that "competition is the economic counterpart of individual liberty" and requires "the banning of union monopoly just as we long since outlawed industrial monopoly."

The citizens' Traffic Action Committee, organized yesterday, is preparing to tackle one of the most difficult problems of metropolitan living. Although street congestion is probably worse now than ever before, and its control or alleviation is an official responsibility, we have been far less critical of the city administration for failing to act on this problem than we have on other critical needs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Government officials said today they believed millions probably were made in speculation in Government bonds issued during the war despite Treasury efforts to prevent such speculation.

Because industrial wages have doubled since 1939 and this rise has not been accompanied by a corresponding increase in output per worker, they constitute one of the primary economic pressures leading to present high prices, according to a price investigation by the National Association of Manufacturers, released yesterday.

Word came to the Bronx County Building yesterday that Francesco Bonizio had died Tuesday in Parkchester General Hospital. It meant nothing to judges, lawyers, reporters, members of the District Attorney's staff and building attaches until someone recognized the name -- it was "Frank, the Bootblack," who had been shining shoes in the Bronx for the last forty years.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission reported registration statements filed with it today.

Sixty-two years ago Dr. Francis Wharton, examiner of claims for the State Department, turned to a 24-year-old Department law clerk for aid in his monumental "Digest of the International Law of the United States." In the following year the law clerk became a third assistant Secretary of State.

ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Brig. Gen. John M. Devine, commanding the universal military training experimental unit at Fort Knox, Ky., declared here tonight that critics of the program, whom he charged with having made "nebulous generalities," would be of more service were they to study the training at first hand and offer specific comments.

John M. Hancock, former member of the United States delegation to the United Nations Atomic Energy Commission, declared last night that the report published in Paris on Nov. 11 that the Soviet Union had tested an atomic bomb in Siberia was an attempted ruse to get technical information.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Stanoje Simitch, Yugoslav Foreign Minister, presented a note to Secretary of State Marshall during an hour's conference today requesting the United States to release $56,000,000 of Yugoslav gold that was frozen in this country during the war.

LONDON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- King George himself ended a squall of disagreement today over the advisability of touching up Princess Elizabeth's wedding procession with a little pomp. He ordered the War Office to turn out the Royal Household cavalry escort in full dress.
The Scalloped Tuna and Potato Casserole Peace Plate suggested for today spells economy, conservation and nutrition.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Nov. 13 -- The loyalty and devotion given to Harold E. Stassen in his home state was probably never better demonstrated than it was today, when the touring candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination made a twenty-eight-hour stop-over here on his way West.

A slow but steady deterioration of prices took place again yesterday on the stock market. Losses in some of the key pivotal issues were increased a point or more, with the composite rate reduced 0.66 point, which placed the list at the lowest levels since September.

Newark's much-publicized threat to use its miniature fire fleet to bar entrance of the decommissioned battleship New Mexico to the city's seaport for scrapping will be put to the test about 10 A.M. today, barring last-minute changes in plans formulated yesterday.

A nearly completed stone nude by the American sculptor, Cecil Howard, artfully concealed from the Nazis when they entered Paris in 1940, has been purchased by the French Government for the collection of the Modern Museum of Art in Paris, it was made known yesterday.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 13 -- Charles Edison, former Secretary of the Navy and former Governor of New Jersey, declared tonight that control of atomic energy poses a choice between "local mastery or subjugation by a powerful central government exercising the kind of control that could too easily pass into the hands of enemies of democracy."

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Survivors of the atomic bombing of Nagasaki are about normal now, but it will take twenty-five years before the genetic effect can be completely determined, Navy Capt. Shields Warren, noted medical researcher in atomic energy, said today.

OCEANSIDE, Calif., Nov. 13 -- A fleet of some forty United States naval craft including the battleship Iowa steamed into the Santa Catalina Gulf at dawn today and unleashed a miniature "invasion" against the Southern California coast.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 -- Owing partly to some industrial curtailment and partly to a moderate decrease in freight shipments, business in the Pittsburgh district last week declined somewhat from the near-record level reached at the end of October, according to the Bureau of Business Research of Pittsburgh University.
A new high in boxing attendance for the season at Madison Square Garden is forecast for tonight, and, if the record means anything, the attraction will be worthy the setting.

Psychiatric experts urged increased support yesterday for a national education program to prevent the development of mental illness, which now affects about 8,000,000 persons, or one out of seventeen in the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- The Commonwealth Southern Corporation filed an application with the Securities and Exchange Commission today requesting permission to sell 800,000 common shares of the South Carolina Power Company to the South Carolina Electric and Gas Company for $10,200,000.
JERUSALEM, Friday, Nov. 14 -- Terrorists killed at least five Britons and wounded twenty-six soldiers in attacks in Haifa and Jerusalem last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Representative Harold Knutson, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, expressed surprise and disappointment today over the failure of a Committee for Economic Development report, released yesterday, to recommend immediate reduction of individual income taxes.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Nov. 13 -- Gov. Earl Warren of California today became a candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 13 (U.P.) -- The $40,588 physics prize went to Sir Edward Appleton for research in the physics of the atmosphere and particularly for his discovery of the Appleton layer, from which radio short waves are reflected after they penetrate the ionosphere.

A television network 500 miles long between Boston and Washington, D. C., capable of reaching a potential video audience of 25,000,000 persons, was demonstrated yesterday for the first time by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 13 -- Southwestern Nebraska has yielded evidence of the earliest existence of man in the Western Hemisphere, Dr. C. Bertrand Schultz, director of the University of Nebraska State Museum, said today. Three camp sites of semi-nomadic hunters have been found along Lime Creek, about twelve miles north of Cambridge, Neb.

Two members of the Senate Appropriations Committee, arriving here last night from Europe on the United States liner America, said Germany must be considered in any plan for the rehabilitation of Europe.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission in an order handed down late today, postponed for thirty days Standard Gas and Electric Company's annual meeting to allow the SEC staff time to consider a series of recent events "which show the necessity for a fuller inquiry into the facts" surrounding the meeting and the election of directors.

Horse racing in New York State, which slacked off both in attendance and betting in the season just closed, will utilize the full legal quota of 196 racing days in 1948, it was announced yesterday. With all dates approved by the State Racing Commission, the campaign will get under way on April 1 and continue through Nov. 15.

ROME, Nov. 13 -- Pope Pius XII was reported today to be working on several reorganization measures, including the raising of the plenum of the Sacred College of Cardinals from seventy to 100, as well as studying the filling of the now vacant offices of the Secretary of State and the Cardinal Camerlengo.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 13 -- Precisely as expected, Walter P. Reuther, right-wing president of the United Automobile Workers CIO, carried his slate into control of the international executive board tonight by a vote of 18 to 4.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Secretary of State George C. Marshall was again requested today to permit the resignation without prejudice of seven former employes dismissed by the State Department in June or to give them a statement of charges and a hearing.

A prosperous future for television, in which the infant industry will become a six-billion dollar giant and a possible "shock absorber in our national economy," was forecast yesterday by representative leaders of radio, television, publishing and advertising in a seminar conducted by the Radio Executive Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- An unqualified demand by President Truman that Marshall plan costs be met from current tax revenues highlighted foreign aid developments today as Administration spokesmen continued making their case for European relief and recovery before international affairs committees of Congress.

A convicted securities swindler was arrested yesterday on a charge of having violated his parole promise of less than one year ago not to engage in the securities business ever again. The defendant, taken into custody at his home by detectives of State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein, was George Spiegel, 44 years old, of 4411 Thirteenth Avenue, Brooklyn.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Avoidance of both the "tear gas" and the "tear duct" approach to the problems of criminals was advocated here today by Edwin J. Lucas, executive director of the Society for the Prevention of Crime.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 13 -- Representatives of Roy Rogers, cowboy star, disclosed today that the actor has notified Republic Studios that he considers himself no longer under contract to the company, for which he has worked since 1937.

The State Board of Social Welfare adjourned its scheduled public hearing on relief for one week yesterday as it was attacked by twenty-eight faculty members of the New York School of Social Work, who charged the board was conducting an unproductive inquiry.

A cat and a dog that set up a clamor in trying to awake their mistress, a 14-year-old girl, played an important part early yesterday in saving the lives of twenty-eight persons when coal gas fumes spread through a four-story tenement at 594 Rogers Avenue, Brooklyn.

A seven - man joint legislative committee on insurance rates and regulations, headed by Senator Walter J. Mahoney of Buffalo, began public hearings here yesterday to provide amendments or additions to present state regulations on insurance.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Republican majority of a joint Congressional Price Investigating subcommittee rejected today all proposals for Federal controls to check inflation and suggested instead strict economy in foreign and military programs of the Government.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (NANA) -- A Department of Commerce report to be released in a few days will reveal a strong new buying wave that raised inventory accumulation in September by close to $1,000,000,000. Government experts view this as a significant indication of continued business optimism.

Alarmed over soaring construction and equipment costs, an economy-minded Board of Education rejected 1346,459 in plumbing, drainage and other bids yesterday while approving contracts totaling $3,988,072 for the erection of three new schools and the modernizing of fifteen old ones.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 5, the Federal Reserve Board reported today: An increase of 5154,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, decreases of $210,000,000 in holdings of United States Government obligations and $319,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and an increase of $341,000,000 in demand deposits credited to domestic banks.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Soviet foreign policy opposes a settlement of the Austrian problem, at any time within the next year, according to British diplomats. British diplomatic circles are deeply disturbed by the Soviet refusal to give Austrian affairs priority on the agenda for the Council of Foreign Ministers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- President Truman completed today the top tier of the country's new unified defense organization by designating the members of the National Security Resources Board. The new board, established by the National Defense Act of 1947, held its first meeting this afternoon.

Help for the football Giants -- 250 pounds of it -- arrived at the Polo Grounds yesterday morning in the person of John Treadway, former Hardin-Simmons tackle, who was brought up from the Jersey City club to replace Frank Cope, who was forced out for the season with a knee injury.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The infant sixteen-club Professional Basketball League of America blew up today in a splash of red ink, dropping 160 players, plus managers and coaches, into the pro player market.
PARIS, Nov. 13 -- In an excited and impassioned Assembly, Premier Paul Ramadier told the Communists today that the Government would "go the limit" to defend the Republic against them.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Sir Alexander Cadogan gave a mystifying British reply here today to the question of the United Kingdom's accepting the role that would be required of it under the United States-Soviet compromise plan for carrying out the partition of Palestine.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The National Federation of American Shipping, expressing agreement with many of the conclusions on shipping in the report of the Harriman committee, took exception in a statement today to the committee's proposal for the sale of surplus plus war-built vessels to the nations included in the Marshall plan.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- Following is the text of the statement made here today by Sir Alexander Cadogan, British representative, before subcommittee 1 of the United Nations General Assembly's Ad Hoc Committee on Palestine.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs, 10,000 head: total, 18,000. Early trade fairly active and about steady but later trade and close slow and weak; bulk of good and choice 190-270-pound butchers hogs.

WHEN Freda Utley was a young woman in England in the Nineteen Twenties she was a loyal member of the Communist party and used to speak from soap boxes advocating the latest twist of the party line as just received from Moscow. In 1928 she went to China as a secret agent for the Comintern. But from 1932 to 1938 she lived in the Soviet with her Russian husband.

The International Paper Company reported yesterday a consolidates net profit of $16,716,492, equal to $4.63 a common share for the quarter ended Sept. 30, compared with $9,161,847, or $2.51 a share, in the third quarter of 1946.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- Controversy over official direction and policies of the National Association of Real Estate Boards is expected to reach a climax tomorrow, when resolutions and nominations come before its annual convention.

Wagner's "Tannhaeuser," which was dropped from the repertoire last season, came to performance last night at the Metropolitan. Because of the sudden indisposition of Fritz Stiedry, the opera was conducted on short notice by Wolfgang Martin, who had no opportunity to hold a rehearsal.

Shipbuilders, owners and operators have too many government agencies with which they have to deal and too many laws, rules and regulations with which to comply, it was charged yesterday in a paper read before the fifty-fifth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
An airborne addition to the Friendship Food Train, which is collecting food from the people of America for the hungry of Prance and Italy, has gone into operation on a daily coast-to-coast basis.

This year's Nobel Prizes in the physical sciences go to Great Britain-specifically, to Sir Edward Appleton for physics and to Sir Robert Robinson for chemistry. There will be general approval of the awards, for Sir Edward is England's leading authority on the ionosphere and Sir Robert is England's leading organic chemist.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13 -- Betty Smith's new play, "The First in Heart," had its premiere before an invited audience in the main theatre of the Yale Department of Drama last night, and it was warmly received by the capacity audience.

Amassing ten straight points in the final two minutes, the New York Knickerbockers launched their second season in the Basketball Association of America with a convincing 80-65 victory over the Washington Capitols at Madison Square Garden last night.
NANKING, Nov. 13 -- The Government today conceded the loss of Shihkiachwang, the strategic rail center in Hopeh Province, which the Communist radio said was captured at noon yesterday.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Nov. 13 -- The Taft-Hartley act has been the subject of "the grossest and most vicious kind of misrepresentation and misinterpretation on the part of those opposed to it," Senator Irving M. Ives, Republican, of New York, declared here today.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Good for markets, but as an anti-inflation measure too half-hearted, was the City's financial experts' appraisal today of the supplementary budget introduced yesterday by Hugh Dalton, the Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Both the borrower and the lender in an $860,000 war contract deal were named in two true bills charging thirty counts of grand larceny, forgery and perjury that were handed up yesterday to General Sessions Judge Owen W. Bohan.

New York designers gave interesting evidence of their talents last night when a handsome collection of costumes, based on inspiration derived from the French tapestries which will go on public display next Saturday, was placed on view in the great hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- President Truman announced today the appointment of Admiral Louis E. Denfeld to succeed Fleet Admiral Chester W. Nimitz as Chief of Naval Operations.

GRENLOCH, N.J., Nov. 13 (AP) -- After watching Jersey Joe Walcott work nine rounds today in preparation for his title fight with Joe Louis, Manager Joe Webster announced that he "is getting down too fine, so I've decided to lay him off tomorrow."

Poultry and fish, which, had been recommended by the Department of Markets as substitutes for higher priced meats, have been moving upward in price, Markets Commissioner Eugene G. Schulz reported yesterday.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- Student enrollment in New York State colleges and universities has reached an all-time high of 309,643, with the peak not yet reached, the Division of Higher Education, State Education Department, said today.

Though there are, low-cost varieties still available this week-end, the general trend in the vegetable market has been upward, with changes from 1 to 6 cents a pound reported for several types by the City Department of Markets. The effects of the hurricane that hit Florida in September are being felt, and supplies are smaller than usual for this time of year.

A small group, mostly veteran actors, celebrated yesterday the 114th birthday of Edwin Booth, the Shakespearean actor, at the Players Club with a few reminiscenses about their entrances and their, exits.

The thorough documentation of the city's own findings on Welfare Department maladministration just given to the public by Commissioner Fielding makes it plainer than ever that it was not a few isolated cases of poor judgment that brought the department before the bar of public opinion.

Garment manufacturers using rayon fabrics will know in the next ten days what quantities they will have on hand for spring and summer production, according to trade sources yesterday. Rayon converters who have been slow in coming through with first quarter 1948 allotments, it was pointed out, will soon make known how much goods they can supply to the trade.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial of Nov. 6 entitied "The Results on PR" you say "the closeness of the vote in Cincinnati, where it won out, showed the substantial distrust of the system there."

"Giant retailers" are fighting for repeal of the fair trade laws to bring back "loss leaders," which would hit small merchants and put pressure on manufacturers to reduce quality to meet demands for lower and lower prices, John W. Anderson, president of the American Fair Trade Council, declared yesterday.

An era of unparalleled prosperity was forecast last night by Joe R. Hanley, Lieutenant Governor of New York, at the fifteenth annual conference of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators at the New Yorker Hotel.
Long Island University's basketball team has scheduled twenty-two games for the 1947-48 campaign, it was announced yesterday by Coach Glair Bee.

STORMVILLE, N.Y., Nov. 13 -- A twenty-four-hour search by land and air for Dan Hunter Chadwick, 3 years old, ended this morning when the boy was found, unharmed, lying in the thicket of a lonely swampland four miles from his Dutchess County home.

The Council of Relief Agencies Licensed for Operation in Germany (CRALOG), announced yesterday that in the last eighteen months 45,000,000 pounds of supplies, having an estimated value of $32,000,000, were sent to Germany.

The predominating feature of the Philharmonic-Symphony concert which Charles Muench directed last night in Carnegie Hall was the performance of the Brahms concerto with Ginette Neveu as violin soloist. This was Miss Neveu's first appearance with orchestra in this city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, retired, as a high Army Air Forces procurement officer held $35,074 worth of aviation stock on a broker's records in 1943, but disclaimed any such holdings to his superiors, the Senate War Investigating subcommittee was told today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Reporting on national defense to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, Senator Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. declared today that the Air Force was stunted, the Army gravely depleted and the nation was without a country-wide organization to cope with massive air attacks.

The Board of Estimate appropriated yesterday $100,000 for preliminary expenses for Mayor O'Dwyer's committee for the commemoration of the city's Golden Anniversary in 1948. In voting the money the board approved the committee's general plan for the celebration, except for the phase calling for the construction of a moving sidewalk over Park Avenue between Forty-sixth and Fifty-seventh Streets and the use of the central mall of that thoroughfare for exhibit purposes.
The Catskill deer season will open tomorrow and the late reports indicate that conditions are excellent with many areas reporting larger deer herds than have been seen in some years.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Lew Andreas, Syracuse University athletic director, says the university's football team, "can't match" the competition provided by its opponents "unless we have the same sort of scholarships."

After nearly two hours of stormy debate involving interchanges of personal remarks, the City Council adopted yesterday by a vote of 16 to 3 a resolution calling on the city's delegation in Congress to approve the Marshall plan for the relief of European nations.
Gales that lashed New YorK with driving rain two days ago had moved seaward and were battering shipping and delaying several passenger liners yesterday off the New England coast.
Organization of a syndicate by forty-one Latin-American newspaper publishers for the publication of a Sunday pictorial supplement was announced yesterday by the newly formed ABC Publications, Inc.

Bob Hope for the first time in his radio career will miss his regular broadcast next Tuesday night over NBC, the comedian deciding after all not to attempt to do his program from England, where he will participate in the Command Performance in connection with the wedding of Princess Eizabeth.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Here is the text of the letter which the Army Air Forces sent to ten procurement officers during the war asking them to list holdings of aircraft securities: MEMORANDUM January 15, 1943.

More 'Greenfields' Forecast Confidence that the "Greenfield Experiment" will soon be duplicated in other parts of the country was expressed yesterday by Henry E. Abt, president of Brand Names Foundation, Inc., in reporting on the recent sixteen-day sales promotion campaign to the foundation's executive committee at the Union League Club.

To the accompaniment of several discreet huzzas, the impending reunion of two former partners is heralded. The gentlemen are Richard Aldrich and Richard Myers, who were quite active as producers until they went their separate ways in the wake of a brief tussle with "Plan M" in February, 1942.

MONTREAL, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Paced by Toe Blake, who scored two goals and assisted in another, the Montreal Canadiens defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 -- 2, tonight to pull into a third-place deadlock with the Toronto Maple Leafs in the National Hockey League.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Nov. 8 were 910,160 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 30,586 cars or 3.3 per cent fewer than or the preceding week, 3,185 cars or 0.3 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 71,942 cars, or 8.6 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- The basic cause of the present imbalance afflicting world trade will continue until western European centers of industry have been restored, Dr. Clair Wilcox, director of the Office of International Trade, Department of State, declared here tonight.

At any time since the liberation the Communists of France and Italy could have staged the mob scenes that are now taking place simultaneously in both countries. Through their control of the trade unions they have power to call strikes, and they have manifested this power in ordering walkouts in the public services as well as in stateowned and private industries.

COLUMBIA VS. Holy Cross -- For a team which was deemed to be rather formidable at the start of this campaign, the Crusaders have had a rather undistinguished season. But Lou Little's Lions haven't stopped roaring since the first half of the Army game. They don't figure to quiet down now. One vote for Columbia.

Taking command early and leading the rest of the way, Donald Anderson, Fordham Prep star who earlier this week captured the city C.H.S.A.A. crown, finished first in the cross-country run for Catholic Schools of Manhattan, the Bronx and Westchester at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- During the week ended Nov. 12, member bank reserve balances decreased $249,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The United States proposal to create a "Little Assembly" was adopted last night by the United Nations General Assembly over the bitter protests of the Soviet Union and other members of the Soviet bloc. The vote was 41 to 6, with the six members of the Arab bloc abstaining.

Bankers Acceptances Up Bankers dollar acceptances throughout the United States were increased $17,721,000 during October to reach a total of $236,661,000 at the end of the month, compared with $218,940,000 on Sept. 30 and $203,842,000 at the end of October, last year.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- Anton Refregier, New York artist, formally protested to Washington today against revision of designs for his mural in the Rincon Post Office annex.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 13 -- J.B. Priestley, for Britain, accused the United States today of dominating efforts to spread culture across national frontiers -- the accusation coming in a heated debate in the mass media committee of the Assembly of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Princeton University has complied with a request from the Eligibility Committee of the Ivy League to halt the spread of rumors and no member of the Tiger football squad, coaching staff or University Council on Athletics has cause to submit the names of any players on opposing Ivy group teams as being subsidized athletes, it was revealed today by R. Kenneth Fairman, director of Princeton athletics.

Col. Hugh A. Kelly, chairman of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company, announced yesterday a broad program for more complete utilization of the company's properties and improvement of its financial condition.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Exports to Europe dropped in September to the lowest point for any month this year, falling to $394,300,000 from $410,000,000 in August, the Census Bureau reported today.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- The New York State Food Commission, meeting in Albany today, announced the appointment of a seventeen-member food trade advisory committee to assist the commission in its job of maintaining high health standards while conserving food.

Commercial, industrial, and agricultural loans of the New York City reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System have reached another new peak of $5,190,000,000, it was disclosed yesterday. According to the statistics released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York covering the week ended on Wednesday, such borrowings were increased $104,000,000 and covered a wide range of items.

We hope the American Federation of Labor will proceed with its support of "an attack on world-wide communism and its influence on all labor fronts, whether in Europe, the Middle East, Latin America or elsewhere," as reported to this newspaper by Louis Stark.

A slow demand from mill interests, the disposition to await developments in Congress next week and accumulative hedge selling imparted a softer tone yesterday to cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange. Final quotations were at the day's lows, with net declines 01 14 to 28 points
BALTIMORE, Nov. 13 -- A runaway victory was scored by the Mill River Stable's Miss Grille in the $25,000 added Pimlico Cup race as the Maryland Jockey Club meeting ended today.
ROME, Nov. 13 -- After yesterday's grave disturbances in Milan and other northern cities, Naples lived through hours of riot and panic today.

The disparity between charges for hospital care and services and the actual operating costs of New York's eighty-nine voluntary hospitals is mounting steadily, the United Hospital Fund pointed out yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The Bureau of Transport Economics and Statistics of the Interstate Commerce Commission today issued a comparison of the par value and the market value of railway reorganization securities for three railroads that have completed reorganization proceedings and for four roads still in the process of reorganization.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Further buying by mills, together with continued dry weather in the South-west and more active operations by the Commodity Credit Corporation, served to maintain a strong tone today in the wheat market, and further substantial gains were registered on the Board of Trade.

Intertype A year-end dividend of 60 cents and a quarterly dividend of 40 cents on common, both payable on Dec. 15, was voted by the Intertype Corporation. Total declarations for the year are $2, compared with 51 in 1946.

The New England Garden in the main bird house of the Bronx Zoo has been redecorated and is on display again with its collection of native American birds. Michael, the bicycle riding chimpanzee at the Central Park Zoo, is back in his winter quarters, sharing a cage with his friend Anne.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Although no further disorders were reported in Marseille today, the Prefect of the Department of Bouches du Rhone issued an order forbidding public assemblies in Marseille. Some parts of the city were still patrolled by troops and security police.

Samuel Goldwyn yesterday renewed his long-standing campaign against double features by warning the Independent Theatre Owners Association that turning theatres into "bargain basements" will have serious harmful effects on the progress of motion pictures.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Congress was told today that it stood in danger, on the basis of official recommendations, of promising more food and other supplies to stricken foreign countries than could be delivered.

The construction industry in this city operates behind an "iron curtain," under rigid rules enforced by a monopolistic combination of contractors and trades unions, a subcommittee of the House of Representatives was told yesterday.

The second highest earnings and third largest sales in the company's fourteen-year history were reported yesterday by the Schenley Distillers Corporation in the annual statement for the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31 signed by Lewis S. Rosenstiel, chairman, and Lester E. Jacobi, president.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Michigan's football team may be the "Monsters of the Midwest" and the "Wily Wolverines" to a lot of experts, but to a Wisconsin squad preparing for Saturday's battle for the Big Nine title the superlatives don't mean a thing.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 -- A message from President Truman urging young Democrats to rally "young persons to the battlefield of politics" and attacks on the Republican party for "failing" veterans of the second World War marked the opening session of the convention of the Young Democratic Clubs of America tonight.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 13 -- This year's Nobel prize for literature, worth about $40,630, went this afternoon to the French writer, Andre Gide. The Nobel prizes for physics and chemistry both went to Britons.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- In the peace treaties signed by the victors of World War H with the Nazi satellite states, including Rumania, and ratified by all, machinery was set up to deal with charges of treaty violation. This machinery is established in Article 3, Part 2 of Section 2, and Articles 37 and 38 of Part 8.

What are we going to do about those "forgotten cities" of human beings -- the DP camps of Europe where 1,073,000 men, women and children still desperately cling to life and the idea that the rest of the world will act like human beings? They need no spokesman for their courage.
Fielding Wallace of Augusta, Ga., is slated to become president of the United States Golf Association at the annual meeting and election on Jan. 10 in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- Hugh Dalton is out of the Chancellorship of the Exchequer tonight owing to his own acknowledged indiscretion. He resigned because he had revealed highlights of his interim budget yesterday to a newspaper man before he presented the budget to Parliament.

An agreement between the Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America, CIO, and the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, reached here yesterday afternoon. ended a twenty-week strike that had tied up virtually all shipbuilding and ship repairing on the east coast.

Paul Makovsky is 26, and his recital at Town Hall last night was only his third appearance in New York. It would be easy -- and accurate -- to describe him as one of the best of the younger generation of violinists and let it go at that, which wouldn't do any harm to his standing.

HYANNIS, Mass., Nov. 13 -- A northeaster of hurricane proportions, accompanied by driving gusts of rain, sleet and snow, swept the sixty-five-mile-long Cape Cod peninsula yesterday afternoon and last night and left property damage estimated at. $2,000,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Sir Norman Angell, English author and Nobel Prize winner, said tonight that there need not be a third world war if the United States and Great Britain use their power "aright" to prevent war.

Studies by Fordham "University physicists, carried out at a temporary laboratory on the platform of the 190th Street station of the IND Subway (Washington Heights Division), have revealed a hitherto unknown penetrating radiation emanating from granite, and possibly by most of the rocks of the earth.

Paul Makovsky is 26, and his recital at Town Hall last night was only his third appearance in New York. It would be easy -- and accurate -- to describe him as one of the best of the younger generation of violinists and let it go at that, which wouldn't do any harm to his standing.

HYANNIS, Mass., Nov. 13 -- A northeaster of hurricane proportions, accompanied by driving gusts of rain, sleet and snow, swept the sixty-five-mile-long Cape Cod peninsula yesterday afternoon and last night and left property damage estimated at. $2,000,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 13 -- Sir Norman Angell, English author and Nobel Prize winner, said tonight that there need not be a third world war if the United States and Great Britain use their power "aright" to prevent war.

Studies by Fordham "University physicists, carried out at a temporary laboratory on the platform of the 190th Street station of the IND Subway (Washington Heights Division), have revealed a hitherto unknown penetrating radiation emanating from granite, and possibly by most of the rocks of the earth.

Operators of American-flag vessels, whose Handling of the shipment of relief cargoes to Greece was virtually eliminated by State Department order early this week were somewhat relieved yesterday afternoon when this directive was modified so as to insure their continued participation in this business.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 13 -- On some of the aged elms and maples that line the Princeton campus, undergraduates have tacked a significant slogan this week, "Nail Yale."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Contempt action against ten Hollywood writers and executives will be debated in the House on Nov. 24.

Modern electronics has opened a new age of almost immediate service on special food orders in hotel restaurants and cafes, Robert Howard, president of the New York Hotel Sales Managers Association revealed yesterday in summarizing technical business developments in the thirty-second National Hotel Exposition at the Grand Central Palace.

Shipbuilding in the United States is declining so rapidly that its year-end "on hand" volume will be approximately 50 per cent of the total at the beginning of the year, according to a report yesterday from H. Gerrish Smith, president of the Shipbuilders Council of America.

Noah's Ark to Cozen Sleep The lady visitor said that as a substitute for the old-time device of counting sheep to woo reluctant slumber she had invented a game of her own. She tried to remember the common or even the uncommon surnames that had belonged originally to four-footed beasts.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- The men of Penn and their coaches too, were full of zest and the joie de vivre today as they went through their last lengthy workout for the coming of Army to Franklin Field on Saturday.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- Governor Dewey lashed back today at supporters of Harold E. Stassen and other rival aspirants to the 1948 Republican Presidential nomination who have accused him of avoiding a public stand on major issues.

Friday, Nov. 14, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at Flushing Meadow at 11 A.M. and elected the Ukraine to Security Council after India withdrew candidacy. Elected Philippines and Costa Rica to Trusteeship Council after withdrawal of Norway.

On the comparative records of the teams, Columbia would appear to be in for an easy afternoon at Baker Field tomorrow, when it meets Holy Cross for the first time. The Crusaders have not had a good year. Ox DaGrosa's squad has won only two games, while losing three and tying two.

A trousseau of twenty-five dresses, suits, coats, evening gowns and negligees, the gift of the New York fashion industry to Princess Elizabeth, has been sent to Buckingham Palace, it was announced yesterday.

By way of clearing the decks for any possible player transactions that may develop at the annual minor and major league meetings next month, the Dodgers yesterday lopped two names from their roster to receive hi exchange a sizable piece of money.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Speaking as one radio commentator to a lot of others, President Truman said today that a man should weigh his words carefully when he steps in front of a microphone.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The American Federation of Labor announced officially today that it was streamlining its machinery dealing with international labor problems in an all-out effort to support the United States Government's plan for world peace and reconstruction through the Marshall plan.

The United Nations General Assembly's committee on headquarters, approving President Truman's offer of an interest-free construction loan of $65,000,000, voted unanimously yesterday to erect the proposed glass-and-marble world capital in midtown Manhattan as a dramatic "symbol of permanency."

Gamer Again Heads ABO Carl F. Gamer of Arkwright, Inc., was re-elected president of the Association of Buying Offices at the annual meeting held yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania. Other officers also re-elected were: vice president, A.A. McCarty, Cavendish Trading Corporation; vice president, John Block, Kirby, Block Co.; vice president, F.L. Bradley, Mutual Buying Syndicate; treasurer, Milton J. Greenebaum, Felix Lilienthal Co., and secretary, Irving C. Krewson of the Irving C. Krewson Corporation.

Bloomingdale's decorating staff used a lavish hand with color in the eight model rooms that opened yesterday in the store's furniture department. The clear bright tones that are rapidly growing in popularity have been combined courageously in a manner that should inspire the timid amateur.

Breaking a deadlock that had existed since September, the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow yesterday elected the Ukraine to fill the remaining vacancy on the Security Council. The Philippines and Costa Rica were elected to vacancies on the Trusteeship Council.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- The controversial Higley Dam project in northern Herkimer County, which would have flooded thousands of acres of virgin timber and one of the best deer-yarding areas in the Adirondacks, was scrapped today by Governor Dewey.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Interim aid by "the first days of December" is essential to spare France almost unbearable restrictions, according to a statement issued today by Herve Alphand, Director of Economic Affairs of the French Foreign Ministry, after his return from negotiations in Washington.

The Pennsylvania Railroad has turned the corner from the stand-point of both revenues and control over costs, James M. Symes, vice president, in charge of operations, asserted here yesterday. However, he admitted there were many uncertainties in the situation.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The reported agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union or the establishment of a commission composed of three to five small Powers constitutes, no doubt, a step forward in solving the problem of establishing a Jewish and an Arab state in Palestine.

Bedroom furniture manufacturers who have produced nothing but low-end suites since they began operating have now entered the quality field in force, manufacturers' representatives and retailers revealed yesterday. Both trade elements agreed that the move is being made because of in-ability of established operators in the quality case goods field to supply continuing high demand.

Admiral Louis E. Denfeld will bring from the Pacific to the Office of Chief of Naval Operations in Washington one of the most inquiring minds and the most engaging personalities in the Navy. He has an appreciation of public interest in the naval establishment and of the public's right to full information.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 14 -- General Juarez Tavora declared today to newsmen that Brazil must import foreign capital to develop her national petroleum resources. General Tavora, who is deputy chief of the General Staff, has been lecturing lately, recommending the participation of foreign capital in developing Brazilian subsoil products.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 14 -- The eleventh annual convention of the United Auto Workers Union, CIO, adjourned at 10:15 o'clock tonight with a boisterous night session highlighted by the nomination at one point of all of the approximately 2,000 delegates for one office.

Allen Industries Alien Industries, Inc., declared a dividend of 25 cents on the new common stock, payable Dec. 12. This is equivalent to 50 cents on the old common on which a 100 per cent stock dividend was paid in October.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at 11:20 A.M. at Flushing Meadow, Queens, and resumed consideration of problem of independence of Korea. Heard representatives of China, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia, White Russia, Panama, Poland, Norway and the Ukraine.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- Rabbi Benjamin Schultz, who resigned a week ago as spiritual leader of Temple Emanu-El as the result of a controversy over a series of articles he wrote on anticommunism, called yesterday on the National Conference of Christians and Jews to investigate communism in the churches.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The National Labor Relations Boar cut deeper into its backlog today with the revocation of five order of election. Unions which sough the elections to establish their claims to exclusive bargaining rights have not filed the require non-Communist affidavits and financial data.

MANILA, Nov. 14 -- An election scandal of serious national proportions was in the making today as the Nacionalista (minority) party leadership openly charged that election irregularities had been committed by majority party leaders in many sections of the Philippines for the purpose of overriding the popular will."

The Lincoln Savings Bank of Brooklyn made a mortgage loan of $400,000 at 4 per cent interest for two years on the twenty-story loft building with penthouse at 322 Eighth Avenue, at the corner of West Twenty-fourth Street, to the 322 Eighth Avenue Corporation.
