The Index is based on spot market prices. Most of the twenty-eight commodities are basic raw materials.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The dramatic resignation of Hugh Dalton yesterday as Chancellor of the Exchequer has presented a grave crisis to the Labor movement. Winston Churchill and other Opposition leaders are pressing their motion for a select committee of inquiry into Mr. Dalton's premature disclosures of budget information and this will be discussed in Monday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- United States officers will be assigned to the headquarters of Greek Army units "down to the division level" through a considerable enlargement of the United States Military Mission in Greece, Kenneth C. Royall, Secretary of the Army, announced today.

Categorical Weather Statements They were talking about the weather map in the morning paper. It had hieroglyphics spattered all over its face; also a key at one side explaining what was meant by cold front ant warm front and occluded front and isobars.

Mozart's last opera, "The Magic Flute," was done at the Metropolitan last night with grace and tenderness and a touch of the nobility that informs the music. It was not a great performance, for in this generation there are not enough great Mozart singers to give "The Magic Flute" the sense of vocal abundance that it needs.

A recession can be avoided if business reduces prices to the extent that increased productivity and profits permit, according to George Soule, economist. A way must be found, also, he said, to bring down food prices.
The State of Louisiana announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Dec. 11 on an issue of $10,000,000 institutional improvement bonds dated Dec. 1, 1947, and due on Dec. 1, from 1952 to 1973.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- State and Federal relief officials were accused of laxity here today for their failure to uncover abuses in the operation of New York City's Department of Welfare and to act constructively and unpolitically for their correction.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 14 -- President Juan D. Peron was honored tonight at a dinner marking the fact that he has just been named doctor honoris causa by each of the six national universities that have been under his personally named interventors since May, 1946.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Truman said today that disloyal and subversive Government employes must be removed from the Federal payroll, but that there would he no "witch hunts." He issued a statement after meeting for the first time with twenty members of the Loyalty Review Board recently named by the Civil Service Commission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Samuel Goldwyn of Hollywood, head of Samuel Goldwyn Productions, received the President's Certificate of Merit today for his war services and after a visit to the White House denounced the House Committee on Un-American Activities of being itself un-American.

Random notes. The first of the special three-day hunts which are being conducted on the Pisgah National Forest in North Carolina was fairly successful despite adverse weather conditions. A total of 233 deer and bear hunters participated in the hunt and fourteen deer and one black bear were taken opening day.

To the editor of the new york times: The action taken by New Jersey is ratifying its new Charter is of greate significance in the progress of women we venture to say, than Wyoming's ac in granting them the vote in 1869. Fo Wyoming gave the vote to a subject class called female.

The Port of New York Authority expects to issue early next year the first bonds for financing its $175,000,000 airport development program, with the initial marketing consisting of both serial and term bonds, Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Authority, said yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 14 -- Difference of opinion among major religions is a healthy condition in a democracy but should exist with better spirit, precluding name calling and open animosity, the Rev. George B. Ford, rector of Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church, New York City, said here tonight.

The men who govern Britain are as much governed by unwritten laws as the nation is bound by its unwritten constitution. It is an inviolable tradition, for instance, that the budget is never presented before the Stock Exchange closes for the day and that no hint of its contents can be revealed until it is presented to the House of Commons.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Citizens Food Committee heard suggestions today that permanent machinery be set up to encourage food conservation in the United States.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A plan to suppress the international walk, baseball's most irking stratagem to the average fan, by making it worth two bases was proposed today by Jack Sheehan, director of the Cubs' farm system. Sheehan also proposed a restricting catcher's box which would force the pitcher to throw the ball somewhere within the vicinity of the plate against all batters.

The former battleship New Mexico did not enter Newark seaport yesterday but her arrival at Gravesend Bay, agai ndelayed by an unfavorable northwest wind, was the signal for a series of legal moves and proposed compromises that may well mean peace over Newark Bay.
PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Two companies of state security police in Marseille were dissolved today and their officers and enlisted men suspended without pay as the result of Wednesday's riots.

The American National Theatre and Academy and the National Broadcasting Company plan the joint presentation of a series of dramas over the NBC chain of video stations, it was learned yesterday. The initial bill is scheduled to be the Tennessee Williams one-act play, "The Last of My Solid Gold Watches," which will be offered at 8:30 P.M. on Sunday, Nov. 30.

Roy Conacher will skate at Madison Square Garden tonight, but he won't be wearing the uniform of the New York Rangers. The sharp-shooting left forward, whom Manager Prank Boucher tried to buy for the New York club, will play with the Chicago Black Hawks against the local puck chasers in a National Hockey League contest that promises to draw a capacity crowd of 15,000 onlookers.
The market for pound sterling was marked yesterday by lively trading activity, with evident signs of strength and improvement in the spot pound. "Futures," however, broke sharply.

Today's events: "Tosca," Metropolitan Opera House, 2 P. M. Lukas Foss, piano, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Katherine Bacon, piano, Town Hall, 3; American Youth Orchestra, Dean Dixon, conductor, Central High School of Needle Trades, 2; Dorothy Averell, violin, Town Hall, 5:30; Bloch Festival, Edgar Schenkmann, conducor, Juilliard Concert Hall, 5 and 8:30.

Disregarding a Soviet threat "grave consequences," the General Assembly voted at Flushing Meadow yesterday to establish United Nations Commission to supervise elections in Korea and he establish a provisional government. The vote was 43 to 0, with six announced abstentions.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- A.A. Smirnov, Soviet representative, refused to discuss the inclusion of a United States draft of a disarmament treaty for Germany on the agenda of the Council of Foreign Ministers at the deputies' meeting today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A Communist surge which, if successful, would take over Italy, United States-backed Greece and Turkey and the entire Middle East was predicted today by Representative John D. Lodge, Republican, of Connecticut, of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Nov. 14 -- "Rogues' Regiment," a film about the post-war French foreign legion in indo-China, will be produced early next year at Universal-International by Robert Buckner, the studio announced today.

ALL Gen. George S. Patten Jr.'s qualities -- great, gruesome or grotesque -- stand out in his memoirs, "War As I Knew It." He was, as Douglas Southall Freeman remarks mildly enough in his introduction, "a man to win, to intrigue "and sometimes to enrage his fellow-commanders." Not to mention the soldiers who served under him -- and the majority of his fellow-men.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 14 (AP) -- A year's suspension from baseball will be imposed by Commissioner A.B. Chandler on any one who violates the rule prohibiting the signing of high school players, he announced today.

AKRON, Ohio, Nov. 14 -- A one-year contract, its terms retroactive to Oct. 1 and in compliance with the Taft-Hartley Labor Act, was signed yesterday between the Graphics Art Association of the Akron district and Akron Typographical Union, Local 182, of the International Typographical Union, AFL.

Congress or the Supreme Court may overrule the state laws which permit acting in concert to set insurance premium rates, according to George H. Ort, executive vice president of the Insurance Brokers Association of New York, Inc., at the end of the two-day hearing conducted at the Bar Association, 42 West Forty-fourth street, by the joint legislative committee of insurance rates and regulations.

VIENNA, Nov. 14 -- Disclosures that Soviet authorities in Austria had been shipping Austrian oil for the use of the Russian Black Sea Fleet and that Hungary and Rumania had been insisting that the Austrian Government pay the whole freight rate for such shipments were made at today's Allied Council meeting.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 14 -- Princeton hotels and accommodations were completely filled tonight by the vanguard of 53,000 persons who will jam Palmer Stadium tomorrow to watch the seventieth football meeting between Yale and Princeton.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 -- After long debate, the members of the National Association of Real Estate Boards today left their directors free to plead guilty to antitrust charges in an indictment obtained by the Department of Justice in Washington.

The United Nations General Assembly will decide this morning whether its debates will be heard next year in Europe or in the familiar committee rooms of Lake Success and the Assembly Hall at flushing Meadow. The Assembly began consideration at Flushing Meadow yesterday afternoon of a proposal that its third regular session be held in Europe, but at adjournment time only two speakers had been heard, with fourteen still on the list.

The twenty-two forced transfers of Manhattan real estate during October showed a sharp drop from September figures, according to the regular monthly survey of foreclosures and surrenders to mortgagees in lieu of foreclosure reported by the Real Estate Board of New York.

Domestic production of wood-pulp in 1947 will exceed any previous record and imports will come close to the highest previous total if not surpass it, but even so the record supply of pulp will not be sufficient to satisfy demand, Fred G. Stevenot, president of the Puget Sound Pulp and Timber

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- Registration statements were filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by Northern Natural Gas Company, the American Insurance Company of Newark, N.J., and General Instrument Corporation of Elizabeth, N.J.

Buddy Ensor, one of the leading jockeys in the 1920's, was found dead Thursday morning in Prospect Cemetery in South Jamaica, Queens, into which he had wandered while ill of lobar pneumonia. His body remained unidentified in the morgue at Queens General Hospital until yesterday morning.

Florida Citrus Drive Expanded The Florida Citrus Commission will launch tomorrow a four-month $1,500,000 advertising campaign, which will employ approximately one-third more newspapers than last season. Intensive promotional programs by leading grocer groups have been arranged to supplement the 1947-48 drive, which will emphasize improved canning processes.

Further tightening of flat rolled steel supplies here is forcing some buyers to seek deliveries from Middle Western and Southwestern markets, industrial purchasing agents disclosed here yesterday. Heavily increased costs of procurement resulting from increased purchasing and expediting costs, plus large extra charges in first cos and transportation, eventually will have to be reflected in higher prices for finished steel hardware products next year, they revealed.

A 43-year-old gynecologist and a 49-year-old plastic surgeon were booked last night at the East Sixty-seventh Street police station on charges of homicide in connection with the death of a 22-year-old woman, who according to the police died on Oct. 28 after a criminal abortion.

The force of the downward spiral in the stock market was stemmed somewhat Yesterday as offerings diminished and modest gains were shown by some issues. On balance the market was little changed from the previous close as the composite rate showed only a recession of 0.02 point on the day.

MADRID, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Spanish Catholics are protesting to the Government of Generalissimo Francisco Franco against what they call a "Protestant offensive" in Spain, and are asking strict adherence to the law that forbids the public conduct of Protestant rites.

An extensive and varied education is the primary prerequisite of any person desiring to enter the profession of journalism and its allied fields. Dean John T. Madden of the New York University School of Commerce, Accounts and Finance declared yesterday at the eighth annual N.Y.U. conference on school publications.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- The French Communist party, which has stood conspicuously apart from the rest of the National Assembly since its setback in the municipal elections, today proclaimed a policy of political isolation.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 14 -- Two British policemen and two soldiers were shot down from behind and killed today in the renewed terrorist drive. The soldiers were slain in the heart of Tel Aviv and the policemen in the center of Jerusalem.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- Three companies applied today to the Securities and Exchange Commission for authority to purchase electric transmission facilities in Arkansas and Oklahoma, commonly known as the "Ark-La line," from the Ark-La Electric Cooperative, for $3,800,000.

Sporting a three-game winning streak, Columbia will toss its diversified air and ground attack against Holy Cross, one of the East's leading defensive machines, at Baker Field at 2 P.M. today. It will be the first football game between these two schools, and the next-to-last appearance of the season for the Lions.

The first knockout in his eight years of bruising fighting is in the record books today against sturdy Jake LaMotta of the Bronx, 26-year-old gladiator who had been considered a possible successor to the world light-heavyweight title now held by Gus Lesnevich, but the Bronxite's claim of never having been knocked off his feet remains.

ATHENS, Nov. 14 (U.P.) -- Greek Army units stepped up operations in some sectors today as the offer of amnesty made by Premier Themistocles Sophoulis' Government to the guerrillas neared its expiration at midnight.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- General rains in the Southwest, covering much of western and southern Kansas, Oklahoma and the Texas Panhandle dry sections, caused today a sharp reversal, of price trend in the grain markets on the Board of Trade.
LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Scotland Yard disclosed today the tightest security net in its history will guard Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten on their wedding" day next Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The "increase of chaos in the world situation" last spring influenced the Navy's approval of the sale of 100 surplus tankers to foreign countries, Secretary of the Navy John L. Sullivan told the Senate Small Business Committee today.

The reported move by Sweden to cut exports of cellulose pulp to continental Europe by 50 per cent will not mean a corresponding increase in the quantity of pulp shipped to the United States, according to trade reports here yesterday.

DENVER, Nov. 14 -- Harold E. Stassen, speaking tonight to the Lincoln Republican Club of Denver, urged what amounted to an embargo on shipments of machine tools and heavy industrial equipment to Russia and its satellite nations unless and until Russia agreed to help us rebuild Europe.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 14 -- The principal problem of cities requiring increased revenues to meet the rising costs of government is how to convince their citizens that tax payments are an economy measure on a collective scale, the National Municipal League was told today.

Dr. Erich Fromm, chairman of the faculty of the William Alanson White Institute of Psychiatry, and Patrick Mullahy of the same institute are reported by Hermitage Press to be editing a volume on the Oedipus complex, entitled "Oedipus -- Myth and Complex."

The Queens Electrical Appliance Merchants Association yesterday went on record as supporting the cooperating appliance dealer plan of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc. In a statement issued following several meetings between a special committee of the group and Brig. Gen. E.F. Jeffe, Consolidated Edison vice president in charge of sales, relevant to termination of cooperating dealer status of Lou Gray, Forest Hills appliance dealer, Joseph Loscalzo, president, said:

With two key operatives back in action, Fordham has high hopes of registering its second victory of the 1947 football campaign today at the Polo Grounds against Lafayette. A crowd of 10,000 is expected to be on hand for the opening kick-off at 2 P.M.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- Gathered in joint sessions, 125 representatives of the Northeastern Poultry Producers Council, the International Baby Chick Association and the National Poultry Producers Federation opened a campaign today to reduce chick and poultry production to meet the Government's grain saving program.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The State Department said today that this country was no longer sending goods to Russia under the old wartime lend-lease program.
PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Balmain's midseason showing of twenty models confirms a trend toward the ultra feminine in spring suits.

The conservation spotlight turns on Sausage and Apple Patties, the Peace Plate suggested for today. With this tasty dish, serve buttered green beans (canned, fresh or frozen) Hubbard squash or yellow turnips which have been steamed or boiled, then mashed, and seasoned with salt, pepper, and butter or cream, with a dash of grated orange rind for extra flavor.
NANKING, Nov. 14 -- China is negotiating in Washington for the purchase of 600 surplus transport planes and an undisclosed amount of munitions, an authoritative Chinese source said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Secretary of State Marshall is expected to make an important foreign policy address in Chicago Tuesday when he will speak before foreign policy groups prior to his departure for the conference of Foreign Ministers in London.

Emergency action to avert a predicted shortage of milk for the metropolitan area was taken yesterday by Dr. Charles J. Blanford, administrator of Federal and State regulations governing the marketing of milk here. He announced that he had issued a "92 per cent rule."

The League of New York Theatres' board of governors yesterday approved the proposal to curtail first night press tickets. Under the new plan, which must be ratified by the league's general membership before it can become effective, only drama reviewers and editors of metropolitan newspapers will be invited to attend Broadway premieres.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Pacific Northwest business men urged the Civil Aeronautics Board today to authorize direct air service to Hawaii to enable them to bypass California in reaching Hawaiian customers.

Despite an impassioned charge by Soviet delegate Andrei Y. Vishinsky that certain delegations were attempting to revise the Charter according to their own partisan interests, the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow yesterday adopted three resolutions calling attention to the need in the United Nations for greater use of the International Court of Justice.

TRENTON, N.J., Nov. 14 -- The State School Aid Commission, a study group, recommended to Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll today an increase in New Jersey grants to public schools of $13,000,000 to make the annual total approximately $28,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A company personally recommended by Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, retired, got $1,053,000 in subcontracts for warplane parts, the Senate War Investigating subcommittee was told today.

To the editor of the new york times: Since THE NEW YORK TIMES has, now twice misquoted the findings o the Harriman Committee on the subject of the effect of the Marshall Plan on possible tax reduction, let me ask the privilege of your columns to quote what the Harriman Committee said which bears upon this subject.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:
STINNETT, Tex., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Frankie Groves, a slip of a girl who likes to play rough, got into a football game tonight and made sports history in Texas. And she didn't even smear her lipstick.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- Pennsylvania stands confronted by the most dangerous team to bar its way to its first season of uninterrupted success on the gridiron since 1904.

This city has "one of the most impossible traffic problems in the country for which we have not found the answer," Governor Dewey asserted yesterday during a luncheon at the closing session of the fifteenth annual conference of the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators at the New Yorker Hotel.

War is not inevitable, provided we follow a brief formula-"physical defense, psychological offense" -- it was asserted last night at the New York Academy of Medicine by Prof. Harold Dwight Lasswell of the Yale University Law School. He delivered the last in a series of three Thomas "William Salmon Memorial Lectures on the subject, "The Dynamics of Power and Personality."

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Woodruff Randolph, president of the International Typographical Union, AFL, announced today that a "complete deadlock" had been reached in contract negotiations between Local 16, Chicago Typographical Union, and the Chicago Newspaper" Publishers Association.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 -- Supporters of Governor Dewey for the 1948 Republican Presidential nomination said today that they did not regard the announcement by Governor Warren of California that he was a candidate as a serious setback for the New York chief executive.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Speculators In the gilt-edge section of stock markets here today sold heavily following the news of the resignation late yesterday of Hugh Dalton as Chancellor of the Exchequer. At the opening jobbers quoted stock 2 points off and soon showed that they were unwilling to take more than a small amount on their books.

There is a touch of personal tragedy in the resignation of Hugh Dalton as Chancellor of the British Exchequer. Although ostensibly that resignation was voluntary, actually it was a dictated one-dictated by the stern British tradition which holds it to be a breach of Ministerial responsibility to divulge any part of the contents of the budget in advance of its presentation to the House of Commons.

A total of $1,086,700 has been allocated for New York's four municipal colleges in the final proposals of the City Planning Commission for the 1948 capital budget, it was learned yesterday. The recommendations, which have heen submitted to the Board of Estimate, include an allocation of $200,000 for the construction of a science building at Queens College.

NEWARK, N. J., Nov. 14 -- Sharply conflicting testimony on the issue of Federal aid in solving the housing problem was offered today by fifty-five witnesses before Representative Frank L. Sundstrom here. The hearing was one of three being held in the nation by the joint housing committee of the Senate and House.

Although, as one member callously suggested, the world was not "waiting breathlessly" for the decision, our City Council has gravely given us the benefit of its judgment on the Marshall Plan of aid to Europe. Thus the Council once more demonstrated its ability to handle, urbanely and with hardly a break in legislative rhythm, a wide sweep of problems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Joint Committee on the Economic Report was asked by its Eastern price - investigating subcommittee today to give "serious consideration" to statutory rationing of meat, butter and eggs as one way to curb rising living costs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- President Truman's statement on loyalty of Federal employes was as follows:

Miss Hester Davis, 19-year-old student at Pine Manor College, Wellesley, Mass., plunged to her death yesterday from a window on the thirtieth floor of an office building at 501 Madison Avenue. The body landed on the roof of a three-story building at 36 East Fifty-third Street.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Lewis P. Andreas, Syracuse University athletic director, denied today that he was urging Chancellor William P. Tolley to establish football scholarships in order to match competition of Colgate, Cornell, Penn State and other opponents.

To the editor op THE NEW YORK TIMES: During the war, when there was shortage of manpower and equipmen the Department of Sanitation issued notice that the practice of collectin garbage every day would be temporarily discontinued and it would collected on every other day.

In proportion to the quality of his output, the music of Ernest Bloch has not received the measure of attention to which it is richly entitled by its qualities. And last night, in the concert room on Claremont Avenue, the Juilliard School, collaborating with the League of Composers, gave the first of the three concerts which will constitute a festival and an admirably comprehensive summation of Bloch's best music.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- In a message on the occasion of the annual meeting of the American Hierarchy, Pope Pius praised efforts to aid those multitudes afflicted by the aftermath of war.
PARIS, Nov. 14 -- The French Parliament approved tonight the introduction of French currency into the territory of the Saar.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, India, Nov. 14 (AP) -- An Indian military spokesman said today that strafing planes of the Royal Indian Air Force were supporting garrisons of Kashmir State troops pocketed by Moslem invaders from Pakistan in the hilly regions of Jammu, south of Srinagar.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 14 -- With the weather clear, the track fairly fast and the customers happy to collect some mid-November suntan, the spruced-up Bowie race course opened its fourteen-day meeting today. It's the last session of the Maryland campaign.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Reversing last week's decline, average primary market prices increased 0.3 per cent during the week ended last Saturday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Department of Labor, reported today.

Replacement or the 108-year-old Brooklyn City Prison, long condemned as obsolete, insanitary and inadequate, came one step nearer yesterday with the filing of plans for a $5,219,000 eleven-story structure on which work is expected to start in the spring.

The Roman Catholic Church is planning to play a role in the industrialization of India by opening two technical schools at a cost of $250,000 to train skilled technicians in various engineering fields and allied sciences.

Undeterred by threats of a boycott on the part of the Russian bloc, the General Assembly of the United Nations has approved by an overwhelming majority the creation of a "Little Assembly" to help guard international peace and security after the big Assembly has adjourned.

One of the oldest gridiron rivalries in the East will be resumed today when New York University meets Rutgers at New Brunswick, N.J., in the thirty-eighth game of a series that began in 1890. The kick-off is at 2 P.M., and a crowd of 15,000 will be on hand to see if Rutgers, a heavy favorite, can even the record between the two schools at eighteen triumphs apiece.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Senate Republican Policy Committee agreed today to permit nothing to block earliest possible floor action on the $597,000,000 emergency relief program for France, Italy and Austria.
ROME, Nov. 14 -- Political disturbances, which started in Milan two days ago and continued in Naples yesterday, spread to Palermo in Sicily and throughout Italy today.

Steel Prices Although both the United States Steel Corporation and the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the two top producers of steel in the nation, have expressed determination recently to maintain prices at current levels, other companies in the industry are seriously considering new price increases.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 -- Wendell Berge, former Assistant United States Attorney General, said today there has been among business men an ever-increasing tendency in practice to eliminate competition from the production and distribution of goods.

Lake Success, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- India's charges of racial discrimination against the Union of South Africa were backed by seven more states today in the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

A saving to the home-buyer of $2,500 on the price of a house now selling for $7,500 could be effected if middlemen's profits were eliminated, the House Labor Committee group investigating restrictive labor practices in housing heard yesterday.

Scoring in every period, Poly Prep rolled to a 40-0 triumph over St. Paul's in the forty-sixth meeting of the 63-year-old rivalry at Poly Prep Field yesterday. The triumph put Poly into the lead in the series, 23 -- 22, with one game having ended in a tie.

The final chapter in one of the largest transactions ever accomplished by the War Assets Administration was written yesterday when a check for $143,270,000 was handed to Robert M. Littlejohn, WAA Administrator, by Reginald H. Hargrove, president of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, for title to the Big Inch and Little Big Inch pipelines.

The tenth memorial show of paintings by William Glackens and a group of drawings and paintings by Lenna Glackens may be seen at the Glackens home, 10 West Ninth Street, from 2 to 6 P. M. daily, through Nov. 30.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Dr. Johannes Schmidt, the German scientist mainly responsible for the development of Germany's first rocket-propelled fighter plane, was one of three persons killed today during the testing of a rocket motor at a top-secret British research laboratory in Westcott, Buckinghamshire.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- A two - temperature refrigerator o improved design in which a sharp freezing compartment is provided without impingement upon or interference with the conditioning of the other food storage areas was patented this week by Donald E. Dailey of Germantown, Pa. His invention was one of 408 listed for awards in the current official gazette of the United States Patent Office.
Contributions for the Friendship Food Train, which is on its way to the city, began to pour in yesterday as New Yorkers responded to pleas to aid the hungry of Europe.

Birds of all descriptions from the four corners of the world and from here in the city were preening yesterday for veteran judges, as 1,500 birds representing exhibitors from almost every state and Canada opened the first New York National Cage Bird Show in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- The "inevitable" fusion of the Socialist party with the Polish Communist party was predicted today by Kazimierz Baginski, vice chairman of the Peasant party.

The theory that all activity in college football after the Army-Notre Dame game is purely anticlimactic explodes in the face of the attractive nation-wide program offered today. With the 1947 campaign nearing its end, many big battles are up for decision.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 14 -- The United States Army grain mission has purchased 25,500 metric tons [28,110 short tons] of Argentine corn for direct shipment to Germany, it disclosed tonight.
Considerable evenlng-up in cotton futures occurred on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 18 points higher to 1 point lower than the day before.
The long-term stabilization of wages in the building trades, which Mayor O'Dwyer has demanded as necessary to allow the city to get into full production, appeared close at hand yesterday.

Many New York churches will join with others all over the world in celebrating tomorrow the 100th anniversary of the hymn "Abide With Me." The aim is to link "all lovers of the hymn into an international family," according to the Rev. H.J. Garland of London, honorary secretary of the Centenary Commemorations Committee.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The good right foot of big John Siano gave the bowl-bound Villanova College eleven its second extra-point victory of the season tonight as the Wildcats rallied in the second half to beat Georgetown University, 14 to 12, before 15,000 at Shibe Park.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 14 -- Although the full force of the United States Military Government has been mobilized to combat communism in Germany, the Communist party received full assurance today it would be permitted to carry on its activities.

Another war is inevitable if Uncle Sam again adopts the policy of being "Uncle Ostrich" as he did after the end of World War I, Admiral W.H.P. Blandy, commander of the Navy's Atlantic Fleet, declared last night. The admiral spoke at the annual dinner of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Representatives of the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom, the three countries which collaborated in producing fissionable material for the atomic bomb, began a three-day conference here today on atomic security problems.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 14 -- A mild recession that may develop into a serious depression threatens the United States next year unless this country keeps up foreign loans or aids, and thus avoids a sharp cut in exports, according to a "Survey of Current inflationary and Deflationary Tendencies" just completed by experts in the United Nations economic stability section.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 14 -- New corporate issues offered for cash sale in August aggregated $248,000,000, the lowest amount since November, 1945, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today in its statistical bulletin for October.
T. Norman Willcox has been appointed manager of the methods and equipment laboratory of the Plastics Division of General Electric's Chemical Department at Pittsfield, Mass.

Ready-to-use frostings that are prepared simply by adding water to the contents of a package, stirring and spreading over a cake result in an uncooked icing that for creamy, smooth texture can't be equalled if one mixes the ingredients oneself for a similar product.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Whatever controls are reimposed on American economy in order to rehabilitate Europe must be clearjy explained to the women voters of this country, Mrs. Robert W. MacAuley, assistant chairman of the Republican National Committee, said on her return today from a swing round the country.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- The country's 132 Class One railroads and two railroad unions today negotiated a $100,000,000-a-year wage increase for 200,000 employes, retroactive to Nov. 1, and reached an agreement on changes in four working rules.

VIENNA, Nov. 13 (Delayed) -- Hope that 1,000,000 displaced persons in Europe for whom no home is yet in sight can be geared in within the Marshall plan was expressed at a press conference here today by William Hallam Tuck, executive secretary of the Preparatory Commission of the International Refugee Organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Denial of a series of applications aimed mainly at enabling the Santa Fe to establish entry into St. Louis was recommended today by C. E. Boles, assistant director of the Bureau of Finance of the Interstate Commerce Commission, and A. G. Nye, an examiner.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 -- The country's number one shortage today was the shortage of young men and women in politics which permitted elections to be won by a minority, Senator J. Howard McGrath of Rhode Island told delegates to the Young Democratic Clubs of America at their convention tonight.

A possibility that the independence date for the propsed Jewish and Arab states might have to be postponed to Oct. 1 was discussed yesterday by the four-nation working group drafting a plan for partition of Palestine under the auspices of the United Nations.

BARBERTON, Ohio, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Major rubber companies are getting close to an agreement on disposing of the Government's synthetic rubber plants, Representative Shafer, Republican, of Michigan said today as his committee called its first public hearing in Ohio.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- In twin moves to spur coal production as the key to British, recovery the National Union of Mineworkers and the National Coal Board agreed today on a wage increase and on the recruitment of 30,000 European volunteers into the industry.

Lack of adequate administrative control by the Welfare Department over the placement of fortyone relief clients in hotels was criticized in a supplementary report of the city's Analysis Bureau made public yesterday by Benjamin Fielding, Welfare Commissioner.

About forty of the 130 new buses whose purchase was recently authorized by the Board of Estimate will be delivered early next month, in time to help relieve traffic congestion in Brooklyn during the Christinas shopping season, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday.

BY late November, the season in the rock garden and rock wall is drawing to a close. The time has come to give serious thought to the protection of the lovely alpine plants that have made this garden an enjoyable spot during the months when they grew and flowered.
BERLIN, Nov. 15 -- A hotbed of nazism and anti-Semitism flourishes without interference in the little town of Kleinmachnow just outside Berlin in the Soviet occupation zone.

THE Studebaker Corporation is offering as a feature of the new line of 1948 models, announced yesterday, a type of construction that allows more view on all sides. With traffic congestion far above the pre-war average, the "panoramic design" in the Commander and Champion lines is said to be increasingly popular because of the extended field of vision it provides.

When the last war issue of Government bonds -- the Victory 2 1/2s due in 1972 and callable in 1967 -- settled in price below 101 1/2 and stayed there, a new question was raised overnight in the financial market place and has haunted it ever since.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Amid an atmosphere marked by the prospect of a happier Thanksgiving and Christmas for the more than 200,000 operating railroad employes throughout the country as a result of an annual wage increase of $100,000,000 agreed upon yesterday by officials of 132 Class 1 carriers, a feeling of gratification over the speedy and amicable way by which the negotiations were concluded also was upper-most in the thoughts of the unions' officials today.

With the appearance of some early Christmas buying, retail trade here continued active last week. Gains, however, were narrower than in preceding weeks. The rise for department stores was around 5 per cent, reflecting in part at least comparison with heavy sales a year ago following the end of the delivery and trucking strikes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Maryland made three mistakes In the fourth period today, and North Carolina promptly turned them into three touchdowns and a 19 to 0 Southern Conference victory.

THIS combination of the lectures of a grandfather and a grandson, the second given fifty years later than the first, is a fascinating and lucid record of man's progress in combining the theory of evolution with the much later and less developed theories of psychology and anthropology.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- President Truman will touch off a formal debate which is certain to continue right through the 1948 Presidential campaign when he goes before Congress Monday to prescribe what should be done to combat inflation at home and to speed recovery abroad.

THE mecca of millions of movie-goers is a loft in New York City. Fans from China and Africa, Canada and Australia, daily fill up dozens of mail bags with letters to 212 East Fourteenth Street. What they want usually are just photographs of their screen heroes or sweet-hearts; sometimes they want more.

PENNSYLVANIA -- Civic-Minded Attesting to the value of combining classroom study and community service, students and faculty of the Pennsylvania College for Women have contributed the largest gift in proportion of any school, college or university in Pittsburgh to the Community Chest drive.

THE sea-minded Yankee of countinghouse and bog-iron days, the ax-helve type renowned for his political vigor, sharp dealing and sardonic wit, exists no more. He has been out-traded, outworked, outfought, outvoted.

THIS novel is the gross, episodic record of a hazardous year in the labyrinth of a New York City high school -- of the maladjustments, perversions, corruption of its students and teachers. Reflected here, in lurid detail, is the current crisis in public education, with its by-products of faculty, as well as student body, demoralization.

ANKARA, Nov. 15 -- As the American program of aid to Greece and Turkey nears the halfway mark evidence is piling up that $300 million for Greece and $100 million for Turkey was not enough, that this investment can only mark a beginning if the objectives of the Truman doctrine are to be realized.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- Monthly steel quotas for many companies have been reduced and deliveries delayed during the last quarter despite virtual capacity operation of steel mills, P.C. Patch, chairman of the business survey committee of the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago, revealed today following a poll of members on various phases of the steel situation.

TOKYO, Nov. 15 -- The adoption of an interim agreement between Japan and the sterling areas was announced today by Gen. Douglas MacArthur. The pact promises to revive private trade with British countries, which has been gradually drying up since Britain suspended sterling convertibility Aug. 5.

ATHENS, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Greek Press Ministry announced tonight that leftist guerrillas attacked Komotine in Thrace but were repulsed by the artillery-supported defenders. The leftists retreated, leaving several dead, the Ministry said.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: We, the undersigned citizens and students of American foreign affairs, respectfully transmit to you the following observations which we believe pertinent to the success of the Marshall plan for the reconstruction of Europe.

WITH more accuracy and considerably less eyebrowraising ambiguity, this author might have entitled her book "Petticoat and Dagger," for it is a girl's view of the inside of that most intriguing of our secret wartime agencies, the Office of Strategic Services.

Prices of shares fluctuated narrowly in yesterday's brief session on the New York Stock Exchange, and final quotations were irregularly higher. Trading was quiet, with transactions amounting to 300,000 shares, compared with 250,000 on the preceding Saturday.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- France's supplementary need in stop-gap aid over and above the $328,000,000 proposed in the Marshall speech was set at $76,000,000 in an article published tonight in the evening newspaper Paris Presse.
NANKING, Nov. 15 -- A contingent of paratroopers and a fresh division of troops were flown to Suchow today as the Government moved to counter the Communist attack there.
MANILA, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- The typhoon "Flora" ripped a north-westerly course across Luzon Island today, leaving a wake of destruction in the Philippines and at least one ship in distress.

The program for Federal tax and budget reform announced last week by the Committee for Economic Development has been recognized widely as something more than the ordinary pressure group's cry for lower or higher taxes, or for more or less government spending, depending on the direction of the pressure.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 15 -- Albert D. Cash, Mayor-designate of Cincinnati, will be the first Democratic Mayor since 1913. He will take office Jan. 1, 1948, and is the choice of the five City Charter Committee candidates who were elected to City Council Nov. 4.

Unleashing a sprint in the last 100 yards, Bob Audolensky, Bronx Science harrier, defeated Howard Jacobson of De Witt Clinton to capture individual honors in the annual Public Schools Athletic League city cross-country championship run yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- One crew member was drowned but the other forty-four reportedly reached shore in lifeboats today when the British freighter Langleecrag broke in two after piling up on a reef on the northern tip of New-foundland.

JACKSON, Miss., Nov. 15 -- The Legislature today completed a three-day special session called by Gov. Fielding Wright after passing all but one of six measures aimed at ending violence and terrorism in connection with the Trailways bus strike.

IVY in all its varieties is one of the most satisfactory of all house plants. Of the many sorts, five or six kinds will provide light and dark and variegated leaves, climbing and trailing and bush plants, and even -- perhaps -- a few flowers.

Discussing the Palestine partition, Rabbi Louis I. Newman in Temple Rodeph Sholom, 7 West Eighty-third Street, said yesterday "that surely neither Britain nor the Arabs can afford to flaunt public opinion by running counter to the expressed will of the United Nations Assembly."

A few remarkable companies have proved that they can "hold pre-war or lower prices now," despite increased labor and material costs. While their products are little known to the public because they are sold primarily to commercial and industrial buyers, industrial engineers making consumer goods are intensely interested in this unique "know-how" of actually "holding the line on prices," spokesmen revealed yesterday.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Purdue's Boilermakers gained their easiest football victory of the season today, beating the Pittsburgh Panthers 28 to 0, on a wet field before 19,000 spectators.

Hugh Dalton, Eton and Cambridge-trained British Laborite, whose father was chaplain in Queen Victoria's household, has long been one of the Labor party's leading economic theorists. He became a Cabinet Minister at 42 in the second MacDonald Labor Cabinet.

Several card parties in behalf of charitable enterprises will be held during the coining week. The Mary Fisher Home will be the beneficiary of a card party and bazaar to be held on Thursday afternoon at the Pierre. Mrs. Daniel H. Payne and Mrs. Daniel E. Lurch are co-chairmen of the benefit committee.

THE great debate over the Marshall Plan is about to begin -- a debate comparable in importance and intensity with the discussions of the neutrality and lend-lease issues. It will take place in the Congress which convenes tomorrow and it will echo to all corners of the country.

A spirited Stuyvesant eleven, which hadn't won a game all season, registered one of the biggest upsets in local interscholastic football this year when it defeated De Witt Clinton, 13-7, at Randall's Island yesterday. A crowd of 3,000 saw the Peglegs score the winning touchdown midway in the third quarter when Ray Lanflisi intercepted a Whitney Arceneaux pass on the Clinton 33 and Romped the remaining distance to the goal line.

Formation of a national non-partisan committee to back the Marshall plan was announced yesterday. The committee is headed by Henry L. Stimson as national chairman and by a national council including more than 200 leaders in business, labor, religion, education and civic affairs.

County Judge Lester W. Patterson of the Bronx, who was reelected recently to a second fourteen-year term, died yesterday morning in Mount Sinai Hospital, where he had been a patient for a month. He had been suffering from a complication of illnesses.

HE undoubtedly would have been a great football player anyway but Lee Artoe gave him the extra impetus which sent him roaring along the road to stardom. Orban (Spec) Sanders is a mild-mannered, serious-minded and intense young man who is slow to wrath. But Artoe got him mad. The All-America Football Conference teams -- except Spec's New York Yankees, of course -- have been regretting it ever since.

Eight hundred sixty-seven thousand eight hundred forty-one were enrolled in the Naval Reserve on Oct. 1, an increase of 11,158 over the total on Sept. 1, headquarters of the Commandant, Third Naval District, announced yesterday.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Nov. 15 (AP) -- An inspired band of fighting Citadel Bulldogs upset the dope bucket in the Southern Conference today by coming from behind in the final two minutes of play to topple Virginia Military Institute, 7 -- 6.

THIS penetrating essay, urbane in style, rich in erudition, is by far the most comprehensive and satisfying analysis yet made of Jefferson's lifelong contemplation of ancient civilizations. Limited to his incredibly thorough study of the Greek and Roman world -- and to its effect upon him as an heir of the Renaissance -- it does not explore Jefferson's admiration or other ancient languages and literatures, the Anglo-Saxon, for example.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The reappearance on the British political scene of Sir Oswald Mosley, former Fascist leader, was marked tonight by a clash between police and demonstrators trying to storm the meeting.

MONTREAL, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Boston's Bruins administered a terrific 9-1 lacing here tonight to the Montreal Canadiens. It was one of the worst defeats last year's National Hockey League champions have suffered in years.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Mort Stuart's Halbarail, with George Hettinger in the saddle, won the New Hampshire Endurance Handicap, mile and a half test for $10,000, at Rockingham Park today before a crowd of 11,039.
RALEIGH, N.C., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Halfback Charlie Richkus and Fullback Les Palmer led North Carolina State College to a stunning 20-to-0 victory over heavier and highly favored Wake Forest today.

WARSAW, Nov. 15 -- The Polish Parliament, in proclaiming Stanislaw Mikolajczyk "guilty of treason against the Polish State and nation," deprived the former Peasant party leader of his Parliamentary seat today and asked the Government to take away his Polish citizenship.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- From the ashes of the disaster at Notre Dame, Army rose fiercely today to play favored Pennsylvania to a 7-7 draw on the wet turf of Franklin Field.

WASHINGTON. NOT since the days when official guests at the White House shook the hand of President Calvin Coolidge and passed down the receiving line for a sparkling beaker from the water-cooler has Washington official entertaining been as severely streamlined as it is in this era of Marshall plan and meatless Tuesdays.

TO THE EDITOR: With all due respect for Arthur M. Schlesinger's authority and calm survey of "What Is Loyalty?" I am unable to agree with his implied conclusion to the effect that the press has done an admirable job in safeguarding the civil liberties of the American citizen.

The annual sale and luncheon to support St. Luke's Home for Aged Women will be held on Wednesday and Thursday at the Home, 2914 Broadway. A luncheon will be given on Wednesday and a tea on Thursday and on both days there will be a sale of a variety of articles, including toys, food, baby clothes and gifts suitable for Christmas giving.

As a man who was most pleasantly "embarrassed by the reviews of 'Body and Soul'" Abraham Polonsky, scenarist of the fine prize ring drama at the Globe, is grateful for the critical approbation of his writing stint.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 15 -- Princeton's underdog and underrated Tigers waited until the second period to take charge of Yale today, but once the home team assumed command it swept the Elis out of the ball game and out of the Big Three championship circle.
EAST STROUDSBURG, Pa., Nov. 15 -- Touchdowns were almost as plentiful as snowflakes today as a power-laden East Stroudsburg State Teachers College eleven triumphed over C.C.N.Y. by a 42 -- 6 score.

HANOVER, N.H., Nov. 15 -- Starting its operations with a blocked kick that brought a touchdown in the first period, Dartmouth's Big Green eleven went on to tumble Cornell to a 21-13 defeat on snow-bordered Memorial Field today.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Capitalizing on a poor kick and a fumble for two quick second-period touchdowns, Buffalo University turned back Bucknell's football team, 14 to 6, on a snow-covered gridiron today. It was Buffalo's eighth victory in nine games.

The city's own "home-made" port rehabilitation program, virtually ignored by municipal au thorities in favor of the World Trade Corporation proposals and the current Port of New York Authority study, would give the city all the improvements its lucrative shipping customers could afford h the next five years, it was disclosed yesterday.

That magical forward-passing combination of Gene Rossides to Bill Swiacki clicked again for Columbia yesterday. The aerial artists wh dispelled the myth of Army's invincibility last month supplied the only touchdown as the rampaging Lions defeated Holy Cross, 10-0, before a crowd of 28,000 at Baker Field.

LOFTY, luminous and austere, this authentic aristocrat among crowding upstarts is the work of H.L. Davis -- who won both Harper and Pulitzer Prizes twelve years ago, and an enduring literary reputation, with "Honey in the Horn."

"AND what is the use of a book," thought Alice, "without pictures or conversations?" Apparently Mr. Butterfield absorbed the wisdom of Alice's opening remark and determined to write the history of the United States "from Concord to Hiroshima" with the aid of a thousand pictures and an easy-to-read text of some 125,000 words.

TEST CEREAL -- Americans use an average of 66,000,000 bushels of grain a year in breakfast foods (both the explosive and nonexplosive varieties), the Department of Agriculture estimates -- 8,000,000 bushels of wheat, 11,000,000 bushels of corn and 47,000,000 bushels of oats.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, Nov. 14 (Delayed) -- The panic that swept this playground city when invading Moslem tribesmen were in its outskirts has faded into the distant hills with the beaten raiders. Srinagar -- though bitterly cold at this time of year and hence empty of tourists -- is again its normal, quaint combination of ancient India, Venice and Tudor England.

THE vampire problem, which may or may not have been bothering you lately, is Mr. Jacobi's first consideration in this, his first collection of horror stories. He leads off boldly with a tale about a young man in a curio shop, where are discovered three small volumes written by a madman shortly before his death in an asylum.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- In making what may be, perhaps, its last attempt to fight inflation Premier Paul Ramadier's Government will face next week an uneasy choice. It may allow the present labor discontent to erupt into work stoppages or it may try to satisfy labor's wage demands and thus further weaken the anti-inflation program.
MANILA, Nov. 15 -- Manila's Mayor Valerano Fugoso has refused to issue a police permit to Nacionalista leaders for a mass indignation rally protesting against alleged nation-wide election frauds.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- London's famed Arsenal team boosted its unbeaten streak to sixteen games, and Notts County, with Tommy Lawton the spearhead of its attack, won its first game away from home this season to feature today's British soccer.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

HAVING been the historian of the boarding house -- "Chicken Every Sunday" was the report -- Rosemary Taylor now has gone on to visit another home away from home. This time, and in "Bar Nothing Ranch," she is where the cattle and the dudes frolic in the open spaces of Arizona, and where man is amiable and the rattlesnake seldom bites.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Following is a statement on secularism issued by the Catholic Bishops of the United States today after their annual meeting and signed by them as members of the administrative board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference:

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 -- The three-day national convention of the Young Democratic Clubs of America closed today after adopting thirteen resolutions and electing a new slate of officers headed by Roy G. Baker, a 33-year-old lawyer of Sherman, Tex.

IT IS Ash Wednesday in New Orleans, and Maggie Slone, like many another survivor of the Mardi Gras, has a hangover. Maggie is a reporter, which means that she has to go to work regardless of a throbbing bead and a dark brown taste in her mouth.

NANKING, Nov. 15 -- Recent months have seen a worsening of the critical situation faced by the National Government of China. The deterioration has been particularly evident in the military and economic spheres.

ONE of the pleasantest and most convenient workrooms has been built around a flower arrangement bench that was shown at the International Flower Show about ten years ago and later transported to my home.

CHICAGO. ROOSEVELT COLLEGE, the nation's youngest major center of higher learning, has found its permanent home in a historic Chicago landmark. The institution that was started two years ago to provide equality of educational opportunity for all races and creeds is now functioning in the massive old Auditorium Hotel and Theatre building, which for more than half a century has faced Grant Park and Lake Michigan.

Financial markets continued to mark time last week pending the opening of the special session of Congress tomorrow. The uncertainty surrounding the nation's economy, as to what the European recovery plan should cost, created a nervousness in the stock market which was not helped by the decline in high-grade preferred stocks and Government bonds.
AUSTIN, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The University of Texas Longhorns rolled over the Texas Christian Horned Frogs, 20 -- 0, here today, hanging on to a chance for the Southwest Conference title.
HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 15 -- Wesleyan completed its football season with a 13-to-0 victory over Trinity in the only game in the country that brought together two undefeated and untied teams today.

OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- Charley Conerly, Mississippi's leather-armed candidate for All-America, set a new collegiate record today when he completed his 120th pass of the season while his mates buried Chattanooga, 52 to 0.

"DECORATIONS in the Holiday Mood," the two-day program to be held in Times Hall on Nov. 18 and 19, will have one demonstration type of session that has proved popular in other years. "Decorations for a Door" is the theme, and suggestions will be included for doors outside and inside the house.

"MISTY of Chincoteague" makes the most of an unusual setting off the coast of Virginia. On a windy Saturday Paul and Maureen go with Grandpa on a trip from Chincoteague, island of men, to Assateague, island of the wild ponies.

"A LSOS" is a report of the activities and findings of the Alsos mission, a military-scientific group sent to Europe in 1944 to follow the advancing Allied armies and obtain the earliest possible information about German scientific work of significance to the war.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Universal relief over the fact that Britain has formally announced her intention of getting out of Palestine, surrendering her mandate and disassociating herself from United Nations partition in the program was evident here this week-end.
GENEVA, Nov. 15 -- The United States is putting on a strong drive to have a multilateral commercial air agreement signed at Geneva this month without further reference to governments.

LONDON, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- The official wedding cake of Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten was unveiled today -- a snow-white beauty nine feet tall and 500 pounds in weight that was three months in the making.

OVERCONFIDENCE is as dangerous in bridge as in any other form of competition. When a contract seems safest it may still be wise for declarer to pause and consider ways of making it even safer than that.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- The ultimate outcome of an experiment in compulsory health insurance was a matter of wide speculation on the West Coast this week after more than 900 doctors had resigned from a 1,000-physician panel of the ten-year-old San Francisco health service system.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 15 -- Hofstra completed a clean sweep of its schedule of games with opponents from metropolitan New York this afternoon, downing Wagner, 34 to 0.

"OH, it's wonderful to feel free," exclaimed Joan Fontaine in answer to a question about Rampart Productions, the independent company formed by the actress and her husband, William Dozier. "For the first time in my life I'm independent," she rushed on.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 8 -- A multi-million-dollar civic center eliminating seventy acres of substandard housing from the Pittsburgh business district has come from the drawing boards of two Pittsburgh architects.

THIS is a sort of homespun "Romeo and Juliet," based on what is said to be an actual incident (ca. August, 1880) in the long-standing feud between "the Hatfields and the McCoys" on the Kentucky-West Virginia border. As such, it makes no pretensions to being a historical novel, but rather tells a love story pure and simple.
The New York Rangers suffered their fifth straight defeat last night, dropping a 5-3 decision to the revitalized Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden.
The waterfowl season in Connecticut and New Jersey is scheduled to open on Tuesday, and reports indicate that most species common to both states are more plentiful than last year.

IT is probably true that any travel book gives a portrait of the author as well as a picture of the country visited. It is certainly true of the Very Rev. Dr. Johnson and "Soviet Russia Since the War." The Dean of Canterbury has written a carefully documented, informative book about present-day Russia, and throughout the entire volume his own amiable, persuasive and deeply sincere character glows brightly.

THE bygone days when grandmother sat on her front porch with a rifle slung across her knees taking pot shots at local undesirables are with us once again in Herbert Best's latest novel of the Lake Champlain country in the early Eighteen Hundreds.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- A four-power settlement of Germany's future, probably the most important single question in Europe today, appears farther from solution today, two years and six months after Germany's surrender, than ever before.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- A continued high level of demand, construction activity and prices of comes is predicted by most leaders in the realty and building field for 1948.

The annual White Elephant Cocktail Party and Tea Dance, now planned as a four-hour fete from 5 to 9 P.M., will take place on Thursday in the ballroom suite of the Hotel Plaza. It will be the ninth event of its name arranged in the interests of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

MARITTA WOLFF. author of two well-read novels, "Whistle Stop" and "Night Shift," writes conversation as if she were playing it back from a wire recorder. Nothing is left out, from the first "Got a cigarette?" to the last "Okay, pal."
Mrs. Esther Manton King, widow of the novelist Basil King, died on Friday in her home at the Hotel Holley, 36 Washington Square, at the age of 93.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Carroll Reece, Republican National Chairman, predicted tonight that Congress would achieve "noteworthy success" at the coming special session in meeting the foreign aid and domestic price problems.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 15 -- Alabama bounced Georgia Tech from the list of the nation's perfect-record teams today, 14 -- 7, as Harry Gilmer turned in one of his brighter pitching performances.

WITH an astute eye June Wetherell dissects the fifteen years from the depression to World War H and comes up with an interesting and disturbingly reminiscent novel. Knowing the generation that graduated from college into hopelessness and economic insecurity, she writes of them with penetrating sympathy.

ALTHOUGH the name of Niles Spencer is one of the most familiar in contemporary American painting, he is holding his first one-man show in nineteen years. Most of the fifteen canvases now being shown at the Downtown Gallery have been done in the last five years.

ROME, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Communist-dominated General Confederation of Labor sent to Premier Alcide de Gasperi today a letter professing a desire to "avoid any peril of civil war." The letter said the Confederation could act to restore tranquility only on these conditions:

AS hinted elsewhere in the columns of this issue, this is Children's Book Week, during which the small and medium fry come into their own, the book trade goes all out for them and the juvenile divisions of the publishing houses put their best feet forward.

History textbooks used In the elementary and high schools of the United States and Canada give a fragmentary, inadequate and sometimes wholly erroneous impression of the relations between these two great North American democracies. Too often Canadians know little about the culture and development of this country, while our students have a warped picture of our northern neighbor.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 15 -- The announcement by Representative Estes Kefauver that he would enter the Democratic primary next August as a candidate for the United States Senate seat of Tom Stewart, protege of Edward H. Crump, political arbiter of the state, has raised the curtain on one of the most dramatic political developments in the South.

PHILADELPHIA -- The emphasis on the 1948 line of automobile trailers, as revealed at the thirteenth annual convention and show of the Trailer Coach Manufacturers Association here last week, is on the luxury, comfort and convenience that can, it is said, convert a trailer into a home.

WEST COAST vacationists are now sailing up and down the Pacific Ocean from Long Beach, Calif., to Acapulco, Mexico, in the S.S. Corsair, the fabulous private yacht built by and for the late J.P. Morgan. The Corsair made her first cruise under the flag of the Pacific Cruise Lines, Ltd., only recently after a long reconversion from active service as a warship.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The text of a statement by President Truman, issued tonight with the report of his advisory committee on the Merchant Marine, was as follows:
FOOTBALL Unbeaten Penn tied Army and Princeton won the Big Three title by defeating Yale in the East's big games yesterday. Michigan routed Wisconsin to clinch the Big Nine championship.

THE poems which E.L. Mayo has collected in "The Diver" span a decade, and most of them have already been published in magazines -- as most contemporary poetry must be if it is to attract a book publisher. Some of the poems are occasional pieces ("On the Student Peace Strikers Who Went to War").

TO seek signs and portents in the children's book field is at best risky and baffling. For instance, it seemed reasonable to predict that, production difficulties being what they are, the output this year would represent a decline from 1946. On the contrary, the first ten months of 1947 brought an increase over the corresponding period last season -- and with it some surprises.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 15 -- Lutheran churchmen must "stand up fearlessly and do battle with martyr courage and devotion" against the forces of totalitarianism, nihlism and secularism, Dr. P.O. Bersell of Minneapolis, president of the Augustana Synod, asserted here tonight at the closing session of the American Federation of Lutheran Brotherhoods.

The withdrawal of United States military aid to China because it has failed to bring about unity of the opposing political factions in that country was recommended yesterday by some of the nigh school students who participated in the Youth Forum sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES and broadcast over WQXR.

CASE histories rather than precepts offer the most clues, we suspect, to the solution of that jigsaw puzzle: how to fit yourself, your effects and your round-the-clock activities into the boundaries of one room.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 15 -- J.H. Hammond's Butler proved the "courses for horses" adage today when, for the second successive year, he was a surprise victor in a $10,000 added race over this track. The 5-year-old with a not too imposing record rallied from far back to be a going-away winner of the Thomas K. Lynch Memorial Handicap before a crowd of 9.726 that bet $858,110 on the eight races.

With final recommendations on co-education in City College's liberal arts school scheduled to be presented to the college administration this week by the student council, almost unanimous approval of the measure was voiced yesterday by deans, faculty members and student leaders at the college.

"CHRISTIANITY TODAY" is a handbook of the state of Christianity in the different parts of the world, and the attitude of the various churches toward the ecumenical movement. Forty-two authors contribute a chapter each on particular countries or geographical areas.

CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- A word of caution was spoken here this week to persons who plan, upon retiring, to give up all activities and thereby achieve what they suppose is unconfined bliss. If they go through with any such idea they may have to reckon with senile dementia.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- India and South Africa should settle their racial dispute at a roundtable conference that includes Pakistan, provided South Africa is not prejudged guilty before the conference begins, Charles Fahy, United States Representative, today told the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

TO THE EDITOR: In the article, "What Is Loyalty? A Difficult Question." Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., commenting upon the recent Hollywood probe by the House Committee on Un-American Activities, says with regard to "insistence on the infallibility of capitalism" that "it reaches its pinnacle of imbecility in such episodes as the attack on the film The Best Years of Our Laves' as Communist-minded because it makes fun of the American business man.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Brilliant spot punting by Barrel Royal and a Missouri fumble set up the winning touchdown as powerful University of Oklahoma toppled the Tigers off the top rung of the Big Six Conference football standing today, 21 to 12.

IN this brief book, first published in England in 1944, C. Day Lewis sets about the difficult task of convincing the unconvinced school child of the pleasure and profit to be had in reading poetry. It is even a questionable task: can argument win to art (in this case, the art of poetry) more effectively than the art itself?

Of all forms of Federal taxation, capital levies are probably the most difficult to defend on either economic or social grounds. In 1946 the estate tax approximated only 1 per cent of the Federal revenues.

CEDAR GROVE, N.J., Sunday, Nov. 16 -- An automobile overturned and burned last night on the Newark - Pompton Turnpike and the five occupants, two men and three women, lost their lives, entrapped in the flames.

THIRTY years ago next Wednesday a young doctor opened the doors of a new type of hospital -- a hospital devoted exclusively to the treatment of speech disorders. With $1,000 which had been given to him and boundless hope, he had rented an old-fashioned house on Thirty-seventh Street, turned its two lower floors into offices and examining rooms, and circularized schools, hospitals and physicians, informing them of his aims.

Storewide activity last week was grood, according to a survey prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Meyer Both Reports. The rain affected Armistice Day business, the report stated, but not too adversely. Coat and suit sections reported good business.

If we are ever to fly at heights of ten miles or so at 1,000 miles an hour what will happen if the pressure cabin is punctured and air leaks out, or if it is necessary for passengers to parachute to earth? Dr. Samuel Gelfan of Yale is finding the answer with a small decompression chamber, which has taken rats up to simulated altitudes as high as 80,000 feet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Struggling to rebuild its war-battered economy, the world faces an oil shortage this winter -- a phenomenon unknown in peacetime for the last quarter of a century. How severe it will be depends on the weather.

An official inspection tour of the New York Foreign Trade Zone on Staten Island last week proved impressive to a Liberian delegation. This group of four Liberian Government officials, led by Gabriel Dennis, Secretary of State, is in this country in connection with the establishment of a similar Free Port at Monrovia the republic's capital city.

The Battle of Newark turned into a more or less "cold war" yesterday, with only long-range legal ammunition being used. Later even this artillery was withdrawn as both sides -- the City of Newark and Lipsett, Inc., which wants to begin scrapping the battleship New Mexico -- agreed to "cease fire" until Tuesday morning.

TORONTO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Spotting the Detroit Red Wings three goals, the world champion Toronto Maple Leafs stormed from behind tonight to win, 5 -- 3, and move into second place in the National Hockey League. The loss dropped the Wings into third position.

Many of the major domestic airlines, convinced that they will have to work out their own salvation without too much help from the Government, are preparing to initiate a 10 per cent increase in passenger fares next month.
To the Drama Editor: THAT indispensable dispenser of theatrical golden eggs -- the "angel" -- is being strangled by certain of today's narrow-visioned theatrical producers.

ALTHOUGH John van Druten's "The Voice of the Turtle" is still on view and ringing up money on the box office cash register, it now seems like an echo of yesterday. For Mr. van Druten is currently represented at the Morosco by a serious drama, ambiguously entitled "The Druid Circle."

COMMITTEES went into action the other afternoon and prospects for that series of benefits on behalf of the American National Theatre and Academy are rosier than they've been in months. Cheryl Crawford's suggested list of "Bright Memories" -- famous scenes from famous shows with the original stars -- has been adopted, though it is not likely her title will be retained.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 15 -- Led by its star aerialist, Frank Burns, and its three hard-running backs. Irwin Winkleried, Herman Hering and Harvey Grimsley, Rutgers celebrated its New Jersey Day successfully as it crushed New York University by 40 -- 0 at Rutgers Stadium today.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Foreign Secretary Bevin issued an implied warning to the Soviet Union tonight that Britain was about ready to join in writing a German peace treaty without Russian participation if the forthcoming Council of Foreign Ministers failed to reach an agreement.

American Brake Shoe Company is putting on the first demonstration of direct selling methods in Europe. Under a consolidation of five industrial lines the company will now sell through one exclusive distributor located in Stockholm, Sweden, it was revealed here yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 15 -- Inspired by the vigorous protest led by the New York delegation late yesterday against taking the rate-fixing indictment "lying down," the National Association of Real Estate Boards now is considered likely to wage a legal battle "without compromise" in the anti-trust action brought against it in Washington, it was learned today.
Last Rose of Summer Thomas Moore, the Irish poet, may have wandered into a small garden at about this time of year and seen one rose and only one. Or he may have imagined the scene.

What is believed to be the largest natural woodlands area of its kind set aside at any modern housing development is the six-acre grove furnishing one of the main features of landscaping at Fresh Meadow, the 170-acre garden apartment project of the New York Life Insurance Complany on Long Island.

IN another day or two business will learn a lot about how it must shape its affairs for the next several months or more. President Truman will make his recommendations tomorrow to the special session of Congress on foreign aid and ways of taking care of price inflation at home.

THE theatre season is in full swing. The lights are on the marquees and the stars are in their dressing rooms. The angels, fingers cramped from writing additional checks, are hopefully awaiting that turn of fortune which eventually should be coming. Soon it will be Thanksgiving Day, and along about that time someone will start worrying about the winter's booking jam.

Many buyers visited the New York wholesale market last week to place orders for spring merchandise on goods of all types, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell Co., resident buyers.

A pledge luncheon of the New York Philanthropic League in Aid of the Orthopedically Handicapped, to raise funds for a New York center to train handicapped children, was held yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Nearly 900 women attended for a program of entertainment and speeches in support of the drive.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- For about a year and a half the Secret Service has been investigating high denomination counterfeit United States currency which has been appearing in port cities, it was learned today.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 -- Alarm that American democracy might lose its greatness and move toward "reaction on the right" was expressed today by the Rev. Carl Hermann Voss at the annual meeting of the World Alliance for International Friendship Through the Churches.

THE title of Warwick Deeping's new novel sounds misleadingly like a Coney Island fun-factory. But "Laughing House" is only Sir John Mortimer's private name for his English mansion, which had seen many happy times.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 13 (Delayed) -- German financial traders, eking out what living they can from paltry deals on Frankfort's stock exchange, expressed enthusiasm today about the future. In general, they believe that good times are sure to come -- with Germany irrevocably split and western Germany nurtured to strength by the United States.

APHILATELIC item is the annual Christmas seal, since 1920 issued by the National Tuberculosis Association and earlier through the American National Red Cross. The issues are chronicled in Scott's "Specialized United States" catalogue, and a complete collection of the approximately 170 major and minor varieties printed from 1907 to date would cost about $200.

The session of Congress which begins tomorrow will not be, in parliamentary law either extra or special. It will be a resumption of the regular session. But in fact it will be an extraordinary convocation to deal with a grave emergency -- the threatened collapse of Europe's economy.

Realty prices, rent control and building costs will be discussed at a panel meeting of realtors to be held next Wednesday night at the Hotel Delmonico by the Real Estate Board of New York. Members of the board and their employes will be permitted to attend the conference which is expected to take-up any topic of major importance in the realty field.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Indiana Hoosiers finally found their scoring punch today and smashed a fighting Marquette team, 48 to 6.
