More attention must be paid to the study of foreign languages in the colleges and universities of the United States to aid international understanding, so vital to world peace, Francis C. Rosecrance, associate dean of the New York University School of Education, said yesterday at the fourteenth annual Foreign Language Conference.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt expressed her belief last night that problems between the United States and Britain were as great as those between the United States and Russia and declared that the issue before all was how much is peace really worth.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 15 -- Harvard provided a mild Ivy League football upset today when it turned back Brown, 13 -- 7, before 25,000 fans. All the scoring was confined to the second half, with the Crimson getting its winning touchdown with less than a minute and a half remaining.

TUSKEGEE INSTITUTE, Ala., Nov. 15 -- Tuskegee Institute today declared ready for use a four-room house constructed with cement and local sand and gravel by students and designed to demonstrate the feasibility of low-cost housing for rural families. The house cost less than $1,000, including labor.

EARLY in "Gentleman's Agreement," which is the highly commendable film about anti-Jewish prejudice that has been made from Laura Z. Hobson's popular book, an obviously prosperous Jewish industrialist states his emphatic belief that no good can come from blasting open the ticklish issue of anti-Semitism in a big American magazine, "Oh, that again," says this skeptic to the editor who has ordered the survey done.

AS Professor Lillard declares in his opening sentence: "When explorers landed, America was trees," and much of our subsequent development has been tied up with the problem of how to make use of the trees, how to adjust to live on terms with them, or how to get rid of them.

THE only way to discover what the teen age thinks of books is to listen. Writers, editors and publishers produce books, critics recommend, and parents buy books they think a specific age will read -- but too few of them stop to listen to the young people's own criticisms.

LONDON. THE British Broadcasting Corporation, which last week celebrated its silver jubilee, is becoming increasingly introspective. For over a year now the highbrow Third Program has been running a series of criticisms of their own programs called "Critic on the Air."

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- Two thousand armed police, supported by four tanks, today raided a refugee camp near Paris operated by the Soviet Government. The camp was surrounded while the raid was being carried out.

SOUTH SUDBURY, Mass. -- As Thanksgiving Day approaches, the New England countryside stirs with anticipation and there is a pleasant bustle of preparation for the many visitors who spend the holiday amid the peaceful charm of rural Massachusetts.
The old and vexing question of "official secrets" is again troubling Washington and the nation's agencies of public information.

SOMETHING has been learned about children -- how they develop and thrive and learn -- from the research done in the past twenty years. We don't begin to have all the answers, but when we apply the knowledge we have, many children are helped off to a healthier, happier, more self-confident start.

The Boston symphony Orchestra, under Serge Koussevitzky, presented a noble program, resplendently performed, at its concert yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Mendelssohn's Piano Concerto No. 1, in G minor, with Lukas Foss as soloist, had the central position on the list, which also included William Schuman's Third symphony and the fourth Symphony of Brahms.

WICHITA, Kan., Nov. 15 -- Concern over next year's wheat crop expressed this week in a pessimistic report issued by the Department of Agriculture has for weeks been reflected in the Great Plains by parched fields, seeds wasting in dust and farmers anxiously eyeing weather reports.

GETTYSBURG. Pa., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Gettysburg College's football team battled from behind today with two second-half touchdowns and a 20-to-7 triumph over St. Lawrence University of Canton, N.Y. Less than 1,000 fans saw the muddy battle in snow, sleet and rain.

PARIS -- A few weeks ago non-stop sleeper - plane service was established between New York and Paris, London and Brussels, and sleeper planes began flying from Miami down to Rio de Janeiro and to other South American points.
IOWA CITY, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The resignation of Dr. Eddie Anderson, University of Iowa football coach since 1939, was announced today but there was a question whether it would stick.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- An active demand developed for grains shortly before the close on the Board of Trade today and prices pushed up sharply, under the leadership of corn.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- Two 7,000-ton transports carrying unauthorized Jewish immigrants were reported steaming toward the shore of Palestine tonight and sources here doubted that British destroyers would attempt to intercept them at sea.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 15 -- Michigan's deft, poised precisionists swept aside rain, mist, snow and a briefly inspired Wisconsin eleven in Camp Randall Stadium this afternoon to lay firm hands on the Western Conference championship and its accompanying bid to the Rose Bowl.

Modernization on a large scale of existing business and residential buildings in the metropolitan area to avoid obsolescence and prolong their investment value is suggested by Henry J. Davenport, president of the Home Title Guaranty Company.
Fifty-three civic leaders of Brooklyn have formed Youth United in a neighborhood movement to combat juvenile delinquency in Brooklyn's blighted areas.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 15 -- Dr. I. Schwartzbart, member of the World Zionist Council and member of the Polish Parliament in pre-war Poland, said tonight the Jewish people may be far from reaching their goal of a Jewish state, "for the way is still fraught with obstacles."

JUST twenty-one years ago this week in this Review: Page 1 is given over to Field Marshal Robertson's "Soldiers and Statesmen," a defense of his work as Chief of the General Staff in London in World War I and a criticism of civilian interference on the part of the Cabinet.

HAROLD E. STASSEN has won wide respect for the forthrightness with which he has approached the game of politics. Until recently the only avowed Republican Presidential aspirant, the former Governor of Minnesota has spoken out candidly and courageously on a multitude of issues.

If unmated queen bees are subjected to a carbon dioxide gas anesthetic, they lay eggs that later hatch into drone bees. This discovery makes it possible to accelerate the production of hybrid strains in which parentage is absolutely controlled.

Wall Street is locked in debate on the subject of permissive incorporation of members of the New York Stock Exchange in place of the present legal form of firms. The debate on the Exchange has reached a crescendo seldom surpassed.

HARALD KREUTZBERG'S first recital at the Ziegfeld Theatre last week was so successful that two additional ones have been added besides the one he was already scheduled to give tonight. The new dates are next Sunday and Dec. 7, after which he leaves for a Scandinavian tour.

With the 436 country plants sending milk to metropolitan New York under orders yesterday from the Milk Marketing Administration to ship at least 92 per cent of their receipts as fluid milk, farmers' returns received an additional increase.

THE Little Orchestra Society, newly born this season, has given the first two concerts of its initial series of eight, and has proved itself a freshening force in the musical life of this city. That life, in the orchestral and operatic field, had fallen into a rut until the performances by the orchestra and opera company of the City Center of Drama and Music were established.

The inexorable pressure of simple arithmetic has again forced Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Estimate to move toward a higher fare on the municipal transit system. The city lines piled up a deficit of $18,000,000 for the year ending June 30.

MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass. AS the mystery story approaches the inevitable end of its course (and there are those who believe the course already run) it is natural that in a world as anticipatory as ours, there should be occasional obsequies.
TROY, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute defeated Brooklyn College, 27 -- 12, in the season finale for both teams before 5,000 spectators today.

The French Communists are reported to have adopted a political isolationist policy. In other words, they have isolated themselves from everybody but Russia. Henceforth they can hardly profess to have a national program for France. They have proclaimed them-selves the servile tools of Moscow and the Cominform.

A STRIKING feature of this novel by a pseudonymous English writer is the detachment and discreet irony with which it treats an emotionally charged subject. War-ravaged Europe, waiting to be saved from itself, has inspired American writers with dramatic or melodramatic plots -- but hardly yet with a truly moving theme.

A TONE of tempered conservatism is to be noted in many of the exhibitions opening last week. Although most of the startling vicissitudes of contemporary painting are apparent, the tendency is less in the direction of advancing the language of painting and new discovery than toward stabilizing already established conventions available to the painter.

In Marshall Plan Areas In the two key countries of western Europe the Communist parties are strong. CP membership in France is 1,300,000; in Italy, 2,200,000. Though the Communists have been excluded from the French and Italian Cabinets their moves have a deep effect in both countries.

More than a hundred prizes were awarded yesterday to winning birds yorkshires, columbus fancy, exotic American singers and European wildbirds -- at the first New York National Cage Bird show, spon ed by the Eastern and Empire Bird Associations and the American Color Breeders, in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Whether the Peron Government in Argentina is preparing to abate its policy of charging exorbitant prices for the surplus grains so desperately needed by a hungry world seems a little uncertain. On Friday it sold the United States three shiploads of corn at a price about a dollar a bushel above the prevalent rate in this country, and since this includes delivery at the Buenos Aires docks it is thought to be fairly reasonable.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 15 -- Representatives of movements in nine states to gain the Republican Presidential nomination for Gen. Douglas MacArthur at the Philadelphia convention in June met here today in the general's legal residence, Plankinton House, and voted to urge the formation of a National MacArthur for President Committee.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- The Jewish Agency for Palestine today proposed to the United Nations Subcommittee on Palestine that, pending the appointment of the United Nations commission to supervise partition, the British Government refrain from any action to liquidate or dispose of the assets of the Palestine Government.

BUCHAREST. KING MICHAEL, of Rumania had small cause for rejoicing on the observance, Nov. 8, of his name day -- an anniversary which in eastern Europe is considered more important than a birthday. For Michael -- Mihai in his own country -- can best be described as a young man on a hot seat, with the temperature steadily rising.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 14 (Delayed) -- The three principal Turkish ports -- Iskenderun [Alexandrettal], on the southern coast, Izmir [Smyrna], on the Aegean, and Istanbul, on the Bosporous -- will be jammed as never before during the next six weeks with the arrival of the first substantial shipments of military supplies under the $100,000,000 Truman aid program.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

BALLET THEATRE opens its four - week season at the City Center on Wednesday, with nothing in the way of a novelty on the schedule until Saturday evening when "Princess Aurora" is revived. This is only a semi-novelty, at best, but there have been additions and substitutions among its divertissements, and some of its casting is of interest.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 15 -- Penn State's bowl-bound football team, bagging touchdowns in each of the first three periods, bowled over Navy in the mud and rain at Municipal Stadium today to keep its place among the nation's undefeated and untied outfits. The score was 20 to 7.

KNOXVILLE, Term., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Tennessee bounded back from five defeats to outclass a powerminded Boston College team, 38 to 13, today before a crowd of 25,000. It was the Volunteers' first major triumph of the most disastrous season for Bob Neyland in sixteen years of coaching at Tennessee.

THESE two books should go far toward satisfying some of the curiosity of air-minded youngsters. In a way they are companion pieces. Mr. Ray's detailed history of commercial air transport in the United States sticks closely to what's been done in sound and applied aviation.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 15 -- The executive board of the United Steel Workers of America, Congress of Industrial Organizations, will open here Monday its first major conference in six months.

DENVER, Nov. 15 -- Harold E. Stassen, candidate for the Republican Presidential nomination, today denounced candidates who seek that nomination by evasion and "Me too" answers at the eleventh hour. His declaration, delivered here in both a press conference and a speech to the Colorado State Central Committee, was aimed at Governor Dewey of New York.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- Southern Methodist needed all the brilliance of its great backfield today to defeat a supercharged University of Arkansas eleven, 14 to 6, and stay in the ranks of the nation's perfect record teams.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Nov. 15 -- Dr. George Grant MacCurdy, anthropologist formerly associated with Yale University, died in Muhlenberg Hospital here this afternoon of injuries suffered this morning when he was struck by an automobile in near-by Green Brook Township.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 15 -- The dogged, mud-splashed Northwestern Wildcats, humiliated by five defeats in seven earlier starts, almost made a myth of Notre Dame's football invincibility today, but the desperate fighting Irish shook off the surprise for a 26-to-19 victory, their seventh in a row.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 (U.P.) -- The first editions of some Chicago Sunday morning newspapers were delayed today by what they described as "slowdowns" in their composing rooms.

(Mr. Mayer is managing director of the Rialto Theatre, which will adopt a foreign film policy, starting Nov. 27, with the premiers of the French "Panic," directed by Julien Duvivier and starring Viviane Romance.)

While the extent of tariff reductions under the Geneva Conference agreement remain a closely guarded secret, "guesses" among foreign traders here are that they will be deep, and in some cases will perhaps tend to approach the 50 per cent maximum cuts permitted under the Reciprocal Trade Agreement Act.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 15 -- Miguel Miranda, Argentine economic chief, in confirming the purchase of 25,500 metric tons of corn for Germany, said he apparently had been misunderstood on the conditions under which Argentina would agree to put all grain on the market at the world price.

COLUMBUS, Ga., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Outplaying their opponents in almost every department, the University of Georgia Bulldogs defeated the Auburn Tigers, 28 to 6, in their fifty-first football contest today. Some 22,000 fans saw the game, played on a soggy gridiron in misty, cold weather.

BANGKOK, Siam, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Siamese military command cracked down today on a group of individuals that, it said, was Blot ting to prevent the immediate return of 19-year-old King Phumibol Aduldet from Geneva and to oust the monarchy in favor of a republican form of Government.
SAN FRANCISCO. IN this time of world food shortages the United States is planning to develop an important new source of food from the teeming pastures of the ocean.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The return of Congress to the Capitol next Monday, to remain in session until summer, except for a brief holiday recess, will inaugurate one of the greatest tests to which the workability of our political system has been subjected in the nation's history.

"THAT'S romance without finance!" says Bertha ("Chippie") Hill between verses of "Careless Love" as she sashays across the tiny stage at the Village Vanguard night club. One of the few Negro blues shouters still around to give the younger generation a taste of singing as it was in Chicago of the Twenties, she is also a living example of one of the strongest influences on the new jazz.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- A summer of construction work at Arizona hotels and resort centers has augmented winter tourist accommodations somewhat, but shortages of material and labor and transportation difficulties have upset plans to enlarge available facilities to the extent required by last winter's great crowds.

The festival of the music of Ernest Bloch continued yesterday afternoon with the second of three concerts at the Juilliard Concert Hall under the joint sponsorship of the Juilliard School of Music and the League of Composers. The music, in three utterly different veins, was drawn from the latest three decades of his life, and was all of the chamber variety.

Theatre parties at performances of Broadway productions continue as a popular means of furthering the work of various philanthropic projects. The United Hospital Fund's 69th Annual Campaign will be the beneficiary of the performance of Shakespeare's "Antony and Cleopatra," with Katharine Cornell and Godfrey Tearle, on the night of Dec. 17 at the Martin Beck Theatre.

SALT LAKE CITY. UTAH'S centennial year -- 1947 -- has been marked by a number of impressive events commemorating the first settlement of the Mormon founders near Great Salt Lake. There have been musical pageants, circuses, aquacades and art exhibitions. An imposing bronze monument has been erected on the spot where Brigham Young said, "This is the place."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The National Grange called to day for "maximum control by farmers" of all agricultural programs at state and county levels.

HOLLYWOOD. THE Motion Picture Alliance for the Preservation of American Ideals, to which most of the "friendly" witnesses of the recent Congressional inquiry into Hollywood communism belong, has issued a twelve-page pamphlet titled "Screen Guide For Americans," presenting "A List of the More Common Devices Used to Turn Non-political Pictures Into Carriers of Political Propaganda."

The united Nations General Assembly voted at Flushing Meadow yesterday to hold its session next year in Europe, but an unexpected parliamentary development will require that this decision be confirmed by a different and more decisive balloting procedure.

There is a gray wind to November, which whips the low scud across the, sky and sends the last of the maples' color swirling through the woodland. Give it a bright day, and there is a silvery sheen to it; you can almost see it. Give it a dull day and it moans and whispers through the oaks, still brown with clinging leaves.

Remarkable accuracy from the foul line gave the New York Knickerbockers their second straight victory in the Basketball Association of America over the St. Louis Bombers, 73 -- 67, last night at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

TRIESTE (By Wireless.) There is hereby constituted the Free Territory of Trieste, consisting of the area lying between the Adriatic Sea and the boundaries defined in Articles 4 and 22 of the present treaty. The Free Territory of Trieste is recognized by the Allied and Associated Powers and by Italy, which agree that its integrity and independence shall be assured by the Security Council of the United Nations. -- From the peace treaty with Italy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A direct accusation that Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers tried to "stand up" Howard Hughes in wartime by attempts to exact money tribute was made today as the long Senate investigation of the Hughes war contracts came to a provisional end.

The first complete series of the publications of Ambroise Vollard to appear in this country will be auctioned at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 30 East Fifty-seventh Street, tomorrow and Tuesday evenings. The Vollard books and other modern French illustrated works, together with rare fifteenth to nineteenth century books, are from the collection of Daniel Sickles.

AMONG unorthodox but thoroughly respectable religious groups there sometimes arise certain others whose good repute is open to possible question. One of these, according to Mr. Freund's fiction, is Tao Ananda, which makes no claims to being a bona fide religion but devotes its efforts to "reverent inquiry" into the accumulated religious teachings of the Eastern and Western world.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 -- Three of six men arrested yesterday in a campaign against Eastern gangsters were summarily "deported" from Los Angeles County today, and a fourth was told he had until Tuesday to get out.

The General Assembly of the United Nations agreed yesterday to ask all member governments to combat the spread of false information and distorted news that would be likely to disturb friendly relations between nations.

MORE than 100 stations in key cities now comprise the "Network for Peace" developed by the United Nations, an agency of which provides them with a radio program service in an endeavor to answer the cross-country appeal from listeners for an opportunity "to hear what's happening" in the international body.

To the Music Editor: THE recent article, "The Negro in Music," suggests an even greater problem than that which affects the Negro alone. It is certainly an obvious fact that with the social abuses so widely prevalent today that the Negro will be the greatest sufferer.

BUCHAREST. PRESSURE is mounting here against the exhibition of American motion pictures, which are intensely popular and draw the biggest audiences. The other day a Government order designed to favor the distribution of Russian Films was announced.

IT SHOULD be an object lesson to injudicious publishing house editors that H. Allen Smith, a man not given to violent physical activity, felt called upon to murder -- if that is the proper word -- one of their number for trying surreptitiously to change the title of his latest book to "My Mummy Was an Egyptian."

WAYS to lengthen the all-too-fleeting life of cut flowers have long been sought. They have always been symbols of beauty, love and sentiment, and we try to keep them fresh as long as possible. Several years of research at Ohio State University have shown that there are practical means of delaying maturity of many popular flowers used for home decoration.

RADIO commercials which do not please the listener's fancy may now be eliminated with the flick of a finger through use of a gadget called "Commercial Control" now available locally at several department stores.

THE small greenhouse has become one of the most popular spots of a home in West Englewood, N.J. When Mr. and Mrs. Robert Naumberg were deciding about this addition, they discovered that there was more to this important step than choosing any one of the several good-looking styles now available.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange fluctuated within a narrow range yesterday and closing prices were 9 points higher to 7 points lower than the day before. Starting irregular, the market worked up to modest gains, but met week-end profit-taking and liquidation.

PERHAPS the toughest assignment in the Army was leading an infantry company in combat. The author of this fascinating and sincere book had such a job -- with one tremendous additional handicap. Without combat experience he was called upon to command Company 1, Twenty-third Regiment of the famed Second Infantry Division.

Regardless of the future performance of the Navy's Douglas-built Skyrocket, the combination rocket and jet propelled plane, completed in California last Thursday, aeronautical experts said yesterday that they believed supersonic speed in piloted aircraft would be achieved in one to three years.

MOST of the gremlins that put cameras out of commission and send them to the repair shop can be avoided by proper care, according to A.C. Muller of 421 Seventh Avenue, camera repair expert. The result of normal wear and tear, or lack of use, is something else, says Mr. Muller, who handles camera troubles ranging from those of the novice's box camera to the expensive instruments of top-bracket photographers.
DENVER, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Arnold Ronnebeck, widely known sculptor, died last night at his home here of throat cancer. His age was 62.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Catholic Bishops of the United States declared today that "the practical exclusion of God from human thinking and living" was largely to blame for the world's present personal, social, economic and political ills.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Nov. 15 -- Led by Grant Ford, Amherst defeated Williams, 14 to 6 here today before a capacity crowd of 11,000 at Weston Field.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Virginia's plunging Cavaliers, taking advantage of a series of right side plays which befuddled a Mountaineer line, defeated West Virginia University, 6 to 0, today in the last four minutes of the game.

A 77-yard march in the first period provided the only touchdown for Lafayette against Fordham at the Polo Grounds yesterday. For the greater part of the time indications were that it would not stand up, that the under-dog Rams were on the way to contriving an upset, but Lafayette stubbornly held its slim margin to win, 7 to 0.

BERLIN, Nov. 15 -- The new Constitutions of the three states in the United States zone of Germany are all potential instruments for the creation of a dictatorship once the occupation ends, in the opinion of some United States Military Government officials who have studied them.

EVERY new type of aircraft, whether it be tiny private putt-putt or giant military bomber, goes through a relatively short but more or less trying period when it is first put into operation. The manufacturers and users of planes speak of this period as the time in which they "work the bugs out."
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Horace Smith, 176-pound sophomore halfback, led Michigan State to a 14-6 victory over Temple today, scoring twice on plays of 54 and 72 yards.

As builders in the metropolitan area push their efforts to help relieve the housing shortage, announcements are made of four large apartment developments which will provide living quarters for 1,218 families. Three of these already are under construction, with sections nearing completion in two of them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Two clergymen, reporting on their observations of United States occupation forces in Germany and Austria, called today for a strengthening of the morale and operations of Military Government forces in those areas.
The possibility that the Department of Justice might be asked to investigate a "seeming monopoly" of the building industry in this city was disclosed last night by Representative Ralph W. Gwinn.
UNTIL the end of last August British tourists were allowed to take $300 with them for a stay in the United States up to six months. From the end of August until Oct. 1 this was reduced to $140.

CORVALLIS, Ore., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Quarterback Tiz Miller's accurate passing with a wet ball today carried the Washington State Cougars to an upset 14-13 victory over the Oregon State Beavers before 12,400 Oregon State homecoming fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The President's Advisory Committee on the Merchant Marine recommended today a four-year program for the construction of forty-six passenger-carrying vessels at a cost of about $600,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission strengthened today existing controls over the export of equipment that could be used in atomic energy research and production work. Effective Thursday a new regulation stipulates that a specific license must be issued by the agency and required of persons intending to manufacture or produce such facilities for export.

THE nature of human values is a subject in which the reflections of the technical philosopher have a special interest for the intelligent layman. That is why this volume -- originally delivered as the Carus Lectures by Clarence I. Lewis, Edgar Pierce Professor of Philosophy in Harvard University -- is not only a first-rate contribution to philosophical analysis but a cultural event of great importance.

There is no occasion to say very much of the performance of Puccini's "Tosca" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, which was saddening. There was no first class protagonist on the stage, so far as the principals were concerned, and hopes that had been aroused of Mr. Antonicelli, the conductor, the previous Monday were on this occasion disappointed.
Moses Brown of Providence, R.I., handed the Horace Mann j football team its only setback in six games by defeating the Maroon and Black, 12 -- 6, yesterday at Horace Mann.

The Federal Reserve authorities, while certain of the validity of their policies to restrict the inflationary trend of prices, now appear to be convinced that these policies cannot be made practically effective unless supplemented by Congressional action along the broad social and commercial fronts.

New York City's school system with its more than 35,000 teachers and 900,000 students will go all-out in aiding the city-wide food drive which will be held in connection with the arrival of the Friendship Food Train on Tuesday, the Board of Education announced.

DRY TORTUGAS -- This little island off the Florida coast, or, more properly, sixty-eight miles west of Key West, is one of the most interesting places for winter tourists. There is only one drawback -- the island is almost, though not quite, inaccessible.

VIENNA. WHEN Dr. Adelheid Wawerka, supervisor of the Vienna children's clinics and homes, wrote for THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine last June an article entitled "Scourge of Millions -- Hunger," describing the prevalence and effects of hunger in Europe, she did not dream that the response to it would be so continuing and so substantial.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Resentment against Communist activities in the labor movement is steadily increasing among the rank and file of American trade unionists.

FIGURE paintings and portraits play an unusually impressive part among newly opened exhibitions. The gallery visitor, artist and student who like to compare how diversely artists approach their problems have a wealth of material to examine and reflect upon.

To THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES. All thoughtful Americans are concerned with the present cost of building construction. Representing as he does the building public, it is of concern to the professional architect.

Recent approving action by the Secretary of War has curtailed the operation of drawbridges over navigable waters within the State of New Jersey. This came as a result of public hearings some months ago.
GOVERNMENT hospitals in the United States have 73.7 per cent of the 1,468,714 hospital beds in the country.

Largely because of the interest in the emotional problems of returning veterans, the public during the last few years has been exposed to a great deal of information about psychiatry through the press, popular magazines, fiction, radio and the movies.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Representative Harold Knutson of Minnesota, chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, raised the question today whether "foundations, religious, educational and other tax-exempt organizations" objected to being taxed. He said:

An air of optimism featured the fifty-fifth annual meeting of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, held here last week in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, despite the present poor condition of the country's shipbuilding industry.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- A recent issue of the Moscow weekly New Times contemptuously called attention to the fact that Ernest Bevin has been "the most enthusiastic supporter of the Marshall plan in Europe." It also takes it for granted that "Bevin and his colleagues are not so naive as to fail to see that the so-called Marshall plan is designed not to save but to strangle Europe."

A CONSIDERATION of the classics which have offered the best material for illustrated children's books (such as Mr. Philip Hofer provides in his excellent contribution to this symposium) is one of the best approaches to the question of what appeals most immediately to the child's mind.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Newspaper comment upon the resignation of Hugh Dalton as Chancellor of the Exchequer because of his advance disclosure to a newspaper of budget information was sympathetic but uncompromising today.

A MEXICAN who visited New York last spring marveled at the excellence of the subsidiary roads that thread the surrounding countryside. "Now in Mexico," he observed, "we have the great highways and they are fine; the rest are trails."

FRANCIS DAHL draws a daily, highly popular, usually six-paneled cartoon for The Boston Herald on some matter in the news which seems to him worthy of exploration. Periodically -- at least, it has happened twice so far -- Charles Morton of The Atlantic Monthly looks over a sizable batch of these reports and speculations and writes a commentary which knits them all together into a book.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 15 -- The newly elected twenty-two-man executive board of the United Auto Workers, CIO, signed non-Communist affidavits today for filing with the National Labor Relations Board under provisions of the Taft-Hartley law.
Secretary Marshall's recommendation before a Congressional committee last week for aid to China focused attention on the whole problem of American policy in China.

EVERY day there come across my desk letters which begin like this: "The X Fraternal and Benevolent Society is holding a dance to raise money for worthy charities. Would you be good enough to contribute an orchestra free for this event? Thank you."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- Ch. Try-Cob's Success, solid black American cocker spaniel belonging to the Pentown Kennels of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Jacobsen of New York, made the fifty-third dog show of the Kennel Club of Philadelphia a complete triumph tonight by winning best in show and also the fifth and final competition for the Mellinthin Memorial Award.

THE Paganini Quartet is a relatively new ensemble. It was heard for the first time last year, and now Victor has bestowed upon it the accolade of inviting it to record all three of Beethoven's Rasumovsky Quartets, Op. 59, Nos. 1, 2, and 3.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 -- The development of a ram-jet helicopter, the first of its kind, was disclosed today by the McDonnell Aircraft Corporation.

DURING October wage negotiations were conducted between the owners of dairies serving the New York metropolitan area and their employes. These resulted in the granting to the employes of an increase of $8.50 per week. This amounted to a weighted average cost increase per quart of milk of six-tenths of a cent.

All the tables have been taken for the luncheon and fashion show in behalf of the Judson Health Center to be held on Tuesday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza. The occasion will mark the twenty-sixth anniversary of the founding of the beneficiary by Dr. Eleanor A. Campbell, who is general director of the center, located at 237 Thompson Street.

The city a radical experiment to lessen the flow of traffic to congested midtown Manhattan will get under way tomorrow when the old World's Fair parking lot site will be opened, it was announced yesterday by Police Commissioner Arthur W. Wallander.

PRESS and documentary photography will be features of the Twelfth Rochester International Salon of Photography, to be held March 5 through April 4. A new section covering nature photography is also announced, as well as divisions for color and pictorial photography.

PRESS and documentary photography will be features of the Twelfth Rochester International Salon of Photography, to be held March 5 through April 4. A new section covering nature photography is also announced, as well as divisions for color and pictorial photography.

THIS is the test and most comprehensive book which has yet appeared in this complex field. The difficulty of making a comprehensive survey is shown by the fact that the volume includes forty articles, written by forty-three authors and presented in eight parts.

INSECT CONTROL -- Insects destroy annually 300,000,000 bushels of stored grain, worth $600,000,000. Only 5 per cent of the grain stored on farms is adequately protected against the ravages of insect pests, and 97 per cent of the nation's corn crop, 94 per cent of the oats and 60 per cent of the wheat are stored on farms at some time during the year.

LIBERTY, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Otto Hillig, who in June, 1931, gained world-wide fame when with the late Major Holger Hoiriis, of Wilmington, Del., he crossed the Atlantic Ocean to his own airplane, retired today from the photography business which he established here fifty years ago.

A CONSIDERATION of the classics which have offered the best material for illustrated children's books (such as Mr. Philip Hofer provides in his excellent contribution to this symposium) is one of the best approaches to the question of what appeals most immediately to the child's mind.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Newspaper comment upon the resignation of Hugh Dalton as Chancellor of the Exchequer because of his advance disclosure to a newspaper of budget information was sympathetic but uncompromising today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 15 -- Any decision on the relationship between the Security Council and the Trusteeship Council in the consideration of strategic trusteeship agreements was deferred today by the Security Council.

BOSTON, Nov. 15 -- After being limited to two first-period touch-downs by a stubborn Kings Point eleven, Boston University's Terriers broke loose for three touchdowns in the third period and coasted to an easy 33-6 victory over the cadets this afternoon, at Fenway Park.

ROME, Nov. 15 -- The present wave of political violence that is sweeping over Italy has made most Italians more keenly aware that their political future depends to a considerable degree on the Marshall plan. Communists and their allies regard it as a devilishly cunning scheme to "fasten the American yoke" permanently on Europe's neck.

MONTREAL -- A $3,000,000 development and construction program covering ski trails, tows, jumps and highways, and enlargement and improvement of hotel facilities is being rushed to completion throughout the Laurentian Mountains in preparation for the coming winter sports season.

SOME of America's most interesting historical landmarks lie in the Hudson Highlands, but fifty miles from the heart of Times Square, in the Bear Mountain State Park, the Harriman State Park or the United States Military Reservation at West Point.

IOWA CITY, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Iowa goaded into a stunning performance by the resignation of its coach, tumbled Minnesota 13 to 7 today for a stirring tribute to Dr. Eddie Anderson in what may have been his final appearance at the Hawkeye helm.

Sparked by the power running of Gene Uehlinger, Brooklyn Tech, the only school in Brooklyn with a perfect record, removed Manual Training from the unbeaten class in the first game of the football double-header at Ebbets Field yesterday before 5,000 fans, 38 -- 19.

HEROISM and sacrifice at sea in line of duty mark the exploits of John Paul Jones -- our first professional naval officer, commissioned as captain in the United States Navy in August, 1776. Viewing his story more or less as a tragi-comedy, Gerald W. Johnson -- Journalist, historian, author of "Andrew Jackson" and "Woodrow Wilson" -- finds in the career of this romantic figure aspects significant for today and tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Mme. Lulu Vetta Karst, who taught Helen Traubel, Metropolitan Opera soprano, to sing, died here today in her hotel apartment. Her age was 87. She had sung in most of the European capitals and, despite her advanced age, had remained active as a voice instructor.

ROME, Nov. 15 --The wave of Communist-instigated riots spread today at Apulia in the heel of Italy. In Cerignola, twenty-four miles southeast of Foggia, the police fired on a crowd that had used automatic weapons and hand grenades against Government offices and barracks of the Carabinieri.

FOR the vacationist who thinks it takes a sea voyage to make a holiday, the recent announcement of six-day cruises to Bermuda aboard the Holland-America's Veendam is good news. The Veendam, which will make three cruises to Bermuda -- on Feb. 3, March 16 and April 27 -- will serve as a hotel for passengers while the ship is in port.

When the GI Bill of Rights was adopted, giving ex-service men financial support to continue with their education, some cynical educators were afraid that college standards would de-teriorate. They warned that the veterans would swamp the campuses for the government "handout," consisting of $500 in free tuition costs and maintenance grants ranging from $65 to $90 monthly.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 15 -- Edward G. Wilms of Paterson, chairman of the independent unions of the State of New Jersey, said today that only the combined efforts of all working men and women whether they are white collar or shop, American Federation of Labor, Congress of Industrial Organizations or independent, will halt the inroads by the forces of reaction.
BAR HARBOR, Nov. 15 -- Housing difficulties caused by the recent fire are rapidly being solved by local residents with the aid of Red Cross funds.

BRNO, Moravia, Nov. 15 -- Zidenek Fierlinger, president of the Social Democratic party, whose alliance with the Communists guarantees Communist parliamentary control, is fighting bitterly for his political leadership here tonight.
Representatives of five maritime unions will attend a conference tomorrow at the headquarters of the National Maritime Union, CIO, 346 West Seventeenth Street.

Next Step in ERP Tomorrow at 1:30 P.M. President Truman will appear before a joint session of the Eightieth Congress to deliver a message that may have a vital bearing on America's world role. It will be his fifth formal appearance in Congress in his thirty months in office.

ROBERT KEE is a 27-year-old Englishman who spent most of the war in German prison camps. (He was an RAF pilot who was shot down and captured.) He has written a book about his internment and called it a novel.

Mayor O'Dwyer and former Governor Herbert H. Lehman called upon Congress to pass the Taft-Ellender-Wagner bill at its next regular session as vital to a solution of the city's housing problem. They spoke at ground-breaking ceremonies for the first of three twelve-story cooperative apartment buildings to be erected in the Sidney Hillman housing development for 800 families at Grand and Delancey Streets between Willett and Lewis Streets.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Whether human ingenuity can contrive a formula for surmounting the financial, economic and administrative obstacles to the European Recovery Program is the big question left unanswered by the recent series of reports that gave meaning to the so-called Marshall plan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Chamber of Commerce of the United States said today that the future of the railroad financial situation and the quantity and quality of service which would be provided depended largely on the decision reached by the Interstate Commerce Commission on the pending application for rate increases.
A CHEF in Milwaukee baked a cake weighing half a ton. It served 4,000 people attending a rally to raise money for infantile paralysis sufferers.

ELSWYTH THANE, author-wife of naturalist William Beebe, is literally giving her reading public the bird, the bird in this case being one Che-Wee, as cocky and presuming a car-podacus purpureus purpureus as ever summered in Vermont and wintered in New York City.

An unusual program of divertissements has been planned to feature the Winter Ball which will take place Nov. 29 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria as a benefit for the Outdoor Cleanliness Association.

MORE than twice the size of last year's exhibition, the thirty-second annual of the Society of American Etchers, Gravers, Lithographers and Woodcutters, Inc., has opened in the galleries of the National Academy. Some 650 examples by half as many artists are included, furnishing the most avid lover of the print with a surfeit of work in the various media.

ON Broadway an actor's most varied and demanding roles are often played off-stage in response to the inspiration of food, clothing and shelter. This is an axiom springing from the unglamorous fact that, in point of security and availability of work, the actor's calling is the most chaotic of occupations.

IF the estimated 50,000 or more American families who are going to adopt children during the next twelve months would read this book, many homes could look forward to rewarding love where otherwise there will be heart-break and disillusionment.

EARNING a living in music is hardly an easy matter for anyone. Or the whole, though, it is less difficult for performers than composers. It is always cheering, therefore, when a performer commissions a new work.

THIS story of the Japanese prison camps has been told before: the planned starvation and brutality, the callous disregard by Japanese officers and men alike of all international conventions regarding treatment of prisoners of war, the few examples of common decency and humanity that only proved the rule.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- President Truman will go to the Capitol in person on Monday to ask Congress in a message delivered at a joint session of the Senate and House to authorize interim aid for European countries during the winter season along lines already outlined by his Cabinet officers and to lay the groundwork for action on the Marshall plan proper.

BRUSSELS, Nov. 15 -- Belgium will not devalue her franc because she hopes to cash in on the Marshall plan for aid to Europe. Assistance from the United States in dollar credits might enable Belgium to recoup something of the 12,000,000,000 francs owed to her by Britain, the Netherlands, France, Denmark and Norway.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- Acharya Kripalani, president of the Indian Congress party, the powerful majority group, in presenting his resignation to the Congress party's central committee here today said that the president was "not taken into full confidence on important matters affecting the nation."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- A House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on displaced persons submitted today a program designed to wind up the problem before the United States found itself left alone and solely responsible for a solution of the question.
THE Theatre Guild, venerable doyen of the Broadway stage, ventured out into the strange, new world of television last Sunday night, and promptly fell on its art.

BATON ROUGE, La., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Louisiana State threw the Southeastern Conference football championship race into a wild scramble today by whipping Mississippi State, 21 to 6, while Georgia Tech was being bounced out of the unbeaten ranks.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Tulane and Florida pulled a crowd of 25,000 to its feet in the final quarter today in a 7-7 finish to one of the better games seen here this year.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Illinois powered and finessed its way to a 28-to-7 victory over Ohio State's hapless Buckeyes today before 70,036 fans, wheeling to two startlingly fast touchdowns in the final session to grab easily a verdict which had been doubtful through the first three quarters.

The latest edition of ice shows, the Ice Follies of 1948, will open at Madison Square Garden on Tuesday night and, in addition to two Sunday matinees, performances will be given each evening through Nov. 30.
SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 15 -- Utah, the Beehive State, may soon be flashing an SOS call for bee-keepers. Ever since the days of the first Mormon settlement, the beehive has been a Utah symbol.

SINCE our daughter, June, made her appearance recently at Henry Miller's Theatre in F. Hugh Herbert's play, "For Love or Money," her mother, Kathleen, and I have been asked what share we had in preparing June for her theatrical debut.

Two of the largest financial organizations in the world, the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development and the International Monetary Fund, officially became specialized agencies of the United Nations yesterday by a unanimous vote of the General Assembly.

NEW ORLEANS. THE seventy-three delegates to the Fourth Annual Newspaper Food Editors Conference, which met here recently, learned a little about Creole cookery in five days of breakfast, lunch and dinner sessions. e white of an egg, a half-tea-spoon of orange-flower water, two heaping tablespoons of crushed ice and two table-spoons rich cream. (Altman's sells Twin Trees Garden orange-flower water -- 50 cents for a three-ounce bottle.)

A winter ball, featuring dances of the turn of the century -- the polka, the waltz and the cotillion -- will be given on Dec. 2 in the Ritz-Carlton by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra to augment its pension fund. The winter ball, the first to be given by the society, is being sponsored by the organization's Auxilary Board, of which Mrs. Lytle Hull is chairman.

Some forty common diseases, including many that are infectious, cause blood to sludge through clumping of red cells, according to a report in Science by Drs. Melvin H. Knisely and Edward H. Bloch and Miss Louise Warner, all of the University of Chicago, in cooperation with Prof. Theodore E. Eliot of the University of Tennessee.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public which will mature within twelve months amount to $57,096,691,696. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows :

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The independent party of the International Typographical Union (AFL) attacked the union's "no-contract" policy and started an effort to unseat Woodruff Randolph as international president in a policy meeting today.

Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet deputy Foreign Minister and chief Russian delegate to the United Nations, asserted last night that insiters of a new war had made such progress that public opinion in this country was now receptive to fighting the Soviet Union.

In a week the early part of which showed no particular trend in the foreign exchanges, there developed suddenly and unexpectedly on Friday a heavy demand for spot sterling which lifted that, currency for a good size gain but brought in its wake a depressed market in "forwards" and a consequently soft undertone in discounts.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Pood Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The stock markets here were thrown last week into a state of some confusion by the Government's supplementary budget and by the dramatic resignation of Hugh Dalton as Chancellor of the Exchequer Within twenty-four hours of the introduction of the budget.

Wearing a rented turban and speaking with a "slight Swedish accent," a Negro clergyman of, Jamaica, Queens, recently spent a week in Mobile, Ala., and was treated by white civic, social and political leaders like a "visiting dignitary," he reported yesterday.

With colleges overcrowded and required to select candidates for higher education, moral character, not academic ability, should be the first prerequisite for entrance, the Rev. William Brewster, headmaster of St. Mark's School, Southboro, Mass., declared yesterday.

The outstanding event of the week in art circles is the exhibition of priceless French tapestries at the Metropolitan Museum, opening to the public on Saturday. Some 200 examples, installed in twenty-four upstairs galleries, include work of the famous Gobelin and Beauvaia looms, nearly a hundred of them representing work done during the period from the fourteenth to the sixteenth century.

ACAPULCO, Mexico, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Two new speedboat records, subject to approval of the American Power Boat Association, were set today during the final events of the international races held here under auspices of the Mexican National Sweepstakes Regatta Association.

In the Red lexicon now standard throughout Russia's belt of European satellites the word "traitor" means patriot. The latest to receive this accolade is Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, the Polish peasant leader, now safely beyond the clutches of the Communist secret police.

THE young woman with the feather in her hat and the determined expression seemed rather breathless, although ,she had been sitting perfectly still on the one spare office chair for some time. "So," she said, "it's quite clear that I shall never be able to write a great novel. I just haven't any great thoughts, nor even any great ambitions.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- The Marseille transport workers, 4,300 strong, went on strike today as part of the Communist strategy to bring about a general strike in the city that has been in the grip of disorders and tension for four days. Street car and bus traffic is at a standstill.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- Justifying the Communist-led demonstrations that have resulted in riots in France and Italy as a defense against "reaction," the Soviet trade union organ Trud stated today that Russia was seeking to make the World Federation of Trade Unions a "militant" organization.

Quietly -- ever so quietly -- Ruth Gordon has been fashioning a play other than the long-awaited Kitchen Canaries," which is destined to be unveiled by the patient Max Gordon under the direction of the author's husband, Garson Kanin.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- A resumption of active buying by the Commodity Credit Corporation with renewed buying of flour by the Production and Marketing Administration after the latter agency had been out of the market several weeks, caused free buying of wheat futures last week on the Board of Trade and a substantial rally in all deliveries of that grain from the low spots early in the week.

BRUENN, Czechoslovakia, Nov 16 -- Zdenek Fierlinger, Moscow-oriented leader of the Social Democratic party and recognized guarantor of Communist parliamentary control, was repudiated today by the annual congress of his party here.

A tablet in memory of Dr. John Lovejoy Elliott was unveiled yesterday at Elliott Houses by two of the earliest members of the Hudson Guild, founded by Dr. Elliott in 1895. Mrs. George Burnett of 362 West Twenty-seventh Street, who joined the guild in 1901 -- and met her husband there -- was assisted in the unveiling by William J. Gowrie of 50-36 Forty-first Street, Long Island City, a charter member of the club.
Surveys conducted in New York Harbor by Federal and municipal agencies show that commercial justification for junkboats in port waters is virtually nonexistent, it was reported yesterday.

LONDON. Nov. 16 -- This is the week and Thursday is the day when Princess Elizabeth will be married to the man of her choice Lieut. Philip Mountbatten. For Britons, little else that will happen in an exciting world will matter much.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mayor O'Dwyer's decision to study plans for increasing subway fares is a step which may go a long way to rehabilitate the financial structure of our transit system.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- A $13,664,000 welfare program for displaced persons and refugees entering the United States in 1948, the greatest ever conducted in this field, was outlined today by Irvin Bettmann Sr. of St. Louis, chairman of the financial planning committee of United Service for New Americans, Inc., following a meeting of the committee.

Sugar Jim Henry was everything that's dandy for the Rangers last night. The agile goalie, conscripted from the Blue Shirts' farm team at New Haven to replace the injured Chuck Rayner, turned in a superb performance as his skating colleagues went on to carve out a 4-to-2 triumph over the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your aditorial "The NewspaperRadio Issue," you question the "soundness of the ground" on which the Federal Communications Commission has denied the application of The Daily News to operate a frequency-modulation radio station.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 16 -- A building boom is taking place in this strange modern capital of Turkey which Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, first President of the Republic, founded in the midst of the primitive semi-arid Anatolian plateau twenty-five years ago with the intention of breaking forever with the Ottoman traditions of Constantinople.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- President Truman worked for three and a half hours today putting the finishing touches to the special message he will deliver to Congress tomorrow when it reconvenes at his call.

Young America had its share in the program presented by the Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, under Charles Muench, yesterday afternoon at Carnegie Hall. Jacques Abram, Texas-born pianist, was the soloist in Beethoven's Fourth Concerto, and Earl George, 23-year-old composer from Wisconsin, was represented by his "Introduction and Allegro" on a list also including Handel's Concerto Grosso in A minor, Op. 6, No. 4, Faure's "Pelleas et Melisande" and Ravel's "La Valse."

With three plenary sessions and a long schedule of committee meetings today, the United Nations General Assembly enters the homestretch as it presses to complete its business by Nov. 27, Thanksgiving Day.

A solemn high mass of thanks-giving, at which Cardinal Spellman presided, opened a week-long celebration yesterday of the golden jubilee of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Catherine of Siena, 411 East Sixty-eighth Street.

Support of the current campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York for $15,000,000 to maintain its services through its seven hospitals and other medical and welfare institutions was urged last night by Dr. George Barehr, president of the New York Academy of Medicine, and George Bernheim, president of Mount Sinai Hospital.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Eagles, displaying superiority on both the ground and in the air, took advantage of fumbles, blocked kicks and a dozen penalties to crush the Boston Yanks, 32 to 0, today in a National Football League game before 27,323.

WASHINGTON. Nov. 16 -- President Truman said today that the financial problems of private religious, educational and welfare agencies would be quickly solved if the millions of American working people would set aside regularly a part of their pay for that purpose.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Trade in lard on the Board of Trade here was quite active last week. Some late selling of deferred deliveries indicated disappointment that Government purchases announced on Friday were 2,460,000 pounds, whereas upward of 20,000,000 pounds was offered.
AMSTERDAM, Nov. 16 -- Interest is centering on the Government's price policy that is coming Into the active stage.

A close battle for varsity team honors among Michigan State, Penn State, Syracuse, North Carolina, Manhattan and New York University's defending squad is foreseen in the thirty-ninth annual cross-country championship of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. at Van Cortlandt Park today.

The Town Hall concert of the New Friends of Music yesterday was not broadcast, as scheduled, by frequency modulation station WABF, which is carrying the group's Sunday concerts this season on an exclusive basis.

The Community Service Society has made a courageous decision in adopting a record budget for the coming year. In face of mounting costs of operation and relief, the society has chosen to strengthen its welfare and health services rather than curtail its program. Its new budget of $3,483,000, an increase of $100,000 over last year's record, is all the mope courageous in that the agency has just closed its books with a deficit of $529,000.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- Walt Disney has announced a regrouping of various cartoons at his studio under two titles, "Melody Time" and "Two Fabulous Characters." He has scheduled the first for release in August 1948, and the second for release late in 1949.

In establishing its National Scholarship Plan, Columbia College has taken a significant step in extending the advantages of higher education to worthy students who might otherwise be unable to continue with their schooling. Starting with the 1948-49 academic year, the college is to offer scholarships amounting to $1,000 a year to qualified students from all regions of the country who show exceptional promise and ability.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- In a poll conducted by The United Press of twenty-five Republican Governors six made Gov. Thomas E. Dewey, of New York, their choice as against Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio for the 1948 Presidential nomination.

Two salvage and scrap offerings of obsolete machine tools and industrial equipment, originally worth $1,484,000, are among the offerings of the War Assets Administration, it was announced over the week-end by Alwyn A. Throckmorton, regional director.

Brooklyn's powerful running attack, spearheaded by Bob Hoernschemeyer and Mickey Colmer, prevailed over the passing wizardry of Baltimore's Bud Schwenk yesterday, with the result that the Dodgers gained a 21-to-14 triumph over the Colts before 9,604 spectators at Ebbets Field.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 16 -- Pakistan's action last week in altering the duty arrangements on the export of jute has again highlighted the growing hostility between the two new Dominion Governments.

Dalisay Aldaba, young soprano from the Philippines, made her debut with the New York City Opera Company last night in the name role of "Madama Butterfly," the company's final presentation of the season at the City Center. Convincing in appearance as well as in her dramatization of the part, she received prolonged applauge from the large audience.

Phenomenal growth of teen-age merchandising in the last two years has been one of the outstanding factors in keeping apparel sales at unprecedented levels, it was pointed out last week in the trade. Catering to consumers in the ll-to-17-year age group has not only brought up dollar volume of merchants maintaining teen-age departments, manufacturers said, but has stabilized unit sales in the face of rising prices.

A third-round wage increase of 12 1/2 cents an hour and a second week of paid vacations have been won by 150,000 workers in the men's and boys' clothing industry under an agreement announced yesterday by the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, CIO, and the United States Clothing Manufacturers Association.

The formation of International House Association, members of Which will be enrolled from among the 50,000 former residents of the three International Houses in the United States and dedicated to tho furtherance of world peace and international understanding, was announced last night at a dinner at the New York International House, 500 Riverside Drive.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- Chairman Owen Brewster of the Senate War Investigating Committee invited Attorney General Tom C. Clark today to look into the dealings of American oil companies in Arabian oil to see if any action was needed to protect the interests of the United States.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: When Vishinsky made one of his bitter attacks on this country at Lake Success two weeks ago I was sitting about twenty feet behind him. Next to him sat Herschel Johnson of our delegation -- the United States and the U.S.S.R. being that close together in the alphabetical seating;

No Complaints on Credit Ads No complaints over promotion of easier credit terms in advertising since the recent lapse of "Regulation W" have yet been received by the Batter Business Bureau, Inc., of New York, it was learned over the week-end.

A Committee on Sea Transport, composed of representatives of the shipping industry in the United States, has been appointed by the United States Associates of the International Chamber of Commerce, it was announced here yesterday.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 16 -- Leading United States, British and German officials in the economically merged zones believe that Congressional action on the European. Recovery Program rather than Big Four measures in London will spell the difference between continued economic disruption in and the orderly rehabilitation of Europe.

LONDON, Nov. 16 (U.P.) -- Princess Elizabeth, with her mother, Queen Elizabeth, and her sister, Princess Margaret, watched the start of the parade from a palace balcony. Afterward the royal family, including King George, went to services in the Chapel Royal in near-by St. James' Palace.

An array of Christmas trimmings, gay enough to inspire homemakers to shop in advance for decorations, is available now in New York stores. Imaginative ornaments, in which mirrored balls, sequins and fabrics often are combined, go on view today at the Eve Brueser Studios, 22 West Thirty-eighth Street.
The first section of the Friendship Food Train pulled into the Jersey City rail yards last night with thirty carloads of gifts from the American people to relieve hunger in France and Italy.

DETROIT, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Scoring at least once in every period and three times on touchdown passes by a rookie quarterback, Clyde Leforce, the Detroit Lions defeated the Washington Redskins, 38 to 21, today before 19,192 fans for their second National League football victory in their last three starts.

TO HTE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Your editorial of Nov. 11 criticizes the Federal Communications Commission for denying a frequency-modulation radio station to The New York Daily News because, as you state, the ground on which the FM station was denied was not sound.

Creation of a fully-rounded Air Force as an equal partner of the Army and the Navy in the Department of Defense raises problems which go deeper than that of its new titular status. Not the least of these is the drawing of personnel from the older services.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Department of Agriculture has started about three-fourths of the approximately 160 research projacts which will constitute the firs year's work under the Research and Marketing Act.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs went into a 3 -- 0 lead in the first six minutes of play tonight and held off the Chicago Black Hawks successfully to the end to win, 5 to 4 and gain undisputed possession of first place in the National Hockey league.

Eula Beal, contralto from Los Angeles, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Attractive to the eye and endowed with a fine voice, Miss Beal also was the fortunate possessor of an innate musical instinct and an interpretive skill not often encountered among vocalists of the younger generation.

Continuing costs of World War II are expected to amount to more than the $31,000,000,000 total military costs of World War I by next June 30, according to a survey, "America's Resources for World Leadership," just made public by the National Industrial Conference Board, 247 Park Avenue.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Nov. 16 -- Mayor Stanley W. Church of this city was a Republican until party bosses tossed him bodily from an office. Ever since then he has been an ardent Democrat. Examining: his record majority polled in the recent election, some Republican leaders are wondering if they shouldn't have tried to handle him more gently.

Favorite book characters that dance and talk, story-book riddles that are acted out and famous authors and illustrators who tell stories and draw pictures are among the features of the Boys and Girls Book Fair to open Friday at the American Museum of Natural History and to run through the following Monday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) --Unidentified gunmen killed a former suburban police chief and his wife early today within a few feet of their home in Posen on the southern outskirts of Chicago.

Great decisions are impending. Today Congress meets to take action in an emergency of a kind this body has never consciously faced before. It has to legislate for people beyond its constituency and a future beyond its sight. The aching cavities in the economy of France, Italy and Austria which cry for immediate treatment are only the biggest holes in the crumbling edifice of Europe.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 -- Timed in conjunction with the meeting of Congress tomorrow, a mass meeting was staged by the Progressive Citizens of America today in further protest against the House Un-American Activities Committee's investigation of communism in Hollywood.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Steelers scored three touchdowns in a minute and 48 seconds of the last period today to come from behind and defeat the New York Giants, 24 -- 7, before 35,000 frenzied fans. Pittsburgh thus retained its slim lead in the National Football League's eastern division.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, India, Nov. 16 (Reuters) -- Liaqat Ali Khan, Prime Minister of Pakistan, proposed tonight that the United Nations should be asked immediately to send representatives to stop the fighting in Kashmir, now in its fourth week, a dispatch from Lahore said.

Two firemen went into the East River yesterday to rescue a woman being swept along by the strong Hell Gate currents at Eighty-ninth Street. The firemen saved her after she had been carried under the East River Drive and was trying to stay afloat amid the pilings.

In his tenth year at Ann Arbor Fritz Crisler has piloted Michigan to sole possession of the Western Conference championship for the first time since 1933, and the Wolverine Special is Rose Bowl bound.

MUD is known among the football coaching fraternity as the Great Equalizer. It is an ally of the underdog. Since the past week-end produced some really nasty weather that ranged from cold mists to heavy snows, it also produced more surprises than one ordinarily finds this late in the season.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today that the makers and distributors of Philco radios and appliances had agreed to stop a promotional campaign which drew an FTC complaint two weeks ago.

In his address last Monday evening before the Ohio Society, Senator Taft touched on the question of attaching "strings," or "conditions," to loans and grants made under the so-called Marshall plan. "If," said he, "we impose conditions which turn out to be unpopular with the people, we nullify to a large extent such credit as we might otherwise obtain.

CAMDEN, N.J., Nov. 16 -- An imported Pekingese, Sheraton Dorian, belonging to Mrs. Ruth Burnette Sayres of Westbury, L.I., took the best-in-show award tonight in the sixteenth annual fixture of the Camden County Kennel Club.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Automatic Otto Graham hurled three touchdown passes today as the explosive Cleveland Browns smothered the San Francisco Forty-niners, 37 to 14, to annex their second straight western division championship in the All-America Football Conference.

The statement on secularism issued Saturday by fourteen bishops comprising the administrative board of the National Catholic Welfare Conference will be thoughtfully read in circles far beyond the pale of any single religious communion. It is a sobering diagnosis of the maladies which have taken root in modern society through loss of emphasis upon spiritual values and moral responsibilities.

DENVER, Nov. 16 -- On the eve of President Truman's message to Congress, Harold E. Stassen, aspirant for the Republican nomination for the Presidency, demanded here that the President indicate that he would approve a tax cut of $3,000,000,000 after the enactment of the European aid program under the Marshall plan.

After advancing early last week on the low official forecast for this year's crop, cotton prices in the domestic market subsequently held within a narrow range. At the close on Saturday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange showed advances of 46 to 78 points for the week.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 16 -- Withdrawal of the British Army and of military stores from Palestine, which is to end in complete evacuation, has begun. It is being made by sea from Haifa and by land across the Egyptian border to Port Said and it may last up to a year.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- An impressive parade of 10,000 members of the Association of Jewish Ex-Service Men and Women took place here today. Tributes from the Government and from the highest officers of the British armed forces emphasized that while there are terrorists killing Britons in Palestine there are generations of Jews in Britain who have played their roles as loyal and brave citizens.

New York's football Yankees barely beat the Los Angeles Dons, 16 -- 13, in an All-America Conference game at the Stadium yesterday. It might be in order to report that the winners appeared to be looking ahead to next Sunday's meeting with the champion Browns.

Autumn weather, especially morning fog, has caused many delays and some cancellations of airline schedules into and out of La Guardia Field and Newark airport in the last few days, reports at the two fields showed yesterday. But all airlines, domestic and foreign, reported passenger business holding up exceptionally well and cargo exceeding expectations.

Robert R. Nathan, consulting economist and economic advisor to the Jewish Agency for Palestine, asserted yesterday that "the future Jewish State in Palestine will require $3,000,000,000 in private, corporate and Government investments during the next decade."

BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- "Concrete steps for even provisional reform of German currency will be possible only after the London Conference of Foreign Ministers has arrived at definite decisions about Germany's future," a competent allied authority said today

The plan for the establishment of a permanent organization to coordinate all Jewish activities in the United States was outlined yesterday afternoon by spokesmen of The American Jewish Conference before several hundred Jewish leaders of New York in the Hotel New Yorker.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The power-packed Chicago Bears, rolling relentlessly in quest of another National Football League title, subdued the Los Angeles Rams today, 41 -- 21, in a viciously fought game from which five players were ejected.

HAIFA, Palestine, Nov. 16 -- Nearly 200 Jewish unauthorized immigrants aboard a sailing ship eluded naval patrols and landed safely on the coast of Palestine near here before dawn today. A second ship carrying 794 persons was intercepted by British forces and brought into Haifa.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce reported today that the volume of economic activity in the third quarter of this year made little real advance over that of the second quarter.

Bank accounts and other financial data of both Welfare Department employes and relief recipients are being examined by Department of Investigation examiners as they study various cases in their inquiry into the relief administration, James H. Sheils, Deputy Commissioner of investigation, said yesterday.

A top-heavy lead built up by the New York Rovers in their Eastern Hockey League game with the Boston Olympics at Madison Square Garden yesterday proved just enough. The visiting athletes, accorded little chance when the second period opened, came through with four late tallies, while the Rovers scored one.

With retailers wishing to insure early deliveries, and a large number of buyers in the wholesale market placing orders, spring buying took on new impetus last week, according to the weekly market reports prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by leading resident buying offices.

Miss Florence N. Levy, art educator, Writer and publisher, and former secretary of the board of trustees of the School Art League of New York City, died Saturday in her home at 115 West Seventythird Street, after a long illness. Her age was 77.

Former Gov. Herbert H. Lehman, speaking yesterday from the pulpit of the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street, urged Americans of all faiths to make "the spirit of religion the major motivating force behind our endeavors to succor suffering humanity."

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Off form for three quarters While Green Bay was compiling a 20-7 lead, Paul Christman clicked with his passes in the final period today to herd the Chicago Cardinals to a 21-20 National Football League triumph over the rugged Packers before a crowd of 40,086 in Comiskey Park.

Reluctance on the part of retailers to buy Russian linens which have been recently offered in the textile market reflects consumer opposition to such merchandise, it was pointed out last week. Movement of Russian goods, chiefly linen towels, which were bought for distribution in the Middle West, has been far from satisfactory, according to New York importers.

A bipartisan, four-member House subcommittee, headed by Representative James G. Fulton of Pennsylvania, finds that the United States has been losing some good citizens by refusing to admit a reasonable number of Europe's "displaced persons." There are in Europe now about 1,300,000 of these unlucky people, of whom more than half are stagnating in internment camps in American zones.

The Marshall plan can be carried out by private foreign trade on both sides of the ocean if the Export-Import Bank is empowered to discount American exporters' drafts in dollars, according to James B. Herzog, president of Stern, Morgenthau Co., Inc.

Theos Bernard, American author and Tibetan scholar who on Nov. 2 was reported as having been killed in the Punjab by tribal raiders, is alive according to word from his wife received here yesterday by Dr. Dagobert D. Runes. Dr. Runes, head of the Philosophical Library, Mr. Bernard's publisher, said that Mrs. Bernard had written to him from New Delhi, India, on Nov. 5 that her husband was safe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) --A Baptist group said today that programs of religious instruction in public school building's were "an invasion of the time-honored doctrine of the separation of church and state."

State Housing: Commissioner Herman Stichman assailed yesterday the proponents of religious prejudice who would have prevented subsidization of many of the fifty -three colleges with building projects that were completed with state funds in the last eighteen months.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16 -- Ambassador James Bruce said tonight that he was "entirely in accord" with the statement yesterday of Miguel Miranda, Economic Director, regarding the difficulties Argentina faced in obtaining supplies in the United States.

The church is the "conscience of the state, and if it ceases to be sensitive, society plunges downward," the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor of Clirist Church, Methodist, Park Avenue and Sixtieth Street, said yesterday in his sermon.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 16 -- Rumors are circulating in Bucharest today that Rumania may sever diplomatic relations with the United States and possibly with Great Britain, as a result of the disclosures in the Peasant party treason trial of alleged intervention by Anglo-American representatives against the Groza Government.
