BOSTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Detroit Red Wings, blending speed with spirited play, defeated the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 2, in a penaltyless National Hockey League clash tonight before a 13,900 crowd at the Boston Garden. Bep Guidolin, a recent Bruin, plagued his former mates by collecting a goal and an assist.

Beethoven is the chief composer being honored this season by the New Friends of Music, and late yesterday afternoon at Town Hall the organization presented its most ambitious single Beethoven project -- a performance of Beethoven's other Mass, the one in C major, that has been all but obliterated in the public consciousness by the "Missa Solemnis."

Harald Kreutzberg last night gave the second of a series of four Sunday recitals at the Ziegfeld Theatre, and once again attracted a large audience that was moved to copious applause and frequent brasos.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The American steel industry, already charged by the Federal Trade Commission with illegal price-fixing and restraint of competition, was arraigned anew today by the FTC on charges of combining to block increased production and discriminating against the Far West by its selling methods.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Prices of corn for future delivery made
The Public Education Association urged the Board of Higher Education yesterday to reject an amendment to its by-laws that would ban subversive groups from the municipal college campuses.

BANGKOK, Slam, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The new Siamese Government today linked a secretary to the fugitive opposition leader. Pride Panymyong, with the assassination of King Ananda Mahidol, and said it had definite proof that the youthful monarch was murdered.

The City Planning Commission's proposed 1948 capital budget of $244,541,292 was approved "in general" yesterday by Controller Lazarus Joseph, who disagreed, however, with two of the commission's recommendations on the financing of seven new schools and a number of sewage disposal plants.

Brooklyn Prep rolled up one of the biggest scores in local scholastic football history by trouncing St. Basil's Prep of Stamford, Gonn., 61 to 0, at Boys High Field yesterday. It was the eighth successive triumph for the Crown Heighters who clinched the mythical city Catholic higti school football crown.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16 -- An increase of 1 1/2 points was noted last week in the steel ingot output for the country, raising operations to 97.5 per cent of capacity. The increase, according to trade sources, was probably a minor fluctuation in operations rather than any indication of a long-term alleviation of the shortages of scrap and pig iron that are harassing the industry.

Current studies on port rehabilitation in New York should produce positive plans for expanding the foreign trade zone on Staten Island, according to Thomas E. Lyons, executive secretary of the Foreign Trade Zones Board.

WARSAW, Nov. 16 -- The Communist newspaper Glos Ludu published today the text of a letter, reported to have been sent from Sir Alexander Cadogan to the Polish Government in London during the war, indicating that as early as 1944, the United States had misgivings about moving Poland's western border to the Oder River.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 16 -- The second General Assembly of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization has completed its first ten days of deliberation with only one specific achievement -- the approval of its budget for 1948.

The arrest here early yesterday Of the driver of a truck containing 42,000 worth of merchandise that was stolen on Oct. 15 disclosed the existence of what police gaid was one of the largest interstate hijack gangs in recent years.

Pasadena's annual Rose Bowl football classic will be televised for the first time on New Year's Day, 1948, With KTLA, Los Angeles, carrying the game directly to a Southern California audience and the National Broadcasting Company filming the action for subsequent release over its East Coast television network.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Eight new members will take their seats tomorrow when the Eightieth Congress ends its recess and resumes its first session. Seven are Representatives-elect and one is a Senator-elect.

TOKYO, Nov. 16 -- Although occupation officials continue to plead for delay, a body of opinion is growing for immediate establishment of an exchange rate for the yen. In the Allied Council, both Maj. Gen. Alexei P. Kislenko and Patrick Shaw, Soviet and British Commonwealth members, have proposed action at the "earliest possible date."

Confidence that members of Congress would act promptly on President Truman's proposals for interim aid to Europe was expressed here yesterday by Lewis W. Douglas, Ambassador to Great Britain, as he left La Guardia Field to return to his post abroad.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 16 -- The principles by which post-war Turkey will live -- whether under authoritarianism and economic socialism or democracy and a measure of economic liberalism -- will be at issue when the Republican Peoples' party begins tomorrow its first plenary congress since the war.

TOKYO, Nov. 16 -- Although occupation officials continue to plead for delay, a body of opinion is growing for immediate establishment of an exchange rate for the yen. In the Allied Council, both Maj. Gen. Alexei P. Kislenko and Patrick Shaw, Soviet and British Commonwealth members, have proposed action at the "earliest possible date."

Confidence that members of Congress would act promptly on President Truman's proposals for interim aid to Europe was expressed here yesterday by Lewis W. Douglas, Ambassador to Great Britain, as he left La Guardia Field to return to his post abroad.
Music and laughter echoed from the ceiling of Madison Square Garden for four hours last night as a capacity audience witnessed the fourteenth annual "Night of Stars" benefit show.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Soviet Air Force is believed to have 14,000 military airplanes in active service, including quantities of a Russian version of the B-29 bombers, Gen. Carl Spaatz, commanding general of the United States Air Force, said here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- A Presidential Committee report recommending a multi-million-dollar United States merchant ship construction program during the next four years was promised careful study in Congress today.
Despite an obvious apathy on the part of the motoring public, the opening yesterday of the city's free parking lot on the old World's Fair site in Queens seemed headed for eventual success.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 17 -- Several thousand soft-drink manufacturers and distributors from the United States and Canada, and some from Europe and Latin America, were on hand today for the opening of the first post-war international beverage exposition at Municipal Auditorium.
The United Nations General Assembly endorsed yesterday the trade union rights laid down by the International Labor Organization and urged the ILO to study further means of protecting labor's rights.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The turmoil set off by the President's recommendations on foreign aid and domestic price curbs appeared tonight not to have put the $597,000,000 emergency relief program for France, Italy and Austria in danger.

Two centuries of boxing history in Great Britain and the United States are depicted in an exhibit at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, which will be opened to the public tomorrow.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 17 -- India's Constituent Assembly met today as the sovereign legislature of the independent Dominion of India for the first time. It elected a veteran Congress party leader, G.V. Mavalankar, as its first Speaker.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The President asked Congress for authority to impose limited consumer rationing, if needed, as he addressed the joint session of Congress which he called to provide emergency aid for Europe and to combat inflation at home.

TOKYO, Nov. 17 -- In the mountainous regions of Kirin Province in Manchuria about 1,000 Japanese soldiers are still holding out against the Chinese Communist armies and are living the life of "bandits." This is reported by Japanese repatriates from the mainland who landed at Maizuru yesterday.

Ads to Urge Oil Saving The American Petroleum Institute has authorized preparation of organization-sponsored and dealer tie-in newspaper advertising in support of the fuel oil conservation program in sections which will be affected by a temporary shortage this winter, it was learned yesterday.

Representatives of the four national networks will confer today on the proposal of Niles Trammell, president of the National Broadcasting Company, that the chains should adopt their own joint code of standards. Mr. Trammell's suggestion was made Saturday night after the board of the National Association of Broadcasters postponed final action on industry-wide standards until its next convention in May.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Nov. 17 -- Opposition to the return of rationing or price controls were voiced today by leaders of the Illinois Agricultural Association and associated groups fallowing President Truman's age to Congress as they gathered for the IAA's thirtythird annual meeting.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Senator Robert A. Taft of Ohio assailed President Truman's pricecontrol program tonight as "a step toward a completely totalitarian nation."
The waterfowl season will open in New Jersey and Connecticut at noon today, and according to most reports the opening day shooting should be excellent although it will last only four hours.

The Ice Follies of 1948 will open at Madison Square Garden tonight, and will run at the Eighth Avenue Arena until Nov. 30. Already having shown to favorable response in Los Angeles and Chicago, the event promises to please New York's ice fans for the thirteen nights it is scheduled to show here.

Money Market Easier Holding excess reserves of approximately $80,000,000, the New York City Federal Reserve Banks began the week yesterday in a fairly comfortable position, and federal funds were at 3/4 of 1 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Nov. IT (AP) -- The Commerce Department's Office of International Trade announced today it has decided against removing export controls on lower grades of soft wood lumber. Present controls will be retained, OIT said, because an inquiry showed that type of lumber Is still too scarce to meet domestic demand.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 19 to 42 points net yesterday on the belief that foreign aid eventually would absorb any surplus of cotton.

Three issues of common stock amounting to $4,307,500 will be offered publicly today by underwriters, as follows: American-Marietta Company -- 125,000 shares of common stock at $15 a share by the First Boston Corporation and associates.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The injury suffered by Bob Waterfield, Los Angeles Rams' quarterback, in yesterday's rough RamsChicago Bears game, was diagnosed today as a severely bruised jaw.

The emphasis on Europe in President Truman's address to Congress is justified because, as he pointed out and as events in Europe illustrate, the future of the free nations on that continent hangs literally in the balance. It is in Europe that we meet the most immediate and most direct challenge to freedom, and it is there that our first aid must be rushed.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Gifts that would turn the head of any young woman were pouring into St. James's Palace for Princess Elizabeth today and hundreds of them were put on view. Philip, like any other bridegroom, comes out of it rather badly.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Very nearly our entire attention is turned these days to the pressing problems of Europe. We have almost ruled the Orient out of our world, and forgotten that its hundreds of millions of human being will have a great deal to do, in the long run, with the shape and safety of our future.

The new decor in the Stuyvesant Town model apartment at Hearn's, which will reopen to the public on Thursday morning, is so different from the original version that visitors may think they are looking at a different set of rooms. Clear, fresh fabric colors and space-saving furniture arrangements show how one can obtain a completely new look, without even changing the color of the walls.

Three additional new models of the 1948 Crosley automobile were presented yesterday by Powel Crosley Jr., president of Crosley Motors, Inc. They are the "sports utility," which will sell delivered here for about $850, a station wagon at $1,049, and a panel delivery truck at about $950.

The people of this city made preparations yesterday to add the equivalent of twenty to thirty carloads of food to the Friendship Train, which will complete today its historic run across the continent.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Frank Wead of Los Angeles, naval aviator in the first World War, who became a film writer, died Saturday night in Santa Monica Hospital, which he entered Nov. 1 for surgery. His age was 52.

Events in Czechoslovakia have taken the expected fateful turn. The sudden deposition of Zdenek Fierlinger from his post as Socialist party president seemed to offer some assurance that the freedom-loving little nation would not be swallowed by Russia without a struggle.

IOWA CITY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Board in Control of Athletics at the University of Iowa tonight postponed final consideration of the resignation of Football Coach Dr. Eddie Anderson until it has an opportunity to confer with Anderson personally.

No one associated with the New York Football Yankees of the AllAmerica Conference is willing to enter into the controversy concerning Orban (Spec) Sanders and Claude (Buddy) Young, their respective merits and who is the better football player.

A change in training routine loomed for Joe Louis yesterday as the world heavyweight champion advanced a day closer to the defense of his title against Jersey Joe Walcott in Madison Square Garden on Dec. 5. Joe was idle yesterday at his Pompton Lakes, N.J., quarters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Export-Import Bank agreed today to lend Canada up to $300,000,000 to purchase essential equipment and raw materials in this country and to prevent impairment of Canada's contribution to European recovery.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Meat, grain, steel and other metals, coal and machinery were regarded by official and unofficial circles today as the key commodities in terms of President Truman's recommendations for selective price and rationing controls.

The sandhogs' union, which has been out on strike from the Brooklyn -Battery Tunnel construction for two weeks, charged yesterday that the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority, which is building the tube, awarded two of the contracts without competitive bidding, as required by law.

Robert Moses, as president of the Long Island State Park Commission, has appealed to the Town Board of North Hempstead not to change its zoning classifications to permit the construction of a large number of small dwellings at New Cassel, east of the Wantagh State Parkway.

Noting that the area within the Arctic Circle is most important strategically, Admiral Richard E. Byrd, USN retired, warned last night that in the event of another war the center of action would be across the top of the world.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt of Australia contended here today that the United Nations General Assembly should go on record at its present meeting as opposing the use of the veto in connection with the peaceful settlement of disputes.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- A formal Parliamentary inquiry into the circumstances of the budget leak that caused Hugh Dalton to resign the office of Chancellor of the Exchequer last week, seemed a certainty here tonight. Pressure of the opposition brought a statement from Prime Minister Attlee to the House of Commons that the Government would offer no opposition to the request for an inquiry.

Milwaukee, Wis., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Dec. 8 on $5,550,000 of various bonds at an interest rate not exceeding 2 per cent, to be dated Jan. 31, 1948, and maturing from Feb. 1, 1949 to 1953.
Officials of five Congress of Industrial Organizations maritime unions voted yesterday during a "unity conference" here to strike next June 15, if necessary to "protect and maintain hiring halls."

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- In a two-hour conversation today, former Premier Leon Blum, Socialist, and Paul Reynaud, Independent Conservative, failed to agree upon a Cabinet In which they would be the leading figures.

WARSAW, Nov. 17 -- The Polish Government disclosed today in a Parliamentary commission's discussion of the 1948 budget for the Ministry of Security that underground terrorists had killed 166 members of the secret police during the first ten months of 1947.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- Governor Dewey will visit five New England communities and meet with the Governors of Vermont and New Hampshire during a two-day trip starting Wednesday morning, his secretary, Paul E. Lockwood, said today.

It started from Los Angeles on Friday night, Nov. 7, as a single train of twelve cars, easily pulled by one locomotive. At Oakland it picked up seven more cars. It left Reno on Sunday with 29, Ogden on Monday with 31, Kearney, Neb., on Wednesday with 50, Council Bluffs on Friday with 62.

Rosina Lhevinne, duo-pianist of long experience, teamed with her former pupils Vitya Vronsky and Victor Babin last night to play Mozart's Concerto for Three Pianos with the Little Orchestra Society under Thomas K. Scherman. It was the third concert in the orchestra's series at Town Hall, and will be repeated tomorrow night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Any attempt to tax as income true patronage refunds that co-ops make to members would be unconstitutional. Congress was told today by Eugene L. Hensel, counsel for the National Association of Cooperatives.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Labor was surprised today by President Truman's request to Congress for authority to impose limited wage and price controls.

The consumer service section of the Citizens food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: For meatless Tuesday, OvenFried Fish is a tempting dish that comes' to the table crisp outside and juicy and tender inside. Use whatever small whole fish are available in your local markets, or any kind of fish fillets or fish steaks, fresh or frozen.

Suggestions that Puerto Ricans migrating to this city be settled elsewhere would require from $6,000 to $10,000 a family if proper environment was set up, Dr. Leonard Covello, principal of the Benjamin Franklin High School, in East Harlem, said yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- A plan to carry out the partition of Palestine without the active participation of Great Britain was approved unanimously tonight by the partition subcommittee of the United Nations General Assembly.

By a margin of nineteen to five, members of the general executive board of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, CIO, voted early yesterday morning to exonerate Samuel Wolchok, the union's president, of charges filed against him by two union officers.

Purchasing agents for large manufacturers will immediately step up subcontracting of machine parts production to other companies which have a historical record as large steel users, spokesmen revealed here yesterday, following President Truman's message for price controls and allocations.

CHICAGO. Nov. 17 (AP) -- Today's report at the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 13.500 head, total 21.000: general market on butchers fairly active and steady to 25 cents lower than Friday: market opened 15 to 25 cents lower but closed active

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Political implications of the message President Truman delivered to Congress created almost as much interest today as did the actual program of the Administration for extending aid abroad and fighting inflation at home.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Nov. 17 -- Alfred Krupp von Bohlen und Halbach, scion of a German armaments dynasty that dates back to 1812, was arraigned today in the main courtroom of the Palace of Justice with eleven other officials of the company.

The United Aircraft Corporation and its consolidated subsidiaries, in a report issued yesterday for the nine months ended with last September, showed an increase in sales of 76 per cent to $144,084,728 from $81,582,732 in the corresponding period of 1946.

Crushed, 40 -- 0, beneath Rutgers' powerful grid machine last Saturday at New Brunswick for their fifth loss in seven games, New York University's football team will spend the entire week in preparation for its traditional battle with Fordham on November 29 at the Polo Grounds.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Britain's financial set-up under the new Chancellor of the Exchequer, Sir Stafford Cripps, continued to be the main subject of discussion in the stock markets here today. As a result a general air of uncertainty and uneasiness was in evidence.

Ten seniors started their last week of football at Baker Field yesterday as Columbia began preparations for the game with Syracuse Saturday. Bill Swiacki and Ventan Yablonski are the outstanding members of this group, which includes seven regular performers.

Following are excerpts from the report, made public yesterday by he State Department, on concessions made to the United States in the trade agreements signed in Geneva by twenty-three countries: Grains and Cereal Products -- The United Kingdom bound wheat duty free and barley at a 10 per cent rate.

Following is the text of Senator Taff's radio address of last night, as recorded by the new YORK TIMES: Today the President of the United States demanded that Congress, and the people, turn the clock backward.

Without a dissenting vote, the United Nations General Assembly approved yesterday a compromise immigration proposal that urges member nations to speed the return of repatriable refugees to their homelands, and asks each Government to admit a "fair share" of the non-repatriable displaced persons.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 17 -- Charles Milton of Jersey City, counsel for Lipsett, Inc., the New York salvage concern that was to dismantle the battleship New Mexico on the Newark waterfront, today assured Thomas L. Parsonnet, Newark corporation counsel, that his client would not attempt to move the ship into Newark Channel until it had given the city twenty-four hours' notice.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Nov. 17 -- An appeal for increased opportunities for small business and a higher income for white-collar workers was made tonight by Harold E. Stassen in a dinner speech, but overshadowing his remarks was the political picture presented after two days of his tour in search of delegates in the Solid South.

The concerts of Leonard Bernstein with the New York City Symphony can always be counted on for interest, excitement and many moments of beauty. The one which opened the ninth and next to last week of his season at the City Center last night was no exception.

From the over-all standpoint of interest, attendance, team and school, morale and final results, the City College football team which completed its 1947 campaign Saturday showed more progress than any Beaver eleven since 1940. Dr. Sam Winograd, C.C.N.Y.'s faculty manager of athletics, said yesterday.

LONDON, Tuesday, Nov. 18 -- The tenor of President Truman's message to Congress earned high praise in this mornings British newspapers. They emphasized the boldness of his proposals to combat inflation in the United States.

The football season will run its course this week for most of t college teams, but many of t sectional champions are yet to crowned and the bowl entrepreneurs still have a lot of unfinished business on hand before the invitations go out.

Charles B. McDermott has been appointed divisional vice president of Winthrop-Stearns, Inc., and general manager of its Canadian branch, with offices in Windsor, Ont. Direction of sales will remain with T.R. Rider, for ten years Canadian sales manager.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 17 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission granted permission today to the Georgia Power Company, Atlanta, to reduce the stated capital value of its 2,500,000 shares of no par value common stock from $55,000,000 to $37,000,000.

President Truman's bid to the Congress yesterday for reimposition of price and wage controls produced no reaction on the stock market. The narrow and irregular drift which prevailed prior to delivery of the President's message was unchanged after the details of his proposals became known in brokerage offices.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- The shifting of the United Nations General Assembly to Europe next year was virtually assured today by the Administrative and Budgetary Committee's approval of separate funds for the move. The vote, 30 to 8, with three abstentions, was more than enough to meet the two-thirds requirement.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Truman will not be the only official who will have to show neutrality this year at the Army-Navy football game.

The American President liner President Cleveland, the largest merchant vessel built in the United States since 1939, will make her maiden voyage from San Francisco on Dec. 27, the company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Truman made his report on the economic crisis facing this country and Europe to a Congress that heard his solemn words in a tense atmosphere of anxiety and grave urgency.

On opposite sides of the fence for the first time in nearly thirty years, Glenn Scobie (Pop) Warner, the retired coach, who fathered the single and double-wing formations, and Lou Little, Columbia mentor, presented conflicting views yesterday of the current unlimited substitutions rule in football.
The newly formed Traffic Action Committee started yesterday to find out the cause and suggest a cure for the continued traffic congestion in the city.
The urgency of Europe's need for aid should not obscure the continuing importance of assistance to Latin America, two Colombian diplomats said here yesterday.

OTTAWA, Nov. 17 -- Within a few hours of the announcement of the benefits to trade to be obtained from the Geneva tariff agreements, the Canadian Government announced tonight a series of heavy restrictive and other measures that are being imposed immediately on imports from the United States to safeguard and improve Canada's exchange position.

The R.C.A. Service Corporation, a division, of the Radio Corporation of America, has leased 30,000 square feet of space on the first and third floors of the former Clark Thread Company mill at Ogden and Gouverneur Streets, Newark, N.J., and will use the space as a warehouse and for servicing television sets.

HALIFAX, N.S., Nov. 17 (Canadian Press) -- A repeated plea for help in forty-eight hours for crew members "in pretty bad shape" from exposure crackled out tonight from the wireless of the foundering 4,900-ton British freighter Langleecrag as a heroic radio operator once more returned to the vessel to send out a report on his shipwrecked mates.

Robert (Skin and Bones) Black, the thin man from Rhode Island State, scored a stirring sixty-yard triumph over Penn State's Horace Ashenfelter in the thirty-ninth annual cross-country championship of the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday as Manhattan's well - balanced forces swept varsity and freshman team honors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers was the clandestine founder and hidden owner of a corporation that got at least $1,053,000 in wartime subcontracts which he solicited as an Army Air Forces officer, the Senate War Investigating Subcommittee was told today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- Larry Parks, whose suit for declaratory relief against Columbia will come to trial next February, has agreed to star in "The Gallant Blade" at the studio under a stipulation that the picture will be made without prejudice to his claims, his attorneys disclosed today.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 17 (AP) -- H.L. Straus' March Chick, a busy campaigner, made his twentieth start of the year his third successful one when he came through with a stretch rush to win the St. Mary's purse, feature of today's program of the Bowie meeting.
LONDON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Kings, Queens and nobles danced tonight

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 17 -- Premier Petru Groza said today in an interview that he did not believe that the allegations of United States interference in Rumanian affairs, made in the treason trial of Peasant party leaders, should or would lead to a break in diplomatic relations between the United States and Rumania.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- In substance the President today asked Congress to do these things by March 31: Appropriate enough for emergency assistance to Europe to last until April 1. Legislate a European Recovery Program, long-range in intent, to start on that date at the latest.

"Don Giovanni," presented last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association, was so well done dramatically, so capably directed on the stage by Herbert Crab and so admirably conducted by Max Rudolph that these characteristics recompensed in large measure for a good deal of second-class singing.

A chance to do the things they were too busy to do earlier in life, or just chat over a cup of tea, was offered to the aged of Brooklyn at the formal opening yesterday of the Stuyvesant Center for the Older Person, 265 Decatur Street, Brooklyn.

Many More Years Than Fifty Action of our municipal authorities in appropriating money toward the celebration next year of a Golden Anniversary reminds our city scout that a mere half century as a city of five boroughs is only a small slice of the history of a settlement the heart of which has always been a seaport holding in its mesh the land on which all those boroughs rest.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Bel Beau of Little Rhodey Farm won the $3,000 Madison claiming purse for $10,000 platers at Rockingham Park today by turning back the stretch challenge of R.W. Collins' Scottsville. J.L. McKnight's Blenweed finished third.

Ceramic vases and decorative glass murals by Belgian artists now working in small village industries went on display yesterday for the first time in this country at Georg Jensen, 667 Fifth Avenue. Many of the ceramic pieces are by craftsmen in Bouffioulx, who have added new colors and enamel processes to the traditional skills handed down by the masters of that noted fifteenth century center.

Written examinations for applicants for driver, licenses were put into effect yesterday by the Motor Vehicle Bureau at 155 Worth Street and other branches in the city. More than 1,000 persons took the test in the five boroughs on the first day.

Tariff reductions ranging up to 50 per cent of present rates on major imports, and affecting 60 per cent of United States trade, were disclosed yesterday by State Department sources in a conference at 2 Park Avenue.

Though the closeness of timing was sheer coincidence, there is a direct and fundamental connection between the program submitted to Congress yesterday by President Truman and the farreaching tariff agreement announced later in the day by Trygve Lie, as Secretary General of the United Nations, and made public in a State Department analysis in Washington.

ROME, Nov. 17 -- Premier Alcide de Gasperi, in a speech lasting almost two hours at the national congress of his own Christian Democratic party in Naples today, attacked the Communists with extraordinary vehemence and pledged Italy to cooperate with the United States in "the fight for freedom, democracy and peace."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- A new method for producing rain, by which ordinary water dispensed in small quantities into activity growing cumulus clouds starts a "chain reaction" rainfall from such clouds, was disclosed tonight by Dr. Irving Langmuir, associate director of the General Electric Company's Research Laboratory.

The Port of New York Authority urged the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to reject proposed rail rates on mixed freight moving in carloads between Washington, Newport News, Richmond, Norfolk and other southern destinations.

GUY McCRONE, author of a trilogy of novels now published in this country in an omnibus volume as "Red Plush,"* threatens to continue writing about the same family's fortunes until he brings them up to the present. Since it took him 626 pages to cover only about twelve years in the Eighteen Seventies and early Eighteen Eighties, one shudders to think how many more three-decker volumes he will require to complete his family chronicle.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Accused of "seditious libel" against the Jews in Britain, James Caunt, editor of a weekly newspaper, was found not guilty by a Liverpool jury today.

James W. Carpenter, commercial vice president for the Long Island Lighting Company and its Subsidiaries, told "Public Service Commissioner Spencer C. Eddy yesterday that the company was doing its utmost to reduce gas consumption so that there would be more for heating Long Island homes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Here is President Truman's plan to fight the high cost of living: 1 -- Restore consumer credit controls and curb inflationary bank credits. Outstanding consumer credit has jumped from $6,500,000,000 in 1945 to more than $11,000,000,000 now, and the President called this "a disturbing rate" of increase.
LINCOLN, R.I., Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- Possibility of a racing war among New England's four horse tracks was foreseen today as little Lincoln Downs went ahead independently with plans for Its 1948 season.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The acquisition of Vern Stephens, shortstop, and Jack Kramer, a righthanded pitcher, from the Browns for seven players, plus undisclosed cash, estimated at from $50,000 to $100,000, today featured Joe Cronin's first public appearance as general managed of the Red Sox.

A resolution on the Franco regime in Spain was adopted last night by the United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow by a vote of 36 to 5 with twelve abstentions, but only after it had been much watered down from the form in which it came before the plenary session.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Truman asked Congress today for authority to impose price controls, consumer rationing and wage controls in limited areas of the national economy. He said these were needed to prevent economic catastrophe in the United States and to enable the United States to aid foreign nations wishing to remain free and to regain a self-supporting status.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 17 -- British Army headquarters in Palestine unequivocally denied tonight a report published in London and New York that the withdrawal of British troops from the Holy Land had begun.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 17 -- President Ismet Inonu, opening the congress of the Republican Peoples' party today, proposed reforms in the domestic political life that if applied would be likely to replace the authoritarian regime that has ruled Turkey nearly twenty-five years with a democracy of the Western type.

Two hundred seventy-five business and professional men and women who are chairmen of the committees of the 1948 finance campaign of the Greater New York Council, Boy Scouts of America, met yesterday in the Hotel Commodore to plan a drive for $1,000,000 to begin on Jan. 7.

Over the last-ditch opposition of the Soviet bloc, the United Nations General Assembly went overwhelmingly on record last night as favoring the admission of six states whose applications had previously been vetoed by the Soviet Union.

A broad, energetic program to stimulate private production of housing and to help local communities provide homes for those who cannot otherwise obtain adequate ones, was urged here yesterday by President Truman.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Nov. 17 -- The Ministry of the Interior and the Ministry of National Defense announced today the discovery of a conspiracy against Czechoslovakia in border regions of Bohemia and the arrest of thirty-six persons.

Business here yesterday, in a quick reaction, envisaged a rush to beat price controls and allocation deadlines that may be fixed as a result of President Truman's speech to the special session of Congress. Labor and finance both deplored lack of a definite program in the President's address.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Professional Golfers Association, pening its annual meeting confronted by a mess of "family trouble," today announced sponsorship of a thirty-eight tournament program with a total prize list of $550,000 for the 1948 season.

Store Sales Up 10% in Week Sales of New York and Brooklyn department stores last week showed an increase of 10 per cent over the like week of last year, according to a "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 17 -- A three - point recommendation to meet the imperative need for the machine tool industry of this country to turn out large quantities of the finest and most modern machine tools that can be produced was advanced here today by Herbert H. Pease, president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association.

The New York County grand jury, which since February has been investigating alleged underworld control of prize-ring figures, will investigate "unsparingly" last Friday's match at Madison Square Garden between Jake LaMotta and Billy Fox, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday.

Mayor O'Dwyer declared yesterday that the "time has come to stop piddling" with the problem of urgently needed capital improvements and decide on new measures to find more funds. He expressed his view several times during a Board of Estimate hearing on the proposed 1948 capital budget as pleas were made for hospitals, health centers, new schools, school additions and school repairs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Mill supply items are more plentiful than a year ago, but the threaded products situation is the chief exception, a spokesman for the Central States Mill Supply Association said today during the annual convention of the group.

The first hopeful words from the Netherlands Indies since the Netherlands Indies Government forsook the council room for the firing line last July were spoken yesterday by two members of the United Nations Committee of Good Offices that was sent to the Southwest Pacific by the Security Council last month to see what could be done to bring a peaceful settlement between the Dutch and the Republic of Indonesia.

Declaring that his company had too much respect for the skill and ingenuity of the garment trade to attempt competing with it, Kenneth Collins, vice president of Burlington Mills Corporation of New York, said yesterday that Burlington did not propose to go into manufacturing of finished garments of any type.

Du Font Directors of E.I. Du Pont de Nemours Co. yesterday declared a year-end dividend of $2 a share on the common stock payable on Dec. 13. This increases 1947 disbursements to $8 a share from $7 distributed last year. Christiana Securities Company, investment company controlled by, Du Pont, voted a dividend of $37.60 a share on its common stock, payable on Dec. 15.

Steel and iron scrap cannot be allocated because no plan could ever work, despite present critical scarcities, members of the trade revealed here yesterday after studying the message of President Truman. But if members of the industry "do not behave" a price ceiling could be imposed, they added.

A few hundred people physically present in the House Chamber and its galleries heard President Truman yesterday in the old-fashioned way. Many millions heard, not his actual voice but a fairly faithful reproduction of it, achieved by means few among the millions understood.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- Thirty thousand coal miners in the Lille mine basin were on strike today in protest against the removal from office of Gaston Delfosse, Communist head of the Government coal administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Sharp language by the so-called liberal justices of the Supreme Court featured a decision in which they found themselves a four-man minority today: Ruling for the other five jurists, Justice Harold H. Burton held that truck drivers spending a small part of their time hauling goods in interstate commerce were exempt from overtime pay under the Federal wages and hours law.
GENEVA, Nov. 17 -- Europe faces its worst coal deficit in 1948, the Secretariat of the Economic Commission for Europe said today.

"Amberlight," the new family of colors introduced last month, at the fashion show presented by THE NEW YORK TIMES, is destined for an equally important role in home decorating, Rene Carillo, Stylist of F. Schumacher Co., predicted yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- Following is the text of a proposal for carrying out the partition of Palestine, which was approved today lay a "working party" of the partition subcommittee of the United Nations General Assembly. It constitutes a revision of Sections A and B of Part I of the majority recommendations of UNSCOP. The parts in brackets await revision of the subcommittee in Jerusalem:

Tuesday, Nov. 18, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at Flushing Meadow at 11:1 A.M. and considered items dealing with freedom of association and trade union rights. Heard representatives of New Zealand Soviet Union, Colombia, Argentina, Chile, the Netherlands and Guatemala.

Improved techniques for the treatment of children crippled by cerebral palsy were demonstrated yesterday afternoon in ceremonies opening the Lenox Hill Hospital Cerebral Palsy Pre-school Center at 111 Bast Seventy-sixth Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES. There are two points to be noted in connection with the lowering of Federal personal income taxes on corporation dividends, as recommended by the Magill Committee.

Welfare Commissioner Benjamin Fielding organized a one-week survey yesterday to improve conditions in two public lodging houses and a children's center, after making surprise inspections of all three over last week-end.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- After the Indian delegation had consented to some modification, its resolution condemning the treatment of Indians in South Africa was approved here today by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

First signs of Christmas in the epicure shops of the city are the bright packages of puddings shipped to New Yorkers from England by one of Britain's oldest biscuit manufacturers, Peek-Frean Co., Ltd. Welcome at any Yuletide, they are particularly so this season because they are the first such puddings to be received in this country since 1941.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The Soviet Union barred today from the agenda for the Council of Foreign Ministers the introducing of a United States draft of a fourpower disarmament treaty for Germany. This treaty was proposed in 1946 by the then Secretary of State, James F. Byrnes.

Whole-hearted cooperation in his new post as chairman of the City Planning Commission was promised Robert F. Wagner Jr. at a luncheon given in his honor at the Hotel Plaza yesterday by the Citizens Zoning Committee. Thirtythree representatives of civic, commercial, industrial and labor organizations attended the meeting.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The State Department, in a reversal of its stand, granted permission today to seven employes discharged as bad security risks to "resign without prejudice."

Following is the text of President Truman's address to Congress yesterday, as recorded and transcribed by THE NEW YORK TIMES: Mr. President, Mr. Speaker, members of the Eightieth Congress: The Congress has been convened to consider two problems of major concern to the citizens of the United States and to the peoples of the world.

The recent sales slump in standard brand automatic electric irons has ended and supplies in the last week have run far behind consumer demand, retailers and distributors reported yesterday. All trade elements emphasize that the resurgence in iron volume applies only to name brands and dealers add that weeding out of off-brands is all but completed.

NANKING, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Gen. Chen Yi's Communist forces attacking in North Kiangsu Province have been thrown back fifteen miles by Government air and ground troops after a three-day battle for Suchow, Government military dispatches reported today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (U.P.) -- The House Committee on un-American activities today unanimously approved contempt citations for ten Hollywood writers and directors, clearing the way for the House action next Monday.

The first opening to come along in a dozen days takes place this evening at the Royale Theatre, where Nancy Stern presents "Eastward in Eden." Written by Dorothy Gardner; it tells the story of the New England poet, Emily Dickinson, who withdrew from the world while still in her twenties because she loved a married clergyman, the Rev. Charles Wadsworth.

British Government officials he interviewed expressed the hope that fulfillment of the Marshall plan would take European nations "off the dole," former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson said yesterday after a brief trip to London and Berlin.

Nathan Milstein has become one of the master violinists of our day. If his recital at Carnegie Hall last night is any criterion -- and it ought to be, since that/was its purpose, in part -- Mr. Milstein belongs with the top three or four men of his craft.

The President's address at the opening of the emergency session of Congress was by almost any test a genuinely commendable effort, reflecting both in its form and substance the application of much time and pains-taking thought. It commended itself particularly, it seems to us, in four respects.

Henry J. Taylor, journalist and author, declared last night that the duty of America was to help Europe, not according to our desires but according to careful judgment as to the extent of our abilities. He spoke at the annual dinner of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms in the Hotel Commodore.
Bernard J. Ridder, publisher of The Journal of Commerce of New York, announced yesterday an agreement to merge it with The Chicago Journal of Commerce.

Switching To facilitate switching by financial institutions from Government securities to non-Government bonds and mortgages, the Government "must" support the market for its own obligations, August Ihlefeld, president of the Savings Banks Trust Company, asserted yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The executive committee for Britain's advertising association charged today the new advertising tax was unjust and certain to create confusion. The proposal was contained in the interim budget of Hugh Dalton, who has since resigned as Chancellor of the Exchequer.

Canada's plan to pay a flat subsidy of $7 an ounce on gold production was described in financial circles here yesterday as an "answer" to recent devaluation rumors. The announcement of the new list of emergency controls to correct the Dominion's foreign exchange position, including a ban on luxury imports, resulted in an improvement in the position of the Canadian free dollar in the local foreign exchange market.

Ballyhoo advertising has resulted from "formula thinking" adopted to win top ratings on radio audience research studies because advertisers have made a "fetish" out of high scores, Gerald Carson, vice president of Kenyon Eckhardt, Inc., declared here yesterday.

More sparkling and gayer than they have been in years, the Christmas cards that will soon weight the postmen's pouches are being installed in their special displays in the stationery stores, the big department stores, the book shops and the luxury stores.
PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Princeton University's varsity football team engaged in a light practice session today with the emphasis again on passing and pass defense.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday registered net gains of 5 to 23 points. During the day it worked up to gains of 27 to 37 points on active months, but the advance attracted profit-taking and some hedge selling.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Dudley S. De Groot stepped out as head coach of the Los Angeles Dons of the All-America Football Conference today, a decision that occasioned no surprise here and led to the following interesting conjectures:

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- When the Council of Foreign Ministers meets in London next Tuesday there will be two proposed programs for discussion of the German and Austrian peace settlements and no agreement. This unhappy solution of weeks of fruitless discussions by the deputies of the Foreign Ministers here became a virtual certainty today.

A funeral service, attended, by a gathering that police described as unprecedented in the Bronx for such an occasion, was held yesterday morning for County Judge Lester W. Patterson in St. Jerome's Roman Catholic Church, 138th Street and Alexander Avenue, the Bronx.

The two sixteen-family apartment houses at 234 and 236 Greene Avenue, Brooklyn, have been purchased by the Dansker Realty and Securities Corporation from John Katzman in an all-cash transaction. The properties, assessed at $60,000, occupy a plot 96 by 100 feet.

SUMMIT, N.J., Nov. 18 -- The Marshall plan was depicted as the crux of difficult relations between the United States and Russia in the forum discussion of the problem "How Should We Deal With Russia?" held in Summit High School this afternoon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18 -- Trans-Atlantic Pictures, the Alfred Hitchcock-Sidney Bernstein producing company, has concluded a distribution contract with Warner Brothers for two projected productions, "Rope" and "Under Capricorn," which Hitchcock will produce and direct next year, Warners announced today.

Neither private interests nor Government authority can go very far in meeting the housing emergency unless they go together, Raymond M. Foley, Housing and Home Finance Administrator, told members of the National Association of Housing Officials yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- Arthur Lewis, 30-year-old Laborite Member of Parliament who was arrested last night outside the Savoy Hotel during a clash between pickets and police, appeared in court today and was charged with obstructing free passage of a highway.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In light of the current discussions on Palestine, a statement of some basic facts about the surviving Jews of Europe may be helpful.

YONKERS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Irvin E. Klein, a former Yonkers attorney who had been active in labor legal cases, died at his home in Los Angeles yesterday, according to word received here by relatives. He went to California seven years ago because of ill health.

Greatly expanded research, cost reduction through improved machinery and emphasis on design for competitive selling were set as goals yesterday for raising the three-billion dollar packaging industry higher on the list of the nation's ten leading businesses.
The members of the Eastern Ice Yachting Association gathered at a dinner last night in the Ruppert Brewery to discuss plans and put forth hopeful theories to prove that a cold winter is in prospect.

The recent temporary withdrawal of British buyers from the tobacco markets of Virginia and North Carolina, the famed "Old Belt" of bright leaf production, may be a factor in bringing about a reduction of from 25 to 30 per cent in tobacco acreages of the South in 1948.

OCEANSIDE, Calif., Nov. 18 -- In one of the most unusual moving projects ever undertaken, the "big eye," a 200-inch telescope mirror, was taken safely by road today more than halfway from the California Institute of Technology at Pasadena to the institute's Mount Palomar Observatory, 130 miles to the southeast.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 (U.P.) -- A three-judge Federal Court of Appeals today began debating whether Negroes had a constitutional right to vote in the South Carolina Democratic primary.

ATHENS, Nov. 18 -- Planning of the campaign against the Greek guerrillas will become a "joint Greek-American operation" when United States officers begin advising Greek forces, Dwight P. Griswold, head of the United States aid mission, said today at a press conference.

Nuts deserve attention now not only because they are one of the most abundant of the foods considered to be an integral feature of Thanksgiving but, what's more attractive, many varieties are lower in price than they were a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The chief argument among the politicians in both major parties here today is over this question:

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 18 -- "Flying squads" of radio experts to encourage programs that would help to maintain peace were recommended today to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization. The proposal was made by the program and budget commissions of the UNESCO General Assembly, meeting here.

Down South they're calling Charlie Conerly the "Ole Hit" of "Ole Miss" since his spectacular performance of last Saturday when he completed 20 out of 32 passes to set a new collegiate record of 120 completions for Mississippi.

Buyers' Total Lower Out-of-town buyers registered in the market for the week ended yesterday totaled 1,800, against 1,924 in the previous week and 2,455 in the similar week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

Coach Fritz Crisler's Michigan team was rated the nation's greatest gridiron machine yesterday in the weekly poll by The Associated Press with Notre Dame second and Southern Methodist University third. The largest number of football writers ever to take part in an Associated Press poll -- 246 -- participated.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- About 250 employes and delegation members of the United Nations will spend a three-day Christmas holiday as community guests in private homes in Binghamton, Endicott and Johnson City, N.Y.

Houston, Tex., Independent School District announced yesterday that it would take bids Dec. 12 on a bond issue to consist either of $5,004,000 of bonds due Jan. 10 from 1949 to 1954, or $5,000,000 of bonds due Jan. 10 from 1949 to 1974.

The news of last night's performance of "Carmen," the first of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House, was the debut here of Claudia Pinza as Micaela. Her father, Ezio, usually a central figure on the stage, sat in the auditorium with the other customers and listened, suffering, no doubt, from more nervousness than he has known in his own singing in years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Amateur women gardeners turned out in numbers at a Department of Agriculture hearing today to back up a Netherlands protest against further exclusions of Dutch nursery stock in any ruling Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson may make as to more plant quarantine restrictions under a law passed by the last Congress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- In envelopes of bills delivered by hand Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers drew heavy profits surreptitiously for four years from his secretly controlled war contracting company, the Senate War Investigating Subcommittee was told today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18 -- Noting that during the past two years many newcomers with new money and new ideas have been attracted to the carbonated beverage industry, Thomas F. Mansfield, Newark, president of the American Bottlers of Carbonated Beverages, warned today that the strength that should come from those additions to the industry may be lost unless all involved heed the basic rules of fair play and fair competition.

Mayor O'Dwyer opened the annual city-wide sale of Christmas Seals yesterday by buying the first sheet of stamps from Mrs. Mary Whitford, registered nurse, representing the New York, Brooklyn and Queensboro tuberculosis associations.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- President Truman's speech to Congress, the Geneva Trade Pact and Sir Stafford Cripps' announcement of "no change" in financial or monetary policy cheered stock markets here today.

Charmingly feminine brims and sailors in fresh light colors, enhanced by a liberal use of flowers and handsome ribbon trims, provided the main silhouettes for the showing of spring hats presented yesterday at the St. Regis by the Millinery Creators Guild.

A down-the-bay salute, a parade up Broadway and a City Hall welcome were given yesterday by New York to the world's current champion--food for the hungry mouths of Europe. Eight trucks laden with food rolled behind blaring bands from Bowling Green to City Hall at noon along the route of earlier parades of Channel swimmers, royalty and war heroes.
WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 18 (AP) -- A Trans-World Airline Constellation transport undershot the New Castle airport after a training flight today, crashed and burned, killing all five occupants.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 -- In ceremonies at Plymouth Rock tomorrow, Gov. Robert Bradford of Massachusetts, a ninth generation descendant of the first Governor of the Massachusetts Bay Colony who also originated Thanksgiving, will call upon Americans to share their Thanksgiving dinners with others, as did the Plymouth colonists with the Indians.
Seeking to locate in this area a hospital similar to the Kenny Institute of Minneapolis, the New York chapter of the Sister Elizabeth Kenny Foundation announced plans yesterday to raise $750,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- As the National Labor Relations Board officially began its investigation today of charges that members of Local 16, Chicago Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, are conducting slowdows of production in composing rooms of Chicago's six daily newspapers, the Chicago Newspaper Publishers Association charged that the AFL printers continued "their onerous loafing tactics."

Lack of "adequate and decent facilities" for unmarried mothers in this city is a "disgrace" and the black market in babies thrives on it, Justice Justine Wise Polier declared yesterday. She spoke at an all-day conference on adoption sponsored by the Spence-Chapin Adoption Service at the Hotel Pierre.

JAMES THOMAS FLEXNER, who has written of American medicine and American inventions in earlier volumes, has embarked on an ambitious series of books about American art. The first volume, "American Painting: First Flowers of Our Wilderness," is devoted to the pre-Revolutionary period.

The conviction that "equal educational opportunity is a matter of justice, and therefore of genuine concern to the Christian Church," was the basis on which the Human Relations Commission of the Protestant Council of the City of New York made an appeal yesterday for state legislation to end discrimination in education.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The CIO United Steelworkers Union appealed to the National Labor Relations Board today to rule that an employe retired at the age of 65 under a pension plan has been discharged and discriminated against if the terms of his severance have not been made a subject of collective bargaining.
Arbitration as a method of settling labor disputes threatens to destroy the American free enterprise system, John E. McCarthy, president of the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, said yesterday.

In appreciation of the financial rewards earned in the theatre over a period of twenty-five years as a lighting and sound expert, Edward F. Kook, 44-year old executive vice president of the Century Lighting Company, popularly known as "Kookie" to workers in the theatrical vineyard, is anxious to do something in return.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 18 -- Formation of a national third party under the leadership of former Vice President Henry A. Wallace was urged here today by Ben Gold, president of the International Fur and Leather Workers Union, CIO.

Skirts swirled and whirled the length of the seventh floor showroom at Russeks Fifth Avenue yesterday at a presentation of Henry Rosenfeld's midseason dresses. Gay in holiday and resort colors the clothes were wearable and, best of all, in a moderate price bracket.

Tariff concessions in the Geneva trade pacts published yesterday are a "blow" to those segments of United States industry, agriculture and labor that depend upon import duties to compete with products from countries with lower wage standards, the American Tariff League asserted yesterday.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- The United States moved today to hand the veto problem to the "Little Assembly" for year-round study and was immediately met with charges from the Soviet bloc that the campaign to water down the veto was deliberately aimed at destroying the United Nations.

The Harlem Savings Bank has sold the six-story thirty-seven-family apartment house at 220-226 Audubon Avenue, northwest corner of 176th Street, to the Audubon Management Corporation, represented by Reuben Lesser, attorney. Schimmer, Kerner Feder were the brokers.

To date $5,700,000 has been collected in the campaign to raise $15,575,000 for the projected New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, it was announced yesterday by Nevil Ford General Chairman of the Fund Campaign.

ROME, Nov. 18 -- For the first time since the end of the war, the army was called in today to quell civilian riots. Detachments of Italy's Ninth Infantry Regiment were rushed in trucks from Bari to the small town of Corato, twenty-five miles away, where two persons were killed when the carabinieri [militarized police] were obliged to open fire on a turbulent mob of strikers trying to take the police barracks by storm.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Secretary of State Marshall tonight branded Soviet propaganda against this country as "brazen and contemptuous" and declared "it is time to call a halt."

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Racing under the wire in a dead heat, J.L. McKnight's Bee W. Bee, and Thomas R. Queen's Plucky Boy today led the field home in the featured sixth race before 5,416 at Rockingham Park.

Enactment of legislation permitting the Public Schools Athletic League to arrange football schedules for its member schools, starting with the 1948 campaign, highlighted the monthly meeting of the High Schools Games Committee yesterday at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, endorsed today nine of President Truman's anti-inflation proposals but shrank from the tenth, price and wage controls, without flatly rejecting it.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 18 -- The Argentine University Federation, the largest student organization, issued last night a statement condemning the Peron government's domination of the universities.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- An investigation of the facts surrounding the scheduled annual meeting and election of the board of directors of the Standard Gas and Electric Company, a subsidiary of the Standard Power and Light Corporation, was begun today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Figure skating's first revue of the season, the Ice Follies of 1948, was presented last night at Madison Square Garden before 11,500 spectators. This marked the twelfth year that the Shipstads (Roy and Eddie) and Oscar Johnson brought their production to the big arena.

MARSEILLE, France, Nov. 18 -- Crew members of two United States ships in strike-bound Marseille supported 85,000 Communistled French dock workers today in demanding that Moroccan troops cease unloading vital coal and food cargoes.

The projected partitioning of Palestine can ease considerably the problem of displaced persons of Europe, Lewis Neikrug, director general for Europe of the Hebrew Sheltering and Immigrant Aid Society, declared here yesterday. Mr. Neikrug was among 400 passengers who sailed from Pier 88, North River, for Europe on the French liner De Grasse.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In a recent letter printed in THE NEW YORK TIMES George Elcaness asks "Who cries against NYU's 'appropriation' of [Washington] Square for a campus? It would appear to be the apartment and hotel owners, to whom the Square is a windfall, for they get rents far out of the true value of their rooms and flats because they front on the Square."

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 18 -- Philip Murray, president of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, asked the top officers of the CIO today to meet in Washington Dec. 2 to determine the attitude of the organization toward President Truman's foreign and domestic proposals.

In a letter on this page yesterday David Bernstein, who was an American adviser to two Presidents of the Philippine Commonwealth, has called attention again to the lack of material appreciation shown by the United States for the Filipino veterans who fought so valiantly against the Japanese.

Our Nautical Vocabulary In every department of our present-day activities in which they still survive the sailing vessel and the seafaring life of yesteryear, of which it is the symbol have a bit more of their importance whittled away except in the vocabulary of our English language.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18--The battle of Newark Bay ended in a negotiated peace today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The latest insurrection against the "old guard" in the Professional Golfers Association was quelled today as Ed Dudley unanimously was elected president for his seventh straight term.

The New York Knickerbockers, who played at Providence last night, will be in action again tonight at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory, opposing the Chicago Stags in a Basketball Association of America encounter. In their first two home games the Knicks defeated Washington and St. Louis.
The Consumer Service Section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- France, Italy and the Benelux Union (Belgium, Netherlands, Luxembourg) today signed an agreement growing out of the sixteen power conference to lay the cornerstone for European self-help in trade balances.
Holiday floral decorations for the home were displayed yesterday at the opening of a two-day show in New York Times Hall, 240 West Forty-fourth Street.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 18 -- In a major address delivered tonight before the New Orleans Foreign Policy Association at Tulane University, Harold E. Stassen made a direct plea to his party leaders in Congress to accept the foreign aid plan for Europe, as mapped in the Harriman report and the Marshall plan, without whittling it down a penny.

SOUTH NORWALK, Conn., Nov. 18 -- Although the noon opening seemed to have separated the men from the boys, the ducks at Nel's Island were plentiful, not too wild and due to the fairly stiff northwest wind they were on the move most of the day.

Two converted tank landing ships will sail simultaneously at 6 P.M. today from New York and Albany, reopening a trailer-truck delivery service between the two ports that has been hampered by labor disputes since its opening last Aug. 15.

HARTFORD, Conn., Nov. 18 -- The Right Rev. Frederick G. Budlong, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Connecticut, and Mrs. Henry Erskine Kelly were married today in Christ Church Cathedral here. The ceremony was performed by the Right Rev.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 17 -- With the Trusteeship Council scheduled to convene here Thursday, Britain and France are planning to submit a joint memorandum to the United Nations in an attempt to settle native dissatisfaction in the Togoland region of Africa, it was learned here today.

Representatives of organizations embracing persons of Ukrainian descent in the countries of North and South America will petition the United Nations General Assembly to halt what is termed "the deliberate policy of genocide being pursued by Soviet Russia and its satellite nations," which, they charge, is a threat to lasting peace.

TWIN investigations of the Jake LaMotta-Billy Fox fight (?) at Madison Square Garden last Friday already have been instituted by District Attorney Frank Hogan and Boxing Chairman Eddie Eagan. Better late than never. As soon as the bout ended, Eagan's lips set in a grim line and he hastened, to the rear of the Garden.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Grain prices soared early today on the Board of Trade, with corn in the lead. The December delivery of corn was up 6 cent a bushel at one time and within 2 1/8 cents of the seasonal peak before reacting under professional profit-taking and in sympathy with wheat.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Senator Robert A. Taft said tonight that he expected Congressional action to curb inflation would be limited during this session to three or four of the less-controversial items in President Truman's tenpoint program.
Following is the text of Secretary of State Marshall's speech in Chicago last night, as recorded by THE NEW YORK TIMES:

One of the Netherlands' highest honors, that of Grand Officer in the Order of Orange Nassau, was bestowed yesterday on the Right Rev. William T. Manning, retired bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York. Dr. Willem Cnoop-Koopmans, Consul General of the Netherlands, made the presentation in behalf of Queen Wilhelmina.
BOSTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Braves tonight traded Outfielder Johnny Hopp and Infielder Danny Murtaugh to the Pirates for Out-fielder Jim Russell, Pitcher Al Lyons and Catcher Bill Salkeld.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 18 (AP) -- H.L. Straus' Pilaster, from the mare Air Cooled, found the chilly atmosphere of the Bowie track to his liking today and ran off with the featured Hambleton Purse. Jockey Carson Kirk booted the Pilate gelding home four lengths in advance of the closest opposition in a field of six going a mile and seventy yards.

Harold Green, 158, Brownsville, subjected Nick Kashuba, 161, Brooklyn, to a severe beating in easily winning the main event of eight rounds last night before a sell-out crowd at the Broadway Arena, Brooklyn. Using a sharp left hook continuously and then hammering away at his foe's midsection in close fighting, Green had Kashuba on the verge of a knockout on three occasions.

How Lou Little ever brings his Columbia football team up to anything even approaching perfection of performance is a major mystery that was revealed anew yesterday to a visitor who appeared to watch a workout that was scheduled for 3 o'clock.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- If French exporters try to make a quick killing by raising prices as a result of the tariff cuts announced yesterday they will spoil their country's chances of getting the maximum amount of much-needed dollars, according to persons associated with the French-American tariff negotiations at Geneva.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Nov. 18 -- Prof. Robert F. Chambers, chairman of the chemistry department at Brown University, and wellknown philatelist and historian, died here in Jane Brown Hospital yesterday.

A.F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen, announced yesterday that he would join John L. Lewis and Philip Murray in refusing to sign non-Communist affidavits under the Taft-Hartley Labor Act.

A resolution calling upon the State Department to define clearly its policies of distribution of merchandise under the Marshall plan was adopted yesterday by the international trade section of the New York Board of Trade at a luncheon meeting at its offices, 291 Broadway.

ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- A sharp rise in the state's budget, which may exceed $70*0,000:000 for 1948-1949, was indicated today when Governor Dewey revealed that the 1948 Legislature would be asked to make an early deficiency appropriation of $6,120,000 to carry state institutions through the rest of this fiscal year.

Plans are being advanced rapidly for the card party,and Christmas sale in behalf of the National Cathedral in Washington to be held on the afternoon of Dec. 4 in the ballroom of the Colony Club under the auspices of the New York Committee of the National Cathedral Association.

Abraham Klorman has purchased the vacant irregular plot about 100 by 149 feet at the northwest corner of Pelham Parkway North and Wallace Avenue, the Bronx, from Richard and Elizabeth Hagedorn. Max Sakow was the broker in the transaction, in which the attorneys were John F. Frees for the sellers and Jack S. Glasser for the buyer.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Raymond S. McKeough, member of the Maritime Commission, said today that the Government had made commitments for sales of ninety-six tankers to foreign countries and could not, "in good conscience, back down."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Longrange projects set up in China by the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration will be turned over with the close of UNRRA's work in China, Dec. 31, to a fifteen-member board of trustees.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows:

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, stated yesterday that his union never had demanded that "Information Please" hire 300 musicians -- one for each station carrying the cooperatively sponsored program -- as the price of receiving the services of a single pianist.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Robert P. Patterson, former Secretary of War, told the President's Air Policy Commission today that the "feeble" condition of American air power was a "grave risk" in the present condition of world affairs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Instructions have been issued to the General Staff of the Army to make available to responsible inquirers all information about its activities in World War II, General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower said today.

The Board of Estimate hearing on the proposed capital budget really became a hearing on the five-cent fare, and the most eloquent witness present was that silent specter of a mounting transit deficit that warps our whole municipal economy.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Nov. 18 -- Officials of I.G. Farbeninduatrie now on trial here were accused today of knowing of the horrifying conditions under which inmates of the Oswiecim concentration camp lived and worked. The charge was made by the assistant prosecutor, E.E. Minskoff of New York.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., Nov. 18 -- An eight-point program of Federal tax revision was recommended here today by the National Machine Tool Builders Association at its annual fall meeting.

There are some rare artists who are interesting no matter what they play. Ania Dorfman, Russian pianist, who gave a recital last night at Town Hall, is one of them. It is largely because she has such lovely ideas.

The stock market staged yesterday its best rally in more than a month as strength in the pivotal issues spread to other sections of the list and produced average gains of about 1 1/2 points In the industrials. The market broadened out on the advance to include many stocks not recently traded more than the minimum, and left only 213 out of the 993 issue dealt in on the lower side at the close.

FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 18 -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay, the United States Military Governor, said today that aid to western Germany under the Marshall plan would entail about $2,200,000,000 over the next four years if present estimates, originally submitted confidentially to the sixteen-nation conference in Paris, were accepted.

BOSTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- British sailors whose vessel grounded and broke in two last Saturday off the northernmost tip of Newfoundland huddled on barren, wind-swept Sacred Island tonight while four rescue ships pounded through the ocean to save them from death by exposure.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Meeting in three sessions today, a United Nations subcommittee on Palestine virtually completed its report on the partition of the Holy Land. The subcommittee was spurred to added effort by the urgent pleading of Andrew J. Cordier, executive assistant to the Secretary General, on behalf of Assembly President Oswaldo Aranha to complete its work to meet the Assembly's time schedule.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Charges that James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, and the federation have violated the Taft-Hartley law were filed with the Chicago regional office of the National Labor Relations Board today by radio station WMLO of Milwaukee.

The issue of economic controls, especially in peacetime, is one that by its very nature invites excited controversy. Any program of the kind, regardless of its economic soundness or unsoundness, is certain to step on a great many toes, even under the most favorable circumstances.

BUFFALO, Nov. 18 -- A new anti-malarial drug which when Used with quinine will effect cures in 95 per cent of all malaria relapse cases has passed all clinical tests and is practically ready for commercial production, Dr. Robert C. Elderfield, Professor of Chemistry at Columbia University, stated here tonight.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 18 -- The forced resignation yesterday of a Popular Front party member, Jose R. Lemus, as administrator of the "National Intervened Plantations" is expected to result in a protest by his party to President Juan Jose Arevalo and to possible action by the Congress.

To bring opera to more people everywhere the Metropolitan Opera Association plans to make sound motion pictures of music dramas to be exhibited in theatres and rented or sold to schools and clubs, Edward Johnson, general manager, announced yesterday.

NANKING, Nov. 18 -- The Foreign Ministry is scheduled to issue soon a formal statement pressing the United States and Russia for action on China's compromise plan for settling the Japanese peace treaty deadlock.

YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Discussed United States proposal to refer veto problem to year-round "Little Assembly" for further study and heard Soviet bloc announce it would boycott interim committee's talks on veto and would not participate in any veto conference.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Determined opposition to a return of commodity rationing and price controls was expressed today by the National Association of Retail Meat Dealers, the Illinois Federation of Retail Associations and the Conference of American Small Business Organizations.

Word comes from London that the deputies of the Big Four Foreign Ministers have failed entirely to agree on an agenda for what may well turn out to be the last joint effort at peacemaking: the Marshall-Molotov-Bevin-Bidault conference which is scheduled to begin next Wednesday.

Dr. Junius Agnelli was on hand to tell about plans for Paul Governali Day. George Strickler was eager to extol the merits of the Green Bay Packers, and Stout Steve Owen was all for enlarging upon the improvement of the Giants.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Installment credit companies may be facing a shortage of money available for consumer credit and installment financing, Maxwell C. King, president of the Pacific Finance Corporation, Los Angeles, declared today in an address before the annual convention of the American finance conference.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- Plans to hold daily sessions of the full United Nations General Assembly, starting Friday and lasting until it adjourns, were completed today.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- So that the United Nations can implement its own "Marshall plan" for Trieste, a maximum of $5,000,000 was voted today for use in bolstering the economy of that free city.
MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Syl Apps, veteran play-maker of the National Hockey League leading Toronto Maple Leafs, continues to pace the circuit in individual scoring today.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Nov. 18 -- The International Civil Aviation Organization conference took a big step forward today by adopting a United States proposal on the arbitration and adjudication of disputes under the multilateral civil aviation agreement being drafted here.
