The executive committee of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America reaffirmed yesterday, by a vote of 28 to 14, its opposition to the establishment of compulsory military training "at this time."

A legislative investigation of boxing was in prospect with the announcement yesterday that State Democratic leaders would offer a resolution urging an inquiry into the State Athletic Commission and "various abuses in the sport."

An Autumn Ball was given last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza to raise funds for the Hospitalized Veterans' Music Service, an organization providing musical Instruction, to more than 1,600 amputees, paraplegics and other wounded service men in seven government hospitals in this area.

PRAGUE, Nov. 18 -- Premier Klement Gottwald was forced today to accept a compromise on the Slovak administrative Cabinet. His failure to get all that the Communists wished was regarded here as further evidence that the Czechs and Slovaks are made of different political stuff from that of some of their neighboring countries where the Communists have been making more rapid headway in getting rid of hindrances to their program.

LONDON, Nov. 18 -- King George, in a message to the House of Commons today, offered to dig into his savings to provide for Princes Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten for a period after their marriage.

A 54-year-old theatrical booking agent was arraigned yesterday as a material witness in the still-unsolved murder of Albert E. Langford, a textile company sales manager, who was shot dead in the doorway of his seventh-floor apartment in the Hotel Marguery, 270 Park Avenue, the night of June 4, 1945.

VIENNA, Nov. 18 -- Whether Russia will permit Austrians to reform their currency without charging a heavy price and, if Russia refuses, whether the reform can be achieved without her consent has become the subject of speculation in Vienna.

GRAVESEND, England, Nov. 18 -- The political spotlight in Britain is focused on this little waterfront town where, for the first time, the Conservatives are acknowledged to have a good chance of breaking the Labor party's unique record of more than two years in office without losing a single seat at a by-election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Senate Appropriations Committee decided today to measure its recommendations on the $597,000,000 interim European relief program in terms of food and supplies, rather than the usual dollars.
Business and industrial leaders expressed disapproval here yesterday of President Truman's plan for control of prices and materials.

Consolidated net sales of Ohrbach's, Inc., operator of specialty apparel stores in this city and Newark, N.J., in the fiscal year ended with last July, reached a new high of $34,346,365, and exceeded the $30,200,403 volume of the previous year by 13.7 per cent, according to the annual report of Jerome K. Ohrbach, president, and N.M. Ohrbach, chairman, mailed to stockholders yesterday.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York effectuated yesterday the last of this year's four bond refunding transactions by awarding at competitive sale an issue of $30,000,000 of twenty-five-year bonds to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., at an interest cost of about 2.975 per cent.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: I read with interest a news item in your columns last week regarding the fact that, New York City teachers are seeking a new "$800-a-year cost-of-living bonus."

OTTAWA, Ont., Nov. 18 -- Canada's drastic cut in imports from the United States is only a temporary measure destined to protect her dollar exchange position, Finance Minister Douglas Abbott and Reconstruction Minister C.D. Howe explained at a press conference this morning.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 -- A revised plan of disintegration for the American Power and Light Company was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission by H. Lane Ogle, an engineer and holder of blocks of preferred and common stocks of the company.

PARIS, Nov. 18--While efforts to strengthen the Government through an alliance of former Premiers Leoa Blum and Paul Reynaud stalled today, the Communist strike campaign gathered force in the form of walkouts that spread so far and so fast as to cause high officials to suggest that the long-awaited general strike might be near.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 18 -- The Eastern States Antiques Fair opened this afternoon at the Westchester County Center with one of the largest exhibitions in its history of twenty-five consecutive shows. One hundred and five dealers display their wares, with many having double their usual space.

While the European recovery program advanced by Secretary of State George C. Marshall is "nearer to being Christian than anything offered to Europe by a single government or by a group of governments for more than a generation," it still must be supplemented by "Christian forces of reconstruction," the Rev. Dr. Stewart W. Herman Jr., pastor of the American Church in Berlin before World War II, declared last night at the Riverside Church.

None the worse for their flight over the Atlantic and wishing they had made the trip years ago, five German grandmothers, two of them more than 80 years old, who will live with their children in the United States, arrived at La Guardia Field yesterday on an American overseas airliner from Berlin.

Although the story of Emily Dickinson is fragmentary and elusive, Dorothy Gardner comes closer to recapturing it than the playwrights who have preceded her. In "Eastward in Eden," which was acted at the Royale last evening, she is writing the character portrait of a New England poet who sought refuge in mysticism.

Noted authors and illustrators of children's books will take part in the Book Week festivities at the Boys and Girls Book Fair from Friday through next Monday at the American Museum of Natural History. Such favorites of young readers as Munro Leaf, Carl Glick, Robb White, Mae and Ira Freeman, Mrs. Syd Skolsky, Lois Fisher, Carolyn Haywood and Stephen Meader will greet the young visitors, acting as masters of ceremony or telling stories.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Bob Rodenberg, Washington sportsman and president of the Baltimore Colts in professional football, disclosed today that he was endeavoring to purchase controlling interest in the Browns and to transfer the St. Louis American League baseball franchise to this city.

LONDON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -- Princess Elizabeth is taking a great interest in the music to be played at her wedding. By her personal request a special descant (a tune superimposed on the original theme), has been composed for the Scottish metrical version of the Twenty-third Psalm, sung to the old Scottish tune "Crimmond."

The American people still have not been "sold" on the idea of world peace or the United Nations as the only real machinery for the atmosphere of peace, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt declared yesterday at the Hotel Astor.
New Issues of common stock valued at $56,968,333 will be offered preferentially today to stock-holders of the Phillips Petroleum Company and the Springfield Fire and Marine Insurance Company.

A new club for the 15,000 Swedish sailors who call regularly at the Port of New York was officially opened last night on the second floor of the Seamen's Church Institute of New York, 25 South Street.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Large and small businesses throughout the city are being subjected to great loss of time and money because of increasing traffic strangulation. Surveys, originating from many directions, all lead to the same conclusion. The over-all solution envisages a bold and comprehensive plan of broad spending and arterial redesign.

The New York City Housing Authority yesterday sold $11,121,000 of temporary loan notes due June 17 and Dec. 17, 1948, at net interest rates ranging from 0.8584 per cent to 0.92 per cent. Proceeds will be used to continue the temporary financing of Farragut and Alfred E. Smith Houses.

The investigation of the Jake LaMotta-Billy Fox fight by the District Attorney's office got underway yesterday when Bobby Gleason, former ring second for LaMotta, was questioned for several hours. Mr. Gleason, who manages a gymnasium at 430 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, where LaMotta usually trains, was not in the fighter's corner last Friday night.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Nov. 19 -- The Swedish Foreign Office announced tonight the recall of Claes Westring, Swedish Minister in Warsaw, "for consultation" following the Polish Government's demand that the Swedish Consul in Gdynia be withdrawn as persona non grata.

Thom McAn Prices Up 50 Cents Effective yesterday, the Thom McAn stores have raised prices of approximately two-thirds of their shoes 50 cents a pair to $6.45. The remainder continues at $5.95. Earlier this year the company reduced prices from $5.95 to $5.65, but restored them to the $5.95 level in August.

Special entertainment, designed children as well as their elders, the goal of Walt Whitman school's non-profit venture, Theatre Arts Program, it was announced yesterday. In conjunction with the school's Junior Dramatic Workshop, dramatizations, embellished with music, are to be presented under the direction of Maria Ley-Piscator.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- Paul Ramadier's tenacious ten-month struggle to find a middle way for France was characterized by compromises effected to show the world that her governments no longer were of the pre-war revolving door variety in which Cabinets fell, often with bewildering rapidity.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19 -- The deal for Will Rogers Jr. to play his late father in Warner Brothers' "The Life of Will Rogers" has been revived and Alex Gottleib will produce the picture next spring, with Michael Curtiz directing, the studio announced today.

Gifts of food and money by New Yorkers kept pouring in yesterday for the Friendship Train. With collections at the schools ended, police and fire houses still will accept today donations of the eight basic foods that are to go to the people of France and Italy.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Six prominent local business men who comprised the Bridgeton City Council in November, 1945, were indicted today by a hold-over April panel of the Cumberland County Grand Jury on three counts of misfeasance in office.

Establishment of a national policy to govern the employment of Communists in private industry was advocated by Eric Johnston last night in an address to the Picture Pioneers at their eighth annual dinner, held in the Plaza Hotel.

Since she made her debut at the age of 11 in 1939 playing at a musician's benefit at Madison Square Garden, and since she has appeared as soloist at the Lewisohn Stadium the summers of 1940, 1943 and 1946, one might have expected Teresa Sterne's first New York piano recital last night at Town Hall to reveal a young woman with a taste for large-scale playing.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 19 -- Attorney General Tom C. Clark said here today that as soon as the Senate War Investigating subcommittee completes its hearings the Justice Department will seek an indictment of Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers for evasion of income taxes.

CONCORD, N.H., Nov. 19 -- Governor Dewey received encouragement from New Hampshire Republican leaders today in his contest with Harold E. Stassen for that state's eight delegates to the 1948 Republican National Convention.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- A summary of the report submitted by Subcommittee 1 of the United Nations General Assembly's Ad Hoc Committee on Palestine follows: The report recommends a draft resolution for the General Assembly that would declare that the present situation in Palestine is likely to impair the general welfare and friendly relations among nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- When the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations today unanimously approved the bill to authorize a credit of $597 millions for stop-gap relief this winter in France, Austria and Italy, it assigned responsibility for handling the supplies to the personnel that already is engaged in making and supervising similar distribution through funds voted by Congress last May.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Princess Elizabeth will be married in Westminster Abbey tomorrow forenoon to His Royal Highness the Duke of Edinburgh. That is Lieut. Philip Mountbatten's new name and a part of his titles, conferred upon him by King George this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Initial reaction of Congressional leaders today to tariff concessions in the Geneva trade accord indicated that renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act next year would be subjected to hostile scrutiny. Severe restrictions of the Administration's power to negotiate such pacts were considered possible.

Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, criticized the state Yesterday for denying funds to the city to subsidize the five-year program now mandatory for secondary school teachers, while it used revenue from this city to finance the program in up-state colleges.

At present Coach Ed Danowski compares himself somewhat to a hunter with a double-barreled gun. Fordham's football chief is preparing to fire first at Holy Cross on Saturday but if the team fails to down that foe, there will be some ammunition left for the traditional fray with New York University a week later.

A tax study, representing a collaboration by Emil Schram, president of the New York Stock Exchange, and Franklin Cole Co., economic consultants, sharply criticises the present tax structure, according to a report of it issued yesterday.

With the debut of Cloe Elmo, mezzo-soprano from Italy, the Metropolitan Opera struck gold last night. Singing Azucena in Verdi's "Il Trovatore," Miss Elmo proved herself to be an artist of the first rank. It is a long time since a newcomer impressed her first New York audience so profoundly.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 19 -- Zionist leaders here are worried about rumored British plans to sell valuable state-owned lands. They hold that if the present Government carries out such sales, the future Jewish state would consider the sales invalid and would seize the lands.

Refusing to confirm or deny a report that the police have three suspects in the 1945 slaying of Albert E. Langford, textile sales manager, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan yesterday expressed considerable annoyance over alleged police leaks in connection with recent developments in the case.

The report of United Air Lines, Inc., for the third guarter of this year yesterday disclosed net earnings of $1,428,587, equal to 70 cents a share of common and management stock outstanding. In the corresponding three months of last year the net income was $1,502,571, or 80 cents a share.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Alan T. Clarke's Fritz Maisel, named for the one-time star infielder of the New York Yankees, was an easy winner of the co-featured $10,000 added Bowie Breeders' Stake to day.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 19 -- Lieut. Gen. John R. Hodge, United States commander in Korea, today issued a statement to the Koreans in which he assured them that the United States Government and its representatives here would give the fullest assistance to United Nations Commission supervision of elections.

The board of directors of the Cities Service Company declared a dividend of $1.50 a common share yesterday, payable on Dec. 19 to stockholders of record on Nov. 28. It was the first dividend declaration by the company since June, 1932.

Because of the world role now played by the United States, it is essential that American colleges and universities place greater emphasis on the teaching of international relations, according to Dr. Oliver C. Carmichael, president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- State allocations of funds for education amount to virtually twice as much a pupil in rural areas as in the more populous centers, with areas such as Westchester County steadily losing some of the percentage standing possessed in past years, State Senator Pliny W. Williamson of Scarsdale reported today to the County Board of Supervisors.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- As the main battle lines were drawn tonight for the future destiny of Palestine, it became known that a new British statement would be made here tomorrow to the Palestine committee of the United Nations General Assembly.

An increasing number of criminal prosecutions for tax fraud was predicted last night by Boris Kostelanetz, former special assistant to the Attorney General and chief prosecutor in the Lustig tax evasion case. The "criminal arm of the Government" in the field of tax evasion, once felt only among gangsters, bootleggers and corrupt politicians, he said, is now reaching into the ranks of business men whose "sole anti-social conduct was that of income tax evasion."

Thirty-one contests in swimming, wrestling and fencing have been scheduled for Columbia's athletes this winter, Ralph Furey, director of athletics, announced yesterday. This will give the Lions a total of fifty-three varsity engagements during the coming season, since a twenty-two game basketball list was announced earlier.

WHEN Glenn Scobie Warner was formally introduced to the Football Writers Association the other day he was presented as "the inventor of the single wing, the double wing -- and Jim Thorpe." They all were mighty fine inventions. As a matter of fact, the grizzled old strategist will be honored tonight by the Touchdown Club for his "outstanding contributions" to the sport.

BEDFORD VILLAGE, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Herman D. Kountze, of this place, retired New York banker, died yesterday in the Northern Westchester Hospital at neighboring Mount Kisco after a two-month illness at the age of 74. He belonged to a family long prominent in financial and social circles.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Her war with Newark's fleet of two fireboats called off after a negotiated peace signed in Washington yesterday, the 30,600-ton decommissioned battleship New Mexico was greeted with music, cheers and welcoming sirens as she was docked this afternoon by eleven tugboats at the Navy pier at Port Newark, where she is to be scrapped.

Announced as a Broadway prospect for late spring production is "Queen of the West," described as a musical dealing with "the romantic aspects of the building of the aqueduct that transformed the site of Los Angeles from a desert to a habitable land."

MOUNT PALOMAR, Calif., Nov. 19 -- Scientists moving the 200-inch "big eye," the world's largest telescope mirror, overland to the Mount Palomar Observatory, won a nip-and-tuck race with a mountaintop blizzard today.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Nov. 19 -- Former Lieut. Gen. Hubert janz, defendant in the trial "south-east generals" in the Palace of Justice, testified here today that he had twice defied direct orders from Adolf Hitler and on a third occasion had modified another order with no punishment other than a four-month suspension from active duty.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- Control of Ruhr coal production was handed over to the Germans today when the United States and British Military Governments transferred most of the powers of the British North German Coal Control to two German organizations.

Mayor O'Dwyer served notice yesterday that opposition from within political parties, including the Democratic organization, would not prevent him from pressing his campaign for a fare rise on the municipal transit lines sufficient to make them pay all operating expenses.

Opportunities for the packaging industry to win new markets for established products, particularly in the pharmaceutical exporting field, were outlined yesterday in closing sessions of the annual forum of the Packaging Institute at the Hotel Commodore.

Compulsory health insurance for low-income groups, financed through payroll deductions and some Government aid, was advocated last night by Bernard M. Baruch as vital to the attainment of adequate medical care for all the people of the United States.
For the third time this season, a center has been selected in The Associated Press poll as football's lineman of the week.

The stock market pushed ahead yesterday to the resistance level of two weeks ago, the price average rising about a point on the day. The follow-through extended to many sections of the list but by passed the motors and steels where early increases failed to hold.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 19 -- The bells of Nassau Hall rang Saturday as Princeton celebrated its first victory over Yale since 1941. This week the champions of the Big Three are looking for their first triumph over Dartmouth since 1940 as they ring down the curtain in Palmer Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Leonard C. Calhoun, attorney for the National Tax Equality Association, testified today that survival of taxpaying business is in danger if taxes take a large part of its earnings while-competing cooperatives pay little or no taxes.

LONDON, Thursday, Nov. 20 -- Against the historic gray background of Westminster Abbey and the colorful fashions of assembled royal wedding guests, Princess Elizabeth and her bridal entourage will provide a brilliant contrasting symphony in ivory white.

A "narrowly conceived and selfish nationalism" may defeat the purposes for which the International Trade Organization is being formed, according to a report to the State Department by the International Chamber of Commerce, made public here yesterday.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee of the National Board of Review, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recomends as suitable for children between the ages of 8 and 14, a group of motion pictures to be shown, tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

ROME, Nov. 19 -- A revealing commentary on the Italian political situation was made this morning by the Liberal party paper, Risorgimento Liberale, which stated that the black market price of tommy-guns had doubled in the last two weeks.

Of all our holidays, Thanksgiving is perhaps the one we should like to share most with other nations. Governor Bradford of Massachusetts has had a happy and heart-warming thought that this year of 1947 makes it possible for Americans to carry a spirit of Thanksgiving to people in many parts of the world.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Federal observers here see signs of a possible split or a "readjustment of forces" leading to a split in the international labor movement centering around the World Federation of Trade Unions. These are the signs:
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- The old problem of the veto was passed on to the United Nations' brand-new "Little Assembly" today by the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly.

A public bond issue will be floated in the Philippines this month by the Rehabilitation Finance Corporation to capitalize one-fourth of the Government's partnership enterprise with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for the establishment and operation of an electrical manufacturing plant in Manila.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Nov. 19 -- The Supreme Court In Johannesburg has confirmed its provisional order of Oct. 27 placing the group known as New Union Goldfields, Ltd., under judicial management.

Mrs. Russell Holman of Innis Arden, chairman of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association nominating committee, announced yesterday the following ticket that will be elected for next year at the annual meeting of the association at the Hotel Shelton on Thursday, Dec. 4:

SOMERVILLE, N.J., Nov. 19 -- Francis Lockwood Brokaw was found dead yesterday under a tree on the farm where he was born sixty-one years ago and where he had lived in boyhood. He had been nationally known for his handling of insurance company stocks.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The President's Committee on Foreign Aid reported to the nation. The report is lucid and straightforward, although the philosophy applied in it is hemmed in and restricted by the assignment: "the limits within which the United States could safely and wisely extend aid to Western Europe."

Colors were lowered yesterday for the 10,500-ton Liberty ship Booker T. Washington, which was launched five years ago at Los Angeles, Calif., under the command of Captain Hugh J. Mulzac, first Negro in this country to become master of a merchant ship.
BOSTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Boston Bruins regained the National Hockey League lead tonight by defeating Toronto's Maple Leafs, 7 -- 2, before a crowd of 13,900 at the Boston Garden.

Dan Topping, president of the football Yankees, fired a few rounds yesterday aimed in the general direction of Tim Mara, head of the rival National Football League Giants. They were in response to Mara's animadversions about the All-America Conference in general and the Yankees in particular.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 19 -- Mexico never will agree to the principle of absolute world free trade, Finance Minister Ramon Beteta Quintana declared before his departure today to attend the world trade and employment conference in Havana as chairman of the Mexican delegation.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 19 -- Governor Dewey accused the Kremlin tonight of an attempt to keep American aid from the starving peoples of free nations "so they too, may fall prey to the cold aggression of totalitarian Russia."

Featuring imported English suede in custom-made suits and coats and worsted tweeds and gabardines trimmed with suede, the Sport and Travel Shop, 511 Madison Avenue, presented a fashion show at the Hotel Pierre yesterday.
The majority of the reports received on the opening of the duck season on Barnegat Bay were excellent, but broadbill and blackduck predominated in most of the bags.

Bruce Gehrke of Floral Park, L.I., will end his Columbia football career Saturday by acting as game captain for the Lions against Syracuse at Baker Field. This was announced yesterday as the Light Blue squad went through its nextto-last practice scrimmage of the season.

Five key officials of the City Welfare Department testified yesterday that the shortage of trained relief workers was responsible for the city's difficulties in administering a relief program of $142,000,000 a year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninetyfour leading cities, the Federal Reserve Board. announced today, shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 12: An increase of $181,000,000 in commercial, industrial and agricultural loans, decreases of $161,000,000 in holdings of Treasury certificates of indebtedness and $177,000,000 in demand deposits adjusted, and an increase of $149,000,000 in borrowings.

President Gideonse of Brooklyn College laid down in no uncertain terms yesterday the facts that support one fair and proper demand on Albany for financial aid to New York City. New York State is granting substantial help to the training of teachers when that training is given in upstate colleges.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 19 (AP) -- The University of Nebraska student council today recommended that unless what members interpreted as a racial discrimination clause in Big Six athletic rules was deleted, Nebraska should quit the conference.

Helping the victims of inflation in France is among the new activities of the Salvation Army, Mrs. Taylor Cochran, chairman of the women's division for the 1948 Salvation Army Annual Maintenance Appeal, said yesterday. She has just returned from a four-month tour of France and England.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Grain markets were unsettled on the Board of Trade today. Liquidation by holders of December wheat caused that delivery to lose ground, while the distant months were strong, the new crop months leading. Closing trades were 1 1/4 cents a bushel lower to 2 cents higher than yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Continued expansion in coal and steel output, plus a crop of good dividend reports sent industrial shares up in the stock markets here today. All groups advanced and prices generally closed at the top.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 19 -- The United Steelworkers of America, CIO, with 875,000 members, will maintain its policy of aloofness toward the National Labor Relations Board and the Taft-Hartley Law. The union's executive board of forty-one voted unanimously at its closing fall session not to sign nonCommunist affidavits.

Speedy action by Congress in creating a commission or Government corporation, with a single executive head, to administer both interim aid to Europe and to get organized for the second "tough but delicate" phase of assisting reconstruction of European production was urged yesterday by Philip D. Reed, chairman of the board of the General Electric Company.

Simplicity and diversity marked the collection of spring millinery presented yesterday by Madame Andree at her shop, 63 East Fiftyseventh Street. The pillbox, well thought of by this designer, was shown in several versions, many with ribbons that tied beneath the chin.

The Ballet Theatre opened its fall season at the City Center last night and again proved itself to be a company without a peer. It has recently undergone a sweeping renovation of its ensemble and minor soloists, but it was as supremely poised and sure of itself on this occasion as if its equilibrium had never been disturbed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The record made by American home builders was proclaimed today at the meeting of the Construction Industry Advisory Council of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States.

In his Chicago speech, delivered on the eve of his departure for London, Secretary Marshall sought to counteract a development which has played an increasing role in international affairs, namely, the Russian propaganda campaign against the United States.

The public must have more accurate and understandable information about the working of the food conservation program before it will cooperate wholeheartedly, Dr. Leonard A. Maynard, director of the School of Nutrition, Cornell University, a member of the New York State Food Commission, declared yesterday.

Enactment of the Taft-EllenderWagner national housing bill, while essential, should be only the first step in a "wartime housing program," Representative Jacob K. Javits declared last night. The Manhattan Republican told members of the National Association of Housing Representatives, meeting at the Hotel New Yorker, that such a program would do nothing to interfere with European aid.

SALEM, N.H., Nov. 19 (AP) -- After running fourth most of the way, the Mount Desert Stable's Halomer passed the leader in the stretch to win the $5,000 Tom Thorp Memorial Handicap before a crowd of 7,614 at Rockingham Park today.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- As the westbound Empire State Express cut a ribbon this afternoon the New York Central System opened service over a 6,400-foot cut-off to eliminate a sharp turn known as "Gulf Curve" in a narrow gorge and permit maximum speed on the four tracks here.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Negotiations between the railroads and three operating unions on employe demands for a 30 per cent pay rise and forty-four changes in working rules ended abruptly today, with both sides openly hostile.

TOKYO, Nov. 19 -- Emperor Hirohito has been compelled by the dwindling fortunes of the reigning family to scrap the imperial Poetry Bureau, which for years conducted the Emperor's annual poetry contest, one of the traditions of Japan.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Four "task forces" have been organized within the Commission on the Organization of the Executive Branch of the Government to scrutinize separate fields of the problem, Herbert Hoover, its chairman, reported today.

Though Brussels endive is as common a vegetable in Europe as carrots are here, this member of the chicory family is more or less a rarity at the American greengrocer's. Most of what we do see -- it's beginning to appear in stores here now as the season gets under way-comes from Belgium, the only country that has been able to grow it successfully.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Nov. 19 -- A ruthless political coup has just been executed here with the tacit support of President Gen. Higinio Morinigo. It has led diplomatic and other observers to the conclusion that the dark, high-strung man who has ruled as dictator for six years has by no means made up his mind to step down even if the promised elections take place in February.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Ambassador Robert D. Murphy of the United States blamed the Soviet delegation today for the inability of the foreign ministers' deputies to agree on the agenda for the Big Four Council conference or on anything else in the last ten days. He termed the Soviet tactics and statements "unfair and untrue."

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- A summary of the report submitted today by subcommittee 2 of the United Nations General Assembly's Committee on the Palestine question follows: INTRODUCTION At the outset the subcommittee decided to concentrate on three broad issues: 1. The legal questions arising from the Palestine problem.

ROMSEY, England, Nov. 19 -- This picturesque old Hampshire village, within whose bounds Princess Elizabeth and Lieut. Philip Mountbatten, the new Duke of Edinburgh, will spend the first half of their wedding trip, had by a great last-minute effort fully decorated itself tonight for tomorrow's welcome.
ST. ANTHONY, Nfld., Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- The whaler Olaf Olsen today rescued forty-one, shipwrecked seamen marooned on desolate, Sacred Island in the Straits of Belle Isle for five days and nights.

The local television industry is giving serious consideration to the idea of joint construction of a "television city" to effect economies in operation, it became known yesterday. The project, which is still only in the early talking stage, is known to have the indorsement of Mayor O'Dwyer and Robert Moses, Park Commissioner.

A new overhead monorail system for the loading and unloading of ships and using high-speed electric hoists remotely controlled by radio, was announced yesterday by Charles E. Dougherty, president of both the Carter Weeks Stevedoring Company and the Trenton Marine Service Corporation.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Labor Members of Parliament unanimously expressed their "full confidence" today in Hugh Dalton, who resigned as Chancellor of the Exchequer last week following an "indiscreet" disclosure of budgetary secrets.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: Arthur Krock's appraisal, in THE TIMES of Oct. 31, does insufficient justice to Representative Taber's ability to distinguish "between porch-climbers and those who could enter by the front door" (of the United States Treasury).

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Dr. Robert C. Clothier, president of Rutgers University, today announced "several bowl bids have been received," but that Rutgers would not play any post-season football games. Dr. Clothier praised the record of the squad, which has won seven games after bowing to Columbia, 40 -- 28, in the first contest.

Gasoline stocks of the nation last week increased to 83,041,000 barrels from 82,007,000 the week before, but declined from the supplies of 88,108,000 for the corresponding week of last year, according to yesterday's report of the American Petroleum Institute.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Persistent rumors that the Department of Agriculture had huge food stocks in storage as a result of purchases under the mandatory price-support program were denied today by Secretary Clinton P. Anderson.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- The campaign to counter Soviet propaganda in Germany is bogging down as the result of a shifting policy and the absence of any real propaganda agency in the United States Military Government.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 19 -- This city's war on gamblers, started by Mayor Fred M. DeSapio, leader of the reform administration, backfired early today when four conscientious policeman raided the clubhouse of the Fred M. DeSapio Democratic Association, arresting five men, one of them the Mayor's secretary.

Led by individual winner, Donald Anderson, Fordham Prep upset Bishop Loughlin for the team title yesterday in the twenty-fifth annual Athletic Association of Private Schools cross - country championship at Van Cortlandt Park. The Little Rams thus ended the fourteen -year domination of the Brooklyn school in this meet.

Defeat caught up with the New York Knickerbockers for the first time in the Basketball Association of America season last night. After three straight triumphs, in which they showed to advantage over Washington, St. Louis and Providence, the Knicks met their masters, bowing to the Chicago Stags, 81-63, before 5,231 fans at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A bill to authorize emergency relief up to the full $597,000,000 proposed for France, Italy and Austria was approved unanimously by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

The Kings County Council of the Veterans of Foreign Wars will request Mayor O'Dwyer and the Board of Education today to conduct a "sweeping Investigation" of the city's public school system, it was announced last night by Daniel J. O'Neil, council commander.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- B.H. Lamarre swore today that he sat in his living room and docilely accepted explicit orders from Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers to blacken and perjure himself in behalf of the general. He rebelled and determined at last to "tell the truth," he declared, only after months of trying to protect the general.

The Board of Higher Education rejected last night by a 10 to 6 vote an amendment to its by-laws that would have banned subversive groups from the campuses of New York's four municipal colleges. The decision was reached after almost four hours in closed session at Hunter College, Park Avenue and Sixty-eighth Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Unions won thirty out of thirty-one union shop elections in October, but lost four out of five decertification elections, the National Labor Relations Board reported today. The month brought 964 new cases.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Weekly pay envelopes still buy more than they did in 1939, despite the price rises. The extent of the improvement varies by industries, with John L. Lewis soft coal miners far in front of the field.

The Consumer Service Section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and, save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: For a meat dish that embraces good eating and economy serve a Peace Plate of Pan-Fried Liver with fried onions, well-seasoned canned corn, cole slaw and a DeepDish Orange Apple Pie for dessert.

Peace, like a poultice, has descended on Newark Bay to heal the wounds of the famous battle that never took place. Future naval strategists will never know now whether a couple of fire-tugs with streaming hose can repel an aged battleship with holes bored in the barrels of her fourteen-inch guns.

Possible re-imposition of price controls on clothing and apparel has not affected purchasing policies on women's coats, suits or dresses for spring, according to resident buyers yesterday. Out-of-town buyers winding up their early spring purchases have not been influenced by President Truman's program for halting inflation, it was indicated.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today found that the crash of a Capital Airlines' four-engine transport on June 13 in West Virginia, which took fifty lives, was due to action by the pilot, Horace Stark, in flying below a level of 3,000 feet.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The United States in a note to Rumania given out by the State Department today formally protested charges made in "devious fashion" during the recent trial of former Premier Juliu Maniu in Bucharest that United States representatives had been part of a conspiracy to overthrow the Rumanian Government by force.
Irregularity developed in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and closing prices were 7 points higher to 33 points lower than the day before.

LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Britain's Boxing Board of Control, reversing a previous decision after reviewing what it described as new evidence, tonight handed back to Jackie Paterson of Glasgow, Scotland, the world flyweight boxing title it had taken from him last July.

Contributions of $730,272 to the United Hospital Fund, solicited by the women's division for Manhattan and Bronx, have brought the city total from all sources to $1,601,933, it was announced yesterday by Mrs. Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the division.

Penn State's rock-ribbed football defenses successfully survived their Navy shelling last Saturday, but not without acquiring some irreparable dents in their aspiration to set a new total-defense record, The Associated Press reports.

MARSEILLE, France, Nov. 19 (U.P.) -- Heavy troop reinforcements and a number of tanks arrived in Marseille today. Approximately 1,000 soldiers reinforcing a large number already here moved through the streets of Marseille late today aboard trucks and armored cars.

This is the day when Princess Elizabeth is being married in Westminster Abbey to Philip Mountbatten. We regard it as a fine thing when young people in love get married. When the bride is a Princess it is an occasion for gaiety in grim England, beset in peace with troubles almost as burdensome as those of war.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 19 -- Warren R. Austin, permanent United States delegate to the United Nations, today evaluated this session of the General Assembly as the "most significant" in the organization's history, with many evidences of progress.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Senator Robert A. Taft's plan to expedite Congressional consideration of Presidential recommendations for curbing prices fell through today when House leaders declined to go along with the idea of joint hearings by three committees.

Moore-McCormack Lines, operators of the Good Neighbor Fleet in the New York-South American route, announced yesterday that reconversion work on the three 20,000-ton liners Uruguay, Argentina and Brazil would be speeded up, with the country's major repair yards returning to full volume after the long strike.

It was an unfortunate conjunction of events which decreed that Canada should introduce sweeping embargo and quota restrictions on American products almost at the very moment when our own State Department was announcing the details of the 123 trade treaties negotiated at Geneva -- treaties which add up to the most ambitious program of tariff reduction of our time.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- The resignation of Leo T. Crowley as chairman of the board of directors of the Standard Gas and Electric Company was demanded by a majority of the board members because he was "not the type of executive to administer the office," Robert J. Levy of New York, a director of the company, told the Securities and Exchange Commission today.

Victor Serge, a disillusioned Russian Communist who had long lived in exile, died Tuesday night in his home in Mexico City of a heart attack, at the age of 57, according to word received here yesterday at the offices of The New Leader, 7 East Fifteenth Street.

Wednesday, Nov. 19, 1947 YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Committee 1 (Political and Security) -- Approved, 36 to 6, with 11 abstentions, United States proposal to refer veto study to "Little Assembly" and Big Five in Security Council; approved new rules in relation to admission of new members and noted report of Security Council, thus completing its work.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- With France in a serious labor crisis, James B. Carey, secretary-treasurer of the Congress of Industrial Organizations, arrived here today for labor conferences that will include meetings with leaders of the Communist -dominated French General Confederation of Labor.
Furs designed for holidays down South were presented by DeinBacher of the Waldorf yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in a showing entitled: "Palm Beach at Christmas."
LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Warmed by a family feeling of affection and intimacy Londoners welcomed the pageantry and glamour of a royal wedding tonight despite the pinch of every day existence.
Accounts Sardik Food Products Corporation to Julian Scott Advertising. All media will be used in a 1948 campaign.

Aluminum Goods Declaration of a 40-cent dividend plus an extra of 25 cents was announced yesterday by the Aluminum Goods Manufacturing Company for payment on Dec. 15. An extra of 75 cents was also declared, payable on Jan. 31, bringing total declarations for the current year to $2.75, compared with $1.25 in 1946.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Maurice Richard's goal with 63 seconds of play remaining in the third period gave the Montreal Canadiens a 2-2 tie with the Chicago Black Hawks before 16,149 tonight in a rough game in which 17 penalties were called, including two majors and a misconduct.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 19 -- The National Aviation Clinic at its opening session today bitterly attacked alleged ineptitudes of the Civil Aeronautics Administration and Board as delaying the national airport program.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The text of the $597,000,000 foreign-aid bill as approved today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee follows: To promote the general welfare, national interest, and foreign policy of the United States by providing supplies to certain European countries on an emergency basis.

Princes at the wheel From time to time this corner has had occasion to pay deserved attention to New York's taxi - drivers. But these gentlemen belong to a brotherhood which is an international institution, and, as such, like the U.N., is charged with grave responsibilities and armed with privileges and immunities.

MR. VISHINSKY, who seems to be doing more to unite the American people than anything since Pearl Harbor, probably won't like John Gilbert Winant's "Letter from Grosvenor Square"* because it considers international affairs in a Lincolnian mood of malice toward none and charity for all. Mr. Winant's report on his stewardship as our Ambassador to Britain is balanced, just and humane.

VIENNA, Nov. 19 -- The new Austrian currency law, which was approved by Parliament tonight and next goes to the secretariat of the Allied Council for confirmation on Friday, cancels more than 11,000,000,000 schillings [about $1,100,000,000] of hitherto frozen deposits in Austrian banks and financial institutions.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- President Truman, at luncheon with Democratic leaders at the Capitol, chose the occasion today to appeal for national unity in dealing with international problems.

Frances Magnes, a young violinist of special gifts and certain present limitations, gave a recital before a packed house last night in Carnegie Hall. She is the daughter-in-law of the Rev. Judas Magnes, president of the Hebrew University in Jerusalem.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Dismissal of nine Army civilian employes on disloyalty grounds, six of them because of Communist connections, was reported by the Army today.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The suggestion made through your column by N. Henry Josephs that it would be helpful if the city would send some of its patients to voluntary hospitals and alleviate the great overcrowding in city hospitals is of considerable interest.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 13,000 head, total 25,500; market very slow: early sales 10 to 15 cents lower; later trade and close 15 to 25 cents lower; sows around 25 cents off; top 524.85; bulk of

A four-point attack on high costs of operation in the five billion dollar industrial distribution field was opened yesterday by more than 250 manufactures and distributors who met in a joint regional conference of two industry trade associations in the Robert Treat Hotel, Newark, N.J.
PARIS, Thursday, Nov. 20 -- Premier Paul Ramadier resigned last night and France had only a caretaker government today as she faced the gravest strike threat since the war.
A double-barreled attack on unemployment insurance chiseling has been started by the State Labor Department, it was learned yesterday.

Plans to establish the American Jewish Conference on a permanent basis to coordinate all Jewish activities in this country were opposed yesterday by Lessing J. Rosenwald, president of the American Council for Judaism. He stressed that Jews here were not a political entity, and that therefore "it is impossible for any individual or single agency to speak politically for them in a democratic way."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 -- The amended plan of reorganization filed by the American and Foreign Power Company, Inc., providing for a shift of allocations of assets from the public holders of the company's second preferred and common stocks to the public holders of the first preferred stock was approved today by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The congregation of Central Synagogue and virtually all of the 180 children in its religious school will attend a ceremony Sunday at 11 A.M. in front of the structure at Lexington Avenue and Fiftyfifth Street. The dedication and blessing of four plane trees, the gift of Louis Samler of 875 Fifth Avenue, an active parishioner, will take place.

Outstanding local craftsmen have pooled their talents for the first Christmas show and sale opened yesterday by Craftsmen's Equity at the Barbizon-Plaza galleries. The newly formed group aims to put crafts on a business basis without sacrificing the individuality inherent in handmade articles, Arpad Rosti, president, explained at the preview.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Scoring three times within less than two minutes in a wild second-period splurge, the New York Rangers carved out a 6-to-5 National Hockey League victory over the Detroit Red Wings tonight before 11,737 fans at the Olympia.

Study of more than 800 cases of injury in airplane accidents showed that the snubbing action of safety belts is not injurious to passengers, Hugh De Haven, director of a project in crash injury at the New York Hospital - Cornell Medical Center, reported yesterday.
If the Municipal Art Society of New York has anything to say about it, the City's streets--most of them barren stretches of brick and concrete now--will become tree-lined thoroughfares.

PLYMOUTH, Mass., Nov. 19 -- Amid scenes of pageantry, in which Pilgrims and Indians walked again through historic streets, the original Thanksgiving was re-enacted with solemnity today, and Governor Robert Bradford of Massachusetts, standing directly before Plymouth Rock, called upon every American family to give the equivalent cost of one Thanksgiving dinner to buy a meal for a European.

A resolution declaring that administration of relief cannot be improved "merely by the negative step of dramatizing improper handling of individual cases" and urging the appointment of a special committee to "review the findings of both city and state investigations" on public assistance, was adopted unanimously yesterday at a meeting in the Henry Hudson Hotel of the Welfare Council of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Navy men who salvaged a sinking German freighter off Brazil six years ago, one month before the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, today began receiving checks for their exploits.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 19 -- Premier Petru Groza has indicated in recent days that there are no immediate plans to change the constitutional relationship between King Michael, the only reigning monarch behind the "Iron Curtain," and his Government, whose largest party is committed to the creation of a Communist, classless Rumania.

LONDON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Princess Elizabeth, as nervous as any commoner bride, walked up the aisle today in Westminster Abbey in a final private rehearsal for her wedding tomorrow to Lieut. Philip Mountbatten.

To meet rising: demands for petroleum, products, the Socony- Vacuum Oil Company is extending the period of service of vessels in its tanker fleet before they are sent to drydock for overhaul, it was reported yesterday.

Dimitri Mitropoulos, who made his first appearance as guest leader of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, is one of the strangest and most curiously gifted conductors that the American public knows.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- T.P. Wright, Civil Aeronautics Administrator, said today that eleven scheduled airlines and airports in thirty-nine cities were ready to begin using instrument landing systems this winter.
SALEM, N.H., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Shaffie, the star 3-year-old from Little Rhody Farm, won the featured Franconia Purse at Rockingham Park today before a crowd of 6,492.

ATHENS, Nov. 20 -- Greek Government quarters learned today that Dwight Griswold would carry on as chief of the United States mission for aid to Greece after the State Department had cancelled a directive that would have shifted the authority for all major decisions from him to United States Ambassador Lincoln MacVeagh.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Financial control of Consolidated Vultee Aircraft (Convair) Corporation today passed to Floyd B. Odlum of New York and Indio, Calif., president of the Atlas Corporation.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 20 -- Karol Peyer, former Premier and once leader of the Right Wing Hungarian Socialists, has fled Hungary and is believed to have sought safety in Austria or Germany.

On the assumption that Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower is likely to be the Republican nominee for President, Dr. Alvin Johnson, president emeritus of the New School for Social Research, yesterday called upon President Truman to decline to run for election and make way for the nomination of Secretary of State George C. Marshall by the Democratic party.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- The United Nations will end a three-month gap in its laborious search for atomic energy control early in December and is expected to face the final deadlock between the ten-nation majority and the Soviet-Polish minority.

As President of the United Nations General Assembly, Dr. Oswaldo Aranha of Brazil appealed directly yesterday to the fifty-seven member nations to help the children's emergency fund increase its "pitifully small" financial resources.

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- As was to be expected, attendance in the stock markets here today was almost negligible as most members took the day off to see the royal wedding. Despite the resulting paucity of business, prices generally remained firm, with new gains recorded throughout the industrial list.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Senate Banking and Currency Committee listed today four of President Truman's anti-inflation proposals for early action, scheduling hearings on them to begin Monday.

Mrs. Rose Russell, legislative representative of the Teacher's Union, CIO, urged last night that the Greater New York CIO Council throw its support behind Isadore Rubin, high school English teacher who was suspended yesterday by Dr. William Jansen, Superintendent of Schools, for conduct unbecoming a teacher.

The Committee for the Marshall Plan to Aid European Recovery will start to circulate on Monday a petition calling for the support of the program, it was announced yesterday. In line with what former Secretary of War Robert P. Patterson, chairman of the executive committee, yesterday called an appeal "to whole-hearted citizen support," one million signatures will be sought for presentation to the Congress.

With an anxious nation joining President Truman's "God speed and good luck," Secretary Marshall has gone to London for another and possibly last conference of the Big Four Foreign Ministers. It is a conference which must determine whether the grand alliance that won the Second World War can still write a joint peace, or whether the victors have come to a parting of the ways.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- The development of a new chemical insecticide that is effective against a wider range of insects, mites and other lower invertebrates than any chemical now in practical use, including nicotine, rotenone and DDT, was announced today by the American Cynamid Company.

"Watch the Engineers" is the title of a special demonstration to be given by Station WQXR in connection with THE NEW YORK TIMES YOUTH Forum being broadcast tomorrow, from the auditorium of the American Museum of Natural History during the Boys' and Girls' Book Fair there.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended Nov. 15, 1947, totaled 878,337 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 31,823 cars or 3.5 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 38,787 cars, or 4.2 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 77,803 cars, or 9.7 per cent more than during the corresponding week two years ago.

BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- Reaction on a nation-wide basis to the "Silent Guest Plan" of Gov. Robert Bradford of Massachusetts was so heavy in the first day after its launching that neither the Governor's office here, nor headquarters for the drive in Plymouth, could tabulate the contributions nor the telegraphic promise of support that has poured in.

Making a selection that doubtless surprised most fans, the Baseball Writers Association of America announced yesterday that its twenty-four-man committee had named Bob Elliott, third baseman for the Braves, as the National League's most valuable player of 1947.
When some service vital to the people's welfare, such as mass transportation, is involved in a labor dispute that threatens to become a paralyzing strike the routine is familiar.

A growing opposition to Soviet tactics behind the Iron Curtain, as evidenced by recent purges, was underscored last night by Herbert Hoover as indicative of a restiveness that ultimately would blossom into revolution.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- Promising "plenty more deals," General Manager William O. De Witt of the Browns today denied that his club was selling its stars recklessly and added that the Browns were seeking players "who don't have a defeatist complex."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Commerce Department said today it was "likely" the proposed St. Lawrence Seaway could handle annually up to 53,000,000 tons of iron ore, grain and coal in contrast to the 25,000,000 tons previously estimated.

CHICAGO. Nov. 20 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the United States Department of Agriculture follows: HOGS Salable hogs 11,500 head, total 25,500; market fairly active and uneven, strong to 25 cents, mostly 15 to 25 cents, higher on all weights butchers: sows scarce, fully 25 cents

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 20 -- Latin America succeeded today in outvoting the official nominating committee's choice of the Philippines to occupy the vacancy on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization's executive board when Dr. Benjamin Carrion of Ecuador was elected at a plenary session of the assembly being held here.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Charles Luckman bowed out as active head of the Government's food conservation program today, but President Truman said in accepting his retirement that the campaign to save grain for Europe must continue and "be intensified."

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- President Vincent Auriol nominated the veteran Socialist Leon Blum as Premier tonight after a day of intense consultations, during which M. Blum's acceptance seemed doubtful until the last moment.

The stock market completed yesterday the process of erasing the losses sustained earlier this month and, although the advance was magnified by some spectacular increases in a few stocks, the average rise again was about a point. Tax selling proved a drawback to some sections of the list but this was offset by dividend announcements and proposed stock splits.

The consumer service section of the Citizens food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today: Besides good eating and sound nutrition, two other reasons recommend today's Peace Plate -- its main ingredients are inexpensive and in line with food-conservation ideas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Truman personally wished Secretary of State Marshall god-speed and declared his utmost confidence in him at the National Airport this afternoon when the Cabinet officer left for the London Conference of Foreign Ministers.

DENVER, Nov. 20 -- John C. Wilcox of Colorado Springs, nationally known singing teacher, died today in a Denver hospital where he had undergone a major operation early this week. His age was 77. He had been visiting Professor of Music at Colorado College since 1945.

RAANANA, Palestine, Nov. 20 -- The bitter vengeance of Stern group terrorists cost four Arab lives today. Armed men dressed as British soldiers and policemen, but speaking Hebrew, took five men of an Arab family from their home near Raanana before dawn and shot them down in the road, apparently on suspicion that it was their information that led to the death of five young members of the Stern group on Nov. 12.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 20 -- Federal Judge Paul Jones, in an opinion of country-wide importance, held here today that the housing and rent act of 1947 was unconstitutional.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- The French delegation to the Foreign Ministers conference will leave for London Saturday prepared to press for a discussion of the French proposals for the organization of Germany with essential details unchanged.

Mexico and her people have been made the subject of two books issued by two concerns five days apart. Dodd, Mead published yesterday "This Is Mexico," by E. Evalyn McNally and Dr. Andrew McNally Jr., a travel book illustrated with photographs by the authors.
Four items in yesterday's newspapers are straws in the wind showing that we are making progress in breaking down the barriers of racial bias that still exist in this country.

Victor J. Herwitz, counsel to the state committee investigating relief, charged yesterday that Mayor O'Dwyer's executive committee on administration had made a "very perfunctory" study of the Welfare Department.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A season of record-breaking attendances in the Western Conference ends Saturday with Michigan's undefeated Wolverines playing before their sixth sellout crowd of the campaign against Ohio State at Ann Arbor.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Members of the National Labor Relations Board who may dissent in future cases apparently will be willing hereafter to consider themselves bound by the majority view in later cases where the facts are similar.
MANCHESTER, N.H., Nov. 20 -- Governor Dewey made the direct charge today that President Truman either was unaware of the threat of Communist conquest in China or had "deliberately ignored it."

Appointment of E. Hamilton Campbell as vice president in charge of merchandising as announced yesterday by Rex Cole, president of Rex Cole, Inc. Prior to World War II he was manager of the Rex Cole advertising and sales promotion department.

Although the price for which turkeys will sell on the days just before Thanksgiving has not been set, anyone purchasing the holiday bird today will find the tariff the same as it was a week ago. A survey, by the City Department of Markets, shows that turkeys under eighteen pounds are about 63 cents a pound while those over that weight arfe about 55 cents.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 20 -- Whether it's because Ferdinand Nadherny and Levi Jackson are ready to answer the opening bell or because the opponent is Johnny Harvard, Yale is primed to play its football game of the year come Saturday in the Bowl.

Although continuing to expand, commercial, industrial and agricultural loans of the reporting New York City member banks of the Federal Reserve System increased only $45,000,000 last week, the smallest gain since Oct. 8. According to the statistics released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, covering the week ended on Wednesday, a wide variety of borrowings accounted for the rise and sent the total to another new high of $5,235,000,000.

Liberalization of the State Unemployment Insurance Law to provide more substantial benefits for the jobless and supplementary protection for their families will be sought by the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations at the January session of the Legislature, both groups announced yesterday.

Another step in the expansion of the Dodgers' ever-increasing minor leaguel baseball holdings was taken yesterday when it was revealed that the Flock had completed the outright purchase of the St. Paul club of the American Association.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- Experiments made at Tufts College to study vision showed that continous reading for six hours at a time produces no measurable fatigue, Dr. Leonard Carmichael, president of Tufts, reported today at the autumn general meeting of the American Philosphical Society.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Benriett E. Meyers, the former Air Force officer whose wartime activities are under investigation by a Senate committee, entered the Army as a private and climbed to the rank of major general before retiring twenty-seven years later.

Secretary of the Treasury John W. Snyder and Charles A. Halleck, floor leader of the Republican majority in the House of Representatives, debated last night whether tax reduction is of immediate urgent necessity for the stability of the American economy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The text of a letter sent by President Truman to Charles Luckcman, chairman of the Citizens Food Committee, and one by Mr. Luckman to the President, on the food conservation campaign, follow: President's Letter Dear Mr. Luckman:

Preparation for the varied offensive formations employed by Holy Cross was the keynote of the final drill of the week for Fordham yesterday. Coach Ed Danowski continued the pattern of light drills that he had established for the Crusader contest at Worcester tomorrow.
Assistant Secretary of State Norman Armour called on the Arab world last night to accept the partition of Palestine if that solution of the problem was recommended by the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Higher prices for agricultural and nonagricultural commodities were responsible for an advance of 0.4 per cent in average primary market prices during the week ended on Nov. 15, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the Department of Labor.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Dilman M.K. Smith, vice president, Opinion Research Corporation, Princeton, N.J., said today that the biggest single problem before business men is the re-establishment of leadership with the public "to gain their confidence in your service for the common good; to get their backing for the freeenterprise solution to economic problems.

The New York Young Republican Club adopted a resolution last night calling for establishment of a Transit Authority and an increase in the subway fare sufficient to pay operating and maintenance costs and interest on indebtedness and to provide for safety and other measures that would result in complete rehabilitation of the subway system.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Representative Patman, Democrat, of Texas, charged today that "one of the most sinister and vicious lobbies that has ever invaded Washington" is seeking to destroy cooperatives.

Inez Matthews, soprano, grave tier first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. One of the singers who appeared in the title role of "Carmen Jones" in this city and on the road, Miss Matthews boasted the poise that conies of extensive experience before the public in her able delivery of an interesting program, which was enthusiastically received by a large gathering.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Plans for a drastic revision of the country's high schools, designed to provide a more adequate education for the 6,500,000 students attending them, are under way, Dr. John W. Studebaker, Federal Commissioner of Education, stated here today.

Eight IRT subway cars started yesterday on a pioneer thirty-sixmile trip by rail and water to meet the need for added service on the joint BMT-IRT Flushing line stemming from increased use of the city's free parking lot at the old World's Fair site.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Browns' latest player deal today -- their third in less than, a week -- sent two more regulars -- First Baseman Walt Judnich and Pitcher Bob Muncrief -- to the Indians for Pitcher Bryan Stephens, Outfielder Joe Frazier, a player still to be named and an indicated $525,000 or more in cash.
Ector County, Texas, Independent School District announced yesterday that it would consider bids on Dec. 4 on $1,600,000 of bonds dated Dec. 1, 1947, and due Dec. 1 from 1948 to 1967.

Glowing murals painted on fluorescent -treated velour and brought to life by concealed ultra violet or black lighting were introduced fop home use last night at a meeting of the Residence Lighting Forum, 570 Lexington Avenue. Since the murals provide a bright glow of color but no visible source of light, they were suggested for dramatic treatment at the head of a, staircase, in playrooms, or for walls of a television area.

Dillon S. Myer, who has been a target of Intermittent Congressional fire for several years, announced yesterday that at the request of President Truman he was preparing to leave his present post as head of the Public Housing Administration and consider acceptance of new Government work.

Chamberlin Company of America The Chamberlin Company of America declared yesterday a 10cent dividend on the new common stock, payable on Dec. 15, and an extra of 60 cents, payable on Dec. 24. Payments on the old common shares, which recently were split three-for-one, were 15 cents quarterly and a year-end extra of $1.50 last December.

The Ballet Theatre presented its first "Giselle" of the season at the City Center last night, with Alicia Alonso in the title role and Igor Youskevitch as Count Albrecht. As far as the two principals were concerned, it was an outstanding performance, brilliantly danced and mimed with quite as much conviction as the style of the old work will permit.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Nov. 20 -- The excessive brutalities and incredible living conditions imposed on the inmates of the Oswiecim [Auschwitz] prison camp by the I.G. Farben management became so revolting during 1943 and 1944 that even the notoriously merciless SS issued repeated warnings and protests to Farben officials, and conducted hearings against the supervisors immediately responsible.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Mediation of the dispute over wages and working rules between the railroads and their engineers, firemen and switchmen will be opened in Chicago on Monday. Frank P. Douglass, chairman of the National Mediation Board, Francis A. O'Neill Jr., a member, and two mediators are scheduled to open the proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Truman accepted today the report of the Citizens Food Committee that it has accomplished its grain conservation mission, as well as its suggestion that it now revert to an advisory status. He requested Charles Luckman to remain as its chairman "for so long a period may be necessary."

ROME, Nov. 20 -- While unrest and disorders continued throughout the extreme southern part of Italy, Minister of Agriculture Antonio Segni moved today to settle the strikes that tied up the regions of Apulia and Lucania and threatene t spread also to Calabria.

BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- President Truman called today for "teamwork" from all groups and sections of the country to deal with rising prices and to give "adequate and timely help to the countries of Western Europe."

LONDON, Nov. 20 (U.P.) -- Princess Elizabeth was up shortly after 7 A.M. on her wedding day and was completely dressed in her ivory satin wedding gown by 10:20 A.M., ready for one last final inspection by her mother, Queen Elizabeth.

Robert Moses threatened yesterday at a meeting of the Board of Estimate to resign as Park Commissioner and City Construction Coordinator but nothing came of it, thanks to the peace-making talents of Mayor O'Dwyer.

HAVANA, Nov. 20 -- Trade delegations from sixty-two countries with more than 1,000 representatives will convene in the Capitolio tomorrow afternoon for the United Nations conference that will establish the proposed International Trade Organization.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Department store sales in the week ended Nov. 15 were 11 per cent above sales in the corresponding week last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The following lists percentage changes from like periods of 1946:

Britain has had its holiday and gone back to work. Years hence the young of today will remember yesterday as some who are old remember Victoria's jubilee, and as some who were old in 1887 remembered the coronation in 1838 and the marriage with Albert in 1840.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Training for thousands of girls in Camp Fire Girls, Inc., may be as domestic as a baby-sitter course or as community-conscious as instruction in citizenship, Mrs. James C. Parker, the national president, said today.

CHICAGO, Friday, Nov. 21 -- Chicagoans were unable to buy copies of two morning newspapers early today as a result of continued deliberate loafing tactics by members of Local 16 of the Chicago Typographical Union, AFL, designed to harass the city's six daily publications into acceding to the union's "no contract" demands.

Strong objections to President Truman's proposals to stabilize the domestic economy and supply heavy foreign aid were raised last night by Representative Jesse P. Wolcott of Michigan, chairman of the House Committee on Banking and Currency.

LONDON, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- Millions in the cities throughout the British Commonwealth and the world crowded around radio receivers today and heard Princess Elizabeth say "I will" before assembling for parties to toast the royal couple.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at 11:25 A.M. at Flushing Meadow, Queens, and approved by acclamation resolution in support of International Children's Emergency Fund.

IOWA CITY, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The University of Iowa board in control of athletics voted tonight not to accept the resignation of Dr. Eddie Anderson. The head football coach then announced: "I'm glad we got things straightened out."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Import restrictions established by the Canadian Government to protect its dollar balance led today to issuance by the Association of American Railroads of an embargo, effective immediately, on all freight to Canada, except coal and fuel oil, and such freight as carries certification that the collector of customs at the port of entry will authorize the importation.

ROME, Nov. 20 -- Alfredo Ildefonso Cardinal Schuster, Archbishop of Milan, today deplored in strong terms what he said was Communist - fomented unrest throughout Italy and appealed to Italians to restore law and order. The Archbishop spoke in Milan Cathedral and his speech, it was said in Vatican circles tonight, expressed the Church's viewpoint on the week-long series of disorders.

The world should no longer be permitted to rely solely on the United States for insuring its food supply, Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson said last night in calling for a meeting of agriculture ministers of countries capable of increasing their exportable foods.

Rayon fabric converters were urged yesterday to broaden the scope of their proposed fair trade practice rules to include a prohibition of cancellation of orders. The rules as formulated by the Textile Distributors Institute, representing 137 uptown converters in an industry with an annual volume of $400,000,000, were presented at a conference conducted by Henry.

The possibility that the historic name of The Bowery may be changed to something as prosaic as, for example, Fourth Avenue South, was raised yesterday when the Bowery Improvement Committee of the East Side Chamber of Commerce announced plans to ask merchants of the district for their attitude on the question.

HOBOKEN, N. J., Nov. 20 -- Factionalism, in this city's administration, which divided the fiveman commission today prompted Gov. Alfred E. Driscoll to begin a study of the present-day effectiveness of the commission form of municipal government throughout the state.

MOBILE, Ala., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Luke Sewell said tonight wholesale player deals made by the Browns were "revising the club downward" and that they would do better "to get some new blood in the front office."

The 14,000-ton liner Marine Tiger, carrying 632 passengers, docked yesterday at Pier 62, North River, six days behind schedule after fighting Atlantic storms that at one time forced her skipper to head back toward Europe to escape the full force of the wind and seas.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 (AP) -- New York State's maximum veterans bonus payment of $250 for foreign service must be paid for such "ordered service of any duration," Attorney General Nathaniel Goldstein held today.

Expressing alarm that the American League was In danger of becoming a "seven-club league," the world champion Yankees yesterday Joined in the general hue and cry aroused by recent unloading of players by the Browns. The blast followed by a few hours the Browns' announcement of their third deal of the week, in which they shipped Bob Muncrief, veteran pitcher, and Walter Judnich, infielder-outfielder, to the Indians.

Reports that friction in the ranks of city Democrats would cause hard sledding at Albany for Mayor O'Dwyer's proposed legislation to clear the way for a fare rise on the municipal transit lines without a referendum were discounted yesterday at City Hall.

Members of the board of trustees of the 80-year-old Brooklyn Friends School and Meeting House, 112 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn; the 285 pupils and more than thirty members of the faculty are concerned over the announcement of the filing of preliminary plans for the construction of the new Brooklyn City Prison on the site of their property.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Minority Socialist officials of the French Confederation of Labor (CGT), according to unofficial but thoroughly trustworthy sources, believe that the strike waves let loose by Communists in France and Italy are designed to increase the Soviet Union's bargaining powers at the forthcoming Conference of Foreign Ministers in London.

NEWARK, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Speaking before 700 industrial and business leaders at a dinner meeting of the New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce here tonight, Representative Charles A. Eaton, chairman of the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, declared that "the Russian dictatorship has proved beyond question that its purpose is to destroy every capitalistic system of free enterprise in the world."

Treasury Calls Funds Anticipating the scheduled redemption of $100,000,000 of its bills on Nov. 28, the United States Treasury issued yesterday a call on its War Loan accounts with the Class B banks for the required funds.

The ninth annual White Elephant Cocktail Party and Tea Dance was given as a four-hour fete yesterday afternoon and evening in the grand ballroom and adjoining foyers of the Plaza. It drew a capacity attendance of members of society, many of whom are actively interested in the work of the fete's beneficiary, the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

The police arrested yesterday and charged with forgery at the Elizabeth Street station, a 41-year-old boilermaker, who, they said, by an intricate technique of depositing and withdrawing forged checks, got away with more than $94,000 from five banks in the last three months.
