Stores Favor Newspaper Ads Newspaper advertising continues to be regarded as the most valuable publicity medium for sales promotion by department and specialty stores, according to the annual book, "Analysis of Publicity Expenses," issued yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Associlation.
ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- The Court of Appeals ruled unanimously today that a person who was a conscientious objector during the last war should not be denied the right to become a lawyer.
Coach Lou Little of Columbia took time out yesterday to extol Bill Swiacki as the greatest pass receiver the Lions ever had and as good a receiver was held seen anywhere."

Consolidated net income of Pullman, Inc., for the first nine months of this year amounted to $5,651,304, equal to $2.11 a share, David A. Crawford, president, reported yesterday in a statement to stockholders.

Laird W. Archer, foreign director of the Near East Foundation, deplored yesterday the tendency "to see a Communist behind every bush," but admitted at the same time that there was good ground for the view that "Russia had some designs" on Near Eastern countries.

Jake LaMotta, Bronx middle-weight, and five others, including Frank P. Carbo, reputedly a major although shadowy figure in the behind-scenes manipulating of boxing bouts, visited the District Attorney's office yesterday for questioning about last Friday's contest in which the fighter was knocked out in the fourth round.

Goods actually in transit for Canada at 12:01 A.M. of Nov. 18, or paid for in irrevocable letters of credit, will be permitted entry into the Dominion, according to advices yesterday at the Canadian consulate in New York. Bank spokesmen here indicated they were making payments on the letters of credit.

Persistent thieves who have practically become house guests of the Atlantic Casting and Manufacturing Company of 158 Pioneer Street, Brooklyn, robbed the establishment early yesterday for the fourth time in three weeks.
Considerable Irregularity developed in the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and final prices were 33 points higher to 20 points lower.

Safety pins can be dangerous for baby-sitters as well as for babies, Mrs. Marjorie B. May, director of home safety for the Greater New York Safety Council, told a class of fifteen teen-age girls, a grandmother and two high school teachers yesterday.

ROTTERDAM, The Netherlands, Nov. 20 -- Netherlands authorities are investigating the shipment of 2,000,000 rounds of small arms ammunition from Prague, Czechoslovakia, to New York through this port in the last four months.

Trends And the Census Shortly after the turn of the new year the Bureau of the Census is going to launch its survey of manufactures. This serves to remind us that the Bureau does a good deal more than count the nation's noses.
General improvement in this port with regard to illegal activities along the waterfront, was reported yesterday by James B. Young, president of the Security Bureau, Inc.

ALABAMA vs. Louisiana State -- The football season is approaching the finish line and Alabama has come roaring up the homestretch like Stymie on the loose with little Harry Gilmer serving as the jockey. It looks too tough a combination for the Bayou Tigers. One vote for Alabama.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Senator Robert A. Taft pronounced as "excessive" today the $597,000,000 which the Foreign Relations Committee approved yesterday for the stop-gap relief program in Europe.

The United Nations General Assembly decided late last night in a final vote taken at Flushing Meadow to hold next year's session in Europe. The proposal to shift operations received 37 votes, with none in opposition and twelve countries abstaining.

Fifty reconditioned ships in the Government's ninety-six tanker fleet expansion program will be ready for service by the third week in January, the shipping and oil industries in New York were told yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Navy revealed today that twenty-three of its civilian employes had been released in the last six months on charges of disloyalty, mostly involving Communist activity.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 20 -- The National Aviation Clinic, reversing action taken earlier in the day and reversing a position generally adhered to previously, this afternoon approved a "bill of policy" recommending that Congress authorize the state courts to punish violators of Federal air safety regulations.

ROMSEY, England, Nov. 20 -- Princess Elizabeth and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, concluded the first part of their wedding trip here tonight when the great iron gates of Broadlands, Earl Mountbatten's estate, shut behind their car.

Bernard J. Gillroy, new Commissioner of Housing; and Buildings, said yesterday that he favored some amendments to the city building code which may reduce construction costs "to some extent" but opposed any lowering of standards that might make New York "a shantytown or a conflagration hazard."

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- Victor Emanuel, president of the Standard Power and Light Corporation, said today that he had asked Leo T. Crowley to resign as president of Standard Power's subsidiary, the Standard Gas and Electric Company, and that he had suggested to Christian A. Johnson that he seek the position.

THE HAGUE, Nov. 20 (Aneta) -- The Royal Dutch Petroleum Company announced today an issue of 302,174,000 guilders in ordinary shares of 1,000 guilders par and subshares of 100 guilders par, sharing in profits for 1948 and subsequent years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The amount and nature of the damage done to the projected European recovery program by the President's unexpected intrusion of piecemeal controls in its domestic corollary are yet to be measured. The bipartisan and intra-Democratic opposition aroused by Mr. Truman's request for advance and blanket powers to this end may be canceled by a denial of that request by Congress; but it may reduce the work-ability of the ERP also.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 -- The principal duty of a company's top executive officer is to concentrate on the employes and their needs, rather than on sales, or any other company function, William B. Given Jr., president of the American Brake Shoe Company, said today in the keynote speech at the Industrial Hygiene Foundation's twelfth annual meeting at Mellon Institute.
James Cardinal McGuigan, Archbishop of Toronto, who arrived here yesterday on the Italian liner Vulcania, advocated immediate aid to Europe, to halt the spread of communism.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 20 -- "The Best Man Wins," a screen adaptation of Mark Twain's story, "The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County," has been scheduled for the camera next week at Columbia, the studio announced today.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Baseball Commissioner Albert B. Chandler today officially notified major league clubs that spring training in 1948 would start on March 1 and that they should "not suggest, invite or encourage players to report before that day or on some subsequent date that the club might fix."
The General Assembly reached a stalemate last night on the United Nations' first human rights case India's charges of racial discrimination against South Africa.

"Fibber McGee and Molly" has moved into the top spot in the Hooper popularity poll, according to the results announced yesterday. The runners-up finished in the following order: Bob Hope, Jack Benny, Radio Theatre, Charlie McCarthy, Amos 'n' Andy, Fred Alien, Red Skelton, Mr. District Attorney and Al Jolson.

Members of the New York Stock Exchange disapproved yesterday by a vote of 835 to 344 a proposal to allow corporations to become members of the Exchange. Firms still must be partnerships to be members of the Exchange.

ALBANY, Nov. 20 -- The Western Union Telegraph Company is not responsible for paying income taxes of three small companies taken over by lease more than half a century ago, the Court of Appeals ruled today.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 20 (AP) -- E.A. Nicodemus' Laran drew out to an easy victory in the featured Martha Raye Purse at the Bowie course today. Jockey Carson Kirk booted the son of Hiran home four lengths in advance of W. Newmeyer's Balu Mike with the latter a half-length in front of Pentagon Stable's Bahrameter, coupled with the winner as the Trainer F.A. Bonsal entry.
Private agencies still have art essential role in foreign relief operations, Secretary of Agriculture Clinton P. Anderson declared here yesterday.
The National Sugar Refining Company declared yesterday a 50cent dividend payable on Jan. 2, increasing the quarterly rate from the 40 cents a share which has been paid since Oct. 1, 1946.
Big bears and big boars are plentiful in the North Carolina corner of the Smokies, but a black bear that dresses out 554 pounds is in the giant class anywhere he is found.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 20 -- Twenty-eight orthopedic surgeons, who were picked from key cities all over the country, were in training at the University of California today, preliminary to release by the Veterans Administration of a suction type of artificial leg to qualified above-the-knee amputees.
LONDON, Nov. 20 -- Princess Elizabeth and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, were married this morning in a ceremony of singular beauty and grandeur.

Rug Openings Set for Jan. 5 The carpet industry's official opening for 1948 will occur simultaneously in New York and Chicago on Jan. 5, 1948, Merrill A. Watson, president, Carpet Institute, Inc., announced yesterday.

A "third round" of price increases has started in hardware and industrial supply lines, industrial distributors revealed here yesterday. Most of the increases, covering sheet abrasives, tools, tapping accessories, electric sanders and polishers and machinists' files, range from 5 to 10 per cent, distributors reported.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The board of trustees of the National Catholic Community Service has voted to continue on a peacetime basis the society's welfare program for members of the armed forces, it was announced here today.

Machine tool builders are baching a new plan under which industries of the United States can deliver the extra burden of goods to fulfill Marshall plan needs next year, Alexander G. Bryant, newly elected president of the National Machine Tool Builders Association disclosed in an interview at the Engineers Club yesterday.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Coarse grains featured trading on the Board of Trade today, moving up sharply after an early break.

DUBLIN, Nov. 20 -- Officially, the Irish Government was not associated in any way with the royal wedding celebrations in London. But if Premier Eamon de Valera's Administration remained aloof for political reasons, mainly because of the existence of partition, the people of this country, especially the young folk, were immensely interested in everything that happened in London today.

Demand for upholstery fabrics is "not as real as it seems," Earl O. Hulquist, president of the Jamestown Royal Upholstery Corporation, declared yesterday. Mr. Hulquist, who heads one of the most substantial upholstery furniture manufacturing concerns in the East, cited several instances in the last thirty days where his company was offered such merchandise at reduced prices.
The National Sugar Refining Company declared yesterday a 50cent dividend payable on Jan. 2, increasing the quarterly rate from the 40 cents a share which has been paid since Oct. 1, 1946.
Big bears and big boars are plentiful in the North Carolina corner of the Smokies, but a black bear that dresses out 554 pounds is in the giant class anywhere he is found.
LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- With the chair of the Soviet Union again vacant, the Trusteeship Council convened here today under the chairmanship of Francis B. Sayre of tne United States.

The American Youth for Democracy organization may lose its charter at Hunter College, one of the two municipal colleges at which it is now permitted to organize, as a result of its condemnation by the Board of Higher Education Wednesday night as "a Communist-front group," it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, retired, attacked today the honor of the wife of his principal accuser before the Senate War Investigating subcommittee, B.H. Lamarre.

Aurora Mauro-Cottone, pianist of this city, gave her fourth local recital last night at Town Hall. The program presented was composed of Franck's "Prelude, Chorale and Fugue"; three Scarlatti Sonatas; Beethoven's "Appassionata" Sonata; Chopin's "Nocturne" in B flat minor, Waltz in F major, Op. 34, No. 3, and "Fantasie"; Liszt's "Rakoczy March" and Marvin Payraer's Sonatina, which received its first New York performance.

Glenn S. (Pop) Warner, on the receiving end of the Touchdown Club Award for 1947 at the organization's annual dinner at Ruppert's Brewery last night, took time out to offer two more proposals for changes in the intercollegiate football rules.

In the overabundance of professional football fare to be spread before Greater New York fans Sunday it may be that the choicest tidbit will be laid out at Ebbets Field, where what amounts to a grudge game will be played by the Brooklyn Dodgers and the Los Angeles Dons -- although it can't compete with the Yankee Stadium and Polo Grounds affairs for patronage.

Festivities at the Boys and Girls Book Fair begin today, at 1:30 P.M. at the American Museum of Natural History, with a children's book quiz and the play, "The Sentimental Scarecrow." A display of 5,000 books, illustrated talks by noted authors, plays, films, puppet shows and story hours are planned for this four-day fair, sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES, the Children's Book Council and the Museum.

IN the Finger Lakes region of upstate New York the hills are high and rolling and very beautiful and the lakes are a delight to the eye. No motorist driving through on the modern concrete highways would ever suspect that so smiling a landscape would appeal to a writer and native of the region as just the setting for a morose and gloomy novel.

NANKING, Nov. 20 -- A million Chinese, consisting primarily of the impoverished, illiterate peasantry, are scheduled to go to the polls tomorrow to participate in the first national elections ever held in this country.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- Following is the statement presented by Sir Alexander Cadogan, British representative, to the United Nations General Assembly's Committee on the Palestine question here today: The Committee has before it the results of the work of three subcommittees.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- The Elliott Company of Jeannette, Pa., manufacturer of turbines and allied products, filed a registration statement today with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 60,000 shares of $50 par value, 5 per cent, convertible stock that will be offered publicly by a group of underwriters headed by F. Eberstadt Co., Inc., New York.
MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 20 -- Minnesota became the first state today to take a definite step toward resettlement of displaced persons in Europe in the United States.

Directors of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, at a meeting held here yesterday, voted to split both the common and preferred stocks on a two-for-one basis. The action must be approved by the Interstate Commerce Commission and by the stockholders.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 20 -- Indicating the Redman had forsaken traveling by canoe or trail in favor of blimp and automobile, six Dartmouth undergraduates, garbed from head to foot in Indian regalia, "lay ambush" to Princeton today.

A portrait bust of Voltaire by Houdoh went to Chester Dale, collector, for $11,000 last night at an auction of portrait sculptures, American portraits and Barbizon and genre paintings in the ParkeBernet Galleries, 30 East Fiftyseventh Street.

Mrs. Bertha Grimmell Judd, a leader in home-mission work, died yesterday in her home at 275 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn. She was 76 years old last Sunday. Mrs. Judd was the wife of Orrin R. Judd, vibe president and treasurer of the Kings County Savings Bank.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- During the week ended Nov. 19, member bank reserve balances increased $229,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 20 -- Edward O'Neal said today he would retire next month as president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, a post he has held since 1931.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 20 -- The British Government served notice today that it would not share jurisdiction with a United Nations commission during the transition prior to the proposed partition of Palestine. It also said it would transfer complete authority to the commission all at once, not area by area, as proposed by the partition subcommittee of the General Assembly.

In a roundabout way from London comes word that Mike Myerberg has been moving heaven and earth for permission to produce the Benjamin Britten opera, "The Rape of Lucretia," on Broadway. Queried as to his intentions, Mr. Myerberg confirmed the report, adding the deal hadn't been concluded with the opera's New York agents.

PRAGUE, Nov. 20 -- A sensational revelation growing out of the investigation of clues to the attempt to assassinate Foreign Minister Jan Masaryk and two Socialist Ministers are beginning to show possibilities of farreaching political consequences.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The idea of encouraging housing construction by Government insurance against loss to builders gained headway today in Congress.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Browns were quiet in the trading mart today but disposed of two more players to a farm club, while it was hinted that an embarrassing financial situation had been cleared up through recent deals draining the club of several better-known players.

Export credit collections paid in Latin America by twelve New York City banks declined 2.5 per cent in number during October and were slightly slower than in the previous month, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Middle Witwatersrand gold-mining shares claimed most attention in the stock markets here today. Dealers in London and at the Cape reported increased public speculation in the shares and the turnover again was large.

Wage demands for a $600 general increase for all employes of the Welfare Department were discussed yesterday by Commissioner Benjamin Fielding and officials of the United Public Workers of America, CIO, in welfare headquarters at 902 Broadway.

A move to compromise differences between the Hotel and Restaurant Employes and Bartenders International Union, AFL, and its New York local executive joint board was disclosed yesterday with the dissolution of a temporary restraining order obtained last May by the local group against any interference in its affairs by the international.

A "full-scale" investigation is being conducted by the District Attorney' office of Kings County into the alleged assault last Tuesday on a jobber of smoked fish whose plant is on strike, Miles F McDonald, Brooklyn prosecutor announced yesterday.

New York State's private business schools were urged yesterday to maintain their high standards and continue to graduate students of unusual caliber, the request came in a message front Mayor O'Dwyer and Vincent R. Impelliteri, City Council president to the annual two-day fall convention of the Business Education Association of New York State at the New Yorker Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Senator Robert A. Taft was criticized by two colleagues at a closed meeting of the Senate Republican, Conference today for taking what they considered a negative approach to the inflation problem and permitting his views to be regarded as party policy.

ROME, Nov. 21 -- Count Giuseppe Dalla Torre, chief editor of The Osservatore Romano, urged the United States and the Soviet Union today to approach the forthcoming Conference of Foreign Ministers in London with mutual confidence and a desire to eliminate what he termed the animosity and suspicion that might lead to war.

"THE VICTIM," by Saul Bellow, is a strange, saturnine novel, written with unusual power and insight. Mr. Bellow, whose earlier book, "Dangling Man," won considerable praise from the critics, shows here a mature grasp of character and a capacity for exploring situations to ultimate ends. His book is more disturbing than entertaining; it fulfills the Conradian object of the novel -- to make you see.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- A group of theatrical celebrities from New York awarded prizes tonight to the winners of the original play and scenic design contests sponsored jointly by the Philadelphia Art Alliance and the American National Theatre and Academy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Senator Clyde M. Reed, Republican, of Kansas, today issued a blunt warning that in view of a Certain short crop next year this country must safeguard its own carry-over ahead of foreign relief goals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A now-it-can-be-told story of spies probing frantically for the Oak Ridge atom secret came to light today along with details of how Congress poured out $2,000,000,000 for atom research without knowing it.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Details of how an attorney who fought the Standard Gas and Electric Company in a proxy fight last year and now has been retained by the company as special counsel through efforts of a client were disclosed today in an inquiry by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The nation's railroads urged today that prompt action be taken "to bring railroad revenues into balance with railroad expenses."

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 21 -- All railway service between the capital and the suburbs, involving almost 300,000 commuters, was at a standstill today as a result of a twenty-four-hour strike. Trains are scheduled to resume runs at midnight.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: In your editorial "Less Heat, More Light" you take the position that "the lesson of OPA was not that selective control is impossible." You also state in connection with the President's 10-point anti-inflation program that "the effectiveness of these powers, if they are granted, will depend, of course, largely upon how they are legislatively framed and how they are administered."

LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Board of Trade announced today that United Kingdom experts in October totaled u108,200,000 ($432,800,000) -- second highest monthly figure since the war. The October total, which was u9,200,000 ($36,800,000) above the September figure, fell u2,100,000 ($8,400,000) short of the July peak.

A long and urgently needed foundation for a national merchant marine policy has been presented to the country by President Truman's advisory committee under the chairmanship of K.T. Keller. Such a policy was badly needed. For too long a time the nation has been alternately feverish and lackluster now building industriously like ants in a hill and now in the construction doldrums, with yards idle and other nations carrying our commerce.
Housewives who have begun to plan their holiday menus were assured yesterday that despite some rumors to the contrary there will be no sharp spurt in the price of turkey next week.

The Christie Scow Corporation must pay the Federal Government $250 because a few pieces of lumber were thrown into the North River at Pier 59 from its craft, the scow Helen, the United States Circuit Court of Appeals ruled yesterday.

Three young musicians were given a hearing at Times Hall last night in the season's first concert of the New York Little Symphony, in line with that organization's policy of eight years standing. They were Joan Lloyd, pianist and wife of Francis D. Perkins, music editor of The Herald Tribune; Francesco Di Blasi, conductor, and Peter Mennin, composer.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Nov. 21 -- President Higinio Morinigo today swore in his own confidential secretary as new Foreign Minister in a move to complete the maneuver whereby the nation's only unsuppressed party was split in two.

OTTAWA, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- Canada has requested the Soviet Government to release two members of the Canadian military mission to Germany who were arrested inside the Russian border, the External Affairs Department announced tonight.
GRAVESEND, England, Nov. 21 -- President Truman's appeal to Congress to reimpose price controls in the United States became a major factor today in the crucial Gravesend by-election campaign.

Dr. Francis T. Spaulding, State Commissioner of Education, announced yesterday that Algo D. Henderson, president of Antioch College, Yellow Springs, Ohio, has been appointed as Associate Commissioner of Education. The announcement was made after the appointment was confirmed by the State Board of Regents.

The future disposition of the 17,000-ton liner John Ericsson was finally resolved yesterday with the announcement by the company that the vessel would be reconditioned in Genoa for Service in the Italy-South America trade.
Provo, Wash., announced yesterday that it would receive bids Dec. 1 on $1,250,000 of electric revenue bonds dated Sept. 1, 1947, and due on Sept. 1 from 1949 to 1961.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21 -- RKO has purchased a screen story by Samuel Grafton, tentatively titled "A Modern Ecstasy," dealing with two people who become victims of radioactivity during atomic bomb experiments at Los Alamos, the studio announced today.
Four new rules governing the admission of new members to the United Nations were adopted yesterday by the General Assembly at Flushing Meadow without discussion or a record vote.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- James A. Sullivan, a political figure in Yonkers for twenty-four years and Vice Mayor of that city until his sudden resignation last August, was indicted here today by a Westchester County grand jury on three felony charges that would entail twenty - seven years' imprisonment.

Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Andrei Y. Vishinsky charged yesterday that the United States was using the Marshall plan to strip European states of their sovereignty, enmesh them in United States dollars and tie them to "Shylock" guarantees.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Princeton, newly crowned Big Three champion, and Dartmouth will meet for the twenty-seventh time tomorrow as they close their gridiron campaigns before a crowd of 35,000 persons in Palmer Stadium.

The entire newly completed factory building at 40-09 Twenty-fourth Street, Long Island City, Queens, has been leased for a long term of years by A.S. Block Associates to the Boston Wire Stitcher Company, manufacturer of Bostitch stapling machines.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Carl R. Gray Jr. is described by associates as "a plump version" of the late Will Rogers who delights in storytelling.

NANKING, Nov. 21 -- Unwieldly election machinery, including a primitive system of writing in candidates' names, and limited communications facilities delayed figures on the number of votes cast on the first day of the three-day elections.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- Steadily rising prices, if they continue over the course of years, as economists predict, will so seriously affect life insurance and pensions that a new method of handling old-age benefits may be required, Dr. Sumner H. Slichter, Lament University professor at Harvard, declared here today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Dr. Harold W. McCormick of the New York City Board of Education, urged a $100,000,000 school lunch program today for the next Federal fiscal year. He spoke at a conference called in order to get a seven-month start on meeting the next annual school lunch crisis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The title and rights of Miss Anita Pollitzer, chairman, and other incumbent officers of the National Woman's Party, were upheld in a decision handed down today in the Federal Court for the District of Columbia.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Readers of omens had a perfect subject today in the death from pneumonia of Navy's goat mascot Billy X.

Virtually all of the estate of Harold Davis Kittinger, late president of H.L. Green Co., Inc., operators of more than 200 variety stores in this country and in Canada, was bequeathed for charitable and religious purposes. This was disclosed yesterday in Surrogate's Court, where his will was filed for probate.

WESTFIELD, N.J., Nov. 21 -- A persistent collector of antiques who has a thorough knowledge of some specific field still can make discoveries in attics, junk shops and small country auction sales, Walter Rendell Storey of THE NEW YORK TIMES said today.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Britain had an adverse balance of trade at the close of the first ten months of this year considerably greater than at the corresponding period a year ago, the Board of Trade revealed today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Grain markets continued the advance on the Board of Trade today that started in the late trading Monday after President Truman asked Congress for rationing, price ceilings and other inflation curbs. All deliveries of corn, except July, as well as December oats and December, January and July lard, sold at new seasonal peak prices, with December oats at an all-time high.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Chicago's daily newspapers were hampered again today by slowdowns in their composing rooms conducted by members of Local 16 of the Chicago Typographical Union, American Federation of Labor, but late tonight the morning papers said the practice had been abandoned.

Billy Graham, young East Side welterweight, squeezed through with a decision over Rocco Rossano, Brooklyn lad, last night in a stirring ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas Arena, and bagged his seventy-fourth victory in seventy-seven ring engagements, his tenth in a row at the West Sixty-sixth Street club.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Grand Jury subpoenas designed to produce records of Canadian newsprint interests have been withdrawn, Attorney General Tom C. Clark stated today.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Nov. 21 -- A twin-engine Navy Neptune patrol bomber carrying eleven men crashed and sank in the ocean 100 miles southwest of here early today. Two of the men were rescued by the submarine Pomodon, which was cruising in the area.

MOSCOW, Nov. 21 -- The Soviet Union charged today that Iran, by having voided a 1946 agreement granting oil concessions to the Soviet Union, had been guilty of "hostile activity * * * incompatible with normal relations between the two nations."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Special Alaska Transportation Committee was told today by Representative Fred L. Crawford, Republican, of Michigan, that Congress must solve the transportation problems of the territory at the next regular session.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- New England cannot find shipping, except at high rates, to move large cargoes of free food, which has been pledged for European relief and is likely to go to waste here, Michael T. Kelleher, president of the Boston Chamber of Commerce, asserted today.

A further delay in the completion of the Florence Nightingale Hospital at 163d Street and Fort Washington Avenue was encountered yesterday when Dr. Edward M. Bernecker, Commissioner of Hospitals, announced that recently submitted bids had been rejected.

Kermit McReynolds, 38-year-old bus driver, was arrested yesterday afternoon on charges of felonious assault and violation of the Sullivan Law after he had stabbed a woman in a taxicab at Fifty-fourth Street and Eighth Avenue, about fifty yards from the West Fifty-fourth Street police station.

In a Thanksgiving "proclamation" issued yesterday, the Rev. Dr. A. Livingston Warnshues, executive vice president of Church World Service, interdenominational relief and reconstruction agency with American headquarters at 37 East Thirty-sixth Street, called upon "all men of good-will" to share their Thanksgiving with those in need.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Joseph Tucci's Amanecer, one of a group of horses purchased recently by the Washington sportsman from King Ranch, turned in his first victory for his new owner in the featured mile-and-a-sixteenth race at the Bowie track today.

In arranging the exhibition of French tapestries at the Metropolitan Museum emphasis hag seen placed on the famous medieval tapestries and on the modern work in which contemporary artists have been called upon under the sponsorship of the French government to aid in revitalizing the age-old weaving industry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- An improved process for the purification of penicillin (No. 2,430,946), worked out by Richard Pasternack of Islip, N.Y., and Peter P. Regna of West New York, N.J., assignors to Charles Pfizer and Co. of Brooklyn, N.Y., won one of the 451 patents issued this week by the United States Patent Office.
ROME, Nov. 21 -- At least three persons were killed and thirty wounded in the last twenty-four hours in riots, especially in Apulia.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Nov. 21 -- Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president emeritus of Columbia University and a native of this city, will be unable because of "total blindness and resulting infirmities," to attend ceremonies on Dec. 14 initiating the rebuilding of the First Presbyterian Church here.

Four automobiles parked in West Eighty-fifth Street were set afire between 5 and 6 A.M. yesterday. Detective Larry Way of the West Sixty-eight Street station reported that nothing had been stolen from the cars. He concurred with investigators from the Fire Marshal's office that it was the work of vandals or a pyromaniac.
Again featured by the strength in December, the cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed yesterday 39 points higher to 10 points lower.

Sugar and spice and many things nice go into the twenty-four recipes in a new booklet edited with an eye to the approaching holidays by the American Sugar Refining Company. We imagine the company is happy that it once more can distribute information on its product, the food that was on the ration list for the longest period.

When shippping losses due to improper packaging can be reduced from a high of 3 per cent to a low of 1 per cent, enough money can be saved to pay the entire cost of repackaging the product, as well as to considerably increase company profits, Joseph F. Shadgen, of Queens, industrial packaging consultant, revealed here yesterday in an interview.

A new type low-cost surface and underwater metal cutter that employs electric arc-vapor, known by the trade name "CutTrode," was demonstrated here yesterday by the Eutectic Welding Alloys Corporation in its research laboratories, 110 Duane Street.

BOSTON, Nov. 21 -- The problem of how aid to Europe should be handled was to the fore today before the New England Council's 1,000 businessmen and industrialists and agreement was general that such aid should be provided and quickly.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Jack Matheson, star end of the Chicago Bears, was barred today from playing in the Sunday game with the Pittsburgh Steelers, and five other players were fined for their conduct during the Chicago-Los Angeles Rams contest last Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- An early peace treaty with Japan, with or without Russian participation, was recommended today by a House Armed Services subcommittee.

There is a poignant time of hesitancy just before the browns of November give way to the grays of the twelfth month. Squaw winter has flung its introduction over the land. Snow showers have dusted brown fields and upland pastures. Ice sheets have temporarily covered the pools in the swamps.

WARSAW, Poland, Nov. 21 (AP) -- United States Ambassador Stanton Griffis disclaimed anew tonight any knowledge of how Stanislaw Mikolajczyk, former leader of the Polish Peasant party, fled Poland. He said there was no organization for smuggling Poles out of this country.

Nadia Reisenberg has had a long and honorable career as a pianist in this country since her debut twenty-five years ago at the age of 17. Although she has played her share of solo recitals, such appearances at the major concert halls in New York have been relatively rare.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 -- Carrying out a threat contained in a warning issued three weeks ago, Dennis Cardinal Dougherty today ordered the 1,000,000 Catholics in the Archdiocese of Philadelphia not to patronize the midtown Fox Theatre here for at least one year.

Random notes. The four-day deer season for archers will open in New Jersey on Dec. 8, with no special license required. The bow and arrow hunter will be required to possess the regular hunting license, and will be limited to the regulation long bow (or variation thereof) and arrow.
PARIS, Nov. 21 -- The chips are now down in the struggle for power in Western Europe between democracy as advocated by the United States and democracy as advocated by the Soviet Union.

Prices of German china will be reduced substantially at both the importer and retail level after the first of the year, a spokesman for a large store disclosed yesterday. He reported that importers have notified his organization that prices to dealers will be cut after Jan. 1 because of lower duties on merchandise arriving from Germany.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- The National Labor Relations Board today issued a Taft-Hartley Law complaint against the International Typographical Union, AFL, charging it with refusal to bargain with and attempting to coerce the American Newspaper Publishers Association, its members and employes in the choice of bargaining representatives.

The first post-Nazi appeal against the crime of genocide, or the extermination of entire groups of human beings, has been submitted to the United Nations by the Lithuanian Legation in Washington, representing one of the three Baltic nations overrun and annexed by Russia but still recognized as independent by the United States.

The American Federation of Radio Artists confirmed yesterday that it expected to ask the national networks for a 10 per cent cost-of-living increase in the minimum pay scales for radio actors. The existing pact between the union and the chains makes provision for negotiation of such an increase after the first of the year.

The 1947 football trail for Columbia and Syracuse will end this afternoon when these two old rivals meet at Baker Field. The beginning of this end is scheduled for 2 o'clock, with at least 25,000 fans -- perhaps more if the weather is good -- sitting in on the battle.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 21 -- Yale and Harvard meet tomorrow for the sixty-fourth time with nothing at stake except a football game, but the largest crowd to jam the Bowl since 1937 will be in at the kick-off, scheduled for 1:30 P.M.

Some furniture and department stores this year will revert partially to the normal pre-war policy of tight purchasing of case goods and other heavy furniture between Thanksgiving and Christmas, buyers reported yesterday. They explained that sales during October and the current month indicate consumers are slowly returning to pre-war holiday concentration on occasional and novelty furniture suitable for gifts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, today replied to a criticism of FBI procedures by a fellow Government official by asserting his office regularly supplies information to other Government agencies when the material is "of interest" to them.

In the shadow of Public School 3, Brooklyn, one of the oldest in the city, ground was broken yesterday for a new three-story school building that, when completed and equipped in the spring of 1949, will cost about $2,400,000.

To conserve dwindling United States stocks of tin, some restrictions on the use of tinplate containers for beer and coffee, as well as some other commodities are regarded by brewers and coffee packers as inevitable next year, it was learned yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Rumania, Nov. 21 -- The Rumanian Government demonstrated today its totalitarian concept of democracy by summoning to trial next Tuesday leaders of the Social Democratic party, whose alleged crime is that they sought to distribute political handbills that had not been approved by the Government's censors.

The rescue of Wac Sgt. Vivian O'Rourke of Chicago, who was swept overboard from the transport Gen. C.C. Ballou last Wednesday in a raging Atlantic storm, was reported here yesterday by the New York Port of Embarkation.
Zachary Norman has been appointed sales manager of the Edward Fields Company, 509 Madison Avenue, distributor of carpets and decorative fabrics.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 21 -- An arrest of a technical nature was made today by Greenwich police in their investigation of how a poisonous substance got into soup prepared last Saturday evening in the home of the late Lorenzo D. Armstrong, New York lawyer.

The broad experience and sound common sense of Bernard M. Baruch were evident in his report to the joint meeting of the five County Medical Societies and the Hospital Association of Greater New York on the national problems confronting us in providing adequate medical care.

A long lesson at the chalk board and an equally long session in front of the moving picture screen were the practice prescriptions doled out by Coach Ray Flaherty yesterday as his New York Football Yankees made ready for their battle with the Cleveland Browns at the Stadium tomorrow.
PARIS, Saturday, Nov. 22 -- Leon Blum failed by 9 votes to be accepted as Premier by the National Assembly yesterday.
SHANGHAI, Nov. 21 -- There was a lack of secrecy in Shanghai's voting. Ballots were marked in public, with election officials and curious by-standers looking on.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- Gov. Thomas E. Dewey said today that state contributions to the retirement system in the 1948-49 budget will be $4,700,000 higher than the total of such contributions in the current budget.

The headquarters agreement between the United Nations and the United States was put into force yesterday at Flushing Meadow by a formal exchange of notes granting special inviolability status to the East River site of the future United Nations capital.

Close-up motion pictures of wild buffaloes, elephants and lions on the plains of the Belgian Congo, shown by Mrs. Carl Akeley, widow of the explorer, brought a new insight on jungle life to high school students from various parts of the metropolitan area, who came to the Book Fair yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: You have always been generous in your columns in granting space for appeals on behalf of worthy causes. This is especially true of the stories you have carried of the need for helping the people of Europe this winter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Clinton P. Anderson, Secretary of Agriculture, asked Congress today for broad powers to curb speculation on commodity exchanges and to stimulate food production here and abroad.

Ads Aid Big Whisky Brands Constant advertising and vigorous promotion regardless of marketing conditions again are paying off for manufacturers of well-known whiskies, spokesmen for leading distillers stated yesterday. The trend toward dealer and consumer preference for some dozen "big name" brands is growing, and while there has been a tendency among retailers to stock a higher percentage of certain whiskies because of the sixty-day grain conservation shutdown, they are not buying little-known brands.

New Capital Market There is little of interest to distributors of new securities scheduled for the week of Thanksgiving coming up on Monday. There will be bidding on Monday for $14,500,000 of one-to-ten-year equipment trust certificates of the Southern Pacific Company, the largest sale of railroad equipments, since the Pennsylvania Railroad's sale of $14,970,000 last January.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- William R. McComb, Wage-Hour Administrator, testified today that raising the minimum wage to 75 cents an hour would put "very few" companies out of business, but he conceded that "there are bound to be casualties."
Savings banks were among the sellers of Manhattan properties reported in new ownerships yesterday.

Directors of the Texas Company placed the common stock on a $3 annual basis with the declaration yesterday of a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share payable on Jan. 2. The common stock previously had been on a $2 yearly rate.

How a swindler suspect was caught accidentally in a cocktail bar by an assistant attorney general, who immediately wrote out a subpoena on blank paper and served it on the man was told yesterday by State Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein.

Associate Justice Henry H. Curran marked his final day on the bench in Part I of the Court of Special Sessions yesterday by suspending execution of a sentence, the same procedure he followed thirty years ago when he adjudged his first case as a magistrate in the old Jefferson Markets Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- B. H. Lamarre, whose wife's fidelity had been impugned by Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, retired, appealed to the Senate War Investigating subcommittee from the stand today to "make General Meyers crawl out of this room on his belly like the snake he is."

Although emphatic that "Caribean Carnival" will be unfolded at the International Theatre next Friday evening, spokesmen for the Calypso entertainment admitted yesterday that several problems must first be solved. Contracts with members of the company and the American Guild of Musical Artists, Inn., which has jurisdiction over the presentation, have yet to be signed.

Led by Joe Fulks, the circuit's high scorer last year who is again setting a dazzling pace, the Philadelphia Warriors will oppose the Knickerbockers in a Basketball Association of America test at the Sixty-ninth Regiment Armory tonight.

The Harlem Division of the New York City Cancer Committee, 2149 Seventh Avenue, appealed yesterday to ministers and public leaders to make people of that area conscious of the efforts to check the rise in cancer among Negro women.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (U.P.) -- President Truman opened the annual Christmas Seal sale of the National Tuberculosis Association today for accepting the first sheet of 1947 seals from Secretary of Commerce W. Averell Harriman. The sale starts throughout the country on Monday.

Following an investigation launched last Monday, the State Athletic Commission yesterday indefinitely suspended Jake LaMotta on the ground he had concealed important information concerning his physical condition for the bout in Madison Square Garden on Nov. 14, in which Billy Fox, Philadelphian, knocked out the Bronx light heavyweight in the fourth round.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The San Francisco Forty-niners defeated the Chicago Rockets tonight, 41 to 16, for their seventh victory in the All-America Football Conference. It was the Chicago team's eleventh loss in twelve games. The attendance at Soldier Field was 5,791.
Eight thousand visitors thronged the Metropolitan Museum of Art last night to see the 200 tapestries on loan from the French Government on display in the twenty-four galleries in the North Wing.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- A further revision of plans for carrying out the partition of Palestine without the active participation of Great Britain was approved tonight by the partition sub-committee of the United Nations General Assembly and will be submitted to the committee tomorrow.
YESTERDAY'S EVENTS General Assembly Met at 11:20 A.M. at Flushing Meadow, Queens, and received report of Security Council.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Nov. 21 -- A former Commissioner of Public Safety and nineteen other defendants received jail sentences and were fined a total of $12,850 as a climax of a six-months-long court-ordered investigation of gambling activities in Millville.

A time limit of two years has been set by the Office of the Quartermaster General to complete its industrial mobilization program, according to Army officers who were present yesterday at the opening of the QM sample exhibit room in the New York Quarter-master Purchasing Office, 111 East Sixteenth Street.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 21 -- The National Aviation Clinic today passed bills of policy ranging from demands for quieter small airplanes to more extensive international cooperation through the International Civil Aviation Organization at Montreal.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 21 (AP) -- A protective committee for preferred stock of the Commonwealth Southern Corporation, headed by Edward Hopkinson Jr. of Drexel Co., proposed today an amended plan of reorganization for the holding company.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: The press has been carrying report of Armenians who are sailing to Armenia to become repatriated to their native land. Dispatches appearing in THE NEW YORK TIMES expressed the thought that the Armenians were being induced to return to Soviet Armenien.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Harold E. Stassen scored one of his major triumphs of his tour of the country in search of the Republican Presidential nomination today when he appeared before a meeting of the National Editorial Association here.

HAVANA, Nov. 21 -- President Ramon Grau San Martin of Cuba officially opened the United Nations conference on trade and employment this afternoon with an appeal for the economic strengthening of Latin America as part of the "bastion of freedom" for the defense of world democracy.

A 12-year-old boy, whose-ambition is to become a lawyer, won his first case yesterday in Mid-Manhattan Court. He successfully defended his mother, a superintendent at 181 East Seventy-eighth Street, on a summons that charged her with violating a section of the Sanitary Code because she kept overflowing garbage cans in front of the apartment house.

ATHENS, Nov. 21 -- Admitting the failure of the amnesty offered by his Government to end the war with the guerrillas, Premier The-mistocles Sophoulis issued an angry battle-cry today before a gathering of Greek Arms officers and men in Salonika.

PRAGUE, Nov. 21 -- President Eduard Benes conferred today with Bohumil Lauschman, new president of the Social Democratic party, who was elected to free the party of Communist domination. The conversation with M. Lauschman followed Dr. Benes' warning in his interview with Catholic Bishops yesterday that the Communist party must not be isolated.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Nov. 21 -- George J. Fitzpatrick, Hoboken patrolman who was elected a City commissioner last May, donned his police uniform today after another City Commissioner, Michael M. Borelli, Public Safety Director, refused to grant a six-month extention on Mr. Fitzpatrick's leave of absence from the Police Department.

"Die Meistersinger" made a welcome return to the repertory last night in the Metropolitan Opera House. Polyna Stoska, who had been announced as Eva., was replaced on brief notice by Astrid Varnay. The Walther was Torsten Ralf; Hans 'Sachs, Herbert Jannssen; Beckmesser, Gerhard Pechner; Pogner, Dezso Ernster; Kothner, Mack Harrell; David, John Garris; the Night Watchman, Philip Kinsman.

A new complaint challenging the legal validity of the International Typographical Union's "no contract" policy was filed yesterday with the regional office of the National Labor Relations Board by the Union Employers Section of the Printing Industry of America, Inc.

Advices from Greece reaching foreign traders here stress the barriers being raised against imports into that country, and say that arbitrary decisions by the Greek trade administration indicate the American Mission to Greece is seeking to eliminate the usual trade channels in favor of direct trade between manufacturer here and industrial user in Greece.

President Truman's announcement that he will appoint General Bradley as Army Chief of Staff when General Eisenhower retires is not the less welcome because it was expected. No other United States general came out of the war with a finer record of intelligent, courageous command.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Navy today ordered permanent dissolution of the "Green Bowl," a secret society at Annapolis, which had, between 1907 and 1944, a total of 387 members. The society was banned on the grounds that it violated a long-standing rule forbidding all associations of this type at the academy.

DETROIT, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Ward's automotive reports said today that a new post-war record production by General Motors Corporation plants in the United States and Canada enabled the automotive industry to mark up its best output since the war during the past two weeks.
Four war widows and their four children who make use of several of the city's ninety-four child-care centers appealed yesterday for continuation of the centers after Dec. 31.

The motion-picture industry is expected to formulate a policy of non-employment for known Communists, it was predicted in trade circles yesterday, as a result of the policy meetings to be held in the offices of the Motion Picture Association of America, 28 West Forty-fourth Street, starting on Monday.

The United Nations General Assembly at Flushing Meadow created yesterday a new organ to draft international laws. The International Law Commission was constituted without a dissenting vote, although the Slav states abstained.

Birthplace of Thanksgiving One of the huge army of New Yorkers by adoption, whose forefathers lived for generations in Plymouth, Mass., has been rejoicing because of the news that Plymouth is to be the headquarters of a generous project for sending quantities of food to hungry people in Europe during this Thanksgiving-tide.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Secretary of State Marshall arrived in London by air from Washington today for the fifth session of the Council of Foreign Ministers, which will open here Tuesday. He found that the Foreign Ministers' deputies, who had been meeting for two weeks, had not even been able to draw up a report on how they had disagreed.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Fourth United States Circuit Court of Appeals dismissed today an appeal by South Carolina from a decision requiring it to accept a Negro law student at its state university unless a comparable legal education was given him elsewhere.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Truman said at a news conference today that he saw no reason to interfere with shipments to Soviet Russia of American farm equipment and heavy machinery needed for that country's rehabilitation.

The stock market was unable yesterday to maintain the forward movement generated in previous sessions of the week. Although gains by selected issues appeared in the morning, the afternoon witnessed sufficient selling to produce an irregularly lower close on the Stock Exchange and the combined averages declined 0.67 point.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today that it had denied certification for the first time to unions which have won elections but which have not complied with affidavit and registration requirements.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- In a condemnation of covenants intended to bar Negroes from buying real estate, the American Jewish Congress told the Supreme Court today that such pacts were creating "dangerous despair and disbelief in democratic values."

Although the sixty-fourth meeting of Yale and Harvard at New Haven and other traditional pairings are on the schedule in the East the national spotlight in college football today will be trained on the big battle between Southern California and U.C.L.A. at Los Angeles.

For its third performance at the City Center last night, the Ballet Theatre introduced "Swan Lake," "Romeo and Juliet" and "Les Patineurs" to the season's repertoire in what was far from a happy evening.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The "Rutland Railroad Crisis Committee" asked the Interstate Commerce Commission, today to authorize the railroad to sponsor a cooperative dairy and poultry feed distribution system in its operating area.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today that it had denied certification for the first time to unions which have won elections but which have not complied with affidavit and registration requirements.

Retail Sales More Active Retail sales here this week were active, with the first spell of fall weather responsible for seasonal merchandise moving readily. Estimates of sales indicated that most stores were averaging between 5 and 10 per cent better than last year. Some early Christmas shopping was reported.

LAKE SUCCESS, N.Y., Nov. 21 -- Following is the text of revised proposals for carrying out the partition of Palestine that were approved today by the partition subcommittee of the United Nations General Assembly. The letters and numbers refer to the original headings in the subcommittee's report, which was submitted to the full committee earlier in the week.
The United Nations General Assembly adjourned indefinitely at Flushing Meadow at 7:35 o'clock last night with all its agenda items completed with the exception of the Palestine problem.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- The steel industry has volunteered to increase shipments of steel to railroad freight car builders by more than 50 per cent beginning early in 1948, J. Monroe Johnson, director of the Office of Defense Transportation and a member of the Interstate Commerce Commission, reported today.
The consumer service section of the Citizens Food Committee has prepared ideas to "save wheat, save meat and save the peace." Here are its recommendations for today:

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- Princess Elizabeth and Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, who spent most of yesterday being acclaimed by cheering crowds, today drove calmly down Hampshire highways in Earl Mountbatten's gray jeep, and very few citizens turned their heads to look at the royal newlyweds.
BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 21 -- Switzerland would welcome United States support in her battle against trade discrimination in Europe, a high Swiss official indicated today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- President Truman announced today the appointment of Gen. Omar N. Bradley as Chief of Staff of the Army, to replace General of the Army Dwight D. Eisenhower when ho leaves active service to assume the presidency of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- A plan for making stop-gap relief available to France, Italy and Austria long before its provision is now indicated by Congressional timetable was being worked out by key leaders today.

"American Government Under the Constitution," by Dr. Paul C. Bartholomew, Professor of Political Science at the University of Notre Dame, published today by the William C. Brown Company of Dubuque, Iowa, is a commentary on the Constitution of the United States.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 21 -- Although Holy Cross will be looking ahead a week to its climactic game with Boston College, Coach John (Ox) DaGrosa announced today that he will start all his physically fit first-stringers against Fordham's Rams tomorrow.

THIS reviewer has watched the process of the restoration of Virginia's colonial capital from the beginning twenty years ago. He tramped over the little old town with Dr. W.A.R. Goodwin when the dream of that indomitable apostle of a worthy cause had just taken practical shape in the mind of John D. Rockefeller.

LEST this commentary evoke counter-charges of bias, let it be stipulated right here that the Royal Air Force did a magnificent job in the war. That applies equally to its Fighter Command in the Battle of Britain and to its Bomber Command -- Sir Arthur Harris' late department -- in the Battle of Germany.

At the beginning of last week President Oswaldo Aranha of the United Nations General Assembly told the delegates: "Gentlemen, you are saying things we have all heard many times before. You all know that your arguments might change some opinions, but they will not change votes."
HUMAN nature being what it is, news stands in the Times Square area have sprouted signs reading: "Who Is Miss Hush? Answer and complete explanation, $1."

Last April the nation saw in New York a brilliant demonstration of public health service in action. Faced with an emergency, nearly 5,500,000 of the city's residents were inoculated against smallpox within a three-week period.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- House Banking and Currency Committee hearings on President Truman's anti-inflation program will be so exhaustive that they cannot possibly be completed before mid-December, if then, Chairman Jesse P. Wolcott, Republican, of Michigan, said today.

VIRGINIA is certainly not a Northern State. But Southerners from the farther South have sometimes had the vague feeling that Virginia is not quite Southern, either. Virginia lacks the extremes of heat, politics, religion, prejudice, temperament, that sometimes mark the rest of the South.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Melvin H. Dalberg, a Government attorney here who was with the Department of Justice, died on Thursday at the Georgetown University Hospital after an illness of two weeks. Mr. Dalberg, a former head of the speaker's bureau of the Democratic party, was 71 years old.

Clinical studies at the Hard of Hearing Clinic of the New York Polyclinic Medical School and Hospital are focusing attention on a chemical known as benzyl cinnamic ether as a highly promising new therapeutic agent for the treatment of chronic infectious diseases, against which the sulfa drugs and such antibiotics as penicillin and streptomycin are largely ineffective.

WACO, Tex., Nov. 22 (AP) -- The great Doak Walker pulled another one out of the fire today as he led Southern Methodist in a last-quarter assault that brought the Methodists a 10-0 victory over Baylor to clinch a tie for the Southwest Conference championship and the host spot in the Cotton Bowl.

THERE may be stories of the career of an opera more curious than that of "The Cradle Will Rock." I should like to hear" them. The work (I have called it a "play in music") has undergone three different productions in New York within one year, and is now about to have its fourth one ten years later; and it has yet to be produced and seen-heard as I meant it to be.

Strongly endorsing the principles of the Moral Re-Armament movement, Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd asserted last night that a world organization "is a matter of urgent and immediate expedience to hold in leash the warlike leaders until mankind can learn how to conduct himself toward his neighbor in this atomic age."

Reports from all sections last week indicated a strong volume of retail trade, Christmas buying having apparently begun early, according to the weekly market report prepared especially for THE NEW YORK TIMES by Kirby, Block Co., Inc., resident buyers.

IN these waning fall days the world is confronted with the greatest food problem in history. The United States has a bumper wheat crop, but in many other lands the harvest of 1947 has been reduced by drought and post-war economic dislocations. Millions of people lack grain for their daily bread.

Senator H. Alexander Smith, Republican, of New Jersey, warned yesterday that if the United States fails to support the Marshall plan the result will be the absorption of Europe by the Soviet Government, which he charged is out to enslave the entire world.

FLEEING from Nazi-dominated Germany, Max Beckmann went to the Netherlands, where he lived through the war years. Some twenty of his paintings of the period 1944-47 are now being shown at the Buchholz Gallery, double interest attaching to the event since Beckmann is now in this country to teach.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee, calling for "speedy action" on interim aid to France, Italy and Austria, reported today that State Department estimates of $597,000,000 to carry out the program were "substantially accurate."

MOST of our 14,500,000 veterans have now been out just about two years. The second anniversary of his date of discharge is a noteworthy moment in a veteran's life; it means that the former soldier, sailor or marine -- assuming that he got home without serious physical or mental disability -- has had plenty of time to become a clear-cut, fully readjusted civilian.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., Nov. 22 -- East Chester High scored a 7-6 victory over Edison Tech of Mt. Vernon as they completed the Southern Westchester Interscholastic Athletic Association season today. Both teams scored in the second quarter.

Landed costs of many imported items handled by retail stores may be reduced by 2 to 22 per cent as a result of the tariff cuts under the Geneva pacts, scheduled to go into effect on Jan. 1, according to estimates here yesterday.

THE clump of snowy white June or Madonna lilies in grandmother's lawn, or the brilliant masses of tiger lilies near an abandoned house site, should be proof enough that this family of flowers likes human habitations.

There will be an easing-up of building material's shortages during 1948 with the probable exception of steel and steel products, according to a forecast prepared by the economists of the Producers Council, national organization of building products manufacturers, David S. Miller, president announced yesterday.

HERE, shown as in a glass, darkly, are a group of casually related characters who have almost all been, in the words of one of them, "slugged by history." The time of this novel is a short stretch in the mid-war period, though actually the narration ranges back over years.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: There are those who say that the time has come to reduce relief to Europe. The framers of the Harrison Report go so far as to say that relief to Poland and Hungary should cease.

Robert Goldsand is a pianist who goes in for series. Fifteen years ago when only 20 years old, he gave three programs to illustrate the last 250 years of piano music. In the spring of 1943 he gave seven concerts devoted to Beethoven's piano sonatas.

The addition of a television set to the Pilot Boat New Jersey last week has improved the lot of harbor-bound pilots to a point where they now have virtually all the comforts of home, a far cry from the days when these men had only checker boards and fingered playing cards to help pass the long waits.

THE HAGUE. LIKE a physician receiving his first patient a year after hanging out his shingle, the International Court of Justice displays a bustle of subdued anticipation as it prepares to consider the British-Albanian dispute over the mining of the Corfu Channel.

While a dozen patrons sought cover, a dissatisfied customer in a restaurant at 1921 Broadway chased the chef with a twelve-inch knife he had seized in the kitchen at 4:30 A.M. yesterday. Two radio patrolmen disarmed and subdued the assailant after a chase in which one bullet was fired.
FRANKFORT ON THE MAIN, Germany, Nov. 22 -- British-American Military Government authorities announced today that German concerns in the combined area may be agents for foreign businesses.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- George Washington University's winless football team -- kicked around by seven opponents this year -- outplayed favored Georgetown by a wide margin today but still had to settle for a scoreless tie.

DETROIT, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Automobile Manufacturers Association announced today that beginning Jan. 1 most manufacturers would be prepared to rate trucks in terms of gross vehicle weight and net horsepower.

ALBANY, Nov. 22 -- Governor Dewey underscored the inevitability of a record-breaking 1948-49 state budget today when he announced that the appropriation for aid to common schools would be at least $30,000,000 more than the current budget item.

SEWANEE, Tenn., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Hundreds of alumni of the University of the South came here today for a home-coming football game at which Willie Six, 61-year-old Negro trainer of Sewanee athletes for thirty-nine years, was honored.

The new United Fruit liner Ulua; eighth in a program of nine refrigerated vessels of the company's "Yaque" class, will be launched tomorrow at the Bethlehem Steel Company's Sparrows Point, Md. yard. The ship will be sponsored by Sefiora Isabel Espinosa de Vallarino, wife of the Panaman Ambassador Extraordinary to the United States.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- A resolution was prepared today at the meeting here of the Civil Rights Congress, urging President Truman to include in his State of the Union message to Congress when it reconvenes in regular session January a request for legislation to implement the recent report of his Civil Rights Committee, entitled "To Secure These Rights."

IN a forthright, and challenging article which was published in these pages two weeks ago, a highly articulate film-maker, Dudley Nichols, laid the fundamental blame for the general low quality of Hollywood movies upon the general low level of public taste.

MORGANTOWN, W.Va., Nov. 22 (AP) -- West Virginia University pounded Temple into submission, 21 to 0, today, with the hard running of Rex Bumgardner and Walt Malyk and the bullet passing of Tom Keane furnishing the scoring punch.

Statesmen of other countries have commented on the velvet-glove practices of representatives of the United States in replying to Russian attacks at the United Nations Assembly upon the practices and motives of this country. Mr. Vishinsky calls us "warmongers," he says we are trying to run the world for the interests of Wall Street, and Friday he got around to branding Uncle Sam as a "Shylock."

During the coming weeks many performances of Broadway theatrical productions will be taken over to raise funds for various philanthropic enterprises. The Catholic Center for the Blind will be the beneficiary of "The Winslow Boy" on the night of Dec. 3 at the Empire Theatre.

NANKING, Nov. 22 -- The American Graves Registration Service announced today that after fifteen months' search in west China it had been "positively established" that no American airmen were being held as slaves by Lolo tribes.

Plans for a modern newspaper publishing plant near Manhattan's downtown Civic Center were announced yesterday by Bernard J. Ridder, publisher of The New York Journal of Commerce, which has purchased the property at 99 Worth Street, near Broadway.

CURT PRENTICE can't bear to kill Judd Mason in the presence of Mason's daughter. That is why he spares the life of the former Chicago policeman whose many crimes have gone unpunished. The murder of Prentice's wife and brother-in-law is the crime which Prentice has come to Hollywood to avenge.

Laying aside his official robes temporarily and speaking as an Irishman, Mayor O'Dwyer wholeheartedly espoused yesterday the cause of the newly formed American League for an Undivided Ireland. He addressed 1,200 delegates from thirty-eight states attending a two-day convention at the Hotel Commodore and joined in their effort to arouse sympathy in the United States to remove the present British partition as "the last barrier to a united and happy Ireland."

MANILA, Nov. 22 -- Delegates from neighboring nations and various powers interested in Pacific problems have been gathering here all week for the opening session in Baguio Monday of the Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East. ECAFE is part of the United Nations Economic Affairs Council.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Moderate gains were scored by cereals on the Board of Trade today, largely reflecting apprehension over damage that might be caused to the winter wheat crop from near-zero temperatures in parts of Kansas and Nebraska.

ST. PAUL, Nov. 22 -- Harold E. Stassen came home to his native Minnesota today, convinced that his delegate hunt in the West and South had increased his potential first-ballot strength at the Republican national convention in Philadelphia from 100 delegates to a minimum of 154.

THERE are several remarkable things about this first novel by Frederic Morton. First, as winner of the Literary Fellowship Award, the book has the stature and excellence plus the promise of still better work to come that all prize novels should (and so seldom do) have.

FOR THIS WEEK: It is still too early to spread mulches for winter protection, even over newly planted beds. Wait until the ground freezes solid. However, hill up soil for several inches around newly planted rose bushes.... Now that there has been some frost in the ground, dig the first of the parsnips. Their flavor will be even better next spring after a winter underground.

GENZANO, Italy. ITALIANS call this Communist-dominated town of 10,000 inhabitants "Little Moscow," and the secretary of the local branch of the Communist party, Ercole de Sanctis, "Little Father." No irony is implied in the labels, which candidly acknowledge that this confused heap of warscarred peasant houses, through which the Allied armies battled their way to Rome, is a masterpiece of Communist organization -- perhaps as nearly perfect as any one can find in western Europe.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- With pointed references to "the question of perjury," the Senate War Investigating subcommittee turned over to the Department of Justice today the whole record of its inquiry into the affairs of Maj. Gen. Bennett E. Meyers, retired.

EIGHT and a half years is a long time for an artist to be away, but Harald Kreutzberg has leaped lightly across the chasm and landed in the midst of as warm a welcome and as large an audience as he ever had in the past.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Minnesota's football team, long considered strictly a power outfit, set up a pass defense that gave it two touchdowns and then sprang a pass play of its own to hand Wisconsin a 21-to-0 defeat in 23degree weather today.

BRIGHTON, Utah -- With four feet of dry-powder snow already covering the downhill runs on Mounts Millicent and Majestic, skiers trekking here from such distant points as Hollywood, Chicago and New York are having an early season field day.

William Masselos, talented pianist who won the National Federation of Music Clubs Young Artist's award last spring, warned listeners to stay away from the first half of his Carnegie Hall recital last night, if they did not like modern music. As a matter of fact they came in force, on time, and only one person was observed leaving before the more familiar music was played.
OXFORD, England, Nov. 22 -- Oxford's ancient university unbended today and broke traditions blithely in honoring Secretary of State Marshall with a degree of Doctor of Civil Law.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- As agent for the accord on the balance of payments recently reached in Paris, the Bank for International Settlements in Basle, Switzerland, will be entrusted with the task of keeping the records and of keeping the participating countries posted on the possibilities for increased trade.

LAFAYETTE, La., Nov. 22 -- Samuel Cardinal Stritch, Archishop of Chicago, was welcomed to this city today as he rode through the streets in a colorful parade which marked the opening of the Silver Jubilee Convention of the National Catholic Rural Life Conference.

"THE money spent by Americans on foreign travel will be an important factor in promoting our post-war foreign trade," Averell Harriman, Secretory of Commerce, wrote in the lead article in the special convention issue of ASTA News, publication of the American Society of Travel Agents, Inc.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 22 -- Yale made it four in a row over Harvard as these ancient and erstwhile Homeric rivals of the gridiron put on one of their finest offensive shows to close the season.

PARIS, Nov., 22 -- The four-power system of control in Germany has failed and should be replaced by central German government agencies under Allied supervision, according to a report distributed here today by the International Chamber of Commerce.

CRIME REALLY PAYS -- the old adage notwithstanding -- considering that New York City's general fund will be enriched this year by an estimated $3,500,000 in court fines. Last year the amount " was close to $4,000,000.

COMMERCIAL airlines, which have not been particularly noted in the past for cooperation among themselves, last week completed the first six months of a maintenance and overhaul operation that has some of the characteristics of a joint enterprise.

Although pledged to fulfill as best it can the requisitions to be made on its production for Europe's recovery program, the domestic steel industry is prepared to oppose segments of any plan involving substantial exports of critically scarce steel products and attempts to reimpose an allocation system in the United States, it became apparent last week.

THE final week of opera at the New York City Center coincided with the Metropolitan's opening week. But the smaller company did not feel the pinch of the competition. It did the best business of its eight-week season in the last five performances.

The new program of the Committee for Economic Development for Federal tax and budget refdrm, which was made public recently, seeks to restore and maintain the profit motive as the spark plug and chief incentive of economic progress under the American free enterprise system.

This Tuesday the Big Four Foreign Ministers meet in London for a second attempt to write a peace treaty for Germany. As preparations for the meeting were being completed last week there were no concrete developments indicating that the Foreign Ministers would succeed now where they had failed before.
LONDON, Nov. 22 (Reuters) -- Arsenal and Notts County's $68,000 Tommy Lawton still held Britain's soccer spotlight in today's matches.

NOW more than two years old, the virtually unilateral and well-ballyhooed American occupation of Japan has had the consistent sympathy and support of most Americans. In easy contrast to the rough give-and-take and shifting indirection of four-power control in Germany, the rule of Gen. Douglas A. MacArthur has seemed -- from afar -- to combine well-plotted and felicitous democratic inspiration among the Japanese with successful firmness in dealing with Soviet sniping.

THE ideas in these three new Prefaces and the patterns of these two new plays are mostly familiar Shaviana. It may be that the suggestion that at election time we vote for couples -- for a man and a woman -- is a new one. We may have an impression of newness when Shaw is discussing the atom bomb or the death of Hitler.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 22 -- President Truman's message to Congress has brought a mixed reaction in this steel center of the world on the issues of wage and price controls. In respect to other anti-inflationary proposals and aid for Europe there has been uniform approval.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 22 -- The National Aviation Clinic adjourned here today after watering down a resolution demanding adequate appropriations for the air arm.

THE modest ofifice of Allen A. Funt, radio productions, on Vanderbilt Avenue, wearing a shabby look with an honest air, really is a trap. Within those short confines Mr. Funt and his accomplices plot, for their mutual profit, to prolong indefinitely what amounts to a huge practical joke, and the fact that radio has become interested is not at all incidental.

IN going out to slay the dragon of excessive commercialism, the organized broadcasters have made it clear that they propose to use a rubber dagger. Their noble intent to hit the trail, voiced at their convention in Atlantic City two months ago, now has turned into another long-drawn-out traipse around the maypole, hand in hand with the happy huckster.

A STATUE of Dr. Sigmund Freud, "father of psychoanalysis," by Olem Nemon, Yugoslav sculptor, was unveiled a few days ago at the New York Psychoanalytical Society and Institute. Before the unveiling Mr. Nemon related a number of anecdotes about his famous" model.

AMERICAN travelers who accept the long view may take heart from last week's comprehensive report of President Truman's advisory committee on the merchant marine.
