An impartial group of business-wise citizens laid down in unmistakable terms the country's urgent need for passenger tonnage, spelling out sufficient reasons for a passenger fleet, apart from the recognized security factor.

THIS volume, a kind of sequel to the author's "The Making of Tomorrow," contains, the reader gathers, all of the late Roussy de Sales journal that is of legitimate public interest from the Peace of Munich of late September, 1938, to late November, 1942, just after the Anglo-American landings in North Africa.

As a second Friendship Train left Kansas with seventy-two carloads of food destined for France and Italy, Grover Whalen, head of the Mayor's Committee, announced yesterday the end of New York's collection of individual contributions for the original train, which arrived here last week.

The office of the Premier of France is in the stately Hotel Matignon on the Left Bank of the Seine in Paris. For most of last week no Premier occupied this office. The Fourth Republic was without a Government: The moderate Ramadier regime, under mounting pressure by Communists and anti-Communists, had fallen during the greatest crisis in France since the liberation.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (Science Service) -- High school seniors in nine states will be getting two-for-one service when they enter the seventh annual Science Talent Search for the Westinghouse Science Scholarships this fall.

All three of the local professional football teams will play at home today. On this occasion, there is no question of a battle for patronage between the Yankees of the All-America Conference and the Giants of the National League.

LET us hope that the current mood of the country is a passing one. The mood is bitter and sullen, streaked with fear. Let us hope that it derives from nothing more permanent than exhaustion from the war. Wars infect the spiritual health of any country, no matter who wins them, and we are not immune.

The six-story addition to the Belmont Plaza Hotel at the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Fiftieth Street is rapidly nearing completion. Work on the building, which was started in April, 1946, represents a total outlay of more than $1,000,000.

ALBANY, Nov. 22 -- Harold R. Moskovit, addressing the Affiliated Young Democrats of New York, of which he instate president, called today for restoration of the "traditional energetic unity of the Democratic party."

Cornelius Hall, borough president of Richmond, announced yesterday that a $5,000,000 housing project primarily for veterans would be erected in the South Beach area of Staten Island, north of McClean Avenue, West of Norway Avenue, and three blocks south of Hyland Boulevard.

HOLLYWOOD. WHEN Hollywood cameras grind on a prizefight scene in which the star battles with a bruiser for a fistic crown -- and, of course, a girl -- it is practically certain that at the director's right hand, giving advice on the rights and wrongs of ring technique, will be Boston-born Johnny Indrisano.

STONINGTON ISLAND, Antarctica. AS members of the Ronne Antarctic Research Expedition, we are among the southernmost inhabitants of the world. We have neighbors -- a party of British explorers who are also doing field work on Palmer Peninsula, which juts northward toward the southern tip of South America.
HERE are two books of short stories that are as dissimilar in approach, feeling, technique and effect as it would be possible to find.

WHETHER or not life follows art, as Oscar Wilde contended, the dear foolish thing unquestionably imitates Hollywood. Witness the case of Miss June Lockhart, a 22-year-old actress who is currently enacting; in real life, a role presumably invented by movie script writers -- the role of the girl who goes to sleep obscure and awakes to find herself a celebrated star.
PARIS, Nov. 22 (AP) -- At 61, Robert Schuman, France's new Premier, is a wealthy widower who has become known for hard work and austere living.

WHITE HAVEN, Pa. -- At Big Boulder, less than two miles from Split Rock Lodge on 2,450-foot-high Lake Mountain, a new sweeping open ski slope with a half-mile-long run has just been cut through the forest.

FOR flower arrangements in November, chrysanthemums are, of course, the dominant bloom, but fruits and vegetables also come into their own and may even outshine the fall flowers. They can be used for a wide variety of harvest decorations.

DULUTH, Minn. -- The future of some of this continent's finest wilderness canoe country may be decided at the naxt regular Congress in January, and residents of Minnesota and of the Province of Ontario are worried that the decision may be unfavorable to them.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 -- With the technological advances which have shrunk our planet in terms of communication and transportation, a world government is inevitable, but it may come through tyranny instead of through cooperation, it was held at the Central Congress for World Security here today.

INTENSIVE tests of polarized headlamps in an effort to halt the steadily rising number of night accidents caused by headlight glare are being carried on throughout the country by the automotive industry and highway safety agencies.

Fort Worth, Tex. GRAND opera has moved into a domain where oil and cattle formerly ruled supreme. With its second season well under way, the Fort Worth Civic Opera today is as much a part of the community as the derricks and sprawling stockyards that brought the town fame and fortune.
The college graduate of today is likely to step into a job paying $200 a month or more, according to alumni surveys conducted by Vanderbilt and Johns Hopkins Universities.

Hundreds of underprivileged children in Croydon, the London suburb that was England's most heavily bombed city for its size during the war, will have their first new Christmas toys since 1939 through the generosity of the children and parents living at the Croydon Hotel, 12 East Eighty-sixth Street.

DETROIT, Nov. 22 (.AP) -- Rookie Jim McFadden rapped in three goals, two of them within eight seconds in the dying minutes of the game, for the Detroit Red Wings in their 8-to-5 National liockey League yictory over the Chicago Black Hawks tonight before 12,351 fans.

OUT of reverence for art, nothing has appeared in this column recently about the vulgar topic of entertainment. All evidence to the contrary, entertainment has a legitimate place in the theatre. And the thumping box-office success of "High Button Shoes" suggests that at the moment there is not much competition in the laugh academies.

HOLLYWOOD. THE Younger Generation, be loved of radio comedians because it customarily builds a catch phrase into a national habit -- non-radio comedians are inclined to say into a national plague -- has a whole new field in Diggerisms, those queerly drawn, somber-toned homilies and metaphors of Digby "Digger" O'Dell, the friendly undertaker.
DURHAM, N.C., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Charlie (Choo Choo) Justice sparked North Carolina to a 21-0 victory today over its arch athletic rival, Duke, as 56,500 fans watched in Duke Stadium.

MONTREAL -- The strict curbs on pleasure travel in the United States and the dollar area just imposed by the Canadian Government on its citizens are causing a hurried shuffle of winter vacation plans. In order to conserve a dwindling supply of United States dollars the Government now permits Canadians to take out of the country for pleasure trips only $150 annually.

Capt. Giorgio Cavallini, former shipmaster of the Italian Line and a veteran Atlantic seaman known to thousands of American travelers, has arrived here to confer with American authorities on sea safety. He is marine superintendent of the Italian Line in Italy and chairman of the search and rescue division of his country's committee on safety at sea.

The Rev. John J. Hopkins, pastor of the Catholic Church of Our Lady Queen of Peace, at New Dorp, S.I. and one of the most widely known clergyman in Richmond County, died of a heart ailment yesterday at the rectory of the church on New Dorp Lane, after an illness of several months.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- In addition to the parliamentary crisis, France faced this week a crisis unlike any other in her history. Her desperately needed coal production was brought nearly to a standstill and other industries were halted by strikes, which Communist leaders proclaimed were designed to defeat the European Recovery Program.

The mention of volume of business done by wholly and partly tax-exempt cooperatives generally touches a sensitive chord in the minds of advocates of this form of tax exemption. A year ago, when it was here suggested that cooperative organizations did an annual business of $12,000,000,000, some bitter exceptions were taken to that statement.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Nov. 22 -- Harry Gilmer, Alabama's great passing star, herded the Crimson Tide into the Sugar Bowl today with a 41-12 victory over a highly regarded Louisiana State eleven.

The City of Dunkirk in western New York State, whose 20,000 citizens shared their last Thanksgiving cheer with the war-impoverished city of Dunquerque, France, this Thanksgiving Day will aid the devastated Italian city of Anzio, it was made known yesterday by American Relief for Italy, Inc., 29 Broadway.

During World War II the Army Air Forces' strength increased 140-fold -- from 17,000 to 2,400,000 men -- an expansion four times as great as that of the rest of the Army. AAF appropriations rose from $300,000,000 in 1939 to $13,000,000,000 in 1944. AAF procurement officers bought 300,000 aircraft, produced by thousands of contractors.

ON the assumption that Russian, and American relations are susceptible to ordinary reason, Vera Micheles Dean has written a compact, factual and objective book. Nothing could be more generally useful at the moment.

The discussion of books suitable for children, Illustrations of characters, the dramatic presentation of themes of well-known stories and the display of 5,000 new volumes in colorful booths at the Book Fair attracted 10,000 children and many adults to the American Museum of Natural History yesterday.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 22 -- Proposals by President Truman for return of price and rationing controls are stimulating mixed reaction in the Deep South.

THE top men of the motion picture industry will assemble tomorrow in the headquarters of the Motion Picture Association, 28 West Forty-fourth Street, "to consider problems presented by the alleged subversive and disloyal activities of persons connected with the motion picture industry."

THE position of Alan Hovhaness as an American composer is unique. His orientation and his style are distinctly his own, and the chief thing American about him, at least in music, is that he is Boston-bred and Boston-educated.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Oklahoma and Kansas tied for the Big Six football title today, the Oklahomans beating Nebraska here, 14 to 13, and Kansas trimming Missouri, 20 to 14, to leave them deadlocked at four conference victories and a tie each. The tie was between them, 13 to 13.

To the Drama Editors: THE theatre professionals have carried on a debate about "Lamp at Midnight" vs. "Galileo"; now may one of the public speak his piece? It seems as though the entire issue has been fogged by vehement and personal preferences.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- With the Council of Foreign Ministers due to begin their crucial discussions on Germany Tuesday, their deputies failed completely today to get any nearer agreement on the agenda for the session.

Eleventh-hour revisions of the legislative program to be submitted by the city tot the 1948 Legislature were studied yesterday by Mayor O'Dwyer. The Mayor's Executive Committee on Administration, which has virtually completed its survey of the program, will submit its report and recommendations to the Mayor and the Board of Estimate this week.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Tennessee, out to salvage the remnants of its worst football season in a dozen years, beat down a favored Kentucky team with a determined passing and ground attack today to win, 13 to 6, before 25,000 fans.

PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 22 (AP) -- California's Bears, scoring on an 80-yard pass play with less than three minutes to go, came from behind today to defeat a fighting Stanford team, 21 -- 18, in their fiftieth annual football classic before 88,000 fans.

Plans for an exhibit of art specimens from the United Art Workshops of Brooklyn Neighborhood Houses, to be held at the Brooklyn Museum in Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn, starting Dec. 10, were announced yesterday by Charles Nagel Jr., director of the museum.

BERNE, Switzerland, Nov. 22 -- Strong evidence of the desire of Poland and Czechoslovakia to strengthen their economic ties with the Western countries is found by Swiss economic authorities in the record of their commercial relations with those countries since the war.

DUBLIN. THE dignified protest made by Valentin Iremonger, the poet and litterateur, and Roger McHugh, playwright and teacher, in the Abbey Theatre recently when they rose and addressed the audience on the present direction of this national institution -- and then walked out -- has led to a whole spate of letters and articles in the Dublin press.

A slight increase in new permanent-type housing in 1948 is forecast by economists of the Producers Council, who foresee a total of 870,000 units, as compared with an estimated 830,000 for 1947. The rate of building is expected to be stronger during the first half of the year.

ORANGK, Va., Nov. 22 (AP) -- More than 3,000 people thronged "Montpelier," historic estate of Mrs. Marion duPont. Scott, near lere today for the fourteenth annual running of the Montpelier Hunt races and saw Tourist List, 6-year-old bay gelding from the stables of Lowry Watkins, Lexington, Ky., win the coveted Noel Laing Steeplechase Handicap for the second consecutive year.

" THE FINANCIER" was published in 1912 and "The Titan" in 1914. These first two volumes in Theodore Dreiser's "trilogy of desire" had a lasting influence on American fiction, and they left many thousands of readers waiting for the volume to follow.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- The "magnificent demonstration of neighborliness and American teamwork" during New England's fight against the forest fires of a few weeks ago was praised this week by President Truman in a message to the New England Council.

THE tidings from Europe brought back by Edith Sulkin, traveler and free-lance writer, are uniformly dispiriting. Not a gleam of hope relieves the November gloom of her travelogue. Finland is quietly starving and tuberculous; Poland is subject to nocturnal terrors; Holland is working merely in order not to think.

WITH two new streamliners being put into service in the Midwest this week and one inaugurated in the East last week, this month will have seen important steps toward the goal of improved tail passenger travel.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Nov. 22 -- Hofsra cemented its claim to the mythical small college gridiron title of the metropolitan area with a convincing 16 to 7 triumph over its Nassau County rival, Kings Point, today. The Dutchmen had previously beaten Brooklyn, C.C.N.Y., Adelphi and Wagner, all from the New York section.

Collecting seven goals in the third period, the Ramapo Polo Club routed the Westbury trio, 16 -- 5, in the feature of the opening double-header of the indoor season at the Squadron A Armory last night.

Although it may not come as a surprise to educators, yet it is discouraging to learn that the history textbooks used in the schools of the United States and Canada do not give an adequate picture of the growth and development of these two North American countries. Our textbooks virtually neglect Canada; it is hard to believe that in our senior high schools the average history book of 600 pages devotes only eight to Canada.

THE Cleveland Browns represent -- or so the enthusiasts in the All-America Conference boldly state -- the greatest football team in the game. To this lofty claim the unconvinced members of the established National Football League are inclined to let go with a derisive, "Oh, yeah?" As a matter of fact, the New York Yankees, who ordinarily never agree with the N.F.L., are very much in accord with this opinion.

The best defense against communism is to acquire a thorough knowledge of its background, history and prniciples, the Rev. Dr. William J. McDonald, Associate Professor of Philosophy at the Catholic University of America, Washington, declared yesterday afternoon.

Can the United States spare the extra food that Europe is going to need in the next ten months ? Can it make this food available for Europe's hungry millions without seriously impairing the nutrition of its own people?

AN exhibit of photographic equipment and supplies, sponsored by the Photographic Manufacturers and Distributors Association, .Inc., will be displayed during February at the New York Museum of Science and Industry.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- There has been a shift toward the right in Britain's Labor Government that has strengthened it administratively for the present, at the risk of setting up serious internal stresses that are likely to weaken it politically later.

The Citizens Housing Council is opposed to the use of $12,020,000 of housing funds to build seven new schools adjacent to housing projects, as proposed by the City Planning Commission in the 1948 capital budget, L.O. Rothschild, attorney, said yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Two successful conversions by Ken Keuffel supplied Princeton with its winning margin over Dartmouth today in a 14-to-12 hurly-burly game. It was so engrossing that the 26,000 spectators in Palmer Stadium were completely oblivious of the chill drizzle that fell all through the second half.

Guiomar Novaes, the eminent Brazilian pianist, was never more completely the inspired poetess of the keyboard than in the splendid series of interpretations she provided at her recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. That her large audience received her performances with extraordinary enthusiasm and shouts of approval only served to show how deeply communicative and stirring every one of her offerings proved, during this display of superlative artistry.

IT is no exaggeration to say that no one was more pleasantly surprised by Celeste Holm's arresting portrayal of the "she's-a-regular-fellow" fashion editor in "Gentleman's Agreement'' than was Darryl F. Zanuck of Twentieth Century-Fox.
While the Catskills have not been too productive of bucks since the opening, the majority of reports indicate that the problem is not so much finding them as hitting them.

UP to his last two points, the ten-point program President Truman put before special session of Congress last week was fairly acceptable to most business interests and legislators as well. The snappers to his story included consumer rationing, price ceilings and wage ceilings to make such prices stick.

CHARLES DICKENS' immortal "Martin. Chuzzlewit," which Mr. D. subtitled "His relatives, friends and enemies comprising all his wills and ways the whole forming a complete key to The House of Chuzzlewit," has been brought out in handsome bulk by Alfred A. Knopf and priced at $7.50.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 22 (AP) -- An Arab was killed and a second was wounded in Haifa tonight shortly after the clandestine Arab organization Hariyeh (freedom) challenged the Jewish underground Stern group to a battle. Arab sources termed the challenge a "declaration of civil war."

MR. BROOMELL arrives at his various points -- the materialistic devastation of the wan modern spirit, the necessity of death, love's anatomy -- as directly as an industrial graph: his poetry is as technically conceived as it is (quoting the jacket) "technically assured."

CLEARLY "You Rolling River" should be made into a picture -- a silent picture, that is. In the cast are Rover boys and fallen maidens, sadistic parents and stiff-necked youths who talk like old movie titles. These move jerkily through an unabashed melodrama that winds up with the reform of a villainous father and the descent of a misguided virgin to just the depths specified in the old ballads.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES: It is not so much the contents of General Wedemeyer's report, classified "secret" by our State Department, which is significant, as the effect this report will have upon the formulation of American policy toward China. For America's stake in China is now inseparable from the burning issues which everywhere have placed the United States vis-a-vis the Soviet Union.

THE public is certain to remember two previous novels of Mrs. Taylor's, if only because they are so very recent, and to remember them with pleasure, because they are truly pleasant. "At Mrs. Lippincote's," the story of a young Englishwoman's daily life in wartime, was published here only last year.

In a continuance of the slackening trend of real estate activity in the city, Manhattan transactions last month were substantially lower in both number and dollar volume than in September and amounted to only about 53 percent of the levels achieved in October, 1946.

Although European textile manufacturers have the productive capacity to turn out a large volume of goods for export to the United States, they are seriously handicapped by shortages of raw materials, labor and power; according to Irene Blunt,. secretary of the National Federation of Textiles, who returned last week from a thirty-day tour of British, French and Swiss textile centers.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Argentina announced today a program of higher prices and bonuses to her grain producers to speed the movement of their harvests to the market. The Government is the sole exporter of Argentine wheat, and some sources said this move was aimed at getting the crop to market ahead of the next United States crop.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Nov. 22 -- Bishop Loughlin High School of Brooklyn, placing its five scorers within the first forty finishers, annexed the Eastern inter-scholastic cross-country crown for the third successive year today and retired the trophy with a low score of 101 points over Seton Hall's two-and-one-quarter-mile course.

A LIVELY chapter from American graphic arts, 1913 to the present, at the Brooklyn Museum, is one of the highlights of a busy week. Selected by Jean Charlot, the retrospective show is tastefully hung and represents the work of 100 artists, ranging from meticulously objective illustration by Timothy Cole and John Taylbr Arms to Marcel Duchamps' mechanically driven color wheels and Boris Margo's abstract experimentation with the cellocut.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- By nightfall next Monday, unless all indications fail, ten Hollywood figures will have been charged by the House of Representatives with contempt for refusal to deny or admit Communist party membership before the Committee on Un-American Activities.

PHIL STONG, Iowa, storyteller, strays far from the tall corn with this novel of John Law, the Scottish financier whose Mississippi Bubble burst in France two hundred years ago. This is an all-European story, for John Law never saw America -- even though the ill-fated Louisiana Company brought his fabulous career down in a crash the like of which was not seen until 1929.

DURING the first session of Congress in 1789, Senator William Maclay, anti-Federalist from rural Pennsylvania, fought against granting the President a title such as "Excellency" or "Highness." He recorded in his journals his fears that as a consequence he had lost "every particle of court favor, for a court our House seems determined on, and to run into all the fooleries, fopperies, fineries, and pomp of royal etiquette; and all this for Mr. Adams.

Lumber manufacturers, standing timber owners and other lumber industry interests operating in nineteen townships in southwestern Maine have organized a cooperative to insure speedy and equitable salvaging of all merchantable timber left in the wake of recent disastrous forest fires, R.E. Broderick, executive secretary of the Northeastern Lumber Manufacturers Association, disclosed in an interview last week.

WILMINGTON, Del., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Washington and Lee University uncorked a final period 43-yard touchdown drive to win a see-saw 18-to-13 victory over a fighting University of Delaware eleven today before 7,500.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were active again yesterday. Closing prices were 9 points higher to 8 points lower than the day before, with the most pronounced strength in December.

Proposals for new monetary controls, originally outined in the 1945 annual report of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, have been adopted by President Truman's advisers as the basis for implementing his request for restriction of inflationary bank credit.

Prices of shares generally lost ground in the short session yesterday on the Stock Exchange in moderately active trading for a Saturday. Changes were mostly small either way. In the final few minutes, leading issues were in supply and they closed near their low marks for the session.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Rifling Ray Evans capped a brilliant Big Six football career today by passing and running the University of Kansas Jayhawks to a 20-14 victory over the Missouri Tigers and a half interest in the Conference title.

IT is the custom, by no means without justification, to make cuts in the performance of the vaster masterpieces of music. "Tristan," "Meistersinger," the "Ring," for example, are customarily cut. So are the Bach Passions and the B minor Mass in performance, although Bach escapes cutting more frequently than others, because of the special reverence we do his name.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 22 -- Call it none to nine, or nine to none, in this college town tonight the important thing was that all were won--by Michigan.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 22 -- There were shenanigans in the stretch in the $10,000 added Prince George Autumn Handicap at Bowie's horse park today, and a time-out while the stewards considered a claim of foul before the sensational photofinish victory of the Ridgewood Stable's Double Jay was confirmed.
